Tialin was not much weaker in the Power than Verin, yet she watched Aeron nearly as warily as the Maidens did, and when the Maidens hurried out of the tent at a gesture of Aeron's hand, leaving Beldeine wavering where she stood, Tialin was only a step behind.

ɛɹən dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ, haʊɛvɝ, nɑɾ ɪmiɾiətli. "ju wɪl nɑt spik ə keɪɾɝin ɔlɹuɾɪn tə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn," ʃi sɛd. "hi hæz ɪnʌf tə ɑkjəpaɪ hɪz θɔts wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm tʃɹaɪfəlz tə wɝi oʊvɝ."

Aeron did not go, however, not immediately. "You will not speak of Katerine Alruddin to the Car'a'carn," she said. "He has enough to occupy his thoughts without giving him trifles to worry over."

"aɪ wɪl seɪ nʌθɪŋ tə hɪm əbaʊt hɝ," vɛɹɪn əɡɹid kwɪkli. tʃɹaɪfəlz? eɪ ɹɛd wɪð keɪɾɝinz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz noʊ tʃɹaɪfəl. pɝhæps ə noʊt. ɪt niɾəd θɔt.

"I will say nothing to him about her," Verin agreed quickly. Trifles? A Red with Katerine's strength was no trifle. Perhaps a note. It needed thought.

"bi sɝɾən tə hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ, vɛɹɪn mæθwɪn, əɹ jəl juz ɪt tə haʊl."

"Be certain to hold your tongue, Verin Mathwin, or you will use it to howl."

ðəɹ sim nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ tə ðæt, soʊ vɛɹɪn kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn miknəs ən dɑsɪləɾi, meɪkɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ kɝtsi. hɝ niz wɑntəd tə ɡɹoʊn.

There seemed nothing to say to that, so Verin concentrated on meekness and docility, making yet another curtsy. Her knees wanted to groan.

wʌns ɛɹən dɪpɑɹɾəd, vɛɹɪn əlaʊd hɝsɛlf ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ʃi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ɛɹən ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪmeɪn. ɡeɪnɪŋ pɝmɪʃən tə bi əloʊn wɪð ðə pɹɪznɝz hæd ɹikwaɪɝd nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ ɛfɝɾ əz ɡɛɾɪŋ sɔɹɪliə ən æmɪz tə dɪsaɪd ðeɪ niɾəd tə bi kwɛstʃənd, ən baɪ sʌmwʌn ɪntəmət wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ lɝn ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡaɪɾəd tə ðət dɪsɪʒən. . . . ɪt wɑz ə wɝi fəɹ ənʌðɝ deɪ. ʃi sim tə bi paɪlɪŋ ʌp ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ʌv ðoʊz.

Once Aeron departed, Verin allowed herself a sigh of relief. She had been afraid Aeron intended to remain. Gaining permission to be alone with the prisoners had required nearly as much effort as getting Sorilea and Amys to decide they needed to be questioned, and by someone intimate with the White Tower. If they ever learned they had been guided to that decision. . . . It was a worry for another day. She seemed to be piling up a great many of those.

"ðɛɹz ɪnʌf wɔɾɝ tə wɑʃ jəɹ feɪs ən hænz, ət list," ʃi toʊl bɛldaɪn maɪldli. "æn ɪf jə wɪʃ, əl hil ju." ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ʃi hæɾ ɪntɝvjud hæd kæɹiɾ ət list ə fju wɛls. ði il dɪd nɑt bit ðə pɹɪznɝz ɪksɛp fəɹ spɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ əɹ bɔkɪŋ əɾ ə tæsk - ðə hɔɾiəst wɝdz ə dɪfaɪəns ɝn oʊnli skɔɹnfəl læftɝ, ɪf ðət - bʌt ðə blæk-ɹoʊbd wɪmən wɝ hɝɾɪd laɪk ænəməlz, ə tæp ə ðə swɪtʃ fəɹ ɡoʊ əɹ tɝn əɹ stɑp, ən ə hɑɹɾɝ tæp ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ oʊbeɪ kwɪkli ɪnʌf. hilɪŋ meɪɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz iziɝ, tu.

"There's enough water to wash your face and hands, at least," she told Beldeine mildly. "And if you wish, I will Heal you." Every sister she had interviewed had carried at least a few welts. The Aiel did not beat the prisoners except for spilling water or balking at a task - the haughtiest words of defiance earned only scornful laughter, if that - but the black-robed women were herded like animals, a tap of the switch for go or turn or stop, and a harder tap if they did not obey quickly enough. Healing made other things easier, too.

fɪlθi, swɛɾi, weɪvɝɪŋ laɪk ə ɹiɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, bɛldaɪn kɝld əɹ lɪp. "aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ blid tə dɛθ ðən bi hil baɪ ju!" ʃi spæt. "meɪbi aɪ ʃʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd tə si jə ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ tə ðiz waɪldɝz, ðiz sævədʒəz, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt jə wəd stup tə ɹɪvilɪŋ taʊɝ sikɹəts! ðət ɹæŋks wɪð tʃɹizən, vɛɹɪn! wɪð ɹɪbɛljən!" ʃi ɡɹʌntɪd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪf jə dɪdnt ʃaɪ ət ðæt, jəl stɑp ət nʌθɪŋ! wʌɾ ɛls əv jə ən ði ʌðɝz tɔɾ əm bɪsaɪdz lɪŋkɪŋ?"

Filthy, sweaty, wavering like a reed in the wind, Beldeine curled her lip. "I would rather bleed to death than be Healed by you!" she spat. "Maybe I should have expected to see you groveling to these wilders, these savages, but I never thought you would stoop to revealing Tower secrets! That ranks with treason, Verin! With rebellion!" She grunted contemptuously. "I suppose if you didn't shy at that, you'll stop at nothing! What else have you and the others taught them besides linking?"

vɛɹɪn klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪɹɪɾəbli, nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə sɛt ðə jʌŋ wʊmən stʃɹeɪt. hɝ nɛk ætʃt fɹəm lʊkɪŋ ʌp əɾ il - fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ivən bɛldaɪn stʊɾ ə hæn əɹ mɔɹ tɔlɝ ðən ʃi - hɝ niz ætʃt fɹəm kɝtsiɪŋ, ən ɪntaɪɝli tu mɛni wɪmən u ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ hæd flʌŋ blaɪn kəntɛmpt ən fulɪʃ pɹaɪɾ əɾ əɹ tədeɪ. hu ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɾ ə sɪstɝ hæd tə wɛɹ mɛni feɪsəz ɪn ðə wɝld? jə kəd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz oʊvɝeɪ pipəl, əɹ blʌdʒən ðɛm, iðɝ. bɪsaɪdz, fɑɹ bɛɾɝ tə bɪheɪv əz ə nɑvəs ðən bi pʌnɪʃt laɪk wʌn, ɪspɛʃli wən ɪɾ ɝn jə oʊnli peɪn ən hjumɪlieɪʃən. ivən kaɪɹunə hæd tə si ðə sɛns ə ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli.

Verin clicked her tongue irritably, not bothering to set the young woman straight. Her neck ached from looking up at Aiel - for that matter, even Beldeine stood a hand or more taller than she - her knees ached from curtsying, and entirely too many women who should know better had flung blind contempt and foolish pride at her today. Who should know better than an Aes Sedai that a sister had to wear many faces in the world? You could not always overawe people, or bludgeon them, either. Besides, far better to behave as a novice than be punished like one, especially when it earned you only pain and humiliation. Even Kiruna had to see the sense of that eventually.

"sɪt daʊn bɪfɔɹ jə fɔl daʊn," ʃi sɛd, suɾɪŋ əɹ oʊn wɝdz. "lɛt mi ɡɛs wʌt juv bɪn duɪŋ tədeɪ. baɪ ɔl ðət dɝt, aɪd seɪ dɪɡɪŋ ə hoʊl. wɪð jəɹ bɛɹ hænz, əɹ dɪd ðeɪ lɛt jə juz ə spun? wən ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾ ɪts fɪnɪʃt, ðəl dʒʌs meɪk jə fɪl ɪɾ əɡɛn, jə noʊ. naʊ, lemi si. ɛvɹi pɑɹt wʌn kən si ʌv jə ɪz ɡɹʌbi, bʌt ðət ɹoʊb ɪz klin, soʊ aɪ ɪkspɛk ðeɪ hæd jə dɪɡɪŋ ɪn jəɹ skɪn. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə doʊnt wɑn hilɪŋ? sʌnbɝn kən bi peɪnfəl." ʃi fɪld ənʌðɝ kʌp wɪð wɔɾɝ ən wɑftɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə tɛn ɑn ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ tə hʌvɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə bɛldaɪn. "jɔɹ θɹoʊt mʌs bi pɑɹtʃt."

"Sit down before you fall down," she said, suiting her own words. "Let me guess what you've been doing today. By all that dirt, I'd say digging a hole. With your bare hands, or did they let you use a spoon? When they decide it's finished, they will just make you fill it again, you know. Now, let me see. Every part I can see of you is grubby, but that robe is clean, so I expect they had you digging in your skin. Are you sure you don't want Healing? Sunburn can be painful." She filled another cup with water and wafted it across the tent on a flow of Air to hover in front of Beldeine. "Your throat must be parched."

ðə jʌŋ ɡɹin stɛɹɾ ənstɛɾəli ət ðə kʌp fəɹ ə moʊmənt; ðən sʌɾənli hɝ lɛɡz ɡeɪv weɪ ən ʃi kəlæpst ɑntu ə kʊʃən wɪð ə bɪɾɝ læf. "ðeɪ . . . wɔɾɝ mi fɹikwənli." ʃi læft əɡɛn, ðoʊ vɛɹɪn kəd nɑt si ðə dʒoʊk. "æz mʌtʃ əz aɪ wɑnt, soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪ swɑloʊ ɪɾ ɔl." stʌɾiɪŋ vɛɹɪn æŋɡɹəli, ʃi pɔzd, ðən wɛn ɑn ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "ðæt dʒɹɛs lʊks vɛɹi naɪs ɑn ju. ðeɪ bɝn maɪn; aɪ sɔ ðɛm. ðeɪ stoʊl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðɪs." ʃi tʌtʃt ðə ɡoʊldən ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɝaʊn əɹ lɛft fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ, ə bɹaɪt ɡoʊldən ɡlim əmʌŋ ðə dɝt. "aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ kʊdn faɪn kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf nɝv fəɹ ðæt. aɪ noʊ wʌt ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du, vɛɹɪn, ən ɪt woʊnt wɝk. nɑt wɪð mi, nɑt wɪð ɛni ʌv ʌs!"

The young Green stared unsteadily at the cup for a moment; then suddenly her legs gave way and she collapsed onto a cushion with a bitter laugh. "They . . . water me frequently." She laughed again, though Verin could not see the joke. "As much as I want, so long as I swallow it all." Studying Verin angrily, she paused, then went on in a tight voice. "That dress looks very nice on you. They burned mine; I saw them. They stole everything except this." She touched the golden Great Serpent around her left forefinger, a bright golden gleam among the dirt. "I suppose they couldn't find quite enough nerve for that. I know what they're trying to do, Verin, and it won't work. Not with me, not with any of us!"

ʃi wɑz stɪl ɑn əɹ ɡɑɹd. vɛɹɪn sɛt ðə kʌp daʊn ɑn ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət bɪsaɪd bɛldaɪn, ðən tʊk ʌp əɹ oʊn ən sɪp bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "oʊ? wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du?"

She was still on her guard. Verin set the cup down on the flowered carpet beside Beldeine, then took up her own and sipped before speaking. "Oh? What are they trying to do?"

ðɪs taɪm, ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz læf wɑz bɹɪɾəl əz wɛl əz hɑɹʃ. "bɹeɪk ʌs, ən jə noʊ ɪt! meɪk əs swɛɹ oʊðz tə ælθɹ, ðə weɪ jə dɪd. oʊ, vɛɹɪn, haʊ kəd ju? swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti! ən wɝs, tə ə mæn, tə hɪm! ivən ɪf jə kəd bɹɪŋ jɝsɛlf tə ɹəbɛl əɡɛns ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, əɡɛns ðə waɪt taʊɝ . . ." ʃi meɪd ðə tu saʊn mʌtʃ ðə seɪm. ". . . haʊ kəd jə də ðæt!"

This time, the other woman's laugh was brittle as well as harsh. "Break us, and you know it! Make us swear oaths to al'Thor, the way you did. Oh, Verin, how could you? Swearing fealty! And worse, to a man, to him! Even if you could bring yourself to rebel against the Amyrlin Seat, against the White Tower . . ." She made the two sound much the same. ". . . how could you do that!"

fəɹ ə moʊmən vɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ θɪŋz wəd bi bɛɾɝ ɪf ðə wɪmən naʊ hɛld ɪn ði il kæmp hæd bɪn kɑɾ ʌp əz ʃi hæd bɪn, ə wʊdtʃɪp ɪn ðə mɪlɹɑs ə ɹænd ælθɹz tɑvɝən swɝl, wɝdz pɔɹɪŋ fɹəm əɹ maʊθ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd taɪm tə fɔɹm ɪn əɹ bɹeɪn. nɑt wɝdz ʃi kəd nɛvɝ əv sɛɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn - ðət wɑz nɑt haʊ tɑvɝən əfɛktəd jə - bʌt wɝdz ʃi maɪt pɑsəbli hæv sɛd wʌn taɪm ɪn ə θaʊzən ʌndɝ ðoʊz sɝkəmstænsəz, wʌn taɪm ɪn tɛn θaʊzənd. noʊ, ði ɑɹɡjəməns hæd bɪn lɔŋ ən hɑɾ oʊvɝ wɛðɝ oʊðz ɡɪvən ɪn ðət weɪ hæd tə bi kɛpt; ən ði ɑɹɡjəməns oʊvɝ haʊ tə kip əm stɪl kəntɪnjud. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ əz ɪt wɑz. æbsənli ʃi fɪŋɡɝɾ ə hɑɹd ʃeɪp ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ə smɔl bɹutʃ, ə tʃɹænslusən stoʊn kɑɹvd ɪndə wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə lɪli wɪð tu mɛni pɛɾəlz. ʃi nɛvɝ wɔɹ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹitʃ ɪn nɪɹli fɪfti jɪɹz.

For a moment Verin wondered whether things would be better if the women now held in the Aiel camp had been caught up as she had been, a woodchip in the millrace of Rand al'Thor's ta'veren swirl, words pouring from her mouth before they had time to form in her brain. Not words she could never have said on her own - that was not how ta'veren affected you - but words she might possibly have said one time in a thousand under those circumstances, one time in ten thousand. No, the arguments had been long and hot over whether oaths given in that way had to be kept; and the arguments over how to keep them still continued. Much better as it was. Absently she fingered a hard shape inside her belt pouch, a small brooch, a translucent stone carved into what appeared to be a lily with too many petals. She never wore it, but it had not been out of her reach in nearly fifty years.

"ju ɑɹ dætsæŋ, bɛldaɪn. jə mʌst əv hɝd ðæt." ʃi dɪd nɑt nid bɛldaɪnz kɝt nɑd; tɛlɪŋ ðə dɪspaɪzd wʌn wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv il lɔ, laɪk pɹənaʊnsɪŋ sɛntəns. ðət mʌtʃ ʃi nu, ɪf vɛɹi lɪɾəl mɔɹ. "jɔɹ kloʊðz, ən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət wəd bɝn, wɝ pʊt tə ðə faɪɝ kəz noʊ il wəɾ oʊn ɛniθɪŋ ðət wʌns bɪlɔŋ tə ə dætsæŋ. ðə ɹɛst wɑz hæk tə pisəz əɹ hæmɝɾ ɪndə skɹæp, ivən ðə dʒuəlɹi jə hæd wɪð ju, ən bɛɹiɾ ʌndɝ ə pɪt dʌɡ fəɹ ə dʒeɪks."

"You are da'tsang, Beldeine. You must have heard that." She did not need Beldeine's curt nod; telling the despised one was part of Aiel law, like pronouncing sentence. That much she knew, if very little more. "Your clothes, and anything else that would burn, were put to the fire because no Aiel would own anything that once belonged to a da'tsang. The rest was hacked to pieces or hammered into scrap, even the jewelry you had with you, and buried under a pit dug for a jakes."

"maɪ . . . ? maɪ hɔɹs?" bɛldaɪn æskt æŋkʃəsli.

"My . . . ? My horse?" Beldeine asked anxiously.

"ðeɪ dɪdn kɪl ðə hɔɹsəz, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ jʊɹz ɪz." biɪŋ ɹɪɾən baɪ sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə sɪɾi, pɹɑbli, əɹ pɝhæps ɡɪvən tə ən æʃəmən. tɛlɪŋ əɹ ðət maɪt də mɔɹ hɑɹm ðən ɡʊd. vɛɹɪn sim tə ɹikɔl ðət bɛldaɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz jʌŋ wɪmən u hæd vɛɹi dip filɪŋz fəɹ hɔɹsəz. "ðeɪ lɛt jə kip ðə ɹɪŋ tə ɹimaɪn jə ʌv u jə wɝ, ən ɪnkɹis jəɹ ʃeɪm. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wəd lɛt jə swɛɹ tə mæstɝ ælθɹ ɪf jə bɛɡd. ɪt wəd teɪk sʌmθɪŋ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɑn jəɹ pɑɹt, aɪ θɪŋk."

"They didn't kill the horses, but I don't know where yours is." Being ridden by someone in the city, probably, or perhaps given to an Asha'man. Telling her that might do more harm than good. Verin seemed to recall that Beldeine was one of those young women who had very deep feelings for horses. "They let you keep the ring to remind you of who you were, and increase your shame. I don't know whether they would let you swear to Master al'Thor if you begged. It would take something incredible on your part, I think."

"aɪ woʊnt! nɛvɝ!" ðə wɝdz ɹæŋ hɑloʊ, ðoʊ, ən bɛldaɪnz ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt. ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkən, bʌt nɑt səfɪʃənli.

"I won't! Never!" The words rang hollow, though, and Beldeine's shoulders slumped. She was shaken, but not sufficiently.

vɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɑn ə wɔɹm smaɪl. ə fɛloʊ hæd wʌns toʊld əɹ ðəɾ əɹ smaɪl meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə hɪz dɪɹ mʌðɝ. ʃi hoʊpt i hæd nɑt bɪn laɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt, ət list. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə slaɪɾ ə dæɡɝ bɪtwin əɹ ɹɪbz ə lɪɾəl leɪɾɝ, ən əɹ smaɪl hæd bɪn ðə læs θɪŋ i ɛvɝ sɔ. "aɪ kæn θɪŋk ə ðə ɹizən jə wʊd. noʊ, aɪ fɪɹ wʌt juv tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ɪz jusləs leɪbɝ. ðæts ʃeɪmɪŋ, tə ðɛm. boʊn ʃeɪmɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðeɪ ɹilaɪz jə doʊn si ɪt ðət weɪ. . . . oʊ, maɪ. əl weɪdʒɝ jə dɪdn laɪk dɪɡɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni kloʊðz ɑn, ivən wɪð meɪɾənz fəɹ ɡɑɹdz, bʌt θɪŋk ʌv, seɪ, stændɪŋ ɪn ə tɛn fʊl ə mɛn ðət weɪ?" bɛldaɪn flɪntʃt. vɛɹɪn pɹæɾəld ɑn; ʃi hæd dɪvɛləpt pɹæɾəlɪŋ tə sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə tælənt. "ðeɪɾ oʊnli meɪk jə stæn ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs. dætsæŋ ɑɹən əlaʊd tə də ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl ənlɛs ðɛɹz ɡɹeɪt nid, ən ən ilmən wəɾ əz sun pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm ɝaʊn ə ɹɑɾɪŋ kɑɹkəs æz. . . . wɛl, ðæts nɑɾ ə plɛzən θɔt, ɪz ɪt? ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðæts wʌt juv tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə. aɪ noʊ jəl ɹɪzɪst əz lɔŋ əz jə kæn, ðoʊ ɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt ðəɹ ɪz tə ɹɪzɪst. ðeɪ woʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən aʊɾ ə ju, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət pipəl juʒəwəli də wɪð pɹɪznɝz. bʌt ðeɪ woʊn lɛt jə ɡoʊ, nɑɾ ɛvɝ, əntɪl ðəɹ ʃʊɹ ðə ʃeɪm ɪz soʊ dip ɪn jə ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ɛls lɛft. nɑɾ ɪf ɪt teɪks ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf."

Verin put on a warm smile. A fellow had once told her that her smile made him think of his dear mother. She hoped he had not been lying about that, at least. He had tried to slide a dagger between her ribs a little later, and her smile had been the last thing he ever saw. "I can't think of the reason you would. No, I fear what you have to look forward to is useless labor. That's shaming, to them. Bone shaming. Of course, if they realize you don't see it that way. . . . Oh, my. I'll wager you didn't like digging without any clothes on, even with Maidens for guards, but think of, say, standing in a tent full of men that way?" Beldeine flinched. Verin prattled on; she had developed prattling to something of a Talent. "They'd only make you stand there, of course. Da'tsang aren't allowed to do anything useful unless there's great need, and an Aielman would as soon put his arm around a rotting carcass as. . . . Well, that's not a pleasant thought, is it? In any case, that's what you have to look forward to. I know you'll resist as long as you can, though I'm not sure what there is to resist. They won't try to get information out of you, or anything that people usually do with prisoners. But they won't let you go, not ever, until they're sure the shame is so deep in you there's nothing else left. Not if it takes the rest of your life."

bɛldaɪnz lɪps muv saʊnləsli, bʌt ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv spoʊkən ðə wɝdz. ðə ɹɛst ə maɪ laɪf. ʃɪftɪŋ ənkʌmftəbli ɑn əɹ kʊʃən, ʃi ɡɹɪməst. sʌnbɝn əɹ wɛls əɹ sɪmpli ði eɪk ʌv ʌnəkʌstəmd wɝk. "wi wɪl bi ɹɛskjud," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ði æmɪɝlɪn woʊn liv ʌs. . . . wɪl bi ɹɛskjud, əɹ wɪl - wɪl bi ɹɛskjud!" snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə sɪlvɝ kʌp fɹəm bɪsaɪd hɝ, ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd bæk tə ɡʌlp əntɪl ɪt wɑz ɛmpti, ðən θɹʌst ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ mɔɹ. vɛɹɪn floʊɾəd ðə pjuɾɝ pɪtʃɝ oʊvɝ ən sɛɾ ɪt daʊn soʊ ðə jʌŋ wʊmən kəd pɔɹ fəɹ hɝsɛlf.

Beldeine's lips moved soundlessly, but she might as well have spoken the words. The rest of my life. Shifting uncomfortably on her cushion, she grimaced. Sunburn or welts or simply the ache of unaccustomed work. "We will be rescued," she said finally. "The Amyrlin won't leave us. . . . We'll be rescued, or we'll - We will be rescued!" Snatching up the silver cup from beside her, she tilted her head back to gulp until it was empty, then thrust it out for more. Verin floated the pewter pitcher over and set it down so the young woman could pour for herself.

"ɔɹ jəl ɪskeɪp?" vɛɹɪn sɛd, ən bɛldaɪnz dɝɾi hænz dʒɝkt, splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ daʊn ðə saɪdz ə ðə kʌp. "ɹɪli, naʊ. juv əz mʌtʃ tʃæns ə ðəɾ əz jə də ʌv ɹɛskju. jəɹ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ən ɑɹmi ʌv il. ən əpɛɹənli ælθɹ kən kɔl ʌp ə fju hʌnʒɹəd ə ðoʊz æʃəmən wɛnɛvɝ i wɑns, tə hʌn jə daʊn." ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðæt, ən vɛɹɪn nɪɹli dɪd. ðət lɪɾəl mɛs ʃʊɾə bɪn stɑpt əz sun əz ɪt stɑɹɾəd. "noʊ, aɪ fɪɹ jə mʌs meɪk jəɹ oʊn weɪ, sʌmhaʊ. dil wɪð θɪŋz əz ðeɪ ɑɹ. jə ɑɹ kwaɪɾ əloʊn ɪn ðɪs. aɪ noʊ ðeɪ doʊn lɛt jə spik tə ði ʌðɝz. kwaɪɾ əloʊn," ʃi saɪd. waɪɾ aɪz stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ əz ðeɪ maɪɾ əv əɾ ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə meɪk ɪt wɝs ðən ɪt mʌs bi. lemi hil ju."

"Or you'll escape?" Verin said, and Beldeine's dirty hands jerked, splashing water down the sides of the cup. "Really, now. You have as much chance of that as you do of rescue. You're surrounded by an army of Aiel. And apparently al'Thor can call up a few hundred of those Asha'man whenever he wants, to hunt you down." The other woman shivered at that, and Verin nearly did. That little mess should have been stopped as soon as it started. "No, I fear you must make your own way, somehow. Deal with things as they are. You are quite alone in this. I know they don't let you speak to the others. Quite alone," she sighed. Wide eyes stared at her as they might have at a red adder. "There's no need to make it worse than it must be. Let me Heal you."

ʃi bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz pɪɾəfəl nɑd bɪfɔɹ muvɪŋ tə nil bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən pleɪs hænz ɑn bɛldaɪnz hɛd. ðə jʌŋ wʊmən wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɹɛɾi əz ʃi kəd bi. oʊpənɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə mɔɹ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, vɛɹɪn woʊv ðə floʊz ə hilɪŋ, ən ðə ɡɹin ɡæspt ən kwɪvɝd. ðə hæf-fɪl kʌp dʒɹɑp fɹəm əɹ hænz, ən ə fleɪlɪŋ ɑɹm nɑk ðə pɪtʃɝ ɑntu ɪts saɪd. naʊ ʃi wɑz əz ɹɛɾi əz ʃi kəd bi.

She barely waited for the other woman's pitiful nod before moving to kneel beside her and place hands on Beldeine's head. The young woman was almost as ready as she could be. Opening herself to more of saidar, Verin wove the flows of Healing, and the Green gasped and quivered. The half-filled cup dropped from her hands, and a flailing arm knocked the pitcher onto its side. Now she was as ready as she could be.

ɪn ðə moʊməns ə kənfjuʒən ðət ɡɹɪpt ɛniwʌn æftɝ biɪŋ hild, waɪl bɛldaɪn stɪl blɪŋkt ən tʃɹaɪd tə kʌm bæk tə hɝsɛlf, vɛɹɪn oʊpən hɝsɛlf fɝðɝ, oʊpən hɝsɛlf θɹu ðə kɑɹvd-flaʊɝ æŋɡɹil ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ. nɑɾ ə vɛɹi paʊɝfəl æŋɡɹil, bʌɾ ɪnʌf, ən ʃi niɾəd ɛvɹi bɪɾ ə ði ɛkstʃɹə paʊɝ ɪt ɡeɪv əɹ fəɹ ðɪs. ðə floʊz ʃi bɪɡæn wivɪŋ bɔɹ noʊ ɹɪzɛmbləns tə hilɪŋ. spɪɹət pɹɪdɑməneɪɾɪd baɪ fɑɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz waɪn ən wɔɾɝ, faɪɝ ən ɝθ, ðə læst ə səm dɪfəkəlti fəɹ hɝ, ən ivən ðə sknz ə spɪɹət hæd tə bi dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, pleɪst wɪð ən ɪntʃɹəkəsi tə bɑɡɡəl ə wivɝ ə faɪn kɑɹpəts. ivən ɪf ə waɪz wʌn poʊkt əɹ hɛɾ ɪndə ðə tɛnt, wɪð ðə smɔləst ə lʌk ʃi wəd nɑt pəzɛs ðə ɹɛɹ tælənt niɾəd tə ɹilaɪz wʌt vɛɹɪn wɑz duɪŋ. ðəɹ wəd stɪl bi dɪfəkəltiz, pɝhæps peɪnfəl dɪfəkəltiz wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ, bʌt ʃi kəd lɪv wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə tʃɹu dɪskʌvɝi.

In the moments of confusion that gripped anyone after being Healed, while Beldeine still blinked and tried to come back to herself, Verin opened herself further, opened herself through the carved-flower angreal in her pouch. Not a very powerful angreal, but enough, and she needed every bit of the extra Power it gave her for this. The flows she began weaving bore no resemblance to Healing. Spirit predominated by far, but there was Wind and Water, Fire and Earth, the last of some difficulty for her, and even the skeins of Spirit had to be divided again and again, placed with an intricacy to boggle a weaver of fine carpets. Even if a Wise One poked her head into the tent, with the smallest of luck she would not possess the rare Talent needed to realize what Verin was doing. There would still be difficulties, perhaps painful difficulties one way and another, but she could live with anything short of true discovery.

"wʌt . . . ?" bɛldaɪn sɛd dʒɹaʊsəli. hɝ hɛd wʊɾə lɑld ɪksɛp fəɹ vɛɹɪnz ɡɹɪp, ən əɹ aɪlɪdz wɝ hæf-kloʊzd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə . . . ? wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ?"

"What . . . ?" Beldeine said drowsily. Her head would have lolled except for Verin's grip, and her eyelids were half-closed. "What are you . . . ? What is happening?"

"nʌθɪŋ ðət wɪl hɑɹm ju," vɛɹɪn toʊld əɹ ɹiəʃɝɪŋli. ðə wʊmən maɪt daɪ ɪnsaɪd ðə jɪɹ, əɹ ɪn tɛn, əz ə ɹɪzʌlt ə ðɪs, bʌt ðə wiv ɪtsɛlf wəd nɑt hɑɹm hɝ. "aɪ pɹɑməs ju, ðɪs ɪz seɪf ɪnʌf tə juz ɑn ən ɪnfənt." ʌv kɔɹs, ðət dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn wʌt jə dɪd wɪð ɪt.

"Nothing that will harm you," Verin told her reassuringly. The woman might die inside the year, or in ten, as a result of this, but the weave itself would not harm her. "I promise you, this is safe enough to use on an infant." Of course, that depended on what you did with it.

ʃi niɾəd tə leɪ ðə floʊz ɪn pleɪs θɹɛd baɪ θɹɛd, bʌt tɔkɪŋ sim tə hɛlp ɹæðɝ ðən hɪndɝ. ən tu lɔŋ ə saɪləns maɪt ɹaʊs səspɪʃən, ɪf əɹ twɪn ɡɑɹɾiənz wɝ lɪsnɪŋ. hɝ aɪz dɑɹɾɪd fɹikwənli tə ðə dæŋɡəlɪŋ dɔɹflæps. ʃi wɑntəd səm ænsɝz ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə ʃɛɹɪŋ, ænsɝz nʌn ə ðə wɪmən ʃi kwɛstʃənd wɝ laɪkli tə ɡɪv fɹili ivən ɪf ðeɪ nu ðɛm. wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ ɪfɛks ə ðɪs wiv wɑz tə lusən ðə tʌŋ ən oʊpən ðə maɪn əz wɛl əz ɛni ɝb ɛvɝ kʊd, ən ɪfɛk ðət keɪm ɑn kwɪkli.

She needed to lay the flows in place thread by thread, but talking seemed to help rather than hinder. And too long a silence might rouse suspicion, if her twin guardians were listening. Her eyes darted frequently to the dangling doorflaps. She wanted some answers she had no intention of sharing, answers none of the women she questioned were likely to give freely even if they knew them. One of the smaller effects of this weave was to loosen the tongue and open the mind as well as any herb ever could, an effect that came on quickly.

dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs ɔlmoʊs tə ə wɪspɝ, ʃi kəntɪnjud. "ði ælθɹ bɔɪ simz tə θɪŋk hiz səpɔɹɾɝz ə səm kaɪn ɪnsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bɛldaɪn. ɪn sikɹət, ʌv kɔɹs; ðeɪ mʌs bi." ivən ə mæn wɪð ɪz ɪɹ pɹɛs tə ðə fæbɹɪk ə ðə tɛnt ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ oʊnli ðət ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ. "tɛl mi ɛniθɪŋ jə noʊ əbaʊt ðɛm."

Dropping her voice almost to a whisper, she continued. "The al'Thor boy seems to think he has supporters of some kind inside the White Tower, Beldeine. In secret, of course; they must be." Even a man with his ear pressed to the fabric of the tent should be able to hear only that they were talking. "Tell me anything you know about them."

"səpɔɹɾɝz?" bɛldaɪn mɝmɝd, ətɛmptɪŋ ə fɹaʊn ðət sim bɪɑn əɹ əbɪləɾi. ʃi stɝd, ðoʊ ɪt hɑɹdli dɪzɝv ðə wɝɾ ædʒəteɪʃən, fibəl ən ənkoʊɔɹɾəneɪtɪd. "fɔɹ hɪm? əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz? ɪt kæn bi. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz ə jə hu. . . . haʊ kəd ju, vɛɹɪn? waɪ dɪdn jə faɪɾ ɪt?"

"Supporters?" Beldeine murmured, attempting a frown that seemed beyond her ability. She stirred, though it hardly deserved the word agitation, feeble and uncoordinated. "For him? Among the sisters? It can't be. Except for those of you who. . . . How could you, Verin? Why didn't you fight it?"

vɛɹɪn tsk veɪksədli. nɑt fəɹ ðə fulɪʃ sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi ʃʊɾə fɔɾ ə tɑvɝən. ðə bɔɪ sim soʊ sɝɾən. waɪ? ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs loʊ. "du juv noʊ səspɪʃənz, bɛldaɪn? dɪd jə hɪɹ noʊ ɹumɝz bɪfɔɹ jə lɛf tɑɹ vəlɑn? noʊ wɪspɝz? noʊ wʌn u hɪntəɾ əɾ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪm dɪfɹənli? tɛl mi."

Verin tsked vexedly. Not for the foolish suggestion that she should have fought a ta'veren. The boy seemed so certain. Why? She kept her voice low. "Do you have no suspicions, Beldeine? Did you hear no rumors before you left Tar Valon? No whispers? No one who hinted at approaching him differently? Tell me."

"noʊ wʌn. hu kəd . . . ? noʊ wʌn wʊd. . . . aɪ ədmaɪɝd kaɪɹunə soʊ." ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ə lɔs ɪn bɛldaɪnz slipi vɔɪs, ən tɪɹz likɪŋ fɹəm əɹ aɪz meɪd tʃɹæks θɹu ðə dɝt. oʊnli vɛɹɪnz hænz kɛpt əɹ sɪɾɪŋ əpɹaɪt.

"No one. Who could . . . ? No one would. . . . I admired Kiruna so." There was a hint of loss in Beldeine's sleepy voice, and tears leaking from her eyes made tracks through the dirt. Only Verin's hands kept her sitting upright.

vɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud tə leɪ daʊn ðə θɹɛdz ə hɝ wivɪŋ, aɪz flæʃɪŋ fɹəm əɹ wɝk tə ðə dɔɹflæps ən bæk. ʃi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl laɪk swɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf. sɔɹɪliə maɪt dɪsaɪd ʃi niɾəd hɛlp wɪð ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ. ʃi maɪt bɹɪŋ aʊt wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz fɹəm ðə sʌn pæləs. ʃəɾ ɛni sɪstɝ lɝn ə ðɪs, stɪlɪŋ wɑz ə vɛɹi ɹil pɑsəbɪləɾi. "soʊ jə wɝ gɑnə dɪlɪvɝ ɪm tə ɪleɪɾə nitli wɑʃt ən wɛl-bɪheɪvd," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə slaɪtli laʊɾɝ toʊn. ðə kwaɪət hæd ɡɔn ɑn tu lɔŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðət pɛɹ aʊtsaɪd ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz wɪspɝɪŋ wɪð ðə pɹɪznɝz.

Verin continued to lay down the threads of her weaving, eyes flashing from her work to the doorflaps and back. She felt a little like sweating herself. Sorilea might decide she needed help with the questioning. She might bring out one of the sisters from the Sun Palace. Should any sister learn of this, stilling was a very real possibility. "So you were going to deliver him to Elaida neatly washed and well-behaved," she said in a slightly louder tone. The quiet had gone on too long. She did not want that pair outside reporting that she was whispering with the prisoners.

"aɪ kʊdnt . . . spik aʊt . . . əɡɛnst ɡəlinəz dɪsɪʒən. ʃi lɛd . . . baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪnz kəmænd." bɛldaɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɡɛn, wikli. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz stɪl dʒɹimi, bʌɾ ɪt pɪkt ʌp ən ædʒəteɪɾəd ɛdʒ. hɝ aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd. "hi hæd tə . . . bi meɪd . . . tə oʊbeɪ! hi hæd tə bi! ʃʊdn əv bɪn . . . tʃɹiɾəd soʊ hɑɹʃli. laɪk pʊɾɪŋ . . . hɪm tə . . . kwɛstʃən. ɹɔŋ."

"I couldn't . . . speak out . . . against Galina's decision. She led . . . by the Amyrlin's command." Beldeine shifted again, weakly. Her voice was still dreamy, but it picked up an agitated edge. Her eyelids fluttered. "He had to . . . be made . . . to obey! He had to be! Shouldn't have been . . . treated so harshly. Like putting . . . him to . . . question. Wrong."

vɛɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd. ɹɔŋ? dɪzæstʃɹəs wɑz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt. ə dɪzæstɝ fɹəm ðə fɝst. naʊ ðə mæn lʊkt əɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlmoʊs ðə weɪ ɛɹən dɪd. ən ɪf ðeɪ hæd səksiɾəd ɪn kæɹiɪŋ ɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? ə tɑvɝən laɪk ɹænd ælθɹ æktʃəli  ɪnsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ? ə θɔt tə meɪk ə stoʊn tʃɹɛmbəl. haʊɛvɝ ɪt hæd tɝn aʊt, dɪzæstɝ wəd ʃʊɹli hæv bɪn tu maɪld ə wɝd. ðə pɹaɪs peɪɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz wɑz smɔl ɪnʌf, fəɹ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðæt.

Verin snorted. Wrong? Disastrous was more like it. A disaster from the first. Now the man looked at any Aes Sedai almost the way Aeron did. And if they had succeeded in carrying him to Tar Valon? A ta'veren like Rand al'Thor actually inside the White Tower? A thought to make a stone tremble. However it had turned out, disaster would surely have been too mild a word. The price paid at Dumai's Wells was small enough, for avoiding that.

ʃi wɛn ɑn æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz ɪn ə toʊn ðət kəd bi hɝd klɪɹli baɪ ɛniwʌn lɪsnɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ ænsɝz fɔɹ, ən əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz tu deɪnʒɝəs tə bi ænsɝd. ʃi peɪd lɪɾəl hid tə ðə wɝdz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ əɹ tə bɛldaɪnz ɹɪplaɪz. meɪnli ʃi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn əɹ wivɪŋ.

She went on asking questions in a tone that could be heard clearly by anyone listening outside. Asking questions she already had answers for, and avoiding those too dangerous to be answered. She paid little heed to the words coming out of her mouth or to Beldeine's replies. Mainly she concentrated on her weaving.

ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz hæd kæptʃɝɾ əɹ ɪntʃɹəst oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, nɑɾ ɔl stʃɹɪkli əpɹuvd ə baɪ ðə taʊɝ. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi waɪldɝ u keɪm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - boʊθ tʃɹu waɪldɝz, hu ɹɪli hæd bɪɡʌn titʃɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ɡɝlz u mɪɹli hæd stɑɹɾəd tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹs kəz ðə spɑɹk bɔɹn ɪn əm hæd kwɪkən ɑn ɪts oʊn; fəɹ səm sɪstɝz, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil dɪfɝəns - nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz waɪldɝz hæd kɹieɪɾəd ət list wʌn tʃɹɪk fəɹ hɝsɛlf, ən ðoʊz tʃɹɪks ɔlmoʊst ɪnvɛɹiəbli fɛl ʌndɝ wʌn ə tu hɛɾɪŋz. ə weɪ tə lɪsən ɪn ɑn ʌðɝ pipəlz kɑnvɝseɪʃənz, əɹ ə weɪ ʌv meɪkɪŋ pipəl də əz ðeɪ wɑntəd.

A great many things had captured her interest over the years, not all strictly approved of by the Tower. Almost every wilder who came to the White Tower for training - both true wilders, who really had begun teaching themselves, and girls who merely had started touching the Source because the spark born in them had quickened on its own; for some sisters, there was no real difference - nearly every one of those wilders had created at least one trick for herself, and those tricks almost invariably fell under one of two headings. A way to listen in on other people's conversations, or a way of making people do as they wanted.

ðə fɝst, ðə taʊɝ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ mʌtʃ əbaʊt. ivən ə waɪldɝ u hæd ɡeɪn kənsɪɾɝəbəl kəntʃɹoʊl ɑn əɹ oʊn kwɪkli lɝn ðəɾ əz lɔŋ əz ʃi wɔɹ nɑvəs waɪt, ʃi wɑz nɑt tə soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪstɝ əɹ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd stændɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ. wɪtʃ dɪd tɛn tə lɪməɾ ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɹæðɝ ʃɑɹpli. ði ʌðɝ tʃɹɪk, haʊɛvɝ, smɛl tu əkɪn tə fɔɹbɪɾən kəmpʌlʃən. oʊ, ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə weɪ tə meɪk fɑðɝ ɡɪv əɹ dʒɹɛsəz əɹ tʃɹɪŋkəts i dɪd nɑt wɑnə baɪ, əɹ meɪk mʌðɝ əpɹuv ə jʌŋ mɛn ʃi ɔɹɾənɛɹəli ɹæn ɔf, θɪŋz ə ðət neɪtʃɝ, bʌt ðə taʊɝ ɹuɾəd ðə tʃɹɪk aʊt moʊst ɪfɛktɪvli. mɛni ʌv ðə ɡɝlz ən wɪmən vɛɹɪn hæd spoʊkən tə oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz kəd nɑt meɪk ðɛmsɛlvz fɔɹm ðə wivz, mʌtʃ lɛs juz ðɛm, ən ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ kəd nɑɾ ivən meɪk ðɛmsɛlvz ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ. fɹəm bɪts ən pisəz ən skɹæps ə hæf-ɹɪmɛmbɝd wivz kɹieɪɾəd baɪ əntʃɹeɪnd ɡɝlz fəɹ vɛɹi lɪməɾəd pɝpəsəz, vɛɹɪn hæd ɹikənstʃɹʌktɪɾ ə θɪŋ fɔɹbɪɾən baɪ ðə taʊɝ sɪns ɪts faʊndɪŋ. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪt hæd bɪn sɪmpəl kjʊɹiɑsəɾi ɑn əɹ pɑɹt. kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, ʃi θɔt ɹaɪli, wɝkɪŋ ət ðə wiv ɑn bɛldaɪn, hæz meɪd mi klaɪm ɪndə mɔɹ ðən wʌn pɪklɪŋ kɛɾəl. jusfəlnəs keɪm leɪɾɝ.

The first, the Tower did not care much about. Even a wilder who had gained considerable control on her own quickly learned that as long as she wore novice white, she was not to so much as touch saidar without a sister or one of the Accepted standing over her. Which did tend to limit eavesdropping rather sharply. The other trick, however, smelled too akin to forbidden Compulsion. Oh, it was just a way to make Father give her dresses or trinkets he did not want to buy, or make Mother approve of young men she ordinarily ran off, things of that nature, but the Tower rooted the trick out most effectively. Many of the girls and women Verin had spoken to over the years could not make themselves form the weaves, much less use them, and a fair number could not even make themselves remember how. From bits and pieces and scraps of half-remembered weaves created by untrained girls for very limited purposes, Verin had reconstructed a thing forbidden by the Tower since its founding. In the beginning it had been simple curiosity on her part. Curiosity, she thought wryly, working at the weave on Beldeine, has made me climb into more than one pickling kettle. Usefulness came later.

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪleɪɾə mɛn tə kip ɪm daʊn ɪn ði oʊpən sɛlz," ʃi sɛd kənvɝseɪʃənəli. ðə ɡɹɪl-wɔl sɛlz wɝ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, əz wɛl əz ɪnɪʃiəts ə ðə taʊɝ ʌndɝ kloʊs ɝɛst, waɪldɝz u hæd kleɪm tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɛniwʌn ɛls u mʌs bi boʊθ kənfaɪn ən blɑkt ɔf fɹəm ðə sɔɹs. "nɑɾ ə kʌmftəɹbəl pleɪs fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. noʊ pɹaɪvəsi. dʒju bɪliv hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bɛldaɪn?" ðɪs taɪm ʃi pɔz tə lɪsən.

"I suppose Elaida meant to keep him down in the open cells," she said conversationally. The grill-walled cells were intended for men who could channel, as well as initiates of the Tower under close arrest, wilders who had claimed to be Aes Sedai, and anyone else who must be both confined and blocked off from the Source. "Not a comfortable place for the Dragon Reborn. No privacy. Do you believe he is the Dragon Reborn, Beldeine?" This time she paused to listen.

"jɛs." ðə wɝd wɑz ə lɔŋ hɪs, ən bɛldaɪn ɹoʊl fɹaɪɾənd aɪz təwɔɹd vɛɹɪnz feɪs. "jɛs . . . bʌɾ i mʌst . . . bi kɛpt . . . seɪf. ðə wɝld . . . mʌs bi . . . seɪf . . . fɹəm hɪm."

"Yes." The word was a long hiss, and Beldeine rolled frightened eyes toward Verin's face. "Yes . . . but he must . . . be kept . . . safe. The world . . . must be . . . safe . . . from him."

ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl sɛd ðə wɝl hæd tə bi kɛp seɪf fɹəm hɪm; wʌt wɑz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ wɑz ðoʊz u θɔɾ i niɾəd pɹətɛkʃən, tu. səm u hæd sɛd ðæt, sɝpɹaɪz hɝ.

Interesting. They had all said the world had to be kept safe from him; what was interesting was those who thought he needed protection, too. Some who had said that, surprised her.

tə vɛɹɪnz aɪz, ðə wiv ʃi hæd meɪd ɹɪzɛmbəl nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə hæphæzɝd tæŋɡəl ə feɪnli ɡloʊɪŋ tʃɹænspɛɹən θɹɛdz ɔl bʌndəld ɝaʊn bɛldaɪnz hɛd, wɪð fɔɹ θɹɛdz ə spɪɹət tʃɹeɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə mɛs. tu ʌv ðoʊz, ɑpəzət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ʃi pʊld, ən ðə tæŋɡəl kəlæpst slaɪtli, fɔlɪŋ ɪnwɝd, ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ɔɹɾɝ. bɛldaɪnz aɪz ʃɑɾ oʊpən waɪd, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə fɑɹ dɪstəns.

To Verin's eyes, the weave she had made resembled nothing so much as a haphazard tangle of faintly glowing transparent threads all bundled around Beldeine's head, with four threads of Spirit trailing out of the mess. Two of those, opposite one another, she pulled, and the tangle collapsed slightly, falling inward, into something on the edge of order. Beldeine's eyes shot open wide, staring into the far distance.

ɪn ə fɝm, loʊ vɔɪs, vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. mɔɹ laɪk sədʒɛstʃənz, ðoʊ ʃi fɹeɪzd əm əz kəmænz. bɛldaɪn wəɾ əv tə faɪn ɹizənz wɪðɪn hɝsɛlf tə oʊbeɪ; ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt, ðən ɔl ðɪs hæd bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ weɪstəɾ ɛfɝt.

In a firm, low voice, Verin gave her instructions. More like suggestions, though she phrased them as commands. Beldeine would have to find reasons within herself to obey; if she did not, then all this had been so much wasted effort.

wɪð ðə faɪnəl wɝdz, vɛɹɪn pʊl ði ʌðɝ tu θɹɛdz ə spɪɹət, ən ðə tæŋɡəl kəlæps fɝðɝ. ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ, ɪt fɛl ɪndə wʌt sim pɝfəkt ɔɹɾɝ, ə pæɾɝn mɔɹ pɹɪsaɪs, mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən ðə moʊst ɪntʃɹəkət leɪs, ən kəmplit, taɪɾ ɔf baɪ ðə seɪm ækʃən ðət bɪɡæn ɪts ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ. ðɪs taɪm, ɪt kəntɪnjud tə fɔl ɪnwɝɾ ɑn ɪtsɛlf, ɪnwɝɾ ɝaʊn bɛldaɪnz hɛd. ðoʊz feɪnli ɡloʊɪŋ θɹɛdz sæŋk ɪndə hɝ, vænɪʃt. hɝ aɪz ɹoʊl bæk ɪn əɹ hɛd, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə θɹæʃ, lɪmz kwɪvɝɪŋ. vɛɹɪn hɛld əɹ əz dʒɛnli əz ʃi kʊd, bʌt bɛldaɪnz hɛd stɪl wɪp fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, ən əɹ bɛɹ hilz dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə kɑɹpəts. sun, oʊnli ðə moʊs kɛɹfəl dɛlvɪŋ wəd tɛl ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæd bɪn dʌn, ən nɑɾ ivən ðət wəɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪ ðə wiv. vɛɹɪn hæd tɛstəd ðət kɛɹfəli, ən ɪf ʃi dɪd seɪ soʊ hɝsɛlf, nʌn sɝpæst əɹ ət dɛlvɪŋ.

With the final words, Verin pulled the other two threads of Spirit, and the tangle collapsed further. This time, though, it fell into what seemed perfect order, a pattern more precise, more complicated than the most intricate lace, and complete, tied off by the same action that began its shrinking. This time, it continued to fall inward on itself, inward around Beldeine's head. Those faintly glowing threads sank into her, vanished. Her eyes rolled back in her head, and she began to thrash, limbs quivering. Verin held her as gently as she could, but Beldeine's head still whipped from side to side, and her bare heels drummed on the carpets. Soon, only the most careful Delving would tell that anything had been done, and not even that would identify the weave. Verin had tested that carefully, and if she did say so herself, none surpassed her at Delving.

ʌv kɔɹs ðə θɪŋ wɑz nɑt tʃɹuli kəmpʌlʃən əz eɪntʃən tɛksts dɪskɹaɪbd ɪt. ðə wivɪŋ wɛnt wɪð peɪnfəl sloʊnəs, kɑbəl təɡɛðɝ əz ɪt wɑz, ən ðəɹ wɑz ðət nid fəɹ ə ɹizən. ɪt hɛlpt ə ɡɹeɪt dil ɪf ði əbdʒɛkt ə ðə wiv wɑz ɪmoʊʃnəli vʌlnɝəbəl, bʌt tʃɹʌst wɑz æbsəlutli ɪsɛnʃəl. ivən kætʃɪŋ sʌmwʌn baɪ sɝpɹaɪz dɪd noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ səspɪʃəs. ðət fækt kʌt daʊn ɪts jusfəlnəs wɪð mɛn kənsɪɾɝəbli; vɛɹi fju mɛn læk səspɪʃən ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Of course the thing was not truly Compulsion as ancient texts described it. The weaving went with painful slowness, cobbled together as it was, and there was that need for a reason. It helped a great deal if the object of the weave was emotionally vulnerable, but trust was absolutely essential. Even catching someone by surprise did no good if they were suspicious. That fact cut down its usefulness with men considerably; very few men lacked suspicion around Aes Sedai.

dɪstʃɹʌst əsaɪd, mɛn wɝ vɛɹi bæd sʌbʒɪkts, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ. moʊst ə ðoʊz ɡɝlz' wivz hæd bɪn ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ðɛɹ fɑðɝz əɹ ʌðɝ mɛn. ɛni stʃɹɔŋ pɝsənælɪɾi maɪt bɪɡɪn tə kwɛstʃən ɪz oʊn ækʃənz - əɹ ivən fɝɡɛt duɪŋ ðɛm, wɪtʃ lɛd tə ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə pɹɑbləmz - bʌɾ ɔl θɪŋz biɪŋ ikwəl, mɛn wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli tə. mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə səspɪʃən əɡɛn. waɪ, wʌns ə mæn hæɾ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə wivz biɪŋ woʊvən ɑn hɪm, ɪf nɑt ði ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz ʃi hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. sətʃ ə lɑɾ ə bɑðɝ ðət kɑzd! nɑt sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wəd ɹɪsk əɡɛn.

Distrust aside, men were very bad subjects, unfortunately. She could not understand why. Most of those girls' weaves had been intended for their fathers or other men. Any strong personality might begin to question his own actions - or even forget doing them, which led to another set of problems - but all things being equal, men were much more likely to. Much more likely. Perhaps it was the suspicion again. Why, once a man had even remembered the weaves being woven on him, if not the instructions she had given him. Such a lot of bother that caused! Not something she would risk again.

ət læs bɛldaɪnz kənvʌlʃənz lɛsənd, stɑpt. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə fɪlθi hæn tə hɝ hɛd. "wʌt - ? wʌt hæpənd?" ʃi sɛd, ɔlmoʊst ɪnɔɾəbli. "dɪɾ aɪ feɪnt?" fɔɝɡɛtfəlnəs wɑz ənʌðɝ ɡʊd pɔɪn əbaʊt ðə wiv, nɑɾ ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli. æftɝ ɔl, fɑðɝ mʌs nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət jə sʌmhaʊ meɪɾ ɪm baɪ ðəɾ ɪkspɛnsɪv dʒɹɛs.

At last Beldeine's convulsions lessened, stopped. She raised a filthy hand to her head. "What - ? What happened?" she said, almost inaudibly. "Did I faint?" Forgetfulness was another good point about the weave, not unexpectedly. After all, Father must not remember that you somehow made him buy that expensive dress.

"ðə hiɾ ɪz vɛɹi bæd," vɛɹɪn sɛd, hɛlpɪŋ əɹ tə sɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn. "aɪ hæv fɛlt laɪt-hɛɾəd maɪsɛlf wʌns əɹ twaɪs tədeɪ." fɹəm wɪɹinəs, nɑt hit. hænlɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ tʊk ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ju, ɪspɛʃli wən jə hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn ɪt fɔɹ taɪmz tədeɪ. ði æŋɡɹil dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə bʌfɝ ði ɪfɛks wʌns jə stɑp juzɪŋ ɪt. ʃi cʊɾə juzd ə stɛɾiɪŋ hæn hɝsɛlf. "aɪ θɪŋk ðæts əbaʊɾ ɪnʌf. ɪf jəɹ feɪntɪŋ, pɝhæps ðəl faɪn sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ jə tə də aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn." ðə pɹɑspɛk dɪd nɑt sim tə tʃɪɹ bɛldaɪn əɾ ɔl.

"The heat is very bad," Verin said, helping her to sit up again. "I have felt light-headed myself once or twice today." From weariness, not heat. Handling that much of saidar took it out of you, especially when you had already done it four times today. The angreal did nothing to buffer the effects once you stopped using it. She could have used a steadying hand herself. "I think that's about enough. If you're fainting, perhaps they'll find something for you to do out of the sun." The prospect did not seem to cheer Beldeine at all.

ɹʌbɪŋ ðə smɔl ə hɝ bæk, vɛɹɪn stʌk əɹ hɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. kɔɹæm ən mɛndæn stɑp ðɛɹ ɡeɪm ə kæts kɹeɪɾəl wʌns mɔɹ; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ðəɾ iðɝ hæd lɪsənd, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt weɪdʒɝ əɹ laɪf ɑn ɪt. ʃi toʊld əm ðət ʃi wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð bɛldaɪn ænd, æftɝ ə moʊməns θɔt, æɾəd ðət ʃi niɾəd ənʌðɝ pɪtʃɝ ʌv wɔɾɝ sɪns bɛldaɪn hæɾ oʊvɝtɝn hɝz. boʊθ mɛnz feɪsəz dɑɹkən bɪniθ ðɛɹ tænz. ðət wəd bi pæst əlɔŋ tə ðə waɪz wʌn u keɪm fəɹ bɛldaɪn. ɪt wəd sɝv əz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ tə hɛlp əɹ ɹitʃ əɹ dɪsɪʒən.

Rubbing the small of her back, Verin stuck her head out of the tent. Coram and Mendan stopped their game of cat's cradle once more; there was no sign that either had listened, but she would not wager her life on it. She told them that she was finished with Beldeine and, after a moment's thought, added that she needed another pitcher of water since Beldeine had overturned hers. Both men's faces darkened beneath their tans. That would be passed along to the Wise One who came for Beldeine. It would serve as something more to help her reach her decision.

ðə sʌn stɪl hæɾ ə lɔŋ weɪ tə fɔl tə ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌt ði eɪk ɪn əɹ bæk toʊld əɹ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stɑp fəɹ ðə deɪ. ʃi kəd stɪl də wʌn mɔɹ sɪstɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd, baɪ mɔɹnɪŋ ʃi wəd fil ɪɾ ɪn ɛvɹi mʌsəl. hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn ɝɡən, naʊ wɪð ðə wɪmən kæɹiɪŋ bæskəts tə ðə hændmɪlz. haʊ wəɾ əɹ laɪf əv ɡɔn ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ kjʊɹiəs, vɛɹɪn wʌndɝd. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ʃi wʊɾə mɛɹiɾ idwɪn ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ʃi wəd bi lɔŋ dɛd, fəɹ ənʌðɝ, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hæd, ən əɹ ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən, tu.

The sun still had a long way to fall to the horizon, but the ache in her back told her it was time to stop for the day. She could still do one more sister, but if she did, by morning she would feel it in every muscle. Her eyes fell on Irgain, now with the women carrying baskets to the handmills. How would her life have gone if she had not been so curious, Verin wondered. For one thing, she would have married Eadwin and remained in Far Madding instead of going to the White Tower. She would be long dead, for another, and the children she had never had, and her grandchildren, too.

wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi tɝn bæk tə kɔɹæm. "wɛn mɛndæn ɹɪtɝnz, wəd jə ɡoʊ tɛl koʊlɪndə ðəɾ aɪ wəd laɪk tə si ɝɡən fɑteɪmd?" ðə peɪn ɪn əɹ mʌsəlz təmɑɹoʊ wəd bi ə smɔl pɛnəns fəɹ bɛldaɪnz sʌfɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ðət spɪld wɔɾɝ, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt waɪ ʃi dɪɾ ɪt, əɹ ivən əɹ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, ɹɪli. ʃi stɪl hæɾ ə tæsk. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi hæd tə kip jʌŋ ɹænd əlaɪv əntɪl ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ɪm tə daɪ.

With a sigh, she turned back to Coram. "When Mendan returns, would you go tell Colinda that I would like to see Irgain Fatamed?" The pain in her muscles tomorrow would be a small penance for Beldeine's suffering over that spilled water, but that was not why she did it, or even her curiosity, really. She still had a task. Somehow, she had to keep young Rand alive until it was time for him to die.

ðə ɹum maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪn ə ɡɹæn pæləs, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt hæd niðɝ wɪndoʊz nɔɹ dɔɹz. ðə faɪɝ ɑn ə ɡoʊldən mɑɹbəl hɑɹθ ɡeɪv noʊ hit, ən ðə fleɪmz dɪd nɑt kənsum ðə lɔɡz. ðə mæn siɾəd əɾ ə teɪbəl wɪð ɡɪldɪd lɛɡz, sɛntɝɾ ɑn ə sɪlk kɑɹpət woʊvən wɪð ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ θɹɛdz ʌv ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ, kɛɹd lɪɾəl fəɹ ðə tʃɹæpɪŋz ə ðɪs eɪdʒ. ðeɪ wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi tə ɪmpɹɛs; noʊ mɔɹ. nɑt ðəɾ i ɹɪli niɾəd mɔɹ ðən hɪmsɛlf tə oʊvɝeɪ ðə stɪfəs pɹaɪd. hi kɔl hɪmsɛlf mɔɹaɪɾɪn, ən ʃʊɹli noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ hæd mɔɹ ɹaɪt tə neɪm hɪmsɛlf dɛθ.

The room might have been in a grand palace, except that it had neither windows nor doors. The fire on a golden marble hearth gave no heat, and the flames did not consume the logs. The man seated at a table with gilded legs, centered on a silk carpet woven with glittering threads of gold and silver, cared little for the trappings of this Age. They were necessary to impress; no more. Not that he really needed more than himself to overawe the stiffest pride. He called himself Moridin, and surely no one had ever had more right to name himself Death.

fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm i aɪdli stʃɹoʊkt wʌn ə ðə tu maɪntʃɹæps ðət hʌŋ ɑn pleɪn sɪlkən kɔɹdz ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. əɾ ɪz tʌtʃ, ðə blʌd-ɹɛd kɹɪstəl ə ðə kɔɹsvɹə pʌlsd, swɝlz muvɪŋ ɪn ɛnləs dɛpθs laɪk ðə biɾɪŋ ʌv ə hɑɹt. hɪz ɹil ətɛnʃən wɑz ɑn ðə ɡeɪm leɪɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɑn ðə teɪbəl, θɝɾi-θɹi ɹɛd pisəz ən θɝɾi-θɹi ɡɹin ɝeɪɾ əkɹɔs ə pleɪɪŋ sɝfəs ə θɝtin skwɛɹz baɪ θɝtin. ə ɹeɪ-kɹieɪʃən ə ði ɝli steɪdʒəz ʌv ə feɪməs ɡeɪm. ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt pis, ðə fɪʃɝ, blæk-ænd-waɪt laɪk ðə pleɪɪŋ sɝfəs, stɪl weɪɾəd ɪn ɪts stɑɹɾɪŋ pleɪs ɑn ðə sɛntʃɹəl skwɛɹ. ə kɑmplɛks ɡeɪm, ʃɝə, eɪntʃən lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ. ʃɝə, tʃɝən, ən nɔɹi, ðə ɡeɪm naʊ kɔl sɪmpli "stoʊnz," itʃ hæɾ ædhɪɹəns u kleɪmd ɪɾ ɛnkʌmpəst ɔl ðə sʌɾəltiz ə laɪf, bʌt mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz feɪvɝd ʃɝə. oʊnli naɪn pipəl lɪvɪŋ ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə ɡeɪm. hi hæd bɪn ə mæstɝ ʌv ɪt. mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmplɛks ðən tʃɝən əɹ nɔɹi. ðə fɝst əbdʒɛkt wɑz kæptʃɝ ə ðə fɪʃɝ. oʊnli ðən dɪd ðə ɡeɪm tʃɹuli bɪɡɪn.

From time to time he idly stroked one of the two mindtraps that hung on plain silken cords around his neck. At his touch, the blood-red crystal of the cour'souvra pulsed, swirls moving in endless depths like the beating of a heart. His real attention was on the game laid out before him on the table, thirty-three red pieces and thirty-three green arrayed across a playing surface of thirteen squares by thirteen. A re-creation of the early stages of a famous game. The most important piece, the Fisher, black-and-white like the playing surface, still waited in its starting place on the central square. A complex game, sha'rah, ancient long before the War of Power. Sha'rah, tcheran, and no'ri, the game now called simply "stones," each had adherents who claimed it encompassed all the subtleties of life, but Moridin had always favored sha'rah. Only nine people living even remembered the game. He had been a master of it. Much more complex than tcheran or no'ri. The first object was capture of the Fisher. Only then did the game truly begin.

ə sɝvən əpɹoʊtʃt, ə slɪm ɡɹeɪsfəl jʌŋ mæn klæɾ ɔl ɪn waɪt, ɪmpɑsəbli hænsəm, boʊɪŋ əz i pɹizɛntəɾ ə kɹɪstəl ɡɑbləɾ ɑn ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ. hi smaɪld, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ ɪz blæk aɪz, aɪz mɔɹ laɪfləs ðən sɪmpli dɛd. moʊs mɛn wʊɾə fɛlt ənkʌmftəɹbəl hævɪŋ ðət ɡeɪz ɑn ðɛm. mɔɹaɪɾɪn mɪɹli tʊk ðə ɡɑbləɾ ən moʊʃən ðə sɝvən əweɪ. ðə vɪntnɝz ə ðɪs taɪm pɹədust səm ɛksələnt waɪnz. hi dɪd nɑt dʒɹɪŋk, ðoʊ.

A servant approached, a slim graceful young man clad all in white, impossibly handsome, bowing as he presented a crystal goblet on a silver tray. He smiled, but it did not touch his black eyes, eyes more lifeless than simply dead. Most men would have felt uncomfortable having that gaze on them. Moridin merely took the goblet and motioned the servant away. The vintners of this time produced some excellent wines. He did not drink, though.

ðə fɪʃɝ hɛld ɪz ətɛnʃən, beɪɾɪŋ hɪm. sɛvɹəl pisəz hæd vɛɹiɪŋ muvz, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə fɪʃɝz ætʃɹəbjuts ɔltɝɾ əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə wɛɹ ɪt stʊd; ɑn ə waɪt skwɛɹ, wik ɪn ətæk jɛɾ ædʒəl ən fɑɹ-ɹeɪnʒɪŋ ɪn ɪskeɪp; ɑn blæk, stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ətæk bʌt sloʊ ən vʌlnɝəbəl. wən mæstɝz pleɪd, ðə fɪʃɝ tʃeɪnʒd saɪdz mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnd. ðə ɡɹin-ænd-ɹɛd ɡoʊl-ɹoʊ ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə pleɪɪŋ sɝfəs kəd bi θɹɛɾənd baɪ ɛni pis, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə fɪʃɝ kəd muv ɑntu ɪt. nɑt ðəɾ i wɑz seɪf, ivən ðɛɹ; ðə fɪʃɝ wɑz nɛvɝ seɪf. wən ðə fɪʃɝ wɑz jʊɹz, jə tʃɹaɪd tə muv ɪm tə ə skwɛɹ ə jəɹ kʌlɝ bɪhaɪn jəɹ əpoʊnəns ɛn ə ðə bɔɹd. ðət wɑz vɪktɝi, ði iziəst weɪ, bʌt nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. wən jəɹ əpoʊnən hɛl ðə fɪʃɝ, jə ətɛmptəd tə liv ɪm noʊ tʃɔɪs fəɹ ðə fɪʃɝ bʌt tə muv ɑntu jəɹ kʌlɝ. ɛniwɛɹ əɾ ɔl əlɔŋ ðə ɡoʊl-ɹoʊ wəd du; hoʊldɪŋ ðə fɪʃɝ kəd bi mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən nɑt. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ə θɝd pæθ tə vɪktɝi ɪn ʃɝə, ɪf jə tʊk ɪt bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ jɝsɛlf bi tʃɹæpt. ðə ɡeɪm ɔlweɪz dɪdʒɛnɝeɪɾɪd ɪn ə blʌɾi meɪleɪ, ðɛn, vɪktɝi kʌmɪŋ oʊnli wɪð kəmpliɾ ənaɪəleɪʃən ə jəɹ ɛnəmi. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd ðæt, wʌns, ɪn dɛspɝeɪʃən, bʌt ði ətɛmp hæd feɪld. peɪnfəli.

The Fisher held his attention, baiting him. Several pieces had varying moves, but only the Fisher's attributes altered according to where it stood; on a white square, weak in attack yet agile and far-ranging in escape; on black, strong in attack but slow and vulnerable. When masters played, the Fisher changed sides many times before the end. The green-and-red goal-row that surrounded the playing surface could be threatened by any piece, but only the Fisher could move onto it. Not that he was safe, even there; the Fisher was never safe. When the Fisher was yours, you tried to move him to a square of your color behind your opponent's end of the board. That was victory, the easiest way, but not the only one. When your opponent held the Fisher, you attempted to leave him no choice for the Fisher but to move onto your color. Anywhere at all along the goal-row would do; holding the Fisher could be more dangerous than not. Of course, there was a third path to victory in sha'rah, if you took it before letting yourself be trapped. The game always degenerated in a bloody melee, then, victory coming only with complete annihilation of your enemy. He had tried that, once, in desperation, but the attempt had failed. Painfully.

fjʊɹi bɔɪl sʌɾənli ɪn mɔɹaɪɾɪnz hɛd, ən blæk flɛks swæm əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz əz i siz ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ. ɛkstəsi ðəɾ əmaʊntɪd tə peɪn θʌndɝd θɹu hɪm. hɪz hæn kloʊzd ɝaʊn ðə tu maɪntʃɹæps, ən ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ kloʊzd ɝaʊn ðə fɪʃɝ, snætʃɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ə hɛɹ fɹəm kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪt tə paʊɾɝ, kɹʌʃɪŋ ðə paʊɾɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns. ðə ɡɑblət ʃæɾɝd ɪn ɪz hænd. hɪz ɡɹɪp bɔɹɾɝd ɑn kɹʌʃɪŋ ðə kɔɹsvɹə. ðə sæɑ wɝ ə blɪzɝɾ ə blæk, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɪndɝ ɪz saɪt. ðə fɪʃɝ wɑz ɔlweɪz wɝkt əz ə mæn, ə bændɪdʒ blaɪndɪŋ ɪz aɪz ən wʌn hæn pɹɛs tə hɪz saɪd, ə fju dʒɹɑps ə blʌd dʒɹɪpɪŋ θɹu hɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə ɹizənz, laɪk ðə sɔɹs ə ðə neɪm, wɝ lɔst ɪn ðə mɪst ə taɪm. ðət tʃɹʌbəld ɪm səmtaɪmz, ɛnɹeɪdʒ hɪm, wʌt nɑlədʒ maɪt bi lɔst ɪn ðə tɝnɪŋz ə ðə wil, nɑlədʒ i niɾəd, nɑlədʒ i hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə. ə ɹaɪt!

Fury boiled suddenly in Moridin's head, and black flecks swam across his eyes as he seized the True Power. Ecstasy that amounted to pain thundered through him. His hand closed around the two mindtraps, and the True Power closed around the Fisher, snatching it into the air, a hair from crushing it to powder, crushing the powder out of existence. The goblet shattered in his hand. His grip bordered on crushing the cour'souvra. The saa were a blizzard of black, but they did not hinder his sight. The Fisher was always worked as a man, a bandage blinding his eyes and one hand pressed to his side, a few drops of blood dripping through his fingers. The reasons, like the source of the name, were lost in the mist of time. That troubled him sometimes, enraged him, what knowledge might be lost in the turnings of the Wheel, knowledge he needed, knowledge he had a right to. A right!

sloʊli hi sɛt ðə fɪʃɝ bæk ɑn ðə bɔɹd. sloʊli hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ʌnkɝl fɹəm ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹsvɹə. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ dɪstʃɹʌkʃən. jɛt. aɪsi kɑm ɹipleɪst ɹeɪdʒ ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ. blʌɾ ən waɪn dʒɹɪp fɹəm ɪz ɡæʃt hænd, ənnoʊɾɪst. pɝhæps ðə fɪʃɝ dɪd kʌm fɹəm səm dɪm ɹɛmnən ʌv ə mɛmɹi ʌv ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ə ʃædoʊ. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz læfɪŋ, ən meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə stɑp. ɑn ðə bɔɹd, ðə fɪʃɝ stʊd weɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɡeɪm, ælθɹ muvd ɔlɹɛɾi tə hɪz wɪʃɪz. ən sun, naʊ. . . . ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd tə luz ə ɡeɪm wən jə pleɪd boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə bɔɹd. mɔɹaɪɾɪn læf soʊ hɑɹd ðət tɪɹz ɹoʊl daʊn ɪz feɪs, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əwɛɹ ə ðɛm.

Slowly he set the Fisher back on the board. Slowly his fingers uncurled from around the cour'souvra. There was no need for destruction. Yet. Icy calm replaced rage in the blink of an eye. Blood and wine dripped from his gashed hand, unnoticed. Perhaps the Fisher did come from some dim remnant of a memory of Rand al'Thor, the shadow of a shadow. It did not matter. He realized he was laughing, and made no effort to stop. On the board, the Fisher stood waiting, but in the greater game, al'Thor moved already to his wishes. And soon, now. . . . It was very hard to lose a game when you played both sides of the board. Moridin laughed so hard that tears rolled down his face, but he was not aware of them.


tʃæptɝ wʌn


CHAPTER 1

tə kip ðə bɑɹɡən


To Keep the Bargain

ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz, ən eɪdʒəz kʌm ən pæs, livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət bɪkʌm lɛdʒənd. lɛdʒən feɪdz tə mɪθ, ən ivən mɪθ ɪz lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən wən ði eɪdʒ ðət ɡeɪv ɪt bɝθ kʌmz əɡɛn. ɪn wʌn eɪdʒ, kɔl ðə θɝɾ eɪdʒ baɪ sʌm, ən eɪdʒ jɛt tə kʌm, ən eɪdʒ lɔŋ pæst, ə wɪn ɹoʊz əbʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt maʊntənəs aɪlən ə tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ. ðə wɪnd wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ niðɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋz nɔɹ ɛndɪŋz tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ə taɪm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

The Wheel of Time turns, and Ages come and pass, leaving memories that become legend. Legend fades to myth, and even myth is long forgotten when the Age that gave it birth comes again. In one Age, called the Third Age by some, an Age yet to come, an Age long past, a wind rose above the great mountainous island of Tremalking. The wind was not the beginning. There are neither beginnings nor endings to the turning of the Wheel of Time. But it was a beginning.

is ðə wɪn blu əkɹɔs tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, wɛɹ ðə fɛɹ-skɪn æmɑjɹ fɑɹm ðɛɹ filz, ən meɪd faɪn ɡlæs ən pɔɹsələn, ən fɑloʊd ðə pis ə ðə wɔɾɝ weɪ. ði æmɑjɹ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə wɝl bɪɑn ðɛɹ skæɾɝd aɪlənz, fəɹ ðə wɔɾɝ weɪ tɔt ðət ðɪs wɝld wɑz oʊnli ɪluʒən, ə mɪɹɝd ɹəflɛkʃən ə bɪlif, jɛt səm wɑtʃt ðə wɪn kæɹi dʌst ən dip sʌmɝ hit wɛɹ koʊld wɪntɝ ɹeɪnz ʃəd bi fɔlɪŋ, ən ðeɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd teɪlz hɝd fɹəm ði æθɑn maɪɹ. teɪlz ə ðə wɝl bɪɑnd, ən wʌt pɹɑfəsi sɛd wɑz tə kʌm. səm lʊk tə ə hɪl wɛɹ ə mæsɪv stoʊn hæn ɹoʊz fɹəm ði ɝθ, hoʊldɪŋ ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən mɛni haʊsəz. ði æmɑjɹ hæd ðɛɹ oʊn pɹɑfəsiz, ən səm ə ðoʊz spoʊk ə ðə hæn ən ðə sfɪɹ. ən ði ɛn ʌv ɪluʒənz.

East the wind blew across Tremalking, where the fair-skinned Amayar farmed their fields, and made fine glass and porcelain, and followed the peace of the Water Way. The Amayar ignored the world beyond their scattered islands, for the Water Way taught that this world was only illusion, a mirrored reflection of belief, yet some watched the wind carry dust and deep summer heat where cold winter rains should be falling, and they remembered tales heard from the Atha'an Miere. Tales of the world beyond, and what prophecy said was to come. Some looked to a hill where a massive stone hand rose from the earth, holding a clear crystal sphere larger than many houses. The Amayar had their own prophecies, and some of those spoke of the hand and the sphere. And the end of illusions.

ɔnwɝd ðə wɪn blu ɪndə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, istwɝd bɪniθ ə sɪɹɪŋ sʌn ɪn ə skaɪ əbændən baɪ klaʊdz, wɪpɪŋ ðə tɑps ʌv ɡɹin si swɛlz, bæɾəlɪŋ wɪnz fɹəm ðə saʊθ ən wɛstwɝd wɪnz, ʃɪɹɪŋ ən swɝlɪŋ əz ðə wɔɾɝz bɪloʊ hivd. nɑt jɛt ðə stɔɹmz ʌv wɪntɝz hɑɹt, ðoʊ wɪntɝ ʃʊɾə bɪn hæf ɡɔn, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ stɔɹmz ʌv ə daɪɪŋ sʌmɝ, bʌt wɪnz ən kɝəns ðət kəd bi juz baɪ oʊʃən-fɛɹiŋ foʊk tə koʊst ɝaʊn ðə kɑntənən fɹəm wɝlz ɛn tə min ən bɪɑnd, ðən bæk əɡɛn. istwɝd ðə wɪn haʊld, oʊvɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ oʊʃən wɛɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt weɪlz ɹoʊz ən saʊndəd, ən flaɪɪŋ fɪʃ sɔɹɾ ɑn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt fɪnz tu peɪsɪz ən mɔɹ əkɹɔs, istwɝd, naʊ wɝlɪŋ nɔɹθ, ist ən nɔɹθ, oʊvɝ smɔl flits ə fɪʃɪŋ ʃɪps dʒɹæɡɪŋ ðɛɹ nɛts ɪn ðə ʃæloʊɝ siz. səm ə ðoʊz fɪʃɝmɪn stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ, hænz aɪɾəl ɑn ðə laɪnz, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə hjudʒ ɝeɪ ʌv tɔl vɛsəlz ən smɔlɝ ðət pɝpəsfəli ɹoʊd ðə wɪnz hɑɹd bɹɛθ, ʃæɾɝɪŋ swɛlz wɪð blʌf baʊz, slaɪsɪŋ swɛlz wɪð nɛɹoʊ, ðɛɹ bænɝ ə ɡoʊldən hɔk wɪð təlɑnz klʌtʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ, ə mʌltətuɾ ə stʃɹimɪŋ bænɝz laɪk pɔɹtɛns ə stɔɹm. ist ən nɔɹθ ən ɑn, ən ðə wɪn ɹitʃt ðə bɹɔd, ʃɪp-fɪl hɑɹbɝ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, wɛɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə si foʊk vɛsəlz ɹoʊɾ əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪn mɛni pɔɹts, əweɪɾɪŋ wɝɾ ə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ðə tʃoʊzən wʌn.

Onward the wind blew into the Sea of Storms, eastward beneath a searing sun in a sky abandoned by clouds, whipping the tops of green sea swells, battling winds from the south and westward winds, shearing and swirling as the waters below heaved. Not yet the storms of winter's heart, though winter should have been half gone, much less the greater storms of a dying summer, but winds and currents that could be used by ocean-faring folk to coast around the continent from World's End to Mayene and beyond, then back again. Eastward the wind howled, over rolling ocean where the great whales rose and sounded, and flying fish soared on outstretched fins two paces and more across, eastward, now whirling north, east and north, over small fleets of fishing ships dragging their nets in the shallower seas. Some of those fishermen stood gaping, hands idle on the lines, staring at a huge array of tall vessels and smaller that purposefully rode the wind's hard breath, shattering swells with bluff bows, slicing swells with narrow, their banner a golden hawk with talons clutching lightning, a multitude of streaming banners like portents of storm. East and north and on, and the wind reached the broad, ship-filled harbor of Ebou Dar, where hundreds of Sea Folk vessels rode as they did in many ports, awaiting word of the Coramoor, the Chosen One.

əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ ðə wɪn ɹɔɹd, tɔsɪŋ smɔl ʃɪps ən lɑɹdʒ, əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf, ɡlimɪŋ waɪt bɪniθ ði ənfɛɾɝd sʌn, spaɪɹz ən wɔlz ən kʌlɝ-ɹɪŋ doʊmz, stʃɹits ən kənælz bʌsəlɪŋ wɪð ðə stɔɹid sʌðɝn ɪndəstʃɹi. ɝaʊn ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ doʊmz ən slɛndɝ taʊɝz ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs ðə wɪn swɝld, kæɹiɪŋ ðə tæŋ ə sɔlt, lɪftɪŋ ðə flæɡ ʌv ɔltɑɹə, tu ɡoʊldən lɛpɝdz ɑn ə fild ə ɹɛɾ ən blu, ən ðə bænɝz ə ɹulɪŋ haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ, ðə sɔɹɾ ən æŋkɝ, ɡɹin ɑn waɪt. nɑt jɛt ðə stɔɹm, bʌɾ ə hɑɹbɪnʒɝ ə stɔɹmz.

Across the harbor the wind roared, tossing small ships and large, across the city itself, gleaming white beneath the unfettered sun, spires and walls and color-ringed domes, streets and canals bustling with the storied southern industry. Around the shining domes and slender towers of the Tarasin Palace the wind swirled, carrying the tang of salt, lifting the flag of Altara, two golden leopards on a field of red and blue, and the banners of ruling House Mitsobar, the Sword and Anchor, green on white. Not yet the storm, but a harbinger of storms.

skɪn pɹɪkəl bɪtwin eɪvinhəz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz əz ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ kəmpænjənz θɹu pæləs hɔlweɪz taɪld ɪn dʌzənz ə plizɪŋ bɹaɪt hjuz. ə sɛns ə biɪŋ wɑtʃt ðət ʃi hæd læs fɛlt waɪl stɪl wɛd tə ðə spɪɹ. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən ən noʊɪŋ ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛnəmiz əbaʊɾ aɪ kænɑt feɪs! nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ ðət kɹɔlɪŋ sɛnseɪʃən hæd mɛn sʌmwʌn maɪt bi ɪntɛndɪŋ tə kɪl hɝ. dɛθ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ - ɛvɹiwʌn daɪd, tədeɪ əɹ ɑn ənʌðɝ - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə daɪ laɪk ə ɹæbət kɪkɪŋ ɪn ə snɛɹ. ʃi hæd toʊ tə mit.

Skin prickled between Aviendha's shoulder blades as she strode ahead of her companions through palace hallways tiled in dozens of pleasing bright hues. A sense of being watched that she had last felt while still wed to the spear. Imagination, she told herself. Imagination and knowing there are enemies about I cannot face! Not so long ago that crawling sensation had meant someone might be intending to kill her. Death was nothing to fear - everyone died, today or on another - but she did not want to die like a rabbit kicking in a snare. She had toh to meet.

sɝvəns skɝid baɪ kloʊs əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz, bɑbɪŋ baʊz ən kɝtsiz, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd ðə ʃeɪm ə ðə laɪvz ðeɪ lɪvd, jɛt ʃʊɹli ɪt kəd nɑt bi ðɛm ðət meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə twɪst əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd skulɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə si sɝvəns, bʌɾ ivən naʊ, wɪð ðə skɪn kɹipɪŋ ɑn əɹ bæk, hɝ ɡeɪz slɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɪt hæd tə bi ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, ən nɝvz. ðɪs wɑz ə deɪ fəɹ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən ən nɝvz.

Servants scurried by close along the walls, bobbing bows and curtsies, dropping their eyes almost as if they understood the shame of the lives they lived, yet surely it could not be them that made her want to twist her shoulders. She had tried schooling herself to see servants, but even now, with the skin creeping on her back, her gaze slid around them. It had to be imagination, and nerves. This was a day for imagination and nerves.

ənlaɪk ðə sɝvəns, ɹɪtʃ sɪlk tæpəstʃɹiz snæɡd əɾ əɹ aɪ, ən ðə ɡɪldɪd stænd-læmps ən silɪŋ læmps laɪnɪŋ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz. peɪpɝ-θɪn pɔɹsələn ɪn ɹɛdz ən jɛloʊz ən ɡɹinz ən bluz stʊɾ ɪn wɔl nɪtʃɪz ən tɔl oʊpən-wɝk kæbənəts əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɔɹnəməns ʌv ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ, aɪvɝi ən kɹɪstəl, skɔɹz əpɑn skɔɹz ə boʊlz ən veɪsəz ən kæskəts ən stætʃuɛts. oʊnli ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl tʃɹuli kɑɾ əɹ ɡeɪz; wʌtɛvɝ wɛtləndɝz θɔt, bjuɾi hɛl mɔɹ wɝθ ðən ɡoʊld. ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ bjuɾi hɪɹ. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv maɪndəd teɪkɪŋ əɹ ʃɛɹ ə ðə fɪfθ fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs.

Unlike the servants, rich silk tapestries snagged at her eye, and the gilded stand-lamps and ceiling lamps lining the corridors. Paper-thin porcelain in reds and yellows and greens and blues stood in wall niches and tall open-work cabinets alongside ornaments of gold and silver, ivory and crystal, scores upon scores of bowls and vases and caskets and statuettes. Only the most beautiful truly caught her gaze; whatever wetlanders thought, beauty held more worth than gold. There was much beauty here. She would not have minded taking her share of the fifth from this place.

vɛkst wɪð hɝsɛlf, ʃi fɹaʊnd. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ən ɑnɝəbəl θɔt bɪniθ ə ɹuf ðət hæɾ ɔfɝɾ əɹ ʃeɪɾ ən wɔɾɝ fɹili. wɪθaʊt sɛɹəmoʊni, tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ wɪθaʊt dɛɾ əɹ blʌd, stil əɹ nid. jɛt bɛɾɝ ðət ðən θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə smɔl bɔɪ əloʊn sʌmwɛɹ aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs kɝʌp sɪɾi. ɛni sɪɾi wɑz kɝʌpt - ʌv ðət mʌtʃ ʃi wɑz sɝɾən, naʊ, hævɪŋ sin səm pɑɹɾ ə fɔɹ - bʌɾ ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz ðə læst wɛɹ ʃi wʊɾə lɛɾ ə tʃaɪld ɹʌn lus. wʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wɑz waɪ θɔts ʌv oʊlvɝ keɪm ənlɛs ʃi wɝk tə əvɔɪd ðɛm. hi wɑz noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðə toʊ ʃi hæd tə ɪleɪn, ən tə ɹænd ælθɹ. eɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ spɪɹ hæd teɪkən ɪz fɑðɝ, stɑɹveɪʃən ən hɑɹdʃɪp ɪz mʌðɝ, jɛt hæɾ ɪt bɪn əɹ oʊn spɪɹ ðət tʊk boʊθ, ðə bɔɪ wɑz stɪl ə tʃɹikɪlɝ, kɛɹhinɪn. waɪ ʃəd ʃi fɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ə tʃaɪl fɹəm ðət blʌd? waɪ? ʃi ətɛmptəd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə wiv ʃi wɑz tə meɪk, bʌɾ ɔlðoʊ ʃi hæd pɹæktəst ʌndɝ ɪleɪnz aɪ əntɪl ʃi cʊɾə fɔɹmd ɪt slipɪŋ, oʊlvɝz waɪd-maʊð feɪs ɪntʃɹuɾəd. bɝdʒɪt wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ɪm ivən mɔɹ ðən ʃi, bʌt bɝdʒɪts bɹɛs hɛld ə stʃɹeɪnʒli sɑf hɑɹt fəɹ smɔl bɔɪz, ɪspɛʃli ʌɡli wʌnz.

Vexed with herself, she frowned. That was not an honorable thought beneath a roof that had offered her shade and water freely. Without ceremony, true, but also without debt or blood, steel or need. Yet better that than thinking about a small boy alone somewhere out in this corrupt city. Any city was corrupt - of that much she was certain, now, having seen some part of four - but Ebou Dar was the last where she would have let a child run loose. What she could not understand was why thoughts of Olver came unless she worked to avoid them. He was no part of the toh she had to Elayne, and to Rand al'Thor. A Shaido spear had taken his father, starvation and hardship his mother, yet had it been her own spear that took both, the boy was still a treekiller, Cairhienin. Why should she fret over a child from that blood? Why? She attempted to concentrate on the weave she was to make, but although she had practiced under Elayne's eye until she could have formed it sleeping, Olver's wide-mouthed face intruded. Birgitte worried about him even more than she, but Birgitte's breast held a strangely soft heart for small boys, especially ugly ones.

saɪɪŋ, eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ əɹ kəmpænjənz' kɑnvɝseɪʃən bɪhaɪn hɝ, ðoʊ ɪɹɪteɪʃən kɹækəl θɹu ɪt laɪk hit laɪtnɪŋ. ivən ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən əpsɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf oʊvɝ ə sʌn ə tʃɹikɪlɝz. oʊθbɹeɪkɝz. ə dɪspaɪz blʌd ðə wɝld wəd bi bɛɾɝ ɔf wɪθaʊt. noʊ kənsɝn əɹ wɝi ʌv hɝz. nʌn. mæt kɔθən wəd faɪn ðə bɔɪ ɪn ɛni keɪs. hi kəd faɪn ɛniθɪŋ, ɪt simd. ən lɪsnɪŋ sɛɾəld hɝ, sʌmhaʊ. ðə pɹɪklɪŋ feɪɾəd əweɪ.

Sighing, Aviendha gave up trying to ignore her companions' conversation behind her, though irritation crackled through it like heat lightning. Even that was better than upsetting herself over a son of treekillers. Oathbreakers. A despised blood the world would be better off without. No concern or worry of hers. None. Mat Cauthon would find the boy in any case. He could find anything, it seemed. And listening settled her, somehow. The prickling faded away.

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt wʌn bɪt!" nɪneɪiv wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ, kəntɪnjuɪŋ ən ɑɹɡjəmən bɪɡʌn bæk ɪn ðɛɹ ɹumz. "nɑɾ ə bɪt, læn, dʒju hɪɹ mi?" ʃi hæɾ ənaʊnst əɹ dɪslaɪk ət lis twɛnti taɪmz ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌt nɪneɪiv nɛvɝ sɝɛndɝd dʒʌs kəz ʃi hæd lɔst. ʃɔɹɾ ən dɑɹk-aɪd, ʃi stʃɹoʊd fɪɹsli, kɪkɪŋ əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd blu skɝts, wʌn hæn ɹaɪzɪŋ tə hʌvɝ nɪɹ əɹ θɪk, weɪst-lɔŋ bɹeɪd, ðən θɹʌs daʊn fɝmli bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn. nɪneɪiv kɛpt ə taɪt hoʊld ɑn æŋɡɝ ən ɪɹɪteɪʃən wən læn wɑz ɝaʊnd. əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə. ən ɪnɔɹɾənɪt pɹaɪd fɪld əɹ əbaʊt mɛɹiɪŋ hɪm. ðə kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu koʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ jɛloʊ-slæʃt sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs hʌŋ oʊpən, ʃoʊɪŋ fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ bʊzəm ɪn ðə wɛtləndɝ weɪ, dʒʌst soʊ ʃi kəd dɪspleɪ hɪz hɛvi ɡoʊl fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋ ɑn ə faɪn tʃeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. "ju hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə pɹɑməs tə teɪk kɛɹ ə mi laɪk ðæt, læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən," ʃi wɛn ɑn fɝmli. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə pɔɹsələn fɪɡjɝin!"

"I don't like it one bit!" Nynaeve was muttering, continuing an argument begun back in their rooms. "Not a bit, Lan, do you hear me?" She had announced her dislike at least twenty times already, but Nynaeve never surrendered just because she had lost. Short and dark-eyed, she strode fiercely, kicking her divided blue skirts, one hand rising to hover near her thick, waist-long braid, then thrust down firmly before rising again. Nynaeve kept a tight hold on anger and irritation when Lan was around. Or tried to. An inordinate pride filled her about marrying him. The close-fitting embroidered blue coat over her yellow-slashed silk riding dress hung open, showing far too much bosom in the wetlander way, just so she could display his heavy gold finger ring on a fine chain around her neck. "You have no right to promise to take care of me like that, Lan Mandragoran," she went on firmly. "I am not a porcelain figurine!"

hi peɪst əɾ əɹ saɪd, ə mæn ə pɹɑpɝ saɪz, taʊɝɪŋ hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz ən mɔɹ əbʌv hɝ, ði aɪ-ɹɛntʃɪŋ kloʊk ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk. hɪz feɪs sim hæk fɹəm stoʊn, ən ɪz ɡeɪz weɪd ðə θɹɛɾ ɪn ɛvɹi sɝvən u pæst, ɪɡzæmən ɛvɹi kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ ən wɔl nɪtʃ fəɹ hɪɾən ətækɝz. ɹɛɾinəs ɹeɪɾieɪtəd fɹəm hɪm, ə laɪən ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə hɪz tʃɑɹdʒ. eɪvinhə hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp ɝaʊn deɪnʒɝəs mɛn, bʌt nɛvɝ wʌn tə mætʃ ənælaɪn. hæd dɛθ bɪn ə mæn, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn hɪm.

He paced at her side, a man of proper size, towering head and shoulders and more above her, the eye-wrenching cloak of a Warder hanging down his back. His face seemed hacked from stone, and his gaze weighed the threat in every servant who passed, examined every crossing corridor and wall niche for hidden attackers. Readiness radiated from him, a lion on the brink of his charge. Aviendha had grown up around dangerous men, but never one to match Aan'allein. Had death been a man, she would have been him.

"ju ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən aɪm ə wɔɹɾɝ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə dip, lɛvəl vɔɪs. "teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ə jə ɪz maɪ duɾi." hɪz toʊn sɔfənd, kənflɪktɪŋ ʃɑɹpli wɪð ɪz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs ən blik, nɛvɝ-tʃeɪnʒɪŋ aɪz. "bɪsaɪdz, kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ jə ɪz maɪ hɑɹts dɪzaɪɝ, nɪneɪiv. jə kən æsk əɹ dɪmæn ɛniθɪŋ ə mi, bʌt nɛvɝ tə lɛt jə daɪ wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə seɪv ju. ðə deɪ jə daɪ, aɪ daɪ."

"You are Aes Sedai, and I am a Warder," he said in a deep, level voice. "Taking care of you is my duty." His tone softened, conflicting sharply with his angular face and bleak, never-changing eyes. "Besides, caring for you is my heart's desire, Nynaeve. You can ask or demand anything of me, but never to let you die without trying to save you. The day you die, I die."

ðət læst i hæd nɑt sɛd bɪfɔɹ, nɑɾ ɪn eɪvinhəz hɪɹɪŋ, ən ɪt hɪt nɪneɪiv laɪk ə bloʊ tə ðə stʌmək; hɝ aɪz stɑɹɾəd hæf aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd, ən əɹ maʊθ wɝk saʊnləsli. ʃi əpɪɹd tə ɹɪkʌvɝ kwɪkli, ðoʊ, əz ɔlweɪz. pɹitɛndɪŋ tə ɹisɛɾəl əɹ blu-plum hæt, ə ɹɪdɪkjələs θɪŋ laɪk ə stʃɹeɪnʒ bɝd ɹustɪŋ ətɑp əɹ hɛd, ʃi ʃɑɾ ə ɡlæns əɾ ɪm fɹəm bɪniθ ðə waɪd bɹɪm.

That last he had not said before, not in Aviendha's hearing, and it hit Nynaeve like a blow to the stomach; her eyes started half out of her head, and her mouth worked soundlessly. She appeared to recover quickly, though, as always. Pretending to resettle her blue-plumed hat, a ridiculous thing like a strange bird roosting atop her head, she shot a glance at him from beneath the wide brim.

eɪvinhə hæd bɪɡʌn tə səspɛk ðət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɔfən juz saɪləns ən səpoʊzədli səɡnɪfɪkən lʊks tə kʌvɝ ɪɡnɝəns. ʃi səspɛktəd. nɪneɪiv nu lɪɾəl mɔɹ əbaʊt mɛn, əbaʊt dilɪŋ wɪð wʌn mæn, ðən ʃi dɪd hɝsɛlf. feɪsɪŋ əm wɪð naɪvz ən spɪɹz wɑz mʌtʃ iziɝ ðən lʌvɪŋ wʌn. mʌtʃ iziɝ. haʊ dɪd wɪmən mænədʒ biɪŋ mɛɹid tə ðɛm? eɪvinhə hæɾ ə dɛspɹɪt nid tə lɝn, ən noʊ aɪdiə haʊ. mɛɹid tə ənælaɪn oʊnli ə deɪ, nɪneɪiv hæd tʃeɪnʒd mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən sɪmpli ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ tɛmpɝ. ʃi sim tə flɪt fɹəm stɑɹɾəlmənt tə ʃɑk, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi ətɛmptəd tə haɪɾ ɪt. ʃi fɛl ɪndə dʒɹimənəs əɾ ɑd moʊməns, blʌʃt əɾ ɪnɑkjuəs kwɛstʃənz, ən - ʃi dɪnaɪd ðɪs fɪɹsli, ivən wən eɪvinhə hæd sin əɹ - ʃi ɡɪɡəld oʊvɝ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm nɪneɪiv.

Aviendha had begun to suspect that the other woman often used silence and supposedly significant looks to cover ignorance. She suspected. Nynaeve knew little more about men, about dealing with one man, than she did herself. Facing them with knives and spears was much easier than loving one. Much easier. How did women manage being married to them? Aviendha had a desperate need to learn, and no idea how. Married to Aan'allein only a day, Nynaeve had changed much more than simply in trying to control her temper. She seemed to flit from startlement to shock, however much she attempted to hide it. She fell into dreaminess at odd moments, blushed at innocuous questions, and - she denied this fiercely, even when Aviendha had seen her - she giggled over nothing at all. There was no point in trying to learn anything from Nynaeve.

"aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ gɑnə tɛl mi əbaʊt wɔɹɾɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛn, əz wɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd kuli tə bɝdʒɪt. "wɛl, jə ən aɪ ɑɹən mɛɹid. aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə ɡɑɹd maɪ bæk, bʌɾ əl nɑɾ əv jə meɪkɪŋ pɹɑməsəz əbaʊt mi bɪhaɪn ɪt." ɪleɪn wɔɹ ɡɑɹməns əz ɪnəpɹoʊpɹiɪɾ əz nɪneɪivz, ə ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɛbu dɑɹi ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹin sɪlk, suɾəbli haɪ-nɛk bʌt wɪð ən oʊvəl oʊpənɪŋ ðət bɛɹd ði ɪnɝ sloʊps ə hɝ bɹɛsts. wɛtləndɝz spləɾɝd ət ðə mɛnʃən ʌv ə swɛt tɛn əɹ biɪŋ ənkloʊðd ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn, ðən wɔkt əbaʊt hæf-ɪkspoʊzd wɛɹ ɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝ kəd si. eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt ɹɪli maɪn fəɹ nɪneɪiv, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ. ən wəd bi mɔɹ, ʃi hoʊpt.

"I suppose you're going to tell me about Warders and Aes Sedai again, as well," Elayne said coolly to Birgitte. "Well, you and I aren't married. I expect you to guard my back, but I will not have you making promises about me behind it." Elayne wore garments as inappropriate as Nynaeve's, a gold-embroidered Ebou Dari riding dress of green silk, suitably high-necked but with an oval opening that bared the inner slopes of her breasts. Wetlanders spluttered at the mention of a sweat tent or being unclothed in front of gai'shain, then walked about half-exposed where any stranger could see. Aviendha did not really mind for Nynaeve, but Elayne was her near-sister. And would be more, she hoped.

ðə ɹeɪz hilz ə bɝdʒɪts buts meɪɾ əɹ ɔlmoʊst ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən nɪneɪiv, ɪf stɪl ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɪleɪn əɹ eɪvinhə. ɪn dɑɹk blu koʊɾ ən waɪd ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz, ʃi kæɹid hɝsɛlf wɪð mʌtʃ ə ðə seɪm wɛɹəli kɑnfəɾənt ɹɛɾinəs əz læn, ðoʊ ɪt simd mɔɹ kæʒəwəl ɪn hɝ. ə lɛpɝd laɪɪŋ ɑn ə ɹɑk, ən nɑt nɪɹli soʊ leɪzi əz ʃi əpɪɹd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ æɹoʊ nɑkt ɪn ðə baʊ bɝdʒɪt kæɹid, bʌt fəɹ ɔl əɹ stʃɹoʊl ən smaɪlz, ʃi kəɾ əv ə ʃæft aʊɾ ə ðə kwɪvɝ əɾ əɹ weɪs bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəd blɪŋk, ən bi lusɪŋ əɹ θɝd bɪfɔɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls cʊɾə fɪɾəd ə sɛkən tə bɑstʃɹɪŋ.

The raised heels of Birgitte's boots made her almost a hand taller than Nynaeve, if still shorter than Elayne or Aviendha. In dark blue coat and wide green trousers, she carried herself with much of the same warily confident readiness as Lan, though it seemed more casual in her. A leopard lying on a rock, and not nearly so lazy as she appeared. There was no arrow nocked in the bow Birgitte carried, but for all her stroll and smiles, she could have a shaft out of the quiver at her waist before anyone could blink, and be loosing her third before anybody else could have fitted a second to bowstring.

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə ɹaɪ ɡɹɪn ən ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd ðət swʌŋ ə ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ əz lɔŋ ən θɪk əz nɪneɪivz dɑɹk wʌn. "aɪ pɹɑməs tə jəɹ feɪs, nɑt bɪhaɪn jəɹ bæk," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "wɛn juv lɝn ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, aɪ woʊn əv tə tɛl jə əbaʊt wɔɹɾɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɪleɪn snɪft ən lɪftəɾ əɹ tʃɪn hɔɾəli, bʌsiɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð ðə ɹɪbənz ə hɝ hæt, wɪtʃ wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð lɔŋ ɡɹin plumz ən wɝs ðən nɪneɪivz. "pɝhæps ə ɡɹeɪt dil mɔɹ," bɝdʒɪɾ æɾəd. "jɔɹ taɪɪŋ ənʌðɝ nɑɾ ɪn ðət baʊ."

She gave Elayne a wry grin and a shake of her head that swung a golden braid as long and thick as Nynaeve's dark one. "I promised to your face, not behind your back," she said dryly. "When you've learned a little more, I won't have to tell you about Warders and Aes Sedai." Elayne sniffed and lifted her chin haughtily, busying herself with the ribbons of her hat, which was covered with long green plumes and worse than Nynaeve's. "Perhaps a great deal more," Birgitte added. "You're tying another knot in that bow."

hæɾ ɪleɪn nɑt bɪn əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ, eɪvinhə wʊɾə læft ət ðə kɹɪmzən ðət flʌɾəd əɹ tʃiks. tʃɹɪpɪŋ sʌmwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə wɔk tu haɪ wɑz ɔlweɪz fʌn, əɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪt dʌn, ən ivən ə ʃɔɹt fɔl wɑz wɝθ ə læf. əz ɪt wɑz, ʃi lɛvəld ə fɝm stɛɹ ət bɝdʒɪt, ə pɹɑməs ðət mɔɹ maɪt bɹɪŋ ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən. ʃi laɪk ðə wʊmən dɪspaɪɾ ɔl əɹ sikɹəts, bʌt ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ə fɹɛn ən ə nɪɹ-sɪstɝ wɑz ə θɪŋ ðiz wɛtləndɝz simd əneɪbəl tə kɑmpɹihɛnd. bɝdʒɪɾ oʊnli smaɪld, ɡlænsɪŋ fɹəm əɹ tə ɪleɪn, ən mɝmɝɾ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. eɪvinhə kɑt ðə wɝd "kɪɾənz." wɝs, ɪt saʊndəd fɑnd. ɛvɹiwʌn mʌst əv hɝd. ɛvɹiwʌn!

Had Elayne not been her near-sister, Aviendha would have laughed at the crimson that flooded her cheeks. Tripping someone who tried to walk too high was always fun, or watching it done, and even a short fall was worth a laugh. As it was, she leveled a firm stare at Birgitte, a promise that more might bring retribution. She liked the woman despite all her secrets, but the difference between a friend and a near-sister was a thing these wetlanders seemed unable to comprehend. Birgitte only smiled, glancing from her to Elayne, and murmured under her breath. Aviendha caught the word "kittens." Worse, it sounded fond. Everyone must have heard. Everyone!

"wʌts ɡɑɾən ɪndə ju, eɪvinhə?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd, pɹɑɾɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə stɪf fɪŋɡɝ. "du jə ɪntɛn tə stæn ðəɹ blʌʃɪŋ ɔl deɪ? wəɹ ɪn ə hɝi."

"What's gotten into you, Aviendha?" Nynaeve demanded, prodding her shoulder with a stiff finger. "Do you intend to stand there blushing all day? We are in a hurry."

oʊnli ðən dɪɾ eɪvinhə ɹilaɪz baɪ ðə hiɾ ɪn əɹ feɪs ðət ʃi mʌs bi əz ɹɛɾ əz ɪleɪn. ən stændɪŋ stɪl əz stoʊn bɪsaɪdz, wən ðeɪ hæd nid fəɹ heɪst. kʌt baɪ ə wɝd, laɪk ə ɡɝl nuli wɛɾəd tə ðə spɪɹ ən ənjuz tə ðə bæntɝ əmʌŋ meɪɾənz. ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs twɛnti jɪɹz, ən ʃi wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə tʃaɪl pleɪɪŋ wɪð əɹ fɝs baʊ. ðəɾ æɾəd fleɪmz tə hɝ tʃiks. wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ ʃi ɔl bʌt lɛpt ɝaʊn ðə nɛks tɝnɪŋ ən vɛɹi nɪɹli ɹæn hɛdlɔŋ ɪndə tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn.

Only then did Aviendha realize by the heat in her face that she must be as red as Elayne. And standing still as stone besides, when they had need for haste. Cut by a word, like a girl newly wedded to the spear and unused to the banter among Maidens. She had almost twenty years, and she was behaving like a child playing with her first bow. That added flames to her cheeks. Which was why she all but leaped around the next turning and very nearly ran headlong into Teslyn Baradon.

skɪɾɪŋ ɔkwɝdli ɑn ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin flɔɹ taɪlz, eɪvinhə hæf-fɛl bækwɝd, kætʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɡɛnst ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv. ðɪs taɪm ʃi mænədʒ nɑt tə blʌʃ hɝsɛlf tə faɪɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə. ʃi wɑz ʃeɪmɪŋ əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ əz mʌtʃ əz hɝsɛlf. ɪleɪn ɔlweɪz hɛld əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. lʌkəli, tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn tʊk ði ɪnkaʊntɝ lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ.

Skidding awkwardly on red-and-green floor tiles, Aviendha half-fell backward, catching herself against Elayne and Nynaeve. This time she managed not to blush herself to fire, but she wanted to. She was shaming her near-sister as much as herself. Elayne always held her composure, no matter what. Luckily, Teslyn Baradon took the encounter little better.

ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən ɹikɔɪld ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ɡeɪpɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp hɝsɛlf, ðən ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ nɛɹoʊ ʃoʊldɝz ɪɹɪɾəbli. ɡɔn tʃiks ən ə nɛɹoʊ noʊz hɪd ði eɪdʒləs kwɑləɾi ʌv ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝz fitʃɝz, ən əɹ ɹɛd dʒɹɛs, bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɪn ə blu ðət wɑz nɪɹli blæk, oʊnli meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ boʊniɝ, jɛt ʃi kwɪkli ɡæðɝɾ ə klæn ɹufməstʃɹəsəz sɛlf-pəzɛʃən, dɑɹk bɹaʊn aɪz əz kul əz dip ʃædoʊz. ðeɪ slɪd pæst eɪvinhə dɪsmɪsɪvli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ læn laɪk ə tul ʃi hæd noʊ jus fɔɹ, bɝn ə bɹif moʊmən ət bɝdʒɪt. moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪsəpɹuvd ə bɝdʒɪt biɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ, ðoʊ nʌn kəd ɡɪv ə ɹizən bɪɑn saʊɝ mʌɾɝz əbaʊt tʃɹədɪʃən. ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, haʊɛvɝ, ðə wʊmən fɪks baɪ tɝnz. eɪvinhə cʊɾə tʃɹæk jɛstɝdeɪz wɪn bɪfɔɹ ɹiɾɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ɑn tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑnz feɪs naʊ.

The sharp-faced woman recoiled in surprise, gaping before she could stop herself, then shifting her narrow shoulders irritably. Gaunt cheeks and a narrow nose hid the ageless quality of the Red sister's features, and her red dress, brocaded in a blue that was nearly black, only made her appear bonier, yet she quickly gathered a clan roofmistress's self-possession, dark brown eyes as cool as deep shadows. They slid past Aviendha dismissively, ignoring Lan like a tool she had no use for, burned a brief moment at Birgitte. Most Aes Sedai disapproved of Birgitte being a Warder, though none could give a reason beyond sour mutters about tradition. Elayne and Nynaeve, however, the woman fixed by turns. Aviendha could have tracked yesterday's wind before reading anything on Teslyn Baradon's face now.

"aɪ dɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tɛl mɛɝɪlɪl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə θɪk ɪliɑnɝ æksɛnt, "bʌɾ aɪ meɪ əz wɛl pʊt jəɹ maɪnz ət ɹɛst, ɔlsoʊ. wʌtɛvɝ . . . mɪstʃəf . . . jə də bi əbaʊt, dʒoʊlin ən əl noʊ ɪntɝfɪɹ. aɪ dɪd si tə ðæt. ɪleɪɾə meɪ nɛvɝ lɝn ʌv ɪt, ɪf jə də hæv səm kɛɹ. stɑp ɡeɪpɪŋ ət mi laɪk kɑɹp, tʃɪlʒɹən," ʃi æɾəd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs ə dɪsteɪst. "aɪ bi niðɝ blaɪnd nɔɹ dɛf. aɪ də noʊ ʌv si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝz ɪn ðə pæləs, ən sikɹət miɾɪŋz wɪð kwin taɪlɪn. ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz." ðət θɪn maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ðoʊ hɝ toʊn ɹɪmeɪn sɝin, hɝ dɑɹk ɡeɪz flɛɹd wɪð æŋɡɝ. "ju wɪl peɪ dɪɹli jɛt fəɹ ðoʊz ʌðɝ θɪŋz, jə ən ðoʊz u də əlaʊ jə tə pleɪ ət biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ əl lʊk əsaɪd fəɹ naʊ. ətoʊnmən kən weɪt."

"I did already tell Merilille," she said in a thick Illianer accent, "but I may as well put your minds at rest, also. Whatever . . . mischief . . . you do be about, Joline and I will no interfere. I did see to that. Elaida may never learn of it, if you do have some care. Stop gaping at me like carp, children," she added with a grimace of distaste. "I be neither blind nor deaf. I do know of Sea Folk Windfinders in the palace, and secret meetings with Queen Tylin. And other things." That thin mouth tightened, and though her tone remained serene, her dark gaze flared with anger. "You will pay dearly yet for those other things, you and those who do allow you to play at being Aes Sedai, but I will look aside for now. Atonement can wait."

nɪneɪiv tʊk ə taɪt ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ bɹeɪd, bæk stʃɹeɪt, hɛd haɪ, ən əɹ oʊn aɪz bleɪzd. ʌndɝ dɪfɹən sɝkəmstænsəz eɪvinhə maɪɾ əv faʊn səm sɪmpəθi fəɹ ðə tɑɹɡəɾ ə ðə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ pleɪnli əbaʊt tə ɪɹʌpt. nɪneɪivz tʌŋ kæɹid mɔɹ spaɪnz ðən ə hɛɹ-niɾəl sɛɡeɪd, ən ʃɑɹpɝ wʌnz. koʊldli, eɪvinhə kənsɪɾɝd ðɪs wʊmən u θɔt ʃi kəd lʊk ɹaɪt θɹu hɝ. eɪ waɪz wʌn dɪd nɑt stup tə θɹæʃɪŋ sʌmwʌn wɪð əɹ fɪsts, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl oʊnli ən əpɹɛntəs; pɝhæps ɪt wəd nɑt kɑst əɹ dʒi ɪf ʃi dʒʌs bɹuz ðɪs tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn ə lɪɾəl. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɡɪv ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ ə tʃæns tə dɪfɛn hɝsɛlf ət ðə seɪm ɪnstənt nɪneɪiv oʊpən hɝz, jɛɾ ɪleɪn spoʊk fɝst.

Nynaeve took a tight grip on her braid, back straight, head high, and her own eyes blazed. Under different circumstances Aviendha might have found some sympathy for the target of the tongue-lashing plainly about to erupt. Nynaeve's tongue carried more spines than a hair-needle segade, and sharper ones. Coldly, Aviendha considered this woman who thought she could look right through her. A Wise One did not stoop to thrashing someone with her fists, but she was still only an apprentice; perhaps it would not cost her ji if she just bruised this Teslyn Baradon a little. She opened her mouth to give the Red sister a chance to defend herself at the same instant Nynaeve opened hers, yet Elayne spoke first.

"wʌt wəɹ əbaʊt, tɛslɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə tʃɪl vɔɪs, "ɪz nʌn ə jəɹ bɪznəs." ʃi, tu, stʊd stʃɹeɪt, hɝ aɪz blu aɪs; ə tʃæns ɹeɪ ʌv laɪt fɹəm ə haɪ wɪndoʊ kɑɾ əɹ ɡoʊldən-ɹɛd kɝlz, simɪŋ tə sɛɾ əm əfaɪɹ. ɹaɪt ðɛn, ɪleɪn cʊɾə meɪɾ ə ɹuf-mɪstʃɹəs sim ə ɡoʊðɝd wɪð tu mʌtʃ uskaɪ ɪn əɹ bɛli. ɪt wɑz ə skɪl ʃi hoʊnd wɛl. ʃi dɪlɪvɝɾ itʃ wɝd wɪð koʊl kɹɪstəl dɪɡnəɾi. "ju hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə ɪntɝfɪɹ ɪn ɛniθɪŋ wi du, ɪn ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ ɛni sɪstɝ dʌz. noʊ ɹaɪt wʌtsoʊɛvɝ. soʊ pʊl jəɹ noʊz aʊɾ ʌv əɹ koʊts, jə sʌmɝ hæm, ən bi ɡlæd wi də nɑt tʃuz tə teɪk ɪʃu wɪð jə səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə jusɝpɝ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"What we are about, Teslyn," she said in a chill voice, "is none of your business."
