She, too, stood straight, her eyes blue ice; a chance ray of light from a high window caught her golden-red curls, seeming to set them afire. Right then, Elayne could have made a roof-mistress seem a goatherd with too much oosquai in her belly. It was a skill she honed well. She delivered each word with cold crystal dignity. "You have no right to interfere in anything we do, in anything that any sister does. No right whatsoever. So pull your nose out of our coats, you summer ham, and be glad we do not choose to take issue with you supporting a usurper on the Amyrlin Seat."

pɝplɛkst, eɪvinhə ɡlænst saɪdweɪz əɾ əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ. pʊl əɹ noʊz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ koʊts? ʃi ən ɪleɪn, ət list, wɝ nɑt wɛɹɪŋ koʊts. ə sʌmɝ hæm? wʌd ðət min? wɛtləndɝz ɔfən sɛd pəkjuljɝ θɪŋz, bʌt ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɔl lʊkt əz pʌzəld əz ʃi. oʊnli læn, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn əskæns, əpɪɹd tə ʌndɝstænd, ən i simd . . . stɑɹɾəld. ən pɝhæps əmjuzd. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl; ənælaɪn kəntʃɹoʊld ɪz fitʃɝz wɛl.

Perplexed, Aviendha glanced sideways at her near-sister. Pull her nose out of their coats? She and Elayne, at least, were not wearing coats. A summer ham? What did that mean? Wetlanders often said peculiar things, but the other women all looked as puzzled as she. Only Lan, staring at Elayne askance, appeared to understand, and he seemed . . . startled. And perhaps amused. It was difficult to tell; Aan'allein controlled his features well.

tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn snɪft, pɪntʃɪŋ əɹ feɪs ivən taɪɾɝ. eɪvinhə wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd tə kɔl ðiz pipəl baɪ oʊnli pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ neɪmz ðə weɪ ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz dɪd - wən ʃi juzd ə hoʊl neɪm, ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz əpsɛt! - bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən biɪŋ soʊ ɪntəmət wɪð tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn. "aɪ wɪl liv jə fulɪʃ tʃɪlʒɹən tə jəɹ bɪznəs," ðə wʊmən ɡɹaʊld. "bi ʃʊɹ jə də noʊ ɡɛt jəɹ noʊzɪz kɑɾ ɪn ə wɝs kɹæk ðən ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi də bi."

Teslyn Baradon sniffed, pinching her face even tighter. Aviendha was trying hard to call these people by only part of their names the way they themselves did - when she used a whole name, they thought she was upset! - but she could not begin to imagine being so intimate with Teslyn Baradon. "I will leave you foolish children to your business," the woman growled. "Be sure you do no get your noses caught in a worse crack than they already do be."

əz ʃi tɝn tə ɡoʊ, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɡɹænli, nɪneɪiv kɑɾ əɹ ɑɹm. wɛtləndɝz juʒəwəli lɛɾ ɪmoʊʃən ɡɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən nɪneɪivz wɑz ði ɪmədʒ ə kɑnflɪkt, æŋɡɝ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə bɹeɪk θɹu fɪks dɪtɝməneɪʃən. "weɪt, tɛslɪn," ʃi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "ju ən dʒoʊlin meɪ bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ. aɪ toʊl taɪlɪn, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃi meɪ bi əfɹeɪd tə tɛl ɛniwʌn ɛls. ənwɪlɪŋ, ɛniweɪ. ɪts nʌθɪŋ ɛnibəɾi ɹɪli wɑns tə tɔk əbaʊt." ʃi dʒɹu ə lɔŋ, dip bɹɛθ, ən ɪf ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ oʊn fɪɹz ɪn ðə mæɾɝ, ʃi hæd kɑz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn filɪŋ fɪɹ, oʊnli ɪn ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə ɪt, əɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɪt ʃoʊ. eɪvinhə fɛlt ə flʌɾɝ ɪn əɹ oʊn bɛli əz nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn. "mɑɡiɾin əz bɪn hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ʃi maɪt stɪl bi. ən meɪbi ənʌðɝ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, tu. wɪð ə ɡoʊləm, ə kaɪndə ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ðə paʊɝ woʊn tʌtʃ. ɪt lʊks laɪk ə mæn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz meɪd, ən meɪd tə kɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ. stil dʌzn sim tə hɝɾ ɪɾ iðɝ, ən ɪt kən skwiz θɹu ə maʊshoʊl. ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪz hɪɹ, əz wɛl. ən ðɛɹz ə stɔɹm kʌmɪŋ, ə bæd stɔɹm. oʊnli ɪɾ ɪzən ə stɔɹm, nɑt wɛðɝ. aɪ kən fil ɪt; ðæts ə skɪl aɪ hæv, ə tælənt, meɪbi. ðɛɹz deɪnʒɝ hɛɾəd fəɹ ɛbu dɑɹ, ən tʃɹʌbəl wɝs ðən ɛni wɪn əɹ ɹeɪn əɹ laɪtnɪŋ."

As she turned to go, gathering her skirts grandly, Nynaeve caught her arm. Wetlanders usually let emotion gild their faces, and Nynaeve's was the image of conflict, anger struggling to break through fixed determination. "Wait, Teslyn," she said reluctantly. "You and Joline may be in danger. I told Tylin, but I think she may be afraid to tell anyone else. Unwilling, anyway. It's nothing anybody really wants to talk about." She drew a long, deep breath, and if she was thinking of her own fears in the matter, she had cause. There was no shame in feeling fear, only in giving way to it, or letting it show. Aviendha felt a flutter in her own belly as Nynaeve went on. "Moghedien has been here in Ebou Dar. She might still be. And maybe another of the Forsaken, too. With a gholam, a kind of Shadowspawn the Power won't touch. It looks like a man, but it was made, and made to kill Aes Sedai. Steel doesn't seem to hurt it either, and it can squeeze through a mousehole. The Black Ajah is here, as well. And there's a storm coming, a bad storm. Only it isn't a storm, not weather. I can feel it; that's a skill I have, a Talent, maybe. There's danger headed for Ebou Dar, and trouble worse than any wind or rain or lightning."

"ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ə stɔɹm ðəɾ ɪz noʊ ə stɔɹm, ən səm ʃæɾoʊzpɔn aɪ dɪd nɛvɝ hɪɹ ə bɪfɔɹ," tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn sɛd ɹaɪli. "nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə blæk ədʒɑ. laɪt! ðə blæk ədʒɑ! ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf, pɝhæps?" hɝ twɪstəd smaɪl wɑz ɹeɪzɝ θɪn. ʃi plʌk nɪneɪivz hæn fɹəm əɹ sliv kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "wɛn jə də bi bæk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɛɹ jə bɪlɔŋ, ɪn waɪɾ əz jə ɔl tʃɹuli bɪlɔŋ, jəl lɝn noʊ tə weɪs jəɹ aʊɝz wɪð waɪl fænsiz. əɹ tə kæɹi jəɹ teɪlz tə sɪstɝz." ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ aɪz oʊvɝ ðɛm, ən wʌns mɔɹ skɪpɪŋ pæst eɪvinhə, ʃi ɡeɪv ə laʊd snɪf ən mɑɹtʃt ɔf daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ soʊ kwɪkli ðət sɝvəns hæd tə lip fɹəm əɹ pæθ.

"The Forsaken, a storm that is no a storm, and some Shadowspawn I did never hear of before," Teslyn Baradon said wryly. "Not to mention the Black Ajah. Light! The Black Ajah! And the Dark One himself, perhaps?" Her twisted smile was razor thin. She plucked Nynaeve's hand from her sleeve contemptuously. "When you do be back in the White Tower where you belong, in white as you all truly belong, you will learn no to waste your hours with wild fancies. Or to carry your tales to sisters." Running her eyes over them, and once more skipping past Aviendha, she gave a loud sniff and marched off down the hallway so quickly that servants had to leap from her path.

"ðæt wʊmən əz ðə nɝv tə . . . !" nɪneɪiv spləɾɝd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ æftɝ ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ wʊmən ən stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd wɪð boʊθ hænz. "æftɝ aɪ meɪd maɪsɛlf . . . !" ʃi ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt ɑn əɹ splin. "wɛl, aɪ tʃɹaɪd." ən naʊ ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ði ətɛmpt, baɪ ðə saʊnd.

"That woman has the nerve to . . . !" Nynaeve spluttered, glaring after the retreating woman and strangling her braid with both hands. "After I made myself . . . !" She almost choked on her spleen. "Well, I tried." And now regretted the attempt, by the sound.

"ju dɪd," ɪleɪn əɡɹid wɪð ə ʃɑɹp nɑd, "æn mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪzɝvz. dɪnaɪɪŋ ðət wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ! aɪ woʊn pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðəɾ ɛnimɔɹ! aɪ woʊnt!" hɝ vɔɪs hæɾ oʊnli sim koʊl bɪfɔɹ; naʊ ɪt wɑz koʊld, ən ɡɹɪm.

"You did," Elayne agreed with a sharp nod, "and more than she deserves. Denying that we're Aes Sedai! I won't put up with that anymore! I won't!" Her voice had only seemed cold before; now it was cold, and grim.

"kæn wʌn laɪk ðət bi tʃɹʌstɪd?" eɪvinhə mʌɾɝd. "meɪbi wi ʃəd bi ʃʊɹ ʃi kænɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ." ʃi ɪɡzæmən əɹ fɪst; tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn wəd si ðæt. ðə wʊmən dɪzɝv tə bi kɑt baɪ ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld, baɪ mɑɡiɾin əɹ ənʌðɝ. fulz dɪzɝvd wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ fulɪʃnəs bɹɔt.

"Can one like that be trusted?" Aviendha muttered. "Maybe we should be sure she cannot interfere." She examined her fist; Teslyn Baradon would see that. The woman deserved to be caught by the Shadowsouled, by Moghedien or another. Fools deserved whatever their foolishness brought.

nɪneɪiv əpɪɹd tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə sədʒɛstʃən, bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛd wɑz "ɪf aɪ dɪdnt noʊ bɛɾɝ, aɪd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə tɝn ɑn ɪleɪɾə." ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

Nynaeve appeared to consider the suggestion, but what she said was "If I didn't know better, I'd think she was ready to turn on Elaida." She clicked her tongue in exasperation.

"ju kən dɪzi jɝsɛlf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹid ðə kɝəns ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑlətɪks." ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt seɪ nɪneɪiv ʃəd noʊ ðət baɪ naʊ, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn dɪd. "ivən ə ɹɛd maɪt bi tɝnɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə, fəɹ səm ɹizən wi kæn bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən. əɹ ʃi kəd bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əs loʊɝ əɹ ɡɑɹd, soʊ ʃi kən sʌmhaʊ tʃɹɪk əs ɪndə pʊɾɪŋ aʊɝsɛlvz ɪndə ɪleɪɾəz hænz. əɹ - "

"You can dizzy yourself trying to read the currents in Aes Sedai politics." Elayne did not say Nynaeve should know that by now, but her tone did. "Even a Red might be turning against Elaida, for some reason we can't begin to imagine. Or she could be trying to make us lower our guard, so she can somehow trick us into putting ourselves into Elaida's hands. Or - "

læn kɔft. "ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk pɑlɪʃt stoʊn, "ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ ɛni moʊmənt. əɹ ðət ɡoʊləm kʊd. ɪn iðɝ keɪs, ɪt wəd bi bɛs tə bi ɛlswɛɹ."

Lan coughed. "If any of the Forsaken are coming," he said in a voice like polished stone, "they could be here any moment. Or that gholam could. In either case, it would be best to be elsewhere."

"wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔlweɪz ə lɪɾəl peɪʃəns," bɝdʒɪt mɝmɝɾ əz ðoʊ kwoʊɾɪŋ. "bʌt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz doʊn sim tə hæv ɛni," ʃi kəntɪnjud, "soʊ jə maɪt də wɛl tə fɝɡɛt tɛslɪn ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɹɪneɪl."

"With Aes Sedai, always a little patience," Birgitte murmured as though quoting. "But the Windfinders don't seem to have any," she continued, "so you might do well to forget Teslyn and remember Renaile."

ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv tɝn stɛɹz ɑn ðə wɔɹɾɝz koʊld ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv tɛn stoʊn dɑɡz pɔz. niðɝ laɪkt ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld ən ðɪs ɡoʊləm, fəɹ ɔl ðeɪ wɝ ðə wʌnz u hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɔɪs. sɝɾənli niðɝ laɪk biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəd ðət ðeɪ niɾəd tə ɹʌn tə mit ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz tə ɪskeɪp ðə fɔɹseɪkən. eɪvinhə wʊɾə stʌɾid ðoʊz lʊks - waɪz wʌnz dɪd wɪð ə ɡlæns əɹ ə fju wɝdz wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz niɾəd ðə θɹɛɾ ə spɪɹ əɹ fɪs fɔɹ, oʊnli ðeɪ juʒəwəli dɪɾ ɪt fæstɝ ən wɪð mɔɹ səksɛs - ʃi wʊɾə stʌɾid ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, ɪksɛp ðət ðɛɹ ɡlɛɹz hæd noʊ vɪzəbəl ɪfɛkt ɑn ðə pɛɹ əɾ ɔl. bɝdʒɪt ɡɹɪn ən kʌɾ əɹ aɪz təwɔɹd læn, hu ʃɹʌɡd bæk əɾ əɹ wɪð ɑbviəs fɔɹbɛɹəns.

Elayne and Nynaeve turned stares on the Warders cold enough to give ten Stone Dogs pause. Neither liked running from the Shadowsouled and this gholam, for all they were the ones who had decided there was no choice. Certainly neither liked being reminded that they needed to run to meet the Windfinders almost as much as to escape the Forsaken. Aviendha would have studied those looks - Wise Ones did with a glance or a few words what she had always needed the threat of spear or fist for, only they usually did it faster and with more success - she would have studied Elayne and Nynaeve, except that their glares had no visible effect on the pair at all. Birgitte grinned and cut her eyes toward Lan, who shrugged back at her with obvious forbearance.

ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv oʊvɝ. ənhɝidli, ən ənnɛsəsɛɹəli, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ðɛɹ skɝts, ðeɪ itʃ tʊk wʌn ʌv eɪvinhəz ɑɹmz bɪfɔɹ sɛɾɪŋ ɔf əɡɛn wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns tə si ðət ðə wɔɹɾɝz fɑloʊd. nɑt ðəɾ ɪleɪn niɾəd tə, wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd. əɹ nɪneɪiv, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən; ənælaɪnz bɑn maɪt bɪlɔŋ tə ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪz hɑɹt hʌŋ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪz ɹɪŋ ɑn ðət tʃeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ðeɪ meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv stʃɹoʊlɪŋ kæʒəwəli, ənwɪlɪŋ tə lɛt bɝdʒɪɾ ən læn θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd bɪn bɹɔt tə hɝi, jɛt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, ðeɪ dɪd wɔk fæstɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ.

Elayne and Nynaeve gave over. Unhurriedly, and unnecessarily, straightening their skirts, they each took one of Aviendha's arms before setting off again without so much as a glance to see that the Warders followed. Not that Elayne needed to, with the Warder bond. Or Nynaeve, if not for the same reason; Aan'allein's bond might belong to another, but his heart hung alongside his ring on that chain around her neck. They made a great show of strolling casually, unwilling to let Birgitte and Lan think they had been brought to hurry, yet the truth was, they did walk faster than before.

əz ɪf tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ðæt, ðeɪ tʃæɾəd wɪð dɪlɪbɝɪɾ aɪɾəlnəs, tʃuzɪŋ ðə moʊs fɹɪvələs sʌbʒɪkts. ɪleɪn ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd nɑt hævɪŋ ə tʃæns tə tʃɹuli si ðə fɛstəvəl ə bɝdz, dʒʌs jɛstɝdeɪ, ən nɛvɝ ɡeɪv ə blʌʃ fəɹ ðə skænt ɡɑɹməns mɛni pipəl hæd wɔɹn. nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt blʌʃ iðɝ, bʌt ʃi kwɪkli bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə fist ʌv ɛmbɝz, tə bi hɛl ðət naɪt. səm ə ðə sɝvəns kleɪm ðəɹ wəd bi faɪɹwɝks, səpoʊzədli meɪd baɪ ə ɹɛfjʊdʒi ɪluməneɪɾɝ. sɛvɹəl tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊz hæd kʌm tə ðə sɪɾi wɪð ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ ænəməlz ən ækɹəbæts, wɪtʃ ɪntʃɹəstəd boʊθ ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, sɪns ðeɪ hæd spɛn səm taɪm wɪð sətʃ ə ʃoʊ. ðeɪ tɔkt ə simstʃɹəsəz, ən ðə vɝaɪəɾiz ə leɪs əveɪləbəl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ðə dɪfɹən kwɑləɾiz ə sɪlk ən lɪnən ðət kəd bi bɑt, ən eɪvinhə faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹɪspɑndɪŋ wɪð plɛʒɝ tə kɑmɛns ɑn haʊ wɛl əɹ ɡɹeɪ sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs lʊkt ɑn hɝ, ən ði ʌðɝ ɡɑɹməns ɡɪvən tə hɝ baɪ taɪlɪn kwɪntɑɹə, faɪn wʊlənz ən sɪlks, ən ðə stɑkɪŋz ən ʃɪfs tə ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm, ən dʒuəlɹi. ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɔlsoʊ hæd ɹəsivd ɪkstʃɹævəɡənt ɡɪfs. ɔl təɡɛðɝ ðɛɹ pɹizɛns fɪld ə nʌmbɝ ə tʃɛsts ən bʌndəlz ðət hæd bɪn kæɹid daʊn tə ðə steɪbəlz baɪ sɝvəns, əlɔŋ wɪð ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz.

As if to make up for that, they chatted with deliberate idleness, choosing the most frivolous subjects. Elayne regretted not having a chance to truly see the Festival of Birds, just yesterday, and never gave a blush for the scant garments many people had worn. Nynaeve did not blush either, but she quickly began talking about the Feast of Embers, to be held that night. Some of the servants claimed there would be fireworks, supposedly made by a refugee Illuminator. Several traveling shows had come to the city with their strange animals and acrobats, which interested both Elayne and Nynaeve, since they had spent some time with such a show. They talked of seamstresses, and the varieties of lace available in Ebou Dar, and the different qualities of silk and linen that could be bought, and Aviendha found herself responding with pleasure to comments on how well her gray silk riding dress looked on her, and the other garments given to her by Tylin Quintara, fine woolens and silks, and the stockings and shifts to go with them, and jewelry. Elayne and Nynaeve also had received extravagant gifts. All together their presents filled a number of chests and bundles that had been carried down to the stables by servants, along with their saddlebags.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə skaʊlɪŋ, eɪvinhə?" ɪleɪn æskt, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə pæɾ ɑn ði ɑɹm ən ə smaɪl. "doʊnt wɝi. jə noʊ ðə wiv; jəl də dʒʌs faɪn."

"Why are you scowling, Aviendha?" Elayne asked, giving her a pat on the arm and a smile. "Don't worry. You know the weave; you will do just fine."

nɪneɪiv lin əɹ hɛd kloʊs ən wɪspɝd, "aɪl fɪks jə ə ti wən aɪ hæv ə tʃæns. aɪ noʊ sɛvɹəl ðət wɪl suð jəɹ stʌmək. əɹ ɛni wʊmənz tʃɹʌbəlz." ʃi pæɾəd eɪvinhəz ɑɹm, tu.

Nynaeve leaned her head close and whispered, "I'll fix you a tea when I have a chance. I know several that will soothe your stomach. Or any woman's troubles." She patted Aviendha's arm, too.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. noʊ kʌmfɝɾɪŋ wɝdz əɹ tiz wəd kjʊɹ wʌɾ eɪl hɝ. ʃi wɑz ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ tɔk ə leɪs ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi! ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə ɡɹaʊl ɪn dɪsɡʌst əɹ weɪl ɪn dɪspɛɹ. ʃi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɑft. nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ ɪn əɹ laɪf hæd ʃi lʊkt əɾ ə wʊmənz dʒɹɛs ɪksɛp tə θɪŋk wɛɹ ɪt maɪt bi haɪɾɪŋ ə wɛpən, nɛvɝ tə noʊɾəs ðə kʌlɝ ən kʌt, əɹ θɪŋk haʊ ɪt wəd lʊk ɑn hɝ. ɪt wɑz pæs taɪm tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs sɪɾi, əweɪ fɹəm wɛtləndɝ pæləsəz. sun ʃi wəd stɑɹt sɪmpɝɪŋ. ʃi hæd nɑt sin ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv də ðæt, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn nu wɛtləndɝ wɪmən sɪmpɝd, ən ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ʃi hæd bɪkʌm əz wik əz ɛni mɪlk-wɔɾɝ wɛtləndɝ. stʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɑɹm-ɪn-ɑɹm, tʃæɾɪŋ əbaʊt leɪs! haʊ wɑz ʃi tə ɹitʃ əɹ bɛl naɪf ɪf sʌmwʌn ətæk ðɛm? ə naɪf maɪt bi jusləs əɡɛns ðə laɪkliəst əseɪləns, bʌt ʃi hæd hæd feɪθ ɪn stil lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu ʃi kəd tʃænəl. ʃəɾ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪ tə hɑɹm ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv - ɪspɛʃli ɪleɪn, bʌt ʃi hæd pɹɑməs mæt kɔθən tə pɹətɛkt əm boʊθ əz ʃʊɹli əz bɝdʒɪɾ ən ənælaɪn hæd - ʃəɾ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪ, ʃi wəd plæn stil ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹts. leɪs! əz ðeɪ wɔkt, ʃi wɛpt ɪnsaɪɾ ət haʊ sɑft ʃi hæd bɪkʌm.

They did not understand. No comforting words or teas would cure what ailed her. She was enjoying talk of lace and embroidery! She did not know whether to growl in disgust or wail in despair. She was growing soft. Never before in her life had she looked at a woman's dress except to think where it might be hiding a weapon, never to notice the color and cut, or think how it would look on her. It was past time to be away from this city, away from wetlander palaces. Soon she would start simpering. She had not seen Elayne or Nynaeve do that, but everyone knew wetlander women simpered, and it was obvious she had become as weak as any milk-water wetlander. Strolling arm-in-arm, chatting about lace! How was she to reach her belt knife if someone attacked them? A knife might be useless against the likeliest assailants, but she had had faith in steel long before she knew she could channel. Should anyone try to harm Elayne or Nynaeve - especially Elayne, but she had promised Mat Cauthon to protect them both as surely as Birgitte and Aan'allein had - should anyone try, she would plant steel in their hearts. Lace! As they walked, she wept inside at how soft she had become.

hjudʒ, pɛɹd steɪbəl dɔɹz fɹʌntɪd θɹi saɪdz ə ðə pæləsəz lɑɹdʒəst steɪbliɑɹd, ðə dɔɹweɪz kɹaʊɾəd baɪ sɝvəns ɪn ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi. bɪhaɪn əm ɪn ðə waɪt stoʊn steɪbəlz weɪɾəd hɔɹsəz, sæɾəld əɹ loʊɾəd wɪð wɪkɝ pænɪɝz. sibɝdz wild ən kɹaɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, ən ənplɛzən ɹimaɪndɝ ə haʊ mʌtʃ wɔɾɝ leɪ nɪɹbaɪ. hit ʃɪmɝɾ ʌp fɹəm peɪl peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tɛnʃən ðət θɪkən ði ɛɹ. eɪvinhə hæd sin blʌd spɪld wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz lɛs stʃɹeɪn.

Huge, paired stable doors fronted three sides of the palace's largest stableyard, the doorways crowded by servants in green-and-white livery. Behind them in the white stone stables waited horses, saddled or loaded with wicker panniers. Seabirds wheeled and cried overhead, an unpleasant reminder of how much water lay nearby. Heat shimmered up from pale paving stones, but it was tension that thickened the air. Aviendha had seen blood spilled where there was less strain.

ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn, ɪn ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ sɪlks, ɑɹmz kɹɔst ɛɹəɡənli bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, stʊd bɪfɔɹ naɪntin mɔɹ bɛɹfʊt wɪmən wɪð tætud hænz ən bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd blaʊsəz, moʊst ɪn tʃɹaʊzɝz ən lɔŋ sæʃɪz dʒʌst əz bɹɪljənt. swɛt ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɑn dɑɹk feɪsəz dɪd nɑt lɛsən ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪv dɪɡnəɾi. səm snɪft ət leɪsi ɡoʊl bɑksəz, fɪld wɪð hɛvi sɛnt, ðət hʌŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ nɛks. faɪv fæt ɡoʊld ɹɪŋz pɪɹst itʃ ə ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑnz ɪɹz, ə tʃeɪn fɹəm wʌn dʒɹɪpɪŋ mədæljənz əz ɪt ɹæn əkɹɔs əɹ lɛf tʃik tə ə ɹɪŋ ɪn əɹ noʊz. ðə θɹi wɪmən kloʊs bɪhaɪn əɹ itʃ wɔɹ eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz ən slaɪtli fjuɝ bɪts ə dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɡoʊld. ðət wɑz haʊ ðə si foʊk mɑɹkt ɹæŋk əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, wɪð ðə wɪmən ət list. ɔl dɪfɝd tə ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn, wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, bʌɾ ivən ðə tu əpɹɛntəsɪz ət ðə ɹɪɹ, ɪn dɑɹk tʃɹaʊzɝz ən lɪnən blaʊsəz ɪnstɛɾ ə sɪlk, æɾəd ðɛɹ oʊn ɡoʊldən ʃɪmɝz tə ði ɛɹ. wən eɪvinhə ən ði ʌðɝz əpɪɹd, ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn ɑstənteɪʃəsli lʊk tə ðə sʌn, pæst ɪts nun pik. hɝ aɪbɹaʊz klaɪmd əz ʃi dɝɛktəɾ əɹ ɡeɪz bæk tə ðɛm, aɪz blæk əz əɹ waɪt-wɪŋ hɛɹ, ə dɪmændɪŋ stɛɹ ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns soʊ laʊd ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv ʃaʊɾəd.

Renaile din Calon, in red and yellow silks, arms crossed arrogantly beneath her breasts, stood before nineteen more barefoot women with tattooed hands and brightly colored blouses, most in trousers and long sashes just as brilliant. Sweat glistening on dark faces did not lessen their grave dignity. Some sniffed at lacy gold boxes, filled with heavy scent, that hung about their necks. Five fat gold rings pierced each of Renaile din Calon's ears, a chain from one dripping medallions as it ran across her left cheek to a ring in her nose. The three women close behind her each wore eight earrings and slightly fewer bits of dangling gold. That was how the Sea Folk marked rank among themselves, with the women at least. All deferred to Renaile din Calon, Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, but even the two apprentices at the rear, in dark trousers and linen blouses instead of silk, added their own golden shimmers to the air. When Aviendha and the others appeared, Renaile din Calon ostentatiously looked to the sun, past its noon peak. Her eyebrows climbed as she directed her gaze back to them, eyes black as her white-winged hair, a demanding stare of impatience so loud she might as well have shouted.

ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv stɑpt ʃɔɹt, dʒɹæɡɪŋ eɪvinhə tə ən əbɹʌp hɔlt. ðeɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid ɡlænsɪz pæs hɝ, ən dip saɪz. ʃi dɪd nɑt si haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə ɪskeɪp. ɑbləɡeɪʃən baʊn əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ ən nɪneɪiv hæn ən fʊt, ən ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz hæd taɪd ðə nɑts taɪt.

Elayne and Nynaeve stopped short, dragging Aviendha to an abrupt halt. They exchanged worried glances past her, and deep sighs. She did not see how they were to escape. Obligation bound her near-sister and Nynaeve hand and foot, and they themselves had tied the knots tight.

"aɪl si tə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ən ɪleɪn sɛd, ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ staʊtli, "aɪl meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹ ɹɛɾi."

"I'll see to the Knitting Circle," Nynaeve muttered under her breath, and Elayne said, a little more stoutly, "I'll make sure the sisters are ready."

ɹilisɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz, ðeɪ wɛn ɪn ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃənz, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ skɝts ʌp tə stɛp kwɪkli ən fɑloʊd baɪ bɝdʒɪɾ ən læn. ðət lɛft əɹ feɪsɪŋ ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑnz ɡeɪz əloʊn, ði iɡəl stɛɹ ʌv ə wʊmən u nu ʃi hɛl ðə haɪ ɡɹaʊn ən kəd nɑt bi dɪslɑdʒd. fɔɹtʃənətli, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps kwɪkli tɝn tə hɝ kəmpænjənz, soʊ kwɪkli ðət ði ɛnz ə hɝ lɔŋ jɛloʊ sæʃ swʌŋ waɪd. ði ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, ɪntɛn ɑn əɹ kwaɪət wɝdz. hɪɾɪŋ əɹ ivən wʌns wəd ʃʊɹli ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. eɪvinhə tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ɡlɛɹ ət ðɛm, bʌɾ əz mʌtʃ ʃi ətɛmptəd tə lʊk ɛlswɛɹ, hɝ aɪz ɹɪtɝnd. noʊ wʌn hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə kætʃ əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ ɪn ə klf stɪk. noʊz ɹɪŋz! ə ɡʊd ɡɹɪp ɑn ðət tʃeɪn, ən ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn blu stɑɹ wəd wɛɹ ə vɛɹi dɪfɹən ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Releasing her arms, they went in opposite directions, holding their skirts up to step quickly and followed by Birgitte and Lan. That left her facing Renaile din Calon's gaze alone, the eagle stare of a woman who knew she held the high ground and could not be dislodged. Fortunately, the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships quickly turned to her companions, so quickly that the ends of her long yellow sash swung wide. The other Windfinders gathered around her, intent on her quiet words. Hitting her even once would surely ruin everything. Aviendha tried not to glare at them, but as much she attempted to look elsewhere, her eyes returned. No one had the right to catch her near-sister in a cleft stick. Nose rings! A good grip on that chain, and Renaile din Calon Blue Star would wear a very different expression.

klʌstɝd təɡɛðɝ ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, taɪni mɛɝɪlɪl ʃiændɪvɪn ən fɔɹ mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlsoʊ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, moʊst wɪð ənɔɪəns ɪl-kənsil bɪhaɪn kul sɝɛnəɾi. ivən slɛndɝ waɪt-hɛɹd vændin neɪmɛl ən əɹ mɪɹɝ-ɪmədʒ fɝst-sɪstɝ æɾɪliz, hu juʒəwəli lʊk ðə moʊst ɪmpɝɾɝbəbəl ə ðɛm ɔl. naʊ ən ðən wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ədʒʌstəɾ ə θɪn lɪnən dʌst-kloʊk əɹ bɹʌʃt ət dɪvaɪɾəd sɪlk skɝts. sʌɾən ɡʌsts dɪd ɹeɪz ə lɪɾəl dʌst ən stɝ ðə kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks ə ðə faɪv wɔɹɾɝz dʒʌst ət ðɛɹ bæks, jɛt klɪɹli ənɔɪəns muv ðɛɹ hænz. oʊnli sɝaɪðə, stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ə lɑɹdʒ waɪt dɪsk-ʃeɪp bʌndəl, dɪd nɑt twɪtʃ, bʌt ʃi fɹaʊnd. mɛɝɪlɪlz . . . meɪd . . . pɔl, skaʊl fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hiɾɪdli dɪsəpɹuvd ə ðə bɑɹɡən ðət hæd bɹɔt ði æθɑn maɪɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ ʃɪps ən ɡɪvən əm ə ɹaɪt tə stɛɹ əɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð dɪmændɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃəns, bʌt ðət bɑɹɡən taɪd ðə sɪstɝz' tʌŋz ən tʃoʊkt əm ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. wɪtʃ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə haɪd; ðeɪ maɪɾ əv səksiɾəd wɪð ðə wɛtləndɝz. ðə θɝd ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən, ɪn ə taɪt nɑɾ ət ði ɑpəzəɾ ɛn ə ðə jɑɹd, ɝn ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ ə ðɛɹ stʌɾi.

Clustered together at one end of the stableyard, tiny Merilille Ceandevin and four more Aes Sedai also regarded the Windfinders, most with annoyance ill-concealed behind cool serenity. Even slender white-haired Vandene Namelle and her mirror-image first-sister Adeleas, who usually looked the most imperturbable of them all. Now and then one or another adjusted a thin linen dust-cloak or brushed at divided silk skirts. Sudden gusts did raise a little dust and stir the color-shifting cloaks of the five Warders just at their backs, yet clearly annoyance moved their hands. Only Sareitha, standing guard over a large white disc-shaped bundle, did not twitch, but she frowned. Merilille's . . . maid . . . Pol, scowled from behind them. The Aes Sedai heatedly disapproved of the bargain that had brought the Atha'an Miere from their ships and given them a right to stare at Aes Sedai with demanding impatience, but that bargain tied the sisters' tongues and choked them on their own irritation. Which they tried to hide; they might have succeeded with the wetlanders. The third group of women, in a tight knot at the opposite end of the yard, earned almost as much of their study.

ɹin kɔɹli ən ði ʌðɝ tɛn sɝvaɪvɝz ə ðə kɪnz nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl stɝɾ ənizəli ʌndɝ ðət dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ skɹuɾəni, dæbɪŋ ðɛɹ swɛɾi feɪsəz wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd hæŋkɝtʃəfs, ədʒʌstɪŋ ðɛɹ bɹɔd, kʌlɝfəl stʃɹɔ hæts, smuðɪŋ soʊbɝ wʊlən skɝts soʊn ʌp ɑn wʌn saɪd tə ɪkspoʊz leɪɝz ə pɛɾikoʊts əz bɹaɪɾ əz ðə si foʊks ɡɑɹb. ɪn pɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz ðə stɛɹz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət hæɾ əm ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm fʊt tə fʊt; fɪɹ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ən ðə ɡoʊləm æɾəd tə ɪt, ən soʊ dɪɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ðə nɛɹoʊ, plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklinz ə ðoʊz dʒɹɛsəz ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf. moʊst ə ðiz wɪmən ʃoʊɾ ət list ə fju laɪnz ɑn ðɛɹ tʃiks, jɛt ðeɪ lʊk laɪk ɡɝlz kɑt wɪð ðɛɹ hænz fʊl ə stoʊlən nʌtbɹɛd. ɔl bʌt staʊt sumeɪkoʊ, fɪsts plæntəɾ ɑn bɹɔd hɪps, hu mɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛɹ fəɹ stɛɹ. ə bɹaɪt ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd wʌn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ, kɝstʃən, hu kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. wɪð ə peɪl feɪs pɝhæps tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪivz, ʃi əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə pleɪs əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝz. ðət feɪs ɡɹu waɪɾɝ ɛvɹi taɪm əɹ blæk aɪz mɛt ðoʊz ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Reanne Corly and the other ten survivors of the Kin's Knitting Circle stirred uneasily under that disapproving scrutiny, dabbing their sweaty faces with embroidered handkerchiefs, adjusting their broad, colorful straw hats, smoothing sober woolen skirts sewn up on one side to expose layers of petticoats as bright as the Sea Folk's garb. In part it was the stares of the Aes Sedai that had them shifting from foot to foot; fear of the Forsaken and the gholam added to it, and so did other things. The narrow, plunging necklines of those dresses should have been enough. Most of these women showed at least a few lines on their cheeks, yet they looked like girls caught with their hands full of stolen nutbread. All but stout Sumeko, fists planted on broad hips, who met the Aes Sedai stare for stare. A bright glow of saidar surrounded one of their number, Kirstian, who kept glancing over her shoulder. With a pale face perhaps ten years older than Nynaeve's, she appeared out of place among the others. That face grew whiter every time her black eyes met those of an Aes Sedai.

nɪneɪiv hɝid tə ðə wɪmən u lɛd ðə kɪn, hɝ feɪs bimɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, ən ɹin ən ði ʌðɝz smaɪld wɪð vɪzəbəl ɹɪlif. mɑɹɾ ə lɪɾəl, tʃɹu, baɪ ðə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz ðeɪ dɝɛktəɾ ət læn; hɪm ðeɪ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz ðə wʊlf i ɹɪzɛmbəld. nɪneɪiv, haʊɛvɝ, wɑz ðə ɹizən sumeɪkoʊ dɪd nɑt wɪlt laɪk ðə ɹɛst wɛnɛvɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡlænst ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. ʃi hæd vaʊd tə titʃ ðoʊz wɪmən ðət ðeɪ pəzɛs bækboʊnz, ðoʊ eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt kəmplitli ʌndɝstænd waɪ. nɪneɪiv wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ hɝsɛlf; noʊ waɪz wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ tɛl ɛniwʌn tə stæn ʌp tə waɪz wʌnz.

Nynaeve hurried to the women who led the Kin, her face beaming encouragement, and Reanne and the others smiled with visible relief. Marred a little, true, by the sidelong glances they directed at Lan; him they regarded as the wolf he resembled. Nynaeve, however, was the reason Sumeko did not wilt like the rest whenever an Aes Sedai glanced in her direction. She had vowed to teach those women that they possessed backbones, though Aviendha did not completely understand why. Nynaeve was Aes Sedai herself; no Wise One would ever tell anyone to stand up to Wise Ones.

haʊɛvɝ wɛl ðət maɪt bi wɝkɪŋ wɪð ɹɪspɛk tə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ivən sumeɪkoʊ wɔɹ ə slaɪtli fɔnɪŋ ɛɹ fəɹ nɪneɪiv. ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl faʊn ɪt stʃɹeɪnʒ, tə seɪ ðə list, ðət wɪmən əz jʌŋ əz ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɝ oʊbeɪd. eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf faʊn ɪt pəkjuljɝ; haʊ kəd stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, sʌmθɪŋ jə wɝ bɔɹn wɪð əz ʃʊɹli əz jəɹ aɪz, weɪ mɔɹ hɛvəli ðən ði ɑnɝ ðət jɪɹz kəd bɹɪŋ? jɛt ði oʊldɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪɾ oʊbeɪ, ən fəɹ ðə kɪnswɪmən, ðət wɑz ɪnʌf. iin, nɪɹli əz tɔl əz eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf ən ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz ðə si foʊk, ɹɪtɝnd nɪneɪivz ɛvɹi ɡlæns wɪð ən əbsikwiəs smaɪl, waɪl dmænə, waɪt stʃɹikɪŋ əɹ bɹaɪt ɹɛd hɛɹ, dʌkt əɹ hɛd kɑnstənli ʌndɝ nɪneɪivz aɪz, ən jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sɪbɛlə hɪd nɝvəs ɡɪɡəlz bɪhaɪn ə hænd. dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ ɛbu dɑɹi ɡɑɹməns, oʊnli tæmɑɹlə, lin ən ɑləv-skɪnd, wɑz ɔltɑɹən, ən nɑɾ ivən fɹəm ðə sɪɾi.

However well that might be working with respect to the other Aes Sedai, even Sumeko wore a slightly fawning air for Nynaeve. The Knitting Circle found it strange, to say the least, that women as young as Elayne and Nynaeve gave orders to the other Aes Sedai and were obeyed. Aviendha herself found it peculiar; how could strength in the Power, something you were born with as surely as your eyes, weigh more heavily than the honor that years could bring? Yet the older Aes Sedai did obey, and for the Kinswomen, that was enough. Ieine, nearly as tall as Aviendha herself and almost as dark as the Sea Folk, returned Nynaeve's every glance with an obsequious smile, while Dimana, white streaking her bright red hair, ducked her head constantly under Nynaeve's eyes, and yellow-haired Sibella hid nervous giggles behind a hand. Despite their Ebou Dari garments, only Tamarla, lean and olive-skinned, was Altaran, and not even from the city.

ðeɪ pɑɹɾəd əz sun əz nɪneɪiv keɪm kloʊs, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə wʊmən ɑn əɹ niz, ɹɪsts baʊn bɪhaɪn hɝ, ə lɛðɝ sæk kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ən əɹ faɪn kloʊðz tɔɹn ən dʌsti. ʃi wɑz əz mʌtʃ ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðɛɹ ʌnizinəs əz mɛɝɪlɪlz fɹaʊnz əɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən. pɝhæps mɔɹ.

They parted as soon as Nynaeve came close, revealing a woman on her knees, wrists bound behind her, a leather sack covering her head, and her fine clothes torn and dusty. She was as much the reason for their uneasiness as Merilille's frowns or the Forsaken. Perhaps more.

tæmɑɹlə dʒɹæɡd ðə hʊɾ ɔf, livɪŋ ðə wʊmənz θɪn, bid-stʌɾɪd bɹeɪdz tæŋɡəld; ɪspæn ʃɛfɹ tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪz, ən mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ ən ɑkwɝd kɹaʊtʃ bɪfɔɹ ʃi stæɡɝɾ ən sæŋk bæk daʊn, blɪŋkɪŋ ən ɡɪɡəlɪŋ fulɪʃli. swɛt ɹæn daʊn əɹ tʃiks, ən ə fju bɹuzəz fɹəm əɹ kæptʃɝ mɑɹɾ əɹ eɪdʒləs fitʃɝz. ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɹiɾəd tu dʒɛnli fəɹ əɹ kɹaɪmz, tə eɪvinhəz maɪnd.

Tamarla dragged the hood off, leaving the woman's thin, bead-studded braids tangled; Ispan Shefar tried to rise, and managed to reach an awkward crouch before she staggered and sank back down, blinking and giggling foolishly. Sweat ran down her cheeks, and a few bruises from her capture marred her ageless features. She had been treated too gently for her crimes, to Aviendha's mind.

ði ɝbz nɪneɪiv hæd fɔɹs daʊn ðə wʊmənz θɹoʊt stɪl fɑɡd əɹ wɪts əz wɛl əz wikənɪŋ əɹ niz, bʌt kɝstʃən hɛld ə ʃild ɑn əɹ wɪð ɛvɹi ʃɹɛɾ ə ðə paʊɝ ʃi kəd sʌmən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns ðə ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ maɪɾ ɪskeɪp - ivən hæd ʃi nɑt bɪn doʊzd, kɝstʃən wɑz əz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ əz ɹin, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪvinhə hæd mɛt - jɛɾ ivən sumeɪkoʊ plʌkt əɹ skɝts nɝvəsli ən əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə nilɪŋ wʊmən.

The herbs Nynaeve had forced down the woman's throat still fogged her wits as well as weakening her knees, but Kirstian held a shield on her with every shred of the Power she could summon. There was no chance the Shadowrunner might escape - even had she not been dosed, Kirstian was as strong in the Power as Reanne, stronger than most Aes Sedai Aviendha had met - yet even Sumeko plucked her skirts nervously and avoided looking at the kneeling woman.

"ʃʊɹli ðə sɪstɝz ʃəɾ əv hɝ, naʊ." ɹinz haɪ-pɪtʃt vɔɪs kæɹid, ənstɛɾi ɪnʌf tə bɪlɔŋ tə ðə blæk sɪstɝ kɝstʃən ʃildɪd. "nɪneɪiv sədaɪ, wi . . . wi ʃəd nɑt bi ɡɑɹ - ʌ - ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv . . . ən ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Surely the sisters should have her, now." Reanne's high-pitched voice carried, unsteady enough to belong to the Black sister Kirstian shielded. "Nynaeve Sedai, we . . . we should not be guar - uh - in charge of . . . an Aes Sedai."

"ðæts ɹaɪt," sumeɪkoʊ pʊɾ ɪn kwɪkli. ən æŋkʃəsli. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃəɾ əv hɝ, naʊ." sɪbɛlə ɛkoʊd hɝ, ən nɑdz ən mɝmɝz ʌv əɡɹimən ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə kɪnswɪmən. ðeɪ bɪlivd ɪn ðɛɹ boʊnz ðət ðeɪ stʊd fɑɹ bɪloʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ; vɛɹi laɪkli ðeɪ wʊɾə tʃoʊzən ɡɑɹɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks oʊvɝ hoʊldɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"That's right," Sumeko put in quickly. And anxiously. "The Aes Sedai should have her, now." Sibella echoed her, and nods and murmurs of agreement rippled through the Kinswomen. They believed in their bones that they stood far below Aes Sedai; very likely they would have chosen guarding Trollocs over holding an Aes Sedai.

ðə dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ stɛɹz fɹəm mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz tʃeɪnʒd wʌns ɪspæn ʃɛfɹz feɪs wɑz ɹɪvild. sɝaɪðə toʊmɑɹz, hu hæd wɔɹn əɹ bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz ən stɪl dɪd nɑɾ əv ði eɪdʒləs əpɪɹəns, ɡlɛɹd wɪð ə dɪsɡʌs ðət ʃʊɾə fleɪd ðə ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ ət fɪfti peɪsɪz. æɾɪliz ən vændin, hænz taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ skɝts, əpɪɹd tə stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð heɪtʃɹəd fəɹ ðə wʊmən u hæd bɪn ðɛɹ sɪstɝ ən bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm. jɛt ðə stɛɹz ðeɪ ɡeɪv ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɝ nɑt ðət mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ. ðeɪ, tu, nu ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹts ðət ðə kɪn stʊɾ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ weɪ bɪloʊ ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt, bʌt ðə bɪtʃɹeɪɝ hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðɛɹ oʊn, ən noʊ wʌn bʌt ðeɪ hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə hɝ. eɪvinhə əɡɹid. eɪ meɪɾən u bɪtʃɹeɪɾ əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz dɪd nɑt daɪ kwɪkli əɹ ʌn-ʃeɪmd.

The disapproving stares from Merilille and the other sisters changed once Ispan Shefar's face was revealed. Sareitha Tomares, who had worn her brown-fringed shawl only a few years and still did not have the ageless appearance, glared with a disgust that should have flayed the Shadowrunner at fifty paces. Adeleas and Vandene, hands tightening on their skirts, appeared to struggle with hatred for the woman who had been their sister and betrayed them. Yet the stares they gave the Knitting Circle were not that much better. They, too, knew in their hearts that the Kin stood a very long way below them. There was much more to it than that, but the betrayer had been one of their own, and no one but they had the right to her. Aviendha agreed. A Maiden who betrayed her spear-sisters did not die quickly or un-shamed.

nɪneɪiv pʊl ðə sæk bæk daʊn oʊvɝ ɪspæn ʃɛfɹz hɛd wɪð səm fɔɹs. "juv dʌn wɛl soʊ fɑɹ, ən jəl kəntɪnju tə də wɛl," ʃi toʊl ðə kɪnswɪmən fɝmli. "ɪf ʃi ʃoʊz saɪnz ə kʌmɪŋ ɹaʊnd, pɔɹ səm mɔɹ ə ðət mɪkstʃɝ daʊn hɝ. ɪɾəl kip əɹ ɡɪɾi əz ə ɡoʊt fʊl ʌv eɪl. hoʊld əɹ noʊz, ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪz nɑt tə swɑloʊ. ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl swɑloʊ ɪf jə hoʊld əɹ noʊz ən θɹɛɾən tə bɑks əɹ ɪɹz."

Nynaeve pulled the sack back down over Ispan Shefar's head with some force. "You've done well so far, and you'll continue to do well," she told the Kinswomen firmly. "If she shows signs of coming round, pour some more of that mixture down her. It'll keep her giddy as a goat full of ale. Hold her nose, if she tries not to swallow. Even an Aes Sedai will swallow if you hold her nose and threaten to box her ears."

ɹinz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt ən əɹ aɪz spɹæŋ waɪd, laɪk moʊst ə hɝ kəmpænjənz'. sumeɪkoʊ nɑɾəd, bʌt sloʊli, ən ɡɑɡəl nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ði ʌðɝz. wən kɪnswɪmən sɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn neɪmɪŋ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. ðə θɔɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz noʊz, ivən ə ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝz, peɪntəd ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɪð hɔɹɝ.

Reanne's jaw dropped and her eyes sprang wide, like most of her companions'. Sumeko nodded, but slowly, and goggled nearly as much as the others. When Kinswomen said Aes Sedai, they might have been naming the Creator. The thought of holding an Aes Sedai's nose, even a Shadowrunner's, painted their faces with horror.

baɪ ðə pɑpɪŋ aɪz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðeɪ laɪk ðə noʊʃən ivən lɛs. mɛɝɪlɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, stɛɹɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv, bʌt dʒʌs ðən ɪleɪn ɹitʃt hɝ, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn əɹ ɪnstɛd, spɛɹɪŋ bɛɹli ə sɪŋɡəl dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ fɹaʊn fəɹ bɝdʒɪt. ɪt wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə hɝ ædʒəteɪʃən ðəɾ əɹ vɔɪs ɹoʊz ɹæðɝ ðən dʒɹɑpɪŋ; nɔɹməli mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz vɛɹi dɪskɹit. "ɪleɪn, jə mʌst spik tə nɪneɪiv. ðoʊz wɪmən ɑɹ kənfjuzd ən fɹaɪɾənd aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ wɪts ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪt woʊn hɛlp ɪf ʃi ʌpsɛts əm ivən mɔɹ. ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɹɪli dʌz ɪntɛn tə əlaʊ ðɛm tə ɡoʊ tə ðə taʊɝ," ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪnaɪ ðæt, ən pɝhæps ə ɡɹeɪt dil ɛls, "ɪf ʃi dʌz min tə, ðeɪ mʌst əv ə klɪɹ pɪktʃɝ ə ðɛɹ pleɪsəz, ən - "

By the popping eyes among the Aes Sedai, they liked the notion even less. Merilille opened her mouth, staring at Nynaeve, but just then Elayne reached her, and the Gray sister rounded on her instead, sparing barely a single disapproving frown for Birgitte. It was a measure of her agitation that her voice rose rather than dropping; normally Merilille was very discreet. "Elayne, you must speak to Nynaeve. Those women are confused and frightened out of their wits already. It won't help if she upsets them even more. If the Amyrlin Seat really does intend to allow them to go to the Tower," she shook her head slowly, trying to deny that, and perhaps a great deal else, "if she does mean to, they must have a clear picture of their places, and - "

"ði æmɪɝlɪn dʌz," ɪleɪn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. fɹəm nɪneɪiv, ə fɝm toʊn wɑz ə fɪst ʃeɪkən ʌndɝ jəɹ noʊz; fɹəm ɪleɪn, ɪt wɑz kɑm sɝɾənti. "ðeɪ wɪl əv ðɛɹ tʃæns tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, ən ɪf ðeɪ feɪl, ðeɪ stɪl wɪl nɑt bi sɛn əweɪ. noʊ wʊmən u kən tʃænəl wɪl bi kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə taʊɝ əɡɛn. ðəl ɔl bi ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ."

"The Amyrlin does," Elayne cut her off. From Nynaeve, a firm tone was a fist shaken under your nose; from Elayne, it was calm certainty. "They will have their chance to try again, and if they fail, they still will not be sent away. No woman who can channel will be cut off from the Tower again. They will all be a part of the White Tower."

fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ bɛl naɪf aɪdli, eɪvinhə wʌndɝɾ əbaʊt ðæt. ɛɡwin, ɪleɪnz æmɪɝlɪn sit, sɛd mʌtʃ ðə seɪm. ʃi wɑz ə fɹɛnd, tu, bʌt ʃi hæd ɹæpt əɹ hɑɹɾ ɝaʊn biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. eɪvinhə hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊɾɪd ðət sɔɹɪliə əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ waɪz wʌn dɪd, iðɝ.

Fingering her belt knife idly, Aviendha wondered about that. Egwene, Elayne's Amyrlin Seat, said much the same. She was a friend, too, but she had wrapped her heart around being Aes Sedai. Aviendha herself did not want to be part of the White Tower. She very much doubted that Sorilea or any other Wise One did, either.

mɛɝɪlɪl saɪɾ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz, jɛt fəɹ ɔl əɹ aʊtwɝɾ æksɛptəns, ʃi stɪl fɝɡɑt tə loʊɝ əɹ vɔɪs. "æz jə seɪ, ɪleɪn. bʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɪspæn. wi sɪmpli kænɑɾ əlaʊ - "

Merilille sighed and folded her hands, yet for all her outward acceptance, she still forgot to lower her voice. "As you say, Elayne. But about Ispan. We simply cannot allow - "

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ə hænd ʃɑɹpli. kəmæn ɹipleɪs mɪɹ sɝɾənti. "sis, mɛɝɪlɪl. juv ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz tə wɑtʃ. ðəɾ ɪz ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn. ɪɾəl bi ɪnʌf fəɹ ju."

Elayne raised a hand sharply. Command replaced mere certainty. "Cease, Merilille. You have the Bowl of the Winds to watch. That is enough for anyone. It will be enough for you."

mɛɝɪlɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn ən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli ɪn ækwiɛsəns. ʌndɝ ɪleɪnz stɛɾi ɡeɪz, ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɛn ðɛɹz, tu. ɪf səm dɪspleɪd ɹɪlʌktəns, haʊɛvɝ smɔl, nɑɾ ɔl dɪd. sɝaɪðə hɝidli pɪkt ʌp ðə dɪsk-ʃeɪp bʌndəl, ɹæpt ɪn leɪɝz ʌv waɪt sɪlk, ðət hæd bɪn laɪɪŋ baɪ hɝ fit. hɝ ɑɹmz bɛɹli wɛn ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn əz ʃi hɛl ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz tə hɝ bʊzəm, smaɪlɪŋ æŋkʃəsli əɾ ɪleɪn əz ɪf tə ʃoʊ ðət ʃi ɹɪli wɑz kipɪŋ ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ɪt.

Merilille opened her mouth, then closed it again and bowed her head slightly in acquiescence. Under Elayne's steady gaze, the other Aes Sedai bent theirs, too. If some displayed reluctance, however small, not all did. Sareitha hurriedly picked up the disc-shaped bundle, wrapped in layers of white silk, that had been lying by her feet. Her arms barely went all the way around as she held the Bowl of the Winds to her bosom, smiling anxiously at Elayne as if to show that she really was keeping a close eye on it.

ðə si foʊk wɪmən stɛɹd hʌŋɡɹəli ət ðə bʌndəl, ɔlmoʊs linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. eɪvinhə wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðɛm lip əkɹɔs ðə stoʊnz tə siz ðə boʊl. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɔ ðə seɪm, pleɪnli. sɝaɪðə klʌtʃt ðə waɪt pɑɹsəl mɔɹ taɪtli, ən mɛɝɪlɪl æktʃəli  stɛp bɪtwin əɹ ən ði æθɑn maɪɹ. smuð ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz taɪɾənd wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃənləs. ðeɪ bɪliv ðə boʊl ʃəd bɪlɔŋ tə ðɛm; ɔl θɪŋz ðət juzd əɹ mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ bɪlɔŋ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, noʊ mæɾɝ u hæpən tə pəzɛs əm ət ðə moʊmənt. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ðə bɑɹɡən.

The Sea Folk women stared hungrily at the bundle, almost leaning forward. Aviendha would not have been surprised to see them leap across the stones to seize the Bowl. The Aes Sedai saw the same, plainly. Sareitha clutched the white parcel more tightly, and Merilille actually stepped between her and the Atha'an Miere. Smooth Aes Sedai faces tightened with the effort of remaining expressionless. They believed the Bowl should belong to them; all things that used or manipulated the One Power belonged to the White Tower in their eyes, no matter who happened to possess them at the moment. But there was the bargain.

"ðə sʌn muvz, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn ənaʊns laʊdli, "æn deɪnʒɝ θɹɛɾənz. soʊ jə meɪnteɪn. ɪf jə θɪŋk tə wɝm fɹi ɪn səm fæʃən baɪ dɪleɪɪŋ, θɪŋk twaɪs ən əɡɛn. tʃɹaɪ tə bɹeɪk ðə bɑɹɡən, ən baɪ maɪ fɑðɝz hɑɹt, əl ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ʃɪps ət wʌns. ən kleɪm ðə boʊl fəɹ ɹɪdʒɹɛs. ɪt wɑz aʊɝz fɹəm ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ."

"The sun moves, Aes Sedai," Renaile din Calon announced loudly, "and danger threatens. So you maintain. If you think to worm free in some fashion by delaying, think twice and again. Try to break the bargain, and by my father's heart, I will return to the ships at once. And claim the Bowl for redress. It was ours from the Breaking."

"ju wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɹin bɑɹkt, skændəlaɪzd ɪndɪɡneɪʃən fɹəm əɹ blu stʃɹɔ hæt tə ðə staʊt ʃuz pikɪŋ fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt pɛɾikoʊts.

"You watch your tongue with Aes Sedai," Reanne barked, scandalized indignation from her blue straw hat to the stout shoes peeking from beneath her green-and-white petticoats.

ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑnz maʊθ kɝld ɪndə ə snɪɹ. "ðə dʒɛlifɪʃ əv tʌŋz, ɪt simz. ə sɝpɹaɪz ðeɪ kən juz ðɛm, ðoʊ, wən noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv pɝmɪʃən."

Renaile din Calon's mouth curled into a sneer. "The jellyfish have tongues, it seems. A surprise they can use them, though, when no Aes Sedai gave permission."

ɪn ən ɪnstən ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɑz fʊl ə ʃaʊɾəd ɪnsʌls flaɪɪŋ bɪtwin kɪn ən æθɑn maɪɹ, "waɪldɝ" ən "spaɪnləs" ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɝs, stʃɹaɪɾənt kɹaɪz ðət bɛɹid mɛɝɪlɪlz ətɛmps tə hʌʃ ɹin ən əɹ kəmpænjənz ɑn wʌn hæn ən suð ðə si foʊk ɑn ði ʌðɝ. sɛvɹəl wɪndfɪndɝz stɑp fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə dæɡɝz θɹʌs bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ sæʃɪz ən ɡɹɪp hɪls ɪnstɛd. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn fɝst wʌn ðən ənʌðɝ ə ðə bɹaɪtli klæd wɪmən. ðə kɪnswɪmən lʊk stɑɹɾəld, ðoʊ ɪt dɪd nɑt sloʊ ðɛɹ taɪɹeɪd, bʌt sumeɪkoʊ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, ðən tæmɑɹlə, ðən wɪləwi, doʊ-aɪd tʃɪlɛɹz, ən sun ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ʃoʊn waɪl wɝdz flu ən tɛmpɝz bɔɪld.

In an instant the stableyard was full of shouted insults flying between Kin and Atha'an Miere, "wilder" and "spineless" and growing worse, strident cries that buried Merilille's attempts to hush Reanne and her companions on one hand and soothe the Sea Folk on the other. Several Windfinders stopped fingering the daggers thrust behind their sashes and gripped hilts instead. The glow of saidar sprang up around first one then another of the brightly clad women. The Kinswomen looked startled, though it did not slow their tirade, but Sumeko embraced the Source, then Tamarla, then willowy, doe-eyed Chilares, and soon every one of them and every one of the Windfinders shone while words flew and tempers boiled.

eɪvinhə wɑntəd tə ɡɹoʊn. ɛni moʊmən blʌd wəd bɪɡɪn tə floʊ. ʃi wəd fɑloʊ ɪleɪnz lɛd, bʌɾ əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ koʊl fjʊɹi ət wɪndfɪndɝz ən nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl əlaɪk. ɪleɪn hæd smɔl peɪʃəns wɪð stupɪɾɪti, ɪn hɝsɛlf əɹ ʌðɝz, ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪnsʌls wən ən ɛnəmi maɪt bi kʌmɪŋ wɑz ðə wɝst sɔɹt. eɪvinhə tʊk ə fɝm ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ bɛl naɪf, ðən æftɝ ə moʊmən ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ; laɪf ən dʒɔɪ fɪld əɹ tə nɪɹ wipɪŋ. waɪz wʌnz oʊnli juz ðə paʊɝ wən wɝdz hæd feɪld, bʌt niðɝ wɝdz nɔɹ stil wəd də hɪɹ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd səm aɪdiə ʌv u tə kɪl fɝst.

Aviendha wanted to groan. Any moment blood would begin to flow. She would follow Elayne's lead, but her near-sister was glaring cold fury at Windfinders and Knitting Circle alike. Elayne had small patience with stupidity, in herself or others, and shouting insults when an enemy might be coming was the worst sort. Aviendha took a firm grip on her belt knife, then after a moment embraced saidar; life and joy filled her to near weeping. Wise Ones only used the Power when words had failed, but neither words nor steel would do here. She wished she had some idea of who to kill first.

"ɪnʌf!" nɪneɪivz pɪɹsɪŋ ʃɹik slaɪs ðə wɝdz ʃɔɹɾ ɑn ɛvɹi tʌŋ. əstɑnɪʃt feɪsəz swɪvəl təwɔɹd hɝ. hɝ hɛd swʌŋ deɪnʒɝəsli, ən ʃi stæbd ə fɪŋɡɝ ət ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl. "stɑp bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk tʃɪlʒɹən!" ɔlðoʊ ʃi hæd mɑɾɝeɪtɪd əɹ toʊn, ɪt wɑz baɪ hɛɹz. "ɔɹ dʒju min tə skwɑbəl əntɪl ðə fɔɹseɪkən kʌm tə skup ʌp ðə boʊl ən ʌs? ən ju," ðət fɪŋɡɝ θɹʌst ət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, "stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪɡəl aʊɾ ə jəɹ əɡɹimənt! jə woʊnt ɡɛt ðə boʊl əntɪl juv mɛɾ ɛvɹi læst wɝd! doʊn θɪŋk jə wɪl!" nɪneɪiv swʌŋ ɹaʊn ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "æn jə . . . !" mɛt baɪ kul sɝpɹaɪz, hɝ floʊ ʌv wɝdz teɪpɝɾ ɔf ɪndə ə saʊɝ ɡɹʌnt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt dʒɔɪn ɪn ðə ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪksɛp tə tʃɹaɪ kwaɪəɾɪŋ ɪt. nʌn ʃoʊn wɪð ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ.

"Enough!" Nynaeve's piercing shriek sliced the words short on every tongue. Astonished faces swiveled toward her. Her head swung dangerously, and she stabbed a finger at the Knitting Circle. "Stop behaving like children!" Although she had moderated her tone, it was by hairs. "Or do you mean to squabble until the Forsaken come to scoop up the Bowl and us? And you," that finger thrust at the Windfinders, "stop trying to wriggle out of your agreement! You won't get the Bowl until you've met every last word! Don't think you will!" Nynaeve swung round on the Aes Sedai. "And you . . . !" Met by cool surprise, her flow of words tapered off into a sour grunt. The Aes Sedai had not joined in the shouting except to try quieting it. None shone with the light of saidar.

ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kɑm nɪneɪiv kəmplitli, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi tʌɡd fɪɹsli əɾ əɹ hæt, pleɪnli stɪl fʊl ʌv æŋɡɝ ʃi wɑntəd tə lus. bʌt ðə kɪnswɪmən wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ɪn ɹɛd-feɪst ʃəɡɹɪn, ən ivən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz əpɪɹɾ ə lɪɾəl əbæʃt - ə lɪɾəl - mʌɾɝɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz jɛt ɹəfjuzɪŋ kwaɪt tə mit nɪneɪivz ɡlɛɹ. ðə ɡloʊ wɪŋkt aʊɾ ɝaʊnd wʌn wʊmən æftɝ ənʌðɝ, əntɪl oʊnli eɪvinhə stɪl hɛl tə ðə sɔɹs.

That was not enough to calm Nynaeve completely, of course. She tugged fiercely at her hat, plainly still full of anger she wanted to loose. But the Kinswomen were staring at the paving stones in red-faced chagrin, and even the Windfinders appeared a little abashed - a little - muttering to themselves yet refusing quite to meet Nynaeve's glare. The glow winked out around one woman after another, until only Aviendha still held to the Source.

ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ɪleɪn tʌtʃt əɹ ɑɹm. ʃi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ sɑft. lɛɾɪŋ pipəl snik ʌp ɑn hɝ, dʒʌmpɪŋ əɾ ə tʌtʃ.

She gave a start as Elayne touched her arm. She was getting soft. Letting people sneak up on her, jumping at a touch.

"ðɪs kɹaɪsəs simz tə bi wɛðɝd," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "pɝhæps ɪts taɪm tə ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə nɛks bɹeɪks aʊt." ə tʌtʃ ə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks wɑz ði oʊnli saɪn ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn æŋɡɹi. ən ə bɪɾ ɪn bɝdʒɪts; ðə tu ɹəflɛktəd wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn səm weɪz sɪns ðə bɑndɪŋ.

"This crisis seems to be weathered," Elayne murmured. "Perhaps it's time to go before the next breaks out." A touch of color in her cheeks was the only sign that she had ever been angry. And a bit in Birgitte's; the two reflected one another in some ways since the bonding.

"pæs taɪm," eɪvinhə əɡɹid. mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ən ʃi wəd bi ə mɪlk-hɑɹɾəd wɛtləndɝ.

"Past time," Aviendha agreed. Much longer, and she would be a milk-hearted wetlander.

ɛvɹi aɪ fɑloʊɾ əz ʃi wɔkt aʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpən speɪs ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, tə ðə spɑt ʃi hæd stʌɾid ən fɛlt əntɪl ʃi nu ɪt wɪð əɹ aɪlɪdz kloʊzd. ðəɹ wɑz ə dʒɔɪ ɪn hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ə dʒɔɪ ɪn wɝkɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðət ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv pʊɾ ɪndə wɝdz. tə kənteɪn seɪaɪdɑɹ, tə bi kənteɪn baɪ ɪt, wɑz tə sim əlaɪv bɪɑn ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm. ə dɪluʒən, ðə waɪz wʌnz sɛd, əz fɔls ən deɪnʒɝəs əz ə mɝɑʒ ʌv wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə tɝmul, jɛɾ ɪt simd mɔɹ ɹil ðən ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz bɪniθ əɹ fit. ʃi fɔt ði ɝdʒ tə dʒɹɔ mɔɹ; ɔlɹɛɾi ʃi hɛl nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kʊd. ɛvɹiwʌn kɹaʊɾəd kloʊs əz ʃi bɪɡæn tə wiv ðə floʊz.

Every eye followed as she walked out into the open space in the center of the stableyard, to the spot she had studied and felt until she knew it with her eyelids closed. There was a joy in holding the Power, a joy in working saidar, that she could not have put into words. To contain saidar, to be contained by it, was to seem alive beyond any other time. A delusion, the Wise Ones said, as false and dangerous as a mirage of water in the Termool, yet it seemed more real than the paving stones beneath her feet. She fought the urge to draw more; already she held nearly as much as she could. Everyone crowded close as she began to weave the flows.

ðət ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt də stɪl stɑɹɾəld eɪvinhə, æftɝ ɔl ʃi hæd sin. sɛvɹəl ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf, bʌɾ oʊnli sumeɪkoʊ ænd, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ɹin oʊpənli stʌɾid wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. sumeɪkoʊ wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə ʃɹʌɡ ɔf ði ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ pæts nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɪv əɹ - wɪtʃ ɝn ə lʊk ə stɑɹɾəld ɪndɪɡneɪʃən fɹəm nɪneɪiv ðət sumeɪkoʊ, hɝ ɡeɪz fɪkst ɑn eɪvinhə, nɛvɝ sɔ. ɔl ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hæd səfɪʃən stʃɹɛŋkθ. ðeɪ wɑtʃt əz hʌŋɡɹəli əz ðeɪ hæd stɛɹɾ ət ðə boʊl. ðə bɑɹɡən ɡeɪv əm ɛvɹi ɹaɪt.

That there were things many Aes Sedai could not do still startled Aviendha, after all she had seen. Several of the Knitting Circle were strong enough, but only Sumeko and, surprisingly, Reanne openly studied what she was doing. Sumeko went so far as to shrug off the encouraging pats Nynaeve tried to give her - which earned a look of startled indignation from Nynaeve that Sumeko, her gaze fixed on Aviendha, never saw. All of the Windfinders had sufficient strength. They watched as hungrily as they had stared at the Bowl. The bargain gave them every right.

eɪvinhə foʊkəst, ən ðə floʊz woʊv təɡɛðɝ, kɹieɪɾɪŋ aɪdɛntəɾi bɪtwin ðɪs pleɪs ən ðə pleɪs ʃi ən ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv hæd tʃoʊzən ɑn ə mæp. ʃi dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ðoʊ oʊpənɪŋ tɛntflæps. ðət wɑz noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðə wiv ɪleɪn hæd tɔt hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɔl ʃi kəd ɹikɔl ʌv wʌt ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd dʌn, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin meɪɾ əɹ fɝst ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə floʊz koʊəlɛst ɪndə ə sɪlvɝi, vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ðət ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ən bɪkeɪm ən oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, tɔlɝ ðən ə mæn ən dʒʌst əz waɪd. bɪɑn leɪ ə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ sɝaʊndəd baɪ tʃɹiz twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi fit haɪ, maɪlz nɔɹθ ə ðə sɪɾi, ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ni-haɪ bɹaʊn ɡɹæs keɪm ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, sweɪɪŋ θɹu ɪn ə smɔl bɹiz; ɪt hæd nɑt tʃɹuli tɝnd, oʊnli sim tə. səm ə ðoʊz bleɪdz wɝ slaɪs klinli, ðoʊ, səm lɛŋθwaɪz. ði ɛdʒəz ʌv ən oʊpənɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪ meɪɾ ə ɹeɪzɝ sim dʌl.

Aviendha focused, and the flows wove together, creating identity between this place and the place she and Elayne and Nynaeve had chosen on a map. She gestured as though opening tentflaps. That was no part of the weave Elayne had taught her, but it was almost all she could recall of what she herself had done, long before Egwene made her first gateway. The flows coalesced into a silvery, vertical slash that rotated and became an opening in the air, taller than a man and just as wide. Beyond lay a large clearing surrounded by trees twenty or thirty feet high, miles north of the city, on the far side of the river. Knee-high brown grass came right up to the gateway, swaying through in a small breeze; it had not truly turned, only seemed to. Some of those blades were sliced cleanly, though, some lengthwise. The edges of an opening gateway made a razor seem dull.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ fɪld əɹ wɪð dɪsæɾɪsfækʃən. ɪleɪn kəd meɪk ðɪs wiv wɪð oʊnli ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ, jɛt fəɹ səm ɹizən ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɔl bʌɾ ə fɹækʃən ʌv eɪvinhəz. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi cʊɾə woʊvən ə lɑɹdʒɝ, əz lɑɹdʒ əz ɪleɪn kʊd, juzɪŋ ðə wivz ʃi hæd meɪd wɪθaʊt θɔt waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp ɹænd ælθɹ wʌt simd ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ, bʌt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ʃi tʃɹaɪd, oʊnli skɹæps keɪm bæk tə hɝ. ʃi fɛl noʊ ɛnvi - ɹæðɝ, ʃi tʊk pɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝz əkɑmplɪʃməns - bʌɾ əɹ oʊn feɪljɝ meɪd ʃeɪm sɝdʒ ɪn əɹ hɑɹt. sɔɹɪliə əɹ æmɪz wəd bi hɑɹɾ ɑn hɝ, ɪf ðeɪ nu ðæt. əbaʊt ðə ʃeɪm. tu mʌtʃ pɹaɪd, ðeɪ wəd kɔl ɪt. æmɪz ʃəɾ ʌndɝstænd; ʃi hæd bɪn ə meɪɾən. ðəɹ wɑz ʃeɪm ɪn feɪlɪŋ ət wʌt jə ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə du. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt hæd tə hoʊl ðə wiv, ʃi wʊɾə ɹʌn əweɪ soʊ noʊ wʌn kəd si hɝ.

The gateway filled her with dissatisfaction. Elayne could make this weave with only a part of her strength, yet for some reason it required all but a fraction of Aviendha's. She was sure she could have woven a larger, as large as Elayne could, using the weaves she had made without thought while trying to escape Rand al'Thor what seemed a very long time ago, but no matter how often she tried, only scraps came back to her. She felt no envy - rather, she took pride in her near-sister's accomplishments - but her own failure made shame surge in her heart. Sorilea or Amys would be hard on her, if they knew that. About the shame. Too much pride, they would call it. Amys should understand; she had been a Maiden. There was shame in failing at what you should be able to do. If she had not had to hold the weave, she would have run away so no one could see her.

ðə dɪpɑɹtʃɝ hæd bɪn kɛɹfəli plænd, ən ðə hoʊl steɪbliɑɹd spɹæŋ ɪndə moʊʃən əz sun əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən fʊli. tu ʌv ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl pʊl ðə hʊɾɪd ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ tə hɝ fit, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hɝidli fɔɹmd ə laɪn bɪhaɪn ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn. ðə sɝvəns bɪɡæn bɹɪŋɪŋ hɔɹsəz aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəlz. læn, bɝdʒɪt, ən wʌn ə kɛɝinz wɔɹɾɝz, ə læŋki mæn kɔl sɪɛɹəl ɑɹdʒunə, ɪmiɾiətli dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, wʌn bɪhaɪn ði ʌðɝ. laɪk fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, wɔɹɾɝz ɔlweɪz kleɪm ðə ɹaɪt tə skaʊɾ əhɛd. eɪvinhəz fiɾ ɪtʃt tə ɹʌn æftɝ ðɛm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪnt. ənlaɪk ɪleɪn, ʃi kəd nɑt muv mɔɹ ðən faɪv əɹ sɪks stɛps wɪθaʊt ðɪs wiv bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wikən, ən ðə seɪm ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə taɪ ɪɾ ɔf. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ.

The departure had been carefully planned, and the whole stableyard sprang into motion as soon as the gateway opened fully. Two of the Knitting Circle pulled the hooded Shadowrunner to her feet, and the Windfinders hurriedly formed a line behind Renaile din Calon. The servants began bringing horses out of the stables. Lan, Birgitte, and one of Careane's Warders, a lanky man called Cieryl Arjuna, immediately darted through the gateway, one behind the other. Like Far Dareis Mai, Warders always claimed the right to scout ahead. Aviendha's feet itched to run after them, but there was no point. Unlike Elayne, she could not move more than five or six steps without this weave beginning to weaken, and the same if she tried to tie it off. It was very frustrating.

ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil ɛkspɛkteɪʃən ə deɪnʒɝ, soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli, ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv əz wɛl. fɑɹmz dɑɾəd ðət tʃɹiɾ ɛɹiə θɪkli, ən ə wɑndɝɪŋ ʃɛpɝɾ əɹ ə jʌŋ kʌpəl sikɪŋ pɹaɪvəsi maɪt nid ɡaɪɾəns əweɪ fɹəm siɪŋ tu mʌtʃ, bʌt noʊ ʃæɾoʊsuld əɹ ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ kəd noʊ ðət klɪɹɪŋ; oʊnli ʃi, ɪleɪn, ən nɪneɪiv dɪd, ən ðeɪ hæd nɑt spoʊkən ɪn ðə tʃuzɪŋ, fəɹ fɪɹ ʌv ivzdʒɹɑpɝz. stændɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpənɪŋ, ɪleɪn ɡeɪv eɪvinhə ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊk, bʌɾ eɪvinhə moʊʃən əɹ tə ɡoʊ ɑn. plænz wɝ mɛn tə bi fɑloʊɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz ɹizən tə tʃeɪnʒ ðɛm.

This time there was no real expectation of danger, so the Aes Sedai followed immediately, Elayne and Nynaeve as well. Farms dotted that treed area thickly, and a wandering shepherd or a young couple seeking privacy might need guidance away from seeing too much, but no Shadowsouled or Shadowrunner could know that clearing; only she, Elayne, and Nynaeve did, and they had not spoken in the choosing, for fear of eavesdroppers. Standing in the opening, Elayne gave Aviendha a questioning look, but Aviendha motioned her to go on. Plans were meant to be followed unless there was reason to change them.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝz bɪɡæn faɪlɪŋ sloʊli θɹu tə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, itʃ sʌɾənli ɪɹəsəluɾ əz ʃi əpɹoʊtʃt ðɪs θɪŋ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv, teɪkɪŋ ə bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛntɝd. ən əbɹʌpli, ðə pɹɪklɪŋ ɹɪtɝnd.

The Windfinders began filing slowly through to the clearing, each suddenly irresolute as she approached this thing she had never dreamed of, taking a breath before she entered. And abruptly, the prickling returned.

eɪvinhəz aɪz ɹoʊz tə ðə wɪndoʊz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹd. ɛniwʌn maɪt bi hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə waɪt skɹinz ʌv ɪntʃɹəkət ɹɔɾ aɪɝn ən pɪɹswɝk kɑɹvɪŋ. taɪlɪn hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə sɝvəns tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz wɪndoʊz, bʌɾ u wəd stɑp tɛslɪn, əɹ dʒoʊlin, ɔɹ. . . . sʌmθɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ lʊk haɪɝ, tə ðə doʊmz ən taʊɝz. nɛɹoʊ wɔks ɹɪŋ səm ə ðoʊz slɪm spaɪɹz, ən ɑn wʌn, vɛɹi haɪ, wɑz ə blæk ʃeɪp hæloʊd baɪ ə ʃɑɹp nɪmbəs fɹəm ðə sʌn bɪhaɪnd. ə mæn.

Aviendha's eyes rose to the windows overlooking the stableyard. Anyone might be hidden behind the white screens of intricate wrought iron and piercework carving. Tylin had ordered the servants to stay away from those windows, but who would stop Teslyn, or Joline, or. . . . Something made her look higher, to the domes and towers. Narrow walks ringed some of those slim spires, and on one, very high, was a black shape haloed by a sharp nimbus from the sun behind. A man.

hɝ bɹɛθ kɑt. nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɪz stæns, hænz ɑn ðə stoʊn ɹeɪlɪŋ, spoʊk ə deɪnʒɝ, jɛt ʃi nu hi wɑz ðə wʌn u pʊt ðət kɹɔlɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld wəd nɑt stæn ðəɹ sɪmpli wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌt ðət kɹitʃɝ, ðət ɡoʊləm. . . . aɪs fɔɹmd ɪn əɹ bɛli. hi kəd bi dʒʌst ə pæləs sɝvənt. hi kəd bi, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn noʊɪŋ fɪɹ.

Her breath caught. Nothing in his stance, hands on the stone railing, spoke of danger, yet she knew he was the one who put that crawling between her shoulder blades. One of the Shadowsouled would not stand there simply watching, but that creature, that gholam. . . . Ice formed in her belly. He could be just a palace servant. He could be, but she did not believe it. No shame in knowing fear.

æŋkʃəsli ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə wɪmən stɪl ɛdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪð æɡənaɪzɪŋ sloʊnəs. hæf ðə si foʊk wɝ ɡɔn, ən ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl weɪɾəd bɪhaɪn ðə ɹɛst wɪð ðə ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ fɝmli ɪn hænd, ðɛɹ oʊn əniz ət ðə pæsədʒ wɔɹɪŋ wɪð ɹɪzɛnmənt ðət ðə si foʊk wɪmən wɝ əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ fɝst. ɪf ʃi vɔɪst əɹ səspɪʃənz, ðə kɪnswɪmən ʃʊɹli wəd ɹʌn - mɪɹ mɛnʃən ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld dʒɹaɪd ðɛɹ maʊðz ən tɝn ðɛɹ baʊəlz tə wɔɾɝ - waɪl ðə wɪndfɪndɝz maɪt wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə kleɪm ðə boʊl stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ. wɪð ðɛm, ðə boʊl stʊɾ əbʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. bʌɾ oʊnli ə blaɪn ful stʊd skɹætʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf waɪl ə laɪən kɹɛpt ʌp ɑn ðə hɝd ʃi hæd bɪn sɛt tə ɡɑɹd. ʃi kɑt wʌn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ baɪ ə ɹɛd sɪlk sliv.

Anxiously she glanced at the women still edging through the gateway with agonizing slowness. Half the Sea Folk were gone, and the Knitting Circle waited behind the rest with the Shadowrunner firmly in hand, their own unease at the passage warring with resentment that the Sea Folk women were allowed to go first. If she voiced her suspicions, the Kinswomen surely would run - mere mention of the Shadowsouled dried their mouths and turned their bowels to water - while the Windfinders might well try to claim the Bowl straightaway. With them, the Bowl stood above anything else. But only a blind fool stood scratching herself while a lion crept up on the herd she had been set to guard. She caught one of the Atha'an Miere by a red silk sleeve.

"tɛl ɪleɪn - " ə feɪs laɪk smuð blæk stoʊn tɝn tə hɝ; ðə wʊmən sʌmhaʊ meɪd fʊl lɪps sim θɪn; hɝ aɪz wɝ blæk pɛbəlz, flæɾ ən hɑɹd. wʌt mɛsədʒ kəd ʃi sɛn ðət wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ daʊn ɔl ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ʃi fɪɹd fɹəm ðɛm? "tɛl ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv tə bi wɛɹi. tɛl əm ɛnəmiz ɔlweɪz kʌm wən jə list wɑn ðɛm. jə mʌst seɪ ðɪs tə hɝ, wɪθaʊt feɪl." ðə wɪndfɪndɝ nɑɾəd wɪð bɛɹli kənsild ɪmpeɪʃəns, bʌt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ eɪvinhə tə ɹilis əɹ bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛzɪɾənt weɪ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ.

"Tell Elayne - " A face like smooth black stone turned to her; the woman somehow made full lips seem thin; her eyes were black pebbles, flat and hard. What message could she send that would not bring down all the troubles she feared from them? "Tell Elayne and Nynaeve to be wary. Tell them enemies always come when you least want them. You must say this to her, without fail." The Windfinder nodded with barely concealed impatience, but surprisingly, she waited for Aviendha to release her before making her hesitant way through the gateway.

ðə wɔk ʌp ɑn ðə taʊɝ stʊɾ ɛmpti. eɪvinhə fɛl noʊ ɹɪlif. hi kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ. meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ daʊn tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. huɛvɝ i wɑz, wʌtɛvɝ i wɑz, hi wɑz deɪnʒɝəs; ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə dʌst-fʌnəl dænsɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ðə læs fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz hæd fɔɹmd ə skwɛɹ ɝaʊn ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ə ɡɑɹɾ u wəd bi læs tə liv, ən mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪspaɪz ðɛɹ sɔɹdz, ʃi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl ðət sʌmwʌn ðəɹ bɪsaɪdz hɝsɛlf nu ðə jus ə ʃɑɹp mɛɾəl. nɑt ðət ðeɪ wəɾ əv ɛni mɔɹ tʃæns əɡɛnst ə ɡoʊləm, əɹ wɝs, wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld, ðən ðə sɝvəns weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. əɹ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf.

The walk up on the tower stood empty. Aviendha felt no relief. He could be anywhere. Making his way down to the stableyard. Whoever he was, whatever he was, he was dangerous; this was not a dust-funnel dancing in her imagination. The last four Warders had formed a square around the gateway, a guard who would be last to leave, and much as she despised their swords, she was grateful that someone there besides herself knew the use of sharp metal. Not that they would have any more chance against a gholam, or worse, one of the Shadowsouled, than the servants waiting with the horses. Or than she herself.

ɡɹɪmli ʃi dʒɹu ðə paʊɝ, əntɪl ðə switnəs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɡɹu nɪɹ tə peɪn. ə hɛɹ bɪɑnd, ən peɪn wəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪkʌm blaɪndɪŋ æɡəni fəɹ ðə moʊməns niɾəd tə daɪ əɹ luz ði əbɪləɾi kəmplitli. wəd ðoʊz ʃʌflɪŋ wɪmən kwɪkən ðɛɹ fit! noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn filɪŋ fɪɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz vɛɹi mʌtʃ əfɹeɪd ðət hɝz wɑz peɪntəɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Grimly she drew the Power, until the sweetness of saidar grew near to pain. A hair beyond, and pain would almost become blinding agony for the moments needed to die or lose the ability completely. Would those shuffling women quicken their feet! No shame in feeling fear, but she was very much afraid that hers was painted on her face.


tʃæptɝ tu


CHAPTER 2

ənwivɪŋ


Unweaving

ɪleɪn stɛp tə wʌn saɪɾ əz sun əz ʃi wɑz θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt nɪneɪiv tʃɹæmpəld əkɹɔs ðə klɪɹɪŋ, kɪkɪŋ ʌp bɹaʊn ɡɹæshɑpɝz fɹəm ðə dɛd ɡɹæs ən piɹɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðət fəɹ ɛvəɾəns ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz. ʌv wʌn wɔɹɾɝ, ɛniweɪ. ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd bɝd flæʃt əkɹɔs ðə klɪɹɪŋ ən wɑz ɡɔn. nʌθɪŋ ɛls muvd ɪksɛp ðə sɪstɝz; ə skwɝəl bɑɹk sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə moʊsli lifləs tʃɹiz, ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns. tə ɪleɪn ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðoʊz θɹi cʊɾə pæs ðɪs weɪ wɪθaʊt livɪŋ pæðz əz waɪɾ əz ðət bɪhaɪnd nɪneɪiv, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɛni saɪn ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðəɹ əɾ ɔl.

Elayne stepped to one side as soon as she was through the gateway, but Nynaeve trampled across the clearing, kicking up brown grasshoppers from the dead grass and peering this way and that for evidence of the Warders. Of one Warder, anyway. A bright red bird flashed across the clearing and was gone. Nothing else moved except the sisters; a squirrel barked somewhere in the mostly leafless trees, and then there was silence. To Elayne it seemed impossible those three could have passed this way without leaving paths as wide as that behind Nynaeve, yet she could not make out any sign that they had been there at all.

ʃi sɛns bɝdʒɪt sʌmwɛɹ ɔf tə hɝ lɛft, ɹʌfli saʊθwɛst ʃi θɔt, ən filɪŋ kwaɪt kɑntɛnt, klɪɹli ɪn noʊ ɪmiɾiət deɪnʒɝ. kɛɝin, pɑɹɾ ʌv ə pɹətɛktɪv sɝkəl ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn sɝaɪðə ən ðə boʊl, kɑkt əɹ hɛɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf lɪsnɪŋ. əpɛɹənli hɝ sɪɛɹəl wɑz tə ðə saʊθist. wɪtʃ mɛn læn wɑz nɔɹθ. ɑdli ɪnʌf, nɔɹθ wɑz ðə dɝɛkʃən nɪneɪiv hæd sɛɾəld daʊn tə wɑtʃ, ɔl ðə waɪl mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. pɝhæps biɪŋ mɛɹid hæd kɹieɪɾəd səm sɛns ə hɪm ɪn hɝ. mɔɹ laɪkli, ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ə tʃɹæk ðəɾ ɪskeɪpt ɪleɪn. nɪneɪiv wɑz əz skɪld ət wʊdskɹæft əz ʃi wɑz wɪð ɝbz.

She sensed Birgitte somewhere off to her left, roughly southwest she thought, and feeling quite content, clearly in no immediate danger. Careane, part of a protective circle gathered around Sareitha and the Bowl, cocked her head almost as if listening. Apparently her Cieryl was to the southeast. Which meant Lan was north. Oddly enough, north was the direction Nynaeve had settled down to watch, all the while muttering under her breath. Perhaps being married had created some sense of him in her. More likely, she had noticed a track that escaped Elayne. Nynaeve was as skilled at woodscraft as she was with herbs.

fɹəm wɛɹ ɪleɪn stʊɾ ət fɝst, eɪvinhə wɑz klɪɹli vɪzəbəl θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə pæləs ɹuftɑps əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ən æmbʊʃ. baɪ hɝ stæns, ʃi cʊɾə bɪn kæɹiɪŋ spɪɹz, ɹɛɾi tə lip ɪndə bæɾəl ɪn əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs. ʃi meɪɾ ɪleɪn smaɪl, haɪɾɪŋ haʊ dɪstʃɹɛst ʃi wɑz əbaʊɾ əɹ pɹɑbləmz wɪð ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, soʊ mʌtʃ bɹeɪvɝ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf. bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp wɝiɪŋ. eɪvinhə wɑz bɹeɪv, ən noʊ wʌn ɪleɪn nu wɑz bɛɾɝ eɪbəl tə kip əɹ hɛd. ʃi ɔlsoʊ maɪt dɪsaɪd ðət dʒiɾoʊ ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə faɪt wən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns ɪksɛpt ɪn ɹʌnɪŋ. ðə laɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊn soʊ bɹaɪtli ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ʃi kəd nɑt dʒɹɔ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ɪf wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən dɪɾ əpɪɹ. . . .

From where Elayne stood at first, Aviendha was clearly visible through the gateway, studying the palace rooftops as if she expected an ambush. By her stance, she could have been carrying spears, ready to leap into battle in her riding dress. She made Elayne smile, hiding how distressed she was about her problems with the gateway, so much braver than she herself. But at the same time she could not help worrying. Aviendha was brave, and no one Elayne knew was better able to keep her head. She also might decide that ji'e'toh required her to fight when there was no chance except in running. The light around her shone so brightly it was obvious she could not draw much more of saidar. If one of the Forsaken did appear. . . .

aɪ ʃʊɾə steɪd wɪð hɝ. ɪleɪn ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ðə θɔɾ ɪmiɾiətli. wʌtɛvɝ ɪkskjus ʃi ɡeɪv, eɪvinhə wəd noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ, ən ʃi wɑz tʌtʃi əz ə mæn, səmtaɪmz. moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ɪspɛʃli wən ɪt bɔɹ əpɑn əɹ ɑnɝ. wɪð ə saɪ, ɪleɪn lɛt ði æθɑn maɪɹ kɹaʊɾ əɹ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ əz ðeɪ faɪl θɹu. ʃi steɪd kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ɛni ʃaʊɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ðoʊ. kloʊs ɪnʌf tə lip tə eɪvinhəz eɪɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. ən fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɹizən.

I should have stayed with her. Elayne rejected the thought immediately. Whatever excuse she gave, Aviendha would know the truth, and she was touchy as a man, sometimes. Most of the time. Especially when it bore upon her honor. With a sigh, Elayne let the Atha'an Miere crowd her farther from the gateway as they filed through. She stayed close enough to hear any shout on the other side, though. Close enough to leap to Aviendha's aid in a heartbeat. And for another reason.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝz keɪm θɹu ɪn ɔɹɾɝ ə ɹæŋk, stʃɹaɪvɪŋ tə kip ðɛɹ feɪsəz smuð, bʌɾ ivən ɹɪneɪl ɹɪlæks taɪt ʃoʊldɝz wʌns əɹ bɛɹ fit wɝ biɾɪŋ daʊn ðə tɔl bɹaʊn ɡɹæs. səm ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl ʃɪvɝ, kwɪkli səpɹɛst, əɹ ɡlæns bæk wɪð ɹaʊn aɪz ət ði oʊpənɪŋ hæŋɪŋ ɪn mɪdɛɹ. wʌn ən ɔl, ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪleɪn səspɪʃəsli əz ðeɪ stɛp baɪ hɝ, ən tu əɹ θɹi oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz, pɝhæps tə æsk wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, pɝhæps tə æsk - əɹ tɛl - hɝ tə muv. ʃi wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæd ðət ðeɪ hɝiɾ ɑn ɪn oʊbiɾiəns tə ɹɪneɪlz kɝɾ ɝdʒɪŋz. ðeɪ wəɾ əv ðɛɹ tʃæns tə tɛl ɛɛs sədaɪ wʌt tə də sun ɪnʌf; ɪt dɪd nɑɾ əv tə stɑɹt wɪð hɝ.

The Windfinders came through in order of rank, striving to keep their faces smooth, but even Renaile relaxed tight shoulders once her bare feet were beating down the tall brown grass. Some gave a little shiver, quickly suppressed, or glanced back with round eyes at the opening hanging in midair. One and all, they stared at Elayne suspiciously as they stepped by her, and two or three opened their mouths, perhaps to ask what she was doing, perhaps to ask - or tell - her to move. She was just as glad that they hurried on in obedience to Renaile's curt urgings. They would have their chance to tell Aes Sedai what to do soon enough; it did not have to start with her.

ðət θɔt meɪɾ əɹ stʌmək sɪŋk, ən ðə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm meɪɾ əɹ ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd. ðeɪ hæd ðə nɑlədʒ ʌv wɛðɝ tə juz ðə boʊl pɹɑpɝli, jɛɾ ivən ɹɪneɪl əɡɹid - ɪf ɹɪlʌktənli - ðət ðə mɔɹ paʊɝ dɝɛktəd θɹu ðə boʊl, ðə bɛɾɝ ðə tʃænsəz ə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə hil ðə wɛðɝ. ɪt mʌs bi dɝɛktəd wɪð ə pɹisɪʒən ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn wʊmən əloʊn əɹ ə sɝkəl, ðoʊ. ə fʊl sɝkəl ə θɝtin ɪt hæd tə bi. ðət θɝtin sɝɾənli wəɾ ɪnklud nɪneɪiv ən eɪvinhə ən ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf, ən pɹɑbli ə fju ʌv ðə kɪn, bʌt ɹɪneɪl pleɪnli ɪntɛndəd tə dʒʌmp ɑn ðə pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən ðət sɛd ðeɪ wəd bi əlaʊd tə lɝn ɛni əbɪləɾiz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd titʃ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hæd bɪn ðə fɝst, ən fɔɹmɪŋ ə sɝkəl wəd bi ðə sɛkənd. ə wʌndɝ ʃi hæd nɑt bɹɔɾ ɛvɹi wɪndfɪndɝ ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ. ɪmædʒən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dil wɪð θɹi əɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd ə ðiz wɪmən! ɪleɪn ɔfɝɾ ə smɔl pɹɛɹ ə θæŋks ðət ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli twɛnti.

That thought made her stomach sink, and the number of them made her shake her head. They had the knowledge of weather to use the Bowl properly, yet even Renaile agreed - if reluctantly - that the more Power directed through the Bowl, the better the chances of being able to heal the weather. It must be directed with a precision impossible except for one woman alone or a circle, though. A full circle of thirteen it had to be. That thirteen certainly would include Nynaeve and Aviendha and Elayne herself, and probably a few of the Kin, but Renaile plainly intended to jump on the part of the bargain that said they would be allowed to learn any abilities the Aes Sedai could teach. The gateway had been the first, and forming a circle would be the second. A wonder she had not brought every Windfinder in the harbor. Imagine trying to deal with three or four hundred of these women! Elayne offered a small prayer of thanks that there were only twenty.

ʃi wɑz nɑt stændɪŋ ðəɹ tə kaʊn ðɛm, ðoʊ. əz itʃ wɪndfɪndɝ pæst, bɛɹli mɔɹ ðən ə peɪs əweɪ, ʃi lɛt hɝsɛlf fil ðə wʊmənz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. ɝliɝ ðəɹ hæd bɪn taɪm tə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊnli ə hændfʊl, wʌt wɪð ɔl ðə tʃɹʌbəl ə kənvɪnsɪŋ ɹɪneɪl tə kʌm əɾ ɔl. əpɛɹənli ətʃivɪŋ ɹæŋk əmʌŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð iðɝ eɪdʒ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ; ɹɪneɪl wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ivən ɪn ðə fɝs θɹi əɹ fɔɹ, waɪl wʌn wʊmən təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪɹ, sɛnaɪn, hæd wɛðɝd tʃiks ən θɪkli ɡɹeɪd hɛɹ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, baɪ ðə mɑɹks ɪn əɹ ɪɹz ɪt sim ðət sɛnaɪn maɪt wʌns əv wɔɹn mɔɹ ðən sɪks ɪɹɪŋz, ən θɪkɝ wʌnz ðən ʃi dɪd naʊ.

She was not standing there to count them, though. As each Windfinder passed, barely more than a pace away, she let herself feel the woman's strength in the Power. Earlier there had been time to get close enough to only a handful, what with all the trouble of convincing Renaile to come at all. Apparently achieving rank among the Windfinders had nothing to do with either age or strength; Renaile was far from the strongest even in the first three or four, while one woman toward the rear, Senine, had weathered cheeks and thickly grayed hair. Strangely, by the marks in her ears it seemed that Senine might once have worn more than six earrings, and thicker ones than she did now.

ɪleɪn sɔɹɾɪd ən stɔɹɾ əweɪ feɪsəz ən ðə neɪmz ʃi nu wɪð ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɛns ə kəmpleɪsənsi. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz maɪɾ əv sɪkjʊɹɾ ən ʌpɝ hæn ə sɔɹts, ən ʃi ən nɪneɪiv maɪt bi ɪn dip tʃɹʌbəl, vɛɹi dip, wɪð boʊθ ɛɡwin ən ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ wʌns ðə tɝmz ə ðɛɹ bɑɹɡən bɪkeɪm noʊn, bʌt nʌn ə ðiz wɪmən wəd stæn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli haɪ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. sɝɾənli nɑt loʊ, bʌt nɑt haɪ. ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf nɑt tə fil smʌɡ - ɪt tʃeɪnʒd nʌθɪŋ ɪn wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɹid - jɛɾ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə. ðiz wɝ ðə bɛs ði æθɑn kəd pɹədus, æftɝ ɔl. hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ɛniweɪ. ən ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm, fɹəm kɹɪn, wɪð əɹ stoʊni blæk stɛɹ, tə ɹɪneɪl hɝsɛlf, wʊɾə lɪsənd wən ʃi spoʊk ən stʊd wən ʃi ɛntɝɾ ə ɹum. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ðeɪ ʃʊd.

Elayne sorted and stored away faces and the names she knew with a growing sense of complacency. The Windfinders might have secured an upper hand of sorts, and she and Nynaeve might be in deep trouble, very deep, with both Egwene and the Hall of the Tower once the terms of their bargain became known, but none of these women would stand particularly high among Aes Sedai. Certainly not low, but not high. She told herself not to feel smug - it changed nothing in what they had agreed - yet it was very hard not to. These were the best the Atha'an could produce, after all. Here in Ebou Dar, anyway. And if they had been Aes Sedai, every one of them, from Kurin, with her stony black stare, to Renaile herself, would have listened when she spoke and stood when she entered a room. If they were Aes Sedai and behaving as they should.

ən ðən ði ɛn ə ðə laɪn əpɪɹd, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ə jʌŋ wɪndfɪndɝ ɔf wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ ʃɪps pæs hɝ, ə ɹaʊnd-tʃikt wʊmən kɔld ɹeɪnɪn, ɪn pleɪn blu sɪlks, wɪð bɛɹli ə hæf-dʌzən ɔɹnəməns hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əɹ noʊz tʃeɪn. ðə tu əpɹɛntəsɪz, bɔɪɪʃli slɪm tɑlɑn ən bɪɡ-aɪd mɛtʃɹə, skɝiɾ ət ðə vɛɹi teɪl wɪð hɛɹiɾ ɪkspɹɛʃənz. ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ɝn ðə noʊz ɹɪŋ jɛt, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə tʃeɪn, ən oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl θɪn ɡoʊld ɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə lɛft ɪɹ bæləns ðə θɹi ɪn ðə ɹaɪt. hɝ aɪz fɑloʊd ðə θɹi ʌv əm dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə stɛɹɪŋ. pɝhæps nɑt ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪt, ət ðæt.

And then the end of the line appeared, and she gave a start as a young Windfinder off one of the smaller ships passed her, a round-cheeked woman called Rainyn, in plain blue silks, with barely a half-dozen ornaments hanging from her nose chain. The two apprentices, boyishly slim Talaan and big-eyed Metarra, scurried at the very tail with harried expressions. They had not earned the nose ring yet, much less the chain, and only a single thin gold earring in the left ear balanced the three in the right. Her eyes followed the three of them just short of staring. Perhaps not short of it, at that.

ði æθɑn maɪɹ klʌstɝd wɪð ɹɪneɪl əɡɛn, moʊst, laɪk hɝ, ɡlɛɹɪŋ hʌŋɡɹəli ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə boʊl. ðə læs θɹi wɪmən stʊɾ ət ðə ɹɪɹ, ði əpɹɛntəsɪz wɪð ði ɛɹ ə ðoʊz ənsɝɾən wɛðɝ ðeɪ hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə bi ðəɹ əɾ ɔl, ɹeɪnɪn foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɪn ɪməteɪʃən ə ɹɪneɪl, jɛt duɪŋ lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ tu. ðə wɪndfɪndɝ ɑn ə dɑɹɾɝ, ðə list ə ðə si foʊk vɛsəlz, laɪkli sɛldəm faʊn hɝsɛlf ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə hɝ klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. ɹeɪnɪn wɑz izəli əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ləleɪn əɹ ɹoʊmændə, ən mɛtʃɹə ɑn ə lɛvəl wɪð ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf, waɪl tɑlɑn. . . . tɑlɑn, soʊ mik ɪn əɹ ɹɛd lɪnən blaʊs, wɪð aɪz ðət sim pɝmənənli daʊnkæst, keɪm vɛɹi kloʊs tə nɪneɪiv. vɛɹi kloʊs. mɔɹ, ɪleɪn nu ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɑt jɛt ɹitʃt əɹ fʊl pətɛnʃəl, ən niðɝ hæd nɪneɪiv. haʊ kloʊs wɝ mɛtʃɹə ən tɑlɑn? ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn əkʌstəm tə noʊɪŋ ðəɾ oʊnli nɪneɪiv ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʃi. wɛl, ɛɡwin, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹst, ən əɹ oʊn pətɛnʃəl, ən eɪvinhəz, mætʃt ɛɡwinz. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ kəmpleɪsənsi, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf ɹufəli. lini wʊɾə sɛɾ ɪt wɑz wʌt ʃi dɪzɝv fəɹ teɪkɪŋ θɪŋz fəɹ ɡɹæntəd.

The Atha'an Miere clustered with Renaile again, most, like her, glaring hungrily at the Aes Sedai and the Bowl. The last three women stood at the rear, the apprentices with the air of those uncertain whether they had a right to be there at all, Rainyn folding her arms in imitation of Renaile, yet doing little better than the other two. The Windfinder on a darter, the least of the Sea Folk vessels, likely seldom found herself in company with the Windfinder to her clan Wavemistress, not to mention the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships. Rainyn was easily as strong as Lelaine or Romanda, and Metarra on a level with Elayne herself, while Talaan. . . . Talaan, so meek in her red linen blouse, with eyes that seemed permanently downcast, came very close to Nynaeve. Very close. More, Elayne knew she herself had not yet reached her full potential, and neither had Nynaeve. How close were Metarra and Talaan? She had grown accustomed to knowing that only Nynaeve and the Forsaken were stronger than she. Well, Egwene, but she had been forced, and her own potential, and Aviendha's, matched Egwene's. So much for complacency, she told herself ruefully. Lini would have said it was what she deserved for taking things for granted.

læfɪŋ sɔfli ət hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn tɝn bæk tə tʃɛk ɑn eɪvinhə, bʌt ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl stʊd ɹuɾəd tə wʌn spɑɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, twɪtʃɪŋ ət koʊl stɛɹz fɹəm kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə. ɔl bʌt sumeɪkoʊ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt muv əweɪ iðɝ fəɹ ɔl ðət ʃi hæd mɛt ðə sɪstɝz' ɡeɪzəz. kɝstʃən əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə bɝst ɪndə tɪɹz.

Laughing softly at herself, Elayne turned back to check on Aviendha, but the Knitting Circle stood rooted to one spot in front of the gateway, twitching at cold stares from Careane and Sareitha. All but Sumeko, and she did not move away either for all that she had met the sisters' gazes. Kirstian appeared ready to burst into tears.

səpɹɛsɪŋ ə saɪ, ɪleɪn hɝɾɪd ðə kɪnswɪmən aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə steɪbəl foʊk weɪɾɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz θɹu. ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɛn əlɔŋ laɪk ʃip - ʃi wɑz ðə ʃɛpɝd, mɛɝɪlɪl ən ðə ɹɛs ðə wʊlvz - ən ðeɪ wʊɾə muv fæstɝ ɪf nɑt fəɹ ɪspæn.

Suppressing a sigh, Elayne herded the Kinswomen out of the way of the stable folk waiting to bring the horses through. The Knitting Circle went along like sheep - she was the shepherd, Merilille and the rest the wolves - and they would have moved faster if not for Ispan.

feɪmɛl, wʌn ʌv oʊnli fɔɹ əmʌŋ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɪθaʊɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ əɹ waɪɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ən ɪldeɪs, ə fɪɹs-aɪd wʊmən wən ʃi wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hɛld ɪspæn baɪ ði ɑɹmz. ðeɪ kəd nɑt sim tə dɪsaɪd bɪtwin hoʊldɪŋ əɹ fɝmli ɪnʌf tə kip əɹ əpɹaɪɾ ən nɑt klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ tu taɪtli, wɪð ðə ɹɪzʌl ðət ðə blæk sɪstɝ muvd ɪn ə bɑbɪŋ fæʃən, sæɡɪŋ hæfweɪ tə hɝ niz wən ðeɪ lusən ðɛɹ ɡɹɪps, ðən pʊl bæk ʌp dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɛl kəmplitli.

Famelle, one of only four among the Knitting Circle without a touch of gray or white in her hair, and Eldase, a fierce-eyed woman when she was not looking at an Aes Sedai, held Ispan by the arms. They could not seem to decide between holding her firmly enough to keep her upright and not clutching her too tightly, with the result that the Black sister moved in a bobbing fashion, sagging halfway to her knees when they loosened their grips, then pulled back up just before she fell completely.

"fɝɡɪv mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ," feɪmɛl kɛp mɝmɝɪŋ tə ɪspæn wɪð ə feɪn tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛnt. "oʊ, aɪm sɑɹi, ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɪldeɪs wɪnst ən ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl moʊn ɛvɹi taɪm ɪspæn stʌmbəld. dʒʌst əz ɪf ɪspæn hæd nɑt hɛlp mɝɾɝ tu ʌv ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu haʊ mɛni ʌðɝz. ðeɪ wɝ fʌsɪŋ oʊvɝ ə wʊmən u wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. ðə kɪlɪŋz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ðəɾ ɪspæn hæd kənspaɪɝɾ ət wɝ ɪnʌf tə kəndɛm əɹ baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz.

"Forgive me, Aes Sedai," Famelle kept murmuring to Ispan with a faint Taraboner accent. "Oh, I am sorry, Aes Sedai." Eldase winced and gave a little moan every time Ispan stumbled. Just as if Ispan had not helped murder two of their number and the Light alone knew how many others. They were fussing over a woman who was going to die. The killings in the White Tower that Ispan had conspired at were enough to condemn her by themselves.

"teɪk əɹ oʊvɝ ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ," ɪleɪn toʊl ðɛm, weɪvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ðeɪ oʊbeɪd, bɑbɪŋ kɝtsiz ən nɪɹli dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪspæn, mɝmɝɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz tə ɪleɪn ən tə ðə hʊɾɪd pɹɪznɝ. ɹin ən ðə ɹɛst skɝiɾ əlɔŋ, æŋkʃəsli aɪɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz ɝaʊn mɛɝɪlɪl.

"Take her over there somewhere," Elayne told them, waving away from the gateway into the clearing. They obeyed, bobbing curtsies and nearly dropping Ispan, murmuring apologies to Elayne and to the hooded prisoner. Reanne and the rest scurried along, anxiously eyeing the sisters around Merilille.

ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli ðə wɔɹ ʌv ɡlɛɹz stɑɹɾəd ʌp əɡɛn, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðə kɪnswɪmən, ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ən ði æθɑn maɪɹ əɾ ɛnibəɾi ðɛɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn. ɪleɪn klæmpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌt. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə ʃaʊɾ ət ðɛm. nɪneɪiv ɔlweɪz ɡɑt bɛɾɝ ɹɪzʌls wɪð jɛlz, ɛniweɪ. bʌt ʃi dɪd wɑnə ʃeɪk səm sɛns ɪndə ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm, ʃeɪk əm əntɪl ðɛɹ tiθ ɹæɾəld. ɪnkluɾɪŋ nɪneɪiv, hu wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɔɹɡənaɪzd ɪnstɛɾ ə stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz. bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn ɹænd u wɑz gɑnə daɪ ənlɛs ʃi kəd faɪn ə weɪ tə seɪv hɪm?

Almost immediately the war of glares started up again, the Aes Sedai at the Kinswomen, the Knitting Circle at the Windfinders, and the Atha'an Miere at anybody their eyes fell on.
