Elayne clamped her teeth shut. She was not going to shout at them. Nynaeve always got better results with yells, anyway. But she did want to shake some sense into every one of them, shake them until their teeth rattled. Including Nynaeve, who was supposed to be getting everyone organized instead of staring into the trees. But what if it had been Rand who was going to die unless she could find a way to save him?

sʌɾənli tɪɹz tʃɹɛmbəld ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə fɔlɪŋ, stɪŋɪŋ əɹ aɪz. ɹænd wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃi kəd də tə stɑp ɪt. pil ði æpəl ɪn jəɹ hænd, ɡɝl, nɑt ðə wʌn ɑn ðə tʃɹi, liniz θɪn vɔɪs sim tə wɪspɝ ɪn əɹ ɪɹ. tɪɹz ɑɹ fəɹ æftɝ; ðeɪ dʒʌst weɪs taɪm bɪfɔɹ.

Suddenly tears trembled on the edge of falling, stinging her eyes. Rand was going to die, and there was nothing she could do to stop it. Peel the apple in your hand, girl, not the one on the tree, Lini's thin voice seemed to whisper in her ear. Tears are for after; they just waste time before.

"θæŋk ju, lini," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. hɝ oʊl nɝs wɑz ən ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ wʊmən səmtaɪmz, nɛvɝ ædmɪɾɪŋ ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz hæd ɹɪli ɡɹoʊn ʌp, bʌɾ əɹ ædvaɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz ɡʊd. dʒʌs kəz nɪneɪiv wɑz slækɪŋ əɹ duɾiz wɑz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɪleɪn tə slæk hɝz.

"Thank you, Lini," Elayne murmured. Her old nurse was an irritating woman sometimes, never admitting that any of her charges had really grown up, but her advice was always good. Just because Nynaeve was slacking her duties was no reason for Elayne to slack hers.

sɝvəns hæd stɑɹɾəd tʃɹɑɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz θɹu ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə hilz ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. nʌn ə ðoʊz fɝst ænəməlz kæɹiɾ ɛniθɪŋ soʊ fɹɪvələs əz kloʊðz. ðeɪ kəd wɔk ɪf ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz niɾəd tə bi əbændən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən wɛɹ wʌt ðeɪ stʊɾ ʌp ɪn ɪf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk ænəməlz hæd tə bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd, bʌt wʌt wɑz ɑn ðoʊz fɝs hɔɹsəz kəd nɑt bi lɛft fəɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ɪleɪn moʊʃən ðə lɛðɝ-tʃikt wʊmən liɾɪŋ ðə vɛɹi fɝs tə fɑloʊ hɝ əsaɪd, aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ði ʌðɝz.

Servants had started trotting horses through right on the heels of the Knitting Circle, beginning with the packhorses. None of those first animals carried anything so frivolous as clothes. They could walk if the riding horses needed to be abandoned on the other side of the gateway, and wear what they stood up in if the rest of the pack animals had to be left behind, but what was on those first horses could not be left for the Forsaken. Elayne motioned the leather-cheeked woman leading the very first to follow her aside, out of the way of the others.

əntiɪŋ ən tɔsɪŋ bæk ðə stɪf kænvəs kʌvɝ ɑn wʌn ə ðə waɪd wɪkɝ pænɪɝz ɹɪvild ə ɡɹeɪt hip ʌv wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ɹʌbɪʃ stʌft ɪn ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ, ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə tɑp, səm ʌv ɪt ɹæpt ɪn klɔθ ðət wɑz fɔlɪŋ tə pisəz. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt pɹɑbli wɑz ɹʌbɪʃ. ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn sɔɹɾɪŋ. ə ɹʌstəd bɹɛstpleɪt kwɪkli wɛn ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd, əlɔŋ wɪð ə bɹoʊkən teɪbəl lɛɡ, ə kɹæk plæɾɝ, ə bædli dɛntɪd pjuɾɝ pɪtʃɝ, ən ə boʊlt ə ɹɑɾɪd, ʌnaɪɾentəfaɪəbəl klɔθ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɹoʊk əpɑɹɾ ɪn əɹ hænz.

Untying and tossing back the stiff canvas cover on one of the wide wicker panniers revealed a great heap of what appeared to be rubbish stuffed in every which way, right up to the top, some of it wrapped in cloth that was falling to pieces. The greater part of it probably was rubbish. Embracing saidar, Elayne began sorting. A rusted breastplate quickly went onto the ground, along with a broken table leg, a cracked platter, a badly dented pewter pitcher, and a bolt of rotted, unidentifiable cloth that almost broke apart in her hands.

ðə stɔɹɹum wɛɹ ðeɪ faʊn ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz hæd bɪn stʌft fʊl, θɪŋz ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn ɑn ə ɹɛfjus hip dʒʌmbəld ɪn wɪð mɔɹ ɑbʒɛkts ə ðə paʊɝ ðən dʒʌs ðə boʊl, səm ɪn biɾəl-ɹɪdəld kæsks əɹ tʃɛsts, səm kɛɹləsli stækt. fəɹ hʌnʒɹədz ən hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz ðə kɪn hæd hɪɾən əweɪ ɔl θɪŋz ðeɪ faʊn ðət wɝ kənɛktəd tə ðə paʊɝ, fɪɹfəl ə juzɪŋ əm ən fɪɹfəl ə dɪlɪvɝɪŋ əm tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. əntɪl ðət vɛɹi mɔɹnɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs tʃæns ɪleɪn hæd hæd tə si wʌt wɑz wɝθ kipɪŋ. ðə laɪt sɛn ðət ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən əweɪ wɪð ɛniθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt; ðeɪ hæd teɪkən sʌm, bʌt sɝɾənli lɛs ðən ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv wʌt ðə ɹum hæd hɛld, ɹʌbɪʃ ɪnkluɾəd. ðə laɪt sɛnd ʃi faʊn sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd juz. pipəl hæd daɪd tə bɹɪŋ ðiz θɪŋz aʊɾ ə ðə ɹæhəd.

The storeroom where they found the Bowl of the Winds had been stuffed full, things that should have been on a refuse heap jumbled in with more objects of the Power than just the Bowl, some in beetle-riddled casks or chests, some carelessly stacked. For hundreds and hundreds of years the Kin had hidden away all things they found that were connected to the Power, fearful of using them and fearful of delivering them to Aes Sedai. Until that very morning. This was the first chance Elayne had had to see what was worth keeping. The Light send that the Darkfriends had not gotten away with anything important; they had taken some, but certainly less than a quarter of what the room had held, rubbish included. The Light send she found something they could use. People had died to bring these things out of the Rahad.

ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃænəl, dʒʌs hɛl ðə paʊɝ əz ʃi lɪftəɾ itʃ aɪɾəm. ə tʃɪp kleɪ kʌp, θɹi bɹoʊkən pleɪts, ə tʃaɪlz mɔθ-iɾən dʒɹɛs, ən ən oʊl but wɪð ə hoʊl wɔɹn θɹu ðə saɪɾ ɔl fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ə stoʊn kɑɹvɪŋ ə lɪɾəl lɑɹdʒɝ ðən əɹ hænd - ɪt fɛlt laɪk stoʊn; ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə kɑɹvɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzækli lʊk kɑɹvd, fəɹ səm ɹizən - ɔl dip blu kɝvz veɪɡli laɪk ɹuts. ɪt sim tə wɔɹm feɪnli əɾ əɹ tʌtʃ; ɪt hɛld ə . . . ɹɛzənəns . . . tə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ðət wɑz ðə kloʊsəst wɝd ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv. wʌɾ ɪt wɑz mɛn tə du, ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt. ɪt wɛn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ, əweɪ fɹəm ðə paɪl ə ɹʌbɪʃ.

She did not channel, just held the Power as she lifted each item. A chipped clay cup, three broken plates, a child's moth-eaten dress, and an old boot with a hole worn through the side all fell to the ground. A stone carving a little larger than her hand - it felt like stone; it might have been a carving, though it did not exactly look carved, for some reason - all deep blue curves vaguely like roots. It seemed to warm faintly at her touch; it held a . . . resonance . . . to saidar. That was the closest word she could think of. What it was meant to do, she had no idea, but it was a ter'angreal without any doubt. It went on the other side of her, away from the pile of rubbish.

ðə hip ə ɹɛfjus kəntɪnjud tə ɡɹoʊ, bʌt soʊ dɪd ði ʌðɝ, ɪf mɔɹ sloʊli, θɪŋz ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ ɪn kɑmən ɪksɛp ðə feɪnt wɔɹmθ ən ðə sɛns ʌv ɛkoʊɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ə smɔl bɑks ðət fɛlt laɪk aɪvɝi, kʌvɝɾ ɪn weɪvɝɪŋ ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin stʃɹaɪps; ʃi sɛɾ ɪt daʊn kɛɹfəli wɪθaʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ ðə hɪnʒd lɪd. jə kəd nɛvɝ tɛl wʌt maɪt tʃɹɪɡɝ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ə blæk ɹɑd noʊ θɪkɝ ðən əɹ lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ, ə peɪs ɪn lɛŋθ, stɪf jɛt soʊ flɛksəbəl ʃi θɔt ʃi cʊɾə dʌbəld ɪɾ ɪndə ə sɝkəl. ə taɪni stɑpɝd vaɪəl ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn kɹɪstəl, wɪð ə dɑɹk ɹɛd lɪkwəɾ ɪnsaɪd. ðə fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə staʊt, bɪɹɾəd mæn wɪð ə dʒɑli smaɪl, hoʊldɪŋ ə bʊk; tu fit tɔl, ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən bɹɑnz ən tʊk boʊθ ə hɝ hænz tə muv. ʌðɝ θɪŋz. moʊst wɑz tʃɹæʃ, ðoʊ. ən nʌn wɑz wʌt ʃi tʃɹuli wɑntəd. nɑt jɛt.

The heap of refuse continued to grow, but so did the other, if more slowly, things that had nothing in common except the faint warmth and the sense of echoing the Power. A small box that felt like ivory, covered in wavering red and green stripes; she set it down carefully without opening the hinged lid. You could never tell what might trigger a ter'angreal. A black rod no thicker than her little finger, a pace in length, stiff yet so flexible she thought she could have doubled it into a circle. A tiny stoppered vial that might have been crystal, with a dark red liquid inside. The figure of a stout, bearded man with a jolly smile, holding a book; two feet tall, it appeared to be age-darkened bronze and took both of her hands to move. Other things. Most was trash, though. And none was what she truly wanted. Not yet.

"ɪz ðɪs ðə taɪm tə bi duɪŋ ðæt?" nɪneɪiv æskt. ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd heɪstəli fɹəm ðə smɔl klʌstɝ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ən ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hæn ɑn əɹ skɝt. "ðæt ɹɑd filz laɪk . . . peɪn," ʃi mʌɾɝd. ðə hɑɹd-feɪst wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ ðə pækhɔɹsəz hɛd blɪŋkt ət ðə ɹɑɾ ən ɛdʒd əweɪ.

"Is this the time to be doing that?" Nynaeve asked. She straightened hastily from the small cluster of ter'angreal, grimacing and rubbing her hand on her skirt. "That rod feels like . . . pain," she muttered. The hard-faced woman holding the packhorse's head blinked at the rod and edged away.

ɪleɪn aɪd ðə ɹɑd - nɪneɪivz əkeɪʒənəl ɪmpɹɛʃənz əbaʊɾ ɑbʒɛkts ʃi tʌtʃt kəd bi jusfəl - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp sɔɹɾɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu mʌtʃ peɪn leɪtli tə niɾ ɛni mɔɹ, ʃʊɹli. nɑt ðət wʌt nɪneɪiv sɛnst wɑz ɔlweɪz ðət stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. ðə ɹɑd maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɛzənt wən ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə peɪn wɑz kɑzd wɪθaʊt biɪŋ ðə kɑz ɪn ɪtsɛlf. ðə pæniɝ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɛmpti; səm ʌv wʌt wɑz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔɹs wəɾ əv tə bi ʃɪftəd tə bæləns ðə weɪt. "ɪf ðɛɹz ən æŋɡɹil ɪn ðɪs sʌmwɛɹ, nɪneɪiv, aɪ wəd laɪk tə faɪn ɪt bɪfɔɹ mɑɡiɾin tæps wʌn ʌv əs ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ."

Elayne eyed the rod - Nynaeve's occasional impressions about objects she touched could be useful - but she did not stop sorting. There had been too much pain lately to need any more, surely. Not that what Nynaeve sensed was always that straightforward. The rod might have been present when a great deal of pain was caused without being the cause in itself. The pannier was almost empty; some of what was on the other side of the horse would have to be shifted to balance the weight. "If there's an angreal in this somewhere, Nynaeve, I would like to find it before Moghedien taps one of us on the shoulder."

nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli, bʌt ʃi pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə wɪkɝ bæskət.

Nynaeve grunted sourly, but she peered into the wicker basket.

dʒɹɑpɪŋ ənʌðɝ teɪbəl lɛɡ - ðət meɪd θɹi, nʌn ʌv wɪtʃ mætʃt - ɪleɪn spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ɔl ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz wɝ aʊt, ən ðə maʊns wɝ kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, naʊ, fɪlɪŋ ði oʊpən speɪs bɪtwin ðə tʃɹiz wɪð bʌsəl ən kənfjuʒən. mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlɹɛɾi sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, bɛɹli kənsilɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns tə bi ɔf, waɪl pɔl fʌs hɝidli wɪð əɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz sæɾəlbæɡz, bʌt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz.

Dropping another table leg - that made three, none of which matched - Elayne spared a glance for the clearing. All of the packhorses were out, and the mounts were coming through the gateway, now, filling the open space between the trees with bustle and confusion. Merilille and the other Aes Sedai already sat their saddles, barely concealing their impatience to be off, while Pol fussed hurriedly with her mistress's saddlebags, but the Windfinders.

ɡɹeɪsfəl əfʊt, ɡɹeɪsfəl ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɪps, ðeɪ wɝ ənjuz tə hɔɹsəz. ɹɪneɪl wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə maʊn fɹəm ðə ɹɔŋ saɪd, ən ðə dʒɛntəl beɪ mɛɹ tʃoʊzən fəɹ əɹ dænst sloʊ sɝkəlz ɝaʊn ðə lɪvɹid mæn u wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə bɹaɪɾəl wɪð wʌn hænd waɪl tʌɡɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən wɪð ði ʌðɝ ən veɪnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɝɛk ðə wɪndfɪndɝ. tu ʌv ðə steɪbəlwɪmən wɝ ətɛmptɪŋ tə hɔɪs dɔɹəl, hu sɝv ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn soʊmɝɪn, ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl, waɪl ə θɝd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪz hɛd, wɔɹ ðə taɪt feɪs ə sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə læf. ɹeɪnɪn wɑz ɑn ðə bæk ʌv ə lɛɡi bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ, bʌt sʌmhaʊ wɪθaʊɾ iðɝ fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəps əɹ ðə ɹeɪnz ɪn əɹ hænz ən hævɪŋ kənsɪɾɝəbəl tʃɹʌbəl faɪndɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ən ðoʊz θɹi sim tə bi hævɪŋ ði iziəs taɪm ʌv ɪt. hɔɹsəz wɪniɾ ən dænst ən ɹoʊl ðɛɹ aɪz, ən wɪndfɪndɝz ʃaʊɾəd kɝsɪz ɪn vɔɪsəz ðət cʊɾə bɪn hɝɾ oʊvɝ ə ɡeɪl. wʌn ə ðɛm nɑkt ə sɝvɪŋ mæn flæt wɪð əɹ fɪst, ən θɹi mɔɹ steɪbəl foʊk wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ maʊns ðət hæd ɡɑɾən fɹi.

Graceful afoot, graceful on their ships, they were unused to horses. Renaile was trying to mount from the wrong side, and the gentle bay mare chosen for her danced slow circles around the liveried man who was gripping the bridle with one hand while tugging his hair in frustration with the other and vainly trying to correct the Windfinder. Two of the stablewomen were attempting to hoist Dorile, who served the Wavemistress of Clan Somarin, into her saddle, while a third, holding the gray's head, wore the tight face of someone trying not to laugh. Rainyn was on the back of a leggy brown gelding, but somehow without either foot in the stirrups or the reins in her hands and having considerable trouble finding any of them. And those three seemed to be having the easiest time of it. Horses whinnied and danced and rolled their eyes, and Windfinders shouted curses in voices that could have been heard over a gale. One of them knocked a serving man flat with her fist, and three more stable folk were trying to catch mounts that had gotten free.

ðəɹ wɑz ɔlsoʊ wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə si, ɪf nɪneɪiv wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kipɪŋ əɹ pɹaɪvət wɑtʃ. læn stʊd baɪ hɪz blæk wɔɹhɔɹs, mændɑɹb, dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɡeɪz bɪtwin ðə tʃɹilaɪn, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən nɪneɪiv. bɝdʒɪt keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə wʊdz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, sɪɛɹəl, tʃɹɑɾəd fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt wɪð noʊ sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ aʊt ðəɹ tə θɹɛɾən əɹ ɪnkənvinjəns ðɛm.

There was also what she had expected to see, if Nynaeve was no longer keeping her private watch. Lan stood by his black warhorse, Mandarb, dividing his gaze between the treeline, the gateway, and Nynaeve. Birgitte came striding out of the woods shaking her head, and a moment later, Cieryl, trotted from the trees, but with no sense of urgency. There was nothing out there to threaten or inconvenience them.

nɪneɪiv wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, aɪbɹaʊz ɹeɪz haɪ.

Nynaeve was watching her, eyebrows raised high.

"aɪ dɪdn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd. hɝ hæn kloʊzd ɑn sʌmθɪŋ smɔl, ɹæpt ɪn ɹɑɾɪŋ klɔθ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn waɪt wʌns. əɹ bɹaʊn. ʃi nu ɪmiɾiətli wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd.

"I didn't say anything," Elayne said. Her hand closed on something small, wrapped in rotting cloth that might have been white once. Or brown. She knew immediately what was inside.

"ə ɡʊd θɪŋ fəɹ ju," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld, nɑt kwaɪt fɑɹ ɪnʌf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "aɪ kæn əbaɪd wɪmən u poʊk ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪndə ʌðɝ pipəlz bɪznəs." ɪleɪn lɛɾ ɪt pæs wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə stɑɹt; ʃi wɑz pɹaʊd ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə baɪɾ əɹ tʌŋ.

"A good thing for you," Nynaeve grumbled, not quite far enough under her breath. "I can't abide women who poke their noses into other people's business." Elayne let it pass without so much as a start; she was proud that she did not have to bite her tongue.

stʃɹɪpɪŋ əweɪ ðə dəkeɪd klɔθ ɹɪvild ə smɔl æmbɝ bɹutʃ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɝɾəl. ɪt lʊk laɪk æmbɝ, ɛniweɪ, ən ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn æmbɝ wʌns, bʌt wən ʃi oʊpən hɝsɛlf tə ðə sɔɹs θɹu ɪt, seɪaɪdɑɹ ɹʌʃt ɪndə hɝ, ə tɔɹən kəmpɛɹd tə wʌt ʃi kəd dʒɹɔ seɪfli ɑn əɹ oʊn. nɑɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ æŋɡɹil, bʌt fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən nʌθɪŋ. wɪð ɪt, ʃi kəd hændəl twaɪs əz mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ əz nɪneɪiv, ən nɪneɪiv hɝsɛlf wəd də bɛɾɝ stɪl. ɹilisɪŋ ði ɛkstʃɹə floʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ, ʃi slɪp ðə bɹutʃ ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ wɪð ə smaɪl ə dɪlaɪɾ ən wɛn bæk tə sɝtʃɪŋ. wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz wʌn, ðəɹ maɪt bi mɔɹ. ən naʊ ðət ʃi hæd wʌn tə stʌɾi, ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɹizən aʊt haʊ tə meɪk ən æŋɡɹil. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd wɪʃt fɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də nɑt tə teɪk ðə bɹutʃ aʊɾ əɡɛn ən bɪɡɪn pɹoʊbɪŋ ɪt ɹaɪt ðɛɹ.

Stripping away the decayed cloth revealed a small amber brooch in the shape of a turtle. It looked like amber, anyway, and it might have been amber once, but when she opened herself to the Source through it, saidar rushed into her, a torrent compared to what she could draw safely on her own. Not a strong angreal, but far better than nothing. With it, she could handle twice as much of the Power as Nynaeve, and Nynaeve herself would do better still. Releasing the extra flow of saidar, she slipped the brooch into her belt pouch with a smile of delight and went back to searching. Where there was one, there might be more. And now that she had one to study, she might be able to reason out how to make an angreal. That was something she had wished for. It was all she could do not to take the brooch out again and begin probing it right there.

vændin hæd bɪn aɪɪŋ nɪneɪiv ən əɹ fəɹ səm taɪm, ən naʊ ʃi hild əɹ slæb-saɪɾəd ɡɛldɪŋ oʊvɝ tə ðɛm ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. ðə ɡɹum ət ðə pækhɔɹsəz hɛd mænədʒd ə disən ɪf ɑkwɝd kɝtsi, mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæd fəɹ ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv. "jɔɹ biɪŋ kɛɹfəl," vændin sɛd tə ɪleɪn, "æn ðæts vɛɹi ɡʊd. bʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ tə liv ðiz θɪŋz əloʊn əntɪl ðəɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ."

Vandene had been eyeing Nynaeve and her for some time, and now she heeled her slab-sided gelding over to them and dismounted. The groom at the packhorse's head managed a decent if awkward curtsy, more than she had for Elayne or Nynaeve. "You're being careful," Vandene said to Elayne, "and that's very good. But it might be better to leave these things alone until they're in the Tower."

ɪleɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd. ɪn ðə taʊɝ? əntɪl ðeɪ kəd bi ɪɡzæmən baɪ sʌmwʌn ɛls, wɑz wʌt ʃi mɛnt. sʌmwʌn oʊldɝ ən səpoʊzədli mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiənst. "aɪ də noʊ wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ, vændin. aɪ hæv meɪd tɛɹæŋɡɹil, æftɝ ɔl. noʊbɑdi ɛls lɪvɪŋ əz dʌn ðæt." ʃi hæd tɔt ðə beɪsɪks tə səm sɪstɝz, bʌt noʊ wʌn hæd mænədʒ ðə tʃɹɪk ʌv ɪt baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi lɛft fəɹ ɛbu dɑɹ.

Elayne's mouth tightened. In the Tower? Until they could be examined by someone else, was what she meant. Someone older and supposedly more experienced. "I do know what I'm doing, Vandene. I have made ter'angreal, after all. Nobody else living has done that." She had taught the basics to some sisters, but no one had managed the trick of it by the time she left for Ebou Dar.

ði oʊldɝ ɡɹin nɑɾəd, flɪpɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz aɪdli əɡɛns ðə pɑm ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌv. "mɑɹtin dʒənæɾə ɔlsoʊ nu wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd," ʃi sɛd kæʒəwəli. "ʃi wɑz ðə læst sɪstɝ tə ɹɪli meɪk ə bɪznəs ə stʌɾiɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ʃi dɪɾ ɪt fəɹ oʊvɝ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz, ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ðə ʃɔl. ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl, tu, soʊ aɪ wɑz toʊld. ðən wʌn deɪ, mɑɹtinz meɪd faʊn əɹ ʌnkɑnʃəs ɑn ðə flɔɹ ə hɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. bɝn aʊt." ivən ɪn ə kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl toʊn, ðoʊz wɝdz wɝ ə ʃɑɹp slæp. vændinz vɔɪs dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ ə hɛɹ, ðoʊ. "hɝ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz dɛd fɹəm ðə ʃɑk. nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl ɪn keɪsəz laɪk ðæt. wən mɑɹtin keɪm tə, θɹi deɪz leɪɾɝ, ʃi kʊdn ɹikɔl wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ wɪð. ʃi kʊdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə pɹisiɾɪŋ wik əɾ ɔl. ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ən noʊ wʌn sɪns əz hæd ðə nɝv tə tʌtʃ ɛni ʌv ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wɝ ɪn əɹ ɹumz. hɝ noʊts mɛnʃən ɛvɹi læst wʌn, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi hæd dɪskʌvɝd wɑz ɪnɑkjuəs, ɪnəsənt, ivən fɹɪvələs, bʌt. . . ." vændin ʃɹʌɡd. "ʃi faʊn sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wɑzn ɪkspɛktɪŋ."

The older Green nodded, flipping her reins idly against the palm of her riding glove. "Martine Janata also knew what she was doing, so I understand," she said casually. "She was the last sister to really make a business of studying ter'angreal. She did it for over forty years, almost from the time she reached the shawl. She was careful, too, so I was told. Then one day, Martine's maid found her unconscious on the floor of her sitting room. Burned out." Even in a conversational tone, those words were a sharp slap. Vandene's voice did not alter a hair, though. "Her Warder was dead from the shock. Not unusual in cases like that. When Martine came to, three days later, she couldn't recall what she had been working with. She couldn't remember the preceding week at all. That was more than twenty-five years ago, and no one since has had the nerve to touch any of the ter'angreal that were in her rooms. Her notes mentioned every last one, and everything she had discovered was innocuous, innocent, even frivolous, but. . . ." Vandene shrugged. "She found something she wasn't expecting."

ɪleɪn pikt ət bɝdʒɪt, ən faʊn bɝdʒɪt lʊkɪŋ bæk ət hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt nid tə si ðə wɝid fɹaʊn ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz feɪs; ɪt wɑz mɪɹɝɾ ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ɪn ðə smɔl pætʃ ə hɝ maɪn ðət wɑz bɝdʒɪɾ ən ɪn ðə ɹɛst. bɝdʒɪt fɛlt əɹ wɝi, ən ʃi fɛl bɝdʒɪts, əntɪl səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə seɪ wɪtʃ wɑz wɪtʃ. ʃi ɹɪsk mɔɹ ðən hɝsɛlf. bʌt ʃi dɪd noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ðɛɹ, ət list. ən ivən ɪf nʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən əpɪɹd, ðeɪ niɾəd ɔl ði æŋɡɹil ʃi kəd faɪnd.

Elayne peeked at Birgitte, and found Birgitte looking back at her. She did not need to see the worried frown on the other woman's face; it was mirrored in her mind, in the small patch of her mind that was Birgitte and in the rest. Birgitte felt her worry, and she felt Birgitte's, until sometimes it was hard to say which was which. She risked more than herself. But she did know what she was doing. More than anyone else there, at least. And even if none of the Forsaken appeared, they needed all the angreal she could find.

"wʌt hæpən tə mɑɹtin?" nɪneɪiv æskt kwaɪətli. "æftɝwɝd, aɪ min." ʃi kəd sɛldəm hɪɹ ʌv ɛniwʌn biɪŋ hɝt wɪθaʊt wɑntɪŋ tə hil ðɛm; ʃi wɑntəd tə hil ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

"What happened to Martine?" Nynaeve asked quietly. "Afterward, I mean." She could seldom hear of anyone being hurt without wanting to Heal them; she wanted to Heal everything.

vændin ɡɹɪməst. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə wʌn tə bɹɪŋ ʌp mɑɹtin, bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt wɪmən u hæd bɪn bɝn aʊɾ əɹ stɪld. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðɛm. "ʃi vænɪʃt wʌns ʃi wɑz wɛl ɪnʌf tə slɪp aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ," ʃi sɛd hɝidli. "ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪz ðət ʃi wɑz kɔʃəs. aɪ nɛvɝ mɛt hɝ, bʌɾ aɪv bɪn toʊld ʃi tʃɹiɾəd ɛvɹi tɛɹæŋɡɹil əz ɪf ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ɪt maɪt də nɛkst, ivən ðə wʌn ðət meɪks ðə klɔθ fəɹ wɔɹɾɝz' kloʊks, ən noʊbɑdi hæz ɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ðət də ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl, ən ɪt dɪɾ əɹ noʊ ɡʊd."

Vandene grimaced. She might have been the one to bring up Martine, but Aes Sedai did not like talking about women who had been burned out or stilled. They did not like remembering them. "She vanished once she was well enough to slip out of the Tower," she said hurriedly. "The important thing to remember is that she was cautious. I never met her, but I've been told she treated every ter'angreal as if she had no idea what it might do next, even the one that makes the cloth for Warders' cloaks, and nobody has ever been able to make that do anything else. She was careful, and it did her no good."

nɪneɪiv leɪɾ ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ðə nɪɹli ɛmpti pæniɝ. "meɪbi jə ɹɪli ʃʊd," ʃi bɪɡæn.

Nynaeve laid an arm across the nearly empty pannier. "Maybe you really should," she began.

"noʊ-oʊ-oʊ-oʊ!" mɛɝɪlɪl ʃɹikt.

"No-o-o-o!" Merilille shrieked.

ɪleɪn spʌn, ɪnstɪŋktɪvli oʊpənɪŋ hɝsɛlf θɹu ði æŋɡɹil əɡɛn, oʊnli hæf kɑnʃəs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ flʌɾɪŋ ɪndə nɪneɪiv ən vændin. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə klɪɹɪŋ u kəɾ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ, wʌn hæn ɹitʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪleɪn fɹaʊnd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðəɹ ɪksɛpt eɪvinhə, ən ðə læs fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz, stɑɹɾəld ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wɔkɪŋ əweɪ, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə θɹɛt wɪð sɔɹdz hæf-dʒɹɔn. ðən ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ eɪvinhə wɑz duɪŋ ən nɪɹli lɔst seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪn əɹ ʃɑk.

Elayne spun, instinctively opening herself through the angreal again, only half conscious of saidar flooding into Nynaeve and Vandene. The glow of the Power sprang up around every woman in the clearing who could embrace the Source. Merilille was straining forward in her saddle, eyes bulging, one hand reaching toward the gateway. Elayne frowned. There was nothing there except Aviendha, and the last four Warders, startled in the middle of walking away, searching for the threat with swords half-drawn. Then she realized what Aviendha was doing and nearly lost saidar in her shock.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tʃɹɛmbəld əz eɪvinhə kɛɹfəli pɪkt əpɑɹt ðə wiv ðət hæd meɪɾ ɪt. ɪt ʃɪvɝɾ ən flɛkst, ði ɛdʒəz weɪvɝɪŋ. ðə læs floʊz keɪm lus, ən ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɪŋkɪŋ aʊt, ði oʊpənɪŋ ʃɪmɝd, ðə vju θɹu ɪɾ ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd feɪɾɪŋ əweɪ əntɪl ɪɾ ɪvæpɝeɪɾəd laɪk mɪst ɪn ðə sʌn.

The gateway trembled as Aviendha carefully picked apart the weave that had made it. It shivered and flexed, the edges wavering. The last flows came loose, and instead of winking out, the opening shimmered, the view through it of the courtyard fading away until it evaporated like mist in the sun.

"ðæɾ ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl!" ɹɪneɪl sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. ən əstɑnɪʃt mɝmɝ ʌv əɡɹimən bɹoʊk aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. ðə kɪnswɪmən ɡeɪpt əɾ eɪvinhə, maʊðz wɝkɪŋ saʊnləsli.

"That is impossible!" Renaile said incredulously. An astonished murmur of agreement broke out among the Windfinders. The Kinswomen gaped at Aviendha, mouths working soundlessly.

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. klɪɹli ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl, bʌt wʌn ə ðə fɝs θɪŋz ʃi hæd bɪn toʊld əz ə nɑvəs wɑz ðət nɛvɝ, ɛvɝ, ʌndɝ ɛni sɝkəmstænsəz wɑz ʃi tə tʃɹaɪ wʌɾ eɪvinhə hæd dʒʌs dʌn. pɪkɪŋ əpɑɹɾ ə wiv, ɛni wiv, ɹæðɝ ðən sɪmpli lɛɾɪŋ ɪt dɪsəpeɪt, kəd nɑt bi dʌn, ʃi hæd bɪn toʊld, nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɪnɛvəɾəbəl dɪzæstɝ. ɪnɛvəɾəbəl.

Elayne nodded slowly in spite of herself. Clearly it was possible, but one of the first things she had been told as a novice was that never, ever, under any circumstances was she to try what Aviendha had just done. Picking apart a weave, any weave, rather than simply letting it dissipate, could not be done, she had been told, not without inevitable disaster. Inevitable.

"ju ful ɡɝl!" vændin snæpt, hɝ feɪs ə θʌndɝhɛd. ʃi stʃɹoʊd təwɔɹɾ eɪvinhə dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. "du jə ɹilaɪz wʌt jə ɔlmoʊs dɪd? wʌn slɪp - wʌn! - ən ðɛɹz noʊ seɪɪŋ wʌt ðə wiv wɪl snæp ɪntu, əɹ wʌɾ ɪɾəl du! jə kəɾ əv kəmplitli dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz! faɪv hʌnʒɹəd! ɛvɹiθɪŋ! jə cʊɾə bɝn jɝsɛlf aʊɾ ən - "

"You fool girl!" Vandene snapped, her face a thunderhead. She strode toward Aviendha dragging her gelding behind. "Do you realize what you almost did? One slip - one! - and there's no saying what the weave will snap into, or what it will do! You could have completely destroyed everything for a hundred paces! Five hundred! Everything! You could have burned yourself out and - "

"ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi," eɪvinhə kʌɾ ɪn. ə bæbəl ɪɹʌptəd fɹəm ðə maʊntəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ ən vændin, bʌt ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ əm ən ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs oʊvɝ ðɛɹz. "aɪ noʊ ðə deɪnʒɝz, vændin neɪmɛl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. ɪz ðɪs ənʌðɝ θɪŋ jə ɛɛs sədaɪ kænɑt du? ðə waɪz wʌnz seɪ ɛni wʊmən kən lɝn, ɪf ʃiz tɔt, səm wɪmən mɔɹ ən səm lɛs, bʌɾ ɛni wʊmən, ɪf ʃi kən pɪk aʊɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi." ʃi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt snɪɹ. nɑt kwaɪt.

"It was necessary," Aviendha cut in. A babble erupted from the mounted Aes Sedai crowding around her and Vandene, but she glared at them and raised her voice over theirs. "I know the dangers, Vandene Namelle, but it was necessary. Is this another thing you Aes Sedai cannot do? The Wise Ones say any woman can learn, if she is taught, some women more and some less, but any woman, if she can pick out embroidery." She did not quite sneer. Not quite.

"ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ɡɝl!" mɛɝɪlɪlz vɔɪs wɑz dip wɪntɝ aɪs. "wʌtɛvɝ soʊ-kɔl tʃɹeɪnɪŋ jə ɹəsivd əmʌŋ jəɹ pipəl, jə kænɑt pɑsəbli noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ pleɪɪŋ wɪð! jəl pɹɑməs mi - swɛɹ tə mi! - ðət jəl nɛvɝ də ðɪs əɡɛn!"

"This is not embroidery, girl!" Merilille's voice was deep winter ice. "Whatever so-called training you received among your people, you cannot possibly know what you are playing with! You will promise me - swear to me! - that you will never do this again!"

"hɝ neɪm ʃəd bi ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk," sɝaɪðə sɛd fɝmli, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə boʊl stɪl hɛl fɝmli tə hɝ bʊzəm. "aɪv ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɪt. ʃi ʃəd bi ɛntɝɾ ɪn ðə bʊk." kɛɝin nɑɾəd, hɝ stɝn ɡeɪz mɛʒɝɪŋ eɪvinhə fəɹ ə nɑvəs dʒɹɛs.

"Her name should be in the novice book," Sareitha said firmly, glaring across the Bowl still held firmly to her bosom. "I've always said it. She should be entered in the book." Careane nodded, her stern gaze measuring Aviendha for a novice dress.

"ðæt maɪt nɑt bi nɛsəsɛɹi fəɹ ðə moʊmənt," æɾɪliz toʊld eɪvinhə, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, "bʌt jə mʌs lɛt jɝsɛlf bi ɡaɪɾəd baɪ ʌs." ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz toʊn wɑz mʌtʃ maɪldɝ ðən ði ʌðɝz', jɛt ʃi wɑz nɑt meɪkɪŋ ə sədʒɛstʃən.

"That might not be necessary for the moment," Adeleas told Aviendha, leaning forward in her saddle, "but you must let yourself be guided by us." The Brown sister's tone was much milder than the others', yet she was not making a suggestion.

ə mʌnθ əɹ soʊ ɝliɝ, eɪvinhə maɪɾ əv bɪɡʌn tə wɪlt ʌndɝ ɔl ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪsəpɹuvəl, bʌt nɑt naʊ. ɪleɪn hɝidli pʊʃt ɪn əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz bɪfɔɹ əɹ fɹɛn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dʒɹɔ ðə naɪf ʃi wɑz fɑndəlɪŋ. əɹ tə də sʌmθɪŋ wɝs. "meɪbi sʌmbɑɾi ʃəɾ æsk waɪ ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi," ʃi sɛd, slɪpɪŋ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn eɪvinhəz ʃoʊldɝz əz mʌtʃ tə kip əɹ ɑɹmz əɾ əɹ saɪdz əz fəɹ kʌmfɝt.

A month or so earlier, Aviendha might have begun to wilt under all that Aes Sedai disapproval, but not now. Elayne hurriedly pushed in among the horses before her friend decided to draw the knife she was fondling. Or to do something worse. "Maybe somebody should ask why she thought it was necessary," she said, slipping an arm around Aviendha's shoulders as much to keep her arms at her sides as for comfort.

eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt kwaɪɾ ɪnkluɾ əɹ ɪn ði ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk ʃi ɡeɪv ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz. "ðɪs livz noʊ ɹɛzədu," ʃi sɛd peɪʃənli. tu peɪʃənli. "ðə ɹɛzəduz ʌv ə wiv ðɪs lɑɹdʒ maɪt bi ɹɛd tu deɪz fɹəm naʊ."

Aviendha did not quite include her in the exasperated look she gave the other sisters. "This leaves no residue," she said patiently. Too patiently. "The residues of a weave this large might be read two days from now."

mɛɝɪlɪl snɔɹɾɪd, ə vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ saʊn tə kʌm fɹəm ðət slaɪt bɑɾi. "ðæɾ ɪz ə ɹɛɹ tælənt, ɡɝl. niðɝ tɛslɪn nɔɹ dʒoʊlin əz ɪt. əɹ dʒju il waɪldɝz ɔl lɝn ðəɾ əz wɛl?"

Merilille snorted, a very strong sound to come from that slight body. "That is a rare Talent, girl. Neither Teslyn nor Joline has it. Or do you Aiel wilders all learn that as well?"

"fju kən də ɪt," eɪvinhə ədmɪɾəd kɑmli. "bʌɾ aɪ kæn." ðət pɹədust ə dɪfɹən sɔɹɾ ə stɛɹ, fɹəm ɪleɪn əz wɛl; ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɹɛɹ tælənt. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. "du jə kleɪm ðət nʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld kæn?" ʃi wɛn ɑn. ðə taɪtnəs ə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ ʌndɝ ɪleɪnz hæn sɛd ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ kul əz ʃi pɹitɛndəd. "ɑɹ jə sətʃ fulz ðət jə liv tʃɹæks fəɹ jəɹ ɛnəmiz tə fɑloʊ? ɛni hu kəd ɹid ðə ɹɛzəduz kəd meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ðɪs spɑt."

"Few can do it," Aviendha admitted calmly. "But I can." That produced a different sort of stare, from Elayne as well; it was a very rare Talent. She did not seem to notice. "Do you claim that none of the Shadowsouled can?" she went on. The tightness of her shoulder under Elayne's hand said she was not so cool as she pretended. "Are you such fools that you leave tracks for your enemies to follow? Any who could read the residues could make a gateway to this spot."

ðət wʊɾə teɪkən ɡɹeɪt dɛkstɛɹəɾi, vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dɛkstɛɹəɾi, bʌt ðə sədʒɛstʃən wɑz ɪnʌf tə liv mɛɝɪlɪl blɪŋkɪŋ. æɾɪliz oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪt wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, ən vændin fɹaʊn θɔtfəli. sɝaɪðə sɪmpli lʊkt wɝid. hu kəd seɪ wʌt tæləns ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd, wʌt skɪl?

That would have taken great dexterity, very great dexterity, but the suggestion was enough to leave Merilille blinking. Adeleas opened her mouth, then closed it without speaking, and Vandene frowned thoughtfully. Sareitha simply looked worried. Who could say what Talents the Forsaken had, what skill?

stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɔl ðə fɪɹsnəs dʒɹeɪn aʊɾ ʌv eɪvinhə. hɝ aɪz fɛl, hɝ ʃoʊldɝz lusənd. "pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv teɪkən ðə ɹɪsk," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "wɪð ðət mæn wɑtʃɪŋ mi, aɪ kəd nɑt θɪŋk klɪɹli, ən wən i dɪsəpɪɹd. . . ." ə lɪɾəl ə hɝ spɪɹət ɹɪtɝnd, bʌt nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ə mæn kəd ɹid maɪ wivz," ʃi sɛd tə ɪleɪn, "bʌɾ ɪf i wɑz wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld, əɹ ivən ðə ɡoʊləm. . . . ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ʌs. ɪf aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ, aɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt toʊ. bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ wɑz. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɪt."

Strangely, all the fierceness drained out of Aviendha. Her eyes fell, her shoulders loosened. "Perhaps I should not have taken the risk," she muttered. "With that man watching me, I could not think clearly, and when he disappeared. . . ." A little of her spirit returned, but not a great deal. "I do not think a man could read my weaves," she said to Elayne, "but if he was one of the Shadowsouled, or even the gholam. . . . The Shadowsouled know more than any of us. If I was wrong, I have great toh. But I do not think I was. I do not think it."

"wʌt mæn?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. hɝ hæt hæd bɪn nɑkt əskju ɪn pʊʃɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz, ən ðæt, wɪð ðə taɪt fɹaʊn ʃi dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪmpɑɹʃəli, meɪɾ əɹ lʊk ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə faɪt. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz. kɛɝinz ɡɛldɪŋ æksədɛntəli nʌdʒd əɹ wɪð ə ʃoʊldɝ, ən ʃi swɑɾɪd ðə blu dʌnz noʊz.

"What man?" Nynaeve demanded. Her hat had been knocked askew in pushing among the horses, and that, with the tight frown she directed at everyone impartially, made her look ready for a fight. Perhaps she was. Careane's gelding accidentally nudged her with a shoulder, and she swatted the blue dun's nose.

"ə sɝvənt," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. "wʌtɛvɝ ɔɹɾɝz taɪlɪn ɡeɪv, ɔltɑɹən sɝvəns ɑɹ ən ɪndɪpɛndən lɑt. əɹ pɝhæps əɹ sʌn; ðət bɔɪ ɪz tu kjʊɹiəs baɪ hæf."

"A servant," Merilille said dismissively. "Whatever orders Tylin gave, Altaran servants are an independent lot. Or perhaps her son; that boy is too curious by half."

ðə sɪstɝz ɝaʊn əɹ nɑɾəd, ən kɛɝin sɛd, "wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wəd hɑɹdli hæv stʊɾ ən wɑtʃt. jə sɛd soʊ jɝsɛlf." ʃi wɑz pæɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋz nɛk ən fɹaʊnɪŋ əkjuzɪŋli ət nɪneɪiv - kɛɝin wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u ɡeɪv əɹ hɔɹs ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv əfɛkʃən moʊs pipəl ɹɪzɝv fəɹ ɪnfəns - ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv, ən nɪneɪiv tʊk ðə wɝdz fəɹ hɝ, tu.

The sisters around her nodded, and Careane said, "One of the Forsaken would hardly have stood and watched. You said so yourself." She was patting her gelding's neck and frowning accusingly at Nynaeve - Careane was one of those who gave her horse the sort of affection most people reserved for infants - she was frowning at Nynaeve, and Nynaeve took the words for her, too.

"meɪbi ɪt wɑz ə sɝvənt, ən meɪbi ɪt wɑz bɛslən. meɪbi." nɪneɪivz snɪf sɛd ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. əɹ ðət ʃi wɑntəɾ əm tə bɪliv ʃi dɪd nɑt; ʃi kəd tɛl jə tə jəɹ feɪs ðət jə wɝ ə blaɪn ɪɾiət, jɛt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls seɪ ɪt, ən ʃi wəd dɪfɛn jə əntɪl ʃi wɛn hɔɹs. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi dɪd nɑt sim ɹɛɾi tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ʃi laɪkt eɪvinhə, bʌt ʃi dɛfənətli dɪd nɑt laɪk ði oʊldɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi tʌɡd əɹ hæɾ ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪt, ən əɹ fɹaʊn swɛpt əkɹɔs ðɛm, ðən stɑɹɾəd oʊvɝ. "wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz bɛslən əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ðɛɹz noʊ kɔl tə stæn hɪɹ ɔl deɪ. wi nid tə ɡɛt ɹɛɾi ən muv ɑn tə ðə fɑɹm. wɛl? muv!" ʃi klæpt əɹ hænz ʃɑɹpli, ən ivən vændin ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl stɑɹt.

"Maybe it was a servant, and maybe it was Beslan. Maybe." Nynaeve's sniff said she did not believe it. Or that she wanted them to believe she did not; she could tell you to your face that you were a blind idiot, yet let anyone else say it, and she would defend you until she went hoarse. Of course, she did not seem ready to decide whether she liked Aviendha, but she definitely did not like the older Aes Sedai. She tugged her hat almost straight, and her frown swept across them, then started over. "Whether it was Beslan or the Dark One, there's no call to stand here all day. We need to get ready and move on to the farm. Well? Move!" She clapped her hands sharply, and even Vandene gave a little start.

ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl pɹɛpɝeɪʃən lɛf tə də wən ðə sɪstɝz muv ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əweɪ. læn ən ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz hæd nɑt sæɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz wʌns ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪnʒɝ. səm ə ðə sɝvəns hæd ɡɔn bæk θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪfɔɹ eɪvinhə dɪspoʊzd ʌv ɪt, bʌt ðə ɹɛst stʊd wɪð ðə θɹi dʌzən əɹ soʊ pækhɔɹsɪz, əkeɪʒənəli ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, klɪɹli wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt mɑɹvəl ðeɪ maɪt pɹədus nɛkst. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɔl maʊntəd, ɪf ɔkwɝdli, ən hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz əz ðoʊ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tə boʊlt ɛni moʊmənt, əɹ pɝhæps spɹaʊt wɪŋz ən teɪk flaɪt. soʊ wɝ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, wɪð ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ ɡɹeɪs, ʌnkənsɝn ðət ðɛɹ skɝts ən pɛɾikoʊts wɝ pʊʃt ʌp pæs ðɛɹ niz, ən wɪð ɪspæn stɪl hʊɾɪd ən taɪɾ əkɹɔs ə sæɾəl laɪk ə sæk. ʃi kəd nɑt pɑsəbli hæv sæɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɑn ə hɔɹs, jɛɾ ivən sumeɪkoʊz aɪz pɑpt wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ tʌtʃt hɝ.

There was little preparation left to do when the sisters moved their horses away. Lan and the other Warders had not sat on their heels once they realized there was no danger. Some of the servants had gone back through the gateway before Aviendha disposed of it, but the rest stood with the three dozen or so packhorses, occasionally glancing at the Aes Sedai, clearly wondering what marvel they might produce next. The Windfinders were all mounted, if awkwardly, and holding their reins as though expecting their horses to bolt any moment, or perhaps sprout wings and take flight. So were the Knitting Circle, with a good deal more grace, unconcerned that their skirts and petticoats were pushed up past their knees, and with Ispan still hooded and tied across a saddle like a sack. She could not possibly have sat upright on a horse, yet even Sumeko's eyes popped whenever they touched her.

ɡlɛɹɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ, nɪneɪiv lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə tʌŋ-læʃ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪndə duɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn, bʌɾ oʊnli əntɪl læn hændəɾ əɹ ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɝ plʌmp bɹaʊn mɛɹ. ʃi hæɾ æɾəməntli ɹəfjuz ðə ɡɪft ʌv ə bɛɾɝ hɔɹs fɹəm taɪlɪn. hɝ hæn tʃɹɛmbəld ə lɪɾəl wən ɪt tʌtʃt lænz, ən əɹ feɪs tʃeɪnʒd kʌlɝ əz ʃi swɑloʊd ði æŋɡɝ ʃi hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə ənliʃ. wən i ɔfɝɾ ə hæn fəɹ əɹ fʊt, ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmən əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt, ðən kʌlɝɾ əɡɛn wən i bustɪɾ əɹ tə hɝ sæɾəl. ɪleɪn kəɾ oʊnli ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd. ʃi hoʊpt ʃi dɪd nɑt tɝn ɪndə ən ɪɾiət wən ʃi mɛɹid. ɪf ʃi mɛɹid.

Glaring about her, Nynaeve looked ready to tongue-lash everybody into doing what they had already done, but only until Lan handed her the reins of her plump brown mare. She had adamantly refused the gift of a better horse from Tylin. Her hand trembled a little when it touched Lan's, and her face changed color as she swallowed the anger she had been about to unleash. When he offered a hand for her foot, she stared at him for a moment as if wondering what he was about, then colored again when he boosted her to her saddle. Elayne could only shake her head. She hoped she did not turn into an idiot when she married. If she married.

bɝdʒɪt bɹɔɾ əɹ sɪlvɝi-ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ ən ðə jɛloʊ dʌn eɪvinhə ɹoʊd, bʌt ʃi sim tə ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑntəɾ ə pɹaɪvət wɝd wɪð eɪvinhə. ʃi nɑɾəd ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ɪleɪn hæd spoʊkən, swʌŋ ʌp ɑntu hɝ maʊs-kʌlɝd ɡɛldɪŋ, ən ɹoʊd tə wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ. ðeɪ ɡɹiɾəd əɹ wɪð nɑdz ən bɪɡæn dɪskʌsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn loʊ vɔɪsəz. baɪ ðə ɡlænsɪz dɝɛktəɾ ət ðə sɪstɝz, ðə "sʌmθɪŋ" hæd tə də wɪð teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd kɛɹ teɪkən əɹ nɑt. ɪnkluɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn noʊɾəd ɡɹɪmli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm naʊ fəɹ ðæt, ðoʊ. eɪvinhə stʊd fɪdlɪŋ wɪð əɹ hɔɹsəz ɹeɪnz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ði ænəməl laɪk ə nɑvəs stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə kɪtʃən fʊl ʌv ɡɹisi pɑts. vɛɹi laɪkli, eɪvinhə sɔ smɔl dɪfɝəns bɪtwin hævɪŋ tə skɹʌb pɑts ən hævɪŋ tə ɹaɪd.

Birgitte brought her silvery-gray mare and the yellow dun Aviendha rode, but she seemed to understand that Elayne wanted a private word with Aviendha. She nodded almost as if Elayne had spoken, swung up onto her mouse-colored gelding, and rode to where the other Warders were waiting. They greeted her with nods and began discussing something in low voices. By the glances directed at the sisters, the "something" had to do with taking care of Aes Sedai whether Aes Sedai wanted care taken or not. Including herself, Elayne noted grimly. There was no time now for that, though. Aviendha stood fiddling with her horse's reins, staring at the animal like a novice staring at a kitchen full of greasy pots. Very likely, Aviendha saw small difference between having to scrub pots and having to ride.

snʌɡɪŋ əɹ ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz, ɪleɪn kæʒəwəli ʃɪftəd laɪoʊnəs tə blɑk əm fɹəm ði ʌðɝz' vju, ðən tʌtʃt eɪvinhəz ɑɹm. "tɔkɪŋ tə æɾɪliz əɹ vændin maɪt hɛlp," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli. ʃi hæd tə bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl hɪɹ, əz kɛɹfəl əz wɪð ɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil. "ðeɪɹ oʊld ɪnʌf tə noʊ mɔɹ ðən jə maɪt səspɛkt. ðəɹ əz tə bi ə ɹizən juv bɪn . . . hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl . . . wɪð tʃɹævlɪŋ." ðət wɑz ə maɪld weɪ ʌv pʊɾɪŋ ɪt. eɪvinhə ɔlmoʊs hæd feɪl tə meɪk ðə wiv wɝk əɾ ɔl, ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. kɛɹfəl. eɪvinhə wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɛvɝ kəd bi. "ðeɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp."

Snugging her green riding gloves, Elayne casually shifted Lioness to block them from the others' view, then touched Aviendha's arm. "Talking to Adeleas or Vandene might help," she said gently. She had to be very careful here, as careful as with any ter'angreal. "They're old enough to know more than you might suspect. There has to be a reason you've been . . . having trouble . . . with Traveling." That was a mild way of putting it. Aviendha almost had failed to make the weave work at all, in the beginning. Careful. Aviendha was far more important than any ter'angreal ever could be. "They might be able to help."

"haʊ kən ðeɪ?" eɪvinhə stɛɹd stɪfli ət ðə sæɾəl ɑn əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ. "ðeɪ kænɑt tʃɹævəl. haʊ kəɾ ɛni ʌv əm noʊ haʊ tə hɛlp?" əbɹʌpli hɝ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt, ən ʃi tɝn əɹ hɛd tə ɪleɪn. ʃɑkɪŋli, ənʃt tɪɹz ɡlɪsən ɪn əɹ ɡɹin aɪz. "ðæɾ ɪzən ðə tʃɹuθ, ɪleɪn. nɑt ðə hoʊl tʃɹuθ. ðeɪ kænɑt hɛlp, bʌt. . . . jə ɑɹ maɪ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ; juv ðə ɹaɪt tə noʊ. ðeɪ θɪŋk aɪ pænɪkt əɾ ə sɝvənt. ɪf aɪ æsk fəɹ hɛlp, ɪt mʌst ɔl kʌm aʊt. ðəɾ aɪ tʃɹævəld wʌns tə ɹʌn fɹəm ə mæn, ə mæn aɪ hoʊpt ɪn maɪ soʊl wəd kætʃ mi. tə ɹʌn laɪk ə ɹæbət. tə ɹʌn, wɑntɪŋ tə bi kɑt. haʊ kəɾ aɪ lɛɾ əm noʊ sətʃ ʃeɪm? ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪli kəd hɛlp, haʊ kəɾ aɪ?"

"How can they?" Aviendha stared stiffly at the saddle on her gelding. "They cannot Travel. How could any of them know how to help?" Abruptly her shoulders slumped, and she turned her head to Elayne. Shockingly, unshed tears glistened in her green eyes. "That isn't the truth, Elayne. Not the whole truth. They cannot help, but. . . . You are my near-sister; you have the right to know. They think I panicked at a servant. If I ask for help, it must all come out. That I Traveled once to run from a man, a man I hoped in my soul would catch me. To run like a rabbit. To run, wanting to be caught. How could I let them know such shame? Even if they really could help, how could I?"

ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. əbaʊt ðə kætʃɪŋ pɑɹt, ət list. əbaʊt ðə fæk ðət ɹænd hæd kɑt hɝ. snætʃɪŋ ðə flɛks ə dʒɛləsi ðət sʌɾənli wɝ floʊɾɪŋ θɹu hɝ, ʃi pʊʃt əm ɪndə ə sæk ən stʌft ɪɾ ɪndə ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. ðən ʃi dʒʌmpt ʌp ən daʊn ɑn ɪt fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ. wən ə wʊmən pleɪz ðə ful, lʊk fəɹ ðə mæn. ðət wɑz wʌn ə liniz feɪvɹɪts. ənʌðɝ wɑz, kɪɾənz tæŋɡəl jəɹ jɑɹn, mɛn tæŋɡəl jəɹ wɪts, ən ɪts sɪmpəl əz bɹiðɪŋ fəɹ boʊθ. ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "noʊ wʌn wɪl noʊ fɹəm mi, eɪvinhə. əl hɛlp jə əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ kæn. ɪf aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ." nɑt ðət ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ ʃi kəd θɪŋk tə du. eɪvinhə wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbli kwɪk ət siɪŋ haʊ wivz wɝ fɔɹmd, mʌtʃ kwɪkɝ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf.

Elayne wished she did not know. About the catching part, at least. About the fact that Rand had caught her. Snatching the flecks of jealousy that suddenly were floating through her, she pushed them into a sack and stuffed it into the back of her head. Then she jumped up and down on it for good measure. When a woman plays the fool, look for the man. That was one of Lini's favorites. Another was, Kittens tangle your yarn, men tangle your wits, and it's simple as breathing for both. She drew a deep breath. "No one will know from me, Aviendha. I'll help you as much as I can. If I can figure out how." Not that there was much she could think to do. Aviendha was remarkably quick at seeing how weaves were formed, much quicker than she herself.

eɪvinhə mɪɹli nɑɾəd ən skɹæmbəl klʌmsəli ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl, ʃoʊɪŋ ə bɪt mɔɹ ɡɹeɪs ðən ðə si foʊk. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə mæn wɑtʃɪŋ, ɪleɪn, ən i wɑz noʊ sɝvənt." lʊkɪŋ ɪleɪn ɹaɪɾ ɪn ði aɪ, ʃi æɾəd, "hi fɹaɪɾənd mi." ən ædmɪʃən ʃi laɪkli wʊɾə meɪd tə noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn ðə wɝld.

Aviendha merely nodded and scrambled clumsily into her saddle, showing a bit more grace than the Sea Folk. "There was a man watching, Elayne, and he was no servant." Looking Elayne right in the eye, she added, "He frightened me." An admission she likely would have made to no one else in the world.

"wɝ seɪf fɹəm ɪm naʊ, huɛvɝ i wɑz," ɪleɪn sɛd, tɝnɪŋ laɪoʊnəs tə fɑloʊ nɪneɪiv ən læn fɹəm ðə klɪɹɪŋ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪt vɛɹi laɪkli hæd bɪn ə sɝvənt, bʌt ʃi wəd nɛvɝ tɛl ðət tə ɛniwʌn, eɪvinhə list ʌv ɔl. "wɝ seɪf, ən ɪn ə fju mɔɹ aʊɝz, wɪl ɹitʃ ðə kɪnz fɑɹm, wɪl juz ðə boʊl, ən ðə wɝld wɪl bi ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn." wɛl, sʌmwʌt. ðə sʌn sim loʊɝ ðən ɪt hæɾ ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd, bʌt ʃi nu ðət wɑz oʊnli ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. fəɹ wʌns, ðeɪ hæd ɡeɪn ə klɪɹ dʒʌmp ɑn ðə ʃædoʊ.

"We're safe from him now, whoever he was," Elayne said, turning Lioness to follow Nynaeve and Lan from the clearing. In truth, it very likely had been a servant, but she would never tell that to anyone, Aviendha least of all. "We're safe, and in a few more hours, we will reach the Kin's farm, we'll use the Bowl, and the world will be right again." Well, somewhat. The sun seemed lower than it had in the stableyard, but she knew that was only imagination. For once, they had gained a clear jump on the Shadow.

fɹəm bɪhaɪn ə skɹin ʌv waɪt ɹɔɾ aɪɝn, mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑtʃt ðə læst ə ðə hɔɹsəz vænɪʃ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ðən ðə tɔl jʌŋ wʊmən ən ðə fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz. ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl ðeɪ wɝ kæɹiɪŋ əweɪ səm aɪɾəm i kəd juz - ən æŋɡɹil ətun tə mɛn, pɝhæps - bʌt ðə tʃænsəz wɝ smɔl. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst laɪklihʊd wɑz ðət ðeɪ wəd kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt haʊ tə juz ðɛm. sɑmaɪl wɑz ə ful tə hæv ɹɪsk soʊ mʌtʃ tə siz ə kəlɛkʃən ə noʊ wʌn nu wʌt. bʌt ðɛn, sɑmaɪl hæd nɛvɝ bɪn hæf əz klɛvɝ əz i θɔt. hi hɪmsɛlf wəd nɑt dɪsɹʌpt ɪz oʊn plænz mɪɹli ɑn ði ɔf tʃæns, tə si wʌt skɹæps ə sɪvəlɪzeɪʃən i kəd faɪnd. oʊnli aɪɾəl kjʊɹiɑsəɾi hæd bɹɔɾ ɪm hɪɹ. hi laɪk tə noʊ wʌɾ ʌðɝz θɔɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dʒɹɔs.

From behind a screen of white wrought iron, Moridin watched the last of the horses vanish through the gateway, and then the tall young woman and the four Warders. It was possible they were carrying away some item he could use - an angreal attuned to men, perhaps - but the chances were small. For the rest, the ter'angreal, the greatest likelihood was that they would kill themselves trying to puzzle out how to use them. Sammael was a fool to have risked so much to seize a collection of no one knew what. But then, Sammael had never been half as clever as he thought. He himself would not disrupt his own plans merely on the off chance, to see what scraps of civilization he could find. Only idle curiosity had brought him here. He liked to know what others thought important. But it was dross.

hi wɑz əbaʊt tə tɝn əweɪ wən ði aʊtlaɪnz ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ sʌɾənli bɪɡæn tə flɛks ən tʃɹɛmbəl. tʃɹænsfɪkst, hi wɑtʃt əntɪl ði oʊpənɪŋ sɪmpli - mɛltəd. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ə mæn tə ɡɪv weɪ tə ɑbsɛnɪɾiz, bʌt sɛvɹəl ɹoʊz ɪn ɪz maɪnd. wʌt hæd ðə wʊmən dʌn? ðiz bɑɹbɝəs ɹʌstɪks ɔfɝd tu mɛni sɝpɹaɪzəz. ə weɪ tə hil biɪŋ sɛvɝd, haʊɛvɝ ɪmpɝfɪkli. ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl! ɪksɛp ðət ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɪt. ɪnvɑləntɛɹi ɹɪŋz. ðoʊz wɔɹɾɝz ən ðə bɑn ðeɪ ʃɛɹd wɪð ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi hæd noʊn ə ðət fəɹ ə lɔŋ, lɔŋ taɪm, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ i hæd ðə mɛʒɝ ə ðɛm, ðiz pɹɪmɪɾɪvz ɹɪvil səm nu skɪl, dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ðət noʊ wʌn ɪn ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ hæd dʒɹimd ʌv. sʌmθɪŋ ðə pɪnəkəl ə sɪvəlɪzeɪʃən hæd nɑt noʊn! wʌt hæd ðə ɡɝl dʌn?

He was about to turn away when the outlines of the gateway suddenly began to flex and tremble. Transfixed, he watched until the opening simply - melted. He had never been a man to give way to obscenities, but several rose in his mind. What had the woman done? These barbarous rustics offered too many surprises. A way to Heal being severed, however imperfectly. That was impossible! Except that they had done it. Involuntary rings. Those Warders and the bond they shared with their Aes Sedai. He had known of that for a long, long time, but whenever he thought he had the measure of them, these primitives revealed some new skill, did something that no one in his own Age had dreamed of. Something the pinnacle of civilization had not known! What had the girl done?

"ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ?"

"Great Master?"

mɔɹaɪɾɪn bɛɹli tɝn ɪz hɛd fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ. "jɛs, mæɾɪk?" hɝ soʊl bi dæmd, wʌt hæd ðə ɡɝl dʌn?

Moridin barely turned his head from the window. "Yes, Madic?" Her soul be damned, what had the girl done?

ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn ɪn ɡɹin-ænd-waɪɾ u hæd slɪpt ɪndə ðə smɔl ɹum baʊd dipli bɪfɔɹ fɔlɪŋ tə hɪz niz. wʌn ə ði ʌpɝ sɝvəns ɪn ðə pæləs, mæɾɪk, wɪð ɪz lɔŋ feɪs, pəzɛst ə pɑmpəs dɪɡnəɾi ðəɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə meɪnteɪn ivən naʊ. mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd sin mɛn u stʊd fɑɹ haɪɝ də fɑɹ wɝs. "ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ, aɪ hæv lɝnd wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɹɔt tə ðə pæləs ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ɪts sɛd ðeɪ faʊn ə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹɛʒɝ hɪɾən ɪn eɪntʃən deɪz, ɡoʊld ən dʒuəlz ən hɑɹtstoʊn, ɑɹɾəfækts fɹəm ʃioʊɾə ən ɛɹən ən ivən ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðəɹ ɑɹ sɛd tə bi θɪŋz əmʌŋ əm ðət juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪts sɛd ðət wʌn kən kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wɛðɝ. noʊ wʌn noʊz wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. ðə pæləs ɪz ækwaɪvɝ wɪð tɔk, bʌt tɛn tʌŋz neɪm tɛn dɪfɹən dɛstəneɪʃənz."

The balding man in green-and-white who had slipped into the small room bowed deeply before falling to his knees. One of the upper servants in the palace, Madic, with his long face, possessed a pompous dignity that he tried to maintain even now. Moridin had seen men who stood far higher do far worse. "Great Master, I have learned what the Aes Sedai brought to the palace this morning. It is said they found a great treasure hidden in ancient days, gold and jewels and heartstone, artifacts from Shiota and Eharon and even the Age of Legends. There are said to be things among them that use the One Power. It is said that one can control the weather. No one knows where they are going, Great Master. The palace is aquiver with talk, but ten tongues name ten different destinations."

mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹd bɪloʊ əz sun əz mæɾɪk spoʊk. ɹɪdɪkjələs teɪlz ʌv ɡoʊld ən kwəndɪlɝ hɛl noʊ ɪntʃɹəst. nʌθɪŋ wəd meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪheɪv ðət weɪ. ənlɛs. . . . kəd ʃi æktʃəli  hæv ənɹævəl ðə wɛb? dɛθ hɛl noʊ fɪɹ fəɹ hɪm. koʊldli hi kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðəɾ i hæd bɪn wɪðɪn saɪɾ ʌv ən ənɹævəlɪŋ wɛb. wʌn ðət hæd bɪn ənmeɪd səksɛsfəli. ənʌðɝ ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi kæʒəwəli ɔfɝɾ ʌp baɪ ðiz . . .

Moridin went back to studying the stableyard below as soon as Madic spoke. Ridiculous tales of gold and cuendillar held no interest. Nothing would make a gateway behave that way. Unless. . . . Could she actually have unraveled the web? Death held no fear for him. Coldly he considered the possibility that he had been within sight of an unraveling web. One that had been unmade successfully. Another impossibility casually offered up by these . . .

sʌmθɪŋ mæɾɪk hæd sɛd kɑɾ ɪz ɪɹ. "ðə wɛðɝ, mæɾɪk?" ðə ʃædoʊz ə ðə pæləs spaɪɹz hæd bɛɹli lɛŋθən fɹəm ðɛɹ beɪsəz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə klaʊd tə ʃil ðə beɪkɪŋ sɪɾi.

Something Madic had said caught his ear. "The weather, Madic?" The shadows of the palace spires had barely lengthened from their bases, but there was not a cloud to shield the baking city.

"jɛs, ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ. ɪts kɔl ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz."

"Yes, Great Master. It is called the Bowl of the Winds."

ðə neɪm mɛnt nʌθɪŋ tə hɪm. bʌt . . . ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə wɛðɝ. . . . ɪn ɪz oʊn eɪdʒ, wɛðɝ hæd bɪn kɛɹfəli ɹɛɡjəleɪɾəd wɪð ðə jus ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. wʌn ə ðə sɝpɹaɪzəz ə ðɪs eɪdʒ - wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ, ɪt hæd simd - wɑz ðət ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u kəd mənɪpjəleɪt wɛðɝ tə ə dɪɡɹi ðət ʃʊɾə ɹikwaɪɝd wʌn ə ðoʊz tɛɹæŋɡɹil. wʌn sətʃ dɪvaɪs ʃəd nɑt bi ɪnʌf tə əfɛkt ivən ə lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl kɑntənənt. bʌt wʌt kəd ðiz wɪmən də wɪð ɪt? wʌt? ɪf ðeɪ juzd ə ɹɪŋ?

The name meant nothing to him. But . . . a ter'angreal to control the weather. . . . In his own Age, weather had been carefully regulated with the use of ter'angreal. One of the surprises of this Age - one of the smaller, it had seemed - was that there were those who could manipulate weather to a degree that should have required one of those ter'angreal. One such device should not be enough to affect even a large part of a single continent. But what could these women do with it? What? If they used a ring?

hi siz ðə tʃɹu. paʊɝ wɪθaʊt θɔt, ðə sæɑ bɪloʊɪŋ blæk əkɹɔs ɪz saɪt. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz taɪɾənd ɪn ðə ɹɔt-aɪɝn ɡɹɪl əkɹɔs ðə wɪndoʊ; ðə mɛɾəl ɡɹoʊnd, twɪstɪŋ, nɑt fɹəm ɪz ɡɹɪp bʌt fɹəm ðə tɛnʒɹəlz ə ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ, dʒɹɔn fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪmsɛlf, ðət ɹɛðd ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹɪlwɝk, flɛksɪŋ əz i flɛkst ɪz hæn ɪn æŋɡɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wəd nɑt bi plizd. hi hæd stʃɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz pɹɪzən tə tʌtʃ ðə wɝld ɪnʌf tə fɪks ðə sizənz ɪn pleɪs. hi wɑz ɪmpeɪʃən tə tʌtʃ ðə wɝl mɔɹ, tə ʃæɾɝ ðə vɔɪd ðət kənteɪn hɪm, ən i wəd nɑt bi plizd. ɹeɪdʒ ɛnvɛləp mɔɹaɪɾɪn, blʌd paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. ə moʊmən pæst, hi hæd nɑt kɛɹd wɛɹ ðoʊz wɪmən wɛnt, bʌt naʊ. . . . sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ fɹəm hɪɹ. pipəl fliɪŋ ɹæn əz fɑɹ ən əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd. sʌmwɛɹ ðeɪ fɛl seɪf. noʊ jus sɛndɪŋ mæɾɪk tə æsk kwɛstʃənz, noʊ jus skwizɪŋ ɛniwʌn hɪɹ; ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ful ɪnʌf tə liv ɛniwʌn bɪhaɪn əlaɪv u nu ðɛɹ dɛstəneɪʃən. nɑt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. tə ælθɹ? tə ðət bæn ə ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪn ɔl θɹi pleɪsəz i hæɾ aɪz, səm ðət dɪd nɑt noʊ ðeɪ sɝv hɪm. ɔl wəd sɝv hɪm, bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnd. hi wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ tʃæns slɪps tə spɔɪl ɪz plænz naʊ.

He seized the True. Power without thought, the saa billowing black across his sight. His fingers tightened in the wrought-iron grille across the window; the metal groaned, twisting, not from his grip but from the tendrils of the True Power, drawn from the Great Lord himself, that wreathed around the grillework, flexing as he flexed his hand in anger. The Great Lord would not be pleased. He had strained from his prison to touch the world enough to fix the seasons in place. He was impatient to touch the world more, to shatter the void that contained him, and he would not be pleased. Rage enveloped Moridin, blood pounding in his ears. A moment past, he had not cared where those women went, but now. . . . Somewhere far from here. People fleeing ran as far and as fast as they could. Somewhere they felt safe. No use sending Madic to ask questions, no use squeezing anyone here; they would not have been fool enough to leave anyone behind alive who knew their destination. Not to Tar Valon. To al'Thor? To that band of rebel Aes Sedai? In all three places he had eyes, some that did not know they served him. All would serve him, before the end. He would not allow chance slips to spoil his plans now.

əbɹʌpli hi hɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ðə θʌndɝɪŋ dʒɹʌmbiɾ ə hɪz oʊn fjʊɹi. ə bʌbəlɪŋ saʊnd. hi lʊkt ət mæɾɪk kjʊɹiəsli, ən stɛp bæk fɹəm ðə spɹɛɾɪŋ pʌɾəl ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪn ɪz æŋɡɝ i hæd sizd ət mɔɹ ðən ðə ɹɔt-aɪɝn skɹin wɪð ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ. ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ mʌtʃ blʌd kəd bi skwiz fɹəm ə hjumən bɑɾi.

Abruptly he heard something other than the thundering drumbeat of his own fury. A bubbling sound. He looked at Madic curiously, and stepped back from the spreading puddle on the floor. It seemed that in his anger he had seized at more than the wrought-iron screen with the True Power. Remarkable how much blood could be squeezed from a human body.

hi lɛt wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə mæn fɔl wɪθaʊt ɹəɡɹɛt; ɪndid, θɪŋkɪŋ oʊnli ðət wən mæɾɪk wɑz faʊnd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd ʃʊɹli bi bleɪmd. ə smɔl ədɪʃən tə ðə keɪɑs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. ɹɪpɪŋ ə hoʊl ɪn ðə fæbɹɪk ə ðə pæɾɝn, hi tʃɹævəld wɪð ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ. hi hæd tə faɪn ðoʊz wɪmən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ juz ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. ən feɪlɪŋ ðæt. . . . hi dɪslaɪk pipəl mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ɪz kɛɹfəli leɪd plænz. ðoʊz u dɪd soʊ ən lɪvd, lɪv tə peɪ.

He let what remained of the man fall without regret; indeed, thinking only that when Madic was found, the Aes Sedai would surely be blamed. A small addition to the chaos growing in the world. Ripping a hole in the fabric of the Pattern, he Traveled with the True Power. He had to find those women before they used this Bowl of the Winds. And failing that. . . . He disliked people meddling with his carefully laid plans. Those who did so and lived, lived to pay.

ðə ɡoʊləm stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum kɔʃəsli, nɑstʃɹəlz ɔlɹɛɾi twɪtʃɪŋ wɪð ðə sɛn ə stɪl hɑt blʌd. ðə lɪvɪd bɝn ɑn ɪts tʃik sim laɪk ə laɪv koʊl. ðə ɡoʊləm əpɪɹd tə bi mɪɹli ə slɛndɝ mæn, ə lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən ævɝɪdʒ ɪn ðɪs taɪm, jɛɾ ɪt hæd nɛvɝ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd hɑɹm ɪt. əntɪl ðət mæn wɪð ðə mədæljən. wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn smaɪl əɹ snɑɹl bɛɹɾ ɪts tiθ. kjʊɹiəs, ɪt pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ bɪɑn ðə kɹʌʃt kɔɹps ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ən ə . . . fil . . . ʌv sʌmθɪŋ. nɑt ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪt . . . ɪtʃ, ɪf nɑt kwaɪɾ ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ. kjʊɹiɑsəɾi hæd bɹɔɾ ɪt hɪɹ. pɑɹts ə ðə ɡɹɪl oʊvɝ ðə wɪndoʊ wɝ kɹʌʃt, pʊlɪŋ ðə hoʊl θɪŋ lus ət ðə saɪdz. ðə ɡoʊləm sim tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪtʃ ɪn ðət mænɝ, jɛt soʊ mʌtʃ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt ɹɪkɔld wɑz fɑɡd ən dɪm. ðə wɝl hæd tʃeɪnʒd, əz ɪt simd, ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə wɝld ʌv wɔɹ ən kɪlɪŋ ɑn ə hjudʒ skeɪl, wɪð wɛpənz ðət ɹitʃt əkɹɔs maɪlz, əkɹɔs θaʊzənz ə maɪlz, ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz . . . ðɪs. bʌt ðə ɡoʊləm hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd. ɪt wɑz stɪl ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs wɛpən ʌv ɔl.

The gholam stepped into the room cautiously, nostrils already twitching with the scent of still hot blood. The livid burn on its cheek seemed like a live coal. The gholam appeared to be merely a slender man, a little taller than average in this time, yet it had never encountered anything that could harm it. Until that man with the medallion. What might have been smile or snarl bared its teeth. Curious, it peered around the room, but there was nothing beyond the crushed corpse on the floor tiles. And a . . . feel . . . of something. Not the One Power, but something that made it . . . itch, if not quite in the same way. Curiosity had brought it here. Parts of the grille over the window were crushed, pulling the whole thing loose at the sides. The gholam seemed to remember something that made it itch in that manner, yet so much of what it recalled was fogged and dim. The world had changed, as it seemed, in the blink of an eye. There had been a world of war and killing on a huge scale, with weapons that reached across miles, across thousands of miles, and then there was . . . this. But the gholam had not changed. It was still the most dangerous weapon of all.

ɪts nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹɾ əɡɛn, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt baɪ sɛn ðəɾ ɪt tʃɹæk ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl. ðə wʌn paʊɝ hæd bɪn juz bɪloʊ, ən maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ. tə fɑloʊ, əɹ nɑt? ðə mæn u hæd wundəɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt wɪð ðɛm; ɪt hæd meɪd ʃʊɹ ə ðət bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə haɪ væntədʒ pleɪs. ðə wʌn u kəmændəɾ ɪt wɑntəd ðə mæn u hæd wundəɾ ɪt dɛd pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd ðə wɪmən, bʌt ðə wɪmən wɝ ən iziɝ tɑɹɡət. ðə wɪmən hæd bɪn neɪmd, tu, ən fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, ɪt wɑz kənstʃɹeɪnd. fəɹ ɪts ɪntaɪɝ ɛɡzɪstəns ɪt hæd bɪn kəmpɛl tə oʊbeɪ wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ hjumən, bʌɾ ɪts maɪn hɛl ðə kɑnsɛpt ə nɑt biɪŋ kənstʃɹeɪnd. ɪt mʌs fɑloʊ ðə wɪmən. ɪt wɑntəd tə fɑloʊ. ðə moʊmən ə dɛθ, wən ɪt fɛl ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl vænɪʃ əlɔŋ wɪð laɪf, pɹədust ɛkstəsi. ɹæptʃɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hʌŋɡɹi, tu, ən ðəɹ wɑz taɪm. wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd ɹʌn, ɪt kəd fɑloʊ. sɛɾəlɪŋ fludli bɪsaɪd ðə mæŋɡəl bɑɾi, ɪt bɪɡæn tə fid. fɹɛʃ blʌd, hɑt blʌd, wɑz ə nəsɛsəɾi, bʌt hjumən blʌɾ ɔlweɪz hɛl ðə swiɾəst seɪvɝ.

Its nostrils flared again, though it was not by scent that it tracked those who could channel. The One Power had been used below, and miles to the north. To follow, or not? The man who had wounded it was not with them; it had made sure of that before leaving the high vantage place. The one who commanded it wanted the man who had wounded it dead perhaps as much as he did the women, but the women were an easier target. The women had been named, too, and for the time being, it was constrained. For its entire existence it had been compelled to obey one or another human, but its mind held the concept of not being constrained. It must follow the women. It wanted to follow. The moment of death, when it felt the ability to channel vanish along with life, produced ecstasy. Rapture. But it was hungry, too, and there was time. Where they could run, it could follow. Settling fluidly beside the mangled body, it began to feed. Fresh blood, hot blood, was a necessity, but human blood always held the sweetest savor.


tʃæptɝ θɹi


CHAPTER 3

eɪ plɛzən ɹaɪd


A Pleasant Ride

fɑɹmz ən pæstʃɝz ən ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə læn ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt mɛni smɔl fɔɹəsts stʃɹɛtʃt ə fju maɪlz əkɹɔs əz wɛl, ən waɪl ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz mʌtʃ flæɾɝ ðən ðə ɹænən hɪlz tə ðə saʊθ, ɪt ɹoʊld ən səmtaɪmz ɹoʊz ɪn ə pɹɑmənəns ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd fiɾ əɹ haɪɝ, səfɪʃən tə kæs dip ʃædoʊz ɪn ði æftɝnun sʌn. ɔl ɪn ɔl, ðə kʌntʃɹi pɹəvaɪɾəd mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf kʌvɝ tə kip ənwɔntɪɾ aɪz fɹəm wʌt maɪɾ əv pæst əz səm ɑd mɝtʃəns pæk tʃɹeɪn, nɪɹli fɪfti pipəl maʊntəɾ ən ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni əfʊt, ɪspɛʃli wən ɪt hæd wɔɹɾɝz tə faɪn ənfɹikwəntɪd pæðz θɹu ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt saɪɾ ə mɑɹk ə hjumən hæbəteɪʃən bɪɑn ə fju ɡoʊts kɹɑpɪŋ ɑn səm ə ðə hɪlz.

Farms and pastures and olive groves covered most of the land around Ebou Dar, but many small forests stretched a few miles across as well, and while the ground was much flatter than the Rhannon Hills to the south, it rolled and sometimes rose in a prominence of a hundred feet or higher, sufficient to cast deep shadows in the afternoon sun. All in all, the country provided more than enough cover to keep unwanted eyes from what might have passed as some odd merchant's pack train, nearly fifty people mounted and almost as many afoot, especially when it had Warders to find unfrequented paths through the undergrowth. Elayne did not sight a mark of human habitation beyond a few goats cropping on some of the hills.

ivən plæns ən tʃɹiz juz tə hit wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə wɪðɝ ən daɪ, jɛɾ əɾ ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm ʃi maɪɾ əv ɛndʒɔɪd mɪɹli siɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ə θaʊzən liɡz fɹəm ðə lænd ʃi hæd sin ɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ði ʌðɝ bæŋk ə ði ɪldɑɹ. ðə hɪlz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ, nɑbi ʃeɪps, əz ðoʊ skwiz təɡɛðɝ baɪ hjudʒ, kɛɹləs hænz. flɑks ə bɹɪljənli hjud bɝdz sɔɹɾ ʌp ət ðɛɹ pæsɪŋ, ən ə dʌzən sɔɹts ə hʌmɪŋbɝdz flɪɾɪd əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɔɹsəz, hʌvɝɪŋ dʒuəlz ɑn blɝd wɪŋz. θɪk vaɪnz hʌŋ laɪk ɹoʊps ɪn səm pleɪsəz, ən ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹiz wɪð bʌndəlz ə nɛɹoʊ fɹɑnz ət ðə tɑp fəɹ foʊlɪdʒ, ən θɪŋz ðət lʊk laɪk ɡɹin fɛðɝ dʌstɝz əz tɔl əz ə mæn. ə hændfʊl ə plæns, ful baɪ ðə hit, stʃɹʌɡəl tə pʊɾ aʊt blɑsəmz, bɹaɪt ɹɛdz ən vɪvəd jɛloʊz, səm twaɪs əz waɪɾ əz əɹ tu hænz. ðɛɹ pɝfjum wɑz lʌʃ ən - "sʌltʃɹi" keɪm tə maɪnd. ʃi sɔ səm boʊldɝz ʃi wʊɾə weɪdʒɝd hæd wʌns bɪn toʊz ɑn ə stætʃu, ðoʊ waɪ ɛniwʌn wəd meɪk ə stætʃu ðət lɑɹdʒ wɪð bɛɹ fit ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən, ən ənʌðɝ taɪm ðə weɪ lɛd θɹu ə fɔɹəst ə θɪk fluɾəd stoʊnz əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ðə wɛðɝd stʌmps ə kɑləmz, mɛni tɑpəld ən ɔl lɔŋ sɪns maɪn ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊn fəɹ ðɛɹ stoʊn baɪ loʊkəl fɑɹmɝz. ə plɛzən ɹaɪd dɪspaɪt ðə dʌs ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz ɹeɪz fɹəm pɑɹtʃt sɔɪl. ðə hit dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðəɹ wɝ nɑt vɛɹi mɛni flaɪz. ɔl ðə deɪnʒɝz leɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm; ðeɪ hæɾ aʊtʃɹʌn ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ən noʊ tʃæns ɛni ʌv əm əɹ ðɛɹ sɝvəns kəd kætʃ ʌp naʊ. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ə plɛzən ɹaɪd, ɪksɛpt. . . .

Even plants and trees used to heat were beginning to wither and die, yet at any other time she might have enjoyed merely seeing the countryside. It could have been a thousand leagues from the land she had seen riding down the other bank of the Eldar. The hills were strange, knobby shapes, as though squeezed together by huge, careless hands. Flocks of brilliantly hued birds soared up at their passing, and a dozen sorts of hummingbirds flitted away from the horses, hovering jewels on blurred wings. Thick vines hung like ropes in some places, and there were trees with bundles of narrow fronds at the top for foliage, and things that looked like green feather dusters as tall as a man. A handful of plants, fooled by the heat, struggled to put out blossoms, bright reds and vivid yellows, some twice as wide as her two hands. Their perfume was lush and - "sultry" came to mind. She saw some boulders she would have wagered had once been toes on a statue, though why anyone would make a statue that large with bare feet she could not imagine, and another time the way led through a forest of thick fluted stones among the trees, the weathered stumps of columns, many toppled and all long since mined almost to the ground for their stone by local farmers. A pleasant ride despite the dust the horses' hooves raised from parched soil. The heat did not touch her, of course, and there were not very many flies. All the dangers lay behind them; they had outrun the Forsaken, and no chance any of them or their servants could catch up now. It could have been a pleasant ride, except. . . .

fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, eɪvinhə lɝn ðət ðə mɛsədʒ ʃi hæd sɛn əbaʊɾ ɛnəmiz kʌmɪŋ wən list ɪkspɛktəd hæd nɑt bɪn dɪlɪvɝd. ət fɝst ɪleɪn fɛlt ɹɪlif əɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə tɑpɪk fɹəm ɹænd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə dʒɛləsi kʌm bæk; ɹæðɝ, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf wɑntɪŋ wʌɾ eɪvinhə hæd ʃɛɹd wɪð hɪm. nɑt dʒɛləsi. ɛnvi. ʃi wəɾ ɔlmoʊst əv pɹəfɝd ði ʌðɝ. ðən ʃi bɪɡæn ɹɪli hɪɹɪŋ wʌɾ əɹ fɹɛnd wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ mɑnətoʊn, ən ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk tʃɹaɪd tə stænd.

For one thing, Aviendha learned that the message she had sent about enemies coming when least expected had not been delivered. At first Elayne felt relief at anything to change the topic from Rand. It was not the jealousy come back; rather, more and more she found herself wanting what Aviendha had shared with him. Not jealousy. Envy. She would almost have preferred the other. Then she began really hearing what her friend was saying in a low monotone, and the hair on the back of her neck tried to stand.

"ju kæn də ðæt," ʃi pɹətɛstəd, ɹeɪnɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs kloʊsɝ tə eɪvinhəz. æktʃəli , ʃi səpoʊzd eɪvinhə wəd nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl dʒɹʌbɪŋ kɹɪn, əɹ taɪɪŋ əɹ ʌp, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə ɹɛst. ɪf ði ʌðɝ si foʊk wɪmən stʊd stɪl fəɹ ɪt, ɛniweɪ. "wi kæn stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ wɪð ðɛm, sɝɾənli nɑt bɪfɔɹ wi juz ðə boʊl. ən nɑɾ oʊvɝ ðɪs," ʃi æɾəd heɪstəli. "nɑɾ əɾ ɔl." ðeɪ sɝɾənli wɝ gɑnə tə stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ bɪfɔɹ əɹ æftɝ ðə boʊl wɑz juzd. nɑt dʒʌs kəz ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ bɪheɪvɪŋ mɔɹ haɪ-hændɪdli baɪ ði aʊɝ. nɑt dʒʌs bɪkɔz. . . . dʒɹɔɪŋ bɹɛθ, ʃi hɝiɾ ɑn. "ɪf ʃi hæd toʊl mi, aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv noʊn wʌt jə mɛnt. aɪ ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə kʊdn spik mɔɹ klɪɹli, bʌt jə də si, doʊn ju?"

"You can't do that," she protested, reining her horse closer to Aviendha's. Actually, she supposed Aviendha would not have much trouble drubbing Kurin, or tying her up, or any of the rest. If the other Sea Folk women stood still for it, anyway. "We can't start a war with them, certainly not before we use the Bowl. And not over this," she added hastily. "Not at all." They certainly were not going to start a war before or after the Bowl was used. Not just because the Windfinders were behaving more high-handedly by the hour. Not just because. . . . Drawing breath, she hurried on. "If she had told me, I would not have known what you meant. I understand why you couldn't speak more clearly, but you do see, don't you?"

eɪvinhə ɡlɛɹɾ əhɛɾ ət nʌθɪŋ, æbsənli bɹʌʃɪŋ flaɪz əweɪ fɹəm əɹ feɪs. "wɪθaʊt feɪl, aɪ toʊl hɝ," ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld. "wɪθaʊt feɪl! wʌɾ ɪf i hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld? wʌɾ ɪf i hæd mænədʒ tə ɡɛt baɪ mi θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən jə wɪð noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ? wʌɾ ɪf . . . ?" ʃi tɝn ə sʌɾənli fɝlɔɹn ɡeɪz ɑn ɪleɪn. "aɪ wɪl baɪt maɪ naɪf," ʃi sɛd sædli, "bʌt maɪ lɪvɝ meɪ bɝs fəɹ ɪt."

Aviendha glared ahead at nothing, absently brushing flies away from her face. "Without fail, I told her," she grumbled. "Without fail! What if he had been one of the Shadowsouled? What if he had managed to get by me through the gateway, and you with no warning? What if . . . ?" She turned a suddenly forlorn gaze on Elayne. "I will bite my knife," she said sadly, "but my liver may burst for it."

ɪleɪn wɑz əbaʊt tə seɪ ðət swɑloʊɪŋ əɹ æŋɡɝ wɑz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə də ən ʃi kəd pɪtʃ əz lɑɹdʒ ə fɪɾ əz ʃi wɑntəd soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd nɑt hɝl ɪɾ ət ði æθɑn maɪɹ - ðət wɑz wʌɾ ɔl ðəɾ əbaʊt naɪvz ən lɪvɝz mɛnt - bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, æɾɪliz bɹɔɾ əɹ ɹeɪnʒi ɡɹeɪ ʌp ɑn əɹ ʌðɝ saɪd. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd sɪstɝ hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə nu sæɾəl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ə ɡɔɾi θɪŋ wɝkt wɪð sɪlvɝ ɑn pɑməl ən kæntəl. ðə flaɪz sim tə əvɔɪd hɝ, fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðoʊ ʃi wɔɹ ə sɛn əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛni ʌv ðə flaʊɝz.

Elayne was about to say that swallowing her anger was the right thing to do and she could pitch as large a fit as she wanted so long as she did not hurl it at the Atha'an Miere - that was what all that about knives and livers meant - but before she could open her mouth, Adeleas brought her rangy gray up on her other side. The white-haired sister had acquired a new saddle in Ebou Dar, a gaudy thing worked with silver on pommel and cantle. The flies seemed to avoid her, for some reason, though she wore a scent as strong as any of the flowers.

"pɑɹɾən mi. aɪ kəd nɑt hɛlp oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ ðət læst." æɾɪliz dɪd nɑt saʊn əɾ ɔl əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk, ən ɪleɪn wʌndɝd dʒʌs haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd. ʃi fɛlt əɹ tʃiks kʌlɝɪŋ. səm ʌv wʌɾ eɪvinhə hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt ɹænd hæd bɪn ɹɪmɑɹkəbli fɹæŋk ən stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. səm ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd hæd bɪn, tu. ɪt wɑz wʌn θɪŋ tə tɔk ðət weɪ wɪð jəɹ nɪɹəs fɹɛnd, kwaɪɾ ənʌðɝ tə səspɛk sʌmwʌn ɛls hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ. eɪvinhə sim tə fil ðə seɪm weɪ; ʃi dɪd nɑt blʌʃ, bʌt ðə saʊɝ lʊk ʃi ʃɑɾ ət ðə bɹaʊn wʊɾə dʌn nɪneɪiv pɹaʊd.

"Pardon me. I could not help overhearing that last." Adeleas did not sound at all apologetic, and Elayne wondered just how much she had overheard. She felt her cheeks coloring. Some of what Aviendha had said about Rand had been remarkably frank and straightforward. Some of what she had said had been, too. It was one thing to talk that way with your nearest friend, quite another to suspect someone else had been listening. Aviendha seemed to feel the same way; she did not blush, but the sour look she shot at the Brown would have done Nynaeve proud.

æɾɪliz mɪɹli smaɪld, ə veɪɡ smaɪl əz blæn əz wɔɾɝ sup. "ɪt maɪt bi bɛst ɪf jə ɡeɪv jəɹ fɹɛn ðəɹ fɹi ɹeɪn wɪð ði æθɑn maɪɹ." ʃi pɪɹd pæst ɪleɪn əɾ eɪvinhə, blɪŋkɪŋ. "wɛl, ə lus ɹeɪn. pʊɾɪŋ ðə fɪɹ ə ðə laɪɾ ɪndə ðɛm ɔt tə bi səfɪʃənt. ðəɹ ɔlmoʊs ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi, ɪn keɪs jə hævənt noʊɾəst. ðəɹ mʌtʃ mɔɹ wɛɹi ʌv ðə 'sævədʒ' il - fɝɡɪv mi, eɪvinhə - ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɛɝɪlɪl wʊɾə sədʒɛstəɾ ɪt, bʌɾ əɹ ɪɹz ɑɹ stɪl bɝnɪŋ."

Adeleas merely smiled, a vague smile as bland as water soup. "It might be best if you gave your friend there free rein with the Atha'an Miere." She peered past Elayne at Aviendha, blinking. "Well, a loose rein. Putting the fear of the Light into them ought to be sufficient. They're almost there already, in case you haven't noticed. They're much more wary of the 'savage' Aiel - forgive me, Aviendha - than they are of Aes Sedai. Merilille would have suggested it, but her ears are still burning."

eɪvinhəz feɪs ɹɛɹli ɡeɪv mʌtʃ əweɪ, bʌt ɹaɪt ðən ʃi lʊkt əz pʌzəld əz ɪleɪn fɛlt. ɪleɪn twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə fɹaʊn bɪhaɪn hɝ. mɛɝɪlɪl ɹoʊɾ əbɹɛst wɪð vændin, kɛɝin, ən sɝaɪðə nɑt fɑɹ bæk, ɔl vɛɹi stuɾiəsli lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɪleɪn. bɪɑn ðə sɪstɝz wɝ ðə si foʊk, stɪl ɪn sɪŋɡəl faɪl, ən ðən wəd kʌm ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, kipɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz aʊɾ ə saɪt fəɹ ðə moʊmən dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ðeɪ wɝ θɹɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə ɡleɪdz ə tʃɹʌŋkeɪɾɪd kɑləmz. fɪfti əɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd lɔŋ-teɪld ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin bɝdz wɪŋd oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz, fɪlɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð tʃæɾɝɪŋ kɹaɪz.

Aviendha's face rarely gave much away, but right then she looked as puzzled as Elayne felt. Elayne twisted in her saddle to frown behind her. Merilille rode abreast with Vandene, Careane, and Sareitha not far back, all very studiously looking at anything except Elayne. Beyond the sisters were the Sea Folk, still in single file, and then would come the Knitting Circle, keeping themselves out of sight for the moment just ahead of the packhorses. They were threading their way through the glades of truncated columns. Fifty or a hundred long-tailed red-and-green birds winged over their heads, filling the air with chattering cries.

"waɪ?" ɪleɪn æskt kɝtli. ɪt sim fulɪʃ tə æd tə ðə tɝmɔɪl ɔlɹɛɾi bʌbəlɪŋ dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə sɝfəs - ən səmtaɪmz ɑn ðə sɝfəs - bʌt ʃi hæd sin noʊ hɪn ə ðə ful ɪn æɾɪliz. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɪn əpɛɹən sɝpɹaɪz. meɪbi ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd; æɾɪliz juʒəwəli θɔɾ ɛniwʌn ʃəd si wʌt ʃi sɔ. meɪbi.

"Why?" Elayne asked curtly. It seemed foolish to add to the turmoil already bubbling just below the surface - and sometimes on the surface - but she had seen no hint of the fool in Adeleas. The Brown sister's eyebrows rose in apparent surprise. Maybe she was surprised; Adeleas usually thought anyone should see what she saw. Maybe.

"waɪ? tə ɹɪstɔɹ ə lɪɾəl bæləns, ðəɾ ɪz waɪ. ɪf ði æθɑn maɪɹ fil ðeɪ niɾ əs tə pɹətɛkt əm fɹəm ən il, ɪt maɪt bi ə jusfəl bæləns əɡɛnst. . . ." æɾɪliz pɔz slaɪtli, sʌɾənli əbzɔɹbd ɪn ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ peɪl ɡɹeɪ skɝts. ". . . ʌðɝ θɪŋz."

"Why? To restore a little balance, that is why. If the Atha'an Miere feel they need us to protect them from an Aiel, it might be a useful balance against. . . ." Adeleas paused slightly, suddenly absorbed in adjusting her pale gray skirts. ". . . other things."

ɪleɪnz feɪs taɪɾənd. ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ðə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə si foʊk wɑz wʌɾ æɾɪliz mɛnt. "ju meɪ ɹaɪd wɪð ði ʌðɝz," ʃi sɛd kuli.

Elayne's face tightened. Other things. The bargain with the Sea Folk was what Adeleas meant. "You may ride with the others," she said coolly.

æɾɪliz meɪd noʊ pɹoʊɾɛst, noʊ ətɛmps tə pɹɛs əɹ ɑɹɡjəmənt. ʃi dʒʌst ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛɾ ən lɛɾ əɹ hɔɹs fɔl bæk. hɝ smɔl smaɪl nɛvɝ ɔltɝɾ ə wɪt. ði oʊldɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ æksɛptɪd ðət nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn stʊɾ əbʌv əm ən spoʊk wɪð ɛɡwinz əθɔɹəɾi ət ðɛɹ bæks, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, ðət tʃeɪnʒd lɪɾəl bɪɑn ðə sɝfəs. pɝhæps nʌθɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ aʊtwɝdli ɹɪspɛkfəl, ðeɪ oʊbeɪd, ən jɛt. . . .

Adeleas made no protest, no attempts to press her argument. She just inclined her head and let her horse fall back. Her small smile never altered a whit. The older Aes Sedai accepted that Nynaeve and Elayne stood above them and spoke with Egwene's authority at their backs, but the truth was, that changed little beyond the surface. Perhaps nothing. They were outwardly respectful, they obeyed, and yet. . . .

æftɝ ɔl wɑz sɛɾ ən dʌn, ɪleɪn, ət list, wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ əɾ ən eɪdʒ wən moʊst ɪnɪʃiəts ə ðə taʊɝ stɪl wɔɹ nɑvəs waɪɾ ən vɛɹi fju hæd ɹitʃt ði æksɛptɪd. ən ʃi ən nɪneɪiv hæɾ əɡɹid tə ðət bɑɹɡən, hɑɹdli ə dɪspleɪ ʌv wɪzdəm ən əkjumən. nɑt dʒʌs ðə si foʊk ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə boʊl, bʌt twɛnti sɪstɝz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, sʌbʒɪkt tə ðɛɹ lɔz, ɹikwaɪɝd tə titʃ ɛniθɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɑntəd tə lɝn ən əneɪbəl tə liv əntɪl ʌðɝz keɪm tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm. wɪndfɪndɝz əlaʊd tə ɛntɝ ðə taʊɝ əz ɡɛsts, əlaʊd tə lɝn wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɪʃt, liv wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɪʃt. ðoʊz əloʊn wəd meɪk ðə hɔl skɹim, ən pɹɑbli ɛɡwin əz wɛl, jɛt ðə ɹɛst. . . . ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ði oʊldɝ sɪstɝz θɔt ʃi wʊɾə faʊn ə weɪ ɝaʊn meɪkɪŋ ðət bɑɹɡən. pɝhæps ðeɪ ɹɪli kəd hæv. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ.

After all was said and done, Elayne, at least, was Aes Sedai at an age when most initiates of the Tower still wore novice white and very few had reached the Accepted. And she and Nynaeve had agreed to that bargain, hardly a display of wisdom and acumen. Not just the Sea Folk getting the Bowl, but twenty sisters going to the Atha'an Miere, subject to their laws, required to teach anything the Windfinders wanted to learn and unable to leave until others came to replace them. Windfinders allowed to enter the Tower as guests, allowed to learn whatever they wished, leave whenever they wished. Those alone would make the Hall scream, and probably Egwene as well, yet the rest. . . . Every last one of the older sisters thought she would have found a way around making that bargain. Perhaps they really could have. Elayne did not believe it, but she was not sure.

ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ tə eɪvinhə, bʌɾ æftɝ ə fju moʊməns, ði ʌðɝ wʊmən spoʊk. "ɪf aɪ kən sɝv ɑnɝ ən hɛlp jə ət ðə seɪm taɪm, aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ɪt sɝvz səm ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛnd." ʃi nɛvɝ sim tə teɪk ɪɾ ɪn ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑt kəmplitli.

She did not say anything to Aviendha, but after a few moments, the other woman spoke. "If I can serve honor and help you at the same time, I do not care whether it serves some Aes Sedai end." She never seemed to take it in that Elayne was also Aes Sedai, not completely.

ɪleɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən nɑɾəd. sʌmθɪŋ hæd tə bi dʌn tə tɛmpɝ ðə si foʊk. mɛɝɪlɪl ən ði ʌðɝz hæd dɪspleɪɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl fɔɹbɛɹəns soʊ fɑɹ, bʌt haʊ lɔŋ wəd ðət læst? nɪneɪiv maɪɾ ɪksploʊd, wʌns ʃi æktʃəli  tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃənz tə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. mæɾɝz hæd tə bi kɛpt əz smuð əz pɑsəbəl fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl, bʌɾ ɪf ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɛn ɑn bɪlivɪŋ ðeɪ kəd stɛɹ daʊn ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðəɹ wəd bi tʃɹʌbəl. laɪf wɑz mɔɹ kɑmplɛks ðən ʃi hæɾ ɪmædʒən bæk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni lɛsənz ʃi hæd ɹəsivd əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. soʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd sɪns ʃi ɛntɝd ðə taʊɝ.

Elayne hesitated, then nodded. Something had to be done to temper the Sea Folk. Merilille and the others had displayed a remarkable forbearance so far, but how long would that last? Nynaeve might explode, once she actually turned her attentions to the Windfinders. Matters had to be kept as smooth as possible for as long as possible, but if the Atha'an Miere went on believing they could stare down any Aes Sedai, there would be trouble. Life was more complex than she had imagined back in Caemlyn, no matter how many lessons she had received as Daughter-Heir. So much more complicated since she entered the Tower.

"dʒʌs doʊn bi tu . . . ɛmfæɾɪk," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "æn pliz əv ə kɛɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ twɛnti ʌv ðɛm, æftɝ ɔl, ən oʊnli wʌn ə ju. aɪ wʊdnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ tə hæpən bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd hɛlp ju." eɪvinhə ɡeɪv əɹ ə ɡɹɪn wɪð ə ɡʊd bɪɾ ʌv wʊlf ɪn ɪɾ ən dʒɹu hɝ dʌn mɛɹ ɔf ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə stoʊnz tə weɪt fəɹ ði æθɑn maɪɹ.

"Just don't be too . . . emphatic," she said softly. "And please have a care. There are twenty of them, after all, and only one of you. I wouldn't want anything to happen before I could help you." Aviendha gave her a grin with a good bit of wolf in it and drew her dun mare off at the edge of the stones to wait for the Atha'an Miere.

fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm ɪleɪn ɡlæns bæk, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi sɔ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz wɑz eɪvinhə ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɛks tə kɹɪn, spikɪŋ kwaɪt kɑmli ən nɑɾ ivən lʊkɪŋ ət ðə si foʊk wʊmən. sɝɾənli nɑt ɡlɛɹɪŋ, ðoʊ kɹɪn sim tə stɛɹ əɾ əɹ wɪð kənsɪɾɝəbəl əstɑnɪʃmənt. wən eɪvinhə θʌmpt əɹ hɔɹs bæk ʌp tə dʒɔɪn ɪleɪn, flæpɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz - ʃi wəd nɛvɝ bi ə hɔɹswʊmən - kɹɪn ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd tə spik wɪð ɹɪneɪl, ən ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ ɹɪneɪl æŋɡɹəli sɛn ɹeɪnɪn tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm.

From time to time Elayne glanced back, but all she saw through the trees was Aviendha riding next to Kurin, speaking quite calmly and not even looking at the Sea Folk woman. Certainly not glaring, though Kurin seemed to stare at her with considerable astonishment. When Aviendha thumped her horse back up to join Elayne, flapping her reins - she would never be a horsewoman - Kurin rode forward to speak with Renaile, and a short time later Renaile angrily sent Rainyn to the head of the column.

ðə moʊs dʒunjɝ ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz sæɾ əɹ hɔɹs ivən mɔɹ ɔkwɝdli ðən eɪvinhə, hum ʃi pɹitɛndəd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɑn ɪleɪnz ʌðɝ saɪd dʒʌst əz ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə smɔl ɡɹin flaɪz bʌzɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ dɑɹk feɪs. "ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn blu stɑɹ," ʃi sɛd stɪfli, "dɪmænz ðət jə snʌb ɪn ði il wʊmən, ɪleɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ." eɪvinhə ɡɹɪn tuthəli ət hɝ, ən ɹeɪnɪn mʌst əv bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ət list ə lɪɾəl, kəz əɹ tʃiks ɹɛɾənd bɪniθ ðə ʃin ə swɛt.

The most junior of the Windfinders sat her horse even more awkwardly than Aviendha, whom she pretended to ignore on Elayne's other side just as she ignored the small green flies buzzing around her dark face. "Renaile din Calon Blue Star," she said stiffly, "demands that you snub in the Aiel woman, Elayne Aes Sedai." Aviendha grinned toothily at her, and Rainyn must have been watching at least a little, because her cheeks reddened beneath the sheen of sweat.

"tɛl ɹɪneɪl ðəɾ eɪvinhə ɪz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ wɪl æsk əɹ tə bi kɛɹfəl," noʊ laɪ ðɛɹ; ʃi hæd, ən wəɾ əɡɛn, "bʌɾ aɪ kæn meɪk əɹ də ɛniθɪŋ." ɑn ɪmpəls, ʃi æɾəd, "ju noʊ haʊ il ɑɹ." ðə si foʊk hæd səm vɛɹi ɑɾ aɪdiəz ə haʊ ði il wɝ. ɹeɪnɪn stɛɹd waɪd-aɪɾ əɾ ə stɪl-ɡɹɪnɪŋ eɪvinhə, hɝ feɪs ɡoʊɪŋ ɡɹeɪ, ðən dʒɝkt əɹ hɔɹs ɝaʊn ən ɡæləp bæk tə ɹɪneɪl, baʊnsɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl.

"Tell Renaile that Aviendha is not Aes Sedai," Elayne replied. "I will ask her to be careful," no lie there; she had, and would again, "but I can't make her do anything." On impulse, she added, "You know how Aiel are." The Sea Folk had some very odd ideas of how the Aiel were. Rainyn stared wide-eyed at a still-grinning Aviendha, her face going gray, then jerked her horse around and galloped back to Renaile, bouncing in her saddle.

eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ə pliz tʃʌkəl, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðə hoʊl noʊʃən hæd bɪn ə mɪsteɪk. ivən wɪð ə ɡʊd θɝɾi peɪsɪz bɪtwin ðɛm, ʃi kəd si ɹɪneɪlz feɪs swɛl ʌp ət ɹeɪnɪnz ɹipɔɹt, ən ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn tə bʌz laɪk biz. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt lʊk fɹaɪɾənd, ðeɪ lʊkt æŋɡɹi, ən ðə ɡlɛɹz ðeɪ dɝɛktəɾ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ɡɹu beɪlfəl. nɑɾ əɾ eɪvinhə, ət ðə sɪstɝz. æɾɪliz nɑɾəd θɔtfəli wən ʃi sɔ ðæt, ən mɛɝɪlɪl dʒʌs bɛɹli feɪl tə haɪɾ ə smaɪl. ət lis ðeɪ wɝ plizd.

Aviendha gave a pleased chuckle, but Elayne wondered whether the whole notion had been a mistake. Even with a good thirty paces between them, she could see Renaile's face swell up at Rainyn's report, and the others began to buzz like bees.
