They did not look frightened, they looked angry, and the glares they directed at the Aes Sedai ahead of them grew baleful. Not at Aviendha, at the sisters. Adeleas nodded thoughtfully when she saw that, and Merilille just barely failed to hide a smile. At least they were pleased.

ɪf ðət hæd bɪn ði oʊnli ɪnsəɾənt dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹaɪɾ ɪt wʊɾə teɪkən ði ɛdʒ ɔf ɛni ɛndʒɔɪmən ə flaʊɝz ən bɝdz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ivən ðə fɝst. bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʃɔɹtli æftɝ livɪŋ ðə klɪɹɪŋ, ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl hæd meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ fɔɹwɝd tə ɪleɪn wʌn baɪ wʌn, ɔl bʌt kɝstʃən, ən noʊ daʊt ʃi wʊɾə kʌm tu hæd ʃi nɑt bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə kip ɪspæn ʃildɪd. wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ keɪm, itʃ hɛzɪɾənt, smaɪlɪŋ timɝəsli əntɪl ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə tɛl əm tə æk ðɛɹ eɪdʒəz. ðeɪ sɝɾənli meɪd noʊ dɪmænz, ən ðeɪ wɝ tu smɑɹt tə æsk stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt fəɹ wʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd bɪn dɪnaɪd, bʌt ðeɪ faʊn ʌðɝ pæðz.

If that had been the only incident during the ride it would have taken the edge off any enjoyment of flowers and birds, but it was not even the first. Beginning shortly after leaving the clearing, the Knitting Circle had made their way forward to Elayne one by one, all but Kirstian, and no doubt she would have come too had she not been ordered to keep Ispan shielded. One by one they came, each hesitant, smiling timorously until Elayne wanted to tell them to act their ages. They certainly made no demands, and they were too smart to ask straight out for what already had been denied, but they found other paths.

"ɪɾ əkɝd tə mi," ɹin sɛd bɹaɪtli, "ðæt jə mʌst wɑnə kwɛstʃən ɪspæn sədaɪ kwaɪɾ ɝdʒənli. hu kən seɪ wʌɾ ɛls ʃi wɑz ʌp tə ɪn ðə sɪɾi bɪsaɪdz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ðə stɔɹɹum?" ʃi pɹitɛndəd tə dʒʌs bi meɪkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən, bʌt fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm ʃi dɑɹɾɪd kwɪk lʊks əɾ ɪleɪn tə si haʊ ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ ɪt. "aɪm ʃʊɹ wɪl teɪk oʊvɝ ən aʊɝ tə ɹitʃ ðə fɑɹm, ðə weɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, pɝhæps tu, ən jə sɝɾənli doʊnt wɑnə weɪs tu aʊɝz. ði ɝbz nɪneɪiv sədaɪ ɡeɪv əɹ meɪk əɹ kwaɪt tɔkəɾɪv, ən aɪm ʃʊɹ ʃi wəd sɪɾ ʌp fəɹ sɪstɝz."

"It occurred to me," Reanne said brightly, "that you must want to question Ispan Sedai quite urgently. Who can say what else she was up to in the city besides trying to find the storeroom?" She pretended to just be making conversation, but from time to time she darted quick looks at Elayne to see how she was taking it. "I'm sure we'll take over an hour to reach the farm, the way we're going, perhaps two, and you certainly don't want to waste two hours. The herbs Nynaeve Sedai gave her make her quite talkative, and I'm sure she would sit up for sisters."

ðə bɹaɪt smaɪl feɪɾəd wən ɪleɪn sɛd ðət kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɪspæn kəd weɪɾ ən wʊd. laɪt, dɪd ðeɪ ɹɪli ɪkspɛkt ɛniwʌn tə æsk kwɛstʃənz ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu fɔɹəsts ɑn pæðz ðət bɛɹli dɪzɝv ðə neɪm? ɹin ɹoʊd bæk tə ði ʌðɝ kɪnswɪmən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf.

The bright smile faded when Elayne said that questioning Ispan could wait and would. Light, did they really expect anyone to ask questions riding through forests on paths that barely deserved the name? Reanne rode back to the other Kinswomen muttering to herself.

"fɝɡɪvnəs, ɪleɪn sədaɪ," tʃɪlɛɹz mɝmɝɾ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ, ðə tʃɹeɪsəz ə mʊɹændi klɪŋɪŋ tə hɝ æksɛnt. hɝ ɡɹin stʃɹɔ hæt mætʃt səm ə hɝ leɪɝd pɛɾikoʊts ɪɡzækli. "jɔɹ fɝɡɪvnəs, ɪf aɪ ɪntʃɹud." ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ðə ɹɛd bɛlt ʌv ə waɪz wʊmən; moʊst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl dɪd nɑt. ɪvɑɹə wɑz ə ɡoʊldsmɪθ, ən ɪldeɪs səplaɪd lækɹwɛɹ tə ðə mɝtʃəns fəɹ ɛkspɔɹt; tʃɪlɛɹz wɑz ə ɹʌɡ sɛlɝ, waɪl ɹin hɝsɛlf ɝeɪnʒd ʃɪpɪŋ fəɹ smɔl tʃɹeɪɾɝz. səm wɝkt ət sɪmpəl tæsks - kɝstʃən ɹæn ə taɪni wivɝz ʃɑp, ən dmænə wɑz ə simstʃɹɪs, ðoʊ ə pɹɑspɝəs wʌn - bʌt ðɛn, ɪn ðə kɔɹs ə ðɛɹ lɪvz, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl fɑloʊd mɛni kɹæfs. ən juz mɛni neɪmz. "ɪspæn sədaɪ əpɪɹz tə bi ənwɛl," tʃɪlɛɹz sɛd, ʃɪftɪŋ ənizəli ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. "pɝhæps ði ɝbz ɑɹ əfɛktɪŋ əɹ mɔɹ ðən nɪneɪiv sədaɪ θɔt. ɪt wəd bi tɛɹəbəl ɪf ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə hɝ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kən bi kwɛstʃənd, aɪ min. pɝhæps ðə sɪstɝz wəd lʊk ət hɝ? hilɪŋ, jə noʊ. . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, blɪŋkɪŋ ðoʊz bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz nɝvəsli. əz wɛl ʃi maɪt, wɪð sumeɪkoʊ əmʌŋ əɹ kəmpænjənz.

"Forgiveness, Elayne Sedai," Chilares murmured a short time later, the traces of Murandy clinging to her accent. Her green straw hat matched some of her layered petticoats exactly. "Your forgiveness, if I intrude." She did not wear the red belt of a Wise Woman; most of the Knitting Circle did not. Ivara was a goldsmith, and Eldase supplied lacquerware to the merchants for export; Chilares was a rug seller, while Reanne herself arranged shipping for small traders. Some worked at simple tasks - Kirstian ran a tiny weaver's shop, and Dimana was a seamstress, though a prosperous one - but then, in the course of their lives, they had all followed many crafts. And used many names. "Ispan Sedai appears to be unwell," Chilares said, shifting uneasily in her saddle. "Perhaps the herbs are affecting her more than Nynaeve Sedai thought. It would be terrible if anything happened to her. Before she can be questioned, I mean. Perhaps the sisters would look at her? Healing, you know. . . ." She trailed off, blinking those big brown eyes nervously. As well she might, with Sumeko among her companions.

ə ɡlæns bæk ʃoʊd ðə staʊt wʊmən stændɪŋ ɪn əɹ stɝəps tə pɪɹ pæs ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, əntɪl ʃi sɔ ɪleɪn lʊkɪŋ ən sæt bæk daʊn hɝidli. sumeɪkoʊ, hu nu mɔɹ ə hilɪŋ ðən ɛni sɪstɝ ɪksɛp nɪneɪiv. pɝhæps mɔɹ ðən nɪneɪiv. ɪleɪn sɪmpli pɔɪntəd tə ðə ɹɪɹ əntɪl tʃɪlɛɹz kʌlɝɾ ən ɹeɪn əɹ maʊn ɝaʊnd.

A glance back showed the stout woman standing in her stirrups to peer past the Windfinders, until she saw Elayne looking and sat back down hurriedly. Sumeko, who knew more of Healing than any sister except Nynaeve. Perhaps more than Nynaeve. Elayne simply pointed to the rear until Chilares colored and reined her mount around.

mɛɝɪlɪl dʒɔɪn ɪleɪn oʊnli moʊməns æftɝ ɹin lɛft, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ meɪɾ ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ pɹitɛns ət sɪmpəl tʃæt ðən ðə kɪnswʊmən hæd. ɪn əɹ mænɝ ə spikɪŋ, ət list, ʃi wɑz pɔɪz ɪtsɛlf. wʌt ʃi hæd tə seɪ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. "aɪ wʌndɝ haʊ tʃɹʌstwɝði ðoʊz wɪmən ɑɹ, ɪleɪn." hɝ lɪps pɝst ɪn dɪsteɪst əz ʃi bɹʌʃt dʌs fɹəm əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd blu skɝts wɪð ə ɡlʌv hænd. "ðeɪ seɪ ðeɪ də nɑt teɪk ɪn waɪldɝz, bʌt ɹin hɝsɛlf meɪ wɛl bi ə waɪldɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ʃi kleɪmz əbaʊt feɪlɪŋ əɹ tɛs fəɹ æksɛptɪd. sumeɪkoʊ, əz wɛl, ən sɝɾənli kɝstʃən." ə slaɪt fɹaʊn fəɹ kɝstʃən, ə dɪsmɪsɪv ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd. "ju mʌst əv noʊɾəst haʊ ʃi lips əɾ ɛni mɛnʃən ə ðə taʊɝ. ʃi noʊz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ʃi maɪɾ əv pɪkt ʌp ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð sʌmwʌn u ɹɪli wɑz pʊɾ aʊt." mɛɝɪlɪl saɪd, ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd tə seɪ; ʃi ɹɪli wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊd. "hæv jə kənsɪɾɝd ðət ðeɪ meɪ bi laɪɪŋ əbaʊɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz? ðeɪ kəd bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz, fəɹ ɔl wi noʊ, əɹ dups ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz. pɝhæps nɑt, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ hɑɹdli tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd vɛɹi fɑɹ. aɪ bɪliv ðəɹ ɪz ə fɑɹm, wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɹɪli juz ɪt fəɹ ə ɹitʃɹiɾ əɹ nɑt, əɹ aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv əɡɹid tə ðɪs, bʌɾ əl nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ə fju ɹæmʃækəl bɪldɪŋz ən ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ waɪldɝz. wɛl, nɑt ɹæmʃækəl - ðeɪ də sim tə hæv kɔɪn - bʌt ðə pɹɪnsəpəl ɪz ðə seɪm. noʊ, ðeɪ ɑɹ sɪmpli nɑt tʃɹʌstwɝði."

Merilille joined Elayne only moments after Reanne left, and the Gray sister made a much better pretense at simple chat than the Kinswoman had. In her manner of speaking, at least, she was poise itself. What she had to say was another matter. "I wonder how trustworthy those women are, Elayne." Her lips pursed in distaste as she brushed dust from her divided blue skirts with a gloved hand. "They say they do not take in wilders, but Reanne herself may well be a wilder, whatever she claims about failing her test for Accepted. Sumeko, as well, and certainly Kirstian." A slight frown for Kirstian, a dismissive shake of her head. "You must have noticed how she leaps at any mention of the Tower. She knows no more than she might have picked up in conversation with someone who really was put out." Merilille sighed, regretting what she had to say; she really was very good. "Have you considered that they may be lying about other things? They could be Darkfriends, for all we know, or dupes of Darkfriends. Perhaps not, but they are hardly to be trusted very far. I believe there is a farm, whether they really use it for a retreat or not, or I would not have agreed to this, but I will not be surprised to find a few ramshackle buildings and a dozen or so wilders. Well, not ramshackle - they do seem to have coin - but the principle is the same. No, they are simply not trustworthy."

ɪleɪn bɪɡæn ə sloʊ bɝn əz sun əz ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə dɝɛkʃən mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz teɪkɪŋ, ən ɪt ɡɹu hɑɾɝ. əz ðɪs slɪpɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ɔl ðɪs "meɪ" ən "kʊd" soʊ ðə wʊmən kəɾ ɪnsɪnjueɪt θɪŋz ʃi hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑt bɪliv. dɑɹkfɹɛnz? ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl hæd fɔt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. tu hæd daɪd. ən wɪθaʊt sumeɪkoʊ ən iin, nɪneɪiv maɪt bi dɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪspæn ə pɹɪznɝ. noʊ, ðə ɹizən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd wɑz nɑt kəz mɛɝɪlɪl fɪɹd ðeɪ wɝ swɔɹn tə ðə ʃædoʊ, əɹ ʃi wʊɾə sɛd soʊ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd kəz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tʃɹʌstɪd, ðən ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə hoʊld ɪspæn.

Elayne began a slow burn as soon as she realized the direction Merilille was taking, and it grew hotter. As this slipping around, all this "may" and "could" so the woman could insinuate things she herself did not believe. Darkfriends? The Knitting Circle had fought Darkfriends. Two had died. And without Sumeko and Ieine, Nynaeve might be dead instead of Ispan a prisoner. No, the reason they were not to be trusted was not because Merilille feared they were sworn to the Shadow, or she would have said so. They were not to be trusted because if they were not trusted, then they could not be allowed to hold Ispan.

ʃi swɑɾɪd ə bɪɡ ɡɹin flaɪ ðət hæd sɛɾəld ɑn laɪoʊnəsəz nɛk, pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪlz læst wɝd wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ dʒɝkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "haʊ dɛɹ ju?" ɪleɪn bɹiðd. "ðeɪ feɪst ɪspæn ən fæljən ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ən ðə ɡoʊləm, nɑt tə mɛnʃən tu dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ tʌfs wɪð sɔɹdz. jə wɝn ðɛɹ." ðət wɑz hɑɹdli fɛɹ. mɛɝɪlɪl ən ðə ɹɛs hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪn kəz ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ɑbviəs ɛɛs sədaɪ, maɪɾ əz wɛl bi tʃɹʌmpəts ən dʒɹʌmz fəɹ ði ətɛnʃən ðeɪ ətʃɹæktəd. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hɝ æŋɡɝ ɡɹu baɪ ðə moʊmənt, ən əɹ vɔɪs ɹoʊz baɪ ðə wɝd. "ju wɪl nɛvɝ sədʒɛst sətʃ ə θɪŋ tə mi əɡɛn. nɛvɝ! nɑt wɪθaʊt hɑɹɾ ɛvəɾəns! nɑt wɪθaʊt pɹuf! ɪf jə du, əl sɛt jə ə pɛnəns ðət wɪl meɪk jəɹ aɪz pɑp!" noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ haɪ ʃi stʊɾ əbʌv ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, ʃi hæd noʊ əθɔɹəɾi tə sɛɾ əɹ ɛni pɛnəns əɾ ɔl, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ. "aɪl meɪk jə wɔk ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn! iɾɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌt bɹɛɾ ən wɔɾɝ ði ɪntaɪɝ weɪ! əl pʊt jə ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒ, ən tɛl əm tə slæp jə daʊn ɪf jə seɪ bu tə ə ɡus!"

She swatted a big green fly that had settled on Lioness's neck, punctuating Merilille's last word with a loud crack, and the Gray sister jerked in surprise. "How dare you?" Elayne breathed. "They faced Ispan and Falion in the Rahad, and the gholam, not to mention two dozen or more toughs with swords. You weren't there." That was hardly fair. Merilille and the rest had been left behind because Aes Sedai in the Rahad, obvious Aes Sedai, might as well be trumpets and drums for the attention they attracted. She did not care. Her anger grew by the moment, and her voice rose by the word. "You will never suggest such a thing to me again. Never! Not without hard evidence! Not without proof! If you do, I'll set you a penance that will make your eyes pop!" No matter how high she stood above the other woman, she had no authority to set her any penance at all, but she did not care about that, either. "I'll make you walk the rest of the way to Tar Valon! Eating nothing but bread and water the entire way! I'll put you in their charge, and tell them to slap you down if you say boo to a goose!"

ɪt dɔn ɑn əɹ ðət ʃi wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ. səm sɔɹɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪ-ænd-waɪt bɝdz wɛn flɪɾɝɪŋ pæst oʊvɝhɛɾ ɪn ə bɹɔd bænd, ən ʃi wɑz dʒɹaʊnɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ kɹaɪz. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɑm hɝsɛlf. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv ə vɔɪs fəɹ ʃaʊɾɪŋ; ɪɾ ɔlweɪz keɪm aʊɾ əz ə ʃɹik. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, moʊst ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. eɪvinhə nɑɾəd əpɹuvɪŋli. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wʊɾə dʌn ðə seɪm hæɾ ɪleɪn plʌnʒd ə naɪf ɪndə mɛɝɪlɪlz hɑɹt. eɪvinhə stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ fɹɛnz noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. mɛɝɪlɪlz kɛɹhinɪn pælnəs hæd bɪkʌm dɛd waɪt.

It dawned on her that she was shouting. Some sort of gray-and-white birds went flittering past overhead in a broad band, and she was drowning out their cries. Drawing a deep breath, she tried to calm herself. She did not have a voice for shouting; it always came out as a shriek. Everyone was looking at her, most in astonishment. Aviendha nodded approvingly. Of course, she would have done the same had Elayne plunged a knife into Merilille's heart. Aviendha stood beside her friends no matter what. Merilille's Cairhienin paleness had become dead white.

"aɪ min wʌɾ aɪ seɪ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ, ɪn ə mʌtʃ kulɝ toʊn. ɪt sim tə meɪk ivən mɔɹ blʌd liv mɛɝɪlɪlz feɪs. ʃi dɪd min ɛvɹi wɝd; ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd ðət sɔɹɾ ə ɹumɝ floʊɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ ʃi wəd si ɪt dʌn, ðoʊ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl vɛɹi laɪkli wəd feɪnt.

"I mean what I say," Elayne told her, in a much cooler tone. It seemed to make even more blood leave Merilille's face. She did mean every word; they could not afford that sort of rumor floating among them. One way or another she would see it done, though the Knitting Circle very likely would faint.

ʃi hoʊp ðət wɑz ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ɪt ʃəɾ əv bɪn. bʌt wən tʃɪlɛɹz lɛft, sɝaɪðə ɹipleɪs hɝ, ən ʃi tu hæɾ ə ɹizən ðə kɪnswɪmən wɝ nɑt tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd. ðɛɹ eɪdʒəz. ivən kɝstʃən kleɪm tə bi oʊldɝ ðən ɛni lɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, waɪl ɹin wɑz oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz mɔɹ ðən ðəɾ ən nɑɾ ivən ði oʊldəst ə ðə kɪn. hɝ taɪɾəl ʌv ɛldəst wɛn tə ði oʊldəst ə ðɛm ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ðə ɹɪdʒəd skɛdʒʊl ðeɪ fɑloʊd tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs hæɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə stɪl oʊldɝ wɪmən ɔf ɪn ʌðɝ pleɪsəz. ɪt wɑz ɑbviəsli ɪmpɑsəbəl, sɝaɪðə meɪnteɪnd.

She hoped that was the end of it. It should have been. But when Chilares left, Sareitha replaced her, and she too had a reason the Kinswomen were not to be trusted. Their ages. Even Kirstian claimed to be older than any living Aes Sedai, while Reanne was over a hundred years more than that and not even the oldest of the Kin. Her title of Eldest went to the oldest of them in Ebou Dar, and the rigid schedule they followed to avoid notice had a number of still older women off in other places. It was obviously impossible, Sareitha maintained.

ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt ʃaʊt; ʃi vɛɹi kɛɹfəli dɪd nɑt ʃaʊt. "wi wɪl lɝn ðə tʃɹuθ ɪvɛntʃəwəli," ʃi toʊl sɝaɪðə. ʃi dɪd nɑt daʊt ðə kɪnswɪmənz wɝd, bʌt ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə ɹizən waɪ ðə kɪnswɪmən lʊk niðɝ eɪdʒləs nɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ nɪɹ ði eɪdʒəz ðeɪ kleɪmd. ɪf ʃi kəɾ oʊnli pʌzəl ɪɾ aʊt. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld əɹ ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ lɛpt ʌp ðət sɛd wʌt. "ɪvɛntʃəwəli," ʃi æɾəd fɝmli wən ðə bɹaʊn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn. "ðæt wɪl bi ɪnʌf, sɝaɪðə." sɝaɪðə nɑɾəd ənsɝteɪnli ən fɛl bæk. nɑt tɛn mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, sɪbɛlə ɹipleɪs hɝ.

Elayne did not shout; she very carefully did not shout. "We will learn the truth eventually," she told Sareitha. She did not doubt the Kinswomen's word, but there had to be a reason why the Kinswomen looked neither ageless nor anything near the ages they claimed. If she could only puzzle it out. Something told her it was obvious, but nothing leaped up that said what. "Eventually," she added firmly when the Brown opened her mouth again. "That will be enough, Sareitha." Sareitha nodded uncertainly and fell back. Not ten minutes later, Sibella replaced her.

ɛvɹi taɪm wʌn ə ðə kɪnswɪmən keɪm tə meɪk əɹ ɹaʊndəbaʊt pli tə bi ɹɪlivd ʌv ɪspæn, wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz keɪm sun æftɝ tə ɔfɝ ðə seɪm pli. ɔl seɪv mɛɝɪlɪl, hu stɪl blɪŋkt wɛnɛvɝ ɪleɪn lʊkt ət hɝ. pɝhæps ʃaʊɾɪŋ dɪɾ əv ɪts juzɪz. sɝɾənli noʊ wʌn ɛls tʃɹaɪd tə bi soʊ stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ətækɪŋ ðə kɪn.

Every time one of the Kinswomen came to make her roundabout plea to be relieved of Ispan, one of the sisters came soon after to offer the same plea. All save Merilille, who still blinked whenever Elayne looked at her. Perhaps shouting did have its uses. Certainly no one else tried to be so straightforward in attacking the Kin.

fəɹ ɪnstəns, vændin bɪɡæn wɪð dɪskʌsɪŋ ðə si foʊk ən haʊ tə kaʊntɝ ði ɪfɛks ə ðə bɑɹɡən meɪd wɪð ðɛm, waɪ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə kaʊntɝ əm əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl. ʃi wɑz kwaɪt mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt, wɪð nɛvɝ ə wɝɾ əɹ dʒɛstʃɝ tə leɪ ɛni bleɪm. nɑt ðət ʃi niɾəd ɛni; ðə sʌbʒɪkt dɪd ðæt, haʊɛvɝ dɛləkətli hændəld. ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ʃi sɛd, meɪnteɪn ɪts ɪnfluəns ɪn ðə wɝl nɑt baɪ fɔɹs ʌv ɑɹmz, əɹ pɝsweɪʒən, əɹ ivən baɪ plɑɾɪŋ əɹ mənɪpjəleɪʃən, ðoʊ ðoʊz tu ʃi bɹʌʃt pæs laɪtli. ɹæðɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ ɪnfluənst ɪvɛns tə wʌtɛvɝ ɪkstɛn ðeɪ dɪd kəz ɛvɹiwʌn sɔ ðə taʊɝ əz stændɪŋ əpɑɹɾ ən əbʌv, mɔɹ ivən ðən kɪŋz əɹ kwinz. ðəɾ ɪn tɝn dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ biɪŋ sin ðət weɪ, əz mɪstɪɹiəs ən əpɑɹt, dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. ə dɪfɹən flɛʃ. hɪstɔɹɪkəli, ɛɛs sədaɪ hu kəd nɑt mænədʒ ðət - ən ðəɹ wɝ ə fju - wɝ kɛpt aʊɾ ə pʌblɪk vju əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl.

For instance, Vandene began with discussing the Sea Folk and how to counter the effects of the bargain made with them, why it was necessary to counter them as much as possible. She was quite matter-of-fact, with never a word or gesture to lay any blame. Not that she needed any; the subject did that, however delicately handled. The White Tower, she said, maintained its influence in the world not by force of arms, or persuasion, or even by plotting or manipulation, though those two she brushed past lightly. Rather the White Tower controlled or influenced events to whatever extent they did because everyone saw the Tower as standing apart and above, more even than kings or queens. That in turn depended on every Aes Sedai being seen that way, as mysterious and apart, different from everyone else. A different flesh. Historically, Aes Sedai who could not manage that - and there were a few - were kept out of public view as much as possible.

ɪt tʊk ɪleɪn ə lɪɾəl waɪl tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə θɹʌst ə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən hæd ʃɪftəɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə si foʊk, ən tə si wɛɹ ɪt wɑz hɛɾəd. ə dɪfɹən flɛʃ, mɪstɪɹiəs ən əpɑɹt, kəd nɑɾ əv ə sæk θɹʌst oʊvɝ ɪts hɛɾ ən bi taɪɾ əkɹɔs ə sæɾəl. nɑt wɛɹ ɛniwʌn u wɑz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd si, ɛniweɪ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðə sɪstɝz wəd bi ɹʌfɝ ɑn ɪspæn ðən ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl kəd pɑsəbli meɪk ðɛmsɛlvz bi, dʒʌs nɑɾ ɪn pʌblɪk. ði ɑɹɡjəmən maɪɾ əv bɔɹn mɔɹ weɪt hæɾ ɪt kʌm fɝst, bʌɾ əz ɪt wɑz, ɪleɪn sɛn vændin pækɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz ʃi dɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls. ən sɔ hɝ ɹipleɪs baɪ æɾɪliz, ɹaɪɾ æftɝ sɪbɛlə wɑz toʊl ðəɾ ɪf nʌn ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl kəɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ ɪspæn wɑz mʌmbəlɪŋ, ðən nʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz wɑz laɪkli tə iðɝ. mʌmbəlɪŋ! laɪt! ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʊk ðɛɹ ɹɪpiɾɪd tɝnz, ən ivən noʊɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ʌp tə, səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə si ðə kənɛkʃən ət fɝst. baɪ ðə taɪm kɛɝin bɪɡæn baɪ tɛlɪŋ əɹ ðət ðoʊz boʊldɝz ɹɪli hæd bɪn toʊz wʌns, səpoʊzədli ɑn ə stætʃu ʌv səm wɔɹiɝ kwin nɪɹli tu hʌnʒɹəd fit haɪ. . . .

It took Elayne a little while to realize that the thrust of the conversation had shifted away from the Sea Folk, and to see where it was headed. A different flesh, mysterious and apart, could not have a sack thrust over its head and be tied across a saddle. Not where anyone who was not Aes Sedai could see, anyway. In truth, the sisters would be rougher on Ispan than the Knitting Circle could possibly make themselves be, just not in public. The argument might have borne more weight had it come first, but as it was, Elayne sent Vandene packing as quickly as she did anyone else. And saw her replaced by Adeleas, right after Sibella was told that if none of the Knitting Circle could understand what Ispan was mumbling, then none of the sisters was likely to either. Mumbling! Light! The Aes Sedai took their repeated turns, and even knowing what they were up to, sometimes it was hard to see the connection at first. By the time Careane began by telling her that those boulders really had been toes once, supposedly on a statue of some warrior queen nearly two hundred feet high. . . .

"ɪspæn steɪz wɛɹ ʃi ɪz," ʃi toʊl kɛɝin kuli wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ. "naʊ, ənlɛs jə ɹɪli wɑnə tɛl mi waɪ ðə ʃiəɾənz θɔɾ ə pʊɾɪŋ ʌp ə stætʃu laɪk ðæt. . . ." ðə ɡɹin sɛɾ eɪntʃən ɹɛkɝdz kleɪmd ɪt hæd wɔɹn lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ɑɹmɝ, ən nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ðæt! ə kwin! "noʊ? ðɛn, ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd, aɪd laɪk tə tɔk wɪð eɪvinhə əloʊn. θæŋk jə soʊ mʌtʃ." ivən biɪŋ kɝt dɪd nɑt stɑp ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sɛn mɛɝɪlɪlz meɪd tə teɪk ə tɝn.

"Ispan stays where she is," she told Careane coolly without waiting for more. "Now, unless you really want to tell me why the Shiotans thought of putting up a statue like that. . . ." The Green said ancient records claimed it had worn little more than armor, and not a great deal of that! A queen! "No? Then, if you don't mind, I'd like to talk with Aviendha alone. Thank you so much." Even being curt did not stop them, of course. She was surprised they did not send Merilille's maid to take a turn.

nʌn ə ðɪs wʊɾə hæpən hæd nɪneɪiv bɪn wɛɹ ʃi wɑz mɛn tə bi. ət list, ɪleɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət nɪneɪiv cʊɾə kwɛl ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ən ðə sɪstɝz boʊθ, ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ. ʃi wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt wʌn fəɹ kwɛlɪŋ. ðə pɹɑbləm wɑz ðət nɪneɪiv hæd ɡlud hɝsɛlf taɪt tə lænz saɪd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ lɛf ðə fɝs klɪɹɪŋ. ðə wɔɹɾɝz skaʊɾəd əhɛɾ ən tə boʊθ saɪdz ə ðɛɹ pæθ, ən səmtaɪmz tə ðə ɹɪɹ, oʊnli ɹaɪɾɪŋ bæk tə ðə kɑləm lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹipɔɹt wʌt ðeɪ hæd sin əɹ ɡɪv dɝɛkʃənz ɑn haʊ tə əvɔɪɾ ə fɑɹm əɹ ə ʃɛpɝd. bɝdʒɪt ɹeɪnʒd fɑɹ, nɛvɝ spɛndɪŋ mɔɹ ðən moʊməns wɪð ɪleɪn. læn ɹeɪnʒd fɑɹðɝ. ən wɛɹ læn wɛnt, nɪneɪiv wɛnt.

None of this would have happened had Nynaeve been where she was meant to be. At least, Elayne was sure that Nynaeve could have quelled the Knitting Circle and the sisters both, in short order. She was a great one for quelling. The problem was that Nynaeve had glued herself tight to Lan's side before they left the first clearing. The Warders scouted ahead and to both sides of their path, and sometimes to the rear, only riding back to the column long enough to report what they had seen or give directions on how to avoid a farm or a shepherd. Birgitte ranged far, never spending more than moments with Elayne. Lan ranged farther. And where Lan went, Nynaeve went.

"noʊ wʌnz meɪkɪŋ ɛni tʃɹʌbəl, ɑɹ ðeɪ?" ʃi dɪmændəd wɪð ə dɑɹk stɛɹ fəɹ ðə si foʊk, ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi fɑloʊd læn bæk. "wɛl, ðæts ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn hæɾ ə tʃæns tə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. spɪnɪŋ əɹ ɹaʊnd-bɛlid mɛɹ laɪk ə ɹeɪsɝ, ʃi flɪk ðə ɹeɪnz ən ɡæləpt æftɝ læn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hæɾ ɑn wɪð wʌn hænd, kætʃɪŋ ʌp tə hɪm dʒʌst əz i vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ðə flæŋk ə ðə hɪl əhɛd. ʌv kɔɹs, ðən ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊt. ɹin hæd meɪɾ əɹ vɪzət, ən mɛɝɪlɪl hɝz, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim sɛɾəld.

"No one's making any trouble, are they?" she demanded with a dark stare for the Sea Folk, the first time she followed Lan back. "Well, that's all right, then," she said before Elayne had a chance to open her mouth. Spinning her round-bellied mare like a racer, she flicked the reins and galloped after Lan holding her hat on with one hand, catching up to him just as he vanished around the flank of the hill ahead. Of course, then there really was nothing to complain about. Reanne had made her visit, and Merilille hers, and everything seemed settled.

baɪ ðə nɛks taɪm nɪneɪiv əpɪɹd, ɪleɪn hæd sʌfɝd θɹu ə nʌmbɝ ə dɪsɡaɪzd ətɛmps tə hæv ɪspæn tɝn oʊvɝ tə ðə sɪstɝz, eɪvinhə hæd spoʊkən tə kɹɪn, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɑn ə sloʊ bɔɪl, bʌt wən ɪleɪn ɪkspleɪnd, nɪneɪiv sɪmpli lʊkt ɝaʊnd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ɹaɪɾ ət ðət moʊmən ɛvɹiwʌn hæd tə bi wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋd. ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɔɹ ɡlɛɹz, tʃɹu, bʌt ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɝ ɔl bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən əz fəɹ ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, noʊ ɡɹup ə nɑvəsɪz cʊɾə əpɪɹd mɔɹ wɛl-bɪheɪvd ən ɪnəsənt. ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə ʃɹik!

By the next time Nynaeve appeared, Elayne had suffered through a number of disguised attempts to have Ispan turned over to the sisters, Aviendha had spoken to Kurin, and the Windfinders were on a slow boil, but when Elayne explained, Nynaeve simply looked around, frowning. Of course, right at that moment everyone had to be where they belonged. The Atha'an Miere wore glares, true, but the Knitting Circle were all behind them, and as for the other sisters, no group of novices could have appeared more well-behaved and innocent. Elayne wanted to shriek!

"aɪm ʃʊɹ jə kən hændəl ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ju hæv hæɾ ɔl ðət tʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə bi ə kwin. ðɪs kæn bi ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ soʊ - dʒɹæt ðə mæn! hiz ɡoʊɪŋ əɡɛn! jə kən hændəl ɪt." ən ɔf ʃi wɛnt, ɡæləpɪŋ ðət pʊɹ mɛɹ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ ə wɔɹhɔɹs.

"I'm sure you can handle everything, Elayne," Nynaeve said. "You have had all that training to be a queen. This can't be anywhere near so - Drat the man! He's going again! You can handle it." And off she went, galloping that poor mare as though it were a warhorse.

ðət wɑz wən eɪvinhə tʃoʊz tə dɪskʌs haʊ ɹænd sim tə laɪk kɪsɪŋ ðə saɪdz ə hɝ nɛk. ən ɪnsɪdɛntəli haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi hæd laɪkt ɪt. ɪleɪn hæd laɪk ðət wən i dɪɾ ɪt tə hɝ, tu, bʌt haʊɛvɝ juz tə dɪskʌsɪŋ ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪkʌm - ənkʌmftəbli juz tə ɪt - ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt ɹaɪt ðɛn. ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi wɪð ɹænd. ɪt wɑz ənfɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪf nɑt fəɹ hɪm, ʃi cʊɾə toʊl nɪneɪiv tə stɑp tʃɹiɾɪŋ læn laɪk ə tʃaɪld u maɪt tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn fiɾ ən ətɛn tə hɝ oʊn duɾiz. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɑntəd tə bleɪm ɪm fəɹ ðə weɪ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ, tu, ən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. ɪts wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz mɛn ɑɹ fɔɹ, teɪkɪŋ ðə bleɪm, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd lini seɪɪŋ wʌns, ən læfɪŋ waɪl ʃi dɪd. ðeɪ juʒəwəli dɪzɝv ɪt, ivən ɪf jə doʊnt noʊ ɪɡzækli haʊ. nɑt fɛɹ, jɛt ʃi wɪʃt i wɝ ðəɹ lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə bɑks ɪz ɪɹz, dʒʌst wʌns. lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kɪs hɪm, tə hæv ɪm kɪs ðə saɪdz ə hɝ nɛk sɔfli. lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə. . . .

That was when Aviendha chose to discuss how Rand seemed to like kissing the sides of her neck. And incidentally how much she had liked it. Elayne had liked that when he did it to her, too, but however used to discussing this sort of thing she had become - uncomfortably used to it - she did not want to talk about it right then. She was angry with Rand. It was unfair, but if not for him, she could have told Nynaeve to stop treating Lan like a child who might trip over his own feet and attend to her own duties. She almost wanted to blame him for the way the Knitting Circle was behaving, too, and the other sisters, and the Windfinders. It's one of the things men are for, taking the blame, she remembered Lini saying once, and laughing while she did. They usually deserve it, even if you don't know exactly how. Not fair, yet she wished he were there long enough for her to box his ears, just once. Long enough to kiss him, to have him kiss the sides of her neck softly. Long enough to. . . .

"hi wɪl lɪsən tə ædvaɪs, ivən wən i dʌzn laɪk hɪɹɪŋ ɪt," ʃi sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, hɝ feɪs ɹɛɾənɪŋ. laɪt, fəɹ ɔl əɹ tɔk əbaʊt ʃeɪm, ɪn səm ɛɹiəz eɪvinhə hæd nʌn. ən ɪt sim ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæɾ ɛni, iðɝ! "bʌɾ ɪf aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ hɪm, hi dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz ivən wən ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðəɾ aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt. wɑz i ðət weɪ wɪð ju?"

"He will listen to advice, even when he doesn't like hearing it," she said abruptly, her face reddening. Light, for all her talk about shame, in some areas Aviendha had none. And it seemed that she herself no longer had any, either! "But if I tried to push him, he dug in his heels even when it was plain that I was right. Was he that way with you?"

eɪvinhə ɡlænst əɾ əɹ ən əpɪɹd tə ʌndɝstænd. ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ʃi laɪk ðəɾ əɹ nɑt. ət lis ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ tɔk ə ɹænd ən kɪsɪŋ. fəɹ ə waɪl, ɛniweɪ. eɪvinhə hæd səm nɑlədʒ ə mɛn - ʃi hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð əm əz ə meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ, fɔt bɪsaɪɾ əm - bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə bi ɛniθɪŋ bʌt fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, ən ðəɹ wɝ . . . ɡæps. ivən wɪð əɹ dɑlz əz ə tʃaɪld ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz pleɪɾ ət ðə spɪɹz ən ɹeɪɾɪŋ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ flɝɾɪd, dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi fɛl ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd wən ɹændz aɪz fɛl ɑn hɝ, əɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɪleɪn hæd bɪɡʌn lɝnɪŋ ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi noʊɾəst ə bɔɪ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dɪfɹənli ðən i dɪɾ ət ði ʌðɝ bɔɪz. ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪleɪn tə titʃ əɹ ɔl ʌv ɪt, ən ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd. ʃi ɹɪli kəd tɔk tə eɪvinhə əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ɪf oʊnli ɹænd hæd nɑt bɪn ði ɪɡzæmpəl juz kwaɪt soʊ ɔfən. ɪf i hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, ʃi wʊɾə bɑkst ɪz ɪɹz. ən kɪs hɪm. ðən bɑkst ɪz ɪɹz əɡɛn.

Aviendha glanced at her and appeared to understand. Elayne was not sure whether she liked that or not. At least there was no more talk of Rand and kissing. For a while, anyway. Aviendha had some knowledge of men - she had traveled with them as a Maiden of the Spear, fought beside them - but she had never wanted to be anything but Far Dareis Mai, and there were . . . gaps. Even with her dolls as a child she had always played at the spears and raiding. She had never flirted, did not understand it, and she did not understand why she felt the way she did when Rand's eyes fell on her, or a hundred other things Elayne had begun learning the first time she noticed a boy looking at her differently than he did at the other boys. She expected Elayne to teach her all of it, and Elayne tried. She really could talk to Aviendha about anything. If only Rand had not been the example used quite so often. If he had been there, she would have boxed his ears. And kissed him. Then boxed his ears again.

nɑɾ ə plɛzən ɹaɪɾ əɾ ɔl. ə mɪzɝəbəl ɹaɪd.

Not a pleasant ride at all. A miserable ride.

nɪneɪiv meɪd sɛvɹəl mɔɹ bɹif vɪzəts, bɪfɔɹ faɪnəli kʌmɪŋ tə ənaʊns ðət ðə kɪnz fɑɹm leɪ dʒʌst əhɛd, aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɝaʊn ə loʊ ɹaʊndəd hɪl ðəɾ əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə fɔl ɑn ɪts saɪd. ɹin hæd bɪn pɛsəmɪstɪk ɪn əɹ ɛstəmeɪt; ðə sʌn hæd nɑt fɔlən nɪɹli tu aʊɝz' wɝθ.

Nynaeve made several more brief visits, before finally coming to announce that the Kin's farm lay just ahead, out of sight around a low rounded hill that appeared ready to fall on its side. Reanne had been pessimistic in her estimate; the sun had not fallen nearly two hours' worth.

"wil bi ðəɹ vɛɹi kwɪkli, naʊ," nɪneɪiv toʊld ɪleɪn, nɑt simɪŋ tə noʊɾəs ðə sʌlən stɛɹ ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ɪn ɹɪtɝn. "læn, fɛtʃ ɹin ʌp hɪɹ, pliz. bɛst ɪf ðeɪ si ə fəmɪljɝ feɪs ɹaɪɾ ɔf." hi wɝld ɪz hɔɹs əweɪ, ən nɪneɪiv tɝn ɪn əɹ sæɾəl bɹifli tə fɪks ðə sɪstɝz wɪð ə fɝm aɪ. "aɪ doʊnt wɑn jə fɹaɪɾənɪŋ ðɛm, naʊ. jə hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋz əntɪl wɪv ə tʃæns tə ɪkspleɪn wʌts wʌt. ən haɪd jəɹ feɪsəz. pʊl ʌp ðə hʊdz ə jəɹ kloʊks." stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛni ɹɪplaɪ, ʃi ɡeɪv ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. "ðɛɹ. ɔl sɛɾəld, ən ɔl ɹaɪt. aɪ vaʊ, ɪleɪn, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jə wɝ moʊnɪŋ soʊ əbaʊt. ɛvɹiwʌnz duɪŋ ɪɡzækli əz ðeɪ ʃʊd, soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪ kən si."

"We'll be there very quickly, now," Nynaeve told Elayne, not seeming to notice the sullen stare Elayne gave in return. "Lan, fetch Reanne up here, please. Best if they see a familiar face right off." He whirled his horse away, and Nynaeve turned in her saddle briefly to fix the sisters with a firm eye. "I don't want you frightening them, now. You hold your tongues until we have a chance to explain what's what. And hide your faces. Pull up the hoods of your cloaks." Straightening without waiting for any reply, she gave a satisfied nod. "There. All settled, and all right. I vow, Elayne, I don't know what you were moaning so about. Everyone's doing exactly as they should, so far as I can see."

ɪleɪn ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ. ʃi wɪʃt ðeɪ wɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɔlɹɛɾi. ðət wɑz wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ wʌns ðɪs wɑz dʌn. ʃi hæd duɾiz lɔŋ oʊvɝdu ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɔl ʃi hæd tə dil wɪð ðəɹ wɑz kənvɪnsɪŋ ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ haʊsəz ðət ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑz hɝz dɪspaɪɾ əɹ lɔŋ æbsəns, ðəɾ ən hænlɪŋ ə ɹaɪvəl kleɪmən əɹ tu. ðəɹ maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn ɛni hæd ʃi bɪn ðəɹ wən əɹ mʌðɝ vænɪʃt, wən ʃi daɪd, bʌt ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ sɛd ðəɹ wəd bi baɪ naʊ. sʌmhaʊ, ɪt simd ɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ ðən ðɪs.

Elayne ground her teeth. She wished they were in Caemlyn already. That was where they were heading once this was done. She had duties long overdue in Caemlyn. All she had to deal with there was convincing the stronger Houses that the Lion Throne was hers despite her long absence, that and handling a rival claimant or two. There might not have been any had she been there when her mother vanished, when she died, but the history of Andor said there would be by now. Somehow, it seemed ever so much easier than this.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹ


CHAPTER 4

eɪ kwaɪət pleɪs


A Quiet Place

ðə kɪnz fɑɹm leɪ ɪn ə bɹɔd hɑloʊ sɝaʊndəd baɪ θɹi loʊ hɪlz, ə spɹɔlɪŋ əfɛɹ ə mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən lɑɹdʒ, waɪt-plæstɝd bɪldɪŋz wɪð flæt ɹufs, ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn. fɔɹ ɡɹeɪt bɑɹnz wɝ bɪlt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə sloʊp ə ðə haɪəs hɪl, ə flæt-tɑp θɪŋ wɪð wʌn saɪd ðət fɛl əweɪ ɪn stip klɪfs bɪɑn ðə bɑɹnz. ə fju tɔl tʃɹiz ðət hæd nɑt lɔst ɔl ə ðɛɹ livz pɹəvaɪɾəd ə mɑɾɪkəm ə ʃeɪɾ ɪn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd. tə ðə nɔɹθ ən ist, ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz mɑɹtʃt əweɪ ən ivən ʌp ðə saɪdz ə ðə hɪlz. ə sɔɹɾ ə sloʊ bʌsəl ɛnvɛləp ðə fɑɹm, wɪð izəli oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd pipəl ɪn ɛvəɾəns dɪspaɪt ði æftɝnun hit, kæɹiɪŋ ɑn ɔl ði ɛvɹideɪ tæsks bʌt nʌn kwɪkli.

The Kin's farm lay in a broad hollow surrounded by three low hills, a sprawling affair of more than a dozen large, white-plastered buildings with flat roofs, gleaming in the sun. Four great barns were built right into the slope of the highest hill, a flat-topped thing with one side that fell away in steep cliffs beyond the barns. A few tall trees that had not lost all of their leaves provided a modicum of shade in the farmyard. To the north and east, olive groves marched away and even up the sides of the hills. A sort of slow bustle enveloped the farm, with easily over a hundred people in evidence despite the afternoon heat, carrying on all the everyday tasks but none quickly.

ɪt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əv pæs fəɹ ə smɔl vɪlədʒ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə fɑɹm, ɪksɛp ðət ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə mæn əɹ ə tʃaɪl tə bi sin. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛni. ðɪs wɑz ə weɪpɔɪn fəɹ kɪnswɪmən pæsɪŋ θɹu ɛbu dɑɹ tə ɛlswɛɹ, soʊ ðəɹ wəd nɑt bi tu mɛni ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf ət wʌn taɪm, bʌt ðət wɑz ə sikɹət mæɾɝ, əz sikɹəɾ əz ðə kɪn ðɛmsɛlvz. pʌblɪkli ðɪs fɑɹm wɑz noʊn fəɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əɹ mɔɹ əz ə ɹitʃɹit fəɹ wɪmən, ə pleɪs fəɹ kɑntəmpleɪʃən ən ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə kɛɹz ə ðə wɝl fəɹ ə taɪm, ə fju deɪz, ə wik, səmtaɪmz lɔŋɡɝ. ɪleɪn kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil sɝɛnəɾi ɪn ði ɛɹ. ʃi maɪɾ əv ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə wɝld ɪndə ðɪs kwaɪət pleɪs, ɪksɛp ðət ʃi ɔlsoʊ bɹɔt nu hoʊp.

It might almost have passed for a small village instead of a farm, except that there was not a man or a child to be seen. Elayne did not expect any. This was a waypoint for Kinswomen passing through Ebou Dar to elsewhere, so there would not be too many in the city itself at one time, but that was a secret matter, as secret as the Kin themselves. Publicly this farm was known for two hundred miles or more as a retreat for women, a place for contemplation and escape from the cares of the world for a time, a few days, a week, sometimes longer. Elayne could almost feel serenity in the air. She might have regretted bringing the world into this quiet place, except that she also brought new hope.

ðə fɝst əpɪɹəns ə ðə hɔɹsəz kʌmɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə linɪŋ hɪl pɹədus fɑɹ lɛs stɝ ðən ʃi ɪkspɛktəd. ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə wɪmən stɑp tə wɑtʃ, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ vɛɹid waɪdli - ɪleɪn ivən sɔ ə ʃin ə sɪlk hɪɹ ən ðəɹ - bʌt səm kæɹid bæskəts ən ʌðɝz bʌkəts, əɹ ɡɹeɪt waɪt bʌndəlz ʌv wʌt hæd tə bi wɑʃ. wʌn hɛld ə pɛɹ ə baʊn dʌks baɪ ðə fiɾ ɪn iðɝ hænd. noʊbəlwʊmən ən kɹæftswʊmən, fɑɹmɝ ən bɛɡɝ, ɔl wɝ ikwəli wɛlkəm hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn dɪɾ ə ʃɛɹ ə ðə wɝk dʊɹɪŋ əɹ steɪ. eɪvinhə tʌtʃt ɪleɪnz ɑɹm, ðən pɔɪntəd tə ðə tɑp ʌv wʌn ə ðə hɪlz, ə θɪŋ laɪk ən ɪnvɝɾɪd fʌnəl skjud tə wʌn saɪd. ɪleɪn æɾəd ə hæn tə ðə ʃeɪɾ ə hɝ hæɾ ən æftɝ ə moʊmən sɔ muvmənt. smɔl wʌndɝ noʊ wʌn wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd. lʊkaʊts ʌp ðəɹ kəd si ɛniwʌn kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə lɔŋ weɪ.

The first appearance of the horses coming around the leaning hill produced far less stir than she expected. A number of the women stopped to watch, but no more than that. Their clothing varied widely - Elayne even saw a sheen of silk here and there - but some carried baskets and others buckets, or great white bundles of what had to be wash. One held a pair of bound ducks by the feet in either hand. Noblewoman and craftswoman, farmer and beggar, all were equally welcome here, but everyone did a share of the work during her stay. Aviendha touched Elayne's arm, then pointed to the top of one of the hills, a thing like an inverted funnel skewed to one side. Elayne added a hand to the shade of her hat and after a moment saw movement. Small wonder no one was surprised. Lookouts up there could see anyone coming from a long way.

ə mɪɾəlɪŋ wʊmən wɔkt aʊt tə miɾ əm ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɪn ði ɛbu dɑɹi staɪl, wɪð ə dip nɛɹoʊ nɛklaɪn, bʌɾ əɹ dɑɹk skɝts ən bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd pɛɾikoʊts wɝ ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt nid tə hoʊld əm ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə dʌst. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ə mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf; ðə kɪnz ɹulz pɹoʊhɪbəɾəd mɛɹɪdʒ. ðə kɪn hæd tu mɛni sikɹəts tə kip.

A middling woman walked out to meet them short of the farm buildings. Her dress was in the Ebou Dari style, with a deep narrow neckline, but her dark skirts and brightly colored petticoats were short enough that she did not need to hold them up out of the dust. She did not wear a marriage knife; the Kin's rules prohibited marriage. The Kin had too many secrets to keep.

"ðæts æləz," ɹin mɝmɝd, ɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. "ʃi ɹʌnz ðə fɑɹm ðɪs tɝn. ʃiz vɛɹi ɪntɛlədʒənt." ɔlmoʊs laɪk ən æftɝθɑt, ʃi æɾəd, ivən mɔɹ kwaɪətli, "æləz dʌz nɑt sʌfɝ fulz ɡlædli." əz æləz əpɹoʊtʃt, ɹin dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, skwɛɹɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz əz ðoʊ fəɹ ən ɔɹdil.

"That's Alise," Reanne murmured, reining in between Nynaeve and Elayne. "She runs the farm this turn. She's very intelligent." Almost like an afterthought, she added, even more quietly, "Alise does not suffer fools gladly." As Alise approached, Reanne drew herself up in her saddle, squaring her shoulders as though for an ordeal.

mɪɾəlɪŋ wɑz ɪɡzækli haʊ ɪleɪn θɔɾ ʌv æləz, nɑt sʌmwʌn tə ɡɪv ɹin pɔz, sɝɾənli, ivən hæd ʃi nɑt bɪn ði ɛldəst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl. stʃɹeɪt-bækt, æləz əpɪɹd tə bi sʌmwɛɹ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, niðɝ slɛndɝ nɔɹ staʊt, tɔl nɔɹ ʃɔɹt, ə lɪɾəl ɡɹeɪ flɛkɪŋ dɑɹk bɹaʊn hɛɹ ðət wɑz taɪd bæk wɪð ə pis ə ɹɪbən, bʌɾ ɪn ə vɛɹi pɹæktəkəl mænɝ. hɝ feɪs wɑz ənɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, ðoʊ plɛzən ɪnʌf, ə maɪl feɪs, pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl lɔŋ ɪn ðə dʒɔ. wən ʃi sɔ ɹin, ʃi ɡeɪv ə fliɾɪŋ lʊk ə sɝpɹaɪz, ðən smaɪld. ðət smaɪl tʃɹænsfɔɹmd ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪt dɪd nɑt meɪk əɹ bjuɾəfəl əɹ ivən pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ ɪleɪn fɛlt wɔɹm baɪ ɪt, kʌmfɝɾɪd.

Middling was exactly how Elayne thought of Alise, not someone to give Reanne pause, certainly, even had she not been the Eldest of the Knitting Circle. Straight-backed, Alise appeared to be somewhere in her middle years, neither slender nor stout, tall nor short, a little gray flecking dark brown hair that was tied back with a piece of ribbon, but in a very practical manner. Her face was unremarkable, though pleasant enough, a mild face, perhaps a little long in the jaw. When she saw Reanne, she gave a fleeting look of surprise, then smiled. That smile transformed everything. It did not make her beautiful or even pretty, but Elayne felt warmed by it, comforted.

"aɪ hɑɹdli ɪkspɛktəd tə si jə . . . ɹin," æləz sɛd, bɛɹli hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə neɪm. ɑbviəsli ʃi wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɛðɝ tə juz ɹinz ɹaɪtfəl taɪɾəl ɪn fɹʌn ə nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə. ʃi stʌɾid əm wɪð kwɪk ɡlænsɪz əz ʃi spoʊk. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə bɪɾ ə tæɹɑbən ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "bɛɹaʊɪn bɹɔt wɝɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk ɪt wɑz soʊ bæd jə wəɾ əv tə liv. hu ɑɹ ɔl ðiz. . . ." hɝ wɝdz tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ən əɹ aɪz waɪɾənd, stɛɹɪŋ bɪɑn ðɛm.

"I hardly expected to see you . . . Reanne," Alise said, barely hesitating over the name. Obviously she was unsure whether to use Reanne's rightful title in front of Nynaeve and Elayne and Aviendha. She studied them with quick glances as she spoke. There seemed to be a bit of Tarabon in her voice. "Berowin brought word of trouble in the city, of course, but I didn't think it was so bad you would have to leave. Who are all these. . . ." Her words trailed off, and her eyes widened, staring beyond them.

ɪleɪn ɡlæns bæk, nɪɹli lusɪŋ ə fju ʌv ðə tʃɔɪs fɹeɪzəz ʃi hæd pɪkt ʌp ɪn vɛɹiəs pleɪsəz, moʊst ɹisənli fɹəm mæt kɔθən. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɔl ə ðɛm, nɑt moʊst ə ðɛm ɹɪli - noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ wɑntəd tə ɪkspleɪn wʌt ðeɪ mɛn ɪɡzækli - bʌt ðeɪ dɪɾ əv ə weɪ ʌv ɹɪlivɪŋ ɪmoʊʃən. ðə wɔɹɾɝz hæd dɑf ðɛɹ kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks, ən ðə sɪstɝz hæd dʒɹɔn ʌp ðə hʊdz ə ðɛɹ dʌst-kloʊks əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd, ivən sɝaɪðə, hu hæd noʊ nid tə haɪɾ əɹ juθfəl feɪs, bʌt kɛɝin hæd nɑt pʊl hɝz fɔɹwɝd fɑɹ ɪnʌf. ɪt sɪmpli fɹeɪmd əɹ eɪdʒləs fitʃɝz. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wəd noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ siɪŋ, jɛɾ ɛniwʌn u hæd bɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ ʃʊɹli wʊd. kɛɝin dʒɝk ðə hʊd fɔɹwɝɾ əɾ ɪleɪnz ɡlɛɹ, bʌt ðə dæmədʒ wɑz dʌn.

Elayne glanced back, nearly loosing a few of the choice phrases she had picked up in various places, most recently from Mat Cauthon. She did not understand all of them, not most of them really - nobody ever wanted to explain what they meant exactly - but they did have a way of relieving emotion. The Warders had doffed their color-shifting cloaks, and the sisters had drawn up the hoods of their dust-cloaks as instructed, even Sareitha, who had no need to hide her youthful face, but Careane had not pulled hers forward far enough. It simply framed her ageless features. Not everyone would know what they were seeing, yet anyone who had been in the Tower surely would. Careane jerked the hood forward at Elayne's glare, but the damage was done.

ʌðɝz ət ðə fɑɹm bɪsaɪɾ æləz pəzɛst ʃɑɹp aɪz. "ɛɛs sədaɪ!" ə wʊmən haʊld ɪn toʊnz suɾəbəl fəɹ ənaʊnsɪŋ ði ɛn ə ðə wɝld. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz, fəɹ əɹ wɝld. ʃɹiks spɹɛd laɪk dʌs bloʊn ɑn ðə wɪnd, ən ðət kwɪkli, ðə fɑɹm bɪkeɪm ə kɪkt æntɪl. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə wʊmən sɪmpli feɪntɪd dɛɾ əweɪ, bʌt moʊst ɹæn waɪldli, skɹimɪŋ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kæɹid, bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ, fɔlɪŋ daʊn ən skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp tə ɹʌn ɑn. flæpɪŋ dʌks ən tʃɪkənz ən ʃɔɹt-hɔɹn blæk ɡoʊts dɑɹɾɪd waɪldli tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ tʃɹæmpəld. ɪn ðə mɪdst ʌv ɪɾ ɔl, səm wɪmən stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ, pleɪnli ðoʊz u hæd kʌm tə ðə ɹitʃɹit wɪð noʊ nɑlədʒ ə ðə kɪn, ðoʊ ə fju ʌv əm bɪɡæn tə muv hɝidli, tu, kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə fɹɛnzi.

Others at the farm beside Alise possessed sharp eyes. "Aes Sedai!" a woman howled in tones suitable for announcing the end of the world. Perhaps she was, for her world. Shrieks spread like dust blown on the wind, and that quickly, the farm became a kicked anthill. Here and there a woman simply fainted dead away, but most ran wildly, screaming, dropping what they carried, bumping into one another, falling down and scrambling up to run on. Flapping ducks and chickens and short-horned black goats darted wildly to avoid being trampled. In the midst of it all, some women stood gaping, plainly those who had come to the retreat with no knowledge of the Kin, though a few of them began to move hurriedly, too, caught up in the frenzy.

"laɪt!" nɪneɪiv bɑɹkt, jæŋkɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd. "sʌm ə ðɛm ɑɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ði ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz! stɑp ðɛm! ðə læs θɪŋ wi wɑn ɪz ə pænɪk! sɛn ðə wɔɹɾɝz! kwɪk, kwɪk!" læn ɹeɪzd ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt ʃi weɪvd ə pɝɛmptɝi hæn ət hɪm. "kwɪk! bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɔl ɹʌn əweɪ!" wɪð ə nɑd ðət sim tə bɪɡɪn əz ə ʃeɪk ə hɪz hɛd, hi sɛn mændɑɹb ɡæləpɪŋ æftɝ ði ʌðɝ mɛn, kɝvɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðə spɹɛɾɪŋ pændɪmoʊniəm əmʌŋ ðə bɪldɪŋz.

"Light!" Nynaeve barked, yanking her braid. "Some of them are running into the olive groves! Stop them! The last thing we want is a panic! Send the Warders! Quick, quick!" Lan raised a questioning eyebrow, but she waved a peremptory hand at him. "Quick! Before they all run away!" With a nod that seemed to begin as a shake of his head, he sent Mandarb galloping after the other men, curving to avoid the spreading pandemonium among the buildings.

ɪleɪn ʃɹʌɡd ət bɝdʒɪt, ðən moʊʃən əɹ tə fɑloʊ. ʃi əɡɹid wɪð læn. ɪt simd ə bɪt leɪt tə tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ ə pænɪk, ən wɔɹɾɝz ɑn hɔɹsbæk ətɛmptɪŋ tə hɝd fɹaɪɾənd wɪmən pɹɑbli wɑz nɑt ðə bɛst weɪ. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ tə tʃeɪnʒ mæɾɝz naʊ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn lɛɾɪŋ əm ɹʌn ɔf ɪndə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl wɑnə hɪɹ ðə nuz ʃi ən nɪneɪiv bɹɔt.

Elayne shrugged at Birgitte, then motioned her to follow. She agreed with Lan. It seemed a bit late to try stopping a panic, and Warders on horseback attempting to herd frightened women probably was not the best way. But she could not see how to change matters now, and there was no point letting them run off into the countryside. They would all want to hear the news she and Nynaeve brought.

æləz ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə ɹʌnɪŋ, əɹ ivən fɪdʒəɾɪŋ. hɝ feɪs peɪl slaɪtli, bʌt ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ɹin wɪð ə stɛɾi ɡeɪz. ə fɝm ɡeɪz. "waɪ?" ʃi bɹiðd. "waɪ, ɹin? aɪ kəd nɑɾ əv ɪmædʒən jə duɪŋ ðɪs! dɪd ðeɪ ɡɪv jə bɹaɪbz? ɔfɝ ɪmjunəɾi? wɪl ðeɪ lɛt jə wɔk fɹi waɪl wi peɪ ðə pɹaɪs? ðeɪ pɹɑbli woʊn əlaʊ ɪt, bʌɾ aɪ vaʊ əl æsk əm tə lemi kɔl jə daʊn. jɛs, ju! ðə ɹulz əplaɪ ivən tə ju, ɛldəst! ɪf aɪ kən faɪn ə weɪ tə mænədʒ ɪt, aɪ vaʊ jə woʊnt wɔk əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs smaɪlɪŋ!" ə vɛɹi fɝm ɡeɪz. stili, ɪn fækt.

Alise gave no sign of running, or even fidgeting. Her face paled slightly, but she stared up at Reanne with a steady gaze. A firm gaze. "Why?" she breathed. "Why, Reanne? I could not have imagined you doing this! Did they give you bribes? Offer immunity? Will they let you walk free while we pay the price? They probably won't allow it, but I vow I'll ask them to let me call you down. Yes, you! The rules apply even to you, Eldest! If I can find a way to manage it, I vow you won't walk away from this smiling!" A very firm gaze. Steely, in fact.

"ɪɾ ɪzənt wʌt jə θɪŋk," ɹin sɛd hɝidli, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ən dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz. ʃi kɑt boʊθ ʌv æləzəz hænz ɪn hɝz dɪspaɪt ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɛfɝts tə fɹi ðɛm. "oʊ, aɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪt tə bi laɪk ðɪs. ðeɪ noʊ, æləz. əbaʊt ðə kɪn. ðə taʊɝ əz ɔlweɪz noʊn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ. bʌt ðəɾ ɪzənt wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt." æləzəz aɪbɹaʊz tʃɹaɪd tə klaɪm ɑntu hɝ skælp ət ðæt, bʌt ɹin ɹʌʃt ɑn, bimɪŋ iɡɝli fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ lɑɹdʒ stʃɹɔ hæt. "wi kən ɡoʊ bæk, æləz. wi kən tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. ðeɪ sɛd wi kæn." ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz sim tə bi ɛmptiɪŋ əz wɛl, wɪmən ɹʌʃɪŋ aʊt tə lɝn wʌt ðə kəmoʊʃən wɑz, ðən dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə flaɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə pɔz fəɹ mɔɹ ðən haɪkɪŋ skɝts. ʃaʊts fɹəm ði ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz sɛd ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɝ ət wɝk, bʌt nɑt haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ wɝ ətʃivɪŋ. pɝhæps nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ɪleɪn sɛnst ɡɹoʊɪŋ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən fɹəm bɝdʒɪt, ən ɪɹɪteɪʃən. ɹin aɪd ðə tɝmɔɪl ən saɪd. "wi mʌst ɡæðɝ əm ɪn, æləz. wi kən ɡoʊ bæk."

"It isn't what you think," Reanne said hurriedly, dismounting and dropping her reins. She caught both of Alise's hands in hers despite the other woman's efforts to free them. "Oh, I did not want it to be like this. They know, Alise. About the Kin. The Tower has always known. Everything. Almost everything. But that isn't what is important." Alise's eyebrows tried to climb onto her scalp at that, but Reanne rushed on, beaming eagerly from under her large straw hat. "We can go back, Alise. We can try again. They said we can." The farm buildings seemed to be emptying as well, women rushing out to learn what the commotion was, then joining the flight without a pause for more than hiking skirts. Shouts from the olive groves said the Warders were at work, but not how much they were achieving. Perhaps not a great deal. Elayne sensed growing frustration from Birgitte, and irritation. Reanne eyed the turmoil and sighed. "We must gather them in, Alise. We can go back."

"ðæts ɔl vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ jə ən səm ə ði ʌðɝz," æləz sɛd daʊtfəli. "ɪf ɪts tʃɹu. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs? ðə taʊɝ wəd nɑɾ əv lemi steɪ əz lɔŋ əz aɪ dɪd hæɾ aɪ bɪn kwɪkɝ tə lɝn." ʃi dɑɹɾɪd ə fɹaʊn ət ðə naʊ wɛl-hʊɾɪd sɪstɝz, ən ðə stɛɹ ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə ɹin hɛl noʊ lɪɾəl æŋɡɝ. "wʌt wəd wi ɡoʊ bæk fɔɹ? tə bi toʊld əɡɛn wi ɑɹən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ən bi sɛn ɑn əɹ weɪ? əɹ wɪl ðeɪ dʒʌs kip əs əz nɑvəsɪz ðə ɹɛst ʌv əɹ lɪvz? səm maɪɾ æksɛp ðæt, bʌɾ aɪ woʊnt. wʌt fɔɹ, ɹin? wʌt fɔɹ?"

"That's all very well for you and some of the others," Alise said doubtfully. "If it's true. What about the rest of us? The Tower would not have let me stay as long as I did had I been quicker to learn." She darted a frown at the now well-hooded sisters, and the stare she returned to Reanne held no little anger. "What would we go back for? To be told again we aren't strong enough and be sent on our way? Or will they just keep us as novices the rest of our lives? Some might accept that, but I won't. What for, Reanne? What for?"

nɪneɪiv klaɪm daʊn, tʌɡɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ fɔɹwɝɾ ət ði ɛn ə hɝ ɹeɪnz, ən ɪleɪn ɪməteɪɾɪd hɝ, ðoʊ liɾɪŋ laɪoʊnəs mɔɹ izəli. "tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ɪf ðæts wʌt jə wɪʃ," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli bɪfɔɹ ivən ɹitʃɪŋ ðə tu kɪnswɪmən. "meɪbi tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. maɪsɛlf, aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ juv tə bi ə sɝɾən stʃɹɛŋkθ, ɪf jə kən pæs ðə ful tɛsts. əɹ doʊnt ɡoʊ bæk; ɹʌn əweɪ, fəɹ ɔl aɪ kɛɹ. wʌns aɪm dʌn hɪɹ, ɛniweɪ." plæntɪŋ əɹ fit, ʃi pʊld ɔf əɹ hæɾ ən plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. "ðɪs ɪz weɪstɪŋ taɪm, ɹin, ən wɪv wɝk tə du. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ðɛɹz ɛnibəɾi hɪɹ wi kən juz? spik ʌp. ɪf jəɹ nɑt ʃʊɹ, ðən wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt. ðə hɝi maɪt bi aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, bʌt naʊ wɪv ðə θɪŋ, aɪɾ əz sun ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ ən dʌn wɪð."

Nynaeve climbed down, tugging her mare forward at the end of her reins, and Elayne imitated her, though leading Lioness more easily. "To be part of the Tower, if that's what you wish," Nynaeve said impatiently before even reaching the two Kinswomen. "Maybe to be Aes Sedai. Myself, I don't know why you have to be a certain strength, if you can pass the fool tests. Or don't go back; run away, for all I care. Once I'm done here, anyway." Planting her feet, she pulled off her hat and planted her fists on her hips. "This is wasting time, Reanne, and we have work to do. Are you sure there's anybody here we can use? Speak up. If you're not sure, then we might as well get on with it. The hurry might be out of the way, but now we have the thing, I'd as soon it was over and done with."

wən ʃi ən ɪleɪn wɝ ɪntʃɹədust əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd ɡɪvən ðə pɹɑməsəz, æləz meɪɾ ə tʃoʊk saʊn ən bɪɡæn smuðɪŋ əɹ wʊlən skɝts əz ðoʊ hɝ hænz wɑntəd tə lætʃ ɑn tə ɹinz θɹoʊt. hɝ maʊθ oʊpən æŋɡɹəli - ðən snæpt ʃʌt wɪθaʊɾ ə saʊnd wən mɛɝɪlɪl dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ðət stɝn ɡeɪz dɪd nɑt feɪd kəmplitli, bʌɾ ɪt bɪkeɪm mɪkst wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv wʌndɝ. ən mɔɹ ðən ə tʌtʃ ʌv wɛɹinɪs.

When she and Elayne were introduced as Aes Sedai, the Aes Sedai who had given the promises, Alise made a choked sound and began smoothing her woolen skirts as though her hands wanted to latch on to Reanne's throat. Her mouth opened angrily - then snapped shut without a sound when Merilille joined them. That stern gaze did not fade completely, but it became mixed with a touch of wonder. And more than a touch of wariness.

"nɪneɪiv sədaɪ," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛd kɑmli, "ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɑɹ . . . ɪmpeɪʃənt . . . tə bi ɔf ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. aɪ θɪŋk səm meɪ æsk fəɹ hilɪŋ." ə bɹif smaɪl flɪkɝɾ əkɹɔs əɹ lɪps.

"Nynaeve Sedai," Merilille said calmly, "the Atha'an Miere are . . . impatient . . . to be off their horses. I think some may ask for Healing." A brief smile flickered across her lips.

ðət sɛɾəld ðət kwɛstʃən, ðoʊ nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld ɛkstʃɹævəɡənli əbaʊt wʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə də tə ðə nɛks pɝsən u daʊɾɪd hɝ. ɪleɪn maɪɾ əv sɛɾ ə fju tʃɔɪs wɝdz hɝsɛlf, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, nɪneɪiv lʊk mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl sɪli kæɹiɪŋ ɑn ðət weɪ wɪð mɛɝɪlɪl ən ɹin boʊθ weɪɾɪŋ ətɛntɪvli fəɹ əɹ tə fɪnɪʃ ən æləz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɔl θɹi. ðət sɛɾəld ɪt, əɹ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, əfʊɾ ən pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɛvɹi ʃɹɛɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪs hæd vænɪʃt dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹaɪd, wɔɹn əweɪ baɪ hɑɹd sæɾəlz - ðɛɹ lɛɡz simd əz stɪf əz ðɛɹ feɪsəz - jɛt noʊ wʌn kəd mɪsteɪk əm fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ u ðeɪ wɝ.

That settled that question, though Nynaeve grumbled extravagantly about what she was going to do to the next person who doubted her. Elayne might have said a few choice words herself, but the truth was, Nynaeve looked more than a little silly carrying on that way with Merilille and Reanne both waiting attentively for her to finish and Alise staring at all three. That settled it, or perhaps it was the Windfinders, afoot and pulling their horses behind them. Every shred of grace had vanished during the ride, worn away by hard saddles - their legs seemed as stiff as their faces - yet no one could mistake them for anything but who they were.

"ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ twɛnti si foʊk ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm ðə si," æləz mʌɾɝd, "aɪl bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ." nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ, fəɹ wɪtʃ ɪleɪn wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. ðə wʊmən sim tə bi hævɪŋ ə hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf taɪm æksɛptɪŋ ivən wɪð mɛɝɪlɪl neɪmɪŋ əm ɛɛs sədaɪ. niðɝ taɪɹeɪd nɔɹ tæntʃɹəm wəd hɛlp.

"If there are twenty Sea Folk this far from the sea," Alise muttered, "I'll believe anything." Nynaeve snorted but said nothing, for which Elayne was grateful. The woman seemed to be having a hard enough time accepting even with Merilille naming them Aes Sedai. Neither tirade nor tantrum would help.

"ðɛn hil ðɛm," nɪneɪiv toʊl mɛɝɪlɪl. ðɛɹ aɪz wɛn tə ðə hɑbəlɪŋ wɪmən təɡɛðɝ, ən nɪneɪiv æɾəd, "ɪf ðeɪ æsk. pəlaɪtli." mɛɝɪlɪl smaɪld əɡɛn, bʌt nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi əbændən ðə si foʊk ən ɡɔn bæk tə fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə naʊ ɔl bʌɾ ɛmpti fɑɹm. ə fju ɡoʊts stɪl tʃɹɑɾəd ɝaʊn ə fɑɹmjɑɹd lɪɾɝd wɪð dʒɹɑpt wɑʃ ən ɹeɪks ən bɹumz, spɪl bʌkəts ən bæskəts, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə kɹʌmpəl fɔɹmz ə kɪnswɪmən u hæd feɪntɪd, ən ə hændfʊl ə tʃɪkənz hæd ɡɔn bæk tə skɹætʃɪŋ ən pɛkɪŋ, bʌt ði oʊnli kɑnʃəs wɪmən stɪl ɪn saɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz wɝ pleɪnli nɑɾ ə ðə kɪn. səm wɔɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd lɪnən əɹ sɪlk ən səm ɹʌf kʌntʃɹi wʊlənz, jɛt ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹʌn spoʊk ðət mʌtʃ ə ðɛm. ɹin sɛd ðəɾ əɾ ɛni ɡɪvən taɪm əz mɛni əz hæf ðoʊz ət ðə fɑɹm maɪt fɔl ɪndə ðət ɡɹup. moʊst əpɪɹd stʌnd.

"Then Heal them," Nynaeve told Merilille. Their eyes went to the hobbling women together, and Nynaeve added, "If they ask. Politely." Merilille smiled again, but Nynaeve had already abandoned the Sea Folk and gone back to frowning at the now all but empty farm. A few goats still trotted around a farmyard littered with dropped wash and rakes and brooms, spilled buckets and baskets, not to mention the crumpled forms of Kinswomen who had fainted, and a handful of chickens had gone back to scratching and pecking, but the only conscious women still in sight among the farm buildings were plainly not of the Kin. Some wore embroidered linen or silk and some rough country woolens, yet the fact that they had not run spoke that much of them. Reanne said that at any given time as many as half those at the farm might fall into that group. Most appeared stunned.

dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ, nɪneɪiv weɪstəd noʊ taɪm teɪkɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv æləz. əɹ pɝhæps æləz tʊk tʃɑɹdʒ ə nɪneɪiv. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl, sɪns ðə kɪnswʊmən ʃoʊd lɪɾəl ə ðə dɛfɝəns təwɔɹɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl dɪd. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz stɪl dʒʌs tu nʌm baɪ ðə sʌɾən tɝn ʌv ɪvɛns. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðeɪ muvd ɔf təɡɛðɝ, nɪneɪiv liɾɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ ən dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ðə hæɾ ɪn əɹ ʌðɝ hænd, ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ æləz ɑn haʊ tə bɹɪŋ ɪn ðə skæɾɝd wɪmən ən wʌt tə də wɪð əm wʌns ðeɪ wɝ kəlɛktəd. ɹin hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ət list wʌn wʊmən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɔɪn ðə sɝkəl wɑz ðɛɹ, ɡæɹiniə ɹoʊsɔɪnd, ən pɑsəbli tu mɔɹ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɪleɪn wɑz hoʊpɪŋ ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl ɡɔn. æləz ɔltɝneɪɾəd bɪtwin nɑɾɪŋ ən ɡɪvɪŋ nɪneɪiv vɛɹi lɛvəl lʊks ðət nɪneɪiv sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs.

Despite her grumbling, Nynaeve wasted no time taking charge of Alise. Or perhaps Alise took charge of Nynaeve. It was difficult to tell, since the Kinswoman showed little of the deference toward Aes Sedai that the Knitting Circle did. Perhaps she was still just too numbed by the sudden turn of events. In any case, they moved off together, Nynaeve leading her mare and gesturing with the hat in her other hand, instructing Alise on how to bring in the scattered women and what to do with them once they were collected. Reanne had been sure that at least one woman strong enough to join the circle was there, Garenia Rosoinde, and possibly two more. In truth, Elayne was hoping they had all gone. Alise alternated between nodding and giving Nynaeve very level looks that Nynaeve seemed not to notice.

naʊ, ɪn ðə weɪt waɪl ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ wɑz dʌn, simd ə ɡʊd taɪm tə də ə bɪt mɔɹ sɝtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə pænɪɝz, bʌt wən ɪleɪn tɝn təwɔɹd ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, wɪtʃ wɝ dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bi lɛd təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz, ʃi noʊɾəst ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ɹin ən ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm, meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ ɪndə ðə fɑɹm ɑn fʊt, səm hɝiɪŋ təwɔɹd wɪmən laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ʌðɝz təwɔɹd ðoʊz stændɪŋ əbaʊt ɡeɪpɪŋ. ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm, ən noʊ saɪn ʌv ɪspæn. ɪt tʊk oʊnli ə ɡlæns tə faɪn hɝ, ðoʊ. bɪtwin æɾɪliz ən vændin, itʃ hoʊldɪŋ ən ɑɹm əz ðeɪ hæf-dʒɹæɡd əɹ əlɔŋ, ðɛɹ dʌst-kloʊks stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪnd.

Now, in the wait while the gathering was done, seemed a good time to do a bit more searching through the panniers, but when Elayne turned toward the packhorses, which were just beginning to be led toward the farm buildings, she noticed the Knitting Circle, Reanne and the whole lot of them, making their own way into the farm on foot, some hurrying toward women lying on the ground, others toward those standing about gaping. The whole lot of them, and no sign of Ispan. It took only a glance to find her, though. Between Adeleas and Vandene, each holding an arm as they half-dragged her along, their dust-cloaks streaming behind.

ðə waɪt-hɛɹd sɪstɝz wɝ lɪŋkt, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌmhaʊ ɛnkʌmpəsɪŋ əm boʊθ wɪθaʊɾ ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɪspæn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɪtʃ lɛd ðə smɔl sɝkəl ən hɛl ðə ʃild ɑn ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, bʌt nɑɾ ivən wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən cʊɾə bɹoʊkən ɪt. ðeɪ stɑp tə spik tə ə staʊt wʊmən ɪn pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊl, hu ɡeɪpt ət ðə lɛðɝ sæk kʌvɝɪŋ ɪspænz hɛd bʌt stɪl kɝtsiɾ ən pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə waɪt-plæstɝd bɪldɪŋz.

The white-haired sisters were linked, the glow of saidar somehow encompassing them both without including Ispan. There was no way to tell which led the small circle and held the shield on the Darkfriend, but not even one of the Forsaken could have broken it. They stopped to speak to a stout woman in plain brown wool, who gaped at the leather sack covering Ispan's head but still curtsied and pointed toward one of the white-plastered buildings.

ɪleɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd æŋɡɹi ɡlænsɪz wɪð eɪvinhə. wɛl, hɝz wɑz æŋɡɹi, ɛniweɪ. səmtaɪmz eɪvinhə ɡeɪv əweɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə stoʊn. hændɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz oʊvɝ tə tu ʌv ðə pæləs steɪbəlmən, ðeɪ hɝiɾ æftɝ ðə θɹi. səm ə ðə wɪmən u wɝ nɑɾ ə ðə kɪn tʃɹaɪd tə kwɛstʃən əm əbaʊt wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, ə fju ɪn ɹæðɝ oʊvɝbɛɹɪŋ fæʃən, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əm ʃɔɹt ʃɹɪft, livɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə weɪk ʌv ɪndɪɡnən snɪfs ən snɔɹts. oʊ, wʌt ʃi wəd nɑt ɡɪv tə hæv ði eɪdʒləs feɪs ɔlɹɛɾi! ðət twikt ə θɹɛɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ θɔts, bʌɾ ɪt vænɪʃt əz sun əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡzæmɪn ɪt.

Elayne exchanged angry glances with Aviendha. Well, hers was angry, anyway. Sometimes Aviendha gave away no more than a stone. Handing their horses over to two of the palace stablemen, they hurried after the three. Some of the women who were not of the Kin tried to question them about what was happening, a few in rather overbearing fashion, but Elayne gave them short shrift, leaving behind a wake of indignant sniffs and snorts. Oh, what she would not give to have the ageless face already! That tweaked a thread in the back of her thoughts, but it vanished as soon as she tried to examine it.

wən ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə pleɪn wʊɾən dɔɹ wɛɹ ðə tʃɹioʊ hæd vænɪʃt, æɾɪliz ən vændin hæɾ ɪspæn siɾəd ɪn ə læɾɝ-bæk tʃɛɹ wɪð əɹ hɛd bɛɹ, ðə sæk laɪɪŋ ətɑp ə nɛɹoʊ tʃɹɛsəl teɪbəl wɪð ðɛɹ lɪnən kloʊks. ðə ɹum pəzɛst oʊnli wʌn wɪndoʊ, sɛɾ ɪn ðə silɪŋ, bʌt wɪð ðə sʌn stɪl haɪ ɪt lɛɾ ɪn ə ɡʊd laɪt. ʃɛlvz laɪn ðə wɔlz, stækt wɪð lɑɹdʒ kɑpɝ pɑts ən bɪɡ waɪt boʊlz. baɪ ðə smɛl ə bɹɛd beɪkɪŋ, ði oʊnli ʌðɝ dɔɹ lɛɾ ɪndə ə kɪtʃən.

When she pushed open the plain wooden door where the trio had vanished, Adeleas and Vandene had Ispan seated in a ladder-back chair with her head bare, the sack lying atop a narrow trestle table with their linen cloaks. The room possessed only one window, set in the ceiling, but with the sun still high it let in a good light. Shelves lined the walls, stacked with large copper pots and big white bowls. By the smell of bread baking, the only other door led into a kitchen.

vændin lʊkt ɝaʊnd ʃɑɹpli ət ðə saʊn ə ðə dɔɹ, bʌt siɪŋ ðɛm, ʃi smuðd əɹ feɪs tə ə toʊɾəl læk ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən. "sumeɪkoʊ sɛd ði ɝbz nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ wɝ wɛɹɪŋ ɔf," ʃi sɛd, "æn ɪt sim bɛs tə kwɛstʃən əɹ ə lɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ fʌzɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪn əɡɛn. wi də sim tə hæv taɪm, naʊ. ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə noʊ wʌt ðə . . . ðə blæk ədʒɑ," hɝ maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn dɪsteɪst, "wɑz ʌp tə ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ən wʌt ðeɪ noʊ."

Vandene looked around sharply at the sound of the door, but seeing them, she smoothed her face to a total lack of expression. "Sumeko said the herbs Nynaeve gave her were wearing off," she said, "and it seemed best to question her a little before fuzzing her brain again. We do seem to have time, now. It would be good to know what the . . . the Black Ajah," her mouth twisted in distaste, "was up to in Ebou Dar. And what they know."

"aɪ daʊt ðeɪ ɑɹ əwɛɹ ə ðɪs fɑɹm, sɪns wi wɝ nɑt," æɾɪliz sɛd, tæpɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ θɔtfəli ɑn əɹ lɪps əz ʃi stʌɾid ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, "bʌɾ ɪts bɛɾɝ tə bi ʃʊɹ ðən tə wip leɪɾɝ, əz əɹ fɑðɝ juz tə seɪ." ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ən ænəməl ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, ə kɹitʃɝ ʃi kəd nɑt fæðəm ɪɡzɪstɪŋ.

"I doubt they are aware of this farm, since we were not," Adeleas said, tapping a finger thoughtfully on her lips as she studied the woman in the chair, "but it is better to be sure than to weep later, as our father used to say." She might have been examining an animal she had never seen before, a creature she could not fathom existing.

ɪspænz lɪp kɝld. swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ bɹuz feɪs, ən əɹ dɑɹk, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz wɝ dɪʃɛvəld ən əɹ kloʊðɪŋ ɔl dɪsɹeɪd, bʌt dɪspaɪt blɪɹi aɪz, ʃi wɑz nɑt nɪɹli soʊ wuzi əz ʃi hæd bɪn. "ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ɪts ə feɪbəl, ən ə fɪlθi wʌn," ʃi snɪɹd, ə tʃɹaɪfəl hɔɹsli. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn vɛɹi hɑɾ ɪnsaɪd ðət lɛðɝ sæk, ən ʃi hæd hæd noʊ wɔɾɝ sɪns livɪŋ ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. "mi, aɪm sɝpɹaɪz ðət jəl ɡɪv ɪt vɔɪs. ən tə kæs ðə tʃɑɹdʒ ɑn mi! wʌɾ aɪ hæv dʌn, aɪ hæv dʌn ɑn ði ɔɹɾɝz ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

Ispan's lip curled. Sweat rolled down her bruised face, and her dark, beaded braids were disheveled and her clothing all disarrayed, but despite bleary eyes, she was not nearly so woozy as she had been. "The Black Ajah, it is a fable, and a filthy one," she sneered, a trifle hoarsely. It must have been very hot inside that leather sack, and she had had no water since leaving the Tarasin Palace. "Me, I am surprised that you will give it voice. And to cast the charge on me! What I have done, I have done on the orders of the Amyrlin Seat."

"ɪleɪɾə?" ɪleɪn spæɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ju hæv ðə nɝv tə kleɪm ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə ɔɹɾɝd jə tə mɝɾɝ sɪstɝz ən stil fɹəm ðə taʊɝ? ɪleɪɾə ɔɹɾɝd wʌt jə dɪɾ ɪn tiɹ ən tæntʃəkoʊ? əɹ dʒju min sɪuən? jəɹ laɪz ɑɹ pəθɛɾɪk! juv fɔɹseɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz, sʌmhaʊ, ən ðət neɪmz jə blæk ədʒɑ."

"Elaida?" Elayne spat incredulously. "You have the nerve to claim that Elaida ordered you to murder sisters and steal from the Tower? Elaida ordered what you did in Tear and Tanchico? Or do you mean Siuan? Your lies are pathetic! You've forsaken the Three Oaths, somehow, and that names you Black Ajah."

"aɪ də nɑɾ əv tə ænsɝ ðə kwɛstʃənz fɹəm ju," ɪspæn sɛd sʌlənli, hʌntʃɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "ju ɑɹ ɹɛbəlz əɡɛns ðə lɔfəl æmɪɝlɪn sit. jəl bi pʌnɪʃt, pɝhæps stɪld. ɪspɛʃli ɪf jə hɑɹm mi. aɪ sɝv ðə tʃɹu æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən jəl bi pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli ɪf jə hɑɹm mi."

"I do not have to answer the questions from you," Ispan said sullenly, hunching her shoulders. "You are rebels against the lawful Amyrlin Seat. You will be punished, perhaps stilled. Especially if you harm me. I serve the true Amyrlin Seat, and you will be punished severely if you harm me."

"ju wɪl ænsɝ ɛni kwɛstʃənz maɪ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ æsks." eɪvinhə tɛstəɾ əɹ bɛl naɪf ɑn ə θʌmneɪl, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ ɑn ɪspænz. "wɛtləndɝz fɪɹ peɪn. ðeɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ɪt, æksɛpt ɪt. jəl ænsɝ əz jə ɑɹ æskt." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡlɛɹ əɹ snɑɹl, ʃi dʒʌst spoʊk, bʌɾ ɪspæn ʃɹæŋk bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ.

"You will answer any questions my near-sister asks." Aviendha tested her belt knife on a thumbnail, but her eyes were on Ispan's. "Wetlanders fear pain. They do not know how to embrace it, accept it. You will answer as you are asked." She did not glare or snarl, she just spoke, but Ispan shrank back in the chair.

"aɪ fɪɹ ðəɾ ɪz pɹoʊskɹaɪbd, ivən wɝ ʃi nɑɾ ən ɪnɪʃiəɾ ə ðə taʊɝ," æɾɪliz sɛd. "wi ɑɹ fɔɹbɪɾən tə ʃɛd blʌɾ ɪn kwɛstʃənɪŋ, əɹ tə əlaʊ ʌðɝz tə də soʊ ɪn əɹ neɪm." ʃi saʊndəd ɹɪlʌktənt, ðoʊ wɛðɝ oʊvɝ ðə pɹoʊəbɪʃən əɹ oʊvɝ ædmɪɾɪŋ ðəɾ ɪspæn wɑz ən ɪnɪʃiət, ɪleɪn kəd nɑt seɪ. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɑt ɹɪli kənsɪɾɝd ðəɾ ɪspæn maɪt stɪl bi kənsɪɾɝd wʌn. ðəɹ wɑz ə seɪɪŋ ðət noʊ wʊmən wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə taʊɝ əntɪl ɪt wɑz fɪnɪʃt wɪð hɝ, bʌt tʃɹuθfəli, wʌns ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʌtʃt ju, ɪt nɛvɝ wɑz fɪnɪʃt.

"I fear that is proscribed, even were she not an initiate of the Tower," Adeleas said. "We are forbidden to shed blood in questioning, or to allow others to do so in our name." She sounded reluctant, though whether over the prohibition or over admitting that Ispan was an initiate, Elayne could not say. She herself had not really considered that Ispan might still be considered one. There was a saying that no woman was finished with the Tower until it was finished with her, but truthfully, once the White Tower touched you, it never was finished.

hɝ bɹaʊ fɝoʊɾ əz ʃi stʌɾid ðə blæk sɪstɝ, soʊ bɪdʒɹæɡəld, ən stɪl soʊ ʃʊɹ ə hɝsɛlf. ɪspæn sæɾ ʌp ə lɪɾəl stʃɹeɪɾɝ, ən dɑɹɾɪd ɡlænsɪz fʊl ʌv əmjuz kəntɛmpt əɾ eɪvinhə - ən ɪleɪn. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ pɔɪzd ɝliɝ, wən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn əloʊn u hæd hɝ; ɹiɡeɪn kəmpoʊʒɝ hæd kʌm wɪð ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət ðəɹ wɝ oʊldɝ sɪstɝz pɹɛzənt. sɪstɝz u wəd hoʊld waɪt taʊɝ lɔ əz pɑɹɾ ə ðɛmsɛlvz. ðət lɔ fɝbeɪd nɑɾ oʊnli ʃɛɾɪŋ blʌd, bʌt bɹeɪkɪŋ boʊnz ən ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðəɾ ɛni waɪtkloʊk kwɛstʃənɝ wəd bi mɔɹ ðən ɹɛɾi tə du. bɪfɔɹ ɛni sɛʃən bɪɡæn, hilɪŋ hæd tə bi ɡɪvən, ən ɪf ðə kwɛstʃənɪŋ stɑɹɾəd æftɝ sʌnɹaɪz, ɪt hæd tə ɛn bɪfɔɹ sʌndaʊn; ɪf æftɝ sʌnsɛt, ðən bɪfɔɹ sʌnɹaɪz. ðə lɔ wɑz ivən mɔɹ ɹistʃɹɪktɪv wən ɪt keɪm tə ɪnɪʃieɪts ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə sɪstɝz ən æksɛptɪɾ ən nɑvəsɪz, bænɪŋ ðə jus ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪn kwɛstʃənɪŋ, pʌnɪʃmənt, əɹ pɛnəns. oʊ, ə sɪstɝ maɪt flɪk ə nɑvəsəz ɪɹ wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪf ʃi wɑz ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd, əɹ ivən ɡɪv əɹ ə swɑɾ ɑn ðə bɑɾəm, bʌt nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ mɔɹ. ɪspæn smaɪld ət hɝ. smaɪld! ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ.

Her brow furrowed as she studied the Black sister, so bedraggled, and still so sure of herself. Ispan sat up a little straighter, and darted glances full of amused contempt at Aviendha - and Elayne. She had not been so poised earlier, when she thought it was Nynaeve and Elayne alone who had her; regained composure had come with remembering that there were older sisters present. Sisters who would hold White Tower law as part of themselves. That law forbade not only shedding blood, but breaking bones and a number of other things that any Whitecloak Questioner would be more than ready to do. Before any session began, Healing had to be given, and if the questioning started after sunrise, it had to end before sundown; if after sunset, then before sunrise. The law was even more restrictive when it came to initiates of the Tower, the sisters and Accepted and novices, banning the use of saidar in questioning, punishment, or penance. Oh, a sister might flick a novice's ear with the Power if she was exasperated, or even give her a swat on the bottom, but not very much more. Ispan smiled at her. Smiled! Elayne took a deep breath.

"æɾɪliz, vændin, aɪ wɑn jə tə liv eɪvinhə ən mi əloʊn wɪð ɪspæn." hɝ stʌmək tʃɹaɪd tə taɪ ɪtsɛlf ɪndə ə nɑt. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ tə pɹɛs ðə wʊmən səfɪʃənli tə lɝn wʌt wɑz niɾəd wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ taʊɝ lɔ. bʌt haʊ? pipəl u wɝ tə bi kwɛstʃən baɪ ðə taʊɝ juʒəwəli bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ə fɪŋɡɝ wɑz leɪɾ ɑn əm - ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət noʊ wʌn hɛld aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə taʊɝ; noʊ wʌn! - bʌt ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi sɛldəm ɪnɪʃiəts. ʃi kəd hɪɹ ənʌðɝ vɔɪs, nɑt liniz ðɪs taɪm, bʌɾ əɹ mʌðɝz. wʌt jə ɔɹɾɝ dʌn, jə mʌs bi wɪlɪŋ tə də wɪð jəɹ oʊn hænd. əz ə kwin, wʌt jə ɔɹɾɝ dʌn, juv dʌn. ɪf ʃi dɪd bɹeɪk ðə lɔ. . . . hɝ mʌðɝz vɔɪs əɡɛn. ivən ə kwin kænɑt bi əbʌv ðə lɔ, əɹ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ lɔ. ən liniz. jə kən də wʌtɛvɝ jə wɪʃ, tʃaɪld. soʊ lɔŋ əz jəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə peɪ ðə pɹaɪs. ʃi dʒɹæɡd əɹ hæɾ ɔf wɪθaʊɾ əntiɪŋ ðə ɹɪbənz. kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs stɛɾi tʊk ən ɛfɝt. "wɛn wəɹ - wən wəɹ dʌn tɔkɪŋ wɪð hɝ, jə kən teɪk əɹ bæk tə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl." æftɝwɝd, ʃi wəd səbmɪt hɝsɛlf tə mɛɝɪlɪl. ɛni faɪv sɪstɝz kəd sɪɾ ɪn dʒʌdʒmən tə sɛɾ ə pɛnəns, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ æskt.

"Adeleas, Vandene, I want you to leave Aviendha and me alone with Ispan." Her stomach tried to tie itself into a knot. There had to be a way to press the woman sufficiently to learn what was needed without breaking Tower law. But how? People who were to be questioned by the Tower usually began talking before a finger was laid on them - everyone knew that no one held out against the Tower; no one! - but they were very seldom initiates. She could hear another voice, not Lini's this time, but her mother's. What you order done, you must be willing to do with your own hand. As a queen, what you order done, you have done. If she did break the law. . . . Her mother's voice again. Even a queen cannot be above the law, or there is no law. And Lini's. You can do whatever you wish, child. So long as you're willing to pay the price. She dragged her hat off without untying the ribbons. Keeping her voice steady took an effort. "When we are - when we are done talking with her, you can take her back to the Knitting Circle." Afterward, she would submit herself to Merilille. Any five sisters could sit in judgment to set a penance, if they were asked.

ɪspænz hɛd swʌŋ, swoʊlən aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ fɹəm ɪleɪn tə eɪvinhə ən bæk, sloʊli waɪɾənɪŋ əntɪl ðə waɪts ʃoʊɾ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd. ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ ə hɝsɛlf naʊ.

Ispan's head swung, swollen eyes going from Elayne to Aviendha and back, slowly widening until the whites showed all the way around. She was not so sure of herself now.

saɪlənt ɡlænsɪz pæs bɪtwin vændin ən æɾɪliz, ɪn ðə mænɝ ə pipəl u hæd spɛn soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm təɡɛðɝ ðeɪ hɑɹdli niɾəd tə spik əlaʊɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ; ðən vændin tʊk ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə itʃ baɪ ən ɑɹm. "ɪf aɪ meɪ spik wɪð jə aʊtsaɪɾ ə moʊmənt," ʃi mɝmɝd. ɪt saʊndəɾ ə sədʒɛstʃən, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɝdʒɪŋ əm tə ðə dɔɹ.

Silent glances passed between Vandene and Adeleas, in the manner of people who had spent so much time together they hardly needed to speak aloud any longer; then Vandene took Elayne and Aviendha each by an arm. "If I may speak with you outside a moment," she murmured. It sounded a suggestion, but she was already urging them to the door.

aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd, pɝhæps tu dʌzən əɹ soʊ kɪnswɪmən wɝ hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ laɪk ʃip. nɑɾ ɔl wɔɹ ɛbu dɑɹi kloʊðz, bʌt tu hæd ðə ɹɛd bɛls ʌv waɪz wɪmən, ən ɪleɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz bɛɹaʊɪn, ə staʊt lɪɾəl wʊmən u nɔɹməli ʃoʊɾ ə pɹaɪd fɑɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. nɑt naʊ. laɪk ðə ɹɛst, hɝ feɪs wɑz fɹaɪɾənd, hɝ aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ, dɪspaɪt ði ɪntaɪɝ nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl sɝaʊndɪŋ əm ən tɔkɪŋ ɝdʒənli. daʊn ðə weɪ, nɪneɪiv ən æləz wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hɝd pɝhæps twaɪs əz mɛni wɪmən ɪnsaɪd wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ bɪldɪŋz. "tʃɹaɪɪŋ" dɪd sim tə bi ðə wɝd.

Outside in the farmyard, perhaps two dozen or so Kinswomen were huddled together like sheep. Not all wore Ebou Dari clothes, but two had the red belts of Wise Women, and Elayne recognized Berowin, a stout little woman who normally showed a pride far greater than her strength in the Power. Not now. Like the rest, her face was frightened, her eyes darting, despite the entire Knitting Circle surrounding them and talking urgently. Down the way, Nynaeve and Alise were trying to herd perhaps twice as many women inside one of the larger buildings. "Trying" did seem to be the word.

". . . doʊn kɛɹ wʌɾ ɪsteɪts jə hoʊld," nɪneɪiv wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ əɾ ə pɹaʊd-nɛkt wʊmən ɪn peɪl ɡɹin sɪlk. "ju ɡɛɾ ɪn ðəɹ ən steɪ ɪn ðɛɹ, aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, əɹ əl kɪk jə ɪnsaɪd!"

". . . don't care what estates you hold," Nynaeve was shouting at a proud-necked woman in pale green silk. "You get in there and stay in there, out of the way, or I'll kick you inside!"

æləz sɪmpli siz ðə ɡɹin-klæd wʊmən baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə ðə nɛk ən ɹæn əɹ θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ dɪspaɪt vɑljəbəl ən hiɾəd pɹoʊɾɛsts. ðəɹ wɑz ə laʊd skwɔk laɪk ə hjudʒ ɡus biɪŋ stɛpt ɑn, ðən æləz ɹiəpɪɹd, dʌstɪŋ əɹ hænz. ði ʌðɝz sim tə ɡɪv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl æftɝ ðæt.

Alise simply seized the green-clad woman by the scruff of the neck and ran her through the doorway despite voluble and heated protests. There was a loud squawk like a huge goose being stepped on, then Alise reappeared, dusting her hands. The others seemed to give no trouble after that.

vændin ɹilis ðɛm, stʌɾiɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz. ðə ɡloʊ stɪl ɛnvɛləp hɝ, jɛɾ æɾɪliz mʌst əv bɪn foʊkəsɪŋ ðɛɹ kəmbaɪn floʊz. vændin cʊɾə meɪnteɪn ðə ʃild, wʌns woʊvən, wɪθaʊt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə si ɪt, bʌt hæd ʃi bɪn ðə wʌn, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ laɪkliɝ ðəɾ æɾɪliz wʊɾə bɹɔɾ əm aʊt. vændin cʊɾə ɡɔn sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bɪfɔɹ ðə lɪŋk bɪɡæn tə ətɛnjueɪt - ɪt wəd nɑt bɹeɪk ɪf ʃi ən æɾɪliz wɛn tə ɑpəzət kɔɹnɝz ə ði ɝθ, ðoʊ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn jusləs lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðət - bʌt ʃi ɹɪmeɪn kloʊs tə ðə dɔɹ. ʃi sim tə sɔɹt wɝdz ɪn əɹ hɛd.

Vandene released them, studying their eyes. The glow still enveloped her, yet Adeleas must have been focusing their combined flows. Vandene could have maintained the shield, once woven, without being able to see it, but had she been the one, it was much likelier that Adeleas would have brought them out. Vandene could have gone several hundred paces before the link began to attenuate - it would not break if she and Adeleas went to opposite corners of the earth, though it would have been useless long before that - but she remained close to the door. She seemed to sort words in her head.

"aɪv ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt bɛst ɪf wɪmən wɪð ɪkspɪɹiəns hændəl ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "ðə jʌŋ kən izəli bi kɑɾ ʌp ɪn hɑt blʌd. ðən ðeɪ də tu mʌtʃ. əɹ səmtaɪmz, ðeɪ ɹilaɪz ðeɪ kæn bɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə də ɪnʌf. kəz ðeɪ hævən ɹɪli sin ɪnʌf, jɛt. əɹ wɝst ʌv ɔl, ðeɪ faɪn ə . . . teɪs fəɹ ɪt. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ bɪliv iðɝ ə jə hæz ðət flɔ." ʃi ɡeɪv eɪvinhə ə weɪɪŋ ɡlæns wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ; eɪvinhə heɪstəli ʃiðd əɹ bɛl naɪf. "æɾɪliz ən aɪ hæv sin ɪnʌf tə noʊ waɪ wi mʌs də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, ən wi lɛf hɑt blʌd bɪhaɪn lɔŋ əɡoʊ. pɝhæps jəl liv ðɪs tə ʌs. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðət weɪ, ɔl ɝaʊnd." vændin sim tə teɪk ðə ɹɛkəməndeɪʃən əz æksɛptɪd. ʃi nɑɾəd ən tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ.

"I've always thought it best if women with experience handle this sort of thing," she said finally. "The young can easily be caught up in hot blood. Then they do too much. Or sometimes, they realize they can't bring themselves to do enough. Because they haven't really seen enough, yet. Or worst of all, they find a . . . taste for it. Not that I believe either of you has that flaw." She gave Aviendha a weighing glance without pausing; Aviendha hastily sheathed her belt knife. "Adeleas and I have seen enough to know why we must do what must be done, and we left hot blood behind long ago. Perhaps you will leave this to us. Much better that way, all around." Vandene seemed to take the recommendation as accepted. She nodded and turned back toward the door.

noʊ sunɝ hæd ʃi dɪsəpɪɹd bɪhaɪn ɪt, ðən ɪleɪn fɛl ðə jus ə ðə paʊɝ wɪðɪn, ə wiv ðət mʌst əv blæŋkəɾɪd ðə ɹum ɪnsaɪd. ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, sɝɾənli. ðeɪ wəd nɑt wɑn stʃɹeɪ ɪɹz tə kætʃ wʌtɛvɝ ɪspæn sɛd. ðən ənʌðɝ jus hɪt hɝ, ən sʌɾənli ðə saɪləns fɹəm wɪðɪn wɑz mɔɹ ɑmənəs ðən ɛni ʃɹiks ðət wɔɹd wəd kənteɪn.

No sooner had she disappeared behind it, than Elayne felt the use of the Power within, a weave that must have blanketed the room inside. A ward against eavesdropping, certainly. They would not want stray ears to catch whatever Ispan said. Then another use hit her, and suddenly the silence from within was more ominous than any shrieks that ward would contain.

ʃi kɹʌʃt əɹ hæt bæk ɑntu hɝ hɛd. ðə hit ʃi kəd nɑt fil, bʌt ðə sʌnz ɡlɛɹ sʌɾənli meɪɾ əɹ kwizi. "meɪbi jəl hɛlp mi lʊk oʊvɝ wʌt ðə pækhɔɹsɪz ɑɹ kæɹiɪŋ," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθəli. ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪt dʌn - wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz - bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ. eɪvinhə nɑɾəd wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ kwɪknəs; ʃi sim tə wɑnə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðət saɪləns, tu.

She crushed her hat back onto her head. The heat she could not feel, but the sun's glare suddenly made her queasy. "Maybe you'll help me look over what the packhorses are carrying," she said breathily. She had not ordered it done - whatever it was - but that did not seem to change anything. Aviendha nodded with surprising quickness; she seemed to want to be away from that silence, too.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ðə sɝvəns hæd ðə pæk ænəməlz, weɪɾɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli ən stɛɹɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪmpɪɹiəsli, ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ ðɛɹ bɹɛsts, kɑpiɪŋ ɹɪneɪl. æləz mɑɹtʃt ʌp tə ðɛm, mɑɹkɪŋ ɹɪneɪl aʊɾ əz ðə liɾɝ æftɝ wʌn swipɪŋ ɡlæns. ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd.

The Windfinders were waiting not far from where the servants had the pack animals, waiting impatiently and staring about imperiously, arms folded beneath their breasts, copying Renaile. Alise marched up to them, marking Renaile out as the leader after one sweeping glance. Elayne and Aviendha she ignored.

"kʌm wɪð mi," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn bɹɪsk toʊnz ðət bɹʊk noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ seɪ jəl wɑnə bi aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn əntɪl mæɾɝz ɑɹ mɔɹ sɛɾəld." ðə wɝdz "ɛɛs sədaɪ" hɛld əz mʌtʃ bɪɾɝnəs əz ðeɪ dɪd ði ɑ ɪleɪn wɑz juz tə fɹəm kɪnswɪmən. meɪbi mɔɹ. ɹɪneɪl stɪfənd, hɝ dɑɹk feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹkɝ, bʌɾ æləz plaʊɾ ɑn. "ju waɪldɝz kən sɪɾ aʊt hɪɹ ən swɛɾ ɪf ðæts wʌt jə wɑnt, fəɹ ɔl ə mi. ɪf jə kən sɪt." ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs nʌn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ hæd ɹəsiv hilɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ sæɾəl sɔɹnəs; ðeɪ stʊd laɪk wɪmən u wɑntəd tə fɝɡɛt ðeɪ ɪɡzɪstəd bɪloʊ ðə weɪst. "wʌt jəl nɑt də ɪz kip mi weɪɾɪŋ."

"Come with me," she said in brisk tones that brooked no argument. "The Aes Sedai say you will want to be out of the sun until matters are more settled." The words "Aes Sedai" held as much bitterness as they did the awe Elayne was used to from Kinswomen. Maybe more. Renaile stiffened, her dark face growing darker, but Alise plowed on. "You wilders can sit out here and sweat if that's what you want, for all of me. If you can sit." It was obvious none of the Atha'an Miere had received Healing for their saddle soreness; they stood like women who wanted to forget they existed below the waist. "What you will not do is keep me waiting."

"du jə noʊ hu aɪ æm?" ɹɪneɪl dɪmændəɾ ɪn ə taɪt fjʊɹi, bʌɾ æləz wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wɔkɪŋ əweɪ ən nɑt lʊkɪŋ bæk. stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð hɝsɛlf vɪzəbli, ɹɪneɪl dæʃt swɛt fɹəm əɹ fɔɹhɛd wɪð ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd, ðən æŋɡɹəli ɔɹɾɝd ði ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz tə liv ðə "ʃɔɹ-kɝst" hɔɹsəz ən fɑloʊ hɝ. ðeɪ meɪɾ ə spɹæəl-lɛɡəd laɪn wɑbəlɪŋ əlɔŋ æftɝ æləz, ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt ðə tu əpɹɛntəsɪz mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf - æləz ɪnkluɾəd.

"Do you know who I am?" Renaile demanded in a tight fury, but Alise was already walking away and not looking back. Struggling with herself visibly, Renaile dashed sweat from her forehead with the back of her hand, then angrily ordered the other Windfinders to leave the "shore-cursed" horses and follow her. They made a spraddle-legged line wobbling along after Alise, everyone but the two apprentices muttering to herself - Alise included.

ɪnstɪŋktɪvli, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn tə plæn haʊ tə smuð mæɾɝz oʊvɝ, haʊ tə ɡɛt ði æθɑn maɪɹz peɪnz hild wɪθaʊɾ əm hævɪŋ tə æsk. əɹ ə sɪstɝ hævɪŋ tə ɔfɝ tu stʃɹɛnjuəsli; nɪneɪiv hæd tə bi əpizd, tu, ən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ʃi sʌɾənli ɹilaɪz ðət fəɹ wʌns ɪn əɹ laɪf ʃi hæd noʊ ɹil dɪzaɪɝ tə smuð ɛniθɪŋ. wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz lɪmp təwɔɹd wʌn ə ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət mæɾɝz wɝ faɪn dʒʌst əz ðeɪ wɝ. eɪvinhə wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ, oʊpən ɡɹɪn əz ʃi wɑtʃt ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ɪleɪn snætʃt ðə mʌtʃ smɔlɝ smaɪl fɹəm əɹ oʊn feɪs ən tɝn tə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ðeɪ dɪd dɪzɝv ɪt, ðoʊ. nɑt ɡɹɪnɪŋ wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd.

Instinctively, Elayne began to plan how to smooth matters over, how to get the Atha'an Miere's pains Healed without them having to ask. Or a sister having to offer too strenuously; Nynaeve had to be appeased, too, and the other sisters. To her surprise, she suddenly realized that for once in her life she had no real desire to smooth anything. Watching the Windfinders limp toward one of the farm buildings, she decided that matters were fine just as they were. Aviendha wore a large, open grin as she watched the Atha'an Miere. Elayne snatched the much smaller smile from her own face and turned to the packhorses. They did deserve it, though. Not grinning was very hard.

wɪð eɪvinhəz hɛlp, ðə sɝtʃɪŋ wɛn mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən bɪfɔɹ, ðoʊ eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ əz kwɪkli əz ʃi dɪd. nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpɹaɪz. ə fju ʌv ðə sɪstɝz ɪleɪn hæd tʃɹeɪnd ʃoʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ skɪl ɪn ðɪs ðən ʃi dɪd hɝsɛlf, bʌt moʊs keɪm noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ. stɪl, tu sɛts ə hænz faʊn mɔɹ ðən wʌn, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə bi faʊnd. lɪvɹid steɪbəlmən ən wɪmən kæɹiɾ əweɪ ðə ɹʌbɪʃ, waɪl ə kəlɛkʃən ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɡɹu ɑn ðə bɹɔd stoʊn lɪɾ ʌv ə skwɛɹ sɪstɝn.

With Aviendha's help, the searching went more quickly than before, though Aviendha did not recognize what they were after as quickly as she did. Not a great surprise.
