A few of the sisters Elayne had trained showed a greater skill in this than she did herself, but most came nowhere near. Still, two sets of hands found more than one, and there was a great deal to be found. Liveried stablemen and women carried away the rubbish, while a collection of ter'angreal grew on the broad stone lid of a square cistern.

fɔɹ mɔɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ ənloʊɾəd kwɪkli, ən ðeɪ əkjumjəleɪɾəd ə səlɛkʃən ðət wʊɾə kɑzd ə sɛləbɹeɪʃən, bɹɔɾ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ. ivən wɪð noʊ wʌn stʌɾiɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ðeɪ tʊk ɛvɹi fɔɹm ɪmædʒənəbəl. kʌps ən boʊlz ən veɪsəz, noʊ tu ðə seɪm saɪz əɹ dɪzaɪn əɹ ɪn ðə seɪm mətɪɹiəl. ə flæt, wɝm-iɾən bɑks, hæf-fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹɾ ən wʌtɛvɝ hæd laɪn ɪt lɔŋ sɪns ɡɔn tə dʌst, hɛl pisəz ə dʒuəlɹi - ə nɛkləs ən bɹeɪslɪts sɛt wɪð kʌlɝd stoʊnz, ə slɪm dʒɛm-stʌɾɪd bɛlt, sɛvɹəl fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz - ən ðəɹ wɝ speɪsəz fəɹ mɔɹ. ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl wʌn wɑz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ən ðeɪ ɔl mætʃt, mɛn tə bi wɔɹn təɡɛðɝ, ðoʊ ɪleɪn kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən waɪ ɛni wʊmən wəd wɑnə kæɹi soʊ mɛni əbaʊɾ əɹ ət wʌn taɪm. eɪvinhə faʊn ə dæɡɝ wɪð ɡoʊld waɪɝ ɹæpt ɝaʊn ə hɪlt ə ɹʌf dɪɹ-hɔɹn; ðə bleɪd wɑz dʌl, ən baɪ ɔl ɛvəɾəns, ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn. ʃi kɛp tɝnɪŋ ðəɾ oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz - hɝ hænz æktʃəli  bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɛmbəl - əntɪl ɪleɪn tʊk ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ən pʊɾ ɪt wɪð ði ʌðɝz ɑn ðə sɪstɝnz lɪd. ivən ðən eɪvinhə stʊd fəɹ ə taɪm, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪɾ ən lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ. ðəɹ wɝ fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz, ɪɹɪŋz, nɛkləsɪz, bɹeɪslɪts ən bʌkəlz, mɛni ʌv vɛɹi pəkjuljɝ pæɾɝn ɪndid. ðəɹ wɝ stætʃuɛts ən fɪɡjɝz ə bɝdz ən ænəməlz ən pipəl, sɛvɹəl naɪvz ðət dɪɾ əv ɛdʒəz, hæf ə dʌzən lɑɹdʒ mədæljənz ɪn bɹɑnz əɹ stil, moʊst wɝkt wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ pæɾɝnz ən nɑt wʌn kæɹiɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ɪleɪn kəd ɹɪli ʌndɝstænd, ə pɛɹ ə pəkjuljɝ hæts simɪŋli meɪɾ ə mɛɾəl, tu ɔɹneɪɾ ən tu θɪn tə bi hɛlməts, ən ɛni nʌmbɝ ʌv aɪɾəmz ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk wʌt tə kɔl. ə ɹɑd, əz θɪk əz əɹ ɹɪst, bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ən smuð ən ɹaʊndəd, fɝm ɹæðɝ ðən hɑɹd fəɹ ɔl ðəɾ ɪt sim tə bi stoʊn; ɪt dɪd nɑt wɔɹm slaɪtli ɪn əɹ hænd, ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs fɛl hɑt! nɑt ɹil hiɾ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə wɔɹmθ wɑz ɹil, bʌt stɪl! wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ə sɛɾ ə mɛɾəl bæskətwɝk bɔlz, wʌn ɪnsaɪd ði ʌðɝ? ɛni muvmən pɹədust ə feɪn mjuzɪkəl tʃaɪm, ə dɪfɹən toʊn ɛvɹi taɪm, ən ʃi hæd ðə filɪŋ ðət noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑɹd ʃi lʊkt ɪndə ɪt, ðəɹ wəɾ ɔlweɪz bi ə stɪl smɔlɝ bɔl weɪɾɪŋ tə bi dɪskʌvɝd. ə θɪŋ ðət lʊk laɪk ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl meɪɾ ʌv ɡlæs? ɪt wɑz hɛvi ɪnʌf ðət ʃi dʒɹɑpt ɪt, ən ɪt bɹoʊk ə tʃɪp ɔf ði ɛdʒ ə ðə sɪstɝn kʌvɝ. ə kəlɛkʃən tə stɝ əmeɪzmən ɪn ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðeɪ faʊn tu mɔɹ æŋɡɹil. ðoʊz ɪleɪn sɛt vɛɹi kɛɹfəli əsaɪd, wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ.

Four more horses were unloaded quickly, and they accumulated a selection that would have caused a celebration, brought into the Tower. Even with no one studying ter'angreal. They took every form imaginable. Cups and bowls and vases, no two the same size or design or in the same material. A flat, worm-eaten box, half-falling apart and whatever had lined it long since gone to dust, held pieces of jewelry - a necklace and bracelets set with colored stones, a slim gem-studded belt, several finger rings - and there were spaces for more. Every single one was a ter'angreal, and they all matched, meant to be worn together, though Elayne could not imagine why any woman would want to carry so many about her at one time. Aviendha found a dagger with gold wire wrapped around a hilt of rough deer-horn; the blade was dull, and by all evidence, always had been. She kept turning that over and over in her fingers - her hands actually began to tremble - until Elayne took it away from her and put it with the others on the cistern's lid. Even then Aviendha stood for a time, looking at it and licking her lips as though they had gone dry. There were finger rings, earrings, necklaces, bracelets and buckles, many of very peculiar pattern indeed. There were statuettes and figures of birds and animals and people, several knives that did have edges, half a dozen large medallions in bronze or steel, most worked with strange patterns and not one carrying an image Elayne could really understand, a pair of peculiar hats seemingly made of metal, too ornate and too thin to be helmets, and any number of items she could not think what to call. A rod, as thick as her wrist, bright red and smooth and rounded, firm rather than hard for all that it seemed to be stone; it did not warm slightly in her hand, it almost felt hot! Not real heat any more than the warmth was real, but still! What about a set of metal basketwork balls, one inside the other? Any movement produced a faint musical chime, a different tone every time, and she had the feeling that no matter how hard she looked into it, there would always be a still smaller ball waiting to be discovered. A thing that looked like a blacksmith's puzzle made of glass? It was heavy enough that she dropped it, and it broke a chip off the edge of the cistern cover. A collection to stir amazement in any Aes Sedai. More important, they found two more angreal. Those Elayne set very carefully aside, within arm's reach.

wʌn wɑz ən ɑd pis ə dʒuəlɹi, ə ɡoʊldən bɹeɪsləɾ ətætʃt baɪ fɔɹ flæt tʃeɪnz tə fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz, ɛvɹi bɪɾ ʌv ɪɾ ɪnɡɹeɪvd ɪn ən ɪntʃɹəkət məzəlaɪk pæɾɝn. ðət wɑz ðə stʃɹɔŋɝ ə ðə tu, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə tɝɾəl stɪl ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ. ɪt wɑz meɪd fəɹ ə smɔlɝ hæn ðən hɝz əɹ eɪvinhəz. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə bɹeɪslət hæɾ ə taɪni lɑk, kəmplit wɪð ə mɪnəskjul, tubjəlɝ ki dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ə faɪn tʃeɪn ðət wɑz ɑbviəsli meɪd tə bi ɹimuvd. əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ki! ði ʌðɝ wɑz ə siɾəd wʊmən ɪn eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən aɪvɝi, hɝ lɛɡz foʊldəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, hɝ ɪkspoʊz niz bɛɹ, bʌt wɪð hɛɹ soʊ lɔŋ ən ləɡʒɝiənt ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ mʌfəld ɪn ðə hɛviəs kloʊk. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ivən əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ðə tɝɾəl, bʌt ʃi faʊn ɪt vɛɹi əpilɪŋ. wʌn hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ə ni, pɑm ʌp ən fɪŋɡɝz ɝeɪnʒd soʊ ðə θʌm tʌtʃt ðə tɪps ə ðə mɪɾəl tu fɪŋɡɝz, waɪl ði ʌðɝ hænd wɑz lɪftəd, ðə fɝs tu fɪŋɡɝz ɹeɪzd ən ði ʌðɝz foʊldəd. ðə hoʊl fɪɡjɝ kæɹiɾ ən ɛɹ ə səpɹim dɪɡnəɾi, jɛt ðə dɛləkətli wɝk feɪs ʃoʊɾ əmjuzmən ən dɪlaɪt. meɪbi ɪt hæd bɪn meɪd fəɹ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ wʊmən? ɪt sim pɝsənəl, sʌmhaʊ. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd dʌn ðæt, ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. səm tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝ ɪmɛns, niɾɪŋ mɛn ən hɔɹsəz, əɹ ivən ðə paʊɝ, tə muv, bʌt moʊst æŋɡɹil wɝ smɔl ɪnʌf tə kæɹi əbaʊt jəɹ pɝsən; nɑɾ ɔl, bʌt moʊst.

One was an odd piece of jewelry, a golden bracelet attached by four flat chains to finger rings, every bit of it engraved in an intricate mazelike pattern. That was the stronger of the two, stronger than the turtle still in her pouch. It was made for a smaller hand than hers or Aviendha's. Strangely, the bracelet had a tiny lock, complete with a minuscule, tubular key dangling from a fine chain that was obviously made to be removed. Along with the key! The other was a seated woman in age-darkened ivory, her legs folded in front of her, her exposed knees bare, but with hair so long and luxuriant she could not have been more muffled in the heaviest cloak. It was not even as strong as the turtle, but she found it very appealing. One hand rested on a knee, palm up and fingers arranged so the thumb touched the tips of the middle two fingers, while the other hand was lifted, the first two fingers raised and the others folded. The whole figure carried an air of supreme dignity, yet the delicately worked face showed amusement and delight. Maybe it had been made for a particular woman? It seemed personal, somehow. Perhaps they had done that, in the Age of Legends. Some ter'angreal were immense, needing men and horses, or even the Power, to move, but most angreal were small enough to carry about your person; not all, but most.

ðeɪ wɝ tɔsɪŋ bæk ðə kænvəs kʌvɝz ɑn ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ʌv wɪkɝ pænɪɝz wən nɪneɪiv keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp. ði æθɑn maɪɹ bɪɡæn faɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɪmpɪŋ. mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɹɪneɪl, əɹ ɹæðɝ, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ wɑz tɔkɪŋ ən mɛɝɪlɪl lɪsnɪŋ. ɪleɪn wʌndɝd wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðɛɹ. ðə slɪm ɡɹeɪ dɪd nɑt lʊk soʊ sæɾəsfaɪd ɛnimɔɹ. ðə hʌɾəl ə kɪnswɪmən hæd ɡɹoʊn lɑɹdʒɝ, bʌɾ ivən əz ɪleɪn lʊkt ʌp, θɹi mɔɹ keɪm hɛzɪɾəntli ɪndə ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd, ən ənʌðɝ tu stʊɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ði ɑləv tʃɹiz, piɹɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪndɪsaɪsɪvli. ʃi kəd sɛns bɝdʒɪt, sʌmwɛɹ aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹoʊvz ən oʊnli ə lɪɾəl lɛs ɪɹəteɪɾəd ðən ɝliɝ.

They were tossing back the canvas covers on another set of wicker panniers when Nynaeve came striding up. The Atha'an Miere began filing out of one of the farm buildings, no longer limping. Merilille was talking with Renaile, or rather, the Windfinder was talking and Merilille listening. Elayne wondered what had happened in there. The slim Gray did not look so satisfied anymore. The huddle of Kinswomen had grown larger, but even as Elayne looked up, three more came hesitantly into the farmyard, and another two stood at the edge of the olive trees, peering about indecisively. She could sense Birgitte, somewhere out among the groves and only a little less irritated than earlier.

nɪneɪiv ɡlænst ət ðə dɪspleɪ ʌv tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən ɡeɪv əɹ bɹeɪɾ ə tʌɡ. hɝ hæt hæd ɡɔn mɪsɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ. "ðæt kən weɪt," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ dɪsɡʌstəd. "ɪts taɪm."

Nynaeve glanced at the display of ter'angreal and gave her braid a tug. Her hat had gone missing somewhere. "That can wait," she said, sounding disgusted. "It's time."


tʃæptɝ faɪv


CHAPTER 5

ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ stɔɹm


The Breaking Storm

ðə sʌn stʊd lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ daʊn təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ klæmbɝɾ ʌp ðə wɛl-wɔɹn, sneɪkɪŋ pæθ tə ðə tɑp ə ðə stip-saɪɾəd hɪl əbʌv ðə bɑɹnz. ðət wɑz ðə spɑt ɹɪneɪl hæd tʃoʊzən. ɪt dɪd meɪk sɛns fɹəm wʌɾ ɪleɪn nu ʌv wɝkɪŋ wɛðɝ, ɔl lɝn fɹəm ə si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝ, tə bi ʃʊɹ. tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bɪɑn jəɹ ɪmiɾiət vəsɪnəɾi ɹikwaɪɝd wɝkɪŋ oʊvɝ lɔŋ dɪstənsəz, wɪtʃ mɛn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə si ə lɔŋ dɪstəns, mʌtʃ iziɝ ɑn ði oʊʃən ðən ɑn lænd. ɪksɛp fɹəm ə maʊntən əɹ hɪltɑp. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ niɾəd ə dɛf hæn tə əvɔɪd kɑzɪŋ tɔɹɛntʃəl ɹeɪnz əɹ wɝlwaɪnz əɹ ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɛlswɛɹ. wʌtɛvɝ jə dɪd, ði ɪfɛks spɹɛd laɪk ɹɪpəlz fɹəm ə stoʊn tɔst ɪndə ə pɑnd. ʃi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ wʌtsoʊɛvɝ tə lid ðə sɝkəl ðət wəd juz ðə boʊl.

The sun stood little more than halfway down toward the horizon by the time they clambered up the well-worn, snaking path to the top of the steep-sided hill above the barns. That was the spot Renaile had chosen. It did make sense from what Elayne knew of working weather, all learned from a Sea Folk Windfinder, to be sure. Changing anything beyond your immediate vicinity required working over long distances, which meant being able to see a long distance, much easier on the ocean than on land. Except from a mountain or hilltop. It also needed a deft hand to avoid causing torrential rains or whirlwinds or the Light alone knew what elsewhere. Whatever you did, the effects spread like ripples from a stone tossed into a pond. She had no desire whatsoever to lead the circle that would use the Bowl.

ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪl wɑz klɪɹ ə bɹʌʃ ən flæt, ɪf fɑɹ fɹəm lɛvəl, ə ɹʌf stoʊn teɪbəl, fɪfti peɪsɪz lɔŋ ən bɹɔd, wɪð plɛnti ʌv ɹum fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi hu niɾəd tə bi ðɛɹ, ən səm u dɪd nɑt, stʃɹɪkli spikɪŋ. fɹəm ət lis fɪfti peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə fɑɹm, ðə spɛktækjəlɝ vju stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ maɪlz oʊvɝ ə pætʃwɝk kwɪlt ə fɑɹmz ən pæstʃɝz, fɔɹəsts ən ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz. fɑɹ tu mɛni bɹaʊnz ən sɪɹ jɛloʊz wɝ mɪkst ɪn wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹin, kɹaɪɪŋ ðə nid fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ tə du, jɛɾ ivən soʊ, ðə bjuɾi ʌv ɪt stʃɹʌk ɪleɪn. dɪspaɪt dʌst ɪn ði ɛɹ laɪk ə feɪn mɪst, ʃi kəd si soʊ fɑɹ! ðə læn ɹɪli wɑz kwaɪt flæt hɪɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz fju hɪlz. ɛbu dɑɹ leɪ dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt tə ðə saʊθ ivən ɪf ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə paʊɝ, jɛɾ ɪt simd ʃi ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə si ɪt, baɪ stʃɹeɪnɪŋ dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl. ʃʊɹli wɪð ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝt ʃi kəd si ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪldɑɹ. ə mɑɹvələs vju. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ɪntʃɹəstəd.

The top of the hill was clear of brush and flat, if far from level, a rough stone table, fifty paces long and broad, with plenty of room for everybody who needed to be there, and some who did not, strictly speaking. From at least fifty paces above the farm, the spectacular view stretched for miles over a patchwork quilt of farms and pastures, forests and olive groves. Far too many browns and sere yellows were mixed in with a hundred shades of green, crying the need for what they were to do, yet even so, the beauty of it struck Elayne. Despite dust in the air like a faint mist, she could see so far! The land really was quite flat here except for those few hills. Ebou Dar lay just out of sight to the south even if she embraced the Power, yet it seemed she should be able to see it, by straining just a little. Surely with a little effort she could see the River Eldar. A marvelous view. Not everyone was interested.

"æn aʊɝ weɪstəd," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld, ɡlɛɹɪŋ saɪdweɪz ət ɹin. ən ət dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. wɪð læn nɑt ðɛɹ, ɪt simd ʃi maɪt teɪk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ənliʃ əɹ tɛmpɝ. "ɔlmoʊst ən aʊɝ. meɪbi mɔɹ. kəmplitli weɪstəd. æləz ɪz keɪpəbəl ɪnʌf, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt jud θɪŋk ɹin wəd noʊ hu wɑz ðɛɹ! laɪt! ɪf ðət ful wʊmən feɪns ɑn mi əɡɛn . . . !" ɪleɪn hoʊpt ʃi hɛld ɑn ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. ɪt lʊk tə bi kwaɪɾ ə stɔɹm wʌns ʃi lɛɾ ɪt bɹeɪk.

"An hour wasted," Nynaeve grumbled, glaring sideways at Reanne. And at just about everyone else. With Lan not there, it seemed she might take the opportunity to unleash her temper. "Almost an hour. Maybe more. Completely wasted. Alise is capable enough, I suppose, but you'd think Reanne would know who was there! Light! If that fool woman faints on me again . . . !" Elayne hoped she held on a little longer. It looked to be quite a storm once she let it break.

ɹin tʃɹaɪd tə kip ə tʃɪɹfəl, iɡɝ feɪs, jɛɾ əɹ hænz wɝ nɛvɝ stɪl ɑn əɹ skɝts, kɑnstənli plʌkɪŋ ən smuðɪŋ. kɝstʃən sɪmpli klʌtʃt hɝz ən swɛɾɪd, əpɪɹɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə ɛmpti hɝ stʌmək ɛni mɪnət; wən ɛniwʌn lʊkt ət hɝ, ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl, ʃi ʃɪvɝd. ðə θɝd kɪnswʊmən, ɡæɹiniə, wɑz ə sɑldəiən mɝtʃənt wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ noʊz ən ə waɪd maʊð, ə ʃɔɹt slɪm-hɪpt wʊmən, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ tu, hu lʊk nɑt ðət mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv. ə ɡɹisi dæmpnəs ɡlɪsən ɑn əɹ peɪl feɪs, ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz ɡɹu waɪɾɝ wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ fɛl ɑn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi maɪt sun dɪskʌvɝ wɛðɝ sʌmwʌnz aɪz æktʃəli  kəd pɑp aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ət list ɡæɹiniə hæd stɑp moʊnɪŋ, wɪtʃ ʃi hæd dʌn ɔl ðə weɪ ʌp ðə hɪl.

Reanne tried to keep a cheerful, eager face, yet her hands were never still on her skirts, constantly plucking and smoothing. Kirstian simply clutched hers and sweated, appearing ready to empty her stomach any minute; when anyone looked at her, anyone at all, she shivered. The third Kinswoman, Garenia, was a Saldaean merchant with a strong nose and a wide mouth, a short slim-hipped woman, stronger than the other two, who looked not that much older than Nynaeve. A greasy dampness glistened on her pale face, and her dark eyes grew wider whenever they fell on an Aes Sedai. Elayne thought she might soon discover whether someone's eyes actually could pop out of her head. At least Garenia had stopped moaning, which she had done all the way up the hill.

ðəɹ ɹɪli hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ pɛɹ u maɪɾ əv bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf - pɑsəbli; ðə kɪn dɪd nɑt peɪ mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən tə ðət - bʌt ðə læs hæd ɡɔn ɑn əɹ weɪ θɹi deɪz pæst. noʊ wʌn ɛls ət ðə fɑɹm ivən keɪm kloʊs. wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl dɪsɡʌstəd. wʌn ɹizən. ði ʌðɝ wɑz ðət ɡæɹiniə hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə vɛɹi fɝs faʊnd, pæst aʊɾ ɪn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi feɪntɪɾ əɡɛn ðə fɝs tu taɪmz ʃi wɑz ɹaʊzd, əz sun əz əɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz. ʌv kɔɹs, nɪneɪiv biɪŋ nɪneɪiv, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ədmɪt ðət ʃi ʃʊɾə dʌn ɛniθɪŋ soʊ sɪmpəl əz æsk æləz u wɑz stɪl ət ðə fɑɹm. əɹ ivən tɛl æləz wʌt ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən ɪnkwaɪɝd. nɪneɪiv nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛniwʌn tə hæv sɛns tə noʊ ʌp fɹəm daʊn. ɪksɛp hɝsɛlf.

There really had been another pair who might have been strong enough - possibly; the Kin did not pay much attention to that - but the last had gone on her way three days past. No one else at the farm even came close. Which was why Nynaeve was still disgusted. One reason. The other was that Garenia had been one of the very first found, passed out in the farmyard. For that matter, she fainted again the first two times she was roused, as soon as her eyes fell on one of the sisters. Of course, Nynaeve being Nynaeve, she was not about to admit that she should have done anything so simple as ask Alise who was still at the farm. Or even tell Alise what she was looking for before the woman inquired. Nynaeve never expected anyone to have sense to know up from down. Except herself.

"wi kəd bi dʌn baɪ naʊ!" nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊld. "wi kəd bi ʃʌɾ ʌv - !" ʃi ɔlmoʊs kwɪvɝd wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə nɑt skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə si foʊk əz ðeɪ ɡæðɝd nɪɹ ði ist ɛn ə ðə stoʊn teɪbəl. ɹɪneɪl, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɛmfæɾɪkli, əpɪɹd tə bi ɡɪvɪŋ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ɪleɪn wʊɾə ɡɪvən ə pɹɪɾi tə hɪɹ ðoʊz.

"We could be done by now!" Nynaeve growled. "We could be shut of - !" She almost quivered with the effort of not scowling at the Sea Folk as they gathered near the east end of the stone table. Renaile, gesturing emphatically, appeared to be giving instructions. Elayne would have given a pretty to hear those.

nɪneɪivz ɡlɛɹz sɝɾənli tʊk ɪn mɛɝɪlɪl ən kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə, hu stɪl klʌtʃt ðə sɪlk-ɹæp boʊl taɪtli. æɾɪliz ən vændin hæd ɹɪmeɪn bɪloʊ, sɪkwɛstɝd wɪð ɪspæn. ðə θɹi sɪstɝz stʊd tʃæɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, nɑt peɪɪŋ ɛni maɪn tə nɪneɪiv ənlɛs ʃi spoʊk tə ðɛm dɝɛkli, bʌt mɛɝɪlɪlz ɡeɪz səmtaɪmz slɪp tə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ðən dʒɝkt əweɪ; hɝ mæsk ə sɝɛnəɾi fɔltɝd slaɪtli, ən ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps wɪð ðə tɪp ə hɝ tʌŋ.

Nynaeve's glares certainly took in Merilille and Careane and Sareitha, who still clutched the silk-wrapped Bowl tightly. Adeleas and Vandene had remained below, sequestered with Ispan. The three sisters stood chatting together, not paying any mind to Nynaeve unless she spoke to them directly, but Merilille's gaze sometimes slipped to the Windfinders, then jerked away; her mask of serenity faltered slightly, and she licked her lips with the tip of her tongue.

hæd ʃi meɪd səm mɪsteɪk daʊn bɪloʊ waɪl hilɪŋ ðɛm? mɛɝɪlɪl hæd nəɡoʊʃieɪɾəd tʃɹiɾiz ən miɾieɪtɪd dɪspjuts bɪtwin neɪʃənz; fju ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ʃi. bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪɹɪŋ ə stɔɹi wʌns, ə dʒoʊk ə sɔɹts, əbaʊɾ ə dəmɑni mɝtʃənt, ə si foʊk kɑɹɡəmæstɝ ən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑt mɛni pipəl toʊl dʒoʊks ɪnvɑlvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ; tɛlɪŋ wʌn maɪt nɑt bi ɪntaɪɝli seɪf. ðə mɝtʃən ən ðə kɑɹɡəmæstɝ faʊn ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɹɑk ɑn ðə ʃɔɹ ən pɹəsiɾəd tə sɛl ɪt bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪtwin ðɛm, sʌmhaʊ meɪkɪŋ ə pɹɑfəɾ itʃ taɪm. ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm əlɔŋ. ðə dəmɑni kənvɪns ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə baɪ ðə sɪmpəl stoʊn fəɹ twaɪs wʌt ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd læs peɪd. æftɝ wɪtʃ ði æθɑn maɪɹ kənvɪns ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə baɪ ðə seɪm ɹɑk fɹəm ɪm fəɹ twaɪs ðəɾ əɡɛn. oʊnli ə dʒoʊk, bʌɾ ɪt ʃoʊd wʌt pipəl bɪlivd. meɪbi ði oʊldɝ sɪstɝz wəd nɑɾ əv dʌn ɛni bɛɾɝ bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə si foʊk.

Had she made some mistake down below while Healing them? Merilille had negotiated treaties and mediated disputes between nations; few in the White Tower were better than she. But Elayne remembered hearing a story once, a joke of sorts, about a Domani merchant, a Sea Folk Cargomaster and an Aes Sedai. Not many people told jokes involving Aes Sedai; telling one might not be entirely safe. The merchant and the Cargomaster found an ordinary rock on the shore and proceeded to sell it back and forth between them, somehow making a profit each time. Then an Aes Sedai came along. The Domani convinced the Aes Sedai to buy the simple stone for twice what she herself had last paid. After which the Atha'an Miere convinced the Aes Sedai to buy the same rock from him for twice that again. Only a joke, but it showed what people believed. Maybe the older sisters would not have done any better bargaining with the Sea Folk.

eɪvinhə stʃɹoʊd stʃɹeɪt tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə klɪfs əz sun əz ʃi ɹitʃt ðə hɪltɑp, ən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ nɔɹθ, moʊʃənləs əz ə stætʃu. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ædmaɪɹɪŋ ðə vju; eɪvinhə wɑz sɪmpli stɛɹɪŋ. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts ə bɪɾ ɔkwɝdli wɪð ðə θɹi æŋɡɹil ɪn hænd, ʃi dʒɔɪn əɹ fɹɛnd.

Aviendha strode straight to the edge of the cliffs as soon as she reached the hilltop, and stood staring north, motionless as a statue. After a moment, Elayne realized that she was not admiring the view; Aviendha was simply staring. Gathering her skirts a bit awkwardly with the three angreal in hand, she joined her friend.

ðə klɪf fɛl ɪn fɪfti-fʊt stɛps tə ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz, stip swɑðz ə ɹɪdʒd ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, bɛɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju smɔl, daɪɪŋ bʊʃəz. ðə dʒɹɑp wɑz nɑt ɹɪli bɑðɝsəm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ðə seɪm əz lʊkɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊn fɹəm ðə tɑp ʌv ə tʃɹi, iðɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, lʊkɪŋ daʊn meɪɾ ɪleɪn fil ə tʃɹaɪfəl dɪzi. eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs ðət ði ɛdʒ wɑz ɹaɪɾ əɾ əɹ toʊz.

The cliff fell in fifty-foot steps to olive groves, steep swathes of ridged gray stone, bare except for a few small, dying bushes. The drop was not really bothersome, but it was hardly the same as looking at the ground from the top of a tree, either. Strangely, looking down made Elayne feel a trifle dizzy. Aviendha did not seem to notice that the edge was right at her toes.

"ɪz sʌmθɪŋ tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ju?" ɪleɪn æskt kwaɪətli.

"Is something troubling you?" Elayne asked quietly.

eɪvinhə kɛpt əɹ ɡeɪz ɑn ðə dɪstəns. "aɪ hæv feɪl ju," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz flæt, ɛmpti. "aɪ kænɑt fɔɹm ðə ɡeɪtweɪ pɹɑpɝli, ən ɔl sɔ mi ʃeɪm ju. aɪ θɔɾ ə sɝvənt wɑz wʌn ə ðə ʃæɾoʊɹaʊt, ən bɪheɪvd wɝs ðən fulɪʃli. ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɪɡnɔɹ mi ən ɡlɛɹ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, əz ɪf aɪm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dɔɡ jæpɪŋ ət ðɛɹ kəmænd. aɪ pɹitɛndəɾ aɪ kəd meɪk ðə ʃæɾoʊɹʌnɝ tɔk fəɹ ju, bʌt noʊ fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ ɪz əlaʊd tə kwɛstʃən pɹɪznɝz əntɪl ʃiz bɪn wɛd tə ðə spɪɹ fəɹ twɛnti jɪɹz, əɹ ivən tə wɑtʃ əntɪl ʃiz kæɹiɾ ɪt tɛn. aɪm wik ən sɑft, ɪleɪn. aɪ kænɑt bɛɹ tə ʃeɪm jə fɝðɝ. ɪf aɪ feɪl jə əɡɛn, əl daɪ."

Aviendha kept her gaze on the distance. "I have failed you," she said finally. Her voice was flat, empty. "I cannot form the gateway properly, and all saw me shame you. I thought a servant was one of the Shadowwrought, and behaved worse than foolishly. The Atha'an Miere ignore me and glare at the Aes Sedai, as if I am an Aes Sedai dog yapping at their command. I pretended I could make the Shadowrunner talk for you, but no Far Dareis Mai is allowed to question prisoners until she has been wed to the spear for twenty years, or even to watch until she has carried it ten. I am weak and soft, Elayne. I cannot bear to shame you further. If I fail you again, I will die."

ɪleɪnz maʊθ wɛn dʒɹaɪ. ðət saʊndəd tu kloʊs tə ə pɹɑməs. ɡɹɪpɪŋ eɪvinhəz ɑɹm fɝmli, ʃi dʒɹu hɝ bæk fɹəm ði ɛdʒ. il kəd bi ɔlmoʊst əz pəkjuljɝ əz ðə si foʊk θɔt ðeɪ wɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli θɪŋk eɪvinhə wəd dʒʌmp ɔf - nɑt ɹɪli - bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə teɪk ɛni tʃænsəz. ət lis ði ʌðɝ wʊmən dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɪzɪst.

Elayne's mouth went dry. That sounded too close to a promise. Gripping Aviendha's arm firmly, she drew her back from the edge. Aiel could be almost as peculiar as the Sea Folk thought they were. She did not really think Aviendha would jump off - not really - but she was not about to take any chances. At least the other woman did not try to resist.

ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls sim tə bi ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ ɪn itʃ ʌðɝ. nɪneɪiv hæd bɪɡʌn spikɪŋ tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, boʊθ hænz taɪɾ ɑn əɹ bɹeɪɾ ən əɹ feɪs ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz ðɛɹz fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪn ə nɑt ʃaʊɾɪŋ, waɪl ðeɪ lɪsənd wɪð kəntɛmptʃuəs ɛɹəɡəns. mɛɝɪlɪl ən sɝaɪðə stɪl ɡɑɹɾəd ðə boʊl, bʌt kɛɝin wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ tə tɔk wɪð ðə kɪnswɪmən, wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ səksɛs. ɹin ænsɝd, ɪf blɪŋkɪŋ ənizəli ən lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps, bʌt kɝstʃən stʊd tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ən saɪlənt, waɪl ɡæɹiniəz aɪz wɝ skwizd ʃʌt. ɪleɪn kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs loʊ ɛniweɪ; ðɪs wɑz nʌn ə ðɛɹ bɪznəs.

Everyone else seemed to be engrossed in themselves, or in each other. Nynaeve had begun speaking to the Atha'an Miere, both hands tight on her braid and her face almost as dark as theirs from the strain of not shouting, while they listened with contemptuous arrogance. Merilille and Sareitha still guarded the Bowl, but Careane was attempting to talk with the Kinswomen, without much success. Reanne answered, if blinking uneasily and licking her lips, but Kirstian stood trembling and silent, while Garenia's eyes were squeezed shut. Elayne kept her voice low anyway; this was none of their business.

"ju hævən feɪld ɛniwʌn, list ʌv ɔl mi, eɪvinhə. nʌθɪŋ juv dʌn əz ɛvɝ ʃeɪmd mi, ən nʌθɪŋ jə də ɛvɝ kʊd." eɪvinhə blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ daʊtfəli. "æn jəɹ əbaʊɾ əz wik ən sɑft əz ə stoʊn." ðət hæd tə bi ði ɑɾəst kɑmpləmənt ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ peɪɾ ɛniwʌn, jɛɾ eɪvinhə æktʃəli  lʊkt ɡɹæɾəfaɪd. "aɪl bɛt ðə si foʊk ɑɹ skɛɹd sɪli ʌv ju, tu." ənʌðɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ wʌn; ɪt meɪɾ eɪvinhə smaɪl, ɪf oʊnli feɪnli. ɪleɪn dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ. "æz fəɹ ɪspæn. . . ." ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ivən θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd də wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, tu, bʌt dʒʌs lɛɾɪŋ maɪ maɪn dwɛl ɑn ɪt meɪks maɪ hænz swɛɾ ən maɪ stʌmək ɹɔɪl. aɪd θɹoʊ ʌp ɪf aɪ ivən tʃɹaɪd. soʊ wi ʃɛɹ ðæt."

"You haven't failed anyone, least of all me, Aviendha. Nothing you've done has ever shamed me, and nothing you do ever could." Aviendha blinked at her doubtfully. "And you're about as weak and soft as a stone." That had to be the oddest compliment she had ever paid anyone, yet Aviendha actually looked gratified. "I'll bet the Sea Folk are scared silly of you, too." Another strange one; it made Aviendha smile, if only faintly. Elayne drew a breath. "As for Ispan. . . ." She did not like even thinking about this. "I thought I could do what was necessary, too, but just letting my mind dwell on it makes my hands sweat and my stomach roil. I'd throw up if I even tried. So we share that."

eɪvinhə meɪd ðə meɪɾən hæntɔk saɪn fəɹ "ju stɑɹɾəl mi"; ʃi hæd stɑɹɾəd titʃɪŋ səm ə ðɛm tə ɪleɪn, ðoʊ ʃi sɛɾ ɪt wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən. əpɛɹənli, biɪŋ nɪɹ-sɪstɝz u wɝ lɝnɪŋ tə bi mɔɹ tʃeɪnʒd ðæt. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt, ɹɪli. eɪvinhə sim tə θɪŋk əɹ ɛkspləneɪʃən hæd bɪn pɝfəkli klɪɹ. "aɪ dɪd nɑt min aɪ kəd nɑt," ʃi sɛɾ əlaʊd, "oʊnli ðəɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ haʊ. laɪkli aɪ wʊɾə kɪl hɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ." sʌɾənli ʃi smaɪld, mʌtʃ waɪɾɝ ən wɔɹmɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ, ən laɪtli tʌtʃt ɪleɪnz tʃik. "wi boʊθ əv wiknəs ɪn ʌs," ʃi wɪspɝd, "bʌɾ ɪt bɹɪŋz noʊ ʃeɪm soʊ lɔŋ əz oʊnli wi tu noʊ."

Aviendha made the Maiden handtalk sign for "You startle me"; she had started teaching some of them to Elayne, though she said it was forbidden. Apparently, being near-sisters who were learning to be more changed that. Except that it did not, really. Aviendha seemed to think her explanation had been perfectly clear. "I did not mean I could not," she said aloud, "only that I do not know how. Likely I would have killed her, trying." Suddenly she smiled, much wider and warmer than before, and lightly touched Elayne's cheek. "We both have weakness in us," she whispered, "but it brings no shame so long as only we two know."

"jɛs," ɪleɪn sɛd wikli. ʃi dʒʌs dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ! "ʌv kɔɹs ɪt dʌznt." ðɪs wʊmən kənteɪn mɔɹ sɝpɹaɪzəz ðən ɛni ɡlimən. "hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, pɹɛsɪŋ ðə wʊmən-ɹæpt-ɪn-hɝ-hɛɹ ɪndə eɪvinhəz hænd. "juz ðɪs ɪn ðə sɝkəl." lɛɾɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil ɡoʊ wɑz nɑɾ izi. ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə juz ɪt hɝsɛlf, bʌt smaɪlz əɹ noʊ smaɪlz, hɝ fɹɛnz spɪɹəts - hɝ nɪɹ-sɪstɝz spɪɹəts - niɾəd ɹeɪzɪŋ. eɪvinhə tɝn ðə smɔl aɪvɝi fɪɡjɝ oʊvɝ ɪn əɹ hænz; ɪleɪn kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si hɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd haʊ tə ɡɪv ɪt bæk. "eɪvinhə, jə noʊ haʊ ɪt filz wən jə hoʊld əz mʌtʃ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ əz jə kæn? θɪŋk ə hoʊldɪŋ ɔlmoʊs twaɪs əz mʌtʃ. ɹɪli θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. aɪ wɑn jə tə juz ɪt. pliz?"

"Yes," Elayne said weakly. She just did not know how! "Of course it doesn't." This woman contained more surprises than any gleeman. "Here," she said, pressing the woman-wrapped-in-her-hair into Aviendha's hand. "Use this in the circle." Letting the angreal go was not easy. She had intended to use it herself, but smiles or no smiles, her friend's spirits - her near-sister's spirits - needed raising. Aviendha turned the small ivory figure over in her hands; Elayne could almost see her trying to decide how to give it back. "Aviendha, you know how it feels when you hold as much of saidar as you can? Think of holding almost twice as much. Really think of it. I want you to use it. Please?"

pɝhæps il dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌɾ eɪvinhəz ɡɹin aɪz waɪɾənd. ðeɪ hæd dɪskʌst æŋɡɹil, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðɛɹ sɝtʃ, bʌt ʃi pɹɑbli nɛvɝ hæd θɔt wʌɾ ɪt wəd bi laɪk tə juz wʌn bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. "twaɪs əz mʌtʃ," ʃi mɝmɝd. "tə hoʊld ɔl ðæt. aɪ kən bɛɹli meɪk maɪsɛlf ɪmædʒən. ðɪs ɪz ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt ɡɪft, ɪleɪn." ʃi tʌtʃt ɪleɪnz tʃik əɡɛn, pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps; ðət wɑz ði il ɪkwɪvələn ʌv ə kɪs ən ə hʌɡ.

Perhaps Aiel did not show a great deal on their faces, but Aviendha's green eyes widened. They had discussed angreal, considering their search, but she probably never had thought what it would be like to use one before this. "Twice as much," she murmured. "To hold all that. I can barely make myself imagine. This is a very great gift, Elayne." She touched Elayne's cheek again, pressing her fingertips; that was the Aiel equivalent of a kiss and a hug.

wʌtɛvɝ nɪneɪiv hæd tə seɪ tə ðə si foʊk, ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ. ʃi stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm əm twɪtʃɪŋ əɾ əɹ skɝts fjʊɹiəsli. əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪleɪn, ʃi fɹaʊn ikwəli əɾ eɪvinhə ən ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə klɪf. juʒəwəli ʃi dɪnaɪɾ əɹ pʊɹ hɛd fəɹ haɪts, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əm bɪtwin hɝsɛlf ən ðə dʒɹɑp. "aɪ hæv tə tɔk tə ju," ʃi mʌɾɝd, ɡaɪɾɪŋ ɪleɪn ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns əlɔŋ ðə hɪltɑp. ən fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ði ɛdʒ. ə lɪɾəl weɪ, bʌt fɑɹ ɪnʌf fɹəm ɛniwʌn tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ oʊvɝhɝd. ʃi dʒɹu sɛvɹəl dip bɹɛθs bɪfɔɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪleɪn.

Whatever Nynaeve had to say to the Sea Folk, it did not take long. She stalked away from them twitching at her skirts furiously. Approaching Elayne, she frowned equally at Aviendha and at the edge of the cliff. Usually she denied her poor head for heights, but she kept them between herself and the drop. "I have to talk to you," she muttered, guiding Elayne a little distance along the hilltop. And farther from the edge. A little way, but far enough from anyone to avoid being overheard. She drew several deep breaths before beginning, in a low voice, and she did not look at Elayne.

"aɪ. . . . aɪv bɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə ful. ɪts ðət blʌɾi mænz fɔlt! wən hiz nɑt ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə mi, aɪ kən hɑɹdli θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ən wən i ɪz, aɪ kən hɑɹdli θɪŋk əɾ ɔl! jə . . . juv tə tɛl mi wən aɪ . . . wən aɪm æktɪŋ ðə ful. aɪ dɪpɛn ɑn ju, ɪleɪn." hɝ vɔɪs steɪd loʊ, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn bɪkeɪm ɔlmoʊst ə weɪl. "aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə luz maɪ wɪts ɪn ə mæn, nɑt naʊ."

"I. . . . I've been behaving like a fool. It's that bloody man's fault! When he's not right in front of me, I can hardly think of anything else, and when he is, I can hardly think at all! You . . . you have to tell me when I . . . when I'm acting the fool. I depend on you, Elayne." Her voice stayed low, but her tone became almost a wail. "I can't afford to lose my wits in a man, not now."

ɪleɪn wɑz soʊ ʃɑkt, ʃi kəd nɑt spik fəɹ ə moʊmənt. nɪneɪiv, ædmɪɾɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn ə ful? ʃi ɔlmoʊs lʊk tə si wɛðɝ ðə sʌn hæd tɝnd ɡɹin! "ɪɾ ɪzən lænz fɔlt, ən jə noʊ ɪt, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst. ʃi pʊʃt əweɪ mɛmɹiz ə hɝ oʊn ɹisən θɔts əbaʊt ɹænd. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm. ən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi wɑz ə ɡɪft ə ðə laɪt. təmɑɹoʊ, nɪneɪiv wəd laɪkli tʃɹaɪ tə bɑks əɹ ɪɹz ɪf ʃi sɛd nɪneɪiv wɑz biɪŋ fulɪʃ. "teɪk hoʊld ə jɝsɛlf, nɪneɪiv. stɑp bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɪɾi ɡɝl." dɛfənətli nɑt θɔts ə ɹænd! ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn munɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪm ðət bædli! "jɔɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən jə ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi liɾɪŋ ʌs. lɛd! ən θɪŋk!"

Elayne was so shocked, she could not speak for a moment. Nynaeve, admitting she had been a fool? She almost looked to see whether the sun had turned green! "It isn't Lan's fault, and you know it, Nynaeve," she said at last. She pushed away memories of her own recent thoughts about Rand. This was not the same. And the opportunity was a gift of the Light. Tomorrow, Nynaeve would likely try to box her ears if she said Nynaeve was being foolish. "Take hold of yourself, Nynaeve. Stop behaving like a giddy girl." Definitely not thoughts of Rand! She had not been mooning over him that badly! "You're an Aes Sedai, and you are supposed to be leading us. Lead! And think!"

foʊldɪŋ əɹ hænz əɾ əɹ weɪst, nɪneɪiv æktʃəli  hʌŋ əɹ hɛd. "aɪl tʃɹaɪ," ʃi mʌmbəld. "aɪ wɪl, tʃɹuli. jə doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪts laɪk, ðoʊ. aɪ. . . . aɪm sɑɹi."

Folding her hands at her waist, Nynaeve actually hung her head. "I'll try," she mumbled. "I will, truly. You don't know what it's like, though. I. . . . I'm sorry."

ɪleɪn nɪɹli swɑloʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ. nɪneɪiv, əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ ɑn tɑp ə ði ʌðɝ? nɪneɪiv, əbæʃt? meɪbi ʃi wɑz ɪl.

Elayne nearly swallowed her tongue. Nynaeve, apologizing on top of the other? Nynaeve, abashed? Maybe she was ill.

ɪt dɪd nɑt læst, ʌv kɔɹs. əbɹʌpli fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ði æŋɡɹil, nɪneɪiv klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. "ju ɡeɪv wʌn tə eɪvinhə, dɪd ju?" ʃi sɛd bɹɪskli. "wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz ʃiz ɔl ɹaɪt. ə pɪɾi wɪv tə lɛt ðə si foʊk juz wʌn. əl weɪdʒɝ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə hæŋ ɑn tə ɪt! wɛl, dʒʌs lɛɾ əm tʃɹaɪ! wɪtʃ wʌn ɪz maɪn?"

It did not last, of course. Abruptly frowning at the angreal, Nynaeve cleared her throat. "You gave one to Aviendha, did you?" she said briskly. "Well, I suppose she's all right. A pity we have to let the Sea Folk use one. I'll wager they try to hang on to it! Well, just let them try! Which one is mine?"

wɪð ə saɪ, ɪleɪn hændəɾ əɹ ðə bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz, ən ʃi stɔkt əweɪ, fʌmbəlɪŋ ðə pis ə dʒuəlɹi ɑntu hɝ lɛf hæn ən kɔlɪŋ laʊdli fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə teɪk ðɛɹ pleɪsəz. səmtaɪmz, ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə tɛl nɪneɪiv liɾɪŋ fɹəm nɪneɪiv bʊliɪŋ. əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd lɛd, ðoʊ.

With a sigh, Elayne handed her the bracelet-and-rings, and she stalked away, fumbling the piece of jewelry onto her left hand and calling loudly for everyone to take their places. Sometimes, it was difficult to tell Nynaeve leading from Nynaeve bullying. As long as she did lead, though.

ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz sæɾ ətɑp ɪts ənfoʊldəd waɪt ɹæpɪŋz ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə hɪltɑp, ə ʃæloʊ, hɛvi dɪsk ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl tu fiɾ əkɹɔs, wɝkt ɪnsaɪd wɪð θɪk swɝlɪŋ klaʊdz. ən ɔɹneɪt pis, jɛt sɪmpəl wən jə θɔɾ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt kəd du. wʌt ðeɪ hoʊpt ɪt kəd du. nɪneɪiv tʊk ʌp əɹ pleɪs nɪɹbaɪ, ði æŋɡɹil faɪnəli klɪkɪŋ ʃʌɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪst. ʃi wɝkt əɹ hænd, lʊkɪŋ sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðə tʃeɪnz dɪd nɑt sim tə ɪnkənvinjəns hɝ; ɪt fɪɾ əz ɪf meɪd fəɹ əɹ hænd. ðə θɹi kɪnswɪmən wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, kɝstʃən ən ɡæɹiniə hʌɾəlɪŋ ət ɹinz bæk ən əpɪɹɪŋ mɔɹ fɹaɪɾənd ðən ɛvɝ, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz stɪl stʊɾ ɝeɪd bɪhaɪn ɹɪneɪl, ɔlmoʊs twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ.

The Bowl of the Winds sat atop its unfolded white wrappings in the center of the hilltop, a shallow, heavy disc of clear crystal two feet across, worked inside with thick swirling clouds. An ornate piece, yet simple when you thought of what it could do. What they hoped it could do. Nynaeve took up her place nearby, the angreal finally clicking shut on her wrist. She worked her hand, looking surprised that the chains did not seem to inconvenience her; it fit as if made for her hand. The three Kinswomen were already there, Kirstian and Garenia huddling at Reanne's back and appearing more frightened than ever, if that was possible. The Windfinders still stood arrayed behind Renaile, almost twenty paces away.

lɪftɪŋ əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts, ɪleɪn mɛɾ eɪvinhə ət ðə boʊl ən aɪd ðə si foʊk səspɪʃəsli. dɪd ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə kɹieɪɾ ə fʌs? ʃi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪɡzækli ðət fɹəm ðə fɝs mɛnʃən ʌv wɪmən ət ðə fɑɹm u maɪt bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɔɪn ðə lɪŋk. ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ stɪklɝz fəɹ ɹæŋk ɪnʌf tə ʃeɪm ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ɡæɹiniəz pɹɛzəns mɛn ðət ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn blu stɑɹ, wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, wəd nɑt bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɝkəl. ʃəd nɑt bi.

Lifting her divided skirts, Elayne met Aviendha at the Bowl and eyed the Sea Folk suspiciously. Did they intend to create a fuss? She had been afraid of exactly that from the first mention of women at the farm who might be strong enough to join the link. The Atha'an Miere were sticklers for rank enough to shame the White Tower, and Garenia's presence meant that Renaile din Calon Blue Star, Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, would not be part of the circle. Should not be.

ɹɪneɪl fɹaʊn sɝtʃəŋli ət ðə wɪmən ɝaʊn ðə boʊl. ʃi sim tə bi weɪɪŋ ðɛm, dʒʌdʒɪŋ ðɛɹ keɪpəbɪləɾiz. "tɑlɑn dɪn ɡɛlɪn," ʃi bɑɹk sʌɾənli, "teɪk jəɹ steɪʃən!" ɪt wɑz laɪk ə wɪp-kɹæk! ivən nɪneɪiv dʒʌmpt.

Renaile frowned searchingly at the women around the Bowl. She seemed to be weighing them, judging their capabilities. "Talaan din Gelyn," she barked suddenly, "take your station!" It was like a whip-crack! Even Nynaeve jumped.

tɑlɑn baʊd loʊ, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ hɑɹt, ðən ɹæn tə ðə boʊl. əz sun əz ʃi muvd, ɹɪneɪl bɑɹkt əɡɛn. "mɛtʃɹə dɪn dʒunæl, teɪk jəɹ steɪʃən!" mɛtʃɹə, plʌmp jɛt sɑləd, spɛɾ ɑn tɑlɑnz hilz. niðɝ əpɹɛntəs wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf tə hæv ɝnd wʌt ðə si foʊk kɔld ə "sɔl neɪm."

Talaan bowed low, touching her heart, then ran to the Bowl. As soon as she moved, Renaile barked again. "Metarra din Junalle, take your station!" Metarra, plump yet solid, sped on Talaan's heels. Neither apprentice was old enough to have earned what the Sea Folk called a "salt name."

wʌns bɪɡʌn, ɹɪneɪl ɹæɾəld ɔf neɪmz kwɪkli, sɛndɪŋ ɹeɪnɪn ən tu ʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝz, ɔl ə hum muv kwɪkli, jɛt nɑt soʊ fæst əz ði əpɹɛntəsɪz. baɪ ðə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛɹ mədæljənz, nɑm ən ɹaɪsl wɝ haɪɝ ɪn ɹæŋk ðən ɹeɪnɪn, dɪɡnəfaɪd wɪmən wɪð ə kwaɪəɾ ɛɹ ə kəmænd, bʌt mɑɹkədli wikɝ. ðən ɹɪneɪl pɔzd, oʊnli fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, jɛɾ ɪn ðət ɹæpəd lɪstɪŋ ɪt stʊɾ aʊt. "tɛbɹl dɪn ɡɛlɪn saʊθ wɪnd, teɪk jəɹ steɪʃən! kɛɹ dɪn ɡɛlɪn ɹʌnɪŋ weɪv, əsum ðə kəmænd!"

Once begun, Renaile rattled off names quickly, sending Rainyn and two other Windfinders, all of whom moved quickly, yet not so fast as the apprentices. By the number of their medallions, Naime and Rysael were higher in rank than Rainyn, dignified women with a quiet air of command, but markedly weaker. Then Renaile paused, only for a heartbeat, yet in that rapid listing it stood out. "Tebreille din Gelyn South Wind, take your station! Caire din Gelyn Running Wave, assume the command!"

ɪleɪn fɛlt ə moʊmən ə ɹɪlif ðət ɹɪneɪl hæd nɑt neɪm hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ ɪt læstəɾ əbaʊɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɹɪneɪlz pɔz hæd. tɛbɹl ən kɛɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wʌn lʊk, tɛbɹl ɡɹɪm ən kɛɹ smʌɡ, bɪfɔɹ muvɪŋ tə ðə boʊl. eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz ən ə mʌltətuɾ ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ mədæljənz mɑɹkt itʃ wɪndfɪndɝ tə ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs. oʊnli ɹɪneɪl stʊɾ əbʌv ðɛm; oʊnli dɔɹəl əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk ɑn ðə hɪltɑp wɑz ðɛɹ ikwəl. ɪn bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd jɛloʊ sɪlks, kɛɹ wɑz slaɪtli ðə tɔlɝ, tɛbɹl ɪn bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɡɹin sʌmwʌt stɝnɝ ə feɪs, boʊθ mɔɹ ðən hænsəm wɪmən, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk ðɛɹ neɪmz tə noʊ ðɛm blʌd sɪstɝz. ðeɪ hæd ðə seɪm bɪɡ, ɔlmoʊs blæk aɪz, ðə seɪm stʃɹeɪt noʊz, ðə seɪm stʃɹɔŋ tʃɪn. kɛɹ saɪlənli pɔɪntəd tə ə spɑɾ əɾ əɹ ɹaɪt saɪd; tɛbɹl dɪd nɑt spik iðɝ, nɔɹ dɪd ʃi hɛzəteɪɾ ɪn stændɪŋ wɛɹ əɹ sɪstɝ pɔɪntəd, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz stoʊn. wɪð hɝ, ə sɝkəl ə θɝtin wɪmən sɝaʊndəd ðə boʊl nɪɹli ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ. kɛɹz aɪz ɔlmoʊst spɑɹkəld. tɛbɹlz wɝ lɛɾən. ɪleɪn wɑz ɹimaɪndəɾ ʌv ənʌðɝ ə liniz seɪɪŋz. noʊ naɪf ɪz ʃɑɹpɝ ðən ə sɪstɝz heɪt.

Elayne felt a moment of relief that Renaile had not named herself, but it lasted about as long as Renaile's pause had. Tebreille and Caire exchanged one look, Tebreille grim and Caire smug, before moving to the Bowl. Eight earrings and a multitude of overlapping medallions marked each Windfinder to a Clan Wavemistress. Only Renaile stood above them; only Dorile among the Sea Folk on the hilltop was their equal. In brocaded yellow silks, Caire was slightly the taller, Tebreille in brocaded green somewhat sterner of face, both more than handsome women, and it did not take their names to know them blood sisters. They had the same big, almost black eyes, the same straight nose, the same strong chin. Caire silently pointed to a spot at her right side; Tebreille did not speak either, nor did she hesitate in standing where her sister pointed, but her face was stone. With her, a circle of thirteen women surrounded the Bowl nearly shoulder-to-shoulder. Caire's eyes almost sparkled. Tebreille's were leaden. Elayne was reminded of another of Lini's sayings. No knife is sharper than a sister's hate.

kɛɹ ɡlɛɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə sɝkəl ʌv wɪmən sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə boʊl, nɑt jɛt tʃɹuli ə sɝkəl, əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪks itʃ feɪs ɪn əɹ maɪnd. əɹ meɪbi tə fɪks əɹ skaʊl ɪn ðɛɹz. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn hɝidli pæs ðə læst æŋɡɹil, ðə smɔl æmbɝ tɝɾəl, tə tɑlɑn ən stɑɹɾəd tə ɪkspleɪn haʊ ɪt wɑz juzd. ði ɛkspləneɪʃən wɑz sɪmpəl, jɛɾ ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ haʊ kəd fʌmbəl fəɹ aʊɝz. ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡɪvən ðə tʃæns fəɹ faɪv wɝdz.

Caire glared around the circle of women surrounding the Bowl, not yet truly a circle, as though trying to fix each face in her mind. Or maybe to fix her scowl in theirs. Remembering herself, Elayne hurriedly passed the last angreal, the small amber turtle, to Talaan and started to explain how it was used. The explanation was simple, yet anyone who tried without knowing how could fumble for hours. She was not given the chance for five words.

"saɪləns!" kɛɹ ɹɔɹd. tætud fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ən bɛɹ fiɾ əpɑɹt, ʃi bɪlɔŋd ɑn ðə dɛk ʌv ə ʃɪp ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə bæɾəl. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ tɔkɪŋ ɑn steɪʃən wɪθaʊt maɪ pɝmɪʃən. tɑlɑn, ɹipɔɹt jɝsɛlf ɪmiɾiətli ɑn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə jəɹ ʃɪp." nʌθɪŋ ɪn kɛɹz toʊn sədʒɛstəd ðət ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ tə hɝ oʊn dɔɾɝ. tɑlɑn baʊd dipli, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ hɑɹt, ən mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪnɔɾəbəl. kɛɹ snɔɹɾɪd kəntɛmptʃwəsli - ən ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə ɡlɛɹ ðət sədʒɛstəɾ ə wɪʃ ðət ʃi kəɾ ɔɹɾɝ əɹ tə ɹipɔɹt hɝsɛlf tə sʌmwʌn əz wɛl - bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn hɝɾ ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl. "tədeɪ, wi ʃæl də wʌɾ əz nɑt bɪn dʌn sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wən əɹ ænsɛstɝz fɔt wɪn ən weɪv ɡɔn mæd. baɪ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ən ðə mɝsi ʌv ðə laɪt, ðeɪ sɝvaɪvd. tədeɪ, wɪl juz ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, lɔs tə əs fəɹ mɔɹ ðən tu θaʊzən jɪɹz, ən naʊ ɹɪtɝnd. aɪ hæv stʌɾid ði eɪntʃən lɔɹ, stʌɾid ðə ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə deɪz wən əɹ fɔɹməðɝz fɝs lɝn ðə si ən ðə wivɪŋ ə ðə wɪnz, ən ðə sɔlt ɛntɝɾ əɹ blʌd. wʌɾ ɪz noʊn ə ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, aɪ noʊ, mɔɹ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls." hɝ aɪz kʌt təwɔɹɾ əɹ sɪstɝ, ə sæɾəsfaɪd ɡlæns ðət tɛbɹl dɪd nɑɾ æknɑlɪdʒ. wɪtʃ sim tə sæɾəsfaɪ kɛɹ ivən mɔɹ. "wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kænɑt du, əl də tədeɪ, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt. aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɛvɹi wʊmən tə stæn əɹ steɪʃən tə ðə læst. əl nɑɾ æksɛp feɪljɝ."

"Silence!" Caire roared. Tattooed fists on her hips and bare feet apart, she belonged on the deck of a ship going into battle. "There will be no talking on station without my permission. Talaan, report yourself immediately on returning to your ship." Nothing in Caire's tone suggested that she was speaking to her own daughter. Talaan bowed deeply, touching her heart, and murmured something inaudible. Caire snorted contemptuously - and gave Elayne a glare that suggested a wish that she could order her to report herself to someone as well - before going on in a voice that might have been heard at the base of the hill. "Today, we shall do what has not been done since the Breaking of the World, when our ancestors fought wind and wave gone mad. By the Bowl of the Winds and the mercy of the Light, they survived. Today, we will use the Bowl of the Winds, lost to us for more than two thousand years, and now returned. I have studied the ancient lore, studied the records of the days when our foremothers first learned the sea and the Weaving of the Winds, and the salt entered our blood. What is known of the Bowl of the Winds, I know, more than anyone else." Her eyes cut toward her sister, a satisfied glance that Tebreille did not acknowledge. Which seemed to satisfy Caire even more. "What the Aes Sedai cannot do, I will do today, if it pleases the Light. I expect every woman to stand her station to the last. I will not accept failure."

ðə ɹɛst ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ sim tə æksɛp ðət spitʃ əz ɪkspɛktəɾ ən pɹɑpɝ, bʌt ðə kɪnswɪmən ɡeɪpt ət kɛɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ɪn ɪleɪnz əpɪnjən, ɡɹændioʊs dɪd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə dɪskɹaɪb ɪt; pleɪnli kɛɹ fʊli ɪkspɛktəd ðət ðə laɪt wəd bi plizd, ən ʃi wəd bi moʊs dɪsplizd ɪf ɪt wɑz nɑt! nɪneɪiv ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz tə ðə hɛvənz ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. kɛɹ fɔɹstɑl hɝ.

The rest of the Atha'an Miere seemed to accept that speech as expected and proper, but the Kinswomen gaped at Caire in astonishment. In Elayne's opinion, grandiose did not begin to describe it; plainly Caire fully expected that the Light would be pleased, and she would be most displeased if it was not! Nynaeve rolled her eyes to the heavens and opened her mouth. Caire forestalled her.

"nɪneɪiv," ðə wɪndfɪndɝ ənaʊns laʊdli, "ju wɪl naʊ dɛmənstʃɹeɪt jəɹ skɪl ət lɪŋkɪŋ. bi əbaʊɾ ɪt, wʊmən, ən kwɪkli!"

"Nynaeve," the Windfinder announced loudly, "you will now demonstrate your skill at linking. Be about it, woman, and quickly!"

ɪn ɹɪspɑns, nɪneɪiv ʃʌɾ əɹ aɪz taɪt. hɝ lɪps . . . ɹɪθd. ʃi lʊkt əbaʊt tə bɝst ə blʌd vɛsəl. "aɪ əsum ðət minz aɪ hæv pɝmɪʃən tə spik!" ʃi mɝmɝd. fɔɹtʃənətli tu loʊ tə bi hɝd baɪ kɛɹ, ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə sɝkəl. oʊpənɪŋ əɹ aɪz, ʃi pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl ðət wɑz kwaɪt hɔɹəbəl wən æɾəd tə ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ʃi wɑz ə saʊɝ stʌmək ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ kəmpleɪns ɹoʊld ɪndə wʌn.

In response, Nynaeve shut her eyes tight. Her lips . . . writhed. She looked about to burst a blood vessel. "I assume that means I have permission to speak!" she murmured. Fortunately too low to be heard by Caire, on the far side of the circle. Opening her eyes, she put on a smile that was quite horrible when added to the rest of her expression. She was a sour stomach and several other complaints rolled into one.

"ðə fɝs θɪŋ ɪz tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, kɛɹ." ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn bɹaɪɾ ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv; ʃi wɑz juzɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil ɑn əɹ hæn ɔlɹɛɾi, baɪ wʌɾ ɪleɪn kəd fil. "aɪ əsum jə noʊ haʊ tə də ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs." ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði əbɹʌp taɪɾənɪŋ ə kɛɹz maʊθ, nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn. "ɪleɪn wɪl naʊ əsɪs mi ɪn ðə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən. ɪf wɪv jəɹ pɝmɪʃən?"

"The first thing is to embrace the True Source, Caire." The light of saidar suddenly shone bright around Nynaeve; she was using the angreal on her hand already, by what Elayne could feel. "I assume you know how to do that, of course." Ignoring the abrupt tightening of Caire's mouth, Nynaeve went on. "Elayne will now assist me in the demonstration. If we have your permission?"

"aɪ pɹipɛɹ maɪsɛlf tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs," ɪleɪn pʊɾ ɪn kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ kɛɹ kəɾ ɪɹʌpt, "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn æktʃəli  ɛmbɹeɪs ɪt." ʃi oʊpən hɝsɛlf, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz lin fɔɹwɝd, piɹɪŋ ət hɝ, ðoʊ ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə si jɛt. ivən kɝstʃən ən ɡæɹiniə fɝɡɑt ðɛɹ fɪɹ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ɪntʃɹəst. "waɪl aɪm ət ðɪs pɔɪnt, ðə ɹɛst ɪz ʌp tə nɪneɪiv."

"I prepare myself to embrace the Source," Elayne put in quickly, before Caire could erupt, "but I don't actually embrace it." She opened herself, and the Windfinders leaned forward, peering at her, though there really was nothing to see yet. Even Kirstian and Garenia forgot their fear enough to show interest. "While I'm at this point, the rest is up to Nynaeve."

"naʊ əl ɹitʃ aʊt tə hɝ. . . ." nɪneɪiv pɔzd, lʊkɪŋ ət tɑlɑn. ɪleɪn hæd nɑt hæɾ ə tʃæns tə tɛl əɹ ɛniθɪŋ, ɹɪli. "ɪts mʌtʃ ðə seɪm əz wɪð ən æŋɡɹil," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ðə slɛndɝ əpɹɛntəs. kɛɹ ɡɹaʊld, ən tɑlɑn tʃɹaɪd tə wɑtʃ nɪneɪiv wɪð əɹ hɛd daʊn. "ju oʊpən jɝsɛlf tə ðə sɔɹs θɹu ən æŋɡɹil, dʒʌst əz əl θɹu ɪleɪn. əz ðoʊ jə min tə ɛmbɹeɪs ði æŋɡɹil ən ðə sɔɹs ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ɪɾ ɪzən vɛɹi dɪfəkəlt, ɹɪli. wɑtʃ, ən jəl si. wən ɪts taɪm tə bɹɪŋ jə ɪndə ðə sɝkəl, dʒʌs pʊt jɝsɛlf ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk. ðət weɪ, wən aɪ ɛmbɹeɪs θɹu ju, əl ɛmbɹeɪs θɹu ði æŋɡɹil əz wɛl."

"Now I will reach out to her. . . ." Nynaeve paused, looking at Talaan. Elayne had not had a chance to tell her anything, really. "It's much the same as with an angreal," Nynaeve said, addressing the slender apprentice. Caire growled, and Talaan tried to watch Nynaeve with her head down. "You open yourself to the Source through an angreal, just as I will through Elayne. As though you mean to embrace the angreal and the Source at the same time. It isn't very difficult, really. Watch, and you'll see. When it's time to bring you into the circle, just put yourself on the brink. That way, when I embrace through you, I'll embrace through the angreal as well."

kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən əɹ noʊ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən, swɛt bɪɡæn tə biɾ ɑn ɪleɪnz fɔɹhɛd. bʌt ðɛn, ðə hit hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs bɛkənd; ɪt θɹɑbd, ən ʃi θɹɑbd wɪð ɪt. ɪt dɪmændəd. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ʃi hʌŋ dʒʌst ə hɛɹzbɹɛdθ fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ðə wɝs ðə dɪzaɪɝ, ðə nid, wəd ɡɹoʊ. hæŋɪŋ, ʃi bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɛmbəl slaɪtli. vændin hæd toʊld əɹ ðət ðə lɔŋɡɝ jə tʃænəld, ðə wɝs ðəɾ æntɪsəpeɪʃən ɡɹu.

Concentration or no concentration, sweat began to bead on Elayne's forehead. But then, the heat had nothing to do with it. The True Source beckoned; it throbbed, and she throbbed with it. It demanded. The longer she hung just a hairsbreadth from touching the Power, the worse the desire, the need, would grow. Hanging, she began to tremble slightly. Vandene had told her that the longer you channeled, the worse that anticipation grew.

"wɑtʃ wɪð eɪvinhə," nɪneɪiv toʊl tɑlɑn. "ʃi noʊz haʊ tə - " ʃi kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ɪleɪnz feɪs ən fɪnɪʃt hɝidli. "wɑtʃ!"

"Watch with Aviendha," Nynaeve told Talaan. "She knows how to - " She caught sight of Elayne's face and finished hurriedly. "Watch!"

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm əz juzɪŋ ən æŋɡɹil, ðoʊ vɛɹi kloʊs. ɪt wɑz nɑt mɛn tə bi dʌn hɝidli, iðɝ; nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑɾ əv ə sɑf tʌtʃ, ət bɛst. ɪleɪn fɛlt əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ biɪŋ ʃeɪkən; nʌθɪŋ hæpən fɪzɪkəli, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd ʃi sim tə bi baʊnsɪŋ ɝaʊnd, tʌmbəlɪŋ waɪldli daʊnhɪl. wɝs, ʃi wɑz dʒɑsəl təwɔɹɾ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪð ɪkskɹuʃieɪɾɪŋ sloʊnəs. ɪt tʊk lɛs ðən ə hɑɹtbit, ən sim tə teɪk aʊɝz, deɪz. ʃi wɑntəd tə haʊl, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɹið. əbɹʌpli, laɪk ə dæm bɝstɪŋ, ðə wʌn paʊɝ floʊd θɹu hɝ, ə ɹʌʃ ə laɪf ən dʒɔɪ, ʌv blɪs, ən bɹɛθ lɛft əɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ ɡæsp ə plɛʒɝ ən ɹɪlif soʊ oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ ðəɾ əɹ lɛɡz wɑbəld. ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də tə kip fɹəm pæntɪŋ. tɑɾɝɪŋ, pʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp, ʃi ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə stɝn lʊk, ən nɪneɪiv ʃɹʌɡd əpɑlədʒɛɾɪkli. twaɪs ɪn wʌn deɪ! ðə sʌn hæd tə bi tɝnɪŋ ɡɹin.

It was not exactly the same as using an angreal, though very close. It was not meant to be done hurriedly, either; Nynaeve did not have a soft touch, at best. Elayne felt as though she were being shaken; nothing happened physically, but inside her head she seemed to be bouncing around, tumbling wildly downhill. Worse, she was jostled toward embracing saidar with excruciating slowness. It took less than a heartbeat, and seemed to take hours, days. She wanted to howl, but she could not breathe. Abruptly, like a dam bursting, the One Power flowed through her, a rush of life and joy, of bliss, and breath left her in a long gasp of pleasure and relief so overwhelming that her legs wobbled. It was all she could do to keep from panting. Tottering, pulling herself up, she gave Nynaeve a stern look, and Nynaeve shrugged apologetically. Twice in one day! The sun had to be turning green.

"aɪ naʊ kəntʃɹoʊl ðə floʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ fɹəm əɹ əz wɛl əz maɪ oʊn," nɪneɪiv wɛn ɑn, nɑt kwaɪt miɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz aɪz, "ænd wɪl əntɪl aɪ lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ. naʊ, doʊn fɪɹ ðət huɛvɝ lidz ðə sɝkəl," ʃi ʃɑɾ ə fɹaʊn ət kɛɹ ən snɪft, "kæn meɪk jə dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ. ðɪs ɹɪli ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt dil laɪk ən æŋɡɹil. ði æŋɡɹil bʌfɝz jə əɡɛns ði ɛkstʃɹə paʊɝ, ən ɪn sʌmwʌt ðə seɪm weɪ, ɪn ə sɝkəl jə kæn bi meɪd tə dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ. ɪn fækt, ɪn ə sɝkəl jə kæn dʒɹɔ kwaɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz jə kən ʌðɹwi - "

"I now control the flow of saidar from her as well as my own," Nynaeve went on, not quite meeting Elayne's eyes, "and will until I let her go. Now, don't fear that whoever leads the circle," she shot a frown at Caire and sniffed, "can make you draw too much. This really is a great deal like an angreal. The angreal buffers you against the extra Power, and in somewhat the same way, in a circle you can't be made to draw too much. In fact, in a circle you can't draw quite as much as you can otherwi - "

"ðɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs!" ɹɪneɪl bɹoʊk ɪn, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ ɹʌfli bɪtwin kɛɹ ən tɛbɹl. hɝ skaʊl tʊk ɪn nɪneɪiv, ɪleɪn, ən ðə sɪstɝz stændɪŋ ɔf fɹəm ðə sɝkəl əz wɛl. "ju seɪ ðət wʌn wʊmən kən sɪmpli siz ənʌðɝ, hoʊld əɹ kæptɪv, juz hɝ? haʊ lɔŋ əv jə ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊn ðɪs? aɪ wɔɹn ju, ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə juz ɪɾ ɑn wʌn ʌv əs - " ɪt wɑz əɹ tɝn tə bi kʌɾ ɔf.

"This is dangerous!" Renaile broke in, shouldering roughly between Caire and Tebreille. Her scowl took in Nynaeve, Elayne, and the sisters standing off from the circle as well. "You say that one woman can simply seize another, hold her captive, use her? How long have you Aes Sedai known this? I warn you, if you try to use it on one of us - " It was her turn to be cut off.

"ɪt dʌznt wɝk ðət weɪ, ɹɪneɪl." sɝaɪðə tʌtʃt ɡæɹiniə, ən ʃi ən kɝstʃən lɛpt əpɑɹt tə meɪk ɹum. ðə jʌŋ bɹaʊn aɪd nɪneɪiv ənsɝteɪnli, ðən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ən tʊk ɑn ə lɛktʃɝɪŋ toʊn, əz ɪf ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ə klæs. wɪð ɪt keɪm kəmpoʊʒɝ; pɝhæps ʃi dɪd si ɹɪneɪl əz ə pjupəl ɹaɪt ðɛn. "ðə taʊɝ stʌɾid ðɪs fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. aɪ hæv ɹɛɾ ɛvɹi peɪdʒ ðət sɝvaɪvz ɪn ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi ʌv ðoʊz stʌɾiz. ɪt wɑz pɹuvən kənklusɪvli ðət wʌn wʊmən kænɑt fɔɹm ə lɪŋk wɪð ənʌðɝ əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl. ɪt sɪmpli kænɑt bi dʌn; nʌθɪŋ hæpənz. ə wɪlɪŋ sɝɛndɝ ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi, dʒʌst əz ɪn ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ tə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪtsɛlf." ʃi saʊndəɾ æbsəlutli dɛfənət, bʌt ɹɪneɪl stɪl fɹaʊnd; tu mɛni pipəl nu haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd saɪdstɛp ði oʊθ əɡɛns laɪɪŋ.

"It doesn't work that way, Renaile." Sareitha touched Garenia, and she and Kirstian leaped apart to make room. The young Brown eyed Nynaeve uncertainly, then folded her hands and took on a lecturing tone, as if addressing a class. With it came composure; perhaps she did see Renaile as a pupil right then. "The Tower studied this for many years, long before the Trolloc Wars. I have read every page that survives in the Tower Library of those studies. It was proven conclusively that one woman cannot form a link with another against her will. It simply cannot be done; nothing happens. A willing surrender is necessary, just as in embracing to saidar itself." She sounded absolutely definite, but Renaile still frowned; too many people knew how Aes Sedai could sidestep the Oath against lying.

"ænd waɪ dɪd ðeɪ stʌɾi ɪt?" ɹɪneɪl dɪmændəd. "waɪ wɑz ðə waɪt taʊɝ soʊ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn sətʃ ə θɪŋ? pɝhæps jə ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl stʌɾi?"

"And why did they study it?" Renaile demanded. "Why was the White Tower so interested in such a thing? Perhaps you Aes Sedai still study?"

"ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs." ɛksæspɝeɪʃən dʒɹɪp fɹəm sɝaɪðəz vɔɪs. "ɪf jə mʌs noʊ, ɪt wɑz ðə pɹɑbləm ə mɛn u kən tʃænəl ðət dʒɹu ðɛm tə ɪt. ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld wɑz ə lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi tə sʌm, ðɛn. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ivən vɛɹi mɛni sɪstɝz ɹɪmɛmbɝ - ɪt hæzən bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz - bʌt mɛn kən bi bɹɔɾ ɪndə ə sɝkəl, tu, ən əz ðə sɝkəl dʌzn bɹeɪk ivən ɪf jə ɡoʊ tə slip. . . . wɛl, jə kən si ði ædvæntɪdʒɪz. ðət wɑz ən ʌɾɝ feɪljɝ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. mɔɹ tə ðə pɔɪn hɪɹ, aɪ seɪ əɡɛn ðəɾ ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl tə fɔɹs ə wʊmən ɪndə ə sɝkəl. ɪf jə daʊt, tʃɹaɪ ɪt jɝsɛlf. jəl si."

"That is ridiculous." Exasperation dripped from Sareitha's voice. "If you must know, it was the problem of men who can channel that drew them to it. The Breaking of the World was a living memory to some, then. I don't suppose even very many sisters remember - it hasn't been part of the required instruction since before the Trolloc Wars - but men can be brought into a circle, too, and as the circle doesn't break even if you go to sleep. . . . Well, you can see the advantages. That was an utter failure, unfortunately. More to the point here, I say again that it is impossible to force a woman into a circle. If you doubt, try it yourself. You will see."

ɹɪneɪl nɑɾəd, æksɛptɪŋ ət læst; ðəɹ wɑz vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɛls tə də wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪɾ ə sɪmpəl steɪtmən ə fækt. jɛɾ ɪleɪn wʌndɝd. wʌt wɑz ɪn ðə peɪdʒəz ðət hæd nɑt sɝvaɪvd? ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ə slaɪt tʃeɪnʒ ɪn sɝaɪðəz ɪnflɛkʃən ət wʌn pɔɪnt. ʃi hæd kwɛstʃənz. fəɹ leɪɾɝ, wən ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ ɪɹz ɝaʊnd.

Renaile nodded, accepting at last; there was very little else to do when an Aes Sedai made a simple statement of fact. Yet Elayne wondered. What was in the pages that had not survived? She had noticed a slight change in Sareitha's inflection at one point. She had questions. For later, when there were fewer ears around.

wən ɹɪneɪl ən sɝaɪðə wɪθdʒɹu, nɪneɪiv twɪtʃt əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts stʃɹeɪt, pleɪnli ɪɹəteɪɾəd ət ði ɪntɝʌpʃən, ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn.

When Renaile and Sareitha withdrew, Nynaeve twitched her divided skirts straight, plainly irritated at the interruption, and opened her mouth again.

"kəntɪnju jəɹ dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən, nɪneɪiv," kɛɹ kəmændəd hɑɹʃli. hɝ dɑɹk feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn smuð əz ə fɹoʊzən pɑnd, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt vɛɹi plizd, iðɝ.

"Continue your demonstration, Nynaeve," Caire commanded harshly. Her dark face might have been smooth as a frozen pond, but she was not very pleased, either.

nɪneɪivz maʊθ wɝk bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd meɪk ɛni saʊn kʌm aʊt, ən wən ɪt dɪd, ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə ɹʌʃ, əz ðoʊ əfɹeɪd sʌmwʌn ɛls maɪt bɹeɪk ɪn.

Nynaeve's mouth worked before she could make any sound come out, and when it did, she went on in a rush, as though afraid someone else might break in.

ðə nɛks pɑɹɾ ə ðə lɛsən wɑz pæsɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə sɝkəl. ðət hæd tə bi dʌn vɑləntɛɹəli, tu, ən ivən əz ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv, ɪleɪn hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ əntɪl ʃi fɛl ðə sʌɾəl ʃɪf ðət mɛnt ʃi naʊ kəntʃɹoʊl ðə paʊɝ floʊɪŋ ɪndə hɝ. ən ðət floʊɪŋ θɹu nɪneɪiv, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd wɝk. nɪneɪiv kəd fɔɹm ə sɝkəl izəli, ɪf nɑt wɪð ɛni fɪnɛs, bʌt pæsɪŋ ɡaɪɾəns ɔlsoʊ ɪnvɑlvd ə fɔɹm ə sɝɛndɝ; nɪneɪiv hæd kənsɪɾɝəbəl dɪfəkəltiz ɹilɪŋkwɪʃɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ biɪŋ bɹɔɾ ɪndə ə sɝkəl, dʒʌst əz ʃi hæd wʌns hæd dɪfəkəlti sɝɛndɝɪŋ tə seɪaɪdɑɹ. wɪtʃ wɑz waɪ ɪleɪn kɛp ðə ɡaɪɾəns fəɹ naʊ. ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi pæs tə kɛɹ, ən nɪneɪiv maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ twaɪs. ðoʊz əpɑlədʒiz mʌst əv bɪn mʌtʃ iziɝ fəɹ hɝ.

The next part of the lesson was passing control of the circle. That had to be done voluntarily, too, and even as she reached out toward Nynaeve, Elayne held her breath until she felt the subtle shift that meant she now controlled the Power flowing into her. And that flowing through Nynaeve, of course. She had not been sure it would work. Nynaeve could form a circle easily, if not with any finesse, but passing guidance also involved a form of surrender; Nynaeve had considerable difficulties relinquishing control or being brought into a circle, just as she had once had difficulty surrendering to saidar. Which was why Elayne kept the guidance for now. It would have to be passed to Caire, and Nynaeve might not be able to manage letting go twice. Those apologies must have been much easier for her.

ɪleɪn lɪŋk nɛkst wɪð eɪvinhə, soʊ tɑlɑn kəɾ æktʃəli  si haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn wɪð ən æŋɡɹil, əz mʌtʃ əz ðəɹ wɑz tə si, ən ɪt wɛn pɝfəkli; eɪvinhə wɑz ə vɛɹi kwɪk stʌɾi, blɛndɪŋ ɪn izəli. tɑlɑn wɑz kwɪk əz wɛl, ɪt tɝn aʊt, æɾɪŋ əɹ stɪl ɡɹeɪɾɝ æŋɡɹil eɪɾəd floʊ wɪθaʊɾ ə hɪtʃ. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ɪleɪn bɹɔɾ əm ɪn, ən ʃi hɝsɛlf ɔlmoʊst ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðə ɹɪvɝ ə ðə paʊɝ ðət stʃɹimd ɪndə hɝ. noʊ wʌn jɛt wɑz dʒɹɔɪŋ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kʊd, bʌɾ ɪɾ æɾəd ʌp, ɪspɛʃli wɪð æŋɡɹil ɪnvɑlvd. ɪleɪnz əwɛɹnəs klaɪm haɪɝ wɪð itʃ ədɪʃən ə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ʃi kəd smɛl ðə hɛvi sɛns ɪn ðə leɪswɝk ɡoʊl bɑksəz ðət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɔɹ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks, ən sɛpɹət wʌn fɹəm ənʌðɝ. ʃi kəd meɪk aʊɾ itʃ foʊld ən kɹis ɪn ɛvɹiwʌnz kloʊðz əz ʃɑɹpli əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ əɹ noʊz pɹɛs tə ðə klɔθ, mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli. ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə feɪntəs muvmən ə ði ɛɹ əɡɛnst əɹ hɛɹ ən skɪn, kɝɛsəz ʃi wʊɾə əv noʊɾəst wɪθaʊt ðə paʊɝ.

Elayne linked next with Aviendha, so Talaan could actually see how it was done with an angreal, as much as there was to see, and it went perfectly; Aviendha was a very quick study, blending in easily. Talaan was quick as well, it turned out, adding her still greater angreal aided flow without a hitch. One by one, Elayne brought them in, and she herself almost shivered at the river of the Power that streamed into her. No one yet was drawing nearly as much as she could, but it added up, especially with angreal involved. Elayne's awareness climbed higher with each addition of saidar. She could smell the heavy scents in the lacework gold boxes that the Windfinders wore around their necks, and separate one from another. She could make out each fold and crease in everyone's clothes as sharply as if she had her nose pressed to the cloth, more sharply. She was aware of the faintest movement of the air against her hair and skin, caresses she never would have noticed without the Power.

ðət wɑz nɑt ðə hoʊl ə hɝ əwɛɹnəs, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə lɪŋk hæɾ ə sɝɾən kɪnʃɪp tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd, dʒʌst əz ɪntɛns ən sʌmhaʊ ivən mɔɹ ɪntəmət. ʃi nu ðəɾ ə taɪni blɪstɝ fɹəm klaɪmɪŋ ðə hɪl meɪɾ ə spɑɾ ə peɪn ɑn nɪneɪivz ɹaɪt hil; nɪneɪiv ɔlweɪz tɔkt əbaʊt ɡʊd staʊt ʃuz, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə wiknəs fəɹ slɪpɝz wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. nɪneɪiv wɔɹ ə fɪks fɹaʊn, dɝɛktəɾ ət kɛɹ, hɝ ɑɹmz wɝ kɹɔst, hɝ fɪŋɡɝz wɛɹɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil pleɪɾ ɑn ðə bɹeɪd pʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ɹaɪt ʃoʊldɝ, ɛvɹi laɪn ə hɝ ʌv ə pis, jɛɾ ɪnsaɪd ʃi wɑz ə meɪlstʃɹəm ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz. fɪɹ, wɝi, æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ɪɹɪteɪʃən, wɛɹinɪs ən ɪmpeɪʃəns baʊnst oʊvɝ itʃ ʌðɝ, ən wɑʃɪŋ θɹu ɪɾ ɔl, səmtaɪmz səbmɝdʒɪŋ ðə ɹɛst, ɹɪpəlz ʌv wɔɹmθ ən weɪvz ə hit ðət θɹɛɾənd tə bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. ðoʊz læs nɪneɪiv səpɹɛs kwɪkli, ɪspɛʃli ðə hit, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ɹɪtɝnd. ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊs θɔt ʃi kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk sʌmθɪŋ ɡlɪmps fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə jəɹ aɪ ðət wɑz ɡɔn wən jə tɝn jəɹ hɛd.

That was not the whole of her awareness, of course. The link had a certain kinship to the Warder bond, just as intense and somehow even more intimate. She knew that a tiny blister from climbing the hill made a spot of pain on Nynaeve's right heel; Nynaeve always talked about good stout shoes, but she had a weakness for slippers with a great deal of embroidery. Nynaeve wore a fixed frown, directed at Caire, her arms were crossed, her fingers wearing the angreal played on the braid pulled over her right shoulder, every line of her of a piece, yet inside she was a maelstrom of emotions. Fear, worry, anticipation, irritation, wariness and impatience bounced over each other, and washing through it all, sometimes submerging the rest, ripples of warmth and waves of heat that threatened to burst into flame. Those last Nynaeve suppressed quickly, especially the heat, but they always returned. Elayne almost thought she could recognize them, but it was like something glimpsed from the corner of your eye that was gone when you turned your head.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, eɪvinhə fɛl fɪɹ, tu, bʌt smɔl ən taɪtli kənteɪnd, ən ɔl bʌt swɑloʊd baɪ dɪtɝməneɪʃən. ɡæɹiniə ən kɝstʃən, ʃeɪkɪŋ vɪzəbli, wɝ nɪɹli pjʊɹ tɛɹɝ, soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɪt wɑz əmeɪzɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kəɾ ivən əv bɪɡʌn tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. wʌt fɪld ɹin tə oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ wɑz iɡɝnəs, ən noʊ mæɾɝ əɹ skɝt smuðɪŋ. əz fəɹ ði æθɑn maɪɹ. . . . ivən tɛbɹl ɪɡzuɾɪd ə wɛɹi əlɝtnəs, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk ðə kwɪk dɑɹɾɪŋ ə mɛtʃɹəz aɪz, ən ɹeɪnɪnz, tə noʊ ðə foʊkəs wɑz kɛɹ, wɑtʃɪŋ əm ɔl, ɪmpeɪʃən ən kəmændɪŋ.

Surprisingly, Aviendha felt fear, too, but small and tightly contained, and all but swallowed by determination. Garenia and Kirstian, shaking visibly, were nearly pure terror, so strong it was amazing that they could even have begun to embrace the Source. What filled Reanne to overflowing was eagerness, and no matter her skirt smoothing. As for the Atha'an Miere. . . . Even Tebreille exuded a wary alertness, and it did not take the quick darting of Metarra's eyes, and Rainyn's, to know the focus was Caire, watching them all, impatient and commanding.

hɝ, ɪleɪn lɛf tə læst, ən ɪt wɑz noʊ ɹil sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃi hæd tə meɪk fɔɹ tʃɹaɪz - fɔɹ! - tə bɹɪŋ ðə wʊmən ɪndə ðə sɝkəl. kɛɹ wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ ət jildɪŋ ðən nɪneɪiv. ɪleɪn dɛspɝətli hoʊp ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən fəɹ əbɪləɾi, nɑt ɹæŋk.

Her, Elayne left to last, and it was no real surprise that she had to make four tries - four! - to bring the woman into the circle. Caire was no better at yielding than Nynaeve. Elayne desperately hoped the woman had been chosen for ability, not rank.

"aɪ wɪl naʊ pæs ðə sɝkəl tə ju," ʃi toʊl ðə wɪndfɪndɝ wən ɪt faɪnəli wɑz dʌn. "ɪf jə ɹikɔl wʌɾ aɪ dɪd wɪð naɪ - " wɝdz fɹoʊz moʊməntɛɹəli ɪn əɹ θɹoʊɾ əz ɡaɪɾəns ə ðə sɝkəl wɑz tɔɹn fɹəm əɹ sɝɛndɝ, ə sɛnseɪʃən laɪk hævɪŋ ə sʌɾən bɝst ʌv wɪn ɹɪp ɔl ə hɝ kloʊðz ɔf əɹ jæŋk ðə boʊnz aʊɾ ə hɝ. ʃi ɛksheɪl fɪɹsli, ən ɪf ɪt saʊndəd kloʊs tə spɪɾɪŋ, wɛl, soʊ bi ɪt.

"I will now pass the circle to you," she told the Windfinder when it finally was done. "If you recall what I did with Ny - " Words froze momentarily in her throat as guidance of the circle was torn from her surrender, a sensation like having a sudden burst of wind rip all of her clothes off or yank the bones out of her. She exhaled fiercely, and if it sounded close to spitting, well, so be it.

"ɡʊd," kɛɹ sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ. "ɡʊd." hɝ ətɛnʃən foʊkəst ɑn ðə boʊl, hɝ hɛd twɪstɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðəɾ əz ʃi stʌɾid ɪt. wɛl, pɝhæps nɑɾ ɔl əɹ ətɛnʃən. ɹin stɑɹɾəd tə sɪt daʊn, ən wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ʌp, kɛɹ snæpt, "hoʊl jəɹ steɪʃən, wʊmən! ðɪs ɪzən ə fɪʃ lɑli! stæn tɪl jəɹ toʊl tə muv!"

"Good," Caire said, rubbing her hands together. "Good." Her attention focused on the Bowl, her head twisting this way and that as she studied it. Well, perhaps not all her attention. Reanne started to sit down, and without looking up, Caire snapped, "Hold your station, woman! This isn't a fish lolly! Stand till you're told to move!"

stɑɹɾəld, ɹin dʒɝk bæk tə hɝ fit, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, bʌt ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv sis tə ɪɡzɪst əz fɑɹ əz kɛɹ wɑz kənsɝnd. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz aɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə flæɾənd kɹɪstəl ʃeɪp. ɪleɪn fɛlt ɹizɑlv ɪn əɹ ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə muv ə maʊntən. ən sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, taɪni ən kwɪkli stæmpt aʊt. ənsɝɾənti. ənsɝɾənti? ɪf æftɝ ɔl ə ðɪs, ðə wʊmən ɹɪli dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də -  ət ðət moʊmənt, kɛɹ dʒɹu dipli. seɪaɪdɑɹ flʌɾəd θɹu ɪleɪn, ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kəd hoʊld; ən ənbɹoʊkən ɹɪŋ ə laɪt bleɪzd ɪndə biɪŋ, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə sɝkəl, bɹaɪɾɝ wɛɹɛvɝ wʌn juzd ən æŋɡɹil, bʌt noʊwɛɹ feɪnt. ʃi wɑtʃt kloʊsli əz kɛɹ tʃænəld, fɔɹmɪŋ ə kɑmplɛks wiv ʌv ɔl faɪv paʊɝz, ə fɔɹ-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ ðət ʃi leɪɾ ətɑp ðə boʊl wɪð wʌɾ ɪleɪn sʌmhaʊ wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz ɛkskwəzət pɹisɪʒən. ðə stɑɹ tʌtʃt, ən ɪleɪn ɡæspt. wʌns, ʃi hæd tʃænəld ə tʃɹɪkəl ɪndə ðə boʊl - ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, tə bi ʃʊɹ, ən oʊnli ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðə boʊl, ðoʊ stɪl ə deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋ tə də - ən ðət klɪɹ kɹɪstəl hæd tɝn ə peɪl blu, ən ðə kɑɹv klaʊdz muvd. naʊ, ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz wɑz blu, ðə bɹaɪt blu ʌv ə sʌmɝ skaɪ, ən flisi waɪt klaʊdz bɪloʊɾ əkɹɔs ɪt.

Startled, Reanne jerked back to her feet, muttering under her breath, but she might as well have ceased to exist as far as Caire was concerned. The Windfinder's eyes remained on the flattened crystal shape. Elayne felt resolve in her great enough to move a mountain. And something else, tiny and quickly stamped out. Uncertainty. Uncertainty? If after all of this, the woman really did not know what to do -  At that moment, Caire drew deeply. Saidar flooded through Elayne, almost as much as she could hold; an unbroken ring of light blazed into being, joining the women in the circle, brighter wherever one used an angreal, but nowhere faint. She watched closely as Caire channeled, forming a complex weave of all Five Powers, a four-pointed star that she laid atop the Bowl with what Elayne somehow was sure was exquisite precision. The star touched, and Elayne gasped. Once, she had channeled a trickle into the Bowl - in Tel'aran'rhiod, to be sure, and only a reflection of the Bowl, though still a dangerous thing to do - and that clear crystal had turned a pale blue, and the carved clouds moved. Now, the Bowl of the Winds was blue, the bright blue of a summer sky, and fleecy white clouds billowed across it.

ðə fɔɹ-pɔɪn stɑɹ bɪkeɪm faɪv-pɔɪntəd, ðə kɑmpəzɪʃən ə ðə wiv ɔltɝd slaɪtli, ən ðə boʊl wɑz ə ɡɹin si wɪð ɡɹeɪt hivɪŋ weɪvz. faɪv pɔɪns bɪkeɪm sɪks, ən ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ skaɪ, ə dɪfɹən blu, dɑɹkɝ, wɪntɝ pɝhæps, wɪð pɝpəl klaʊdz hɛvi wɪð ɹeɪn əɹ snoʊ. sɛvən pɔɪns, ən ə ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin si ɹeɪdʒd ɪn stɔɹm. eɪt pɔɪns ən skaɪ. naɪn ən si, ən sʌɾənli, ɪleɪn fɛl ðə boʊl ɪtsɛlf dʒɹɔɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ə waɪl tɔɹən fɑɹ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɔl ðə sɝkəl təɡɛðɝ kəd mænədʒ.

The four-point star became five-pointed, the composition of the weave altered slightly, and the Bowl was a green sea with great heaving waves. Five points became six, and it was another sky, a different blue, darker, winter perhaps, with purple clouds heavy with rain or snow. Seven points, and a gray-green sea raged in storm. Eight points and sky. Nine and sea, and suddenly, Elayne felt the Bowl itself drawing saidar, a wild torrent far greater than all the circle together could manage.

ðə tʃeɪnʒəz kəntɪnjuɾ ʌnəbeɪɾɪd ɪnsaɪd ðə boʊl, si tə skaɪ, weɪvz tə klaʊdz, bʌɾ ə ɹaɪðɪŋ, bɹeɪɾɪd kɑləm ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃɑɾ ʌp fɹəm ðət flæɾɪʃ kɹɪstəl dɪsk, faɪɝ ən ɛɹ, wɔɾɝ ən ɝθ ən spɪɹət, ə kɑləm ʌv ɪntʃɹəkət leɪs əz waɪɾ əz ðə boʊl, klaɪmɪŋ ʌp ən ʌp ɪndə ðə skaɪ, əntɪl ɪts tɑp ɹoʊz aʊɾ ə saɪt. kɛɹ kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ wivɪŋ, swɛt stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ feɪs; ʃi pɔz simɪŋli oʊnli tə blɪŋk sɔlti dʒɹɑps əweɪ fɹəm əɹ aɪz əz ʃi ɪɡzæmən ði ɪmədʒəz ɪn ðə boʊl, ðən leɪɾ ə nu wiv. ðə pæɾɝn ə ðə bɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə θɪk kɑləm ɔltɝd wɪð ɛvɹi wiv, sʌɾəli ɛkoʊɪŋ wʌt kɛɹ woʊv.

The changes continued unabated inside the Bowl, sea to sky, waves to clouds, but a writhing, braided column of saidar shot up from that flattish crystal disc, Fire and Air, Water and Earth and Spirit, a column of intricate lace as wide as the Bowl, climbing up and up into the sky, until its top rose out of sight. Caire continued her weaving, sweat streaming down her face; she paused seemingly only to blink salty drops away from her eyes as she examined the images in the Bowl, then laid a new weave. The pattern of the braiding in the thick column altered with every weave, subtly echoing what Caire wove.

ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd θɪŋ ʃi hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə foʊkəs ðə floʊz fəɹ ðɪs sɝkəl, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪzd; wʌt ðə wʊmən wɑz duɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝd jɪɹz mɔɹ stʌɾi ðən ʃi hæd. mɛni jɪɹz mɔɹ. sʌɾənli, ʃi ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ðəɾ ɛvɝ-tʃeɪnʒɪŋ leɪswɝk ə seɪaɪdɑɹ bɛn ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, sʌmθɪŋ ənsin ðət meɪd ðə kɑləm sɑləd. ʃi swɑloʊd, hɑɹd. ðə boʊl wɑz dʒɹɔɪŋ seɪɾɪn əz wɛl əz seɪaɪdɑɹ.

It was a very good thing she had not wanted to focus the flows for this circle, Elayne realized; what the woman was doing required years more study than she had. Many years more. Suddenly, she realized something else. That ever-changing lacework of saidar bent itself around something else, something unseen that made the column solid. She swallowed, hard. The Bowl was drawing saidin as well as saidar.

hɝ hoʊp ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd pʌzəl ðəɾ aʊt vænɪʃt wɪð wʌn ɡlæns ət ði ʌðɝ wɪmən. hæf stɛɹɾ ət ðə twɪstɪŋ kɑləm wɪð ə ɹɪvʌlʃən ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn ɹɪzɝv fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. fɪɹ ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ əmʌŋ ði ɪmoʊʃənz ʃɛɹɾ ɪn əɹ hɛd. səm wɝ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə lɛvəl ʌv ɡæɹiniə ən kɝstʃən, ən ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ðoʊz tu hæd nɑt feɪntɪd. nɪneɪiv wɑz ə hɛɹ fɹəm sɪkɪŋ ʌp, fəɹ ɔl əɹ sʌɾənli tu smuð feɪs. eɪvinhə əpɪɹd dʒʌst əz kɑm aʊtwɝdli, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪd, ðət taɪni fɪɹ kwɪvɝɾ ən pʌlsd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɹoʊ.

Her hope that no one else had puzzled that out vanished with one glance at the other women. Half stared at the twisting column with a revulsion that should have been reserved for the Dark One. Fear grew stronger among the emotions shared in her head. Some were approaching the level of Garenia and Kirstian, and it was a wonder those two had not fainted. Nynaeve was a hair from sicking up, for all her suddenly too smooth face. Aviendha appeared just as calm outwardly, but inside, that tiny fear quivered and pulsed, trying to grow.

fɹəm kɛɹ keɪm oʊnli dɪtɝməneɪʃən, əz stili hɑɹɾ əz əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən. nʌθɪŋ wɑz gɑnə stæn ɪn kɛɹz weɪ, sɝɾənli nɑt ðə mɪɹ pɹɛzəns ə ʃædoʊ-teɪntɪd seɪɾɪn mɪkst ɪndə hɝ wivɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ wɑz gɑnə stɑp hɝ. ʃi wɝk ðə floʊz, ən əbɹʌpli spaɪɾɝwɛbz ə seɪaɪdɑɹ blɑsəm fɹəm ði ənsin tɑp ə ðə kɑləm, laɪk ənivən spoʊks ʌv ə wil, ɔlmoʊst ə sɑləd fæn tə ðə saʊθ, spɑɹsɝ fænz ɹitʃɪŋ nɔɹθ ən nɔɹθwɛst, sɪŋɡəl leɪsi spoʊks stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɪn ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃənz. ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒd əz ðeɪ ɡɹu, nɛvɝ ðə seɪm fɹəm wʌn moʊmən tə ðə nɛkst, spɹɛɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, fɑɹðɝ ən fɑɹðɝ, əntɪl ði ɛnz ə ðə pæɾɝn ɔlsoʊ pæst aʊɾ ə saɪt. nɑt dʒʌst seɪaɪdɑɹ ðəɹ iðɝ, ɪleɪn wɑz sɝɾən; ɪn pleɪsəz ðət spaɪɾɝwɛb kɑɾ ən kɝvd ɝaʊn sʌmθɪŋ ʃi kəd nɑt si. stɪl kɛɹ woʊv, ən ðə kɑləm dæns tə hɝ bɪɾɪŋ, seɪaɪdɑɹ ən seɪɾɪn təɡɛðɝ, ən ðə spaɪɾɝwɛb ɔltɝɾ ən floʊd laɪk ə lɑpsaɪɾɪd kəlaɪɾəskoʊp spɪnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə hɛvənz, vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɪstəns, ɑn ən ɑn ən ɑn.

From Caire came only determination, as steely hard as her expression. Nothing was going to stand in Caire's way, certainly not the mere presence of Shadow-tainted saidin mixed into her weaving. Nothing was going to stop her. She worked the flows, and abruptly spiderwebs of saidar blossomed from the unseen top of the column, like uneven spokes of a wheel, almost a solid fan to the south, sparser fans reaching north and northwest, single lacy spokes stretching in other directions. They changed as they grew, never the same from one moment to the next, spreading across the sky, farther and farther, until the ends of the pattern also passed out of sight. Not just saidar there either, Elayne was certain; in places that spiderweb caught and curved around something she could not see. Still Caire wove, and the column danced to her bidding, saidar and saidin together, and the spiderweb altered and flowed like a lopsided kaleidoscope spinning across the heavens, vanishing into the distance, on and on and on.

wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, kɛɹ stʃɹeɪɾənd, nʌklɪŋ əɹ bæk, ən ɹilis ðə sɔɹs kəmplitli. kɑləm ən spaɪɾɝwɛb ɪvæpɝeɪɾəd, ən ʃi kəlæpst əz mʌtʃ əz sæt daʊn, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. ðə boʊl tɝn klɪɹ əɡɛn, bʌt smɔl pætʃəz ə seɪaɪdɑɹ flæʃt ən kɹækəld ɝaʊn ɪts ɛdʒəz. "ɪɾ ɪz dʌn, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ," ʃi sɛd taɪɹədli.

Without warning, Caire straightened, knuckling her back, and released the Source completely. Column and spiderweb evaporated, and she collapsed as much as sat down, breathing hard. The Bowl turned clear again, but small patches of saidar flashed and crackled around its edges. "It is done, the Light willing," she said tiredly.

ɪleɪn hɑɹdli hɝd. ðət wɑz nɑt ðə weɪ tə ɛn ə sɝkəl. wən kɛɹ lɛt ɡoʊ ɪn ðət weɪ, ðə paʊɝ dɪsəpɪɹd fɹəm ɛvɹi wʊmən saɪməlteɪniəsli. ɪleɪnz aɪz pɑpt. fəɹ wʌn ɪnstənt, ɪt wɑz əz ðoʊ ʃi stʊɾ ətɑp ðə haɪəs taʊɝ ɪn ðə wɝld, ən sʌɾənli ðə taʊɝ wɑz nɑt ðəɹ ɛnimɔɹ! dʒʌst ən ɪnstənt, jɛt hɑɹdli plɛzənt. ʃi fɛl taɪɝd, ɪf nɑɾ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ wʌt ʃi wʊɾə hæd ʃi æktʃəli  dʌn ɛniθɪŋ bɪɑn sɝv əz ə kɑnduɪt, bʌt wʌt ʃi fɛl moʊst wɑz lɔs. lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf; hævɪŋ ɪt sɪmpli vænɪʃ aʊɾ ə jə wɛn bɪɑn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt.

Elayne hardly heard. That was not the way to end a circle. When Caire let go in that way, the Power disappeared from every woman simultaneously. Elayne's eyes popped. For one instant, it was as though she stood atop the highest tower in the world, and suddenly the tower was not there anymore! Just an instant, yet hardly pleasant. She felt tired, if not anywhere near what she would have had she actually done anything beyond serve as a conduit, but what she felt most was loss. Letting go of saidar was bad enough; having it simply vanish out of you went beyond thinking about.

ʌðɝz hæd sʌfɝd fɑɹ wɝs ðən ʃi. əz ðə ɡloʊ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə sɝkəl wɪŋkt aʊt, nɪneɪiv sæt daʊn ɹaɪt wɛɹ ʃi stʊɾ əz ðoʊ hɝ lɛɡz hæd mɛltəd, sæt stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪɾ ən pæntɪŋ. swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ feɪs. "aɪ fil laɪk ə kɪtʃən sɪv ðət dʒʌs hæd ðə hoʊl mɪl pɔɹd θɹu ɪt," ʃi mɝmɝd. kæɹiɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ hæɾ ɪts kɑst ivən ɪf jə dɪd nʌθɪŋ, ivən wɪð ən æŋɡɹil.

Others had suffered far worse than she. As the glow joining the circle winked out, Nynaeve sat down right where she stood as though her legs had melted, sat stroking the bracelet-and-rings, staring at it and panting. Sweat rolled down her face. "I feel like a kitchen sieve that just had the whole mill poured through it," she murmured. Carrying that much of the Power had its cost even if you did nothing, even with an angreal.

tɑlɑn weɪvɝd, ə ɹiɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd, kæstɪŋ sɝəptɪʃəs ɡlænsɪz əɾ əɹ mʌðɝ, pleɪnli əfɹeɪd tə sɪt. eɪvinhə stʊd stʃɹeɪt, hɝ fɪkst ɪkspɹɛʃən seɪɪŋ ðət wɪlpaʊɝ hæɾ əz mʌtʃ tə də wɪð ðəɾ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi ɡeɪv ə slaɪt smaɪl, ðoʊ, ən meɪɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ ɪn meɪɾən hæntɔk - wɝθ ðə pɹaɪs - ən ðən ənʌðɝ - mɔɹ - ɹaɪt bɪhaɪnd. mɔɹ ðən wɝθ ðə pɹaɪs. ɛvɹiwʌn lʊkt wɪɹi, ɪf nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðoʊz u hæd juzd æŋɡɹil. ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz wɛn kwaɪəɾ ət læst, dʒʌst ə waɪd boʊl ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl, bʌt dɛkɝeɪɾəd naʊ wɪð taʊɝɪŋ weɪvz. seɪaɪdɑɹ stɪl sim tə bi ðɛɹ, ðoʊ, nɑt biɪŋ wildɪd baɪ ɛniwʌn, nɑt vɪzəbəl, bʌɾ ɪn dɪmli fɛl flæʃɪz laɪk ðoʊz ðət hæd pleɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə boʊl ət ði ɛnd.

Talaan wavered, a reed in the wind, casting surreptitious glances at her mother, plainly afraid to sit. Aviendha stood straight, her fixed expression saying that willpower had as much to do with that as anything else. She gave a slight smile, though, and made a gesture in Maiden handtalk - worth the price - and then another - more - right behind. More than worth the price. Everyone looked weary, if not so much as those who had used angreal. The Bowl of the Winds went quiet at last, just a wide bowl of clear crystal, but decorated now with towering waves. Saidar still seemed to be there, though, not being wielded by anyone, not visible, but in dimly felt flashes like those that had played around the Bowl at the end.

nɪneɪiv ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd tə ɡlaʊɝ ət ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ, ðən loʊɝɾ əɹ ɡeɪz tə kɛɹ. "ɔl ðæt, fəɹ wʌt? dɪd wi də ɛniθɪŋ, əɹ nɑt?" ə bɹɛθ ʌv ɛɹ stɝɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɪltɑp, wɔɹm əz ði ɛɹ ɪn ə kɪtʃən.

Nynaeve raised her head to glower at the cloudless sky, then lowered her gaze to Caire. "All that, for what? Did we do anything, or not?" A breath of air stirred across the hilltop, warm as the air in a kitchen.

ðə wɪndfɪndɝ stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɝ fit. "du jə θɪŋk wivɪŋ ðə wɪnz ɪz laɪk θɹoʊɪŋ ðə hɛlm oʊvɝ ɑn ə dɑɹɾɝ?" ʃi dɪmændəd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "aɪ dʒʌs muv ðə ɹʌɾɝ ɑn ə skɪmɝ wɪð ə bim əz bɹɔɾ əz ðə wɝld! hɪl teɪk taɪm tə tɝn, taɪm tə noʊ hiz səpoʊz tə tɝn. ðəɾ i mʌs tɝn. bʌt wən i dʌz, nɑt ðə fɑðɝ ə stɔɹmz hɪmsɛlf wɪl bi eɪbəl tə stæn ɪn ɪz weɪ. aɪ hæv dʌn ɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ɪz aʊɝz!"

The Windfinder struggled to her feet. "Do you think Weaving the Winds is like throwing the helm over on a darter?" she demanded contemptuously. "I just moved the rudder on a skimmer with a beam as broad as the world! He will take time to turn, time to know he is supposed to turn. That he must turn. But when he does, not the Father of Storms himself will be able to stand in his way. I have done it, Aes Sedai, and the Bowl of the Winds is ours!"

ɹɪneɪl muvd ɪndə ðə sɝkəl, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə boʊl. kɛɹfəli ʃi bɪɡæn foʊldɪŋ ðə waɪt sɪlk ɝaʊn ɪt. "aɪ wɪl teɪk ðɪs tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps," ʃi sɛd tə nɪneɪiv. "wi hæv fʊlfɪld əɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən. naʊ, jə ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌs fʊlfɪl ðə ɹɛst ə jʊɹz." mɛɝɪlɪl meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, bʌt wən ɪleɪn ɡlænst ət hɝ, ðə ɡɹeɪ əpɪɹɾ ə stʌɾi ɪn kəmpoʊʒɝ.

Renaile moved into the circle, kneeling beside the Bowl. Carefully she began folding the white silk around it. "I will take this to the Mistress of the Ships," she said to Nynaeve. "We have fulfilled our part of the bargain. Now, you Aes Sedai must fulfill the rest of yours." Merilille made a sound in her throat, but when Elayne glanced at her, the Gray appeared a study in composure.

"meɪbi juv dʌn jəɹ pɑɹt," nɪneɪiv sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ənstɛɾəli. "meɪbi. wɪl si wən ðɪs . . . ðɪs skɪmɝ ə jʊɹz tɝnz. ɪf ɪt tɝnz!" ɹɪneɪl stɛɹd hɑɹɾ əɾ əɹ əkɹɔs ðə boʊl, bʌt nɪneɪiv ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. "stʃɹeɪnʒ," ʃi mʌɾɝd, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tɛmpəl. ðə bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz kɑɾ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ən ʃi ɡɹɪməst. "aɪ kən ɔlmoʊs fil ən ɛkoʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ. ɪt mʌs bi ðɪs θɪŋ!"

"Maybe you've done your part," Nynaeve said, rising unsteadily. "Maybe. We'll see when this . . . this skimmer of yours turns. If it turns!" Renaile stared hard at her across the Bowl, but Nynaeve ignored her. "Strange," she muttered, rubbing her temple. The bracelet-and-rings caught in her hair, and she grimaced. "I can almost feel an echo of saidar. It must be this thing!"

"noʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ kən fil ɪt, tu." nɑt dʒʌs ðə dɪmli pɝsiv kɹæklɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən nɑɾ ən ɛkoʊ, ɪɡzækli. mɔɹ ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ən ɛkoʊ, soʊ feɪn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ʃi wɝ filɪŋ sʌmwʌn juz seɪaɪdɑɹ əɾ eɪ. . . . ʃi tɝnd. ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən tə ðə saʊθ, laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt, dʌzənz ə boʊls vɪvəd sɪlvɝ-blu əɡɛns ði æftɝnun skaɪ. vɛɹi nɪɹ tə ɛbu dɑɹ.

"No," Elayne said slowly. "I can feel it, too." Not just the dimly perceived crackling in the air, and not an echo, exactly. More the shadow of an echo, so faint that it was as if she were feeling someone use saidar at a. . . . She turned. On the horizon to the south, lightning flashed, dozens of bolts vivid silver-blue against the afternoon sky. Very near to Ebou Dar.
