"ə ɹeɪnstɔɹm?" sɝaɪðə sɛɾ iɡɝli. "ðə wɛðɝ mʌs bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɔlɹɛɾi." bʌt ðəɹ wɝ noʊ klaʊdz ɪn ðə skaɪ ivən wɛɹ ðə laɪtnɪŋ fɔɹkt ən fɛl. sɝaɪðə wɑz nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə sɛns seɪaɪdɑɹ biɪŋ wildɪɾ ət ðət dɪstəns.

"A rainstorm?" Sareitha said eagerly. "The weather must be righting itself already." But there were no clouds in the sky even where the lightning forked and fell. Sareitha was not strong enough to sense saidar being wielded at that distance.

ɪleɪn ʃɪvɝd. ʃi wɑz nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. ənlɛs sʌmwʌn wɑz juzɪŋ əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɑn ðɪs hɪltɑp. fɪfti əɹ ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔl tʃænəlɪŋ ət wʌns. ɔɹ. . . . "nɑt wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ʃi mɝmɝd. sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn əɹ moʊnd.

Elayne shivered. She was not strong enough. Unless someone was using as much as they had on this hilltop. Fifty or even a hundred Aes Sedai, all channeling at once. Or. . . . "Not one of the Forsaken," she murmured. Someone behind her moaned.

"wʌn kʊdn də ðæt," nɪneɪiv əɡɹid kwaɪətli. "meɪbi ðeɪ dɪdn fil əs ðə weɪ wi də ðɛm, meɪbi, bʌt ðəl əv sin, ənlɛs ðəɹ ɔl blaɪnd. ðə laɪt bɝn əɹ lʌk!" kwaɪəɾ əɹ nɑt, ʃi wɑz ædʒəteɪɾəd; ʃi ɔfən kɔld ɪleɪn daʊn fəɹ juzɪŋ læŋɡwədʒ laɪk ðæt. "teɪk ɛvɹiwʌn u wɪl ɡoʊ tə ændɝ wɪð ju, ɪleɪn. aɪl. . . . əl mit jə ðɛɹ. mæts ɪn ðə sɪɾi. aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk fəɹ hɪm. bɝn ðə bɔɪ; hi keɪm fəɹ mi, ən aɪ hæv tə."

"One couldn't do that," Nynaeve agreed quietly. "Maybe they didn't feel us the way we do them, maybe, but they'll have seen, unless they're all blind. The Light burn our luck!" Quiet or not, she was agitated; she often called Elayne down for using language like that. "Take everyone who will go to Andor with you, Elayne. I'll. . . . I'll meet you there. Mat's in the city. I have to go back for him. Burn the boy; he came for me, and I have to."

ɪleɪn ɹæpt əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf ən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. kwin taɪlɪn ʃi lɛf tə ðə mɝsiz ə ðə laɪt; taɪlɪn wəd sɝvaɪv ɪf ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl. bʌt mæt kɔθən, hɝ vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ, vɛɹi ɪnstʃɹʌktɪv səbdʒɛkt; hɝ moʊst ənlaɪkli ɹɛskjuɝ. hi hæd kʌm fəɹ hɝ, tu, ən ɔfɝd mɔɹ. ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn; dɪɹ tɑm, hu ʃi səmtaɪmz stɪl wɪʃt wəd tɝn aʊt tə bi hɝ ɹil fɑðɝ, ən ðə laɪt bɝn wʌt ðət wəd meɪk ə hɝ mʌðɝ. ən ðə bɔɪ, oʊlvɝ, ən tʃəl veɪnɪn, ænd. . . . ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk laɪk ə kwin. ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ɪz hɛviɝ ðən ə maʊntən, hɝ mʌðɝ hæd toʊl hɝ, ən duɾi wɪl meɪk jə wip, bʌt jə mʌs bɛɹ ən də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn.

Elayne wrapped her arms around herself and drew a deep breath. Queen Tylin she left to the mercies of the Light; Tylin would survive if it was possible. But Mat Cauthon, her very strange, very instructive subject; her most unlikely rescuer. He had come for her, too, and offered more. And Thom Merrilin; dear Thom, who she sometimes still wished would turn out to be her real father, and the Light burn what that would make of her mother. And the boy, Olver, and Chel Vanin, and. . . . She had to think like a queen. The Rose Crown is heavier than a mountain, her mother had told her, and duty will make you weep, but you must bear and do what must be done.

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd, ðən mɔɹ fɝmli, "noʊ. lʊk ət ju, nɪneɪiv; jə kən hɑɹdli stænd. ivən ɪf wi ɔl wɛnt, wʌt kəd wi du? haʊ mɛni ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ ðɛɹ? wid daɪ, əɹ wɝs, fəɹ noʊ ɡeɪn. ðə fɔɹseɪkən əv noʊ ɹizən tə lʊk fəɹ mæt əɹ ði ʌðɝz. ɪts əs ðəl bi æftɝ."

"No," she said, then more firmly, "No. Look at you, Nynaeve; you can hardly stand. Even if we all went, what could we do? How many of the Forsaken are there? We'd die, or worse, for no gain. The Forsaken have no reason to look for Mat or the others. It's us they will be after."

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, stʌbɝn nɪneɪiv wɪð swɛt ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn əɹ feɪs ən əɹ lɛɡz ənstɛɾi. wʌndɝfəl, ɡælənt, fulɪʃ nɪneɪiv. "jɔɹ seɪɪŋ liv hɪm, ɪleɪn? eɪvinhə, tɔk tə hɝ. tɛl əɹ əbaʊt ðəɾ ɑnɝ jəɹ ɔlweɪz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əbaʊt!"

Nynaeve gaped at her, stubborn Nynaeve with sweat running down her face and her legs unsteady. Wonderful, gallant, foolish Nynaeve. "You're saying leave him, Elayne? Aviendha, talk to her. Tell her about that honor you're always going on about!"

eɪvinhə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz swɛɾi əz nɪneɪiv, ən fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi muvd, dʒʌst əz taɪɝd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ taɪmz tə faɪt wɪθaʊt hoʊp, nɪneɪiv, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ɪz ɹaɪt. ðə ʃæɾoʊsuld wɪl nɑt bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mæt kɔθən; ðəl bi æftɝ ʌs, ən ðə boʊl. hi meɪ hæv lɛf ðə sɪɾi ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf wi ɡoʊ, wi ɹɪsk ɡɪvɪŋ əm wʌt kən əndu wʌt wɪv dʌn. wɛɹɛvɝ wi sɛn ðə boʊl, ðəl bi eɪbəl tə meɪk əs tɛl əm u wi sɛn ɪt wɪð ən wɛɹ."

Aviendha hesitated, then shook her head. She was almost as sweaty as Nynaeve, and from the way she moved, just as tired. "There are times to fight without hope, Nynaeve, but Elayne is right. The Shadowsouled will not be looking for Mat Cauthon; they will be after us, and the Bowl. He may have left the city already. If we go, we risk giving them what can undo what we have done. Wherever we send the Bowl, they will be able to make us tell them who we sent it with and where."

nɪneɪivz feɪs kɹʌmpəld ɪn peɪn. ɪleɪn ɹitʃt tə pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ.

Nynaeve's face crumpled in pain. Elayne reached to put her arms around her.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn!" sʌmwʌn skɹimd, ən sʌɾənli wɪmən wɝ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ ɔl oʊvɝ ðə hɪltɑp. bɔlz ə faɪɝ ʃɑɾ ʌp fɹəm mɛɝɪlɪlz hænz, fɹəm kɛɝinz ən sɝaɪðəz, əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd θɹoʊ. ə hjudʒ wɪŋd ʃeɪp ɛnvɛləpt ɪn fleɪm tʌmbəld aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ɔɪli blæk smoʊk, fɔlɪŋ dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə klɪf.

"Shadowspawn!" someone screamed, and suddenly women were embracing saidar all over the hilltop. Balls of fire shot up from Merilille's hands, from Careane's and Sareitha's, as fast as they could throw. A huge winged shape enveloped in flame tumbled out of the sky trailing oily black smoke, falling just beyond the cliff.

"ðɛɹz ənʌðɝ wʌn!" kɝstʃən ʃaʊɾəd, pɔɪntɪŋ. ə sɛkənd wɪŋ kɹitʃɝ dʌv əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɪl, bɑɾi əz bɪɡ əz ə hɔɹs, ɹɪbd wɪŋz spænɪŋ θɝɾi peɪsɪz əɹ mɔɹ, lɔŋ nɛk stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt bɪfɔɹ ən lɔŋɡɝ teɪl stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. tu fɪɡjɝz kɹaʊtʃt loʊ ɑn ɪts bæk. ə stɔɹm ə faɪɝ ɹeɪn æftɝ ɪt, kwɪkɪst ʌv ɔl fɹəm eɪvinhə ən ðə si foʊk, hu meɪd noʊ θɹoʊɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ əz pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ wivɪŋ. ə heɪl ə faɪɝ soʊ θɪk ɪt sim ðət faɪɝ mʌs bi fɔɹmɪŋ ɪtsɛlf aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ, ən ðə θɪŋ dɑdʒ bɪhaɪn ðə hɪl ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə fɑɹm ən əpɪɹd tə vænɪʃ.

"There's another one!" Kirstian shouted, pointing. A second winged creature dove away from the hill, body as big as a horse, ribbed wings spanning thirty paces or more, long neck stretched out before and longer tail streaming behind. Two figures crouched low on its back. A storm of fire rained after it, quickest of all from Aviendha and the Sea Folk, who made no throwing gesture as part of their weaving. A hail of fire so thick it seemed that Fire must be forming itself out of the air, and the thing dodged behind the hill on the other side of the farm and appeared to vanish.

"dɪd wi kɪl ɪt?" sɝaɪðə æskt. hɝ aɪz ʃoʊn bɹaɪt, ən ʃi bɹið hɑɹɾ ɪn ædʒəteɪʃən.

"Did we kill it?" Sareitha asked. Her eyes shone bright, and she breathed hard in agitation.

"dɪd wi ivən hɪɾ ɪt?" wʌn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɡɹaʊl dɪsɡʌstɪdli.

"Did we even hit it?" one of the Atha'an Miere growled disgustedly.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn," mɛɝɪlɪl mɝmɝɾ ɪn əmeɪzmənt. "hɪɹ! ət lis ðət pɹuvz ɪts ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ."

"Shadowspawn," Merilille murmured in amazement. "Here! At least that proves it's the Forsaken in Ebou Dar."

"nɑt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn," ɪleɪn sɛd hɑloʊli. nɪneɪivz feɪs wɑz ə pɪktʃɝ ʌv æŋɡwɪʃ; ʃi nu, tu. "ðeɪ kɔl ɪɾ ə ɹeɪkən. ɪts ðə sintʃæn. wi mʌst ɡoʊ, nɪneɪiv, ən teɪk ɛvɹi wʊmən ət ðə fɑɹm wɪð ʌs. wɛðɝ wi kɪl ðət θɪŋ əɹ nɑt, mɔɹ wɪl kʌm. ɛniwʌn wi liv bɪhaɪnd wɪl bi wɛɹɪŋ ə deɪmeɪn liʃ baɪ təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ." nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd, sloʊli, peɪnfəli; ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi mɝmɝd, "oʊ, mæt."

"Not Shadowspawn," Elayne said hollowly. Nynaeve's face was a picture of anguish; she knew, too. "They call it a raken. It's the Seanchan. We must go, Nynaeve, and take every woman at the farm with us. Whether we killed that thing or not, more will come. Anyone we leave behind will be wearing a damane leash by tomorrow morning." Nynaeve nodded, slowly, painfully; Elayne thought she murmured, "Oh, Mat."

ɹɪneɪl stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðə boʊl ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz, wʌns mɔɹ swɑðd ɪn ɪts waɪt kʌvɝɪŋ. "sʌm ʌv əɹ ʃɪps əv ɪnkaʊntɝd ðiz sintʃæn. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðən ðə ʃɪps bit tə si. maɪ ʃɪp faɪts fəɹ ɪz laɪf, ən aɪm nɑɾ ɑn ɪz dɛk! wi ɡoʊ naʊ!" ən ʃi fɔɹm ðə wiv fəɹ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɹaɪt ðɛɹ.

Renaile strode up with the Bowl in her arms, once more swathed in its white covering. "Some of our ships have encountered these Seanchan. If they are in Ebou Dar, then the ships beat to sea. My ship fights for his life, and I am not on his deck! We go now!" And she formed the weave for a gateway, right there.

ɪt tæŋɡəl jusləsli, ʌv kɔɹs, flɛɹd bɹaɪt fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðən kəlæpst ɪndə nʌθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn skwikt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ɹaɪt ðəɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛm! "bʌt moʊst ʌv ɔl, jə ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ɪksɛpt wɪð ʌs, kəz əɹ bɑɹɡən ɪzən kəmplit; ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ɪz nɑt jʊɹz əntɪl ðə wɛðɝ ɪz ɹaɪt." nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli tʃɹu ənlɛs jə twɪstəd ðə wɝdz ə ðə bɑɹɡən ə lɪɾəl, ən ɹɪneɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn plaʊɾ ɑn. "æn kəz jə meɪɾ ə bɑɹɡən wɪð meɪtʃɹim kɔθən, maɪ sʌbʒɪkt. jə ɡoʊ vɑləntɛɹəli wɛɹ aɪ wɑn jə tə, əɹ jə ɡoʊ taɪd tə ə pæksæɾəl. ðoʊz wɝ ðə tʃɔɪsəz jə æksɛptɪd. soʊ, ɡɛt daʊn ðɪs hɪl naʊ, ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn blu stɑɹ, bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn swip daʊn ɑn əs wɪð ən ɑɹmi ən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd wɪmən u kən tʃænəl ən wəd laɪk nʌθɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən tə si əs kɑlɝɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛm. naʊ! ɹʌn!"

It tangled uselessly, of course, flared bright for an instant then collapsed into nothing, but Elayne squeaked in spite of herself. Right there in the middle of them! "You aren't going anywhere from here unless you mean to stay long enough to learn this hilltop!" she snapped. She hoped none of the women who had been in the circle tried the weave; holding saidar was the fastest way to learn a place. She could have made it work here, and very likely so could they. "You aren't going to a moving ship from anywhere; I don't think it's even possible!" Merilille nodded, though that meant little; Aes Sedai believed a great many things to be true, and some of them actually were. As well if the Sea Folk believed it proven, in any case. Nynaeve, haggard and staring, was in no condition to do any leading at the moment, so Elayne went on. She hoped she managed to do her mother's memory proud. "But most of all, you aren't going anywhere except with us, because our bargain isn't complete; the Bowl of the Winds is not yours until the weather is right." Not precisely true unless you twisted the words of the bargain a little, and Renaile opened her mouth, but Elayne plowed on. "And because you made a bargain with Matrim Cauthon, my subject. You go voluntarily where I want you to, or you go tied to a packsaddle. Those were the choices you accepted. So, get down this hill now, Renaile din Calon Blue Star, before the Seanchan sweep down on us with an army and a few hundred women who can channel and would like nothing better than to see us collared alongside them. Now! Run!"

tə hɝ əstɑnɪʃmənt, ðeɪ ɹæn.

To her astonishment, they ran.

ɪleɪn ɹæn, tu, ʌv kɔɹs, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ skɝts ʌp, ən kwɪkli tʊk ðə lɛɾ ɑn ðə wɛl-wɔɹn dɝt pæθ. oʊnli eɪvinhə steɪd kloʊs, ðoʊ ʃi sim tə hæv noʊ aɪdiə haʊ tə ɹʌn ɪn ə dʒɹɛs, dɪvaɪɾəd əɹ nɑt; taɪɝɾ əz ʃi wɑz, ʃi sɝɾənli wʊɾə pæst ɪleɪn ʌðɝwaɪz. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls stʃɹʌŋ aʊt bɪhaɪn əm əlɔŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ, waɪndɪŋ tʃɹæk. nʌn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ wəd pʊʃ baɪ ɹɪneɪl, ən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ sɪlk tʃɹaʊzɝz ʃi kəd nɑt muv vɛɹi fæs kæɹiɪŋ ðə boʊl hʌɡd tə hɝ tʃɛst. nɪneɪiv hæd noʊ sətʃ kəmpjuŋkʃənz, ɛlboʊɪŋ pæst ən ɹʌnɪŋ hɑɹd, ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ pipəl tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ wən ʃi stʌmbəld ɪndə ðɛm wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ wɪndfɪndɝz, kɪnswɪmən, əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Elayne ran, too, of course, holding her skirts up, and quickly took the lead on the well-worn dirt path. Only Aviendha stayed close, though she seemed to have no idea how to run in a dress, divided or not; tired as she was, she certainly would have passed Elayne otherwise. Everyone else strung out behind them along the narrow, winding track. None of the Atha'an Miere would push by Renaile, and despite her silk trousers she could not move very fast carrying the Bowl hugged to her chest. Nynaeve had no such compunctions, elbowing past and running hard, shouting for people to get out of her way when she stumbled into them whether they were Windfinders, Kinswomen, or Aes Sedai.

baʊndɪŋ daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd, tʃɹɪpɪŋ ən kætʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn wɑntəd tə læf dɪspaɪt ði ɝdʒənsi. dɪspaɪt ðə deɪnʒɝ. lini ən əɹ mʌðɝ hæd bɪn dɛθ ɑn ɹʌnɪŋ ən klaɪmɪŋ tʃɹiz fɹəm ðə taɪm ʃi wɑz twɛlv, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ðə ʃɪɹ plɛʒɝ ə ɹʌnɪŋ əɡɛn ðət meɪd dɪlaɪt bʌbəl ʌp ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl. ʃi hæd bɪheɪvd əz ə kwin wɑz səpoʊz tə bɪheɪv, ən ɪt hæd wɝkt ɪɡzækli əz ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə! ʃi hæd teɪkən tʃɑɹdʒ, tə lid pipəl aʊɾ ə deɪnʒɝ, ən ðeɪ fɑloʊd! hɝ hoʊl laɪf hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ ðɪs. ɪt wɑz sæɾəsfækʃən ðət meɪɾ əɹ læf, ən ðə hɑt ɡloʊ ʌv pɹaɪd simd əbaʊt tə bɝs θɹu hɝ skɪn laɪk ðə ɹeɪdʒjəns ə seɪaɪdɑɹ.

Bounding down the hillside, tripping and catching herself, Elayne wanted to laugh despite the urgency. Despite the danger. Lini and her mother had been death on running and climbing trees from the time she was twelve, but it was not just the sheer pleasure of running again that made delight bubble up in her middle. She had behaved as a queen was supposed to behave, and it had worked exactly as it was supposed to! She had taken charge, to lead people out of danger, and they followed! Her whole life had been training for this. It was satisfaction that made her laugh, and the hot glow of pride seemed about to burst through her skin like the radiance of saidar.

ɹaʊndɪŋ ðə læs kɝv, ʃi paʊndɪd daʊn ðə faɪnəl stʃɹeɪt bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə tɔl waɪt-plæstɝd bɑɹnz. ən əɹ toʊ kɑɾ ən ɔlmoʊs bɛɹid stoʊn. ʃi pɪtʃt fɔɹwɝd hɛvəli, wɪndmɪlɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz, ən sʌɾənli ʃi wɑz sʌmɝsɔltɪŋ hɛd-oʊvɝ-hilz θɹu ði ɛɹ. noʊ taɪm ivən tə jɛl. wɪð ə θʌmp ðət dʒɑɹɾ əɹ tiθ ən tʊk ɔl ðə wɪn aʊɾ ə hɝ, ʃi lændəd hɑɹɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə pæθ, sɪɾɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə bɝdʒɪt. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən θɪŋk, ən wən ʃi kʊd, lɪɾəl sæɾəsfækʃən ɹɪmeɪnd. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ kwinli dɪɡnəɾi. bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ feɪs, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ əz ʃi weɪɾəd fəɹ bɝdʒɪts kʌɾɪŋ kɑmɛnt. ðɪs wɑz ə tʃæns fəɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tə pleɪ ði oʊldɝ ən waɪzɝ sɪstɝ wɪð ə vɛnʒəns, ən ʃi sɛldəm lɛɾ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi pæs.

Rounding the last curve, she pounded down the final straight beside one of the tall white-plastered barns. And her toe caught an almost buried stone. She pitched forward heavily, windmilling her arms, and suddenly she was somersaulting head-over-heels through the air. No time even to yell. With a thump that jarred her teeth and took all the wind out of her, she landed hard at the foot of the path, sitting right in front of Birgitte. For an instant she could not even think, and when she could, little satisfaction remained. So much for queenly dignity. Brushing her hair out of her face, she tried to catch her breath as she waited for Birgitte's cutting comment. This was a chance for the other woman to play the older and wiser sister with a vengeance, and she seldom let an opportunity pass.

tə ɪleɪnz sɝpɹaɪz, bɝdʒɪt hivd əɹ tə hɝ fiɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ eɪvinhə kəd ɹitʃ hɝ, ən wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə feɪnt ɡɹɪn ɑn eɪvinhəz feɪs. ɔl ɪleɪn kəd fil fɹəm əɹ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ə sɛns ʌv . . . foʊkəs; ʃi θɔɾ ən æɹoʊ nɑkt ɑn ə dʒɹɔn bɑstʃɹɪŋ maɪt fil ðət weɪ. "du wi ɹʌn əɹ faɪt?" bɝdʒɪɾ æskt. "aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðoʊz sintʃæn flaɪɝz fɹəm fɑlm, ən tʃɹuθ fəɹ tʃɹu, aɪ sədʒɛst ɹʌnɪŋ. maɪ baʊ ɪz ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi sɔɹt, tədeɪ." eɪvinhə ɡeɪv əɹ ə slaɪt fɹaʊn, ən ɪleɪn saɪd; bɝdʒɪt hæd tə lɝn tə ɡɑɹɾ əɹ tʌŋ ɪf ʃi ɹɪli ɪntɛndəd tə haɪɾ u ʃi wɑz.

To Elayne's surprise, Birgitte heaved her to her feet even before Aviendha could reach her, and without so much as the faint grin on Aviendha's face. All Elayne could feel from her Warder was a sense of . . . focus; she thought an arrow nocked on a drawn bowstring might feel that way. "Do we run or fight?" Birgitte asked. "I recognized those Seanchan fliers from Falme, and truth for true, I suggest running. My bow is the ordinary sort, today." Aviendha gave her a slight frown, and Elayne sighed; Birgitte had to learn to guard her tongue if she really intended to hide who she was.

"ʌv kɔɹs wi ɹʌn," nɪneɪiv pæntɪd, leɪbɝɪŋ daʊn ðə faɪnəl stʃɹɛtʃ ə pæθ. "faɪɾ əɹ ɹʌn! ful kwɛstʃən! dʒju θɪŋk wɝ ʌɾɝ - ? laɪt! wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ duɪŋ?" hɝ vɔɪs stɑɹɾəd klaɪmɪŋ ən kɛpt ɹaɪɾ ɑn. "æləz! æləz, wɛɹ ɑɹ ju? æləz! æləz!"

"Of course we run," Nynaeve panted, laboring down the final stretch of path. "Fight or run! Fool question! Do you think we're utter - ? Light! What are they doing?" Her voice started climbing and kept right on. "Alise! Alise, where are you? Alise! Alise!"

wɪð ə stɑɹt, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪz ðə fɑɹm wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ əz bædli əz ɪt hæd wən kɛɝinz feɪs wɑz ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd. meɪbi wɝs. ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɔɹɾi-sɛvən kɪnswɪmən ɪnhæbəɾəd ðə pleɪs ət pɹɛzənt, æləz hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ fɪfti-fɔɹ ɹɛd-bɛltəd waɪz wɪmən sɛn aʊt deɪz əɡoʊ ən ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn pæsɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪɾi; naʊ ɪt lʊkt əz ðoʊ ɛvɹi læst wʌn wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ, ən ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, tu. moʊst ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs sɝvəns ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi dæʃt ðɪs weɪ ən ðət kæɹiɪŋ bɝɾənz. dʌks ən tʃɪkənz dɑɹɾɪd θɹu ðə tuməlt, flæpɪŋ ən skwɔkɪŋ, æɾɪŋ tə ði əpɛɹən kənfjuʒən. ɪleɪn ivən sɔ ə wɔɹɾɝ, vændinz ɡɹɪzəl jeɪɛm, tʃɹɑt baɪ wɪð ɪz wɪɹi ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ə bɪɡ dʒut sæk!

With a start, Elayne realized the farm was boiling as badly as it had when Careane's face was recognized. Maybe worse. A hundred and forty-seven Kinswomen inhabited the place at present, Alise had reported, including fifty-four red-belted Wise Women sent out days ago and a number of others who had been passing through the city; now it looked as though every last one was running somewhere, and a good many of the other women, too. Most of the Tarasin Palace servants in their green-and-white livery dashed this way and that carrying burdens. Ducks and chickens darted through the tumult, flapping and squawking, adding to the apparent confusion. Elayne even saw a Warder, Vandene's grizzled Jaem, trot by with his wiry arms wrapped around a big jute sack!

æləz əpɪɹɾ əz ðoʊ fɹəm ði ɛɹ, pɔɪzd ən kəlɛktəd dɪspaɪt ðə pɝspɝeɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. ɛvɹi stʃɹæn ə hɝ hɛɹ wɑz ɪn pleɪs, ən əɹ dʒɹɛs lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ mɪɹli aʊt fəɹ ə stʃɹoʊl. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə skɹitʃ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, plæntɪŋ hænz ɑn hɪps. "bɝdʒɪt toʊl mi wʌt ðoʊz bɪɡ bɝdz ɑɹ, ən aɪ θɔt wi maɪt bi livɪŋ sunɝ ɹæðɝ ðən leɪɾɝ, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ɔl ə jə ɡæləpɪŋ daʊn ðə hɪl laɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf wɑz æftɝ ju. aɪ toʊld ɛvɹibɑɾi tə kəlɛkt wʌn klin dʒɹɛs əpis, θɹi tʃeɪnʒəz ə ʃɪft ən stɑkɪŋz, soʊp, mɛndɪŋ bæskəts, ən ɔl ðə kɔɪn ðeɪ hæv. ðæt, ən noʊ mɔɹ. ðə læs tɛn tə fɪnɪʃ wɪl də ðə wɑʃɪŋ-ʌp tɪl wi ɡɛt wɛɹ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ; ðət wɪl spid ðɛɹ fit. aɪ toʊl ðoʊz sɝvəns tə ɡæðɝ ɔl ðə fud ðeɪ kʊd, tu, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. ən jəɹ wɔɹɾɝz. sɛnsəbəl fɛloʊz, moʊst ə ðɛm. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli sɛnsəbəl, fəɹ mɛn. dʌz biɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ də sʌmθɪŋ tə ðɛm?"

Alise appeared as though from the air, poised and collected despite the perspiration on her face. Every strand of her hair was in place, and her dress looked as if she were merely out for a stroll. "There's no need to screech," she said calmly, planting hands on hips. "Birgitte told me what those big birds are, and I thought we might be leaving sooner rather than later, especially with all of you galloping down the hill like the Dark One himself was after you. I told everybody to collect one clean dress apiece, three changes of shift and stockings, soap, mending baskets, and all the coin they have. That, and no more. The last ten to finish will do the washing-up till we get where we're going; that will speed their feet. I told those servants to gather all the food they could, too, just in case. And your Warders. Sensible fellows, most of them. Surprisingly sensible, for men. Does being a Warder do something to them?"

nɪneɪiv stʊd ðəɹ wɪð əɹ dʒɔ hæŋɪŋ, ɹɛɾi tə ɪʃu ɔɹɾɝz ən nʌn lɛf tə ɡɪv. ɪmoʊʃənz pleɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs tu fæs tə kætʃ. "vɛɹi ɡʊd," ʃi mʌmbəl faɪnəli. ən saʊɝli. sʌɾənli ʃi bɹaɪɾənd. "ðə wɪmən u ɑɹən kɪn. jɛs! ðeɪv tə bi - "

Nynaeve stood there with her jaw hanging, ready to issue orders and none left to give. Emotions played across her face too fast to catch. "Very good," she mumbled finally. And sourly. Suddenly she brightened. "The women who aren't Kin. Yes! They have to be - "

"kɑm jɝsɛlf," æləz bɹoʊk ɪn, meɪkɪŋ ə suðɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. meɪnli ðoʊz wɪð hʌzbənz əɹ fæmliz ðəɹ wɝiɾ əbaʊt. aɪ kʊdn əv hɛl ðoʊz bæk hæɾ aɪ wɑntəd. bʌɾ ə ɡʊd θɝɾi θɪŋk ðoʊz bɝdz ɹɪli ɑɹ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, ən wɑnə steɪ əz kloʊs tə ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ðeɪ kən ɡɛt." ə ʃɑɹp snɪf sɛd wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðæt. "naʊ, jə dʒʌst ɡæðɝ jɝsɛlf. dʒɹɪŋk səm kul wɔɾɝ; nɑt tu fæst. pʊɾ ə lɪɾəl ɑn jəɹ feɪs. aɪ hæv tə kip ən aɪ ɑn θɪŋz." kæstɪŋ əɹ aɪ oʊvɝ ðə bʌsəl, ɛvɹibɑɾi ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn baʊnz, æləz ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "sʌm wəd slæk ɔf ɪf tʃɹɑləks wɝ kʌmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɪl, ən moʊst ə ðə noʊbəlwɪmən nɛvɝ ɹɪli də ɡɛt juz tə əɹ ɹulz. fəɹ ʃʊɹ, əl nid tə ɹimaɪn tu əɹ θɹi bɪfɔɹ wi ɡoʊ." wɪð ðæt, ʃi weɪɾɪd sɝinəli bæk ɪndə ðə tɝmɔɪl ə ðə fɑɹmjɑɹɾ ən lɛf nɪneɪiv ɡeɪpɪŋ.

"Calm yourself," Alise broke in, making a soothing gesture. "They are already gone, for the most part. Mainly those with husbands or families they're worried about. I couldn't have held those back had I wanted. But a good thirty think those birds really are Shadowspawn, and want to stay as close to Aes Sedai as they can get." A sharp sniff said what she thought of that. "Now, you just gather yourself. Drink some cool water; not too fast. Put a little on your face. I have to keep an eye on things." Casting her eye over the bustle, everybody running in bounds, Alise shook her head. "Some would slack off if Trollocs were coming over the hill, and most of the noblewomen never really do get used to our rules. For sure, I'll need to remind two or three before we go." With that, she waded serenely back into the turmoil of the farmyard and left Nynaeve gaping.

"wɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ skɝt, "ju dɪd seɪ ʃi wɑz ə vɛɹi keɪpəbəl wʊmən."

"Well," Elayne said, brushing her skirt, "you did say she was a very capable woman."

"aɪ nɛvɝ sɛd ðæt," nɪneɪiv snæpt. "aɪ nɛvɝ sɛd 'vɛɹi' mf! wɛɹ dɪd maɪ hæt ɡɛt tə? θɪŋks ʃi noʊz ɛvɹiθɪŋ. əl weɪdʒɝ ʃi dʌznt noʊ ðæt!" ʃi flaʊnst ɔf ɪn ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən ðən æləz.

"I never said that," Nynaeve snapped. "I never said 'very' Hmmph! Where did my hat get to? Thinks she knows everything. I'll wager she doesn't know that!" She flounced off in a different direction than Alise.

ɪleɪn stɛɹɾ æftɝ hɝ. hɝ hæt? ʃi wʊɾə laɪk tə noʊ wɛɹ əɹ oʊn hæt hæd ɡɔn tə - ɪt wɑz ə bjuɾəfəl θɪŋ - bʌt ɹɪli! meɪbi biɪŋ ɪn ə sɝkəl wɝkɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə paʊɝ, juzɪŋ ən æŋɡɹil duɪŋ ɪt, hæɾ ənsɛɾəld nɪneɪivz wɪts tɛmpɝɛɹəli. ʃi stɪl fɛlt ə tʃɹaɪfəl ɑd, hɝsɛlf, əz ðoʊ ʃi kəd plʌk lɪɾəl bɪts ə seɪaɪdɑɹ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi hæɾ ʌðɝ mæɾɝz tə wɝi əbaʊt ɹaɪt ðɛn. laɪk biɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn dɪsɛndəd. fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd sin ɪn fɑlm, ðeɪ ɹɪli maɪt bɹɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd deɪmeɪn, əɹ mɔɹ, ən beɪst ɑn ðə lɪɾəl ɛɡwin wəd lɛt hɝsɛlf seɪ ʌv əɹ kæptɪvəɾi, moʊst ə ðoʊz wɪmən ɹɪli wəd bi iɡɝ tə hɛlp kɑlɝ ʌðɝz. ʃi sɛd ðət wʌt hæd tɝn əɹ stʌmək moʊs hæd bɪn ðə saɪɾ ə deɪmeɪn fɹəm sintʃæn læfɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ sʌldəm, fɔnɪŋ ən pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðɛm, wɛl-tʃɹeɪn haʊnz wɪð ðɛɹ əfɛkʃənət hænlɝz. ɛɡwin sɛd səm ə ðə wɪmən kɑlɝɾ ɪn fɑlm hæd bɪn ðət weɪ, tu. ɪt meɪɾ ɪleɪnz blʌd ɹʌn koʊld. ʃi wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ əm pʊt ðət liʃ ɑn hɝ! ən ʃi wəɾ əz sun lɛt ðə fɔɹseɪkən əv wʌt ʃi hæd faʊn əz ðə sintʃæn. ʃi wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə sɪstɝn, eɪvinhə əɾ əɹ saɪd bɹiðɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi wɑz hɝsɛlf.

Elayne stared after her. Her hat? She would have liked to know where her own hat had gone to - it was a beautiful thing - but really! Maybe being in a circle working that much of the Power, using an angreal doing it, had unsettled Nynaeve's wits temporarily. She still felt a trifle odd, herself, as though she could pluck little bits of saidar out of the air around her. In any case, she had other matters to worry about right then. Like being ready to get away before the Seanchan descended. From what she had seen in Falme, they really might bring a hundred damane, or more, and based on the little Egwene would let herself say of her captivity, most of those women really would be eager to help collar others. She said that what had turned her stomach most had been the sight of damane from Seanchan laughing with their sul'dam, fawning and playing with them, well-trained hounds with their affectionate handlers. Egwene said some of the women collared in Falme had been that way, too. It made Elayne's blood run cold. She would die before letting them put that leash on her! And she would as soon let the Forsaken have what she had found as the Seanchan. She went running to the cistern, Aviendha at her side breathing almost as hard as she was herself.

ɪt simd æləz ɹɪli hæd θɔɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ðoʊ. ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi stoʊɾ əweɪ ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ði ənsɝtʃt pænɪɝz ɹɪmeɪn fʊl ə dʒʌmbəld ɑdz ən ɛnz ən ðə laɪt nu wʌt, bʌt ðoʊz ʃi ən eɪvinhə hæɾ ɛmptid naʊ bʌlʒd wɪð kɔɹs sæks ə flaʊɝ ən sɔlt, binz ən lɛntəlz. ə hændfʊl ə steɪbəlfoʊk maɪndəd ðə pækænəməlz ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ əbaʊt wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmz fʊl. duɪŋ æləzəz bɪɾɪŋ, noʊ daʊt. ivən bɝdʒɪt wɛn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɔf ət ðə wʊmənz kɔl wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɹufəl ɡɹɪn!

It seemed Alise really had thought of everything, though. The ter'angreal were already stowed away on the packhorses. The unsearched panniers remained full of jumbled odds and ends and the Light knew what, but those she and Aviendha had emptied now bulged with coarse sacks of flour and salt, beans and lentils. A handful of stablefolk minded the packanimals instead of running about with their arms full. Doing Alise's bidding, no doubt. Even Birgitte went trotting off at the woman's call with no more than a rueful grin!

ɪleɪn lɪftəd kænvəs kʌvɝz tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil əz wɛl əz ʃi kəd wɪθaʊɾ ənloʊɾɪŋ əm əɡɛn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əpɪɹd tə bi ðɛɹ, ə bɪt tʌmbəl təɡɛðɝ ɪn tu pænɪɝz, nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə fɪl ðɛm, bʌt nʌθɪŋ bɹoʊkən. nɑt ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf kəd bɹeɪk moʊs tɛɹæŋɡɹil, jɛɾ ivən soʊ. . . .

Elayne lifted canvas covers to examine the ter'angreal as well as she could without unloading them again. Everything appeared to be there, a bit tumbled together in two panniers, not enough to fill them, but nothing broken. Not that anything short of the One Power itself could break most ter'angreal, yet even so. . . .

eɪvinhə tʊk ə sit kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, blɑɾɪŋ swɛt fɹəm əɹ feɪs wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ, pleɪn lɪnən hæŋkɝtʃɪf ðət sim vɛɹi mʌtʃ əɾ ɑdz wɪð əɹ pɹɪɾi sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs. ivən ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ wɪɹinəs. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt, ɪleɪn? jə saʊn laɪk nɪneɪiv. ðɪs æləz əz oʊnli seɪvd əs ðə tʃɹʌbəl ə pækɪŋ ðoʊz θɪŋz aʊɝsɛlvz."

Aviendha took a seat cross-legged on the ground, blotting sweat from her face with a large, plain linen handkerchief that seemed very much at odds with her pretty silk riding dress. Even she was beginning to show weariness. "What are you muttering about, Elayne? You sound like Nynaeve. This Alise has only saved us the trouble of packing those things ourselves."

ɪleɪn kʌlɝd feɪnli. ʃi hæd nɑt mɛn tə spik əlaʊd. "aɪ dʒʌs doʊnt wɑn ɛniwʌn hænlɪŋ əm u dʌznt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ, eɪvinhə." səm tɛɹæŋɡɹil kəd tʃɹɪɡɝ ivən fəɹ pipəl əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl, ɪf ðeɪ dɪd ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn hænlɪŋ ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ hɝz! ðə hɔl wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæn ðiz oʊvɝ tə səm ʌðɝ sɪstɝ dʒʌs kəz ʃi wɑz oʊldɝ ən mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiənst, əɹ haɪɾ əm əweɪ kəz stʌɾiɪŋ tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɑz tu deɪnʒɝəs. wɪð ðɪs mɛni ɪɡzæmpəlz tə stʌɾi, meɪbi ʃi kəd faɪnəli fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə meɪk tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət wɝkt ɛvɹi taɪm; ðəɹ hæd bɪn fɑɹ tu mɛni feɪljɝz ən hæf-səksɛsəz. "ðeɪ nid sʌmwʌn u noʊz wʌt ʃiz duɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, læʃɪŋ ðə stɪf kænvəs bæk ɪn pleɪs.

Elayne colored faintly. She had not meant to speak aloud. "I just don't want anyone handling them who doesn't know what they are doing, Aviendha." Some ter'angreal could trigger even for people unable to channel, if they did the wrong thing, but the truth was, she did not want anyone handling them. They were hers! The Hall was not going to hand these over to some other sister just because she was older and more experienced, or hide them away because studying ter'angreal was too dangerous. With this many examples to study, maybe she could finally figure out how to make ter'angreal that worked every time; there had been far too many failures and half-successes. "They need someone who knows what she's doing," she said, lashing the stiff canvas back in place.

ɔɹɾɝ bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ aʊɾ ə pændɪmoʊniəm mɔɹ ɹæpədli ðən ɪleɪn ɪkspɛktəd, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz fæst əz ʃi kəɾ əv wɪʃt. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, nʌθɪŋ sloʊɝ ðən ɪnstəntæniəs cʊɾə mætʃt əɹ wɪʃɪz. əneɪbəl tə kip əɹ aɪz ɔf ðə skaɪ, ʃi sɛn kɛɝin ɹʌnɪŋ bæk tə ðə tɑp ə ðə hɪl tə wɑtʃ təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. ðə stɑki ɡɹin ɡɹʌmbəld ə bɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ kɝtsiɪŋ, ən ivən fɹaʊn ət ðə kɪnswɪmən dæʃɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz ɪf ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə sədʒɛstɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm ɪnstɛd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑntəd sʌmwʌn u wəd nɑt feɪn ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv "ʃæɾoʊzpɔn" əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, ən kɛɝin stʊd loʊəst əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz. æɾɪliz ən vændin bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ɪspæn bɪtwin ðɛm, fɝmli ʃildɪɾ ən ðə lɛðɝ sæk bæk oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. ʃi wɔkt kwaɪɾ izəli, ən nʌθɪŋ vɪzəbəl sɛd ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl hæd bɪn dʌn tə hɝ, ɪksɛpt. . . . ɪspæn kɛpt əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst, nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪz ðə sæk fəɹ ə pik, ən wən ʃi wɑz bustɪɾ ɪndə ə sæɾəl, ʃi hɛld aʊɾ əɹ ɹɪsts tə bi kɔɹɾəd tə ðə pɑməl wɪθaʊt biɪŋ toʊld. ɪf ʃi wɑz ðəɾ əmɛnəbəl, pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm hɝ. ɪleɪn dʒʌs dɪd nɑt wɑnə kɑntəmpleɪt haʊ ðə lɝnɪŋ maɪɾ əv bɪn ətʃivd.

Order began to appear out of pandemonium more rapidly than Elayne expected, though not as fast as she could have wished. Of course, she admitted reluctantly, nothing slower than instantaneous could have matched her wishes. Unable to keep her eyes off the sky, she sent Careane running back to the top of the hill to watch toward Ebou Dar. The stocky Green grumbled a bit under her breath before curtsying, and even frowned at the Kinswomen dashing about as if on the point of suggesting one of them instead, but Elayne wanted someone who would not faint at the sight of "Shadowspawn" approaching, and Careane stood lowest among the sisters. Adeleas and Vandene brought out Ispan between them, firmly shielded and the leather sack back over her head. She walked quite easily, and nothing visible said that anything at all had been done to her, except. . . . Ispan kept her hands folded at her waist, never so much as trying to raise the sack for a peek, and when she was boosted into a saddle, she held out her wrists to be corded to the pommel without being told. If she was that amenable, perhaps they had learned something from her. Elayne just did not want to contemplate how the learning might have been achieved.

ðəɹ wɝ . . . bʌmps, ʌv kɔɹs, ʌv sɔɹts, ivən wɪð wʌt maɪt bi ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm. wʌt ʃʊɹli wɑz ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm. nɪneɪiv ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ blu-plum hæt bæk wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ə bʌmp, ðoʊ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs tɝn ɪndə wʌn; æləz hæd faʊn ɪt, ən hændəɾ ɪt bæk tɛlɪŋ nɪneɪiv ʃi niɾəd tə ʃild əɹ feɪs fɹəm ðə sʌn ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə kip ðət smuð pɹɪɾi skɪn. ən oʊpənməð nɪneɪiv wɑtʃt ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən hɝi ɔf tə dil wɪð wʌn ə ðə numɝəs smɔl pɹɑbləmz, ðən ɑstənteɪʃəsli ʃʌv ðə hæɾ ʌndɝ ə stʃɹæp ə hɝ sæɾəlbæɡz.

There were . . . bumps, of course, of sorts, even with what might be rushing toward them. What surely was rushing toward them. Nynaeve getting her blue-plumed hat back was not really a bump, though it almost turned into one; Alise had found it, and handed it back telling Nynaeve she needed to shield her face from the sun if she wanted to keep that smooth pretty skin. An openmouthed Nynaeve watched the graying woman hurry off to deal with one of the numerous small problems, then ostentatiously shoved the hat under a strap of her saddlebags.

fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ nɪneɪiv sɛɾ əbaʊt flæɾənɪŋ ðə ɹil bʌmps, bʌɾ æləz wɑz nɪɹli ɔlweɪz ðəɹ fɝst, ən wɛɹ æləz mɛɾ ə bʌmp, ðə bʌmp flæɾənd ɪtsɛlf. sɛvɹəl noʊbəlwɪmən dɪmændəd hɛlp pækɪŋ ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz, oʊnli tə bi ɪnfɔɹmd ɪn noʊ ənsɝɾən tɝmz ðət ʃi hæd mɛnt wʌt ʃi sɛɾ ən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɑp tə ɪt, ðeɪ kəd lɪv ɪn wʌt ðeɪ stʊɾ ɪn. ðeɪ hɑpt. sʌm, ən nɑɾ oʊnli noʊbəlz, tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ maɪnz əbaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ wən ðeɪ lɝn ðə dɛstəneɪʃən wɑz ændɝ, ən wɝ lɪɾɝəli tʃeɪst əweɪ. əfʊt, ən toʊl tə kip ɹʌnɪŋ əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kʊd. ɛvɹi hɔɹs wɑz niɾəd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd tə bi wɛl əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn əpɪɹd; ət ðə vɛɹi lis ðeɪ kəd bi ɪkspɛktəd tə pʊɾ ɛniwʌn nɪɹ ðə fɑɹm tə ðə kwɛstʃən. əz ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪkspɛktəd, nɪneɪiv ɡɑɾ ɪndə ə ʃaʊɾɪŋ mætʃ wɪð ɹɪneɪl oʊvɝ ðə boʊl, ən ðə tɝɾəl tɑlɑn hæd juzd, wɪtʃ ɹɪneɪl əpɛɹənli hæd tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ sæʃ. hɑɹdli hæd ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə steɪdʒ ʌv weɪvɪŋ ɑɹmz, haʊɛvɝ, ðən æləz wɑz ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ən ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ ðə boʊl wɑz bæk ɪn sɝaɪðəz kɛɹ ən ðə tɝɾəl ɪn mɛɝɪlɪlz. fɑloʊɪŋ wɪtʃ, ɪleɪn wɑz tʃɹiɾəd tə ðə saɪɾ ʌv æləz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ʌndɝ ði əstɑnɪʃt noʊz ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, dɪlɪvɝɪŋ ə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə θɛf ðət lɛft ɹɪneɪl spləɾɝɪŋ ɪndɪɡnənli. nɪneɪiv dɪɾ ə lɪɾəl spləɾɝɪŋ, tu, stɔkɪŋ əweɪ ɛmpti-hændəd, jɛɾ ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛniwʌn lʊk soʊ fɝlɔɹn.

From the beginning Nynaeve set about flattening the real bumps, but Alise was nearly always there first, and where Alise met a bump, the bump flattened itself. Several noblewomen demanded help packing their belongings, only to be informed in no uncertain terms that she had meant what she said and if they did not hop to it, they could live in what they stood in. They hopped. Some, and not only nobles, changed their minds about going when they learned the destination was Andor, and were literally chased away. Afoot, and told to keep running as long as they could. Every horse was needed, but they had to be well away before the Seanchan appeared; at the very least they could be expected to put anyone near the farm to the question. As should have been expected, Nynaeve got into a shouting match with Renaile over the Bowl, and the turtle Talaan had used, which Renaile apparently had tucked behind her sash. Hardly had they reached the stage of waving arms, however, than Alise was right there, and in short order the Bowl was back in Sareitha's care and the turtle in Merilille's. Following which, Elayne was treated to the sight of Alise shaking her finger under the astonished nose of the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, delivering a tongue-lashing on the subject of theft that left Renaile spluttering indignantly. Nynaeve did a little spluttering, too, stalking away empty-handed, yet Elayne thought she had never seen anyone look so forlorn.

ɔl ɪn ɔl, ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk vɛɹi lɔŋ, ðoʊ. ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ wɪmən u hæd bɪn ət ðə fɑɹm ɡæðɝɾ ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl - ən ʌv æləz, hu kɛɹfəli noʊɾəd ðə læs tɛn tə ɝaɪv, ɔl bʌt tu ɪn faɪn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlks, nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɪleɪnz. dɛfənətli nɑt kɪnswɪmən. ɪleɪn fɛlt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ ɹɪli wəd də ðə wɑʃɪŋ-ʌp ɛniweɪ; æləz wəd nɑt lɛɾ ə lɪɾəl θɪŋ laɪk noʊbəl bɝθ stæn ɪn əɹ weɪ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz laɪn ʌp wɪð ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli saɪlən ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹɪneɪl, hu mʌɾɝd ɪmpɹəkeɪʃənz wɛnɛvɝ ʃi sɔ æləz. kɛɝin wɑz sʌmən bæk fɹəm ðə hɪltɑp. ðə wɔɹɾɝz bɹɔt ðə sɪstɝz ðɛɹ maʊns. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn kɛpt ən aɪ ɑn ðə skaɪ, ən seɪaɪdɑɹ meɪd heɪloʊz ɝaʊn ɔl ə ði oʊldɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən moʊst ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. ɝaʊn ə fju ʌv ðə kɪn, əz wɛl.

All in all, it did not take very long, though. The remaining women who had been at the farm gathered under the watchful eyes of the Knitting Circle - and of Alise, who carefully noted the last ten to arrive, all but two in fine embroidered silks, not much different from Elayne's. Definitely not Kinswomen. Elayne felt sure they really would do the washing-up anyway; Alise would not let a little thing like noble birth stand in her way. The Windfinders lined up with their horses, surprisingly silent except for Renaile, who muttered imprecations whenever she saw Alise. Careane was summoned back from the hilltop. The Warders brought the sisters their mounts. Almost everyone kept an eye on the sky, and saidar made halos around all of the older Aes Sedai and most of the Windfinders. Around a few of the Kin, as well.

liɾɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ tə ðə hɛɾ ə ðə laɪn, ət ðə sɪstɝn, nɪneɪiv fɪŋɡɝd ði æŋɡɹil stɪl ɑn əɹ hæn əz ɪf ʃi wɝ gɑnə bi ðə wʌn tə meɪk ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɹɪdɪkjələs əz ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə maɪt bi. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd wɑʃt əɹ feɪs - ən dɑn əɹ hæt; stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɔl θɪŋz kənsɪɾɝd - ʃi stɪl tɑɾɝd wɛnɛvɝ əɹ sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl slɪpt. læn steɪd pɹæktəkli əɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, stoʊn-feɪst əz ɔlweɪz, bʌɾ ɪf ɛvɝ ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn ɹɛɾi tə kætʃ ə wʊmən wən ʃi fɛl, ɪt wɑz hi. ivən wɪð ðə bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz, nɪneɪiv maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ ɪnʌf tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ʃi hæd bɪn dæʃɪŋ əbaʊt ðə fɑɹm ɛvɝ sɪns ðeɪ fɝst ɝaɪvd; ɪleɪn hæd spɛn ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl taɪm hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ ɹaɪt wɛɹ ðeɪ naʊ stʊd. ʃi nu ðət spɑt. nɪneɪiv skaʊl sʌlkəli wən ɪleɪn ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, bʌɾ ət list ʃi hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə seɪ nʌθɪŋ.

Leading her mare to the head of the line, at the cistern, Nynaeve fingered the angreal still on her hand as if she were going to be the one to make the gateway, ridiculous as the very idea might be. For one thing, though she had washed her face - and donned her hat; strangely, all things considered - she still tottered whenever her self-control slipped. Lan stayed practically at her shoulder, stone-faced as always, but if ever there was a man ready to catch a woman when she fell, it was he. Even with the bracelet-and-rings, Nynaeve might not be able to manage enough to weave a gateway. More important, she had been dashing about the farm ever since they first arrived; Elayne had spent a considerable time holding saidar right where they now stood. She knew that spot. Nynaeve scowled sulkily when Elayne embraced the Source, but at least she had sense enough to say nothing.

ɹaɪt fɹəm ðə fɝst ɪleɪn wɪʃt ðət ʃi hæɾ æskt eɪvinhə fəɹ ðə wʊmən-kloʊkt-ɪn-hɝ-oʊn-hɛɹ; ʃi wɑz wɪɹi, tu, ən ɔl ðə seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃi kəd dʒɹɔ wɑz bɛɹli ɪnʌf tə fɔɹm ðə wiv soʊ ɪt wəd wɝk. ðə floʊz weɪvɝɾ ɪn əɹ ɡɹæsp ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə twɪs fɹi, ðən snæpt ɪndə pleɪs soʊ sʌɾənli ðət ʃi dʒʌmpt; tʃænəlɪŋ wən jə wɝ taɪɝd wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk ʌðɝ taɪmz, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə wɝst ɛvɝ. ət lis ðə fəmɪljɝ vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə sɪlvɝ əpɪɹɾ əz ɪt ʃʊd, ən waɪɾənd ɪndə ən oʊpənɪŋ ɹaɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə sɪstɝn. ən oʊpənɪŋ noʊ bɪɡɝ ðən ðə wʌn eɪvinhə hæd meɪd, ən ət ðæt, ɪleɪn wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl ɪt wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə fɪɾ ə hɔɹs θɹu. ət ðə læst, ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn sɝɾən ɪt wəd bi. ɡæsps ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə kɪnswɪmən, siɪŋ ə vju ʌv ən ʌplən mɛdoʊ sʌɾənli stændɪŋ bɪtwin əm ən ðə fəmɪljɝ ɡɹeɪ bʌlk ə ðə sɪstɝn.

Right from the first Elayne wished that she had asked Aviendha for the woman-cloaked-in-her-own-hair; she was weary, too, and all the saidar she could draw was barely enough to form the weave so it would work. The flows wavered in her grasp almost as if trying to twist free, then snapped into place so suddenly that she jumped; channeling when you were tired was not at all like other times, but this was the worst ever. At least the familiar vertical slash of silver appeared as it should, and widened into an opening right alongside the cistern. An opening no bigger than the one Aviendha had made, and at that, Elayne was grateful it was large enough to fit a horse through. At the last, she had not been certain it would be. Gasps rose from the Kinswomen, seeing a view of an upland meadow suddenly standing between them and the familiar gray bulk of the cistern.

"ju ʃʊɾə lemi tʃɹaɪ," nɪneɪiv sɛd sɔfli. sɔfli, bʌt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp pɔɪn ivən soʊ. "ju nɪɹli fʌbd ɪɾ ɔltəɡɛðɝ."

"You should have let me try," Nynaeve said softly. Softly, but with a sharp point even so. "You nearly fubbed it altogether."

eɪvinhə ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə flæt lʊk ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪleɪn ɡɹæb əɹ ɑɹm. ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪnd nɪɹ-sɪstɝz, ðə mɔɹ ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ʃi hæd tə dɪfɛn ɪleɪnz ɑnɝ; ɪf ðeɪ dɪd bɪkʌm fɝst-sɪstɝz, ɪleɪn kəd si hævɪŋ tə kip əɹ əweɪ fɹəm nɪneɪiv, ən bɝdʒɪt, kəmplitli!

Aviendha gave Nynaeve a flat look that almost made Elayne grab her arm. The longer they remained near-sisters, the more she seemed to think she had to defend Elayne's honor; if they did become first-sisters, Elayne could see having to keep her away from Nynaeve, and Birgitte, completely!

"ɪts dʌn, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli. "ðæts ɔl ðət kaʊns." nɪneɪiv dɝɛktəɾ ə flæt lʊk əɾ əɹ ən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə deɪ biɪŋ pɹɪkli, əz ɪf ɪleɪn wɝ ðə wʌn ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ snæpɪʃ saɪd.

"It's done, Nynaeve," she said quickly. "That's all that counts." Nynaeve directed a flat look at her and muttered something about the day being prickly, as if Elayne were the one showing her snappish side.

bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðə fɝs θɹu, ɡɹɪnɪŋ ɪmpuɾəntli ət læn, liɾɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs wɪð əɹ baʊ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn əɹ ʌðɝ hænd. ɪleɪn kəd sɛns iɡɝnəs ɪn hɝ, ə tʌtʃ ə sæɾəsfækʃən, pɝhæps ðət ðɪs taɪm ʃi hæd ðə lɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə læn - ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə bɪɾ ə ɹaɪvəlɹi bɪtwin wɔɹɾɝz - ən ə smɔl mɛʒɝ ʌv wɛɹinɪs. vɛɹi smɔl. ɪleɪn nu ðət mɛdoʊ wɛl; ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd tɔɾ əɹ tə ɹaɪd nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ. əbaʊt faɪv maɪlz oʊvɝ ðoʊz fɝst spɑɹsli tʃɹid hɪlz leɪ ðə mænɝ haʊs ʌv wʌn ə hɝ mʌðɝz ɪsteɪts. wʌn ə hɝ ɪsteɪts; ʃi hæd tə ɡɛt juz tə ðæt. ðə sɛvən fæmliz u tɛndəd ðə haʊs ən ɪts ɡɹaʊnz wəd bi ði oʊnli pipəl fəɹ hæf ə deɪz dʒɝni ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən.

Birgitte was the first through, grinning impudently at Lan, leading her horse with her bow already in her other hand. Elayne could sense eagerness in her, a touch of satisfaction, perhaps that this time she had the lead instead of Lan - there was always a bit of rivalry between Warders - and a small measure of wariness. Very small. Elayne knew that meadow well; Gareth Bryne had taught her to ride not far from there. About five miles over those first sparsely treed hills lay the manor house of one of her mother's estates. One of her estates; she had to get used to that. The seven families who tended the house and its grounds would be the only people for half a day's journey in any direction.

ɪleɪn hæd tʃoʊzən ðət dɛstəneɪʃən kəz ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn tu wiks fɹəm ðɛɹ. ən kəz ði ɪsteɪt wɑz soʊ aɪsəleɪɾəd, ʃi maɪt bi ɛntɝɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn nu ʃi wɑz ɪn ændɝ. ðət kəd bi ə vɛɹi nɛsəsɛɹi pɹikɔʃən; ət vɛɹiəs taɪmz ɪn ændɝz hɪstɝi, ɹaɪvəlz fəɹ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn hæd bɪn kɛpt əz "ɡɛsts" əntɪl ðeɪ ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃt ðɛɹ kleɪmz. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd kɛp tu, əntɪl ʃi tʊk ðə θɹoʊn. wɪð lʌk, ʃi kəɾ əv ə sɑləd beɪs ɪstæblɪʃt baɪ ðə taɪm ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz ɝaɪvd.

Elayne had chosen that destination because they could reach Caemlyn in two weeks from there. And because the estate was so isolated, she might be entering Caemlyn before anyone knew she was in Andor. That could be a very necessary precaution; at various times in Andor's history, rivals for the Rose Crown had been kept as "guests" until they relinquished their claims. Her mother had kept two, until she took the throne. With luck, she could have a solid base established by the time Egwene and the others arrived.

læn tʊk mændɑɹb ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn bɝdʒɪts bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ, ən nɪneɪiv lɝtʃt əz ɪf tə ɹʌʃ æftɝ ðə blæk wɔɹhɔɹs, ðən pʊl hɝsɛlf ʌp ʃɔɹt wɪð ə lɛvəl stɛɹ ðət dɛɹɾ ɪleɪn tə seɪ ə wɝd. fɪdlɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli wɪð əɹ ɹeɪnz, ʃi meɪɾ ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt tə lʊk ɛniwɛɹ ɪksɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ æftɝ læn. hɝ lɪps muvd. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz kaʊntɪŋ.

Lan took Mandarb right behind Birgitte's brown gelding, and Nynaeve lurched as if to rush after the black warhorse, then pulled herself up short with a level stare that dared Elayne to say a word. Fiddling furiously with her reins, she made a visible effort to look anywhere except through the gateway after Lan. Her lips moved. After a moment, Elayne realized that she was counting.

"nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli, "wi ɹɪli doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ - "

"Nynaeve," she said quietly, "we really don't have time for - "

"muv əlɔŋ," æləz kɔl fɹəm ðə ɹɪɹ, ðə saʊn ə hɝ hænz klæpɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪŋ kɹæk. "noʊ pʊʃɪŋ əɹ ʃʌvɪŋ, naʊ, bʌɾ əl əv noʊ læɡɝdz iðɝ! muv əlɔŋ."

"Move along," Alise called from the rear, the sound of her hands clapping a sharp punctuating crack. "No pushing or shoving, now, but I'll have no laggards either! Move along."

nɪneɪivz hɛd swʌŋ waɪldli, peɪn ɪndɪsɪʒən peɪntɪŋ əɹ feɪs. fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ waɪd hæt, ə fju ʌv ɪts blu plumz bɹoʊkən ən dʒɹupɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ pʊlɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ. "oʊ, ðət ɡoʊt-kɪsɪŋ oʊld . . . !" ʃi ɡɹaʊld, ðə ɹɛs lɔst əz ʃi dʒɹæɡd əɹ mɛɹ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ɪleɪn snɪft. ən nɪneɪiv hæd ðə nɝv tə spik tə ɛnibəɾi əbaʊt ðɛɹ læŋɡwədʒ! ʃi wɪʃt ʃi cʊɾə hɝd ðə ɹɛst, ðoʊ; ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi nu ðə fɝs bɪt.

Nynaeve's head swung wildly, pained indecision painting her face. For some reason she touched her wide hat, a few of its blue plumes broken and drooping, before pulling her hand away. "Oh, that goat-kissing old . . . !" she growled, the rest lost as she dragged her mare through the gateway. Elayne sniffed. And Nynaeve had the nerve to speak to anybody about their language! She wished she could have heard the rest, though; she already knew the first bit.

æləz kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ ɝdʒɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ ɹɪli dɪd nɑt sim tə bi mʌtʃ niɾ æftɝ ðə fɝst. ivən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hɝid, ɡlænsɪŋ wɝidli oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ət ðə skaɪ. ivən ɹɪneɪl, hu mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ æləz ðəɾ ɪleɪn noʊɾəd ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. ðoʊ kɔlɪŋ sʌmwʌn "ə fɪʃ-lʌvɪŋ skævənʒɝ" dɪd sim ɹæðɝ maɪld. ʃi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd ðə si foʊk tə it fɪʃ ɔl ðə taɪm.

Alise continued her urging, but there really did not seem to be much need after the first. Even the Windfinders hurried, glancing worriedly over their shoulders at the sky. Even Renaile, who mumbled something about Alise that Elayne noted in the back of her head. Though calling someone "a fish-loving scavenger" did seem rather mild. She would have expected the Sea Folk to eat fish all the time.

æləz hɝsɛlf bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə vɛɹi ɹɪɹ, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz, əz ɪf tə hɝɾ ivən ðə pækhɔɹsɪz əlɔŋ. ʃi pɔz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hæn ɪleɪn əɹ ɡɹin-plum hæt. "jul wɑnə kip ðə sʌn ɔf ðət swit feɪs ə jʊɹz," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə smaɪl. "sʌtʃ ə pɹɪɾi ɡɝl. noʊ nid tə tɝn tə lɛðɝ bɪfɔɹ jəɹ taɪm."

Alise herself brought up the very rear, except for the remaining Warders, as if to herd even the packhorses along. She paused long enough to hand Elayne her green-plumed hat. "You'll want to keep the sun off that sweet face of yours," she said with a smile. "Such a pretty girl. No need to turn to leather before your time."

eɪvinhə, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd nɪɹbaɪ, fɛl oʊvɝ bækwɝɾ ən kɪkt əɹ hilz læfɪŋ.

Aviendha, sitting on the ground nearby, fell over backward and kicked her heels laughing.

"aɪ θɪŋk əl æsk əɹ tə faɪn jə ə hæt. wɪð lɑts ə plumz, ən bɪɡ baʊz," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn dʌlsət toʊnz bɪfɔɹ kwɪkli fɑloʊɪŋ ðə kɪnswʊmən. ðət sɝɾənli kʌɾ ɔf eɪvinhəz læftɝ.

"I think I'll ask her to find you a hat. With lots of plumes, and big bows," Elayne said in dulcet tones before quickly following the Kinswoman. That certainly cut off Aviendha's laughter.

ðə dʒɛnli ɹoʊlɪŋ mɛdoʊ wɑz bɹɔɾ ən nɪɹli ə maɪl lɔŋ, sɝaʊndəd baɪ hɪlz tɔlɝ ðən ðoʊz ʃi hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ən baɪ tʃɹiz ʃi nu, oʊk ən paɪn ən blækwʊd, saʊɝɡəm ən lɛðɝlif ən fɝ, θɪk fɔɹəst wɪð ɡʊd, tɔl tɪmbɝ tə saʊθ ən wɛst ən ist, ðoʊ ðəɹ maɪt nɑt bi ɛni kʌɾɪŋ ðɪs jɪɹ. moʊst ə ðə mɔɹ skæɾɝd tʃɹiz tə ðə nɔɹθ, təwɔɹd ðə mænɝ, wɝ bɛɾɝ suɾəd fəɹ faɪɝwʊd. smɔl ɡɹeɪ boʊldɝz dɑɾəd ðə θɪk bɹaʊn ɡɹæs hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, ən nɑɾ ivən ə wɪðɝd stɔk mɑɹk ðə dɛθ ʌv ə waɪldflaʊɝ. ðət wɑz nɑt soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə saʊθ.

The gently rolling meadow was broad and nearly a mile long, surrounded by hills taller than those she had left behind, and by trees she knew, oak and pine and blackwood, sourgum and leatherleaf and fir, thick forest with good, tall timber to south and west and east, though there might not be any cutting this year. Most of the more scattered trees to the north, toward the manor, were better suited for firewood. Small gray boulders dotted the thick brown grass here and there, and not even a withered stalk marked the death of a wildflower. That was not so different from the south.

fəɹ wʌns nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt piɹɪŋ ət ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹisaɪd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn læn. hi ən bɝdʒɪt wəd nɑt bi ɡɔn lɔŋ ɛniweɪ, nɑt hɪɹ. ɪnstɛd ʃi stʃɹoʊd bɹɪskli əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz, ɔɹɾɝɪŋ pipəl tə maʊn ɪn ə laʊd, kəmændɪŋ vɔɪs, tʃɪviɪŋ ðə sɝvəns wɪð ðə pæk ænəməlz, kɝtli tɛlɪŋ səm ə ðə kɪnswɪmən u hæd noʊ hɔɹsəz ðəɾ ɛni tʃaɪl kəd wɔk faɪv maɪlz, ʃaʊɾɪŋ əɾ ə slɛndɝ ɔltɑɹən noʊbəlwʊmən wɪð ə skɑɹ ɑn əɹ tʃik ən kæɹiɪŋ ə bʌndəl nɪɹli əz bɪɡ əz hɝsɛlf ðəɾ ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ful ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ɔl ə hɝ dʒɹɛsəz ðən ʃi kəd kæɹi ðɛm. æləz hæd ɡæðɝd ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɝaʊn əɹ ən wɑz ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ əm ɑn haʊ tə maʊn ə hɔɹs. fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ðeɪ æktʃəli  əpɪɹd tə bi peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən. nɪneɪiv ɡlænst əɹ weɪ ən sim pliz tə si æləz stændɪŋ ɪn wʌn spɑt. əntɪl æləz smaɪld ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋli ən moʊʃən əɹ tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ.

For once Nynaeve was not peering at the surrounding countryside trying to find Lan. He and Birgitte would not be gone long anyway, not here. Instead she strode briskly among the horses, ordering people to mount in a loud, commanding voice, chivvying the servants with the pack animals, curtly telling some of the Kinswomen who had no horses that any child could walk five miles, shouting at a slender Altaran noblewoman with a scar on her cheek and carrying a bundle nearly as big as herself that if she had been fool enough to bring all of her dresses then she could carry them. Alise had gathered the Atha'an Miere around her and was instructing them on how to mount a horse. For a wonder, they actually appeared to be paying attention. Nynaeve glanced her way and seemed pleased to see Alise standing in one spot. Until Alise smiled encouragingly and motioned her to go on with what she was doing.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt nɪneɪiv stʊd stɑk-stɪl, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wʊmən. ðən ʃi keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡɹæs tə ɪleɪn. ɹitʃɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ hæt wɪð boʊθ hænz, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪt θɹu hɝ læʃɪz bɪfɔɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ɪɾ ə twɪtʃ stʃɹeɪt. "aɪl dʒʌs lɛɾ əɹ teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðɪs taɪm," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə səspɪʃəsli ɹizənəbəl toʊn. "wil dʒʌst si haʊ wɛl ʃi dʌz wɪð ðoʊz . . . si foʊk. jɛs, wi wɪl." tu ɹizənəbəl ə toʊn baɪ hæf. əbɹʌpli ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə stɪl-oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ. "waɪ ɑɹ jə hoʊldɪŋ ɪt? lɛt ɡoʊ." eɪvinhə wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, tu.

For an instant Nynaeve stood stock-still, staring at the woman. Then she came striding through the grass to Elayne. Reaching up to her hat with both hands, she hesitated, glowering up at it through her lashes before giving it a twitch straight. "I'll just let her take care of everything this time," she said in a suspiciously reasonable tone. "We'll just see how well she does with those . . . Sea Folk. Yes, we will." Too reasonable a tone by half. Abruptly she frowned at the still-open gateway. "Why are you holding it? Let go." Aviendha was frowning, too.

ɪleɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi hæd θɔɾ əbaʊt ðɪs, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ, bʌt nɪneɪiv wəd tʃɹaɪ tə ɑɹɡju hɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ. θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd stʊɾ ɛmpti, ivən ðə tʃɪkənz faɪnəli fɹaɪɾənd əweɪ baɪ ðə hʌbəb, jɛt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪt fɪld ʌp əɡɛn? ʃi stʌɾid əɹ wiv, mɛldəd təɡɛðɝ soʊ snʌɡli ðəɾ oʊnli ə fju θɹɛdz ɹɪmeɪn dɪstɪŋkt. ʃi kəd si ɛvɹi floʊ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz fju, ðeɪ əpɪɹɾ ɪnsəpɝəbli kəmbaɪnd. "teɪk ɛvɹiwʌn tə ðə mænɝ haʊs, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛd. ðə sʌn dɪd nɑɾ əv vɛɹi mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ tə fɔl; pɝhæps tu aʊɝz ə laɪt ɹɪmeɪnd. "mæstɝ hɔɹnwɛl wɪl bi sɝpɹaɪzd ət soʊ mɛni vɪzəɾɝz ɝaɪvɪŋ ət dɑɹk, bʌt tɛl ɪm jəɹ ɡɛsts ə ðə ɡɝl u kɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɛdbɝd wɪð ðə bɹoʊkən wɪŋ; hɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. əl bi əlɔŋ əz sun əz aɪ kæn."

Elayne drew a deep breath. She had thought about this, and there was no other way, but Nynaeve would try to argue her out of it, and there was no time for arguing. Through the gateway, the farmyard stood empty, even the chickens finally frightened away by the hubbub, yet how long before it filled up again? She studied her weave, melded together so snugly that only a few threads remained distinct. She could see every flow, of course, but except for those few, they appeared inseparably combined. "Take everyone to the manor house, Nynaeve," she said. The sun did not have very much farther to fall; perhaps two hours of light remained. "Master Hornwell will be surprised at so many visitors arriving at dark, but tell him you're guests of the girl who cried over the redbird with the broken wing; he'll remember that. I will be along as soon as I can."

"ɪleɪn," eɪvinhə bɪɡæn ɪn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli æŋkʃəs vɔɪs, ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm, nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "dʒʌst wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jəɹ - "

"Elayne," Aviendha began in a surprisingly anxious voice, and at the same time, Nynaeve said sharply, "Just what do you think you're - "

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə stɑp ɪt. ɪleɪn plʌkt wʌn ə ðə dɪsɝnəbəl θɹɛdz fɹi ʌv ðə wiv; ɪt weɪvɝɾ ən fleɪld laɪk ə lɪvɪŋ tɛntəkəl; ɪt fʌzd ən spləɾɝd, taɪni flʌfs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ ɔf ən feɪɾɪŋ əweɪ. ʃi hæd nɑt noʊɾəst ðət wən eɪvinhə ənmeɪɾ əɹ wiv, bʌt ʃi hæɾ oʊnli sin ðə teɪl ə ðæt, ɹɪli. "ɡoʊ ɑn," ʃi toʊl nɪneɪiv. "aɪl weɪt fəɹ ðə ɹɛst əntɪl jə ɑɹ ɔl aʊɾ ə saɪt." nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ aʊt, hɝ dʒɔ hæŋɪŋ. "ɪɾ əz tə bi dʌn," ɪleɪn saɪd. "ðə sintʃæn wɪl bi ət ðə fɑɹm ɪn aʊɝz, fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ivən ɪf ðeɪ weɪɾ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ, wʌɾ ɪf wʌn ə ðə deɪmeɪn əz ðə tælən tə ɹid ɹɛzəduz? nɪneɪiv, aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv tʃɹævlɪŋ tə ðə sintʃæn. aɪ woʊnt!"

There was only one way to stop it. Elayne plucked one of the discernible threads free of the weave; it wavered and flailed like a living tentacle; it fuzzed and spluttered, tiny fluffs of saidar breaking off and fading away. She had not noticed that when Aviendha unmade her weave, but she had only seen the tail of that, really. "Go on," she told Nynaeve. "I'll wait for the rest until you are all out of sight." Nynaeve stared out, her jaw hanging. "It has to be done," Elayne sighed. "The Seanchan will be at the farm in hours, for sure. Even if they wait until tomorrow, what if one of the damane has the Talent to read residues? Nynaeve, I won't give Traveling to the Seanchan. I won't!"

nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊl sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn ðət mʌst əv bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli pɪθi, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ hɝ toʊn. "wɛl, aɪ woʊn lɛt jə bɝn jɝsɛlf aʊt!" ʃi sɛɾ əlaʊd. "naʊ, pʊt ðət bæk! bɪfɔɹ ðə hoʊl θɪŋ ɪksploʊdz ðə weɪ vændin sɛd. jə kəd kɪl ɔl ʌv ʌs!"

Nynaeve growled something under her breath about the Seanchan that must have been particularly pithy, judging by her tone. "Well, I won't let you burn yourself out!" she said aloud. "Now, put that back! Before the whole thing explodes the way Vandene said. You could kill all of us!"

"ɪt kænɑt bi pʊt bæk," eɪvinhə sɛd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn nɪneɪivz ɑɹm. "ʃi hæz bɪɡʌn, ən naʊ ʃi mʌs fɪnɪʃ. jə mʌs də əz ʃi sɛz, nɪneɪiv."

"It cannot be put back," Aviendha said, laying a hand on Nynaeve's arm. "She has begun, and now she must finish. You must do as she says, Nynaeve."

nɪneɪivz bɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn. "mʌst" wɑz ə wɝd ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk hɪɹɪŋ wʌn bɪt, nɑɾ əplaɪd tə hɝ. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ful, ðoʊ, soʊ æftɝ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɡlɛɹɪŋ - əɾ ɪleɪn, ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, əɾ eɪvinhə, ət ðə wɝld ɪn dʒɛnɝəl - ʃi flʌŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɪleɪn ɪn ə hʌɡ ðət meɪɾ əɹ ɹɪbz kɹik.

Nynaeve's brows drew down. "Must" was a word she did not like hearing one bit, not applied to her. She was not a fool, though, so after a bit of glaring - at Elayne, at the gateway, at Aviendha, at the world in general - she flung her arms around Elayne in a hug that made her ribs creak.

"ju bi kɛɹfəl, jə hɪɹ mi," ʃi wɪspɝd. "ɪf jə ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪld, aɪ swɛɹ əl skɪn jə əlaɪv!" ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪleɪn bɝst aʊt læfɪŋ. nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd, pʊʃɪŋ əɹ aʊt tə ɑɹmz lɛŋθ baɪ hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. "ju noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min," ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld. "æn doʊn θɪŋk aɪ doʊn min ɪt, kəz aɪ du! aɪ du," ʃi æɾəd ɪn ə sɑftɝ vɔɪs. "ju teɪk kɛɹ."

"You be careful, you hear me," she whispered. "If you get yourself killed, I swear I'll skin you alive!" In spite of everything, Elayne burst out laughing. Nynaeve snorted, pushing her out to arm's length by her shoulders. "You know what I mean," she grumbled. "And don't think I don't mean it, because I do! I do," she added in a softer voice. "You take care."

ɪt tʊk nɪneɪiv ə moʊmən tə ɡæðɝ hɝsɛlf, blɪŋkɪŋ ən pʊlɪŋ əɹ blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz taɪt. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə hɪn ə mɔɪstʃɝ ɪn əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ ðət kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn; nɪneɪiv meɪɾ ʌðɝ pipəl kɹaɪ, ʃi dɪd nɑt kɹaɪ hɝsɛlf. "wɛl, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd laʊdli. "æləz, ɪf jə doʊn əv ɛvɹiwʌn ɹɛɾi jɛt - " tɝnɪŋ, ʃi kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəl kɹoʊk.

It took Nynaeve a moment to gather herself, blinking and pulling her blue riding gloves tight. There seemed to be a hint of moisture in her eyes, though that could not have been; Nynaeve made other people cry, she did not cry herself. "Well, then," she said loudly. "Alise, if you don't have everyone ready yet - " Turning, she cut off with a strangled croak.

ðoʊz u wɝ səpoʊz tə bi maʊntəd wɝ, ivən ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɝ ɔl ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz; læn ən bɝdʒɪt hæd ɹɪtɝnd, ən bɝdʒɪt wɑtʃt ɪleɪn wɝidli. ðə sɝvəns hæd ðə pæk ænəməlz ɪn ə laɪn, ən ðə kɪnswɪmən wɝ weɪɾɪŋ peɪʃənli, moʊst əfʊɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl. ə nʌmbɝ ə hɔɹsəz ðət cʊɾə bɪn juz fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɝ loʊɾəd wɪð sæks ə fuɾ ən bʌndəlz ə bɪlɔŋɪŋz. wɪmən u hæd bɹɔt mɔɹ ðən æləz əlaʊd - nʌn ə ðɛm kɪn - kæɹid ðɛɹ bʌndəlz ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn bæks. ðə slɛndɝ noʊbəl wɪð ðə skɑɹ wɑz bɛn əɾ ən ɑkwɝɾ æŋɡəl bɪniθ hɝz, ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɛniwʌn bʌɾ æləz. ɛvɹi wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ən ɛvɹi wʊmən u hæd bɪn ðəɹ tə hɪɹ vændin tɛl ə ðə deɪnʒɝz wɑtʃt ðət wʌn wɪpɪŋ fɪləmən əz ʃi wəɾ əv ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ.

Those who were supposed to be mounted were, even the Atha'an Miere. The Warders were all gathered around the other sisters; Lan and Birgitte had returned, and Birgitte watched Elayne worriedly. The servants had the pack animals in a line, and the Kinswomen were waiting patiently, most afoot except for the Knitting Circle. A number of horses that could have been used for riding were loaded with sacks of food and bundles of belongings. Women who had brought more than Alise allowed - none of them Kin - carried their bundles on their own backs. The slender noble with the scar was bent at an awkward angle beneath hers, and glaring at anyone but Alise. Every woman who could channel was staring at the gateway. And every woman who had been there to hear Vandene tell of the dangers watched that one whipping filament as she would have a red adder.

ɪt wɑz æləz hɝsɛlf u bɹɔt nɪneɪiv əɹ hɔɹs. ən stʃɹeɪɾənd ðə blu-plum hæɾ əz nɪneɪiv pʊɾ ə fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp. nɪneɪiv tɝn ðə plʌmp mɛɹ nɔɹθ wɪð læn ɹaɪɾɪŋ mændɑɹb əɾ əɹ saɪɾ ən ə lʊk ʌv ʌɾɝ mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. waɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt dʒʌst sɛɾ æləz daʊn, ɪleɪn dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. tə hɪɹ nɪneɪiv tɛl ɪt, ʃi hæd bɪn pʊɾɪŋ wɪmən oʊldɝ ðən hɝsɛlf ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪs sɪns ʃi wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə ɡɝl. ən ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, naʊ, æftɝ ɔl; ðət ʃəd kæɹi maʊntənz ʌv weɪt wɪð ɛni kɪnswʊmən.

It was Alise herself who brought Nynaeve her horse. And straightened the blue-plumed hat as Nynaeve put a foot in the stirrup. Nynaeve turned the plump mare north with Lan riding Mandarb at her side and a look of utter mortification on her face. Why she did not just set Alise down, Elayne did not understand. To hear Nynaeve tell it, she had been putting women older than herself in their place since she was little more than a girl. And she was Aes Sedai, now, after all; that should carry mountains of weight with any Kinswoman.

əz ðə kɑləm bɪɡæn tə wɛn ɪts weɪ təwɔɹd ðə hɪlz, ɪleɪn lʊkt əɾ eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt. eɪvinhə sɪmpli stʊd ðəɹ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts; ʃi hæd ðə wʊmən-ɹæpt-ɪn-hɝ-oʊn-hɛɹ æŋɡɹil klʌtʃt ɪn wʌn hænd. bɝdʒɪt tʊk laɪoʊnəsəz ɹeɪnz fɹəm ɪleɪn, æɾɪŋ əm tə ðoʊz ə hɝ oʊn hɔɹs ən eɪvinhəz, ðən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ə smɔl boʊldɝ twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ ən sæt daʊn.

As the column began to wend its way toward the hills, Elayne looked at Aviendha and Birgitte. Aviendha simply stood there with her arms folded beneath her breasts; she had the woman-wrapped-in-her-own-hair angreal clutched in one hand. Birgitte took Lioness's reins from Elayne, adding them to those of her own horse and Aviendha's, then walked over to a small boulder twenty paces away and sat down.

"ju tu mʌst," ɪleɪn bɪɡæn, ðən kɔft wən eɪvinhəz aɪbɹaʊz ʃɑɾ ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. sɛndɪŋ eɪvinhə aʊɾ ə deɪnʒɝ wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl wɪθaʊt ʃeɪmɪŋ hɝ. pɝhæps ɪmpɑsəbəl ɔltəɡɛðɝ. "aɪ wɑn jə tə ɡoʊ wɪð ði ʌðɝz," ʃi toʊl bɝdʒɪt. "æn teɪk laɪoʊnəs. eɪvinhə ən aɪ kən teɪk tɝnz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ. aɪd laɪk ə wɔk bɪfɔɹ bɛdtaɪm."

"You two must," Elayne began, then coughed when Aviendha's eyebrows shot up in surprise. Sending Aviendha out of danger was impossible without shaming her. Perhaps impossible altogether. "I want you to go with the others," she told Birgitte. "And take Lioness. Aviendha and I can take turns riding her gelding. I'd like a walk before bedtime."

"ɪf jə ɛvɝ tʃɹiɾ ə mæn hæf əz wɛl əz jə də ðət hɔɹs," bɝdʒɪt sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "hil bi jʊɹz fəɹ laɪf. aɪ θɪŋk əl dʒʌst sɪɾ əwaɪl; aɪv ɹɪɾən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tədeɪ. aɪm nɑɾ ət jəɹ bɛk ən kɔl ɔl ðə taɪm. wi kən pleɪ ðət ɡeɪm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz ən ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz, tə spɛɹ jəɹ blʌʃəz, bʌt jə ən aɪ noʊ bɛɾɝ." dɪspaɪt ðə mɑkɪŋ wɝdz, wʌɾ ɪleɪn fɛl fɹəm əɹ wɑz əfɛkʃən. noʊ; stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən əfɛkʃən. hɝ oʊn aɪz stʌŋ sʌɾənli. hɝ dɛθ wəd hɝt bɝdʒɪt tə ðə boʊn - ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn meɪd ðət sɝɾən - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz fɹɛndʃɪp ðət meɪɾ əɹ steɪ naʊ.

"If you ever treat a man half as well as you do that horse," Birgitte said dryly, "he'll be yours for life. I think I'll just sit awhile; I've ridden long enough today. I'm not at your beck and call all the time. We can play that game in front of the sisters and the other Warders, to spare your blushes, but you and I know better." Despite the mocking words, what Elayne felt from her was affection. No; stronger than affection. Her own eyes stung suddenly. Her death would hurt Birgitte to the bone - the Warder bond made that certain - but it was friendship that made her stay now.

"aɪ æm θæŋkfəl tə hæv tu fɹɛnz sətʃ əz ju," ʃi sɛd sɪmpli. bɝdʒɪt ɡɹɪn əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæd sɛd sʌmθɪŋ sɪli.

"I am thankful to have two friends such as you," she said simply. Birgitte grinned at her as if she had said something silly.

eɪvinhə, haʊɛvɝ, blʌʃt fjʊɹiəsli ən stɛɹɾ ət bɝdʒɪt, waɪd-aɪɾ ən flʌstɝd, əz ðoʊ ðə wɔɹɾɝz pɹɛzəns wɝ tə bleɪm fəɹ əɹ faɪɝi tʃiks. hɝidli ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ɡeɪz tə ðə pipəl stɪl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə fɝs hɪl, pɝhæps hæf ə maɪl dɪstənt. "bɛs tə weɪɾ əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ aʊɾ ə saɪt," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt jə kænɑt weɪt tu lɔŋ. wʌns juv stɑɹɾəd ði ənwivɪŋ, ðə floʊz bɪɡɪn tə ɡɹoʊ . . . slɪk . . . æftɝ ə taɪm. lɛɾɪŋ wʌn slɪp fɹi bɪfɔɹ ɪts aʊɾ ə ðə wiv ɪz ðə seɪm əz lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ʌv ðə wiv; ɪɾəl fɔl ɪndə wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɪʃɪz, ðɛn. bʌt jə mʌs nɑt hɝi, iðɝ. itʃ θɹɛd mʌs bi pʊl fɹi əz fɑɹ əz ɪɾəl ɡoʊ. ðə mɔɹ ðət kʌm lus, ði iziɝ ʌðɝz wɪl bi tə si, bʌt jə mʌst ɔlweɪz pɪk ðə θɹɛd ðəɾ ɪz iziəs tə si." smaɪlɪŋ wɔɹmli, ʃi pɹɛst əɹ fɪŋɡɝz fɝmli əɡɛnst ɪleɪnz tʃik. "ju wɪl də wɛl, ɪf jə ɑɹ kɛɹfəl."

Aviendha, however, blushed furiously and stared at Birgitte, wide-eyed and flustered, as though the Warder's presence were to blame for her fiery cheeks. Hurriedly she shifted her gaze to the people still short of the first hill, perhaps half a mile distant. "Best to wait until they are out of sight," she said, "but you cannot wait too long. Once you have started the unweaving, the flows begin to grow . . . slick . . . after a time. Letting one slip free before it is out of the weave is the same as letting go of the weave; it will fall into whatever it wishes, then. But you must not hurry, either. Each thread must be pulled free as far as it will go. The more that come loose, the easier others will be to see, but you must always pick the thread that is easiest to see." Smiling warmly, she pressed her fingers firmly against Elayne's cheek. "You will do well, if you are careful."

ɪt dɪd nɑt saʊn ðət dɪfəkəlt. ʃi dʒʌs hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl. ɪt sim tə teɪk ə lɔŋ taɪm fəɹ ðə læst wʊmən tə vænɪʃ oʊvɝ ðə hɪl, ðə slɛndɝ noʊbəl bɛn ʌndɝ ðə bʌlk ə hɝ dʒɹɛsəz. ðə sʌn bɛɹli əpɪɹd tə sɛɾəl ɛni əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ɪt sim laɪk aʊɝz. wʌɾ eɪvinhə min pɹɪsaɪsli baɪ "slɪk"? ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn bɪɑn vɛɹieɪʃənz ɑn ðə wɝd; ðeɪ bɪkeɪm dɪfəkəl tə hoʊld, ðət wɑz ɔl.

It did not sound that difficult. She just had to be careful. It seemed to take a long time for the last woman to vanish over the hill, the slender noble bent under the bulk of her dresses. The sun barely appeared to settle any at all, but it seemed like hours. What did Aviendha mean precisely by "slick"? She could not explain beyond variations on the word; they became difficult to hold, that was all.

ɪleɪn faʊn aʊɾ əz sun əz ʃi bɪɡæn əɡɛn. "slɪk" wɑz wʌt jə wəd ɡɛɾ ɪf jə koʊɾəd ə laɪv il wɪð ɡɹis. ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ dʒʌs hoʊldɪŋ ɑn tə ðət fɝs θɹɛd, ən ðət wɑz ɑn tɑp ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl ɪt fɹi. ɔl ðət stɑpt əɹ fɹəm ɡæspɪŋ ɪn ɹɪlif wən ðə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛɹ bɪɡæn wɪpɪŋ əbaʊt, faɪnəli lus, wɑz ðət ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ tə ɡoʊ. ɪf ðeɪ bɪkeɪm mʌtʃ mɔɹ "slɪk," ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd mænədʒ ɪt. eɪvinhə wɑtʃt kloʊsli, bʌt dɪd nɑt seɪ ənʌðɝ wɝd, ðoʊ ʃi ɔlweɪz hæɾ ən ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ smaɪl wən ɪleɪn niɾəd wʌn. ɪleɪn kəd nɑt si bɝdʒɪt - ʃi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ lʊk əweɪ fɹəm əɹ wɝk - jɛt ʃi kəd fil hɝ, ə smɔl nɑɾ ə ɹɑk-sɑləd kɑnfəɾəns ɪn əɹ oʊn hɛd, ɪnʌf kɑnfəɾəns tə fɪl hɝ.

Elayne found out as soon as she began again. "Slick" was what you would get if you coated a live eel with grease. She gritted her teeth just holding on to that first thread, and that was on top of trying to pull it free. All that stopped her from gasping in relief when the thread of Air began whipping about, finally loose, was that there were more to go. If they became much more "slick," she was not sure she could manage it. Aviendha watched closely, but did not say another word, though she always had an encouraging smile when Elayne needed one. Elayne could not see Birgitte - she did not dare look away from her work - yet she could feel her, a small knot of rock-solid confidence in her own head, enough confidence to fill her.

swɛt slɪd daʊn əɹ feɪs, daʊn əɹ bæk ən bɛli, əntɪl ʃi bɪɡæn tə fil "slɪk" hɝsɛlf. ə bæθ tənaɪt wəd bi moʊst wɛlkəm. noʊ, ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ə ðæt. ɔl ətɛnʃən ɑn ðə wivz. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ tə hændəl, kwɪvɝɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɡɹɪp əz sun əz ʃi tʌtʃt wʌn, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl keɪm fɹi, ən ɛvɹi taɪm wʌn θɹɛd bɪɡæn tə læʃ əbaʊt, ənʌðɝ sim tə lip aʊɾ ə ðə mæs, tə sʌɾənli bi klɪɹli pɝsɛptəbəl wɛɹ ðəɹ hæɾ oʊnli bɪn sɑləd seɪaɪdɑɹ bɪfɔɹ. tə hɝ aɪ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɹɪzɛmbəl səm mɑnstʃɹəs, dɪstɔɹɾəd hʌnʒɹəd-hɛdz ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə pɑnd, sɝaʊndəd baɪ fleɪlɪŋ tɛnʒɹəlz, ɛvɹi wʌn θɪkli hɛɹd wɪð θɹɛdz ə ðə paʊɝ ðət ɡɹu ən ɹɪθd ən vænɪʃt oʊnli tə bi ɹipleɪs baɪ nu. ði oʊpənɪŋ vɪzəbəl tə ɛniwʌn flɛkst əlɔŋ ɪts ɛdʒəz, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ʃeɪp ən ivən saɪz kəntɪnjuəsli. hɝ lɛɡz bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɛmbəl; stʃɹeɪn stʌŋ əɹ aɪz əz mʌtʃ əz swɛt dɪd. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ ʃi kəd ɡoʊ ɑn. ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ʃi fɔt. wʌn θɹɛɾ əɾ ə taɪm. wʌn θɹɛɾ əɾ ə taɪm.

Sweat slid down her face, down her back and belly, until she began to feel "slick" herself. A bath tonight would be most welcome. No, she could not think of that. All attention on the weaves. They were getting harder to handle, quivering in her grip as soon as she touched one, but they still came free, and every time one thread began to lash about, another seemed to leap out of the mass, to suddenly be clearly perceptible where there had only been solid saidar before. To her eye the gateway resembled some monstrous, distorted hundred-heads on the bottom of a pond, surrounded by flailing tendrils, every one thickly haired with threads of the Power that grew and writhed and vanished only to be replaced by new. The opening visible to anyone flexed along its edges, changing shape and even size continuously. Her legs began to tremble; strain stung her eyes as much as sweat did. She did not know how much longer she could go on. Gritting her teeth, she fought. One thread at a time. One thread at a time.

ə θaʊzən maɪlz əweɪ, lɛs ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ θɹu ðə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪ, dʌzənz ə soʊlʒɝz swɛpt ɝaʊn ðə waɪt fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz, ʃɔɹt mɛn kæɹiɪŋ kɹɔsboʊz, ɪn bɹaʊn bɹɛstpleɪts ən peɪntəd hɛlməts ðət lʊk laɪk ðə hɛdz ə hjudʒ ɪnsɛks. bɪhaɪn əm keɪm ə wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd pænəlz bɛɹɪŋ sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ ɑn əɹ skɝts, ə bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪs lɪŋk baɪ ə sɪlvɝi liʃ tə ðə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn ðə nɛk ʌv ə wʊmən ɪn ɡɹeɪ, ən ðən ənʌðɝ sʌldəm ən əɹ deɪmeɪn, ðən ənʌðɝ pɛɹ. wʌn ə ðə sʌldəm pɔɪntəɾ ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ əbɹʌpli ɛnvɛləpt əɹ deɪmeɪn.

A thousand miles away, less than a hundred paces away through the shuddering gateway, dozens of soldiers swept around the white farm buildings, short men carrying crossbows, in brown breastplates and painted helmets that looked like the heads of huge insects. Behind them came a woman with red panels bearing silver lightning on her skirts, a bracelet on her wrist linked by a silvery leash to the collar around the neck of a woman in gray, and then another sul'dam and her damane, then another pair. One of the sul'dam pointed at the gateway, and the glow of saidar abruptly enveloped her damane.

"ɡɛt daʊn!" ɪleɪn skɹimd, fɔlɪŋ bækwɝd, aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd, ən sɪlvɝ-blu laɪtnɪŋ ʃɑt θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ðət fɪld əɹ ɪɹz, fɔɹkɪŋ sævɪdʒli ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. hɝ hɛɹ lɪftəd, ɛvɹi stʃɹæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stæn ɑn ɪts oʊn, ən θʌndɝəs faʊntənz ə ɝθ ɪɹʌptəd wɛɹɛvɝ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹks stʃɹʌk. dɝɾ ən pɛbəlz ɹeɪn daʊn ɑn hɝ.

"Get down!" Elayne screamed, falling backward, out of sight of the farmyard, and silver-blue lightning shot through the gateway with a roar that filled her ears, forking savagely in every direction. Her hair lifted, every strand trying to stand on its own, and thunderous fountains of earth erupted wherever one of the forks struck. Dirt and pebbles rained down on her.

hɪɹɪŋ ɹɪtɝn sʌɾənli, ən ə mænz vɔɪs fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði oʊpənɪŋ, ə slɝd, dʒɹɔlɪŋ æksɛn ðət meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹɔl əz mʌtʃ əz ðə wɝdz. ". . . mʌs teɪk əm əlaɪv, jə fulz!"

Hearing returned suddenly, and a man's voice from the other side of the opening, a slurred, drawling accent that made her skin crawl as much as the words. ". . . must take them alive, you fools!"

əbɹʌpli wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɑz lipɪŋ ɪndə ðə mɛdoʊ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. bɝdʒɪts æɹoʊ pʌntʃt θɹu ðə klɛntʃt fɪst ɪmbɔst ɑn ɪz lɛðɝ bɹɛstpleɪt. ə sɛkən sintʃæn soʊlʒɝ stʌmbəld oʊvɝ ðə fɝst əz i fɛl, ən eɪvinhəz bɛl naɪf stæbd ɪndə hɪz θɹoʊt bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹɪkʌvɝ. æɹoʊz flu fɹəm bɝdʒɪts baʊ laɪk heɪl; wɪð wʌn buɾ ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz' ɹeɪnz, ʃi ɡɹɪnd ɡɹɪmli əz ʃi ʃɑt. ðə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hɔɹsəz tɔs ðɛɹ hɛdz ən dænst əz ɪf ðeɪ wəd dʒɝk fɹi ən ɹʌn, bʌt bɝdʒɪt sɪmpli stʊɾ ən ʃɑɾ əz fæst əz ʃi kəd dʒɹɔ. ʃaʊts fɹəm bɪɑn ðə ɡeɪtweɪ sɛd bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ stɪl stʃɹʌk hoʊm wɪð ɛvɹi ʃæft ʃi lust. ænsɝ keɪm, kwɪk əz bæd θɔt, blæk stʃɹiks, kɹɔsboʊ boʊls. soʊ kwɪk, ɔl hæpənɪŋ soʊ fæst. eɪvinhə fɛl, blʌd ɹʌnɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə fɪŋɡɝz klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm, bʌt ʃi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv əɹ waʊn ɪmiɾiətli, kɹɔlɪŋ klɪɹ, skɹæbəlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn fəɹ ði æŋɡɹil, hɝ feɪs sɛt. bɝdʒɪt kɹaɪɾ aʊt; dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ baʊ, ʃi ɡɹæbd əɹ θaɪ wɛɹ ə kwɔɹəl stʌk aʊt. ɪleɪn fɛl ðə stæb ʌv æɡəni əz ʃɑɹpli əz ɪf ɪt wɝ əɹ oʊn.

Abruptly one of the soldiers was leaping into the meadow right in front of her. Birgitte's arrow punched through the clenched fist embossed on his leather breastplate. A second Seanchan soldier stumbled over the first as he fell, and Aviendha's belt knife stabbed into his throat before he could recover. Arrows flew from Birgitte's bow like hail; with one boot on the horses' reins, she grinned grimly as she shot. The trembling horses tossed their heads and danced as if they would jerk free and run, but Birgitte simply stood and shot as fast as she could draw. Shouts from beyond the gateway said Birgitte Silverbow still struck home with every shaft she loosed. Answer came, quick as bad thought, black streaks, crossbow bolts. So quick, all happening so fast. Aviendha fell, blood running over the fingers clutching her right arm, but she let go of her wound immediately, crawling clear, scrabbling on the ground for the angreal, her face set. Birgitte cried out; dropping her bow, she grabbed her thigh where a quarrel stuck out. Elayne felt the stab of agony as sharply as if it were her own.

dɛspɝətli, ʃi sizd ənʌðɝ θɹɛd fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi leɪ hæf ɑn əɹ bæk. ən ɹilaɪz tə hɝ hɔɹɝ æftɝ wʌn tʌɡ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də tə hoʊld ɑn. hæd ðə θɹɛd muvd? hæɾ ɪt slɪp fɹi ɛni əɾ ɔl? ɪf ɪt hæd, ʃi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ lɛt ɡoʊ. ðə θɹɛd tʃɹɛmbəld ɡɹisəli ɪn əɹ ɡɹæsp.

Desperately, she seized another thread from where she lay half on her back. And realized to her horror after one tug that it was all she could do to hold on. Had the thread moved? Had it slipped free any at all? If it had, she did not dare let go. The thread trembled greasily in her grasp.

"əlaɪv, aɪ sɛd!" ðət sintʃæn vɔɪs ɹɔɹd. "ɛniwʌn u kɪlz ə wʊmən ɡɛts noʊ ʃɛɹ ə ðə teɪkɪŋ ɡoʊld!" ðə flɝi ʌv kɹɔsboʊ boʊls sist.

"Alive, I said!" that Seanchan voice roared. "Anyone who kills a woman gets no share of the taking gold!" The flurry of crossbow bolts ceased.

"ju wɪʃ tə teɪk mi?" eɪvinhə ʃaʊɾəd. "ðɛn kʌm ən dæns wɪð mi!" seɪaɪdɑɹz ɡloʊ əbɹʌpli sɝaʊndəd hɝ, dɪm ivən wɪð ði æŋɡɹil, ən bɔlz ə faɪɝ spɹæŋ ɪndə biɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ən spɹeɪd θɹu əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. nɑt vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ bɔlz, bʌt ðə blæsts əz ðeɪ bɝs bæk ɪn ɔltɑɹə saʊndəɾ ɪn ə stɛɾi stʃɹim. eɪvinhə pæntɪd wɪð ɛfɝt, ðoʊ; hɝ feɪs ɡlɪsənd wɪð swɛt. bɝdʒɪt hæd ɹəkʌvɝɾ əɹ baʊ; ʃi lʊkt ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ðə hɪɹoʊ ʌv lɛdʒənd, blʌd stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ lɛɡ, bɛɹli eɪbəl tə stænd, bʌɾ ən æɹoʊ hæf dʒɹɔn, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə tɑɹɡət.

"You wish to take me?" Aviendha shouted. "Then come and dance with me!" Saidar's glow abruptly surrounded her, dim even with the angreal, and balls of fire sprang into being in front of the gateway and sprayed through again and again. Not very large balls, but the blasts as they burst back in Altara sounded in a steady stream. Aviendha panted with effort, though; her face glistened with sweat. Birgitte had recovered her bow; she looked every inch the hero of legend, blood streaming down her leg, barely able to stand, but an arrow half drawn, searching for a target.

ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ bɹiðɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɛmbɹeɪs wʌn ʃɹɛd mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ, nʌθɪŋ tə hɛlp. "ðə tu ʌv jə mʌst ɡɛɾ əweɪ," ʃi sɛd. ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv haʊ ʃi saʊndəd, kɑm əz aɪs; ʃi nu ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn weɪlɪŋ. hɝ hɑɹt wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə paʊn θɹu hɝ ɹɪbz. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ aɪ kən hoʊl ðɪs." ðət hɛl tʃɹu fəɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ wiv əz mʌtʃ əz fəɹ ðət sɪŋɡəl θɹɛd. wɑz ɪt slaɪɾɪŋ? wɑz ɪt? "ɡoʊ, əz fæst əz jə kæn. ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɪlz ʃəd bi seɪf, bʌɾ ɛvɹi spæn jə kən kʌvɝ ɡeɪnz sʌmθɪŋ. ɡoʊ!"

Elayne tried to control her breathing. She could not embrace one shred more of the Power, nothing to help. "The two of you must get away," she said. She could not believe how she sounded, calm as ice; she knew she should have been wailing. Her heart was trying to pound through her ribs. "I don't know how much longer I can hold this." That held true for the entire weave as much as for that single thread. Was it sliding? Was it? "Go, as fast as you can. The other side of the hills should be safe, but every span you can cover gains something. Go!"

bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪleɪn nu. ɪt saʊndəd laɪk fɹeɪzəz ʃi wəd laɪk tə lɝn. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛvɝ ə tʃæns. bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn ɪn wɝdz ɪleɪn kəɾ ʌndɝstænd. "ju lɛt ðət blʌɾi θɪŋ ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ aɪ tɛl ju, ən jə woʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ nɪneɪiv tə skɪn ju; əl də ɪt maɪsɛlf. ən ðən lɛɾ əɹ əv ə tɝn. dʒʌs bi kwaɪəɾ ən hæŋ ɑn! eɪvinhə, ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn hɪɹ - bɪhaɪn ðət θɪŋ! - kən jə kip ðəɾ ʌp fɹəm bɪhaɪn ɪt? - ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn hɪɹ ən ɑn wʌn ə ðiz blʌɾi hɔɹsəz."

Birgitte growled in the Old Tongue, but nothing that Elayne knew. It sounded like phrases she would like to learn. If there was ever a chance. Birgitte went on in words Elayne could understand. "You let that bloody thing go before I tell you, and you won't have to worry about waiting for Nynaeve to skin you; I'll do it myself. And then let her have a turn. Just be quiet and hang on! Aviendha, get around here - behind that thing! - can you keep that up from behind it? - get around here and on one of these bloody horses."

"æz lɔŋ əz aɪ kən si wɛɹ tə wiv," eɪvinhə ɹɪplaɪd, stæɡɝɪŋ tə hɝ fit. ʃi wɑbəl saɪdweɪz ən bɛɹli kɑt hɝsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ə fɔlɪŋ. blʌd floʊd daʊn əɹ sliv fɹəm ə wɪkəd ɡæʃ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kæn." ʃi vænɪʃt bɪhaɪn ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ðə faɪɝbɔlz kəntɪnjud. jə kəd si θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ðoʊ ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə hit heɪz hæŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. jə kəd nɑt wɔk θɹu fɹəm ðət saɪd, ðoʊ - ði ətɛmpt wəd bi ɪkstʃɹimli peɪnfəl - ən wən eɪvinhə ɹiəpɪɹd, ʃi wɑz stʌmbəlɪŋ wɛl waɪd. bɝdʒɪt hɛlpt əɹ maʊn əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ, bʌt bækwɝd, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz!

"As long as I can see where to weave," Aviendha replied, staggering to her feet. She wobbled sideways and barely caught herself short of falling. Blood flowed down her sleeve from a wicked gash. "I think I can." She vanished behind the gateway, and the fireballs continued. You could see through a gateway from the other side, though it appeared to be a heat haze hanging in the air. You could not walk through from that side, though - the attempt would be extremely painful - and when Aviendha reappeared, she was stumbling well wide. Birgitte helped her mount her gelding, but backward, of all things!

wən bɝdʒɪt moʊʃən fɪɹsli tə hɝ, ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ʃi fɪɹd wʌt maɪt hæpən ɪf ʃi dɪd. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən aɪ kən hoʊld ɑn ɪf aɪ tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ʌp." ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ ʌp; taɪɝd wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn ɪt; hɝ mʌsəlz wɝ wɔɾɝ. "ɹaɪɾ əz fæst əz jə kæn. əl hoʊld ɑn əz lɔŋ əz aɪm eɪbəl. pliz, ɡoʊ!"

When Birgitte motioned fiercely to her, Elayne did not bother with shaking her head. For one thing, she feared what might happen if she did. "I'm not certain I can hold on if I try to get up." In truth, she was not certain she could get up; tired was no longer in it; her muscles were water. "Ride as fast as you can. I'll hold on as long as I'm able. Please, go!"

mʌɾɝɪŋ kɝsɪz ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ - ðeɪ hæd tə bi; nʌθɪŋ ɛls ɛvɝ hæd ðə saʊnd! - bɝdʒɪt ʃʌv ðə hɔɹsəz' ɹeɪnz ɪndə eɪvinhəz hænz. nɪɹli fɔlɪŋ twaɪs, ʃi hɑbəl tə ɪleɪn ən bɛn tə teɪk əɹ baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz. "ju kən hæŋ ɑn," ʃi sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs fɪld wɪð ðə seɪm kənvɪkʃən ɪleɪn fɛl fɹəm hɝ. "aɪ nɛvɝ mɛɾ ə kwin ʌv ændɝ bɪfɔɹ ju, bʌɾ aɪv noʊn kwinz laɪk ju. ə bækboʊn ə stil ən ə laɪənz hɑɹt. jə kən də ɪt!"

Muttering curses in the Old Tongue - they had to be; nothing else ever had the sound! - Birgitte shoved the horses' reins into Aviendha's hands. Nearly falling twice, she hobbled to Elayne and bent to take her by the shoulders. "You can hang on," she said, her voice filled with the same conviction Elayne felt from her. "I never met a Queen of Andor before you, but I've known queens like you. A backbone of steel and a lion's heart. You can do it!"

sloʊli ʃi pʊld ɪleɪn ʌp, nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ, hɝ feɪs taɪt, ɛvɹi stæb ɪn əɹ lɛɡ ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ɪleɪnz hɛd. ɪleɪn kwɪvɝd wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ ðə wiv, hoʊldɪŋ ðət wʌn θɹɛd; ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn hɝsɛlf ɪɹɛkt. ən əlaɪv. bɝdʒɪts lɛɡ θɹɑb mædli ɪn əɹ hɛd. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lin ɑn bɝdʒɪt, bʌɾ əɹ oʊn tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ lɪmz wəd nɑt səpɔɹɾ əɹ kəmplitli. əz ðeɪ lɝtʃt təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹsəz, itʃ hæf linɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ, ʃi kɛp lʊkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi kəd hoʊld ə wiv wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt - ʃi kəd nɔɹməli - bʌt ʃi niɾəd tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi ɹɪli dɪd stɪl əv ə ɡɹɪp ɑn ðət wʌn θɹɛd, ðəɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt slɪpɪŋ. ðə ɡeɪtweɪ naʊ əpɪɹd laɪk noʊ wiv ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, twɪstɪŋ waɪldli, ɹɛðd wɪð fʌz tɛntəkəlz.

Slowly she pulled Elayne up, not waiting for an answer, her face tight, every stab in her leg echoing in Elayne's head. Elayne quivered with the effort of holding the weave, holding that one thread; she was surprised to find herself erect. And alive. Birgitte's leg throbbed madly in her head. She tried not to lean on Birgitte, but her own trembling limbs would not support her completely. As they lurched toward the horses, each half leaning on the other, she kept looking back over her shoulder. She could hold a weave without looking at it - she could normally - but she needed to reassure herself that she really did still have a grip on that one thread, that it was not slipping. The gateway now appeared like no weave she had ever seen, twisting wildly, wreathed with fuzzed tentacles.

wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, bɝdʒɪt hivd əɹ ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl mɔɹ ðən hɛlp hɝ. bækwɝd, dʒʌs laɪk eɪvinhə! "ju hæv tə si," ʃi ɪkspleɪnd, lɪmpɪŋ tə hɝ ɡɛldɪŋ; hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ʌv ɔl θɹi hɔɹsəz, ʃi pʊl hɝsɛlf ʌp peɪnfəli. wɪθaʊɾ ə saʊnd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn fɛl ði æɡəni. "ju də wʌt nidz duɪŋ ən liv wɛɹ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə mi." ðə hɔɹsəz lɛpt əweɪ, pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ fɹəm iɡɝnəs tə bi ɡɔn əz fɹəm bɝdʒɪts hil ɪn əɹ oʊn maʊns flæŋk.
