They had been riding hard for some time, these folk. The older woman was just as worn and dust-covered as the younger.

ʃi ɔltɝneɪɾəd bɪtwin bimɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn ən skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə wʊmən huz bɹaɪɾəl i stɪl hɛld. "θæŋk ju, maɪ lɔɹd." hɝ vɔɪs, θɪn bʌt stʃɹɔŋ, ɡeɪv ə hɪtʃ əz ʃi noʊɾəst ɪz aɪz, bʌt ɡoʊldən-jɛloʊ aɪz ɑn ə mæn sloʊɾ əɹ oʊnli ən ɪnstənt. nɑɾ ə wʊmən feɪz baɪ mʌtʃ. ʃi stɪl kæɹid ðə staʊt stɪk ʃi hæd bɪn juzɪŋ fəɹ ə wɛpən. "ə moʊs taɪmli ɹɛskju. meɪaɪɡdɪn, wʌtɛvɝ wɝ jə θɪŋkɪŋ? jə cʊɾə ɡɑɾən jɝsɛlf kɪld! ən ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, tu! ʃiz ə hɛdstʃɹɔŋ ɡɝl, maɪ lɔɹd, ɔlweɪz lipɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi lʊks. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, tʃaɪld, ə ful əbændənz fɹɛnz, ən ɡɪvz ʌp sɪlvɝ fəɹ ʃaɪni bɹæs. wi də θæŋk ju, maɪ lɔɹd, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn wɪl, tu, wən ʃi kʌmz tə hɝ sɛnsɪz."

She alternated between beaming at Perrin and scowling at the woman whose bridle he still held. "Thank you, my Lord." Her voice, thin but strong, gave a hitch as she noticed his eyes, but golden-yellow eyes on a man slowed her only an instant. Not a woman fazed by much. She still carried the stout stick she had been using for a weapon. "A most timely rescue. Maighdin, whatever were you thinking? You could have gotten yourself killed! And the rest of us, too! She's a headstrong girl, my Lord, always leaping before she looks. Remember, child, a fool abandons friends, and gives up silver for shiny brass. We do thank you, my Lord, and Maighdin will, too, when she comes to her senses."

meɪaɪɡdɪn, ə ɡʊd tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən pɛɹɪn, kəɾ oʊnli bi kɔld ə ɡɝl ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən tə ði oʊldɝ wʊmən, bʌt dɪspaɪt wɪɹi ɡɹɪməsɪz ðət mætʃt əɹ sɛnt, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən tɪŋd wɪð æŋɡɝ, ʃi æksɛptɪd ðə taɪɹeɪd, oʊnli pʊlɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ ɪn ə hæfhɑɹɾɪd ətɛmp tə fɹi hɝ hɔɹs, ðən ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp. lɛɾɪŋ əɹ hænz ɹɛst ɑn əɹ kæntəl, ʃi fɹaʊn ət pɛɹɪn əkjuzɪŋli, ðən blɪŋkt. ðə jɛloʊ aɪz əɡɛn. jɛt dɪspaɪt ðət stʃɹeɪnʒnəs, ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt smɛl əfɹeɪd. ði oʊld wʊmən dɪd, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ə hɪm.

Maighdin, a good ten years older than Perrin, could only be called a girl in comparison to the older woman, but despite weary grimaces that matched her scent, frustration tinged with anger, she accepted the tirade, only pulling once more in a halfhearted attempt to free her horse, then giving up. Letting her hands rest on her cantle, she frowned at Perrin accusingly, then blinked. The yellow eyes again. Yet despite that strangeness, she still did not smell afraid. The old woman did, but Perrin did not think it was of him.

ənʌðɝ ə meɪaɪɡdɪnz kəmpænjənz, ən ənʃeɪvən mæn maʊntəɾ ɑn jɛɾ ənʌðɝ bɪdʒɹæɡəl hɔɹs, ðɪs ə nɑb-nid ɡɹeɪ, əpɹoʊtʃt waɪl ði oʊld wʊmən wɑz tɔkɪŋ, bʌt kɛp bæk. hi wɑz tɔl, əz tɔl əz pɛɹɪn ɪf nɑt nɪɹli soʊ waɪd, ɪn ə tʃɹævəl-wɔɹn dɑɹk koʊt wɪð ə sɔɹd bɛltəɾ oʊvɝ. laɪk ðə wɪmən, hi hæɾ ə bʌndəl taɪɾ ɑn bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl. ðət taɪni bɹiz swɝl tə bɹɪŋ pɛɹɪn ɪz sɛnt. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd; hi wɑz wɛɹi. ən ɪf ðə weɪ hi lʊkt ət meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz ɛni ɡaɪd, ɪt wɑz ʃi hi wɑz wɛɹi ʌv. meɪbi ðɪs wɑz nɑt soʊ sɪmpəl əz ɹɛskjuɪŋ tʃɹævəlɝz fɹəm ə ɡæŋ ə ɹʌfaɪənz æftɝ ɔl.

Another of Maighdin's companions, an unshaven man mounted on yet another bedraggled horse, this a knob-kneed gray, approached while the old woman was talking, but kept back. He was tall, as tall as Perrin if not nearly so wide, in a travel-worn dark coat with a sword belted over. Like the women, he had a bundle tied on behind his saddle. That tiny breeze swirled to bring Perrin his scent. He was not afraid; he was wary. And if the way he looked at Maighdin was any guide, it was she he was wary of. Maybe this was not so simple as rescuing travelers from a gang of ruffians after all.

"pɝhæps jə ʃəɾ ɔl kʌm tə maɪ kæmp," pɛɹɪn sɛd, faɪnəli ɹilisɪŋ ðə bɹaɪɾəl. "jul bi seɪf fɹəm . . . bɹɪɡænz . . . ðɛɹ." hi hæf ɪkspɛktəd meɪaɪɡdɪn tə meɪk ə bɹeɪk fəɹ ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹi laɪn, bʌt ʃi tɝn əɹ hɔɹs wɪð hɪz, bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɡoʊtpən. ʃi smɛld . . . ɹɪzaɪnd.

"Perhaps you should all come to my camp," Perrin said, finally releasing the bridle. "You'll be safe from . . . brigands . . . there." He half expected Maighdin to make a break for the nearest tree line, but she turned her horse with his, back toward the goatpen. She smelled . . . resigned.

ivən soʊ, ʃi sɛd, "aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɔfɝ, bʌɾ aɪ . . . wi . . . mʌs kəntɪnju əɹ dʒɝni. wɪl ɡoʊ ɑn, lini," ʃi æɾəd fɝmli, ən ði oʊldɝ wʊmən fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ soʊ stɝnli ðəɾ i wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ mʌðɝ ən dɔɾɝ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ jus ə ðə wʊmənz neɪm. ðeɪ sɝɾənli lʊk nʌθɪŋ əlaɪk. lini wɑz nɛɹoʊ-feɪst ən pɑɹtʃmənt-skɪnd, ɔl sɪnu, waɪl meɪaɪɡdɪn maɪt bi bjuɾəfəl ʌndɝ ðət dʌst. ɪf ə mæn laɪk fɛɹ hɛɹ.

Even so, she said, "I thank you for the offer, but I . . . we . . . must continue our journey. We will go on, Lini," she added firmly, and the older woman frowned at her so sternly that he wondered whether they were mother and daughter despite her use of the woman's name. They certainly looked nothing alike. Lini was narrow-faced and parchment-skinned, all sinew, while Maighdin might be beautiful under that dust. If a man liked fair hair.

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə mæn tʃɹeɪlɪŋ æftɝ. ə hɑɹd-lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊ, ɪn niɾ ʌv ə ɹeɪzɝ. pɝhæps i laɪk fɛɹ hɛɹ. pɝhæps i laɪkt ɪt tu mʌtʃ. mɛn hæd meɪd tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz əz wɛl əz ʌðɝz fəɹ ðət ɹizən bɪfɔɹ ðɪs.

Perrin glanced over his shoulder at the man trailing after. A hard-looking fellow, in need of a razor. Perhaps he liked fair hair. Perhaps he liked it too much. Men had made trouble for themselves as well as others for that reason before this.

əhɛd, feɪl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ swɑloʊ ən piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɔl ə ðə pɛn ət ðə pipəl ɪnsaɪd. pɝhæps wʌn ə ðɛm hæd bɪn hɝt. siɑnɪɾ ən ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ noʊwɛɹ ɪn saɪt. ɛɹæm hæɾ ʌndɝstʊd, əpɛɹənli; hi wɑz kloʊs tə feɪl, ðoʊ lʊkɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ðə deɪnʒɝ wɑz klɪɹli pæst, ðoʊ.

Ahead, Faile was sitting Swallow and peering over the wall of the pen at the people inside. Perhaps one of them had been hurt. Seonid and the Wise Ones were nowhere in sight. Aram had understood, apparently; he was close to Faile, though looking impatiently toward Perrin. The danger was clearly past, though.

bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz hæfweɪ tə ðə ɡoʊtpən, tɛɹəl əpɪɹd wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ-aɪd, stʌbəl-tʃik mæn stʌmbəlɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz ɹoʊn, ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt ɡɹɪpt ɪn ðə wɔɹɾɝz fɪst. "aɪ θɔt wi ʃəd kætʃ wʌn ə ðɛm," tɛɹəl sɛd wɪð ə hɑɹd ɡɹɪn. "ɔlweɪz bɛs tə hɪɹ boʊθ saɪdz, wʌtɛvɝ jə θɔt jə sɔ, maɪ oʊl dɑ ɔlweɪz sɛd." pɛɹɪn wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd; hi hæd θɔt tɛɹəl kəd nɑt θɪŋk bɪɑn ði ɛn ə hɪz sɔɹd.

Before Perrin was halfway to the goatpen, Teryl appeared with a narrow-eyed, stubble-cheeked man stumbling along beside his roan, the collar of his coat gripped in the Warder's fist. "I thought we should catch one of them," Teryl said with a hard grin. "Always best to hear both sides, whatever you thought you saw, my old da always said." Perrin was surprised; he had thought Teryl could not think beyond the end of his sword.

ivən haɪkt ʌp əz ɪt wɑz, ðə stʌbəl-tʃik fɛloʊz fɹeɪd koʊt wɑz pleɪnli tu bɪɡ fəɹ hɪm. pɛɹɪn daʊɾɪd ɛniwʌn ɛls hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə si wɛl ɪnʌf ət ðə dɪstəns, bʌɾ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət θɹʌstɪŋ noʊz, tu. ðɪs mæn hæd bɪn ðə læs tə ɹʌn, ən i wɑz nɑt kaʊd naʊ, iðɝ. hɪz snɪɹ tʊk əm ɔl ɪn. "jɔɹ ɔl ɪn dip mʌk, fəɹ ðɪs," hi ɹæspt. "wi wɑz duɪŋ ðə pɹɑfəts bɪɾɪŋ, wi wɑz. ðə pɹɑfət sɛz ɪf ə mæn bɑðɝz ə wʊmən əz dʌznt wɑn hɪm, hi daɪz. ðɪs lɑt wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ hɝ" - hi dʒɝkt ɪz tʃɪn ət meɪaɪɡdɪn - "ænd ʃi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ hɑɹd. ðə pɹɑfəɾəl əv jəɹ ɪɹz fəɹ ðɪs!" hi spæt fəɹ ɛmfəsəs.

Even hiked up as it was, the stubble-cheeked fellow's frayed coat was plainly too big for him. Perrin doubted anyone else had been able to see well enough at the distance, but he recognized that thrusting nose, too. This man had been the last to run, and he was not cowed now, either. His sneer took them all in. "You're all in deep muck, for this," he rasped. "We was doing the Prophet's bidding, we was. The Prophet says if a man bothers a woman as doesn't want him, he dies. This lot was chasing after her" - he jerked his chin at Maighdin - "and she was running hard. The Prophet'll have your ears for this!" He spat for emphasis.

"ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs," meɪaɪɡdɪn ənaʊnst ɪn ə klɪɹ vɔɪs. "ðiz pipəl ɑɹ maɪ fɹɛnz. ðɪs mæn kəmplitli mɪsəndɝstʊd wʌɾ i sɔ."

"That is ridiculous," Maighdin announced in a clear voice. "These people are my friends. This man completely misunderstood what he saw."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd, ən ɪf ʃi θɔɾ i wɑz əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð hɝ, ɔl wɛl ən ɡʊd. bʌt pʊɾɪŋ wʌt ðɪs fɛloʊ sɛɾ əlɔŋsaɪd wʌt lini hæd. . . . nɑt sɪmpəl əɾ ɔl.

Perrin nodded, and if she thought he was agreeing with her, all well and good. But putting what this fellow said alongside what Lini had. . . . Not simple at all.

feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz dʒɔɪn ðɛm, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə ɹɛst ə meɪaɪɡdɪnz tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz, θɹi mɔɹ mɛn ən ənʌðɝ wʊmən, ɔl liɾɪŋ wɔɹn-daʊn hɔɹsəz wɪð fju maɪlz lɛft ɪn ðɛm. nɑt ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn pɹaɪm hɔɹsflɛʃ ɪn səm jɪɹz, ɪf ɛvɝ. ə faɪnɝ kəlɛkʃən ə bʌk niz, baʊ hɑks, speɪvɪnz, ən sweɪbæks, pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt ɹikɔl. əz ɔlweɪz, hɪz ɡeɪz wɛn fɝs tə feɪl - hɪz nɑstʃɹəlz stʃɹeɪn fəɹ əɹ sɛnt - bʌt siɑnɪd snæɡd ɪz aɪz. slʌmpt ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, flʌʃɪŋ skɑɹlət, ʃi wɔɹ ə sʌlən ɡlaʊɝ, ən əɹ feɪs lʊkt ɑd, hɝ tʃiks pʌft aʊɾ ən əɹ maʊθ nɑt kwaɪt kloʊzd. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ, ə bɪɾ ə ɹɛd-ænd-blu. . . . pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt. ənlɛs i wɑz siɪŋ θɪŋz, ʃi hæɾ ə wɑɾəd-ʌp skɑɹf stʌft ɪndə hɝ maʊθ! əpɛɹənli wən waɪz wʌnz toʊld ən əpɹɛntəs tə bi kwaɪət, ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɹɛntəs, ðeɪ mɛn ɪt.

Faile and the others joined them, followed by the rest of Maighdin's traveling companions, three more men and another woman, all leading worn-down horses with few miles left in them. Not that they had been prime horseflesh in some years, if ever. A finer collection of buck knees, bow hocks, spavins, and swaybacks, Perrin could not recall. As always, his gaze went first to Faile - his nostrils strained for her scent - but Seonid snagged his eyes. Slumped in her saddle, flushing scarlet, she wore a sullen glower, and her face looked odd, her cheeks puffed out and her mouth not quite closed. There was something, a bit of red-and-blue. . . . Perrin blinked. Unless he was seeing things, she had a wadded-up scarf stuffed into her mouth! Apparently when Wise Ones told an apprentice to be quiet, even an Aes Sedai apprentice, they meant it.

hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn wɪð ʃɑɹp aɪz; meɪaɪɡdɪnz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən wən ʃi sɔ siɑnɪd, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə lɔŋ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ lʊk əz ɪf i wɝ ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðə skɑɹf. soʊ ʃi nu ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn saɪt, dɪd ʃi? ənkɑmən, fəɹ ðə kʌntʃɹi wʊmən ʃi əpɪɹd. ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn laɪk wʌn, ðoʊ.

He was not the only one with sharp eyes; Maighdin's mouth fell open when she saw Seonid, and she gave him a long, considering look as if he were responsible for the scarf. So she knew an Aes Sedai on sight, did she? Uncommon, for the country woman she appeared. She did not sound like one, though.

fʊɹən, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn siɑnɪd, wɔɹ ə θʌndɝhɛd fəɹ ə feɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tɛɹəl u meɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ivən lɛs sɪmpəl baɪ tɔsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "aɪ faʊn ðɪs bɪhaɪn hɪm," hi sɛd, "wɛɹ i maɪɾ əv dʒɹɑpt ɪt, ɹʌnɪŋ."

Furen, riding behind Seonid, wore a thunderhead for a face, but it was Teryl who made everything even less simple by tossing something to the ground. "I found this behind him," he said, "where he might have dropped it, running."

ət fɝst, pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ æt, ə lɔŋ lup ə ɹɔhaɪd θɪkli stʃɹʌŋ wɪð wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi tæɡz ə ʃɹɪvəld lɛðɝ. ðən i dɪd noʊ, ən ɪz tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə snɑɹl. "ðə pɹɑfət wəɾ əv əɹ ɪɹz, jə sɛd."

At first, Perrin did not know what he was looking at, a long loop of rawhide thickly strung with what appeared to be tags of shriveled leather. Then he did know, and his teeth bared in a snarl. "The Prophet would have our ears, you said."

ðə stʌbəl-tʃik mæn stɑpt ɡeɪpɪŋ ət siɑnɪɾ ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps. "ðæt . . . ðæts hɑɹiz wɝk!" hi pɹətɛstəd. "hɑɹiz ə min wʌn. hi laɪks tə kip kaʊnt, teɪk tʃɹoʊfiz, ən i . . . ʌ. . . ." ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪn ɪz kæptɪv koʊt, hi sæŋk ɪn ɑn hɪmsɛlf laɪk ə kɔɹnɝd dɔɡ. "ju kæn taɪ ðət tə mi! ðə pɹɑfəɾəl hæŋ jə ɪf jə tʌtʃ mi! hiz hæŋ noʊbəlz bɪfɔɹ, faɪn lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz. aɪ wɔk ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə blɛsɪd lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!"

The stubble-cheeked man stopped gaping at Seonid and licked his lips. "That . . . that's Hari's work!" he protested. "Hari's a mean one. He likes to keep count, take trophies, and he . . . uh. . . ." Shrugging in his captive coat, he sank in on himself like a cornered dog. "You can't tie that to me! The Prophet'll hang you if you touch me! He's hanged nobles before, fine lords and ladies. I walk in the Light of the blessed Lord Dragon!"

pɛɹɪn wɔk stɛpɝ tə ðə mæn, kɛɹfəl tə kip ðə dʌnz hʊvz klɪɹ ə ðə . . . θɪŋ . . . ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ lɛs ðən tə hæv ðə fɛloʊz sɛn ɪn ɪz noʊz, bʌɾ i bɛn daʊn, pʊɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs kloʊsɝ. saʊɝ swɛt wɔɹd wɪð fɪɹ, pænɪk, ə tɪnʒ ʌv æŋɡɝ. ə pɪɾi hi kəd nɑt snɪf aʊt ɡɪlt. "maɪɾ əv dʒɹɑpt" wɑz nɑt "hæd dʒɹɑpt." kloʊs-sɛɾ aɪz waɪɾənd, ən ðə mæn pɹɛs bæk əɡɛns tɛɹəlz ɡɛldɪŋ. jɛloʊ aɪz hæd ðɛɹ jusəz.

Perrin walked Stepper to the man, careful to keep the dun's hooves clear of the . . . thing . . . on the ground. He wanted nothing less than to have the fellow's scent in his nose, but he bent down, putting his face closer. Sour sweat warred with fear, panic, a tinge of anger. A pity he could not sniff out guilt. "Might have dropped" was not "had dropped." Close-set eyes widened, and the man pressed back against Teryl's gelding. Yellow eyes had their uses.

"ɪf aɪ kəd taɪ ðət tə ju, jud hæŋ fɹəm ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹi," hi ɡɹaʊld. ðə fɛloʊ blɪŋkt, bɪɡæn tə bɹaɪɾən əz i ʌndɝstʊd wʌt ðət mɛnt, bʌt pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ taɪm tə ɹɪɡeɪn ɪz blʌstɝ. "aɪm pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, ən jəɹ pɹɛʃəs lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən sɛn mi hɪɹ. jə spɹɛd ðə wɝd. hi sɛn mi, ən ɪf aɪ faɪn ə mæn wɪð . . . tʃɹoʊfiz . . . hi hæŋz! ɪf aɪ faɪn ə mæn bɝnɪŋ ə fɑɹm, hi hæŋz! ɪf wʌn ə jə lʊks ət mi kɹɔs-aɪd, hi hæŋz! ən jə kən tɛl mæsimə aɪ sɛd soʊ, tu!" dɪsɡʌstəd, pɛɹɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd. "lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ, tɛɹəl. ɪf i ɪzən aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪɾ ɪn tu ʃeɪks . . . !"

"If I could tie that to you, you'd hang from the nearest tree," he growled. The fellow blinked, began to brighten as he understood what that meant, but Perrin gave him no time to regain his bluster. "I'm Perrin Aybara, and your precious Lord Dragon sent me here. You spread the word. He sent me, and if I find a man with . . . trophies . . . he hangs! If I find a man burning a farm, he hangs! If one of you looks at me cross-eyed, he hangs! And you can tell Masema I said so, too!" Disgusted, Perrin straightened. "Let him go, Teryl. If he isn't out of my sight in two shakes . . . !"

tɛɹəlz hæn oʊpənd, ən ðə fɛloʊ dæʃt ɔf əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn fəɹ ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹiz, nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænsɪŋ bæk. pɑɹɾ ə pɛɹɪnz dɪsɡʌst wɑz fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. θɹɛɾənɪŋ! ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm lʊkt əɾ ɪm kɹɔs-aɪd? bʌɾ ɪf ðə neɪmləs mæn hæd nɑt kʌɾ ɔf ɪɹz hɪmsɛlf, hi hæd wɑtʃt ɪɾ ən dʌn nʌθɪŋ.

Teryl's hand opened, and the fellow dashed off at a dead run for the nearest trees, never so much as glancing back. Part of Perrin's disgust was for himself. Threatening! If one of them looked at him cross-eyed? But if the nameless man had not cut off ears himself, he had watched it and done nothing.

feɪl wɑz smaɪlɪŋ, pɹaɪd ʃaɪnɪŋ θɹu ðə swɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs. hɝ lʊk wɑʃt əweɪ səm ə pɛɹɪnz ɹɪvʌlʃən. hi wəd wɔk bɛɹfʊt θɹu faɪɝ fəɹ ðət lʊk.

Faile was smiling, pride shining through the sweat on her face. Her look washed away some of Perrin's revulsion. He would walk barefoot through fire for that look.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn əpɹuvd, ʌv kɔɹs. siɑnɪdz aɪz wɝ skwizd ʃʌt, ən əɹ ɡlʌv fɪsts kwɪvɝɾ ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz əz ðoʊ ʃi dɛspɝətli wɑntəd tə jæŋk ðət skɑɹf fɹəm əɹ maʊθ ən tɛl ɪm wʌt ʃi θɔt. hi kəd ɡɛs ɛniweɪ. ɛdʒɹə ən nəvɛɝɪn hæd ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ ʃɔlz ɝaʊn əm ən wɝ aɪɪŋ ɪm dɑɹkli. oʊ, jɛs; hi kəd ɡɛs.

Not everyone approved, of course. Seonid's eyes were squeezed shut, and her gloved fists quivered on her reins as though she desperately wanted to yank that scarf from her mouth and tell him what she thought. He could guess anyway. Edarra and Nevarin had gathered their shawls around them and were eyeing him darkly. Oh, yes; he could guess.

"aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi ɔl sikɹəsi," tɛɹəl sɛd kæʒəwəli, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə stʌbəl-tʃik mæn ɹʌn. "aɪ θɔt mæsimə wɑzn tə noʊ jə wɝ hɪɹ tɪl jə spoʊk ɪn ɪz pɪŋk ɪɹ."

"I thought it was to be all secrecy," Teryl said casually, watching the stubble-cheeked man run. "I thought Masema wasn't to know you were here till you spoke in his pink ear."

ðət hæd bɪn ðə plæn. ɹænd hæd sədʒɛstəɾ ɪɾ əz ə pɹikɔʃən, siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɪɾ ɛvɹi tʃæns ðeɪ ɡɑt. æftɝ ɔl, pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əɹ noʊ, mæsimə maɪt nɑt wɑnə kʌm feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð sʌmwʌn ɹænd sɛnt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə θɪŋz i wɑz sɛd tə hæv əlaʊd. ðoʊz ɪɹz wɝ nɑt ðə wɝst, ɪf ðə tɛnθ pɑɹɾ ə ɹumɝ wɑz tə bi bɪlivd. ɛdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz sɔ mæsimə əz ə pɑsəbəl ɛnəmi, tə bi æmbʊʃt bɪfɔɹ i kəd sɛɾ ɪz oʊn tʃɹæp.

That had been the plan. Rand had suggested it as a precaution, Seonid and Masuri had insisted on it every chance they got. After all, Prophet of the Lord Dragon or no, Masema might not want to come face-to-face with someone Rand sent, considering the things he was said to have allowed. Those ears were not the worst, if the tenth part of rumor was to be believed. Edarra and the other Wise Ones saw Masema as a possible enemy, to be ambushed before he could set his own trap.

"aɪm səpoʊz tə stɑp . . . ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ æŋɡɹəli tə ðə ɹɔhaɪd stʃɹɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi hæd hɝd ðə ɹumɝz, ən dʌn nʌθɪŋ. naʊ hi hæd sin. "aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl stɑɹt naʊ." ən ɪf mæsimə dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑz ən ɛnəmi? haʊ mɛni θaʊzənz fɑloʊd ðə pɹɑfət, aʊɾ ə bɪlif əɹ fɪɹ? ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. "ɪt stɑps, tɛɹəl. ɪt stɑps!"

"I'm supposed to stop . . . that," Perrin said, gesturing angrily to the rawhide string on the ground. He had heard the rumors, and done nothing. Now he had seen. "I might as well start now." And if Masema decided he was an enemy? How many thousands followed the Prophet, out of belief or fear? It did not matter. "It stops, Teryl. It stops!"

ðə mʊɹændiən nɑɾəd sloʊli, aɪɪŋ pɛɹɪn əz ðoʊ siɪŋ ɪm fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm.

The Murandian nodded slowly, eyeing Perrin as though seeing him for the first time.

"maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?" meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd. hi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ɔl əbaʊɾ əɹ ən əɹ fɹɛnz. ði ʌðɝz hæd ɡæðɝd wɪð əɹ ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf, moʊst stɪl əfʊt. ðəɹ wɝ θɹi mɛn əsaɪd fɹəm ðə fɛloʊ hu hæd fɑloʊd meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən tu ʌv ðoʊz wɝ haɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. lini əpɪɹd ðə wɛɹiəst ʌv ɔl, aɪz foʊkəst ɑn ɪm wɝidli; ʃi hæɾ əɹ hɔɹs kloʊs tə meɪaɪɡdɪnz ən simd ɹɛɾi tə siz ðə bɹaɪɾəl hɝsɛlf. nɑt tə stɑp ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən boʊltɪŋ, bʌt tə boʊl hɝsɛlf ən teɪk meɪaɪɡdɪn wɪð hɝ. meɪaɪɡdɪn hɝsɛlf əpɪɹd kəmplitli əɾ iz, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ stʌɾid pɛɹɪn. lɪɾəl wʌndɝ, æftɝ ɔl ðət tɔk ə ðə pɹɑfəɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɑn tɑp ə hɪz aɪz. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡæɡd. hi ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə seɪ ðət ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ naʊ, ɪmiɾiətli, bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd wɑz "wi wɪl æksɛp jəɹ kaɪn ɔfɝ. ə deɪ əɹ tu ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn jəɹ kæmp maɪt bi dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ."

"My Lord Perrin?" Maighdin said. He had forgotten all about her and her friends. The others had gathered with her a little way off, most still afoot. There were three men aside from the fellow who had followed Maighdin, and two of those were hiding behind their horses. Lini appeared the wariest of all, eyes focused on him worriedly; she had her horse close to Maighdin's and seemed ready to seize the bridle herself. Not to stop the younger woman bolting, but to bolt herself and take Maighdin with her. Maighdin herself appeared completely at ease, but she also studied Perrin. Little wonder, after all that talk of the Prophet and the Dragon Reborn, on top of his eyes. Not to mention an Aes Sedai gagged. He expected her to say that they wanted to go now, immediately, but what she said instead was "We will accept your kind offer. A day or two resting in your camp might be just the thing."

"æz jə seɪ, mɪstʃɹəs meɪaɪɡdɪn," hi sɛd sloʊli. mæskɪŋ ɪz sɝpɹaɪz wɑz dɪfəkəlt. ɪspɛʃli sɪns i hæd dʒʌst ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə tu mɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪtwin əm ən hɪm. tɑvɝən wɝk, tə bɹɪŋ əm hɪɹ? ə stʃɹeɪnʒ twɪst ɪn ɛni keɪs. "ɪt maɪt bi dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ ət ðæt."

"As you say, Mistress Maighdin," he said slowly. Masking his surprise was difficult. Especially since he had just recognized the two men trying to keep their horses between them and him. Ta'veren work, to bring them here? A strange twist in any case. "It might be just the thing at that."


tʃæptɝ eɪt


CHAPTER 8

eɪ sɪmpəl kʌntʃɹi wʊmən


A Simple Country Woman

ðə kæmp leɪ əbaʊɾ ə liɡ fɑɹðɝ ɑn, wɛl bæk fɹəm ðə ɹoʊɾ əmʌŋ loʊ, wʊɾɪd hɪlz, dʒʌs bɪɑn ə stʃɹim ðət wɑz tɛn peɪsɪz' wɪdθ ə stoʊnz ən oʊnli faɪv ʌv wɔɾɝ nɛvɝ dipɝ ðən ə mænz niz. taɪni ɡɹin ən sɪlvɝ fɪʃ dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz. kæʒəwəl pæsɝzbi wɝ ənlaɪkli tə kʌm ɑn əm hɪɹ. ðə nɪɹəst ɪnhæbəɾəd fɑɹm wɑz oʊvɝ ə maɪl əweɪ, ən pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɛk pɝsənəli tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðoʊz foʊk tʊk ðɛɹ ænəməlz tə wɔɾɝ ɛlswɛɹ.

The camp lay about a league farther on, well back from the road among low, wooded hills, just beyond a stream that was ten paces' width of stones and only five of water never deeper than a man's knees. Tiny green and silver fish darted away from the horses' hooves. Casual passersby were unlikely to come on them here. The nearest inhabited farm was over a mile away, and Perrin had checked personally to make sure those folk took their animals to water elsewhere.

hi tʃɹuli hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, tʃɹævlɪŋ baɪ bæk ɹoʊdz ən ðə smɔləs kʌntʃɹi pæðz wən ðeɪ kəd nɑt kip tə ðə fɔɹəsts. ə fjuɾəl ɛfɝt, ɹɪli. ðə hɔɹsəz kəd bi pæstʃɝd wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɡɹæs, bʌt ðeɪ ɹikwaɪɝɾ ət list səm ɡɹeɪn, ən ivən ə smɔl ɑɹmi hæd tə baɪ fud, ən ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪt. ɛvɹi mæn niɾəd fɔɹ paʊnz ə deɪ, ɪn flaʊɝ ən binz ən mit. ɹumɝz mʌst əv bɪn floʊɾɪŋ ɔl oʊvɝ ɡildən, ðoʊ wɪð lʌk, noʊ wʌn səspɛktəɾ u ðeɪ wɝ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd nɑt, əntɪl i wɛn ən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. stɪl, hi wʊɾə dʌn nʌθɪŋ dɪfɹənli.

He truly had been trying to avoid notice as much as possible, traveling by back roads and the smallest country paths when they could not keep to the forests. A futile effort, really. The horses could be pastured wherever there was grass, but they required at least some grain, and even a small army had to buy food, and a lot of it. Every man needed four pounds a day, in flour and beans and meat. Rumors must have been floating all over Ghealdan, though with luck, no one suspected who they were. Perrin grimaced. Perhaps they had not, until he went and opened his mouth. Still, he would have done nothing differently.

ɪt wɑz θɹi kæmps ɹɪli, kloʊs tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ən nʌn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə stʃɹim. ðeɪ tʃɹævəl təɡɛðɝ, ɔl fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm, oʊbeɪɪŋ ɪm səpoʊzədli, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni pɝsənælɪɾiz ɪnvɑlvd, ən noʊ wʌn wɑz ɪntaɪɝli ʃʊɹ ði ʌðɝz eɪmd ət ðə seɪm ɡoʊl. səm naɪn hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz hæd ðɛɹ kʊk faɪɝz kɹaʊɾəd bɪtwin ɹoʊz ə pɪkəɾɪd hɔɹsəz ɪn ə bɹɔd mɛdoʊ ʌv tʃɹæmpəl bɹaʊn ɡɹæs. hi tʃɹaɪd tə kloʊz ɪz noʊz tə ðə mɪŋɡəl smɛlz ə hɔɹsəz, swɛt, dʌŋ ən bɔɪlɪŋ ɡoʊt mit, ən ənplɛzən kɑmbəneɪʃən ɑn ə hɑt deɪ. ə dʌzən maʊntəd sɛntʃɹiz ɹoʊɾ ə sloʊ sɝkəɾ ɪn pɛɹz, ðɛɹ lɔŋ, ɹɛd-stʃɹimɝd lænsɪz ɔl ət pɹɪsaɪsli ðə seɪm æŋɡəl, bʌt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə minɝz hæd ʃɛd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts. koʊtləs ən ɔfən ʃɝtləs ɪn ðə sʌn, ðeɪ leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ðɛɹ blæŋkəts əɹ daɪst əz ðeɪ weɪɾəd ɑn ðə fud. səm lʊkt ʌp əz pɛɹɪn pæst, ə nʌmbɝ stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ tə stʌɾi ði ədɪʃənz tə hɪz pɑɹɾi, bʌt nʌn keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ, soʊ ðə pətʃɹoʊlz wɝ stɪl aʊt. smɔl pətʃɹoʊlz, wɪθaʊt lænsɪz, hu kəd si wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin. wɛl, ðət wɑz ðə hoʊp. ɪt hæd bɪn.

It was three camps really, close to one another and none far from the stream. They traveled together, all following him, obeying him supposedly, but there were too many personalities involved, and no one was entirely sure the others aimed at the same goal. Some nine hundred or so Winged Guards had their cook fires crowded between rows of picketed horses in a broad meadow of trampled brown grass. He tried to close his nose to the mingled smells of horses, sweat, dung and boiling goat meat, an unpleasant combination on a hot day. A dozen mounted sentries rode a slow circuit in pairs, their long, red-streamered lances all at precisely the same angle, but the rest of the Mayeners had shed breastplates and helmets. Coatless and often shirtless in the sun, they lay sprawled on their blankets or diced as they waited on the food. Some looked up as Perrin passed, a number straightened from what they were doing to study the additions to his party, but none came running, so the patrols were still out. Small patrols, without lances, who could see without being seen. Well, that was the hope. It had been.

ə hændfʊl ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn muvd ət vɛɹiəs tʃɔɹz əmʌŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz' loʊ ɡɹeɪ-bɹaʊn tɛns ɑn ðə spɑɹsli wʊɾɪd kɹɛst ə ðə hɪl əbʌv ðə minɝz. ət ðɪs dɪstəns, ðə waɪt-ɹoʊb fɪɡjɝz əpɪɹd hɑɹmləs, aɪz daʊnkæst ən mik. ʌp kloʊs, ðeɪ wəd lʊk ðə seɪm, bʌt moʊst wɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðə waɪz wʌnz kleɪmd ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn; pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌst ɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt. ɔf tə wʌn saɪɾ ɑn ðə sloʊp, bɪniθ ə bɪdʒɹæɡəl saʊɝɡəm, pɝhæps ə dʌzən meɪɾənz ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ nɛlt ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn səlɪn, ðə tʌfəst ə ðɛm dɪspaɪɾ əɹ waɪt hɛɹ. ʃi hæd sɛn aʊt skaʊts, tu, wɪmən u kəd muv əz fæst əfʊɾ əz ðə minɝz ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli tə ɪskeɪp ənwɔntɪɾ ətɛnʃən. nʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz ʌp ðəɹ wɝ ɪn ði oʊpən, bʌɾ ə slɛndɝ wʊmən stɝɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ stu kɛɾəl stʃɹeɪɾənd, nʌklɪŋ əɹ bæk əz ʃi wɑtʃt pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz pæs. ə wʊmən ɪn ə ɡɹin sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs.

A handful of gai'shain moved at various chores among the Wise Ones' low gray-brown tents on the sparsely wooded crest of the hill above the Mayeners. At this distance, the white-robed figures appeared harmless, eyes downcast and meek. Up close, they would look the same, but most were Shaido. The Wise Ones claimed gai'shain were gai'shain; Perrin did not trust any Shaido out of his sight. Off to one side on the slope, beneath a bedraggled sourgum, perhaps a dozen Maidens in cadin'sor knelt in a circle around Sulin, the toughest of them despite her white hair. She had sent out scouts, too, women who could move as fast afoot as the Mayeners on their horses and were much more likely to escape unwanted attention. None of the Wise Ones up there were in the open, but a slender woman stirring a large stew kettle straightened, knuckling her back as she watched Perrin and the others pass. A woman in a green silk riding dress.

hi kəd si ðə ɡlɛɹ ɑn mɑsʊɝiz feɪs. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑt stɝ kɛɾəlz, nɔɹ pɝfɔɹm twɛnti ʌðɝ tæsks ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ əɹ ən siɑnɪd duɪŋ. mɑsʊɝi leɪɾ ɪɾ ət ɹændz fit, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt hɪɹ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz. ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns, ʃi wəd pil ɪz haɪd fəɹ hɪm.

He could see the glare on Masuri's face. Aes Sedai did not stir kettles, nor perform twenty other tasks the Wise Ones had her and Seonid doing. Masuri laid it at Rand's feet, but he was not here, and Perrin was. Given half a chance, she would peel his hide for him.

ɛdʒɹə ən nəvɛɝɪn tɝn ʌp ðət weɪ, ivən ɪn ðoʊz bʌlki skɝts bɛɹli dɪstɝbɪŋ ðə leɪɝz ə dɛd livz ðət kɑɹpəɾɪd ðə ɡɹaʊnd. siɑnɪd fɑloʊd, hɝ tʃiks stɪl bʌlʒɪŋ ɝaʊn ðət skɑɹf. ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, piɹɪŋ bæk ət pɛɹɪn. ɪf i cʊɾə bɪlivd ən ɛɛs sədaɪ lʊkɪŋ æŋkʃəs, ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wʊɾə kɔl hɝ. ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, fʊɹən ən tɛɹəl wɔɹ skaʊlz.

Edarra and Nevarin turned up that way, even in those bulky skirts barely disturbing the layers of dead leaves that carpeted the ground. Seonid followed, her cheeks still bulging around that scarf. She twisted in her saddle, peering back at Perrin. If he could have believed an Aes Sedai looking anxious, that was what he would have called her. Riding behind her, Furen and Teryl wore scowls.

mɑsʊɝi sɔ ðɛm kʌmɪŋ ən heɪstəli bɛn bæk tə ðə blæk kɛɾəl, stɝɪŋ wɪð ɹɪnud vɪɡɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ stɑpt. soʊ lɔŋ əz mɑsʊɝi steɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪz wʌnz' tʃɑɹdʒ, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz haɪd. ðə waɪz wʌnz sim tə kip ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt liʃ.

Masuri saw them coming and hastily bent back to the black kettle, stirring with renewed vigor, trying to make out that she had never stopped. So long as Masuri stayed in the Wise Ones' charge, Perrin thought he did not have to worry about his hide. The Wise Ones seemed to keep a very short leash.

nəvɛɝɪn lʊk bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm, ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz dɑɹk stɛɹz i hæd bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹəm əɹ ən ɛdʒɹə sɪns sɛndɪŋ ɪz wɔɹnɪŋ, hɪz θɹɛt, baɪ ðə stʌbəl-tʃik fɛloʊ. pɛɹɪn ɛksheɪld ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz pɛlt ənlɛs ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ɪt. tu mɛni pɝsənælɪɾiz. tu mɛni ɡoʊlz.

Nevarin looked back over her shoulder at him, another of those dark stares he had been getting from her and Edarra since sending his warning, his threat, by the stubble-cheeked fellow. Perrin exhaled in exasperation. He did not have to worry about his pelt unless the Wise Ones decided they wanted it. Too many personalities. Too many goals.

meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹoʊɾ ət feɪlz saɪd, simɪŋli peɪɪŋ noʊ ətɛnʃən tə wʌt ðeɪ pæst, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv weɪdʒɝɾ ə splɪt kɑpɝ ɑn ɪt. hɝ aɪz hæd waɪɾənd ə hɛɹ ət saɪɾ ə ðə minɝ sɛntʃɹiz. ʃi nu wʌt ɹɛd bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts laɪk ɹɪm pɑts mɛnt, əz ʃʊɹli əz ʃi hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs. moʊs pipəl wəd nɑɾ əv noʊn iðɝ, ɪspɛʃli nɑt foʊk dʒɹɛst əz ʃi wɑz. ʃi wɑz ə mɪstɝi, ðɪs meɪaɪɡdɪn. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi sim veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ.

Maighdin rode at Faile's side, seemingly paying no attention to what they passed, but he would not have wagered a split copper on it. Her eyes had widened a hair at sight of the Mayener sentries. She knew what red breastplates and helmets like rimmed pots meant, as surely as she had recognized an Aes Sedai face. Most people would not have known either, especially not folk dressed as she was. She was a mystery, this Maighdin. For some reason, she seemed vaguely familiar.

lini ən tɑlænvɝ - ðət wɑz wʌɾ i hæd hɝd meɪaɪɡdɪn kɔl ðə fɛloʊ hu hæd ɹɪɾən æftɝ hɝ; "jʌŋ" tɑlænvɝ, ðoʊ ðəɹ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ əɹ faɪv jɪɹz bɪtwin əm ɪf ðət - steɪɾ əz kloʊs bɪhaɪn meɪaɪɡdɪn əz pɑsəbəl, wɪð ɛɹæm ɪn ðə weɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hil pɛɹɪn. soʊ dɪɾ ə lɪɾəl stɪk ʌv ə fɛloʊ wɪð ə pɝs maʊθ, kɔl beɪlwɝ, hu sim tə peɪ lɛs hid tə ðɛɹ sɝaʊndɪŋz ðən meɪaɪɡdɪn pɹitɛndəd. ivən soʊ, pɛɹɪn θɔt beɪlwɝ sɔ mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪd. hi kəd nɑt seɪ waɪ, pɹɪsaɪsli, bʌt ðə fju taɪmz i hæd kɑt ðə boʊni lɪɾəl mænz sɛnt, hi hæd bɪn maɪndəɾ ʌv ə wʊlf tɛstɪŋ ði ɛɹ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪɹ ɪn beɪlwɝ, oʊnli kwɪkli səpɹɛst ɹɪdʒəz ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən ʃɑt θɹu wɪð ðə kwɪvɝi smɛl ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ə meɪaɪɡdɪnz kəmpænjənz tʃɹeɪld əlɔŋ wɛl bæk. ðə θɝd wʊmən, bɹin, wɑz wɪspɝɪŋ fɪɹsli tə ə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ hu kɛpt ɪz aɪz daʊn ən səmtaɪmz nɑɾəd saɪlənli, səmtaɪmz ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ə ʃoʊldɝstʃɹaɪkɝ ən stʃɹit tʌf ɪf ɛvɝ ðəɹ wɑz wʌn, bʌt ðə ʃɔɹt wʊmən hæɾ ən ɛdʒ ə tʌfnəs əbaʊt hɝ, tu. ðə læs mæn ʃɛltɝd bɪhaɪn ðoʊz tu, ə staʊt mæn wɪð ə bæɾɝd stʃɹɔ hæt pʊld loʊ tə haɪɾ ɪz feɪs. ɑn hɪm, ðə sɔɹd ðə mɛn ɔl wɔɹ lʊkt əz stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ɪt dɪɾ ɑn beɪlwɝ.

Lini and Tallanvor - that was what he had heard Maighdin call the fellow who had ridden after her; "young" Tallanvor, though there could not have been more than four or five years between them if that - stayed as close behind Maighdin as possible, with Aram in the way trying to heel Perrin. So did a little stick of a fellow with a pursed mouth, called Balwer, who seemed to pay less heed to their surroundings than Maighdin pretended. Even so, Perrin thought Balwer saw more than she did. He could not say why, precisely, but the few times he had caught the bony little man's scent, he had been minded of a wolf testing the air. Strangely, there was no fear in Balwer, only quickly suppressed ridges of irritation shot through with the quivery smell of impatience. The remainder of Maighdin's companions trailed along well back. The third woman, Breane, was whispering fiercely to a hulking fellow who kept his eyes down and sometimes nodded silently, sometimes shook his head. A shoulderstriker and street tough if ever there was one, but the short woman had an edge of toughness about her, too. The last man sheltered behind those two, a stout man with a battered straw hat pulled low to hide his face. On him, the sword the men all wore looked as strange as it did on Balwer.

ðə θɝd pɑɹɾ ə ðə kæmp, spɹɛɾ aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz dʒʌst ɝaʊn ðə kɝv ə ðə hɪl fɹəm ðə minɝz, kʌvɝɾ əz mʌtʃ ɡɹaʊn əz ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz' ðoʊ ɪt hɛl fɑɹ fjuɝ pipəl. hɪɹ, ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ pɪkəɾɪd wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə kʊk faɪɝz, soʊ ði ənblɛmɪʃt smɛl ə dɪnɝ fɪl ði ɛɹ. ɹoʊstɪŋ ɡoʊt, ðɪs taɪm, ən hɑɹd tɝnəps ðə fɑɹmɝz pɹɑbli hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə fid tə ðɛɹ pɪɡz ivən wɪð taɪmz əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ wɝ. kloʊs ɑn tə θɹi hʌnʒɹəd tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn u hæd fɑloʊd pɛɹɪn əweɪ fɹəm hoʊm wɝ tɛndɪŋ miɾ ɑn spɪts, mɛndɪŋ kloʊðz, tʃɛkɪŋ oʊvɝ æɹoʊz ən baʊz, ɔl skæɾɝd ɪn hæphæzɝd klʌmps ə faɪv əɹ sɪks fɹɛnz ɝaʊn ə faɪɝ. nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm weɪvd ən ʃaʊɾəd ɡɹiɾɪŋz, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ ʌv "lɔɹd pɛɹɪn" ən "pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz" tə sut hɪm. feɪl hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə ðə taɪɾəlz ðeɪ ɡeɪv hɝ.

The third part of the camp, spread out among the trees just around the curve of the hill from the Mayeners, covered as much ground as the Winged Guards' though it held far fewer people. Here, the horses were picketed well away from the cook fires, so the unblemished smell of dinner filled the air. Roasting goat, this time, and hard turnips the farmers probably had intended to feed to their pigs even with times as hard as they were. Close on to three hundred Two Rivers men who had followed Perrin away from home were tending meat on spits, mending clothes, checking over arrows and bows, all scattered in haphazard clumps of five or six friends around a fire. Nearly every one of them waved and shouted greetings, though there was too much of "Lord Perrin" and "Perrin Goldeneyes" to suit him. Faile had a right to the titles they gave her.

ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild, ənswiɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ naɪt-blæk koʊts, dɪd nɑt tʃɪɹ; stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə kʊk faɪɝ ðeɪ hæd bɪlt ə lɪɾəl əweɪ fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ðeɪ mɪɹli lʊkt ət hɪm. ɪkspɛktən lʊks, hi θɔt. ɪkspɛktɪŋ wʌt? ðət wɑz ðə kwɛstʃən i ɔlweɪz æsk hɪmsɛlf əbaʊt ðɛm. ði æʃəmən meɪɾ ɪm ənizi, mɔɹ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ waɪz wʌnz. wɪmən tʃænəlɪŋ ðə paʊɝ wɑz nætʃɹəl, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɛniθɪŋ ə mæn kəd bi kʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊnd. pleɪn-feɪst ɡɹeɪɾi əpɪɹɾ ə fɑɹmɝ dɪspaɪɾ ɪz koʊɾ ən sɔɹd, ən nild ə poʊpənʒ wɪð ɪz kɝl mʌstæʃɪz, jɛt pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt fɝɡɛt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. bʌt ðɛn, hi hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, tu. ðə laɪt hɛlp hɪm, hi hæd. pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæn fɹəm ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt, hi dɪsmaʊntɪd.

Grady and Neald, unsweating in their night-black coats, did not cheer; standing beside the cook fire they had built a little away from everyone else, they merely looked at him. Expectant looks, he thought. Expecting what? That was the question he always asked himself about them. The Asha'man made him uneasy, more than Aes Sedai or Wise Ones. Women channeling the Power was natural, if not exactly anything a man could be comfortable around. Plain-faced Grady appeared a farmer despite his coat and sword, and Neald a popinjay with his curled mustaches, yet Perrin could not forget what they were, what they had done at Dumai's Wells. But then, he had been there, too. The Light help him, he had. Pulling his hand from the axe at his belt, he dismounted.

sɝvəns, mɛn ən wɪmən fɹəm lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪnz ɪsteɪts ɪn kɛɹhin, keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə laɪnz wɛɹ ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ pɪkəɾɪd, tə teɪk ðɛɹ maʊns. nʌn stʊd tɔlɝ ðən pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ, kʌntʃɹi-klæd foʊk, fɝɛvɝ boʊɪŋ ən kɝtsiɪŋ əbsɪkwiəsli. feɪl sɛɾ i dʒʌst ʌpsɛɾ əm wən i tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk əm stɑp, əɹ ət lis nɑt tə bɑb ɝaʊn ɪm soʊ ɔfən; ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðət wɑz haʊ ðeɪ smɛld wən i dɪd, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz wɛn bæk tə bɑbɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɝ əɹ tu. ʌðɝz, nɪɹli əz mɛni əz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, wɝ wɝkɪŋ wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz əɹ ɝaʊn ðə lɔŋ ɹoʊz ə haɪ-wil kɑɹts ðət hɔld ɔl ðɛɹ səplaɪz. ə fju wɝ dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt tɛnt.

Servants, men and women from Lord Dobraine's estates in Cairhien, came running from the lines where the horses were picketed, to take their mounts. None stood taller than Perrin's shoulder, country-clad folk, forever bowing and curtsying obsequiously. Faile said he just upset them when he tried to make them stop, or at least not to bob around him so often; in truth, that was how they smelled when he did, and they always went back to bobbing in an hour or two. Others, nearly as many as the Two Rivers men, were working with the horses or around the long rows of high-wheeled carts that hauled all their supplies. A few were darting in and out of a large red-and-white tent.

əz juʒəwəl, ðət tɛn meɪd pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌnt ɡluməli. bɹəleɪn hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒɝ wʌn bæk ɪn ðə minɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə kæmp, plʌs wʌn fəɹ əɹ tu meɪdz ən ənʌðɝ fəɹ ðə pɛɹ ə θif-kætʃɝz ʃi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn bɹɪŋɪŋ. ənʊɹə hæɾ ə tɛn ə hɝ oʊn, ən ɡælɛn əz wɛl, bʌɾ oʊnli hi ən feɪl pəzɛst wʌn hɪɹ. fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, hi wʊɾə slɛpt ʌndɝ ðə skaɪ laɪk ði ʌðɝ mɛn fɹəm hoʊm. ðeɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ oʊvɝ əm ət naɪt bʌɾ ə blæŋkət. ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ fɪɹ ə ɹeɪn. ðə kɛɹhinɪn sɝvəns bɛɾəd daʊn bɪniθ ðə kɑɹts. hi kəd nɑɾ æsk feɪl tə də ðæt, ðoʊ, nɑt wən bɹəleɪn hæɾ ə tɛnt. ɪf oʊnli hi cʊɾə lɛf bɹəleɪn ɪn kɛɹhin. bʌt ðən i wʊɾə hæd tə sɛn feɪl ɪndə bɛθɔl.

As usual, that tent made Perrin grunt gloomily. Berelain had a larger one back in the Mayener part of the camp, plus one for her two maids and another for the pair of thief-catchers she had insisted on bringing. Annoura had a tent of her own, and Gallenne as well, but only he and Faile possessed one here. For himself, he would have slept under the sky like the other men from home. They had nothing over them at night but a blanket. There was certainly no fear of rain. The Cairhienin servants bedded down beneath the carts. He could not ask Faile to do that, though, not when Berelain had a tent. If only he could have left Berelain in Cairhien. But then he would have had to send Faile into Bethal.

ə pɛɹ ə bænɝz ɑn tɔl, fɹɛʃ-kʌt poʊlz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə klɪɹ speɪs nɪɹ ðə tɛn saʊɝɾ ɪz mud fɝðɝ. ðə bɹiz hæd pɪkt ʌp ə tʃɹaɪfəl, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz stɪl tu wɔɹm; hi θɔɾ i hɝd ðət θʌndɝ əɡɛn, feɪn ɪn ðə wɛst. ðə flæɡz ənfoʊldəɾ ɪn sloʊ weɪvz, kəlæpst ə ðɛɹ oʊn weɪt, ɹɪpəld oʊpən əɡɛn. hɪz kɹɪmzən-bɔɹɾɝd ɹɛd wʊlfhɛɾ ən ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə lɔŋ-dɛd meɪnɛðɝən, aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən əɡɛn dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz. pɝhæps i hæd stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd, æftɝ ə fæʃən, bʌt wʌt wɑz naʊ ɡildən hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən; æliændɝ wəd nɑt bi suð baɪ hɪɹɪŋ ə ðət bænɝ! hi mænədʒd ə plɛzən feɪs ən ə smaɪl fəɹ ðə stɑki lɪɾəl wʊmən u kɝtsid dipli ən tʊk stɛpɝ əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə nɪɹ θɪŋ. lɔɹdz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi oʊbeɪd, ən ɪf i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ə lɔɹd, wɛl, hi sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ə pʊɹ dʒɑb ʌv ɪt.

A pair of banners on tall, fresh-cut poles in the middle of a clear space near the tent soured his mood further. The breeze had picked up a trifle, though it was still too warm; he thought he heard that thunder again, faint in the west. The flags unfolded in slow waves, collapsed of their own weight, rippled open again. His crimson-bordered Red Wolfhead and the Red Eagle of long-dead Manetheren, out in the open again despite his orders. Perhaps he had stopped trying to hide, after a fashion, but what was now Ghealdan had been part of Manetheren; Alliandre would not be soothed by hearing of that banner! He managed a pleasant face and a smile for the stocky little woman who curtsied deeply and took Stepper away, but it was a near thing. Lords were supposed to be obeyed, and if he was supposed to be a lord, well, he seemed to be making a poor job of it.

fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, meɪaɪɡdɪn stʊd stʌɾiɪŋ ðoʊz ɹɪpəlɪŋ flæɡz əz əɹ hɔɹs wɑz teɪkən ɔf wɪð ðə ɹɛst. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, bɹin hæd boʊθ ðɛɹ bʌndəlz, hɛld ɔkwɝdli; ʃi wɔɹ ə pɛtʃələn skaʊl, dɝɛktəɾ ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ əbaʊt bænɝz laɪk ðoʊz," meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. ən æŋɡɹəli; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ æŋɡɝ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, ən əɹ feɪs wɑz smuð əz aɪs, bʌɾ əɹ fjʊɹi fɪl pɛɹɪnz noʊz. "ðeɪ wɝ ɹeɪz baɪ mɛn ɪn ændɝ, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, hu ɹɪbɛld əɡɛns ðɛɹ lɔfəl ɹulɝ. eɪbɑɹə ɪz ə tu ɹɪvɝz neɪm, aɪ θɪŋk."

Fists on her hips, Maighdin stood studying those rippling flags as her horse was taken off with the rest. Surprisingly, Breane had both their bundles, held awkwardly; she wore a petulant scowl, directed at the other woman. "I have heard about banners like those," Maighdin said suddenly. And angrily; there was no anger in her voice, and her face was smooth as ice, but her fury filled Perrin's nose. "They were raised by men in Andor, in the Two Rivers, who rebelled against their lawful ruler. Aybara is a Two Rivers name, I think."

"wi doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt lɔfəl ɹulɝz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mɪstʃɹəs meɪaɪɡdɪn," hi ɡɹaʊld. hi wɑz gɑnə skɪn huɛvɝ hæd pʊɾ əm ʌp ðɪs taɪm. ɪf stɔɹiz əbaʊt ɹɪbɛljən hæd spɹɛd ðɪs fɑɹ. . . . hi feɪs tu mɛni kɑmpləkeɪʃənz ɔlɹɛɾi wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ mɔɹ. "aɪ səpoʊz mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz ə ɡʊd kwin, bʌt wi hæd tə fɛn fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz, ən wi dɪd." əbɹʌpli hi nu hu ʃi ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv. ɪleɪn. nɑt ðəɾ ɪt mɛn ɛniθɪŋ; hi hæd sin mɛn ə θaʊzən maɪlz fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz u cʊɾə bɪlɔŋ tə fæmliz i nu bæk hoʊm. stɪl, ʃi hæd tə hæv səm ɹizən fəɹ æŋɡɝ. hɝ æksɛn kəd bi ændɔɝən. "θɪŋz ɑɹən əz bæɾ ɪn ændɝ əz jə maɪɾ əv hɝd," hi toʊl hɝ. "keɪɛmlɪn wɑz kwaɪət, læst aɪ wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ɹænd - ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - minz tə pʊt mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɔɾɝ ɪleɪn ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn."

"We don't know much about lawful rulers in the Two Rivers, Mistress Maighdin," he growled. He was going to skin whoever had put them up this time. If stories about rebellion had spread this far. . . . He faced too many complications already without adding more. "I suppose Morgase was a good queen, but we had to fend for ourselves, and we did." Abruptly he knew who she reminded him of. Elayne. Not that it meant anything; he had seen men a thousand miles from the Two Rivers who could have belonged to families he knew back home. Still, she had to have some reason for anger. Her accent could be Andoran. "Things aren't as bad in Andor as you might have heard," he told her. "Caemlyn was quiet, last I was there, and Rand - the Dragon Reborn - means to put Morgase's daughter Elayne on the Lion Throne."

fɑɹ fɹəm biɪŋ mɑləfaɪd, meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɪm, blu aɪz bleɪzɪŋ. "hi ɪntɛnz tə pʊɾ əɹ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn? noʊ mæn pʊts ə kwin ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn! ɪleɪn wɪl kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ baɪ hɝ ɹaɪt!"

Far from being mollified, Maighdin rounded on him, blue eyes blazing. "He intends to put her on the throne? No man puts a queen on the Lion Throne! Elayne will claim the throne of Andor by her right!"

skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛd, pɛɹɪn wɪʃt feɪl wəd stɑp wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊmən soʊ kɑmli ən seɪ sʌmθɪŋ. bʌɾ ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz tʌk əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt. bɪfɔɹ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv wʌt tə seɪ, lini dɑɹɾɪd ɪn, sizɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪnz ɑɹm ən ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə ʃeɪk fɪt tə ɹæɾəl əɹ tiθ.

Scratching his head, Perrin wished Faile would stop watching the woman so calmly and say something. But all she did was tuck her riding gloves behind her belt. Before he could think of what to say, Lini darted in, seizing Maighdin's arm and giving her a shake fit to rattle her teeth.

"ju əpɑlədʒaɪz!" ði oʊld wʊmən bɑɹkt. "ðɪs mæn seɪv jəɹ laɪf, meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən jə fɝɡɛt jɝsɛlf, ə sɪmpəl kʌntʃɹi wʊmən spikɪŋ soʊ tə ə lɔɹd! ɹɪmɛmbɝ u jə ɑɹ, ən doʊn lɛt jəɹ tʌŋ læn jə ɪn hɑɾɝ wɔɾɝ! ɪf ðɪs jʌŋ lɔɹd wɑz əɾ ɑdz wɪð mɔɹɡeɪs, wɛl, ɛvɹiwʌn noʊz ʃiz dɛd, ən ɪts nʌn ə jəɹ əfɛɹ ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt! naʊ əpɑlədʒaɪz bɪfɔɹ i ɡɹoʊz æŋɡɹi!"

"You apologize!" the old woman barked. "This man saved your life, Maighdin, and you forget yourself, a simple country woman speaking so to a lord! Remember who you are, and don't let your tongue land you in hotter water! If this young lord was at odds with Morgase, well, everyone knows she's dead, and it's none of your affair in any event! Now apologize before he grows angry!"

meɪaɪɡdɪn stɛɹɾ ət lini, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ, ivən mɔɹ stɑɹɾəld ðən pɛɹɪn. əɡɛn ʃi sɝpɹaɪz hɪm, ðoʊ. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪɹʌptɪŋ ət ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən, ʃi sloʊli dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, ʃoʊldɝz skwɛɹd, ən lʊkt ɪm ɪn ði aɪ. "lini ɪz ɪntaɪɝli ɹaɪt. aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə spik tə jə soʊ, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə. aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz. hʌmbli. ən aɪ æsk jəɹ pɑɹɾən." hʌmbəl? hɝ dʒɔ wɑz stʌbɝn, hɝ toʊn pɹaʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əɹ sɛn sɛd ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə tʃu ə hoʊl ɪn sʌmθɪŋ.

Maighdin stared at Lini, her mouth working, even more startled than Perrin. Again she surprised him, though. Instead of erupting at the white-haired woman, she slowly drew herself up, shoulders squared, and looked him in the eye. "Lini is entirely right. I have no right to speak to you so, Lord Aybara. I apologize. Humbly. And I ask your pardon." Humble? Her jaw was stubborn, her tone proud enough for an Aes Sedai, and her scent said she was ready to chew a hole in something.

"ju hæv ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd heɪstəli. wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt sim tə pleɪkeɪɾ əɹ wʌn bɪt. ʃi smaɪld, ən meɪbi ʃi ɪntɛndəd ɡɹæɾətud, bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ əɹ tiθ ɡɹaɪndɪŋ. wɝ wɪmən ɔl kɹeɪzi?

"You have it," Perrin said hastily. Which did not seem to placate her one bit. She smiled, and maybe she intended gratitude, but he could hear her teeth grinding. Were women all crazy?

"ðeɪ ɑɹ hɑɾ ən dɝɾi, hʌzbənd," feɪl sɛd, pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn ɪn ət læst, "æn ðə læs fju aʊɝz əv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm, aɪ noʊ. ɛɹæm kən ʃoʊ ðə mɛn wɛɹ tə klin ðɛmsɛlvz. əl teɪk ðə wɪmən wɪð mi. əl əv dæmp klɔθs bɹɔt tə wɑʃ jəɹ hænz ən feɪsəz," ʃi toʊl meɪaɪɡdɪn ən lini. ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp bɹin wɪð ə dʒɛstʃɝ, ʃi bɪɡæn hɝɾɪŋ əm təwɔɹd ðə tɛnt. əɾ ə nɑd fɹəm pɛɹɪn, ɛɹæm moʊʃən ðə mɛn tə fɑloʊ hɪm.

"They are hot and dirty, husband," Faile said, putting a hand in at last, "and the last few hours have been trying for them, I know. Aram can show the men where to clean themselves. I will take the women with me. I'll have damp cloths brought to wash your hands and faces," she told Maighdin and Lini. Gathering up Breane with a gesture, she began herding them toward the tent. At a nod from Perrin, Aram motioned the men to follow him.

"æz sun əz jə fɪnɪʃ jəɹ wɑʃ, mæstɝ ɡɪl, aɪd laɪk tə tɔk wɪð ju," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"As soon as you finish your wash, Master Gill, I'd like to talk with you," Perrin said.

hi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv meɪd ðət spɪnɪŋ wil ə faɪɝ. meɪaɪɡdɪn wɪpt ɝaʊn tə ɡeɪp ət hɪm, ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən fɹoʊz ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹæks. tɑlænvɝ wɑz sʌɾənli ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt əɡɛn, ən beɪlwɝ ɹoʊz ɑn ɪz toʊz, piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz bʌndəl, hɛd tɪltɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ðən ðæt. nɑɾ ə wʊlf, pɝhæps; səm sɔɹɾ ə bɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ kæts. ðə staʊt mæn, bɑzəl ɡɪl, dʒɹɑpt ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz ən lɛpt ə fʊɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ.

He might as well have made that spinning wheel of fire. Maighdin whipped around to gape at him, and the other two women froze in their tracks. Tallanvor was suddenly gripping his sword hilt again, and Balwer rose on his toes, peering over his bundle, head tilting this way then that. Not a wolf, perhaps; some sort of bird, watching for cats. The stout man, Basel Gill, dropped his belongings and leaped a foot in the air.

"waɪ, pɛɹɪn," hi stæmɝd, snætʃɪŋ ɔf ðə stʃɹɔ hæt. swɛt meɪd tʃɹæks ɪn ðə dʌst ɑn ɪz tʃiks. hi bɛn tə pɪk ʌp ɪz bʌndəl, tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪn ən stʃɹeɪɾənd əɡɛn heɪstəli. "aɪ min, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. aɪ . . . ɑ . . . aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ju, bʌt . . . bʌt wɪð əm kɔlɪŋ jə lɔɹd, aɪ wɑznt ʃʊɹ jud wɑnə noʊ ən oʊld ɪnkipɝ." skɹʌbɪŋ ə hæŋkɝtʃɪf əkɹɔs ɪz nɪɹli bɔl hɛd, hi læf nɝvəsli. "ʌv kɔɹs, əl tɔk tə ju. wɑʃɪŋ kən weɪɾ ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ."

"Why, Perrin," he stammered, snatching off the straw hat. Sweat made tracks in the dust on his cheeks. He bent to pick up his bundle, changed his mind and straightened again hastily. "I mean, Lord Perrin. I . . . ah . . . I thought it was you, but . . . but with them calling you lord, I wasn't sure you'd want to know an old innkeeper." Scrubbing a handkerchief across his nearly bald head, he laughed nervously. "Of course, I'll talk to you. Washing can wait a little longer."

"həloʊ, pɛɹɪn," ðə hʌlkɪŋ mæn sɛd. wɪð ɪz hɛvi-lɪɾɪd aɪz, læmɡwɪn dɔɹn əpɪɹd leɪzi dɪspaɪɾ ɪz mʌsəlz ən ðə skɑɹz ɑn ɪz feɪs ən hænz. "wi hɝɾ əbaʊt jʌŋ ɹænd biɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, mæstɝ ɡɪl ən mi. ʃʊɾə fɪɡjɝd juɾ əv kʌm ʌp ɪn ðə wɝld, tu. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹəz ə ɡʊd mæn, mɪstʃɹəs meɪaɪɡdɪn. aɪ θɪŋk jə kəd tʃɹʌst ɪm wɪð ɛniθɪŋ juv ə maɪn tə." hi wɑz nɑt leɪzi, ən i wɑz nɑt stupəd, iðɝ.

"Hello, Perrin," the hulking man said. With his heavy-lidded eyes, Lamgwin Dorn appeared lazy despite his muscles and the scars on his face and hands. "We heard about young Rand being the Dragon Reborn, Master Gill and me. Should have figured you'd have come up in the world, too. Perrin Aybara's a good man, Mistress Maighdin. I think you could trust him with anything you've a mind to." He was not lazy, and he was not stupid, either.

ɛɹæm dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli, ən læmɡwɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu fɑloʊd, bʌt tɑlænvɝ ən beɪlwɝ dʒɹæɡd ðɛɹ fit, kæstɪŋ wʌndɝɪŋ ɡlænsɪz bæk ət pɛɹɪn ən mæstɝ ɡɪl. kənsɝnd ɡlænsɪz. ən ət ðə wɪmən. feɪl hæɾ əm muvɪŋ əɡɛn, əz wɛl, ðoʊ wɪð plɛnti ʌv dɑɹɾɪd lʊks ət pɛɹɪn ən mæstɝ ɡɪl, ət ðə mɛn tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ɛɹæm. sʌɾənli ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ plizd ət biɪŋ sɛpɝeɪɾəd.

Aram jerked his head impatiently, and Lamgwin and the other two followed, but Tallanvor and Balwer dragged their feet, casting wondering glances back at Perrin and Master Gill. Concerned glances. And at the women. Faile had them moving again, as well, though with plenty of darted looks at Perrin and Master Gill, at the men trailing Aram. Suddenly they were not so pleased at being separated.

mæstɝ ɡɪl mɑpt ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən smaɪld ənizəli. laɪt, waɪ dɪɾ i smɛl əfɹeɪd? pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd. ʌv hɪm? ʌv ə mæn taɪd tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, kɔlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf lɔɹɾ ən liɾɪŋ ən ɑɹmi, haʊɛvɝ smɔl, θɹɛɾənɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət. maɪɾ əz wɛl θɹoʊ ɡæɡɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪndə ɪt, tu; hi wəd teɪk ðə bleɪm fəɹ ðæt, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. noʊ, pɛɹɪn θɔt ɹaɪli; nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðət tə fɹaɪɾən ɛnibəɾi. ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm wɝ pɹɑbli əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt mɝɾɝ əm ɔl.

Master Gill mopped his forehead and smiled uneasily. Light, why did he smell afraid? Perrin wondered. Of him? Of a man tied to the Dragon Reborn, calling himself lord and leading an army, however small, threatening the Prophet. Might as well throw gagging Aes Sedai into it, too; he would take the blame for that, one way or another. No, Perrin thought wryly; nothing in that to frighten anybody. The whole lot of them were probably afraid he might murder them all.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt mæstɝ ɡɪl əɾ iz, hi lɛd ðə mæn tə ə lɑɹdʒ oʊk ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt tɛnt. moʊst ə ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz livz wɝ ɡɔn ən hæf ðoʊz lɛft wɝ bɹaʊn, bʌt mæsɪv lɪmz spɹɛɾɪŋ loʊ pɹəvaɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl ʃeɪd, ən səm ə ðə nɑɹld ɹuts stʊd haɪ ɪnʌf tə sɝv əz bɛntʃɪz. pɛɹɪn hæd juzd wʌn fəɹ dʒʌs ðæt, twɪɾəlɪŋ ɪz θʌmz waɪl kæmp wɑz biɪŋ sɛt. wɛnɛvɝ i tʃɹaɪd tə də ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl, ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz tɛn hænz snætʃɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm.

Trying to put Master Gill at ease, he led the man to a large oak a hundred paces from the red-and-white tent. Most of the great tree's leaves were gone and half those left were brown, but massive limbs spreading low provided a little shade, and some of the gnarled roots stood high enough to serve as benches. Perrin had used one for just that, twiddling his thumbs while camp was being set. Whenever he tried to do anything useful, there were always ten hands snatching it away from him.

bɑzəl ɡɪl wɑz nɑɾ izd, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ pɛɹɪn æskt æftɝ ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, hɪz ɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, əɹ ɹɪkɔld ɪz oʊn vɪzət ðɛɹ. bʌt ðɛn, pɝhæps ɡɪl wɑz ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðət ðət vɪzət wɑz nɑt ðə θɪŋ tə kɑm ə mæn, wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ən tɔk ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ə flaɪɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. hi peɪst æŋkʃəsli ən hʌɡd ɪz bʌndəl tə hɪz tʃɛst, ʃɪftəɾ ɪt fɹəm wʌn ɑɹm tə ði ʌðɝ ən ænsɝɾ ɪn ə bɛɹ hændfʊl ʌv wɝdz, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps bɪtwin.

Basel Gill was not eased, however much Perrin asked after the Queen's Blessing, his inn in Caemlyn, or recalled his own visit there. But then, perhaps Gill was remembering that that visit was not the thing to calm a man, with Aes Sedai and talk of the Dark One and a flight in the night. He paced anxiously and hugged his bundle to his chest, shifted it from one arm to the other and answered in a bare handful of words, licking his lips between.

"mæstɝ ɡɪl," pɛɹɪn toʊld ɪm faɪnəli, "stɑp kɔlɪŋ mi lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. aɪm nɑt. ɪts kɑmpləkeɪɾəd, bʌɾ aɪm nɑɾ ə lɔɹd. jə noʊ ðæt."

"Master Gill," Perrin told him finally, "stop calling me Lord Perrin. I'm not. It's complicated, but I'm not a lord. You know that."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ðə ɹaʊn mæn ɹɪplaɪd, ət læst siɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn wʌn ə ði oʊk ɹuts. hi əpɪɹd ɹɪlʌktən tə sɛɾ ɪz bʌndəl θɪŋz daʊn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz hænz fɹəm əm sloʊli. "æz jə seɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ɑ, ɹænd . . . ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən . . . hi ɹɪli minz ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn tə hæv ðə θɹoʊn? nɑt ðəɾ aɪ daʊt jəɹ wɝd, ʌv kɔɹs," hi æɾəd hɝidli. pʊlɪŋ ɔf ɪz hæt, hi bɪɡæn mɑpɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ əɡɛn. ivən fəɹ sətʃ ə ɹaʊn mæn, hi sim tə bi swɛɾɪŋ twaɪs əz mʌtʃ əz ðə hit kɔl fɔɹ. "aɪm ʃʊɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɪl də dʒʌst əz jə seɪ." hɪz læf wɑz ʃeɪki. "ju wɑntəd tə tɔk tə mi. ən nɑɾ əbaʊt maɪ oʊld ɪn, aɪm ʃʊɹ."

"Of course," the round man replied, at last seating himself on one of the oak roots. He appeared reluctant to set his bundled things down, drawing his hands from them slowly. "As you say, Lord Perrin. Ah, Rand . . . the Lord Dragon . . . he really means the Lady Elayne to have the throne? Not that I doubt your word, of course," he added hurriedly. Pulling off his hat, he began mopping his forehead again. Even for such a round man, he seemed to be sweating twice as much as the heat called for. "I'm sure the Lord Dragon will do just as you say." His laugh was shaky. "You wanted to talk to me. And not about my old inn, I'm sure."

pɛɹɪn ɛksheɪld wɛɹəli. hi hæd θɔt nʌθɪŋ kəd bi wɝs ðən oʊl fɹɛnz ən neɪbɝz boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ, bʌɾ ət lis ðeɪ fɝɡɑt səmtaɪmz ən spoʊk ðɛɹ maɪnz. ən nʌn ə ðɛm wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm. "jɔɹ ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm hoʊm," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɛntəl vɔɪs. noʊ nid tə ɡoʊ tu fæst, nɑt wɪð ə mæn ɹɛɾi tə dʒʌmp aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn. "aɪ wʌndɝd wʌt bɹɔt jə hɪɹ. nɑt tʃɹʌbəlz ʌv ɛni kaɪnd, aɪ hoʊp."

Perrin exhaled wearily. He had thought nothing could be worse than old friends and neighbors bowing and scraping, but at least they forgot sometimes and spoke their minds. And none of them was afraid of him. "You're a long way from home," he said in a gentle voice. No need to go too fast, not with a man ready to jump out of his skin. "I wondered what brought you here. Not troubles of any kind, I hope."

"ju tɛl ɪm ɹaɪt, bɑzəl ɡɪl," lini sɛd ʃɑɹpli, mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp tə ði oʊk. "noʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, maɪnd." ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɡɔn vɛɹi lɔŋ, jɛt sʌmhaʊ ʃi hæd faʊn taɪm tə wɑʃ əɹ feɪs ən hænz ən wɝk əɹ hɛɹ ɪndə ə nit waɪt bʌn ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. ən tə bit moʊst ə ðə dʌs fɹəm əɹ pleɪn wʊlən dʒɹɛs. bɑbɪŋ ə pɝfʌŋktɝi kɝtsi ɪn pɛɹɪnz dɝɛkʃən, ʃi tɝn tə ʃeɪk ə nɑɹl fɪŋɡɝ ət ɡɪl. " 'θɹi θɪŋz ənɔɪ tə dɪstʃɹækʃən: ə tuθ ðəɾ eɪks, ə ʃu ðət pɪntʃɪz, ən ə mæn ðət tʃæɾɝz.' soʊ jə hoʊl tə ðə pɔɪn ən doʊnt ɡoʊ tɛlɪŋ ðə jʌŋ lɔɹd mɔɹ ðən i wɑns tə hɪɹ." fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi hɛl ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ ɪnkipɝ wɪð ən ædmənətɔɹi stɛɹ, ðən əbɹʌpli ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ənʌðɝ kwɪk kɝtsi. "hi dʌz lʌv ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn vɔɪs - moʊs mɛn də - bʌt hɪl tɛl ɪt tə jə pɹɑpɝli, naʊ, maɪ lɔɹd."

"You tell him right, Basel Gill," Lini said sharply, marching up to the oak. "No embroidery, mind." She had not been gone very long, yet somehow she had found time to wash her face and hands and work her hair into a neat white bun on the back of her head. And to beat most of the dust from her plain woolen dress. Bobbing a perfunctory curtsy in Perrin's direction, she turned to shake a gnarled finger at Gill. " 'Three things annoy to distraction: a tooth that aches, a shoe that pinches, and a man that chatters.' So you hold to the point and don't go telling the young lord more than he wants to hear." For a moment she held the gaping innkeeper with an admonitory stare, then abruptly gave Perrin another quick curtsy. "He does love the sound of his own voice - most men do - but he'll tell it to you properly, now, my Lord."

mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡlaʊɝɾ ət hɝ, ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ wən ʃi weɪvd ʃɑɹpli fəɹ ɪm tə spik. "boʊni oʊld . . ." wɑz wʌt pɛɹɪn hɝd. "wʌt hæpənd - ðə sɪmpəl ən stʃɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt - " ðə ɹaʊn mæn ɡlɛɹɾ ət lini əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə noʊɾəs, "wɑz ðəɾ aɪ hæd səm bɪznəs daʊn tə luɡɹd. ə tʃæns tə ɪmpɔɹt waɪn. bʌt jəɹ nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðæt. aɪ tʊk læmɡwɪn əlɔŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən bɹin, kəz ʃi woʊn lɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪɾ ən aʊɝ ʃi dʌzn əv tə. əlɔŋ ðə weɪ, wi mɛt mɪstʃɹəs dɔɹleɪn, mɪstʃɹəs meɪaɪɡdɪn əz wi kɔl hɝ, ən lini, ən tɑlænvɝ. ən beɪlwɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. nɪɹ tə luɡɹd."

Master Gill glowered at her, and muttered under his breath when she waved sharply for him to speak. "Bony old . . ." was what Perrin heard. "What happened - the simple and straight of it - " The round man glared at Lini again, but she did not appear to notice, "was that I had some business down to Lugard. A chance to import wine. But you're not interested in that. I took Lamgwin along, of course, and Breane, because she won't let him out of her sight an hour she doesn't have to. Along the way, we met Mistress Dorlain, Mistress Maighdin as we call her, and Lini, and Tallanvor. And Balwer, of course. On the road. Near to Lugard."

"meɪaɪɡdɪn ən aɪ wɝ ɪn sɝvəs ɪn mʊɹændi," lini pʊɾ ɪn ɪmpeɪʃənli. "əntɪl ðə tʃɹʌbəlz. tɑlænvɝ wɑz ən ɑɹmsmən tə ðə haʊs, ən beɪlwɝ ðə sɛkɹətɛɹi. bændəts bɝn ðə mænɝ, ən əɹ leɪɾi kʊdn əfɔɹd tə kip ʌs, soʊ wi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹævəl təɡɛðɝ fəɹ pɹətɛkʃən."

"Maighdin and I were in service in Murandy," Lini put in impatiently. "Until the troubles. Tallanvor was an armsman to the House, and Balwer the secretary. Bandits burned the manor, and our lady couldn't afford to keep us, so we decided to travel together for protection."

"aɪ wɑz tɛlɪŋ ɪt, lini," mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡɹʌmbəld, skɹætʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹ. "ðə waɪn mɝtʃən hæd lɛf luɡɹd fəɹ ðə kʌntʃɹi, fəɹ səm ɹizən, ən . . ." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪts ɔl tu mʌtʃ tə ɡoʊ ɪntu, pɛɹɪn. lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, aɪ min. fɝɡɪv mi. jə noʊ ðɛɹz tʃɹʌbəl ɛvɹiwɛɹ naʊədeɪz, wʌn kaɪn əɹ ənʌðɝ. simz laɪk ɛvɹi taɪm wi ɹæn fɹəm wʌn kaɪnd, wi faʊn ənʌðɝ, ən ɔlweɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn. tɪl hɪɹ wi ɑɹ, taɪɝɾ ən ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ə ɹɛst. ən ðæts ðə ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪt."

"I was telling it, Lini," Master Gill grumbled, scratching behind his ear. "The wine merchant had left Lugard for the country, for some reason, and . . ." He shook his head. "It's all too much to go into, Perrin. Lord Perrin, I mean. Forgive me. You know there's trouble everywhere nowadays, one kind or another. Seems like every time we ran from one kind, we found another, and always getting farther from Caemlyn. Till here we are, tired and grateful for a rest. And that's the short of it."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli. ðət kəd bi sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ hi hæd lɝn ðət pipəl hæɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹizənz fəɹ laɪɪŋ, əɹ dʒʌst ʃeɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ. ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, hi ɹeɪk fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. laɪt! hi wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ səspɪʃəs əz ə kɛɹhinɪn, ən ðə dipɝ ɹænd tæŋɡəl hɪm, ðə wɝs ɪt ɡɑt. waɪ ɑn ɝθ wəd bɑzəl ɡɪl, ʌv ɔl pipəl, laɪ tə hɪm? ə leɪɾiz meɪd, əkʌstəm tə pɹɪvlədʒ ən fɔlən ɑn hɑɹd taɪmz; ðəɾ ɪkspleɪn meɪaɪɡdɪn. səm θɪŋz wɝ sɪmpəl.

Perrin nodded slowly. That could be simple truth, though he had learned that people had a hundred reasons for lying, or just shading the truth. Grimacing, he raked fingers through his hair. Light! He was becoming suspicious as a Cairhienin, and the deeper Rand tangled him, the worse it got. Why on earth would Basel Gill, of all people, lie to him? A lady's maid, accustomed to privilege and fallen on hard times; that explained Maighdin. Some things were simple.

liniz hænz wɝ foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst, bʌt ʃi wɑtʃt wɪð ə kin aɪ, noʊ lɪɾəl laɪk ə fælkən hɝsɛlf, ən mæstɝ ɡɪl bɪɡæn fɪdʒəɾɪŋ əz sun əz i stɑp tɔkɪŋ. hi sim tə teɪk pɛɹɪnz ɡɹɪmɑs əz ə dɪmæn fəɹ mɔɹ. hi læft, mɔɹ ɑn ɛdʒ ðən əmjuzd. "aɪ hævən sin soʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə wɝl sɪns ði il wɔɹ, ən aɪ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbli skɪniɝ, ðɛn. waɪ, wiv bɪn əz fɑɹ əz æmədɔɹ. ʌv kɔɹs, wi lɛft æftɝ ðoʊz sintʃæn tʊk ðə sɪɾi, bʌt tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ ɑɹən ɛni wɝs ðən ðə waɪtkloʊks, ðəɾ aɪ kəd - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əz pɛɹɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ əbɹʌpli ən sizd ɪz ləpɛl.

Lini's hands were folded at her waist, but she watched with a keen eye, no little like a falcon herself, and Master Gill began fidgeting as soon as he stopped talking. He seemed to take Perrin's grimace as a demand for more. He laughed, more on edge than amused. "I haven't seen so much of the world since the Aiel War, and I was considerably skinnier, then. Why, we've been as far as Amador. Of course, we left after those Seanchan took the city, but truth, they aren't any worse than the Whitecloaks, that I could - " He cut off as Perrin leaned forward abruptly and seized his lapel.

"sintʃæn, mæstɝ ɡɪl? ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ə ðæt? əɹ ɪz ɪt wʌn ə ðoʊz ɹumɝz, laɪk ði il, əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"Seanchan, Master Gill? Are you sure of that? Or is it one of those rumors, like the Aiel, or Aes Sedai?"

"aɪ sɔ ðɛm," ɡɪl ɹɪplaɪd, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ənsɝɾən lʊks wɪð lini. "æn ðæts wʌt ðeɪ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz. aɪm sɝpɹaɪz jə doʊnt noʊ. wɝdz bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ əhɛɾ ʌv əs ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm æmədɔɹ. ðiz sintʃæn wɑn pipəl tə noʊ wʌt ðəɹ əbaʊt. stʃɹeɪnʒ pipəl, wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz." hɪz vɔɪs pɪkt ʌp ɪntɛnsəɾi. "laɪk ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. bɪɡ lɛðɝi θɪŋz ðət flaɪ, ən kæɹi mɛn, ən ðiz θɪŋz laɪk lɪzɝdz, oʊnli ðəɹ bɪɡ əz hɔɹsəz, ən ðeɪv θɹi aɪz. aɪ sɔ ðɛm! aɪ dɪd!"

"I saw them," Gill replied, exchanging uncertain looks with Lini. "And that's what they call themselves. I'm surprised you don't know. Word's been running ahead of us all the way from Amador. These Seanchan want people to know what they're about. Strange people, with strange creatures." His voice picked up intensity. "Like Shadowspawn. Big leathery things that fly, and carry men, and these things like lizards, only they're big as horses, and they have three eyes. I saw them! I did!"

"aɪ bɪliv ju," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ɹilisɪŋ ðə mænz koʊt. "aɪv sin ðɛm, tu." ət fɑlm, wɛɹ ə θaʊzənd waɪtkloʊks daɪɾ ɪn mɪnəts ən ɪt hæd teɪkən dɛd hɪɹoʊz ə lɛdʒənd, kɔl baɪ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, tə θɹoʊ ðə sintʃæn bæk. ɹænd hæd sɛd ðeɪ wəd ɹɪtɝn, bʌt haʊ kəd ðeɪv soʊ sun? laɪt! ɪf ðeɪ hɛld æmədɔɹ, ðeɪ hæd tə hæv tæɹɑbən əz wɛl, əɹ moʊst ʌv ɪt. oʊnli ə ful kɪld ə dɪɹ wən i nu ðəɹ wɑz ə wundəd bɛɹ bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. haʊ mʌtʃ hæd ðeɪ teɪkən? "aɪ kæn sɛn jə tə keɪɛmlɪn ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, mæstɝ ɡɪl, bʌɾ ɪf jə steɪ wɪð mi ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ, əl si jə ðəɹ seɪfli." ɪf steɪɪŋ wɪð ɪm ɛni lɛŋθ ə taɪm wɑz seɪf. ðə pɹɑfət, waɪtkloʊks, ən naʊ meɪbi sintʃæn æɾəd ɪn.

"I believe you," Perrin said, releasing the man's coat. "I've seen them, too." At Falme, where a thousand Whitecloaks died in minutes and it had taken dead heroes of legend, called by the Horn of Valere, to throw the Seanchan back. Rand had said they would return, but how could they have so soon? Light! If they held Amador, they had to have Tarabon as well, or most of it. Only a fool killed a deer when he knew there was a wounded bear behind his back. How much had they taken? "I can't send you to Caemlyn right away, Master Gill, but if you stay with me a while longer, I'll see you there safely." If staying with him any length of time was safe. The Prophet, Whitecloaks, and now maybe Seanchan added in.

"aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ə ɡʊd mæn," lini sɛd sʌɾənli. "aɪm əfɹeɪd wi dɪdn tɛl jə ðə hoʊl tʃɹuθ, ən meɪbi wi ʃʊd."

"I think you're a good man," Lini said suddenly. "I'm afraid we didn't tell you the whole truth, and maybe we should."

"lini, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ?" mæstɝ ɡɪl ɪkskleɪmd, baʊndɪŋ tə hɪz fit. "aɪ θɪŋk ðə hits ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɝ," hi toʊl pɛɹɪn. "æn ɔl ðə tʃɹævəl. ʃiz stʃɹeɪnʒ fænsiz, səmtaɪmz. jə noʊ haʊ oʊl foʊks kən ɡɛt. hʌʃ, naʊ, lini!"

"Lini, what are you saying?" Master Gill exclaimed, bounding to his feet. "I think the heat's getting to her," he told Perrin. "And all the travel. She has strange fancies, sometimes. You know how old folks can get. Hush, now, Lini!"

lini slæpt əweɪ ðə hæn i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ. "ju maɪn jɝsɛlf, bɑzəl ɡɪl! əl 'oʊld' ju! meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm tɑlænvɝ, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ, ən i wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ hɝ. wi ɔl wɝ, fɔɹ deɪz naʊ, ən nɪɹ kɪlɪŋ əs ən ðə hɔɹsəz boʊθ. wɛl, ɪts noʊ wʌndɝ ʃi dʌznt noʊ hɝ oʊn maɪn hæf ðə taɪm; jə mɛn snɑɹl ʌp ə wʊmənz wɪts soʊ ʃi kən hɑɹdli θɪŋk, ðən jə pɹitɛn juv dʌn nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ðə lɑɾ ə jə ɔt tə hæv jəɹ ɪɹz bɑkst ɑn dʒɛnɝəl pɹɪnsəpəl. ðə ɡɝlz əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ oʊn hɑɹt! ðoʊz tu ʃəd bi mɛɹid, ən ðə kwɪkɝ ðə bɛɾɝ."

Lini slapped away the hand he was trying to put over her mouth. "You mind yourself, Basel Gill! I'll 'old' you! Maighdin was running from Tallanvor, in a manner of speaking, and he was chasing her. We all were, four days now, and near killing us and the horses both. Well, it's no wonder she doesn't know her own mind half the time; you men snarl up a woman's wits so she can hardly think, then you pretend you've done nothing at all. The lot of you ought to have your ears boxed on general principle. The girl's afraid of her own heart! Those two should be married, and the quicker the better."

mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪz oʊn maʊθ maɪt nɑt bi hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən aɪ ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ ɪts jə wɑn ə mi," hi sɛd sloʊli, ən ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən lɛpt ɪn bɪfɔɹ i wɑz wɛl fɪnɪʃt.

Master Gill gaped at her, and Perrin was not sure his own mouth might not be hanging open. "I'm not certain I understand what it is you want of me," he said slowly, and the white-haired woman leaped in before he was well finished.

"doʊn pɹitɛn tə bi dɛns. aɪ woʊn bɪliv ɪɾ ɪn jə fəɹ ə moʊmənt. aɪ kən si juv mɔɹ wɪts ðən moʊs mɛn. ðæts ðə wɝs hæbət jə mɛn hæv, meɪkɪŋ bɪliv jə doʊn si wʌts pleɪn ʌndɝ jəɹ noʊzɪz." wʌt hæd hæpən tə ɔl ðoʊz kɝtsiz? foʊldɪŋ θɪn ɑɹmz əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, ʃi aɪɾ ɪm stɝnli. "wɛl, ɪf jə mʌs pɹitɛnd, əl sɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ ju. ðɪs lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ə jʊɹz dʌz wʌtɛvɝ i wɑns, ðə weɪ aɪ hɪɹ. jəɹ pɹɑfət pɪks aʊt pipəl ən mɛɹiz əm ɑn ðə spɑt. vɛɹi wɛl; jə snætʃ ʌp meɪaɪɡdɪn ən tɑlænvɝ ən mɛɹi ðɛm. hɪl θæŋk ju, ən soʊ wɪl ʃi. wən əɹ maɪn sɛɾəlz."

"Don't pretend to be dense. I won't believe it in you for a moment. I can see you have more wits than most men. That's the worst habit you men have, making believe you don't see what's plain under your noses." What had happened to all those curtsies? Folding thin arms across her chest, she eyed him sternly. "Well, if you must pretend, I'll set it out for you. This Lord Dragon of yours does whatever he wants, the way I hear. Your Prophet picks out people and marries them on the spot. Very well; you snatch up Maighdin and Tallanvor and marry them. He'll thank you, and so will she. When her mind settles."

stʌnd, pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət mæstɝ ɡɪl, hu ʃɹʌɡd ən meɪɾ ə sɪkli ɡɹɪn. "ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi," pɛɹɪn toʊl ðə fɹaʊnɪŋ wʊmən, "aɪ hæv səm mæɾɝz aɪ mʌst si tə." hi hɝiɾ əweɪ, oʊnli lʊkɪŋ bæk wʌns. lini wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət mæstɝ ɡɪl, bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪm dɪspaɪɾ ɪz pɹoʊtɛsts. ðə bɹiz wɑz ɹɔŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə hɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi dɪd nɑt wɑn tə. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl kɹeɪzi!

Stunned, Perrin glanced at Master Gill, who shrugged and made a sickly grin. "If you will forgive me," Perrin told the frowning woman, "I have some matters I must see to." He hurried away, only looking back once. Lini was shaking a finger at Master Gill, berating him despite his protests. The breeze was wrong for Perrin to hear what they were saying. In truth, he did not want to. They were all crazy!

bɹəleɪn maɪɾ əv əɹ tu meɪdz ən əɹ θif-kætʃɝz, bʌt feɪl hæɾ əɹ oʊn ətɛndəns, ʌv ə sɔɹt. kloʊs ɑn twɛnti jʌŋ tɛɹənz ən kɛɹhinɪn wɝ sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəd nɪɹ ðə tɛnt, ðə wɪmən ɪn koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz wɪð sɔɹdz bɛltəɾ ɑn dʒʌs laɪk ðə mɛn. nʌn wɔɹ ðɛɹ hɛɹ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə ʃoʊldɝ, ən mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ hæɾ ɪt taɪd bæk wɪð ə ɹɪbən, ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ði il teɪl. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛɹ ðə ɹɛst wɝ; ðeɪ sɛldəm stʃɹeɪd fɑɹ fɹəm ðə saʊn ə feɪlz vɔɪs. nɑt kɑzɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl, hi hoʊpt. ʃi hæd teɪkən əm ʌndɝ əɹ wɪŋ tə kip əm aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl, ʃi sɛd, ən ðə laɪt nu ðeɪ wʊɾə ɡɑɾən ɪndə ɪt, lɛf bæk ɪn kɛɹhin wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt lɑɾ ə jʌŋ fulz dʒʌs laɪk ðɛm. ɪn pɛɹɪnz əpɪnjən, ðə hoʊl læʃɪŋ ə ðɛm niɾəd ə swɪf kɪk ɪn ðə bɑɾəm tə nɑk səm sɛns ɪndə ðɛm. dulɪŋ, pleɪɪŋ ət dʒiɾoʊ, pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi səm sɔɹɾ ʌv il. ɪɾiəsi!

Berelain might have her two maids and her thief-catchers, but Faile had her own attendants, of a sort. Close on twenty young Tairens and Cairhienin were sitting cross-legged near the tent, the women in coats and breeches with swords belted on just like the men. None wore their hair longer than the shoulder, and men and women both had it tied back with a ribbon, imitating the Aiel tail. Perrin wondered where the rest were; they seldom strayed far from the sound of Faile's voice. Not causing trouble, he hoped. She had taken them under her wing to keep them out of trouble, she said, and the Light knew they would have gotten into it, left back in Cairhien with a great lot of young fools just like them. In Perrin's opinion, the whole lashing of them needed a swift kick in the bottom to knock some sense into them. Dueling, playing at ji'e'toh, pretending to be some sort of Aiel. Idiocy!

lətʃəl ɹoʊz tə hɝ fiɾ əz pɛɹɪn keɪm kloʊsɝ, ə peɪl lɪɾəl wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd ɹɪbənz pɪn tə hɝ ləpɛlz, smɔl ɡoʊl hups ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, ən ə tʃælənʒɪŋ stɛɹ ðət səmtaɪmz meɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn θɪŋk ʃi maɪt laɪk ə kɪs dɪspaɪɾ əɹ sɔɹd. ɹaɪt ðɛn, ðə tʃælənʒ wɑz stoʊni hɑɹd. ə moʊmən bɪhaɪn hɝ, ɹɛlə stʊd tu, tɔl ən dɑɹk, wɪð əɹ hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ əz ə meɪɾənz ən əɹ kloʊðz pleɪnɝ ðən moʊst ə ðə mɛnz. ənlaɪk lətʃəl, ɹɛlə meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ʃi wəɾ əz sun kɪs ə dɔɡ əz ɛni mæn. ðə pɛɹ meɪɾ əz ɪf tə muv ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛnt, tə blɑk pɛɹɪnz weɪ, bʌɾ ə skwɛɹ-tʃɪn fɛloʊ ɪn ə pʌfi-sliv koʊt bɑɹkt ən ɔɹɾɝ ən ðeɪ sæɾ əɡɛn. ɹɪlʌktənli. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, pɛɹɪlin θʌm ðət blɑk ʌv ə tʃɪn əz ðoʊ hi maɪt bi ɹikənsɪɾɝɪŋ. hi hæd wɔɹn ə bɪɹd ðə fɝs taɪm pɛɹɪn sɔ hɪm - sɛvɹəl ə ðə tɛɹən mɛn hæd hæɾ əm - bʌɾ il dɪd nɑt wɛɹ bɪɹdz.

Lacile rose to her feet as Perrin came closer, a pale little woman with red ribbons pinned to her lapels, small gold hoops in her ears, and a challenging stare that sometimes made the Two Rivers men think she might like a kiss despite her sword. Right then, the challenge was stony hard. A moment behind her, Arrela stood too, tall and dark, with her hair cut short as a Maiden's and her clothes plainer than most of the men's. Unlike Lacile, Arrela made it clear she would as soon kiss a dog as any man. The pair made as if to move in front of the tent, to block Perrin's way, but a square-chinned fellow in a puffy-sleeved coat barked an order and they sat again. Reluctantly. For that matter, Parelean thumbed that block of a chin as though he might be reconsidering. He had worn a beard the first time Perrin saw him - several of the Tairen men had had them - but Aiel did not wear beards.

pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd əbaʊt fulɪʃnəs ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ðeɪ wɝ feɪlz tə ðə boʊn, ən ðə fæk ðəɾ i wɑz əɹ hʌzbən mɛn lɪɾəl. ɛɹæm maɪt bi dʒɛləs ə hɪz ətɛnʃənz, jɛɾ ɛɹæm ət list ʃɛɹɾ ɪz əfɛkʃənz wɪð feɪl. hi kəd fil ðə jʌŋ ɪɾiəts' aɪz ɑn ɪm əz i stʃɹoʊɾ ɪnsaɪd. feɪl wəd skɪn ɪm ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ lɝn ðəɾ i hoʊp ðeɪ wəd kip əɹ fɹəm tʃɹʌbəl.

Perrin muttered about foolishness under his breath. They were Faile's to the bone, and the fact that he was her husband meant little. Aram might be jealous of his attentions, yet Aram at least shared his affections with Faile. He could feel the young idiots' eyes on him as he strode inside. Faile would skin him if she ever learned that he hoped they would keep her from trouble.

ðə tɛnt wɑz tɔl ən speɪʃəs, wɪð ə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət fəɹ ə flɔɹ ən spɑɹs fɝnɪʃɪŋz ðət foʊldəd fəɹ stɔɹədʒ ɑn ə kɑɹt, moʊst ə ðɛm. ðə hɛvi stænd-mɪɹɝ sɝɾənli kəd nɑt. ɪksɛp fəɹ bɹæs-baʊn tʃɛsts dʒɹeɪpt wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd klɔθs ən dʌbəlɪŋ əz ɛkstʃɹə teɪbəlz, stʃɹeɪt laɪnz ə bɹaɪt ɡɪl dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɛvɹiθɪŋ daʊn tə ðə wɑʃstæn ən ɪts mɪɹɝ. ə dʌzən mɪɹɝd læmps meɪd ði ɪntɪɹiɝ nɪɹli əz bɹaɪɾ əz aʊtsaɪd, ɪf kənsɪɾɝəbli kulɝ, ən ðəɹ wɝ ivən ə pɛɹ ə sɪlk hæŋʒɪŋz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹuf poʊlz, tu ɔɹneɪt fəɹ pɛɹɪnz teɪst. tu ɹɪdʒəd, wɪð ðə bɝdz ən flaʊɝz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪn laɪnz ən æŋɡəlz. dɑbɹeɪn hæd sɛɾ əm ʌp tə tʃɹævəl laɪk kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hæd mænədʒ tə "luz" ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt. ðə hjudʒ bɛd, fəɹ wʌn, ə ɹɪdɪkjələs θɪŋ tə tʃɹævəl wɪð. ɪt hæd teɪkən ʌp ɔlmoʊst ə hoʊl kɑɹt tə ɪtsɛlf.

The tent was tall and spacious, with a flowered carpet for a floor and sparse furnishings that folded for storage on a cart, most of them. The heavy stand-mirror certainly could not. Except for brass-bound chests draped with embroidered cloths and doubling as extra tables, straight lines of bright gilt decorated everything down to the washstand and its mirror. A dozen mirrored lamps made the interior nearly as bright as outside, if considerably cooler, and there were even a pair of silk hangings dangling from the roof poles, too ornate for Perrin's taste. Too rigid, with the birds and flowers marching in lines and angles. Dobraine had set them up to travel like Cairhienin nobles, though Perrin had managed to "lose" the worst of it. The huge bed, for one, a ridiculous thing to travel with. It had taken up almost a whole cart to itself.

feɪl ən meɪaɪɡdɪn wɝ sɪɾɪŋ əloʊn təɡɛðɝ, wɝk sɪlvɝ kʌps ɪn hænd. ðeɪ hæd ði ɛɹ ʌv wɪmən filɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ aʊt, ɔl smaɪlz ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd jɛt wɪð ə hɪn ə ʃɑɹpnəs tə ði aɪz, ə hɪn ə lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə wɝdz, ən nɑɾ ə klu əz tə wɛðɝ ðeɪ wəd hʌɡ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən əɹ dʒɹɔ naɪvz. wɛl, hi θɔt moʊst wɪmən wəd nɑɾ æktʃəli  ɡoʊ əz fɑɹ əz naɪvz, bʌt feɪl kʊd. meɪaɪɡdɪn əpɪɹd mʌtʃ lɛs tʃɹævəl-wɔɹn ðən ʃi hæd, wɑʃt ən koʊmd, ðə dʌs bɹʌʃt fɹəm əɹ dʒɹɛs. ə smɔl moʊzeɪɪk-tɑp teɪbəl bɪtwin əm hɛl mɔɹ kʌps ən ə tɔl swɛɾɪŋ sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ðə mɪnti sɛn ə ɝb ti. boʊθ wɪmən lʊkt ɝaʊn əɾ ɪz ɛntʃɹəns, ən fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən, kuli wʌndɝɪŋ u wɑz bɑɹdʒɪŋ ɪn ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plizd wɪð ði ɪntɝʌpʃən. ət lis feɪl sɔfən hɝz ɪmiɾiətli wɪð ə smaɪl.

Faile and Maighdin were sitting alone together, worked silver cups in hand. They had the air of women feeling one another out, all smiles on the outside yet with a hint of sharpness to the eyes, a hint of listening for something behind the words, and not a clue as to whether they would hug in the next instant or draw knives. Well, he thought most women would not actually go as far as knives, but Faile could. Maighdin appeared much less travel-worn than she had, washed and combed, the dust brushed from her dress. A small mosaic-topped table between them held more cups and a tall sweating silver pitcher that gave off the minty scent of herb tea. Both women looked around at his entrance, and for an instant, they had almost exactly the same expression, coolly wondering who was barging in and not at all pleased with the interruption. At least Faile softened hers immediately with a smile.

"mæstɝ ɡɪl toʊl mi jəɹ stɔɹi, mɪstʃɹəs dɔɹleɪn," hi sɛd. "juv feɪs hɑɹd deɪz, bʌt jə kən bi ʃʊɹ jəɹ seɪf hɪɹ tɪl jə dɪsaɪd tə liv." ðə wʊmən mɝmɝd θæŋks oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ə hɝ kʌp, bʌt ʃi smɛld wɛɹi, ən əɹ aɪz tʃɹaɪd tə ɹiɾ ɪm laɪk ə bʊk.

"Master Gill told me your story, Mistress Dorlain," he said. "You've faced hard days, but you can be sure you're safe here till you decide to leave." The woman murmured thanks over the rim of her cup, but she smelled wary, and her eyes tried to read him like a book.

"meɪaɪɡdɪn ɔlsoʊ toʊl mi ðɛɹ stɔɹi, pɛɹɪn," feɪl sɛd, "æn aɪ hæv ən ɔfɝ tə meɪk hɝ. meɪaɪɡdɪn, jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnz əv hæd tʃɹaɪɪŋ mʌnθs bɪhaɪnd, ən jə tɛl mi ʌv noʊ pɹɑspɛks əhɛd. ɛntɝ maɪ sɝvəs, ɔl ə ju. jəl stɪl əv tə dʒɝni, bʌt ðə sɝkəmstænsəz wɪl bi mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ. aɪ peɪ wɛl, ən aɪm nɑɾ ə hɑɹʃ mɪstʃɹəs." pɛɹɪn vɔɪst ɪz əpɹuvəl ɪmiɾiətli. ɪf feɪl wɑntəd tə ɪndʌlʒ əɹ fænsi fəɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪn stʃɹeɪz, ət list i wɑntəd tə hɛlp ðɪs lɑt, tu. meɪbi ðeɪ wəd bi seɪfɝ wɪð ɪm ðən wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊn əloʊn ət ðæt.

"Maighdin also told me their story, Perrin," Faile said, "and I have an offer to make her. Maighdin, you and your friends have had trying months behind, and you tell me of no prospects ahead. Enter my service, all of you. You will still have to journey, but the circumstances will be much better. I pay well, and I am not a harsh mistress." Perrin voiced his approval immediately. If Faile wanted to indulge her fancy for taking in strays, at least he wanted to help this lot, too. Maybe they would be safer with him than wandering around alone at that.

tʃoʊkɪŋ ɑn əɹ ti, meɪaɪɡdɪn nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt əɹ kʌp. ʃi blɪŋkt ət feɪl, dæbɪŋ ət ðə dæmp ɑn əɹ tʃɪn wɪð ə leɪs-ɛdʒ lɪnən hæŋkɝtʃɪf, ən əɹ tʃɛɹ kɹik feɪnli əz ʃi tɝnd, stʃɹeɪnʒli, tə stʌɾi pɛɹɪn. "aɪ . . . θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, sloʊli. "aɪ θɪŋk. . . ." ənʌðɝ moʊməns pɝuzəl ə pɛɹɪn, ən əɹ vɔɪs pɪkt ʌp. "jɛs, aɪ θæŋk ju, ən aɪ æksɛp jəɹ kaɪn ɔfɝ ɡɹeɪtfəli. aɪ mʌs tɛl maɪ kəmpænjənz." ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪn sɛɾɪŋ əɹ kʌp ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, ðən stʃɹeɪɾənd oʊnli tə spɹɛɾ əɹ skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi suɾəbəl fəɹ ɛni pæləs. "aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɪv ɡʊd sɝvəs, maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛd lɛvəli. "meɪ aɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ?" ət feɪlz əsɛnt, ʃi kɝtsiɾ əɡɛn ən bækt əweɪ tu stɛps bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ! pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹd. sʌmbɑɾi ɛls u wəd bi bɑbɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi tɝn ɝaʊnd.

Choking on her tea, Maighdin nearly dropped her cup. She blinked at Faile, dabbing at the damp on her chin with a lace-edged linen handkerchief, and her chair creaked faintly as she turned, strangely, to study Perrin. "I . . . thank you," she said at last, slowly. "I think. . . ." Another moment's perusal of Perrin, and her voice picked up. "Yes, I thank you, and I accept your kind offer gratefully. I must tell my companions." Rising, she hesitated in setting her cup on the tray, then straightened only to spread her skirts in a curtsy suitable for any palace. "I will try to give good service, my Lady," she said levelly. "May I withdraw?" At Faile's assent, she curtsied again and backed away two steps before turning to go! Perrin scratched his beard. Somebody else who would be bobbing at him every time she turned around.

noʊ sunɝ hæd ðə tɛntflæp dʒɹɑp bɪhaɪn meɪaɪɡdɪn ðən feɪl pʊɾ əɹ kʌp daʊn ən læft, dʒɹʌmɪŋ əɹ hilz ɑn ðə kɑɹpət. "oʊ, aɪ laɪk hɝ, pɛɹɪn. ʃiz spɪɹət! əl weɪdʒɝ ʃi wʊɾə sɪŋʒd jəɹ bɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðoʊz bænɝz ɪf aɪ hædn seɪv ju. oʊ, jɛs. spɪɹət!"

No sooner had the tentflap dropped behind Maighdin than Faile put her cup down and laughed, drumming her heels on the carpet. "Oh, I like her, Perrin. She has spirit! I'll wager she would have singed your beard over those banners if I hadn't saved you. Oh, yes. Spirit!"

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. dʒʌst wʌɾ i niɾəd; ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə sɪnʒ ɪz bɪɹd. "aɪ pɹɑməs mæstɝ ɡɪl tə lʊk æftɝ ðɛm, feɪl, bʌt. . . . kən jə ɡɛs wʌt ðət lini æskt? ʃi wɑntəd mi tə mɛɹi meɪaɪɡdɪn tə ðət fɛloʊ tɑlænvɝ. dʒʌst stæn əm ʌp ən mɛɹi ðɛm wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ sɛd! ʃi kleɪm ðeɪ wɑn ɪt." hi fɪld ə sɪlvɝ kʌp wɪð ti ən dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd veɪkeɪɾəd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɪts əlɑɹmɪŋ ɡɹoʊnz ʌndɝ ɪz sʌɾən weɪt. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðət nɑnsɛns ɪz ðə list ə maɪ wɝiz. mæstɝ ɡɪl sɛz ɪt wɑz ðə sintʃæn tʊk æmədɔɹ, ən aɪ bɪliv hɪm. laɪt! ðə sintʃæn!"

Perrin grunted. Just what he needed; another woman to singe his beard. "I promised Master Gill to look after them, Faile, but. . . . Can you guess what that Lini asked? She wanted me to marry Maighdin to that fellow Tallanvor. Just stand them up and marry them whatever they said! She claimed they want it." He filled a silver cup with tea and dropped into the chair Maighdin had vacated, ignoring its alarming groans under his sudden weight. "In any case, that nonsense is the least of my worries. Master Gill says it was the Seanchan took Amador, and I believe him. Light! The Seanchan!"

feɪl tæpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps təɡɛðɝ, stɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs əm ət nʌθɪŋ. "ðæt maɪt bi dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ," ʃi mjuzd. "moʊst sɝvəns də bɛɾɝ mɛɹid ðən nɑt. pɝhæps aɪ ʃəɾ ɝeɪnʒ ɪt. ən fəɹ bɹin, tu. ðə weɪ ʃi wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ tə tʃɛk ɑn ðət bɪɡ fɛloʊ əz sun əz əɹ feɪs wɑz klin, aɪ səspɛk ðeɪ ʃəd bi ɔlɹɛɾi. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡlim ɪn əɹ aɪ. aɪ woʊn əv ðət kaɪndə bɪheɪvjɝ ɪn maɪ sɝvəns, pɛɹɪn. ɪt dʒʌs lidz tə tɛɹz ən ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃənz ən sʌlkɪŋ. ən bɹin wɪl bi wɝs ðən i ɪz."

Faile tapped her fingertips together, staring across them at nothing. "That might be just the thing," she mused. "Most servants do better married than not. Perhaps I should arrange it. And for Breane, too. The way she went running out of here to check on that big fellow as soon as her face was clean, I suspect they should be already. There was a gleam in her eye. I won't have that kind of behavior in my servants, Perrin. It just leads to tears and recriminations and sulking. And Breane will be worse than he is."

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "dɪd jə hɪɹ mi?" hi sɛd sloʊli. "ðə sintʃæn əv kæptʃɝɾ æmədɔɹ! ðə sintʃæn, feɪl!"

Perrin stared at her. "Did you hear me?" he said slowly. "The Seanchan have captured Amador! The Seanchan, Faile!"

ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt - ʃi ɹɪli hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt mɛɹiɪŋ ɔf ðoʊz wɪmən! - ðən smaɪld ət hɪm, əmjuzd. "æmədɔɹ ɪz ə lɔŋ weɪ, jɛt, ən ɪf wi də mit wɪð ðiz sintʃæn, aɪm ʃʊɹ jəl dil wɪð ðɛm. æftɝ ɔl, jə tɔt mi tə pɝtʃ ɑn jəɹ ɹɪst, dɪdn ju?" ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi kleɪmd, ðoʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛni saɪn ʌv ɪt.

She gave a start - she really had been thinking about marrying off those women! - then smiled at him, amused.
