"Amador is a long way, yet, and if we do meet with these Seanchan, I'm sure you will deal with them. After all, you taught me to perch on your wrist, didn't you?" That was what she claimed, though he had never seen any sign of it.

"ðeɪ maɪt bi ə tʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən jə wɝ," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, ən ʃi smaɪld əɡɛn. ʃi smɛld ɪkstʃɹimli plizd, fəɹ səm ɹizən. "aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt sɛndɪŋ ɡɹeɪɾi əɹ nil tə wɔɹn ɹænd, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ i sɛd." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd fɪɹsli, smaɪlz ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ i pʊʃt ɑn. "ɪf aɪ nu haʊ tə faɪn hɪm, aɪ wʊd. ðəɹ əz tə bi səm weɪ tə ɡɛt wɝd tə hɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn lɝnɪŋ ʌv ɪt." ɹænd hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ðət mɔɹ ðən i hæɾ ɑn sikɹəsi əbaʊt mæsimə. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn ɛɡzaɪl fɹəm ɹændz pɹɛzəns, ən noʊ wʌn wɑz tə noʊ ɛniθɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn bɪtwin əm ɪksɛpt ɛnməɾi.

"They might be a touch more difficult than you were," he said dryly, and she smiled again. She smelled extremely pleased, for some reason. "I'm thinking about sending Grady or Neald to warn Rand, no matter what he said." She shook her head fiercely, smiles evaporating, but he pushed on. "If I knew how to find him, I would. There has to be some way to get word to him without anyone learning of it." Rand had insisted on that more than he had on secrecy about Masema. Perrin had been exiled from Rand's presence, and no one was to know anything remained between them except enmity.

"hi noʊz, pɛɹɪn. aɪm ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. meɪaɪɡdɪn sɔ pɪdʒɑnkoʊts ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɪn æmədɔɹ, ən əpɛɹənli ðə sintʃæn dɪdn lʊk əɾ əm twaɪs. baɪ ðɪs taɪm, ɛni mɝtʃən u hæz bɪznəs wɪð æmədɔɹ əz hɝd, ən soʊ hæz ðə waɪt taʊɝ. bɪliv mi, ɹænd mʌs hæv, tu. juv tə tʃɹʌs ðəɾ i noʊz bɛst. ɪn ðɪs, hi dʌz." ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz soʊ sɝɾən ə ðæt.

"He knows, Perrin. I'm sure of it. Maighdin saw pigeoncotes everywhere in Amador, and apparently the Seanchan didn't look at them twice. By this time, any merchant who has business with Amador has heard, and so has the White Tower. Believe me, Rand must have, too. You have to trust that he knows best. In this, he does." She was not always so certain of that.

"meɪbi," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd ɪɹɪɾəbli. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə wɝi əbaʊt ɹændz sænəɾi, bʌt ɹænd meɪd pɛɹɪn əɾ ɪz moʊst səspɪʃəs lʊk laɪk ə tʃaɪl skɪpɪŋ ɪn ə mɛdoʊ. haʊ mʌtʃ dɪd ɹænd tʃɹʌst ivən hɪm? ɹænd kɛp θɪŋz bæk, hæd plænz i nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɑn.

"Maybe," Perrin muttered irritably. He tried not to worry about Rand's sanity, but Rand made Perrin at his most suspicious look like a child skipping in a meadow. How much did Rand trust even him? Rand kept things back, had plans he never let on.

ɪkshəlɪŋ, pɛɹɪn sɛɾəld bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, ɡʌlpt ə swɑloʊ ʌv ti. ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt wɑz, mæɾ əɹ seɪn, ɹænd wɑz ɹaɪt. ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən kɑɾ ə səspɪʃən ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz ʌp tə, əɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ dɪd, ðeɪ wəd faɪn səm weɪ tə oʊvɝtɝn ði ænvəl ɑn ɪz fit. "æt list aɪ kən ɡɪv ðə taʊɝz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz lɛs tə tɔk əbaʊt. ðɪs taɪm, aɪm bɝnɪŋ ðət blʌɾi bænɝ." ən ðə wʊlfhɛd, tu. hi maɪɾ əv tə pleɪ ət biɪŋ ə lɔɹd, bʌɾ i kəd də ɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə blʌɾi flæɡ!

Exhaling, Perrin settled back in the chair, gulped a swallow of tea. The truth of it was, mad or sane, Rand was right. If the Forsaken caught a suspicion of what he was up to, or the White Tower did, they would find some way to overturn the anvil on his feet. "At least I can give the Tower's eyes-and-ears less to talk about. This time, I'm burning that bloody banner." And the Wolfhead, too. He might have to play at being a lord, but he could do it without a bloody flag!

feɪlz fʊl lɪps pɝs dʒudɪʃɪsli, ən ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. slɪpɪŋ fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ, ʃi nɛl bɪsaɪd hɪm, tʊk ɪz ɹɪst ɪn əɹ hænz. pɛɹɪn mɛɾ əɹ lɛvəl ɡeɪz wɛɹəli. wən ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm soʊ ɪntɛnli, soʊ sɪɹiəsli, ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə tɛl ɪm sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðæt, əɹ pʊl ðə wʊl oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz ən spɪn ɪm ɝaʊn tɪl i dɪd nɑt noʊ fɹʌn fɹəm bæk. hɝ sɛn toʊld ɪm nʌθɪŋ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp smɛlɪŋ hɝ; ɪt wɑz ɔl tu izi tə luz hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðæt, ən ðən ʃi wəd pʊl ðə wʊl oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz. wʌn θɪŋ i hæd lɝn sɪns mɛɹiɪŋ: ə mæn niɾəd ɔl ə hɪz wɪts dilɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən. tu ɔfən ivən ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf; wɪmən dɪd wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Faile's full lips pursed judiciously, and she shook her head slightly. Slipping from her chair, she knelt beside him, took his wrist in her hands. Perrin met her level gaze warily. When she looked at him so intently, so seriously, she was about to tell him something important. That, or pull the wool over his eyes and spin him around till he did not know front from back. Her scent told him nothing. He tried to stop smelling her; it was all too easy to lose himself in that, and then she would pull the wool over his eyes. One thing he had learned since marrying: a man needed all of his wits dealing with a woman. Too often even that was not enough; women did what they wanted as surely as Aes Sedai.

"ju maɪt wɑnə ɹikənsɪɾɝ, hʌzbənd," ʃi mɝmɝd. ə taɪni smaɪl kwɝkt əɹ maʊθ əz ɪf ʃi wʌns əɡɛn nu wʌɾ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. "aɪ daʊɾ ɛniwʌn huz sin əs sɪns wi ɛntɝd ɡildən nu wʌt ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ɪz. ɝaʊn ə taʊn ðə saɪz ə bɛθɔl, səm wɪl, ðoʊ. ən ðə lɔŋɡɝ wɪv tə hʌn fəɹ mæsimə, ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðə tʃæns."

"You might want to reconsider, husband," she murmured. A tiny smile quirked her mouth as if she once again knew what he was thinking. "I doubt anyone who's seen us since we entered Ghealdan knew what the Red Eagle is. Around a town the size of Bethal, some will, though. And the longer we have to hunt for Masema, the greater the chance."

hi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð seɪɪŋ ðət wɑz ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɹizən tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə bænɝ. feɪl wɑz noʊ ful, ən ʃi θɔt mʌtʃ fæstɝ ðən hi. "ðɛn waɪ kip ɪt," hi æsk sloʊli, "wɛn ɔl ɪɾəl də ɪz dʒɹɔ aɪz tə ði ɪɾiət ɛvɹibɑɾi wɪl θɪŋk ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl meɪnɛðɝən aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv?" mɛn hæd tʃɹaɪd ðəɾ ɪn ðə pæst, ən wɪmən, tu; ðə neɪm ə meɪnɛðɝən kæɹid paʊɝfəl mɛmɹiz, ən ɪt wɑz kənvinjən fəɹ ɛniwʌn u wɑntəd tə stɑɹɾ ə ɹɪbɛljən.

He did not bother with saying that was all the more reason to get rid of the banner. Faile was no fool, and she thought much faster than he. "Then why keep it," he asked slowly, "when all it'll do is draw eyes to the idiot everybody will think is trying to pull Manetheren out of the grave?" Men had tried that in the past, and women, too; the name of Manetheren carried powerful memories, and it was convenient for anyone who wanted to start a rebellion.

"bɪkɔz ɪɾəl dʒɹɔ aɪz." ʃi lin təwɔɹɾ ɪm ɪntɛnli. "tə ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪz ʌp meɪnɛðɝən əɡɛn. lɛsɝ foʊk wɪl smaɪl tə jəɹ feɪs, hoʊp jə ɹaɪɾ ɑn sun, ən tʃɹaɪ tə fɝɡɛt jə əz sun əz jə du. əz fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ, ðeɪv tu mʌtʃ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɹaɪt naʊ tə lʊk twaɪs ənlɛs jə pɪntʃ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz. kəmpɛɹd tə ðə sintʃæn, əɹ ðə pɹɑfət, əɹ ðə waɪtkloʊks, ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪz meɪnɛðɝən ɪz smɔl tɝnəps. ən aɪ θɪŋk ɪts seɪf tə seɪ ðə taʊɝ woʊn lʊk twaɪs iðɝ, nɑt naʊ." hɝ smaɪl waɪɾənd, ən ðə laɪɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz sɛd ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə meɪk əɹ moʊs tɛlɪŋ pɔɪnt. "bʌt moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt, noʊ wʌn wɪl θɪŋk ðət mæn ɪz duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls." əbɹʌpli hɝ smaɪl vænɪʃt; ʃi stʌk ə fɪŋɡɝ əɡɛnst ɪz noʊz, hɑɹd. "æn doʊn kɔl jɝsɛlf ən ɪɾiət, pɛɹɪn tæʃɪɹ eɪbɑɹə. nɑɾ ivən saɪdweɪz, laɪk ðæt. jə ɑɹənt, ən aɪ də nɑt laɪk ɪt." hɝ sɛnt wɑz taɪni spaɪks, nɑt tʃɹu æŋɡɝ bʌt dɛfənətli dɪsplizd.

"Because it will draw eyes." She leaned toward him intently. "To a man trying to raise up Manetheren again. Lesser folk will smile to your face, hope you ride on soon, and try to forget you as soon as you do. As for the greater, they've too much in front of their faces right now to look twice unless you pinch their noses. Compared to the Seanchan, or the Prophet, or the Whitecloaks, a man trying to raise Manetheren is small turnips. And I think it's safe to say the Tower won't look twice either, not now." Her smile widened, and the light in her eyes said she was about to make her most telling point. "But most important, no one will think that man is doing anything else." Abruptly her smile vanished; she stuck a finger against his nose, hard. "And don't call yourself an idiot, Perrin t'Bashere Aybara. Not even sideways, like that. You aren't, and I do not like it." Her scent was tiny spikes, not true anger but definitely displeased.

kwɪksɪlvɝ. ə kɪŋfɪʃɝ flæʃɪŋ baɪ fæstɝ ðən θɔt. sɝɾənli fæstɝ ðən ɪz θɔts. ɪt wəd nɛvɝ əv əkɝd tə hɪm tə haɪd soʊ . . . fleɪɡɹənli. bʌɾ i kəd si ðə sɛns. ɪt wɑz laɪk kənsilɪŋ ðə fæk ðət jə wɝ ə mɝɾɝɝ baɪ kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ə θif. jɛɾ ɪt maɪt wɝk.

Quicksilver. A kingfisher flashing by faster than thought. Certainly faster than his thoughts. It would never have occurred to him to hide so . . . flagrantly. But he could see the sense. It was like concealing the fact that you were a murderer by claiming to be a thief. Yet it might work.

tʃʌklɪŋ, hi kɪst əɹ fɪŋɡɝɾɪp. "ðə bænɝ steɪz," hi sɛd. hi səpoʊz ðət mɛn ðə wʊlfhɛd dɪd, tu. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! "æliændɝ əz tə noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ. ɪf ʃi θɪŋks ɹænd minz tə sɛt mi ʌp əz kɪŋ ə meɪnɛðɝən ən teɪk əɹ lænz. . . ."

Chuckling, he kissed her fingertip. "The banner stays," he said. He supposed that meant the Wolfhead did, too. Blood and bloody ashes! "Alliandre has to know the truth, though. If she thinks Rand means to set me up as King of Manetheren and take her lands. . . ."

feɪl ɹoʊz soʊ sʌɾənli, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, ðəɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪɾ i hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə kwin. æliændɝ kəd lid tə bɹəleɪn ɔl tu izəli, ən feɪl smɛld . . . pɹɪkli. wɛɹi. bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛd, oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, wɑz "æliændɝ woʊn bi ə bɪɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz. ðət bɝdz əz ɡʊɾ əz nɛɾɪd, hʌzbənd, soʊ ɪts taɪm tə pʊɾ əɹ maɪnz ɑn haʊ tə faɪn mæsimə." nilɪŋ ɡɹeɪsfəli bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl tʃɛst əɡɛns ðə tɛnt wɔl, ði oʊnli tʃɛst wɪθaʊt dʒɹeɪpɝiz, ʃi lɪftəd ðə lɪɾ ən bɪɡæn ɹimuvɪŋ ɹoʊl mæps.

Faile rose so suddenly, turning away, that he was afraid he had made a mistake bringing up the Queen. Alliandre could lead to Berelain all too easily, and Faile smelled . . . prickly. Wary. But what she said, over her shoulder, was "Alliandre won't be a bit of trouble for Perrin Goldeneyes. That bird's as good as netted, husband, so it's time to put our minds on how to find Masema." Kneeling gracefully beside a small chest against the tent wall, the only chest without draperies, she lifted the lid and began removing rolled maps.

pɛɹɪn hoʊpt ʃi wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊɾ æliændɝ, kəz i dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də ɪf ʃi wɑz ɹɔŋ. ɪf oʊnli hi wɝ hæf wʌt ʃi θɔt hɪm. æliændɝ wɑz ə nɛɾɪd bɝd, ðə sintʃæn wəd fɔl oʊvɝ laɪk dɑlz fəɹ pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz, ən i wəd snætʃ ʌp ðə pɹɑfəɾ ən teɪk ɪm tə ɹænd ɪf mæsimə hæd tɛn θaʊzən mɛn ɝaʊn hɪm. nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm i ɹilaɪz ðət haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ əɹ æŋɡɝ hɝɾ ən kənfjuz hɪm, ɪt wɑz əɹ dɪsəpɔɪnmənt i fɪɹd. ɪf i ɛvɝ sɔ ðəɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz, ɪt wəd ɹɪp ðə hɑɹɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛst.

Perrin hoped she was right about Alliandre, because he did not know what to do if she was wrong. If only he were half what she thought him. Alliandre was a netted bird, the Seanchan would fall over like dolls for Perrin Goldeneyes, and he would snatch up the Prophet and take him to Rand if Masema had ten thousand men around him. Not for the first time he realized that however much her anger hurt and confused him, it was her disappointment he feared. If he ever saw that in her eyes, it would rip the heart out of his chest.

hi nɛl bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ən hɛlpt əɹ spɹɛɾ aʊt ðə lɑɹdʒəs mæp, kʌvɝɪŋ ðə saʊθ ʌv ɡildən ən ðə nɔɹθ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ən stʌɾid ɪɾ əz ðoʊ mæsiməz neɪm wəd lip ɔf ðə pɑɹtʃmən ət hɪm. hi hæd mɔɹ ɹizən ðən ɹænd tə wɑnə səksid. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls, hi kəd nɑt feɪl feɪl.

He knelt beside her and helped her spread out the largest map, covering the south of Ghealdan and the north of Amadicia, and studied it as though Masema's name would leap off the parchment at him. He had more reason than Rand to want to succeed. Whatever else, he could not fail Faile.

feɪl leɪ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, lɪsnɪŋ əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət pɛɹɪnz bɹɛθ hæd ðə dip ɹɪðəm ə slip, ðən slɪpt aʊt fɹəm ðə blæŋkəts ðeɪ ʃɛɹd. ɹufəl əmjuzmən tʌtʃt əɹ əz ʃi pʊld əɹ lɪnən naɪtdʒɹɛs ʌp oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. dɪɾ i ɹɪli θɪŋk ʃi wəd nɑt faɪn aʊt ðəɾ i hæd hɪɾən ðə bɛd dip ɪn ə kɑps wʌn mɔɹnɪŋ waɪl ðə kɑɹts wɝ biɪŋ loʊɾəd? nɑt ðət ʃi maɪndəd; nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil, ət list. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd slɛpt ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn əz ɔfən əz hi. ʃi hæd pɹitɛndəd sɝpɹaɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, ən meɪd laɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ən i wəɾ əv əpɑlədʒaɪzd, pɝhæps ivən ɡɔn bæk tə fɛtʃ ðə bɛd. mænɪdʒɪŋ ə hʌzbənd wɑz ən ɑɹt, soʊ hɝ mʌðɝ sɛd. hæd dʒɹə ni ɡeɪlin ɛvɝ faʊn ɪt soʊ dɪfəkəlt?

Faile lay in the darkness, listening until she was sure that Perrin's breath had the deep rhythm of sleep, then slipped out from the blankets they shared. Rueful amusement touched her as she pulled her linen nightdress up over her head. Did he really think she would not find out that he had hidden the bed deep in a copse one morning while the carts were being loaded? Not that she minded; not a great deal, at least. She was sure she had slept on the ground as often as he. She had pretended surprise, of course, and made light of it. Anything else, and he would have apologized, perhaps even gone back to fetch the bed. Managing a husband was an art, so her mother said. Had Deira ni Ghaline ever found it so difficult?

skʌfɪŋ əɹ bɛɹ fiɾ ɪndə slɪpɝz, ʃi ʃɹʌɡd ɪndə ə sɪlk ɹoʊb, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət pɛɹɪn. hi wəd bi eɪbəl tə si hɝ klɪɹli, ɪf i woʊk, bʌt tə hɝ, hi wɑz dʒʌst ə ʃæɾoʊd maʊnd. ʃi wɪʃt əɹ mʌðɝ wɝ ðɛɹ, naʊ, tə ædvaɪz hɝ. ʃi lʌv pɛɹɪn wɪð ɛvɹi faɪbɝ ə hɝ biɪŋ, ən i kənfjuzd ɛvɹi faɪbɝ. æktʃəli  ʌndɝstændɪŋ mɛn wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ i wɑz soʊ ənlaɪk ɛniwʌn ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð. hi nɛvɝ swæɡɝd, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə læfɪŋ ət hɪmsɛlf, hi wɑz . . . mɑɾəst. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪlivd ə mæn kəd bi mɑɾəst! hi ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ oʊnli tʃæns hæd meɪɾ ɪm ə liɾɝ, kleɪmd i dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə lid, wən mɛn u mɛɾ ɪm wɝ ɹɛɾi tə fɑloʊ æftɝ ən aʊɝ. hi dɪsmɪst ɪz oʊn θɪŋkɪŋ əz sloʊ, wən ðoʊz sloʊ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ θɔts sɔ soʊ dipli ðət ʃi hæd tə dæns ə mɛɹi dʒɪɡ tə kip ɛni sikɹəts əɾ ɔl. hi wɑz ə wʌndɝfəl mæn, hɝ kɝli-hɛɹd wʊlf. soʊ stʃɹɔŋ. ən soʊ dʒɛntəl. saɪɪŋ, ʃi tɪptoʊd fɹəm ðə tɛnt. hɪz ɪɹz hæd kɑzd əɹ dɪfəkəltiz bɪfɔɹ.

Scuffing her bare feet into slippers, she shrugged into a silk robe, then hesitated, looking down at Perrin. He would be able to see her clearly, if he woke, but to her, he was just a shadowed mound. She wished her mother were there, now, to advise her. She loved Perrin with every fiber of her being, and he confused every fiber. Actually understanding men was impossible, of course, but he was so unlike anyone she had grown up with. He never swaggered, and instead of laughing at himself, he was . . . modest. She had not believed a man could be modest! He insisted that only chance had made him a leader, claimed he did not know how to lead, when men who met him were ready to follow after an hour. He dismissed his own thinking as slow, when those slow, considering thoughts saw so deeply that she had to dance a merry jig to keep any secrets at all. He was a wonderful man, her curly-haired wolf. So strong. And so gentle. Sighing, she tiptoed from the tent. His ears had caused her difficulties before.

ðə kæmp leɪ kwaɪət bɪniθ ə ɡɪbəs mun ðət ɡeɪv əz mʌtʃ laɪɾ ɪn ə klaʊdləs skaɪ əz ɪt nɔɹməli wəɾ əv fʊl, ə bɹaɪtnəs ðət wɑʃt aʊt ðə stɑɹz. səm sɔɹɾ ə naɪt-bɝd kɹaɪd ʃɹɪli, ðən fɛl saɪlən əɾ ən aʊlz dip hut. ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl bɹiz, ən fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ɪɾ æktʃəli  simd ə lɪɾəl kul. pɹɑbli hɝ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ðə naɪts wɝ kul oʊnli ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən tə ðə deɪz.

The camp lay quiet beneath a gibbous moon that gave as much light in a cloudless sky as it normally would have full, a brightness that washed out the stars. Some sort of night-bird cried shrilly, then fell silent at an owl's deep hoot. There was a small breeze, and for a wonder, it actually seemed a little cool. Probably her imagination. The nights were cool only in comparison to the days.

moʊst ə ðə mɛn wɝ əslip, dɑɹk hʌmps əmʌŋ ðə ʃædoʊz bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz. ə fju ɹɪmeɪn əweɪk, tɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə hændfʊl ə faɪɝz stɪl bɝnɪŋ. ʃi meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə haɪd, bʌt nʌn noʊɾəst hɝ. səm əpɪɹd hæf əslip wɛɹ ðeɪ sæt, hɛdz nɑɾɪŋ. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn haʊ wɛl ðə mɛn ɑn sɛntʃɹi duɾi wəd bi kipɪŋ wɑtʃ, ʃi maɪɾ əv θɔt ðə kæmp kəd bi sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ə hɝɾ ʌv waɪl kæɾəl. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə meɪɾənz wəd bi ɑn ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ðə naɪt, tu. bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ sɔ hɝ, iðɝ.

Most of the men were asleep, dark humps among the shadows beneath the trees. A few remained awake, talking around the handful of fires still burning. She made no effort to hide, but none noticed her. Some appeared half asleep where they sat, heads nodding. If she had not known how well the men on sentry duty would be keeping watch, she might have thought the camp could be surprised by a herd of wild cattle. Of course, the Maidens would be on guard in the night, too. But it did not matter if they saw her, either.

ðə haɪ-wil kɑɹts meɪd lɔŋ, ʃæɾoʊd ɹoʊz, ðə sɝvəns ɔlɹɛɾi snʌɡ ən snɔɹɪŋ bɪniθ. moʊst ə ðə sɝvəns. wʌn faɪɝ stɪl kɹækəl ðɛɹ. meɪaɪɡdɪn ən əɹ fɹɛnz sæɾ ɝaʊn ɪt. tɑlænvɝ wɑz tɔkɪŋ, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ fɪɹsli, bʌɾ oʊnli ði ʌðɝ mɛn sim tə bi peɪɪŋ ɪm ɛni maɪnd, ðoʊ hi əpɪɹd tə bi ədʒɹɛsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə meɪaɪɡdɪn. ðət ðeɪ hæd hæd bɛɾɝ ɡɑɹb ɪn ðɛɹ bʌndəlz ðən ðoʊz nɪɹ ɹæɡz wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, bʌt ðɛɹ fɔɹmɝ mɪstʃɹəs mʌst əv hæɾ ə vɛɹi fɹi hæn tə ɡɪv aʊt sɪlk tə hɝ pipəl, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn wɔɹ faɪnli kʌt sɪlk ɪndid, ɪn ə mjuɾɪd blu. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz wɑz dʒɹɛst soʊ wɛl, soʊ pɝhæps meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd bɪn ðɛɹ leɪɾiz feɪvɹɪt.

The high-wheeled carts made long, shadowed rows, the servants already snug and snoring beneath. Most of the servants. One fire still crackled there. Maighdin and her friends sat around it. Tallanvor was talking, gesturing fiercely, but only the other men seemed to be paying him any mind, though he appeared to be addressing himself to Maighdin. That they had had better garb in their bundles than those near rags was not surprising, but their former mistress must have had a very free hand to give out silk to her people, and Maighdin wore finely cut silk indeed, in a muted blue. None of the others was dressed so well, so perhaps Maighdin had been their lady's favorite.

ə twɪɡ snæpt ʌndɝ feɪlz fʊt, ən hɛdz wɪpt ɝaʊnd, tɑlænvɝ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə hɪz fit, hæf dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ i sɔ hɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊb ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ əlɝt ðən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn bɪhaɪn hɝ. fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm dʒʌst stɛɹɾ ət hɝ; ðən meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli ən meɪɾ ə dip kɝtsi, ən ði ʌðɝz heɪstəli fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪɡzæmpəl wɪð vɛɹiɪŋ dɪɡɹiz ə skɪl. oʊnli meɪaɪɡdɪn ən beɪlwɝ əpɪɹɾ əɾ ɔl əɾ iz. ə nɝvəs smaɪl splɪt ɡɪlz ɹaʊn feɪs.

A twig snapped under Faile's foot, and heads whipped around, Tallanvor starting to his feet, half drawing his sword before he saw her gathering her robe in the moonlight. They were more alert than the Two Rivers men behind her. For an instant the lot of them just stared at her; then Maighdin rose gracefully and made a deep curtsy, and the others hastily followed her example with varying degrees of skill. Only Maighdin and Balwer appeared at all at ease. A nervous smile split Gill's round face.

"ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð wʌt jə wɝ duɪŋ," feɪl toʊld əm kaɪnli. "bʌt doʊn steɪ ʌp tu leɪt; təmɑɹoʊ wɪl bi fʊl." ʃi wɔkt ɑn, bʌt wən ʃi ɡlæns bæk, ðeɪ wɝ stɪl stændɪŋ, stɪl piɹɪŋ æftɝ hɝ. ðɛɹ tʃɹævəlz mʌst əv meɪɾ əm wɛɹi əz ɹæbəts, ɔlweɪz wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə fɑks. ʃi wʌndɝd haʊ wɛl ðeɪ wəd fɪɾ ɪn. oʊvɝ ðə nɛks fju wiks, ʃi wəd bi bɪzi tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əm tə hɝ weɪz, lɝnɪŋ ðɛɹz. wʌn wɑz əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz ði ʌðɝ fəɹ ə wɛl-ɹʌn haʊshoʊld. ðə taɪm wəɾ əv tə bi faʊnd.

"Go on with what you were doing," Faile told them kindly. "But don't stay up too late; tomorrow will be full." She walked on, but when she glanced back, they were still standing, still peering after her. Their travels must have made them wary as rabbits, always watching for a fox. She wondered how well they would fit in. Over the next few weeks, she would be busy training them to her ways, learning theirs. One was as important as the other for a well-run household. The time would have to be found.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑt steɪ lɔŋ ɪn əɹ θɔts tənaɪt. sun ʃi wɑz bɪɑn ðə kɑɹts, nɑt kwaɪɾ aʊt tə wɛɹ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wəd bi kipɪŋ ʃɑɹp wɑtʃ fɹəm ʌp ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. nʌθɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə maʊs wəd ɡɛt baɪ ðɛm ənsin - ivən səm ə ðə meɪɾənz hæd bɪn spɑɾəd əpɑn əkeɪʒən - bʌt ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɛniwʌn ətɛmptɪŋ tə snik ɪn. nɑt fəɹ ðoʊz u hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə bi ðɛɹ. ɪn ə smɔl munlɪt klɪɹɪŋ, hɝ pipəl wɝ weɪɾɪŋ.

They did not stay long in her thoughts tonight. Soon she was beyond the carts, not quite out to where Two Rivers men would be keeping sharp watch from up in the trees. Nothing larger than a mouse would get by them unseen - even some of the Maidens had been spotted upon occasion - but they were watching for anyone attempting to sneak in. Not for those who had a right to be there. In a small moonlit clearing, her people were waiting.

səm ə ðə mɛn baʊd, ən pɛɹɪlin nɪɹli wɛn tə wʌn ni bɪfɔɹ stɑpɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. sɛvɹəl wɪmən ɪnstɪŋktɪvli meɪd kɝtsiz ðət lʊkt kwaɪt pəkjuljɝ ɪn mɛnz ɡɑɹb, ðən dʒɹɑp ðɛɹ aɪz əɹ ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪmbɛɹəsmən ət ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn. ðə mænɝz ə ðə kɔɹt hæd bɪn bɹɛɾ ɪndə ðɛm, ðoʊ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd tə ədɑpt il kʌstəmz. wʌt ðeɪ bɪlivd wɝ il kʌstəmz, ət list. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ hɔɹəfaɪd ðə meɪɾənz wɪð wʌt ðeɪ bɪlivd. pɛɹɪn kɔld əm fulz, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɪn səm weɪz, bʌt ðeɪ hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə hɝ, ðiz kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz - wɔɾɝ oʊθ, ðeɪ neɪmd ɪt, kɑpiɪŋ ði il, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə - ən ðət meɪɾ əm hɝz. əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ðeɪ hæd teɪkən tə kɔlɪŋ ðɛɹ "səsaɪəɾi" tʃɑ feɪl, ðə fælkənz tælən, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd sin ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv kipɪŋ ðət kwaɪət. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt fulz ɪn ɔl weɪz. ɪn fækt, ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz ɛniweɪ, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt tu ənlaɪk ðə jʌŋ mɛn ən wɪmən ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð.

Some of the men bowed, and Parelean nearly went to one knee before stopping himself. Several women instinctively made curtsies that looked quite peculiar in men's garb, then dropped their eyes or shifted in embarrassment at realizing what they had done. The manners of the court had been bred into them, though they tried very hard to adopt Aiel customs. What they believed were Aiel customs, at least. Sometimes they horrified the Maidens with what they believed. Perrin called them fools, and they were in some ways, but they had sworn fealty to her, these Cairhienin and Tairens - water oath, they named it, copying the Aiel, trying to - and that made them hers. Among themselves they had taken to calling their "society" Cha Faile, the Falcon's Talon, though they had seen the necessity of keeping that quiet. They were not fools in all ways. In fact, around the edges anyway, they were not too unlike the young men and women she had grown up with.

ðoʊz ʃi hæd sɛn ɔf ɝli ðət mɔɹnɪŋ hæd dʒʌst ɹɪtɝnd, fəɹ ðə wɪmən əmʌŋ əm wɝ stɪl tʃeɪnʒɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹɛsəz ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn ə nəsɛsəɾi. ivən wʌn wʊmən dʒɹɛst əz ə mæn wʊɾə ɹaʊz noʊɾəs ɪn bɛθɔl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən faɪv. ðə klɪɹɪŋ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt flɝi ʌv skɝts ən ʃɪfs, koʊts ən ʃɝts ən bɹitʃɪz. ðə wɪmən meɪd bɪliv ðeɪ dɪd nɑt maɪn biɪŋ ənkloʊðd ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌðɝz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ mɛn, sɪns ði il əpɛɹənli dɪd nɑt, bʌt heɪst ən leɪbɝd bɹiðɪŋ ɡeɪv əm ðə laɪ. ðə mɛn wɝ ɔl ʃɪftɪŋ fiɾ ən tɝnɪŋ hɛdz, tɔɹn bɪtwin lʊkɪŋ əweɪ disənli ən wɑtʃɪŋ, əz ðeɪ θɔt ði il dɪd, waɪl pɹitɛndɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hæf-dʒɹɛst wɪmən. feɪl hɛld əɹ ɹoʊb kloʊs oʊvɝ əɹ naɪtdʒɹɛs; ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv dʒɹɛs fɝðɝ wɪθaʊt weɪkɪŋ pɛɹɪn fəɹ ʃʊɹ, bʌt ʃi meɪd noʊ pɹitɛns ət kʌmfɝt. ʃi wɑz noʊ dəmɑni, tə ɹəsiv əɹ ɹɪteɪnɝz ɪn əɹ bæθ.

Those she had sent off early that morning had just returned, for the women among them were still changing out of the dresses they had worn of necessity. Even one woman dressed as a man would have roused notice in Bethal, not to mention five. The clearing was a great flurry of skirts and shifts, coats and shirts and breeches. The women made believe they did not mind being unclothed in front of others, including men, since the Aiel apparently did not, but haste and labored breathing gave them the lie. The men were all shifting feet and turning heads, torn between looking away decently and watching, as they thought the Aiel did, while pretending they were not looking at half-dressed women. Faile held her robe close over her nightdress; she could not have dressed further without waking Perrin for sure, but she made no pretense at comfort. She was no Domani, to receive her retainers in her bath.

"fɝɡɪv əs fəɹ biɪŋ leɪt, maɪ leɪɾi feɪl," sɛlən pæntɪd, tʌɡɪŋ əɹ koʊɾ ɑn. ði æksɛns ə kɛɹhin wɝ ʃɑɹp ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt wʊmənz vɔɪs. ivən fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, ʃi wɑz nɑt tɔl. ʃi mænədʒd ə kɹɛɾəbəl swæɡɝ, ðoʊ, ə suɾəbəl boʊlnəs ɪn ðə tɪlt ə hɝ hɛɾ ən ðə sɛɾ ə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. "wi wʊɾə ɹɪtɝn sunɝ, bʌt ðə ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz meɪɾ ə bɑðɝ lɛɾɪŋ əs aʊt."

"Forgive us for being late, my Lady Faile," Selande panted, tugging her coat on. The accents of Cairhien were sharp in the short woman's voice. Even for a Cairhienin, she was not tall. She managed a credible swagger, though, a suitable boldness in the tilt of her head and the set of her shoulders. "We would have returned sooner, but the gate guards made a bother letting us out."

"ə bɑðɝ?" feɪl sɛd ʃɑɹpli. ɪf oʊnli ʃi cʊɾə sin wɪð əɹ oʊn aɪz, ɑn tɑp ə ðɛɹz; ɪf oʊnli pɛɹɪn hæd lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɪnstɛɾ ə ðət tʃɹɑləp. noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt θɪŋk əbaʊt bɹəleɪn. ɪt wɑz nɑt pɛɹɪnz fɔlt. ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd ðət tə hɝsɛlf twɛnti taɪmz ə deɪ, laɪk ə pɹɛɹ. bʌt waɪ wɑz ðə mæn soʊ blaɪnd? "wʌt kaɪndə bɑðɝ?" ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃəɡɹɪn bɹɛθ. tʃɹʌbəlz wɪð jəɹ hʌzbənd ʃəd nɛvɝ əfɛk jəɹ toʊn wɪð jəɹ væsəlz.

"A bother?" Faile said sharply. If only she could have seen with her own eyes, on top of theirs; if only Perrin had let her go instead of that trollop. No, she would not think about Berelain. It was not Perrin's fault. She repeated that to herself twenty times a day, like a prayer. But why was the man so blind? "What kind of bother?" She drew a chagrined breath. Troubles with your husband should never affect your tone with your vassals.

"nʌθɪŋ ə noʊt, maɪ leɪɾi." sɛlən bʌkəld əɹ sɔɹd bɛlt ən sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps. "ðeɪ lɛt səm fɛloʊz əhɛɾ ʌv əs dʒɹaɪv ðɛɹ wæɡənz θɹu wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛkən lʊk, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ wɝiɾ əbaʊt lɛɾɪŋ wɪmən ɡoʊ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt." səm ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən læft. ðə faɪv mɛn u hæd ɡɔn ɪndə bɛθɔl stɝɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli, noʊ daʊt kəz ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn θɔɾ ɪnʌf pɹətɛkʃən. ðə ɹɛst ə tʃɑ feɪl meɪɾ ə θɪk sɛmɪsɝkəl bɪhaɪn ðoʊz tɛn, wɑtʃɪŋ feɪl kloʊsli, lɪsnɪŋ kloʊsli. munlaɪt ʃæɾoʊd ðɛɹ feɪsəz.

"Nothing of note, my Lady." Selande buckled her sword belt and settled it on her hips. "They let some fellows ahead of us drive their wagons through without a second look, but they were worried about letting women go out into the night." Some of the other women laughed. The five men who had gone into Bethal stirred irritably, no doubt because they had not been thought enough protection. The rest of Cha Faile made a thick semicircle behind those ten, watching Faile closely, listening closely. Moonlight shadowed their faces.

"tɛl mi wʌt jə sɔ," feɪl kəmændəɾ ɪn ə kɑmɝ toʊn. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ.

"Tell me what you saw," Faile commanded in a calmer tone. Much better.

sɛlən meɪɾ əɹ ɹipɔɹt kənsaɪsli, ən fəɹ ɔl feɪlz wɪʃɪz ðət ʃi hæd ɡɔn hɝsɛlf, ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt ðeɪ hæd sin ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kəɾ əv wɪʃt. ðə stʃɹits ə bɛθɔl wɝ nɪɹli ɛmpti ivən ət ðə bɪziəst aʊɝz ə ðə deɪ. pipəl steɪd tə ðɛɹ oʊn hoʊmz əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl. ə lɪɾəl kɑmɝs tʃɹɪkəld ɪn ən aʊt, bʌt fju mɝtʃəns vɛntʃɝɾ ɪndə ðɪs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɡildən, ən bɛɹli ɪnʌf fud keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd tə kip ɛvɹiwʌn fɛd. moʊst ə ðə taʊnzpipəl sim stʌnd, əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʌt leɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, sɪŋkɪŋ dipɝ ən dipɝ ɪndə æpəθi ən dɪspɛɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn kɛp ðɛɹ maʊðz kloʊz fəɹ fɪɹ ə ðə pɹɑfəts spaɪz, ən ðɛɹ aɪz əz wɛl, fəɹ fɪɹ ə biɪŋ teɪkən fəɹ spaɪz. ðə pɹɑfət hæɾ ə dip ɪfɛkt. fəɹ ɪnstəns, haʊɛvɝ mɛni bændəts ɹoʊm ðə hɪlz, kʌtpɝsɪz ən fʊtpædz hæd vænɪʃt fɹəm bɛθɔl. ɪt wɑz sɛd ðə pɹɑfəts pɛnəlti fəɹ ə θif wɑz tə kʌɾ ɔf ðə mænz hænz. ðoʊ ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə əplaɪ tə hɪz oʊn pipəl.

Selande made her report concisely, and for all Faile's wishes that she had gone herself, she had to admit they had seen almost as much as she could have wished. The streets of Bethal were nearly empty even at the busiest hours of the day. People stayed to their own homes as much as possible. A little commerce trickled in and out, but few merchants ventured into this part of Ghealdan, and barely enough food came in from the countryside to keep everyone fed. Most of the townspeople seemed stunned, afraid of what lay outside the walls, sinking deeper and deeper into apathy and despair. Everyone kept their mouths closed for fear of the Prophet's spies, and their eyes as well, for fear of being taken for spies. The Prophet had a deep effect. For instance, however many bandits roamed the hills, cutpurses and footpads had vanished from Bethal. It was said the Prophet's penalty for a thief was to cut off the man's hands. Though that did not seem to apply to his own people.

"ðə kwin tʊɹz ðə sɪɾi ɛvɹi deɪ, ʃoʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə kip spɪɹəts ʌp," sɛlən sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɪt hɛlps mʌtʃ. ʃiz meɪkɪŋ ə pɹɑɡɹɛs hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ tə ɹimaɪn pipəl ðeɪv ə kwin; meɪbi ʃiz hæd mɔɹ səksɛs ɛlswɛɹ. ðə wɑtʃ əz bɪn æɾəd tə ðə wɔl ɡɑɹdz, ən ɔl bʌɾ ə hændfʊl ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz, tu. pɝhæps ɪt meɪks ðə taʊnzfoʊk fil seɪfɝ. əntɪl ʃi muvz ɑn. ənlaɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, æliændɝ hɝsɛlf əpɛɹənli filz noʊ fɪɹ ðə pɹɑfət wɪl kʌm stɔɹmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɔlz. ʃi wɔks əloʊn ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz ə lɔɹd tɛləbɪnz pæləs, mɔɹnɪŋ ən ivnɪŋ, ən kips oʊnli ə fju soʊlʒɝz, hu spɛn moʊst ə ðɛɹ taɪm ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə sɪɾi simz əz kənsɝnd wɪð fud, wɪð haʊ lɔŋ ðəɹ wɪl bi ɪnʌf, əz ðeɪ ɑɹ wɪð ðə pɹɑfət. ɪn tʃɹuθ, maɪ leɪɾi, fəɹ ɔl ðə ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðə wɔlz, aɪ θɪŋk ɪf mæsimə əpɪɹɾ ət ðə ɡeɪts əloʊn, ðeɪ maɪt ɡɪv ɪm ðə taʊn."

"The Queen tours the city every day, showing herself to keep spirits up," Selande said, "but I do not think it helps much. She is making a progress here in the south to remind people they have a Queen; maybe she has had more success elsewhere. The Watch has been added to the wall guards, and all but a handful of her soldiers, too. Perhaps it makes the townsfolk feel safer. Until she moves on. Unlike everyone else, Alliandre herself apparently feels no fear the Prophet will come storming over the walls. She walks alone in the gardens of Lord Telabin's palace, morning and evening, and keeps only a few soldiers, who spend most of their time in the kitchens. Everybody in the city seems as concerned with food, with how long there will be enough, as they are with the Prophet. In truth, my Lady, for all the guards on the walls, I think if Masema appeared at the gates alone, they might give him the town."

"ðeɪ wʊd," mɛɹɑldə pʊɾ ɪn kəntɛmptʃwəsli, bʌklɪŋ əɹ oʊn sɔɹd ɹaʊn əɹ weɪst, "æn bɛɡ fəɹ mɝsi." dɑɹk ən stɑki, mɛɹɑldə wɑz əz tɔl əz feɪl, bʌt ðə tɛɹən wʊmən dʌkt əɹ hɛɾ əɾ ə fɹaʊn fɹəm sɛlən ən mɝmɝɾ ən əpɑlədʒi. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ daʊts u lɛd tʃɑ feɪl, æftɝ feɪl hɝsɛlf.

"They would," Meralda put in contemptuously, buckling her own sword round her waist, "and beg for mercy." Dark and stocky, Meralda was as tall as Faile, but the Tairen woman ducked her head at a frown from Selande and murmured an apology. There were no doubts who led Cha Faile, after Faile herself.

ʃi hæd bɪn pliz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə pɹɛsəɾəns ðeɪ hæɾ ɪstæblɪʃt. sɛlənd wɑz ðə bɹaɪɾəst ə ðɛm ɪksɛpt pɝhæps fəɹ pɛɹɪlin, ən oʊnli ɹɛlə ən kɑmɛl wɝ kwɪkɝ. ən sɛlən hæd sʌmθɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə, ə stɛɾinɪs, əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi feɪs ðə wɝs fɪɹ ɪn əɹ laɪf ən nʌθɪŋ kəɾ ɛvɝ bi ðət bæɾ əɡɛn. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wɑntəɾ ə skɑɹ laɪk ðoʊz səm ə ðə meɪɾənz hæd. feɪl pəzɛst sɛvɹəl smɔl skɑɹz, bædʒɪz ʌv ɑnɝ moʊst ə ðɛm, bʌɾ æktʃəli  sikɪŋ wʌn wɑz ɪɾiəsi. ət lis ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt tu vɛɹi iɡɝ ɪn ðə mæɾɝ.

She had been pleased there was no need to change the precedence they had established. Selande was the brightest of them except perhaps for Parelean, and only Arrela and Camaille were quicker. And Selande had something extra, a steadiness, as if she had already faced the worst fear in her life and nothing could ever be that bad again. Of course, she wanted a scar like those some of the Maidens had. Faile possessed several small scars, badges of honor most of them, but actually seeking one was idiocy. At least the woman was not too very eager in the matter.

"wi meɪɾ ə mæp, əz jə ɹikwaɪɝd, maɪ leɪɾi," ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv wʊmən fɪnɪʃt wɪð ə læst, wɔɹnɪŋ ɡlæns ət mɛɹɑldə. "wi mɑɹkt aʊt lɔɹd tɛləbɪnz pæləs ɑn ðə bæk əz mʌtʃ əz wi kʊd, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ðəɾ ɪz nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðə ɡɑɹɾənz ən steɪbəlz."

"We made a map, as you required, my Lady," the diminutive woman finished with a last, warning glance at Meralda. "We marked out Lord Telabin's palace on the back as much as we could, but I fear that is not much more than the gardens and stables."

feɪl dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk aʊt ðə laɪnz ɑn ðə peɪpɝ ʃi ənfoʊldəɾ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ə pɪɾi ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡoʊ hɝsɛlf; ʃi cʊɾə mæp ði ɪntɪɹiɝ, tu. noʊ. dʌn wɑz dʌn, əz pɛɹɪn laɪk tə seɪ. ən ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf. "ju ɑɹ sɝɾən noʊ wʌn sɝtʃɪz wæɡənz livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi?" ivən ɪn ðə peɪl laɪt, ʃi kəd si kənfjuʒən ɑn mɛni ʌv ðə feɪsəz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. nʌn nu waɪ ʃi hæd sɛn səm ə ðɛm ɪndə bɛθɔl.

Faile did not try to make out the lines on the paper she unfolded in the moonlight. A pity she had not been able to go herself; she could have mapped the interior, too. No. Done was done, as Perrin liked to say. And it was enough. "You are certain no one searches wagons leaving the city?" Even in the pale light, she could see confusion on many of the faces in front of her. None knew why she had sent some of them into Bethal.

sɛlən dɪd nɑt lʊk kənfjuzd. "jɛs, maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. kwaɪt bɹaɪt, ən mɔɹ ðən kwɪk ɪnʌf.

Selande did not look confused. "Yes, my Lady," she said calmly. Quite bright, and more than quick enough.

ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɹʌslɪŋ livz ɑn ðə tʃɹiz, ɹʌslɪŋ dɛd livz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən feɪl wɪʃt ʃi hæd pɛɹɪnz ɪɹz. hɪz noʊz ən aɪz, tu. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf ɛniwʌn sɔ hɝ hɪɹ wɪð əɹ ɹɪteɪnɝz, bʌɾ ivzdʒɹɑpɝz wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. "juv dʌn vɛɹi wɛl, sɛlənd. ɔl ə jə hæv." pɛɹɪn nu ðə deɪnʒɝz hɪɹ, əz ɹil əz ɛni fɑɹðɝ saʊθ; hi nu, bʌt laɪk moʊs mɛn, hi θɔt wɪð ɪz hɑɹɾ əz ɔfən əz ɪz hɛd. ə waɪf hæd tə bi pɹæktəkəl, tə kip əɹ hʌzbən aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl. ðət hæd bɪn əɹ mʌðɝz vɛɹi fɝs pis ʌv ædvaɪs ɑn mɛɹid laɪf. "æt fɝs laɪt, jəl ɹɪtɝn tə bɛθɔl, ən ɪf jə ɹəsiv wɝd fɹəm mi, ðɪs ɪz wʌt jəl du. . . ."

The wind gusted for a moment, rustling leaves on the trees, rustling dead leaves on the ground, and Faile wished she had Perrin's ears. His nose and eyes, too. It did not matter if anyone saw her here with her retainers, but eavesdroppers would be something else. "You've done very well, Selande. All of you have." Perrin knew the dangers here, as real as any farther south; he knew, but like most men, he thought with his heart as often as his head. A wife had to be practical, to keep her husband out of trouble. That had been her mother's very first piece of advice on married life. "At first light, you will return to Bethal, and if you receive word from me, this is what you will do. . . ."

ivən sɛlənz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn ʃɑk əz ʃi wɛn ɑn, bʌt noʊ wʌn mɝmɝd ðə slaɪɾəst pɹoʊɾɛst. feɪl wʊɾə bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd. hɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz wɝ tə ðə pɔɪnt. ðəɹ wəd bi səm deɪnʒɝ, bʌɾ ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, nɑt nɪɹli wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn.

Even Selande's eyes widened in shock as she went on, but no one murmured the slightest protest. Faile would have been surprised if anyone had. Her instructions were to the point. There would be some danger, but under the circumstances, not nearly what might have been.

"ɑɹ ðəɹ ɛni kwɛstʃənz?" ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "dʌz ɛvɹiwʌn ʌndɝstænd?"

"Are there any questions?" she said finally. "Does everyone understand?"

wɪð wʌn vɔɪs, tʃɑ feɪl ænsɝd. "wi lɪv tə sɝv əɹ leɪɾi feɪl." ən ðət mɛn ðeɪ wəd sɝv əɹ bɪlʌvd wʊlf, wɛðɝ i wɑntəɾ əm tə əɹ nɑt.

With one voice, Cha Faile answered. "We live to serve our Lady Faile." And that meant they would serve her beloved wolf, whether he wanted them to or not.

meɪaɪɡdɪn ʃɪftəɾ ɪn əɹ blæŋkəts ɑn ðə hɑɹd ɡɹaʊnd, slip ɪluɾɪŋ hɝ. ðət wɑz əɹ neɪm, naʊ; ə nu neɪm fəɹ ə nu laɪf. meɪaɪɡdɪn, fəɹ əɹ mʌðɝ, ən dɔɹleɪn, fəɹ ə fæmli ɑn ən ɪsteɪt ðət hæd bɪn hɝz. ə nu laɪf fəɹ ən oʊld laɪf ɡɔn, bʌt taɪz ə ðə hɑɹt kəd nɑt bi kʌt. ən naʊ. . . . naʊ. . . .

Maighdin shifted in her blankets on the hard ground, sleep eluding her. That was her name, now; a new name for a new life. Maighdin, for her mother, and Dorlain, for a family on an estate that had been hers. A new life for an old life gone, but ties of the heart could not be cut. And now. . . . Now. . . .

ə feɪn kɹækəl ə dɛd livz bɹɔɾ əɹ hɛɾ ʌp, ən ʃi wɑtʃt ə dɪm ʃeɪp pæs θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ðə leɪɾi feɪl, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ tɛn fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi hæd ɡɔn. ə plɛzən jʌŋ wʊmən, kaɪndhɑɹɾɪd ən wɛl spoʊkən. wʌtɛvɝ əɹ hʌzbənz stɑk, ʃi ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli wɑz nɑbli bɔɹn. bʌt jʌŋ. ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst. ðət maɪt bi ə hɛlp.

A faint crackle of dead leaves brought her head up, and she watched a dim shape pass through the trees. The Lady Faile, returning to her tent from wherever she had gone. A pleasant young woman, kindhearted and well spoken. Whatever her husband's stock, she almost certainly was nobly born. But young. Inexperienced. That might be a help.

meɪaɪɡdɪn lɛɾ əɹ hɛd fɔl bæk ɑn ðə kloʊk ʃi hæd wɑɾəd ʌp fəɹ ə pɪloʊ. laɪt, wʌt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ hɪɹ? teɪkɪŋ sɝvəs əz ə leɪɾiz meɪd! noʊ. ʃi wəd hoʊld ɑn tə hɝ kɑnfəɾəns ɪn hɝsɛlf, ət list. ʃi kəd stɪl faɪn ðæt. ʃi kʊd. ɪf ʃi dʌɡ dipli. hɝ bɹɛθ kɑɾ ət ðə saʊn ə fʊtstɛps kloʊs baɪ.

Maighdin let her head fall back on the cloak she had wadded up for a pillow. Light, what was she doing here? Taking service as a lady's maid! No. She would hold on to her confidence in herself, at least. She could still find that. She could. If she dug deeply. Her breath caught at the sound of footsteps close by.

tɑlænvɝ nɛlt ɡɹeɪsfəli əɾ əɹ saɪd. hi wɑz ʃɝtləs, munlaɪt ɡlimɪŋ ɑn ðə smuð mʌsəlz ə hɪz tʃɛst ən ʃoʊldɝz, hɪz feɪs ɪn ʃædoʊz. ə slaɪt bɹiz ɹʌfəld ɪz hɛɹ. "wʌt mædnəs ɪz ðɪs?" hi æsk sɔfli. "ɛntɝɪŋ sɝvəs? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ʌp tə? ən doʊn tɛl mi ðət nɑnsɛns əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə nu laɪf; aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪt. noʊ wʌn dʌz."

Tallanvor knelt gracefully at her side. He was shirtless, moonlight gleaming on the smooth muscles of his chest and shoulders, his face in shadows. A slight breeze ruffled his hair. "What madness is this?" he asked softly. "Entering service? What are you up to? And don't tell me that nonsense about making a new life; I don't believe it. No one does."

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɝn əweɪ, bʌɾ i leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. hi ɪɡzɝɾɪd noʊ pɹɛʃɝ, jɛɾ ɪt stɑpt əɹ əz ʃʊɹli əz ə hɔltɝ. laɪt, pliz lɛɾ əɹ nɑt tʃɹɛmbəl. ðə laɪt dɪd nɑt lɪsən, bʌɾ ət list ʃi mænədʒ tə kip əɹ vɔɪs stɛɾi. "ɪf jə hævənt noʊɾəst, aɪ mʌs meɪk maɪ weɪ ɪn ðə wɝld, naʊ. bɛɾɝ əz ə leɪɾiz meɪd ðən ə tævɝn meɪd. jə meɪ fil fɹi tə ɡoʊ ɑn əloʊn ɪf sɝvəs hɪɹ dʌzn sut."

She tried to turn away, but he laid a hand on her shoulder. He exerted no pressure, yet it stopped her as surely as a halter. Light, please let her not tremble. The Light did not listen, but at least she managed to keep her voice steady. "If you haven't noticed, I must make my way in the world, now. Better as a lady's maid than a tavern maid. You may feel free to go on alone if service here doesn't suit."

"ju dɪdn æbdəkeɪt jəɹ wɪts əɹ jəɹ pɹaɪd wən jə ɡeɪv ʌp ðə θɹoʊn," hi mʌɾɝd. bɝn lini fəɹ ɹɪvilɪŋ ðæt! "ɪf jə min tə pɹitɛn ðət jə dɪd, aɪ sədʒɛs jə əvɔɪd lɛɾɪŋ lini ɡɛt jə əloʊn." ðə mæn tʃʌkəld ət hɝ! hi tʃʌkəld, oʊ, soʊ ɹɪtʃli! "ʃi wɑns ə wɝd wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən aɪ səspɛkt ʃi woʊn bi əz dʒɛntəl wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn əz ʃi wɑz wɪð mɔɹɡeɪs."

"You didn't abdicate your wits or your pride when you gave up the throne," he muttered. Burn Lini for revealing that! "If you mean to pretend that you did, I suggest you avoid letting Lini get you alone." The man chuckled at her! He chuckled, oh, so richly! "She wants a word with Maighdin, and I suspect she won't be as gentle with Maighdin as she was with Morgase."

æŋɡɹəli ʃi sæɾ ʌp, bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz hæn əweɪ. "ɑɹ jə blaɪnd, ən dɛf əz wɛl? ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz plænz fəɹ ɪleɪn! laɪt, aɪ wʊdn laɪk ɪɾ ɪf i sɪmpli nu hɝ neɪm! ɪt mʌs bi mɔɹ ðən tʃæns ðət bɹɔt mi tə wʌn ə hɪz hɛntʃmən, tɑlænvɝ. ɪts tə bi!"

Angrily she sat up, brushing his hand away. "Are you blind, and deaf as well? The Dragon Reborn has plans for Elayne! Light, I wouldn't like it if he simply knew her name! It must be more than chance that brought me to one of his henchmen, Tallanvor. It has to be!"

"bɝn mi, aɪ nu ɪt mʌs bi ðæt. aɪ hoʊpt aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ, bʌt. . . ." hi saʊndəɾ əz æŋɡɹi əz ʃi. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə bi æŋɡɹi! "ɪleɪn ɪz seɪf ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit woʊn lɛɾ əɹ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ə mæn u kən tʃænəl, ivən ɪf hiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - ɪspɛʃli ɪf i ɪz! - ən meɪaɪɡdɪn dɔɹleɪn kən də nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, əɹ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ɔl ʃi kən də ɪz ɡɛɾ əɹ nɛk snæpt, əɹ əɹ θɹoʊt kʌt, əɹ - !"

"Burn me, I knew it must be that. I hoped I was wrong, but. . . ." He sounded as angry as she. He had no right to be angry! "Elayne is safe in the White Tower, the Amyrlin Seat won't let her anywhere near a man who can channel, even if he is the Dragon Reborn - especially if he is! - and Maighdin Dorlain can do nothing about the Amyrlin Seat, the Dragon Reborn, or the Lion Throne. All she can do is get her neck snapped, or her throat cut, or - !"

"meɪaɪɡdɪn dɔɹleɪn kən wɑtʃ!" ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn, ət lis pɑɹtli tə stɑp ðəɾ ɑfəl lɪɾəni. "ʃi kən lɪsən! ʃi kən . . . !" ɪɹɪɾəbli, ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf. wʌt kəd ʃi du? sʌɾənli ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ə θɪn ʃɪft ən hɝidli foʊldəɾ əɹ blæŋkəts ɝaʊn hɝ. ðə naɪɾ æktʃəli  simd ə lɪɾəl kul. əɹ meɪbi ðə ɡus bʌmps ɑn əɹ skɪn wɝ fɹəm tɑlænvɝz ənsin aɪz ɑn hɝ. ðə θɔt ɹaʊzd ə flʌʃ ɪn əɹ tʃiks ʃi hoʊpt i kəd nɑt si. lʌkəli, ɪt pʊɾ ə hiɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, tu. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡɝl, tə ɡoʊ blʌʃɪŋ kəz ə mæn lʊkt ət hɝ! "aɪ wɪl də wʌɾ aɪ kæn, wʌtɛvɝ ðəɾ ɪz. ðə tʃæns wɪl kʌm tə lɝn sʌmθɪŋ əɹ də sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɪl hɛlp ɪleɪn, əl wɪl teɪk ɪt!"

"Maighdin Dorlain can watch!" she broke in, at least partly to stop that awful litany. "She can listen! She can . . . !" Irritably, she trailed off. What could she do? Suddenly she realized she was sitting there in a thin shift and hurriedly folded her blankets around her. The night actually seemed a little cool. Or maybe the goose bumps on her skin were from Tallanvor's unseen eyes on her. The thought roused a flush in her cheeks she hoped he could not see. Luckily, it put a heat in her voice, too. She was not a girl, to go blushing because a man looked at her! "I will do what I can, whatever that is. The chance will come to learn something or do something that will help Elayne, and I will take it!"

"ə deɪnʒɝəs dɪsɪʒən," hi toʊld əɹ kɑmli. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd meɪk aʊɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. oʊnli tə ɹiɾ ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. "ju hɝɾ ɪm θɹɛɾən tə hæŋ ɛniwʌn u lʊkt əɾ ɪm ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ. aɪ kən bɪliv ɪt, ɪn ə mæn wɪð ðoʊz aɪz. laɪk ə bist. aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd i lɛt ðət fɛloʊ ɡoʊ; aɪ θɔt hid ɹɪp ɪz θɹoʊɾ aʊt! ɪf i dɪskʌvɝz u jə ɑɹ, hu jə juz tə bi. . . . beɪlwɝ maɪt bɪtʃɹeɪ ju. hi nɛvɝ ɹɪli ɪkspleɪnd waɪ hi hɛlpt əs ɪskeɪp æmədɔɹ. meɪbi hi θɔt kwin mɔɹɡeɪs wəd ɡɪv ɪm ə nu pəzɪʃən. naʊ hi noʊz ðɛɹz noʊ tʃæns ə ðæt, ən i maɪt wɑnə kʌɹi feɪvɝ wɪð ɪz nu mæstɝ ən mɪstʃɹəs."

"A dangerous decision," he told her calmly. She wished she could make out his face in the darkness. Only to read his expression, of course. "You heard him threaten to hang anyone who looked at him the wrong way. I can believe it, in a man with those eyes. Like a beast. I was surprised he let that fellow go; I thought he'd rip his throat out! If he discovers who you are, who you used to be. . . . Balwer might betray you. He never really explained why he helped us escape Amador. Maybe he thought Queen Morgase would give him a new position. Now he knows there's no chance of that, and he might want to curry favor with his new master and mistress."

"ɑɹ jə əfɹeɪɾ ə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz?" ʃi dɪmændəd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. laɪt, ðə mæn fɹaɪɾənd hɝ! ðoʊz aɪz bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə wʊlf. "beɪlwɝ noʊz ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ɪz tʌŋ. ɛniθɪŋ i sɛz wɪl ɹəflɛkt ɑn hɪm; hi keɪm wɪð mi, æftɝ ɔl. ɪf jəɹ əfɹeɪd, ðən ɹaɪɾ ɑn!"

"Are you afraid of Lord Perrin Goldeneyes?" she demanded contemptuously. Light, the man frightened her! Those eyes belonged on a wolf. "Balwer knows enough to hold his tongue. Anything he says will reflect on him; he came with me, after all. If you're afraid, then ride on!"

"ju ɔlweɪz flɪŋ ðəɾ ɪn maɪ feɪs," hi saɪd, sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn ɪz hilz. ʃi kəd nɑt si hɪz aɪz, bʌt ʃi kəd fil ðɛm. "ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪf jə wɪʃ, jə seɪ. wʌns, ðəɹ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ lʌvd ə kwin fɹəm əfɑɹ, noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz hoʊpləs, noʊɪŋ i kəd nɛvɝ dɛɹ spik. naʊ ðə kwin ɪz ɡɔn, ən oʊnli ə wʊmən ɹɪmeɪnz, ən aɪ hoʊp. aɪ bɝn wɪð hoʊp! ɪf jə wɑn mi tə liv, meɪaɪɡdɪn, seɪ ɪt. wʌn wɝd. 'ɡoʊ!' ə sɪmpəl wɝd."

"You always fling that in my face," he sighed, settling back on his heels. She could not see his eyes, but she could feel them. "Ride on if you wish, you say. Once, there was a soldier loved a queen from afar, knowing it was hopeless, knowing he could never dare speak. Now the queen is gone, and only a woman remains, and I hope. I burn with hope! If you want me to leave, Maighdin, say it. One word. 'Go!' A simple word."

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊð. ə sɪmpəl wɝd, ʃi θɔt. laɪt, ɪts oʊnli wʌn wɝd! waɪ kæn aɪ seɪ ɪt! laɪt, pliz! fəɹ ðə sɛkən taɪm ðət naɪt, ðə laɪt feɪl tə hɪɹ. ʃi sæt ðəɹ hʌɾəld ɪn əɹ blæŋkəts laɪk ə ful, hɝ maʊθ oʊpən, hɝ feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɾɝ ən hɑɾɝ.

She opened her mouth. A simple word, she thought. Light, it's only one word! Why can't I say it! Light, please! For the second time that night, the Light failed to hear. She sat there huddled in her blankets like a fool, her mouth open, her face growing hotter and hotter.

ɪf i hæd tʃʌkəld əɡɛn, ʃi wʊɾə pʊɾ əɹ bɛl naɪf ɪn hɪm. ɪf i hæd læft, əɹ ɡɪvən ɛni saɪn ə tʃɹaɪəmf. . . . ɪnstɛd, hi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ən dʒɛnli kɪst əɹ aɪz. ʃi meɪɾ ə saʊn dip ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt; ʃi kəd nɑt sim tə muv. waɪd-aɪd, ʃi wɑtʃt ɪm stænd. hi lumd ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ʃi wɑz ə kwin - ʃi hæd bɪn ə kwin - juz tə kəmænd, juz tə hɑɹd dɪsɪʒənz ɪn hɑɹd taɪmz, bʌt ɹaɪt ðən ðə paʊndɪŋ ə hɝ hɑɹt dʒɹʌm θɔt fɹəm əɹ hɛd.

If he had chuckled again, she would have put her belt knife in him. If he had laughed, or given any sign of triumph. . . . Instead, he leaned forward and gently kissed her eyes. She made a sound deep in her throat; she could not seem to move. Wide-eyed, she watched him stand. He loomed in the moonlight. She was a queen - she had been a queen - used to command, used to hard decisions in hard times, but right then the pounding of her heart drummed thought from her head.

"hæd jə sɛd 'ɡoʊ,' " hi toʊl hɝ, "aɪɾ əv bɛɹid hoʊp, bʌɾ aɪ kəd nɛvɝ liv ju."

"Had you said 'go,' " he told her, "I'd have buried hope, but I could never leave you."

nɑɾ əntɪl i wɑz bæk ɪn ɪz oʊn blæŋkəts kəd ʃi meɪk hɝsɛlf laɪ daʊn ən dʒɹɔ hɝz ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi bɹiðd əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ. ðə naɪt wɑz kul; ʃi wɑz ʃɪvɝɪŋ, nɑt tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. tɑlænvɝ wɑz tu jʌŋ. tu jʌŋ! wɝs, hi wɑz ɹaɪt. bɝn ɪm fəɹ ðæt! ə leɪɾiz meɪd kəd də nʌθɪŋ tə əfɛkt ɪvɛns, ən ɪf ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz wʊlf-aɪd kɪlɝ lɝn ðəɾ i hæd mɔɹɡeɪs ʌv ændɝ ɪn ɪz hænz, ʃi kəd bi juzd əɡɛnst ɪleɪn ɪnstɛɾ ə hɛlpɪŋ hɝ. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə bi ɹaɪt wən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪm tə bi ɹɔŋ! ði ɪlɑdʒɪk ə ðət θɔɾ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃæns ʃi maɪt də səm ɡʊd! ðəɹ hæd tə bi!

Not until he was back in his own blankets could she make herself lie down and draw hers around her. She breathed as if she had been running. The night was cool; she was shivering, not trembling. Tallanvor was too young. Too young! Worse, he was right. Burn him for that! A lady's maid could do nothing to affect events, and if the Dragon Reborn's wolf-eyed killer learned that he had Morgase of Andor in his hands, she could be used against Elayne instead of helping her. He had no right to be right when she wanted him to be wrong! The illogic of that thought infuriated her. There was a chance she might do some good! There had to be!

ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, ə smɔl vɔɪs læft. jə kæn fɝɡɛt ðət jəɹ mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, ɪt toʊld əɹ skɔɹnfəli, ən ivən æftɝ ʃiz æbdəkeɪɾəd əɹ θɹoʊn, kwin mɔɹɡeɪs kæn stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ əɹ hæn ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə ðə maɪɾi, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ ɹuən ʃiz meɪɾ ʌv ɪt soʊ fɑɹ. ən ʃi kæn tɛl ə mæn tə ɡoʊ əweɪ, iðɝ, kəz ʃi kæn stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ haʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɪz hænz ɑɹ, ən haʊ hɪz lɪps kɝv wən i smaɪlz, ən -  fjʊɹiəs, ʃi pʊl ðə blæŋkəɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃʌɾ aʊt ðə vɔɪs. ʃi wɑz nɑt steɪɪŋ kəz ʃi kəd nɑt wɔk əweɪ fɹəm paʊɝ. əz fəɹ tɑlænvɝ. . . . ʃi wəd sɛɾ ɪm fɝmli ɪn ɪz pleɪs. ðɪs taɪm ʃi wʊd! bʌt. . . . wʌt wɑz ɪz pleɪs, wɪð ə wʊmən u wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ə kwin? ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪn ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðət mɑkɪŋ vɔɪs ðət wəd nɑt bi kwaɪət, jɛt wən slip faɪnəli keɪm, ʃi kəd stɪl fil ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz lɪps ɑn əɹ aɪlɪdz.

In the back of her head, a small voice laughed. You can't forget that you're Morgase Trakand, it told her scornfully, and even after she's abdicated her throne, Queen Morgase can't stop trying her hand in the affairs of the mighty, no matter how much ruin she's made of it so far. And she can't tell a man to go away, either, because she can't stop thinking how strong his hands are, and how his lips curve when he smiles, and -  Furious, she pulled the blanket over her head, trying to shut out the voice. She was not staying because she could not walk away from power. As for Tallanvor. . . . She would set him firmly in his place. This time she would! But. . . . What was his place, with a woman who was no longer a queen? She tried to put him out of her mind and tried to ignore that mocking voice that would not be quiet, yet when sleep finally came, she could still feel the pressure of his lips on her eyelids.


tʃæptɝ naɪn


CHAPTER 9

tæŋɡəlz


Tangles

pɛɹɪn woʊk bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪɾ əz juʒəwəl, ən əz juʒəwəl, feɪl wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ʌp ən əbaʊt. ʃi kəd meɪk ə maʊs sim nɔɪzi wən ʃi wɑntəd tə, ən i səspɛktəd ðəɾ ɪf i woʊk ən aʊɝ æftɝ laɪɪŋ daʊn, ʃi wəd stɪl mænədʒ tə bi ʌp fɝst. ðə dɔɹ-flæps wɝ taɪd bæk, ðə saɪd pænəlz ɹeɪzd ə lɪɾəl ət ðə bɑɾəm, ən ə stɝ ʌv ɛɹ ɹoʊz θɹu ðə vɛnθhoʊl ɪn ðə pik, ɪnʌf tə kɹieɪɾ ən ɪluʒən ə kulnəs. pɛɹɪn æktʃəli  ʃɪvɝd waɪl sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz ʃɝɾ ən bɹitʃɪz. wɛl, ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə bi wɪntɝ, ivən ɪf ðə wɛðɝ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt.

perrin woke before first light as usual, and as usual, Faile was already up and about. She could make a mouse seem noisy when she wanted to, and he suspected that if he woke an hour after lying down, she would still manage to be up first. The door-flaps were tied back, the side panels raised a little at the bottom, and a stir of air rose through the venthole in the peak, enough to create an illusion of coolness. Perrin actually shivered while searching for his shirt and breeches. Well, it was supposed to be winter, even if the weather did not know it.

hi dʒɹɛst ɪn ðə dɑɹk ən skɹʌbd ɪz tiθ wɪð sɔlt, niɾɪŋ noʊ læmps, ən wən i lɛf ðə tɛnt, stæmpɪŋ ɪz fiɾ ɪndə hɪz buts, feɪl hæɾ əɹ nu sɝvəns ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ɪn ðə dip ɡɹeɪnəs ə ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ, səm hoʊldɪŋ laɪɾəd læntɝnz. ə lɔɹdz dɔɾɝ niɾəd sɝvəns; hi ʃʊɾə ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. ðəɹ wɝ tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ðət feɪl hæd tʃɹeɪn hɝsɛlf, bʌt wɪð ðə nid fəɹ sikɹəsi ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ weɪ tə fɛtʃ əm əlɔŋ. mæstɝ ɡɪl wəd wɑnə ɡoʊ hoʊm əz sun əz pɑsəbəl, ən læmɡwɪn ən bɹin wɪð hɪm, bʌt meɪbi meɪaɪɡdɪn ən lini wəd steɪ.

He dressed in the dark and scrubbed his teeth with salt, needing no lamps, and when he left the tent, stamping his feet into his boots, Faile had her new servants gathered around her in the deep grayness of early morning, some holding lighted lanterns. A lord's daughter needed servants; he should have arranged for it before this. There were Two Rivers folk in Caemlyn that Faile had trained herself, but with the need for secrecy there had been no way to fetch them along. Master Gill would want to go home as soon as possible, and Lamgwin and Breane with him, but maybe Maighdin and Lini would stay.

ɛɹæm stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəd bɪsaɪd ðə tɛnt, ən weɪɾəd saɪlənli ɑn pɛɹɪn. ɪf pɛɹɪn hæd nɑt stɑp hɪm, ɛɹæm wʊɾə slɛpt əkɹɔs ði ɛntʃɹəns. ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ɪz koʊt wɑz stʃɹaɪpt ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt, ðoʊ ðə waɪt wɑz ə tʃɹaɪfəl dɪnʒi, ən ivən hɪɹ ðət wʊlfhɛd-pɑməl sɔɹd hɪlt ɹoʊz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. pɛɹɪn hæd lɛft ɪz æks ɪn ðə tɛnt, ən ɡɹeɪtfəl tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt. tɑlænvɝ stɪl wɔɹ ɪz sɔɹd bɛltəɾ oʊvɝ ɪz koʊt, bʌt nɑt mæstɝ ɡɪl əɹ ði ʌðɝ tu.

Aram straightened from where he had been sitting cross-legged beside the tent, and waited silently on Perrin. If Perrin had not stopped him, Aram would have slept across the entrance. This morning his coat was striped red-and-white, though the white was a trifle dingy, and even here that wolfhead-pommeled sword hilt rose over his shoulder. Perrin had left his axe in the tent, and grateful to be rid of it. Tallanvor still wore his sword belted over his coat, but not Master Gill or the other two.

feɪl mʌst əv bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ, kəz noʊ sunɝ dɪd pɛɹɪn kʌm aʊt ðən ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd ðə tɛnt, klɪɹli ɪʃuɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. meɪaɪɡdɪn ən bɹin keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ pæst ɪm ən ɛɹæm wɪð læntɝnz, ðɛɹ dʒɔz sɛt, smɛlɪŋ ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən fəɹ səm ɹizən. niðɝ kɝtsid, ə plɛzən sɝpɹaɪz. lini dɪd, ə kwɪk bɛn ə ðə ni bɪfɔɹ ʃi dɑɹɾɪd æftɝ ði ʌðɝ tu mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt "noʊɪŋ ðɛɹ pleɪs." pɛɹɪn səspɛktəd lini wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz wɪmən u sɔ hɝ "pleɪs" əz biɪŋ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ. kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, moʊst wɪmən dɪd. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, ɪt simd, nɑt dʒʌs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

Faile must have been watching, because no sooner did Perrin come out than she gestured toward the tent, clearly issuing orders. Maighdin and Breane came bustling past him and Aram with lanterns, their jaws set, smelling of determination for some reason. Neither curtsied, a pleasant surprise. Lini did, a quick bend of the knee before she darted after the other two muttering about "knowing their place." Perrin suspected Lini was one of those women who saw her "place" as being in charge. Come to think of it, most women did. That was the way of the world, it seemed, not just the Two Rivers.

tɑlænvɝ ən læmɡwɪn fɑloʊd kloʊs bɪhaɪn ðə wɪmən, ən læmɡwɪn wɑz əz sɪɹiəs əbaʊt boʊɪŋ əz tɑlænvɝ, hu wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡɹɪm. pɛɹɪn saɪɾ ən baʊd bæk, ən ðeɪ boʊθ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ɡeɪpɪŋ ət hɪm. ə kɝt ʃaʊt fɹəm lini dʒɝkt əm ɪndə ðə tɛnt.

Tallanvor and Lamgwin followed close behind the women, and Lamgwin was as serious about bowing as Tallanvor, who was almost grim. Perrin sighed and bowed back, and they both gave a start, gaping at him. A curt shout from Lini jerked them into the tent.

wɪð oʊnli ə kwɪkli flæʃt smaɪl fəɹ hɪm, feɪl stʃɹoʊɾ ɔf təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹts, tɔkɪŋ ɔltɝnətli tə bɑzəl ɡɪl ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ ən sɛbæn beɪlwɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝ. ðə mɛn itʃ hɛld ə læntɝn aʊt tə laɪɾ əɹ weɪ. ʌv kɔɹs, ə dʌbəl hændfʊl ə ðoʊz ɪɾiəts kɛpt peɪs wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd hɪɹ ɪf ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs, stʃɹʌɾɪŋ ən stʃɹoʊkɪŋ sɔɹd hɪls ən stɛɹɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪmnəs əz ðoʊ ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ətæk əɹ hoʊp fəɹ wʌn. pɛɹɪn tʌɡd əɾ ɪz ʃɔɹt bɪɹd. ʃi ɔlweɪz faʊn plɛnti ʌv wɝk tə fɪl əɹ aʊɝz, ən noʊbɑdi tʊk ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hænz. noʊbɑdi wəd dɛɹ.

With only a quickly flashed smile for him, Faile strode off toward the carts, talking alternately to Basel Gill on one side of her and Sebban Balwer on the other. The men each held a lantern out to light her way. Of course, a double handful of those idiots kept pace where they could hear if she raised her voice, strutting and stroking sword hilts and staring about in the dimness as though they expected an attack or hoped for one. Perrin tugged at his short beard. She always found plenty of work to fill her hours, and nobody took it out of her hands. Nobody would dare.

nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə fɝs fɪŋɡɝz ə dɔn ʃoʊɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən jɛt, bʌt ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə stɝ ɝaʊn ðə kɑɹts, ən muvɪŋ mɔɹ kwɪkli ðə kloʊsɝ feɪl keɪm. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi ɹitʃt ðɛm, ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə bi tʃɹɑɾɪŋ, ðɛɹ læntɝnz bɑbɪŋ ən swɪŋɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪmnəs. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, juz tə fɑɹmɝz' deɪz, wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi meɪkɪŋ bɹɛkfəst, səm læfɪŋ ən ɹʌhaʊzɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kʊk faɪɝz, səm ɡɹʌmpɪŋ, bʌt moʊst ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə wɝk dʌn. ə fju tʃɹaɪd tə steɪ ɪn ðɛɹ blæŋkəts ən wɝ ʌnsɛɹəmoʊniəsli tʌmbəld aʊt. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild wɝ ʌp, tu, əz ɔlweɪz ɔf baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz, ʃædoʊz ɪn blæk koʊts əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt ɹikɔl siɪŋ əm wɪθaʊt ðoʊz koʊts, ɔlweɪz bʌɾənd tə ðə nɛk, ɔlweɪz klin ən ənɹɪŋkəl kʌm sʌnɹaɪz, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd lʊk laɪk ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. stɛpɪŋ θɹu ðə fɔɹmz ɪn junəsən, ðə pɛɹ wɝ pɹæktəsɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ. ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ðɛɹ ivnɪŋ pɹæktəs, wən ðeɪ wəd sɪt kɹɔs-lɛɡəd, hænz ɑn niz, stɛɹɪŋ ət səm dɪstənt nʌθɪŋ. ðeɪ nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðən ðəɾ ɛniwʌn kəd si, jɛt nɑɾ ə mæn ɪn ðə kæmp bʌt nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊɾ ən kɛpt əz fɑɹ ɔf əz pɑsəbəl. nɑɾ ivən ðə meɪɾənz wəd stɛp ɪndə ðɛɹ laɪn ə saɪt ðɛn.

Not so much as the first fingers of dawn showed on the horizon yet, but the Cairhienin were beginning to stir around the carts, and moving more quickly the closer Faile came. By the time she reached them, they appeared to be trotting, their lanterns bobbing and swinging in the dimness. The Two Rivers men, used to farmers' days, were already making breakfast, some laughing and roughhousing around their cook fires, some grumping, but most getting the work done. A few tried to stay in their blankets and were unceremoniously tumbled out. Grady and Neald were up, too, as always off by themselves, shadows in black coats among the trees. Perrin could not recall seeing them without those coats, always buttoned to the neck, always clean and unwrinkled come sunrise, whatever they had looked like the night before. Stepping through the forms in unison, the pair were practicing the sword as they did every morning. That was better than their evening practice, when they would sit cross-legged, hands on knees, staring at some distant nothing. They never did anything then that anyone could see, yet not a man in the camp but knew what they were about and kept as far off as possible. Not even the Maidens would step into their line of sight then.

sʌmθɪŋ wɑz mɪsɪŋ, pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə stɑɹt. feɪl ɔlweɪz hæd wʌn ə ðə mɛn miɾ ɪm fɝs θɪŋ wɪð ə boʊl ə ðə θɪk pɔɹədʒ ðeɪ bɹɛkfæstəɾ ɑn, bʌɾ ɪt simd ʃi hæd bɪn tu bɪzi ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. bɹaɪɾənɪŋ, hi hɝid təwɔɹd ðə kʊk faɪɝz, hoʊpɪŋ ət lis tə bi eɪbəl tə dɪp ʌp ɪz oʊn pɔɹədʒ fəɹ wʌns. ə smɔl hoʊp.

Something was missing, Perrin realized with a start. Faile always had one of the men meet him first thing with a bowl of the thick porridge they breakfasted on, but it seemed she had been too busy this morning. Brightening, he hurried toward the cook fires, hoping at least to be able to dip up his own porridge for once. A small hope.

flæn bɑɹstɪɹ, ə læŋki fɛloʊ wɪð ə dɛn ɪn ɪz tʃɪn, mɛɾ ɪm hæfweɪ ən ʃʌvd ə kɑɹv boʊl ɪndə hɪz hænz. flæn wɑz fɹəm ʌp təwɔɹd wɑtʃ hɪl, ən pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ hɪm wɛl, bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn hʌntɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ə taɪm əɹ tu, ən wʌns pɛɹɪn hæd hɛlpt ɪm dɪɡ wʌn ə hɪz fɑðɝz kaʊz aʊɾ ʌv ə bɑɡhoʊl ɪn ðə wɔɾɝwʊd. "ðə leɪɾi feɪl toʊl mi tə bɹɪŋ ðɪs tə ju, pɛɹɪn," flæn sɛɾ æŋkʃəsli. "ju woʊn tɛl əɹ aɪ fɝɡɑt, wɪl ju? jə woʊn tɛl? aɪ faʊn səm hʌni, ən aɪ pʊɾ ɪn ə ɡʊd dɑləp." pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə saɪ. ət lis flæn hæd ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪz neɪm.

Flann Barstere, a lanky fellow with a dent in his chin, met him halfway and shoved a carved bowl into his hands. Flann was from up toward Watch Hill, and Perrin did not know him well, but they had been hunting together a time or two, and once Perrin had helped him dig one of his father's cows out of a boghole in the Waterwood. "The Lady Faile told me to bring this to you, Perrin," Flann said anxiously. "You won't tell her I forgot, will you? You won't tell? I found some honey, and I put in a good dollop." Perrin tried not to sigh. At least Flann had remembered his name.

wɛl, meɪbi hi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð duɪŋ ðə sɪmpləs tʃɔɹz fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðə mɛn iɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz. wɪθaʊt hɪm, ðeɪ wəd bi wɪð ðɛɹ fæmliz, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðə deɪz tʃɔɹz ɝaʊn ðə fɑɹm, mɪlkɪŋ kaʊz ən kʌɾɪŋ faɪɝwʊɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə kɪl əɹ bi kɪl bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. ɡʌlpɪŋ daʊn ðə hʌnid pɔɹədʒ kwɪkli, hi toʊld ɛɹæm tə teɪk ɪz iz oʊvɝ bɹɛkfəst, bʌt ðə mæn lʊk soʊ mɪzɝəbəl ðəɾ i ɹɪlɛntɪd, soʊ ɛɹæm fɑloʊɾ əz i meɪɾ ɪz weɪ ɝaʊn ðə kæmp. ðə dʒɝni wɑz nɑt wʌn pɛɹɪn ɛndʒɔɪd.

Well, maybe he could not get away with doing the simplest chores for himself, but he was still responsible for the men eating beneath the trees. Without him, they would be with their families, getting ready for the day's chores around the farm, milking cows and cutting firewood instead of wondering whether they might have to kill or be killed before sunset. Gulping down the honeyed porridge quickly, he told Aram to take his ease over breakfast, but the man looked so miserable that he relented, so Aram followed as he made his way around the camp. The journey was not one Perrin enjoyed.

mɛn pʊt daʊn ðɛɹ boʊlz wən i əpɹoʊtʃt, əɹ ivən stʊɾ əntɪl i pæst. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ wɛnɛvɝ sʌmbɑɾi hi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð, əɹ wɝs, ə mæn u hæd sɛn ɪm ɑn ɛɹənz əz ə bɔɪ, kɔld ɪm lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn dɪd, bʌt tu mɛni. fɑɹ tu mɛni. æftɝ ə taɪm, hi ɡeɪv ʌp tɛlɪŋ əm tə stɑp aʊɾ ə ʃɪɹ wɪɹinəs; ɔl tu ɔfən ðə ɹɪplaɪ wɑz "oʊ! wʌtɛvɝ jə seɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn." ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə mæn haʊl!

Men put down their bowls when he approached, or even stood until he passed. He gritted his teeth whenever somebody he had grown up with, or worse, a man who had sent him on errands as a boy, called him Lord Perrin. Not everyone did, but too many. Far too many. After a time, he gave up telling them to stop out of sheer weariness; all too often the reply was "Oh! Whatever you say, Lord Perrin." It was enough to make a man howl!

dɪspaɪt ðæt, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf pɔz tə spik ə wɝɾ əɹ tu tə ɛvɹi mæn. meɪnli, ðoʊ, hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz oʊpən. ən ɪz noʊz. ðeɪ ɔl nu ɪnʌf tə kip ðɛɹ baʊz ɪn ɡʊd ɹɪpɛɹ ən tɛn ðə flɛtʃɪŋ ən pɔɪns ɑn ðɛɹ æɹoʊz, bʌt səm wəd wɛɹ ðə soʊlz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ buts əɹ ðə bɑɾəm aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ bɹitʃɪz wɪθaʊt noʊɾɪsɪŋ, əɹ lɛt blɪstɝz fɛstɝ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi bɑðɝd tə də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əm dʒʌs jɛt. sɛvɹəl hæd ðə hæbəɾ ə pɪkɪŋ ʌp bɹændi wən ðeɪ kʊd, ən tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ðoʊz hæd noʊ hɛd fəɹ ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə smɔl vɪlədʒ ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ bɛθɔl ðət hɛl noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi ɪnz.

Despite that, he made himself pause to speak a word or two to every man. Mainly, though, he kept his eyes open. And his nose. They all knew enough to keep their bows in good repair and tend the fletching and points on their arrows, but some would wear the soles out of their boots or the bottom out of their breeches without noticing, or let blisters fester because they could not be bothered to do anything about them just yet. Several had the habit of picking up brandy when they could, and two or three of those had no head for it at all. There had been a small village the day before reaching Bethal that held no fewer than three inns.

ɪt wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ. hævɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs luhən əɹ ɪz mʌðɝ tɛl ɪm i niɾəd nu buts əɹ ɪz bɹitʃɪz mɛndɪd hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ i wʊɾə bɪn ɪɹəteɪɾəd ət ðə seɪm fɹəm ɛnibəɾi ɛls, bʌt fɹəm ɡɹɪzəld oʊl dʒɑndɪn bæɹən ɑn daʊn, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn dʒʌst sɛd "waɪ, ɹaɪt jə ɑɹ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn; əl si tə ɪt stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ" əɹ səm sʌtʃ. hi kɑɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ wən i muvd ɑn. ən ðeɪ smɛl plizd! wən i ɹuɾəd ə kleɪ dʒɑɹ ə pɛɹ bɹændi aʊɾ ə dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝz sæɾəlbæɡz - ə skɪni fɛloʊ hu eɪt twaɪs əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniwʌn ɛls ən ɔlweɪz lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd nɑt hæɾ ə baɪɾ ɪn ə wik, dʒɔɹi wɑz ə ɡʊd ʃɑt wɪð ə baʊ, bʌt ɡɪvən ə tʃæns i wəd dʒɹɪŋk əntɪl i kəd nɑt stænd, ən i hæd laɪt fɪŋɡɝz bɪsaɪdz - dʒɔɹi ɡeɪv ɪm ə waɪd-aɪd lʊk ən spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ðə dʒɑɹ hæd kʌm fɹʌm. bʌɾ əz pɛɹɪn wɔkt ɑn, ɛmptiɪŋ ðə bɹændi ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd, dʒɔɹi læft, "ju kæn pʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ oʊvɝ ɑn lɔɹd pɛɹɪn!" hi saʊndəd pɹaʊd! səmtaɪmz, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i wɑz ði oʊnli seɪn pɝsən lɛft.

It was very strange. Having Mistress Luhhan or his mother tell him he needed new boots or his breeches mended had always been embarrassing, and he was sure he would have been irritated at the same from anybody else, but from grizzled old Jondyn Barran on down, the Two Rivers men just said "Why, right you are, Lord Perrin; I'll see to it straightaway" or some such. He caught a number of them grinning at one another when he moved on. And they smelled pleased! When he rooted a clay jar of pear brandy out of Jori Congar's saddlebags - a skinny fellow who ate twice as much as anyone else and always looked as if he had not had a bite in a week, Jori was a good shot with a bow, but given a chance he would drink until he could not stand, and he had light fingers besides - Jori gave him a wide-eyed look and spread his hands as if he did not know where the jar had come from. But as Perrin walked on, emptying the brandy onto the ground, Jori laughed, "You can't put anything over on Lord Perrin!" He sounded proud! Sometimes, Perrin thought he was the only sane person left.

ənʌðɝ θɪŋ, hi noʊɾəst. wʌn ən ɔl, ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌɾ i dɪd nɑt seɪ. mæn æftɝ mæn kæst ən aɪ təwɔɹd ðə tu bænɝz ðəɾ əkeɪʒənəli flæpt ətɑp ðɛɹ poʊlz ɪn ə bɹif ɡʌst, ɹɛd wʊlfhɛɾ ən ɹɛɾ iɡəl. ðeɪ aɪd ðə bænɝz ən wɑtʃt hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ɔɹɾɝ i hæd ɡɪvən ɛvɹi taɪm ðə θɪŋz hæd kʌm aʊt sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ ɡildən. ən ɔfən ɪnʌf bɪfɔɹ ðæt. ɪksɛp ðəɾ i hæd sɛd nʌθɪŋ jɛstɝdeɪ, ən i sɛd nʌθɪŋ tədeɪ, ən i sɔ spɛkjəleɪʃən blumɪŋ ɑn mɛnz feɪsəz. hi lɛf bɪhaɪn klʌstɝz ə mɛn piɹɪŋ ət ðə bænɝz ən ət hɪm, mɝmɝɪŋ ɪksaɪɾədli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə lɪsən. wʌt wəd ðeɪ seɪ ɪf i wɑz ɹɔŋ, ɪf ðə waɪtkloʊks əɹ kɪŋ eɪlɹən dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ kəd lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəɾ ən ðə sintʃæn lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə snʌf aʊɾ ə səpoʊzd ɹɪbɛljən? ðeɪ wɝ ɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, ən i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑɾən tu mɛni ʌv əm kɪld.

Another thing, he noticed. One and all, they were very interested in what he did not say. Man after man cast an eye toward the two banners that occasionally flapped atop their poles in a brief gust, Red Wolfhead and Red Eagle. They eyed the banners and watched him, waiting for the order he had given every time the things had come out since reaching Ghealdan. And often enough before that. Except that he had said nothing yesterday, and he said nothing today, and he saw speculation blooming on men's faces. He left behind clusters of men peering at the banners and at him, murmuring excitedly among themselves. He did not try to listen. What would they say if he was wrong, if the Whitecloaks or King Ailron decided they could look away from the Prophet and the Seanchan long enough to snuff out a supposed rebellion? They were his responsibility, and he had already gotten too many of them killed.

ðə sʌn wɑz mɔɹ ðən pikɪŋ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, spɹɛɾɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, baɪ ðə taɪm i fɪnɪʃt, ən oʊvɝ ət ðə tɛnt, tɑlænvɝ ən læmɡwɪn wɝ lʌɡɪŋ aʊt tʃɛsts ʌndɝ liniz dɝɛkʃən, waɪl meɪaɪɡdɪn ən bɹin əpɪɹd tə bi sɔɹɾɪŋ ðə kɑntɛns aʊɾ ɑn ə bɹɔd pætʃ ə dɛd ɡɹæs, blæŋkəts ən lɪnənz meɪnli, ən lɔŋ bɹaɪt swɑθs ə sɪlk sæɾən ðət hæd bɪn ɪntɛndəd tə dʒɹeɪp ðə bɛɾ i hæd mɪspleɪst. feɪl mʌst əv bɪn ɪnsaɪd, kəz ðət ɡæɡəl ʌv ɪɾiəts wɝ kulɪŋ ðɛɹ hilz nɑt fɑɹ ɔf. noʊ kæɹiɪŋ ən hɔlɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm. jusfəl əz ɹæts ɪn ðə bɑɹn.

The sun was more than peeking above the horizon, spreading a sharp morning light, by the time he finished, and over at the tent, Tallanvor and Lamgwin were lugging out chests under Lini's direction, while Maighdin and Breane appeared to be sorting the contents out on a broad patch of dead grass, blankets and linens mainly, and long bright swaths of silk satin that had been intended to drape the bed he had misplaced. Faile must have been inside, because that gaggle of idiots were cooling their heels not far off. No carrying and hauling for them. Useful as rats in the barn.

pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ ə lʊk ət steɪɝ ən stɛpɝ, bʌt wən i ɡlæns θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ət ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, hi wɑz sin. noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi ʌv ðə fɛɹiɝz stɛpt aʊɾ æŋkʃəsli, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðeɪ wɝ blɑki mɛn ɪn lɛðɝ eɪpɹənz, əlaɪk əz ɛɡz ɪn ə bæskət, ðoʊ fɑltən hæɾ oʊnli ə fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, æɛmɪn wɑz ɡɹeɪɪŋ, ən dʒɛɝæsɪd hæd nɑt jɛt kʌm ɪndə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz. pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm. ðeɪ wəd hʌvɝ ɪf i leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn iðɝ hɔɹs, ən ɡɑɡəl ɪf i lɪftəɾ ə huf. ðə wʌn taɪm i hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tʃeɪnʒ ə wɔɹn ʃu, ɑn steɪɝ, ɔl sɪks fɛɹiɝz hæd dɑɹɾɪd əbaʊt ɡɹæbɪŋ ʌp tulz bɪfɔɹ i kəd tʌtʃ ðɛm, nɪɹli nɑkɪŋ ðə beɪ oʊvɝ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹʌʃ tə də ðə wɝk ðɛmsɛlvz.

Perrin thought about taking a look at Stayer and Stepper, but when he glanced through the trees at the horselines, he was seen. No fewer than three of the farriers stepped out anxiously, watching him. They were blocky men in leather aprons, alike as eggs in a basket, though Falton had only a fringe of white around his head, Aemin was graying, and Jerasid had not yet come into his middle years. Perrin growled at the sight of them. They would hover if he laid a hand on either horse, and goggle if he lifted a hoof. The one time he had tried to change a worn shoe, on Stayer, all six farriers had darted about grabbing up tools before he could touch them, nearly knocking the bay over in their rush to do the work themselves.

"ðeɪɹ əfɹeɪd jə doʊn tʃɹʌs ðɛm," ɛɹæm sɛd sʌɾənli. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən ɛɹæm ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ɪn ɪz koʊt. "aɪv tɔk tə ðɛm, sʌm. ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪf ə lɔɹd tɛnz ɪz oʊn hɔɹsəz, ɪt mʌs bi kəz i dʌzn tʃɹʌs ðɛm. jə maɪt sɛn əm ɔf, wɪð noʊ weɪ tə ɡɛt hoʊm." hɪz toʊn sɛd ðeɪ wɝ fulz tə θɪŋk ðæt, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə saɪdweɪz ɡlæns ən ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn, ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪmbɛɹəst, tu. ɪf jə doʊn bɪheɪv ðə weɪ ðeɪ θɪŋk ə lɔɹd ʃʊd, ɪt ɹɪflɛks ɑn ðɛm, əz ðeɪ si ɪt."

"They're afraid you don't trust them," Aram said suddenly. Perrin looked at him in surprise, and Aram shifted his shoulders in his coat. "I've talked to them, some. They think if a lord tends his own horses, it must be because he doesn't trust them. You might send them off, with no way to get home." His tone said they were fools to think that, but he gave Perrin a sideways glance and shrugged again, uncomfortably. "I think they're embarrassed, too. If you don't behave the way they think a lord should, it reflects on them, as they see it."

"laɪt!" pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. feɪl hæd sɛd ðə seɪm - əbaʊɾ əm biɪŋ ɪmbɛɹəst, ɛniweɪ - bʌɾ i hæd bɪlivd ɪt dʒʌst ə lɔɹdz dɔɾɝ tɔkɪŋ. feɪl hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp sɝaʊndəd baɪ sɝvəns, jɛt haʊ kəɾ ə leɪɾi noʊ ðə θɔts ʌv ə mæn u hæd tə wɝk fəɹ ɪz bɹɛd? hi fɹaʊn təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹslaɪnz. faɪv ə ðə fɛɹiɝz stʊd təɡɛðɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, naʊ. ɪmbɛɹəs ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə lʊk æftɝ ɪz oʊn hɔɹsəz, ən əpsɛt ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑn əm pʊlɪŋ wʊl ən skɹætʃɪŋ ɡɹævəl ɔl oʊvɝ ðə pleɪs. "du jə θɪŋk aɪ ɔt tə æk laɪk ə ful ɪn sɪlk smɔlkloʊðz?" hi æskt. ɛɹæm blɪŋkt, ən bɪɡæn stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz buts. "laɪt!" pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld.

"Light!" Perrin muttered. Faile had said the same - about them being embarrassed, anyway - but he had believed it just a lord's daughter talking. Faile had grown up surrounded by servants, yet how could a lady know the thoughts of a man who had to work for his bread? He frowned toward the horselines. Five of the farriers stood together watching him, now. Embarrassed that he wanted to look after his own horses, and upset that he did not want them pulling wool and scratching gravel all over the place. "Do you think I ought to act like a fool in silk smallclothes?" he asked. Aram blinked, and began studying his boots. "Light!" Perrin growled.

spɑɾɪŋ bɑzəl ɡɪl hɝiɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə kɑɹts, pɛɹɪn muv tə mit hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i hæd dʌn vɛɹi wɛl ət meɪkɪŋ ɡɪl fil əɾ iz jɛstɝdeɪ. ðə staʊt mæn wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ən wʌns mɔɹ mɑpɪŋ ɪz hɛd wɪð ə kɝtʃəf, swɛɾɪŋ əweɪ ɪn ə ɹʌmpəl dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ koʊt. ðə deɪz hit wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə teɪk hoʊld ɔlɹɛɾi. hi dɪd nɑt si pɛɹɪn əntɪl pɛɹɪn wɑz nɪɹli ɑn hɪm, ən ðən i ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp, stʌfɪŋ ðə kɝtʃəf ɪndə ə koʊt pɑkəɾ ən meɪkɪŋ ə baʊ. hi lʊkt kɝiɾ ən bɹʌʃt fɪt fəɹ ə fistdeɪ.

Spotting Basel Gill hurrying from the direction of the carts, Perrin moved to meet him. He did not think he had done very well at making Gill feel at ease yesterday. The stout man was talking to himself and once more mopping his head with a kerchief, sweating away in a rumpled dark gray coat. The day's heat was beginning to take hold already. He did not see Perrin until Perrin was nearly on him, and then he gave a jump, stuffing the kerchief into a coat pocket and making a bow. He looked curried and brushed fit for a feastday.

"ɑ. maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. jəɹ leɪɾi toʊl mi tə teɪk ə kɑɹɾ ɪndə bɛθɔl. ʃi sɛz aɪm tə faɪn jə səm tu ɹɪvɝz təbæk, ɪf aɪ kæn, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðæts pɑsəbəl. tu ɹɪvɝz lif əz ɔlweɪz bɪn dɪɹ, ən tʃɹeɪɾ ɪzənt wʌɾ ɪt wɑz."

"Ah. My Lord Perrin. Your Lady told me to take a cart into Bethal. She says I'm to find you some Two Rivers tabac, if I can, but I don't know that's possible. Two Rivers leaf has always been dear, and trade isn't what it was."

"ʃiz sɛndɪŋ jə fəɹ təbæk?" pɛɹɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. hi səpoʊz sikɹəsi hæd ɡɔn daʊn ðə wɛl, bʌt stɪl. "aɪ bɑt θɹi kæsks, tu vɪlədʒəz bæk. ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi."

"She's sending you for tabac?" Perrin said, frowning. He supposed secrecy had gone down the well, but still. "I bought three casks, two villages back. Enough for everybody."

ɡɪl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd fɝmli. "nɑt tu ɹɪvɝz lif, ən jəɹ leɪɾi sɛz jə laɪk ðəɾ əbʌv ɛni ʌðɝ. ðə ɡildænɪn lif wɪl də fəɹ jəɹ mɛn. aɪm tə bi jəɹ ʃæmbaɪən, ʃi kɔld ɪt, ən kip jə ən əɹ səplaɪd wɪð wʌt jə nid. nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ dɪd ɹʌnɪŋ ðə blɛsɪŋ, ɹɪli." ðə sɪməlɛɹəɾi sim tə əmjuz hɪm; hɪz bɛli ʃʊk wɪð kwaɪət tʃʌkəlz. "aɪ hæv kwaɪɾ ə lɪst, ðoʊ aɪ kæn seɪ haʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɪɾ əl faɪnd. ɡʊd waɪn, ɝbz, fɹut, kændəlz ən læmp ɔɪl, oʊlklɔθ ən wæks, peɪpɝ ən ɪŋk, niɾəlz, pɪnz, oʊ, ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz. tɑlænvɝ ən læmɡwɪn ən aɪ ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, wɪð səm ə jəɹ leɪɾiz ʌðɝ ɹɪteɪnɝz."

Gill shook his head firmly. "Not Two Rivers leaf, and your Lady says you like that above any other. The Ghealdanin leaf will do for your men. I'm to be your shambayan, she called it, and keep you and her supplied with what you need. Not much different from what I did running the Blessing, really." The similarity seemed to amuse him; his belly shook with quiet chuckles. "I have quite a list, though I can't say how much of it I'll find. Good wine, herbs, fruit, candles and lamp oil, oilcloth and wax, paper and ink, needles, pins, oh, all sorts of things. Tallanvor and Lamgwin and I are going, with some of your Lady's other retainers."

hɪz leɪɾiz ʌðɝ ɹɪteɪnɝz. tɑlænvɝ ən læmɡwɪn wɝ bɹɪŋɪŋ aʊt jɛɾ ənʌðɝ tʃɛs fəɹ ðə wɪmən tə sɔɹt θɹu. ðeɪ hæd tə pæs baɪ ðə skwɑɾɪŋ klʌmp ə jʌŋ fulz, hu nɛvɝ ɔfɝd tə lɛn ə hænd. ɪn fækt, ðə laɪəbaʊts ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm kəmplitli.

His Lady's other retainers. Tallanvor and Lamgwin were bringing out yet another chest for the women to sort through. They had to pass by the squatting clump of young fools, who never offered to lend a hand. In fact, the layabouts ignored them completely.

"ju kip ən aɪ ɑn ðət lɑt," pɛɹɪn kɑʃənd. "ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm stɑɹts ɛni tʃɹʌbəl - ɪf i ivən lʊks əz ɪf hɪl - juv læmɡwɪn kɹæk ɪz hɛd." ən ɪf ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðə wɪmən? ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst əz laɪkli, meɪbi mɔɹ soʊ. pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd. feɪlz "ɹɪteɪnɝz" wɝ gɑnə taɪ hɪz bɛli ɪndə pɝmənənt nɑts jɛt. tu bæd ʃi kəd nɑt bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðə laɪks ə mæstɝ ɡɪl ən meɪaɪɡdɪn. "ju dɪdn mɛnʃən beɪlwɝ. hæz i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡoʊ ɑn əloʊn?" dʒʌs ðɛn, ə ʃɪft ɪn ðə bɹiz bɹɔɾ ɪm beɪlwɝz sɛnt, ən əlɝt smɛl vɛɹi mʌtʃ əɾ ɑdz wɪð ðə fɛloʊz ɔlmoʊs dɪsɪkeɪɾɪd ɪkstɪɹiɝ.

"You keep an eye on that lot," Perrin cautioned. "If one of them starts any trouble - if he even looks as if he will - you have Lamgwin crack his head." And if it was one of the women? They were just as likely, maybe more so. Perrin grunted. Faile's "retainers" were going to tie his belly into permanent knots yet. Too bad she could not be satisfied with the likes of Master Gill and Maighdin. "You didn't mention Balwer. Has he decided to go on alone?" Just then, a shift in the breeze brought him Balwer's scent, an alert smell very much at odds with the fellow's almost desiccated exterior.

ivən fəɹ soʊ ɹiɾi ə mæn, beɪlwɝ meɪd sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli lɪɾəl nɔɪz ɑn ðə dʒɹaɪd livz ʌndɝfʊt. ɪn ə spɛɹoʊ-bɹaʊn koʊt, hi ɔfɝɾ ə kwɪk baʊ, ən ɪz tɪltəd hɛɾ æɾəd tə ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ə bɝd. "aɪ æm steɪɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd kɔʃəsli. əɹ meɪbi ðət wɑz dʒʌst ɪz mænɝ. "æz jəɹ ɡɹeɪʃəs leɪɾiz sɛkɹətɛɹi. ən jʊɹz, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju." hi stɛp kloʊsɝ, vɛɹi nɪɹli ə hɑp. "aɪ æm wɛl vɝst, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ pəzɛs ə ɡʊd mɛmɹi ən ɹaɪɾ ə ɡʊd hænd, ən maɪ lɔɹd kən bi əʃʊɹd ðət wʌtɛvɝ i kənfaɪdz ɪn mi wɪl nɛvɝ pæs maɪ lɪps tə ənʌðɝ. ði əbɪləɾi tə kip sikɹəts ɪz ə pɹaɪmɛɹi skɪl ʌv ə sɛkɹətɛɹi. doʊn juv pɹɛsɪŋ duɾiz fəɹ əɹ nu mɪstʃɹəs, mæstɝ ɡɪl?"

Even for so reedy a man, Balwer made surprisingly little noise on the dried leaves underfoot. In a sparrow-brown coat, he offered a quick bow, and his tilted head added to the image of a bird. "I am staying, my Lord," he said cautiously. Or maybe that was just his manner. "As your gracious Lady's secretary. And yours, if it pleases you." He stepped closer, very nearly a hop. "I am well versed, my Lord. I possess a good memory and write a good hand, and my Lord can be assured that whatever he confides in me will never pass my lips to another. The ability to keep secrets is a primary skill of a secretary. Don't you have pressing duties for our new mistress, Master Gill?"

ɡɪl fɹaʊn ət beɪlwɝ, oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪt wɪð ə snæp. spɪnɪŋ ɑn ɪz hil, hi tʃɹɑɾəd əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə tɛnt.

Gill frowned at Balwer, opened his mouth, then closed it with a snap. Spinning on his heel, he trotted away toward the tent.

fəɹ ə moʊmən beɪlwɝ wɑtʃt ɪm ɡoʊ, hɛd tə wʌn saɪd, lɪps pɝs θɔtfəli. "aɪ kən ɔfɝ ʌðɝ sɝvəsəz, əz wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "nɑlədʒ. aɪ oʊvɝhɝd səm ə maɪ lɔɹdz mɛn spikɪŋ, ən aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðət maɪ lɔɹd meɪ hæv hæd səm . . . dɪfəkəltiz . . . wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ə sɛkɹətɛɹi lɝnz mɛni θɪŋz. aɪ noʊ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ əmaʊn əbaʊt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən."

For a moment Balwer watched him go, head to one side, lips pursed thoughtfully. "I can offer other services, as well, my Lord," he said finally. "Knowledge. I overheard some of my Lord's men speaking, and I understand that my Lord may have had some . . . difficulties . . . with the Children of the Light. A secretary learns many things. I know a surprising amount about the Children."

"wɪð ɛni lʌk aɪ kən əvɔɪd waɪtkloʊks," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "bɛɾɝ ɪf jə nu wɛɹ ðə pɹɑfəɾ ɪz. əɹ ðə sintʃæn." hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛni ʌv ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt beɪlwɝ sɝpɹaɪz hɪm.

"With any luck I can avoid Whitecloaks," Perrin told him. "Better if you knew where the Prophet is. Or the Seanchan." He did not expect any of that, of course, but Balwer surprised him.

"aɪ kænɑt bi sɝɾən, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðə sintʃæn əv nɑt spɹɛd fɑɹ bɪɑn æmədɔɹ əz jɛt. fækt ɪz dɪfəkəl tə sɪft fɹəm ɹumɝ, maɪ lɔɹd, bʌɾ aɪ kip maɪ ɪɹz oʊpən. ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ də sim tə muv wɪð ʌnɪkspɛktɪd sʌɾənnəs. ə deɪnʒɝəs pipəl, wɪð lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə tæɹɑbənɝ soʊlʒɝz. aɪ bɪliv fɹəm mæstɝ ɡɪl ðət maɪ lɔɹd noʊz ə ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ əbzɝvd əm kloʊsli ɪn æmədɔɹ, ən wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ɪz ət maɪ lɔɹdz dɪspoʊzəl. əz tə ðə pɹɑfət, ðəɹ ɑɹ əz mɛni ɹumɝz kənsɝnɪŋ ɪm əz ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv aɪ kən seɪ ɹɪlaɪəbli ðəɾ i wɑz ɹisənli əɾ ɑbilə, ə lɑɹdʒɪʃ taʊn səm fɔɹɾi liɡz saʊθ ə hɪɹ." beɪlwɝ smaɪl θɪnli, ə bɹif sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl.

"I cannot be certain, of course, but I think the Seanchan have not spread far beyond Amador as yet. Fact is difficult to sift from rumor, my Lord, but I keep my ears open. Of course, they do seem to move with unexpected suddenness. A dangerous people, with large numbers of Taraboner soldiers. I believe from Master Gill that my Lord knows of them, but I observed them closely in Amador, and what I saw is at my Lord's disposal. As to the Prophet, there are as many rumors concerning him as the Seanchan, but I believe I can say reliably that he was recently at Abila, a largish town some forty leagues south of here." Balwer smiled thinly, a brief self-satisfied smile.

"haʊ kən jə bi soʊ ʃʊɹ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd sloʊli.

"How can you be so sure?" Perrin said slowly.

"æz aɪ sɛd, maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ kip maɪ ɪɹz oʊpən. ðə pɹɑfət ɹɪpɔɹɾədli kloʊzd ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɪnz ən tævɝnz, ən tɔɹ daʊn ðoʊz i kənsɪɾɝd tu dɪsɹɛpjəɾəbəl. sɛvɹəl wɝ mɛnʃənd, ən baɪ tʃæns, aɪ hæpən tə noʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnz ə ðoʊz neɪmz ɪn ɑbilə. aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl tʃæns ənʌðɝ taʊn wəɾ əv ɪnz wɪð ðə seɪm neɪmz." hi flæʃt ənʌðɝ nɛɹoʊ smaɪl. hi sɝɾənli, smɛl plizd wɪð hɪmsɛlf.

"As I said, my Lord, I keep my ears open. The Prophet reportedly closed a number of inns and taverns, and tore down those he considered too disreputable. Several were mentioned, and by chance, I happen to know there are inns of those names in Abila. I think there is little chance another town would have inns with the same names." He flashed another narrow smile. He certainly, smelled pleased with himself.
