pɛɹɪn skɹætʃt ɪz bɪɹd θɔtfəli. ðə mæn dʒʌs hæpən tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɛɹ səm ɪnz ðət mæsimə səpoʊzədli hæd tɔɹn daʊn wɝ loʊkeɪɾəd. ən ɪf mæsimə tɝn aʊt nɑt tə bi ðəɹ æftɝ ɔl, wɛl, ðiz deɪz ɹumɝz spɹaʊɾəd laɪk mʌʃɹumz æftɝ ɹeɪn. beɪlwɝ saʊndəɾ ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪld ʌp ɪz oʊn ɪmpɔɹɾəns. "θæŋk ju, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ. əl kip ðət tə maɪnd. ɪf jə hɪɹ ɛni mɔɹ, bi ʃʊɹ tə tɛl mi." əz i tɝn tə ɡoʊ, ðə mæn kɑɾ ɪz sliv.

Perrin scratched his beard thoughtfully. The man just happened to remember where some inns that Masema supposedly had torn down were located. And if Masema turned out not to be there after all, well, these days rumors sprouted like mushrooms after rain. Balwer sounded a man trying to build up his own importance. "Thank you, Master Balwer. I'll keep that to mind. If you hear any more, be sure to tell me." As he turned to go, the man caught his sleeve.

beɪlwɝz skɪni fɪŋɡɝz lɛpt əweɪ ɪmiɾiətli, əz ðoʊ bɝnd, ən i meɪd wʌn ə ðoʊz bɝdlaɪk baʊz, dʒɹaɪ-wɑʃɪŋ ɪz hænz. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ hɛzəteɪt tə pɹɛs, bʌt də nɑt teɪk ðə waɪtkloʊks tu laɪtli. əvɔɪɾɪŋ əm ɪz waɪz, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ nɑt bi pɑsəbəl. ðeɪ ɑɹ mʌtʃ kloʊsɝ ðən ðə sintʃæn. imən vɑldə, ðə nu lɔɹd kæptən kəmændɝ, lɛd moʊst ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz təwɔɹd nɔɹðɝn ɑmɑdɪʃiə bɪfɔɹ æmədɔɹ fɛl. hi wɑz hʌntɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət, ɔlsoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. vɑldə ɪz ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn, ən ɹɑɾəm əsunɑwə, ðə ɡɹæn ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, meɪks vɑldə sim plɛzənt. ən aɪ fɪɹ niðɝ əz ɛni lʌv fəɹ jəɹ oʊn lɔɹd. fɝɡɪv mi." hi baʊɾ əɡɛn, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən wɛn ɑn smuðli. "ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ, maɪ lɔɹdz dɪspleɪ ʌv meɪnɛðɝənz bænɝ ɪz ɪnspaɪɝd. maɪ lɔɹd wɪl bi mɔɹ ðən ə mætʃ fəɹ vɑldə ən əsunɑwə, ɪf i teɪks kɛɹ."

Balwer's skinny fingers leaped away immediately, as though burned, and he made one of those birdlike bows, dry-washing his hands. "Forgive me, my Lord. I hesitate to press, but do not take the Whitecloaks too lightly. Avoiding them is wise, but it may not be possible. They are much closer than the Seanchan. Eamon Valda, the new Lord Captain Commander, led most of their numbers toward northern Amadicia before Amador fell. He was hunting the Prophet, also, my Lord. Valda is a dangerous man, and Rhadam Asunawa, the Grand Inquisitor, makes Valda seem pleasant. And I fear neither has any love for your own Lord. Forgive me." He bowed again, hesitated, then went on smoothly. "If I may say so, my Lord's display of Manetheren's banner is inspired. My Lord will be more than a match for Valda and Asunawa, if he takes care."

wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm baʊ hɪmsɛlf əweɪ, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i nu pɑɹɾ ə beɪlwɝz stɔɹi naʊ. klɪɹli, hi ɔlsoʊ hæd ɹʌn əfaʊl ə ðə waɪtkloʊks. ðət kəd teɪk noʊ mɔɹ ðən biɪŋ ɑn ðə seɪm stʃɹit wɪð ðɛm, ə fɹaʊn ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm, bʌɾ ɪt sim beɪlwɝ hæɾ ə ɡɹʌdʒ. ə ʃɑɹp maɪnd, tu, siɪŋ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl. ən ə ʃɑɹp tʌŋ wɪð mæstɝ ɡɪl.

Watching him bow himself away, Perrin thought he knew part of Balwer's story now. Clearly, he also had run afoul of the Whitecloaks. That could take no more than being on the same street with them, a frown at the wrong time, but it seemed Balwer had a grudge. A sharp mind, too, seeing right away about the Red Eagle. And a sharp tongue with Master Gill.

ɡɪl wɑz ɑn ɪz niz bɪsaɪd meɪaɪɡdɪn, tɔkɪŋ ɹæpədli dɪspaɪt liniz ɛfɝt tə hʌʃ hɪm. meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd tɝn tə stɛɹ æftɝ beɪlwɝ əz ðə fɛloʊ hɝid θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹts, bʌt naʊ ən ðən əɹ ɡeɪz swʌŋ tə pɛɹɪn. ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm klʌstɝd kloʊs tə hɝ, piɹɪŋ naʊ ət beɪlwɝ, naʊ ət pɛɹɪn. ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ə ɡɹup ə pipəl wɝiɾ əbaʊt wʌt sʌmbɑɾi ɛls hæd sɛd, ɪt wɑz ðeɪ. bʌt wʌt wɝ ðeɪ wɝiɾ i maɪɾ əv hɝd? bækbaɪɾɪŋ, pɹɑbli. teɪlz ə ɹɪzɛnmənts ən mɪsdidz, ɹil əɹ ɪmædʒənd. pipəl kupt ʌp təɡɛðɝ tɛndəd tə stɑɹt pɛkɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪf ðət wɑz ɪt, meɪbi hi kəd pʊɾ ə stɑp bɪfɔɹ sʌmbɑɾi dʒɹu blʌd. tɑlænvɝ wɑz fɑndəlɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt əɡɛn! wʌd feɪl ɪntɛn tə də wɪð ðə fɛloʊ?

Gill was on his knees beside Maighdin, talking rapidly despite Lini's effort to hush him. Maighdin had turned to stare after Balwer as the fellow hurried through the trees toward the carts, but now and then her gaze swung to Perrin. The rest of them clustered close to her, peering now at Balwer, now at Perrin. If he had ever seen a group of people worried about what somebody else had said, it was they. But what were they worried he might have heard? Backbiting, probably. Tales of resentments and misdeeds, real or imagined. People cooped up together tended to start pecking at one another. If that was it, maybe he could put a stop before somebody drew blood. Tallanvor was fondling his sword hilt again! What did Faile intend to do with the fellow?

"ɛɹæm, aɪ wɑn jə tə ɡoʊ tɔk tə tɑlænvɝ ən ðət lɑt. tɛl əm wʌt beɪlwɝ sɛd tə mi. dʒʌst slaɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ðə tɔk, bʌt tɛl ɛvɹiθɪŋ." ðət ʃəd suð fɪɹz ə teɪl-bɛɹɪŋ. feɪl sɛd sɝvəns niɾəd tə bi meɪd tə fil ət hoʊm. "meɪk fɹɛnz wɪð əm ɪf jə kæn, ɛɹæm. bʌɾ ɪf jə dɪsaɪd tə mun oʊvɝ wʌn ə ðə wɪmən, bi ʃʊɹ ɪts lini. ði ʌðɝ tu ɑɹ teɪkən."

"Aram, I want you to go talk to Tallanvor and that lot. Tell them what Balwer said to me. Just slide it into the talk, but tell everything." That should soothe fears of tale-bearing. Faile said servants needed to be made to feel at home. "Make friends with them if you can, Aram. But if you decide to moon over one of the women, be sure it's Lini. The other two are taken."

ðə mæn hæɾ ə smuð tʌŋ fəɹ ɛni pɹɪɾi wʊmən, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd ən əfɛndəd, boʊθ. "æz jə wɪʃ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," hi mʌɾɝd sʌlkəli. "aɪl kætʃ jə ʌp kwɪkli."

The man had a smooth tongue for any pretty woman, but he managed to look surprised and offended, both. "As you wish, Lord Perrin," he muttered sulkily. "I'll catch you up quickly."

"aɪ wɪl bi oʊvɝ wɪð ði il."

"I will be over with the Aiel."

ɛɹæm blɪŋkt. "ɑ. jɛs. wɛl, ɪt maɪt teɪk ə waɪl, ət ðæt, ɪf aɪm tə meɪk fɹɛnz wɪð ðɛm. ðeɪ doʊn lʊk laɪk ðeɪ mʌtʃ wɑn fɹɛnz, tə mi." ðɪs fɹəm ə fɛloʊ hu stɛɹd səspɪʃəsli əɾ ɛniwʌn ɪksɛp feɪl u keɪm nɪɹ pɛɹɪn ən nɛvɝ smaɪl fəɹ ɛniwʌn nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ə skɝt.

Aram blinked. "Ah. Yes. Well, it might take a while, at that, if I'm to make friends with them. They don't look like they much want friends, to me." This from a fellow who stared suspiciously at anyone except Faile who came near Perrin and never smiled for anyone not wearing a skirt.

nɛvɝðəlɛs, hi wɛn oʊvɝ ən skwɑɾɪd ɑn ɪz hilz wɛɹ i kəd spik tə ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz. ivən fɹəm ə dɪstəns ðɛɹ stændɔfɪʃnəs wɑz pleɪn. ðeɪ kəntɪnjud wɪð ðɛɹ wɝk, oʊnli naʊ ən ðən seɪɪŋ ə wɝd tə ɛɹæm, ən ðeɪ lʊkt əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ əz ɔfən əz ət hɪm. skɪɾɪʃ əz ɡɹin kweɪl ɪn sʌmɝ, wən ðə fɑksəz wɝ titʃɪŋ ðə kʌbz tə hʌnt. bʌɾ ət lis ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ.

Nevertheless, he went over and squatted on his heels where he could speak to Gill and the others. Even from a distance their standoffishness was plain. They continued with their work, only now and then saying a word to Aram, and they looked at each other as often as at him. Skittish as green quail in summer, when the foxes were teaching the cubs to hunt. But at least they were talking.

pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wʌt mɪstʃəf ɛɹæm hæd ɡɑɾən ʌp tə wɪð ði il - ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə hæv bɪn ɛni taɪm fəɹ ɪt! - bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wʌndɝ lɔŋ. ɛni sɪɹiəs tʃɹʌbəl wɪð il juʒəwəli mɛn sʌmwʌn dɛd, ən nɑt ði il. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz nɑt soʊ iɡɝ tə mit ðə waɪz wʌnz hɪmsɛlf. hi wɔkt ɝaʊn ðə kɝv ə ðə hɪl, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə klaɪmɪŋ ðə sloʊp, hɪz fit kæɹiɾ ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə minɝz. hi hæd steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ kæmp əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, tu, ən nɑt sɪmpli kəz ə bɹəleɪn. ðəɹ wɝ dɪsədvæntɪdʒɪz tə hævɪŋ tu kin ə noʊz.

Perrin wondered what mischief Aram had gotten up to with the Aiel - there did not seem to have been any time for it! - but he did not wonder long. Any serious trouble with Aiel usually meant someone dead, and not the Aiel. In truth, he was not so eager to meet the Wise Ones himself. He walked around the curve of the hill, but instead of climbing the slope, his feet carried him all the way to the Mayeners. He had stayed away from their camp as much as possible, too, and not simply because of Berelain. There were disadvantages to having too keen a nose.

fɔɹtʃənətli, ə fɹɛʃənɪŋ bɹiz wɑz kæɹiɪŋ moʊst ə ðə stɪŋk əweɪ, ðoʊ ɪt dɪd lɪɾəl fəɹ ðə hit. swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn ðə feɪsəz ə ðə maʊntəd sɛntʃɹiz ɪn ðɛɹ ɹɛɾ ɑɹmɝ. ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ðeɪ sæɾ ʌp ivən mɔɹ ɹɪdʒɪdli ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, wɪtʃ wɑz seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. wɛɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɹoʊd laɪk fɛloʊz hɛɾɪŋ aʊt tə ðə filz, ðə minɝz juʒəwəli wɝ stætʃuz ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ðeɪ kəd faɪt, ðoʊ. ðə laɪt sɛn ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid.

Fortunately, a freshening breeze was carrying most of the stink away, though it did little for the heat. Sweat rolled down the faces of the mounted sentries in their red armor. At the sight of him, they sat up even more rigidly in their saddles, which was saying something. Where the Two Rivers men rode like fellows heading out to the fields, the Mayeners usually were statues on horseback. They could fight, though. The Light send there was no need.

heɪvin nɹɛl keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ, bʌtoʊnɪŋ ʌp ɪz koʊt, bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz wɛl pæs ðə sɛntʃɹiz. ðə dʌzən əɹ soʊ ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz fɑloʊɾ ət nɹɛlz hilz, ɔl koʊɾəd ən səm fæsənɪŋ ðə stʃɹæps ə ðɛɹ ɹɛd bɹɛstpleɪts. tu əɹ θɹi kæɹid hɛlməts wɪð θɪn ɹɛd plumz tʌkt ʌndɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz. moʊst wɝ jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən nɹɛl, səm twaɪs ɪz eɪdʒ, ɡɹeɪɪŋ mɛn wɪð hɑɹd, skɑɹd feɪsəz, bʌt nɹɛlz ɹɪwɔɹd fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ tə ɹɛskju ɹænd hæd bɪn tə bi neɪmd ɡælɛnz sɛkənd, hɪz fɝs lutɛnənt, ðeɪ kɔld ɪt.

Havien Nurelle came running, buttoning up his coat, before Perrin was well past the sentries. The dozen or so other officers followed at Nurelle's heels, all coated and some fastening the straps of their red breastplates. Two or three carried helmets with thin red plumes tucked under their arms. Most were years older than Nurelle, some twice his age, graying men with hard, scarred faces, but Nurelle's reward for helping to rescue Rand had been to be named Gallenne's second, his First Lieutenant, they called it.

"ðə fɝs hæzən ɹɪtɝnd, jɛt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," nɹɛl sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə baʊ mɪɹɝd baɪ ði ʌðɝz. ə tɔl slɛndɝ mæn, hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əz jʌŋ əz i hæd bɪfɔɹ dəməaɪz wɛlz. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɛdʒ tə hɪz aɪz, wɪtʃ hæd sin mɔɹ blʌd ðən moʊs vɛɾɝənz ə twɛnti bæɾəlz. bʌɾ ɪf ɪz feɪs wɑz hɑɹɾɝ, ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ən iɡɝnəs tə pliz ɪn ɪz sɛnt. tə heɪvin nɹɛl, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɑz ə mæn u kəd flaɪ əɹ wɔk ɑn wɔɾɝ əz i tʃoʊz. "ðə mɔɹnɪŋ pətʃɹoʊlz sɔ nʌθɪŋ, ðoʊz ðəɾ ɑɹ bæk. aɪ wəɾ əv ɹipɔɹɾəd, ʌðɝwaɪz."

"The First hasn't returned, yet, Lord Perrin," Nurelle said, making a bow mirrored by the others. A tall slender man, he did not look as young as he had before Dumai's Wells. There was an edge to his eyes, which had seen more blood than most veterans of twenty battles. But if his face was harder, there was still an eagerness to please in his scent. To Havien Nurelle, Perrin Aybara was a man who could fly or walk on water as he chose. "The morning patrols saw nothing, those that are back. I would have reported, otherwise."

"ʌv kɔɹs," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "aɪ . . . dʒʌst wɑntəd tə lʊk əbaʊɾ ə bɪt."

"Of course," Perrin told him. "I . . . just wanted to look about a bit."

hi sɪmpli mɛn tə wɔk ɝaʊn əntɪl i kəd wɝk ʌp ɪz nɝv tə feɪs ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt ðə jʌŋ minɝ fɑloʊɾ ɪm wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɔfəsɝz, æŋkʃəsli wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn tə faɪn səm flɔ ɪn ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, wɪnsɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ keɪm ɑn bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mɛn tɔsɪŋ daɪs ɑn ə blæŋkəɾ əɹ səm fɛloʊ snɔɹɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ðə sʌn ɑn ðə klaɪm. hi nid nɑɾ əv bɑðɝd; tə pɛɹɪn, ðə kæmp lʊk leɪɾ aʊt wɪð ə plʌm laɪn ən lɛvəl. itʃ mæn hæɾ ɪz blæŋkəts, ən ɪz sæɾəl fəɹ ə pɪloʊ, nɑt mɔɹ ðən tu peɪsɪz fɹəm wɛɹ ɪz hɔɹs wɑz taɪd tə wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ ɹoʊps dʒɹupɪŋ bɪtwin tʃɛst-haɪ poʊlz sɛɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ə kʊk faɪɝ stʊɾ ɛvɹi twɛnti peɪsɪz, wɪð lænsɪz stækt ɪn stil-tɪp koʊnz bɪtwin. ðə hoʊl meɪɾ ə sɔɹɾ ə bɑks ɝaʊn faɪv pik tɛns, wʌn stʃɹaɪpt ɡoʊld-ænd-blu ən lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ kəmbaɪnd. ɔl vɛɹi dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛnz ɛvɹi-wɪtʃ-weɪ ɝeɪnʒmənt.

He simply meant to walk around until he could work up his nerve to face the Wise Ones, but the young Mayener followed him with the rest of the officers, anxiously watching for Lord Perrin to find some flaw in the Winged Guards, wincing whenever they came on bare-chested men tossing dice on a blanket or some fellow snoring away with the sun on the climb. He need not have bothered; to Perrin, the camp looked laid out with a plumb line and level. Each man had his blankets, and his saddle for a pillow, not more than two paces from where his horse was tied to one of the long ropes drooping between chest-high poles set upright in the ground. A cook fire stood every twenty paces, with lances stacked in steel-tipped cones between. The whole made a sort of box around five peaked tents, one striped gold-and-blue and larger than the other four combined. All very different from the Two Rivers men's every-which-way arrangement.

pɛɹɪn wɔkt əlɔŋ bɹɪskli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk tu mʌtʃ ə ful. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ səksɛs i wɑz hævɪŋ. hi ɪtʃt tə stɑp ən lʊk oʊvɝ ə hɔɹs əɹ tu - dʒʌs tə bi eɪbəl tə pɪk ʌp ə huf wɪθaʊt sʌmbɑɾi pɹæktəkli feɪntɪŋ - bʌt maɪnfəl ʌv wʌɾ ɛɹæm hæd sɛd, hi kɛpt ɪz hænz tə hɪmsɛlf. ɛvɹiwʌn simd əz stɑɹɾəld əz nɹɛl əɾ ɪz peɪs. tʌf-aɪd bænɝmɪn tʃɪid mɛn tə ðɛɹ fiɾ oʊnli tə hæv pɛɹɪn stʃɹaɪd baɪ wɪð ə nɑd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl əpɹaɪt. ə pʌzəl mɝmɝ tʃɹeɪld ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən ɪz ɪɹz kɑɾ ə fju kɑmɛns əbaʊɾ ɔfəsɝz, lɔɹdz ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ, ðəɾ i wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæd nɹɛl ən ði ʌðɝz mɪst. faɪnəli, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə vɝdʒ ə ðə kæmp, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ðə bɹʌʃi sloʊp təwɔɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz' tɛns. oʊnli ə fju ʌv ðə meɪɾənz wɝ vɪzəbəl əmʌŋ ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz ʌp ðɛɹ, ən səm ə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn.

Perrin walked along briskly, trying not to look too much a fool. He was not sure how much success he was having. He itched to stop and look over a horse or two - just to be able to pick up a hoof without somebody practically fainting - but mindful of what Aram had said, he kept his hands to himself. Everyone seemed as startled as Nurelle at his pace. Tough-eyed bannermen chivvied men to their feet only to have Perrin stride by with a nod before they were all upright. A puzzled murmur trailed in the air behind him, and his ears caught a few comments about officers, lords in particular, that he was just as glad Nurelle and the others missed. Finally, he found himself on the verge of the camp, staring up the brushy slope toward the Wise Ones' tents. Only a few of the Maidens were visible among the scattered trees up there, and some of the gai'shain.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," nɹɛl sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. . . . hi stɛp kloʊsɝ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs tə ə hɔɹs wɪspɝ. "aɪ noʊ ðeɪ swɔɹ tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ænd. . . . aɪv sin θɪŋz, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ də kæmp tʃɔɹz! ɛɛs sədaɪ! ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪd keɪm daʊn tə fɛtʃ wɔɾɝ! ən jɛstɝdeɪ, æftɝ jə ɹɪtɝnd. . . . jɛstɝdeɪ, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hɝd sʌmwʌn ʌp ðəɹ . . . kɹaɪɪŋ aʊt. ɪt kʊdn əv bɪn wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz, ʌv kɔɹs," hi æɾəd hɝidli, ən læf tə ʃoʊ haʊ ɹɪdɪkjələs ði aɪdiə wɑz, ə vɛɹi ʃeɪki læf. "ju. . . . jəl si ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz . . . ɔl ɹaɪt . . . wɪð ðɛm?" hi hæd ɹɪɾən ɪndə fɔɹɾi θaʊzənd ʃeɪɾoʊ liɾɪŋ tu hʌnʒɹəd lænsɝz, bʌt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs hæɾ ɪm hʌntʃɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz fit. ʌv kɔɹs, hi hæd ɹɪɾən ɪndə fɔɹɾi θaʊzənd ʃeɪɾoʊ kəz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm tə.

"Lord Perrin," Nurelle said hesitantly. "The Aes Sedai. . . . He stepped closer and lowered his voice to a hoarse whisper. "I know they swore to the Lord Dragon, and. . . . I've seen things, Lord Perrin. They do camp chores! Aes Sedai! This morning, Masuri and Seonid came down to fetch water! And yesterday, after you returned. . . . Yesterday, I thought I heard someone up there . . . crying out. It couldn't have been one of the sisters, of course," he added hurriedly, and laughed to show how ridiculous the idea was, a very shaky laugh. "You. . . . You will see that everything is . . . all right . . . with them?" He had ridden into forty thousand Shaido leading two hundred lancers, but talking about this had him hunching his shoulders and shifting his feet. Of course, he had ridden into forty thousand Shaido because an Aes Sedai wanted him to.

"aɪl də wʌɾ aɪ kæn," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. meɪbi mæɾɝz wɝ wɝs ðən i hæd θɔt. naʊ hi hæd tə stɑp əm ɡɛɾɪŋ wɝs stɪl. ɪf i kʊd. hi wəd ɹæðɝ əv feɪs ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ əɡɛn.

"I'll do what I can," Perrin muttered. Maybe matters were worse than he had thought. Now he had to stop them getting worse still. If he could. He would rather have faced the Shaido again.

nɹɛl nɑɾəd əz ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hæd pɹɑməst ɔl i æskt ən mɔɹ. "ðæɾ ɪz wɛl, ðɛn," hi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɹɪlivd. kæstɪŋ saɪdweɪz ɡlænsɪz ət pɛɹɪn, hi wɝk hɪmsɛlf ʌp tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðɪs wɑz nɑt soʊ tʌtʃi əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "aɪ hɝd ðət jə lɛt ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl steɪ.".

Nurelle nodded as though Perrin had promised all he asked and more. "That is well, then," he said, sounding relieved. Casting sideways glances at Perrin, he worked himself up to say something else, but apparently this was not so touchy as the Aes Sedai. "I heard that you let the Red Eagle stay.".

pɛɹɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli dʒʌmpt. ivən fəɹ dʒʌst ɝaʊn ðə hɪl, nuz hæd tʃɹævəl fæst. "ɪt sim ðə θɪŋ tə du," hi sɛd sloʊli. bɹəleɪn wəɾ əv tə noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ, jɛɾ ɪf tu mɛni nu, ðət tʃɹuθ wəd spɹɛd fɹəm ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ ðeɪ pæst, ðə nɛks fɑɹm. "ðɪs juz tə bi pɑɹɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən," hi æɾəd, əz ɪf nɹɛl dɪd nɑt noʊ ðət pɝfəkli wɛl. tʃɹuθ! hi hæd ɡɑɾən soʊ hi kəd bɛn tʃɹuθ laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən tə mɛn ɑn ɪz saɪd. "nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðət flæɡz bɪn ɹeɪzd ɝaʊn hɪɹ, əl wɔɹənt, bʌt nʌn ə ðoʊz fɛloʊz hæd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn bɪhaɪn hɪm." ən ɪf ðət dɪd nɑt sɛt ðə nɛsəsɛɹi sidz, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə plaʊ ə fɝoʊ.

Perrin very nearly jumped. Even for just around the hill, news had traveled fast. "It seemed the thing to do," he said slowly. Berelain would have to know the truth, yet if too many knew, that truth would spread from the next village they passed, the next farm. "This used to be part of Manetheren," he added, as if Nurelle did not know that perfectly well. Truth! He had gotten so he could bend truth like an Aes Sedai, and to men on his side. "Not the first time that flag's been raised around here, I'll warrant, but none of those fellows had the Dragon Reborn behind him." And if that did not set the necessary seeds, he did not know how to plow a furrow.

əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪz ðət wʌt simd ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪð ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz. noʊ daʊt wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz seɪɪŋ, æftɝ ɔl bʌt ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðət weɪ. ivən ðə lin bɔldɪŋ oʊl soʊlʒɝ ɡælɛn kɔld ɪz dɔɡɹɑbɝ hæd kʌm aʊt tə stɛɹ, ən bɹəleɪnz meɪdz, ə pɛɹ ə plʌmp pleɪn-feɪst wɪmən ɡɑɹb tə mætʃ ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz tɛnt. pɛɹɪn hæd hɑɹdli sin ə θɪŋ, bʌɾ i nu hi hæd tə ɡɪv səm sɔɹɾ ə pɹeɪz.

Abruptly he realized that what seemed every last one of the Winged Guards was watching him with their officers. No doubt wondering what he was saying, after all but running through that way. Even the lean balding old soldier Gallenne called his dogrobber had come out to stare, and Berelain's maids, a pair of plump plain-faced women garbed to match their mistress's tent. Perrin had hardly seen a thing, but he knew he had to give some sort of praise.

ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs ɪnʌf tə kæɹi, hi sɛd, "ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz wɪl də min pɹaʊɾ ɪf wi ɛvɝ feɪs ənʌðɝ dəməaɪz wɛlz." ðoʊz wɝ ðə fɝst wɝdz ðət keɪm tə maɪnd, bʌɾ i wɪnst ət seɪɪŋ ðɛm.

Raising his voice enough to carry, he said, "The Winged Guards will do Mayene proud if we ever face another Dumai's Wells." Those were the first words that came to mind, but he winced at saying them.

tə hɪz ʃɑk, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɹoʊz stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ əmʌŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz, tʃɪɹɪŋ, "pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz!" ən "min fəɹ ɡoʊldeɪniz!" ən "ɡoʊldeɪniz ən meɪnɛðɝən!" mɛn dænst ən keɪpɝd, ən səm snætʃt lænsɪz fɹəm ðə stæks tə ʃeɪk əm soʊ ðə ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz weɪvd ɪn ðə bɹiz. ɡɹɪzəl bænɝmɪn wɑtʃt əm wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd, nɑɾɪŋ əpɹuvəl. nɹɛl bimd, ən nɑɾ oʊnli hɪm. ɔfəsɝz wɪð ɡɹeɪ ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ ən skɑɹz ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɡɹɪn laɪk bɔɪz pɹeɪzd ət ðɛɹ lɛsənz. laɪt, hi wɑz ði oʊnli seɪn mæn lɛft! hi pɹeɪd nɛvɝ tə si ənʌðɝ bæɾəl!

To his shock, shouting rose straightaway among the soldiers, cheering, "Perrin Goldeneyes!" and "Mayene for Goldeneyes!" and "Goldeneyes and Manetheren!" Men danced and capered, and some snatched lances from the stacks to shake them so the red streamers waved in the breeze. Grizzled bannermen watched them with arms folded, nodding approval. Nurelle beamed, and not only him. Officers with gray in their hair and scars on their faces grinned like boys praised at their lessons. Light, he was the only sane man left! He prayed never to see another battle!

wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðɪs wɑz gɑnə kɑz tʃɹʌbəl wɪð bɹəleɪn, hi meɪɾ ɪz ɡʊdbaɪz wɪð nɹɛl ən ði ʌðɝz ən tʃɹæmpt ʌp ðə sloʊp θɹu dɛɾ əɹ daɪɪŋ bɹʌʃ, nʌn ʌv ɪt weɪst-haɪ. bɹaʊn widz kɹækəl bɪniθ ɪz buts. ʃaʊɾɪŋ stɪl fɪl ðə minɝ kæmp. ivən æftɝ ʃi lɝn ðə tʃɹuθ, ðə fɝs maɪt nɑt bi pliz tə hæv əɹ soʊlʒɝz tʃɪɹɪŋ ɪm ðɪs weɪ. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət kəɾ əv ɡʊd pɔɪns. meɪbi ʃi wəd bi æŋɡɹi ɪnʌf tə stɑp pɛstɝɪŋ hɪm.

Wondering whether this was going to cause trouble with Berelain, he made his goodbyes with Nurelle and the others and tramped up the slope through dead or dying brush, none of it waist-high. Brown weeds crackled beneath his boots. Shouting still filled the Mayener camp. Even after she learned the truth, the First might not be pleased to have her soldiers cheering him this way. Of course, that could have good points. Maybe she would be angry enough to stop pestering him.

ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə kɹɛst, hi pɔzd, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə tʃɪɹz faɪnəli feɪɾ əweɪ. noʊ wʌn wɑz gɑnə tʃɪɹ ɪm hɪɹ. ɔl ə ðə saɪd flæps wɝ daʊn ɑn ðə waɪz wʌnz' loʊ ɡɹeɪ-bɹaʊn tɛns, kloʊzɪŋ əm ɪn. oʊnli ə fju ʌv ðə meɪɾənz wɝ ɪn saɪt, naʊ. skwɑɾɪŋ izəli ɑn ðɛɹ hilz bɪniθ ə lɛðɝlif ðət stɪl ʃoʊd səm ɡɹin, ðeɪ aɪɾ ɪm kjʊɹiəsli. ðɛɹ hænz muv kwɪkli ɪn ðət weɪ ðeɪ hæɾ ə tɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð saɪnz. æftɝ ə moʊmən səlɪn ɹoʊz, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ hɛvi bɛl naɪf, ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, ə tɔl, wɪɹi wʊmən wɪð ə pɪŋk skɑɹ əkɹɔs əɹ sʌn-dɑɹk tʃik. ʃi ɡlæns bæk daʊn ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm ən simd ɹɪliv ðəɾ i wɑz əloʊn, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ɔfən hɑɹd tə tɛl wɪð il.

Short of the crest, he paused, listening to the cheers finally fade away. No one was going to cheer him here. All of the side flaps were down on the Wise Ones' low gray-brown tents, closing them in. Only a few of the Maidens were in sight, now. Squatting easily on their heels beneath a leatherleaf that still showed some green, they eyed him curiously. Their hands moved quickly in that way they had of talking among themselves with signs. After a moment Sulin rose, shifting her heavy belt knife, and strode in his direction, a tall, wiry woman with a pink scar across her sun-dark cheek. She glanced back down the way he had come and seemed relieved that he was alone, though it was often hard to tell with Aiel.

"ðɪs ɪz ɡʊd, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ðə waɪz wʌnz əv nɑt bɪn pliz ðət jə meɪk əm kʌm tə ju. oʊnli ə ful dɪsplisɪz waɪz wʌnz, ən aɪ hæv nɑt teɪkən jə fəɹ ə ful."

"This is good, Perrin Aybara," she said quietly. "The Wise Ones have not been pleased that you make them come to you. Only a fool displeases Wise Ones, and I have not taken you for a fool."

pɛɹɪn skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz bɪɹd. hi hæd bɪn kipɪŋ klɪɹ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz - ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ - əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, bʌɾ i hæd hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə fɔɹsɪŋ əm tə kʌm tə hɪm. hi dʒʌs faʊn ðɛɹ kʌmpəni ənkʌmftəɹbəl. tə pʊɾ ɪt maɪldli. "wɛl, aɪ nid tə si ɛdʒɹə naʊ," hi toʊl hɝ. "əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Perrin scrubbed at his beard. He had been keeping clear of the Wise Ones - and the Aes Sedai - as much as possible, but he had had no intention of forcing them to come to him. He just found their company uncomfortable. To put it mildly. "Well, I need to see Edarra now," he told her. "About the Aes Sedai."

"pɝhæps aɪ wɑz mɪsteɪkən æftɝ ɔl," səlɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "bʌɾ əl tɛl hɝ." tɝnɪŋ, ʃi pɔzd. "tɛl mi sʌmθɪŋ. tɛɹəl wɪntɝ ən fʊɹən ælhæɹə ɑɹ kloʊs tə siɑnɪd tʃɹeɪɡən - laɪk fɝst-bɹʌðɝz wɪð ə fɝst-sɪstɝ; ʃi dʌz nɑt laɪk mɛn əz mɛn - jɛt ðeɪ ɔfɝd tə teɪk əɹ pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ hɝ. haʊ kəd ðeɪ ʃeɪm əɹ soʊ?"

"Perhaps I was mistaken after all," Sulin said dryly. "But I will tell her." Turning, she paused. "Tell me something. Teryl Wynter and Furen Alharra are close to Seonid Traighan - like first-brothers with a first-sister; she does not like men as men - yet they offered to take her punishment for her. How could they shame her so?"

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ keɪm aʊt. ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝs sloʊp, itʃ liɾɪŋ tu ʌv ði ilz pæk mjulz; ðə waɪt-ɹoʊb mɛn pæst wɪðɪn ə fju peɪsɪz, hɛɾɪŋ daʊn təwɔɹd ðə stʃɹim. hi kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ i θɔt boʊθ wɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðə pɛɹ kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz mikli daʊn, bɛɹli lʊkɪŋ ʌp ɪnʌf tə si wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd hæɾ ɛvɹi ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ɹʌn əweɪ, duɪŋ tʃɔɹz laɪk ðət wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn tə wɑtʃ. ə pəkjuljɝ pipəl.

He opened his mouth, but nothing came out. A pair of gai'shain appeared from the reverse slope, each leading two of the Aiel's pack mules; the white-robed men passed within a few paces, heading down toward the stream. He could not be sure, but he thought both were Shaido. The pair kept their eyes meekly down, barely looking up enough to see where they were going. They had had every opportunity to run away, doing chores like that without anyone to watch. A peculiar people.

"aɪ si jə ɑɹ ʃɑkt, tu," səlɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæd hoʊp jə kəɾ ɪkspleɪn. əl tɛl ɛdʒɹə." əz ʃi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə tɛns, ʃi æɾəd oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, "ju wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

"I see you are shocked, too," Sulin said. "I had hoped you could explain. I will tell Edarra." As she started for the tents, she added over her shoulder, "You wetlanders are very strange, Perrin Aybara."

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn æftɝ hɝ, ən wən ʃi vænɪʃt ɪndə wʌn ə ðə tɛns, hi tɝn tə fɹaʊn ət ðə tu ɡeɪʃeɪn liɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz tə wɔɾɝ. wɛtləndɝz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ? laɪt! soʊ nɹɛl hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ ɪn wʌɾ i hɝd. ɪt wɑz bɪɑn taɪm tə stɪk ɪz noʊz ɪndə wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn bɪtwin ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi ʃəɾ əv bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. hi wɪʃt i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wəd bi ðə seɪm əz stɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊz ɪndə ə hɔɹnɪts nɛst.

Perrin frowned after her, and when she vanished into one of the tents, he turned to frown at the two gai'shain leading the horses to water. Wetlanders were strange? Light! So Nurelle had been right in what he heard. It was beyond time to stick his nose into what was going on between the Wise Ones and the Aes Sedai. He should have before this. He wished he did not think it would be the same as sticking his nose into a hornet's nest.

ɪt sim tə teɪk ə lɔŋ taɪm fəɹ səlɪn tə ɹiəpɪɹ, ən ʃi dɪd lɪɾəl tə hɛlp ɪz mud wən ʃi dɪd. hoʊldɪŋ ðə tɛntflæp fəɹ hɪm, ʃi flɪkt ɪz bɛl naɪf kəntɛmptʃwəsli wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ əz i dʌk θɹu. "ju ʃəd bi bɛɾɝ ɑɹm fəɹ ðɪs dæns, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd.

It seemed to take a long time for Sulin to reappear, and she did little to help his mood when she did. Holding the tentflap for him, she flicked his belt knife contemptuously with a finger as he ducked through. "You should be better armed for this dance, Perrin Aybara," she said.

ɪnsaɪd, hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɔl sɪks waɪz wʌnz sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn kʌlɝfəl tæsɛl kʊʃənz, ðɛɹ ʃɔlz taɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ weɪsts ən ðɛɹ skɝts meɪkɪŋ kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd fænz əkɹɔs ðə leɪɝd ɹʌɡz. hi hæd hoʊp fəɹ dʒʌst ɛdʒɹə. nʌn lʊk tə bi mɔɹ ðən fɔɹ əɹ faɪv jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hi, səm noʊ oʊldɝ əɾ ɔl, jɛt sʌmhaʊ ðeɪ ɔlweɪz meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i wɝ feɪsɪŋ ði oʊldəs mɛmbɝz ə ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl, ðə wʌnz u hæd spɛn jɪɹz lɝnɪŋ tə snɪf aʊt wʌtɛvɝ jə wɑntəd tə haɪd. sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ wʌn wʊmənz sɛn fɹəm ənʌðɝz wɑz ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl, bʌɾ i hɑɹdli niɾəd tə. sɪks sɛts ʌv aɪz lætʃt ɑn tə hɪm, fɹəm dʒəninəz peɪl skaɪ blu tə mɑɹlaɪnz pɝpəl twaɪlaɪt, nɑt tə mɛnʃən nəvɛɝɪnz ʃɑɹp ɡɹin. ɛvɹi aɪ cʊɾə bɪn ə skjuɝ.

Inside, he was surprised to find all six Wise Ones sitting cross-legged on colorful tasseled cushions, their shawls tied around their waists and their skirts making carefully arranged fans across the layered rugs. He had hoped for just Edarra. None looked to be more than four or five years older than he, some no older at all, yet somehow they always made him feel as if he were facing the oldest members of the Women's Circle, the ones who had spent years learning to sniff out whatever you wanted to hide. Separating one woman's scent from another's was all but impossible, but he hardly needed to. Six sets of eyes latched on to him, from Janina's pale sky blue to Marline's purple twilight, not to mention Nevarin's sharp green. Every eye could have been a skewer.

ɛdʒɹə bɹʌskli moʊʃən ɪm tə teɪk ə kʊʃən hɪmsɛlf, wɪtʃ i dɪd wɪð ɡɹæɾətud, ðoʊ ɪt pʊɾ ɪm feɪsɪŋ əm ɔl ɪn ə sɛmɪsɝkəl. meɪbi waɪz wʌnz hæd dɪzaɪn ðiz tɛns, tə meɪk mɛn bɛn ðɛɹ nɛks ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd tə stæn əpɹaɪt. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɪt wɑz kulɝ ɪn ðə dɪm ɪntɪɹiɝ, bʌɾ i stɪl fɛlt laɪk swɛɾɪŋ. meɪbi hi kəd nɑt pɪk wʌn fɹəm ənʌðɝ, jɛt ðiz wɪmən smɛld laɪk wʊlvz stʌɾiɪŋ ə tɛðɝd ɡoʊt. ə skwɛɹ-feɪst ɡeɪʃeɪn u wɑz hæf əɡɛn əz bɪɡ əz i wɑz nɛl tə ɔfɝ ə ɡoʊldən kʌp ə dɑɹk waɪn-pʌntʃ ɑn ən ɪlæbɹət sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ. ðə waɪz wʌnz ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl mɪsmætʃt sɪlvɝ kʌps ən ɡoʊbləts. ənʃʊɹ wʌɾ ɪt mɛn ðəɾ i wɑz biɪŋ ɔfɝd ɡoʊld - meɪbi nʌθɪŋ, jɛɾ u kəd seɪ, wɪð il? - pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪt kɔʃəsli. ɪt ɡeɪv ɔf ðə sɛn ə plʌmz. ðə fɛloʊ baʊd mikli ɪnʌf wən ɛdʒɹə klæpt əɹ hænz, ən bɛn hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə tɛn bækwɝd, bʌt ðə hæf-hil slæʃ daʊn ɪz hɑɹd feɪs hæd tə deɪt fɹəm dəməaɪz wɛlz.

Edarra brusquely motioned him to take a cushion himself, which he did with gratitude, though it put him facing them all in a semicircle. Maybe Wise Ones had designed these tents, to make men bend their necks if they wanted to stand upright. Strangely, it was cooler in the dim interior, but he still felt like sweating. Maybe he could not pick one from another, yet these women smelled like wolves studying a tethered goat. A square-faced gai'shain who was half again as big as he was knelt to offer a golden cup of dark wine-punch on an elaborate silver tray. The Wise Ones already held mismatched silver cups and goblets. Unsure what it meant that he was being offered gold - maybe nothing, yet who could say, with Aiel? - Perrin took it cautiously. It gave off the scent of plums. The fellow bowed meekly enough when Edarra clapped her hands, and bent himself out of the tent backward, but the half-healed slash down his hard face had to date from Dumai's Wells.

"naʊ ðət jə ɑɹ hɪɹ," ɛdʒɹə sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə tɛntflæp dʒɹɑp bɪhaɪn ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn, "wi wɪl ɪkspleɪn əɡɛn waɪ jə mʌs kɪl ðə mæn kɔl mæsimə dɑɡɝ."

"Now that you are here," Edarra said as soon as the tentflap dropped behind the gai'shain, "we will explain again why you must kill the man called Masema Dagar."

"wi ʃəd nɑɾ əv tə ɪkspleɪn əɡɛn," dɛlɔɹə pʊɾ ɪn. hɝ hɛɹ ən aɪz wɝ nɪɹli ðə seɪm ʃeɪɾ əz meɪaɪɡdɪnz, bʌt noʊ wʌn wəd kɔl əɹ pɪntʃt feɪs pɹɪɾi. hɝ mænɝ wɑz pjʊɹ aɪs. "ðɪs mæsimə dɑɡɝ ɪz ə deɪnʒɝ tə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn. hi mʌs daɪ."

"We should not have to explain again," Delora put in. Her hair and eyes were nearly the same shade as Maighdin's, but no one would call her pinched face pretty. Her manner was pure ice. "This Masema Dagar is a danger to the Car'a'carn. He must die."

"ðə dʒɹimwɔkɝz əv toʊld ʌs, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." kɛɹɛl sɝɾənli wɑz pɹɪɾi, ən ðoʊ hɝ faɪɝi hɛɹ ən pɪɹsɪŋ aɪz meɪɾ əɹ lʊk əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ə tɛmpɝ, ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz maɪld. fəɹ ə waɪz wʌn. ən sɝɾənli nɑt sɑft. "ðeɪ hæv ɹɛd ðə dʒɹim. ðə mæn mʌs daɪ."

"The dreamwalkers have told us, Perrin Aybara." Carelle certainly was pretty, and though her fiery hair and piercing eyes made her look as though she had a temper, she was always mild. For a Wise One. And certainly not soft. "They have read the dream. The man must die."

pɛɹɪn tʊk ə swɑloʊ ʌv plʌm pʌntʃ tə ɡeɪn ə moʊmənt. sʌmhaʊ, ðə pʌntʃ wɑz kul. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə seɪm wɪð ðɛm. ɹænd hæd nɑt mɛnʃən ɛni wɔɹnɪŋ fɹəm ðə dʒɹimwɔkɝz. ðə fɝs taɪm, pɛɹɪn hæd mɛnʃən ðæt. oʊnli ðə wʌns; ðeɪ hæd θɔɾ i wɑz kæstɪŋ daʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ wɝd, ən ivən kɛɹɛl hæd ɡɔn hɑt-aɪd. nɑt ðət pɛɹɪn θɔt ðeɪ wəd laɪ. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. hi hæd nɑt kɑɾ əm ɪn wʌn, ɛniweɪ. bʌt wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd fəɹ ðə fjutʃɝ ən wʌt ɹænd wɑntəd - wʌɾ i hɪmsɛlf wɑntəd, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ - maɪt bi vɛɹi dɪfɹən θɪŋz. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɹænd u wɑz kipɪŋ sikɹəts. "ɪf jə kəd dʒʌst ɡɪmi səm aɪdiə wʌt ðɪs deɪnʒɝ ɪz," hi sɛd, faɪnəli. "ðə laɪt noʊz, mæsiməz ə mædmæn, bʌɾ i səpɔɹts ɹænd. ə faɪn θɪŋ, ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ ɝaʊn kɪlɪŋ pipəl ɑn əɹ saɪd. ðət wɪl sɝɾənli kənvɪns pipəl tə dʒɔɪn ɹænd."

Perrin took a swallow of plum punch to gain a moment. Somehow, the punch was cool. It was always the same with them. Rand had not mentioned any warning from the dreamwalkers. The first time, Perrin had mentioned that. Only the once; they had thought he was casting doubt on their word, and even Carelle had gone hot-eyed. Not that Perrin thought they would lie. Not exactly. He had not caught them in one, anyway. But what they wanted for the future and what Rand wanted - what he himself wanted, for that matter - might be very different things. Maybe it was Rand who was keeping secrets. "If you could just give me some idea what this danger is," he said, finally. "The Light knows, Masema's a madman, but he supports Rand. A fine thing, if I go around killing people on our side. That will certainly convince people to join Rand."

sɑɹkæzəm wɑz lɔst ɑn ðɛm. ðeɪ lʊkt ət hɪm, ənblɪŋkɪŋ. "ðə mæn mʌs daɪ," ɛdʒɹə sɛɾ ət læst. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪnʌf ðət θɹi dʒɹimwɔkɝz əv sɛd soʊ, ən sɪks waɪz wʌnz tɛl ju." ðə seɪm əz ɔlweɪz. meɪbi ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðæt. ən meɪbi hi ʃəd ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð waɪ hi hæd kʌm.

Sarcasm was lost on them. They looked at him, unblinking. "The man must die," Edarra said at last. "It is enough that three dreamwalkers have said so, and six Wise Ones tell you." The same as always. Maybe they did not know any more than that. And maybe he should get on with why he had come.

"aɪ wɑnə tɔk əbaʊt siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi," hi sɛd, ən sɪks feɪsəz tɝn tə fɹɔst. laɪt, ðiz wɪmən kəd stɛɹ daʊn ə stoʊn! sɛɾɪŋ ðə waɪnkʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, hi lin təwɔɹɾ əm stʌbɝnli. "aɪm səpoʊz tə ʃoʊ pipəl ɛɛs sədaɪ swɔɹn tə ɹænd." hi wɑz səpoʊz tə ʃoʊ mæsimə, æktʃəli , bʌt ðɪs dɪd sim ə ɡʊd taɪm tə mɛnʃən ðæt. "ðeɪ gɑnə tə bi vɛɹi koʊɑpɝeɪɾɪv ɪf jə lɑt bit ðɛm! laɪt! ðəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ! ɪnstɛɾ ə meɪkɪŋ əm hɔl wɔɾɝ, waɪ doʊn jə lɝn fɹəm ðɛm? ðeɪ mʌs noʊ ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz jə doʊnt." tu leɪt, hi bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ. ði il wɪmən dɪd nɑt teɪk əfɛns, ðoʊ; nɑt ðəɾ ɪt ʃoʊd, ɛniweɪ.

"I want to talk about Seonid and Masuri," he said, and six faces turned to frost. Light, these women could stare down a stone! Setting the winecup beside him, he leaned toward them stubbornly. "I'm supposed to show people Aes Sedai sworn to Rand." He was supposed to show Masema, actually, but this did seem a good time to mention that. "They aren't going to be very cooperative if you lot beat them! Light! They're Aes Sedai! Instead of making them haul water, why don't you learn from them? They must know all sorts of things you don't." Too late, he bit his tongue. The Aiel women did not take offense, though; not that it showed, anyway.

"ðeɪ noʊ səm θɪŋz wi də nɑt," dɛlɔɹə toʊld ɪm fɝmli, "ænd wi noʊ səm ðeɪ də nɑt." əz fɝmli əz ə spɪɹpɔɪn ɪn ðə ɹɪbz.

"They know some things we do not," Delora told him firmly, "and we know some they do not." As firmly as a spearpoint in the ribs.

"wi lɝn wʌt ðəɹ ɪz tə lɝn, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," mɑɹlaɪn sɛd kɑmli, koʊmɪŋ nɪɹli blæk hɛɹ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju il i hæd sin wɪð sətʃ dɑɹk hɛɹ, ən ʃi ɔfən tɔɪd wɪð ɪt. "ænd wi titʃ wʌt ðəɹ ɪz tə titʃ."

"We learn what there is to learn, Perrin Aybara," Marline said calmly, combing nearly black hair with her fingers. She was one of the few Aiel he had seen with such dark hair, and she often toyed with it. "And we teach what there is to teach."

"ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt," dʒəninə sɛd, "ɪɾ ɪz nʌn ə jəɹ əfɛɹ. mɛn də nɑɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ bɪtwin waɪz wʌnz ən əpɹɛntəsɪz." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪz fulɪʃnəs.

"In any event," Janina said, "it is none of your affair. Men do not interfere between Wise Ones and apprentices." She shook her head over his foolishness.

"ju meɪ stɑp lɪsnɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ən kʌm ɪn, siɑnɪd tʃɹeɪɡən," ɛdʒɹə sɛd sʌɾənli. pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt nʌn ə ðə wɪmən bæɾɪd ən aɪ.

"You may stop listening outside and come in, Seonid Traighan," Edarra said suddenly. Perrin blinked in surprise, but none of the women batted an eye.

ðəɹ wɑz ə moʊmən ə saɪləns, ðən ðə tɛntflæp twɪtʃt əsaɪd, ən siɑnɪd dʌkt ɪnsaɪd, nilɪŋ kwɪkli ɑn ðə ɹʌɡz. ðət vɔntɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi wɑz ʃæɾɝd ɪn hɝ. hɝ maʊθ wɑz ə θɪn laɪn, hɝ aɪz taɪt, hɝ feɪs ɹɛd. ʃi smɛld ʌv æŋɡɝ, fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ən ə dʌzən mɔɹ ɪmoʊʃənz ɔl wɝlɪŋ əbaʊt soʊ kwɪkli ðət pɛɹɪn kəd bɛɹli sɛpɝeɪɾ ɛni aʊt. "meɪ aɪ spik tə hɪm?" ʃi æskt ɪn ə stɪf vɔɪs.

There was a moment of silence, then the tentflap twitched aside, and Seonid ducked inside, kneeling quickly on the rugs. That vaunted Aes Sedai serenity was shattered in her. Her mouth was a thin line, her eyes tight, her face red. She smelled of anger, frustration, and a dozen more emotions all whirling about so quickly that Perrin could barely separate any out. "May I speak to him?" she asked in a stiff voice.

"ɪf jə teɪk kɛɹ wʌt jə seɪ," ɛdʒɹə toʊl hɝ. sɪpɪŋ əɹ waɪn, ðə waɪz wʌn wɑtʃt oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ə hɝ kʌp. ə titʃɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ə pjupəl? ə hɔk wɑtʃɪŋ ə maʊs? pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛdʒɹə wɑz vɛɹi ʃʊɹ ə hɝ pleɪs, wʌtɛvɝ ðə pɛɹɪŋ. soʊ wɑz siɑnɪd. bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt kæɹi oʊvɝ tə hɪm.

"If you take care what you say," Edarra told her. Sipping her wine, the Wise One watched over the rim of her cup. A teacher watching a pupil? A hawk watching a mouse? Perrin could not be sure. Except that Edarra was very sure of her place, whatever the pairing. So was Seonid. But that did not carry over to him.

ʃi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə feɪs ɪm ɑn əɹ niz, bæk ɡoʊɪŋ stʃɹeɪt, aɪz hiɾəd. æŋɡɝ ɹeɪdʒd ɪn ðə smɛl ə hɝ. "wʌtɛvɝ jə noʊ," ʃi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli, "wʌtɛvɝ jə θɪŋk jə noʊ, jəl fɝɡɛt!" noʊ, ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə ʃɹɛɾ ə sɝɛnəɾi lɛft ɪn hɝ. "wʌtɛvɝ ɪz bɪtwin ðə waɪz wʌnz ən əs ɪz fəɹ əs əloʊn! jəl stæn əsaɪd, əvɝt jəɹ aɪz, ən kip jəɹ maʊθ kloʊzd!"

She twisted around to face him on her knees, back going straight, eyes heated. Anger raged in the smell of her. "Whatever you know," she said angrily, "whatever you think you know, you will forget!" No, there was not a shred of serenity left in her. "Whatever is between the Wise Ones and us is for us alone! You will stand aside, avert your eyes, and keep your mouth closed!"

əmeɪzd, pɛɹɪn ɹeɪkt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. "laɪt, jəɹ əpsɛt kəz aɪ noʊ jə ɡɑɾ ə swɪtʃɪŋ?" hi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. wɛl, hi wəɾ əv bɪn, tu, bʌt nɑɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ɹɛst. "doʊn jə noʊ ðiz wɪmən wəɾ əz sun kʌt jəɹ θɹoʊɾ əz lʊk ət ju? slɪt jəɹ θɹoʊɾ ən liv jə baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd! wɛl, aɪ pɹɑməs maɪsɛlf aɪ wʊdn lɛt ðət hæpən! aɪ doʊn laɪk ju, bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs tə pɹətɛk jə fɹəm ðə waɪz wʌnz, əɹ ði æʃəmən, əɹ ɹænd hɪmsɛlf, soʊ kʌm daʊn ɔf ðət haɪ hɔɹs!" ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ, hi dʒɹu ə dip, ɪmbɛɹəs bɹɛθ ən sɛɾəld bæk ɑn ɪz kʊʃən, snætʃt ʌp ɪz waɪnkʌp ən tʊk ə lɔŋ dʒɹɪŋk.

Amazed, Perrin raked his fingers through his hair. "Light, you're upset because I know you got a switching?" he said incredulously. Well, he would have been, too, but not alongside the rest. "Don't you know these women would as soon cut your throat as look at you? Slit your throat and leave you by the side of the road! Well, I promised myself I wouldn't let that happen! I don't like you, but I promised to protect you from the Wise Ones, or the Asha'man, or Rand himself, so come down off that high horse!" Realizing that he was shouting, he drew a deep, embarrassed breath and settled back on his cushion, snatched up his winecup and took a long drink.

siɑnɪd wɛn stɪfɝ baɪ ðə wɝd wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, ən əɹ lɪp kɝld wɛl bɪfɔɹ i fɪnɪʃt. "ju pɹɑməst?" ʃi snɪɹd. "ju θɪŋk ɛɛs sədaɪ nid jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən? jə - ?"

Seonid went stiffer by the word with indignation, and her lip curled well before he finished. "You promised?" she sneered. "You think Aes Sedai need your protection? You - ?"

"ɪnʌf," ɛdʒɹə sɛd kwaɪətli, ən siɑnɪdz dʒɔ snæpt ʃʌt, ðoʊ hɝ hænz meɪd waɪt-nʌkəl fɪsts klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts.

"Enough," Edarra said quietly, and Seonid's jaw snapped shut, though her hands made white-knuckled fists clutching her skirts.

"wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk wi wəd kɪl hɝ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?" dʒəninə æskt kjʊɹiəsli. il sɛldəm ʃoʊd mʌtʃ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌt ði ʌðɝz fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əɹ lʊkt wɪð oʊpən ɪnkɹədulɪɾi.

"What makes you think we would kill her, Perrin Aybara?" Janina asked curiously. Aiel seldom showed much on their faces, but the others frowned at him or looked with open incredulity.

"aɪ noʊ haʊ jə fil," hi ɹɪplaɪd sloʊli. "aɪv noʊn sɪns aɪ sɔ jə wɪð ðə sɪstɝz æftɝ dəməaɪz wɛlz." hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ i hæd smɛl ðɛɹ heɪtʃɹəd, ðɛɹ kəntɛmpt, ɛvɹi taɪm ə waɪz wʌn lʊkt əɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ bæk ðɛn. hi dɪd nɑt smɛl ɪt naʊ, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəd meɪnteɪn ðət lɛvəl ə fjʊɹi fəɹ lɔŋ wɪθaʊt bɝstɪŋ. ðət dɪd nɑt min ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, oʊnli ðəɾ ɪt hæd sʌŋk dip, meɪbi ɪndə ðə boʊn.

"I know how you feel," he replied slowly. "I've known since I saw you with the sisters after Dumai's Wells." He was not about to explain that he had smelled their hatred, their contempt, every time a Wise One looked at an Aes Sedai back then. He did not smell it now, but no one could maintain that level of fury for long without bursting. That did not mean it was gone, only that it had sunk deep, maybe into the bone.

dɛlɔɹə snɔɹɾɪd, ə saʊn laɪk lɪnən ɹɪpɪŋ. "fɝs jə seɪ ðeɪ mʌs bi kɑɾəld kəz jə nid ðɛm, ən naʊ kəz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən juv pɹɑməs tə pɹətɛk ðɛm. wɪtʃ ɪz tʃɹuθ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə?"

Delora snorted, a sound like linen ripping. "First you say they must be coddled because you need them, and now because they are Aes Sedai and you have promised to protect them. Which is truth, Perrin Aybara?"

"boʊθ." pɛɹɪn mɛt dɛlɔɹəz hɑɹd ɡeɪz fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ðən aɪɾ itʃ ə ði ʌðɝz ɪn tɝn. "boʊθ ɑɹ tʃɹu, ən aɪ min boʊθ."

"Both." Perrin met Delora's hard gaze for a long moment, then eyed each of the others in turn. "Both are true, and I mean both."

ðə waɪz wʌnz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, ðə sɔɹt wɛɹ ɛvɹi flɪkɝ ʌv ən aɪləd hɛld ə hʌnʒɹəd wɝdz ən noʊ mæn kəd meɪk aʊɾ ə wʌn. faɪnəli, ɪn ə ʃɪftɪŋ ə nɛkləsɪz ən ɹiədʒʌstɪŋ ə taɪd ʃɔlz, ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə ɹitʃ əɡɹimənt.

The Wise Ones exchanged glances, the sort where every flicker of an eyelid held a hundred words and no man could make out a one. Finally, in a shifting of necklaces and readjusting of tied shawls, they appeared to reach agreement.

"wi də nɑt kɪl əpɹɛntəsɪz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd. ʃi saʊndəd ʃɑkt ət ði aɪdiə. "wɛn ɹænd ælθɹ æskt əs tə əpɹɛntəs ðɛm, pɝhæps i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tə meɪk əm oʊbeɪ ʌs, bʌt wi də nɑt spik ɛmpti wɝdz. ðeɪ ɑɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz, naʊ."

"We do not kill apprentices, Perrin Aybara," Nevarin said. She sounded shocked at the idea. "When Rand al'Thor asked us to apprentice them, perhaps he thought it was just to make them obey us, but we do not speak empty words. They are apprentices, now."

"ðeɪ wɪl ɹɪmeɪn soʊ əntɪl faɪv waɪz wʌnz əɡɹi ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə bi mɔɹ," mɑɹlaɪn æɾəd, swipɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "æn ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹiɾəd noʊ dɪfɹənli ðən ɛni ʌðɝz."

"They will remain so until five Wise Ones agree they are ready to be more," Marline added, sweeping her long hair over her shoulder. "And they are treated no differently than any others."

ɛdʒɹə nɑɾəd oʊvɝ əɹ waɪnkʌp. "tɛl ɪm ði ædvaɪs jə wəd ɡɪv ɪm kənsɝnɪŋ mæsimə dɑɡɝ, siɑnɪd tʃɹeɪɡən," ʃi sɛd.

Edarra nodded over her winecup. "Tell him the advice you would give him concerning Masema Dagar, Seonid Traighan," she said.

ðə nilɪŋ wʊmən hæd pɹæktəkli ɹɪθ dʊɹɪŋ nəvɛɝɪn ən mɑɹlaɪnz ʃɔɹt spitʃəz, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ skɝɾ əntɪl pɛɹɪn θɔt ðə sɪlk maɪt ɹɪp, bʌt ʃi weɪstəd noʊ taɪm kəmplaɪɪŋ wɪð ɛdʒɹəz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. "ðə waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ ɹaɪt, wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ ɹizənz. aɪ də nɑt seɪ ðɪs kəz ðeɪ wɪʃ ɪt." ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp əɡɛn, smuðɪŋ əɹ fitʃɝz wɪð ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt. ə tʌtʃ ə hit stɪl flɛɹɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, ðoʊ. "aɪ sɔ ðə wɝk ə soʊ-kɔl dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɛvɝ mɛt ɹænd ælθɹ. dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, tə noʊ pɝpəs. ivən ə feɪθfəl dɔɡ mʌs bi pʊt daʊn ɪf ɪt bɪɡɪnz tə foʊm ət ðə maʊθ."

The kneeling woman had practically writhed during Nevarin and Marline's short speeches, gripping her skirt until Perrin thought the silk might rip, but she wasted no time complying with Edarra's instructions. "The Wise Ones are right, whatever their reasons. I do not say this because they wish it." She drew herself up again, smoothing her features with a visible effort. A touch of heat still flared in her voice, though. "I saw the work of so-called Dragonsworn before I ever met Rand al'Thor. Death and destruction, to no purpose. Even a faithful dog must be put down if it begins to foam at the mouth."

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz!" pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌmbəld. "haʊ kən aɪ ivən lɛt jə ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə mæn æftɝ ðæt? jə swɔɹ fiəlti tə ɹænd; jə noʊ ðəɾ ɪzənt wʌɾ i wɑns! wʌɾ əbaʊt ðət 'θaʊzənz wɪl daɪ ɪf jə feɪl'?" laɪt, ɪf mɑsʊɝi fɛl ðə seɪm, ðən i hæd tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz fəɹ nʌθɪŋ! noʊ, wɝs. hi wəɾ əv tə ɡɑɹd mæsimə fɹəm ðɛm!

"Blood and ashes!" Perrin grumbled. "How can I even let you in sight of the man after that? You swore fealty to Rand; you know that isn't what he wants! What about that 'thousands will die if you fail'?" Light, if Masuri felt the same, then he had to put up with Aes Sedai and Wise Ones for nothing! No, worse. He would have to guard Masema from them!

"mɑsʊɝi noʊz mæsimə fəɹ ɹæbɪɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ," siɑnɪd ɹɪplaɪd wən i pʊt ðə kwɛstʃən tə hɝ. ɔl ə hɝ sɝɛnəɾi hæd ɹɪtɝnd. ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð ə kul, ənɹiɾəbəl feɪs. hɝ sɛnt wɑz ʃɑɹpli əlɝt. ɪntɛnt. əz ɪf i niɾəd ɪz noʊz, wɪð əɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪz, bɪɡ ən dɑɹk ən bɑɾəmləs. "aɪ swɔɹ tə sɝv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðə bɛst sɝvəs aɪ kən ɡɪv ɪm naʊ ɪz tə kip ðɪs ænəməl fɹəm hɪm. bæɾ ɪnʌf ðət ɹulɝz noʊ mæsimə səpɔɹts hɪm; wɝs ɪf ðeɪ si hɪm ɛmbɹeɪs ðə mæn. ən θaʊzənz wɪl daɪ ɪf jə feɪl - tə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə mæsimə tə kɪl hɪm."

"Masuri knows Masema for rabid as well as I," Seonid replied when he put the question to her. All of her serenity had returned. She regarded him with a cool, unreadable face. Her scent was sharply alert. Intent. As if he needed his nose, with her eyes fixed on his, big and dark and bottomless. "I swore to serve the Dragon Reborn, and the best service I can give him now is to keep this animal from him. Bad enough that rulers know Masema supports him; worse if they see him embrace the man. And thousands will die if you fail - to get close enough to Masema to kill him."

pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ɪz hɛd wəd spɪn. əɡɛn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝld wɝdz əbaʊt laɪk ə tɑp, meɪɾ ɪt sim ʃi hæd sɛd blæk wən ʃi mɛnt waɪt. ðən ðə waɪz wʌnz æɾəd ðɛɹ bɪt.

Perrin thought his head would spin. Again an Aes Sedai whirled words about like a top, made it seem she had said black when she meant white. Then the Wise Ones added their bit.

"mɑsʊɝi soʊkɑwə," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd kɑmli, "bɪlivz ðə ɹæbɪd dɔɡ kən bi liʃt ən baʊn soʊ hi meɪ bi juz seɪfli." fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, siɑnɪd lʊkt əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz pɛɹɪn fɛlt, bʌt ʃi ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli. aʊtsaɪd, ʃi dɪd; hɝ sɛnt wɑz sʌɾənli wɛɹi, əz ɪf ʃi sɛnst ə tʃɹæp wɛɹ ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd wʌn.

"Masuri Sokawa," Nevarin said calmly, "believes the rabid dog can be leashed and bound so he may be used safely." For an instant, Seonid looked as surprised as Perrin felt, but she recovered quickly. Outside, she did; her scent was suddenly wary, as if she sensed a trap where she had not expected one.

"ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɪʃɪz tə fɪt jə fəɹ ə hɔltɝ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," kɛɹɛl æɾəd, ivən mɔɹ kæʒəwəli. "ʃi θɪŋks jə mʌs bi baʊn ɔlsoʊ, tə meɪk jə seɪf." nʌθɪŋ ɑn əɹ fɹɛkəl feɪs toʊld wɛðɝ ʃi əɡɹid.

"She also wishes to fit you for a halter, Perrin Aybara," Carelle added, even more casually. "She thinks you must be bound also, to make you safe." Nothing on her freckled face told whether she agreed.

ɛdʒɹə ɹeɪzd ə hæn təwɔɹd siɑnɪd. "ju meɪ ɡoʊ, naʊ. jəl nɑt lɪsən fɝðɝ, bʌt jə meɪ æsk ɡɝɑɾɪn əɡɛn tə lɛt jə hil ðə waʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf i stɪl ɹəfjuzəz, jə mʌst æksɛpt ɪt. hiz ɡeɪʃeɪn, nɑt wʌn ə jəɹ wɛtləndɝ sɝvəns." ʃi ɪnvɛstəd ðət læst wɝd wɪð dɛpθs ə skɔɹn.

Edarra raised a hand toward Seonid. "You may go, now. You will not listen further, but you may ask Gharadin again to let you Heal the wound on his face. Remember, if he still refuses, you must accept it. He is gai'shain, not one of your wetlander servants." She invested that last word with depths of scorn.

siɑnɪd stɛɹɾ aɪsi ɔɡɝz ət pɛɹɪn. ʃi lʊkt ət ðə waɪz wʌnz, hɝ lɪps tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə spitʃ. ɪn ði ɛnd, ðoʊ, ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz ɡoʊ wɪð əz ɡʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪs əz ʃi kəd mʌstɝ. aʊtwɝdli, ðət wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbəl, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ fɪt tə ʃeɪm ə kwin. bʌt ðə sɛnt ʃi tʃɹeɪl bɪhaɪn əɹ wɑz fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə kʌt.

Seonid stared icy augers at Perrin. She looked at the Wise Ones, her lips trembling on the brink of speech. In the end, though, all she could do was go with as good a grace as she could muster. Outwardly, that was considerable, an Aes Sedai being Aes Sedai fit to shame a queen. But the scent she trailed behind her was frustration sharp enough to cut.

əz sun əz ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, ðə sɪks waɪz wʌnz foʊkəst ɑn pɛɹɪn əɡɛn.

As soon as she was gone, the six Wise Ones focused on Perrin again.

"naʊ," ɛdʒɹə sɛd, "ju kən ɪkspleɪn tə əs waɪ jə wəd pʊɾ ə ɹæbɪɾ ænəməl nɛks tə ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn."

"Now," Edarra said, "you can explain to us why you would put a rabid animal next to the Car'a'carn."

"oʊnli ə ful oʊbeɪz ənʌðɝz kəmæn tə pʊʃ ɪm oʊvɝ ə klɪf," nəvɛɝɪn sɛd.

"Only a fool obeys another's command to push him over a cliff," Nevarin said.

"ju wɪl nɑt lɪsən tə ʌs," dʒəninə sɛd, "soʊ wɪl lɪsən tə ju. spik, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

"You will not listen to us," Janina said, "so we will listen to you. Speak, Perrin Aybara."

pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝd meɪkɪŋ ə bɹeɪk fəɹ ðə dɔɹflæps. bʌɾ ɪf i dɪd, hi wəd liv bɪhaɪnd wʌn ɛɛs sədaɪ hu maɪt pɑsəbli bi ʌv səm daʊtfəl hɛlp, ən ənʌðɝ, əlɔŋ wɪð sɪks waɪz wʌnz, hu wɝ ɔl sɛt tə ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ i hæd kʌm tə du. hi pʊɾ ɪz waɪnkʌp daʊn əɡɛn, ən sɛɾəld ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz niz. hi niɾəd ə klɪɹ hɛɾ ɪf i wɑz tə ʃoʊ ðiz wɪmən i wɑz noʊ tɛðɝd ɡoʊt.

Perrin considered making a break for the doorflaps. But if he did, he would leave behind one Aes Sedai who might possibly be of some doubtful help, and another, along with six Wise Ones, who were all set to ruin everything he had come to do. He put his winecup down again, and settled his hands on his knees. He needed a clear head if he was to show these women he was no tethered goat.

Changes

wən pɛɹɪn lɛf ðə waɪz wʌnz' tɛnt, hi kənsɪɾɝd ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz koʊt tə si wɛðɝ ɪz haɪd wɑz stɪl ətætʃt ən hoʊl. nɑɾ ə tɛðɝd ɡoʊt, meɪbi, bʌɾ ə stæɡ wɪð sɪks ʃi-wʊlvz ɑn ɪz hilz, ən i wɑz ənʃʊɹ wʌt fæs fit hæd ɡeɪn hɪm. fəɹ sɝɾən, nʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd tʃeɪnʒd əɹ maɪnd, ən ðɛɹ pɹɑməsəz nɑt tə teɪk ɛni ækʃən ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn hæd bɪn veɪɡ ət bɛst. əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ pɹɑməsəz, ivən fɑɡi wʌnz.

When Perrin left the Wise Ones' tent, he considered removing his coat to see whether his hide was still attached and whole. Not a tethered goat, maybe, but a stag with six she-wolves on his heels, and he was unsure what fast feet had gained him. For certain, none of the Wise Ones had changed her mind, and their promises not to take any action on their own had been vague at best. About the Aes Sedai, there had been no promises, even foggy ones.

hi lʊk fəɹ iðɝ ə ðə sɪstɝz, ən faʊn mɑsʊɝi. ə nɛɹoʊ ɹoʊp hæd bɪn taɪd bɪtwin tu tʃɹiz ən ə fɹɪn ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin ɹʌɡ dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ ɪt. ðə slɛndɝ bɹaʊn wɑz fleɪlɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ə bɛnt-wʊd biɾɝ, ɹeɪzɪŋ θɪn klaʊdz ə dʌs moʊts ðət floʊɾəd ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ sʌn. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, ə kɑmpæk mæn wɪð dɑɹk ɹɪsiɾɪŋ hɛɹ, sæɾ ɑn ə fɔlən tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk nɪɹbaɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌmli. ɹoʊvɛɹ kɝklɪn nɔɹməli hæɾ ə ɹɛɾi ɡɹɪn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɹid dip tədeɪ. mɑsʊɝi kɑt saɪɾ ə pɛɹɪn, ən wɪð bɛɹli ə pɔz ɪn əɹ ɹʌɡ-biɾɪŋ ʃɑɾ ɪm ə lʊk ə sətʃ fɹoʊzən mælɛvələns ðəɾ i saɪd. ən ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u θɔɾ əz i dɪd. əz kloʊs tə ɪɾ əz i wɑz laɪkli tə faɪnd, ɛniweɪ. ə ɹɛd-teɪl hɔk pæst oʊvɝhɛd, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɹaɪzɪŋ kɝəns ə hɑɾ ɛɹ fɹəm hɪl tə hɪl wɪθaʊt flæpɪŋ ɪts aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt wɪŋz. ɪt wəd bi vɛɹi naɪs tə sɔɹ əweɪ fɹəm ɔl ðɪs. ði aɪɝn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, nɑt dʒɹimz ə sɪlvɝ.

He looked for either of the sisters, and found Masuri. A narrow rope had been tied between two trees and a fringed red-and-green rug draped over it. The slender Brown was flailing away with a bent-wood beater, raising thin clouds of dust motes that floated glittering in the midmorning sun. Her Warder, a compact man with dark receding hair, sat on a fallen tree trunk nearby, watching her glumly. Rovair Kirklin normally had a ready grin, but it was buried deep today. Masuri caught sight of Perrin, and with barely a pause in her rug-beating shot him a look of such frozen malevolence that he sighed. And she was the one who thought as he did. As close to it as he was likely to find, anyway. A red-tailed hawk passed overhead, riding rising currents of hot air from hill to hill without flapping its outstretched wings. It would be very nice to soar away from all this. The iron in front of him, not dreams of silver.

nɑɾɪŋ tə səlɪn ən ðə meɪɾənz, hu maɪɾ əv teɪkən ɹuɾ ʌndɝ ðət lɛðɝlif, pɛɹɪn tɝn tə ɡoʊ, ən stɑpt. tu mɛn wɝ klaɪmɪŋ ðə hɪl, wʌn ən il ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪz ən bɹaʊnz ən ɡɹinz ə ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ, hɪz keɪs baʊ ɑn ɪz bæk, ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ən ɪz spɪɹz ən ɹaʊn haɪd bʌkəlɝ ɪn hænd. ɡɔl wɑz ə fɹɛnd, ən ði oʊnli mæn əmʌŋ ði il u dɪd nɑt wɛɹ waɪt. hɪz kəmpænjən, ə hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ɪn ə bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæɾ ən koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ʌv ə pleɪn dʌl ɡɹin, wɑz noʊ il. hi hæɾ ə fʊl kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, tu, ən ə naɪf ivən lɔŋɡɝ ən hɛviɝ ðən ði ilmənz, bʌɾ i kæɹiɾ ɪz baʊ, mʌtʃ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ə tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊ ðoʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə hɔɹn baʊz ə ði il. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz kloʊðz, hi dɪd nɑɾ əv ðə lʊk ʌv ə fɑɹmɝ, əɹ ə sɪɾi mæn iðɝ. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ taɪɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk ən hæŋɪŋ tə hɪz weɪst, ðə bɪɹd fænɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, əɹ pɝhæps dʒʌs ðə weɪ hi muvd, mʌtʃ laɪk ðə mæn əɾ ɪz saɪd, slɪpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə bɹʌʃ ɑn ðə hɪl soʊ ðət jə wɝ ʃʊɹ noʊ twɪɡ snæpt ɪn ɪz pæsɪŋ, noʊ widz bɹoʊk ʌndɝ ɪz fʊt. pɛɹɪn hæd nɑt sin ɪm ɪn wʌt simd ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm.

Nodding to Sulin and the Maidens, who might have taken root under that leatherleaf, Perrin turned to go, and stopped. Two men were climbing the hill, one an Aiel in the grays and browns and greens of the cadin'sor, his cased bow on his back, a bristling quiver at his belt, and his spears and round hide buckler in hand. Gaul was a friend, and the only man among the Aiel who did not wear white. His companion, a head shorter in a broad-brimmed hat and coat and breeches of a plain dull green, was no Aiel. He had a full quiver at his belt, too, and a knife even longer and heavier than the Aielman's, but he carried his bow, much shorter than a Two Rivers longbow though longer than the horn bows of the Aiel. Despite his clothes, he did not have the look of a farmer, or a city man either. Perhaps it was the graying hair tied at the nape of his neck and hanging to his waist, the beard fanning across his chest, or perhaps just the way he moved, much like the man at his side, slipping around the brush on the hill so that you were sure no twig snapped in his passing, no weeds broke under his foot. Perrin had not seen him in what seemed a very long time.

ɹitʃɪŋ ðə hɪltɑp, ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə ɹəɡɑɹɾəd pɛɹɪn, ɡoʊldən aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ feɪnli ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ɪz hæt bɹɪm. hɪz aɪz hæd bɪn ðət weɪ jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪnz; ɛlaɪəs hæɾ ɪntʃɹədus pɛɹɪn tə ðə wʊlvz. hi hæd bɪn dʒɹɛst ɪn haɪdz, ðɛn. "ɡʊd tə si jə əɡɛn, bɔɪ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. swɛt ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz feɪs, bʌt lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ɑn ɡɔlz. "ju ɡɪv əweɪ ðəɾ æks, faɪnəli? aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk juɾ ɛvɝ stɑp heɪɾɪŋ ɪt."

Reaching the hilltop, Elyas Machera regarded Perrin, golden eyes shining faintly in the shadow of his hat brim. His eyes had been that way years before Perrin's; Elyas had introduced Perrin to the wolves. He had been dressed in hides, then. "Good to see you again, boy," he said quietly. Sweat glistened on his face, but little more than on Gaul's. "You give away that axe, finally? I didn't think you'd ever stop hating it."

"aɪ stɪl du," pɛɹɪn sɛd dʒʌst əz kwaɪətli. ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ ðə wʌntaɪm wɔɹɾɝ hæd toʊld ɪm tə kip ði æks əntɪl i stɑp heɪɾɪŋ tə juz ɪt. laɪt, bʌɾ i stɪl heɪɾəd ɪt! ən i hæɾ æɾəd nu ɹizənz, naʊ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ ɪn ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝld, ɛlaɪəs? wɛɹ dɪd ɡɔl faɪn ju?"

"I still do," Perrin said just as quietly. A long time ago the onetime Warder had told him to keep the axe until he stopped hating to use it. Light, but he still hated it! And he had added new reasons, now. "What are you doing in this part of the world, Elyas? Where did Gaul find you?"

"hi faʊn mi," ɡɔl sɛd. "aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hi wɑz bɪhaɪn mi əntɪl i kɔft." hi spoʊk laʊdli ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd baɪ ðə meɪɾənz, ən ðə sʌɾən stɪlnəs əmʌŋ əm wɑz sɑləɾ əz ə tʌtʃ.

"He found me," Gaul said. "I did not know he was behind me until he coughed." He spoke loudly enough to be heard by the Maidens, and the sudden stillness among them was solid as a touch.

pɛɹɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ət list ə fju kʌɾɪŋ kɑmɛns - il hjumɝ kəd nɪɹ dʒɹɔ blʌd, ən ðə meɪɾənz sizd ɛni tʃæns tə dɪɡ ət ðə ɡɹin-aɪd mæn - bʌɾ ɪnstɛd, səm ə ðə wɪmən tʊk ʌp spɪɹz ən bʌklɝz tə ɹæɾəl əm təɡɛðɝ ɪn æpɹəbeɪʃən. ɡɔl nɑɾəd əpɹuvəl.

Perrin expected at least a few cutting comments - Aiel humor could near draw blood, and the Maidens seized any chance to dig at the green-eyed man - but instead, some of the women took up spears and bucklers to rattle them together in approbation. Gaul nodded approval.

ɛlaɪəs ɡɹʌntɪɾ æmbɪɡjuəsli ən tʌɡd ɪz hæt daʊn, jɛɾ i smɛl plizd. ði il dɪd nɑɾ əpɹuv ə mʌtʃ ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl. "aɪ laɪk tə kip muvɪŋ," hi toʊl pɛɹɪn, "æn aɪ dʒʌs hæpən tə bi ɪn ɡildən wən səm mjutʃəwəl fɹɛnz toʊl mi jə wɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ðɪs pɝeɪd." hi dɪd nɑt neɪm ðə mjutʃəwəl fɹɛnz; ɪt wɑz ənwaɪz tə spik oʊpənli əbaʊt tɔkɪŋ tə wʊlvz. "toʊl mi ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz. toʊl mi ðeɪ smɛl ə tʃeɪnʒ kʌmɪŋ. ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt. meɪbi jə du. aɪ hɪɹ juv bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

Elyas grunted ambiguously and tugged his hat down, yet he smelled pleased. The Aiel did not approve of much this side of the Dragonwall. "I like to keep moving," he told Perrin, "and I just happened to be in Ghealdan when some mutual friends told me you were traveling with this parade." He did not name the mutual friends; it was unwise to speak openly about talking to wolves. "Told me a lot of things. Told me they smell a change coming. They don't know what. Maybe you do. I hear you've been running with the Dragon Reborn."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd sloʊli. ə tʃeɪnʒ? hi hæd nɑt θɔt tə æsk ðə wʊlvz ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən wɛɹ lɑɹdʒ ɡɹups ə mɛn wɝ, soʊ hi kəd ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ivən hɪɹ ɪn ɡildən, səmtaɪmz i fɛl bleɪm əmʌŋ əm fəɹ ðə wʊlvz dɛɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. wʌt kaɪndə tʃeɪnʒ? "ɹæn ɪz ʃʊɹli tʃeɪnʒɪŋ θɪŋz, bʌɾ aɪ kʊdn seɪ wʌt ðeɪ min. laɪt, ðə hoʊl wɝld ɪz tɝnɪŋ sʌmɝsɔls, ən nɛvɝ maɪn hɪm."

"I don't know," Perrin said slowly. A change? He had not thought to ask the wolves anything more than where large groups of men were, so he could go around them. Even here in Ghealdan, sometimes he felt blame among them for the wolves dead at Dumai's Wells. What kind of change? "Rand is surely changing things, but I couldn't say what they mean. Light, the whole world is turning somersaults, and never mind him."

"ɔl θɪŋz tʃeɪnʒ," ɡɔl sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. "əntɪl wi weɪk, ðə dʒɹim dʒɹɪfs ɑn ðə wɪnd." fəɹ ə moʊmən i stʌɾid pɛɹɪn ən ɛlaɪəs, kəmpɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm, ðoʊ; ði il sim tə teɪk ɡoʊldən aɪz əz dʒʌst wʌn mɔɹ pɪkjuliɛɹəɾi əmʌŋ wɛtləndɝz. "aɪ wɪl liv jə tu tə tɔk əloʊn. fɹɛnz lɔŋ sɛpɝeɪɾəd nid tə tɔk baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz. səlɪn, ɑɹ kiæɾ ən beɪn əbaʊt? aɪ sɔ ðɛm hʌntɪŋ jɛstɝdeɪ, ən θɔɾ aɪ maɪt ʃoʊ ðɛm haʊ tə dʒɹɔ ə baʊ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðɛm ʃuts hɝsɛlf."

"All things change," Gaul said dismissively. "Until we wake, the dream drifts on the wind." For a moment he studied Perrin and Elyas, comparing their eyes, Perrin was sure. He said nothing about them, though; the Aiel seemed to take golden eyes as just one more peculiarity among wetlanders. "I will leave you two to talk alone. Friends long separated need to talk by themselves. Sulin, are Chiad and Bain about? I saw them hunting yesterday, and thought I might show them how to draw a bow before one of them shoots herself."

"aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si jə kʌm bæk tədeɪ," ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd. "ðeɪ wɛn aʊt tə sɛt snɛɹz fəɹ ɹæbəts." læftɝ ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə meɪɾənz, ən fɪŋɡɝz flɪkɝd ɹæpədli ɪn hæntɔk.

"I was surprised to see you come back today," the white-haired woman replied. "They went out to set snares for rabbits." Laughter rippled through the Maidens, and fingers flickered rapidly in handtalk.

saɪɪŋ, ɡɔl ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz ɑstənteɪʃəsli. "ɪn ðət keɪs, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ kʌɾ əm lus." ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni meɪɾənz læft ət ðæt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səlɪn. "meɪ jə faɪnd ʃeɪd ðɪs deɪ," hi toʊl pɛɹɪn, ə kæʒəwəl fɛɹwɛl bɪtwin fɹɛnz, bʌɾ i klæsp fɹɑɹmz fɔɹməli wɪð ɛlaɪəs ən sɛd, "maɪ ɑnɝ ɪz jʊɹz, ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə."

Sighing, Gaul rolled his eyes ostentatiously. "In that case, I think I must go cut them loose." Almost as many Maidens laughed at that, including Sulin. "May you find shade this day," he told Perrin, a casual farewell between friends, but he clasped forearms formally with Elyas and said, "My honor is yours, Elyas Machera."

"ɑd fɛloʊ," ɛlaɪəs mɝmɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ ɡɔl loʊp bæk daʊn ðə hɪl. "wɛn aɪ kɔft, hi tɝn ɝaʊn ɹɛɾi tə kɪl mi, aɪ θɪŋk, ðən i dʒʌst stɑɹɾəd læfɪŋ ɪnstɛd. juv ɛni əbdʒɛkʃənz tə ɡoʊɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls? aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðə sɪstɝ huz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mɝɾɝ ðət ɹʌɡ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn laɪk teɪkɪŋ tʃænsəz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ." hɪz aɪz nɛɹoʊd. "ɡɔl sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ θɹi wɪð ju. jə doʊn ɪkspɛk tə bi miɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð ɛni mɔɹ, də ju?"

"Odd fellow," Elyas murmured, watching Gaul lope back down the hill. "When I coughed, he turned around ready to kill me, I think, then he just started laughing instead. You have any objections to going somewhere else? I don't know the sister who's trying to murder that rug, but I don't like taking chances with Aes Sedai." His eyes narrowed. "Gaul says there are three with you. You don't expect to be meeting up with any more, do you?"

"aɪ hoʊp nɑt," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. mɑsʊɝi wɑz ɡlænsɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ bɪtwin slæʃɪz wɪð ðə biɾɝ; ʃi wəd lɝn əbaʊɾ ɛlaɪəs' aɪz sun ɪnʌf ən stɑɹt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɛɹəɾ aʊt wʌɾ ɛls lɪŋkt ɪm tə pɛɹɪn. "kʌm ɑn; ɪts taɪm aɪ wɑz bæk ɪn maɪ oʊn kæmp ɛniweɪ. ɑɹ jə wɝiɾ əbaʊt miɾɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu noʊz ju?" ɛlaɪəs' deɪz əz ə wɔɹɾɝ hæɾ ɛndəd wən ɪt wɑz lɝn i kəd tɔk tə wʊlvz. səm sɪstɝz θɔɾ ɪɾ ə mɑɹk ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən i hæd hæd tə kɪl ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ.

"I hope not," Perrin replied. Masuri was glancing their way between slashes with the beater; she would learn about Elyas' eyes soon enough and start trying to ferret out what else linked him to Perrin. "Come on; it's time I was back in my own camp anyway. Are you worried about meeting an Aes Sedai who knows you?" Elyas' days as a Warder had ended when it was learned he could talk to wolves. Some sisters thought it a mark of the Dark One, and he had had to kill other Warders to get away.

ði oʊldɝ mæn weɪɾəd əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ə dʌzən peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə tɛns bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪplaɪd, ən ivən ðɛn, hi spoʊk kwaɪətli, əz ðoʊ hi səspɛktəd sʌmwʌn bɪhaɪn əm maɪɾ əv ɪɹz əz ɡʊɾ əz ðɛɹz. "wʌn u noʊz maɪ neɪm wɪl bi bæɾ ɪnʌf. wɔɹɾɝz doʊn ɹʌn ɔf ɔfən, bɔɪ. moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl fɹi ə mæn u ɹɪli wɑns tə ɡoʊ - moʊst wɪl - ən ɛniweɪ, ʃi kən tʃɹæk jə daʊn haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ jə ɹʌn ɪf ʃi dɪsaɪdz tə hʌnt. bʌɾ ɛni sɪstɝ u faɪnz ə ɹɛnəɡeɪd wɪl spɛn əɹ aɪɾəl moʊməns meɪkɪŋ ɪm wɪʃ hid nɛvɝ bɪn bɔɹn." hi ʃɪvɝd slaɪtli. hɪz smɛl wɑz nɑt fɪɹ, bʌɾ æntɪsəpeɪʃən ə peɪn. "ðɛn ʃɪl tɝn ɪm oʊvɝ tə hɪz oʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ tə dʒɹaɪv ðə lɛsən hoʊm. ə mænz nɛvɝ kwaɪt ðə seɪm æftɝ ðæt." ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə sloʊp, hi lʊk bæk. mɑsʊɝi dɪd sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ðə kɑɹpət, foʊkəsɪŋ ɔl əɹ ɹeɪdʒ ɑn ətɛmptɪŋ tə biɾ ə hoʊl θɹu ɪt. ɛlaɪəs ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn, ðoʊ. "wɝs θɪŋ wəd bi tə ɹʌn ɪndə ɹinə. aɪd ɹæðɝ bi kɑɾ ɪn ə fɔɹəs faɪɝ wɪð boʊθ lɛɡz bɹoʊkən."

The older man waited until they were a dozen paces from the tents before he replied, and even then, he spoke quietly, as though he suspected someone behind them might have ears as good as theirs. "One who knows my name will be bad enough. Warders don't run off often, boy. Most Aes Sedai will free a man who really wants to go - most will - and anyway, she can track you down however far you run if she decides to hunt. But any sister who finds a renegade will spend her idle moments making him wish he'd never been born." He shivered slightly. His smell was not fear, but anticipation of pain. "Then she'll turn him over to his own Aes Sedai to drive the lesson home. A man's never quite the same after that." At the edge of the slope, he looked back. Masuri did seem to be trying to kill the carpet, focusing all her rage on attempting to beat a hole through it. Elyas shivered again, though. "Worse thing would be to run into Rina. I'd rather be caught in a forest fire with both legs broken."

"ɹinəz jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ? bʌt haʊ kəd jə ɹʌn ɪndə hɝ? ðə bɑn lɛts jə noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz." ðət nʌdʒ sʌmθɪŋ ɪn pɛɹɪnz mɛmɹi, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz mɛltəɾ əweɪ əɾ ɛlaɪəs' ɹɪplaɪ.

"Rina's your Aes Sedai? But how could you run into her? The bond lets you know where she is." That nudged something in Perrin's memory, but whatever it was melted away at Elyas' reply.

"ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ kən fʌz ðə bɑnd, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. meɪbi ðeɪ ɔl kæn. jə doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ʃiz stɪl əlaɪv, ən aɪ noʊ ðəɾ ɛniweɪ, kəz aɪ hævənt ɡɔn kɹeɪzi." ɛlaɪəs sɔ ðə kwɛstʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs ən bɑɹkt ə læf. "laɪt, mæn, ə sɪstɝz flɛʃ-ænd-blʌd, tu. moʊst ɑɹ. θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt. wəd jə wɑn sʌmbɑɾi ɪnsaɪd jəɹ hɛd waɪl jə kʌɾəld ʌp wɪð ə laɪkli wɛnk? sɑɹi; aɪ fɝɡɑt jə wɝ mɛɹid, naʊ. noʊ əfɛns mɛnt. aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə hɪɹ jud mɛɹiɾ ə sɑldəiən, ðoʊ."

"A fair number can fuzz the bond, in a manner of speaking. Maybe they all can. You don't know much more than she's still alive, and I know that anyway, because I haven't gone crazy." Elyas saw the question on his face and barked a laugh. "Light, man, a sister's flesh-and-blood, too. Most are. Think about it. Would you want somebody inside your head while you cuddled up with a likely wench? Sorry; I forgot you were married, now. No offense meant. I was surprised to hear you'd married a Saldaean, though."

"sɝpɹaɪzd?" pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd ðəɾ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd. laɪt! fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət weɪ. ɪt simd əbaʊɾ əz pɑsəbəl əz . . . əz ə mæn tɔkɪŋ tə wʊlvz. "waɪ sɝpɹaɪzd?" ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd daʊn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl, nɑt hɝiɪŋ ən meɪkɪŋ lɪɾəl nɔɪz. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə ɡʊd hʌntɝ, əkʌstəm tə ðə fɔɹəsts, ən ɛlaɪəs hɑɹdli dɪstɝb ðə livz ʌndɝfʊt, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ smuðli θɹu ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ wɪθaʊt ʃɪftɪŋ ə bɹæntʃ. hi maɪɾ əv slʌŋ ɪz baʊ ɑn ɪz bæk naʊ, bʌɾ i stɪl kæɹiɾ ɪt ɹɛɾi. ɛlaɪəs wɑz ə wɛɹi mæn, ɪspɛʃli ɝaʊn pipəl.

"Surprised?" Perrin had never considered that about the Warder bond. Light! For that matter, he had never really thought about Aes Sedai that way. It seemed about as possible as . . . as a man talking to wolves. "Why surprised?" They started down through the trees on this side of the hill, not hurrying and making little noise. Perrin had always been a good hunter, accustomed to the forests, and Elyas hardly disturbed the leaves underfoot, gliding smoothly through the undergrowth without shifting a branch. He might have slung his bow on his back now, but he still carried it ready. Elyas was a wary man, especially around people.

"waɪ, kəz jəɹ ə kwaɪət sɔɹt, ən aɪ θɔt jud mɛɹi sʌmbɑɾi kwaɪət, tu. wɛl, jə noʊ baɪ naʊ sɑldəiənz ɑɹən kwaɪət. ɪksɛpt wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ən aʊtsaɪɾɝz. sɛt ðə sʌn ɑn faɪɝ wʌn mɪnət, ən ðə nɛkst, ɪts ɔl bloʊn əweɪ ən fɝɡɑɾən. meɪk ɝæfɛlɪn lʊk stɑləɾ ən dəmɑni daʊnɹaɪt dʌl." ɛlaɪəs ɡɹɪn sʌɾənli. "aɪ lɪvd ə jɪɹ wɪð ə sɑldəiən, wʌns, ən mɛɹiə ʃaʊɾəd maɪ ɪɹz ɔf faɪv deɪz ɪn ðə wik, ən meɪbi hiv ðə dɪʃəz ət maɪ hɛd, tu. ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ θɔɾ əbaʊt livɪŋ, ðoʊ, ʃid wɑnə meɪk ʌp, ən aɪ nɛvɝ sim tə ɡɛt tə ðə dɔɹ. ɪn ði ɛnd, ʃi lɛf mi. sɛɾ aɪ wɑz tu ɹistʃɹeɪn fəɹ əɹ teɪst." hɪz ɹæspɪŋ læf wɑz ɹɛmənɪsənt, bʌɾ i ɹʌbd əɾ ə feɪnt, eɪdʒ-feɪɾəd skɑɹ əlɔŋ ɪz dʒɔ ɹɛmənɪsənli, tu. ɪt lʊk tə hæv bɪn meɪd baɪ ə naɪf.

"Why, because you're a quiet sort, and I thought you'd marry somebody quiet, too. Well, you know by now Saldaeans aren't quiet. Except with strangers and outsiders. Set the sun on fire one minute, and the next, it's all blown away and forgotten. Make Arafellin look stolid and Domani downright dull." Elyas grinned suddenly. "I lived a year with a Saldaean, once, and Merya shouted my ears off five days in the week, and maybe heaved the dishes at my head, too. Every time I thought about leaving, though, she'd want to make up, and I never seemed to get to the door. In the end, she left me. Said I was too restrained for her taste." His rasping laugh was reminiscent, but he rubbed at a faint, age-faded scar along his jaw reminiscently, too. It looked to have been made by a knife.

"feɪlz nɑt laɪk ðæt." ɪt saʊndəd laɪk biɪŋ mɛɹid tə nɪneɪiv! nɪneɪiv wɪð sɔɹ tiθ! "aɪ doʊn min ʃi dʌznt ɡɛɾ æŋɡɹi naʊ ən ðɛn," hi ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, "bʌt ʃi dʌznt ʃaʊɾ ən θɹoʊ θɪŋz." wɛl, ʃi dɪd nɑt ʃaʊt vɛɹi ɔfən, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə flɛɹɪŋ hɑɾ ən vænɪʃɪŋ, hɝ æŋɡɝ stɑɹɾəd hɑɾ ən dʒɹæɡd ɑn tɪl ɪt tɝn koʊld.

"Faile's not like that." It sounded like being married to Nynaeve! Nynaeve with sore teeth! "I don't mean she doesn't get angry now and then," he admitted reluctantly, "but she doesn't shout and throw things." Well, she did not shout very often, and instead of flaring hot and vanishing, her anger started hot and dragged on till it turned cold.

ɛlaɪəs ɡlænst əɾ ɪm saɪdweɪz. "ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ smɛld ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɑdʒ heɪl. . . . juv bɪn ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ sɑft wɝdz ɔl ðə taɪm, hævən ju? maɪld əz mɪlk-wɔɾɝ ən nɛvɝ leɪ jəɹ ɪɹz bæk? nɛvɝ ɹeɪz jəɹ vɔɪs tə hɝ?"

Elyas glanced at him sideways. "If I ever smelled a man trying to dodge hail. . . . You've been giving her soft words all the time, haven't you? Mild as milk-water and never lay your ears back? Never raise your voice to her?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt!" pɛɹɪn pɹətɛstəd. "aɪ lʌv hɝ! waɪ wəɾ aɪ ʃaʊɾ ət hɝ?"

"Of course not!" Perrin protested. "I love her! Why would I shout at her?"

ɛlaɪəs bɪɡæn mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn kəd hɪɹ ɛvɹi wɝd, ʌv kɔɹs. "bɝn mi, ə mæn wɑns tə sɪɾ ɑn ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ, ɪts ɪz əfɛɹ. nɑt maɪ bɪznəs ɪf ə mæn wɑns tə wɔɹm ɪz hænz wən ðə ɹufs ɑn faɪɝ. ɪts ɪz laɪf. wɪl i θæŋk mi? noʊ, hi blʌɾi wɛl woʊnt!"

Elyas began muttering under his breath, though Perrin could hear every word, of course. "Burn me, a man wants to sit on a red adder, it's his affair. Not my business if a man wants to warm his hands when the roof's on fire. It's his life. Will he thank me? No, he bloody well won't!"

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əbaʊt?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəd. kætʃɪŋ ɛlaɪəs' ɑɹm, hi pʊld ɪm tə ə stɑp bɪniθ ə wɪntɝbɛɹi tʃɹi, ɪts pɹɪkli livz stɪl moʊsli ɡɹin. lɪɾəl ɛls nɪɹbaɪ wɑz, ɪksɛp fəɹ səm stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ kɹipɝz. ðeɪ hæd kʌm lɛs ðən hæfweɪ daʊn ðə hɪl. "feɪl ɪzən ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ əɹ ə ɹuf ɑn faɪɝ! weɪɾ əntɪl jə miɾ əɹ bɪfɔɹ jə stɑɹt tɔkɪŋ laɪk jə noʊ hɝ."

"What are you going on about?" Perrin demanded. Catching Elyas' arm, he pulled him to a stop beneath a winterberry tree, its prickly leaves still mostly green. Little else nearby was, except for some struggling creepers. They had come less than halfway down the hill. "Faile isn't a red adder or a roof on fire! Wait until you meet her before you start talking like you know her."

ɪɹɪɾəbli, ɛlaɪəs ɹeɪk fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz lɔŋ bɪɹd. "aɪ noʊ sɑldəiənz, bɔɪ. ðət jɪɹ wɑzn ði oʊnli taɪm aɪv bɪn ðɛɹ. aɪv oʊnli ɛvɝ mɛɾ əbaʊt faɪv sɑldəiən wɪmən aɪd kɔl mik, əɹ ivən maɪld-mænɝd. noʊ, ʃi ɪzən ən æɾɝ; wʌt ʃiz ɪz ə lɛpɝd, əl weɪdʒɝ. doʊnt ɡɹaʊl, bɝn ju! əl bɛt maɪ buts ʃid smaɪl tə hɪɹ mi seɪ ɪt!"

Irritably, Elyas raked fingers through his long beard. "I know Saldaeans, boy. That year wasn't the only time I've been there. I've only ever met about five Saldaean women I'd call meek, or even mild-mannered. No, she isn't an adder; what she is is a leopard, I'll wager. Don't growl, burn you! I'll bet my boots she'd smile to hear me say it!"

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, ðən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn. hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd i wɑz ɡɹoʊlɪŋ dip ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. feɪl wəd smaɪl ət biɪŋ kɔld ə lɛpɝd. "ju kæn bi seɪɪŋ ʃi wɑns mi tə ʃaʊɾ ət hɝ, ɛlaɪəs."

Perrin opened his mouth angrily, then closed it again. He had not realized he was growling deep in his throat. Faile would smile at being called a leopard. "You can't be saying she wants me to shout at her, Elyas."

"jɛs, aɪ æm. moʊs laɪkli, ɛniweɪ. meɪbi ʃiz ðə sɪksθ. meɪbi. dʒʌs hɪɹ mi aʊt. moʊst wɪmən, jə ɹeɪz jəɹ vɔɪs, ən ðeɪ ɡoʊ bʌlʒ-aɪd əɹ aɪs, ən nɛks θɪŋ jə noʊ, jəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əbaʊt jə biɪŋ æŋɡɹi, nɛvɝ maɪnd wʌt pʊt ði ɪmbɝ daʊn jəɹ bæk ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. swɑloʊ jəɹ tʌŋ wɪð ə sɑldəiən, ðoʊ, ən tə hɝ, jəɹ seɪɪŋ ʃi ɪzən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stæn ʌp tə ju. ɪnsʌlt əɹ laɪk ðæt, ən jəɹ lʌki ʃi dʌzn fid jə jəɹ oʊn ɡɪzɝd fəɹ bɹɛkfəst. ʃiz noʊ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɛnk, tə ɪkspɛkt ə mæn tə sɪt wɛɹ ʃi pɔɪns ən dʒʌmp wən ʃi snæps əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃiz ə lɛpɝd, ən ʃi ɪkspɛks əɹ hʌzbən tə bi ə lɛpɝd, tu. laɪt! aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ. ɡɪvɪŋ ə mæn ædvaɪs əbaʊɾ ɪz waɪf ɪz ə ɡʊd weɪ tə ɡɛt jəɹ ɪnɝdz spɪld."

"Yes, I am. Most likely, anyway. Maybe she's the sixth. Maybe. Just hear me out. Most women, you raise your voice, and they go bulge-eyed or ice, and next thing you know, you're arguing about you being angry, never mind what put the ember down your back in the first place. Swallow your tongue with a Saldaean, though, and to her, you're saying she isn't strong enough to stand up to you. Insult her like that, and you're lucky she doesn't feed you your own gizzard for breakfast. She's no Far Madding wench, to expect a man to sit where she points and jump when she snaps her fingers. She's a leopard, and she expects her husband to be a leopard, too. Light! I don't know what I'm doing. Giving a man advice about his wife is a good way to get your innards spilled."

ɪt wɑz ɛlaɪəs' tɝn tə ɡɹaʊl. hi dʒɝkt ɪz hæt stʃɹeɪɾ ənnɛsəsɛɹəli ən lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə sloʊp fɹaʊnɪŋ, əz ðoʊ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə vænɪʃ bæk ɪndə ðə fɔɹəsts, ðən poʊkt ə fɪŋɡɝ ət pɛɹɪn. "lʊk hɪɹ. aɪ ɔlweɪz nu jə wɝ mɔɹ ðən ə stʃɹeɪ, ən pʊɾɪŋ wʌt ðə wʊlvz toʊl mi təɡɛðɝ wɪð jə dʒʌs hæpənɪŋ tə bi hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɪs pɹɑfət fɛloʊ, aɪ θɔt meɪbi jə kəd juz ə fɹɛn tə wɑtʃ jəɹ bæk. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə wʊlvz dɪdn mɛnʃən jə wɝ liɾɪŋ ðoʊz pɹɪɾi minɝ lænsɝz. niðɝ dɪd ɡɔl, tɪl wi sɔ ðɛm. ɪf jud laɪk mi tə steɪ, aɪ wɪl. ɪf nɑt, ðɛɹz plɛnti ʌv ðə wɝld aɪ hævən sin jɛt."

It was Elyas' turn to growl. He jerked his hat straight unnecessarily and looked around the slope frowning, as though considering whether to vanish back into the forests, then poked a finger at Perrin. "Look here. I always knew you were more than a stray, and putting what the wolves told me together with you just happening to be heading toward this Prophet fellow, I thought maybe you could use a friend to watch your back. Of course, the wolves didn't mention you were leading those pretty Mayener lancers. Neither did Gaul, till we saw them. If you'd like me to stay, I will. If not, there's plenty of the world I haven't seen yet."

"aɪ kən ɔlweɪz juz ənʌðɝ fɹɛnd, ɛlaɪəs." kəd feɪl ɹɪli wɑn ɪm tə ʃaʊt? hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn i maɪt hɝt sʌmbɑɾi ɪf i wɑz nɑt kɛɹfəl, ən i ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə kip ə taɪt ɹeɪn ɑn ɪz tɛmpɝ. wɝdz kəd hɝɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz fɪsts, ðə ɹɔŋ wɝdz, wɝdz jə nɛvɝ mɛnt, lɛt lus ɪn ə tɛmpɝ. ɪt hæd tə bi ɪmpɑsəbəl. ɪt dʒʌst stʊd tə ɹizən. noʊ wʊmən wəd stæn fəɹ ðæt, fɹəm əɹ hʌzbən əɹ ɛni mæn.

"I can always use another friend, Elyas." Could Faile really want him to shout? He had always known he might hurt somebody if he was not careful, and he always tried to keep a tight rein on his temper. Words could hurt as hard as fists, the wrong words, words you never meant, let loose in a temper. It had to be impossible. It just stood to reason. No woman would stand for that, from her husband or any man.

ə blufɪntʃəz kɔl bɹɔt pɛɹɪnz hɛɾ ʌp, ɪɹz pɹɪkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ət ði ɛdʒ ə hɪɹɪŋ ivən fəɹ hɪm, bʌɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ ðə tʃɹɪl wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪd kloʊsɝ, ðən əɡɛn, nɪɹɝ stɪl. ɛlaɪəs kɑkt ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm; hi wəd noʊ ðə kɔl ʌv ə bɔɹɾɝlənd bɝd. pɛɹɪn hæd lɝn ɪt fɹəm səm ʃaɪnɝənz, mæsimə əmʌŋ ðɛm, ən tɔt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn.

A bluefinch's call brought Perrin's head up, ears pricking. It was just at the edge of hearing even for him, but a moment later the trill was repeated closer, then again, nearer still. Elyas cocked an eyebrow at him; he would know the call of a Borderland bird. Perrin had learned it from some Shienarans, Masema among them, and taught the Two Rivers men.

"wi hæv vɪzəɾɝz kʌmɪŋ," hi toʊld ɛlaɪəs.

"We have visitors coming," he told Elyas.

ðeɪ keɪm kwɪkli, fɔɹ ɹaɪɾɝz əɾ ə fæs kæntɝ, ɝaɪvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ən ɛlaɪəs ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɪl. bɹəleɪn lɛd ðə weɪ, splæʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹim wɪð ənʊɹə ən ɡælɛn kloʊs bɪhaɪn ən ə wʊmən ɪn ə peɪl, hʊɾɪd dʌst-kloʊk əɾ əɹ saɪd. ðeɪ swɛpt ɹaɪt baɪ ðə minɝ kæmp wɪθaʊɾ ə ɡlæns, nɑt dʒɹɔɪŋ ɹeɪn əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt stʃɹaɪp tɛnt. səm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn sɝvəns ɹʌʃt tə teɪk bɹaɪɾəlz ən hoʊl stɝəps, ən bɹəleɪn ən əɹ kəmpænjənz wɝ ɪnsaɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə dʌst ə ðɛɹ ɝaɪvəl sɛɾəld.

They came quickly, four riders at a fast canter, arriving before he and Elyas reached the bottom of the hill. Berelain led the way, splashing across the stream with Annoura and Gallenne close behind and a woman in a pale, hooded dust-cloak at her side. They swept right by the Mayener camp without a glance, not drawing rein until they were in front of the red-and-white striped tent. Some of the Cairhienin servants rushed to take bridles and hold stirrups, and Berelain and her companions were inside before the dust of their arrival settled.

ɔl ɪn ɔl, ði ɝaɪvəl kɹieɪɾəd kwaɪɾ ə stɝ. ə bʌz ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ðət pɛɹɪn kəɾ oʊnli kɔl æntɪsəpətɔɹi. ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl ɡæðɝɪŋ ə feɪlz jʌŋ fulz skɹætʃt ðɛɹ hɛdz ən stɛɹɾ ət ðə tɛnt, tʃæɾɝɪŋ ɪksaɪɾədli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild wɑtʃt ðə tɛn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, tu, naʊ ən ðən linɪŋ təɡɛðɝ tə tɔk ðoʊ noʊbɑdi wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ sɛd.

All in all, the arrival created quite a stir. A buzz rose among the Two Rivers men that Perrin could only call anticipatory. The inevitable gathering of Faile's young fools scratched their heads and stared at the tent, chattering excitedly among themselves. Grady and Neald watched the tent through the trees, too, now and then leaning together to talk though nobody was close enough to hear anything they said.

"lʊks laɪk jəɹ vɪzəɾɝz ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən kæʒəwəl," ɛlaɪəs sɛd kwaɪətli. "wɑtʃ ɡælɛn; hi kəd bi tʃɹʌbəl."

"Looks like your visitors are more than casual," Elyas said quietly. "Watch Gallenne; he could be trouble."

"ju noʊ hɪm, ɛlaɪəs? aɪd laɪk jə tə steɪ, bʌɾ ɪf jə θɪŋk i maɪt tɛl wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz u jə ɑɹ. . . ." pɛɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd ɪn ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən. "aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə stɑp siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi" - hi θɔɾ i kəd - "bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ənʊɹə wɪl də wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑns." ən wʌd ʃi ɹɪli θɪŋk əbaʊt mæsimə?

"You know him, Elyas? I'd like you to stay, but if you think he might tell one of the sisters who you are. . . ." Perrin shrugged in resignation. "I might be able to stop Seonid and Masuri" - he thought he could - "but I think Annoura will do whatever she wants." And what did she really think about Masema?

"oʊ, bɝteɪn ɡælɛn dʌznt noʊ ðə laɪks ʌv ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə ɹaɪ ɡɹɪn. " 'mɔɹ fulz noʊ dʒæk ful ðən dʒæk ful noʊz.' aɪ noʊ hɪm, ðoʊ. hi woʊnt ɡoʊ əɡɛns jə əɹ bɪhaɪn jəɹ bæk, bʌt bɹəleɪn əz ðə bɹeɪnz bɪtwin ðɛm. ʃiz kɛp tɛɹ aʊɾ ə min baɪ pleɪɪŋ ðə tɛɹənz əɡɛns ði ɪliɑnɝz sɪns ʃi wɑz sɪkstin. bɹəleɪn noʊz haʊ tə mənuvɝ; ɔl ɡælɛn noʊz ɪz ətæk. hiz ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪt, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ siz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ən səmtaɪmz i dʌzn stɑp tə θɪŋk."

"Oh, Bertain Gallenne doesn't know the likes of Elyas Machera," Elyas replied with a wry grin. " 'More fools know Jak Fool than Jak Fool knows.' I know him, though. He won't go against you or behind your back, but Berelain has the brains between them. She's kept Tear out of Mayene by playing the Tairens against the Illianers since she was sixteen. Berelain knows how to maneuver; all Gallenne knows is attack. He's good at it, but he never sees anything else, and sometimes he doesn't stop to think."

"aɪd fɪɡjɝd ðəɾ aʊɾ əbaʊt boʊθ ə ðɛm," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. ət lis bɹəleɪn hæd bɹɔɾ ə mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm æliændɝ. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv kʌm ɹʌʃɪŋ ɪn ðət weɪ wɪð ə nu meɪd. ði oʊnli kwɛstʃən wɑz waɪ æliændɝz ɹɪplaɪ niɾəd ə mɛsənʒɝ. "aɪ hæd bɛs faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ðə nuz ɪz ɡʊd, ɛlaɪəs. leɪɾɝ, wɪl tɔk əbaʊt wʌt laɪz saʊθ. ən jə kən mit feɪl," hi æɾəd bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əweɪ.

"I'd figured that out about both of them," Perrin muttered. At least Berelain had brought a messenger from Alliandre. She would not have come rushing in that way with a new maid. The only question was why Alliandre's reply needed a messenger. "I had best find out whether the news is good, Elyas. Later, we'll talk about what lies south.
