And you can meet Faile," he added before turning away.

"ðə pɪɾ ə dum laɪz saʊθ," ði ʌðɝ mæn kɔld æftɝ hɪm, "ɔɹ əz kloʊs tə ɪɾ əz aɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə si bɪloʊ ðə blaɪt." pɛɹɪn ɪmædʒən i hɝd ðət feɪn θʌndɝ ɪn ðə wɛst əɡɛn. naʊ, ðət wəd bi ə plɛzən tʃeɪnʒ.

"The Pit of Doom lies south," the other man called after him, "or as close to it as I expected to see below the Blight." Perrin imagined he heard that faint thunder in the west again. Now, that would be a pleasant change.

ɪn ðə tɛnt, bɹin wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ əbaʊt wɪð ə boʊl ə ɹoʊz-sɛntɪd wɔɾɝ ən klɔθs fəɹ wɑʃɪŋ feɪsəz ən hænz, kɝtsiɪŋ stɪfli əz ʃi pɹizɛntəɾ ɪt. wɪð ivən stɪfɝ kɝtsiz, meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz ɔfɝɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ hoʊldɪŋ kʌps ʌv waɪn-pʌntʃ - meɪd wɪð ðə læst ə ðə dʒɹaɪd blubɛɹiz, baɪ ðə smɛl - waɪl lini foʊldəd ðə nukʌmɝz dʌst-kloʊk. ðəɹ sim sʌmθɪŋ ɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ feɪl ən bɹəleɪn stʊd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə nu wʊmən, ən ənʊɹə hʌvɝd bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɔl foʊkəst ɑn hɝ. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð ə kæp ʌv ɡɹin nɛt ɡæðɝɪŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ ðət fɛl ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ weɪst, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi ɪf əɹ noʊz hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ lɔŋ. ən ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt kæɹiɾ ɪt soʊ haɪ. ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən feɪl əɹ bɹəleɪn iðɝ wʌn, ʃi stɪl mænədʒ tə lʊk daʊn ðət noʊz ət pɛɹɪn, kuli ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɪm fɹəm hɛɹ tə buts. ʃi dɪd nɑt blɪŋk ət saɪɾ ə hɪz aɪz, ɔlðoʊ nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn dɪd.

In the tent, Breane was carrying a silver tray about with a bowl of rose-scented water and cloths for washing faces and hands, curtsying stiffly as she presented it. With even stiffer curtsies, Maighdin was offering a tray holding cups of wine-punch - made with the last of the dried blueberries, by the smell - while Lini folded the newcomer's dust-cloak. There seemed something odd in the way Faile and Berelain stood to either side of the new woman, and Annoura hovered behind them, all focused on her. Somewhere in her middle years, with a cap of green net gathering dark hair that fell almost to her waist, she might have been pretty if her nose had not been so long. And if she had not carried it so high. Shorter than Faile or Berelain either one, she still managed to look down that nose at Perrin, coolly examining him from hair to boots. She did not blink at sight of his eyes, although nearly everyone did.

"mædʒəsti," bɹəleɪn pɹənaʊnst ɪn ə fɔɹməl vɔɪs əz sun əz pɛɹɪn ɛntɝd, "meɪ aɪ pɹɛzən lɔɹd pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ɪn ændɝ, ðə pɝsənəl fɹɛn ən ɛməsɛɹi ʌv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." ðə lɔŋ-noʊzd wʊmən nɑɾəd kɛɹfəli, kuli, ən bɹəleɪn wɛn ɑn wɪð skɛɹsli ə pɔz. "lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə, ɡɪv ɡɹiɾɪŋz ən wɛlkəm tə æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ʌv ɡæɹənz wɔl, hu ɪz pliz tə ɹəsiv jə ɪn pɝsən." ɡælɛn, stændɪŋ nɪɹ ðə tɛnt wɔl, ədʒʌstəɾ ɪz aɪpætʃ ən ɹeɪzd ɪz waɪnkʌp tə pɛɹɪn wɪð ə smaɪl ə tʃɹaɪəmf.

"Majesty," Berelain pronounced in a formal voice as soon as Perrin entered, "may I present Lord Perrin Aybara of the Two Rivers, in Andor, the personal friend and emissary of the Dragon Reborn." The long-nosed woman nodded carefully, coolly, and Berelain went on with scarcely a pause. "Lord Aybara, give greetings and welcome to Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan, Blessed of the Light, Defender of Garen's Wall, who is pleased to receive you in person." Gallenne, standing near the tent wall, adjusted his eyepatch and raised his winecup to Perrin with a smile of triumph.

fəɹ səm ɹizən feɪl ʃɑt bɹəleɪn ə hɑɹd lʊk. pɛɹɪnz maʊθ nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt oʊpən. æliændɝ hɝsɛlf? hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ i ʃəd nil, ðən sɛɾəld fəɹ ə baʊ æftɝ tu lɔŋ ə pɔz. laɪt! hi hæd noʊ noʊʃən haʊ tə dil wɪð ə kwin. ɪspɛʃli wʌn u tɝn ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə blu wɪð noʊ ɛskɔɹt, wɪθaʊɾ ə dʒuəl ɪn saɪt. hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɑz pleɪn wʊl, lækɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl stɪtʃ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi.

For some reason Faile shot Berelain a hard look. Perrin's mouth nearly dropped open. Alliandre herself? He wondered whether he should kneel, then settled for a bow after too long a pause. Light! He had no notion how to deal with a queen. Especially one who turned up out of the blue with no escort, without a jewel in sight. Her dark green riding dress was plain wool, lacking a single stitch of embroidery.

"æftɝ ðə ɹisənt nuz," æliændɝ sɛd, "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ ʃəd kʌm tə ju, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, hɝ feɪs smuð, hɝ aɪz əluf. ən əbzɝvənt, əɹ i wɑz ə tɛɹən fɛɹi mæn. bɛs tə stɛp wɛɹəli tɪl i nu haʊ ðə pæθ leɪ. "ju meɪ nɑɾ əv hɝd," ʃi kəntɪnjud, "bʌt fɔɹ deɪz əɡoʊ ɪljən fɛl tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm ɪn ðə laɪt. hiz teɪkən ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn, ðoʊ aɪ ʌndɝstæn ɪts naʊ kɔl ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz."

"After the recent news," Alliandre said, "I thought I should come to you, Lord Aybara." Her voice was calm, her face smooth, her eyes aloof. And observant, or he was a Taren Ferry man. Best to step warily till he knew how the path lay. "You may not have heard," she continued, "but four days ago Illian fell to the Dragon Reborn, blessed be his name in the Light. He has taken the Laurel Crown, though I understand it is now called the Crown of Swords."

feɪl, teɪkɪŋ ə kʌp fɹəm meɪaɪɡdɪnz tʃɹeɪ, wɪspɝɾ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, "æn sɛvən deɪz ɡɔn, ðə sintʃæn tʊk ɛbu dɑɹ." ivən meɪaɪɡdɪn dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs.

Faile, taking a cup from Maighdin's tray, whispered under her breath, "And seven days gone, the Seanchan took Ebou Dar." Even Maighdin did not notice.

ɪf pɛɹɪn hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən hoʊld ə hɪmsɛlf, hi tʃɹuli wəɾ əv ɡeɪpt. waɪ dɪd feɪl tɛl ɪm ðɪs weɪ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪt tə kʌm fɹəm ðə wʊmən u mʌst əv toʊl hɝ? ɪn ə vɔɪs ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd hɪɹ, hi ɹɪpiɾɪd əɹ wɝdz. ə hɑɹd vɔɪs, bʌt ðət wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ tə kip ɪt fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ. ɛbu dɑɹ, tu? laɪt! ən sɛvən deɪz əɡoʊ? ðə deɪ ɡɹeɪɾi ən ði ʌðɝz hæd sin ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ðə skaɪ. koʊɪnsɪɾəns, meɪbi. bʌt wəɾ i ɹæðɝ ɪt hæd bɪn ðə fɔɹseɪkən?

If Perrin had not already taken hold of himself, he truly would have gaped. Why did Faile tell him this way instead of waiting for it to come from the woman who must have told her? In a voice that everyone could hear, he repeated her words. A hard voice, but that was the only way to keep it from shaking. Ebou Dar, too? Light! And seven days ago? The day Grady and the others had seen the One Power in the sky. Coincidence, maybe. But would he rather it had been the Forsaken?

ənʊɹə fɹaʊn oʊvɝ əɹ kʌp, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps, bɪfɔɹ i fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ, ən bɹəleɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk ðət vænɪʃt kwɪkli. ðeɪ nu hi hæd nɑt noʊn əbaʊɾ ɛbu dɑɹ wən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə bɛθɔl.

Annoura frowned over her cup, pursing her lips, before he finished speaking, and Berelain gave him a startled look that vanished quickly. They knew he had not known about Ebou Dar when they rode into Bethal.

æliændɝ mɪɹli nɑɾəd, ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz sɛlf-pəzɛst əz ðə ɡɹeɪ. "ju sim ɹɪmɑɹkəbli wɛl ɪnfɔɹmd," ʃi sɛd, kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ tə hɪm. "aɪ daʊt ðə fɝst ɹumɝz ɑɹ ɹitʃɪŋ dʒəhænə wɪð ðə ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪd, jɛt. aɪ maɪsɛlf lɝn ʌv ɪɾ oʊnli ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə mɝtʃəns kip mi əbɹɛst ʌv ɪvɛns. aɪ bɪliv," ʃi æɾəd dʒɹaɪli, "ðæt ðeɪ hoʊp aɪ kən ɪntɝsid fəɹ əm wɪð ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ɪf sətʃ bɪkʌmz nɛsəsɛɹi."

Alliandre merely nodded, every bit as self-possessed as the Gray. "You seem remarkably well informed," she said, coming closer to him. "I doubt the first rumors are reaching Jehannah with the river trade, yet. I myself learned of it only a few days ago. Several of the merchants keep me abreast of events. I believe," she added dryly, "that they hope I can intercede for them with the Prophet of the Lord Dragon, if such becomes necessary."

ət læst i kəd pɪk aʊɾ əɹ sɛnt, ən ɪz əpɪnjən ə hɝ tʃeɪnʒd, ðoʊ nɑt fəɹ ðə wɝs. aʊtwɝdli, ðə kwin wɑz ɔl kul ɹɪzɝv, bʌɾ ənsɝɾənti ʃɑt θɹu wɪð fɪɹ fɪl ðə smɛl ə hɝ. hi dɪd nɑt bɪliv i cʊɾə hɛld ɪz feɪs soʊ kɑm hæɾ i fɛl ðæt.

At last he could pick out her scent, and his opinion of her changed, though not for the worse. Outwardly, the Queen was all cool reserve, but uncertainty shot through with fear filled the smell of her. He did not believe he could have held his face so calm had he felt that.

"ɔlweɪz bɛs tə noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz jə kæn," hi toʊl hɝ, hæf dɪstʃɹæktəd. bɝn mi, hi θɔt, aɪ hæv tə lɛt ɹænd noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs!

"Always best to know as much as you can," he told her, half distracted. Burn me, he thought, I have to let Rand know about this!

"ɪn sɑldɑiə wi faɪn mɝtʃəns jusfəl fəɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, tu," feɪl sɛd. ɪmplaɪɪŋ ðət wɑz haʊ pɛɹɪn nu əbaʊɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. "ðeɪ sim tə lɝn wʌt hæpən ə θaʊzən maɪlz ɔf wiks bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹumɝz bɪɡɪn."

"In Saldaea we find merchants useful for information, too," Faile said. Implying that was how Perrin knew about Ebou Dar. "They seem to learn what happened a thousand miles off weeks before the rumors begin."

ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i nu ʃi spoʊk tə hɪm əz mʌtʃ əz æliændɝ. ɹænd nu, ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. ən ɛniweɪ, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɡɛt wɝd tə hɪm ɪn sikɹət. kəd feɪl ɹɪli wɑn ɪm tə . . . ? noʊ, ɪt wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl. blɪŋkɪŋ, hi ɹilaɪzd i hæd mɪst sʌmθɪŋ æliændɝ hæd sɛd. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, æliændɝ," hi sɛd pəlaɪtli. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd - ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl!

She did not look at Perrin, but he knew she spoke to him as much as Alliandre. Rand knew, she was saying. And anyway, there was no way to get word to him in secret. Could Faile really want him to . . . ? No, it was unthinkable. Blinking, he realized he had missed something Alliandre had said. "Your pardon, Alliandre," he said politely. "I was thinking about Rand - the Dragon Reborn." Of course it was unthinkable!

ɛvɹiwʌn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ivən lini ən meɪaɪɡdɪn ən bɹin. ənʊɹəz aɪz hæd ɡɔn waɪd, ən ɡælɛnz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən. ðən ɪt hɪt hɪm. hi hæd dʒʌs kɔl ðə kwin baɪ neɪm. hi tʊk ə kʌp fɹəm meɪaɪɡdɪnz tʃɹeɪ, ən ʃi ɹoʊz fɹəm əɹ kɝtsi soʊ kwɪkli ðət ʃi nɪɹli nɑkt ɪt fɹəm ɪz hænd. weɪvɪŋ əɹ əweɪ æbsənli, hi waɪpt ɪz dæmp hæn ɑn ɪz koʊt. hi hæd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt hɪɹ, nɑt lɛɾ ɪz maɪnd wɑndɝ ɪn naɪn dɝɛkʃənz. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɛlaɪəs θɔɾ i nu, feɪl wəd nɛvɝ. . . . noʊ! kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt!

Everyone stared at him, even Lini and Maighdin and Breane. Annoura's eyes had gone wide, and Gallenne's mouth hung open. Then it hit him. He had just called the Queen by name. He took a cup from Maighdin's tray, and she rose from her curtsy so quickly that she nearly knocked it from his hand. Waving her away absently, he wiped his damp hand on his coat. He had to concentrate here, not let his mind wander in nine directions. No matter what Elyas thought he knew, Faile would never. . . . No! Concentrate!

æliændɝ ɹəkʌvɝɾ əɹ ikwəlɪbɹiəm kwɪkli. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæɾ əpɪɹd ðə list sɝpɹaɪzd ʌv ɛniwʌn, ən əɹ sɛnt nɛvɝ weɪvɝd. "aɪ wɑz seɪɪŋ ðət kʌmɪŋ tə jə ɪn sikɹət sim ðə waɪzəs kɔɹs, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət kul vɔɪs. "lɔɹd tɛləbɪn bɪlivz aɪm kipɪŋ pɹaɪvəɾ ɪn ɪz ɡɑɹɾənz, wɪtʃ aɪ lɛf baɪ ə sɛldəm-juzd ɡeɪt. pæsɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, aɪ wɑz ənʊɹə sədaɪz meɪd." bɹʌʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝtɪps əkɹɔs wʌn skɝɾ ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl læf. ivən ðəɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɑz kul, soʊ əɾ ɑdz wɪð wʌɾ ɪz noʊz toʊl hɪm. "ə nʌmbɝ ə maɪ oʊn soʊlʒɝz sɔ mi, bʌt wɪð ðə hʊɾ ə maɪ kloʊk pʊld ʌp, nʌn nu mi."

Alliandre recovered her equilibrium quickly. In truth, she had appeared the least surprised of anyone, and her scent never wavered. "I was saying that coming to you in secret seemed the wisest course, Lord Aybara," she said in that cool voice. "Lord Telabin believes I am keeping private in his gardens, which I left by a seldom-used gate. Passing out of the city, I was Annoura Sedai's maid." Brushing fingertips across one skirt of her riding dress, she gave a small laugh. Even that about her was cool, so at odds with what his nose told him. "A number of my own soldiers saw me, but with the hood of my cloak pulled up, none knew me."

"taɪmz biɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ, ðət pɹɑbli wɑz waɪzəst," pɛɹɪn sɛd kɛɹfəli. "bʌt jəl əv tə kʌm ɪndə ði oʊpən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ." pəlaɪɾ ən tə ðə pɔɪnt, ðət wɑz ðə θɪŋ. ə kwin wəd nɑt wɑnə weɪs taɪm wɪð ə mæn u blæðɝd. ən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə dɪsəpɔɪn feɪl baɪ æktɪŋ ðə heɪfʊɾ əɡɛn. "waɪ kʌm əɾ ɔl? ɔl jə hæd tə də wɑz sɛn ə lɛɾɝ, əɹ dʒʌs tɛl bɹəleɪn jəɹ ænsɝ. wɪl jə dɪklɛɹ fəɹ ɹænd əɹ nɑt? iðɝ weɪ, hæv noʊ fɪɹ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk tə bɛθɔl seɪfli." ə ɡʊd pɔɪnt, ðæt. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls fɹaɪɾənd hɝ, biɪŋ hɪɹ əloʊn mʌst.

"Times being what they are, that probably was wisest," Perrin said carefully. "But you will have to come into the open sooner or later. One way or another." Polite and to the point, that was the thing. A queen would not want to waste time with a man who blathered. And he did not want to disappoint Faile by acting the hayfoot again. "Why come at all? All you had to do was send a letter, or just tell Berelain your answer. Will you declare for Rand or not? Either way, have no fear about getting back to Bethal safely." A good point, that. Whatever else frightened her, being here alone must.

feɪl wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, pɹitɛndɪŋ nɑt tə, sɪpɪŋ əɹ pʌntʃ ən dɝɛktɪŋ əɹ smaɪlz əɾ æliændɝ, bʌɾ i kɑt ðə kwɪk flɪkɝz ə hɝ aɪz ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. bɹəleɪn meɪd noʊ pɹitɛns, wɑtʃɪŋ kwaɪɾ oʊpənli, aɪz slaɪtli nɛɹoʊɾ ən nɛvɝ livɪŋ ɪz feɪs. ənʊɹə wɑz dʒʌst əz ɪntɛnt, dʒʌst əz θɔtfəl. dɪd ðeɪ ɔl bɪliv i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn tʌŋ əɡɛn?

Faile was watching him, pretending not to, sipping her punch and directing her smiles at Alliandre, but he caught the quick flickers of her eyes in his direction. Berelain made no pretense, watching quite openly, eyes slightly narrowed and never leaving his face. Annoura was just as intent, just as thoughtful. Did they all believe he was going to trip over his own tongue again?

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt kwɛstʃən, æliændɝ sɛd, "ðə fɝs toʊl mi ə ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊt ju, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə, ən əbaʊt ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm ɪn ðə laɪt." ðət læst saʊndəd baɪ ɹoʊt, ən ədɪʃən ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæd tə θɪŋk əbaʊt. "aɪ kænɑt si hɪm bɪfɔɹ aɪ meɪk maɪ dɪsɪʒən, soʊ aɪ wɪʃt tə si ju, tə teɪk ə mɛʒɝ ə ju. ɪts pɑsəbəl tə tɛl mʌtʃ əbaʊɾ ə mæn baɪ ðoʊz i tʃuzəz tə spik fəɹ hɪm." tɪltɪŋ əɹ feɪs daʊn təwɔɹd ðə kʌp ɪn əɹ hænz, ʃi pɪɹɾ əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ læʃɪz. fɹəm bɹəleɪn, ðət wʊɾə bɪn flɝteɪʃəs, bʌɾ æliændɝ wɑz kɔʃəsli wɑtʃɪŋ ə wʊlf ʃʊɹ əz i wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. "aɪ ɔlsoʊ sɔ jəɹ bænɝz," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ðə fɝs dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðɛm."

Instead of answering the important question, Alliandre said, "The First told me a great deal about you, Lord Aybara, and about the Lord Dragon Reborn, blessed be his name in the Light." That last sounded by rote, an addition she no longer had to think about. "I cannot see him before I make my decision, so I wished to see you, to take a measure of you. It's possible to tell much about a man by those he chooses to speak for him." Tilting her face down toward the cup in her hands, she peered at him through her lashes. From Berelain, that would have been flirtatious, but Alliandre was cautiously watching a wolf sure as he was standing in front of her. "I also saw your banners," she said quietly. "The First did not mention them."

pɛɹɪn skaʊl bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp hɪmsɛlf. bɹəleɪn hæd toʊld əɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊt hɪm? wʌt hæd ʃi sɛd? "ðə bænɝz ɑɹ mɛn tə bi sin." æŋɡɝ pʊɾ ə ɹʌnəs ɪn ɪz vɔɪs ðət ɹikwaɪɝd səm ɛfɝt tə fɔɹs daʊn. naʊ, bɹəleɪn wɑz ə wʊmən u niɾəd ʃaʊɾɪŋ æt. "bɪliv mi, ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ plænz tə sɛɾ ʌp meɪnɛðɝən əɡɛn." ðɛɹ; hɪz toʊn wɑz əz kul əz æliændɝz. "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ dɪsɪʒən? ɹænd kən əv tɛn θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz, ə hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd, hɪɹ ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf." ən i maɪɾ əv tə. ðə sintʃæn ɪn æmədɔɹ ən ɛbu dɑɹ? laɪt, haʊ mɛni wɝ ðeɪ?

Perrin scowled before he could stop himself. Berelain had told her a great deal about him? What had she said? "The banners are meant to be seen." Anger put a roughness in his voice that required some effort to force down. Now, Berelain was a woman who needed shouting at. "Believe me, there are no plans to set up Manetheren again." There; his tone was as cool as Alliandre's. "What is your decision? Rand can have ten thousand soldiers, a hundred thousand, here in the blink of an eye, or near enough." And he might have to. The Seanchan in Amador and Ebou Dar? Light, how many were they?

æliændɝ sɪp dɛləkətli əɾ əɹ waɪn-pʌntʃ bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ, ən əɡɛn ʃi dɑdʒ ðə kwɛstʃən. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə θaʊzən ɹumɝz, əz jə mʌs noʊ, ən ivən ðə waɪldɪst ɪz bəlivəbəl wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn, stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əpɪɹ kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmiz ɹɪtɝnd, ən ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf ɪz bɹoʊkən baɪ ɹɪbɛljən."

Alliandre sipped delicately at her wine-punch before speaking, and again she dodged the question. "There are a thousand rumors, as you must know, and even the wildest is believable when the Dragon is Reborn, strangers appear claiming to be Artur Hawkwing's armies returned, and the Tower itself is broken by rebellion."

"ə mæɾɝ fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ," ənʊɹə sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɪt kənsɝnz noʊ wʌn ɛls." bɹəleɪn flæʃt ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk ət hɝ, wɪtʃ ʃi əfɛktəd nɑt tə noʊɾəs.

"A matter for Aes Sedai," Annoura said sharply. "It concerns no one else." Berelain flashed an exasperated look at her, which she affected not to notice.

æliændɝ flɪntʃt ən tɝn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə ðə sɪstɝ. kwin əɹ nɑt, noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə hɪɹ ðət toʊn fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ðə wɝld ɪz tɝn ʌpsaɪd daʊn, lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə. waɪ, aɪv ivən hæd ɹɪpɔɹts ʌv il sækɪŋ ə vɪlədʒ ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn ɡildən." əbɹʌpli pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ hɪɹ ðən æŋzaɪəɾi oʊvɝ əfɛndɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. æliændɝ wɑtʃt hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ. bʌt fəɹ wʌt? ɹiəʃʊɹəns?

Alliandre flinched and turned her shoulder to the sister. Queen or not, no one wanted to hear that tone from an Aes Sedai. "The world is turned upside down, Lord Aybara. Why, I've even had reports of Aiel sacking a village right here in Ghealdan." Abruptly Perrin realized there was more here than anxiety over offending Aes Sedai. Alliandre watched him, waiting. But for what? Reassurance?

"ði oʊnli il ɪn ɡildən ɑɹ wɪð mi," hi toʊl hɝ. "ðə sintʃæn meɪ bi dɪsɛndəns ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɑɹmi, bʌt hɔkwɪŋ ɪz ə θaʊzən jɪɹz dɛd. ɹænd dɛlt wɪð əm wʌns ɔlɹɛɾi, ən hɪl əɡɛn." hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɑlm əz klɪɹli əz dəməaɪz wɛlz, ðoʊ hi hæd tʃɹaɪd fɝɡɛɾɪŋ. ʃʊɹli ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ɪnʌf ə ðɛm ðəɹ tə teɪk æmədɔɹ ən ɛbu dɑɹ, ivən wɪð ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn. beɪlwɝ kleɪm ðeɪ hæd tæɹɑbənɝ soʊlʒɝz, tu. "æn ɪt maɪt tʃɪɹ jə tə hɪɹ ðət ðoʊz ɹɛbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ səpɔɹt ɹænd. ðeɪ wɪl, sun, ət list." ðət wɑz wʌt ɹænd sɛd, ə hændfʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð noʊwɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ɪksɛp tə hɪm. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ. ɹumɝ ɪn ɡildən pʊɾ ən ɑɹmi wɪð ðoʊz sɪstɝz. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə seɪm ɹumɝz kaʊntəd mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðət hændfʊl ðən ðəɹ wɝ ɪn ðə wɝld, bʌt stɪl. . . . laɪt, hi wɪʃt sʌmwʌn wəd ɹiəʃʊɹ hɪm! "waɪ doʊnt wi sɪt," hi sɛd. "aɪl ænsɝ ɛni kwɛstʃənz jə hæv, tə hɛlp jə meɪk jəɹ dɪsɪʒən, bʌt wi maɪɾ əz wɛl bi kʌmftəɹbəl." dʒɹɔɪŋ wʌn ə ðə foʊldɪŋ tʃɛɹz tə hɪm, hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ət ðə læst ɪnstənt nɑt tə dʒʌs dʒɹɑp ɪndə ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt kɹikt ʌndɝ ɪm dʒʌs ðə seɪm.

"The only Aiel in Ghealdan are with me," he told her. "The Seanchan may be descendants of Artur Hawkwing's army, but Hawkwing is a thousand years dead. Rand dealt with them once already, and he will again." He remembered Falme as clearly as Dumai's Wells, though he had tried forgetting. Surely there had not been enough of them there to take Amador and Ebou Dar, even with their damane. Balwer claimed they had Taraboner soldiers, too. "And it might cheer you to hear that those rebel Aes Sedai support Rand. They will, soon, at least." That was what Rand said, a handful of Aes Sedai with nowhere to go except to him. Perrin was not so sure. Rumor in Ghealdan put an army with those sisters. Of course, the same rumors counted more Aes Sedai in that handful than there were in the world, but still. . . . Light, he wished someone would reassure him! "Why don't we sit," he said. "I'll answer any questions you have, to help you make your decision, but we might as well be comfortable." Drawing one of the folding chairs to him, he remembered at the last instant not to just drop into it, but it creaked under him just the same.

lini ən ði ʌðɝ tu sɝvəns ɹʌʃt əbaʊt, pʊlɪŋ tʃɛɹz ɪndə ə sɝkəl wɪð hɪz, bʌt nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən muv təwɔɹd ðɛm. æliændɝ stʊd lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ən ðə ɹɛs lʊkt ət hɝ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɡælɛn, hu mɪɹli pɔɹd hɪmsɛlf ənʌðɝ kʌp ə pʌntʃ fɹəm ðə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ.

Lini and the other two servants rushed about, pulling chairs into a circle with his, but none of the other women moved toward them. Alliandre stood looking at him, and the rest looked at her. Except for Gallenne, who merely poured himself another cup of punch from the silver pitcher.

ɪt keɪm tə pɛɹɪn ðət feɪl hæd nɑɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ sɪns spikɪŋ ə ðə mɝtʃəns. hi wɑz əz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ bɹəleɪnz saɪləns əz i wɑz ðət ʃi hæd nɑt dɪsaɪɾɪd tə flʌɾɝ əɹ læʃɪz əɾ ɪm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə kwin, bʌɾ i cʊɾə juz səm hɛlp fɹəm feɪl ɹaɪt ðɛn. ə lɪɾəl ædvaɪs. laɪt, ʃi nu tɛn taɪmz wʌɾ i dɪɾ əbaʊt wʌɾ i ʃəd seɪ ən də hɪɹ.

It came to Perrin that Faile had not opened her mouth since speaking of the merchants. He was as grateful for Berelain's silence as he was that she had not decided to flutter her lashes at him in front of the Queen, but he could have used some help from Faile right then. A little advice. Light, she knew ten times what he did about what he should say and do here.

wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i ʃəd stænd wɪð ði ʌðɝz, hi sɛɾ ɪz waɪn-pʌntʃ ɑn wʌn ə ðə smɔl teɪbəlz ən æskt əɹ tə spik tə æliændɝ. "ɪf ɛniwʌn kən meɪk əɹ si ðə ɹaɪt weɪ tə ɡoʊ, jə kæn," hi sɛd. feɪl ɡeɪv ɪm ə pliz smaɪl, bʌt hɛld əɹ tʌŋ.

Wondering whether he should stand with the others, he set his wine-punch on one of the small tables and asked her to speak to Alliandre. "If anyone can make her see the right way to go, you can," he said. Faile gave him a pleased smile, but held her tongue.

əbɹʌpli æliændɝ pʊɾ aʊɾ əɹ kʌp tə wʌn saɪd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ tə bi ðɛɹ. wʌn wɑz, bɛɹli ɪn taɪm tə kætʃ ðə kʌp, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn, hu hɛld ɪt, mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ pɛɹɪn hoʊp feɪl hæd nɑt hɝd. feɪl wɑz dɛθ ɑn sɝvəns juzɪŋ ðət sɔɹɾ ə læŋɡwədʒ. hi stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz əz æliændɝ əpɹoʊtʃt hɪm, bʌt tə hɪz ʃɑk, ʃi nɛlt ɡɹeɪsfəli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, kætʃɪŋ ɪz hænz wɪð hɝz. bɪfɔɹ i nu wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ʃi twɪstəd soʊ hɝ hænz wɝ bæk-tə-bæk bɪtwin ɪz pɑmz. ʃi klʌŋ soʊ hɑɹɾ əɹ hænz mʌst əv hɝt; fəɹ ʃʊɹ, hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən i kəd lus hɪmsɛlf wɪθaʊt hɝɾɪŋ hɝ.

Abruptly Alliandre put out her cup to one side without looking, as if expecting a tray to be there. One was, barely in time to catch the cup, and Maighdin, who held it, muttered something Perrin hoped Faile had not heard. Faile was death on servants using that sort of language. He started to rise as Alliandre approached him, but to his shock, she knelt gracefully in front of him, catching his hands with hers. Before he knew what she was doing, she twisted so her hands were back-to-back between his palms. She clung so hard her hands must have hurt; for sure, he was not certain he could loose himself without hurting her.

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪt," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm, "aɪ, æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, plɛdʒ maɪ fiəlti ən sɝvəs tə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, naʊ ən fəɹ ɔl taɪm, seɪv ðəɾ i tʃuzəz tə ɹilis mi ʌv ɪz oʊn wɪl. maɪ lænz ən θɹoʊn ɑɹ hɪz, ən aɪ jild əm tə hɪz hænd. soʊ aɪ də swɛɹ."

"Under the Light," she said firmly, looking up at him, "I, Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, pledge my fealty and service to Lord Perrin Aybara of the Two Rivers, now and for all time, save that he chooses to release me of his own will. My lands and throne are his, and I yield them to his hand. So I do swear."

fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðəɹ wɑz ə saɪləns bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ɡælɛnz ɡæsp ən ðə mjuɾɪd θʌɾ ə hɪz waɪnkʌp hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹʌɡ.

For an instant there was a silence broken only by Gallenne's gasp and the muted thud of his winecup hitting the rug.

ðən pɛɹɪn hɝd feɪl, wʌns mɔɹ wɪspɝɪŋ soʊ sɔfli noʊ wʌn nɛks tə hɝ cʊɾə meɪɾ aʊɾ əɹ wɝdz. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ də æksɛp jəɹ plɛdʒ ən wɪl dɪfɛn ən pɹətɛk jə ən jʊɹz θɹu bæɾəlz ɹæk ən wɪntɝz blæst ən ɔl ðət taɪm meɪ bɹɪŋ. ðə lænz ən θɹoʊn ʌv ɡildən, aɪ ɡɪv tə jə əz maɪ feɪθfəl væsəl. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ də æksɛpt. . . ." ðət mʌst əv bɪn ðə sɑldəiən mænɝ ʌv æksɛptɪŋ. θæŋk ðə laɪt ʃi wɑz tu bɪzi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪm tə si bɹəleɪn nɑɾɪŋ əɾ ɪm fjʊɹiəsli, ɝdʒɪŋ ðə seɪm. ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm lʊkt ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs! ənʊɹə, ðoʊ, wɪð əɹ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən, əpɪɹɾ əz stʌn əz hi, laɪk ə fɪʃ u hæd dʒʌst sin ðə wɔɾɝ vænɪʃ.

Then Perrin heard Faile, once more whispering so softly no one next to her could have made out her words. "Under the Light, I do accept your pledge and will defend and protect you and yours through battle's wrack and winter's blast and all that time may bring. The lands and throne of Ghealdan, I give to you as my faithful vassal. Under the Light, I do accept. . . ." That must have been the Saldaean manner of accepting. Thank the Light she was too busy concentrating on him to see Berelain nodding at him furiously, urging the same. The pair of them looked almost as if they had expected this! Annoura, though, with her mouth hanging open, appeared as stunned as he, like a fish who had just seen the water vanish.

"waɪ?" hi æsk dʒɛnli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ feɪlz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd hɪs ən bɹəleɪnz ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd ɡɹʌn əlaɪk. bɝn mi, hi θɔt, ɪm ə blʌɾi blæksmɪθ! noʊbɑdi swɔɹ fiəlti tə blæksmɪθs. kwinz dɪd nɑt swɛɹ fiəlti tə ɛniwʌn! "aɪv bɪn toʊld aɪm tɑvɝən; jə maɪt wɑnə ɹikənsɪɾɝ ðɪs ɪn ən aʊɝ."

"Why?" he asked gently, ignoring Faile's frustrated hiss and Berelain's exasperated grunt alike. Burn me, he thought, I'm a bloody blacksmith! Nobody swore fealty to blacksmiths. Queens did not swear fealty to anyone! "I've been told I'm ta'veren; you might want to reconsider this in an hour."

"aɪ hoʊp jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən, maɪ lɔɹd." æliændɝ læft, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn əmjuzmənt, ən ɡɹɪpt ɪz hænz ivən mɔɹ taɪtli, əz ðoʊ fɪɹfəl i maɪt pʊl əweɪ. "wɪð ɔl maɪ hɑɹt, aɪ hoʊp ɪt. aɪ fɪɹ nʌθɪŋ lɛs wɪl seɪv ɡildən. aɪ ɔl bʌt ɹitʃt ðɪs dɪsɪʒən əz sun əz ðə fɝs toʊl mi waɪ jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, ən miɾɪŋ jə oʊnli kənfɝmd mi ɪn ɪt. ɡildən nidz pɹətɛkʃən aɪ kænɑt ɡɪv, soʊ duɾi dɪmænz aɪ faɪn ɪt. jə kən ɡɪv ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd, jə ən ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm ɪn ðə laɪt. ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ wəd swɛɹ dɝɛkli tə hɪm ɪf i wɝ hɪɹ, bʌt jə ɑɹ ɪz mæn. swɛɹɪŋ tə ju, aɪ ɔlsoʊ swɛɹ tə hɪm." dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi fɔɹst aʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd. "pliz." ʃi smɛl dɛspɹɪt, naʊ, ən əɹ aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð fɪɹ.

"I hope you are ta'veren, my Lord." Alliandre laughed, but not in amusement, and gripped his hands even more tightly, as though fearful he might pull away. "With all my heart, I hope it. I fear nothing less will save Ghealdan. I all but reached this decision as soon as the First told me why you are here, and meeting you only confirmed me in it. Ghealdan needs protection I cannot give, so duty demands I find it. You can give it, my Lord, you and the Lord Dragon Reborn, blessed be his name in the Light. In truth, I would swear directly to him if he were here, but you are his man. Swearing to you, I also swear to him." Drawing a deep breath, she forced out another word. "Please." She smelled desperate, now, and her eyes shone with fear.

stɪl, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðɪs wɑz ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹænd kəd wɑn ən mɔɹ, bʌt pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə wɑz dʒʌst ə blæksmɪθ. hi wɑz! kəɾ i stɪl tɛl hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ ɪf i dɪd ðɪs θɪŋ? æliændɝ stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪm pliɾɪŋli. dɪd tɑvɝən wɝk ɑn ðɛmsɛlvz, hi wʌndɝd. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, æksɛp jəɹ plɛdʒ. . . ." hɪz θɹoʊt wɑz dʒɹaɪ baɪ ðə taɪm i fɪnɪʃt ðə wɝdz feɪl hæd wɪspɝd. tu leɪt tə stɑp ən θɪŋk naʊ.

Still, he hesitated. This was everything Rand could want and more, but Perrin Aybara was just a blacksmith. He was! Could he still tell himself that if he did this thing? Alliandre stared up at him pleadingly. Did ta'veren work on themselves, he wondered. "Under the Light, I, Perrin Aybara, accept your pledge. . . ." His throat was dry by the time he finished the words Faile had whispered. Too late to stop and think now.

wɪð ə ɡæsp ə ɹɪlif, æliændɝ kɪst ɪz hænz. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn soʊ ɪmbɛɹəst ɪn ɪz laɪf. stændɪŋ hɝidli, hi dʒɹu hɝ tə hɝ fit. ən ɹilaɪzd i dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də nɛkst. ə pɹaʊdli bimɪŋ feɪl wɪspɝd noʊ fɝðɝ hɪns. bɹəleɪn smaɪld, tu, ɹɪlif soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ɑn əɹ feɪs ʃi maɪɾ əv dʒʌs bɪn pʊl fɹəm ə faɪɝ.

With a gasp of relief, Alliandre kissed his hands. Perrin did not think he had ever been so embarrassed in his life. Standing hurriedly, he drew her to her feet. And realized he did not know what to do next. A proudly beaming Faile whispered no further hints. Berelain smiled, too, relief so strong on her face she might have just been pulled from a fire.

hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ənʊɹə wəd spik - ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz hæd plɛnti tə seɪ, ɪspɛʃli wən ɪt ɡeɪv ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ - bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə waɪnkʌp fəɹ meɪaɪɡdɪn tə ɹifɪl. ənʊɹə wɑtʃt ɪm wɪð ən ənɹiɾəbəl ɪkspɹɛʃən, ən fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, soʊ dɪd meɪaɪɡdɪn, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət ʃi kəntɪnjud tɪltɪŋ əɹ pɪtʃɝ əntɪl pʌntʃ slɑpt oʊvɝ ɑntu ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɹɪst. ət wɪtʃ ənʊɹə ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kʌp ɪn əɹ hæn əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd fɝɡɑɾən ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. feɪl fɹaʊnd, ən lini fɹaʊn ivən hɑɹɾɝ, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn skɝid fəɹ ə klɔθ tə dʒɹaɪ ðə sɪstɝz hænd, ɔl ðə waɪl mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əɡɛn. feɪl wɑz gɑnə hæv fɪts ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ hɝd ðoʊz mʌɾɝz.

He was sure Annoura would speak - Aes Sedai always had plenty to say, especially when it gave an opportunity to take charge - but the Gray sister was holding out a winecup for Maighdin to refill. Annoura watched him with an unreadable expression, and for that matter, so did Maighdin, so much so that she continued tilting her pitcher until punch slopped over onto the Aes Sedai's wrist. At which Annoura gave a start, staring at the cup in her hand as though she had forgotten it was there. Faile frowned, and Lini frowned even harder, and Maighdin scurried for a cloth to dry the sister's hand, all the while muttering under her breath again. Faile was going to have fits if she ever heard those mutters.

pɛɹɪn nu hi wɑz teɪkɪŋ tu lɔŋ. æliændɝ lɪkt əɹ lɪps æŋkʃəsli; ʃi ɪkspɛktəd mɔɹ, bʌt wʌt? "naʊ ðət wɝ dʌn hɪɹ, aɪ hæv tə faɪn ðə pɹɑfət nɛkst," hi sɛd, ən wɪnst. tu əbɹʌpt. hi hæd noʊ fil fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð noʊbəlz, mʌtʃ lɛs kwinz. "aɪ səpoʊz jəl wɑnə ɡɛt bæk tə bɛθɔl bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn lɝnz jəɹ ɡɔn."

Perrin knew he was taking too long. Alliandre licked her lips anxiously; she expected more, but what? "Now that we're done here, I have to find the Prophet next," he said, and winced. Too abrupt. He had no feel for dealing with nobles, much less queens. "I suppose you'll want to get back to Bethal before anyone learns you're gone."

"ðə læst aɪ hɝd," æliændɝ toʊl hɪm, "ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɑz ɪn ɑbilə. ðæts ə lɑɹdʒɪʃ taʊn ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə, pɝhæps fɔɹɾi liɡz saʊθ ə hɪɹ."

"The last I heard," Alliandre told him, "the Prophet of the Lord Dragon was in Abila. That's a largish town in Amadicia, perhaps forty leagues south of here."

ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd, ðoʊ hi smuðd ɪz bɹaʊ kwɪkli. soʊ beɪlwɝ hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ɹaɪɾ ɪn wʌn θɪŋ dɪd nɑt min ɹaɪɾ ɪn ɔl, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi wɝθwaɪl hɪɹɪŋ wʌt ðə mæn hæd tə seɪ əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks. ən ðə sintʃæn. haʊ mɛni tæɹɑbənɝz?

In spite of himself, Perrin frowned, though he smoothed his brow quickly. So Balwer had been right. Right in one thing did not mean right in all, but it might be worthwhile hearing what the man had to say about the Whitecloaks. And the Seanchan. How many Taraboners?

feɪl ɡlaɪɾɪd tə hɪz saɪd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm ən dɝɛktɪŋ ə wɔɹm smaɪl əɾ æliændɝ. "ju kænɑt min tə sɛn əɹ əweɪ naʊ, maɪ hɑɹt. nɑt wən ʃiz dʒʌst ɝaɪvd. liv əs tə tɔk hɪɹ aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn bɪfɔɹ ʃi mʌs feɪs ðə ɹaɪd bæk. aɪ noʊ juv ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz tə si tə."

Faile glided to his side, laying a hand on his arm and directing a warm smile at Alliandre. "You cannot mean to send her away now, my heart. Not when she has just arrived. Leave us to talk here out of the sun before she must face the ride back. I know you have important matters to see to."

hi mænədʒ nɑt tə stɛɹ, wɪð ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝt. wʌt kəd bi mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən? sɝɾən ʃʊɹ, nʌθɪŋ ɛniwʌn wəd lɛɾ ɪm leɪ hæn tə. klɪɹli ʃi wɑntəd tə tɔk wɪð æliændɝ wɪθaʊt hɪm. wɪð lʌk, ʃi wəd tɛl ɪm waɪ leɪɾɝ. wɪð lʌk, ʃi wəd tɛl ɪm ɔl ʌv ɪt. ɛlaɪəs maɪt θɪŋk i nu sɑldəiənz, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd lɝn ɑn ɪz oʊn ðəɾ oʊnli ə ful tʃɹaɪd tə ɹuɾ aʊɾ ɔl ə hɪz waɪfs sikɹəts. əɹ lɛɾ əɹ noʊ əbaʊt ðoʊz i hæɾ ənɝθt ɔlɹɛɾi.

He managed not to stare, with a little effort. What could be more important than the Queen of Ghealdan? Certain sure, nothing anyone would let him lay hand to. Clearly she wanted to talk with Alliandre without him. With luck, she would tell him why later. With luck, she would tell him all of it. Elyas might think he knew Saldaeans, but Perrin had learned on his own that only a fool tried to root out all of his wife's secrets. Or let her know about those he had unearthed already.

livɪŋ æliændɝ ʃəd noʊ daʊɾ ɪnvɑlv əz mʌtʃ sɛɹəmoʊni əz miɾɪŋ hɝ, bʌɾ i mænədʒd ə kɹɛɾəbəl lɛɡ ən meɪɾ ɪz baʊ, æskɪŋ əɹ pɑɹɾən fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf, ən ʃi kɝtsid dipli, mɝmɝɪŋ ðəɾ i ɑnɝɾ əɹ tu mʌtʃ, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. ɪksɛp fəɹ dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ət ɡælɛn tə fɑloʊ hɪm. hi daʊɾɪd ðət feɪl wəd sɛn ɪm ɔf ən wɑn ðət wʌn tə steɪ. wʌd ʃi wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ əloʊn?

Leaving Alliandre should no doubt involve as much ceremony as meeting her, but he managed a credible leg and made his bow, asking her pardon for going off, and she curtsied deeply, murmuring that he honored her too much, and that was that. Except for jerking his head at Gallenne to follow him. He doubted that Faile would send him off and want that one to stay. What did she want to talk about alone?

aʊtsaɪd, ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə klæp ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ðət wʊɾə stæɡɝɾ ə smɔlɝ mæn. "bɝn mi, aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðə laɪk! naʊ aɪ kən seɪ aɪv sin ə tɑvɝən ət wɝk fəɹ tʃɹu. wʌd jə wɑnt wɪð mi?" ən wʌt wɑz i tə seɪ tə ðæt?

Outside, the one-eyed man gave Perrin a clap on the shoulder that would have staggered a smaller man. "Burn me, I've never heard of the like! Now I can say I've seen a ta'veren at work for true. What did you want with me?" And what was he to say to that?

dʒʌs ðɛn, hi hɝd ʃaʊɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə minɝ kæmp, ðə saʊn ʌv ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, laʊɾ ɪnʌf ðət tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stʊd tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ðoʊ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hɪl hɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

Just then, he heard shouting from the Mayener camp, the sound of arguing, loud enough that Two Rivers men stood to peer through the trees, though the side of the hill hid everything.

"fɝs lɛts si wʌɾ ɔl ðəɾ ɪz əbaʊt," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. ðət wəd ɡɪv ɪm taɪm tə θɪŋk. əbaʊt wʌt tə seɪ tə ɡælɛn, ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz.

"First let's see what all that is about," Perrin replied. That would give him time to think. About what to say to Gallenne, and other things.

feɪl weɪɾəd ə fju moʊməns æftɝ pɛɹɪn lɛf bɪfɔɹ tɛlɪŋ ðə sɝvəns ðət ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz wəd si tə ðɛmsɛlvz. meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz soʊ bɪzi stɛɹɪŋ əɾ æliændɝ ðət lini hæd tə plʌk əɾ əɹ sliv bɪfɔɹ ʃi muvd. ðət wəɾ əv tə bi hændəld leɪɾɝ. sɛɾɪŋ əɹ kʌp daʊn, feɪl fɑloʊd ðə θɹi wɪmən tə ðə dɔɹ ə ðə tɛn əz ɪf hɝiɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt ʃi pɔz ðɛɹ.

Faile waited a few moments after Perrin left before telling the servants that she and the others would see to themselves. Maighdin was so busy staring at Alliandre that Lini had to pluck at her sleeve before she moved. That would have to be handled later. Setting her cup down, Faile followed the three women to the door of the tent as if hurrying them, but she paused there.

pɛɹɪn ən ɡælɛn wɝ stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd ðə minɝ kæmp. ɡʊd. moʊst ə tʃɑ feɪl wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ nɑt fɑɹ ɔf. kætʃɪŋ pɛɹɪlinz aɪ, ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd loʊ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ weɪst, wɛɹ noʊ wʌn bɪhaɪn əɹ kəd si. ə kwɪk sɝkjəlɝ moʊʃən fɑloʊd baɪ ə klɛntʃt fɪst. ɪmiɾiətli ðə tɛɹənz ən kɛɹhin bɹoʊk əpɑɹɾ ɪn ɡɹups ə tu əɹ θɹi ən spɹɛɾ aʊt. fɑɹ lɛs ɪlæbɹət ðən meɪɾən hæntɔk, tʃɑ feɪlz sɪɡnəlz səfaɪst. ɪn moʊməns ə skæɾɝd ɹɪŋ ə hɝ pipəl hæd sɝaʊndəd ðə tɛnt, əpɛɹənli ət ɹændəm, tɔkɪŋ aɪdli əɹ pleɪɪŋ ət kæts kɹeɪɾəl. bʌt noʊ wʌn wəd kʌm nɪɹɝ ðən twɛnti peɪsɪz wɪθaʊɾ əɹ ɹəsivɪŋ wɔɹnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə θɹɛʃoʊld.

Perrin and Gallenne were striding off through the trees toward the Mayener camp. Good. Most of Cha Faile was squatting not far off. Catching Parelean's eye, she gestured low in front of her waist, where no one behind her could see. A quick circular motion followed by a clenched fist. Immediately the Tairens and Cairhien broke apart in groups of two or three and spread out. Far less elaborate than Maiden handtalk, Cha Faile's signals sufficed. In moments a scattered ring of her people had surrounded the tent, apparently at random, talking idly or playing at cat's cradle. But no one would come nearer than twenty paces without her receiving warning before they reached the threshold.

ɪt wɑz pɛɹɪn u wɝiɾ əɹ moʊst. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd sʌmθɪŋ moʊmɛntəs əz sun əz æliændɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə flɛʃ, ɪf nɑt wʌt keɪm, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn stʌn baɪ hɝ vaʊ. ɪf i tʊk ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz hɛd tə ɹɪtɝn, tə teɪk ənʌðɝ stæb ət meɪkɪŋ æliændɝ fil kʌmftəɹbəl ɪn əɹ dɪsɪʒən. . . . oʊ, hi dɪd θɪŋk wɪð ɪz hɑɹt wən i ʃəd juz ɪz hɛd. ən wɪð ɪz hɛd wən i ʃəd juz ɪz hɑɹt! ɡɪl pɹɪkt əɹ ət ðə θɔt.

It was Perrin who worried her most. She had expected something momentous as soon as Alliandre appeared in the flesh, if not what came, but he had been stunned by her vow. If he took it into his head to return, to take another stab at making Alliandre feel comfortable in her decision. . . . Oh, he did think with his heart when he should use his head. And with his head when he should use his heart! Guilt pricked her at the thought.

"pəkjuljɝ sɝvəns jə faʊn baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd," bɹəleɪn sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz ə mɑk sɪmpəθi əɾ əɹ saɪd, ən feɪl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd ðə wʊmən kʌm ʌp bɪhaɪn hɝ. lini ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹts, lini ʃeɪkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən bɹəleɪn ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ɡeɪz fɹəm feɪl tə ðɛm. ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs loʊ, bʌt ðə mɑkɪŋ toʊn ɹɪmeɪnd. "ði oʊldəst ət list simz tə noʊ hɝ duɾiz ɪnstɛɾ ə sɪmpli hævɪŋ hɝɾ əbaʊt ðɛm, bʌɾ ənʊɹə tɛlz mi ðə jʌŋɡəst ɪz ə waɪldɝ. vɛɹi wik, ənʊɹə sɛz, nɛɡlədʒəbəl, bʌt waɪldɝz ɔlweɪz kɑz pɹɑbləmz. ði ʌðɝz wɪl kæɹi teɪlz əbaʊt hɝ, ɪf ðeɪ noʊ, ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ʃɪl ɹʌn əweɪ. waɪldɝz ɔlweɪz du, aɪ hɪɹ. ðæts wʌt kʌmz ə pɪkɪŋ ʌp jəɹ meɪdz laɪk stʃɹeɪ dɑɡz."

"Peculiar servants you found by the side of the road," Berelain said in tones of mock sympathy at her side, and Faile gave a start. She had not heard the woman come up behind her. Lini and the others were walking toward the carts, Lini shaking a finger at Maighdin, and Berelain shifted her gaze from Faile to them. She kept her voice low, but the mocking tone remained. "The oldest at least seems to know her duties instead of simply having heard about them, but Annoura tells me the youngest is a wilder. Very weak, Annoura says, negligible, but wilders always cause problems. The others will carry tales about her, if they know, and sooner or later, she will run away. Wilders always do, I hear. That's what comes of picking up your maids like stray dogs."

"ðeɪ sut mi wɛl ɪnʌf," feɪl ɹɪplaɪd kuli. stɪl, ə lɔŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð lini wɑz dɛfənətli niɾəd. ə waɪldɝ? ivən ɪf wik, ðət maɪt pɹuv jusfəl. "aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt jə wɝ fɪt fəɹ haɪɹɪŋ sɝvəns." bɹəleɪn blɪŋkt, ənsɝɾən wʌt ðət mɛnt, ən feɪl kɛɹfəli dɪd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ sæɾəsfækʃən ʃoʊ. tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, ʃi sɛd, "ənʊɹə, wɪl jə meɪk əs pɹaɪvət wɪð ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛns lɪsənɝz?"

"They suit me well enough," Faile replied coolly. Still, a long conversation with Lini was definitely needed. A wilder? Even if weak, that might prove useful. "I always thought you were fit for hiring servants." Berelain blinked, uncertain what that meant, and Faile carefully did not let her satisfaction show. Turning away, she said, "Annoura, will you make us private with a ward against listeners?"

ðəɹ sim lɪɾəl tʃæns ðət siɑnɪɾ əɹ mɑsʊɝi wəd faɪn ɛni ɑpɝtunəɾi tə ivzdʒɹɑp juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ - ʃi wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ɪksploʊʒən wən pɛɹɪn faʊn aʊt dʒʌs haʊ taɪtli ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd ðət pɛɹ hɔltɝd - jɛt ðə waɪz wʌnz ðɛmsɛlvz maɪɾ əv lɝnd. feɪl wɑz ʃʊɹ ɛdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɹɪŋɪŋ siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi dʒɹaɪ.

There seemed little chance that Seonid or Masuri would find any opportunity to eavesdrop using the Power - she was waiting for the explosion when Perrin found out just how tightly the Wise Ones had that pair haltered - yet the Wise Ones themselves might have learned. Faile was sure Edarra and the others were wringing Seonid and Masuri dry.

ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝz biɾɪd bɹeɪdz klɪk sɔfli əz ʃi nɑɾəd. "ɪɾ ɪz dʌn, leɪɾi feɪl," ʃi sɛd, ən bɹəleɪnz lɪps kəmpɹɛs bɹifli. kwaɪt sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ. ðə təmɛɹəɾi ʌv meɪkɪŋ ðə pɹɛzənteɪʃənz hɪɹ ɪn feɪlz oʊn tɛnt! ʃi dɪzɝv mɔɹ ðən hævɪŋ sʌmwʌn stɛp bɪtwin əɹ ən əɹ ædvaɪzɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ.

The Gray sister's beaded braids clicked softly as she nodded. "It is done, Lady Faile," she said, and Berelain's lips compressed briefly. Quite satisfying. The temerity of making the presentations here in Faile's own tent! She deserved more than having someone step between her and her advisor, but it was satisfying.

tʃaɪldiʃli sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ, feɪl ədmɪɾəd, wən ʃi ʃəd bi foʊkəst ɑn ðə mæɾɝ ət hænd. ʃi ɔlmoʊs bɪɾ əɹ lɪp ɪn æɡɹəveɪʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑt daʊɾ əɹ hʌzbənz lʌv, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt tʃɹit bɹəleɪn əz ðə wʊmən dɪzɝvd, ən ðət fɔɹs hɝ, əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl, tə pleɪ ə ɡeɪm wɪð pɛɹɪn tu ɔfən əz ðə ɡeɪmɪŋ bɔɹd. ən ðə pɹaɪz, soʊ bɹəleɪn bɪlivd. ɪf oʊnli pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt səmtaɪmz bɪheɪv əz ɪf i maɪt bi. fɝmli ʃi pʊɾ ɔl ðəɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə waɪfs wɝk tə bi dʌn hɪɹ. ðə pɹæktəkəl saɪd.

Childishly satisfying, Faile admitted, when she should be focused on the matter at hand. She almost bit her lip in aggravation. She did not doubt her husband's love, but she could not treat Berelain as the woman deserved, and that forced her, against her will, to play a game with Perrin too often as the gaming board. And the prize, so Berelain believed. If only Perrin did not sometimes behave as if he might be. Firmly she put all that out of her head. There was a wife's work to be done here. The practical side.

æliændɝ ɡlæns θɔtfəli əɾ ənʊɹə wən ə wɔɹd wɑz mɛnʃənd - ʃi hæd tə ɹilaɪz ɪt mɛn sɪɹiəs tɔk - bʌt wʌt ʃi sɛd wɑz "jɔɹ hʌzbən ɪz ə fɔɹməɾəbəl mæn, leɪɾi feɪl. aɪ min noʊ əfɛns wən aɪ seɪ hɪz blʌf ɪkstɪɹiɝ bɪlaɪz ə ʃɹud maɪnd. wɪð ɑmɑdɪʃiə ɑn əɹ dɔɹstɛp, wi ɪn ɡildən pleɪ deɪz deɪmɑɹ ə nəsɛsəɾi, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk aɪ hæv ɛvɝ bɪn dænst soʊ swɪfli əɹ soʊ dɛfli tə ə dɪsɪʒən əz jəɹ lɔɹd dɪd. ðə hɪn ʌv ə θɹɛt hɪɹ, ə fɹaʊn ðɛɹ. ə vɛɹi fɔɹməɾəbəl mæn."

Alliandre glanced thoughtfully at Annoura when a ward was mentioned - she had to realize it meant serious talk - but what she said was "Your husband is a formidable man, Lady Faile. I mean no offense when I say his bluff exterior belies a shrewd mind. With Amadicia on our doorstep, we in Ghealdan play Daes Dae'mar of necessity, but I do not think I have ever been danced so swiftly or so deftly to a decision as your Lord did. The hint of a threat here, a frown there. A very formidable man."

ðɪs taɪm haɪɾɪŋ əɹ smaɪl tʊk səm ɛfɝɾ ɑn feɪlz pɑɹt. ðiz saʊθlændɝz sɛɾ ə ɡɹeɪt stɔɹ baɪ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk æliændɝ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪt lɝnɪŋ ðət pɛɹɪn sɪmpli sɛd wʌɾ i bɪlivd - tu fɹili baɪ hæf, ət taɪmz - ən pipəl wɪð diviəs maɪnz sɔ kælkjəleɪʃən ɪn ɪz ɑnəsti. "hi spɛn səm taɪm ɪn kɛɹhin," ʃi sɛd. lɛɾ æliændɝ meɪk ə ðət wʌt ʃi wʊd. "wi kən spik fɹili hɪɹ, seɪf bɪhaɪn ənʊɹə sədaɪz wɔɹɾɪŋ. ɪts pleɪn jə də nɑt wɑnə ɹɪtɝn tə bɛθɔl jɛt. ɪz jəɹ oʊθ tə pɛɹɪn, ən ɪz tə ju, nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə taɪ hɪm tə ju?" səm hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ hæd pəkjuljɝ aɪdiəz ʌv wʌt fiəlti ɪnteɪld.

This time hiding her smile took some effort on Faile's part. These southlanders set a great store by the Game of Houses, and she did not think Alliandre would appreciate learning that Perrin simply said what he believed - too freely by half, at times - and people with devious minds saw calculation in his honesty. "He spent some time in Cairhien," she said. Let Alliandre make of that what she would. "We can speak freely here, safe behind Annoura Sedai's warding. It is plain you do not want to return to Bethal yet. Is your oath to Perrin, and his to you, not enough to tie him to you?" Some here in the south had peculiar ideas of what fealty entailed.

bɹəleɪn saɪlənli tʊk ə pəzɪʃən tə feɪlz ɹaɪt, ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ ənʊɹə dɪd ðə seɪm ɑn əɹ lɛft, soʊ ðəɾ æliændɝ faʊn hɝsɛlf kənfɹʌntəd baɪ ɔl θɹi. ɪt sɝpɹaɪz feɪl ðət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl ɪn wɪð əɹ plæn wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz - wɪθaʊt daʊɾ ənʊɹə hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɹizənz, ən feɪl wʊɾə ɡɪvən ə pɹɪɾi tə noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ - bʌt ʃi fɛl noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðət bɹəleɪn dɪd soʊ. wʌn kæʒəwəl mɑkɪŋ sɛntəns kəd spɔɪl ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli əbaʊt pɛɹɪnz skɪl ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt ɡeɪm, jɛt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd nɑt kʌm. ɪn ə weɪ, ðəɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd hɝ. wʌns ʃi hæd dɪspaɪz bɹəleɪn; ʃi stɪl heɪɾəd hɝ, dip ən hɑt, bʌt ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ ɹɪspɛk hæd ɹipleɪs kəntɛmpt. ðə wʊmən nu wən ðɛɹ "ɡeɪm" hæd tə bi pʊɾ əsaɪd. ɪf nɑt fəɹ pɛɹɪn, feɪl θɔt ʃi maɪɾ æktʃəli  hæv laɪk hɝ! bɹifli, tə ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃ ðət heɪtfəl θɔt, ʃi pɪktʃɝd hɝsɛlf ʃeɪvɪŋ bɹəleɪn bɔld. ʃi wɑz ə dʒeɪɾ ən ə tʃɹʌl! ən nɑt sʌmθɪŋ feɪl kəɾ əlaʊ tə daɪvɝɾ əɹ naʊ.

Berelain silently took a position to Faile's right, and a moment later Annoura did the same on her left, so that Alliandre found herself confronted by all three. It surprised Faile that the Aes Sedai fell in with her plan without knowing what it was - without doubt Annoura had her own reasons, and Faile would have given a pretty to know what they were - but she felt no surprise that Berelain did so. One casual mocking sentence could spoil everything, especially about Perrin's skill in the Great Game, yet she was sure it would not come. In a way, that irritated her. Once she had despised Berelain; she still hated her, deep and hot, but grudging respect had replaced contempt. The woman knew when their "game" had to be put aside. If not for Perrin, Faile thought she might actually have liked her! Briefly, to extinguish that hateful thought, she pictured herself shaving Berelain bald. She was a jade and a trull! And not something Faile could allow to divert her now.

æliændɝ stʌɾid itʃ ə ðə wɪmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ɪn tɝn, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ ɛvəɾəns ə nɝvəsnəs. teɪkɪŋ ʌp əɹ waɪnkʌp əɡɛn, ʃi sɪp kæʒəwəli ən spoʊk wɪð saɪz ən ɹufəl smaɪlz əz ɪf əɹ wɝdz wɝ nɑt ɹɪli əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz ðeɪ saʊndəd. "aɪ min tə kip maɪ oʊθ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt jə mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ aɪ hoʊp fəɹ mɔɹ. wʌns jəɹ hʌzbənd ɡoʊz, aɪm lɛft əz aɪ wɑz. wɝs, pɝhæps, əntɪl səm tænʒəbəl eɪd kʌmz fɹəm ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm ɪn ðə laɪt. ðə pɹɑfət kəd ɹuən bɛθɔl əɹ ivən dʒəhænə ɪtsɛlf əz i dɪd sæmɝə, ən aɪ kænɑt stɑp hɪm. ən ɪf i sʌmhaʊ lɝnz ə maɪ oʊθ. . . . hi sɛz hiz kʌm tə ʃoʊ əs haʊ tə sɝv ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪn ðə laɪt, bʌt hiz ðə wʌn u ʃoʊz ðət weɪ, ən aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk hɪl bi plizd wɪð ɛniwʌn u faɪnz ənʌðɝ."

Alliandre studied each of the women in front of her in turn, but she gave no evidence of nervousness. Taking up her winecup again, she sipped casually and spoke with sighs and rueful smiles as if her words were not really as important as they sounded. "I mean to keep my oath, of course, but you must understand that I hoped for more. Once your husband goes, I am left as I was. Worse, perhaps, until some tangible aid comes from the Lord Dragon, blessed be his name in the Light. The Prophet could ruin Bethal or even Jehannah itself as he did Samara, and I cannot stop him. And if he somehow learns of my oath. . . . He says he has come to show us how to serve the Lord Dragon in the Light, but he is the one who shows that way, and I cannot think he will be pleased with anyone who finds another."

"ɪɾ ɪz ɡʊd ðət jəl kip jəɹ oʊθ," feɪl toʊld əɹ dʒɹaɪli. "ɪf jə wɑn mɔɹ ə maɪ hʌzbənd, pɝhæps jə ʃəd də mɔɹ. pɝhæps jə ʃəɾ əkʌmpəni hɪm wən i ɡoʊz saʊθ tə mit ðə pɹɑfət. ʌv kɔɹs, jəl wɑn jəɹ oʊn soʊlʒɝz wɪð ju, bʌɾ aɪ sədʒɛs noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðə fɝst əz wɪð hɝ. ʃæl wi sɪt?" teɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ pɛɹɪn hæd veɪkeɪɾəd, ʃi moʊʃən bɹəleɪn ən ənʊɹə tə ðoʊz ɑn iðɝ saɪd, ən oʊnli ðən dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ fəɹ æliændɝ.

"It is good that you will keep your oath," Faile told her dryly. "If you want more of my husband, perhaps you should do more. Perhaps you should accompany him when he goes south to meet the Prophet. Of course, you will want your own soldiers with you, but I suggest no more than the First has with her. Shall we sit?" Taking the chair Perrin had vacated, she motioned Berelain and Annoura to those on either side, and only then gestured toward another for Alliandre.

ðə kwin sæt sloʊli, stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ət feɪl, nɑt nɝvəs bʌɾ əstaʊndɪd. "waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt wəɾ aɪ də ðæt?" ʃi ɪkskleɪmd. "leɪɾi feɪl, ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt wɪl teɪk ɛni ɪkskjus tə ɪnkɹis ðɛɹ dɛpɹədeɪʃənz ɪn ɡildən, ən kɪŋ eɪlɹən maɪt dɪsaɪd tə sɛn ən ɑɹmi nɔɹθ əz wɛl. ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl!"

The Queen sat slowly, staring wide-eyed at Faile, not nervous but astounded. "Why in the Light would I do that?" she exclaimed. "Lady Faile, the Children of the Light will take any excuse to increase their depredations in Ghealdan, and King Ailron might decide to send an army north as well. It's impossible!"

"ðə waɪf ə jəɹ lidʒ lɔɹɾ æsks ɪɾ ə ju, æliændɝ," feɪl sɛd fɝmli.

"The wife of your liege lord asks it of you, Alliandre," Faile said firmly.

ɪt dɪdn sim pɑsəbəl ðəɾ æliændɝz aɪz kəd waɪɾən fɑɹðɝ, jɛt ðeɪ dɪd. ʃi lʊk tə ənʊɹə ən faʊn oʊnli ɪmpɝɾɝbəbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm lʊkɪŋ bæk. "ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz hɑloʊ. swɑloʊɪŋ, ʃi æɾəd, "ʌv kɔɹs, əl də əz jə . . . æsk . . . maɪ leɪɾi."

It didn't seem possible that Alliandre's eyes could widen farther, yet they did. She looked to Annoura and found only imperturbable Aes Sedai calm looking back. "Of course," she said after a moment. Her voice was hollow. Swallowing, she added, "Of course, I will do as you . . . ask . . . my Lady."

feɪl hɪɾ əɹ ɹɪlif bɪhaɪn ə ɡɹeɪʃəs nɑɾ ʌv æksɛptəns. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ æliændɝ tə bɔk. ðəɾ æliændɝ kəd swɛɹ fiəlti wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðət mɛnt - ðət ʃi fɛlt ɪt nɛsəsɛɹi tə seɪ ðət ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə kip əɹ oʊθ! - hæɾ oʊnli kənfɝm feɪlz bɪlif ðət ðə wʊmən kəd nɑt bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd. baɪ ɔl əkaʊns, æliændɝ hæd dɛlt wɪð mæsimə baɪ jildɪŋ tə hɪm. sloʊli, tə bi ʃʊɹ, wɪð lɪɾəl ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs ən oʊnli wən ʃi hæd tə, jɛt səbmɪʃən kəd bɪkʌm ə hæbət. bæk ɪn bɛθɔl, wɪð nʌθɪŋ vɪzəbəl tʃeɪnʒd, haʊ sun bɪfɔɹ ʃi wəd dɪsaɪd tə hɛdʒ wɪð ə wɔɹnɪŋ tə mæsimə? ʃi hæd fɛl ðə weɪɾ ə hɝ oʊθ; naʊ feɪl kəd laɪɾən əɹ bɝɾən.

Faile hid her relief behind a gracious nod of acceptance. She had expected Alliandre to balk. That Alliandre could swear fealty without realizing what that meant - that she felt it necessary to say that she intended to keep her oath! - had only confirmed Faile's belief that the woman could not be left behind. By all accounts, Alliandre had dealt with Masema by yielding to him. Slowly, to be sure, with little other choice and only when she had to, yet submission could become a habit. Back in Bethal, with nothing visible changed, how soon before she would decide to hedge with a warning to Masema? She had felt the weight of her oath; now Faile could lighten her burden.

"aɪ æm hæpi ðət jəl bi əkʌmpəniɪŋ ʌs," ʃi sɛd wɔɹmli. ən tʃɹuli, ʃi wɑz. "maɪ hʌzbən dʌz nɑt fɝɡɛt ðoʊz u ɹɛndɝ ɪm sɝvəs. wʌn sətʃ sɝvəs wəd bi tə ɹaɪt tə jəɹ noʊbəlz, tɛlɪŋ əm ðəɾ ə mæn ɪn ðə saʊθ əz ɹeɪz ðə bænɝ ə meɪnɛðɝən." bɹəleɪnz hɛd hæf dʒɝkt ɝaʊn ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən ənʊɹə wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə blɪŋk.

"I am happy that you will be accompanying us," she said warmly. And truly, she was. "My husband does not forget those who render him service. One such service would be to write to your nobles, telling them that a man in the south has raised the banner of Manetheren." Berelain's head half jerked around in surprise, and Annoura went so far as to blink.

"maɪ leɪɾi," æliændɝ sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, "hæf ə ðɛm wɪl sɛnd wɝd tə ðə pɹɑfəɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ ɹəsiv maɪ lɛɾɝ. ðeɪ ɑɹ tɛɹəfaɪɾ ə hɪm, ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz wʌɾ i maɪt du." dʒʌs ðə ɹɪspɑns feɪl hæd hoʊp fɔɹ.

"My Lady," Alliandre said urgently, "half of them will send word to the Prophet as soon as they receive my letter. They are terrified of him, and the Light alone knows what he might do." Just the response Faile had hoped for.

"wɪtʃ ɪz waɪ jəl ɹaɪɾ ɪm ɔlsoʊ, seɪɪŋ ðət juv ɡæðɝɾ ə fju soʊlʒɝz tə dil wɪð ðɪs mæn pɝsənəli. æftɝ ɔl, ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪz tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hæv tə tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən tə sətʃ ə maɪnɝ mæɾɝ."

"Which is why you will write him also, saying that you have gathered a few soldiers to deal with this man personally. After all, the Prophet of the Lord Dragon is too important to have to turn his attention to such a minor matter."

"vɛɹi ɡʊd," ənʊɹə mɝmɝd. "noʊ wʌn wɪl noʊ hu ɪz hu."

"Very good," Annoura murmured. "No one will know who is who."

bɹəleɪn læft ɪn dɪlaɪɾəd əpɹuvəl, bɝn hɝ!

Berelain laughed in delighted approval, burn her!

"maɪ leɪɾi," æliændɝ bɹiðd, "aɪ sɛd ðət maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɪz fɔɹməɾəbəl. meɪ aɪ æd ðəɾ ɪz waɪf ɪz ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz fɔɹməɾəbəl?"

"My Lady," Alliandre breathed, "I said that my Lord Perrin is formidable. May I add that his wife is every bit as formidable?"

feɪl tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə bæsk tu vɪzəbli. naʊ ʃi hæd tə sɛnd wɝd tə hɝ pipəl ɪn bɛθɔl. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ðæt. ɪkspleɪnɪŋ tə pɛɹɪn wʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ ðən dɪfəkəlt, bʌɾ ivən i kəd nɑɾ əv kɛpt ɪz tɛmpɝ ɪf ʃi hæd kɪdnæp ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən.

Faile tried not to bask too visibly. Now she had to send word to her people in Bethal. In a way, she regretted that. Explaining to Perrin would have been more than difficult, but even he could not have kept his temper if she had kidnapped the Queen of Ghealdan.

moʊst ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz əpɪɹd tə bi ɡæðɝɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðɛɹ kæmp, sɝaʊndɪŋ tɛn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ði æbsəns ə lænsɪz sɛd ðə ɹaɪɾɝz wɝ skaʊts. ðə mɛn əfʊt mɪld ən pʊʃt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt kloʊsɝ. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i hɝd θʌndɝ əɡɛn, nɑt soʊ dɪstənt, bʌɾ ɪɾ oʊnli tʌtʃt ði ɛdʒ ʌv əwɛɹnəs.

Most of the Winged Guards appeared to be gathered on the edge of their camp, surrounding ten of their number on horseback. The absence of lances said the riders were scouts. The men afoot milled and pushed, trying to get closer. Perrin thought he heard thunder again, not so distant, but it only touched the edge of awareness.

əz i pɹipɛɹd tə pʊʃ ɪz weɪ θɹu, ɡælɛn ɹɔɹd, "meɪk weɪ, jə meɪnʒi haʊnz!" hɛdz wɪpt ɝaʊnd, ən mɛn ɹɪəl saɪdweɪz ɪn ðə mæs, oʊpənɪŋ ə nɛɹoʊ pæθ. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i kɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn meɪnʒi haʊnz. pɹɑbli ɝn ɪm ə pʌntʃ ɪn ðə noʊz. ɪt maɪt bi wɝθ ə tʃɹaɪ.

As he prepared to push his way through, Gallenne roared, "Make way, you mangy hounds!" Heads whipped around, and men wriggled sideways in the mass, opening a narrow path. Perrin wondered what would happen if he called the Two Rivers men mangy hounds. Probably earn him a punch in the nose. It might be worth a try.

nɹɛl ən ði ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz wɝ wɪð ðə skaʊts. soʊ wɝ sɛvən mɛn əfʊt wɪð ðɛɹ hænz taɪd bɪhaɪn əm ən lɛd ɹoʊps ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks, ɔl ʃʌflɪŋ ðɛɹ fiɾ ən hʌntʃɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən skaʊlɪŋ dɪfaɪəns əɹ fɪɹ əɹ boʊθ. ðɛɹ kloʊðz wɝ stɪf wɪð oʊl fɪlθ, ðoʊ səm hæd bɪn faɪn wʌns. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðeɪ smɛl hɛvəli ʌv wʊdzmoʊk. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, səm ə ðə maʊntəd soʊlʒɝz hæd sʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən wʌn əɹ tu sim tə bi nɝsɪŋ bɝnz. ɛɹæm stʊd stʌɾiɪŋ ðə pɹɪznɝz, fɹaʊnɪŋ slaɪtli.

Nurelle and the other officers were with the scouts. So were seven men afoot with their hands tied behind them and lead ropes around their necks, all shuffling their feet and hunching their shoulders and scowling defiance or fear or both. Their clothes were stiff with old filth, though some had been fine once. Strangely, they smelled heavily of woodsmoke. For that matter, some of the mounted soldiers had soot on their faces, and one or two seemed to be nursing burns. Aram stood studying the prisoners, frowning slightly.

ɡælɛn tʊk ə stæns wɪð ɪz fiɾ əpɑɹɾ ən fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps, hɪz wʌn aɪ duɪŋ əz ɡʊɾ ə dʒɑb ʌv ɡlɛɹɪŋ əz moʊs mɛnz tu. "wʌt hæpənd?" hi dɪmændəd. "maɪ skaʊts ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bɹɪŋ bæk ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, nɑt ɹæɡ-pɪkɝz!"

Gallenne took a stance with his feet apart and fists on his hips, his one eye doing as good a job of glaring as most men's two. "What happened?" he demanded. "My scouts are supposed to bring back information, not rag-pickers!"

"aɪ wɪl lɛɾ ɔɹɾɪs ɹipɔɹt, maɪ lɔɹd," nɹɛl sɛd. "hi wɑz ðɛɹ. skwɑd-mæn ɔɹɾɪs!"

"I will let Ortis report, my Lord," Nurelle said. "He was there. Squad-man Ortis!"

ə soʊlʒɝ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl tə baʊ, ɡɔntələɾəd hæn pɹɛs tə hɑɹt. hɪz hɛlmət wɑz pleɪn, wɪθaʊt ðə θɪn plumz ən wɪŋz ðət wɝ wɝkt ɪn ðə saɪdz ʌv ɔfəsɝz' hɛlməts. bɪniθ ðə ɹɪm, ə lɪvɪd bɝn stʊɾ aʊt pleɪnli ɑn ɪz feɪs. ði ʌðɝ tʃik hæɾ ə skɑɹ ðət pʊld ʌp ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maʊθ. "maɪ lɔɹd ɡælɛn, maɪ lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə ɡɹævəli vɔɪs. "wi keɪm ɑn ðiz tɝnəp-iɾɝz əbaʊt tu liɡz tə ðə wɛst, maɪ lɔɹdz. bɝnɪŋ ə fɑɹm, wɪð ðə fɑɹm foʊk ɪnsaɪd. ə wʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə wɪndoʊ, ən wʌn ə ðiz skʌm bæʃt əɹ hɛɾ ɪn. noʊɪŋ haʊ lɔɹɾ eɪbɑɹə filz, wi pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ɪt. wi wɝ tu leɪt tə seɪv ɛnibəɾi, bʌt wi kɑt ðiz sɛvən. ðə ɹɛst ɡɑɾ əweɪ."

A soldier in his middle years scrambled down from his saddle to bow, gauntleted hand pressed to heart. His helmet was plain, without the thin plumes and wings that were worked in the sides of officers' helmets. Beneath the rim, a livid burn stood out plainly on his face. The other cheek had a scar that pulled up the corner of his mouth. "My Lord Gallenne, my Lord Aybara," he said in a gravelly voice. "We came on these turnip-eaters about two leagues to the west, my Lords. Burning a farm, with the farm folk inside. A woman tried to get out a window, and one of these scum bashed her head in. Knowing how Lord Aybara feels, we put a stop to it. We were too late to save anybody, but we caught these seven. The rest got away."

"pipəl ɑɹ ɔfən tɛmptəd tə slaɪd bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ," wʌn ə ðə pɹɪznɝz sɛd sʌɾənli. "ðeɪ mʌs bi ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðə kɑst." ə tɔl, lin mæn wɪð ə steɪtli ɛɹ, hɪz vɔɪs wɑz smuð ən ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd, bʌɾ ɪz koʊt wɑz əz dɝɾi əz ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, ən i hæd nɑt ʃeɪvd ɪn tu əɹ θɹi deɪz. ðə pɹɑfət dɪd nɑt sim tə əpɹuv ʌv weɪstɪŋ taɪm ɑn θɪŋz laɪk ɹeɪzɝz. əɹ wɑʃɪŋ. wɪð ɪz hænz baʊn ən ə ɹoʊp ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, hi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz kæptɝz wɪθaʊt ðə lis bɪɾ ə fɪɹ. hi wɑz ɔl supɝsɪliəs dɪfaɪəns. "jɔɹ soʊlʒɝz də nɑɾ ɪmpɹɛs mi," hi sɛd. "ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, blɛsɪd bi hɪz neɪm ɪn ðə laɪt, hæz dɪstʃɹɔɪd ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɑɹmiz baɪ fɑɹ ðən jəɹ tæɡ ɛnd. jə meɪ kɪl ʌs, bʌt wɪl bi əvɛnʒd wən ðə pɹɑfət spɪlz jəɹ blʌɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nʌn ə jəl sɝvaɪv əs lɔŋ. hɪl tʃɹaɪəmf ɪn faɪɝ ən ɪn blʌd." hi fɪnɪʃt ɑn ə ɹɪŋɪŋ toʊn, hɪz bæk stʃɹeɪɾ əz ən aɪɝn ɹɑd. mɝmɝz ɹæn θɹu ðə lɪsnɪŋ soʊlʒɝz. ðeɪ nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət mæsimə hæd dɪstʃɹɔɪd lɑɹdʒɝ ɑɹmiz ðən ðɛɹz.

"People are often tempted to slide back into the Shadow," one of the prisoners said suddenly. "They must be reminded of the cost." A tall, lean man with a stately air, his voice was smooth and educated, but his coat was as dirty as any of the others, and he had not shaved in two or three days. The Prophet did not seem to approve of wasting time on things like razors. Or washing. With his hands bound and a rope around his neck, he glared at his captors without the least bit of fear. He was all supercilious defiance. "Your soldiers do not impress me," he said. "The Prophet of the Lord Dragon, blessed be his name in the Light, has destroyed greater armies by far than your tag end. You may kill us, but we will be avenged when the Prophet spills your blood on the ground. None of you will survive us long. He will triumph in fire and in blood." He finished on a ringing tone, his back straight as an iron rod. Murmurs ran through the listening soldiers. They knew very well that Masema had destroyed larger armies than theirs.

"hæŋ ðɛm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. əɡɛn, hi hɝd ðət θʌndɝ.

"Hang them," Perrin said. Again, he heard that thunder.

hævɪŋ ɡɪvən ði ɔɹɾɝ, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf wɑtʃ. dɪspaɪt ðə mɝmɝz, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ læk ə ɹɛɾi hænz. səm ə ðə pɹɪznɝz bɪɡæn tə wip əz ðɛɹ lɛd ɹoʊps wɝ θɹoʊn oʊvɝ tʃɹi lɪmz. ə wʌns-fæt mæn huz wɑɾəlz hʌŋ ɪn foʊlz ʃaʊɾəd ðəɾ i ɹɪpɛntɪd, ðəɾ i wəd sɝv ɛni mæstɝ ðeɪ neɪmd. ə bɔld-hɛɾəd fɛloʊ hu lʊkt əz tʌf əz læmɡwɪn θɹæʃt ən skɹimd əntɪl ðə ɹoʊp kʌɾ ɔf ɪz haʊlz. oʊnli ðə smuð-vɔɪs mæn dɪd nɑt kɪk əɹ faɪt, ivən wən ðə nus dʒɹu taɪɾ ɑn ɪz nɛk. tə ði ɛn i ɡlɛɹd dɪfaɪəns.

Having given the order, he made himself watch. Despite the murmurs, there was no lack of ready hands. Some of the prisoners began to weep as their lead ropes were thrown over tree limbs. A once-fat man whose wattles hung in folds shouted that he repented, that he would serve any master they named. A bald-headed fellow who looked as tough as Lamgwin thrashed and screamed until the rope cut off his howls. Only the smooth-voiced man did not kick or fight, even when the noose drew tight on his neck. To the end he glared defiance.

"æt list wʌn ə ðɛm nu haʊ tə daɪ," ɡælɛn ɡɹaʊld əz ðə læs bɑɾi wɛn lɪmp. hi fɹaʊn ət ðə mɛn dɛkɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz əz ɪf ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðeɪ hæd nɑt pʊɾ ʌp mɔɹ faɪt.

"At least one of them knew how to die," Gallenne growled as the last body went limp. He frowned at the men decorating the trees as if regretting they had not put up more fight.

"ɪf ðoʊz pipəl wɝ sɝvɪŋ ðə ʃædoʊ," ɛɹæm bɪɡæn, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "fɝɡɪv mi, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, bʌt wɪl ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əpɹuv ə ðɪs?"

"If those people were serving the Shadow," Aram began, then hesitated. "Forgive me, Lord Perrin, but will the Lord Dragon approve of this?"

pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, əɡæst. "laɪt, ɛɹæm, jə hɝd wʌt ðeɪ dɪd! ɹænd wʊɾəv pʊt ðə ɹoʊps ɑn ðɛɹ nɛks hɪmsɛlf!" hi θɔt ɹænd wəd hæv, hoʊpt i wəd hæv. ɹænd wɑz fɪkst ɑn wɛldɪŋ ðə neɪʃənz təɡɛðɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl, ən i hæd dʌn lɪɾəl kaʊntɪŋ ə kɑs tə də soʊ.

Perrin gave a start and stared at him, aghast. "Light, Aram, you heard what they did! Rand would've put the ropes on their necks himself!" He thought Rand would have, hoped he would have. Rand was fixed on welding the nations together before the Last Battle, and he had done little counting of cost to do so.

mɛnz hɛdz dʒɝkt ʌp əz θʌndɝ pild laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɔl tə hɪɹ, ðən kloʊsɝ, ən əɡɛn kloʊsɝ stɪl. ə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd, fɛl, ɹoʊz əɡɛn, tʌɡɪŋ pɛɹɪnz koʊɾ əz ɪt slæʃt ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. laɪtnɪŋ fɔɹkt ɪn ə klaʊdləs skaɪ. ɪn ðə minɝ kæmp, hɔɹsəz wɪniɾ ən ɹɪɹɾ ət ðɛɹ taɪz. θʌndɝ tɑld ɹɪpiɾɪdli, ən laɪtnɪŋ ɹɪθd ɪn sɪlvɝ-blu sneɪks, ən bɪniθ ə bɝnɪŋ sʌn, ɹeɪn fɛl, fæt skæɾɝd dʒɹɑps ðət splæʃt faʊntənz ə dʌst wɛɹ ðeɪ hɪt bɛɹ ɡɹaʊnd. pɛɹɪn waɪpt wʌn fɹəm ɪz tʃik ən pɪɹɾ ət dæmp fɪŋɡɝz ɪn əmeɪzmənt.

Men's heads jerked up as thunder pealed loud enough for all to hear, then closer, and again closer still. A wind gusted, fell, rose again, tugging Perrin's coat as it slashed this way and that. Lightning forked in a cloudless sky. In the Mayener camp, horses whinnied and reared at their ties. Thunder tolled repeatedly, and lightning writhed in silver-blue snakes, and beneath a burning sun, rain fell, fat scattered drops that splashed fountains of dust where they hit bare ground. Perrin wiped one from his cheek and peered at damp fingers in amazement.

ɪn moʊməns ðə stɔɹm wɑz ɡɔn, θʌndɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn istwɝd. θɝsti ɡɹaʊn əbzɔɹb ðə ɹeɪndʒɹɑps ðət hæd fɔlən, ðə sʌn beɪkt əz fɪɹsli əz ɛvɝ, ən oʊnli flɪkɝɪŋ laɪts ɪn ðə skaɪ ən feɪɾɪŋ bumz sɛd ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæd hæpənd. soʊlʒɝz stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ənsɝteɪnli. ɡælɛn pɹaɪɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz fɹəm ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd wɪð ən ɑbviəs ɛfɝt.

In moments the storm was gone, thunder and lightning rolling on eastward. Thirsty ground absorbed the raindrops that had fallen, the sun baked as fiercely as ever, and only flickering lights in the sky and fading booms said that anything had happened. Soldiers stared at each other uncertainly. Gallenne pried his fingers from the hilt of his sword with an obvious effort.

"ðɪs . . . ðɪs kæn bi ðə dɑɹk wʌnz wɝk," ɛɹæm sɛd, ən flɪntʃt. noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ə nætʃɹəl stɔɹm laɪk ðæt. "ɪt minz ðə wɛðɝ ɪz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ, dʌzn ɪt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn? ðə wɛðɝ ɪz gɑnə bi ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn?"

"This . . . this can't be the Dark One's work," Aram said, and flinched. No one had ever seen a natural storm like that. "It means the weather is changing, doesn't it, Lord Perrin? The weather is going to be right again?"

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə tɛl ðə mæn nɑt tə kɔl ɪm ðæt, bʌɾ i kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪð ə saɪ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hi sɛd. wʌt wɑz ɪt ɡɔl hæd sɛd? "ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒəz, ɛɹæm." hi hæd dʒʌs nɛvɝ θɔt ðəɾ i wəɾ əv tə tʃeɪnʒ, tu.

Perrin opened his mouth to tell the man not to call him that, but he closed it again with a sigh. "I don't know," he said. What was it Gaul had said? "Everything changes, Aram." He had just never thought that he would have to change, too.


tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən


CHAPTER 11

kwɛstʃənz ən ən oʊθ


Questions and an Oath

ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə hjudʒ steɪbəl smɛld ʌv oʊl heɪ ən hɔɹs dʌŋ. ən blʌd, ən bɝn flɛʃ. wɪð ɔl ðə dɔɹz kloʊzd, ði ɛɹ fɛl θɪk. tu læntɝnz ɡeɪv lɪɾəl laɪt, ən ʃædoʊz fɪl moʊst ə ði ɪntɪɹiɝ. ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹoʊz ə stɔlz, hɔɹsəz wɪkɝd nɝvəsli. ðə mæn hæŋɪŋ baɪ hɪz ɹɪsts fɹəm ə ɹuf bim ɡeɪv ə loʊ moʊn, ðən ə ɹæɡəd kɑf. hɪz hɛd fɛl daʊn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. hi wɑz ə tɔl mæn, wɛl-mʌsəld, ɪf ɹæðɝ ðə wɝs fəɹ wɛɹ.

The air in the huge stable smelled of old hay and horse dung. And blood, and burned flesh. With all the doors closed, the air felt thick. Two lanterns gave little light, and shadows filled most of the interior. In the long rows of stalls, horses whickered nervously. The man hanging by his wrists from a roof beam gave a low moan, then a ragged cough. His head fell down on his chest. He was a tall man, well-muscled, if rather the worse for wear.

əbɹʌpli sɪvænə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪz tʃɛs noʊ lɔŋɡɝ muvd. ðə dʒɛm-stʌɾɪd ɹɪŋz ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɡlɪɾɝd ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin əz ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd kɝtli tə ɹiɑli.

Abruptly Sevanna realized that his chest no longer moved. The gem-studded rings on her fingers glittered red and green as she gestured curtly to Rhiale.

ðə fleɪm-hɛɹd wʊmən pʊʃt ðə mænz hɛɾ ʌp ən θʌm bæk wʌn aɪləd, ðən pɹɛst ən ɪɹ tə hɪz tʃɛst, kɛɹləs ə ðə stɪl-smoʊldɝɪŋ splɪntɝz ðət pɛpɝd hɪm. wɪð ə saʊn ə dɪsɡʌst, ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd. "hi ɪz dɛd. wi ʃʊɾə lɛf ðɪs tə ðə meɪɾənz, sɪvænə, əɹ ðə blæk aɪz. aɪ də nɑt daʊt wi kɪld ɪm baɪ ɪɡnɝəns."

The flame-haired woman pushed the man's head up and thumbed back one eyelid, then pressed an ear to his chest, careless of the still-smoldering splinters that peppered him. With a sound of disgust, she straightened. "He is dead. We should have left this to the Maidens, Sevanna, or the Black Eyes. I do not doubt we killed him by ignorance."

sɪvænəz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ɪn ə klæɾɝ ə bɹeɪslɪts. ðeɪ ɹæn nɪɹli tə hɝ ɛlboʊz, ə noʊɾəsəbəl weɪɾ ɪn ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi ən dʒɛmz, jɛt ʃi wʊɾə wɔɹn ɛvɹi wʌn ʃi oʊn ɪf ʃi kʊd. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. pʊɾɪŋ pɹɪznɝz tə ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz nɑt ðə wɝk ʌv waɪz wʌnz, bʌt ɹiɑli nu waɪ ðeɪ hæd tə də ðɪs ðɛmsɛlvz. ðə loʊn sɝvaɪvɝ ə tɛn maʊntəd mɛn u θɔt ðeɪ kəd dɪfit twɛnti meɪɾənz kəz ðeɪ ɹoʊd hɔɹsəz, ðə mæn hæɾ ɔlsoʊ bɪn ðə fɝst sintʃæn kæptʃɝɾ ɪn ðə tɛn deɪz sɪns ðɛɹ ɝaɪvəl ɪn ðɪs lænd.

Sevanna's mouth tightened, and she shifted her shawl in a clatter of bracelets. They ran nearly to her elbows, a noticeable weight in gold and ivory and gems, yet she would have worn every one she owned if she could. None of the other women said anything. Putting prisoners to the question was not the work of Wise Ones, but Rhiale knew why they had to do this themselves. The lone survivor of ten mounted men who thought they could defeat twenty Maidens because they rode horses, the man had also been the first Seanchan captured in the ten days since their arrival in this land.

"hi wʊɾə lɪvd ɪf i hæd nɑt fɔt ðə peɪn soʊ hɑɹd, ɹiɑli," sʌmɛɝɪn sɛd faɪnəli, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ə stʃɹɔŋ mæn fəɹ ə wɛtləndɝ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ æksɛpt peɪn. stɪl, hi toʊld əs mʌtʃ."

"He would have lived if he had not fought the pain so hard, Rhiale," Someryn said finally, shaking her head. "A strong man for a wetlander, but he could not accept pain. Still, he told us much."

sɪvænə aɪɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ ʃi hɪd sɑɹkæzəm. əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn, sʌmɛɝɪn wɔɹ mɔɹ bɹeɪslɪts ən nɛkləsɪz ðən ɛni wʊmən ðəɹ ɪksɛp sɪvænə hɝsɛlf, leɪɝz ə faɪɝdʒɹɑps ən ɛmɹəlz, ɹubiz ən sæfaɪɝz, ɔlmoʊs kənsilɪŋ ə tu-fʊl bʊzəm ðəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz wʊɾə bɪn hæf bɛɹd wɪð əɹ blaʊs əndʌn ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ skɝt. hɝ ʃɔl, taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst, hɪd nʌθɪŋ. ət taɪmz ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl fəɹ sɪvænə tə tɛl wɛðɝ sʌmɛɝɪn wɑz kɑpiɪŋ əɹ əɹ kəmpiɾɪŋ wɪð hɝ.

Sevanna eyed her sideways, trying to see whether she hid sarcasm. As tall as most men, Someryn wore more bracelets and necklaces than any woman there except Sevanna herself, layers of firedrops and emeralds, rubies and sapphires, almost concealing a too-full bosom that otherwise would have been half bared with her blouse undone almost to her skirt. Her shawl, tied around her waist, hid nothing. At times it was difficult for Sevanna to tell whether Someryn was copying her or competing with her.

"mʌtʃ!" mɹə ɪkskleɪmd. ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə læntɝn ʃi hɛld, hɝ lɔŋ feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪmɝ ðən juʒəwəl, ðoʊ ðət hɑɹdli sim pɑsəbəl. mɹə kəd faɪn ðə dɑɹk saɪɾ ə ðə nundeɪ sʌn. "ðæɾ ɪz pipəl laɪ tu deɪz wɛst ɪn ðə sɪɾi kɔld æmədɔɹ? wi nu ðæt. ɔl hiz toʊld əs ɑɹ waɪl teɪlz. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ! bɑ! ðə meɪɾənz ʃʊɾə kɛpt ɪm ən dʌn wʌt wɑz niɾəd."

"Much!" Meira exclaimed. In the light of the lantern she held, her long face was grimmer than usual, though that hardly seemed possible. Meira could find the dark side of the noonday sun. "That his people lie two days west in the city called Amador? We knew that. All he has told us are wild tales. Artur Hawkwing! Bah! The Maidens should have kept him and done what was needed."

"wʊd jə . . . ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn lɝn tu mʌtʃ tu sun?" sɪvænə bɪɾ əɹ lɪp ɪn vɛkseɪʃən. ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs kɔld əm "ju fulz." tu mɛni ɔlɹɛɾi nu tu mʌtʃ, ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən, waɪz wʌnz əmʌŋ ðɛm, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪsk əfɛndɪŋ ðiz wɪmən. ðət nɑlədʒ ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɑn hɝ! "ðə pipəl ɑɹ fɹaɪɾənd." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə haɪɾ əɹ kəntɛmp fəɹ ðæt, ət list. wʌt ʃɑk hɝ, aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ hɝ, wɑz nɑt ðət ðeɪ wɝ əfɹeɪd, bʌt haʊ fju meɪɾ ɛni ɛfɝt tə haɪd ðə fækt. "blæk aɪz, əɹ stoʊn dɑɡz, əɹ ivən meɪɾənz, wʊɾə tɔkt ʌv wʌɾ i sɛd. jə noʊ ðeɪ wʊd! hɪz laɪz wəɾ oʊnli hæv spɹɛd mɔɹ fɪɹ." ðeɪ hæd tə bi laɪz. ɪn sɪvænəz maɪn ə si wɑz laɪk ðə leɪks ʃi hæd sin ɪn ðə wɛtlænz, bʌt wɪð ɪts fɑɹ saɪd bɪɑn saɪt. ɪf hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz mɔɹ ə hɪz pipəl wɝ kʌmɪŋ, ivən fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə soʊ lɑɹdʒ ə bɑɾi ʌv wɔɾɝ, ði ʌðɝ pɹɪznɝz ʃi hæd kwɛstʃənd wʊɾə noʊn ə ðɛm. ən noʊ pɹɪznɝ wɑz kwɛstʃənd wɪθaʊɾ əɹ pɹɛzənt.

"Would you . . . risk letting everyone learn too much too soon?" Sevanna bit her lip in vexation. She had almost called them "you fools." Too many already knew too much, in her opinion, Wise Ones among them, but she could not risk offending these women. That knowledge grated on her! "The people are frightened." There was no need to hide her contempt for that, at least. What shocked her, outraged her, was not that they were afraid, but how few made any effort to hide the fact. "Black Eyes, or Stone Dogs, or even Maidens, would have talked of what he said. You know they would! His lies would only have spread more fear." They had to be lies. In Sevanna's mind a sea was like the lakes she had seen in the wetlands, but with its far side beyond sight. If hundreds of thousands more of his people were coming, even from the other side of so large a body of water, the other prisoners she had questioned would have known of them. And no prisoner was questioned without her present.

ʃən ɹeɪz ðə sɛkən læntɝn ən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ wɪð ənblɪŋkɪŋ ɡɹeɪ aɪz. nɪɹli ə hɛd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən sʌmɛɝɪn, ʃən wɑz stɪl tɔlɝ ðən sɪvænə. ən twaɪs əz waɪd. hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs ɔfən əpɪɹd plæsəd, bʌt θɪŋkɪŋ əɹ soʊ wɑz ə mɪsteɪk. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹaɪt tə fɪɹ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə stoʊni vɔɪs. "aɪ æm əfɹeɪd, ən teɪk noʊ ʃeɪm ɪn ɪt. ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ mɛni ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən tʊk æmədɔɹ, ən wəɹ fju. juv jəɹ sɛpt ɝaʊn ju, sɪvænə, bʌt wɛɹ ɪz maɪ sɛpt? jəɹ wɛtləndɝ fɹɛn kædɑɝ ən ɪz teɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛn əs θɹu hɪz hoʊlz ɪn ði ɛɹ tə daɪ. wɛɹ ɑɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ?"

Tion raised the second lantern and regarded her with unblinking gray eyes. Nearly a head shorter than Someryn, Tion was still taller than Sevanna. And twice as wide. Her round face often appeared placid, but thinking her so was a mistake. "They are right to fear," she said in a stony voice. "I am afraid, and take no shame in it. The Seanchan are many if they are no more than took Amador, and we are few. You have your sept around you, Sevanna, but where is my sept? Your wetlander friend Caddar and his tame Aes Sedai sent us through his holes in the air to die. Where are the rest of the Shaido?"

ɹiɑli muv tə stæn dɪfaɪənli bɪsaɪd ʃən, ən ðeɪ wɝ kwɪkli dʒɔɪn baɪ əlɹiz, ivən naʊ tɔɪɪŋ wɪð əɹ blæk hɛɹ tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən tə ɪt. əɹ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz tə əvɔɪd miɾɪŋ sɪvænəz aɪz. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ə skaʊlɪŋ mɹə æɾəd hɝsɛlf tə ðə klʌstɝ, ən ðən moʊdʒɹə. moʊdʒɹə maɪɾ əv bɪn kɔl slɪm ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑɾ ivən tɔlɝ ðən sʌmɛɝɪn; əz ɪt wɑz, lin wɑz ðə bɛs ðət kəd bi sɛɾ ə hɝ. sɪvænə hæd θɔt moʊdʒɹə əz fɝmli ɪn əɹ ɡɹæsp əz ɛni ʌv ðə ɹɪŋz ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. əz fɝmli ɪn əɹ ɡɹæsp æz. . . . sʌmɛɝɪn lʊkt əɾ əɹ ən saɪd, lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝz. sloʊli ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ tə stæn bɪsaɪd ðɛm.

Rhiale moved to stand defiantly beside Tion, and they were quickly joined by Alarys, even now toying with her black hair to draw attention to it. Or perhaps it was to avoid meeting Sevanna's eyes. After a moment, a scowling Meira added herself to the cluster, and then Modarra. Modarra might have been called slim if she were not even taller than Someryn; as it was, lean was the best that could be said of her. Sevanna had thought Modarra as firmly in her grasp as any of the rings on her fingers. As firmly in her grasp as. . . . Someryn looked at her and sighed, looked at the others. Slowly she walked over to stand beside them.

sɪvænə wɑz lɛf stændɪŋ ɑn ðə vɛɹi ɛdʒ ə ðə læntɝnz laɪt. ʌv ɔl ðə wɪmən taɪd tə hɝ baɪ ðə kɪlɪŋ ə deɪseɪn, ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd ðiz moʊst. nɑt ðət ʃi tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɛniwʌn vɛɹi fɑɹ, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt sʌmɛɝɪn ən moʊdʒɹə ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ wɝ hɝz əz taɪtli əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd swɔɹn wɔɾɝ oʊθ tə fɑloʊ wɛɹ ʃi lɛd. ən naʊ ðeɪ dɛɹd feɪs əɹ wɪð əkjuzɪŋ aɪz. ivən əlɹiz lʊkt ʌp fɹəm pleɪɪŋ wɪð əɹ hɛɹ.

Sevanna was left standing on the very edge of the lantern's light. Of all the women tied to her by the killing of Desaine, she trusted these most. Not that she trusted anyone very far, of course. But Someryn and Modarra she had been sure were hers as tightly as if they had sworn water oath to follow where she led. And now they dared face her with accusing eyes. Even Alarys looked up from playing with her hair.

sɪvænə mɛt ðɛɹ stɛɹz wɪð ə kul smaɪl dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə snɪɹ. naʊ, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd, wɑz nɑt ðə taɪm tə ɹimaɪn əm ə ðə kɹaɪm ðət baʊn ðɛɹ feɪts təɡɛðɝ. nɑt ðə blʌdʒən, ðɪs taɪm. "aɪ səspɛktəd kædɑɝ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ʌs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. ɹiɑliz blu aɪz waɪɾənd ət ði ædmɪʃən, ən ʃən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. sɪvænə wɛn ɑn, nɑt livɪŋ əm ɹum tə spik. "wʊd jə ɹæðɝ əv ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ tə bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd? tə bi hʌntəd laɪk ænəməlz baɪ fɔɹ klænz huz waɪz wʌnz noʊ haʊ tə meɪk ðoʊz hoʊlz wɪθaʊt ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑksəz? ɪnstɛd, wəɹ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ə ɹɪtʃ, sɑf lænd. ɹɪtʃɝ ivən ðən ðə lænz ə ðə tʃɹi-kɪlɝz. lʊk ət wʌt wɪv teɪkən ɪn oʊnli tɛn deɪz. haʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ wɪl wi teɪk ɪn ə wɛtləndɝ sɪɾi? jə fɪɹ ðə sintʃæn kəz ðeɪv nʌmbɝz? ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ aɪ bɹɔɾ ɛvɹi ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌn u kən tʃænəl wɪð mi." ðət ʃi kəd nɑt tʃænəl hɝsɛlf sɛldəm əkɝd tə hɝ, naʊ. sun ðət læk wəd bi ɹɛməɾid. "wi ɑɹ əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛni fɔɹs ðiz wɛtləndɝz kən sɛn əɡɛnst ʌs. ivən ɪf ðeɪ də hæv flaɪɪŋ lɪzɝdz." ʃi snɪft fɔɹsfəli tə ʃoʊ wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðoʊz! nʌn ə ðɛm hæd sin wʌn, nɔɹ ɛni ʌv ðə skaʊts, bʌt nɪɹli ɛvɹi pɹɪznɝ hæd bɪn fʊl ə ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs teɪlz. "æftɝ wi faɪn ði ʌðɝ sɛps, wɪl teɪk ðɪs læn fəɹ əɹ oʊn. ɔl ʌv ɪt! wɪl ɪkstʃɹækt ə tɛnfoʊld ɹipeɪmən fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən wɪl faɪn kædɑɝ ən meɪk ɪm daɪ skɹimɪŋ fəɹ mɝsi."

Sevanna met their stares with a cool smile just short of a sneer. Now, she decided, was not the time to remind them of the crime that bound their fates together. Not the bludgeon, this time. "I suspected Caddar might try to betray us," she said instead. Rhiale's blue eyes widened at the admission, and Tion opened her mouth. Sevanna went on, not leaving them room to speak. "Would you rather have remained in Kinslayer's Dagger to be destroyed? To be hunted like animals by four clans whose Wise Ones know how to make those holes without the traveling boxes? Instead, we are in the heart of a rich, soft land. Richer even than the lands of the tree-killers. Look at what we have taken in only ten days. How much more will we take in a wetlander city? You fear the Seanchan because they have numbers? Remember that I brought every Shaido Wise One who can channel with me." That she could not channel herself seldom occurred to her, now. Soon that lack would be remedied. "We are as strong as any force these wetlanders can send against us. Even if they do have flying lizards." She sniffed forcefully to show what she thought of those! None of them had seen one, nor any of the scouts, but nearly every prisoner had been full of the ridiculous tales. "After we find the other septs, we will take this land for our own. All of it! We will extract a tenfold repayment from the Aes Sedai. And we will find Caddar and make him die screaming for mercy."

ðət ʃʊɾə ɹælid ðɛm, ɹɪstɔɹd ðɛɹ hɑɹts əz ʃi hæd hæd tə də bɪfɔɹ. nɑt wʌn wʊmənz feɪs tʃeɪnʒd. nɑt wʌn.

That should have rallied them, restored their hearts as she had had to do before. Not one woman's face changed. Not one.

"æn ðəɹ ɪz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn," ʃən sɛd kɑmli. "ənlɛs juv ɡɪvən ʌp jəɹ plæn tə mɛɹi hɪm."

"And there is the Car'a'carn," Tion said calmly. "Unless you have given up your plan to marry him."

"aɪ hæv ɡɪvən ʌp nʌθɪŋ," sɪvænə ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ðə mæn - ən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðə paʊɝ ðət keɪm wɪð ɪm - wəd bi hɝz sʌmdeɪ. sʌmhaʊ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʊk. smuðɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs, ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ɹæn ælθɹ ɪz hɑɹdli ʌv kɑnsəkwəns naʊ." ət lis tə ðiz blaɪn sɪmpəltənz. wɪð ɪm ɪn əɹ hænz, ɛniθɪŋ wəd bi pɑsəbəl fəɹ hɝ. "aɪ də nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə stæn hɪɹ ɔl deɪ dɪskʌsɪŋ maɪ bɹaɪɾəl ɹiθ. aɪ hæv mæɾɝz tə si tə ðəɾ ɑɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

"I have given up nothing," Sevanna replied irritably. The man - and more important, the power that came with him - would be hers someday. Somehow. Whatever it took. Smoothing her voice, she went on. "Rand al'Thor is hardly of consequence now." At least to these blind simpletons. With him in her hands, anything would be possible for her. "I do not intend to stand here all day discussing my bridal wreath. I have matters to see to that are important."

əz ʃi stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm əm θɹu ðə ɡlum, təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹz ə ðə steɪbəl, ən ənplɛzən θɔt sʌɾənli əkɝd tə hɝ. ʃi wɑz əloʊn wɪð ðiz wɪmən. haʊ fɑɹ kəd ʃi tʃɹʌs ðɛm, naʊ? deɪseɪnz dɛθ ɹɪmeɪn ɔl tu vɪvəɾ ɪn əɹ maɪnd; ðə waɪz wʌn hæd bɪn . . . bʊtʃɝd . . . juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. baɪ ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn hɝ, əmʌŋ ʌðɝz. ðə θɔt twɪstəɾ əɹ bɛli taɪt. ʃi lɪsən fəɹ ðə feɪn ɹʌsəl ə stʃɹɔ ðət wəɾ ənaʊns fit fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ ən hɝd nʌθɪŋ. wɝ ðeɪ dʒʌst stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ? ʃi ɹəfjuz tə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. kipɪŋ ðə seɪm sloʊ peɪs ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝt - ʃi wəd nɑt dɪspleɪ fɪɹ ən ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf! - jɛt wən ʃi pʊʃt wʌn ə ðə tɔl dɔɹz oʊpən ɑn ɪts wɛl-ɔɪl hɪnʒɪz ən stɛpt ɪndə bɹaɪt mɪddeɪ laɪt, ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp fɹəm dʒɹɔɪŋ ə ɹɪliv bɹɛθ.

As she stalked away from them through the gloom, toward the doors of the stable, an unpleasant thought suddenly occurred to her. She was alone with these women. How far could she trust them, now? Desaine's death remained all too vivid in her mind; the Wise One had been . . . butchered . . . using the One Power. By the women behind her, among others. The thought twisted her belly tight. She listened for the faint rustle of straw that would announce feet following her and heard nothing. Were they just standing there watching? She refused to look over her shoulder. Keeping the same slow pace required only a little effort - she would not display fear and shame herself! - yet when she pushed one of the tall doors open on its well-oiled hinges and stepped into bright midday light, she could not stop from drawing a relieved breath.

ɛfɑlɪn wɑz peɪsɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, ʃoʊufə dʒɹeɪpt ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, baʊ keɪst ɑn əɹ bæk, spɪɹz ən bʌkəlɝ ɪn hænd. ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən tɝn əbɹʌpli, ðə wɝi ɑn əɹ feɪs feɪɾɪŋ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl ət saɪɾ ə sɪvænə. ðə liɾɝ ʌv ɔl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ meɪɾənz, ən ʃi lɛɾ əɹ dɪstʃɹɛs ʃoʊ! ʃi wɑz nɑt dʒuməaɪ, bʌt ʃi hæd kʌm wɪð sɪvænə juzɪŋ ði ɪkskjus ðət sɪvænə spoʊk əz ðə tʃif əntɪl ə nu tʃif ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəd bi tʃoʊzən. sɪvænə wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛfɑlɪn səspɛktəd ðət wəd nɛvɝ hæpən. ɛfɑlɪn nu wɛɹ ðə paʊɝ leɪ. ən wən tə kip əɹ maʊθ kloʊzd.

Efalin was pacing outside, shoufa draped around her neck, bow cased on her back, spears and buckler in hand. The gray-haired woman turned abruptly, the worry on her face fading only a little at sight of Sevanna. The leader of all the Shaido Maidens, and she let her distress show! She was not Jumai, but she had come with Sevanna using the excuse that Sevanna spoke as the chief until a new chief of the Shaido could be chosen. Sevanna was sure that Efalin suspected that would never happen. Efalin knew where the power lay. And when to keep her mouth closed.
