"bɛɹi hɪm dipli ən haɪd ðə ɡɹeɪv," sɪvænə toʊl hɝ.

"Bury him deeply and hide the grave," Sevanna told her.

ɛfɑlɪn nɑɾəd, sɪɡnəlɪŋ ðə meɪɾənz ɹɪŋɪŋ ðə steɪbəl tə ðɛɹ fit, ən ðeɪ vænɪʃt ɪnsaɪd bɪhaɪn hɝ. sɪvænə stʌɾid ðə bɪldɪŋ, wɪð ɪts ʃɑɹp-pikt ɹɛd ɹuf ən blu wɔlz, ðən tɝn tə ðə fild ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt. ə loʊ stoʊn fɛns wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl oʊpənɪŋ, ɹaɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə steɪbəl, ɛnkloʊzd ə sɝkəl ə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əkɹɔs. ðə wɛtləndɝz hæd juzd ɪt fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ hɔɹsəz. waɪ ɪt hæd bɪn pleɪst soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, sɝaʊndəd baɪ tʃɹiz soʊ tɔl ðət sɪvænə stɪl səmtaɪmz stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm, ʃi hæd nɑt θɔt tə æsk ðə fɔɹmɝ oʊnɝz, bʌt ði aɪsəleɪʃən sɝvd əɹ pɝpəsəz. ðə meɪɾənz wɪð ɛfɑlɪn wɝ ðoʊz u hæd kæptʃɝd ðə sintʃæn. noʊ wʌn nɑt hɪɹ nu hi ɪɡzɪstəd. əɹ wəd noʊ. wɝ ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz tɔkɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ? əbaʊt hɝ? ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz? wʌt wɝ ðeɪ seɪɪŋ? ʃi wəd nɑt weɪɾ ɑn əm əɹ ɛniwʌn!

Efalin nodded, signaling the Maidens ringing the stable to their feet, and they vanished inside behind her. Sevanna studied the building, with its sharp-peaked red roof and blue walls, then turned to the field in front of it. A low stone fence with a single opening, right before the stable, enclosed a circle of hard-packed dirt perhaps a hundred paces across. The wetlanders had used it for training horses. Why it had been placed so far from everything else, surrounded by trees so tall that Sevanna still sometimes stared at them, she had not thought to ask the former owners, but the isolation served her purposes. The Maidens with Efalin were those who had captured the Seanchan. No one not here knew he existed. Or would know. Were the other Wise Ones talking in there? About her? In front of the Maidens? What were they saying? She would not wait on them or anyone!

ðeɪ keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəl dʒʌst əz ʃi stɑɹɾəd ɔf təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹəst, sʌmɛɝɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, ən fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn, ən kædɑɝ, ən wɛɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd bɪn sɛnt. nɑɾ əbaʊt hɝ, bʌt ðɛn, ðeɪ wəd nɑt wɛɹ ʃi kəd lɪsən. wʌt ʃi dɪd hɪɹ meɪɾ əɹ ɡɹɪmɑs. ðəɹ wɝ oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd waɪz wʌnz wɪð ðə dʒuməaɪ, ən ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm wɛnɛvɝ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ stɑɹɾəd tɔkɪŋ. wɛɹ wɝ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɛps, ən hæd kædɑɝ bɪn ə spɪɹ hɝl baɪ ɹænd ælθɹ, ən haʊ mɛni sintʃæn wɝ ðɛɹ, ən ivən dɪd ðeɪ ɹɪli ɹaɪd lɪzɝdz? lɪzɝdz! ðiz wɪmən hæd bɪn wɪð əɹ fɹəm ðə fɝst. ʃi hæd ɡaɪɾəd ðɛɹ fit stɛp baɪ stɛp, bʌt ðeɪ bɪliv ðeɪ hæd hɛlpt plæn ɛvɹi muv, bɪliv ðeɪ nu ðə dɛstəneɪʃən. ɪf ʃi wɑz luzɪŋ əm naʊ. . . .

They came out of the stable just as she started off toward the forest, Someryn and the others, and followed her into the trees arguing among themselves about the Seanchan, and Caddar, and where the rest of the Shaido had been sent. Not about her, but then, they would not where she could listen. What she did hear made her grimace. There were over three hundred Wise Ones with the Jumai, and it was the same whenever three or four started talking. Where were the rest of the septs, and had Caddar been a spear hurled by Rand al'Thor, and how many Seanchan were there, and even did they really ride lizards? Lizards! These women had been with her from the first. She had guided their feet step by step, but they believed they had helped plan every move, believed they knew the destination. If she was losing them now. . . .

ðə fɔɹəst ɡeɪv weɪ tə ə hjudʒ klɪɹɪŋ ðət cʊɾə swɑloʊd ðə sɝkəl bæk ət ðə steɪbəl fɪfti taɪmz oʊvɝ, ən sɪvænə fɛlt ɪl tɛmpɝ slɪpɪŋ əweɪ əz ʃi stɑp tə lʊk. loʊ hɪlz ɹoʊz tə ðə nɔɹθ, ən maʊntənz ə fju liɡz bɪɑn əm wɝ kæpt wɪð klaʊdz, ɡɹeɪt mæsəz ʌv waɪt stʃɹikt wɪð dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni klaʊdz ɪn əɹ laɪf. kloʊsɝ ət hænd, θaʊzənz ə dʒuməaɪ wɛn əbaʊt ðə deɪz wɝk. ðə ɹɪŋ ə hæmɝ ɑn ænvəl ɹoʊz fɹəm blæksmɪθs, ən ʃip ən ɡoʊts wɝ biɪŋ slɔɾɝd fəɹ ði ivnɪŋ mil, ðɛɹ bliɾɪŋ mɪkst wɪð ðə læftɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən əz ðeɪ ɹæn ət pleɪ. ɡɪvən mɔɹ taɪm tə pɹipɛɹ fəɹ ðɛɹ flaɪt fɹəm kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ sɛps, ðə dʒuməaɪ hæd bɹɔt ðə flɑks ɡæðɝɾ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən æɾəd tə ðɛm hɪɹ.

The forest gave way to a huge clearing that could have swallowed the circle back at the stable fifty times over, and Sevanna felt ill temper slipping away as she stopped to look. Low hills rose to the north, and mountains a few leagues beyond them were capped with clouds, great masses of white streaked with dark gray. She had never seen so many clouds in her life. Closer at hand, thousands of Jumai went about the day's work. The ring of hammer on anvil rose from blacksmiths, and sheep and goats were being slaughtered for the evening meal, their bleating mixed with the laughter of the children as they ran at play. Given more time to prepare for their flight from Kinslayer's Dagger than the other septs, the Jumai had brought the flocks gathered in Cairhien, and added to them here.

mɛni pipəl hæd sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ tɛns, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. kʌlɝfəl stʃɹʌktʃɝz nɪɹli fɪl ðə klɪɹɪŋ laɪk ə lɑɹdʒ wɛtləndɝ vɪlədʒ, tɔl bɑɹnz ən steɪbəlz, ə lɑɹdʒ fɔɹdʒ ən ðə skwɑt ɹufs ðət hæd ʃɛltɝd sɝvəns, ɔl peɪntəd ɹɛɾ ən blu, sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt ɹuf ɪtsɛlf. ðə mænɝ haʊs ðət wɑz kɔld, θɹi flɔɹz haɪ bɪniθ ə dɑɹk ɡɹin taɪl ɹuf, ɔl ʌv ɪɾ ə pəlɝ ɡɹin tʃɹɪmd wɪð jɛloʊ, ətɑp ə bɹɔd mæn-meɪd stoʊn hɪl tɛn peɪsɪz tɔl. dʒuməaɪ ən ɡeɪʃeɪn klaɪm ðə lɔŋ ɹæmp ðət lɛd tə ðə ɡɹeɪt bɪldɪŋz dɔɹ ən wɔk ði ɔɹnətli kɑɹv bælkəniz ðət ɹɪŋd ɪt.

Many people had set up their tents, but there was no need. Colorful structures nearly filled the clearing like a large wetlander village, tall barns and stables, a large forge and the squat roofs that had sheltered servants, all painted red and blue, surrounding the great roof itself. The manor house that was called, three floors high beneath a dark green tile roof, all of it a paler green trimmed with yellow, atop a broad man-made stone hill ten paces tall. Jumai and gai'shain climbed the long ramp that led to the great building's door and walked the ornately carved balconies that ringed it.

ðə stoʊn wɔlz ən pæləsəz ʃi hæd sin ɪn kɛɹhin hæd nɑɾ ɪmpɹɛst əɹ hæf soʊ mʌtʃ. ðɪs wʌn wɑz peɪntəd laɪk ə wæɡən ə ðə lɔst wʌnz, bʌɾ ivən soʊ, mɑɹvələs. ʃi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪz ðət wɪð soʊ mɛni tʃɹiz, ðiz pipəl kəɾ əfɔɹd tə bɪld ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wʊd. kəd noʊ wʌn bʌt ʃi si haʊ fæt ðɪs lænd wɑz? mɔɹ waɪt-klæd ɡeɪʃeɪn skɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks ðən ɛni twɛnti sɛps hæɾ ɛvɝ hæd bɪfɔɹ, nɪɹli hæf əz mɛni əz ðəɹ wɝ dʒuməaɪ! noʊ wʌn kəmpleɪn əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ wɛtləndɝz ɡeɪʃeɪn ɛnimɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ soʊ dɑsəl! ə waɪd-aɪd jʌŋ mæn ɪn ɹʌf-soʊn waɪt hɝid pæs klʌtʃɪŋ ə bæskət, ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə pipəl ɝaʊn ɪm ən stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɛm ə hɪz ɹoʊb. sɪvænə smaɪld. ðət wʌnz fɑðɝ hæd kɔl hɪmsɛlf ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs ən blʌstɝd ðət ʃi ən əɹ pipəl wəd bi hʌntəd daʊn - baɪ tʃɪlʒɹən, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz! - fəɹ ðɪs aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, jɛt naʊ hi wɔɹ waɪɾ ən wɝkt əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪz sʌn, əz dɪɾ ɪz waɪf ən ɪz dɔɾɝz ən ɪz ʌðɝ sʌnz. ðə wɪmən hæd pəzɛs mɛni faɪn dʒɛmz ən bjuɾəfəl sɪlks, ən sɪvænə hæɾ oʊnli teɪkən ðə fɝs pɪk fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ə fæt lænd, soʊ sɑft ɪɾ uzd ɹɪtʃ ɔɪlz.

The stone walls and palaces she had seen in Cairhien had not impressed her half so much. This one was painted like a wagon of the Lost Ones, but even so, marvelous. She should have realized that with so many trees, these people could afford to build anything of wood. Could no one but she see how fat this land was? More white-clad gai'shain scurried about their tasks than any twenty septs had ever had before, nearly half as many as there were Jumai! No one complained about making wetlanders gai'shain anymore. They were so docile! A wide-eyed young man in rough-sewn white hurried past clutching a basket, gaping at the people around him and stumbling over the hem of his robe. Sevanna smiled. That one's father had called himself the lord of this place and blustered that she and her people would be hunted down - by children, of all things! - for this outrage, yet now he wore white and worked as hard as his son, as did his wife and his daughters and his other sons. The women had possessed many fine gems and beautiful silks, and Sevanna had only taken the first pick for herself. A fat land, so soft it oozed rich oils.

ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn əɹ hæd stɑpt ʃɔɹt tə tɔk əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz. ʃi kɑt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ, ən ɪt tɝn əɹ muɾ əɡɛn.

The women behind her had stopped short to talk among themselves at the edge of the trees. She caught what they were saying, and it turned her mood again.

". . . haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ faɪt fəɹ ðiz sintʃæn," ʃən wɑz seɪɪŋ. "wi mʌs lɝn ðæt." sʌmɛɝɪn ən moʊdʒɹə mɝmɝɾ əɡɹimənt.

". . . how many Aes Sedai fight for these Seanchan," Tion was saying. "We must learn that." Someryn and Modarra murmured agreement.

"aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɪt mæɾɝz," ɹiɑli pʊɾ ɪn. ət list əɹ kɑntʃɹɛɹinəs ɪkstɛndəd tə ði ʌðɝz, tu. "aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðəl faɪɾ ənlɛs wi ətæk ðɛm. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðeɪ dɪd nʌθɪŋ əntɪl wi muvd əɡɛns ðɛm, nɑɾ ivən tə dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz."

"I do not think it matters," Rhiale put in. At least her contrariness extended to the others, too. "I do not think they will fight unless we attack them. Remember, they did nothing until we moved against them, not even to defend themselves."

"ænd wən ðeɪ dɪd," mɹə sɛd saʊɝli, "twɛnti-θɹi ʌv əs daɪd. ən mɔɹ ðən tɛn θaʊzən æl-ɡeɪdsɪswaɪ dɪd nɑt ɹɪtɝn iðɝ. hɪɹ, wɪv lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə θɝɾ ə ðət nʌmbɝ ivən kaʊntɪŋ ðə bɹʌðɝləs." ʃi soʊk ðə læst wɝɾ ɪn skɔɹn.

"And when they did," Meira said sourly, "twenty-three of us died. And more than ten thousand al-gai'd'siswai did not return either. Here, we have little more than a third of that number even counting the Brotherless." She soaked the last word in scorn.

"ðæt wɑz ɹænd ælθɹz wɝk!" sɪvænə toʊld əm ʃɑɹpli. "ɪnstɛɾ ə θɪŋkɪŋ wʌɾ i dɪɾ əɡɛnst ʌs, θɪŋk wʌt wi kən də wən hiz aʊɝz!" wən hiz maɪn, ʃi θɔt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə teɪk ən hoʊld ɪm əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ hæd, ən ʃi hæd sʌmθɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt, ɛls ðeɪ wʊɾə juzd ɪt. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪnstɛd ðət wi hæd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ biɾən əntɪl i tʊk ðɛɹ saɪd. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ!"

"That was Rand al'Thor's work!" Sevanna told them sharply. "Instead of thinking what he did against us, think what we can do when he is ours!" When he is mine, she thought. The Aes Sedai had been able to take and hold him as long as they had, and she had something the Aes Sedai had not, else they would have used it. "Remember instead that we had the Aes Sedai beaten until he took their side. Aes Sedai are nothing!"

wʌns əɡɛn əɹ ɛfɝt tə stʃɹɛŋθən ðɛɹ hɑɹts pɹədus noʊ vɪzəbəl ɪfɛkt. ɔl ðeɪ kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wɑz ðət ðə spɪɹz hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kæptʃɝ ɹænd ælθɹ, ən ðeɪ wɪð ðɛm. moʊdʒɹə maɪɾ əv bɪn stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪv ʌv ɔl əɹ sɛpt, ən ivən ʃən fɹaʊn ənizəli, daʊtləs ɹɪkɔlɪŋ ðət ʃi, tu, hæd ɹʌn laɪk ə fɹaɪɾənd ɡoʊt.

Once again her effort to strengthen their hearts produced no visible effect. All they could remember was that the spears had been broken trying to capture Rand al'Thor, and they with them. Modarra might have been staring into the grave of all her sept, and even Tion frowned uneasily, doubtless recalling that she, too, had run like a frightened goat.

"waɪz wʌnz," ə mænz vɔɪs sɛd bɪhaɪn sɪvænə, "aɪ hæv bɪn sɛn tə æsk fəɹ jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt."

"Wise Ones," a man's voice said behind Sevanna, "I have been sent to ask for your judgment."

ɪnstənli ɛvɹi wʊmənz feɪs ɹiɡeɪn ɪts ikwənɪmɪɾi. wʌt ʃi kəd nɑt du, hi hæd dʌn wɪð ɪz vɛɹi pɹɛzəns. noʊ waɪz wʌn wəɾ əlaʊ ɛni bʌɾ ənʌðɝ waɪz wʌn tə si hɝ aʊɾ ə kaʊntənəns. əlɹiz stɑp stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ, wɪtʃ ʃi hæd pʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. pleɪnli nʌn ə ðɛm ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm. sɪvænə θɔt ʃi dɪd.

Instantly every woman's face regained its equanimity. What she could not do, he had done with his very presence. No Wise One would allow any but another Wise One to see her out of countenance. Alarys stopped stroking her hair, which she had pulled over her shoulder. Plainly none of them recognized him. Sevanna thought she did.

hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əm ɡɹeɪvli, wɪð ɡɹin aɪz mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən ɪz smuð feɪs. hi hæd fʊl lɪps, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛt tə hɪz maʊθ, əz ɪf i hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə smaɪl. "aɪ æm kɪnhuən, ʌv ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn, waɪz wʌnz. ðə dʒuməaɪ seɪ wi meɪ nɑt teɪk əɹ fʊl ʃɛɹ fɹəm ðɪs pleɪs kəz wəɹ nɑt dʒuməaɪ, bʌɾ ɪts kəz ðəl əv lɛs sɪns wəɹ tu fəɹ ɛvɹi dʒuməaɪ æl-ɡeɪdsɪswaɪ. ðə bɹʌðɝləs æsk jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt, waɪz wʌnz."

He regarded them gravely, with green eyes much older than his smooth face. He had full lips, but there was a set to his mouth, as if he had forgotten how to smile. "I am Kinhuin, of the Mera'din, Wise Ones. The Jumai say we may not take our full share from this place because we are not Jumai, but it is because they will have less since we are two for every Jumai al-gai'd'siswai. The Brotherless ask your judgment, Wise Ones."

naʊ ðət ðeɪ nu hu hi wɑz, səm kəd nɑt haɪd ðɛɹ dɪslaɪk ə ðə mɛn u hæɾ əbændən klæn ən sɛp tə kʌm tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɹæðɝ ðən fɑloʊ ɹænd ælθɹ, ə wɛtləndɝ ən noʊ tʃɹu kɑɹəkɑɹn, əz ðeɪ θɔt. ʃənz feɪs mɪɹli wɛn flæt, bʌt ɹiɑliz aɪz flæʃt, ən mɹə tiɾɝd ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə skaʊl. oʊnli moʊdʒɹə ʃoʊd kənsɝn, bʌt ðɛn, ʃi wʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə sɛɾəl ə dɪspjut bɪtwin tʃɹikɪlɝz.

Now that they knew who he was, some could not hide their dislike of the men who had abandoned clan and sept to come to the Shaido rather than follow Rand al'Thor, a wetlander and no true Car'a'carn, as they thought. Tion's face merely went flat, but Rhiale's eyes flashed, and Meira teetered on the edge of a scowl. Only Modarra showed concern, but then, she would have tried to settle a dispute between treekillers.

"ðiz sɪks waɪz wʌnz wɪl ɡɪv dʒʌdʒmən æftɝ hɪɹɪŋ boʊθ saɪdz," sɪvænə toʊl kɪnhuən wɪð ə ɡɹeɪvinəs tə mætʃ hɪz.

"These six Wise Ones will give judgment after hearing both sides," Sevanna told Kinhuin with a graveness to match his.

ði ʌðɝ wɪmən lʊkt ət hɝ, bɛɹli kənsilɪŋ ðɛɹ sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə stæn əsaɪd. ɪt hæd bɪn ʃi hu ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ tɛn taɪmz ðə nʌmbɝ ə mɛɝeɪɾɪn tə əkʌmpəni ðə dʒuməaɪ əz wɛnt wɪð ɛni ʌðɝ sɛpt. ʃi ɹɪli hæd səspɛktəd kædɑɝ, ɪf nɑɾ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd dʌn, ən ʃi hæd wɑntəɾ əz mɛni spɪɹz ɝaʊn əɹ əz pɑsəbəl. bɪsaɪdz, ðeɪ kəɾ ɔlweɪz daɪ ɪn pleɪs ə dʒuməaɪ.

The other women looked at her, barely concealing their surprise that she intended to stand aside. It had been she who arranged for ten times the number of Mera'din to accompany the Jumai as went with any other sept. She really had suspected Caddar, if not of what he had done, and she had wanted as many spears around her as possible. Besides, they could always die in place of Jumai.

ʃi əfɛktəd sɝpɹaɪz ət ði ʌðɝz' sɝpɹaɪz. "ɪt wəd nɑt bi fɛɹ fəɹ mi tə teɪk pɑɹt sɪns maɪ oʊn sɛpt ɪz ɪnvɑlvd," ʃi toʊld əm bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə ɡɹin-aɪd mæn. "ðeɪ wɪl ɡɪv fɛɹ dʒʌdʒmənt, kɪnhuən. ən aɪm sɝɾən ðəl spik ɪn feɪvɝ ə ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn."

She affected surprise at the others' surprise. "It would not be fair for me to take part since my own sept is involved," she told them before turning back to the green-eyed man. "They will give fair judgment, Kinhuin. And I am certain they will speak in favor of the Mera'din."

ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɡeɪv əɹ hɑɹd lʊks bɪfɔɹ ʃən moʊʃən əbɹʌpli fəɹ kɪnhuən tə lid ðə weɪ. hi hæd tə tɛɹ ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm sɪvænə tə kəmplaɪ. wɛɹɪŋ ə feɪn smaɪl - hi hæd bɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ, nɑt sʌmɛɝɪn - ʃi wɑtʃt əm vænɪʃ ɪndə ðə mæs ə pipəl muvɪŋ əbaʊt ðə mænɝ ɡɹaʊnz. fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ mɪsləkɪŋ ðə bɹʌðɝləs - ən əɹ meɪkɪŋ pɹidɪkʃənz tə ðə mæn əbaʊt ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən - ðə tʃænsəz wɝ ðeɪ wəd dɪsaɪd ðət weɪ. iðɝ weɪ, kɪnhuən wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ən tɛl ði ʌðɝz ə hɪz soʊ-kɔl səsaɪəɾi. ðə dʒuməaɪ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət taɪd ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn tə hɝ wɑz wɛlkəm.

The other women gave her hard looks before Tion motioned abruptly for Kinhuin to lead the way. He had to tear his eyes away from Sevanna to comply. Wearing a faint smile - he had been staring at her, not Someryn - she watched them vanish into the mass of people moving about the manor grounds. For all their misliking the Brotherless - and her making predictions to the man about their decision - the chances were they would decide that way. Either Way, Kinhuin would remember and tell the others of his so-called society. The Jumai were already in her belt pouch, but anything that tied the Mera'din to her was welcome.

tɝnɪŋ, sɪvænə stʃɹoʊd bæk ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, ðoʊ nɑt təwɔɹd ðə steɪbəl. naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz əloʊn, ʃi kəd si tə sʌmθɪŋ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə bɹʌðɝləs. ʃi tʃɛkt wʌt ʃi hæd tʌkt ɪndə hɝ skɝɾ ət ðə smɔl ə hɝ bæk, wɛɹ əɹ ʃɔl hɪɾ ɪt. ʃi wʊɾə fɛlt ɪf ɪt slɪpt ə hɛɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə tʌtʃ ɪts smuð lɛŋθ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. noʊ waɪz wʌn wəd dɛɹ θɪŋk əɹ lɛs ðən ðeɪ, wʌns ʃi juz ðæt, pɝhæps tədeɪ. ən wʌn deɪ, ɪt wəd ɡɪv əɹ ɹænd ælθɹ. æftɝ ɔl, ɪf kædɑɝ hæd laɪɾ ɪn wʌn θɪŋ, meɪbi hi hæd laɪɾ ɪn ʌðɝz.

Turning, Sevanna strode back into the trees, though not toward the stable. Now that she was alone, she could see to something much more important than the Brotherless. She checked what she had tucked into her skirt at the small of her back, where her shawl hid it. She would have felt if it slipped a hair, but she wanted to touch its smooth length with her fingers. No Wise One would dare think her less than they, once she used that, perhaps today. And one day, it would give her Rand al'Thor. After all, if Caddar had lied in one thing, maybe he had lied in others.

θɹu ə blɝ ə tɪɹz ɡəlinə kæsbən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə waɪz wʌn ʃildɪŋ hɝ. əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni nid fəɹ ðə slɛndɝ wʊmənz ʃild. ɹaɪt ðən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪtwin tu skwɑɾɪŋ meɪɾənz, bəlɪn ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ən ɡeɪv ə θɪn smaɪl, əz ɪf ʃi nu ɡəlinəz θɔts. hɝ feɪs wɑz nɛɹoʊ ən fɑkslaɪk, ən əɹ hɛɹ ən aɪbɹaʊz hæd bɪn blitʃt nɪɹli waɪt baɪ ðə sʌn. ɡəlinə wɪʃt ʃi hæd kɹʌʃt əɹ skʌl ɪnstɛɾ ə mɪɹli slæpɪŋ hɝ.

Through a blur of tears Galina Casban glared at the Wise One shielding her. As if there were any need for the slender woman's shield. Right then she could not have so much as embraced the Source. Sitting cross-legged on the ground between two squatting Maidens, Belinde adjusted her shawl and gave a thin smile, as if she knew Galina's thoughts. Her face was narrow and foxlike, and her hair and eyebrows had been bleached nearly white by the sun. Galina wished she had crushed her skull instead of merely slapping her.

ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ən ətɛmpt əɾ ɪskeɪp, mɪɹli mɔɹ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ðən ʃi kəd bɛɹ. hɝ deɪz bɪɡæn ən ɛndəd wɪð ɪɡzɔstʃən, ɛvɹi deɪ mɔɹ ðən ðə læst. ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ lɔŋ sɪns ðeɪ hæd stʌft əɹ ɪndə ðət kɔɹs blæk ɹoʊb; ðə deɪz ɹæn təɡɛðɝ laɪk ən ɛvɝlæstɪŋ stʃɹim. ə wik? ə mʌnθ? meɪbi nɑt ðət lɔŋ. ʃʊɹli nɑt mɔɹ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ tʌtʃt bəlɪnd. ɪf ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt stʌft ɹæɡz ɪndə hɝ maʊθ tə saɪləns əɹ sɑbɪŋ, ʃi wʊɾə bɛɡd tə bi əlaʊd tə kæɹi ɹɑks əɡɛn, əɹ muv ə paɪl ə pɛbəlz stoʊn baɪ stoʊn, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə tɔɹtʃɝz ðeɪ fɪld əɹ aʊɝz wɪð. ɛniθɪŋ ɹæðɝ ðən ðɪs.

It had not been an attempt at escape, merely more frustration than she could bear. Her days began and ended with exhaustion, every day more than the last. She could not remember how long since they had stuffed her into that coarse black robe; the days ran together like an everlasting stream. A week? A month? Maybe not that long. Surely not more. She wished she had never touched Belinde. If the woman had not stuffed rags into her mouth to silence her sobbing, she would have begged to be allowed to carry rocks again, or move a pile of pebbles stone by stone, or any of the tortures they filled her hours with. Anything rather than this.

oʊnli ɡəlinəz hɛd stʌk aʊɾ ə ðə lɛðɝ sæk ðət hʌŋ səspɛndəd fɹəm ðə staʊt lɪm ʌv ən oʊk. dɝɛkli bɪniθ ðə sæk, koʊlz ɡloʊɾ ɪn ə bɹɑnz bɹeɪziɝ, ə sloʊ bɝn, hiɾɪŋ ði ɛɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə sæk. ʃi hʌɾəld ɪn ðət swɛltɝɪŋ hit wɪð əɹ θʌmz taɪd tə hɝ toʊz, swɛt slɪkɪŋ əɹ neɪkədnəs. hɝ hɛɹ klʌŋ dæmpli tə hɝ feɪs, ən ʃi pæntɪd, nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ɛɹ, wən ʃi wɑz nɑt sɑbɪŋ. ivən soʊ, ðɪs wʊɾə bɪn bɛɾɝ ðən ði ɛnləs, sɛnsləs, bækbɹeɪkɪŋ leɪbɝ ðeɪ səbdʒɛktɪɾ əɹ tə ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ snʌɡɪŋ ðə nɛk ə ðə sæk bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn, bəlɪn hæɾ ɛmptiɾ ə paʊtʃ ə səm faɪn paʊɾɝ oʊvɝ hɝ, ən əz ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə swɛt, ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn tə bɝn laɪk pɛpɝ flʌŋ ɪn ði aɪz. ɪt sim tə koʊɾ əɹ fɹəm ðə ʃoʊldɝz daʊn, ænd, oʊ, laɪt, ɪt bɝnd!

Only Galina's head stuck out of the leather sack that hung suspended from the stout limb of an oak. Directly beneath the sack, coals glowed in a bronze brazier, a slow burn, heating the air inside the sack. She huddled in that sweltering heat with her thumbs tied to her toes, sweat slicking her nakedness. Her hair clung damply to her face, and she panted, nostrils flaring for air, when she was not sobbing. Even so, this would have been better than the endless, senseless, backbreaking labor they subjected her to except for one thing. Before snugging the neck of the sack beneath her chin, Belinde had emptied a pouch of some fine powder over her, and as she had begun to sweat, it had begun to burn like pepper flung in the eyes. It seemed to coat her from the shoulders down, and, oh, Light, it burned!

ðət ʃi kɔld ɑn ðə laɪt mɛʒɝɾ əɹ dɛspɝeɪʃən, bʌt ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɹoʊkən əɹ fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ. ʃi wəd ɡɛt fɹi - ʃi wʊd! - ən wʌns ʃi dɪd, ʃi wəd meɪk ðiz sævədʒəz peɪ ɪn blʌd! ɹɪvɝz ə blʌd! oʊʃənz! ʃi wəɾ əv əm ɔl skɪn əlaɪv! ʃi wəd . . . ! flɪŋɪŋ bæk əɹ hɛd, ʃi haʊld; ðə wɑɾəd ɹæɡz ɪn əɹ maʊθ mʌfəl ðə saʊnd, bʌt ʃi haʊld, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz ə ʃɹik ə ɹeɪdʒ əɹ ə skɹim fəɹ mɝsi.

That she called on the Light measured her desperation, but they had not broken her for all their trying. She would get free - she would! - and once she did, she would make these savages pay in blood! Rivers of blood! Oceans! She would have them all skinned alive! She would . . . ! Flinging back her head, she howled; the wadded rags in her mouth muffled the sound, but she howled, and she did not know whether it was a shriek of rage or a scream for mercy.

wən əɹ haʊlz daɪɾ ən əɹ hɛd fɛl fɔɹwɝd, bəlɪn ən ðə meɪɾənz wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fit, ən sɪvænə wɑz wɪð ðɛm. ɡəlinə ətɛmptəd tə staɪfəl əɹ sɑbɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kəɾ əz sun əv plʌk ðə sʌn fɹəm ðə skaɪ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

When her howls died and her head fell forward, Belinde and the Maidens were on their feet, and Sevanna was with them. Galina attempted to stifle her sobbing in front of the golden-haired woman, but she could as soon have plucked the sun from the sky with her fingers.

"lɪsən tə hɝ waɪn ən snaɪvəl," sɪvænə snɪɹd, kʌmɪŋ tə lʊk ʌp ət hɝ. ɡəlinə tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ən ikwəl kəntɛmpt ɪn əɹ oʊn stɛɹ. sɪvænə dɛk hɝsɛlf wɪð ɪnʌf dʒuəlɹi fəɹ tɛn wɪmən! ʃi wɔɹ əɹ blaʊs ənleɪs tə nɪɹli bɛɹ əɹ bʊzəm, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɔl ðoʊz mɪsmætʃt nɛkləsɪz, ən bɹið dip wən mɛn lʊkt ət hɝ! ɡəlinə tʃɹaɪd, bʌt kəntɛmpt wɑz hɑɹd tə mænədʒ wɪð tɪɹz ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ swɛt. ʃi ʃʊk wɪð wipɪŋ, meɪkɪŋ ðə sæk sweɪ.

"Listen to her whine and snivel," Sevanna sneered, coming to look up at her. Galina tried to put an equal contempt in her own stare. Sevanna decked herself with enough jewelry for ten women! She wore her blouse unlaced to nearly bare her bosom, except for all those mismatched necklaces, and breathed deep when men looked at her! Galina tried, but contempt was hard to manage with tears rolling down her cheeks along with her sweat. She shook with weeping, making the sack sway.

"ðɪs dætsæŋ ɪz tʌf əz ən oʊld u," bəlɪn kækəld, "bʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz faʊn ivən ðə tʌfəst oʊld u wɑz meɪd tɛndɝ ɪf kʊk sloʊli, wɪð ðə ɹaɪɾ ɝbz. wən aɪ wɑz ə meɪɾən, aɪ sɔfən stoʊn dɑɡz wɪð ɪnʌf kʊkɪŋ." ɡəlinə kloʊzd əɹ aɪz. oʊʃənz ə blʌd, tə peɪ fəɹ . . . !

"This da'tsang is tough as an old ewe," Belinde cackled, "but I always found even the toughest old ewe was made tender if cooked slowly, with the right herbs. When I was a Maiden, I softened Stone Dogs with enough cooking." Galina closed her eyes. Oceans of blood, to pay for . . . !

ðə sæk lɝtʃt, ən ɡəlinəz aɪz pɑpt oʊpən əz ɪt bɪɡæn tə sɛɾəl. ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ əndʌn ðə ɹoʊp ɹʌnɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə lɪm, ən ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm wɝ loʊɝɪŋ əɹ sloʊli. fɹæntəkəli ʃi θɹæʃt əbaʊt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk daʊn, ən ɔlmoʊs bɪɡæn sɑbɪŋ ənu, wɪð ɹɪlif, wən ʃi sɔ ðət ðə bɹeɪziɝ hæd bɪn muvd əsaɪd. wɪð bəlɪnz tɔk ə kʊkɪŋ. . . . ðət wəd bi bəlɪnz feɪt, ɡəlinə dɪsaɪɾɪd. taɪd tə ə spɪɾ ən tɝn oʊvɝ ə faɪɝ əntɪl əɹ dʒusəz dʒɹɪpt! ðət tə bɪɡɪn!

The sack lurched, and Galina's eyes popped open as it began to settle. The Maidens had undone the rope running over the limb, and the pair of them were lowering her slowly. Frantically she thrashed about, trying to look down, and almost began sobbing anew, with relief, when she saw that the brazier had been moved aside. With Belinde's talk of cooking. . . . That would be Belinde's fate, Galina decided. Tied to a spit and turned over a fire until her juices dripped! That to begin!

wɪð ə θʌd ðət meɪd ɡəlinə ɡɹʌnt, ðə lɛðɝ bæɡ hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊn ən tɑpəld oʊvɝ. əz ʌnkənsɝn əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hænlɪŋ ə sæk ə pəteɪɾoʊz, ðə meɪɾənz tʌmbəld əɹ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə bɹaʊn widz, slaɪs ðə kɔɹdz ðət hɛld əɹ θʌmz ən toʊz, plʌk ðə ɡæɡ fɹəm bɪtwin əɹ tiθ. dɝɾ ən dɛd livz stʌk tə ðə swɛt koʊɾɪŋ hɝ.

With a thud that made Galina grunt, the leather bag hit the ground and toppled over. As unconcerned as if they were handling a sack of potatoes, the Maidens tumbled her out onto the brown weeds, sliced the cords that held her thumbs and toes, plucked the gag from between her teeth. Dirt and dead leaves stuck to the sweat coating her.

ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑntəd tə stænd, tə miɾ əm ɔl aɪ-tə-aɪ ən ɡlɛɹ-fɔɹ-ɡlɛɹ. ɪnstɛd, ʃi ɹoʊz oʊnli əz fɑɹ əz hænz ən niz, ðən dʌɡ hɝ fɪŋɡɝz ɪndə ðə mʌltʃ ə ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ, dʌɡ hɝ toʊz ɪn. ɛni fɑɹðɝ, ən ʃi wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə stɑp əɹ hænz fɹəm flaɪɪŋ tə suð əɹ ɹɛd, fleɪmɪŋ skɪn. hɝ swɛt fɛlt laɪk ðə dʒus ʌv aɪs pɛpɝz. ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz kɹaʊtʃ ðəɹ ən kwɪvɝ, tʃɹaɪ tə wɝk səm mɔɪstʃɝ bæk ɪndə hɝ maʊθ ən deɪdʒɹim ʌv wʌt ʃi wəd də tə ðiz sævədʒəz.

She very much wanted to stand, to meet them all eye-to-eye and glare-for-glare. Instead, she rose only as far as hands and knees, then dug her fingers into the mulch of the forest floor, dug her toes in. Any farther, and she would not be able to stop her hands from flying to soothe her red, flaming skin. Her sweat felt like the juice of ice peppers. All she could do was crouch there and quiver, try to work some moisture back into her mouth and daydream of what she would do to these savages.

"aɪ bɪliv jə wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðɪs," sɪvænə sɛɾ əbʌv əɹ ɪn θɔtfəl toʊnz, "bʌt pɝhæps bəlɪn ɪz ɹaɪt. pɝhæps jə ɑɹ sɑft ɪnʌf, naʊ. ɪf jə swɛɹ tə oʊbeɪ mi, jə kən stɑp biɪŋ dætsæŋ. pɝhæps jəl nɑɾ ivən əv tə bi ɡeɪʃeɪn. wɪl jə swɛɹ tə oʊbeɪ mi ɪn ɔl θɪŋz?"

"I believed you were stronger than this," Sevanna said above her in thoughtful tones, "but perhaps Belinde is right. Perhaps you are soft enough, now. If you swear to obey me, you can stop being da'tsang. Perhaps you will not even have to be gai'shain. Will you swear to obey me in all things?"

"jɛs!" ðə hɔɹs wɝd flu fɹəm ɡəlinəz tʌŋ wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, ðoʊ ʃi hæd tə swɑloʊ bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ mɔɹ. "aɪ wɪl oʊbeɪ ju! aɪ swɛɹ ɪt!" ən soʊ ʃi wəɾ oʊbeɪ. əntɪl ðeɪ ɡeɪv ði oʊpənɪŋ ʃi niɾəd. wɑz ðɪs ɔl ðət hæd bɪn nɛsəsɛɹi? ən oʊθ ʃi wʊɾə meɪd ðə fɝs deɪ? sɪvænə wəd lɝn wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk tə hæŋ oʊvɝ hɑt koʊlz. oʊ, jɛs, ʃi. . . .

"Yes!" The hoarse word flew from Galina's tongue without hesitation, though she had to swallow before speaking more. "I will obey you! I swear it!" And so she would obey. Until they gave the opening she needed. Was this all that had been necessary? An oath she would have made the first day? Sevanna would learn what it was like to hang over hot coals. Oh, yes, she. . . .

"ðɛn jəl nɑɾ əbdʒɛk tə swɛɹɪŋ jəɹ oʊθ ɑn ðɪs," sɪvænə sɛd, tɔsɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ.

"Then you will not object to swearing your oath on this," Sevanna said, tossing something down in front of her.

ɡəlinəz skælp kɹɔld əz ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt. ə waɪt ɹɑd laɪk pɑlɪʃt aɪvɝi, ə fʊt lɔŋ ən noʊ θɪkɝ ðən əɹ ɹɪst. ðən ʃi sɔ ðə floʊɪŋ mɑɹks kɑɹvd ɪndə ði ɛn təwɔɹd hɝ, numɝəlz juzd ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. wʌn hʌnʒɹəd ɪlɛvən. ʃi hæd θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ði oʊθ ɹɑd, sʌmhaʊ stoʊlən fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðəɾ ɔlsoʊ wɑz mɑɹkt, bʌt wɪð ðə numɝəl θɹi, wɪtʃ səm θɔt stʊd fəɹ ðə θɹi oʊðz. meɪbi ðɪs wɑz nɑt wʌɾ ɪt simd. meɪbi. jɛt noʊ hʊɾɪd vaɪpɝ fɹəm ðə dʒɹaʊn lænz kɔɪl ðəɹ cʊɾə fɹoʊzən əɹ soʊ stɪl.

Galina's scalp crawled as she stared at it. A white rod like polished ivory, a foot long and no thicker than her wrist. Then she saw the flowing marks carved into the end toward her, numerals used in the Age of Legends. One hundred eleven. She had thought it was the Oath Rod, somehow stolen from the White Tower. That also was marked, but with the numeral three, which some thought stood for the Three Oaths. Maybe this was not what it seemed. Maybe. Yet no hooded viper from the Drowned Lands coiled there could have frozen her so still.

"ə faɪn oʊθ, sɪvænə. wən dɪd jə ɪntɛn tə tɛl ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs?"

"A fine oath, Sevanna. When did you intend to tell the rest of us?"

ðət vɔɪs dʒɝkt ɡəlinəz hɛɾ ʌp. ɪt cʊɾə pʊld əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ə hʊɾɪd vaɪpɝ, tu.

That voice jerked Galina's head up. It could have pulled her eyes away from a hooded viper, too.

θɛɝɑvə əpɪɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz liɾɪŋ ə dʌzən koʊld-feɪst waɪz wʌnz. wən ðeɪ stɑp bɪhaɪn hɝ, kənfɹʌntɪŋ sɪvænə, ɛvɹi wʊmən pɹɛzən ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə meɪɾənz hæd bɪn ðəɹ wən ɡəlinə wɑz sɛntəns tə wɛɹ ðə blæk ɹoʊb. ə wɝd fɹəm θɛɝɑvə, ə ʃɔɹt nɑd fɹəm sɪvænə, ən ðə meɪɾənz dɪpɑɹɾəd swɪfli. swɛt stɪl uz fɹəm ɡəlinə, bʌt sʌɾənli ði ɛɹ sim koʊld.

Therava appeared among the trees leading a dozen cold-faced Wise Ones. When they stopped behind her, confronting Sevanna, every woman present except for the Maidens had been there when Galina was sentenced to wear the black robe. A word from Therava, a short nod from Sevanna, and the Maidens departed swiftly. Sweat still oozed from Galina, but suddenly the air seemed cold.

sɪvænə ɡlænst ət bəlɪnd, hu əvɔɪɾəd əɹ aɪ. sɪvænəz lɪp kɝld, hæf snɪɹ, hæf snɑɹl, ən ʃi plæntəd fɪsts ɑn hɪps. ɡəlinə dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wɛɹ ʃi faʊn ðə nɝv, ə wʊmən u kəd nɑt tʃænəl əɾ ɔl. səm ə ðiz wɪmən pəzɛs nɑɾ ɪnkɑnsɪɾɝəbəl stʃɹɛŋkθ. noʊ, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə θɪŋk ə ðɛm oʊnli əz waɪldɝz ɪf ʃi wɑz tə ɪskeɪp ən əv əɹ ɹivɛnʒ. θɛɝɑvə ən sʌmɛɝɪn wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni wʊmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən ɛni ʌv əm cʊɾə bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ izəli.

Sevanna glanced at Belinde, who avoided her eye. Sevanna's lip curled, half sneer, half snarl, and she planted fists on hips. Galina did not understand where she found the nerve, a woman who could not channel at all. Some of these women possessed not inconsiderable strength. No, she could not afford to think of them only as wilders if she was to escape and have her revenge. Therava and Someryn were stronger than any woman in the Tower, and any of them could have been Aes Sedai easily.

bʌt sɪvænə feɪst əm dɪfaɪənli. "ɪt simz jə ɹɛndɝd dʒʌstəs kwɪkli," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs dʒɹaɪ əz dʌst.

But Sevanna faced them defiantly. "It seems you rendered justice quickly," she said in a voice dry as dust.

"ðə mæɾɝ wɑz sɪmpəl," ʃən ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. "ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn ɹəsiv ðə dʒʌstəs ðeɪ dɪzɝvd."

"The matter was simple," Tion replied calmly. "The Mera'din received the justice they deserved."

"æn ðeɪ wɝ toʊl ðeɪ ɹəsivd ɪɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə jəɹ ətɛmp tə sweɪ ʌs," ɹiɑli æɾəd wɪð səm hit. sɪvænə nɪɹli dɪd snɑɹl ət ðæt.

"And they were told they received it in spite of your attempt to sway us," Rhiale added with some heat. Sevanna nearly did snarl at that.

θɛɝɑvə wəd nɑt bi daɪvɝɾɪd fɹəm əɹ pɝpəs, ðoʊ. ɪn wʌn swɪf stɛp ʃi ɹitʃt ɡəlinə, ɡɹɪpt ə hændfʊl ə hɝ hɛɹ ən dʒɝkt əɹ ʌp tə hɝ niz, bɛn əɹ hɛd bæk. θɛɝɑvə wɑz nɑt ðə tɔlɪst ə ðiz wɪmən baɪ ət list ə hɛd, jɛt ʃi lum tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn wɪð ə hɔks aɪz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əweɪ ɛvɹi θɔɾ ə ɹivɛnʒ əɹ dɪfaɪəns. ðə waɪt stʃɹiks tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ oʊnli meɪɾ əɹ feɪs mɔɹ kəmændɪŋ. ɡəlinəz hænz klɛntʃt ɪndə fɪsts ɑn əɹ θaɪz, neɪlz dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɝ pɑmz. ivən ðə bɝnɪŋ ə hɝ skɪn peɪld ʌndɝ ðət stɛɹ. ʃi hæd deɪdʒɹimd əbaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðiz wɪmən, meɪkɪŋ əm plid fəɹ dɛθ, læfɪŋ əz ʃi dɪnaɪd ðɛɹ bɛɡɪŋ. əbaʊɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ɪksɛp θɛɝɑvə. ət naɪt, θɛɝɑvə fɪld əɹ dʒɹimz ən ɔl ɡəlinə kəd də wɑz tʃɹaɪ tə fli; ði oʊnli ɪskeɪp wɑz tə weɪk skɹimɪŋ. ɡəlinə hæd bɹoʊkən stʃɹɔŋ mɛn ən stʃɹɔŋ wɪmən, bʌt ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət θɛɝɑvə waɪd-aɪɾ ən waɪnd.

Therava would not be diverted from her purpose, though. In one swift step she reached Galina, gripped a handful of her hair and jerked her up to her knees, bent her head back. Therava was not the tallest of these women by at least a head, yet she loomed taller than most men, staring down with a hawk's eyes, driving away every thought of revenge or defiance. The white streaks touching her dark red hair only made her face more commanding. Galina's hands clenched into fists on her thighs, nails digging into her palms. Even the burning of her skin paled under that stare. She had daydreamed about breaking every one of these women, making them plead for death, laughing as she denied their begging. About every one except Therava. At night, Therava filled her dreams and all Galina could do was try to flee; the only escape was to wake screaming. Galina had broken strong men and strong women, but she stared up at Therava wide-eyed and whined.

"ðɪs wʌn əz noʊ ɑnɝ tə ʃeɪm." θɛɝɑvə ɔlmoʊst spæt ðə wɝdz. "ɪf jə wɑn əɹ bɹoʊkən, sɪvænə, lemi hæv hɝ. wən aɪm dʌn, ʃɪl oʊbeɪ wɪθaʊt ðə nid fəɹ jəɹ fɹɛn kædɑɝz tɔɪ."

"This one has no honor to shame." Therava almost spat the words. "If you want her broken, Sevanna, let me have her. When I am done, she will obey without the need for your friend Caddar's toy."

sɪvænə spoʊk ʌp hiɾɪdli, dɪnaɪɪŋ fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð ðɪs kædɑɝ, huɛvɝ i wɑz, ən ɹiɑli bɑɹk ðət sɪvænə hæd bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ði ʌðɝz, ən ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əbaʊt wɛðɝ ðə "baɪndɝ" wəd wɝk ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən ðə "tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑks."

Sevanna spoke up heatedly, denying friendship with this Caddar, whoever he was, and Rhiale barked that Sevanna had brought him to the others, and others began arguing about whether the "binder" would work any better than the "traveling box."

ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ʌv ɡəlinəz maɪn sizd ɑn mɛnʃən ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ bɑks. ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɪt spoʊkən ə bɪfɔɹ, lɔŋ tə leɪ hænz ɑn ɪɾ ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ə moʊmənt. wɪð ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðəɾ ɛneɪbəld əɹ tə tʃɹævəl, haʊɛvɝ ɪmpɝfɪkli ɪt sim tə wɝk, ʃi wəd bi eɪbəl tə. . . . ivən hoʊp ʌv ɪskeɪp kəd nɑt stæn əɡɛns θɔts ʌv wʌt θɛɝɑvə wəd də tə hɝ ɪf ði ʌðɝz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡɪv ɪn tə ðə wʊmənz ɹɪkwɛst. wən ðə hɔk-aɪd waɪz wʌn lust əɹ hɛɹ tə dʒɔɪn ði ɑɹɡjəmənt, ɡəlinə hɝl hɝsɛlf ət ðə ɹɑd, lændɪŋ flæɾ ɑn əɹ bɛli. ɛniθɪŋ, ivən hævɪŋ tə oʊbeɪ sɪvænə, wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən biɪŋ hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə θɛɝɑvə. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ʃildɪd, ʃi wʊɾə tʃænəl tə ɑpɝeɪt ðə ɹɑd hɝsɛlf.

A small part of Galina's mind seized on mention of the traveling box. She had heard it spoken of before, longed to lay hands on it if only for a moment. With a ter'angreal that enabled her to Travel, however imperfectly it seemed to work, she would be able to. . . . Even hope of escape could not stand against thoughts of what Therava would do to her if the others decided to give in to the woman's request. When the hawk-eyed Wise One loosed her hair to join the argument, Galina hurled herself at the rod, landing flat on her belly. Anything, even having to obey Sevanna, was better than being handed over to Therava. If she had not been shielded, she would have channeled to operate the rod herself.

noʊ sunɝ dɪɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz kloʊs ɑn ðə smuð ɹɑd ðən θɛɝɑvəz fʊt keɪm daʊn ɑn ɪt hɑɹd, tʃɹæpɪŋ əɹ hænz peɪnfəli əɡɛns ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst əɾ əɹ wɛɹ ʃi leɪ ɹaɪðɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ fjuɾɪlli tə pʊl fɹi. ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf pʊl tu hɑɹd; dɪmli ʃi kəd ɹikɔl meɪkɪŋ ɹulɝz peɪl wɪð fɪɹ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ dɪstɝb ðɪs wʊmənz fʊt.

No sooner did her fingers close on the smooth rod than Therava's foot came down on it hard, trapping her hands painfully against the ground. None of the Wise Ones so much as glanced at her where she lay writhing, trying futilely to pull free. She could not make herself pull too hard; dimly she could recall making rulers pale with fear, but she did not dare disturb this woman's foot.

"ɪf ʃiz tə swɛɹ," θɛɝɑvə sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ hɑɹɾ ət sɪvænə, "ɪt ʃəd bi tə oʊbeɪ ɔl ʌv əs hɪɹ." ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd, səm vɔɪsɪŋ əɡɹimənt, ɔl bʌt bəlɪnd, ən ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps θɔtfəli.

"If she is to swear," Therava said, staring hard at Sevanna, "it should be to obey all of us here." The others nodded, some voicing agreement, all but Belinde, and she pursed her lips thoughtfully.

sɪvænə stɛɹd bæk dʒʌst əz hɑɹd. "vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi æksiɾɪd faɪnəli. "bʌt mi fɝst əmʌŋ ʌs. aɪm nɑɾ oʊnli ə waɪz wʌn; aɪ spik əz ðə klæn tʃif."

Sevanna stared back just as hard. "Very well," she acceded finally. "But me first among us. I am not only a Wise One; I speak as the clan chief."

θɛɝɑvə smaɪl θɪnli. "soʊ jə du. tu əmʌŋ əs fɝst, sɪvænə. jə ən aɪ." nɑɾ ə wɪspɝ ə dɪfaɪəns feɪɾəd fɹəm sɪvænəz feɪs, bʌt ʃi nɑɾəd. ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. oʊnli ðən dɪd θɛɝɑvə muv əɹ fʊt. ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd hɝ, ən ə floʊ ʌv spɪɹət tʌtʃt ðə numɝəlz ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹɑɾ ɪn ɡəlinəz hænz. dʒʌst əz wɑz dʌn wɪð ði oʊθ ɹɑd.

Therava smiled thinly. "So you do. Two among us first, Sevanna. You and I." Not a whisper of defiance faded from Sevanna's face, but she nodded. Grudgingly. Only then did Therava move her foot. The light of saidar surrounded her, and a flow of Spirit touched the numerals at the end of the rod in Galina's hands. Just as was done with the Oath Rod.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɡəlinə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, flɛksɪŋ mæʃt fɪŋɡɝz. ɪt fɛl ðə seɪm əz ði oʊθ ɹɑd, tu; nɑt kwaɪt laɪk aɪvɝi, nɑt kwaɪt laɪk ɡlæs, dɪstɪŋkli kul ɑn əɹ pɑmz. ɪf ɪt wɑz ə sɛkən oʊθ ɹɑd, ɪt kəd bi juz tə ɹimuv ɛni oʊθ ʃi swɔɹ naʊ. ɪf ʃi wɝ ɡɪvən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə teɪk ðə tʃæns, dɪd nɑt wɑnə swɛɹ tə θɛɝɑvə ɪn ɛni keɪs. ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs ɪn əɹ laɪf, ʃi hæd kəmændəd; laɪf sɪns əɹ kæptʃɝ hæd bɪn mɪzɝi, bʌt θɛɝɑvə wəd meɪk əɹ ə læpdɔɡ! jɛɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt, wəd ðeɪ lɛt θɛɝɑvə bɹeɪk hɝ? ʃi kəd nɑt faɪn ðə smɔləs pɑɹɾəkəl ə daʊt ðət ðə wʊmən wəd də dʒʌs ðæt. ʌɾɝli.

For an instant, Galina hesitated, flexing mashed fingers. It felt the same as the Oath Rod, too; not quite like ivory, not quite like glass, distinctly cool on her palms. If it was a second Oath Rod, it could be used to remove any oath she swore now. If she were given the opportunity. She did not want to take the chance, did not want to swear to Therava in any case. Always before this in her life, she had commanded; life since her capture had been misery, but Therava would make her a lapdog! Yet if she did not, would they let Therava break her? She could not find the smallest particle of doubt that the woman would do just that. Utterly.

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən ən ɹibɝθ" - ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪlivd ɪn ðə laɪɾ əɹ ə hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə spik mɔɹ ðən ə sɪmpəl pɹɑməs, bʌt ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ oʊθ - "aɪ swɛɹ tə oʊbeɪ ɛvɹi waɪz wʌn pɹɛzən hɪɹ ɪn ɔl θɪŋz, ən fɝst əmʌŋ ðɛm, θɛɝɑvə ən sɪvænə." ðə læs hoʊp ðət ðɪs "baɪndɝ" wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls vænɪʃt əz ɡəlinə fɛl ði oʊθ sɛɾəl ɑn hɝ, əz ɪf ʃi sʌɾənli wɔɹ ə ɡɑɹmən ðət kʌvɝɾ əɹ fɑɹ tu taɪtli fɹəm əɹ skælp tə ðə soʊlz ə hɝ fit. θɹoʊɪŋ bæk əɹ hɛd, ʃi skɹimd. ɪn pɑɹt ðət wɑz kəz ɪt sʌɾənli simd əz ɪf ðə bɝnɪŋ ə hɝ skɪn wɑz biɪŋ pɹɛs dip ɪndə hɝ flɛʃ, bʌt meɪnli, ɪt wɑz pjʊɹ dɪspɛɹ.

"Under the Light and by my hope of salvation and rebirth" - she no longer believed in the Light or a hope of salvation, and there was no need to speak more than a simple promise, but they expected a strong oath - "I swear to obey every Wise One present here in all things, and first among them, Therava and Sevanna." The last hope that this "binder" was something else vanished as Galina felt the oath settle on her, as if she suddenly wore a garment that covered her far too tightly from her scalp to the soles of her feet. Throwing back her head, she screamed. In part that was because it suddenly seemed as if the burning of her skin was being pressed deep into her flesh, but mainly, it was pure despair.

"bi kwaɪət!" θɛɝɑvə sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ də nɑt wɑnə lɪsən tə jə weɪlɪŋ!" ɡəlinəz tiθ klɪkt ʃʌt, nɪɹli baɪɾɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ, ən ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə swɑloʊ hɝ sɑbz. nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ oʊbiɾiəns wɑz pɑsəbəl, naʊ. θɛɝɑvə fɹaʊn ət hɝ. "lɛɾ əs si ɪf ðɪs tʃɹuli wɝks," ʃi mʌɾɝd, bɛndɪŋ kloʊsɝ. "hæv jə plæn vaɪələns əɡɛnst ɛni waɪz wʌn hɪɹ? ænsɝ tʃɹuθfəli, ən æsk tə bi pʌnɪʃt ɪf jə hæv. ðə pɛnəlti fəɹ vaɪələns əɡɛnst ə waɪz wʌn," ʃi æɾəd laɪk ən æftɝθɑt, "kæn bi tə bi kɪld laɪk ən ænəməl." ʃi dʒɹu ə fɪŋɡɝ ɪkspɹɛsɪvli əkɹɔs əɹ θɹoʊt ðən ɡɹɪpt əɹ bɛl naɪf wɪð ðə seɪm hænd.

"Be quiet!" Therava said sharply. "I do not want to listen to you wailing!" Galina's teeth clicked shut, nearly biting her tongue, and she struggled to swallow her sobs. Nothing but obedience was possible, now. Therava frowned at her. "Let us see if this truly works," she muttered, bending closer. "Have you planned violence against any Wise One here? Answer truthfully, and ask to be punished if you have. The penalty for violence against a Wise One," she added like an afterthought, "can be to be killed like an animal." She drew a finger expressively across her throat then gripped her belt knife with the same hand.

ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ ɪn hɔɹəfaɪd pænɪk, ɡəlinə ʃaɪd bæk fɹəm ðə wʊmən. ʃi kəd nɑt teɪk əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm θɛɝɑvəz, ðoʊ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ðə wɝdz ðət tʃæɾɝd θɹu hɝ tiθ. "aɪ di-dɪd, æɡ-dʒi-ɡeɪnst ɔl ə ju! pi-pliz pi-pʌnɪʃ mi ɛf-fɔɹ ɪt!" wəd ðeɪ kɪl hɝ, naʊ? æftɝ ɔl ə ðɪs, wɑz ʃi tə daɪ hɪɹ?

Gulping air in horrified panic, Galina shied back from the woman. She could not take her eyes away from Therava's, though, and she could not stop the words that chattered through her teeth. "I d-did, ag-g-gainst all of you! P-please p-punish me f-for it!" Would they kill her, now? After all of this, was she to die here?

"ɪt simz ðɪs baɪndɝ dʌz əz jəɹ fɹɛn kleɪmd æftɝ ɔl, sɪvænə." plʌkɪŋ ðə ɹɑd fɹəm ɡəlinəz lɪmp hænz, θɛɝɑvə tʌkt ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt əz ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd. "ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ simz ðət jəl wɛɹ waɪɾ æftɝ ɔl, ɡəlinə kæsbən." fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi ɡeɪv ə pliz smaɪl ət ðæt. bʌt ʃi ɪʃuɾ ʌðɝ kəmænz, tu. "ju wɪl bɪheɪv mikli, əz ə ɡeɪʃeɪn ʃʊd. ɪf ə tʃaɪl tɛlz jə tə dʒʌmp, jəl dʒʌmp ənlɛs wʌn ʌv əs əz sɛɾ ʌðɝwaɪz. ən jəl nɑt tʌtʃ seɪaɪdɑɹ əɹ tʃænəl ənlɛs wʌn ʌv əs tɛlz ju. ɹilis ðə ʃild ɑn hɝ, bəlɪnd."

"It seems this binder does as your friend claimed after all, Sevanna." Plucking the rod from Galina's limp hands, Therava tucked it behind her belt as she straightened. "It also seems that you will wear white after all, Galina Casban." For some reason, she gave a pleased smile at that. But she issued other commands, too. "You will behave meekly, as a gai'shain should. If a child tells you to jump, you will jump unless one of us has said otherwise. And you will not touch saidar or channel unless one of us tells you. Release the shield on her, Belinde."

ðə ʃil vænɪʃt, ən ɡəlinə nɛl ðɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ hɑloʊli. ðə sɔɹs ʃoʊn dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt, tæntəlaɪzɪŋ. ən ʃi cʊɾə spɹaʊɾəd wɪŋz əz izəli əz ʃi kəd stʃɹɛtʃ aʊt fəɹ ɪt.

The shield vanished, and Galina knelt there, staring hollowly. The Source shone just out of sight, tantalizing. And she could have sprouted wings as easily as she could stretch out for it.

bɹeɪslɪts klæɾɝd əz sɪvænə ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ɪn æŋɡɝ. "ju teɪk tu mʌtʃ ɑn jɝsɛlf, θɛɝɑvə. ðəɾ ɪz maɪn; ɡɪv ɪt tə mi!" ʃi hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hænd, bʌt θɛɝɑvə mɪɹli foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts.

Bracelets clattered as Sevanna shifted her shawl in anger. "You take too much on yourself, Therava. That is mine; give it to me!" She held out her hand, but Therava merely folded her arms beneath her breasts.

"ðɛɹ əv bɪn miɾɪŋz əmʌŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz," ðə stɝn-aɪd wʊmən toʊl sɪvænə. "wi hæv ɹitʃt sɝɾən dɪsɪʒənz." ðə wɪmən u hæd kʌm wɪð əɹ ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn hɝ, ɔl ə ðɛm feɪsɪŋ sɪvænə, ən bəlɪn hɝid tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

"There have been meetings among the Wise Ones," the stern-eyed woman told Sevanna. "We have reached certain decisions." The women who had come with her gathered behind her, all of them facing Sevanna, and Belinde hurried to join them.

"wɪθaʊt mi?" sɪvænə snæpt. "du ɛni ʌv jə dɛɹ ɹitʃ ə dɪsɪʒən wɪθaʊt mi?" hɝ toʊn ɹɪmeɪn əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɛvɝ, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz flɪkɝd tə ðə ɹɑɾ ɪn θɛɝɑvəz bɛlt, ən ɡəlinə θɔt ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ʌv ʌnizinəs ðɛɹ. ənʌðɝ taɪm, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn dɪlaɪɾəd tə si ɪt.

"Without me?" Sevanna snapped. "Do any of you dare reach a decision without me?" Her tone remained as strong as ever, but her eyes flickered to the rod in Therava's belt, and Galina thought there was a touch of uneasiness there. Another time, she would have been delighted to see it.

"wʌn dɪsɪʒən hæd tə bi ɹitʃt wɪθaʊt ju," ʃən sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs.

"One decision had to be reached without you," Tion said in a flat voice.

"æz jə soʊ ɔfən pɔɪn aʊt, jə spik əz ðə klæn tʃif," ɪmɝiz æɾəd, ə mɑkɪŋ laɪɾ ɪn əɹ bɪɡ ɡɹeɪ aɪz. "səmtaɪmz, waɪz wʌnz mʌs tɔk wɪθaʊɾ ə klæn tʃif lɪsnɪŋ. əɹ sʌmwʌn u spiks əz ə tʃif."

"As you so often point out, you speak as the clan chief," Emerys added, a mocking light in her big gray eyes. "Sometimes, Wise Ones must talk without a clan chief listening. Or someone who speaks as a chief."

"wi dɪsaɪɾɪd," θɛɝɑvə sɛd, "ðæt dʒʌst əz ə klæn tʃif mʌst əv ə waɪz wʌn tə ædvaɪz hɪm, soʊ mʌs juv ə waɪz wʌnz ædvaɪs. əl ædvaɪz ju."

"We decided," Therava said, "that just as a clan chief must have a Wise One to advise him, so must you have a Wise One's advice. I will advise you."

ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl ɝaʊn hɝ, sɪvænə stʌɾid ðə wɪmən kənfɹʌntɪŋ hɝ. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ənɹiɾəbəl. haʊ dɪd ʃi də ɪt? ðeɪ kəd kɹʌʃ əɹ laɪk ən ɛɡ bɪniθ ə hæmɝ. "ænd wʌɾ ædvaɪs dʒju ɔfɝ mi, θɛɝɑvə?" ʃi sɛɾ ət læst ɪn ən aɪsi vɔɪs.

Gathering her shawl around her, Sevanna studied the women confronting her. Her expression was unreadable. How did she do it? They could crush her like an egg beneath a hammer. "And what advice do you offer me, Therava?" she said at last in an icy voice.

"maɪ stʃɹɔŋ ædvaɪs ɪz ðət wi muv wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ," θɛɝɑvə ɹɪplaɪd, əz kul əz sɪvænə. "ðiz sintʃæn ɑɹ tu kloʊz ən tu mɛni. wi ʃəd muv nɔɹθ ɪndə ðiz maʊntənz ə mɪst ən ɪstæblɪʃ ə hoʊld. fɹəm ðɛɹ, wi kən sɛn pɑɹɾiz tə faɪn ði ʌðɝ sɛps. ɪt meɪ teɪk lɔŋ tə ɹiunaɪt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, sɪvænə. jəɹ wɛtləndɝ fɹɛn meɪ hæv skæɾɝd əs tə ðə naɪn kɔɹnɝz ə ðə wɝld. əntɪl wi də ðæt, wəɹ vʌlnɝəbəl."

"My strong advice is that we move without delay," Therava replied, as cool as Sevanna. "These Seanchan are too close and too many. We should move north into these Mountains of Mist and establish a hold. From there, we can send parties to find the other septs. It may take long to reunite the Shaido, Sevanna. Your wetlander friend may have scattered us to the nine corners of the world. Until we do that, we are vulnerable."

"wi wɪl muv təmɑɹoʊ." ɪf ɡəlinə hæd nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃi nu sɪvænə ɪnsaɪɾ ən aʊt, ʃi wʊɾə θɔt ðə wʊmən saʊndəd pɛtʃələn əz wɛl əz æŋɡɹi. ðoʊz ɡɹin aɪz flæʃt. "bʌɾ ist. ðəɾ ɔlsoʊ ɪz əweɪ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn, ən ðə lænz tə ði ist ɑɹ ɪn tɝmɔɪl, ɹaɪp fəɹ plʌkɪŋ."

"We will move tomorrow." If Galina had not been sure she knew Sevanna inside and out, she would have thought the woman sounded petulant as well as angry. Those green eyes flashed. "But east. That also is away from the Seanchan, and the lands to the east are in turmoil, ripe for plucking."

ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns, ðən θɛɝɑvə nɑɾəd. "ist." ʃi sɛd ðə wɝd sɔfli, ðə sɔfnəs ə sɪlk leɪɾ oʊvɝ stil. "bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət klæn tʃifs əv lɪv tə ɹəɡɹɛt ɹɪdʒɛktɪŋ ə waɪz wʌnz ædvaɪs tu ɔfən. jə meɪ, əz wɛl." ðə θɹɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs wɑz pleɪn əz ðəɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, jɛt sɪvænə læft!

There was a long silence, then Therava nodded. "East." She said the word softly, the softness of silk laid over steel. "But remember that clan chiefs have lived to regret rejecting a Wise One's advice too often. You may, as well." The threat on her face was plain as that in her voice, yet Sevanna laughed!

"ju ɹɪmɛmbɝ, θɛɝɑvə! ɔl ə jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ! ɪf aɪm lɛft fəɹ ðə vʌltʃɝz, soʊ wɪl jə bi! aɪ hæv meɪɾ əʃʊɹəns ə ðæt."

"You remember, Therava! All of you remember! If I am left for the vultures, so will you be! I have made assurance of that."

ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid ɡlænsɪz, ɔl bʌt θɛɝɑvə, ən moʊdʒɹə ən nɔɹliə fɹaʊnd.

The other women exchanged worried glances, all but Therava, and Modarra and Norlea frowned.

slʌmpt ɑn əɹ niz, wɪmpɝɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ ɪn veɪn tə suð əɹ skɪn wɪð əɹ hænz, ɡəlinə faʊn hɝsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt ðiz θɹɛts mɛnt. ɪt wɑz ə smɔl θɔt, wɝmɪŋ ɪts weɪ θɹu bɪɾɝnəs ən sɛlf-pɪɾi. ɛniθɪŋ ʃi kəd juz əɡɛns ðiz wɪmən wəd bi wɛlkəm. ɪf ʃi dɛɹd juz ɪt. ə bɪɾɝ θɔt.

Slumped on her knees, whimpering and trying in vain to soothe her skin with her hands, Galina found herself wondering what these threats meant. It was a small thought, worming its way through bitterness and self-pity. Anything she could use against these women would be welcome. If she dared use it. A bitter thought.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə skaɪ wɑz tɝnɪŋ dɑɹk. bɪloʊɪŋ klaʊdz wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, stʃɹikt ɡɹeɪ ən blæk, əbskjʊɹɪŋ ðə sʌn. ən bɪniθ ðə klaʊdz fɛl flɝiz ə snoʊ, swɝlɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. nʌn ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd - fju fɛl əz fɑɹ əz ðə tʃɹitɑps - bʌt ɡəlinə ɡeɪpt. snoʊ! hæd ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd lusən ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə wɝl fəɹ səm ɹizən?

Abruptly she realized that the sky was turning dark. Billowing clouds were rolling down from the north, streaked gray and black, obscuring the sun. And beneath the clouds fell flurries of snow, swirling in the air. None reached the ground - few fell as far as the treetops - but Galina gaped. Snow! Had the Great Lord loosened his grip on the world for some reason?

ðə waɪz wʌnz stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ, tu, maʊðz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin klaʊdz, mʌtʃ lɛs snoʊ.

The Wise Ones stared at the sky, too, mouths hanging open as if they had never seen clouds, much less snow.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs, ɡəlinə kæsbən?" θɛɝɑvə dɪmændəd. "spik ɪf jə noʊ!" ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðə skaɪ əntɪl ɡəlinə toʊld əɹ ɪt wɑz snoʊ, ən wən ʃi dɪɾ ɪt wɑz tə læf. "aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ðə mɛn u ɹæn daʊn leɪmən tʃɹikɪlɝ laɪɾ əbaʊt snoʊ. ðɪs kəd nɑt hæmpɝ ə maʊs!"

"What is this, Galina Casban?" Therava demanded. "Speak if you know!" She did not look away from the sky until Galina told her it was snow, and when she did it was to laugh. "I always thought the men who ran down Laman Treekiller lied about snow. This could not hamper a mouse!"

ɡəlinə klæmpt əɹ dʒɔz ʃʌɾ ɑn ɪkspleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt snoʊfɔlz, əɡæs ðəɾ əɹ ɪnstɪŋk hæd bɪn tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ. əɡæst əz wɛl ət ðə smɔl pæŋ ə plɛʒɝ ðət kipɪŋ ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən bæk ɡeɪv. aɪm ðə haɪəst ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ! ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf. aɪ sɪɾ ɑn ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ! ðeɪ saʊndəd laɪk laɪz. ðɪs wɑz nɑt fɛɹ!

Galina clamped her jaws shut on explaining about snowfalls, aghast that her instinct had been to curry favor. Aghast as well at the small pang of pleasure that keeping the information back gave. I am the Highest of the Red Ajah! she reminded herself. I sit on the Supreme Council of the Black Ajah! They sounded like lies. This was not fair!

"ɪf wəɹ dʌn hɪɹ," sɪvænə sɛd, "aɪ wɪl teɪk ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn bæk tə ðə ɡɹeɪt ɹuf ən si hɝ pʊɾ ɪn waɪt. jə kən ɹɪmeɪn ən stɛɹ ət ðə snoʊ ɪf jə wɪʃ." hɝ toʊn wɑz soʊ smuð, laɪk bʌɾɝ ɪn ðə tʌb, ðət noʊ wʌn wʊɾə θɔɾ əɹ ət dæɡɝz' pɔɪns oʊnli moʊməns ɝliɝ. ʃi lupt əɹ ʃɔl oʊvɝ əɹ ɛlboʊz ən ədʒʌstəd səm ə hɝ nɛkləsɪz; nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝl kənsɝn əɹ mɔɹ.

"If we are done here," Sevanna said, "I will take the gai'shain back to the great roof and see her put in white. You can remain and stare at the snow if you wish." Her tone was so smooth, like butter in the tub, that no one would have thought her at daggers' points only moments earlier. She looped her shawl over her elbows and adjusted some of her necklaces; nothing in the world concerned her more.

"wi wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn," θɛɝɑvə toʊld əɹ dʒʌst əz smuðli. "sɪns jə spik əz ðə tʃif, juv ə lɔŋ deɪ ən moʊst ə ðə naɪɾ əhɛɾ ə jə ɪf wəɹ tə muv təmɑɹoʊ." fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, sɪvænəz aɪz flæʃt əɡɛn, bʌt θɛɝɑvə mɪɹli snæpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ən dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli ət ɡəlinə bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ. "kʌm wɪð mi," ʃi sɛd. "æn stɑp paʊɾɪŋ."

"We will take care of the gai'shain," Therava told her just as smoothly. "Since you speak as the chief, you have a long day and most of the night ahead of you if we are to move tomorrow." For an instant, Sevanna's eyes flashed again, but Therava merely snapped her fingers and gestured sharply at Galina before turning to go. "Come with me," she said. "And stop pouting."

hɛd daʊn, ɡəlinə skɹæmbəl tə hɝ fiɾ ən skɝiɾ æftɝ θɛɝɑvə ən ði ʌðɝ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl. paʊɾɪŋ? ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn skaʊlɪŋ, bʌt nɛvɝ paʊɾɪŋ! hɝ θɔts skɹæbəld laɪk ɹæts ɪn ə keɪdʒ, faɪndɪŋ noʊ hoʊp ʌv ɪskeɪp. ðəɹ hæd tə bi wʌn! ðəɹ hæd tə bi! wʌn θɔt ðət sɝfɪst ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðət tɝmɔɪl ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ əɹ bɪɡɪn wipɪŋ əɡɛn. wɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz sɑftɝ ðən ðə skɹætʃi blæk wʊl ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə wɛɹ soʊ fɑɹ? ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ aʊt! ə heɪsti ɡlæns bæk θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ʃoʊd sɪvænə stɪl stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, ɡlɛɹɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm. oʊvɝhɛd, ðə klaʊdz swɝld, ən ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ mɛltəd laɪk ɡəlinəz hoʊps.

Head down, Galina scrambled to her feet and scurried after Therava and the other women who could channel. Pouting? She might have been scowling, but never pouting! Her thoughts scrabbled like rats in a cage, finding no hope of escape. There had to be one! There had to be! One thought that surfaced in the middle of that turmoil almost made her begin weeping again. Were gai'shain robes softer than the scratchy black wool she had been forced to wear so far? There had to be a way out! A hasty glance back through the trees showed Sevanna still standing there, glaring after them. Overhead, the clouds swirled, and the falling snow melted like Galina's hopes.


tʃæptɝ twɛlv


CHAPTER 12

nu əlaɪənsəz


New Alliances

ɡɹeɪndəl wɪʃt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ivən ə sɪmpəl tʃɹænskɹaɪbɝ əmʌŋ ðə θɪŋz ʃi hæd ɹimuv fɹəm ɪljən æftɝ sɑmaɪlz dɛθ. ðɪs eɪdʒ wɑz fɹaɪtfəl juʒəwəli, pɹɪməɾɪv ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl. stɪl, səm ʌv ɪt suɾəd hɝ. ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ bæmbu keɪdʒ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum ə hʌnʒɹəd bɹaɪtli pluməɡd bɝdz sæŋ mɛloʊɾiəsli, ɔlmoʊst əz bjuɾəfəl ɪn ðɛɹ mʌltikʌlɝd flɪɾɪŋ əz əɹ tu pɛts ɪn tʃɹænspɛɹən ɹoʊbz u weɪɾəd ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ, ðɛɹ ɡeɪzəz lɑkt ɑn hɝ, iɡɝ tə sɝv əɹ plɛʒɝ. ɪf ɔɪl læmps dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ðə seɪm laɪɾ əz ɡloʊbəlbz, eɪɾəd baɪ lɑɹdʒ mɪɹɝz ɑn ðə wɔlz ðeɪ pɹədust ə sɝɾən bɑɹbæɹɪk splɛndɝ wɪð ðə ɡɪldɪd fɪʃ-skeɪl silɪŋ. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn naɪs tə niɾ oʊnli spik ðə wɝdz, bʌɾ æktʃəli  pʊɾɪŋ əm ɑn peɪpɝ wɪð əɹ oʊn hæn pɹədust ə plɛʒɝ əkɪn tə ðət ʃi fɛlt ɪn skɛtʃɪŋ. ðə skɹɪpt ə ðɪs eɪdʒ wɑz kwaɪt sɪmpəl, ən lɝnɪŋ tə dupləkeɪɾ ənʌðɝz staɪl hæd bɪn noʊ mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt.

Graendal wished there had been even a simple transcriber among the things she had removed from Illian after Sammael's death. This Age was frightful usually, primitive and uncomfortable. Still, some of it suited her. In a large bamboo cage at the far end of the room a hundred brightly plumaged birds sang melodiously, almost as beautiful in their multicolored flitting as her two pets in transparent robes who waited on either side of the door, their gazes locked on her, eager to serve her pleasure. If oil lamps did not give the same light as glowbulbs, aided by large mirrors on the walls they produced a certain barbaric splendor with the gilded fish-scale ceiling. It would have been nice to need only speak the words, but actually putting them on paper with her own hand produced a pleasure akin to that she felt in sketching. The script of this Age was quite simple, and learning to duplicate another's style had been no more difficult.

saɪnɪŋ wɪð ə flɝɪʃ - nɑɾ əɹ oʊn neɪm, ʌv kɔɹs - ʃi sændɪd ðə θɪk peɪdʒ, ðən foʊldəɾ ɪɾ ən sild ɪt wɪð wʌn ə ðə sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋz ə vɛɹiəs saɪzəz ðət meɪɾ ə dɛkɹəɾɪv laɪn əkɹɔs ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. ðə hæn ən sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən ɪmpɹɛst ɑn ən ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ sɝkəl ə blu-ænd-ɡɹin wæks.

Signing with a flourish - not her own name, of course - she sanded the thick page, then folded it and sealed it with one of the signet rings of various sizes that made a decorative line across the writing table. The Hand and Sword of Arad Doman impressed on an irregular circle of blue-and-green wax.

"teɪk ðɪs tə lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi wɪð ɔl spid," ʃi sɛd, "æn seɪ oʊnli wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju."

"Take this to Lord Ituralde with all speed," she said, "and say only what I told you."

"æz fæst əz hɔɹsəz kən kæɹi mi, maɪ leɪɾi." næzɹən baʊɾ əz i tʊk ðə lɛɾɝ, wʌn fɪŋɡɝ stʃɹoʊkɪŋ θɪn blæk mʌstæʃɪz əbʌv ə wɪnɪŋ smaɪl. skwɛɹ ən dipli bɹaʊn ɪn ə wɛl-fɪɾɪŋ blu koʊt, hi wɑz hænsəm; dʒʌs nɑt səfɪʃənli hænsəm. "aɪ ɹəsiv ðɪs fɹəm ðə leɪɾi tuvə, hu daɪɾ ə hɝ wunz æftɝ tɛlɪŋ mi ðət ʃi wɑz ə kɝiɝ fɹəm ælsələm ən hæd bɪn ətæk baɪ ə ɡɹeɪ mæn."

"As fast as horses can carry me, my Lady." Nazran bowed as he took the letter, one finger stroking thin black mustaches above a winning smile. Square and deeply brown in a well-fitting blue coat, he was handsome; just not sufficiently handsome. "I received this from the Lady Tuva, who died of her wounds after telling me that she was a courier from Alsalam and had been attacked by a Gray Man."

"meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ ɪz hjumən blʌɾ ɑn ɪt," ʃi ədmɑnɪʃt. ʃi daʊɾɪd ɛniwʌn ɪn ðɪs taɪm kəd tɛl hjumən blʌd fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd faʊn tu mɛni sɝpɹaɪzəz tə teɪk ən ənnɛsəsɛɹi tʃæns. "ɪnʌf fəɹ ɹilɪzəm; nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə spɔɪl wʌɾ aɪ ɹoʊt."

"Make sure there is human blood on it," she admonished. She doubted anyone in this time could tell human blood from any other, but she had found too many surprises to take an unnecessary chance. "Enough for realism; not enough to spoil what I wrote."

hɪz blæk aɪz lɪŋɡɝd wɔɹmli ɑn əɹ əz i baʊɾ əɡɛn, bʌɾ əz sun əz i stʃɹeɪɾənd i hɝid tə ðə dɔɹ, buts θəɾɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪl jɛloʊ mɑɹbəl flɔɹ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs ðə sɝvəns wɪð ðɛɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑɹɾəntli ɑn hɝ, əɹ əfɛktəd nɑt tə noʊɾəs, ðoʊ hi hæd wʌns bɪn ə fɹɛn ə ðə jʌŋ mæn. oʊnli ə tʌtʃ ə kəmpʌlʃən hæd bɪn niɾəd tə meɪk næzɹən nɪɹli əz ævəd tə oʊbeɪ əz ðeɪ, nɑt tə mɛnʃən sɝɾən ðəɾ i maɪt jɛt teɪst əɹ tʃɑɹmz əɡɛn. ʃi læf sɔfli. wɛl, hi bɪlivd i hæd teɪstəd ðɛm; dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl pɹɪɾiɝ, ən i maɪt hæv. ʌv kɔɹs, hi wʊɾə bɪn jusləs fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðɛn. hi wəd ɹaɪd hɔɹsəz tə dɛθ ɹitʃɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldi, ən ɪf ðət mɛsədʒ, dɪlɪvɝd baɪ ælsələmz kloʊs kʌzən, səpoʊzədli kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ən wɪð ɡɹeɪ mɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp ɪt, dɪd nɑt sæɾəsfaɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz kəmæn tə ɪnkɹis keɪɑs, nʌθɪŋ wʊd, ʃɔɹɾ ə bɑlfaɪɝ. ən ɪt wəd sɝv əɹ oʊn ɛnz vɛɹi naɪsli əz wɛl. hɝ oʊn ɛnz.

His black eyes lingered warmly on her as he bowed again, but as soon as he straightened he hurried to the door, boots thudding on the pale yellow marble floor. He did not notice the servants with their eyes fixed ardently on her, or affected not to notice, though he had once been a friend of the young man. Only a touch of Compulsion had been needed to make Nazran nearly as avid to obey as they, not to mention certain that he might yet taste her charms again. She laughed softly. Well, he believed he had tasted them; just a little prettier, and he might have. Of course, he would have been useless for anything else then. He would ride horses to death reaching Ituralde, and if that message, delivered by Alsalam's close cousin, supposedly coming from the King himself and with Gray Men trying to stop it, did not satisfy the Great Lord's command to increase chaos, nothing would, short of balefire. And it would serve her own ends very nicely as well. Her own ends.

ɡɹeɪndəlz hænd wɛn tə ði oʊnli ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə sɪɡnɪt, ə pleɪn ɡoʊldən bæn tu smɔl fəɹ ɛni bʌɾ əɹ lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn ə plɛzən sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ən æŋɡɹil ətun tə wɪmən əmʌŋ sɑmaɪlz pəzɛʃənz. ə plɛzən sɝpɹaɪz tə hæv taɪm tə faɪn mʌtʃ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl wɪð ælθɹ ən ðoʊz pʌpiz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz æʃəmən kɑnstənli ɪn ən aʊɾ ə sɑmaɪlz tʃeɪmbɝz ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəl. ðeɪ hæd stʃɹɪpt ɪt bɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd nɑt teɪkən. deɪnʒɝəs pʌpiz, ɔl ə ðɛm, ɪspɛʃli ælθɹ. ən ʃi hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə ɹɪsk ɛniwʌn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə dʒɹɔ ə laɪn fɹəm sɑmaɪl tə hɝ. jɛs, ʃi mʌst ɪnkɹis ðə peɪs ə hɝ oʊn plænz, ən dɪstəns hɝsɛlf fɹəm sɑmaɪlz dɪzæstɝ.

Graendal's hand went to the only ring on the table that was not a signet, a plain golden band too small for any but her little finger. It had been a pleasant surprise to find an angreal attuned to women among Sammael's possessions. A pleasant surprise to have time to find much of anything useful with al'Thor and those puppies who called themselves Asha'man constantly in and out of Sammael's chambers in the Great Hall of the Council. They had stripped it bare of what she had not taken. Dangerous puppies, all of them, especially al'Thor. And she had not wanted to risk anyone being able to draw a line from Sammael to her. Yes, she must increase the pace of her own plans, and distance herself from Sammael's disaster.

əbɹʌpli ə vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə sɪlvɝ əpɪɹɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, bɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə tæpəstʃɹiz hæŋɪŋ bɪtwin ðə hɛvi ɡɪldɪd mɪɹɝz, ən ə kɹɪstəlaɪn tʃaɪm ɹæŋ laʊd. hɝ aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. sʌmwʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə kɝɾəsiz ʌv ə mɔɹ sɪvəlaɪzd eɪdʒ, ɪt simd. stændɪŋ, ʃi fɔɹs ðə pleɪn bæn ʌv ɡoʊl daʊn əɡɛns ðə ɹubi ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ smɔləs fɪŋɡɝ ən ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ θɹu ɪt bɪfɔɹ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wɛb ðət wəd saʊn ən ænsɝɪŋ tʃaɪm fəɹ huɛvɝ wɑntəd tə oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ. ði æŋɡɹil dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ mʌtʃ, jɛɾ ɛniwʌn u θɔt ðeɪ nu hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ wəd faɪn ə ʃɑk.

Abruptly a vertical slash of silver appeared at the far end of the room, bright against the tapestries hanging between the heavy gilded mirrors, and a crystalline chime rang loud. Her eyebrows rose in surprise. Someone remembered the courtesies of a more civilized Age, it seemed. Standing, she forced the plain band of gold down against the ruby ring on her smallest finger and embraced saidar through it before channeling the web that would sound an answering chime for whoever wanted to open a gateway. The angreal did not offer much, yet anyone who thought they knew her strength would find a shock.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənd, ən tu wɪmən ɪn nɪɹli aɪdɛntɪkəl ɹɛd-ænd-blæk sɪlk dʒɹɛsəz stɛp θɹu wɛɹəli. ət list, mɑɡiɾin muv kɔʃəsli, dɑɹk aɪz flɪkɝɪŋ ɪn sɝtʃ ə tʃɹæps, hænz smuðɪŋ əɹ waɪd skɝts; ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋkt aʊɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, bʌt ʃi hɛld ɑn tə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ə sɛnsəbəl pɹikɔʃən, ðoʊ mɑɡiɾin hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə ɡɹeɪt wʌn fəɹ pɹikɔʃənz. ɡɹeɪndəl dɪd nɑt lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə sɔɹs, iðɝ. mɑɡiɾinz kəmpænjən, ə ʃɔɹt jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð lɔŋ sɪlvɝ hɛɹ ən vɪvəd blu aɪz, stɛɹɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ koʊldli, hɑɹdli mɔɹ ðən ɡlænsɪŋ ɪn ɡɹeɪndəlz dɝɛkʃən. baɪ hɝ dɪminɝ, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə pɹaɪm kaʊnsəlɝ fɔɹs tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ðə kʌmpəni ʌv kɑmən leɪbɝɝz ən ɪntɛn ɑn ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns. ə fulɪʃ ɡɝl, tə ɪməteɪt ðə spaɪɾɝ. ɹɛɾ ən blæk dɪd nɑt suɾ əɹ kʌlɝɪŋ, ən ʃi ʃʊɾə meɪd bɛɾɝ jus ə sətʃ ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv bʊzəm.

The gateway opened, and two women in nearly identical red-and-black silk dresses stepped through warily. At least, Moghedien moved cautiously, dark eyes flickering in search of traps, hands smoothing her wide skirts; the gateway winked out after a moment, but she held on to saidar. A sensible precaution, though Moghedien had always been a great one for precautions. Graendal did not let go of the Source, either. Moghedien's companion, a short young woman with long silver hair and vivid blue eyes, stared about her coldly, hardly more than glancing in Graendal's direction. By her demeanor, she might have been a Prime Counselor forced to endure the company of common laborers and intent on ignoring their existence. A foolish girl, to imitate the Spider. Red and black did not suit her coloring, and she should have made better use of such an impressive bosom.

"ðɪs ɪz sɪndeɪn, ɡɹeɪndəl," mɑɡiɾin sɛd. "wi ɑɹ . . . wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ." ʃi dɪd nɑt smaɪl wən ʃi neɪm ðə hɔɾi jʌŋ wʊmən, bʌt ɡɹeɪndəl dɪd. ə pɹɪɾi neɪm fəɹ ə mɔɹ ðən pɹɪɾi ɡɝl, bʌt wʌt twɪst ə feɪt hæd lɛd səm mʌðɝ ə ðɪs taɪm tə ɡɪv əɹ dɔɾɝ ə neɪm ðət mɛnt "læs tʃæns"? sɪndeɪnz feɪs ɹɪmeɪn koʊld ən smuð, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz flɛɹd. ə bjuɾəfəl dɑl kɑɹv fɹəm aɪs, wɪð hɪɾən faɪɝz. ɪt simd ʃi nu ðə minɪŋ ən dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt.

"This is Cyndane, Graendal," Moghedien said. "We are . . . working together." She did not smile when she named the haughty young woman, but Graendal did. A pretty name for a more than pretty girl, but what twist of fate had led some mother of this time to give her daughter a name that meant "Last Chance"? Cyndane's face remained cold and smooth, but her eyes flared. A beautiful doll carved from ice, with hidden fires. It seemed she knew the meaning and did not like it.

"wʌt bɹɪŋz jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnd, mɑɡiɾin?" ɡɹeɪndəl æskt. ðə spaɪɾɝ wɑz ðə vɛɹi læst ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə kʌm aʊt fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz. "hæv noʊ fɪɹ ə spikɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə maɪ sɝvəns." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd, ən ðə pɛɹ baɪ ðə dɔɹ sæŋk tə ðɛɹ niz, pɹɛs ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ðə flɔɹ. ðeɪ wəd nɑt kwaɪt fɔl dɛd baɪ hɝ sɪmpəl kəmænd, bʌt kloʊs.

"What brings you and your friend, Moghedien?" Graendal asked. The Spider was the very last she had expected to come out from the shadows. "Have no fear of speaking in front of my servants." She gestured, and the pair by the door sank to their knees, pressed their faces to the floor. They would not quite fall dead by her simple command, but close.

"wʌɾ ɪntʃɹəs kən jə faɪn ɪn əm wən jə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt meɪk əm ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ?" sɪndeɪn dɪmændəd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɛɹəɡənli əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf vɛɹi stʃɹeɪt, stʃɹaɪvɪŋ fəɹ ɛvɹi hɛɹ ə haɪt. "du jə noʊ ðət sɑmaɪl ɪz dɛd?"

"What interest can you find in them when you destroy anything that might make them interesting?" Cyndane demanded, striding arrogantly across the floor. She held herself very straight, striving for every hair of height. "Do you know that Sammael is dead?"

ɡɹeɪndəl kɛpt əɹ oʊn feɪs smuð, wɪð ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝt. ʃi hæd səpoʊz ðɪs ɡɝl səm fɹɛn ə ðə dɑɹk hum mɑɡiɾin hæd pɪkt ʌp tə ɹʌn ɛɹənz, pɝhæps ə noʊbəl u θɔɾ əɹ taɪɾəl kaʊntəd, bʌt naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz kloʊz. . . . ðə ɡɝl wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf! ivən ɪn əɹ oʊn eɪdʒ, ðət hæd bɪn ənkɑmən əmʌŋ mɛn, ən vɛɹi ɹɛɹ ɪndiɾ əmʌŋ wɪmən. ɑn ði ɪnstənt, ɑn ɪnstɪŋkt, ʃi tʃeɪnʒd əɹ ɪntɛntʃən tə dɪnaɪ ɛni kɑntækt wɪð sɑmaɪl.

Graendal kept her own face smooth, with a little effort. She had supposed this girl some Friend of the Dark whom Moghedien had picked up to run errands, perhaps a noble who thought her title counted, but now that she was close. . . . The girl was stronger in the One Power than she herself! Even in her own Age, that had been uncommon among men, and very rare indeed among women. On the instant, on instinct, she changed her intention to deny any contact with Sammael.

"aɪ səspɛktəd," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, dɝɛktɪŋ ə fɔls smaɪl oʊvɝ ðə jʌŋ wʊmənz hɛɾ ət mɑɡiɾin. haʊ mʌtʃ dɪd ʃi noʊ? wɛɹ hæd ðə spaɪɾɝ faʊn ə ɡɝl soʊ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʃi, ən waɪ wɑz ʃi tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð hɝ? mɑɡiɾin hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn dʒɛləs ʌv ɛniwʌn wɪð mɔɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ. əɹ mɔɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ. "hi juz tə vɪzət mi, ɪmpɹtunɪŋ maɪ hɛlp ɪn wʌn mæd plæn əɹ ənʌðɝ. aɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ɪm aʊtʃɹaɪt; jə noʊ sɑmaɪl ɪz - wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs mæn tə ɹɪdʒɛkt. hi əpɪɹɾ ɛvɹi fju deɪz wɪθaʊt feɪl, ən wən i stɑpt, aɪ əsum sʌmθɪŋ daɪɹ hæd hæpən tə hɪm. hu ɪz ðɪs ɡɝl, mɑɡiɾin? ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl faɪnd."

"I suspected," she replied, directing a false smile over the young woman's head at Moghedien. How much did she know? Where had the Spider found a girl so much stronger than she, and why was she traveling with her? Moghedien had always been jealous of anyone with more strength. Or more of anything. "He used to visit me, importuning my help in one mad plan or another. I never rejected him outright; you know Sammael is - was a dangerous man to reject. He appeared every few days without fail, and when he stopped, I assumed something dire had happened to him. Who is this girl, Moghedien? A remarkable find."

ðə jʌŋ wʊmən stɛp kloʊsɝ, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ əɹ wɪð aɪz laɪk blu faɪɝ. "ʃi toʊl jə maɪ neɪm. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl jə nid noʊ." ðə ɡɝl nu ʃi spoʊk tə wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ən jɛɾ əɹ toʊn ɹɪmeɪn fɹɔst. ivən ɡɪvən əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ, ðɪs wɑz noʊ sɪmpəl fɹɛn ə ðə dɑɹk. ənlɛs ʃi wɑz ɪnseɪn. "hæv jə peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə ðə wɛðɝ, ɡɹeɪndəl?"

The young woman stepped closer, staring up at her with eyes like blue fire. "She told you my name. That is all you need know." The girl knew she spoke to one of the Chosen, and yet her tone remained frost. Even given her strength, this was no simple Friend of the Dark. Unless she was insane. "Have you paid attention to the weather, Graendal?"

əbɹʌpli, ɡɹeɪndəl ɹilaɪz ðət mɑɡiɾin wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡɝl də ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ. hæŋɪŋ bæk əntɪl ə wiknəs bɪkeɪm əpɛɹənt. ən ɡɹeɪndəl hæd bɪn lɛɾɪŋ hɝ! "aɪ də nɑt səpoʊz jə keɪm tə tɛl mi ʌv sɑmaɪlz dɛθ, mɑɡiɾin," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ɔɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt wɛðɝ. jə noʊ aɪ sɛldəm ɡoʊ aʊtsaɪd." neɪtʃɝ wɑz ənɹuli, lækɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ. ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ivən wɪndoʊz ɪn ðɪs ɹum, nɔɹ ɪn moʊs ðət ʃi juzd. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz ɛdʒɪŋ saɪdweɪz əlɔŋ ðə wɔl; ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ stɪl sɝaʊndəd hɝ. ɡɹeɪndəl stɛp kæʒəwəli soʊ ðət boʊθ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ saɪt.

Abruptly, Graendal realized that Moghedien was letting the girl do all the talking. Hanging back until a weakness became apparent. And Graendal had been letting her! "I do not suppose you came to tell me of Sammael's death, Moghedien," she said sharply. "Or to talk about weather. You know I seldom go outside." Nature was unruly, lacking order. There were not even windows in this room, nor in most that she used. "What do you want?" The dark-haired woman was edging sideways along the wall; the glow of the One Power still surrounded her. Graendal stepped casually so that both remained in her sight.

"ju meɪk ə mɪsteɪk, ɡɹeɪndəl." ə tʃɪli smaɪl bɛɹli kɝv sɪndeɪnz fʊl lɪps; ʃi wɑz ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðɪs. "aɪ lɛd bɪtwin ʌs. mɑɡiɾin ɪz ɪn ə bæɾ oʊɾɝ wɪð mɔɹaɪɾɪn fəɹ əɹ ɹisən mɪsteɪks."

"You make a mistake, Graendal." A chilly smile barely curved Cyndane's full lips; she was enjoying this. "I lead between us. Moghedien is in a bad odor with Moridin for her recent mistakes."

ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, mɑɡiɾin ʃɑt ðə sɪlvɝ-hɛɹd lɪɾəl wʊmən ə skaʊl əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛni spoʊkən kɑnfɝmeɪʃən. sʌɾənli sɪndeɪnz bɪɡ aɪz oʊpən ivən waɪɾɝ, ən ʃi ɡæspt, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ.

Wrapping her arms around herself, Moghedien shot the silver-haired little woman a scowl as good as any spoken confirmation. Suddenly Cyndane's big eyes opened even wider, and she gasped, shuddering.

mɑɡiɾinz ɡlɛɹ tɝn məlɪʃəs. "ju lɛd fəɹ ðə moʊmənt," ʃi snɪɹd. "jɔɹ pleɪs ɪn ɪz aɪz ɪz nɑt fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən maɪn." ən ðən ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ʃɪvɝd, baɪɾɪŋ əɹ lɪp.

Moghedien's glare turned malicious. "You lead for the moment," she sneered. "Your place in his eyes is not far better than mine." And then she gave a start and shivered, biting her lip.

wɑz ʃi biɪŋ tɔɪd wɪð, ɡɹeɪndəl wʌndɝd. ðə pjʊɹ heɪtʃɹəd fəɹ itʃ ʌðɝ ɑn ðə tu wɪmənz feɪsəz simd ənfeɪənd. iðɝ weɪ, ʃi wəd si haʊ ðeɪ ɛndʒɔɪd biɪŋ pleɪd. ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ, ɹʌbɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ, ʃi muv tə ə tʃɛɹ wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə pɛɹ. ðə switnəs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ floʊɪŋ ɪndə hɝ wɑz ə kʌmfɝt. nɑt ðət ʃi niɾəd kʌmfɝt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɑd hɪɹ. ðə haɪ stʃɹeɪt bæk, θɪkli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd, meɪd ðə tʃɛɹ sim ə θɹoʊn, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ ɪn ðə ɹum. sətʃ θɪŋz əfɛktəɾ ivən ðə moʊst səfɪstəkeɪɾɪd ɑn lɛvəlz ðeɪ nɛvɝ nu kɑnʃəsli.

Was she being toyed with, Graendal wondered. The pure hatred for each other on the two women's faces seemed unfeigned. Either way, she would see how they enjoyed being played. Unconsciously rubbing her hands together, rubbing the angreal on her finger, she moved to a chair without taking her eyes from the pair. The sweetness of saidar flowing into her was a comfort. Not that she needed comfort, but there was something odd here. The high straight back, thickly carved and gilded, made the chair seem a throne, though it was no different from any other in the room. Such things affected even the most sophisticated on levels they never knew consciously.

ʃi sæt linɪŋ bæk wɪð əɹ lɛɡz kɹɔst, wʌn fʊt kɪkɪŋ aɪdli, ðə pɪktʃɝ ʌv ə wʊmən əɾ əɹ iz, ən meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs bɔɹd. "sɪns jə lɛd, tʃaɪld, tɛl mi, wən ðɪs mæn u kɔlz hɪmsɛlf dɛθ ɪz ɪn ɪz skɪn, hu ɪz hi? wʌɾ ɪz hi?"

She sat leaning back with her legs crossed, one foot kicking idly, the picture of a woman at her ease, and made her voice bored. "Since you lead, child, tell me, when this man who calls himself Death is in his skin, who is he? What is he?"

"mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪz nɛbli." ðə ɡɝlz vɔɪs wɑz kɑm ən koʊld ən ɛɹəɡənt. "ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ əz dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪts taɪm fəɹ jə tə sɝv ðə nɛbli, tu."

"Moridin is Nae'blis." The girl's voice was calm and cold and arrogant. "The Great Lord has decided it is time for you to serve the Nae'blis, too."

ɡɹeɪndəl dʒɝkt əpɹaɪt. "ðɪs ɪz pɹɪpɑstɝəs." ʃi kəd nɑt kip ði æŋɡɝ fɹəm əɹ vɔɪs. "ə mæn aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə hæz bɪn neɪm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ɹidʒən ɑn ɝθ?" ʃi dɪd nɑt maɪnd wən ʌðɝz tʃɹaɪd tə mənɪpjəleɪɾ əɹ - ʃi ɔlweɪz faʊn ə weɪ tə tɝn ðɛɹ skimz əɡɛnst əm - bʌt mɑɡiɾin mʌs teɪk əɹ fəɹ ə hæf-wɪt! ʃi hæd noʊ daʊt ðət mɑɡiɾin wɑz dɝɛktɪŋ ðɪs ɑbnɑkʃəs ɡɝl, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kleɪmd, wʌtɛvɝ lʊks ðeɪ stæbd əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ. "aɪ sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ən maɪsɛlf, noʊ ʌðɝ! aɪ θɪŋk ðə tu ʌv jə ʃəd ɡoʊ, naʊ, ən pleɪ jəɹ lɪɾəl ɡeɪm ɛlswɛɹ. dɪmɑndɝd maɪt bi daɪvɝɾɪd baɪ ɪt. əɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ? bi kɛɹfəl haʊ jə tʃænəl ɪn livɪŋ; aɪ hæv sɛɾ ə fju ɪnvɝɾɪd wɛbz, ən jə wəd nɑt wɑnə tʃɹɪɡɝ wʌn."

Graendal jerked upright. "This is preposterous." She could not keep the anger from her voice. "A man I've never heard of has been named the Great Lord's Regent on Earth?" She did not mind when others tried to manipulate her - she always found a way to turn their schemes against them - but Moghedien must take her for a half-wit! She had no doubt that Moghedien was directing this obnoxious girl, whatever they claimed, whatever looks they stabbed at each other. "I serve the Great Lord and myself, no other! I think the two of you should go, now, and play your little game elsewhere. Demandred might be diverted by it. Or Semirhage? Be careful how you channel in leaving; I have set a few inverted webs, and you would not want to trigger one."

ðət wɑz ə laɪ, bʌɾ ə vɛɹi bəlivəbəl wʌn, soʊ ɪt keɪm əz ə ʃɑk wən mɑɡiɾin sʌɾənli tʃænəld ən ɛvɹi læmp ɪn ðə ɹum wɛn aʊt, plʌnʒɪŋ əm ɪndə dɑɹknəs. ɪnstənli ɡɹeɪndəl flʌŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə tʃɛɹ soʊ əz nɑt tə bi wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd læst sin hɝ, ən ʃi ɔlsoʊ tʃænəld ivən əz ʃi muvd, wivɪŋ ə wɛb ə laɪt ðət hʌŋ tə wʌn saɪd, ə sfɪɹ ə pjʊɹ waɪt ðət kæs lʊɹəd ʃædoʊz əbaʊt ðə ɹum. ən ɹɪvil ðə pɛɹ klɪɹli. wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, ʃi tʃænəld əɡɛn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðə lɪɾəl ɹɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪɾ ɔl, əɹ ivən moʊst, bʌt ʃi wɑntəɾ ɛvɹi ædvæntɪdʒ ʃi kəd faɪnd. ətæk hɝ, wəd ðeɪ! ə nɛɾ ə kəmpʌlʃən taɪɾənd ɑn itʃ ə ðɛm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd twɪtʃ.

That was a lie, but a very believable one, so it came as a shock when Moghedien suddenly channeled and every lamp in the room went out, plunging them into darkness. Instantly Graendal flung herself from the chair so as not to be where they had last seen her, and she also channeled even as she moved, weaving a web of light that hung to one side, a sphere of pure white that cast lurid shadows about the room. And revealed the pair clearly. Without hesitation, she channeled again, drawing the full strength of the little ring. She did not need it all, or even most, but she wanted every advantage she could find. Attack her, would they! A net of Compulsion tightened on each of them before they could twitch.

ʃi hæd spʌn ðə nɛts stʃɹɔŋ, fəɹ æŋɡɝz seɪk, nɪɹli stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə də hɑɹm, ən ðə wɪmən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ ədɔɝɪŋli, aɪz waɪɾ ən maʊðz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən ɪn ædʒəleɪʃən, ɪntɑksəkeɪɾəd wɪð wɝʃəp. ðeɪ wɝ hɝz tə kəmænd, naʊ. ɪf ʃi toʊld əm tə kʌt ðɛɹ oʊn θɹoʊts, ðeɪ wʊd. sʌɾənli ɡɹeɪndəl ɹilaɪz ðət mɑɡiɾin wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. ðɪs mʌtʃ kəmpʌlʃən maɪɾ əv ʃɑkt əɹ ɪndə lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ. ðə sɝvəns baɪ ðə dɔɹ hæd nɑt muvd, ʌv kɔɹs.

She had spun the nets strong, for anger's sake, nearly strong enough to do harm, and the women stood staring at her adoringly, eyes wide and mouths hanging open in adulation, intoxicated with worship. They were hers to command, now. If she told them to cut their own throats, they would. Suddenly Graendal realized that Moghedien was no longer embracing the Source. This much Compulsion might have shocked her into letting go. The servants by the door had not moved, of course.

"naʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ə tʌtʃ bɹɛθləsli, "ju wɪl ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃənz." ʃi hæɾ ə nʌmbɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ u wɑz ðɪs mɔɹaɪɾɪn fɛloʊ, ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sətʃ ə mæn, ən wɛɹ hæd sɪndeɪn kʌm fɹʌm, bʌt wʌn pikt əɹ mɔɹ ðən ðə ɹɛst. "wʌt dɪd jə hoʊp tə ɡeɪn baɪ ðɪs, mɑɡiɾin? aɪ meɪ dɪsaɪd tə nɑt ðoʊz wɛbz ɑn ju. jə kən peɪ fəɹ jəɹ ɡeɪm baɪ sɝvɪŋ mi."

"Now," she said a touch breathlessly, "you will answer my questions." She had a number, including who was this Moridin fellow, if there was such a man, and where had Cyndane come from, but one piqued her more than the rest. "What did you hope to gain by this, Moghedien? I may decide to knot those webs on you. You can pay for your game by serving me."

"noʊ, pliz," mɑɡiɾin ɡɹoʊnd, ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz. ʃi æktʃəli  bɪɡæn tə wip! "ju wɪl kɪl əs ɔl! pliz, jə mʌst sɝv ðə nɛbli! ðəɾ ɪz wʌt wi keɪm fɔɹ. tə bɹɪŋ jə tə mɔɹaɪɾɪnz sɝvəs!" ðə sɪlvɝ-hɛɹd lɪɾəl wʊmənz feɪs wɑz ə ʃæɾoʊd mæsk ə tɛɹɝ ɪn ðə peɪl laɪt, hɝ bʊzəm hivɪŋ əz ʃi ɡʌlp bɹɛθ.

"No, please," Moghedien groaned, wringing her hands. She actually began to weep! "You will kill us all! Please, you must serve the Nae'blis! That is what we came for. To bring you to Moridin's service!" The silver-haired little woman's face was a shadowed mask of terror in the pale light, her bosom heaving as she gulped breath.

sʌɾənli ənizi, ɡɹeɪndəl oʊpən əɹ maʊð. ðɪs meɪd lɛs ən lɛs sɛns baɪ ðə moʊmənt. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ən ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs vænɪʃt. ðə wʌn paʊɝ vænɪʃt fɹəm hɝ, ən blæknəs swɑloʊd ðə ɹum əɡɛn. əbɹʌpli ðə keɪdʒ bɝdz bɹoʊk ɪndə ə fɹɛnzi ʌv tʃɪɹupɪŋ; ðɛɹ wɪŋz flʌɾɝd fɹæntəkəli əɡɛns ðə bæmbu bɑɹz.

Suddenly uneasy, Graendal opened her mouth. This made less and less sense by the moment. She opened her mouth, and the True Source vanished. The One Power vanished from her, and blackness swallowed the room again. Abruptly the caged birds broke into a frenzy of chirruping; their wings fluttered frantically against the bamboo bars.

bɪhaɪn hɝ, ə vɔɪs ɹæsp laɪk ɹɑk biɪŋ ɡɹaʊn tə dʌst. "ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd θɔt jə maɪt nɑt teɪk ðɛɹ wɝd, ɡɹeɪndəl. ðə taɪm wən jə kəd ɡoʊ jəɹ oʊn weɪ hæz pæst." ə bɔl ʌv . . . sʌmθɪŋ . . . əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ə dɛd blæk ɡloʊb, bʌɾ ə sɪlvɝ laɪt fɪl ðə ɹum. ðə mɪɹɝz dɪd nɑt ʃaɪn; ðeɪ sim tə dʌl ɪn ðət laɪt. ðə bɝdz wɛn stɪl, saɪlənt; sʌmhaʊ, ɡɹeɪndəl nu ðeɪ hæd fɹoʊzən ɪn tɛɹɝ.

Behind her, a voice rasped like rock being ground to dust. "The Great Lord thought you might not take their word, Graendal. The time when you could go your own way has passed." A ball of . . . something . . . appeared in the air, a dead black globe, but a silver light filled the room. The mirrors did not shine; they seemed to dull in that light. The birds went still, silent; somehow, Graendal knew they had frozen in terror.

ʃi ɡeɪpt ət ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, peɪl ən aɪləs ən kloʊðd ɪn blæk dipɝ ðən ðə bɔl, bʌt lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɛni ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. ɪt hæd tə bi ðə ɹizən ʃi kəd nɑt sɛns ðə sɔɹs, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl! ɪksɛpt. . . . wɛɹ hæd ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ sfɪɹ ə blæk laɪt kʌm fɹəm ɪf nɑt fɹəm ɪt? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ fɛl ðə seɪm fɪɹ ʌðɝz dɪɾ əɾ ə mɹdʒɹɑlz ɡeɪz, nɑt tə ðə seɪm dɪɡɹi, jɛɾ əɹ hænz ɹoʊz ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn, ən ʃi hæd tə snætʃ əm daʊn tə kip fɹəm kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ feɪs. ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd mɑɡiɾin ən sɪndeɪn, ʃi flɪntʃt. ðeɪ hæɾ ədɑptəd ðə seɪm poʊz əz əɹ sɝvəns, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ niz, hɛdz tə ðə flɔɹ təwɔɹd ðə mɹdʒɹɑl.

She gaped at the Myrddraal standing there, pale and eyeless and clothed in black deeper than the ball, but larger than any she had ever seen. It had to be the reason she could not sense the Source, but that was impossible! Except. . . . Where had that strange sphere of black light come from if not from it? She had never felt the same fear others did at a Myrddraal's gaze, not to the same degree, yet her hands rose on their own, and she had to snatch them down to keep from covering her face. Glancing toward Moghedien and Cyndane, she flinched. They had adopted the same pose as her servants, crouching on their knees, heads to the floor toward the Myrddraal.

ʃi hæd tə wɝk mɔɪstʃɝ ɪndə hɝ maʊθ. "ju ɑɹ ə mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd?" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi, bʌt wik. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ, ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd sɛndɪŋ ə mɛsədʒ baɪ mɹdʒɹɑl, ən jɛt. . . . mɑɡiɾin wɑz ə fɪzɪkəl kaʊɝd, bʌt stɪl wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ən ʃi ɡɹoʊvəld əz əsɪdwəsli əz ðə ɡɝl. ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə laɪt. ɡɹeɪndəl faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs wɝ nɑt kʌt soʊ loʊ. ɹɪdɪkjələs, ʌv kɔɹs; mɹdʒɹɑlz æpətaɪts fəɹ wɪmən wɝ wɛl noʊn, bʌt ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə. . . . hɝ aɪz dʒɹɪftəd tə mɑɡiɾin wʌns mɔɹ.

She had to work moisture into her mouth. "You are a messenger from the Great Lord?" Her voice was steady, but weak. She had never heard of such a thing, the Great Lord sending a message by Myrddraal, and yet. . . . Moghedien was a physical coward, but still one of the Chosen, and she groveled as assiduously as the girl. And there was the light. Graendal found herself wishing her dress were not cut so low.
