Ridiculous, of course; Myrddraal's appetites for women were well known, but she was one of the. . . . Her eyes drifted to Moghedien once more.

ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stʃɹoʊd baɪ hɝ sɪnjuəsli, simɪŋ nɑt tə peɪ hɝ ɛni hid. ɪts lɔŋ blæk kloʊk hʌŋ ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ɪts muvməns. eɪdʒɪnɝ hæd θɔt ðə kɹitʃɝz wɝ nɑt kwaɪɾ ɪn ðə wɝld ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls wɑz; "slaɪtli aʊɾ ə feɪz wɪð taɪm ən ɹiæləɾi," hi hæd kɔld ɪt, wʌtɛvɝ ðət mɛnt.

The Myrddraal strode by her sinuously, seeming not to pay her any heed. Its long black cloak hung undisturbed by its movements. Aginor had thought the creatures were not quite in the world in the same way everything else was; "slightly out of phase with time and reality," he had called it, whatever that meant.

"aɪ æm ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən." stɑpɪŋ baɪ hɝ sɝvəns, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl bɛn tə ɡɹɪp əm baɪ ðə bæks ə ðɛɹ nɛks, wʌn hæn tə itʃ. "wɛn aɪ spik, jə meɪ kənsɪɾɝ ðət jə hɪɹ ðə vɔɪs ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk." ðoʊz hænz taɪɾənd tə ðə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli laʊd saʊn ə kɹækɪŋ boʊn. ðə jʌŋ mæn spæzmd əz i daɪd, kɪkɪŋ aʊt; ðə jʌŋ wʊmən mɪɹli wɛn lɪmp. ðeɪ hæd bɪn tu ʌv əɹ pɹɪɾiəst. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm ðə kɔɹpsəz. "aɪ æm ɪz hæn ɪn ðɪs wɝld, ɡɹeɪndəl. wən jə stæn bɪfɔɹ mi, jə stæn bɪfɔɹ hɪm."

"I am Shaidar Haran." Stopping by her servants, the Myrddraal bent to grip them by the backs of their necks, one hand to each. "When I speak, you may consider that you hear the voice of the Great Lord of the Dark." Those hands tightened to the surprisingly loud sound of cracking bone. The young man spasmed as he died, kicking out; the young woman merely went limp. They had been two of her prettiest. The Myrddraal straightened from the corpses. "I am his hand in this world, Graendal. When you stand before me, you stand before him."

ɡɹeɪndəl kənsɪɾɝd kɛɹfəli, ɪf kwɪkli. ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd, ən ɪmoʊʃən ʃi wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ juz tə ɪnspaɪɹɪŋ ɪn ʌðɝz, bʌt ʃi nu haʊ tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ fɪɹ. waɪl ʃi hæd nɛvɝ kəmændəɾ ɑɹmiz əz səm ə ði ʌðɝz hæd, ʃi wɑz niðɝ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ tə hæzɝd nɔɹ ə kaʊɝd, jɛt ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə mɪɹ θɹɛt. mɑɡiɾin ən sɪndeɪn stɪl nɛlt wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz tə ðə mɑɹbəl flɔɹ, mɑɡiɾin æktʃəli  tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ vɪzəbli. ɡɹeɪndəl bɪliv ðɪs mɹdʒɹɑl. əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɑz teɪkɪŋ ə mɔɹ dɝɛk hæn ɪn ɪvɛns, əz ʃi hæd fɪɹd. ən ɪf i lɝn ə hɝ skimɪŋ wɪð sɑmaɪl. . . . ɪf i tʃoʊz tə teɪk ækʃən, ðət wɑz; bɛɾɪŋ ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ wɑz ə fulɪʃ weɪdʒɝ ət ðɪs pɔɪnt.

Graendal considered carefully, if quickly. She was afraid, an emotion she was far more used to inspiring in others, but she knew how to control her fear. While she had never commanded armies as some of the others had, she was neither a stranger to hazard nor a coward, yet this was more than a mere threat. Moghedien and Cyndane still knelt with their heads to the marble floor, Moghedien actually trembling visibly. Graendal believed this Myrddraal. Or whatever it truly was. The Great Lord was taking a more direct hand in events, as she had feared. And if he learned of her scheming with Sammael. . . . If he chose to take action, that was; betting that he did not know was a foolish wager at this point.

ʃi nɛl smuðli bɪfɔɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. "wʌt wəd juv mi du?" hɝ vɔɪs hæd ɹiɡeɪn ɪts stʃɹɛŋkθ. ə nɛsəsɛɹi flɛksəbɪləɾi wɑz nɑt kaʊɝɾəs; ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt bɛn fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd wɝ bɛnt. əɹ snæpt ɪn tu. "ʃʊɾ aɪ kɔl jə ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ, əɹ wəd jə pɹəfɝ ənʌðɝ taɪɾəl? aɪ wəd nɑt fil kʌmftəɹbəl ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ivən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz hæn əz aɪ wəd hɪm."

She knelt smoothly before the Myrddraal. "What would you have me do?" Her voice had regained its strength. A necessary flexibility was not cowardice; those who did not bend for the Great Lord were bent. Or snapped in two. "Should I call you Great Master, or would you prefer another title? I would not feel comfortable addressing even the Great Lord's hand as I would him."

ʃɑkɪŋli, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl læft. ɪt saʊndəd laɪk aɪs kɹʌmbəlɪŋ. mɹdʒɹɑl nɛvɝ læft. "ju ɑɹ bɹeɪvɝ ðən moʊst. ən waɪzɝ. ʃeɪaɪdɑɹ hæɹən wɪl də fəɹ ju. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ u aɪ æm. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə də nɑt lɛt bɹeɪvɝi oʊvɝkʌm jəɹ fɪɹ tu fɑɹ."

Shockingly, the Myrddraal laughed. It sounded like ice crumbling. Myrddraal never laughed. "You are braver than most. And wiser. Shaidar Haran will do for you. So long as you remember who I am. So long as you do not let bravery overcome your fear too far."

əz ɪɾ ɪʃuɾ ɪts kəmænz - ə vɪzət tə ðɪs mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑz fɝst, ɪt simd; ʃi wəd nid tə bi ɑn əɹ ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛns mɑɡiɾin, ən pɝhæps sɪndeɪn ɔlsoʊ, teɪkɪŋ ɹivɛnʒ fəɹ əɹ bɹif jus ə kəmpʌlʃən; ʃi daʊɾɪd ðə ɡɝl wɑz ɛni mɔɹ fɝɡɪvɪŋ ðən ðə spaɪɾɝ - ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kip tə hɝsɛlf ðə lɛɾɝ ʃi hæd sɛn tə ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi. nʌθɪŋ ʃi wɑz toʊld ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðəɾ əɹ ækʃənz wəd bi dɪsplisɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, ən ʃi stɪl hæd tə kənsɪɾɝ əɹ oʊn pəzɪʃən. mɔɹaɪɾɪn, huɛvɝ i wɑz, maɪt bi nɛbli tədeɪ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz təmɑɹoʊ.

As it issued its commands - a visit to this Moridin was first, it seemed; she would need to be on her guard against Moghedien, and perhaps Cyndane also, taking revenge for her brief use of Compulsion; she doubted the girl was any more forgiving than the Spider - she decided to keep to herself the letter she had sent to Rodel Ituralde. Nothing she was told indicated that her actions would be displeasing to the Great Lord, and she still had to consider her own position. Moridin, whoever he was, might be Nae'blis today, but there was always tomorrow.

bɹeɪsɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə ɹɑkɪŋ ʌv ɑɹɪlɪnz koʊtʃ, kædzueɪn muvd wʌn ə ðə lɛðɝ wɪndoʊ kɝɾənz fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə si aʊt. ə laɪt ɹeɪn fɛl ɑn kɛɹhin fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ fʊl ə blʌstɝɪŋ klaʊdz ən ɹʌf, swɝlɪŋ wɪnz. nɑɾ oʊnli ðə skaɪ wɑz fʊl ʌv wɪnd. haʊlɪŋ ɡʌsts ɹɑk ðə koʊtʃ mɔɹ ðən dɪɾ ɪts fɔɹwɝd moʊʃən. taɪni dʒɹɑpləts stʌŋ əɹ hænd, koʊld əz aɪs. ɪf ði ɛɹ kuld ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, ðəɹ wəd bi snoʊ. ʃi dʒɹu hɝ wʊlən kloʊk kloʊsɝ; ʃi hæd bɪn pliz tə faɪn ɪt, ʃʌv tə ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ sæɾəlbæɡz. ði ɛɹ wəd kul.

Bracing herself against the rocking of Arilyn's coach, Cadsuane moved one of the leather window curtains far enough to see out. A light rain fell on Cairhien from a gray sky full of blustering clouds and rough, swirling winds. Not only the sky was full of wind. Howling gusts rocked the coach more than did its forward motion. Tiny droplets stung her hand, cold as ice. If the air cooled a little more, there would be snow. She drew her woolen cloak closer; she had been pleased to find it, shoved to the bottom of her saddlebags. The air would cool.

ðə sɪɾiz stip sleɪt ɹufs ən stoʊn-peɪv stʃɹits ɡlɪsənd wɛtli, ən ðoʊ ðə ɹeɪn wɑz nɑt hɑɹd, fju wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə bɹeɪv ðə stʃɹɔŋ wɪnz. ə wʊmən ɡaɪɾɪŋ ən ɑks-kɑɹt wɪð tæps ʌv ə lɔŋ ɡoʊd muvd əz peɪʃənli əz əɹ ɑks, bʌt moʊs pipəl əfʊt klʌtʃt kloʊks taɪtli, hʊdz pʊl daʊn, ən stɛp kwɪkli əz ðə bɛɹɝz ʌv ə sɪdæn tʃɛɹ ɹʌʃt baɪ, ɪts stɪf kɑn flʌɾɝɪŋ. ʌðɝz bɪsaɪd ðə wʊmən ən əɹ ɑks sɔ noʊ ɹizən fəɹ heɪst, ðoʊ. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹiɾ ə taʊɝɪŋ ilmən stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ ɪn dɪsbɪlif waɪl ðə dʒɹɪzəl soʊk hɪm, soʊ əbzɔɹb ðəɾ ə dɛɹɪŋ kʌtpɝs slaɪst əweɪ hɪz bɛl paʊtʃ ən dɑɹɾɪd ɔf ənnoʊɾɪst baɪ hɪz vɪktəm. ə wʊmən huz ɪlæbɹətli kɝld, haɪ-paɪl hɛɹ mɑɹkt əɹ əz noʊbəl wɔkt əlɔŋ sloʊli, hɝ kloʊk flæpɪŋ waɪldli, ən ɪts lɔŋ hʊɾ əz wɛl. ðɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə fɝs taɪm ɛvɝ ðət ʃi hæɾ æktʃəli  wɔkt ɪn ðə stʃɹits, bʌt ʃi wɑz læfɪŋ əz ðə ɹeɪn slɪkt əɹ tʃiks. fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ ʌv ə pɝfumɝz ʃɑp, ðə ʃɑpkipɝ stɛɹɾ aʊt dɪskənsəlɑtli; ʃi wəd də lɪɾəl bɪznəs tədeɪ. moʊst ə ðə hɔkɝz hæd vænɪʃt fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən, bʌɾ ə hændfʊl stɪl hoʊpfəli kɹaɪd hɑt ti ən mit paɪz fɹəm bæɹoʊz bɪniθ meɪkʃɪft ɔnɪŋz. ðoʊ ɛniwʌn u bɑɾ ə mit paɪ ɪn ðə stʃɹit ðiz deɪz dɪzɝv ðə bɛlieɪk ʃi wəd ɡɛt.

The city's steep slate roofs and stone-paved streets glistened wetly, and though the rain was not hard, few were willing to brave the strong winds. A woman guiding an ox-cart with taps of a long goad moved as patiently as her ox, but most people afoot clutched cloaks tightly, hoods pulled down, and stepped quickly as the bearers of a sedan chair rushed by, its stiff con fluttering. Others beside the woman and her ox saw no reason for haste, though. In the middle of the street a towering Aielman stood gaping at the sky in disbelief while the drizzle soaked him, so absorbed that a daring cutpurse sliced away his belt pouch and darted off unnoticed by his victim. A woman whose elaborately curled, high-piled hair marked her as noble walked along slowly, her cloak flapping wildly, and its long hood as well. This might have been the first time ever that she had actually walked in the streets, but she was laughing as the rain slicked her cheeks. From the doorway of a perfumer's shop, the shopkeeper stared out disconsolately; she would do little business today. Most of the hawkers had vanished for the same reason, but a handful still hopefully cried hot tea and meat pies from barrows beneath makeshift awnings. Though anyone who bought a meat pie in the street these days deserved the bellyache she would get.

ə pɛɹ ə stɑɹvɪŋ dɑɡz ɹæn aʊt fɹəm ən æli, stɪf-lɛɡəɾ ən hækəlz ʌp, bɑɹkɪŋ ən snɑɹlɪŋ ət ðə koʊtʃ. kædzueɪn lɛt ðə kɝɾən fɔl. dɑɡz sim tə noʊ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl əz izəli əz kæts dɪd, bʌt dɑɡz əpɪɹd tə θɪŋk ðə wɪmən wɝ kæts, ɪf ənnətʃɝəli lɑɹdʒ wʌnz. ðə pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən siɾəd əkɹɔs fɹəm əɹ wɝ stɪl ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

A pair of starving dogs ran out from an alley, stiff-legged and hackles up, barking and snarling at the coach. Cadsuane let the curtain fall. Dogs seemed to know women who could channel as easily as cats did, but dogs appeared to think the women were cats, if unnaturally large ones. The pair of women seated across from her were still in conversation.

"fɝɡɪv mi," deɪdʒiən wɑz seɪɪŋ, "bʌt ðə lɑdʒɪk ɪz ɪnɪskeɪpəbəl." ʃi dʌkt əɹ hɛɾ əpɑlədʒɛɾɪkli, meɪkɪŋ ðə munstoʊn dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑn ə faɪn sɪlvɝ tʃeɪn fɹəm əɹ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ sweɪ əkɹɔs əɹ fɔɹhɛd. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz plʌk ðə waɪt slæʃɪz ɪn əɹ dɑɹk skɝts, ən ʃi spoʊk ɹæpədli, əz ðoʊ əfɹeɪɾ ə biɪŋ ɪntɝʌptɪd. "ɪf jə æksɛp ðət ðə lɪŋɡɝɪŋ hit wɑz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz wɝk, ðə tʃeɪnʒ mʌs bi baɪ səm ʌðɝ eɪdʒənsi. hi wəd nɑɾ əv ɹɪlɛntɪd. jə maɪt seɪ ðət hiz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɹiz əɹ dʒɹaʊn ðə wɝld ɪnstɛɾ ə beɪkɪŋ ɪt, bʌt waɪ? hæd ðə hit kəntɪnjud θɹu spɹɪŋ, ðə dɛd maɪt wɛl əv aʊtnʌmbɝd ðə lɪvɪŋ, noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ɪf snoʊ fɔlz ɪndə ðə sʌmɝ. ðɛɹfɔɹ, lɑdʒɪkli, səm ʌðɝ hæn ɪz ət wɝk." ðə plʌmp wʊmənz dɪfəɾəns wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ ət taɪmz, bʌɾ əz ɔlweɪz, kædzueɪn faʊn əɹ lɑdʒɪk ɪmpɛkəbəl. ʃi dʒʌst wɪʃt ʃi nu huz hæn ən tə wʌɾ ɛnd.

"Forgive me," Daigian was saying, "but the logic is inescapable." She ducked her head apologetically, making the moonstone dangling on a fine silver chain from her long black hair sway across her forehead. Her fingers plucked the white slashes in her dark skirts, and she spoke rapidly, as though afraid of being interrupted. "If you accept that the lingering heat was the Dark One's work, the change must be by some other agency. He would not have relented. You might say that he has decided to freeze or drown the world instead of baking it, but why? Had the heat continued through spring, the dead might well have outnumbered the living, no different than if snow falls into the summer. Therefore, logically, some other hand is at work." The plump woman's diffidence was trying at times, but as always, Cadsuane found her logic impeccable. She just wished she knew whose hand and to what end.

"pis!" kʌmaɪɹə mʌɾɝd. "aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ ən aʊns ə hɑɹd pɹuf ðən ə hʌnʒɹədweɪt ə jəɹ waɪɾ ədʒɑ lɑdʒɪk." ʃi wɑz bɹaʊn, hɝsɛlf, ðoʊ lɪɾəl ɡɪvən tə ðɛɹ juʒəwəl feɪlɪŋz. ə hænsəm wʊmən wɪð ʃɔɹtkʌt hɛɹ, ʃi wɑz hɑɹdhɛɾɪd ən pɹæktəkəl, ə kin əbzɝvɝ, ən nɛvɝ lɔs hɝsɛlf soʊ dipli ɪn θɔt ðət ʃi lɔst saɪɾ ə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn əɹ əz wɛl. noʊ sunɝ hæd kʌmaɪɹə spoʊkən ðən ʃi pæɾəd deɪdʒiənz ni wɪð ə ɡɹeɪsfəl hænd, ən ɡeɪv ə smaɪl ðət tʃeɪnʒd əɹ blu aɪz fɹəm ʃɑɹp tə wɔɹm. ʃaɪnɝənz wɝ ə pəlaɪt pipəl, baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, ən kʌmaɪɹə tʊk kɛɹ nɑt tə əfɛnd. baɪ æksəɾənt, ət list. "pʊt jəɹ maɪn tə wʌt wi kən də əbaʊt ðə sɪstɝz hɛl baɪ ði il. aɪ noʊ jəl ɹizən aʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɪf ɛniwʌn kæn."

"Peace!" Kumira muttered. "I would rather an ounce of hard proof than a hundredweight of your White Ajah logic." She was Brown, herself, though little given to their usual failings. A handsome woman with shortcut hair, she was hardheaded and practical, a keen observer, and never lost herself so deeply in thought that she lost sight of the world around her as well. No sooner had Kumira spoken than she patted Daigian's knee with a graceful hand, and gave a smile that changed her blue eyes from sharp to warm. Shienarans were a polite people, by and large, and Kumira took care not to offend. By accident, at least. "Put your mind to what we can do about the sisters held by the Aiel. I know you'll reason out something if anyone can."

kædzueɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "ðeɪ dɪzɝv wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz tə ðɛm." ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn əlaʊd nɪɹ ði il tɛns hɝsɛlf, nɔɹ hæɾ ɛni ʌv əɹ kəmpænjənz, bʌt səm ə ðə fulz u hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ hæd vɛntʃɝɾ aʊt tə ðə spɹɔlɪŋ ɛnkæmpmən ən kʌm bæk waɪt-feɪst ən tɔɹn bɪtwin aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ən sɪkɪŋ ʌp. nɔɹməli, ʃi ɔlsoʊ wʊɾə bɪn fjʊɹiəs oʊvɝ ði əfɹʌn tə ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪɡnəɾi, wʌtɛvɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz; nɑt naʊ. tə ətʃiv əɹ ɡoʊl, ʃi wʊɾə ɹʌn ði ɪntaɪɝ waɪt taʊɝ θɹu ðə stʃɹits neɪkəd. haʊ kəd ʃi kənsɝn hɝsɛlf wɪð ðə dɪskʌmfɝɾ ʌv wɪmən u maɪɾ əv ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ?

Cadsuane snorted. "They deserve whatever happens to them." She had not been allowed near the Aiel tents herself, nor had any of her companions, but some of the fools who had sworn fealty to the al'Thor boy had ventured out to the sprawling encampment and come back white-faced and torn between outrage and sicking up. Normally, she also would have been furious over the affront to Aes Sedai dignity, whatever the circumstances; not now. To achieve her goal, she would have run the entire White Tower through the streets naked. How could she concern herself with the discomfort of women who might have ruined everything?

kʌmaɪɹə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə pɹoʊtɛs dɪspaɪt noʊɪŋ əɹ filɪŋz, bʌt kædzueɪn wɛn ɑn, kɑm jɛt ɹɪlɛnlɪs. "pɝhæps ðəl wip ɪnʌf tə ətoʊn fəɹ ðə dɔɡz dɪnɝ ðeɪ meɪɾ ə mæɾɝz, bʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ ɪt. ðeɪ ɑɹ aʊɾ ʌv əɹ hænz, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪn maɪn, aɪ maɪt dʒʌst ɡɪv əm tə ði il. fɝɡɛt ðɛm, deɪdʒiən, ən pʊt ðət faɪn maɪn ə jʊɹz ɑn ðə tʃɹæk aɪ sɛt ju."

Kumira opened her mouth to protest despite knowing her feelings, but Cadsuane went on, calm yet relentless. "Perhaps they'll weep enough to atone for the dog's dinner they made of matters, but I doubt it. They are out of our hands, and if they were in mine, I might just give them to the Aiel. Forget them, Daigian, and put that fine mind of yours on the track I set you."

ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmənz peɪl tʃiks flʌʃt ɹɛɾ ət ðə kɑmpləmənt. θæŋk ðə laɪt ʃi wɑz nɑt ðɪs weɪ ɪksɛpt wɪð ʌðɝ sɪstɝz. kʌmaɪɹə sæt saɪlənli, vɛɹi smuð-feɪst, hɝ hænz ɪn əɹ læp. ʃi maɪt bi səbdud naʊ, bʌt lɪɾəl kəd səbdu kʌmaɪɹə fəɹ lɔŋ. ðeɪ wɝ ɪɡzækli ðə pɛɹ kædzueɪn wɑntəd wɪð əɹ tədeɪ.

The Cairhienin woman's pale cheeks flushed red at the compliment. Thank the Light she was not this way except with other sisters. Kumira sat silently, very smooth-faced, her hands in her lap. She might be subdued now, but little could subdue Kumira for long. They were exactly the pair Cadsuane wanted with her today.

ðə koʊtʃ tɪltəɾ əz ðə tim stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə lɔŋ ɹæmp liɾɪŋ tə ðə sʌn pæləs. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju," ʃi toʊl ði ʌðɝ tu fɝmli. "æn əv ə kɛɹ!"

The coach tilted as the team started up the long ramp leading to the Sun Palace. "Remember what I told you," she told the other two firmly. "And have a care!"

ðeɪ mɝmɝd ðət ðeɪ wʊd, əz wɛl ðeɪ maɪt, ən ʃi nɑɾəd. ɪf nid dɪmændəd, ʃi wəd juz əm boʊθ fəɹ mʌltʃ, ən ʌðɝz tu, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə luz iðɝ kəz ðeɪ ɡɹu kɛɹləs.

They murmured that they would, as well they might, and she nodded. If need demanded, she would use them both for mulch, and others too, but she did not intend to lose either because they grew careless.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɑðɝ əɹ dɪleɪ ɪn lɛɾɪŋ ðə koʊtʃ θɹu ðə pæləs ɡeɪts. ðə ɡɑɹdz ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɑɹɪlɪnz sɪdʒəl ɑn ðə dɔɹz, ən ðeɪ nu hu wəd bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ðət koʊtʃ hæd bɪn tə ðə pæləs ɔfən ɪnʌf ɪn ðə pæst wik. ðə moʊmən ðə hɔɹsəz hɔltəd, ən æŋkʃəs-aɪd fʊtmən ɪn ʌnədɔɹn blæk oʊpən ðə koʊtʃ dɔɹ, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ ə bɹɔd flæt pɛɹɑsɑl ə dɑɹk ɔɪl klɔθ. ɹeɪn dʒɹɪp fɹəm ði ɛdʒ ɑntu hɪz bɛɹ hɛd, bʌt ðɛn, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ɪz ʃɛltɝ.

There was no bother or delay in letting the coach through the Palace gates. The guards recognized Arilyn's sigil on the doors, and they knew who would be riding inside. That coach had been to the Palace often enough in the past week. The moment the horses halted, an anxious-eyed footman in unadorned black opened the coach door, holding out a broad flat parasol of dark oiled cloth. Rain dripped from the edge onto his bare head, but then, it was not intended for his shelter.

kwɪkli tʌtʃɪŋ ði ɔɹnəməns dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛd tə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðəɹ - ʃi hæd nɛvɝ lɔst wʌn, bʌt ðət wɑz kəz ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl ə ðɛm - kædzueɪn ɡæðɝd ðə hændəlz ə hɝ skwɛɹ wɪkɝ soʊɪŋ bæskət fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ siɾ ən stɛp daʊn. hæf ə dʌzən fʊtmən stʊd weɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə fɝst, pɛɹɑsəlz ət ðə ɹɛɾi. soʊ mɛni pæsənʒɝz wʊɾə kɹaʊɾəd ðə koʊtʃ bɪɑn kʌmfɝt, bʌt ðə fʊtmən wɝ nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bi kɑt ʃɔɹt, ən ði ɛkstʃɹə dɪd nɑt hɝi əweɪ əntɪl ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm.

Quickly touching the ornaments dangling from the bun atop her head to be sure they were all there - she had never lost one, but that was because she was careful of them - Cadsuane gathered the handles of her square wicker sewing basket from beneath her seat and stepped down. Half a dozen footmen stood waiting behind the first, parasols at the ready. So many passengers would have crowded the coach beyond comfort, but the footmen were not about to be caught short, and the extra did not hurry away until it was plain there were only the three of them.

ɑbviəsli ðə koʊtʃ hæd bɪn sin kʌmɪŋ. dɑɹk-ɡɑɹb sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən meɪɾ ə niɾ ɝeɪ ɑn ðə dip blu ən ɡoʊl taɪlz ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛntʃɹi hɔl wɪð ɪts skwɛɹ-vɔltəd silɪŋ faɪv spænz haɪ. ðeɪ lɛp fɔɹwɝd, teɪkɪŋ kloʊks, ɔfɝɪŋ smɔl, wɔɹm lɪnən taʊəlz ɪn keɪs ɛniwʌn niɾəd tə dʒɹaɪ feɪs əɹ hænz, pɹɑfɝɪŋ si foʊk pɔɹsələn ɡoʊbləts ə mʌld waɪn ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ə hɛɾi sɛn ə spaɪsəz. ə wɪntɝ dʒɹɪŋk, jɛt ðə sʌɾən dʒɹɑp ɪn tɛmpɹətʃɝ meɪɾ ɪt suɾəbəl. ən æftɝ ɔl, ɪt wɑz wɪntɝ. faɪnəli.

Obviously the coach had been seen coming. Dark-garbed serving men and women made a neat array on the deep blue and gold tiles of the great entry hall with its square-vaulted ceiling five spans high. They leaped forward, taking cloaks, offering small, warm linen towels in case anyone needed to dry face or hands, proffering Sea Folk porcelain goblets of mulled wine that gave off a heady scent of spices. A winter drink, yet the sudden drop in temperature made it suitable. And after all, it was winter. Finally.

θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ stʊd weɪɾɪŋ tə wʌn saɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə mæsɪv skwɛɹ kɑləmz ə dɑɹk mɑɹbəl, ɪn fɹʌn ə tɔl, peɪl fɹizɪz dɪpɪktɪŋ bæɾəlz noʊ daʊɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə kɛɹhin, bʌt kædzueɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə wɪmən fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. wʌn ə ðə jʌŋ sɝvɪŋ mɛn hæɾ ə smɔl ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl fɪɡjɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ə hɪz koʊt, wʌt pipəl wɝ kɔlɪŋ ə dʒɹæɡən. kɔɹɡeɪd, ðə ɡɹeɪv-feɪst, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən u ɔɹɾɝd ðə sɝvəns ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs, wɔɹ noʊ ɔɹnəmən seɪv fəɹ ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹɪŋ ə hɛvi kiz əɾ əɹ weɪst. nɔɹ dɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls əv ɛni dɛkɝeɪʃən ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊðz, ən dɪspaɪt ðə jʌŋ mænz əpɛɹən ɪnθuziæzəm, ɪt wɑz kɔɹɡeɪd, ðə hoʊldɝ ə ðə kiz, hu wəd sɛt ðə muɾ əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns. stɪl, ʃi hæɾ əlaʊd ðə jʌŋ fɛloʊ hɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi; ə pɔɪn tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. kædzueɪn spoʊk tə hɝ kwaɪətli, æskɪŋ æftɝ ə ɹum wɛɹ ʃi maɪt wɝk əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ʌndɪstɝbd, ən ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt blɪŋk ət ðə ɹɪkwɛst. bʌt ðɛn, daʊtləs ʃi hæd hɝd stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, sɝvɪŋ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs.

Three Aes Sedai stood waiting to one side among the massive square columns of dark marble, in front of tall, pale friezes depicting battles no doubt important to Cairhien, but Cadsuane ignored the women for the time being. One of the young serving men had a small red-and-gold figure embroidered on the left breast of his coat, what people were calling a Dragon. Corgaide, the grave-faced, gray-haired woman who ordered the servants in the Sun Palace, wore no ornament save for the large ring of heavy keys at her waist. Nor did anyone else have any decoration on their clothes, and despite the young man's apparent enthusiasm, it was Corgaide, the Holder of the Keys, who would set the mood among the servants. Still, she had allowed the young fellow his embroidery; a point to remember. Cadsuane spoke to her quietly, asking after a room where she might work her embroidery hoop undisturbed, and the woman did not blink at the request. But then, doubtless she had heard stranger, serving in this place.

əz ðə sɝvəns wɪð ðə kloʊks ən tʃɹeɪz baʊɾ ən kɝtsid ðɛmsɛlvz ɔf, kædzueɪn faɪnəli tɝn tə ðə θɹi sɪstɝz əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ kʌmaɪɹə ən deɪdʒiən. kɔɹɡeɪd ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌt ʃi steɪd wɛl bæk, ɡɪvɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹaɪvəsi. "aɪ hɑɹdli ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn jə stʃɹoʊlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ət jəɹ iz," kædzueɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɔt ði il wɝk ðɛɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz hɑɹd."

As the servants with the cloaks and trays bowed and curtsied themselves off, Cadsuane finally turned to the three sisters among the columns. They were all looking at her, ignoring Kumira and Daigian. Corgaide remained, but she stayed well back, giving the Aes Sedai privacy. "I hardly expected to find you strolling about at your ease," Cadsuane said. "I thought the Aiel worked their apprentices hard."

feɪlʒɹɪn bɛɹli ɹiæktəd, mɪɹli ə slaɪt dʒɝk ə hɝ hɛd ðət sɔfli ɹæɾəld ðə kʌlɝd bidz ɪn əɹ θɪn bɹeɪdz, bʌt mɛɹænə kʌlɝd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, ən əɹ hænz klɛntʃt ɪn əɹ skɝts. ɪvɛns hæd ʃeɪkən mɛɹænə soʊ dipli ðət kædzueɪn wɑz ənʃʊɹ ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ ɹɪkʌvɝ. bɛɹə, ʌv kɔɹs, wɑz vɛɹi nɪɹli ənflæpəbəl.

Faeldrin barely reacted, merely a slight jerk of her head that softly rattled the colored beads in her thin braids, but Merana colored with embarrassment, and her hands clenched in her skirts. Events had shaken Merana so deeply that Cadsuane was unsure she would ever recover. Bera, of course, was very nearly unflappable.

"moʊst ʌv əs wɝ ɡɪvən ə fɹideɪ kəz ə ðə ɹeɪn," bɛɹə ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. ə stɝɾi wʊmən ɪn pleɪn wʊl - faɪn ən wɛl-kʌt, bʌt dɪsaɪɾədli pleɪn - jə maɪɾ əv θɔɾ əɹ mɔɹ ət hoʊm ɑn ə fɑɹm ðən ɪn ə pæləs. jə maɪɾ ɪf jə wɝ ə ful; bɛɹə hæɾ ə kin maɪnd, ə stʃɹɔŋ wɪl, ən kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt bɪliv ʃi ɛvɝ meɪd ðə seɪm mɪsteɪk twaɪs. laɪk moʊst sɪstɝz, ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ɡɑɾən oʊvɝ miɾɪŋ kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn, əlaɪv ən ɪn ðə flɛʃ, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɑ ɹul hɝ. æftɝ oʊnli ðə slaɪɾəst ə dip bɹɛθs, ʃi wɛn ɑn. "aɪ kænɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə kip kʌmɪŋ bæk, kædzueɪn. klɪɹli, jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ʌs, bʌɾ ənlɛs jə tɛl əs wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, wi kænɑt hɛlp ju. wi noʊ wʌt jə dɪd fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən" - ʃi stʌmbəld ə lɪɾəl oʊvɝ ðə taɪɾəl; ðeɪ stɪl wɝ nɑt kwaɪt ʃʊɹ wʌt tə kɔl ðə bɔɪ - "bʌɾ ɪts ɑbviəs jə keɪm tə kɛɹhin kəz ə hɪm, ən əntɪl jə tɛl əs waɪ ən wʌt jə ɪntɛnd, jə mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðət jəl faɪnd noʊ eɪd fɹəm ʌs." feɪlʒɹɪn, ənʌðɝ ɡɹin, ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət bɛɹəz boʊl toʊn, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾɪŋ əɡɹimən bɪfɔɹ bɛɹə fɪnɪʃt.

"Most of us were given a freeday because of the rain," Bera replied calmly. A sturdy woman in plain wool - fine and well-cut, but decidedly plain - you might have thought her more at home on a farm than in a palace. You might if you were a fool; Bera had a keen mind, a strong will, and Cadsuane did not believe she ever made the same mistake twice. Like most sisters, she had not entirely gotten over meeting Cadsuane Melaidhrin, alive and in the flesh, yet she did not let awe rule her. After only the slightest of deep breaths, she went on. "I cannot understand why you keep coming back, Cadsuane. Clearly, you want something from us, but unless you tell us what it is, we cannot help you. We know what you did for the Lord Dragon" - she stumbled a little over the title; they still were not quite sure what to call the boy - "but it's obvious you came to Cairhien because of him, and until you tell us why and what you intend, you must understand that you'll find no aid from us." Faeldrin, another Green, gave a start at Bera's bold tone, but she was nodding agreement before Bera finished.

"ju mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðɪs, tu," mɛɹænə æɾəd, hɝ sɝɛnəɾi ɹiɡeɪnd. "ɪf wi dɪsaɪd wi mʌst əpoʊz ju, wi wɪl." bɛɹəz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt feɪlʒɹɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd bɹifli. pɝhæps ʃi dɪsəɡɹid, ən pɝhæps ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪvil tu mʌtʃ.

"You must understand this, too," Merana added, her serenity regained. "If we decide we must oppose you, we will." Bera's face did not change, but Faeldrin's mouth tightened briefly. Perhaps she disagreed, and perhaps she did not want to reveal too much.

kædzueɪn feɪvɝɾ əm wɪð ə θɪn smaɪl. tɛl əm waɪ ən wʌt? ɪf ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd? soʊ fɑɹ ðeɪ hæd mænədʒ tə stʌf ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə jʌŋ ælθɹz sæɾəlbæɡz taɪd hæn ən fʊt, ivən bɛɹə. smɔl ɹɛkəməndeɪʃən fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ əm dɪsaɪd soʊ mʌtʃ əz wʌt tə wɛɹ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ! "aɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm tə si ju," ʃi sɛd. "ðoʊ aɪ səpoʊz kʌmaɪɹə ən deɪdʒiən wəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ ə vɪzət, sɪns juv ə fɹideɪ. jəl ɪkskjuz mi."

Cadsuane favored them with a thin smile. Tell them why and what? If they decided? So far they had managed to stuff themselves into young al'Thor's saddlebags tied hand and foot, even Bera. Small recommendation for letting them decide so much as what to wear in the morning! "I did not come to see you," she said. "Though I suppose Kumira and Daigian would enjoy a visit, since you have a freeday. You will excuse me."

moʊʃənɪŋ kɔɹɡeɪd tə liɾ ɑn, ʃi fɑloʊd ðə wʊmən əkɹɔs ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl. ʃi oʊnli ɡlæns bæk wʌns. bɛɹə ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp kʌmaɪɹə ən deɪdʒiən ən wɝ hʌsəlɪŋ əm əweɪ, bʌt hɑɹdli laɪk wɛlkəm ɡɛsts. mɔɹ laɪk hɝɾɪd ɡis. kædzueɪn smaɪld. moʊst sɪstɝz kənsɪɾɝd deɪdʒiən lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ə waɪldɝ ən tʃɹiɾəd əɹ lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ə sɝvənt. ɪn ðət kʌmpəni, kʌmaɪɹə hɑɹdli stʊd mʌtʃ haɪɝ. ðə moʊst səspɪʃəs kəd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ tə tʃɹaɪ tə kənvɪns ɛniwʌn ʌv ɛniθɪŋ. soʊ deɪdʒiən wəd pɔɹ ðə ti ən sɪt kwaɪətli ɪksɛpt wən ədʒɹɛst - ən əplaɪ hɝ ɛksələn maɪn tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi hɝd. kʌmaɪɹə wəd lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp deɪdʒiən spik bɪfɔɹ əɹ - ən sɔɹɾ ən faɪl əweɪ ɛvɹi wɝd, ɛvɹi dʒɛstʃɝ ən ɡɹɪmɑs. bɛɹə ən ðə ɹɛst wəd kip ðɛɹ oʊðz tə ðə bɔɪ, ʌv kɔɹs - ðət wɛnt wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ - bʌt haʊ əsɪdwəsli wɑz ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən. ivən mɛɹænə maɪt bi ənwɪlɪŋ tə ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ bɪɑn bɛɹ oʊbiɾiəns. ðət wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf, jɛɾ ɪt lɛf kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɹum fəɹ əm tə mənuvɝ. əɹ bi mənuvɝd.

Motioning Corgaide to lead on, she followed the woman across the entry hall. She only glanced back once. Bera and the others had already gathered up Kumira and Daigian and were hustling them away, but hardly like welcome guests. More like herded geese. Cadsuane smiled. Most sisters considered Daigian little better than a wilder and treated her little better than a servant. In that company, Kumira hardly stood much higher. The most suspicious could not think they were there to try to convince anyone of anything. So Daigian would pour the tea and sit quietly except when addressed - and apply her excellent mind to everything she heard. Kumira would let everyone except Daigian speak before her - and sort and file away every word, every gesture and grimace. Bera and the rest would keep their oaths to the boy, of course - that went without saying - but how assiduously was another question. Even Merana might be unwilling to go too far beyond bare obedience. That was bad enough, yet it left considerable room for them to maneuver. Or be maneuvered.

dɑɹk-lɪvɹid sɝvəns hɝiɪŋ ət ðɛɹ tæsks əlɔŋ ðə bɹɔd, tæpəstʃɹi-hʌŋ hɔlweɪz dɑɹɾɪd əsaɪd fəɹ kædzueɪn ən kɔɹɡeɪd, ən ðə tu ʌv əm pɹəɡɹɛs tə ə flɝi ʌv dip baʊz ən kɝtsiz meɪɾ oʊvɝ bæskəts ən tʃɹeɪz ən ɑɹmloʊdz ə taʊəlz. fɹəm ðə weɪ aɪz wɑtʃt kɔɹɡeɪd, kædzueɪn səspɛktəd ðə dɛfɝəns wɑz əz mʌtʃ fəɹ ðə hoʊldɝ ə ðə kiz əz fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ wɝ ə fju il əbaʊt, tu, hjudʒ mɛn laɪk koʊld-aɪd laɪənz ən wɪmən laɪk koʊldɝ-aɪd lɛpɝdz. səm ə ðoʊz ɡeɪzəz fɑloʊɾ əɹ aɪsɪli ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ɑn ðə snoʊ θɹɛɾənd baɪ ðə ɹeɪn aʊtsaɪd, bʌɾ ʌðɝ il nɑɾəd tə hɝ ɡɹeɪvli, ən hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wʌn ə ðə fɪɹs-aɪd wɪmən wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə smaɪl. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ kleɪm tə bi ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ seɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ kɑɹəkɑɹn, bʌt teɪlz bɪkeɪm twɪstəɾ ɪn ɹitɛlɪŋ, ən ðə bɪlif ɡɹæntəɾ əɹ mɔɹ ɹɪspɛk ðən ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ, ən sɝɾənli mɔɹ fɹiɾəm ə muvmən ɝaʊn ðə pæləs. ʃi wʌndɝd haʊ ðeɪ wəd fil ɪf ðeɪ nu ðət hæd ʃi hæd ðə bɔɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ɹaɪt ðɛn, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn hɑɹd-pɹɛs tə stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm blɪstɝɪŋ ɪz haɪd fəɹ hɪm! bɛɹli mɔɹ ðən ə wik sɪns i nɪɹli, ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf kɪld, ən nɑɾ oʊnli hæɾ i mænədʒ tə ɪluɾ əɹ kəmplitli, hi hæd meɪɾ əɹ tæsk ivən mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt, ɪf hæf wʌt ʃi hɝd wɑz tʃɹu. ə pɪɾi hi hæd nɑt bɪn ɹeɪzd ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. bʌt ðɛn, ðət maɪɾ əv lɛd tə ɪts oʊn kətæstʃɹəfi.

Dark-liveried servants hurrying at their tasks along the broad, tapestry-hung hallways darted aside for Cadsuane and Corgaide, and the two of them progressed to a flurry of deep bows and curtsies made over baskets and trays and armloads of towels. From the way eyes watched Corgaide, Cadsuane suspected the deference was as much for the Holder of the Keys as for an Aes Sedai. There were a few Aiel about, too, huge men like cold-eyed lions and women like colder-eyed leopards. Some of those gazes followed her icily enough to bring on the snow threatened by the rain outside, but other Aiel nodded to her gravely, and here and there one of the fierce-eyed women went so far as to smile. She had never claimed to be responsible for saving their Car'a'carn, but tales became twisted in retelling, and the belief granted her more respect than any other sister, and certainly more freedom of movement around the Palace. She wondered how they would feel if they knew that had she had the boy in front of her right then, she would have been hard-pressed to stop herself from blistering his hide for him! Barely more than a week since he nearly, got himself killed, and not only had he managed to elude her completely, he had made her task even more difficult, if half what she heard was true. A pity he had not been raised in Far Madding. But then, that might have led to its own catastrophe.

ðə ɹum kɔɹɡeɪd tʊk əɹ tə wɑz kʌmfɝɾəbli wɔɹm, wɪð faɪɝz bleɪzɪŋ ɪn mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪsəz əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ən læmps lɪt, mɪɹɝd fleɪmz ɪn ɡlæs taʊɝz ðət tʃeɪs ðə deɪz ɡlum. pleɪnli kɔɹɡeɪd hæd sɛn ɔɹɾɝz əhɛd tə pɹipɛɹ waɪl ʃi wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl. ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən əpɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz ðeɪ, wɪð boʊθ hɑt ti ən spaɪst waɪn ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ, ən smɔl keɪks ɡleɪzd wɪð hʌni.

The room Corgaide took her to was comfortably warm, with fires blazing in marble fireplaces at either end of the chamber and lamps lit, mirrored flames in glass towers that chased the day's gloom. Plainly Corgaide had sent orders ahead to prepare while she was waiting in the entry hall. A serving woman appeared almost as soon as they, with both hot tea and spiced wine on a tray, and small cakes glazed with honey.

"wɪl ðəɹ bi ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" kɔɹɡeɪɾ æskt əz kædzueɪn sɛɾ əɹ soʊɪŋ bæskət bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ə teɪbəl wɪð ɛdʒ ən lɛɡz θɪkli ɡɪldɪd. ɹɪdʒɪdli kɑɹvd, tu, əz wɑz ðə waɪd kɔɹnəs, ɔlsoʊ kʌvɝd wɪð ɡɪlt. kædzueɪn ɔlweɪz fɛlt ʃi wɑz ɪn ə ɡoʊldən fɪʃ wiɹ wən ʃi vɪzəɾəd kɛɹhin. dɪspaɪt ðə laɪɾ ən wɔɹmθ ɪnsaɪd, ɹeɪn dʒɹɪpɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə tɔl nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊz ən ðə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ aʊtsaɪd haɪɾənd ðə sɛnseɪʃən.

"Will there be anything else, Aes Sedai?" Corgaide asked as Cadsuane set her sewing basket beside the tray on a table with edge and legs thickly gilded. Rigidly carved, too, as was the wide cornice, also covered with gilt. Cadsuane always felt she was in a golden fish weir when she visited Cairhien. Despite the light and warmth inside, rain dripping outside the tall narrow windows and the gray sky outside heightened the sensation.

"ðə ti wɪl də naɪsli," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf jə wɪl, tɛl ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni ðəɾ aɪ wɑnə si hɝ. tɛl hɝ, wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ."

"The tea will do nicely," she said. "If you will, tell Alanna Mosvani that I want to see her. Tell her, without delay."

kɔɹɡeɪdz kiz dʒɪŋɡəld əz ʃi kɝtsid, mɝmɝɪŋ ɹɪspɛkfəli ðət ʃi wəd faɪnd "ɑlɑnə ɛɛs sədaɪ" hɝsɛlf. hɝ ɡɹeɪv ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ ɔltɝɾ əz ʃi lɛft. vɛɹi laɪkli ʃi wɑz ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ sʌɾəltiz. kædzueɪn pɹəfɝd tə bi dɝɛkt, wən pɑsəbəl. ʃi hæd tʃɹɪpt ʌp ɛni nʌmbɝ ə klɛvɝ pipəl u hæd nɑt bɪlivd ʃi mɛn ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi sɛd.

Corgaide's keys jingled as she curtsied, murmuring respectfully that she would find "Alanna Aes Sedai" herself. Her grave expression never altered as she left. Very likely she was examining the request for subtleties. Cadsuane preferred to be direct, when possible. She had tripped up any number of clever people who had not believed she meant exactly what she said.

oʊpənɪŋ ðə lɪɾ ə hɝ soʊɪŋ bæskət, ʃi tʊk aʊɾ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup wɪð ə lɛs ðən hæf-dʌn pis ʌv wɝk ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪt. ðə bæskət hæd pɑkəts woʊvən ɪnsaɪd tə hoʊld aɪɾəmz ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð soʊɪŋ. hɝ aɪvɝi hæn mɪɹɝ ən hɛɹbɹʌʃ ən koʊm, ə pɛn keɪs ən taɪtli stɑpɝɾ ɪŋk bɑɾəl, ə nʌmbɝ ə θɪŋz ðət ʃi hæd faʊn jusfəl tə hæv ət hæn oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm ðət wʊɾə sɝpɹaɪzd ɛniwʌn wɪð nɝv ɪnʌf tə sɝtʃ ðə bæskət. nɑt ðət ʃi ɔfən lɛft ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt. sɛɾɪŋ ðə pɑlɪʃt sɪlvɝ θɹɛd bɑks kɛɹfəli ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ʃi səlɛktəd ðə sknz ʃi niɾəd ən sæt wɪð əɹ bæk tə ðə dɔɹ. ðə meɪdʒɝ ɪmədʒ ɑn əɹ pis ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi wɑz fɪnɪʃt, ə mænz hæn klʌtʃɪŋ ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. kɹæks ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wɛðɝ ðə hænd wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪt təɡɛðɝ əɹ kɹʌʃ ɪt. ʃi nu wʌt ʃi ɪntɛndəd, bʌt taɪm wəd tɛl wʌt wɑz tʃɹuθ.

Opening the lid of her sewing basket, she took out her embroidery hoop with a less than half-done piece of work wrapped around it. The basket had pockets woven inside to hold items that had nothing to do with sewing. Her ivory hand mirror and hairbrush and comb, a pen case and tightly stoppered ink bottle, a number of things that she had found useful to have at hand over the years, including some that would have surprised anyone with nerve enough to search the basket. Not that she often left it out of her sight. Setting the polished silver thread box carefully on the table, she selected the skeins she needed and sat with her back to the door. The major image on her piece of embroidery was finished, a man's hand clutching the ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai. Cracks ran across the black-and-white disc, and there was no telling whether the hand was trying to hold it together or crush it. She knew what she intended, but time would tell what was truth.

θɹɛɾɪŋ ə niɾəl, ʃi sɛt tə wɝk ɑn wʌn ə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪmədʒəz, ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd ɹoʊz. ɹoʊzɪz ən stɑɹ-bleɪz ən sʌnbɝst ɔltɝneɪɾəd wɪð deɪziz ən hɑɹts-blʌʃ ən snoʊkæp, ɔl sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ bænz ə stɑɹk nɛɾəlz ən lɔŋ-θɔɹn bɹaɪɹz. ɪt wəd bi ə dɪstɝbɪŋ pis, wən kəmpliɾəd.

Threading a needle, she set to work on one of the surrounding images, a bright red rose. Roses and star-blaze and sunburst alternated with daisies and hearts-blush and snowcap, all separated by bands of stark nettles and long-thorned briars. It would be a disturbing piece, when completed.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd fɪnɪʃt hæf ə pɛɾəl ɑn ðə ɹoʊz, ə flæʃ ə moʊʃən ɹəflɛktəɾ ɑn ðə flæt lɪɾ ə ðə θɹɛd bɑks kɑɾ əɹ aɪ. ɪt hæd bɪn kɛɹfəli pleɪs tə ɹəflɛk ðə dɔɹweɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz əɹ hɛd fɹəm ðə hup. ɑlɑnə stʊd ðəɹ ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ bæk. kædzueɪn kəntɪnjud ðə sloʊ wɝk ə hɝ niɾəl, bʌt ʃi wɑtʃt ðət ɹəflɛkʃən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. twaɪs ɑlɑnə hæf tɝn əz ɪf tə ɡoʊ, ðən faɪnəli dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, vɪzəbli stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf.

Before she had finished half a petal on the rose, a flash of motion reflected on the flat lid of the thread box caught her eye. It had been carefully placed to reflect the doorway. She did not raise her head from the hoop. Alanna stood there glaring at her back. Cadsuane continued the slow work of her needle, but she watched that reflection from the corner of her eye. Twice Alanna half turned as if to go, then finally drew herself up, visibly steeling herself.

"kʌm ɪn, ɑlɑnə." stɪl nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hɛd, kædzueɪn pɔɪntəd tə ə spɑɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. "stæn ðɛɹ." ʃi smaɪld ɹaɪli əz ɑlɑnə dʒʌmpt. ðəɹ wɝ ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə biɪŋ ə lɛdʒənd; pipəl sɛldəm noʊɾəst ði ɑbviəs wən dilɪŋ wɪð ə lɛdʒənd.

"Come in, Alanna." Still not raising her head, Cadsuane pointed to a spot in front of her. "Stand there." She smiled wryly as Alanna jumped. There were advantages to being a legend; people seldom noticed the obvious when dealing with a legend.

ɑlɑnə stɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum ɪn ə swɪʃ ə sɪlk skɝts ən tʊk ðə pleɪs kædzueɪn hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sʌlki twɪs tə hɝ maʊθ. "waɪ dʒju pɝsɪst ɪn bædʒɝɪŋ mi?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə ɛni mɔɹ ðən aɪ hæv. ən ɪf aɪ kʊd, aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ wʊd! hi bɪlɔŋz tə - !" ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli, baɪɾɪŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp, bʌt ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv fɪnɪʃt. ði ælθɹ bɔɪ bɪlɔŋ tə hɝ; hɝ wɔɹɾɝ. ʃi hæd ðə ɡɔl tə θɪŋk ðæt!

Alanna stalked into the room in a swish of silk skirts and took the place Cadsuane had indicated, but there was a sulky twist to her mouth. "Why do you persist in badgering me?" she demanded. "I cannot tell you any more than I have. And if I could, I don't know that I would! He belongs to - !" She cut off abruptly, biting her lower lip, but she might as well have finished. The al'Thor boy belonged to her; her Warder. She had the gall to think that!

"aɪ hæv kɛp jəɹ kɹaɪm tə maɪsɛlf," kædzueɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, "bʌɾ oʊnli kəz aɪ sɔ noʊ ɹizən tə kɑmpləkeɪt mæɾɝz." lɪftɪŋ əɹ aɪz tə ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs sɑft. "ɪf jə θɪŋk ðət minz aɪ woʊn kɔɹ jə laɪk ə kæbədʒ, θɪŋk əɡɛn."

"I have kept your crime to myself," Cadsuane said quietly, "but only because I saw no reason to complicate matters." Lifting her eyes to the other woman, she kept her voice soft. "If you think that means I won't core you like a cabbage, think again."

ɑlɑnə stɪfənd. ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn ɝaʊn hɝ.

Alanna stiffened. The light of saidar suddenly shone around her.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ tə bi tʃɹuli fulɪʃ." kædzueɪn smaɪld, ə koʊl smaɪl. ʃi meɪd noʊ muv tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs hɝsɛlf. wʌn ə hɝ dæŋɡəlɪŋ hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns, ɪntɝtwaɪnd ɡoʊldən kɹɛsəns, wɑz kul ɑn əɹ tɛmpəl. "ju kip ə hoʊl haɪɾ ət pɹɛzənt, bʌt maɪ sʌfɝæns ɪz nɑɾ ɪnfənət. ɪn fækt, ɪt dæŋɡəlz baɪ ə θɹɛd."

"If you wish to be truly foolish." Cadsuane smiled, a cold smile. She made no move to embrace the Source herself. One of her dangling hair ornaments, intertwined golden crescents, was cool on her temple. "You keep a whole hide at present, but my sufferance is not infinite. In fact, it dangles by a thread."

ɑlɑnə stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð hɝsɛlf, ʌnkɑnʃəsli smuðɪŋ blu sɪlk. əbɹʌpli ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ wɪŋkt aʊt, ən ʃi tɝn əɹ hɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm kædzueɪn soʊ swɪfli ðəɾ əɹ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ swʌŋ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛni mɔɹ tə tɛl." ðə sʌlən wɝdz ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ə hɝ bɹɛθəli. "hi wɑz ɪnʒɝd, ən ðən nɑt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ə sɪstɝ hil hɪm. ðə wunz noʊ wʌn kəd hil ɑɹ stɪl ðɛɹ. hi lips əbaʊt, tʃɹævlɪŋ, bʌt hiz stɪl ɪn ðə saʊθ. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ɪljən, aɪ θɪŋk, bʌɾ ət ðɪs dɪstəns, hi kəd bi ɪn tiɹ fəɹ ɔl aɪ noʊ. hiz fʊl ə ɹeɪdʒ, ən peɪn, ən səspɪʃən. ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni mɔɹ, kædzueɪn. ðəɹ ɪzənt!"

Alanna struggled with herself, unconsciously smoothing blue silk. Abruptly the glow of the Power winked out, and she turned her head away from Cadsuane so swiftly that her long black hair swung. "I don't know any more to tell." The sullen words rushed out of her breathily. "He was injured, and then not, but I don't think a sister Healed him. The wounds no one could Heal are still there. He leaps about, Traveling, but he's still in the south. Somewhere in Illian, I think, but at this distance, he could be in Tear for all I know. He's full of rage, and pain, and suspicion. There isn't any more, Cadsuane. There isn't!"

kɛɹfəl ə ðə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝz hit, kædzueɪn pɔɹɾ ə kʌp ə ti, tɛstɪŋ ðə θɪn ɡɹin pɔɹsələn kʌp fəɹ wɔɹmθ. əz maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn sɪlvɝ, ðə ti hæd kul kwɪkli. tʃænəlɪŋ bɹifli, ʃi hiɾəd ɪɾ əɡɛn. ðə dɑɹk ti teɪstəd tu mʌtʃ ə mɪnt; kɛɹhinɪn juz mɪn ɪntaɪɝli tu fɹili ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ ə kʌp tə ɑlɑnə. tʃɹævlɪŋ. haʊ kəd ðə bɔɪ hæv ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd wʌt hæd bɪn lɔs tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ? "ju wɪl kip mi fʊli ɪnfɔɹmd, haʊɛvɝ, woʊn ju, ɑlɑnə." ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən. "lʊk ət mi, wʊmən! ɪf jə dʒɹim ə hɪm, aɪ wɑn ɛvɹi dɪteɪl!"

Careful of the silver pitcher's heat, Cadsuane poured a cup of tea, testing the thin green porcelain cup for warmth. As might have been expected in silver, the tea had cooled quickly. Channeling briefly, she heated it again. The dark tea tasted too much of mint; Cairhienin used mint entirely too freely in her opinion. She did not offer a cup to Alanna. Traveling. How could the boy have rediscovered what had been lost to the White Tower since the Breaking? "You will keep me fully informed, however, won't you, Alanna." That was not a question. "Look at me, woman! If you dream of him, I want every detail!"

ənʃt tɪɹz ɡlɪsən ɪn ɑlɑnəz aɪz. "ɪn maɪ pleɪs, jə wʊɾə dʌn ðə seɪm!"

Unshed tears glistened in Alanna's eyes. "In my place, you would have done the same!"

kædzueɪn skaʊld oʊvɝ ðə kʌp ət hɝ. ʃi maɪt hæv. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dɪfɝəns bɪtwin wʌɾ ɑlɑnə hæd dʌn ən ə mæn fɔɹsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ə wʊmən, bʌt, ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ʃi maɪt hæv, hæd ʃi bɪlivd ɪt wəd hɛlp əɹ ɹitʃ əɹ ɡoʊl. naʊ, ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kənsɪɾɝd ivən meɪkɪŋ ɑlɑnə pæs ðə bɑn tə hɝ. ɑlɑnə hæd pɹuv haʊ jusləs ðət wɑz ɪn kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ hɪm.

Cadsuane scowled over the cup at her. She might have. There was no difference between what Alanna had done and a man forcing himself on a woman, but, the Light help her, she might have, had she believed it would help her reach her goal. Now, she no longer considered even making Alanna pass the bond to her. Alanna had proved how useless that was in controlling him.

"du nɑt kip mi weɪɾɪŋ, ɑlɑnə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ən aɪsi toʊn. ʃi hæd noʊ sɪmpəθi fəɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ɑlɑnə wɑz ənʌðɝ ɪn ə laɪn ə sɪstɝz, fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn tə ɪleɪɾə, hu hæd bʌŋɡəld ən wɝsənd wʌt ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn mɛndɪŋ. waɪl ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd bɪn ɔf tʃeɪsɪŋ fɝs lɑɡən əblɝ ən ðən mæzɹim teɪm. wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt suð əɹ mud.

"Do not keep me waiting, Alanna," she said in an icy tone. She had no sympathy for the other woman. Alanna was another in a line of sisters, from Moiraine to Elaida, who had bungled and worsened what they should have been mending. While she herself had been off chasing first Logain Ablar and then Mazrim Taim. Which did not soothe her mood.

"aɪ wɪl kip jə fʊli ɪnfɔɹmd," ɑlɑnə saɪd, paʊɾɪŋ laɪk ə ɡɝl. kædzueɪn ɪtʃt tə slæp hɝ. ɑlɑnə hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl oʊvɝ twɛnti jɪɹz; ʃi ʃʊɾə ɡɹoʊn ʌp mɔɹ ðən ðɪs. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wɑz ɝæfɛlɪn. ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, fju ɡɝlz ə twɛnti sʌlkt ən paʊɾɪd əz mʌtʃ əz ən ɝæfɛlɪn kəɾ ɑn əɹ eɪdʒ dɛθbɛd.

"I will keep you fully informed," Alanna sighed, pouting like a girl. Cadsuane itched to slap her. Alanna had worn the shawl over twenty years; she should have grown up more than this. Of course, she was Arafellin. In Far Madding, few girls of twenty sulked and pouted as much as an Arafellin could on her aged deathbed.

əbɹʌpli, ɑlɑnəz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn əlɑɹm, ən kædzueɪn sɔ ənʌðɝ feɪs ɹəflɛktəɾ ɪn ðə lɪɾ ə hɝ θɹɛd bɑks. sɛɾɪŋ ðə kʌp bæk ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ ən əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ɑn ðə teɪbəl, kædzueɪn stʊɾ ən tɝn tə ðə dɔɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑt hɝi, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt dæli əɹ pleɪ ɡeɪmz əz ʃi hæd wɪð ɑlɑnə, iðɝ.

Abruptly, Alanna's eyes widened in alarm, and Cadsuane saw another face reflected in the lid of her thread box. Setting the cup back on the tray and her embroidery hoop on the table, Cadsuane stood and turned to the door. She did not hurry, but she did not dally or play games as she had with Alanna, either.

"ɑɹ jə dʌn wɪð hɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" sɔɹɪliə æskt, stɛpɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum. ðə lɛðɝi, waɪt-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn spoʊk tə kædzueɪn, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɑlɑnə. aɪvɝi ən ɡoʊl klɪk sɔfli əɾ əɹ ɹɪsts əz ʃi plæntəd hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps, ən əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl slɪd tə hɝ ɛlboʊz.

"Are you done with her, Aes Sedai?" Sorilea asked, stepping into the room. The leathery, white-haired Wise One spoke to Cadsuane, but her eyes remained on Alanna. Ivory and gold clicked softly at her wrists as she planted hands on her hips, and her dark shawl slid to her elbows.

wən kædzueɪn sɛd ðət ʃi wɑz ɪndid dʌn, sɔɹɪliə dʒɛstʃɝd kɝtli tə ɑlɑnə, hu stɔk fɹəm ðə ɹum. flaʊns maɪɾ əv bɪn ə bɛɾɝ wɝd, wɪð sʌlən ɪɹɪteɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. sɔɹɪliə fɹaʊn æftɝ hɝ. kædzueɪn hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝd ðə wʊmən bɪfɔɹ, ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ɪnkaʊntɝz ðeɪ hæd bɪn, ɪf bɹif. ʃi hæd nɑt mɛt mɛni pipəl ʃi kənsɪɾɝd fɔɹməɾəbəl, bʌt sɔɹɪliə wɑz wʌn. pɝhæps ivən ə mætʃ fəɹ hɝsɛlf, ɪn səm weɪz. ʃi ɔlsoʊ səspɛktəd ðə wʊmən wɑz əz oʊld əz ʃi wɑz, meɪbi oʊldɝ, ən ðæt, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪnd.

When Cadsuane said that she was indeed done, Sorilea gestured curtly to Alanna, who stalked from the room. Flounced might have been a better word, with sullen irritation on her face. Sorilea frowned after her. Cadsuane had encountered the woman before, and interesting encounters they had been, if brief. She had not met many people she considered formidable, but Sorilea was one. Perhaps even a match for herself, in some ways. She also suspected the woman was as old as she was, maybe older, and that, she had never expected to find.

noʊ sunɝ hæɾ ɑlɑnə vænɪʃt ðən kaɪɹunə əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, kɪkɪŋ ɡɹeɪ sɪlk skɝts ɪn əɹ hɝi ən piɹɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔl ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ɑlɑnə hæd ɡɔn. ən kæɹiɪŋ ən ɪntʃɹəkətli wɝkt ɡoʊldən tʃɹeɪ ðət hɛld ən ivən mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət ɡoʊldən pɪtʃɝ wɪð ə haɪ nɛk, ænd, ɪŋkɔŋɹuəsli, tu smɔl, waɪt-ɡleɪz pɑɾɝi kʌps. "waɪ ɪz ɑlɑnə ɹʌnɪŋ?" ʃi sɛd. "aɪ wʊɾə bɪn fæstɝ, sɔɹɪliə, bʌt - " ʃi sɔ kædzueɪn ðɛn, ən əɹ tʃiks wɛn ðə dipəs pɑsəbəl kɹɪmzən. ɪmbɛɹəsmən lʊkt kwaɪɾ ɑɾ ɑn ðə stætʃuɛsk wʊmən.

No sooner had Alanna vanished than Kiruna appeared in the doorway, kicking gray silk skirts in her hurry and peering down the hall in the direction Alanna had gone. And carrying an intricately worked golden tray that held an even more elaborate golden pitcher with a high neck, and, incongruously, two small, white-glazed pottery cups. "Why is Alanna running?" she said. "I would have been faster, Sorilea, but - " She saw Cadsuane then, and her cheeks went the deepest possible crimson. Embarrassment looked quite odd on the statuesque woman.

"pʊt ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ɡɝl," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, "ænd ɡoʊ tə tʃeɪlɪn. ʃɪl bi weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɪv jə jəɹ lɛsənz."

"Put the tray on the table, girl," Sorilea said, "and go to Chaelin. She will be waiting to give you your lessons."

stɪfli, kaɪɹunə sɛɾ əɹ bɝɾən daʊn, əvɔɪɾɪŋ kædzueɪnz aɪz. əz ʃi tɝn tə ɡoʊ, sɔɹɪliə kɑɾ əɹ tʃɪn ɪn sɪnjui fɪŋɡɝz. "ju hæv bɪɡʌn tə meɪk ə tʃɹu ɛfɝt, ɡɝl," ðə waɪz wʌn toʊld əɹ fɝmli. "ɪf jə kəntɪnju, jəl də vɛɹi wɛl. vɛɹi wɛl. naʊ, ɡoʊ. tʃeɪlɪn ɪz nɑɾ əz peɪʃən əz aɪ."

Stiffly, Kiruna set her burden down, avoiding Cadsuane's eyes. As she turned to go, Sorilea caught her chin in sinewy fingers. "You have begun to make a true effort, girl," the Wise One told her firmly. "If you continue, you will do very well. Very well. Now, go. Chaelin is not as patient as I."

sɔɹɪliə weɪv təwɔɹd ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, bʌt kaɪɹunə stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. ɪf kædzueɪn hæd hæd tə meɪk ə weɪdʒɝ, ʃi wʊɾə kɔl kaɪɹunə plizd ət ðə pɹeɪz ən sɝpɹaɪzd ət biɪŋ plizd. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ən kaɪɹunə ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən hɝid fɹəm ðə ɹum. ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ʃoʊ.

Sorilea waved toward the corridor, but Kiruna stood staring at her for a long moment, a strange expression on her face. If Cadsuane had had to make a wager, she would have called Kiruna pleased at the praise and surprised at being pleased. The white-haired woman opened her mouth, and Kiruna gave herself a shake and hurried from the room. A remarkable show.

"du jə ɹɪli θɪŋk ʃɪl lɝn jəɹ weɪz ʌv wivɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ?" kædzueɪn æskt, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɪnkɹədulɪɾi. kaɪɹunə ən ði ʌðɝz hæd toʊld əɹ ə ðiz lɛsənz, bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə waɪz wʌnz' wivz wɝ vɛɹi dɪfɹən fɹəm ðoʊz tɔɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə fɝst weɪ jə lɝn ðə wiv fəɹ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ θɪŋ ɪmpɹɪntɪɾ ɪtsɛlf ɑn ju; lɝnɪŋ ə sɛkənd wɑz ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl, ən ivən wən jə kəd lɝn, ðə sɛkənd-lɝnd wiv ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ wɝk nɪɹli əz wɛl. ðət wɑz wʌn ɹizən səm sɪstɝz dɪd nɑt wɛlkəm waɪldɝz tə ðə taʊɝ əɾ ɛni eɪdʒ; tu mʌtʃ maɪɾ əv bɪn lɝn ɔlɹɛɾi, ən kəd nɑt bi ənlɝnd.

"Do you really think she will learn your ways of weaving saidar?" Cadsuane asked, hiding her incredulity. Kiruna and the others had told her of these lessons, but many of the Wise Ones' weaves were very different from those taught in the White Tower. The first way you learned the weave for a particular thing imprinted itself on you; learning a second was all but impossible, and even when you could learn, the second-learned weave almost never worked nearly as well. That was one reason some sisters did not welcome wilders to the Tower at any age; too much might have been learned already, and could not be unlearned.

sɔɹɪliə ʃɹʌɡd. "pɝhæps. lɝnɪŋ ə sɛkənd weɪ ɪz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ ɔl ðə hænd-weɪvɪŋ jə ɛɛs sədaɪ du. ðə meɪn θɪŋ kaɪɹunə nækɪmən mʌs lɝn ɪz ðət ʃi oʊnz əɹ pɹaɪd; ɪt dʌz nɑɾ oʊn hɝ. ʃɪl bi ə vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ wʊmən wʌns ʃi lɝnz ðæt." pʊlɪŋ ə tʃɛɹ ɝaʊn tə feɪs ðə wʌn kædzueɪn hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɪn, ʃi aɪɾ ɪt daʊtfəli, ðən sæt daʊn. ʃi əpɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊst əz stɪf ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl əz kaɪɹunə hæd, bʌt ʃi moʊʃən ɔθɔɹəteɪɾɪvli fəɹ kædzueɪn tə sɪt, ə stʃɹɔŋ-wɪld wʊmən juz tə kəmænd.

Sorilea shrugged. "Perhaps. Learning a second way is hard enough without all the hand-waving you Aes Sedai do. The main thing Kiruna Nachiman must learn is that she owns her pride; it does not own her. She will be a very strong woman once she learns that." Pulling a chair around to face the one Cadsuane had been sitting in, she eyed it doubtfully, then sat down. She appeared almost as stiff and uncomfortable as Kiruna had, but she motioned authoritatively for Cadsuane to sit, a strong-willed woman used to command.

kædzueɪn swɑloʊɾ ə ɹufəl tʃʌkəl əz ʃi tʊk əɹ tʃɛɹ. ɪt wɑz wɛl tə bi ɹimaɪndəd ðæt, waɪldɝz əɹ nɑt, ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ fɑɹ fɹəm ɪɡnɝən sævədʒəz. ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ wəd noʊ ðə dɪfəkəltiz. əz fəɹ hænd-weɪvɪŋ. . . . fju hæd tʃænəld wɛɹ ʃi kəd si, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ðət ðeɪ kɹieɪɾəd səm wivz wɪθaʊt ðə dʒɛstʃɝz ðət sɪstɝz juzd. ðə hæn muvməns wɝ nɑt tʃɹuli pɑɹɾ ə ðə wiv, bʌɾ ɪn ə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ, kəz ðeɪ hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ə lɝnɪŋ ðə wiv. pɝhæps, wʌns, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ hu kʊd, seɪ, hɝl ə bɔl ə faɪɝ wɪθaʊt səm sɔɹɾ ə θɹoʊɪŋ moʊʃən, bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, ðeɪ wɝ lɔŋ dɛd, ən ðɛɹ titʃɪŋz wɪð ðɛm. tədeɪ, səm θɪŋz dʒʌs kəd nɑt bi dʌn wɪθaʊt ði əpɹoʊpɹiət dʒɛstʃɝz. ðəɹ wɝ sɪstɝz u kleɪm ðeɪ kəd tɛl u hæd tɔɾ ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ baɪ wɪtʃ moʊʃənz ʃi juz fəɹ wɪtʃ wivz.

Cadsuane swallowed a rueful chuckle as she took her chair. It was well to be reminded that, wilders or not, the Wise Ones were far from ignorant savages. Of course they would know the difficulties. As for hand-waving. . . . Few had channeled where she could see, but she had noticed that they created some weaves without the gestures that sisters used. The hand movements were not truly part of the weave, but in a way they were, because they had been part of learning the weave. Perhaps, once, there had been Aes Sedai who could, say, hurl a ball of fire without some sort of throwing motion, but if so, they were long dead, and their teachings with them. Today, some things just could not be done without the appropriate gestures. There were sisters who claimed they could tell who had taught another sister by which motions she used for which weaves.

"titʃɪŋ ɛni ʌv əɹ nu əpɹɛntəsɪz ɛniθɪŋ əz bɪn dɪfəkəlt ət bɛst," sɔɹɪliə wɛn ɑn. "aɪ də nɑt spik tə əfɛnd, bʌt jə ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɪv oʊθ, ɪt simz, ən ɪmiɾiətli tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ə weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt. ɑlɑnə mɑsvɑni ɪz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dɪfəkəlt." sʌɾənli hɝ klɪɹ ɡɹin aɪz wɝ vɛɹi ʃɑɹp ɑn kædzueɪnz feɪs. "haʊ kən wi pʌnɪʃ əɹ wɪlfəl feɪlɪŋz ɪf ɪt minz hɑɹmɪŋ ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn?"

"Teaching any of our new apprentices anything has been difficult at best," Sorilea went on. "I do not speak to offend, but you Aes Sedai give oath, it seems, and immediately try to find a way around it. Alanna Mosvani is particularly difficult." Suddenly her clear green eyes were very sharp on Cadsuane's face. "How can we punish her willful failings if it means harming the Car'a'carn?"

kædzueɪn foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp. mæskɪŋ sɝpɹaɪz wɑz nɑɾ izi. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ðə sikɹəɾ ʌv ɑlɑnəz kɹaɪm. bʌt waɪ hæd ðə wʊmən lɛɾ əɹ noʊ ðət ʃi nu? pɝhæps wʌn ɹɛvəleɪʃən kɔl fəɹ ənʌðɝ. "ðə bɑn dʌz nɑt wɝk ɪn ðət fæʃən," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf jə kɪl hɝ, hɪl daɪ, ðən əɹ sun æftɝ. ʃɔɹɾ ə ðæt, hɪl bi əwɛɹ ʌv wʌt hæpənz tə hɝ, bʌt hɪl nɑt ɹɪli fil ɪt. əz fɑɹ əweɪ əz hiz naʊ, hɪl oʊnli bi veɪɡli əwɛɹ, ət ðæt."

Cadsuane folded her hands in her lap. Masking surprise was not easy. So much for the secret of Alanna's crime. But why had the woman let her know that she knew? Perhaps one revelation called for another. "The bond does not work in that fashion," she said. "If you kill her, he will die, then or soon after. Short of that, he will be aware of what happens to her, but he will not really feel it. As far away as he is now, he will only be vaguely aware, at that."

sɔɹɪliə nɑɾəd sloʊli. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃt ðə ɡoʊldən tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ðən keɪm əweɪ. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz əz hɑɹd tə ɹiɾ əz ðə feɪs ʌv ə stætʃu, bʌt kædzueɪn səspɛktəd ðəɾ ɑlɑnə wəd faɪn ən ənplɛzən sɝpɹaɪz ðə nɛks taɪm ʃi lɛɾ əɹ tɛmpɝ flɛɹ, əɹ θɹu wʌn ə hɝ ɝæfɛlɪn sʌlks. ðət wɑz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðoʊ. oʊnli ðə bɔɪ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Sorilea nodded slowly. Her fingers touched the golden tray on the table, then came away. Her expression was as hard to read as the face of a statue, but Cadsuane suspected that Alanna would find an unpleasant surprise the next time she let her temper flare, or threw one of her Arafellin sulks. That was unimportant, though. Only the boy was important.

"moʊs mɛn wɪl teɪk wʌɾ ɪz ɔfɝd, ɪf ɪt simz ətʃɹæktɪv ən plɛzənt," sɔɹɪliə sɛd. "wʌns, wi θɔɾ ə ɹænd ælθɹ soʊ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɪts tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə pæθ wi wɔk. naʊ, hi sʌspɛks wʌtɛvɝ ɪz ɔfɝd fɹili. naʊ, ɪf aɪ wɑntəɾ ɪm tə æksɛp sʌmθɪŋ, aɪ wəd pɹitɛn aɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪm tə hæv ɪt. ɪf aɪ wɑntəd tə steɪ kloʊs tə hɪm, aɪ wəd pɹitɛn ɪndɪfɝəns tə wɛðɝ aɪ ɛvɝ sɔ hɪm əɡɛn." wʌns mɔɹ, ðoʊz aɪz foʊkəst ɑn kædzueɪn, ɡɹin ɔɡɝz. nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si wʌt leɪ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd. ðə wʊmən nu. sʌm, ət list. ɪnʌf, əɹ tu mʌtʃ.

"Most men will take what is offered, if it seems attractive and pleasant," Sorilea said. "Once, we thought of Rand al'Thor so. Unfortunately, it is too late to change the path we walk. Now, he suspects whatever is offered freely. Now, if I wanted him to accept something, I would pretend I did not want him to have it. If I wanted to stay close to him, I would pretend indifference to whether I ever saw him again." Once more, those eyes focused on Cadsuane, green augers. Not trying to see what lay inside her head. The woman knew. Some, at least. Enough, or too much.

stɪl, kædzueɪn fɛlt ə ɹaɪzɪŋ θɹɪl ə pɑsəbɪləɾi. ɪf ʃi hæd hæɾ ɛni daʊts ðət sɔɹɪliə wɑntəd tə fil əɹ aʊt, ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn. ən jə dɪd nɑt fil aʊt sʌmwʌn ɪn ðɪs mænɝ ənlɛs jə hoʊp fəɹ səm əɡɹimənt. "du jə bɪliv ə mæn mʌs bi hɑɹd?" ʃi æskt. ʃi wɑz teɪkɪŋ ə tʃæns. "ɔɹ stʃɹɔŋ?" baɪ hɝ toʊn, ʃi lɛf noʊ daʊt ʃi sɔ ə dɪfɝəns.

Still, Cadsuane felt a rising thrill of possibility. If she had had any doubts that Sorilea wanted to feel her out, they were gone. And you did not feel out someone in this manner unless you hoped for some agreement. "Do you believe a man must be hard?" she asked. She was taking a chance. "Or strong?" By her tone, she left no doubt she saw a difference.

əɡɛn sɔɹɪliə tʌtʃt ðə tʃɹeɪ; ðə smɔləst ə smaɪlz maɪɾ əv kwɝkt əɹ lɪps fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. əɹ nɑt. "moʊs mɛn si ðə tu əz wʌn ən ðə seɪm, kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn. stʃɹɔŋ ɛndʒjʊɹz; hɑɹd ʃæɾɝz."

Again Sorilea touched the tray; the smallest of smiles might have quirked her lips for an instant. Or not. "Most men see the two as one and the same, Cadsuane Melaidhrin. Strong endures; hard shatters."

kædzueɪn dʒɹu bɹɛθ. ə tʃæns ʃi wʊɾə skaʊɝɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls fəɹ teɪkɪŋ. bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls, ən səmtaɪmz tʃænsəz hæd tə bi teɪkən. "ðə bɔɪ kənfjuzɪz ðɛm," ʃi sɛd. "hi nidz tə bi stʃɹɔŋ, ən meɪks hɪmsɛlf hɑɹɾɝ. tu hɑɹd, ɔlɹɛɾi, ən hɪl nɑt stɑp əntɪl hiz stɑpt. hiz fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə læf ɪksɛpt ɪn bɪɾɝnəs; ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ tɪɹz lɛft ɪn hɪm. ənlɛs i faɪnz læftɝ ən tɪɹz əɡɛn, ðə wɝl feɪsəz dɪzæstɝ. hi mʌs lɝn ðəɾ ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz flɛʃ. ɪf i ɡoʊz tə tɑɹmən ɡdən əz i ɪz, ivən ɪz vɪktɝi meɪ bi əz dɑɹk əz ɪz dɪfit."

Cadsuane drew breath. A chance she would have scoured anyone else for taking. But she was not anyone else, and sometimes chances had to be taken. "The boy confuses them," she said. "He needs to be strong, and makes himself harder. Too hard, already, and he will not stop until he is stopped. He has forgotten how to laugh except in bitterness; there are no tears left in him. Unless he finds laughter and tears again, the world faces disaster. He must learn that even the Dragon Reborn is flesh. If he goes to Tarmon Gai'don as he is, even his victory may be as dark as his defeat."

sɔɹɪliə lɪsən ɪntɛnli, ən kɛp saɪlən ivən æftɝ kædzueɪn fɪnɪʃt. ðoʊz ɡɹin aɪz stʌɾid hɝ. "jɔɹ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən jəɹ læs bæɾəl ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪn əɹ pɹɑfəsiz," sɔɹɪliə sɛɾ ət læst. "wi hæv tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɹænd ælθɹ noʊ hɪz blʌd, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ i siz əs əz oʊnli ənʌðɝ spɪɹ. ɪf wʌn spɪɹ bɹeɪks ɪn jəɹ hænd, jə də nɑt pɔz tə mɔɹn bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ʌp ənʌðɝ. pɝhæps jə ən aɪ eɪm ət tɑɹɡəts nɑt tu fɑɹ əpɑɹt."

Sorilea listened intently, and kept silent even after Cadsuane finished. Those green eyes studied her. "Your Dragon Reborn and your Last Battle are not in our prophecies," Sorilea said at last. "We have tried to make Rand al'Thor know his blood, but I fear he sees us as only another spear. If one spear breaks in your hand, you do not pause to mourn before taking up another. Perhaps you and I aim at targets not too far apart."

"pɝhæps wi du," kædzueɪn sɛd kɔʃəsli. tɑɹɡəts ivən ə hæn əpɑɹt maɪt bi nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əlaɪk.

"Perhaps we do," Cadsuane said cautiously. Targets even a hand apart might be not at all alike.

əbɹʌpli, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd ðə lɛðɝ-feɪst wʊmən. ʃi wɑz wik ɪnʌf tə meɪk deɪdʒiən lʊk ət lis mɑɾɝətli stʃɹɔŋ. bʌt ðɛn, sɔɹɪliəz stʃɹɛŋkθ dɪd nɑt laɪ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə θɪŋ jə meɪ faɪn jusfəl," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ kænɑt meɪk ɪt wɝk, bʌɾ aɪ kən wiv ðə floʊz tə ʃoʊ ju." ʃi dɪd dʒʌs ðæt, leɪɪŋ fibəl sknz ðət fɛl ɪndə pleɪs ən mɛltəd, tu pʊɹ tə də wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɪntɛndəd fɔɹ. "ɪɾ ɪz kɔl tʃɹævlɪŋ," sɔɹɪliə sɛd.

Abruptly, the glow of saidar surrounded the leather-faced woman. She was weak enough to make Daigian look at least moderately strong. But then, Sorilea's strength did not lie in the Power. "There is a thing you may find useful," she said. "I cannot make it work, but I can weave the flows to show you." She did just that, laying feeble skeins that fell into place and melted, too poor to do what they were intended for. "It is called Traveling," Sorilea said.

ðɪs taɪm, kædzueɪnz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt. ɑlɑnə ən kaɪɹunə ən ðə ɹɛs dɪnaɪd titʃɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz haʊ tə lɪŋk, əɹ ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝ skɪlz ðeɪ sʌɾənli sim tə hæv, ən kædzueɪn hæɾ əsum ði il hæd mænədʒ tə ɹɪŋ əm aʊɾ ə ðə sɪstɝz hɛld ɪn ðə tɛns. bʌt ðɪs wɑz. . . .

This time, Cadsuane's jaw dropped. Alanna and Kiruna and the rest denied teaching the Wise Ones how to link, or a number of other skills they suddenly seemed to have, and Cadsuane had assumed the Aiel had managed to wring them out of the sisters held in the tents. But this was. . . .

ɪmpɑsəbəl, ʃi wəɾ əv sɛd, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv sɔɹɪliə wɑz laɪɪŋ. ʃi kəd hɑɹdli weɪt tə tʃɹaɪ ðə wiv hɝsɛlf. nɑt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə mʌtʃ jus ɪmiɾiətli. ivən ɪf ʃi nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ðə ɹɛtʃɪd bɔɪ wɑz, ʃi hæd tə meɪk ɪm kʌm tə hɝ. sɔɹɪliə wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðæt. "ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt ɡɪft," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ hæv nʌθɪŋ aɪ kən ɡɪv jə tə kəmpɛɹ."

Impossible, she would have said, yet she did not believe Sorilea was lying. She could hardly wait to try the weave herself. Not that it was of much use immediately. Even if she knew exactly where the wretched boy was, she had to make him come to her. Sorilea was right about that. "A very great gift," she said slowly. "I have nothing I can give you to compare."

ðɪs taɪm, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ə ðə bɹif smaɪl ðət flæʃt əkɹɔs sɔɹɪliəz lɪps. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət kædzueɪn wɑz ɪn əɹ dɛt. teɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə hɛvi ɡoʊldən pɪtʃɝ wɪð boʊθ hænz, ʃi kɛɹfəli fɪl ðə smɔl waɪt kʌps. wɪð pleɪn wɔɾɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt spɪl ə dʒɹɑp.

This time, there was no doubt of the brief smile that flashed across Sorilea's lips. She knew very well that Cadsuane was in her debt. Taking up the heavy golden pitcher with both hands, she carefully filled the small white cups. With plain water. She did not spill a drop.

"aɪ ɔfɝ jə wɔɾɝ oʊθ," ʃi sɛd sɔləmli, pɪkɪŋ ʌp wʌn ə ðə kʌps. "baɪ ðɪs, wəɹ baʊn əz wʌn, tə titʃ ɹænd ælθɹ læftɝ ən tɪɹz." ʃi sɪpt, ən kædzueɪn ɪməteɪɾɪd hɝ.

"I offer you water oath," she said solemnly, picking up one of the cups. "By this, we are bound as one, to teach Rand al'Thor laughter and tears." She sipped, and Cadsuane imitated her.

"wi ɑɹ baʊn əz wʌn." ən ɪf ðɛɹ tɑɹɡəts tɝn aʊt nɑt tə bi ðə seɪm əɾ ɔl? ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝɛstəmeɪt sɔɹɪliə əz ælaɪ əɹ əpoʊnənt, bʌt kædzueɪn nu wɪtʃ tɑɹɡət hæd tə bi stʃɹʌk, əɾ ɛni kɑst.

"We are bound as one." And if their targets turned out not to be the same at all? She did not underestimate Sorilea as ally or opponent, but Cadsuane knew which target had to be struck, at any cost.


tʃæptɝ θɝtin


CHAPTER 13

floʊɾɪŋ laɪk snoʊ


Floating Like Snow

ðə nɔɹðɝn hɝaɪzən wɑz pɝpəl wɪð ðə fɪɹs ɹeɪn ðət hæd hæmɝd ði ist ʌv ɪljən θɹu ðə naɪt. oʊvɝhɛd, ə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ ʌv dɑɹk bɔɪlɪŋ klaʊdz θɹɛɾənd, ən stʃɹɔŋ wɪnz flʌŋ kloʊks əbaʊt, meɪd bænɝz snæp ən kɹæk laɪk wɪps ɑn ðə kɹɛst ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, ðə waɪt dʒɹæɡən bænɝ ən ðə kɹɪmzən bænɝ ə laɪt, ən ðə bɹaɪt stændɝdz ə noʊbɪləɾi fɹəm ɪljən ən kɛɹhin ən tɛɹ. ðə noʊbəlz kɛp tə ðɛɹ oʊn kaɪnd, θɹi waɪdli speɪs nɑts əwɑʃ ɪn ɡɪlt ən sɪlvɝ-pleɪɾəd stil, sɪlks ən vɛlvəts ən leɪsəz, bʌɾ ɪn kɑmən ðeɪ lʊkt ɝaʊn ənizəli. ivən ðə bɛst-tʃɹeɪn ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tɔs hɛdz ən stæmp hʊvz ɑn ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊnd. ðə wɪnd wɑz koʊld, ən koʊldɝ simɪŋ fəɹ ðə hiɾ ɪt hæd ɹipleɪst soʊ əbɹʌpli, dʒʌst əz ðə ɹeɪn hæd bɪn ə ʃɑk æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ wɪθaʊt. fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ neɪʃən, ðeɪ hæd pɹeɪd fəɹ ðə beɪkɪŋ dʒɹaʊt tə bɹeɪk, bʌt nʌn nu wʌt tə meɪk ʌv ʌnɹilɛntɪŋ stɔɹmz ɪn ænsɝ tə ðɛɹ pɹɛɹz. səm ɡlænst ət ɹænd wən ðeɪ θɔɾ i wəd nɑt noʊɾəs. pɝhæps wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i hæɾ ænsɝɾ əm soʊ. ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪm læf sɔfli, bɪɾɝli.

The northern horizon was purple with the fierce rain that had hammered the east of Illian through the night. Overhead, a morning sky of dark boiling clouds threatened, and strong winds flung cloaks about, made banners snap and crack like whips on the crest of the ridge, the white Dragon Banner and the crimson Banner of Light, and the bright standards of nobility from Illian and Cairhien and Tear. The nobles kept to their own kind, three widely spaced knots awash in gilt and silver-plated steel, silks and velvets and laces, but in common they looked around uneasily. Even the best-trained of their horses tossed heads and stamped hooves on the muddy ground. The wind was cold, and colder seeming for the heat it had replaced so abruptly, just as the rain had been a shock after so long without. From whatever nation, they had prayed for the baking drought to break, but none knew what to make of unrelenting storms in answer to their prayers. Some glanced at Rand when they thought he would not notice. Perhaps wondering if he had answered them so. The thought made him laugh softly, bitterly.

hi pæɾəd ɪz blæk ɡɛldɪŋz nɛk wɪð ə lɛðɝ-ɡɔntələɾəd hænd, ɡlæd ðət teɪdeɪʃɝ dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ nɝvz. ðə mæsɪv ænəməl maɪɾ əv bɪn ə stætʃu, əweɪɾɪŋ ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə ɹeɪnz əɹ niz tə muv. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz hɔɹs simd əz koʊld əz i dɪd, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ floʊɾəd ɪn ðə vɔɪd təɡɛðɝ. ivən wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹeɪdʒɪŋ θɹu hɪm, faɪɝ ən aɪs ən dɛθ, hi wɑz bɛɹli əwɛɹ ə ðə wɪnd, ðoʊ ɪt fleɪld ɪz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kloʊk əbaʊɾ ən kʌt θɹu hɪz koʊt, ɡɹin sɪlk θɪkli wɝkt wɪð ɡoʊld ən nɑɾ ɪntɛndəd fəɹ wɛɹ ɪn sətʃ wɛðɝ. ðə wunz ɪn ɪz saɪɾ ætʃt ən θɹɑbd, ði oʊld ən ðə nu kʌɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪt, ðə wunz ðət wəd nɛvɝ hil, bʌt ðət wɑz dɪstənt, tu, ənʌðɝ mænz flɛʃ. ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪkɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz tɛmpəlz wɪð ðə ʃɑɹp pɔɪns ə ðə taɪni bleɪdz əmʌŋ ɪts ɡoʊldən lɔɹəl livz. ivən ðə fɪlθ woʊvən θɹu seɪɾɪn sim lɛs əbtʃɹusɪv ðən ɪt wʌns hæd; stɪl vaɪl, stɪl loʊðsəm, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝθ noʊɾəs. ðə noʊbəlz' aɪz ɑn ɪz bæk wɝ pælpəbəl, ðoʊ.

He patted his black gelding's neck with a leather-gauntleted hand, glad that Tai'daishar did not show nerves. The massive animal might have been a statue, awaiting the pressure of reins or knees to move. It was good that the Dragon Reborn's horse seemed as cold as he did, as though they floated in the Void together. Even with the One Power raging through him, fire and ice and death, he was barely aware of the wind, though it flailed his gold-embroidered cloak about and cut through his coat, green silk thickly worked with gold and not intended for wear in such weather. The wounds in his side ached and throbbed, the old and the new cutting across it, the wounds that would never heal, but that was distant, too, another man's flesh. The Crown of Swords might have been pricking someone else's temples with the sharp points of the tiny blades among its golden laurel leaves. Even the filth woven through saidin seemed less obtrusive than it once had; still vile, still loathsome, but no longer worth notice. The nobles' eyes on his back were palpable, though.

ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, hi lin fɔɹwɝd. hi kəd si ðə taɪt klʌstɝ ə loʊ, wʊɾɪd hɪlz hæf ə maɪl tə ði ist əz klɪɹli əz ɪf i wɝ juzɪŋ ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ðə lænd wɑz flæt, hɪɹ, ði oʊnli pɹɑmənənsəz ðoʊz fɔɹəstəd hɪlz ən ðɪs lɔŋ ɹɪdʒ, θɹʌstɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə hiθ. ðə nɛks θɪkɪt dɛns ɪnʌf tə tʃɹuli dɪzɝv ðə neɪm leɪ kloʊs tə tɛn maɪlz ɔf. oʊnli stɔɹm-bæɾɝd hæf-lifləs tʃɹiz ən tæŋɡəlz ʌv ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ wɝ vɪzəbəl ɑn ðə hɪlz, bʌɾ i nu wʌt ðeɪ hɪd. tu, pɝhæps θɹi θaʊzən ə ðə mɛn sɑmaɪl hæd ɡæðɝd tə tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ɪm fɹəm teɪkɪŋ ɪljən.

Shifting his sword hilt, he leaned forward. He could see the tight cluster of low, wooded hills half a mile to the east as clearly as if he were using a looking glass. The land was flat, here, the only prominences those forested hills and this long ridge, thrusting up from the heath. The next thicket dense enough to truly deserve the name lay close to ten miles off. Only storm-battered half-leafless trees and tangles of undergrowth were visible on the hills, but he knew what they hid. Two, perhaps three thousand of the men Sammael had gathered to try to stop him from taking Illian.

ðəɾ ɑɹmi hæd dɪsɪntəɡɹeɪɾɪd wʌns ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðə mæn u hæd sʌmən əm wɑz dɛd, ðət mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz hæd vænɪʃt, pɝhæps ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪv əz wɛl, ən ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə nu kɪŋ ɪn ɪljən. mɛni hæd skæɾɝd bæk tə ðɛɹ hoʊmz, jɛt dʒʌst əz mɛni klʌŋ təɡɛðɝ. juʒəwəli noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti hɪɹ, θɝɾi ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɹmi ɪf ðeɪ keɪm təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, ən kaʊnləs ɑɹm bænz ʌðɝwaɪz. iðɝ weɪ, ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɹoʊm ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. taɪm weɪd daʊn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz laɪk lɛd. ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɪnʌf taɪm, bʌt meɪbi ðɪs wʌns. . . . faɪɝ ən aɪs ən dɛθ.

That army had disintegrated once they learned that the man who had summoned them was dead, that Mattin Stepaneos had vanished, perhaps into the grave as well, and that there was a new king in Illian. Many had scattered back to their homes, yet just as many clung together. Usually no more than twenty here, thirty there, but a great army if they came together again, and countless armed bands otherwise. Either way, they could not be allowed to roam the countryside. Time weighed down on his shoulders like lead. There was never enough time, but maybe this once. . . . Fire and ice and death.

wʌt wəd jə du? hi θɔt. ɑɹ jə ðɛɹ? ən ðɛn, daʊtfəli, heɪɾɪŋ ðə daʊt, wɝ jə ɛvɝ ðɛɹ? saɪləns ænsɝd, dip ən dɛɾ ɪn ði ɛmptinəs ðət sɝaʊndəd hɪm. əɹ wɑz ðəɹ mæd læftɝ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹisɛsəz ə hɪz maɪnd? dɪɾ i ɪmædʒən ɪt, laɪk ðə fil ə sʌmwʌn lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, sʌmwʌn dʒʌst ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə tʌtʃɪŋ ɪz bæk? əɹ ðə kʌlɝz ðət swɝl dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt, mɔɹ ðən kʌlɝz, ən wɝ ɡɔn? ə θɪŋ ə mædmən. hɪz ɡlʌv θʌm slɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə kɑɹvɪŋz ðət sɝpɛntən ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. ðə lɔŋ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt tæsəlz bɪloʊ ðə pɑlɪʃt spɪɹ-pɔɪn flʌɾɝd ɪn ðə wɪnd. faɪɝ ən aɪs, ən dɛθ wəd kʌm.

What would you do? he thought. Are you there? And then, doubtfully, hating the doubt, Were you ever there? Silence answered, deep and dead in the emptiness that surrounded him. Or was there mad laughter somewhere in the recesses of his mind? Did he imagine it, like the feel of someone looking over his shoulder, someone just on the brink of touching his back? Or the colors that swirled just out of sight, more than colors, and were gone? A thing of madmen. His gloved thumb slid along the carvings that serpentined the Dragon Scepter. The long green-and-white tassels below the polished spear-point fluttered in the wind. Fire and ice, and death would come.

"aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ tɔk tə ðɛm maɪsɛlf," hi ənaʊnst. wɪtʃ pɹədust ə fjʊɹɔɹ.

"I will go talk to them myself," he announced. Which produced a furor.

lɔɹd ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, ðə ɡɹin sæʃ ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ɔɹnətli ɡɪldɪd bɹɛstpleɪt, hɝiɾ ɪz faɪn-æŋkəld waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ fɔɹwɝd fɹəm ði ɪliɑnɝz, fɑloʊd kloʊsli baɪ dɛmiɾɝ mɑɹkəlɪn, fɝs kæptən ə ðə kəmpænjənz, ɑn ə sɑləd beɪ. mɑɹkəlɪn wɑz ði oʊnli mæn əmʌŋ əm wɪθaʊt sɪlk əɹ ə spɛk ə leɪs, ði oʊnli mæn ɪn pleɪn ɪf bɹaɪtli bɝnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ, ðoʊ ðə kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz sæɾəlz haɪ pɑməl dɪd bɛɹ θɹi θɪn ɡoʊldən plumz. lɔɹd mɑɹæk lɪftəɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz, ðən lɛɾ əm fɔl ənsɝteɪnli wən i sɔ noʊ ʌðɝz ə ðə naɪn muv. ə waɪd mæn wɪð ə stɑləd mænɝ, ən nu tə ðə kaʊnsəl, hi ɔfən simd mɔɹ kɹæfsmən ðən lɔɹd dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɪtʃ sɪlks bɪniθ ɪz lævɪʃ ɑɹmɝ ən ðə fɔlz ə leɪs spɪlɪŋ oʊvɝ. haɪ lɔɹdz wɪɹɑmɑn ən toʊlmɝæn spɝd təɡɛðɝ fɹəm ðə tɛɹənz, əz kɹʌstɪd wɪð ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ əz ɛni ʌv ðə naɪn, ən ɹoʊzænə, nuli ɹeɪz tə haɪ leɪɾi ən wɛɹɪŋ ə bɹɛstpleɪt wɝkt wɪð ðə hɔk-ænd-stɑɹz ə hɝ haʊs. ðɛɹ, tu, ʌðɝz hæf meɪɾ əz ɪf tə fɑloʊ ðən hʌŋ bæk, lʊkɪŋ wɝid. bleɪd-slɛndɝ ɑɹəkʌm ən blu-aɪd mɑɹəkən ən bɔld-hɛɾəd ɡəm wɝ dɛd mɛn; ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ðæt, bʌt haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə bi ət ðə sɛntɝ ə paʊɝ, ðeɪ fɪɹd ɹænd wəd kɪl ðɛm. oʊnli lɔɹd səmɝædʒɹɪd keɪm fɹəm ðə kɛɹhinɪn, ɑn ə ɡɹeɪ ðət hæd sin bɛɾɝ deɪz, hɪz ɑɹmɝ bæɾɝd, ɪts ɡɪldɪŋ tʃɪpt. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɡɔn ən hɑɹd, ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd laɪk ə kɑmən soʊlʒɝ, ən ɪz dɑɹk aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð kəntɛmp fəɹ ðə tɔlɝ tɛɹənz.

Lord Gregorin, the green sash of the Council of Nine slanted across his ornately gilded breastplate, hurried his fine-ankled white gelding forward from the Illianers, followed closely by Demetre Marcolin, First Captain of the Companions, on a solid bay. Marcolin was the only man among them without silk or a speck of lace, the only man in plain if brightly burnished armor, though the conical helmet resting on his saddle's high pommel did bear three thin golden plumes. Lord Marac lifted his reins, then let them fall uncertainly when he saw no others of the Nine move. A wide man with a stolid manner, and new to the Council, he often seemed more craftsman than lord despite the rich silks beneath his lavish armor and the falls of lace spilling over. High Lords Weiramon and Tolmeran spurred together from the Tairens, as crusted with gold and silver as any of the Nine, and Rosana, newly raised to High Lady and wearing a breastplate worked with the Hawk-and-Stars of her House. There, too, others half made as if to follow then hung back, looking worried. Blade-slender Aracome and blue-eyed Maraconn and bald-headed Gueyam were dead men; they did not know that, but however much they wanted to be at the center of power, they feared Rand would kill them. Only Lord Semaradrid came from the Cairhienin, on a gray that had seen better days, his armor battered, its gilding chipped. His face was gaunt and hard, the front of his head shaved and powdered like a common soldier, and his dark eyes shone with contempt for the taller Tairens.

ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv kəntɛmp tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. tɛɹənz ən kɛɹhinɪn heɪɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪliɑnɝz ən tɛɹənz dɪspaɪzd itʃ ʌðɝ. oʊnli kɛɹhinɪn ən ɪliɑnɝz ɡɑɾ əlɔŋ tə ɛni dɪɡɹi, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ə pɹɪkəl ivən ðɛɹ. ðɛɹ tu neɪʃənz maɪt nɑɾ əv nɪɹ ðə lɔŋ hɪstɝi ʌv bæd blʌd ʃɛɹd baɪ tiɹ ən ɪljən, jɛt ðə kɛɹhinɪn stɪl wɝ fɔɹənɝz, ɑɹmd ən ɑɹmɝɾ ɑn ɪljənz sɔɪl, wɛlkəm hæfhɑɹɾɪdli ət bɛst ən oʊnli ðət mʌtʃ kəz ðeɪ fɑloʊd ɹænd. bʌt dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ðə fɹaʊnɪŋ ən bɹɪsəlɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk ət wʌns əz ðeɪ mɪld əbaʊt ɹænd ɪn ə flɝi ʌv wɪnbloʊn kloʊks, ðeɪ hæɾ ə kɑmən ɡoʊl naʊ. æftɝ ə fæʃən.

There was plenty of contempt to go around. Tairens and Cairhienin hated one another. Illianers and Tairens despised each other. Only Cairhienin and Illianers got along to any degree, and there was a certain amount of prickle even there. Their two nations might not have near the long history of bad blood shared by Tear and Illian, yet the Cairhienin still were foreigners, armed and armored on Illian's soil, welcomed halfheartedly at best and only that much because they followed Rand. But despite all the frowning and bristling and trying to talk at once as they milled about Rand in a flurry of windblown cloaks, they had a common goal now. After a fashion.

"mædʒəsti," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn sɛd heɪstəli, boʊɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɡoʊld-tul sæɾəl, "aɪ də bɛɡ jə lemi ɡoʊ ɪn jəɹ stɛd, əɹ fɝs kæptən mɑɹkəlɪn." ðə skwɛɹ-kʌt bɪɹd ðət lɛft ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ fɹeɪmd ə ɹaʊn feɪs kɹist wɪð wɝi. "ðiz mɛn mʌs noʊ jə ɑɹ kɪŋ - ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz də bi ɹɛɾ ɪn ɛvɹi vɪlədʒ, əɾ ɛvɹi kɹɔsɹoʊdz, əz wi də spik - jɛt ðeɪ meɪ noʊ ʃoʊ pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛk fəɹ jəɹ kɹaʊn." læntɝn-dʒɔd mɑɹkəlɪn, klin-ʃeɪvən, stʌɾid ɹænd wɪð dɑɹk, dip-sɛɾ aɪz, ɡɪvɪŋ noʊ hɪnt wʌt leɪ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪmpæsɪv feɪs. ðə kəmpænjənz' lɔɪəlti wɑz tə ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən, ən mɑɹkəlɪn wɑz oʊld ɪnʌf tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən tɑɹn ælθɹ hæd bɪn sɛkən kæptən oʊvɝ hɪm, bʌɾ oʊnli hi nu wʌɾ i θɔɾ ə ɹænd ælθɹ əz kɪŋ.

"Majesty," Gregorin said hastily, bowing in his gold-tooled saddle, "I do beg you let me go in your stead, or First Captain Marcolin." The square-cut beard that left his upper lip bare framed a round face creased with worry. "These men must know you are King - the proclamations do be read in every village, at every crossroads, as we do speak - yet they may no show proper respect for your crown." Lantern-jawed Marcolin, clean-shaven, studied Rand with dark, deep-set eyes, giving no hint what lay behind his impassive face. The Companions' loyalty was to the crown of Illian, and Marcolin was old enough to remember when Tarn al'Thor had been Second Captain over him, but only he knew what he thought of Rand al'Thor as King.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," wɪɹɑmɑn ɪntoʊn əz i meɪɾ ɪz baʊ, nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɡɹɛɡɹɪn tə fɪnɪʃ. ðə mæn ɔlweɪz ɪntoʊnd, ən ivən ɑn hɔɹsbæk i sim tə stʃɹʌt. hɪz wɝk vɛlvəts ən stʃɹaɪp sɪlks ən fɔlz ə leɪs ɔlmoʊst oʊvɝwɛlmd ɪz ɑɹmɝ, ən ɪz pɔɪntəd ɡɹeɪ bɪɹd ɡeɪv ɔf ə flaʊɝi sɛn ə pɝfjumd ɔɪlz. "ðɪs ɹæbəl ɪz tu pɛɾi tə kənsɝn ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən pɝsənəli. sɛt dɑɡz tə kætʃ dɑɡz, aɪ seɪ. lɛt ði ɪliɑnɝz ɹuɾ əm aʊt. bɝn maɪ soʊl, ðeɪv dʌn nʌθɪŋ soʊ fɑɹ tə sɝv jə bʌt tɔk." tʃɹʌst ɪm tə tɝn əɡɹimənt wɪð ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ɪndə ən ɪnsəlt. toʊlmɝæn wɑz lin ɪnʌf tə meɪk wɪɹɑmɑn əpɪɹ bʌlki ən sɑmbɝ ɪnʌf tə dɪm ðə lʌstɝ ə hɪz ɡɑɹb; hi wɑz noʊ ful, ən ɹaɪvəl tə wɪɹɑmɑn bɪsaɪdz, jɛɾ i nɑɾəd sloʊli ɪn əɡɹimənt. noʊ lʌv lɔs ðəɹ fəɹ ɪliɑnɝz, əɾ ɔl.

"My Lord Dragon," Weiramon intoned as he made his bow, not waiting for Gregorin to finish. The man always intoned, and even on horseback he seemed to strut. His worked velvets and striped silks and falls of lace almost overwhelmed his armor, and his pointed gray beard gave off a flowery scent of perfumed oils. "This rabble is too petty to concern the Lord Dragon personally. Set dogs to catch dogs, I say. Let the Illianers root them out. Burn my soul, they've done nothing so far to serve you but talk." Trust him to turn agreement with Gregorin into an insult. Tolmeran was lean enough to make Weiramon appear bulky and somber enough to dim the luster of his garb; he was no fool, and rival to Weiramon besides, yet he nodded slowly in agreement. No love lost there for Illianers, at all.

səmɝædʒɹɪd kɝld ə lɪp ət ðə tɛɹənz bʌɾ ədʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf tə ɹænd, kʌɾɪŋ ɪn hɑɹɾ ɑn wɪɹɑmɑnz hilz. "ðɪs ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz tɛn taɪmz əz lɑɹdʒ əz ɛni ʌðɝ wɪv faʊn soʊ fɑɹ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." hi kɛɹd nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, ən lɪɾəl ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ɪksɛp ðət ðə θɹoʊn ə kɛɹhin wɑz ɹændz tə ɡɪv, ən səmɝædʒɹɪd hoʊpt ɪt wəd bi ɡɪvən tə wʌn i kəd fɑloʊ ɪnstɛɾ ə faɪt. "ðɛɹ lɔɪəltiz mʌs bi tə bɹɛnd, əɹ soʊ mɛni wəd nɑɾ əv hɛl təɡɛðɝ. aɪ fɪɹ tɔkɪŋ tə ðɛm ɪz ə weɪst ə taɪm, bʌɾ ɪf jə mʌs tɔk, lemi ɹɪŋ ðɛɹ pəzɪʃən oʊpənli wɪð stil soʊ ðeɪ noʊ ðə pɹaɪs ə pʊɾɪŋ ə fʊɾ aʊɾ ə laɪn."

Semaradrid curled a lip at the Tairens but addressed himself to Rand, cutting in hard on Weiramon's heels. "This gathering is ten times as large as any other we have found so far, my Lord Dragon." He cared nothing for the King of Illian, and little enough for the Dragon Reborn, except that the throne of Cairhien was Rand's to give, and Semaradrid hoped it would be given to one he could follow instead of fight. "Their loyalties must be to Brend, or so many would not have held together. I fear talking to them is a waste of time, but if you must talk, let me ring their position openly with steel so they know the price of putting a foot out of line."

ɹoʊzænə ɡlɛɹd ɹaɪt bæk ət səmɝædʒɹɪd, ə lin wʊmən, nɑt tɔl jɛt nɪɹli əz tɔl əz hi, wɪð aɪz laɪk blu aɪs. ʃi dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ɪm tə fɪnɪʃ, iðɝ, ən ʃi, tu, spoʊk tə ɹænd. "aɪv kʌm tu fɑɹ ən ɪnvɛstəd tu mʌtʃ ɪn jə tə si jə daɪ naʊ, fəɹ nʌθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd blʌnli. noʊ mɔɹ ə ful ðən toʊlmɝæn, ɹoʊzænə hæd kleɪmd ə pleɪs ɪn ðə kaʊnsəlz ə ðə haɪ lɔɹdz, ðoʊ tɛɹən haɪ leɪɾiz sɛldəm dɪd, ən blʌnt wɑz ðə wɝd fəɹ hɝ. dɪspaɪt ði ɑɹmɝ moʊst ə ðə noʊbəlwɪmən wɔɹ, nʌn æktʃəli  lɛd ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɪndə bæɾəl, jɛt ɹoʊzænə kæɹiɾ ə flæŋʒd meɪs ɑn əɹ sæɾəl, ən səmtaɪmz ɹænd θɔt ʃi wəd laɪk ə tʃæns tə juz ɪt. "aɪ daʊt ðoʊz ɪliɑnɝz læk fəɹ baʊz," ʃi sɛd, "æn ɪt teɪks oʊnli wʌn æɹoʊ tə kɪl ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." pɝsɪŋ ɪz lɪps θɔtfəli, mɑɹkəlɪn nɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ kætʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ðən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd stɑɹɾəld lʊks wɪð ɹoʊzænə, itʃ mɔɹ sɝpɹaɪz ðən ði ʌðɝ tə faɪn ðɛmsɛlvz ə laɪk maɪnd wɪð ən eɪntʃən ɛnəmi.

Rosana glared right back at Semaradrid, a lean woman, not tall yet nearly as tall as he, with eyes like blue ice. She did not wait for him to finish, either, and she, too, spoke to Rand. "I've come too far and invested too much in you to see you die now, for nothing," she said bluntly. No more a fool than Tolmeran, Rosana had claimed a place in the councils of the High Lords, though Tairen High Ladies seldom did, and blunt was the word for her. Despite the armor most of the noblewomen wore, none actually led their armsmen into battle, yet Rosana carried a flanged mace on her saddle, and sometimes Rand thought she would like a chance to use it. "I doubt those Illianers lack for bows," she said, "and it takes only one arrow to kill even the Dragon Reborn." Pursing his lips thoughtfully, Marcolin nodded before catching himself, then exchanged startled looks with Rosana, each more surprised than the other to find themselves of like mind with an ancient enemy.

"ðiz pɛzəns kəd nɛvɝ əv faʊn ðə mɛɾəl tə steɪ ʌndɝ ɑɹmz wɪθaʊɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt," wɪɹɑmɑn kəntɪnjud smuðli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɹoʊzænə. hi wɑz skɪld əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hu, ən wʌt, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə si əɹ hɪɹ. hi wɑz ə ful. "meɪ aɪ sədʒɛs maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən lʊk tə ðiz soʊ-kɔl naɪn fəɹ ðə sɔɹs?"

"These peasants could never have found the mettle to stay under arms without encouragement," Weiramon continued smoothly, ignoring Rosana. He was skilled at ignoring who, and what, he did not want to see or hear. He was a fool. "May I suggest my Lord Dragon look to these so-called Nine for the source?"

"aɪ də pɹoʊtɛs ðɪs tɛɹən pɪɡz ɪnsʌls, mædʒəsti!" ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ɹaɪɾ ətɑp hɪm, wʌn hæn dɑɹɾɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd. "aɪ də pɹoʊɾɛst moʊs hɑɹɾəli!"

"I do protest this Tairen pig's insults, Majesty!" Gregorin growled right atop him, one hand darting to his sword. "I do protest most heartily!"

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni ðɪs taɪm," səmɝædʒɹɪd sɛɾ ət ðə seɪm ɪnstənt. "moʊst wɪl tɝn əɡɛns jə əz sun əz jəɹ bæk ɪz tə ðɛm ɪn ɛni keɪs." baɪ hɪz pɔɪntəd fɹaʊn, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn spikɪŋ ə ðə tɛɹənz əz wɛl əz ðə mɛn ɑn ðə wʊɾɪd hɪlz. pɝhæps i wɑz. "bɛɾɝ tə kɪl əm ən bi dʌn!"

"There are too many this time," Semaradrid said at the same instant. "Most will turn against you as soon as your back is to them in any case." By his pointed frown, he might have been speaking of the Tairens as well as the men on the wooded hills. Perhaps he was. "Better to kill them and be done!"
