"dɪɾ aɪ æsk fəɹ əpɪnjənz?" ɹænd snæp hɑɹʃli. bæbəl bɪkeɪm saɪləns, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə kɹæk ə kloʊks ən bænɝz flæpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. sʌɾənli ɪkspɹɛʃənləs feɪsəz ɹəɡɑɹɾəd hɪm, mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɡoʊɪŋ ɡɹeɪ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hi hɛl ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ðeɪ nu hɪm. nɑɾ ɔl ʌv wʌt ðeɪ nu wɑz tʃɹuθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl ðeɪ bɪlivd. "ju wɪl kʌm wɪð mi, ɡɹɛɡɹɪn," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə mɔɹ nɔɹməl vɔɪs. stɪl hɑɹd, ðoʊ. stil wɑz ɔl ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd; ɡoʊ sɑft, ən ðeɪ wəd tɝn ɑn hɪm. "æn ju, mɑɹkəlɪn. ðə ɹɛst steɪ hɪɹ. dæʃivə! hɑpwəl!"

"Did I ask for opinions?" Rand snapped harshly. Babble became silence, except for the crack of cloaks and banners flapping in the wind. Suddenly expressionless faces regarded him, more than one going gray. They did not know he held the Power, but they knew him. Not all of what they knew was truth, but it was just as well they believed. "You will come with me, Gregorin," he said in a more normal voice. Still hard, though. Steel was all they understood; go soft, and they would turn on him. "And you, Marcolin. The rest stay here. Dashiva! Hopwil!"

ɛvɹiwʌn nɑt neɪmd ɹeɪn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bæk hɝidli əz ðə tu æʃəmən ɹoʊd tə dʒɔɪn ɹænd, ən ði ɪliɑnɝz aɪd ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wʊɾə laɪk tə ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd, tu. əsaɪd fɹəm ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, kɔɹlən dæʃivə wɑz ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ əz i soʊ ɔfən dɪd. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz əwɛɹ ðət seɪɾɪn dʒɹoʊv mɛn mæd sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən pleɪn-feɪs dæʃivə sɝɾənli lʊk ðə pɑɹt, læŋk əntʃɹɪm hɛɹ flaɪɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɛbən hɑpwəl, dʒʌst sɪkstin ən stɪl wɪð ə fju skæɾɝd blɑtʃəz ɑn ɪz tʃiks, wɔɹ ə stɛɹɪŋ fɹaʊn ðət ɡeɪz bɪɑn ɛniθɪŋ ɪn saɪt. ət list ɹænd nu ðə waɪ ʌv ðæt.

Everyone not named reined their horses back hurriedly as the two Asha'man rode to join Rand, and the Illianers eyed the black-coated men as though they would have liked to remain behind, too. Aside from anything else, Corlan Dashiva was glowering and muttering under his breath as he so often did. Everyone was aware that saidin drove men mad sooner or later, and plain-faced Dashiva certainly looked the part, lank untrimmed hair flying in the wind, licking his lips and shaking his head. For that matter, Eben Hopwil, just sixteen and still with a few scattered blotches on his cheeks, wore a staring frown that gazed beyond anything in sight. At least Rand knew the why of that.

əz ði æʃəmən dʒɹu nɪɹ, ɹænd kəd nɑt hɛlp kɑkɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə lɪsən, ðoʊ wʌɾ i lɪsən fəɹ wɑz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. ɑlɑnə wɑz ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs; niðɝ ðə vɔɪd nɔɹ ðə paʊɝ ɔltɝd ðəɾ ə wɪskɝ. dɪstəns wɔɹ ðəɾ əwɛɹnəs daʊn tə dʒʌs ðət - əwɛɹnəs ðət ʃi ɪɡzɪstəd, sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ - jɛt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ tədeɪ, sʌmθɪŋ i hæd fɛl sɛvɹəl taɪmz ɹisənli, dɪm ən bɛɹli ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə noʊɾəs. ə wɪspɝ ə ʃɑk, pɝhæps, əɹ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, ə bɹɛθ ə sʌmθɪŋ ʃɑɹp i kəd nɑt kwaɪt ɡɹæsp. ʃi mʌs fil wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋli fəɹ ɪm tə bi ivən ðət kɑnʃəs ʌv ɪɾ ət ðɪs dɪstəns. meɪbi ʃi wɑz mɪsɪŋ hɪm. ə ɹaɪ θɔt. hi dɪd nɑt mɪs hɝ. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɑlɑnə wɑz iziɝ ðən ɪt hæd bɪn wʌns. ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌt nɑt ðə vɔɪs ðət juz tə ʃaʊɾ ə dɛθ ən kɪlɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ ən æʃəmən keɪm ɪndə saɪt. luz θɝɪn wɑz ɡɔn. ənlɛs ðət fil ə sʌmwʌn stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd, bɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ, wɑz hɪm. wɑz ðəɹ ə mædmænz hɔɹs læftɝ dip ɪn ɪz θɔts? əɹ wɑz ɪɾ ɪz oʊn? ðə mæn hæd bɪn ðɛɹ! hi hæd!

As the Asha'man drew near, Rand could not help cocking his head to listen, though what he listened for was inside his head. Alanna was there, of course; neither the Void nor the Power altered that a whisker. Distance wore that awareness down to just that - awareness that she existed, somewhere far to the north - yet there was something more today, something he had felt several times recently, dim and barely on the edge of notice. A whisper of shock, perhaps, or outrage, a breath of something sharp he could not quite grasp. She must feel whatever it was very strongly for him to be even that conscious of it at this distance. Maybe she was missing him. A wry thought. He did not miss her. Ignoring Alanna was easier than it had been once. She was there, but not the voice that used to shout of death and killing whenever an Asha'man came into sight. Lews Therin was gone. Unless that feel of someone staring at the back of his head, brushing his shoulder blades with a finger, was him. Was there a madman's hoarse laughter deep in his thoughts? Or was it his own? The man had been there! He had!

hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə mɑɹkəlɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ vɛɹi hɑɹd nɑt tə. "nɑt jɛt," hi toʊld əm ɹaɪli, ən ɔlmoʊs læft wən ðeɪ klɪɹli ʌndɝstʊd ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ɹɪlif wɑz tu pleɪn ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. hi wɑz nɑɾ ɪnseɪn. jɛt. "kʌm," hi toʊl ðɛm, ən stɑɹɾəd teɪdeɪʃɝ daʊn ðə sloʊp əɾ ə tʃɹɑt. dɪspaɪt ðə mɛn fɑloʊɪŋ, hi fɛlt əloʊn. dɪspaɪt ðə paʊɝ, hi fɛlt ɛmpti.

He became aware of Marcolin staring at him, and Gregorin trying very hard not to. "Not yet," he told them wryly, and almost laughed when they clearly understood right away. Relief was too plain on their faces for anything else. He was not insane. Yet. "Come," he told them, and started Tai'daishar down the slope at a trot. Despite the men following, he felt alone. Despite the Power, he felt empty.

bɪtwin ðə ɹɪdʒ ən ðə hɪlz leɪ pætʃəz ə θɪk skɹʌb ən lɔŋ stʃɹɛtʃəz ə dɛd ɡɹæs, ə ɡlɪsnɪŋ mæt ə bɹaʊn ən jɛloʊ biɾən flæt baɪ ðə ɹeɪn. oʊnli ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ ðə ɡɹaʊn hæd bɪn soʊ pɑɹtʃt ðəɾ i hæd θɔɾ ɪt kəd dʒɹɪŋk ə ɹɪvɝ wɪθaʊt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ðən ðə tɔɹəns keɪm, sɛn baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ faɪndɪŋ mɝsi ət læst, əɹ meɪbi baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ə fɪɾ ə blæk hjumɝ; hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ. naʊ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz splæʃt mʌɾ əɾ ɛvɹi sɛkən stɛp. hi hoʊp ðɪs dɪd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ. hi hæd səm taɪm, baɪ wʌt hɑpwəl hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd, bʌt nɑt fɝɛvɝ. pɝhæps wiks, ɪf i wɑz lʌki. hi niɾəd mʌnθs. laɪt, hi niɾəd jɪɹz i wəd nɛvɝ hæv!

Between the ridge and the hills lay patches of thick scrub and long stretches of dead grass, a glistening mat of brown and yellow beaten flat by the rain. Only a few days ago the ground had been so parched that he had thought it could drink a river without changing. Then the torrents came, sent by the Creator finding mercy at last, or maybe by the Dark One in a fit of black humor; he did not know which. Now the horses' hooves splashed mud at every second step. He hoped this did not take long. He had some time, by what Hopwil had reported, but not forever. Perhaps weeks, if he was lucky. He needed months. Light, he needed years he would never have!

hɪz hɪɹɪŋ haɪɾənd baɪ ðə paʊɝ, hi kəd meɪk aʊt səm ʌv wʌt ðə mɛn bɪhaɪn ɪm wɝ seɪɪŋ. ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən mɑɹkəlɪn ɹoʊd ni-tə-ni, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊl ðɛɹ kloʊks əɡɛns ðə wɪn ən spikɪŋ ɪn loʊ toʊnz əbaʊt ðə mɛn əhɛd, əbaʊt ðɛɹ fɪɹz ðə mɛn maɪt faɪt. niðɝ daʊɾɪd ðeɪ wəd bi kɹʌʃt ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪzɪstɪd, bʌt ðeɪ fɪɹd ði ɪfɛkt ɑn ɹænd, ən ɪz ɑn ɪljən, ɪf ɪliɑnɝz fɔɾ ɪm naʊ ðət bɹɛnd wɑz dɛd. ðeɪ stɪl kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə ɡɪv bɹɛn ɪz tʃɹu neɪm, sɑmaɪl. ðə vɛɹi noʊʃən ðət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd ɹuld ɪn ɪljən fɹaɪɾənd əm ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə fæk ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹul ðəɹ naʊ.

His hearing heightened by the Power, he could make out some of what the men behind him were saying. Gregorin and Marcolin rode knee-to-knee, trying to hold their cloaks against the wind and speaking in low tones about the men ahead, about their fears the men might fight. Neither doubted they would be crushed if they resisted, but they feared the effect on Rand, and his on Illian, if Illianers fought him now that Brend was dead. They still could not bring themselves to give Brend his true name, Sammael. The very notion that one of the Forsaken had ruled in Illian frightened them even more than the fact that the Dragon Reborn ruled there now.

dæʃivə, slʌmpt ɪn ɪz ɡɹeɪz sæɾəl laɪk ə mæn u hæd nɛvɝ sin ə hɔɹs bɪfɔɹ, mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, wɪtʃ i spoʊk ən ɹɛɾ əz fluənli əz ə skɑlɝ. ɹænd nu ə lɪɾəl, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ʌndɝstænd wʌt ðə fɛloʊ wɑz mʌmbəlɪŋ. pɹɑbli kəmpleɪns əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ; dɪspaɪt biɪŋ ə fɑɹmɝ, dæʃivə dɪslaɪk biɪŋ aʊt-ʌv-dɔɹz ənlɛs ðə skaɪz wɝ klɪɹ.

Dashiva, slumped in his gray's saddle like a man who had never seen a horse before, muttered angrily under his breath. In the Old Tongue, which he spoke and read as fluently as a scholar. Rand knew a little, though not enough to understand what the fellow was mumbling. Probably complaints about the weather; despite being a farmer, Dashiva disliked being out-of-doors unless the skies were clear.

oʊnli hɑpwəl ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, hɪz hɛɹ ən kloʊk wɪpɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz waɪldli əz dæʃivəz. naʊ ən ðən i klʌtʃt ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹɾ ʌnkɑnʃəsli. ɹænd hæd tə spik θɹi taɪmz, ðə læst ʃɑɹpli, bɪfɔɹ hɑpwəl ɡeɪv ə sɝpɹaɪz dʒɝk ən buɾɪd ɪz læŋki dʌn ʌp bɪsaɪd teɪdeɪʃɝ.

Only Hopwil rode in silence, frowning at something beyond the horizon, his hair and cloak whipping about as wildly as Dashiva's. Now and then he clutched the hilt of his sword unconsciously. Rand had to speak three times, the last sharply, before Hopwil gave a surprised jerk and booted his lanky dun up beside Tai'daishar.

ɹænd stʌɾid hɪm. ðə jʌŋ mæn - nɑɾ ə bɔɪ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ ɪz eɪdʒ - hæd fɪld aʊt sɪns ɹænd fɝst sɔ hɪm, ðoʊ hɪz noʊz ən ɪɹz stɪl simd meɪd fəɹ ə bɪɡɝ mæn. eɪ dʒɹæɡən, ɹɛd-ɪnæməld ɡoʊld, naʊ bæləns ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz haɪ kɑlɝ, dʒʌs laɪk dæʃivəz. wʌns, hi hæd sɛɾ i wəd læf ə jɪɹ fəɹ dʒɔɪ wən ðə dʒɹæɡən wɑz hɪz, bʌɾ i stɛɹɾ ənblɪŋkɪŋ ət ɹænd əz ðoʊ lʊkɪŋ θɹu hɪm.

Rand studied him. The young man - not a boy any longer, no matter his age - had filled out since Rand first saw him, though his nose and ears still seemed made for a bigger man. A Dragon, red-enameled gold, now balanced the silver Sword on his high collar, just like Dashiva's. Once, he had said he would laugh a year for joy when the Dragon was his, but he stared unblinking at Rand as though looking through him.

"wʌt jə lɝnd wɑz ɡʊd nuz," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. oʊnli ən ɛfɝt kɛpt ɪm fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɹʌʃ ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ɪn ɪz fɪst. "ju dɪd wɛl." hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə sintʃæn tə ɹɪtɝn, bʌt nɑt soʊ sun. hi hæd hoʊp nɑt soʊ sun. ən nɑt lipɪŋ aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ, swɑloʊɪŋ sɪɾiz əɾ ə ɡʌlp. wən i faʊn aʊt ðət mɝtʃəns ɪn ɪljən hæd noʊn fəɹ deɪz bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv əm θɔt tə ɪnfɔɹm ðə naɪn - ðə laɪt fɝbɪd ðeɪ ʃəd luz ə tʃæns ət pɹɑfət kəz tu mɛni nu tu mʌtʃ! - hi hæd bɪn wɪðɪn ə hɛɹ ə skaʊɝɪŋ ðə sɪɾi tə ɪts faʊndeɪʃənz. bʌt ðə nuz wɑz ɡʊd, əɹ əz ɡʊɾ əz ɪt kəd bi ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. hɑpwəl hæd tʃɹævəl tə æmədɔɹ, tə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd nɪɹbaɪ, ən ðə sintʃæn əpɪɹd tə bi weɪɾɪŋ. pɝhæps daɪdʒɛstɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæd kənsumd. ðə laɪt sɛn ðeɪ tʃoʊkt ɑn ɪt! hi fɔɹst ɪz ɡɹɪp tə lusən ɑn ðə lɛŋθ ə dʒɹæɡən-kɑɹv spɪɹhɛd. "ɪf mɔɹ bɹɪŋz hæf əz ɡʊd, aɪ hæv taɪm tə sɛɾəl ɪljən bɪfɔɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm." ɛbu dɑɹ, əz wɛl! ðə laɪt bɝn ðə sintʃæn! ðeɪ wɝ ə dɪstʃɹækʃən, wʌn i dɪd nɑt niɾ ən kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə ɪɡnɔɹ.

"What you learned was good news," Rand told him. Only an effort kept him from trying to crush the Dragon Scepter in his fist. "You did well." He had expected the Seanchan to return, but not so soon. He had hoped not so soon. And not leaping out of nowhere, swallowing cities at a gulp. When he found out that merchants in Illian had known for days before any of them thought to inform the Nine - the Light forbid they should lose a chance at profit because too many knew too much! - he had been within a hair of scouring the city to its foundations. But the news was good, or as good as it could be in the circumstances. Hopwil had Traveled to Amador, to the countryside nearby, and the Seanchan appeared to be waiting. Perhaps digesting what they had consumed. The Light send they choked on it! He forced his grip to loosen on the length of Dragon-carved spearhead. "If Morr brings half as good, I have time to settle Illian before dealing with them." Ebou Dar, as well! The Light burn the Seanchan! They were a distraction, one he did not need and could not afford to ignore.

hɑpwəl sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli lʊkt.

Hopwil said nothing, only looked.

"ɑɹ jə əpsɛt kəz jə hæd tə kɪl wɪmən?" dɪsɔɹə, ʌv ðə musɑɹə ɹn, ən ləmɛl, ʌv ðə smoʊk wɔɾɝ maɪæɡoʊmə, ænd. . . . ɹænd fɔɹs daʊn ði ɪnstɪŋktɪv lɪɾəni ivən əz ɪt bɪɡæn floʊɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə vɔɪd. nu neɪmz hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðət lɪst, neɪmz i dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ æɾɪŋ. leɪdʒɪn ɑɹnoʊ, ə ɹɛd sɪstɝ u hæd daɪd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ɪm ə pɹɪznɝ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃʊɹli ʃi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə ə pleɪs, bʌt ʃi hæd kleɪmd wʌn. koʊləveɪɪɹ seɪɡən, hu hæd hæŋ hɝsɛlf ɹæðɝ ðən æksɛp dʒʌstəs. ʌðɝz. mɛn hæd daɪɾ ɪn θaʊzənz, baɪ hɪz ɔɹɾɝ əɹ baɪ hɪz hænd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə feɪsəz ə ðə wɪmən ðət hɔntəɾ ɪz dʒɹimz. itʃ naɪt, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf kənfɹʌn ðɛɹ saɪlənli əkjuzɪŋ aɪz. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ aɪz i hæd fɛlt ə leɪt.

"Are you upset because you had to kill women?" Desora, of the Musara Reyn, and Lamelle, of the Smoke Water Miagoma, and. . . . Rand forced down the instinctive litany even as it began floating across the Void. New names had appeared on that list, names he did not remember adding. Laigin Arnault, a Red sister who had died trying to take him a prisoner to Tar Valon. Surely she had no right to a place, but she had claimed one. Colavaere Saighan, who had hanged herself rather than accept justice. Others. Men had died in thousands, by his order or by his hand, but it was the faces of the women that haunted his dreams. Each night, he made himself confront their silently accusing eyes. Maybe it was their eyes he had felt of late.

"aɪ toʊl jə əbaʊt deɪmeɪn ən sʌldəm," hi sɛd kɑmli, bʌɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm, ɹeɪdʒ flɛɹd, faɪɝ spaɪɾɝwɪbɪŋ ɝaʊn ði ɛmptinəs ə ðə vɔɪd. ðə laɪt bɝn mi, aɪv kɪl mɔɹ wɪmən ðən ɔl jəɹ naɪtmɛɹz kəd hoʊld! maɪ hænz ɑɹ blæk wɪð ðə blʌɾ ʌv wɪmən! "ɪf jə hædnt waɪpt aʊt ðət sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl, ðeɪɾ əv kɪl jə fəɹ ʃʊɹ." hi dɪd nɑt seɪ ðət hɑpwəl ʃʊɾə əvɔɪɾəd ðɛm, əvɔɪɾəd ðə nid tə kɪl ðɛm. tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt. "aɪ daʊt ðət deɪmeɪn ivən nu haʊ tə ʃild ə mæn. jə hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs." ən bɛɾɝ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɛd ðən səm ɪskeɪpɪŋ wɪð wɝɾ ʌv ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl, skaʊɾɪŋ ðɛm.

"I told you about damane and sul'dam," he said calmly, but inside of him, rage flared, fire spiderwebbing around the emptiness of the Void. The Light burn me, I've killed more women than all your nightmares could hold! My hands are black with the blood of women! "If you hadn't wiped out that Seanchan patrol, they'd have killed you for sure." He did not say that Hopwil should have avoided them, avoided the need to kill them. Too late for that. "I doubt that damane even knew how to shield a man. You had no choice." And better they were all dead than some escaping with word of a man who could channel, scouting them.

æbsənli, hɑpwəl tʌtʃt ɪz lɛf sliv, wɛɹ ðə blæk kʌlɝ dɪsɡaɪz faɪɝ-skɑɹd wʊl. ðə sintʃæn hæd nɑt daɪɾ izəli əɹ fæst. "aɪ paɪl ðə bɑɾiz ɪn ə hɑloʊ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "ðə hɔɹsəz, ɛvɹiθɪŋ. aɪ bɝn ɪɾ ɔl tə æʃ. waɪɾ æʃ ðət floʊɾəd ɪn ðə wɪn laɪk snoʊ. ɪt dɪdn bɑðɝ mi əɾ ɔl."

Absently, Hopwil touched his left sleeve, where the black color disguised fire-scarred wool. The Seanchan had not died easily or fast. "I piled the bodies in a hollow," he said in a flat voice. "The horses, everything. I burned it all to ash. White ash that floated in the wind like snow. It didn't bother me at all."

ɹænd hɝd ðə laɪ ɑn ðə mænz tʌŋ, bʌt hɑpwəl hæd tə lɝn. æftɝ ɔl, hi hæd. ðeɪ wɝ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ən ðət wɑz ɔl ðəɹ wɑz tə ɪt. ɔl ðəɹ wɑz. laɪæ, ʌv ðə koʊseɪɾə tʃɑɝin, ə neɪm ɹɪɾən ɪn faɪɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd, ənʌðɝ neɪm ðət sɪɹd tə ðə soʊl ɹæðɝ ðən mɪɹli bɝnɪŋ. ə neɪmləs dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾ oʊnli baɪ ə feɪs, hu hæd daɪd baɪ hɪz sɔɹd nɪɹ. . . .

Rand heard the lie on the man's tongue, but Hopwil had to learn. After all, he had. They were what they were, and that was all there was to it. All there was. Liah, of the Cosaida Chareen, a name written in fire. Moiraine Damodred, another name that seared to the soul rather than merely burning. A nameless Darkfriend, represented only by a face, who had died by his sword near. . . .

"mædʒəsti," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn sɛd laʊdli, pɔɪntɪŋ əhɛd. ə loʊn mæn keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə nɪɹəs hɪl tə stænd weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ən æɾətud ə dɪfaɪəns. hi kæɹiɾ ə baʊ, ən wɔɹ ə pɔɪntəd stil kæp ən ə bɛltəd meɪl ʃɝt ðət hʌŋ nɪɹli tə hɪz niz.

"Majesty," Gregorin said loudly, pointing ahead. A lone man came out of the trees at the foot of the nearest hill to stand waiting in an attitude of defiance. He carried a bow, and wore a pointed steel cap and a belted mail shirt that hung nearly to his knees.

ɹænd spɝd teɪdeɪʃɝ tə miɾ ɪm siθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. seɪɾɪn kəd pɹətɛkt ɪm fɹəm mɛn.

Rand spurred Tai'daishar to meet him seething with the Power. Saidin could protect him from men.

ʌp kloʊz, ðə boʊmən dɪd nɑt meɪk soʊ bɹeɪv ə saɪt. ɹʌst stʃɹikt ɪz hɛlməɾ ən meɪl, ən i lʊk sɑɾən, mʌd tə hɪz θaɪz, dæmp hɛɹ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ daʊn ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs. kɑfɪŋ hɑloʊli, hi skɹʌbd əɾ ə lɔŋ noʊz wɪð ðə bæk ə hɪz hænd. hɪz bɑstʃɹɪŋ əpɪɹd tɔt, ðoʊ; ðæt, hi hæd pɹətɛktəd fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn. ən ðə flɛtʃɪŋz ɑn ði æɹoʊz ɪn ɪz kwɪvɝ lʊk dʒɹaɪ, tu.

Up close, the bowman did not make so brave a sight. Rust streaked his helmet and mail, and he looked sodden, mud to his thighs, damp hair trailing down a narrow face. Coughing hollowly, he scrubbed at a long nose with the back of his hand. His bowstring appeared taut, though; that, he had protected from the rain. And the fletchings on the arrows in his quiver looked dry, too.

"ɑɹ jə ðə liɾɝ hɪɹ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd.

"Are you the leader here?" Rand demanded.

"ju maɪt seɪ aɪ də spik fəɹ hɪm," ðə nɛɹoʊ-feɪs mæn ɹɪplaɪd wɛɹəli. "waɪ?" əz ði ʌðɝz ɡæləpt ʌp bɪhaɪn ɹænd, hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fit, dɑɹk aɪz laɪk ə kɔɹnɝd bædʒɝz. bædʒɝz wɝ deɪnʒɝəs, kɔɹnɝd.

"You might say I do speak for him," the narrow-faced man replied warily. "Why?" As the others galloped up behind Rand, he shifted his feet, dark eyes like a cornered badger's. Badgers were dangerous, cornered.

"wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ, mæn!" ɡɹɛɡɹɪn snæpt. "ju də spik tə ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ən kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən! nil tə jəɹ kɪŋ! wʌt də jəɹ neɪm bi?"

"Watch your tongue, man!" Gregorin snapped. "You do speak to Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, Lord of the Morning and King of Illian! Kneel to your King! What do your name be?"

"hi də bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn?" ðə fɛloʊ sɛd daʊtfəli. aɪɪŋ ɹænd fɹəm ðə kɹaʊn ɑn ɪz hɛd tə hɪz buts, lɪŋɡɝɪŋ ə moʊmən ɑn ðə ɡɪldɪd dʒɹæɡən bʌklɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt, ðə mæn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd sʌmwʌn oʊldɝ, əɹ ɡɹændɝ. "æn lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, jə də seɪ? əɹ kɪŋ dɪd nɛvɝ staɪl hɪmsɛlf soʊ." hi meɪd noʊ muv təwɔɹd nilɪŋ, əɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ɪz neɪm. ɡɹɛɡɹɪnz feɪs dɑɹkən ət ðə mænz toʊn, ən meɪbi ət ðə mænz əblik dɪnaɪəl ə ɹænd əz kɪŋ. mɑɹkəlɪn ɡeɪv ə slaɪt nɑd, əz ðoʊ hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd noʊ mɔɹ.

"He do be the Dragon Reborn?" the fellow said doubtfully. Eyeing Rand from the crown on his head to his boots, lingering a moment on the gilded Dragon buckling his sword belt, the man shook his head as if he had expected someone older, or grander. "And Lord of the Morning, you do say? Our King did never style himself so." He made no move toward kneeling, or giving his name. Gregorin's face darkened at the man's tone, and maybe at the man's oblique denial of Rand as King. Marcolin gave a slight nod, as though he had expected no more.

dæmp ɹʌsəlɪŋz stɝɾ ɪn ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. ɹænd hɝɾ izəli, ən əbɹʌpli hi fɛl seɪɾɪn fɪl hɑpwəl. noʊ lɔŋɡɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, hɑpwəl stʌɾid ðə wʊdlaɪn ɪntɛnli, ə waɪld laɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. dæʃivə, saɪlənt, ɹeɪkɪŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs, lʊk bɔɹd. linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ɡɹɛɡɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli. faɪɝ ən aɪs, bʌt nɑt jɛt dɛθ.

Damp rustlings stirred in the undergrowth among the trees. Rand heard easily, and abruptly he felt saidin fill Hopwil. No longer staring at nothing, Hopwil studied the woodline intently, a wild light in his eyes. Dashiva, silent, raking dark hair out of his face, looked bored. Leaning forward in his saddle, Gregorin opened his mouth angrily. Fire and ice, but not yet death.

"pis, ɡɹɛɡɹɪn." ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz ɪz vɔɪs, bʌɾ i woʊv floʊz tə kæɹi hɪz wɝdz, ɛɹ ən faɪɝ, soʊ ðeɪ bumd əɡɛns ðə wɔl ə tʃɹiz. "maɪ ɔfɝ ɪz dʒɛnɝəs." ðə lɔŋ-noʊz mæn stæɡɝɾ ət ðə saʊnd, ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪnz hɔɹs ʃaɪd. ðoʊz hɪɾən mɛn wəd hɪɹ klɪɹli. "leɪ daʊn jəɹ ɑɹmz, ən ðoʊz u wɑnə ɹɪtɝn hoʊm, kæn. ðoʊz u wɑnə fɑloʊ mi ɪnstɛd, kən də ðæt. bʌt noʊ mæn livz hɪɹ ʌndɝ ɑɹmz ənlɛs i dʌz fɑloʊ mi. aɪ noʊ moʊst ə jə ɑɹ ɡʊd mɛn, hu ænsɝd ðə kɔl ə jəɹ kɪŋ ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn tə dɪfɛn ɪljən, bʌɾ aɪm jəɹ kɪŋ, naʊ, ən əl nɑɾ əv ɛniwʌn tɛmptəd tə tɝn bændət." mɑɹkəlɪn nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli.

"Peace, Gregorin." Rand did not raise his voice, but he wove flows to carry his words, Air and Fire, so they boomed against the wall of trees. "My offer is generous." The long-nosed man staggered at the sound, and Gregorin's horse shied. Those hidden men would hear clearly. "Lay down your arms, and those who want to return home, can. Those who want to follow me instead, can do that. But no man leaves here under arms unless he does follow me. I know most of you are good men, who answered the call of your King and the Council of Nine to defend Illian, but I am your King, now, and I'll not have anyone tempted to turn bandit." Marcolin nodded grimly.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt jəɹ dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn bɝnɪŋ fɑɹmz?" ə mænz fɹaɪɾənd vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz. "ðeɪ də bi fleɪmɪŋ bændəts!"

"What about your Dragonsworn burning farms?" a man's frightened voice shouted from the trees. "They do be flaming bandits!"

"wʌɾ əbaʊt jəɹ il?" ənʌðɝ kɔld. "aɪ də hɪɹ ðeɪ kæɹi ɔf hoʊl vɪlədʒəz!" mɔɹ vɔɪsəz fɹəm ənsin mɛn dʒɔɪn ɪn, ɔl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðə seɪm θɪŋz, dʒɹæɡən-swɔɹn ən il, mɝɾɝəs bɹɪɡænz ən sævədʒəz. ɹænd ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ.

"What about your Aiel?" another called. "I do hear they carry off whole villages!" More voices from unseen men joined in, all shouting the same things, Dragon-sworn and Aiel, murderous brigands and savages. Rand ground his teeth.

wən ðə ʃaʊɾɪŋ feɪɾəd, nɛɹoʊ-feɪs sɛd, "ju də si?" hi pɔz tə kɑf, ðən hɔkt ən spæt, meɪbi fəɹ ɪz tʃɛst ən meɪbi fəɹ ɛmfəsəs. ə pɪɾəfəl saɪt, ɔl wɛɾ ən ɹʌst, bʌɾ ɪz bækboʊn wɑz əz taɪɾ əz ɪz bɑstʃɹɪŋ. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ɹændz ɡlɛɹ əz izəli əz i dɪd ɡɹɛɡɹɪnz. "ju də æsk əs tə ɡoʊ hoʊm ənɑɹmd, əneɪbəl tə dɪfɛn aʊɝsɛlvz əɹ əɹ fæmliz, waɪl jəɹ pipəl də bɝn ən stil ən kɪl. ðeɪ də seɪ ðə stɔɹm bi kʌmɪŋ," hi æɾəd, ən lʊk sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i hæd, sɝpɹaɪzd ən kənfjuz fəɹ ə moʊmənt.

When the shouting faded, narrow-face said, "You do see?" He paused to cough, then hawked and spat, maybe for his chest and maybe for emphasis. A pitiful sight, all wet and rust, but his backbone was as tight as his bowstring. He ignored Rand's glare as easily as he did Gregorin's. "You do ask us to go home unarmed, unable to defend ourselves or our families, while your people do burn and steal and kill. They do say the storm be coming," he added, and looked surprised that he had, surprised and confused for a moment.

"ði il juv hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɑɹ maɪ ɛnəmiz!" nɑt spaɪɾɝwɛbz ə fleɪm ðɪs taɪm, bʌt sɑləd ʃits ə fjʊɹi ðət ɹæp taɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə vɔɪd. ɹændz vɔɪs wɑz aɪs, ðoʊ; ɪt ɹɔɹd laɪk ðə kɹæk ʌv wɪntɝ. ðə stɔɹm wɑz kʌmɪŋ? laɪt, hi wɑz ðə stɔɹm! "maɪ il ɑɹ hʌntɪŋ əm daʊn. maɪ il hʌn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðeɪ ən dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ ən moʊst ə ðə kəmpænjənz hʌn bændəts, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz! aɪm ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, ən əl əlaʊ noʊ wʌn tə dɪsɹʌp ðə pis ʌv ɪljən!"

"The Aiel you've heard about are my enemies!" Not spiderwebs of flame this time, but solid sheets of fury that wrapped tight around the Void. Rand's voice was ice, though; it roared like the crack of winter. The storm was coming? Light, he was the storm! "My Aiel are hunting them down. My Aiel hunt the Shaido, and they and Davram Bashere and most of the Companions hunt bandits, whatever they call themselves! I am the King of Illian, and I will allow no one to disrupt the peace of Illian!"

"ivən ɪf wʌt jə seɪ də bi tʃɹu," nɛɹoʊ-feɪs bɪɡæn.

"Even if what you say do be true," narrow-face began.

"ɪɾ ɪz!" ɹænd snæpt. "ju hæv əntɪl mɪddeɪ tə dɪsaɪd." ðə mæn fɹaʊn ənsɝteɪnli; ənlɛs ðə ɹɔɪlɪŋ klaʊdz klɪɹd, hi maɪɾ əv ə dɪfəkəl taɪm noʊɪŋ mɪddeɪ. ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ ɹɪlif. "dɪsaɪd waɪzli!" hi sɛd. wɝlɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ əbaʊt, hi spɝd ðə ɡɛldɪŋ tə ə ɡæləp bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪdʒ wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz.

"It is!" Rand snapped. "You have until midday to decide." The man frowned uncertainly; unless the roiling clouds cleared, he might have a difficult time knowing midday. Rand gave him no relief. "Decide wisely!" he said. Whirling Tai'daishar about, he spurred the gelding to a gallop back toward the ridge without waiting for the others.

ɹɪlʌktənli hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ, fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf nɑt tə hæŋ ɑn laɪk ə mæn klʌtʃɪŋ sælveɪʃən wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz əz laɪf ən fɪlθ dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɪm təɡɛðɝ. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hi sɔ dʌbəl; ðə wɝl sim tə tɪl dɪtsəli. ðət wɑz ə ɹisən pɹɑbləm, ən i wɝiɾ ɪt maɪt bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪknəs ðət kɪl mɛn u tʃænəld, bʌt ðə dɪzinəs nɛvɝ læstəd mɔɹ ðən moʊməns. ɪt wɑz ðə ɹɛst ə lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ðəɾ i ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd. ðə wɝl sim tə dʌl. noʊ, ɪt dɪd dʌl, ən bɪkeɪm sʌmhaʊ lɛs. kʌlɝz wɝ wɑʃt-aʊt, ðə skaɪ smɔlɝ, kəmpɛɹd tə wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ. hi wɑntəd dɛspɝətli tə siz ðə sɔɹs əɡɛn ən ɹɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. ɔlweɪz ɪt wɑz soʊ wən ðə paʊɝ lɛf hɪm.

Reluctantly he let go of the Power, forced himself not to hang on like a man clutching salvation with his fingernails as life and filth drained from him together. For an instant, he saw double; the world seemed to tilt dizzily. That was a recent problem, and he worried it might be part of the sickness that killed men who channeled, but the dizziness never lasted more than moments. It was the rest of letting go that he regretted. The world seemed to dull. No, it did dull, and became somehow less. Colors were washed-out, the sky smaller, compared to what they had been before. He wanted desperately to seize the Source again and wring the One Power out of it. Always it was so when the Power left him.

noʊ sunɝ hæd seɪɾɪn ɡɔn, ðoʊ, ðən ɹeɪdʒ bʌbəld ɪn ɪts pleɪs, waɪt-hɑɾ ən sɪɹɪŋ, nɪɹli əz hɑɾ əz ðə paʊɝ hæd bɪn. ðə sintʃæn wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf, ən bɹɪɡænz haɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz neɪm? dɛdli dɪstʃɹækʃənz i kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd. wɑz sɑmaɪl ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv? hæɾ i soʊn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə spɹaʊt laɪk θɔɹnz wɛɹɛvɝ ɹænd leɪɾ ə hænd? waɪ? ðə mæn kəd nɑɾ əv bɪlivd i wəd daɪ. ən ɪf hæf ðə teɪlz ɹænd hɝd wɝ tʃɹu, ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɪn mʊɹændi ən ɔltɑɹə ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wɛɹ! mɛni əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən pɹɪznɝ hæd spoʊkən ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. kəd ðə waɪt taʊɝ bi ɪnvɑlv sʌmhaʊ? wəd ðə waɪt taʊɝ nɛvɝ ɡɪv ɪm pis? nɛvɝ? nɛvɝ.

No sooner had saidin gone, though, than rage bubbled in its place, white-hot and searing, nearly as hot as the Power had been. The Seanchan were not enough, and brigands hiding behind his name? Deadly distractions he could not afford. Was Sammael reaching out from the grave? Had he sown the Shaido to sprout like thorns wherever Rand laid a hand? Why? The man could not have believed he would die. And if half the tales Rand heard were true, there were more in Murandy and Altara and the Light alone knew where! Many among the Shaido already taken prisoner had spoken of an Aes Sedai. Could the White Tower be involved somehow? Would the White Tower never give him peace? Never? Never.

bæɾəlɪŋ fjʊɹi, hi wɑz blaɪn tə ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən ðə ɹɛs kætʃɪŋ ʌp. wən ðeɪ tɑp ðə ɹɪdʒ əmʌŋ ðə weɪɾɪŋ noʊbəlz, hi dʒɹu ɹeɪn soʊ əbɹʌpli ðət teɪdeɪʃɝ ɹɪɹd, pɔɪŋ ði ɛɹ ən flɪŋɪŋ mʌd fɹəm ɪz hʊvz. ðə noʊbəlz ɛdʒ ðɛɹ maʊns bæk, fɹəm ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ, fɹəm hɪm.

Battling fury, he was blind to Gregorin and the rest catching up. When they topped the ridge among the waiting nobles, he drew rein so abruptly that Tai'daishar reared, pawing the air and flinging mud from his hooves. The nobles edged their mounts back, from his gelding, from him.

"aɪ ɡeɪv əm tə mɪddeɪ," hi ənaʊnst. "wɑtʃ ðɛm. aɪ doʊnt wɑn ðɪs lɑt bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə fɪfti smɔlɝ bænz ən slɪpɪŋ əweɪ. əl bi ɪn maɪ tɛnt." ɪksɛp fəɹ wɪnd-tɔs kloʊks ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn stoʊn, ɹuɾəd tə wʌn spɑɾ əz ɪf i mɛn ðə kəmæn tə wɑtʃ fəɹ əm pɝsənəli. ət ðət moʊmənt, hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ ɪf ðeɪ steɪd ðəɹ tɪl ðeɪ fɹoʊz əɹ mɛltəd.

"I gave them to midday," he announced. "Watch them. I don't want this lot breaking into fifty smaller bands and slipping away. I'll be in my tent." Except for wind-tossed cloaks they might have been stone, rooted to one spot as if he meant the command to watch for them personally. At that moment, he did not care if they stayed there till they froze or melted.

wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ i tʃɹɑɾəd daʊn ðə bæk sloʊp ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə tu blæk-koʊɾəd æʃəmən ən ɪz ɪliɑnɝ bænɝ-bɛɹɝz. faɪɝ ən aɪs, ən dɛθ wɑz kʌmɪŋ. bʌɾ i wɑz stil. hi wɑz stil.

Without another word he trotted down the back slope of the ridge, followed by the two black-coated Asha'man and his Illianer banner-bearers. Fire and ice, and death was coming. But he was steel. He was steel.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin


CHAPTER 14

mɛsədʒ fɹəm ðə l


Message from the M'Hael

ə maɪl wɛst ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, ðə kæmps bɪɡæn, mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ən kʊk faɪɝz, wɪnd-fleɪl bænɝz ən ə fju skæɾɝd tɛns klʌmp baɪ næʃənæləɾi, baɪ haʊs, itʃ kæmp ə leɪk ə tʃɝn mʌd sɛpɝeɪɾəd fɹəm ði ʌðɝz baɪ stʃɹɛtʃəz ə bɹʌʃi hiθ. mɛn maʊntəɾ ən əfʊt wɑtʃt ɹændz stʃɹimɪŋ bænɝz pæs, ən pɪɹd təwɔɹɾ ʌðɝ kæmps tə ɡeɪdʒ ɹiækʃənz. wən ði il hæd bɪn pɹizɛnt, ðiz mɛn hæd meɪɾ ə sɪŋɡəl hjudʒ kæmp, dʒɹɪvən təɡɛðɝ baɪ wʌn ə ðə fju θɪŋz ðeɪ tʃɹuli ʃɛɹɾ ɪn kɑmən. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ il, ən fɪɹɾ əm haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ dɪnaɪɾ ɪt. ðə wɝld wəd daɪ ənlɛs i səksiɾəd, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ ɪluʒənz ðət ðeɪ ʃɛɹɾ ɛni lɔɪəlti tə hɪm, əɹ ivən bɪliv ðət ðə feɪɾ ə ðə wɝl kəd nɑt bi meɪd tə əkɑmədeɪt ðɛɹ oʊn kənsɝnz, ðɛɹ oʊn dɪzaɪɝz fəɹ ɡoʊld əɹ ɡlɔɹi əɹ paʊɝ. ə hændfʊl dɪd, pɝhæps, ə bɛɹ hændfʊl, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ðeɪ fɑloʊd kəz ðeɪ fɪɹɾ ɪm fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ dɪd ði il. meɪbi mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ dɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪn hum səm dɪd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv, nɑɾ ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðɛɹ hɑɹts, nɑt ðəɾ i kəɾ ən wəd tʌtʃ ðə wɝl hɑɹɾɝ ðən i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɹænd stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən ðeɪ bɪlivd ɪn ðæt. hi æksɛptɪɾ ɪt, naʊ. hi hæd tu mɛni bæɾəlz əhɛɾ ə hɪm tə weɪst ɛfɝɾ ɑn wʌn i kəd nɑt wɪn. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ ən oʊbeɪd, ɪt hæd tə bi ɪnʌf.

A mile west of the ridge, the camps began, men and horses and cook fires, wind-flailed banners and a few scattered tents clumped by nationality, by House, each camp a lake of churned mud separated from the others by stretches of brushy heath. Men mounted and afoot watched Rand's streaming banners pass, and peered toward other camps to gauge reactions. When the Aiel had been present, these men had made a single huge camp, driven together by one of the few things they truly shared in common. They were not Aiel, and feared them however much they denied it. The world would die unless he succeeded, but he had no illusions that they shared any loyalty to him, or even believed that the fate of the world could not be made to accommodate their own concerns, their own desires for gold or glory or power. A handful did, perhaps, a bare handful, but for the most part, they followed because they feared him far more than they did the Aiel. Maybe more than they did the Dark One, in whom some did not really believe, not in the depths of their hearts, not that he could and would touch the world harder than he had already. Rand stood before their faces, and they believed in that. He accepted it, now. He had too many battles ahead of him to waste effort on one he could not win. So long as they followed and obeyed, it had to be enough.

ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ðə kæmps wɑz ɪz oʊn, ən hɪɹ ɪliɑnɝ kəmpænjənz ɪn ɡɹin koʊts wɪð jɛloʊ kʌfs ɹʌbd ʃoʊldɝz wɪð tɛɹən dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn ɪn fæt-sliv koʊts stʃɹaɪp blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld ən ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ə kɛɹhinɪn dʒɹɔn fɹəm fɔɹɾi-ɑd haʊsəz, ɪn dɑɹk kʌlɝz, səm wɪð kɑn stɪf əbʌv ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðeɪ kʊkt ət dɪfɹən faɪɝz, slɛpt əpɑɹt, pɪkəɾɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əpɑɹt, ən aɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ wɛɹəli, bʌt ðeɪ mɪŋɡəld. ðə seɪfti ʌv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ðɛɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, ən ðeɪ tʊk ðə dʒɑb sɪɹiəsli. ɛni ʌv əm maɪt bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm, bʌt nɑt waɪl ði ʌðɝz wɝ ðəɹ tə wɑtʃ. oʊl heɪtʃɹədz ən nu dɪslaɪks wəd bɹɪŋ bɪtʃɹeɪəl ʌv ɛni plɑt bɪfɔɹ ðə bɪtʃɹeɪɝ stɑp tə θɪŋk.

The largest of the camps was his own, and here Illianer Companions in green coats with yellow cuffs rubbed shoulders with Tairen Defenders of the Stone in fat-sleeved coats striped black-and-gold and an equal number of Cairhienin drawn from forty-odd Houses, in dark colors, some with con stiff above their heads. They cooked at different fires, slept apart, picketed their horses apart, and eyed one another warily, but they mingled. The safety of the Dragon Reborn was their responsibility, and they took the job seriously. Any of them might betray him, but not while the others were there to watch. Old hatreds and new dislikes would bring betrayal of any plot before the betrayer stopped to think.

ə ɹɪŋ ə stil stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn ɹændz tɛnt, ə hjudʒ pik θɪŋ ʌv ɡɹin sɪlk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð biz ɪn θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld. ɪt hæd bɪlɔŋ tə hɪz pɹɛɾəsɛsɝ, mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz, ən hæd kʌm wɪð ðə kɹaʊn, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. kəmpænjənz ɪn bɝnɪʃt kɑnɪkəl hɛlməts stʊd saɪd baɪ saɪd wɪð dɪfɛndɝz ɪn hɛlməts ɹɪdʒd ən ɹɪmd, ən kɛɹhinɪn ɪn bɛl-ʃeɪp hɛlmz, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə wɪnd, bɑɹd feɪsɡɑɹdz haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ fitʃɝz, hælbɝdz slæntəd pɹɪsaɪsli. nɑt wʌn muvd ə hɛɹ wən ɹænd dʒɹu ɹeɪn, bʌɾ ə bɛvi ʌv sɝvəns keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə ətɛn tə hɪm ən ði æʃəmən. ə boʊni wʊmən ɪn ðə ɡɹin-ænd-jɛloʊ vɛst ʌv ə ɡɹum fɹəm ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪn ɪljən tʊk ɪz bɹaɪɾəl, waɪl ɪz stɝəp wɑz hɛl baɪ ə bʌlbəs-noʊz fɛloʊ ɪn ðə blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld lɪvɝi ʌv ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ðeɪ tʌɡd fɔɹlɑks tə hɪm, ən kæst oʊnli wʌn ʃɑɹp lʊk ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. bɔɹiən kɛɹɪvɪn, ə staʊt peɪl lɪɾəl wʊmən ɪn ə dɑɹk dʒɹɛs, sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾəntli ɔfɝɾ ɪm ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ ʌv dæmp klɔθs fɹəm wɪtʃ stim ɹoʊz. kɛɹhinɪn, ʃi wɑtʃt ði ʌðɝ tu, ðoʊ mɔɹ əz ɪf meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ðeɪ dɪd ðɛɹ tæsks pɹɑpɝli ðən wɪð ði ænəmɑsəɾi fəɹ itʃ ʌðɝ ðeɪ bɛɹli hɪd. bʌt wɪð kɛɹ, stɪl. wʌt wɝkt wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝkt wɪð ðə sɝvəns əz wɛl.

A ring of steel stood guard around Rand's tent, a huge peaked thing of green silk embroidered all over with bees in thread-of-gold. It had belonged to his predecessor, Mattin Stepaneos, and had come with the crown, in a manner of speaking. Companions in burnished conical helmets stood side by side with Defenders in helmets ridged and rimmed, and Cairhienin in bell-shaped helms, ignoring the wind, barred faceguards hiding their features, halberds slanted precisely. Not one moved a hair when Rand drew rein, but a bevy of servants came running to attend to him and the Asha'man. A bony woman in the green-and-yellow vest of a groom from the Royal Palace in Illian took his bridle, while his stirrup was held by a bulbous-nosed fellow in the black-and-gold livery of the Stone of Tear. They tugged forelocks to him, and cast only one sharp look at one another. Boreane Carivin, a stout pale little woman in a dark dress, self-importantly offered him a silver tray of damp cloths from which steam rose. Cairhienin, she watched the other two, though more as if making sure they did their tasks properly than with the animosity for each other they barely hid. But with care, still. What worked with the soldiers worked with the servants as well.

dʒɹɔɪŋ ɔf ɪz ɡɔnləts, ɹænd weɪvd əweɪ bɔɹiənz tʃɹeɪ. deɪmɝ flɪn hæd ɹɪzən fɹəm ən ɔɹnətli kɑɹv bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛn əz ɹænd dɪsmaʊntɪd. bɔld ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɹæɡəd waɪt fɹɪnʒ, flɪn lʊk mɔɹ ə ɡɹændfɑðɝ ðən ən æʃəmən. ə lɛðɝ-tʌf ɡɹændfɑðɝ wɪð ə stɪf lɛɡ, hu hæd sin mɔɹ ə ðə wɝl ðən ə fɑɹm. ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt bɪlɔŋd, əz wɛl ɪt ʃəɾ ɑn ə fɔɹmɝ soʊlʒɝ ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd. ɹænd tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ ðən moʊst. flɪn hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf, æftɝ ɔl.

Drawing off his gauntlets, Rand waved away Boreane's tray. Damer Flinn had risen from an ornately carved bench in front of the tent as Rand dismounted. Bald except for a ragged white fringe, Flinn looked more a grandfather than an Asha'man. A leather-tough grandfather with a stiff leg, who had seen more of the world than a farm. The sword at his hip looked as if it belonged, as well it should on a former soldier of the Queen's Guard. Rand trusted him more than most. Flinn had saved his life, after all.

flɪn səluɾəd, fɪs tə tʃɛst, ən wən ɹænd æknɑlɪdʒd ɪm wɪð ə nɑd, lɪmp kloʊsɝ ən weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə ɡɹumz lɛft wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. "tɔɹvəlz hɪɹ. sɛn baɪ ðə l, hi sɛz. hi wɑntəd tə weɪɾ ɪn ðə kaʊnsəl tɛnt. aɪ toʊl nɛɹɪʃmə tə wɑtʃ hɪm." ðət hæd bɪn ɹændz kəmænd, ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ hi hæd ɡɪvən ɪt; noʊ wʌn u keɪm fɹəm ðə blæk taʊɝ wɑz tə bi lɛft əloʊn. hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ, flɪn fɪŋɡɝd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz blæk kɑlɝ. "hi wɑzn hæpi tə hɪɹ jud ɹeɪzd ɔl ʌv ʌs."

Flinn saluted, fist to chest, and when Rand acknowledged him with a nod, limped closer and waited until the grooms left with the horses before speaking in a low voice. "Torval's here. Sent by the M'Hael, he says. He wanted to wait in the council tent. I told Narishma to watch him." That had been Rand's command, though he was not sure why he had given it; no one who came from the Black Tower was to be left alone. Hesitating, Flinn fingered the Dragon on his black collar. "He wasn't happy to hear you'd raised all of us."

"wɑzn hi, naʊ," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, tʌkɪŋ ɪz ɡlʌvz bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. ən kəz flɪn stɪl lʊkt ənsɝɾən, hi æɾəd, "ju ɔl ɝn ɪt." hi hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə sɛnd wʌn ə ði æʃəmən tə teɪm - ðə liɾɝ, ðə l, əz ði æʃəmən ɔl kɔld ɪm - bʌt naʊ tɔɹvəl kəd kæɹi ðə mɛsədʒ. ɪn ðə kaʊnsəl tɛnt? "hæv ɹəfɹɛʃməns sɛnt," hi toʊl flɪn, ðən moʊʃən hɑpwəl ən dæʃivə tə fɑloʊ.

"Wasn't he, now," Rand said softly, tucking his gloves behind his sword belt. And because Flinn still looked uncertain, he added, "You all earned it." He had been about to send one of the Asha'man to Taim - the Leader, the M'Hael, as the Asha'man all called him - but now Torval could carry the message. In the council tent? "Have refreshments sent," he told Flinn, then motioned Hopwil and Dashiva to follow.

flɪn səluɾəd əɡɛn, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ, blæk mʌd skwɛltʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz buts. noʊ tʃɪɹz ɹoʊz fəɹ ɪm ɪn ðə blʌstɝɪŋ wɪnd. hi kəd ɹikɔl wən ðəɹ hæd bɪn. ɪf ðət wɑz nɑt wʌn ə luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹiz. ɪf luz θɝɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ɹil. ə flæʃ ə kʌlɝ dʒʌs bɪɑn ði ɛdʒ ə saɪt, ðə fil ə sʌmwʌn əbaʊt tə tʌtʃ ɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, hi foʊkəs hɪmsɛlf.

Flinn saluted again, but Rand was already striding away, black mud squelching around his boots. No cheers rose for him in the blustering wind. He could recall when there had been. If that was not one of Lews Therin's memories. If Lews Therin had ever been real. A flash of color just beyond the edge of sight, the feel of someone about to touch him from behind. With an effort, he focused himself.

ðə kaʊnsəl tɛnt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪpt pəvɪljən ðət hæd wʌns sæɾ ɑn ðə pleɪnz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ, naʊ pɪtʃt ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ɹændz ɛnkæmpmənt, sɝaʊndəd baɪ θɝɾi peɪsɪz ə bɛɹ ɡɹaʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ nɛvɝ ɡɑɹdz hɪɹ, nɑɾ ənlɛs ɹænd wɑz miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə noʊbəlz. ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə slɪp ɪn wʊɾə bɪn sin ɪnstənli baɪ ə θaʊzən pɹaɪɪŋ aɪz. θɹi bænɝz ɑn tɔl poʊlz fɔɹmd ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ɝaʊn ðə tɛnt, ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ə kɛɹhin, ðə θɹi kɹɛsəns ə tiɹ, ən ðə ɡoʊldən biz ʌv ɪljən, ən əbʌv ðə kɹɪmzən ɹuf, haɪɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst, stʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ, ən ðə bænɝ ə laɪt. ðə wɪn meɪɾ əm ɔl stæn aʊt, ɹɪpəlɪŋ ən snæpɪŋ, ən ðə tɛnt wɔlz ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn ðə ɡʌsts. ɪnsaɪd, kʌlɝfəl, fɹɪn kɑɹpəts meɪɾ ə flɔɹ, ən ði oʊnli fɝnɪtʃɝ wɑz ə hjudʒ teɪbəl, θɪkli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd, ɪnleɪd wɪð aɪvɝi ən tɝkwɔɪz. ə dʒʌmbəl ə mæps ɔlmoʊs hɪd ðə teɪbəltɑp.

The council tent was a large red-striped pavilion that had once sat on the Plains of Maredo, now pitched in the middle of Rand's encampment, surrounded by thirty paces of bare ground. There were never guards here, not unless Rand was meeting with the nobles. Anyone trying to slip in would have been seen instantly by a thousand prying eyes. Three banners on tall poles formed a triangle around the tent, the Rising Sun of Cairhien, the Three Crescents of Tear, and the Golden Bees of Illian, and above the crimson roof, higher than the rest, stood the Dragon Banner, and the Banner of Light. The wind made them all stand out, rippling and snapping, and the tent walls shivered in the gusts. Inside, colorful, fringed carpets made a floor, and the only furniture was a huge table, thickly carved and gilded, inlaid with ivory and turquoise. A jumble of maps almost hid the tabletop.

tɔɹvəl lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛd fɹəm ðə mæps, pleɪnli ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ə hɪz tʌŋ tə huɛvɝ hæd bɑɹdʒd ɪn ɑn hɪm. kloʊs tə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz ən tɔl bɪsaɪɾ ɛniwʌn seɪv ɹænd əɹ ən il, hi stɛɹd koʊldli daʊn ə ʃɑɹp noʊz ðət pɹæktəkli kwɪvɝd wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. ðə dʒɹæɡən ən ðə sɔɹd ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz koʊt kɑlɝ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə stænd-læmps. ə sɪlk koʊt, ʃaɪnɪŋ blæk, kʌt faɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ə lɔɹd. hɪz sɔɹd hæd sɪlvɝ maʊntɪŋz wɑʃt wɪð ɡoʊld, ən ə ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɹɛd dʒɛm kæp ðə hɪlt. ənʌðɝ ɡlim dɑɹkli ɑn ə fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋ. jə kəd nɑt tʃɹeɪn mɛn tə bi wɛpənz wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ʌv ɛɹəɡəns, jɛt ɹænd dɪd nɑt laɪk tɔɹvəl. bʌt ðɛn, hi hæd noʊ niɾ ə luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs tə bi səspɪʃəs ʌv ɛni mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt. haʊ fɑɹ dɪɾ i tʃɹuli tʃɹʌst ivən flɪn? jɛɾ i hæd tə lid ðɛm. ði æʃəmən wɝ ɪz meɪkɪŋ, hɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi.

Torval lifted his head from the maps, plainly ready to give the rough side of his tongue to whoever had barged in on him. Close to his middle years and tall beside anyone save Rand or an Aiel, he stared coldly down a sharp nose that practically quivered with indignation. The Dragon and the Sword glistened on his coat collar in the light of the stand-lamps. A silk coat, shining black, cut fine enough for a lord. His sword had silver mountings washed with gold, and a glittering red gem capped the hilt. Another gleamed darkly on a finger ring. You could not train men to be weapons without expecting a certain amount of arrogance, yet Rand did not like Torval. But then, he had no need of Lews Therin's voice to be suspicious of any man in a black coat. How far did he truly trust even Flinn? Yet he had to lead them. The Asha'man were his making, his responsibility.

wən tɔɹvəl sɔ ɹænd, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd kæʒəwəli ən səluɾəd, bʌɾ ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən bɛɹli tʃeɪnʒd. hi hæd hæɾ ə snɪɹɪŋ maʊð ðə fɝs taɪm ɹænd ɛvɝ sɔ hɪm. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛɾ ɪn ði æksɛns ə tæɹɑbən, ən i maɪɾ əv bɪn ɡɹiɾɪŋ ən ikwəl. əɹ biɪŋ ɡɹeɪʃəs tə ən ɪnfɪɹiɝ. hɪz swæɡɝɪŋ baʊ tʊk ɪn hɑpwəl ən dæʃivə əz wɛl. "aɪ ɡɪv kənɡɹætʃəleɪʃənz ɑn ðə kɑŋkwɛst ʌv ɪljən. ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi, jɛs? ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn waɪn tə ɡɹit ju, bʌt ðɪs jʌŋ . . . dɛɾəkeɪtəd . . . dʌz nɑt sim tə ʌndɝstæn ɔɹɾɝz."

When Torval saw Rand, he straightened casually and saluted, but his expression barely changed. He had had a sneering mouth the first time Rand ever saw him. "My Lord Dragon," he said in the accents of Tarabon, and he might have been greeting an equal. Or being gracious to an inferior. His swaggering bow took in Hopwil and Dashiva as well. "I give congratulations on the conquest of Illian. A great victory, yes? There would have been wine to greet you, but this young . . . Dedicated . . . does not seem to understand orders."

ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɑn ði ɛnz ə nɛɹɪʃməz tu lɔŋ dɑɹk bɹeɪdz meɪɾ ə feɪn saʊn əz i ʃɪftəd. hi hæd tæn dɑɹkli ɪn ðə sʌðɝn sʌn, bʌt səm θɪŋz əbaʊɾ ɪm hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd. oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd, hɪz feɪs meɪɾ ɪm sim jʌŋɡɝ ðən hɑpwəl, bʌt ðə ɹɛd ðət ɹoʊz ɪn ɪz tʃiks wɑz æŋɡɝ, nɑɾ ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. hɪz pɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə nu-wʌn sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ wɑz kwaɪət, jɛt dip. tɔɹvəl smaɪld ət hɪm, ə sloʊ smaɪl boʊθ əmjuzd ən deɪnʒɝəs. dæʃivə læft, ə ʃɔɹt bɑɹk, ən wɑz stɪl.

In the corner, silver bells on the ends of Narishma's two long dark braids made a faint sound as he shifted. He had tanned darkly in the southern sun, but some things about him had not changed. Older than Rand, his face made him seem younger than Hopwil, but the red that rose in his cheeks was anger, not embarrassment. His pride in the new-won Sword on his collar was quiet, yet deep. Torval smiled at him, a slow smile both amused and dangerous. Dashiva laughed, a short bark, and was still.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ, tɔɹvəl?" ɹænd æskt ɹʌfli. hi tɔs ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ən ɪz ɡɔnləts daʊn ətɑp ðə mæps ən fɑloʊɾ əm wɪð ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt ən skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹd. ðə mæps ðət tɔɹvəl hæd noʊ ɹizən tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ. noʊ niɾ ə luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs.

"What are you doing here, Torval?" Rand asked roughly. He tossed the Dragon Scepter and his gauntlets down atop the maps and followed them with his sword belt and scabbarded sword. The maps that Torval had no reason to be studying. No need of Lews Therin's voice.

wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ, tɔɹvəl pɹədust ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən hændəɾ ɪt tə ɹænd. "ðə l, hi sɛn ðɪs." ðə peɪpɝ wɑz snoʊi waɪɾ ən θɪk, ðə sil ə dʒɹæɡən ɪmpɹɛst ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ oʊvəl ə blu wæks ðət ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊldən flɛks. ɪt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪn θɔt tə kʌm fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. teɪm dɪd θɪŋk wɛl ə hɪmsɛlf. "ðə l sɛd tə tɛl jə ðə teɪlz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn mʊɹændi wɪð ən ɑɹmi, ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹu. ɹumɝ sɛz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹəbɛlz əɡɛns tɑɹ vəlɑn" - tɔɹvəlz snɪɹ θɪkənd wɪð dɪsbɪlif - "bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ mɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə blæk taʊɝ. sun, ðeɪ meɪ bɪkʌm ə deɪnʒɝ, jɛs?"

With a shrug, Torval produced a letter from his coat pocket and handed it to Rand. "The M'Hael, he sent this." The paper was snowy white and thick, the seal a dragon impressed in a large oval of blue wax that glittered with golden flecks. It might almost have been thought to come from the Dragon Reborn. Taim did think well of himself. "The M'Hael said to tell you the tales of Aes Sedai in Murandy with an army, they are true. Rumor says they are rebels against Tar Valon" - Torval's sneer thickened with disbelief - "but they are marching toward the Black Tower. Soon, they may become a danger, yes?"

ɹænd kɹæk ðə mæɡnɪfəsən sil tə bɪts bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "ðeɪɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, nɑt ðə blæk taʊɝ, ən ðəɹ noʊ θɹɛt. maɪ ɔɹɾɝz wɝ klɪɹ. liv ɛɛs sədaɪ əloʊn ənlɛs ðeɪ kʌm æftɝ ju."

Rand cracked the magnificent seal to bits between his fingers. "They're going to Caemlyn, not the Black Tower, and they're no threat. My orders were clear. Leave Aes Sedai alone unless they come after you."

"bʌt haʊ kən jə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ə θɹɛt?" tɔɹvəl pɝsɪstəd. "pɝhæps ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, əz jə seɪ, bʌɾ ɪf jə ɑɹ ɹɔŋ, wɪl nɑt noʊ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ətæk ʌs."

"But how can you be sure they are not a threat?" Torval persisted. "Perhaps they are going to Caemlyn, as you say, but if you are wrong, we'll not know before they attack us."

"tɔɹvəl maɪt bi ɹaɪt," dæʃivə pʊɾ ɪn θɔtfəli. "aɪ kæn seɪ aɪd tʃɹʌst wɪmən u pʊt mi ɪn ə bɑks, ən ðiz hævən swɔɹn ɛni oʊðz. əɹ əv ðeɪ?"

"Torval might be right," Dashiva put in thoughtfully. "I can't say I'd trust women who put me in a box, and these haven't sworn any oaths. Or have they?"

"aɪ sɛd liv əm əloʊn!" ɹænd slæp ðə teɪbəltɑp, hɑɹd, ən hɑpwəl dʒʌmpt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. dæʃivə fɹaʊnd wɪð ɪɹɪteɪʃən bɪfɔɹ hɝidli smuðɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ, bʌt ɹænd wɑz nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn dæʃivəz mudz. baɪ tʃæns - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz tʃæns - hɪz hæn hæd kʌm daʊn ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. hɪz ɑɹm tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə teɪk ɪɾ ʌp ən stæb tɔɹvəl θɹu ðə hɑɹt. noʊ nid fəɹ luz θɝɪn əɾ ɔl. "ði æʃəmən ɑɹ ə wɛpən tə bi eɪmd wɛɹ aɪ seɪ, nɑt tə flʌɾɝ ɝaʊn laɪk hɛnz ɛvɹi taɪm teɪm ɡɛts fɹaɪɾənd oʊvɝ ə hændfʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ hævɪŋ dɪnɝ ət ðə seɪm ɪn. ɪf aɪ mʌst, aɪ kən kʌm bæk tə meɪk maɪsɛlf klɪɹɝ."

"I said leave them alone!" Rand slapped the tabletop, hard, and Hopwil jumped in surprise. Dashiva frowned with irritation before hurriedly smoothing it over, but Rand was not interested in Dashiva's moods. By chance - he was sure it was chance - his hand had come down on the Dragon Scepter. His arm trembled with the desire to take it up and stab Torval through the heart. No need for Lews Therin at all. "The Asha'man are a weapon to be aimed where I say, not to flutter around like hens every time Taim gets frightened over a handful of Aes Sedai having dinner at the same inn. If I must, I can come back to make myself clearer."

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ niɾ ə ðæt," tɔɹvəl sɛd kwɪkli. ət læst sʌmθɪŋ hæd waɪp ðə ɹaɪ twɪs fɹəm ɪz maʊθ. aɪz taɪt, hi spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz, kloʊs tə dɪfəɾənt, vɛɹi nɪɹli əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk. ən pleɪnli fɹaɪɾənd. "ðə l, hi mɪɹli wɑntəd jə ɪnfɔɹmd. jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz ɑɹ ɹɛɾ əlaʊɾ ɛvɹi deɪ ət mɔɹnɪŋ daɪɹɛktɪvz, æftɝ ðə kɹid."

"I am sure there is no need of that," Torval said quickly. At last something had wiped the wry twist from his mouth. Eyes tight, he spread his hands, close to diffident, very nearly apologetic. And plainly frightened. "The M'Hael, he merely wanted you informed. Your orders are read aloud every day at Morning Directives, after the Creed."

"ðæts ɡʊd, ðɛn." ɹænd kɛpt ɪz vɔɪs kul, kɛpt ə skaʊl fɹəm ɪz feɪs baɪ meɪn ɛfɝt. ɪt wɑz ɪz pɹɛʃəs l ðə mæn fɪɹd, nɑt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. əfɹeɪd teɪm wəd teɪk ɪɾ əmɪs ɪf sʌmθɪŋ i hæd sɛd bɹɔt ɹændz æŋɡɝ ɑn teɪmz hɛd. "bɪkɔz əl kɪl ɛni wʌn ə jə hu ɡoʊz nɪɹ ðoʊz wɪmən ɪn mʊɹændi. jə kʌt wɛɹ aɪ dɝɛkt."

"That's good, then." Rand kept his voice cool, kept a scowl from his face by main effort. It was his precious M'Hael the man feared, not the Dragon Reborn. Afraid Taim would take it amiss if something he had said brought Rand's anger on Taim's head. "Because I'll kill any one of you who goes near those women in Murandy. You cut where I direct."

tɔɹvəl baʊd ɹɪdʒɪdli, mɝmɝɪŋ, "æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." hɪz tiθ wɝ bɛɹɾ ɪn ən ətɛmptəd smaɪl, bʌɾ ɪz noʊz wɑz pɪntʃt, ən i stʃɹʌɡəl tə əvɔɪd miɾɪŋ ɛniwʌnz aɪz waɪl simɪŋ tə əvɔɪd nʌθɪŋ. dæʃivə jɛlpt ənʌðɝ læf, ən hɑpwəl wɔɹ ə smɔl ɡɹɪn.

Torval bowed rigidly, murmuring, "As you say, my Lord Dragon." His teeth were bared in an attempted smile, but his nose was pinched, and he struggled to avoid meeting anyone's eyes while seeming to avoid nothing. Dashiva yelped another laugh, and Hopwil wore a small grin.

nɛɹɪʃmə wɑz nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ tɔɹvəlz dɪskʌmfɝt, ðoʊ, əɹ peɪɪŋ ɪɾ ətɛnʃən. hi lʊkt ət ɹænd wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ, əz ðoʊ hi sɛns dip kɝəns ðət ðə ɹɛs mɪst. moʊst wɪmən ən noʊ fju mɛn θɔɾ ɪm dʒʌst ə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ, bʌt ðoʊz tu-bɪɡ aɪz səmtaɪmz simd mɔɹ noʊɪŋ ðən ɛni ʌðɝz.

Narishma was not enjoying Torval's discomfort, though, or paying it attention. He looked at Rand without blinking, as though he sensed deep currents that the rest missed. Most women and no few men thought him just a pretty boy, but those too-big eyes sometimes seemed more knowing than any others.

ɹænd pʊld ɪz hæn fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ən smuðd oʊpən ðə lɛɾɝ. hɪz hænz dɪd nɑt kwaɪt ʃeɪk. tɔɹvəl smaɪld wikli, saʊɝli, noʊɾɪsɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. əɡɛns ðə tɛnt wɔl, nɛɹɪʃmə ʃɪftəd, ɹɪlæksɪŋ.

Rand pulled his hand from the Dragon Scepter and smoothed open the letter. His hands did not quite shake. Torval smiled weakly, sourly, noticing nothing. Against the tent wall, Narishma shifted, relaxing.

ðə ɹəfɹɛʃməns ɝaɪvd, ðɛn, bɔɹn baɪ ə steɪtli pɹəsɛʃən fɑloʊɪŋ bɔɹiən, ə laɪn ʌv ɪliɑnɝz ən kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz ɪn ðɛɹ vɛɹiəs lɪvɝiz. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɝvən bɛɹɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ ən pɪtʃɝ fəɹ itʃ kaɪndə waɪn, ən tu mɔɹ wɪð tʃɹeɪz ə sɪlvɝ mʌɡz fəɹ hɑt pʌntʃ ən spaɪst waɪnz ən faɪn bloʊn ɡoʊbləts fəɹ ði ʌðɝz. ə pɪŋk-feɪs fɛloʊ ɪn ɡɹin-ænd-jɛloʊ kæɹiɾ ə tʃɹeɪ ɑn wɪtʃ tə də ðə pɔɹɪŋ, ən ə dɑɹk wʊmən ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld wɑz ðəɹ tə æktʃəli  hændəl ðə pɪtʃɝz. ðəɹ wɝ nʌts ən kændid fɹuts, tʃizɪz ən ɑlɪvz, itʃ sɔɹt ɹikwaɪɝɪŋ ə sɝvɪŋ mæn əɹ wʊmən. ʌndɝ bɔɹiənz dɝɛkʃən, ðeɪ floʊɾ ɪn ə fɔɹməl dæns, boʊɪŋ, kɝtsiɪŋ, wʌn ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə ənʌðɝ əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ ɔfɝɪŋz.

The refreshments arrived, then, borne by a stately procession following Boreane, a line of Illianers and Cairhienin and Tairens in their various liveries. There was a servant bearing a silver tray and pitcher for each kind of wine, and two more with trays of silver mugs for hot punch and spiced wines and fine blown goblets for the others. A pink-faced fellow in green-and-yellow carried a tray on which to do the pouring, and a dark woman in black-and-gold was there to actually handle the pitchers. There were nuts and candied fruits, cheeses and olives, each sort requiring a serving man or woman. Under Boreane's direction, they flowed in a formal dance, bowing, curtsying, one giving way to another as they made their offerings.

æksɛptɪŋ spaɪst waɪn, ɹænd hɔɪstəd hɪmsɛlf ɑntu ði ɛdʒ ə ðə teɪbəl ən sæt ðə stimɪŋ mʌɡ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əntʌtʃt əz i bɪzid hɪmsɛlf wɪð ðə lɛɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ədʒɹɛs, noʊ pɹiæmbəl ʌv ɛni kaɪnd. teɪm heɪɾəd ɡɪvɪŋ ɹænd ɛni sɔɹɾ ə taɪɾəl, ðoʊ hi tʃɹaɪd tə haɪd ðə fækt.

Accepting spiced wine, Rand hoisted himself onto the edge of the table and sat the steaming mug beside him untouched as he busied himself with the letter. There was no address, no preamble of any kind. Taim hated giving Rand any sort of title, though he tried to hide the fact.

aɪ hæv ði ɑnɝ tə ɹipɔɹt ðət twɛnti-naɪn æʃəmən, naɪnti-sɛvən dɛɾəkeɪtəd ən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd twɛnti-tu soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ naʊ ɛnɹoʊld ət ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðəɹ əv bɪn ə hændfʊl ə dɛzɝɾɝz, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, huz neɪmz əv bɪn stʃɹɪkən, bʌt lɔsəz ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn æksɛptəbəl.

I have the honor to report that twenty-nine Asha'man, ninety-seven Dedicated and three hundred twenty-two Soldiers are now enrolled at the Black Tower. There have been a handful of deserters, unfortunately, whose names have been stricken, but losses in training remain acceptable.

aɪ naʊ hæv əz mɛni əz fɪfti ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz ɪn ðə fild əɾ ɛni ɡɪvən taɪm, wɪð ðə ɹɪzʌl ðət θɹi əɹ fɔɹ mɛn ɑɹ æɾəd tə ðə ɹoʊlz ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi deɪ. ɪn ə fju mʌnθs, ðə blæk taʊɝ wɪl ikwəl ðə waɪt, əz aɪ sɛɾ ɪt wʊd. ɪn ə jɪɹ, tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪl tʃɹɛmbəl əɾ əɹ nʌmbɝz.

I now have as many as fifty recruiting parties in the field at any given time, with the result that three or four men are added to the rolls almost every day. In a few months, the Black Tower will equal the White, as I said it would. In a year, Tar Valon will tremble at our numbers.

aɪ hɑɹvəstəd ðət blækbɛɹi bʊʃ maɪsɛlf. ə smɔl bʊʃ, ən θɔɹni, bʌɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ nʌmbɝ ə bɛɹiz fəɹ ðə saɪz.

I harvested that blackberry bush myself. A small bush, and thorny, but a surprising number of berries for the size.

mæzɹim teɪm l ɹænd ɡɹɪməst, pʊɾɪŋ ðə . . . ðə blækbɛɹi bʊʃ . . . aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn, hæd tə bi dʌn. ðə hoʊl wɝl peɪɾ ə pɹaɪs fəɹ ɪz ɛɡzɪstəns. hi wəd daɪ fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ðə hoʊl wɝl peɪd.

Mazrim Taim M'Hael Rand grimaced, putting the . . . the blackberry bush . . . out of his mind. What had to be done, had to be done. The whole world paid a price for his existence. He would die for it, but the whole world paid.

ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ θɪŋz tə ɡɹɪmɑs oʊvɝ, ɛniweɪ. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ nu mɛn ə deɪ? teɪm wɑz ɑptəmɪstɪk. ɪn ə fju mʌnθs, ət ðət ɹeɪt, ðəɹ wəd bi mɔɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃɹu, bʌt ðə nuəst sɪstɝ hæd jɪɹz ə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ən pɑɹɾ ə ðət spəsɪfɪkli tɔt haʊ tə dil wɪð ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə kɑntəmpleɪɾ ɛni ɪnkaʊntɝ bɪtwin æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ feɪsɪŋ; blʌɾ ən ɹəɡɹɛt kəd bi ði oʊnli aʊtkʌm, wʌtɛvɝ hæpənd. ði æʃəmən wɝ nɑɾ eɪmd ət ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðoʊ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt teɪm θɔt. ɪt wɑz ə kənvinjən bɪlif, haʊɛvɝ, ɪf ɪt meɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn stɛp wɛɹəli. ən æʃəmən oʊnli niɾəd tə noʊ haʊ tə kɪl. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf tə də ðəɾ ət ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs ən taɪm, ɪf ðeɪ lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə, ðət wɑz ɔl ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɹieɪɾəd fɔɹ.

There were other things to grimace over, anyway. Three or four new men a day? Taim was optimistic. In a few months, at that rate, there would be more men who could channel than Aes Sedai, true, but the newest sister had years of training behind her. And part of that specifically taught how to deal with a man who could channel. He did not want to contemplate any encounter between Asha'man and Aes Sedai who knew what they were facing; blood and regret could be the only outcome, whatever happened. The Asha'man were not aimed at the White Tower, though, no matter what Taim thought. It was a convenient belief, however, if it made Tar Valon step warily. An Asha'man only needed to know how to kill. If there were enough to do that at the right place and time, if they lived long enough to, that was all they had been created for.

"haʊ mɛni dɛzɝɾɝz, tɔɹvəl?" hi sɛd kwaɪətli. hi pɪkt ʌp ðə waɪn mʌɡ ən tʊk ə swɑloʊ, əz ɪf ði ænsɝ wɝ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə waɪn ʃʊɾə bɪn wɔɹmɪŋ, bʌt ðə dʒɪnʒɝ ən swit sɛɹəl ən meɪs teɪstəd bɪɾɝ ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. "haʊ mɛni lɔsəz ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ?"

"How many deserters, Torval?" he said quietly. He picked up the wine mug and took a swallow, as if the answer were unimportant. The wine should have been warming, but the ginger and sweet serrel and mace tasted bitter on his tongue. "How many losses in training?"

tɔɹvəl wɑz ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ ðə ɹəfɹɛʃməns, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz ən ɑɹtʃɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə tʃɔɪs ʌv waɪnz, meɪkɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt ʃoʊ ʌv noʊɪŋ ðə bɛst, meɪkɪŋ ə ʃoʊ ʌv lɔɹɾɪŋ ɪt. dæʃivə hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðə fɝst ɔfɝd, ən stʊd ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ɪndə hɪz twɪst-stɛmd ɡɑbləɾ əz ðoʊ ɪt hɛl swɪl. pɔɪntɪŋ tə wʌn ə ðə tʃɹeɪz, tɔɹvəl kɑkt ɪz hɛd θɔtfəli, bʌɾ i hæd ðə wɝdz ɹɛɾi ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. "naɪntin dɛzɝɾɝz, soʊ fɑɹ. ðə l, hiz ɔɹɾɝd əm kɪld wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ faʊnd, ən ðɛɹ hɛdz bɹɔt bæk fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəlz." plʌkɪŋ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɡleɪz pɛɹ fɹəm ðə pɹɑfɝd tʃɹeɪ, hi pɑpt ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ ən smaɪl bɹaɪtli. "θɹi hɛdz hæŋ laɪk fɹuɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝz tʃɹi ət ðɪs moʊmənt."

Torval was recovering himself over the refreshments, rubbing his hands and arching an eyebrow at the choice of wines, making a great show of knowing the best, making a show of lording it. Dashiva had accepted the first offered, and stood glowering into his twist-stemmed goblet as though it held swill. Pointing to one of the trays, Torval cocked his head thoughtfully, but he had the words ready on his tongue. "Nineteen deserters, so far. The M'Hael, he has ordered them killed whenever they are found, and their heads brought back for examples." Plucking a bit of glazed pear from the proffered tray, he popped it into his mouth and smiled brightly. "Three heads hang like fruit on the Traitor's Tree at this moment."

"ɡʊd," ɹænd sɛd lɛvəli. mɛn u ɹæn naʊ kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd nɑt tə ɹʌn leɪɾɝ, wən lɪvz dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn əm stændɪŋ. ən ðiz mɛn kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ; ðoʊz fɛloʊz bæk ɑn ðə hɪlz, ɪf ðeɪ ɪskeɪpt ɪn ə bɑɾi, wɝ lɛs deɪnʒɝəs ðən wʌn mæn tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðə tʃɹeɪɾɝz tʃɹi? teɪm wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt wʌn fəɹ neɪmɪŋ θɪŋz. bʌt mɛn niɾəd ðə tʃɹæpɪŋz, ðə sɪmbəlz ən ðə neɪmz, ðə blæk koʊts ən ðə pɪnz, tə hɛlp hoʊld əm təɡɛðɝ. əntɪl ɪt wɑz taɪm tə daɪ. "ðə nɛks taɪm aɪ vɪzət ðə blæk taʊɝ, aɪ wɑnə si ɛvɹi dɛzɝɾɝz hɛd."

"Good," Rand said levelly. Men who ran now could not be trusted not to run later, when lives depended on them standing. And these men could not be allowed to go their own way; those fellows back on the hills, if they escaped in a body, were less dangerous than one man trained in the Black Tower. The Traitor's Tree? Taim was a great one for naming things. But men needed the trappings, the symbols and the names, the black coats and the pins, to help hold them together. Until it was time to die. "The next time I visit the Black Tower, I want to see every deserter's head."

ə sɛkən pis ə kændid pɛɹ, hæfweɪ tə tɔɹvəlz maʊθ, dʒɹɑp fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən stʃɹik ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz faɪn koʊt. "ɪt maɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ, meɪkɪŋ ðət sɔɹɾ ʌv ɛfɝt," hi sɛd sloʊli. "ðə dɛzɝɾɝz, ðeɪ də nɑɾ ənaʊns ðɛmsɛlvz."

A second piece of candied pear, halfway to Torval's mouth, dropped from his fingers and streaked the front of his fine coat. "It might interfere with recruiting, making that sort of effort," he said slowly. "The deserters, they do not announce themselves."

ɹænd hɛl ði ʌðɝ mænz ɡeɪz əntɪl ɪt fɛl. "haʊ mɛni lɔsəz ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ?" hi dɪmændəd. ðə ʃɑɹp-noʊzd æʃəmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "haʊ mɛni?"

Rand held the other man's gaze until it fell. "How many losses in training?" he demanded. The sharp-nosed Asha'man hesitated. "How many?"

nɛɹɪʃmə lin fɔɹwɝd, stɛɹɪŋ ɪntɛnli ət tɔɹvəl. soʊ dɪd hɑpwəl. ðə sɝvəns kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ smuð, saɪlən dæns, ɔfɝɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz tə mɛn u noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɔ ðɛm. bɔɹiən tʊk ædvæntɪdʒ ə nɛɹɪʃməz pɹiɑkjəpeɪʃən tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪz sɪlvɝ mʌɡ hɛl mɔɹ hɑt wɔɾɝ ðən spaɪst waɪn.

Narishma leaned forward, staring intently at Torval. So did Hopwil. The servants continued their smooth, silent dance, offering their trays to men who no longer saw them. Boreane took advantage of Narishma's preoccupation to make sure his silver mug held more hot water than spiced wine.

tɔɹvəl ʃɹʌɡd, tu kæʒəwəli. "fɪfti-wʌn, ɔl toʊld. θɝtin bɝn aʊt, ən twɛnti-eɪt dɛd wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd. ðə ɹɛst. . . . ðə l, hi ædz sʌmθɪŋ tə ðɛɹ waɪn, ən ðeɪ də nɑt weɪk." əbɹʌpli hɪz toʊn tɝn məlɪʃəs. "ɪt kən kʌm sʌɾənli, əɾ ɛni taɪm. wʌn mæn bɪɡæn skɹimɪŋ ðət spaɪɾɝz wɝ kɹɔlɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz skɪn ɑn ɪz sɛkən deɪ." hi smaɪl vɪʃəsli ət nɛɹɪʃmə ən hɑpwəl, ən nɪɹli soʊ ət ɹænd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə ði ʌðɝ tu hi ədʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz hɛd bɪtwin ðɛm. "ju si? nɑt tə wɝi ɪf jə slaɪɾ ɪndə mædnəs. jəl nɑt hɝt jʊɹsɛlvz əɹ ə soʊl. jə ɡoʊ tə slip . . . fɝɛvɝ. kaɪndɝ ðən dʒɛntəlɪŋ, ivən ɪf wi nu haʊ. kaɪndɝ ðən livɪŋ jə ɪnseɪn ən kʌɾ ɔf, jɛs?" nɛɹɪʃmə stɛɹd bæk, tɔɾ əz ə hɑɹpstʃɹɪŋ, hɪz mʌɡ fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ɪz hænd. hɑpwəl wɑz wʌns mɔɹ fɹaʊnɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ oʊnli hi kəd si.

Torval shrugged, too casually. "Fifty-one, all told. Thirteen burned out, and twenty-eight dead where they stood. The rest. . . . The M'Hael, he adds something to their wine, and they do not wake." Abruptly his tone turned malicious. "It can come suddenly, at any time. One man began screaming that spiders were crawling beneath his skin on his second day." He smiled viciously at Narishma and Hopwil, and nearly so at Rand, but it was to the other two he addressed himself, swinging his head between them. "You see? Not to worry if you slide into madness. You'll not hurt yourselves or a soul. You go to sleep . . . forever. Kinder than gentling, even if we knew how. Kinder than leaving you insane and cut off, yes?" Narishma stared back, taut as a harpstring, his mug forgotten in his hand. Hopwil was once more frowning at something only he could see.

"kaɪndɝ," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs, sɛɾɪŋ ðə mʌɡ bæk bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɑn ðə teɪbəl. sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪn. maɪ soʊl ɪz blæk wɪð blʌd, ən dæmd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə hɑɹd θɔt, nɑt baɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɛdʒd; ə sɪmpəl steɪtmən ə fækt. "ə mɝsi ɛni mæn maɪt wɪʃ fɔɹ, tɔɹvəl."

"Kinder," Rand said in a flat voice, setting the mug back beside him on the table. Something in the wine. My soul is black with blood, and damned. It was not a hard thought, not biting or edged; a simple statement of fact. "A mercy any man might wish for, Torval."

tɔɹvəlz kɹuəl smaɪl feɪɾəd, ən i stʊd bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. ðə sʌmz wɝ izi; wʌn mæn ɪn tɛn dɪstʃɹɔɪd, wʌn mæn ɪn fɪfti mæd, ən mɔɹ ʃʊɹli tə kʌm. ɝli deɪz jɛt, ən noʊ weɪ tɪl ðə deɪ jə daɪd tə noʊ jə hæd biɾən ði ɑdz. ɪksɛp ðət ði ɑdz wəd bit ju, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɪn ði ɛnd. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls, tɔɹvəl stʊɾ ʌndɝ ðət θɹɛt, tu.

Torval's cruel smile faded, and he stood breathing hard. The sums were easy; one man in ten destroyed, one man in fifty mad, and more surely to come. Early days yet, and no way till the day you died to know you had beaten the odds. Except that the odds would beat you, one way or another, in the end. Whatever else, Torval stood under that threat, too.

əbɹʌpli ɹænd bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə bɔɹiən. ɪt tʊk ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, ən wən i dɪd, hi bɪt bæk koʊld wɝdz. haʊ dɛɹ ʃi fil pɪɾi! dɪd ʃi θɪŋk tɑɹmən ɡdən kəd bi wʌn wɪθaʊt blʌd? ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən dɪmændəd blʌd laɪk ɹeɪn!

Abruptly Rand became aware of Boreane. It took a moment before he recognized the expression on her face, and when he did, he bit back cold words. How dare she feel pity! Did she think Tarmon Gai'don could be won without blood? The Prophecies of the Dragon demanded blood like rain!

"liv ʌs," hi toʊl hɝ, ən ʃi kwaɪətli ɡæðɝd ðə sɝvəns. bʌt ʃi stɪl kæɹid kəmpæʃən ɪn əɹ aɪz əz ʃi hɝɾɪd əm aʊt.

"Leave us," he told her, and she quietly gathered the servants. But she still carried compassion in her eyes as she herded them out.

kæstɪŋ ɝaʊn fəɹ ə weɪ tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə mud, ɹænd faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. pɪɾi wikən əz ʃʊɹli əz fɪɹ, ən ðeɪ hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ. tə feɪs wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə feɪs, ðeɪ ɔl mʌs bi stil. hɪz meɪkɪŋ, hɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi.

Casting around for a way to change the mood, Rand found nothing. Pity weakened as surely as fear, and they had to be strong. To face what they had to face, they all must be steel. His making, his responsibility.

lɔst ɪn ɪz oʊn θɔts, nɛɹɪʃmə pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə stim ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪz waɪn, ən hɑpwəl stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə stɛɹ θɹu ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt. tɔɹvəl kæst saɪdweɪz ɡlænsɪz ət ɹænd ən stʃɹʌɡəl tə pʊt ðə skɔɹnfəl twɪs bæk ɑn ɪz maʊθ. dæʃivə əloʊn əpɪɹɾ ʌnəfɛktɪd, wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd, stʌɾiɪŋ tɔɹvəl əz ə mæn maɪt stʌɾi ə hɔɹs ɔfɝd fəɹ seɪl.

Lost in his own thoughts, Narishma peered into the steam rising from his wine, and Hopwil still tried to stare through the side of the tent. Torval cast sideways glances at Rand and struggled to put the scornful twist back on his mouth. Dashiva alone appeared unaffected, with his arms folded, studying Torval as a man might study a horse offered for sale.

ɪndə ðə peɪnfəli stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ saɪləns bɝst ə hʌski, wɪnbloʊn jʌŋ mæn ɪn blæk, wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ. ʌv ən eɪdʒ wɪð hɑpwəl, stɪl nɑɾ oʊld ɪnʌf tə mɛɹi moʊs pleɪsəz, fɛdwɪn mɔɹ wɔɹ ɪntɛnsəɾi mɔɹ kloʊsli ðən ɪz ʃɝt; hi muvd ɑn ɪz toʊz, ən ɪz aɪz hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ kæt ðət nu ɪtsɛlf hʌntəɾ ɪn tɝn. hi hæd bɪn dɪfɹənt, wʌns, ən nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. "ðə sintʃæn wɪl muv fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ sun," hi sɛɾ əz i səluɾəd. "ðeɪ min tə kʌm əɡɛnst ɪljən nɛkst." hɑpwəl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ə ɡæsp, dʒoʊltɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz dɑɹk stʌɾi. wʌns əɡɛn, dæʃivəz ɹɪspɑns wɑz tə læf, mɝθləsli ðɪs taɪm.

Into the painfully stretching silence burst a husky, windblown young man in black, with the Sword and Dragon on his collar. Of an age with Hopwil, still not old enough to marry most places, Fedwin Morr wore intensity more closely than his shirt; he moved on his toes, and his eyes had the look of a hunting cat that knew itself hunted in turn. He had been different, once, and not so long ago. "The Seanchan will move from Ebou Dar soon," he said as he saluted. "They mean to come against Illian next." Hopwil gave a start and a gasp, jolted out of his dark study. Once again, Dashiva's response was to laugh, mirthlessly this time.

nɑɾɪŋ, ɹænd tʊk ʌp ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. æftɝ ɔl, hi kæɹiɾ ɪt fəɹ ɹimɛmbɹəns. ðə sintʃæn dæns tə ðɛɹ oʊn tun, nɑt ðə sɔŋ i wɪʃt fɔɹ.

Nodding, Rand took up the Dragon Scepter. After all, he carried it for remembrance. The Seanchan danced to their own tune, not the song he wished for.

ɪf ɹænd ɹəsiv ði ənaʊnsmən ɪn saɪləns, tɔɹvəl dɪd nɑt. faɪndɪŋ ɪz snɪɹ, hi ɹeɪzd ə kəntɛmptʃuəs aɪbɹaʊ. "dɪd ðeɪ tɛl jə ɔl ðæt, naʊ?" hi sɛd mɑkəŋli. "ɔɹ əv jə lɝn tə ɹid maɪnz? lemi tɛl jə sʌmθɪŋ, bɔɪ. aɪ hæv fɔt, əɡɛnst ɑmɑdɪʃənz ən dəmɑni boʊθ, ən noʊ ɑɹmi teɪks ə sɪɾi ðən pæks ɪtsɛlf ʌp tə mɑɹtʃ ə θaʊzən maɪlz! mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən maɪlz! əɹ dʒju θɪŋk ðeɪ kən tʃɹævəl?"

If Rand received the announcement in silence, Torval did not. Finding his sneer, he raised a contemptuous eyebrow. "Did they tell you all that, now?" he said mockingly. "Or have you learned to read minds? Let me tell you something, boy. I have fought, against Amadicians and Domani both, and no army takes a city then packs itself up to march a thousand miles! More than a thousand miles! Or do you think they can Travel?"

mɔɹ mɛt tɔɹvəlz dɝɪʒən kɑmli. əɹ ɪf ɪɾ ənsɛɾəld ɪm əɾ ɔl, ði oʊnli saɪn i ɡeɪv wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ ə θʌm daʊn ɪz lɔŋ sɔɹd hɪlt. "aɪ dɪd tɔk tə səm ə ðɛm. moʊst wɝ tæɹɑbənɝz, ən mɔɹ lændɪŋ baɪ ʃɪp ɛvɹi deɪ, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf." ʃoʊldɝɪŋ pæs tɔɹvəl tə ðə teɪbəl, hi feɪvɝd ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wɪð ə lɛvəl lʊk. "ɔl stɛpɪŋ ɹaɪt kwɪk wɛnɛvɝ ɛnibəɾi wɪð ə slɝɪŋ weɪ ʌv spitʃ oʊpən ə maʊθ." ði oʊldɝ mæn oʊpən hɪz, æŋɡɹəli, bʌt ðə jʌŋɡɝ pɹɛst ɑn hɝidli, tə ɹænd. "ðeɪɹ pʊɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz ɔl əlɔŋ ðə vɛnɪɹ maʊntənz. faɪv hʌnʒɹəd, səmtaɪmz ə θaʊzən təɡɛðɝ. ɔl ðə weɪ tə ɹən hɛɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ən ðəɹ baɪɪŋ əɹ teɪkɪŋ ɛvɹi wæɡən ən kɑɹt wɪðɪn twɛnti liɡz ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ði ænəməlz tə dʒɹɔ ðɛm."

Morr met Torval's derision calmly. Or if it unsettled him at all, the only sign he gave was running a thumb down his long sword hilt. "I did talk to some of them. Most were Taraboners, and more landing by ship every day, or near enough." Shouldering past Torval to the table, he favored the Taraboner with a level look. "All stepping right quick whenever anybody with a slurring way of speech opened a mouth." The older man opened his, angrily, but the younger pressed on hurriedly, to Rand. "They're putting soldiers all along the Venir Mountains. Five hundred, sometimes a thousand together. All the way to Arran Head already. And they're buying or taking every wagon and cart within twenty leagues of Ebou Dar, and the animals to draw them."

"kɑɹts!" tɔɹvəl ɪkskleɪmd. "wæɡənz! ɪz ɪt ðət ðeɪ min tə hoʊld ə mɑɹkət fɛɹ, dʒju θɪŋk? ən wʌt ful wəd mɑɹtʃ ən ɑɹmi θɹu maʊntənz wən ðəɹ ɑɹ pɝfəkli ɡʊd ɹoʊdz?" hi noʊɾəst ɹænd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ən kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə smɔl fɹaʊn, sʌɾənli ənsɝɾən.

"Carts!" Torval exclaimed. "Wagons! Is it that they mean to hold a market fair, do you think? And what fool would march an army through mountains when there are perfectly good roads?" He noticed Rand watching him, and cut off with a small frown, suddenly uncertain.

"aɪ toʊl jə tə steɪ loʊ, mɔɹ." ɹænd lɛɾ æŋɡɝ tʌtʃ ɪz vɔɪs. ðə jʌŋ æʃəmən hæd tə stɛp bæk əz i dʒʌmp daʊn fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. "nɑt tə ɡoʊ æskɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ðɛɹ plænz. tə lʊk ən steɪ loʊ."

"I told you to stay low, Morr." Rand let anger touch his voice. The young Asha'man had to step back as he jumped down from the table. "Not to go asking the Seanchan their plans. To look and stay low."

"aɪ wɑz kɛɹfəl; aɪ dɪdnt wɛɹ maɪ pɪnz." mɔɹz aɪz dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ɹænd, stɪl hʌntɝ ən hʌntəɾ ɪn wʌn. hi sim tə bi bɔɪlɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. hæd ɹænd nɑt noʊn bɛɾɝ, hi wʊɾə θɔt mɔɹ hɛl ðə paʊɝ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə sɝvaɪv seɪɾɪn ivən əz ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm laɪf tɛn taɪmz oʊvɝ. hɪz feɪs sim tə wɑnə swɛt. "ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə mɛn aɪ tɔk tə nu wɛɹ ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ nɛkst, ðeɪ dɪdn seɪ, ən aɪ dɪdn æsk, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə kəmpleɪn oʊvɝ ə mʌɡ ʌv eɪl əbaʊt mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɔl ðə taɪm ən nɛvɝ stændɪŋ stɪl. ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðeɪ wɝ soʊkɪŋ ʌp ɔl ði eɪl ɪn ðə sɪɾi əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd, kəz ðeɪ seɪ ðeɪv tə mɑɹtʃ əɡɛn. ən ðəɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ wæɡənz, dʒʌs laɪk aɪ sɛd." ðəɾ ɔl keɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ, ən i klæmpt ɪz tiθ ət ði ɛn əz ðoʊ tə tʃɹæp mɔɹ wɝdz ðət wɑntəd tə flaɪ fɹəm ɪz tʌŋ.

"I was careful; I didn't wear my pins." Morr's eyes did not change for Rand, still hunter and hunted in one. He seemed to be boiling inside. Had Rand not known better, he would have thought Morr held the Power, struggling to survive saidin even as it gave him life ten times over. His face seemed to want to sweat. "If any of the men I talked to knew where they're going next, they didn't say, and I didn't ask, but they were willing to complain over a mug of ale about marching all the time and never standing still. In Ebou Dar, they were soaking up all the ale in the city as fast as they could, because they say they have to march again. And they're gathering wagons, just like I said." That all came out in a rush, and he clamped his teeth at the end as though to trap more words that wanted to fly from his tongue.

smaɪlɪŋ sʌɾənli, ɹænd klæpt ɪm ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "ju dɪd wɛl. ðə wæɡənz wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf, bʌt jə dɪd wɛl. wæɡənz ɑɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt," hi æɾəd, tɝnɪŋ tə tɔɹvəl. "ɪf ən ɑɹmi fidz ɔf ðə kʌntʃɹi, ɪɾ its wʌɾ ɪt faɪnz. əɹ nɑt, ɪf ɪt dʌznt." tɔɹvəl hæd nɑt flɪkɝɾ ən aɪləɾ ət hɪɹɪŋ ə sintʃæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ɪf ðət teɪl hæd ɹitʃt ðə blæk taʊɝ, waɪ hæd teɪm nɑt mɛnʃən ɪt? ɹænd hoʊpt ɪz smaɪl dɪd nɑt lʊk ə snɑɹl. "ɪts hɑɹɾɝ tə ɝeɪnʒ səplaɪ tʃɹeɪnz, bʌt wən juv wʌn jə noʊ ðɛɹz fɑɾɝ fəɹ ði ænəməlz ən binz fəɹ ðə mɛn. ðə sintʃæn ɔɹɡənaɪz ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Smiling suddenly, Rand clapped him on the shoulder. "You did well. The wagons would have been enough, but you did well. Wagons are important," he added, turning to Torval. "If an army feeds off the country, it eats what it finds. Or not, if it doesn't." Torval had not flickered an eyelid at hearing of Seanchan in Ebou Dar. If that tale had reached the Black Tower, why had Taim not mentioned it? Rand hoped his smile did not look a snarl. "It's harder to arrange supply trains, but when you have one you know there's fodder for the animals and beans for the men. The Seanchan organize everything."

sɔɹɾɪŋ θɹu ðə mæps, hi faʊn ðə wʌn i wɑntəɾ ən spɹɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt, weɪɾɪd ət wʌn saɪd wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ət ði ʌðɝ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. ðə koʊs bɪtwin ɪljən ən ɛbu dɑɹ stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm, ɹɪm fəɹ moʊst ʌv ɪts lɛŋθ baɪ hɪlz ən maʊntənz, dɑɾəd wɪð fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒəz ən smɔl taʊnz. ðə sintʃæn dɪɾ ɔɹɡənaɪz. ɛbu dɑɹ hæd bɪn ðɛɹz bɛɹli mɔɹ ðən ə wik, bʌt ðə mɝtʃəns' aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɹoʊɾ ə ɹɪpɛɹz wɛl ʌndɝ weɪ ɑn ðə dæmədʒ dʌn tə ðə sɪɾi ɪn ɪts teɪkɪŋ, ʌv klin sɪk-haʊsəz sɛɾ ʌp fəɹ ði ɪl, ʌv fuɾ ən wɝk ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ ðə pʊɹ ən ðoʊz dʒɹɪvən fɹəm ðɛɹ hoʊmz baɪ tʃɹʌbəlz ɪnlænd. ðə stʃɹits ən ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹisaɪd wɝ pətʃɹoʊl soʊ ðət noʊ wʌn nid fɪɹ fʊtpædz əɹ bændəts, deɪ əɹ naɪt, ən waɪl mɝtʃəns wɝ wɛlkəm, smʌɡəlɪŋ hæd bɪn kʌt tə ə tʃɹɪkəl ɪf nɑt lɛs. ðoʊz ɑnəst ɪliɑnɝ mɝtʃəns hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ɡlʌm əbaʊt ðə smʌɡəlɪŋ. wʌt wɝ ðə sintʃæn ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ naʊ?

Sorting through the maps, he found the one he wanted and spread it out, weighted at one side with his sword and at the other with the Dragon Scepter. The coast between Illian and Ebou Dar stared up at him, rimmed for most of its length by hills and mountains, dotted with fishing villages and small towns. The Seanchan did organize. Ebou Dar had been theirs barely more than a week, but the merchants' eyes-and-ears wrote of repairs well under way on the damage done to the city in its taking, of clean sick-houses set up for the ill, of food and work arranged for the poor and those driven from their homes by troubles inland. The streets and the surrounding countryside were patrolled so that no one need fear footpads or bandits, day or night, and while merchants were welcome, smuggling had been cut to a trickle if not less. Those honest Illianer merchants had been surprisingly glum about the smuggling. What were the Seanchan organizing now?

ði ʌðɝz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl əz ɹænd pɝuz ðə mæp. ðəɹ wɝ ɹoʊdz hɑɹɾ əlɔŋ ðə koʊst, bʌt pʊɹ stʃɹæɡəlɪŋ θɪŋz, mɑɹkt əz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən kɑɹt pæðz. ðə bɹɔd tʃɹeɪd ɹoʊdz leɪ ɪnlænd, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə wɝst ə ðə tɝeɪn ən ðə wɝst ʌv wʌt ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz hæd tə ɔfɝ. "mɛn ɹeɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðoʊz maʊntənz kəd meɪk pæsədʒ dɪfəkəl fəɹ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz ði ɪnlæn ɹoʊdz," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "baɪ kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə maʊntənz, ðeɪ meɪk ðə ɹoʊdz seɪf əz ə sɪɾi stʃɹit. jəɹ ɹaɪt, mɔɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ tə ɪljən."

The others gathered around the table as Rand perused the map. There were roads hard along the coast, but poor straggling things, marked as little more than cart paths. The broad trade roads lay inland, avoiding the worst of the terrain and the worst of what the Sea of Storms had to offer. "Men raiding out of those mountains could make passage difficult for anyone trying to use the inland roads," he said finally. "By controlling the mountains, they make the roads safe as a city street. You're right, Morr. They are coming to Illian."

linɪŋ ɑn ɪz fɪsts, tɔɹvəl ɡlɛɹɾ ət mɔɹ, hu hæd bɪn ɹaɪt wən i wɑz ɹɔŋ. ə ɡɹivəs sɪn, pɝhæps, ɪn tɔɹvəlz bʊk. "ivən soʊ, ɪɾəl bi mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən tʃɹʌbəl jə hɪɹ," hi sɛd sʌlənli. "ə hʌnʒɹəd æʃəmən, fɪfti, pleɪst ɪn ɪljən, kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɛni ɑɹmi ɪn ðə wɝl bɪfɔɹ wʌn mæn kɹɔsɪz ðə kɔzweɪz."

Leaning on his fists, Torval glared at Morr, who had been right when he was wrong. A grievous sin, perhaps, in Torval's book. "Even so, it will be months before they can trouble you here," he said sullenly. "A hundred Asha'man, fifty, placed in Illian, could destroy any army in the world before one man crosses the causeways."

"aɪ daʊɾ ən ɑɹmi wɪð deɪmeɪn ɪz dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əz izəli əz wʌn kɪlz il kəmɪɾəd tə ən ətæk ən kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli, ən tɔɹvəl stɪfənd. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪ hæv tə dɪfɛn ɔl ʌv ɪljən, nɑt dʒʌs ðə sɪɾi."

"I doubt an army with damane is destroyed as easily as one kills Aiel committed to an attack and caught by surprise," Rand said quietly, and Torval stiffened. "Besides, I have to defend all of Illian, not just the city."

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə mæn, ɹænd tʃɹeɪs laɪnz əkɹɔs ðə mæp wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. bɪtwin ɹən hɛɾ ən ðə sɪɾi ʌv ɪljən leɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz ʌv oʊpən wɔɾɝ, əkɹɔs ðə maʊθ ə kɑbəl dip, wɛɹ, ʃɪp kæptənz ɪn ɪljən sɛd, ðɛɹ lɔŋɡəst saʊndɪŋ laɪnz kəd faɪnd noʊ bɑɾəm dʒʌst ə maɪl əɹ soʊ fɹəm ðə ʃɔɹ. ðə weɪvz ðəɹ kəɾ oʊvɝtɝn ʃɪps əz ðeɪ sɝdʒ nɔɹθ tə paʊn ðə koʊst wɪð bɹeɪkɝz fɪftin peɪsɪz haɪ. ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ, ɪt wəd bi wɝs. mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə dip wɑz ə ɹuɾ ə tu hʌnʒɹəd liɡz tə ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi, ivən kipɪŋ tə ðə ʃɔɹɾɪst weɪz, bʌɾ ɪf ðə sintʃæn pɹɛst ɑn fɹəm ɹən hɛd, ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪn tu wiks dɪspaɪt ðə ɹeɪnstɔɹmz. meɪbi lɛs. bɛɾɝ tə faɪt wɛɹ i tʃoʊz, nɑt wɛɹ ðeɪ dɪd. hɪz fɪŋɡɝ slɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə saʊθ koʊst ʌv ɔltɑɹə, əlɔŋ ðə vɛnɪɹ ɹeɪnʒ, əntɪl ðə maʊntənz dwɪndəl tə hɪlz ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. faɪv hʌnʒɹəd hɪɹ, ə θaʊzən ðɛɹ. ə tæntəlaɪzɪŋ stʃɹɪŋ ə bidz dʒɹɑpt əlɔŋ ðə maʊntənz. ə ʃɑɹp ɹæp maɪt ɹoʊl əm bæk tə ɛbu dɑɹ, maɪɾ ivən pɛn əm ðəɹ waɪl ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌɾ i wɑz ʌp tə. ɔɹ. . . .

Ignoring the man, Rand traced lines across the map with a finger. Between Arran Head and the city of Illian lay a hundred leagues of open water, across the mouth of Kabal Deep, where, ship captains in Illian said, their longest sounding lines could find no bottom just a mile or so from the shore. The waves there could overturn ships as they surged north to pound the coast with breakers fifteen paces high. In this weather, it would be worse. Marching around the Deep was a route of two hundred leagues to reach the city, even keeping to the shortest ways, but if the Seanchan pressed on from Arran Head, they could reach the border in two weeks despite the rainstorms. Maybe less. Better to fight where he chose, not where they did. His finger slid along the south coast of Altara, along the Venir range, until the mountains dwindled to hills short of Ebou Dar. Five hundred here, a thousand there. A tantalizing string of beads dropped along the mountains. A sharp rap might roll them back to Ebou Dar, might even pen them there while they tried to figure out what he was up to. Or. . . .

"ðɛɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls," mɔɹ sɛɾ əbɹʌpli, ɹʌʃɪŋ əɡɛn. "ðɛɹ wɑz tɔk əbaʊt səm sɔɹɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛpən. aɪ faʊnd wɛɹ ɪt wɑz juzd, ə fju maɪlz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz ɔl bɝn oʊvɝ, sɪɹd klin ɪn ðə mɪɾəl, ə ɡʊd θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz waɪɾ əɹ mɔɹ, ən ɹuən ɔɹtʃɝdz fɝðɝ. ðə sænd wɑz mɛltəd tə ʃits ʌv ɡlæs. seɪɾɪn wɑz wɝst, ðɛɹ."

"There was something else," Morr said abruptly, rushing again. "There was talk about some sort of Aes Sedai weapon. I found where it was used, a few miles from the city. The ground was all burned over, seared clean in the middle, a good three hundred paces wide or more, and ruined orchards further. The sand was melted to sheets of glass. Saidin was worst, there."

tɔɹvəl weɪvd ə hæn əɾ ɪm dɪsmɪsɪvli. "ðɛɹ cʊɾə bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ nɪɹ wən ðə sɪɾi fɛl, jɛs? əɹ meɪbi ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz dɪɾ ɪt. wʌn sɪstɝ wɪð ən æŋɡɹil kəd - "

Torval waved a hand at him dismissively. "There could have been Aes Sedai near when the city fell, yes? Or maybe the Seanchan themselves did it. One sister with an angreal could - "

ɹænd kʌɾ ɪn. "wʌt dʒju min, seɪɾɪn wɑz wɝs ðɛɹ?" dæʃivə muvd, aɪɪŋ mɔɹ ɑdli, ɹitʃɪŋ əz ðoʊ tə siz ðə jʌŋ mæn. ɹænd fɛndɪɾ ɪm ɔf ɹʌfli. "wʌt dʒju min, mɔɹ?"

Rand cut in. "What do you mean, saidin was worst there?" Dashiva moved, eyeing Morr oddly, reaching as though to seize the young man. Rand fended him off roughly. "What do you mean, Morr?"

mɔɹ stɛɹd, maʊθ ʃʌt taɪt, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz θʌm ʌp ən daʊn ðə lɛŋθ ə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ðə hiɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪm simd ɹɛɾi tə bɝst aʊt. ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz swɛt biɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs naʊ. "seɪɾɪn wɑz . . . stʃɹeɪnʒ," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. hɪz wɝdz keɪm ɪn ɹæpəd bɝsts. "wɝs ðəɹ - aɪ kəd . . . fil ɪt . . . ɪn ði ɛɹ ɔl ɝaʊn mi - bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒ ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ. ən ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əweɪ. aɪ hæd tə faɪɾ ɪt; nɑt laɪk ɔlweɪz; dɪfɹənt. laɪk ɪt wɑz əlaɪv. səmtaɪmz. . . . səmtaɪmz, ɪt dɪdn də wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd. səmtaɪmz, ɪt . . . dɪd sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ɪt dɪd. aɪm nɑt mæd! ɪt dɪd!" ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd, haʊlɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃɪvɝɪŋ ən snæpɪŋ ðə tɛnt wɔlz, ən mɔɹ fɛl saɪlənt. nɛɹɪʃməz bɛlz tʃaɪmd əɾ ə dʒɝk ə hɪz hɛd, ðən wɝ stɪl.

Morr stared, mouth shut tight, running his thumb up and down the length of his sword hilt. The heat inside of him seemed ready to burst out. There really was sweat beading on his face now. "Saidin was . . . strange," he said hoarsely. His words came in rapid bursts. "Worst there - I could . . . feel it . . . in the air all around me - but strange everywhere around Ebou Dar. And even a hundred miles away. I had to fight it; not like always; different. Like it was alive. Sometimes. . . . Sometimes, it didn't do what I wanted. Sometimes, it . . . did something else. It did. I'm not mad! It did!" The wind gusted, howling for a moment, shivering and snapping the tent walls, and Morr fell silent. Narishma's bells chimed at a jerk of his head, then were still.
