Flinging back her delicately embroidered cloak to reveal the narrow blue stole of the Keeper, Sheriam made Egwene as much of a formal curtsy as her bulky garments allowed before taking a place at her side. Wrapped in layers of fine wool and silk, the flame-haired woman was the very picture of equanimity. At Egwene's nod, she took one step forward to intone the ancient formula in a clear, high voice.

"ʃi kʌmz; ʃi kʌmz! ðə wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ətɛn jə ɔl, fəɹ ʃi kʌmz!" ɪt simd ə lɪɾəl aʊɾ ə pleɪs hɪɹ, ən bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, nɑt kʌmɪŋ. ðə sɪɾɝz stʊɾ ɪn saɪləns, weɪɾɪŋ. ə fju fɹaʊn ɪmpeɪʃənli, əɹ fɪɾəld ɹɛsləsli wɪð kloʊks əɹ skɝts.

"She comes; she comes! The Watcher of the Seals, the Flame of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat. Attend you all, for she comes!" It seemed a little out of place here, and besides, she was already there, not coming. The Sitters stood in silence, waiting. A few frowned impatiently, or fiddled restlessly with cloaks or skirts.

ɛɡwin pʊʃt bæk əɹ oʊn kloʊk, ənkʌvɝɪŋ ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl dʒɹeɪpt ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ðiz wɪmən niɾəd ɛni ɹimaɪndɝ ʃi kəd ɡɪv ðət ʃi wɑz ɪndid ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. "ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz wɪɹi fɹəm tʃɹævəl ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ," ʃi ənaʊnst, nɑt kwaɪt soʊ laʊdli əz ʃɛɹiəm, bʌt laʊɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd hɪɹ. ʃi fɛlt ə tɪŋɡəl ʌv æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ən ɔlmoʊs laɪt-hɛɾəd θɹɪl. ɪt wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm biɪŋ kwizi. "aɪ hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stɑp hɪɹ fəɹ tu deɪz, pɝhæps θɹi." ðət bɹɔt hɛdz ʌp ən spɑɹkt ɪntʃɹəst. ʃi hoʊp sɪuən wɑz ɪn ðə lɪsnɪŋ kɹaʊd. ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊl tə ði oʊðz. "ðə hɔɹsəz nid ɹɛst, tu, ən mɛni ʌv ðə wæɡənz bædli nid ɹɪpɛɹz. ðə kipɝ wɪl si tə ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɝeɪnʒmənts." ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz bɪɡʌn, naʊ.

Egwene pushed back her own cloak, uncovering the seven-striped stole draped around her neck. These women needed any reminder she could give that she was indeed the Amyrlin Seat. "Everyone is weary from travel in this weather," she announced, not quite so loudly as Sheriam, but loud enough that everyone could hear. She felt a tingle of anticipation, an almost light-headed thrill. It was not much different from being queasy. "I have decided to stop here for two days, perhaps three." That brought heads up and sparked interest. She hoped Siuan was in the listening crowd. She did try to hold to the Oaths. "The horses need rest, too, and many of the wagons badly need repairs. The Keeper will see to the necessary arrangements." It truly was begun, now.

ʃi ɪkspɛktəd niðɝ ɑɹɡjəmənt nɔɹ dɪskʌʃən, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌn. wʌt ʃi hæd toʊl sɪuən wɑz noʊ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃən. tu mɛni sɪstɝz hoʊp fəɹ ə mɪɹəkəl, soʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv tə mɑɹtʃ ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð ðə wɝld wɑtʃɪŋ. ivən əmʌŋ ðoʊz kənvɪnst ɪn ðɛɹ soʊlz ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə mʌs bi aʊstɪd fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ hæd dʌn, tu mɛni wəd ɡɹæsp ɛni tʃæns ə dɪleɪ, ɛni tʃæns fəɹ ðət mɪɹəkəl tə əpɪɹ.

She expected neither argument nor discussion, and there was none. What she had told Siuan was no exaggeration. Too many sisters hoped for a miracle, so they would not have to march on Tar Valon with the world watching. Even among those convinced in their souls that Elaida must be ousted for the good of the Tower, despite everything they had done, too many would grasp any chance of delay, any chance for that miracle to appear.

wʌn ə ðoʊz læst, ɹoʊmændə, dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ʃɛɹiəm tə spik ðə kloʊzɪŋ laɪnz. əz sun əz ɛɡwin fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ, ɹoʊmændə, lʊkɪŋ kwaɪt juθfəl wɪð əɹ taɪt ɡɹeɪ bʌn hɪɾən baɪ hɝ hʊd, sɪmpli stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ. kloʊks flæpɪŋ, mæɡlə, sɛɝɔɪjə, ən vɛɹɪlɪn skɝiɾ æftɝ hɝ. əz wɛl əz ɛniwʌn kəd skɝi, wən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ stɛp sæŋk æŋkəl-dip. ðeɪ dɪɾ ə ɡʊd dʒɑb ʌv ɪɾ ɛniweɪ; sɪɾɝz əɹ noʊ, ðeɪ hɑɹdli sim tə bɹið wɪθaʊt ɹoʊmændəz pɝmɪʃən. wən ləleɪn sɔ ɹoʊmændə livɪŋ, ʃi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp feɪsɛl, tɑkimə, ən laɪɹɛl fɹəm ðə sɛmɪsɝkəl wɪð ə dʒɛstʃɝ ən wɛnt wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝd ɡlæns, laɪk ə swɑn wɪð θɹi æŋkʃəs ɡɑsəlɪŋz. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt soʊ fɝmli ɪn ləleɪnz ɡɹæsp əz ði ʌðɝ θɹi wɝ ɪn ɹoʊmændəz, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt fɔl fɑɹ ʃɔɹt. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɪɾɝz bɛɹli weɪɾəd ɑn ðə faɪnəl "dɪpɑɹt naʊ ɪn ðə laɪt" tə liv ʃɛɹiəmz lɪps. ɛɡwin tɝn tə ɡoʊ wɪð əɹ hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɔlɹɛɾi skæɾɝɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ðət tɪŋɡəl wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ. ən vɛɹi laɪk biɪŋ kwizi.

One of those last, Romanda, did not wait for Sheriam to speak the closing lines. As soon as Egwene finished speaking, Romanda, looking quite youthful with her tight gray bun hidden by her hood, simply strode away. Cloaks flapping, Magla, Saroiya, and Varilin scurried after her. As well as anyone could scurry, when every other step sank ankle-deep. They did a good job of it anyway; Sitters or no, they hardly seemed to breathe without Romanda's permission. When Lelaine saw Romanda leaving, she gathered up Faiselle, Takima, and Lyrelle from the semicircle with a gesture and went without a backward glance, like a swan with three anxious goslings. If they were not so firmly in Lelaine's grasp as the other three were in Romanda's, they did not fall far short. For that matter, the rest of the Sitters barely waited on the final "Depart now in the Light" to leave Sheriam's lips. Egwene turned to go with her Hall of the Tower already scattering in every direction. That tingle was stronger. And very like being queasy.

"θɹi deɪz," ʃɛɹiəm mɝmɝd, ɔfɝɪŋ ɛɡwin ə hæn tə hɛlp əɹ daʊn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə ɹʌɾɪd pæðz. ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ tɪltəd ɡɹin aɪz kɹɪŋkəl kwɪtsɪkli. "aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd, mʌðɝ. fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt jə dʌɡ ɪn jəɹ hilz nɪɹli ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ wɑntəd tə stɑp fəɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn."

"Three days," Sheriam murmured, offering Egwene a hand to help her down into one of the rutted paths. The corners of her tilted green eyes crinkled quizzically. "I'm surprised, Mother. Forgive me, but you dug in your heels nearly every time I wanted to stop for more than one."

"spik tə mi əɡɛn æftɝ juv tɔk tə ðə wilɹaɪts ən fɛɹiɝz," ɛɡwin toʊl hɝ. "wil nɑt ɡoʊ fɑɹ wɪð hɔɹsəz dʒɹɑpɪŋ dɛɾ ən wæɡənz fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹt."

"Speak to me again after you've talked to the wheelwrights and farriers," Egwene told her. "We'll not go far with horses dropping dead and wagons falling apart."

"æz jə seɪ, mʌðɝ," ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd, nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli mikli, bʌɾ ɪn pɝfəkt æksɛptəns.

"As you say, Mother," the other woman replied, not precisely meekly, but in perfect acceptance.

ðə fʊɾɪŋ wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ naʊ ðən ɪt hæd bɪn ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, ən ðɛɹ stɛps səmtaɪmz slɪd. lɪŋkɪŋ ɑɹmz, ðeɪ wɔkt ɑn sloʊli. ʃɛɹiəm ɔfɝd mɔɹ səpɔɹt ðən ɛɡwin ɹikwaɪɝd, bʌt ʃi dɪd soʊ ɔlmoʊst sɝəptɪʃəsli. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ʃəd nɑt fɔl ɑn əɹ bɑɾəm ɪn ðə fʊl vju ʌv fɪfti sɪstɝz ən ə hʌnʒɹəd sɝvəns, bʌt niðɝ ʃəd ʃi sim pɹɑpt ʌp laɪk ən ɪnvələd.

The footing was no better now than it had been the night before, and their steps sometimes slid. Linking arms, they walked on slowly. Sheriam offered more support than Egwene required, but she did so almost surreptitiously. The Amyrlin Seat should not fall on her bottom in the full view of fifty sisters and a hundred servants, but neither should she seem propped up like an invalid.

moʊst ə ðə sɪɾɝz u hæd swɔɹn tə ɛɡwin, ʃɛɹiəm ɪnkluɾəd, hæd dʌn soʊ aʊɾ ə sɪmpəl fɪɹ, ɹɪli, ən sɛlf-pɹɛzɝveɪʃən. ɪf ðə hɔl lɝn ðeɪ hæd sɛn sɪstɝz tə sweɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən wɝs, kɛp ðə fæk fɹəm ðə hɔl fəɹ fɪɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz, ðeɪ ʃʊɹli ən sɝɾənli wəd spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz ɪn pɛnəns ən ɛɡzaɪl. soʊ ðə wɪmən u hæd bɪliv ðeɪ kəd sʌmhaʊ twɪtʃ ɛɡwin əbaʊt laɪk ə pʌpət, æftɝ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ ɪnfluəns wɪð ðə hɔl mɛltəd, ɪnstɛd faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz swɔɹn tə oʊbeɪ hɝ. ðət wɑz ɹɛɹ ivən ɪn ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz; sɪstɝz wɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə oʊbeɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn, bʌt swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls əɡɛn. moʊst stɪl simd ənsɛɾəld baɪ ɪt, ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪɾ oʊbeɪ. fju wɝ əz bæɾ əz kɑɹlɪnjə, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæɾ æktʃəli  hɝd bioʊnɪnz tiθ tʃæɾɝ ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi sɔ ɛɡwin wɪð sɪɾɝz æftɝ swɛɹɪŋ. mɔɹvɹɪn lʊkt əstɑnɪʃt ənu wɛnɛvɝ əɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn ɛɡwin, əz ɪf ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt kwaɪt bɪliv, ən naɪsaʊ hɑɹdli sim tə stɑp fɹaʊnɪŋ. æneɪjə klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə sikɹəsi, ən maɪɹɛl ɔfən flɪntʃt, ðoʊ fəɹ mɔɹ ɹizən ðən teɪkɪŋ ən oʊθ. bʌt ʃɛɹiəm sɪmpli hæd sɛɾəld ɪndə ðə ɹoʊl ʌv ɛɡwinz kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz ɪn tʃɹuθ, nɑt dʒʌs neɪm.

Most of the Sitters who had sworn to Egwene, Sheriam included, had done so out of simple fear, really, and self-preservation. If the Hall learned they had sent sisters to sway the Aes Sedai in Tar Valon, and worse, kept the fact from the Hall for fear of Darkfriends among the Sitters, they surely and certainly would spend the rest of their lives in penance and exile. So the women who had believed they could somehow twitch Egwene about like a puppet, after the greater part of their influence with the Hall melted, instead found themselves sworn to obey her. That was rare even in the secret histories; sisters were expected to obey the Amyrlin, but swearing fealty was something else again. Most still seemed unsettled by it, though they did obey. Few were as bad as Carlinya, but Egwene had actually heard Beonin's teeth chatter the first time she saw Egwene with Sitters after swearing. Morvrin looked astonished anew whenever her eyes fell on Egwene, as if she still did not quite believe, and Nisao hardly seemed to stop frowning. Anaiya clicked her tongue over the secrecy, and Myrelle often flinched, though for more reason than taking an oath. But Sheriam simply had settled into the role of Egwene's Keeper of the Chronicles in truth, not just name.

"meɪ aɪ sədʒɛs juzɪŋ ðɪs ɑpɝtunəɾi tə si wʌt ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹi ɔfɝz ɪn weɪ ʌv fuɾ ən fɑɾɝ, mʌðɝ? əɹ stɑks ɑɹ loʊ." ʃɛɹiəm fɹaʊn æŋkʃəsli. "ɪspɛʃli ti ən sɔlt, ðoʊ aɪ daʊt wɪl faɪn ðoʊz."

"May I suggest using this opportunity to see what the surrounding country offers in way of food and fodder, Mother? Our stocks are low." Sheriam frowned anxiously. "Especially tea and salt, though I doubt we'll find those."

"du wʌt jə kæn," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə suðɪŋ toʊn. ɑd naʊ, tə θɪŋk ðət wʌns ʃi hæd ɡɔn ɪn ɑ ʌv ʃɛɹiəm, ən ɪn noʊ lɪɾəl fɪɹ ə hɝ dɪsplɛʒɝ. stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ɪt simd, naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʌɡ ən pʊʃ ɛɡwin tə də əz ʃi wɪʃt, ʃɛɹiəm æktʃəli  sim hæpiɝ. "aɪ hæv ɛvɹi kɑnfəɾəns ɪn ju, ʃɛɹiəm." ðə wʊmən pɑzəɾɪvli bimd ət ðə kɑmpləmənt.

"Do what you can," Egwene said in a soothing tone. Odd now, to think that once she had gone in awe of Sheriam, and in no little fear of her displeasure. Strange as it seemed, now that she was no longer Mistress of Novices, no longer trying to tug and push Egwene to do as she wished, Sheriam actually seemed happier. "I have every confidence in you, Sheriam." The woman positively beamed at the compliment.

ðə sʌn stɪl dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ əbʌv ðə tɛns ən wæɡənz tə ði ist, bʌt ðə kæmp wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bʌsəlɪŋ. ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. bɹɛkfəs dʌn, ðə kʊks wɝ klinɪŋ ʌp, hɛlp baɪ ə hɔɹɾ ə nɑvəsɪz. fɹəm ðə vɪɡɝ ðeɪ pʊɾ ɪndə ɪt, ðə jʌŋ wɪmən sim tə faɪn səm wɔɹmθ ɪn skɹʌbɪŋ kɛɾəlz wɪð snoʊ, bʌt ðə kʊks muv ləbɔɹiəsli, nʌklɪŋ ðɛɹ bæks, stɑpɪŋ tə saɪ ən səmtaɪmz tə pʊl ðɛɹ kloʊks kloʊs ən stɛɹ blikli ət ðə snoʊ. ʃɪvɝɪŋ sɝvɪŋ mɛn, wɛɹɪŋ moʊst ə ðə kloʊðz ðeɪ oʊnd, hæd bɪɡʌn stʃɹaɪkɪŋ tɛns ən loʊɾɪŋ wæɡənz ɔɾəmætɪkli əz sun əz ðeɪ fɪnɪʃt ðɛɹ heɪsti mil, ən wɝ naʊ stʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊt tə ɹeɪz ðə tɛns ən hɔl tʃɛsts aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡənz. ænəməlz ðət hæd bɪn biɪŋ hɑɹnəst wɝ naʊ biɪŋ lɛɾ əweɪ baɪ wɪɹi hɔɹshænlɝz u wɔkt wɪð hɛdz daʊn. ɛɡwin hɝɾ ə fju ɡɹʌmbəlz fɹəm mɛn u feɪl tə noʊɾəs ðəɹ wɝ sɪstɝz nɪɹbaɪ, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ sim tu taɪɝd tə vɔɪs ə kəmpleɪnt.

The sun still did not show above the tents and wagons to the east, but the camp was already bustling. In a manner of speaking. Breakfast done, the cooks were cleaning up, helped by a horde of novices. From the vigor they put into it, the young women seemed to find some warmth in scrubbing kettles with snow, but the cooks moved laboriously, knuckling their backs, stopping to sigh and sometimes to pull their cloaks close and stare bleakly at the snow. Shivering serving men, wearing most of the clothes they owned, had begun striking tents and loading wagons automatically as soon as they finished their hasty meal, and were now stumbling about to raise the tents and haul chests out of the wagons. Animals that had been being harnessed were now being led away by weary horsehandlers who walked with heads down. Egwene heard a few grumbles from men who failed to notice there were sisters nearby, but the greater number seemed too tired to voice a complaint.

moʊst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ huz tɛns wɝ ʌp hæd vænɪʃt ɪnsaɪd, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd mɛni stɪl dɝɛktəd wɝkɝz, ən ʌðɝz hɝiɾ əlɔŋ ðə sʌŋkən pæðz ɑn ɛɹənz ə ðɛɹ oʊn. ənlaɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ðeɪ ʃoʊɾ əz lɪɾəl aʊtwɝd wɪɹinəs əz ðə wɔɹɾɝz, hu sʌmhaʊ mænədʒ tə əpɪɹ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd hæɾ ɔl ðə slip ðeɪ niɾəd fəɹ ðɪs faɪn spɹɪŋ deɪ. ɛɡwin səspɛktəd ðət wɑz ə ɹil pɑɹɾ ə haʊ ə sɪstɝ dʒɹu stʃɹɛŋkθ fɹəm əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, kwaɪɾ əsaɪd fɹəm wʌt ʃi kəd də wɪð ðə bɑnd. wən jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ wəd nɑɾ ədmɪt tə hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i wɑz koʊld əɹ taɪɝɾ əɹ hʌŋɡɹi, jə dʒʌs hæd tə bɛɹ ʌp əz wɛl.

Most of the Aes Sedai whose tents were up had vanished inside, but a good many still directed workers, and others hurried along the sunken paths on errands of their own. Unlike everyone else, they showed as little outward weariness as the Warders, who somehow managed to appear as if they had had all the sleep they needed for this fine spring day. Egwene suspected that was a real part of how a sister drew strength from her Warder, quite aside from what she could do with the bond. When your Warder would not admit to himself that he was cold or tired or hungry, you just had to bear up as well.

ɑn wʌn ə ðə kɹɔsɪŋ pæðz, mɔɹvɹɪn əpɪɹd, klʌtʃɪŋ tɑkiməz ɑɹm. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz fəɹ səpɔɹt, ðoʊ mɔɹvɹɪn wɑz waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ wʊmən sim mɔɹ dɪmɪnjəɾɪv ðən ʃi æktʃəli  wɑz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz tə kip tɑkimə fɹəm ɪskeɪpɪŋ; mɔɹvɹɪn wɑz dɔɡd wʌns ʃi sɛɾ ə ɡoʊl. ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd. mɔɹvɹɪn maɪt wɛl bi ɪkspɛktəd tə sik aʊɾ ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ əɹ ədʒɑ, ðə bɹaʊn, jɛt wʊɾə əv θɔt dʒɑnjə əɹ ɛskɹɑldi mɔɹ laɪkli. ðə tu pæst aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪhaɪn ə kænvəs-tɑpt wæɡən ɑn ɹʌnɝz, mɔɹvɹɪn bɛndɪŋ tə tɔk ɪn əɹ kəmpænjənz ɪɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɛðɝ tɑkimə wɑz peɪɪŋ ɛni maɪnd.

On one of the crossing paths, Morvrin appeared, clutching Takima's arm. Perhaps it was for support, though Morvrin was wide enough to make the shorter woman seem more diminutive than she actually was. Perhaps it was to keep Takima from escaping; Morvrin was dogged once she set a goal. Egwene frowned. Morvrin might well be expected to seek out a Sitter for her Ajah, the Brown, yet Egwene would have thought Janya or Escaralde more likely. The two passed out of sight behind a canvas-topped wagon on runners, Morvrin bending to talk in her companion's ear. There was no way to tell whether Takima was paying any mind.

"ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ðə mæɾɝ, mʌðɝ?"

"Is something the matter, Mother?"

ɛɡwin pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl ðət fɛl taɪt. "noʊ mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl, ʃɛɹiəm. noʊ mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl."

Egwene put on a smile that felt tight. "No more than usual, Sheriam. No more than usual."

ət ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, ʃɛɹiəm dɪpɑɹɾəd tə si tə ðə tæsks ɛɡwin hæd ɡɪvən hɝ, ən ɛɡwin wɛn ɪn tə faɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɹɛɾinəs. ʃi wʊɾə bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. sɛləm wɑz dʒʌst sɛɾɪŋ ə ti tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd bidwɝk ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə ɹeɪl-θɪn wʊmənz bɑɾəs ən daʊn əɹ slivz, ən wɪð əɹ lɔŋ noʊz kæɹid haɪ, ʃi hɑɹdli simd ə sɝvən ət fɝst ɡlæns, bʌt ʃi hæd sin tə wʌt niɾəd duɪŋ. tu bɹeɪʒɝz fʊl ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ koʊlz hæd teɪkən səm ə ðə tʃɪl ɔf ði ɛɹ, ðoʊ moʊst ə ðə hit ɹʌʃt aʊt θɹu ðə smoʊk hoʊl. dʒɹaɪɾ ɝbz spɹɪŋkəld ɑn ðə koʊlz ɡeɪv ə plɛzən sɛn tə ðə smoʊk ðət dɪd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp, ðə tʃɹeɪ fɹəm ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ wɑz ɡɔn, ən ðə læntɝn ən tæloʊ kændəlz hæd bɪn tʃɹɪmd ən lɪt. noʊ wʌn wɑz əbaʊt tə liv ə tɛn oʊpən ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ ɪn laɪt fɹəm aʊtsaɪd.

At the Amyrlin's Study, Sheriam departed to see to the tasks Egwene had given her, and Egwene went in to find everything in readiness. She would have been surprised at anything else. Selame was just setting a tea tray on the writing table. Brightly colored beadwork ran across the rail-thin woman's bodice and down her sleeves, and with her long nose carried high, she hardly seemed a servant at first glance, but she had seen to what needed doing. Two braziers full of glowing coals had taken some of the chill off the air, though most of the heat rushed out through the smoke hole. Dried herbs sprinkled on the coals gave a pleasant scent to the smoke that did not escape, the tray from the night before was gone, and the lantern and tallow candles had been trimmed and lit. No one was about to leave a tent open enough to let in light from outside.

sɪuən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ, tu, wɪð ə stæk ə peɪpɝz ɪn əɹ hænz, ə hɛɹiɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, ən ə smʌdʒ ʌv ɪŋk ɑn əɹ noʊz. ðə poʊst ə sɛkɹətɛɹi pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə tu ʌv əm ənʌðɝ ɹizən tə bi sin tɔkɪŋ, ən ʃɛɹiəm hæd nɑt maɪndəɾ əɾ ɔl ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðə wɝk. sɪuən hɝsɛlf ɡɹʌmbəl fɹikwənli, haʊɛvɝ. fəɹ ə wʊmən u hæd sɛldəm lɛf ðə taʊɝ sɪns ɛntɝɪŋ əz ə nɑvəs, ʃi hæɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl dɪslaɪk fəɹ steɪɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ət ðə moʊmənt ʃi wɑz ðə pɪktʃɝ ʌv ə wʊmən biɪŋ peɪʃən ən wɑntɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn tə noʊ ɪt.

Siuan was already there, too, with a stack of papers in her hands, a harried expression on her face, and a smudge of ink on her nose. The post of secretary provided the two of them another reason to be seen talking, and Sheriam had not minded at all giving up the work. Siuan herself grumbled frequently, however. For a woman who had seldom left the Tower since entering as a novice, she had a remarkable dislike for staying inside. At the moment she was the picture of a woman being patient and wanting everyone to know it.

fəɹ ɔl əɹ haɪ noʊz, sɛləm sɪmpɝɾ ən bɑb soʊ mɛni kɝtsiz ðət teɪkɪŋ ɛɡwinz kloʊk ən mɪɾənz tɝn ɪndə ən ɪlæbɹət lɪɾəl sɛɹəmoʊni. ðə wʊmən næɾɝd ɑn əbaʊt ðə mʌðɝ pʊɾɪŋ əɹ fiɾ ʌp, ən pɝhæps ʃi ʃəd fɛtʃ ðə mʌðɝ ə læp ɹoʊb, ən meɪbi ʃi ʃəd steɪ ɪn keɪs ðə mʌðɝ wɑntəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, əntɪl ɛɡwin pɹæktəkli tʃeɪst əɹ aʊt. ðə ti teɪstəɾ ə mɪnt. ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ! sɛləm wɑz ə tʃɹaɪəl, ən ʃi kəd hɑɹdli bi kɔld lɔɪəl, bʌt ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ.

For all her high nose, Selame simpered and bobbed so many curtsies that taking Egwene's cloak and mittens turned into an elaborate little ceremony. The woman nattered on about the Mother putting her feet up, and perhaps she should fetch the Mother a lap robe, and maybe she should stay in case the Mother wanted anything else, until Egwene practically chased her out. The tea tasted of mint. In this weather! Selame was a trial, and she could hardly be called loyal, but she did try.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ laʊnʒɪŋ ən sɪpɪŋ ti, ðoʊ. ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ stoʊl ən tʊk əɹ pleɪs bɪhaɪn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk, æbsəntmaɪndɪdli ɡɪvɪŋ ə jæŋk tə ðə lɛɡ ʌv əɹ tʃɛɹ soʊ ɪt wəd nɑt foʊl bɪniθ əɹ əz ɪɾ ɔfən dɪd, sɪuən pɝtʃt ətɑp ə ɹɪkəɾi stul ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl, ən ðə ti kuld. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt spik ə plænz, əɹ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn, əɹ hoʊps; wʌt kəd bi dʌn ðəɹ fəɹ naʊ, hæd bɪn. ɹɪpɔɹts ən pɹɑbləmz paɪld ʌp wən ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðə muv ən wɪɹinəs oʊvɝkeɪm ətɛmps tə dil wɪð ðɛm, ən naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ stɑpt, ɔl hæd tə bi ɡɔn θɹu. ən ɑɹmi əhɛd dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ðæt.

There was no time for lounging and sipping tea, though. Egwene straightened her stole and took her place behind the writing desk, absentmindedly giving a yank to the leg of her chair so it would not fold beneath her as it often did, Siuan perched atop a rickety stool on the other side of the table, and the tea cooled. They did not speak of plans, or Gareth Bryne, or hopes; what could be done there for now, had been. Reports and problems piled up when they were on the move and weariness overcame attempts to deal with them, and now that they were stopped, all had to be gone through. An army ahead did not change that.

ət taɪmz, ɛɡwin wʌndɝd haʊ soʊ mʌtʃ peɪpɝ kəd bi faʊnd wən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls sim soʊ dɪfəkəlt. ðə ɹɪpɔɹts sɪuən hændəɾ əɹ dɪteɪld ʃɔɹɾədʒəz ən lɪɾəl ɛls. nɑt sɪmpli ðoʊz ʃɛɹiəm hæd mɛnʃənd, bʌt koʊl ən neɪlz ən aɪɝn fəɹ ðə fɛɹiɝz ən wilɹaɪts, lɛðɝ ən ɔɪl θɹɛd fəɹ ðə hɑɹnəsmeɪkɝz, læmp ɔɪl ən kændəlz ən ə hʌnʒɹəd ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ivən soʊp. ən wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɑt ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt wɑz wɛɹɪŋ aʊt, fɹəm ʃuz tə tɛns, ɔl lɪstəɾ ɪn sɪuənz boʊl hænd, wɪtʃ ɡɹu mɔɹ əɡɹɛsɪv ðə mɔɹ ɡlɛɹɪŋ ðə nid ʃi ɹoʊɾ əbaʊt. hɝ əkaʊn ə ðə kɔɪn ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ lʊk tə hæv bɪn slæʃt ɑntu ðə peɪpɝ ɪn ə pɑzəɾɪv fjʊɹi. ən nɑɾ ə θɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt.

At times, Egwene wondered how so much paper could be found when everything else seemed so difficult. The reports Siuan handed her detailed shortages and little else. Not simply those Sheriam had mentioned, but coal and nails and iron for the farriers and wheelwrights, leather and oiled thread for the harnessmakers, lamp oil and candles and a hundred other things, even soap. And whatever was not running out was wearing out, from shoes to tents, all listed in Siuan's bold hand, which grew more aggressive the more glaring the need she wrote about. Her account of the coin remaining looked to have been slashed onto the paper in a positive fury. And not a thing to be done about it.

əmʌŋ sɪuənz peɪpɝz wɝ sɛvɹəl ædʒɹɛsɪz fɹəm sɪɾɝz sədʒɛstɪŋ weɪz tə sɑlv ðə pɹɑbləm ə mʌni. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ɪnfɔɹmɪŋ ɛɡwin wʌt ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə leɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl. ðəɹ wɝ fju ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə ɛni ʌv ðə skimz, haʊɛvɝ, ən mɛni pɪtfɔlz. mɔɹiə kɛɹɛntənɪs pɹəpoʊz stɑpɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz' peɪ, ə noʊʃən ɛɡwin θɔt ðə hɔl hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹilaɪzd wəd kɑz ði ɑɹmi tə mɛlt əweɪ laɪk du ʌndɝ ə mɪdsʌmɝ sʌn. mɑlɪnd nækənɪn pɹizɛntəɾ ən əpil tə nɪɹbaɪ noʊbəlz ðət saʊndəd mɔɹ ə dɪmæn ən maɪt wɛl tɝn ðə hoʊl kʌntʃɹisaɪɾ əɡɛns ðɛm, əz wəd sæliɾə tɔɹeɪnz' ɪntɛntʃən tə lɛvi ə tæks ɑn ðə taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz ðeɪ pæst.

Among Siuan's papers were several addresses from Sitters suggesting ways to solve the problem of money. Or rather, informing Egwene what they intended to lay before the Hall. There were few advantages to any of the schemes, however, and many pitfalls. Moria Karentanis proposed stopping the soldiers' pay, a notion Egwene thought the Hall had already realized would cause the army to melt away like dew under a midsummer sun. Malind Nachenin presented an appeal to nearby nobles that sounded more a demand and might well turn the whole countryside against them, as would Salita Toranes' intention to levy a tax on the towns and villages they passed.

kɹʌmplɪŋ ðə θɹi ædʒɹɛsɪz təɡɛðɝ ɪn əɹ fɪst, ɛɡwin ʃʊk əm ət sɪuən. ʃi wɪʃt ɪt wɝ θɹi sɪɾɝz' θɹoʊts ʃi wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ. "du ðeɪ ɔl θɪŋk ɛvɹiθɪŋ əz tə ɡoʊ ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɪʃ, ən nɛvɝ maɪn ɹiæləɾiz? laɪt, ðəɹ ðə wʌnz bɪheɪvɪŋ laɪk tʃɪlʒɹən!"

Crumpling the three addresses together in her fist, Egwene shook them at Siuan. She wished it were three Sitters' throats she was gripping. "Do they all think everything has to go the way they wish, and never mind realities? Light, they're the ones behaving like children!"

"ðə taʊɝ əz mænədʒ tə meɪk ɪts wɪʃɪz bɪkʌm ɹiæləɾiz ɔfən ɪnʌf," sɪuən sɛd kəmpleɪsənli. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, səm wəd seɪ jəɹ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɹiæləɾi, tu."

"The Tower has managed to make its wishes become realities often enough," Siuan said complacently. "Remember, some would say you're ignoring reality, too."

ɛɡwin snɪft. lʌkəli, wʌtɛvɝ ðə hɔl voʊɾəd, nʌn ə ðə pɹəpoʊzəlz kəd bi kæɹid fɔɹwɝd wɪθaʊɾ ə dɪkɹi fɹəm hɝ. ivən ɪn əɹ stʃɹeɪɾənd sɝkəmstænsəz, ʃi hæɾ ə lɪɾəl paʊɝ. vɛɹi lɪɾəl, bʌt ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən nʌn. "ɪz ðə hɔl ɔlweɪz ðɪs bæd, sɪuən?"

Egwene sniffed. Luckily, whatever the Hall voted, none of the proposals could be carried forward without a decree from her. Even in her straitened circumstances, she had a little power. Very little, but that was more than none. "Is the Hall always this bad, Siuan?"

sɪuən nɑɾəd, ʃɪftɪŋ slaɪtli tə tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ə bɛɾɝ bæləns. noʊ tu ʌv əɹ stulz lɛɡz wɝ ðə seɪm lɛŋθ. "bʌɾ ɪt kəd bi wɝs. ɹimaɪn mi tə tɛl jə əbaʊt ðə jɪɹ ə ðə fɔɹ æmɪɝlənz; ðət wɑz əbaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə faʊndɪŋ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪn ðoʊz deɪz, ðə nɔɹməl wɝkɪŋz ə ðə taʊɝ nɪɹli ɹaɪvəld wʌts hæpənɪŋ tədeɪ. ɛvɹi hæn tʃɹaɪd tə snætʃ ðə tɪlɝ, ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. ðəɹ wɝ æktʃəli  tu ɹaɪvəl hɔlz ə ðə taʊɝ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðət jɪɹ. ɔlmoʊs laɪk naʊ. dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹiwʌn keɪm tə ɡɹif ɪn ði ɛnd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə fju hu θɔt ðeɪ gɑnə tə seɪv ðə taʊɝ. səm ə ðɛm maɪt hæv, ɪf ðeɪ hædn stɛpt ɪn kwɪksænd. ðə taʊɝ sɝvaɪvd ɛniweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dʌz."

Siuan nodded, shifting slightly to try to find a better balance. No two of her stool's legs were the same length. "But it could be worse. Remind me to tell you about the Year of the Four Amyrlins; that was about a hundred and fifty years after the founding of Tar Valon. In those days, the normal workings of the Tower nearly rivaled what's happening today. Every hand tried to snatch the tiller, if they could. There were actually two rival Halls of the Tower in Tar Valon for part of that year. Almost like now. Just about everyone came to grief in the end, including a few who thought they were going to save the Tower. Some of them might have, if they hadn't stepped in quicksand. The Tower survived anyway, of course. It always does."

ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə hɪstɝi ɡɹu ʌp ɪn oʊvɝ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, mʌtʃ səpɹɛst, hɪɾən fɹəm ɔl bʌɾ ə fju aɪz, jɛt sɪuən sim tə hæv ɛvɹi dɪteɪl əɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. ʃi mʌst əv spɛn ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ə hɝ jɪɹz ɪn ðə taʊɝ bɛɹiɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn ðoʊz sikɹət hɪstɝiz. ʌv wʌn θɪŋ, ɛɡwin wɑz sɝɾən. ʃi wəɾ əvɔɪd ʃaɪnz feɪɾ ɪf ʃi kʊd, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn əz ʃi wɑz, lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ɔf ðən səmeɪl sɔɹɛnteɪn. lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ði ɛn ə hɝ ɹeɪn, ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt dɪsɪʒən lɛf tə səmeɪlz dɪskɹɛʃən wɑz wʌt dʒɹɛs tə wɛɹ. ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə æsk sɪuən tə tɛl əɹ əbaʊt ðə jɪɹ ə ðə fɔɹ æmɪɝlənz, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ɪt.

A great deal of history grew up in over three thousand years, much suppressed, hidden from all but a few eyes, yet Siuan seemed to have every detail at her fingertips. She must have spent a good part of her years in the Tower burying herself in those secret histories. Of one thing, Egwene was certain. She would avoid Shein's fate if she could, but she would not remain as she was, little better off than Cemaile Sorenthaine. Long before the end of her reign, the most important decision left to Cemaile's discretion was what dress to wear. She was going to have to ask Siuan to tell her about the Year of the Four Amyrlins, and she did not look forward to it.

ðə ʃɪftɪŋ bim ə laɪt fɹəm ðə smoʊk hoʊl ɪn ðə ɹuf ʃoʊd mɔɹnɪŋ təwɔɹd mɪddeɪ, bʌt sɪuənz stæk ə peɪpɝz sim hɑɹdli dɪmɪnɪʃt. ɛni ɪntɝʌpʃən əɾ ɔl wʊɾə bɪn wɛlkəm, ivən pɹimətʃʊɹ dɪskʌvɝi. wɛl, meɪbi nɑt ðæt.

The shifting beam of light from the smoke hole in the roof showed morning toward midday, but Siuan's stack of papers seemed hardly diminished. Any interruption at all would have been welcome, even premature discovery. Well, maybe not that.

"wʌts nɛkst, sɪuən?" ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

"What's next, Siuan?" she growled.

ə flɪkɝ ə muvmən kɑɾ ɝæŋɡɝz aɪ, ən ʃi pɪɹd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd ði ɑɹmiz kæmp, ən əbskjʊɹɪŋ ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə tɛns ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə laɪn ʌv wæɡən-slɛdʒɪz wɑz muvɪŋ sloʊli ist, ɛskɔɹɾɪd baɪ mɛn ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ðə peɪl sʌn ɡlɪntɪd fɹəm ɑɹmɝ ən ðə pɔɪns ə lænsɪz. ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp snɪɹɪŋ. spɪɹz ən hɔɹsəz! ə pɹɪməɾɪv ɹæbəl ðət kəd muv noʊ fæstɝ ðən ə mæn kəd wɔk, lɛd baɪ ə mæn u dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əweɪ. ɛɛs sədaɪ? ʃi kəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm, ən ivən daɪɪŋ ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ səspɛkt u wɑz kɪlɪŋ ðɛm. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wəd nɑt sɝvaɪv əm lɔŋ. ðət θɔt meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ɡeɪv vɛɹi fju ə sɛkən tʃæns ət laɪf, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə θɹoʊ əweɪ hɝz.

A flicker of movement caught Aran'gar's eye, and she peered through the trees toward the army's camp, an obscuring ring around the tents of the Aes Sedai. A line of wagon-sledges was moving slowly east, escorted by men on horseback. The pale sun glinted from armor and the points of lances. She could not help sneering. Spears and horses! A primitive rabble that could move no faster than a man could walk, led by a man who did not know what was happening a hundred miles away. Aes Sedai? She could destroy the lot of them, and even dying they would never suspect who was killing them. Of course, she would not survive them long. That thought made her shiver. The Great Lord gave very few a second chance at life, and she was not about to throw away hers.

weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ðə ɹaɪɾɝz muvd aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, ʃi stɑɹɾəd bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, θɪŋkɪŋ aɪdli ʌv tənaɪts dʒɹimz. bɪhaɪn hɝ, smuð snoʊ wəd haɪd wʌt ʃi hæd bɛɹiɾ əntɪl ðə spɹɪŋ θɔ, mɔɹ ðən lɔŋ ɪnʌf. əhɛd, səm ə ðə mɛn ɪn ðə kæmp faɪnəli noʊɾəst əɹ ən stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm ðɛɹ tæsks tə wɑtʃ. ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, ʃi smaɪld ən smuðd əɹ skɝɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɪps. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl naʊ tə ɹɪli ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt laɪf hæd bɪn laɪk əz ə mæn; hæd ʃi bɪn sətʃ ən izəli mənɪpjəleɪɾɪd ful, ðɛn? ɡɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðət swɔɹm wɪð ə kɔɹps ənsin hæd bɪn dɪfəkəlt, ivən fəɹ hɝ, bʌt ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd ðə wɔk bæk.

Waiting until the riders moved out of sight into the forest, she started back toward the camp, thinking idly of tonight's dreams. Behind her, smooth snow would hide what she had buried until the spring thaw, more than long enough. Ahead, some of the men in the camp finally noticed her and straightened from their tasks to watch. In spite of herself, she smiled and smoothed her skirt over her hips. It was difficult now to really remember what life had been like as a man; had she been such an easily manipulated fool, then? Getting through that swarm with a corpse unseen had been difficult, even for her, but she enjoyed the walk back.

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɛn ɑn ɪn ə simɪŋli ɛnləs weɪɾɪŋ θɹu peɪpɝ, əntɪl wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd noʊn wəd hæpən, dɪd. sɝɾən deɪli ɪvɛns wɝ ʃʊɹ. ðəɹ wəd bi bɪɾɝ koʊld, ðəɹ wəd bi snoʊ, ðəɹ wəd bi klaʊdz, ən ɡɹeɪ skaɪz, ən wɪnd. ən ðəɹ wəd bi vɪzəts fɹəm ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə.

The morning went on in a seemingly endless wading through paper, until what Egwene had known would happen, did. Certain daily events were sure. There would be bitter cold, there would be snow, there would be clouds, and gray skies, and wind. And there would be visits from Lelaine and Romanda.

wɪɹi ʌv sɪɾɪŋ, ɛɡwin wɑz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz wən ləleɪn swɛpt ɪndə ðə tɛnt wɪð fɑoʊleɪn əɾ əɹ hilz. fɹɪdʒəɾ ɛɹ ɹoʊld ɪn wɪð əm bɪfɔɹ ðə tɛntflæp fɛl ʃʌt. lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð ə feɪnli dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ ɛɹ, ləleɪn plʌkt ɔf blu lɛðɝ ɡlʌvz, waɪl əlaʊɪŋ fɑoʊleɪn tə ɹimuv ðə lɪŋks-laɪn kloʊk fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. slɛndɝ ən dɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɪn dip blu sɪlk, wɪð pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ aɪz, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪn əɹ oʊn tɛnt. əɾ ə kæʒəwəl dʒɛstʃɝ, fɑoʊleɪn ɹitʃɹiɾəd dɪfɝɛntʃəli tə ə kɔɹnɝ wɪð ðə ɡɑɹmənt, mɪɹli ʃɹʌɡɪŋ əɹ oʊn kloʊk bæk. pleɪnli, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ ɑn ði ɪnstən əɾ ənʌðɝ weɪv ə ðə sɪɾɝz hænd. hɝ dɑɹk fitʃɝz wɔɹ ə kæst ə ɹɪzaɪn miknəs, nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk hɝ.

Weary of sitting, Egwene was stretching her legs when Lelaine swept into the tent with Faolain at her heels. Frigid air rolled in with them before the tentflap fell shut. Looking around with a faintly disapproving air, Lelaine plucked off blue leather gloves, while allowing Faolain to remove the lynx-lined cloak from her shoulders. Slender and dignified in deep blue silk, with penetrating eyes, she might have been in her own tent. At a casual gesture, Faolain retreated deferentially to a corner with the garment, merely shrugging her own cloak back. Plainly, she was ready to go on the instant at another wave of the Sitter's hand. Her dark features wore a cast of resigned meekness, not very much like her.

ləleɪnz ɹɪzɝv kɹæk fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli wɔɹm smaɪl fəɹ sɪuən. ðeɪ hæd bɪn fɹɛnz, wʌns, jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ən ʃi hæɾ ivən ɔfɝd sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðə pætʃɹənɪdʒ ðət fɑoʊleɪn hæɾ æksɛptɪd, ə sɪɾɝz pɹətɛkʃən ən ʃɛltɝɪŋ ɑɹm əɡɛns ðə snɪɹz ən ækjəzeɪʃənz ʌv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz. tʌtʃɪŋ sɪuənz tʃik, ləleɪn sɔfli mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət saʊndəd sɪmpəθɛɾɪk. sɪuən blʌʃt, ə stɑɹtlɪŋ ənsɝɾənti flæʃɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs. ɪt wɑz nɑt pɹitɛns, ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ. sɪuən faʊn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə dil wɪð wʌt ɹɪli hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn hɝ, ən mɔɹ, wɪð haʊ izəli ʃi wɑz ədæptɪŋ.

Lelaine's reserve cracked for a moment, in a surprisingly warm smile for Siuan. They had been friends, once, years ago, and she had even offered something like the patronage that Faolain had accepted, a Sitter's protection and sheltering arm against the sneers and accusations of other sisters. Touching Siuan's cheek, Lelaine softly murmured something that sounded sympathetic. Siuan blushed, a startling uncertainty flashing across her face. It was not pretense, Egwene was sure. Siuan found it difficult to deal with what really had changed in her, and more, with how easily she was adapting.

ləleɪn aɪd ðə stul ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ænd, əz juʒəwəl, vɪzəbli ɹɪdʒɛktɪd sətʃ ən ənstɛɾi sit. oʊnli ðən dɪd ʃi æknɑlɪdʒ ɛɡwinz pɹɛzəns, wɪð ðə bɛɹəs dɪp ə hɝ hɛd. "wi nid tə spik ə ðə si foʊk, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə toʊn ə bɪt fɝm tə bi dɝɛktəɾ ət ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Lelaine eyed the stool in front of the writing table and, as usual, visibly rejected such an unsteady seat. Only then did she acknowledge Egwene's presence, with the barest dip of her head. "We need to speak of the Sea Folk, Mother," she said in a tone a bit firm to be directed at the Amyrlin Seat.

nɑɾ əntɪl ɛɡwinz hɑɹt sæŋk daʊn fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt dɪd ʃi ɹilaɪz ʃi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd ðət ləleɪn ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌt lɔɹd bɹaɪn hæd toʊl hɝ. əɹ ivən ðə miɾɪŋ i wɑz ɝeɪnʒɪŋ. ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, hɝ hɑɹt lɛp bæk əɡɛn. ðə si foʊk? ʃʊɹli ðə hɔl kəd nɑɾ əv lɝn ə ði ɪnseɪn bɑɹɡən nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn hæd meɪd. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt hæd lɛɾ əm ɪndə sətʃ ə dɪzæstɝ, əɹ haʊ ʃi wɑz tə dil wɪð ɪt.

Not until Egwene's heart sank down from her throat did she realize she had been afraid that Lelaine already knew what Lord Bryne had told her. Or even the meeting he was arranging. The next instant, her heart leaped back again. The Sea Folk? Surely the Hall could not have learned of the insane bargain Nynaeve and Elayne had made. She could not imagine what had led them into such a disaster, or how she was to deal with it.

hɝ stʌmək ɹɔɪlɪŋ, ʃi tʊk əɹ pleɪs bɪhaɪn ðə teɪbəl wɪθaʊt ɹɪvilɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wʌt ʃi fɛlt. ən ðət ful tʃɛɹ lɛɡ foʊldəd, nɪɹli dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd dʒɝk ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ əɡɛn. ʃi hoʊpt əɹ tʃiks wɝ nɑt kʌlɝɪŋ. "ðə si foʊk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, əɹ ɪn kɛɹhin?" jɛs; ðət saʊndəd suɾəbli kɑm ən kəlɛktəd.

Her stomach roiling, she took her place behind the table without revealing anything of what she felt. And that fool chair leg folded, nearly dropping her onto the carpets before she could jerk it straight again. She hoped her cheeks were not coloring. "The Sea Folk in Caemlyn, or in Cairhien?" Yes; that sounded suitably calm and collected.

"kɛɹhin." ɹoʊmændəz haɪ vɔɪs ɹæŋ laɪk sʌɾən tʃaɪmz. "dɛfənətli kɛɹhin." hɝ ɛntʃɹi meɪd ləleɪnz sim ɔlmoʊs dɪfəɾənt, ðə fɔɹs ə hɝ pɝsənælɪɾi əbɹʌpli fɪlɪŋ ðə tɛnt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɔɹm smaɪlz ɪn ɹoʊmændə; hænsəm əz əɹ feɪs wɑz, ɪt dɪd nɑt sim meɪd fəɹ ðɛm.

"Cairhien." Romanda's high voice rang like sudden chimes. "Definitely Cairhien." Her entry made Lelaine's seem almost diffident, the force of her personality abruptly filling the tent. There were no warm smiles in Romanda; handsome as her face was, it did not seem made for them.

θiədʒɹɪn fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪn, ən ɹoʊmændə swʌŋ əɹ kloʊk ɔf wɪð ə flɝɪʃ ən tɔst ɪt tə ðə slɪm, æpəl-tʃik sɪstɝ wɪð ə pɝɛmptɝi dʒɛstʃɝ ðət sɛn θiədʒɹɪn hɝiɪŋ tə ə kɔɹnɝ ɑpəzət fɑoʊleɪn. fɑoʊleɪn wɑz dɪstɪŋkli səbdud, bʌt θiədʒɹɪnz tɪltəɾ aɪz wɝ vɛɹi waɪd, əz ðoʊ ʃi wɑz pɝmənənli stɑɹɾəld, ən əɹ lɪps simd ɹɛɾi tə ɡæsp. laɪk fɑoʊleɪn, hɝ pɹɑpɝ pleɪs ɪn ðə haɪɝɑɹki ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪmændəd bɛɾɝ ɛmplɔɪmənt, bʌt niðɝ wɑz laɪkli tə ɹəsiv ɪt sun.

Theodrin followed her in, and Romanda swung her cloak off with a flourish and tossed it to the slim, apple-cheeked sister with a peremptory gesture that sent Theodrin hurrying to a corner opposite Faolain. Faolain was distinctly subdued, but Theodrin's tilted eyes were very wide, as though she was permanently startled, and her lips seemed ready to gasp. Like Faolain, her proper place in the hierarchy of Aes Sedai demanded better employment, but neither was likely to receive it soon.

ɹoʊmændəz kəmpɛlɪŋ ɡeɪz ɹɛstəɾ ə moʊmən ɑn sɪuən, əz ɪf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wɛðɝ tə sɛn əɹ tə ə kɔɹnɝ əz wɛl, ðən bɹʌʃt pæs ləleɪn ɔlmoʊs dɪsmɪsɪvli bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn ɛɡwin. "ɪt simz ðət jʌŋ mæn əz bɪn tɔkɪŋ wɪð ðə si foʊk, mʌðɝ. ðə jɛloʊ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn kɛɹhin ɑɹ moʊst ɪksaɪɾəd əbaʊɾ ɪt. juv ɛni aɪdiə wʌt maɪɾ ɪntʃɹəst ɪm ɪn ði æθɑn maɪɹ?"

Romanda's compelling gaze rested a moment on Siuan, as if considering whether to send her to a corner as well, then brushed past Lelaine almost dismissively before settling on Egwene. "It seems that young man has been talking with the Sea Folk, Mother. The Yellow eyes-and-ears in Cairhien are most excited about it. Do you have any idea what might interest him in the Atha'an Miere?"

dɪspaɪt ðə taɪɾəl, ɹoʊmændə hɑɹdli saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, bʌt ðɛn, ʃi nɛvɝ dɪd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ u "ðæt jʌŋ mæn" wɑz. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɪn ðə kæmp æksɛptɪd ðət ɹænd wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn u hɝɾ əm tɔk wʊɾə bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ spikɪŋ ʌv ən ənɹuli jʌŋ laʊɾ u maɪt kʌm tə dɪnɝ dʒɹʌŋk ən θɹoʊ ʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl.

Despite the title, Romanda hardly sounded as if she were addressing the Amyrlin Seat, but then, she never did. There was no doubt who "that young man" was. Every sister in the camp accepted that Rand was the Dragon Reborn, but anyone who heard them talk would have believed they were speaking of an unruly young lout who might come to dinner drunk and throw up on the table.

"ʃi kən hɑɹdli noʊ wʌts ɪn ðə bɔɪz hɛd," ləleɪn sɛd bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊð. hɝ smaɪl wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl wɔɹm ðɪs taɪm. "ɪf ən ænsɝ ɪz tə bi faʊnd, ɹoʊmændə, ɪɾəl bi ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ði æθɑn maɪɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ nɑt sɪkwɛstɝɾ ɑn ə ʃɪp, ən aɪ sɪɹiəsli daʊt ðət haɪ ɹæŋkɪŋ si foʊk keɪm soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə si ɑn dɪfɹən ɛɹənz. aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðɛm duɪŋ soʊ fəɹ ɛni ɹizən. ɪt meɪ bi ðeɪv ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn hɪm. ðeɪ mʌs noʊ hu hiz baɪ naʊ."

"She can hardly know what's in the boy's head," Lelaine said before Egwene could open her mouth. Her smile was not at all warm this time. "If an answer is to be found, Romanda, it will be in Caemlyn. The Atha'an Miere there are not sequestered on a ship, and I seriously doubt that high ranking Sea Folk came so far from the sea on different errands. I've never heard of them doing so for any reason. It may be they have an interest in him. They must know who he is by now."

ɹoʊmændə smaɪl bæk, ən fɹɔst ʃʊɾə əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə tɛnt wɔlz. "ðɛɹz hɑɹdli nid tə steɪt ði ɑbviəs, ləleɪn. ðə fɝs kwɛstʃən ɪz haʊ tə faɪn aʊt."

Romanda smiled back, and frost should have appeared on the tent walls. "There's hardly need to state the obvious, Lelaine. The first question is how to find out."

"aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə ɹizɑlv ðət wən jə bɑɹdʒd ɪn, ɹoʊmændə. ðə nɛks taɪm ðə mʌðɝ ɪnkaʊntɝz ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ʃi kən pæs ɑn ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. mɛɝɪlɪl kən dɪskʌvɝ wʌt ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑnt, əɹ meɪbi wʌt ðə bɔɪ dʌz, wən ʃi ɹitʃəz keɪɛmlɪn. ə pɪɾi ðə ɡɝlz dɪdn θɪŋk tə sɛɾ ə ɹɛɡjəlɝ skɛdʒʊl, bʌt wi mʌst wɝk ɝaʊn ðæt. mɛɝɪlɪl kən mit wɪð ə sɪɾɝ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd wən ʃi noʊz." ləleɪn meɪɾ ə smɔl dʒɛstʃɝ; pleɪnli, ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ði ɪntɛndəd sɪɾɝ. "aɪ θɔt sɑlədɑɹ maɪt bi ə suɾəbəl pleɪs."

"I was about to resolve that when you barged in, Romanda. The next time the Mother encounters Elayne or Nynaeve in Tel'aran'rhiod, she can pass on instructions. Merilille can discover what the Atha'an Miere want, or maybe what the boy does, when she reaches Caemlyn. A pity the girls didn't think to set a regular schedule, but we must work around that. Merilille can meet with a Sitter in Tel'aran'rhiod when she knows." Lelaine made a small gesture; plainly, she herself was the intended Sitter. "I thought Salidar might be a suitable place."

ɹoʊmændə snɔɹɾɪd wɪð əmjuzmənt. ivən ɪn ðæt, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹmθ. "iziɝ tə ɪnstʃɹʌk mɛɝɪlɪl ðən tə si ʃi oʊbeɪz, ləleɪn. aɪ ɪkspɛkt ʃi noʊz ʃi feɪsəz ʃɑɹp kwɛstʃənz. ðɪs boʊl ə ðə wɪnz ʃʊɾə bɪn bɹɔt tə əs fəɹ stʌɾi fɝst. nʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ hæd mʌtʃ əbɪləɾi ɪn klaʊd dænsɪŋ, aɪ bɪliv, ən jə kən si ðə ɹɪzʌlt, ɔl ðɪs hɝli-bɝli ən sʌɾənnəs. aɪ hæv ə θɔt tə kɔl ə kwɛstʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl kənsɝnɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪnvɑlvd." əbɹʌpli ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmənz vɔɪs bɪkeɪm smuð əz bʌɾɝ. "æz aɪ ɹikɔl, jə səpɔɹɾəd ðə tʃɔɪs ə mɛɝɪlɪl."

Romanda snorted with amusement. Even in that, there was no warmth. "Easier to instruct Merilille than to see she obeys, Lelaine. I expect she knows she faces sharp questions. This Bowl of the Winds should have been brought to us for study first. None of the sisters in Ebou Dar had much ability in Cloud Dancing, I believe, and you can see the result, all this hurly-burly and suddenness. I have a thought to call a question before the Hall concerning everyone involved." Abruptly the gray-haired woman's voice became smooth as butter. "As I recall, you supported the choice of Merilille."

wɪð ə dʒɝk, ləleɪn dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp. hɝ aɪz flæʃt. "aɪ səpɔɹɾəd u ðə ɡɹeɪ pʊt fɔɹwɝd, ɹoʊmændə, ən noʊ mɔɹ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. "haʊ kəɾ aɪ hæv ɪmædʒənd ʃi wəd dɪsaɪd tə juz ðə boʊl ðɛɹ? ən tə ɪnklud si foʊk waɪldɝz ɪn ðə sɝkəl! haʊ kəd ʃi bɪliv ðeɪ noʊ əz mʌtʃ ʌv wɝkɪŋ wɛðɝ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ?" əbɹʌpli hɝ aɪɹ slɪpt. ʃi wɑz dɪfɛndɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fɪɹsəst ædvɝsɛɹi ɪn ðə hɔl, hɝ oʊnli ɹil ædvɝsɛɹi. ænd, noʊ daʊt wɝs ɪn əɹ vju, ʃi wɑz əɡɹiɪŋ wɪð əɹ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kwɛstʃən ðət ʃi dɪɾ əɡɹi, bʌt ɡɪvɪŋ ðə fæk vɔɪs wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

With a jerk, Lelaine drew herself up. Her eyes flashed. "I supported who the Gray put forward, Romanda, and no more," she said indignantly. "How could I have imagined she would decide to use the Bowl there? And to include Sea Folk wilders in the circle! How could she believe they know as much of working weather as Aes Sedai?" Abruptly her ire slipped. She was defending herself to her fiercest adversary in the Hall, her only real adversary. And, no doubt worse in her view, she was agreeing with her about the Sea Folk. There was no question that she did agree, but giving the fact voice was another matter.

ɹoʊmændə lɛɾ əɹ koʊl smaɪl dipən əz ləleɪnz feɪs peɪld wɪð fjʊɹi. ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd skɝts wɪð mətɪkjələs kɛɹ əz ləleɪn sɝtʃt fəɹ ə weɪ tə tɝn mæɾɝz əbaʊt. "wi wɪl si haʊ ðə hɔl stænz, ləleɪn," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "əntɪl ðə kwɛstʃən ɪz kɔld, aɪ θɪŋk ɪt bɛst ɪf mɛɝɪlɪl dʌz nɑt mit wɪð ɛni ʌv ðə sɪɾɝz ɪnvɑlvd ɪn əɹ səlɛkʃən. ivən ə sədʒɛstʃən ə kəluʒən wəd bi lʊkt əɾ əskæns. aɪm ʃʊɹ jəl əɡɹi aɪ ʃəd bi ðə wʌn tə spik wɪð hɝ."

Romanda let her cold smile deepen as Lelaine's face paled with fury. She straightened her bronze-colored skirts with meticulous care as Lelaine searched for a way to turn matters about. "We will see how the Hall stands, Lelaine," she said finally. "Until the question is called, I think it best if Merilille does not meet with any of the Sitters involved in her selection. Even a suggestion of collusion would be looked at askance. I'm sure you will agree I should be the one to speak with her."

ləleɪnz feɪs peɪl dɪfɹənli. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, nɑt vɪzəbli, jɛɾ ɛɡwin kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si hɝ kaʊntɪŋ u maɪt stæn fəɹ hɝ, əɹ əɡɛnst. kəluʒən wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz sɪɹiəs əz ə tʃɑɹdʒ ə tʃɹizən, ən ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs. laɪkli, ʃi kəɾ əvɔɪd ðæt, bʌt ði ɑɹɡjəməns wəd bi dip ən ækɹəmoʊniəs. ɹoʊmændəz fækʃən maɪɾ ivən ɪnkɹis. ðət wəd kɑz əntoʊl pɹɑbləmz wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ ɛɡwinz oʊn plænz bɔɹ fɹut. ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃi kəd də tə stɑp ɪt, ʃɔɹɾ ə ɹɪvilɪŋ wʌt ɹɪli hæd hæpən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. əz wɛl æsk əm tə lɛɾ əɹ æksɛp ðə seɪm ɔfɝ fɑoʊleɪn ən θiədʒɹɪn hæd.

Lelaine's face paled differently. She was not afraid, not visibly, yet Egwene could almost see her counting who might stand for her, or against. Collusion was almost as serious as a charge of treason, and required only the lesser consensus. Likely, she could avoid that, but the arguments would be deep and acrimonious. Romanda's faction might even increase. That would cause untold problems whether or not Egwene's own plans bore fruit. And there was nothing she could do to stop it, short of revealing what really had happened in Ebou Dar. As well ask them to let her accept the same offer Faolain and Theodrin had.

ɛɡwin dʒɹu bɹɛθ. ət list ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə pɹɪvɛn ðə jus ə sɑlədɑɹ əz ə miɾɪŋ pleɪs ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ðət wɑz wɛɹ ʃi mɛɾ ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv, naʊ. wən ʃi dɪd, ɛniweɪ; ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪn deɪz. wɪð sɪɾɝz pɑpɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, faɪndɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ jə kəd bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əpɪɹ wɑz dɪfəkəlt. "ðə nɛks taɪm aɪ ɪnkaʊntɝ ɪleɪn əɹ nɪneɪiv, əl pæs ɑn jəɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪl. aɪ kən lɛt jə noʊ wən ʃiz ɹɛɾi tə mit ju." wɪtʃ wəd bi nɛvɝ, wʌns ʃi wɑz dʌn wɪð ðoʊz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz.

Egwene drew breath. At least she might be able to prevent the use of Salidar as a meeting place in Tel'aran'rhiod. That was where she met Elayne and Nynaeve, now. When she did, anyway; she had not in days. With Sitters popping in and out of the World of Dreams, finding anywhere you could be sure they would not appear was difficult. "The next time I encounter Elayne or Nynaeve, I will pass on your instructions regarding Merilille. I can let you know when she's ready to meet you." Which would be never, once she was done with those instructions.

ðə sɪɾɝz' hɛdz wɪpt ɝaʊnd, ən tu sɛts ʌv aɪz stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ! stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kip əɹ feɪs smuð, ʃi ɹilaɪzd əɹ fʊt wɑz tæpɪŋ ɪɹɪɾəbli, ən stɑpt ɪt. ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ əlɔŋ wɪð wʌt ðeɪ θɔɾ ə hɝ ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ, jɛt. ə lɪɾəl waɪl lɔŋɡɝ. ət list ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɛl nɔzieɪɾəd. dʒʌst æŋɡɹi.

The Sitters' heads whipped around, and two sets of eyes stared at her. They had forgotten she was there! Struggling to keep her face smooth, she realized her foot was tapping irritably, and stopped it. She had to go along with what they thought of her a while longer, yet. A little while longer. At least she no longer felt nauseated. Just angry.

ɪndə ðət moʊmən ə saɪləns, tʃɛsə keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ wɪð ɛɡwinz mɪddeɪ mil ɑn ə klɔθ-kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ. dɑɹk-hɛɹd, plʌmp ən pɹɪɾi ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, tʃɛsə mænədʒ tə kənveɪ ə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛkt wɪθaʊt kɹɪŋɪŋ. hɝ kɝtsi wɑz əz sɪmpəl əz əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs, wɪð dʒʌst ə tʌtʃ ə pleɪn leɪs ət ðə θɹoʊt. "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ ɪntʃɹuɾɪŋ, mʌðɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪm sɑɹi ðɪs ɪz leɪt, mʌðɝ, bʌt mɛɹi simz tə hæv wɑndɝɾ ɔf." ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən əz ʃi sɛt ðə tʃɹeɪ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɡwin. wɑndɝɪŋ sim vɛɹi ənlaɪk ðə mɪsneɪmd mɛɹi. ðət daʊɝ wʊmən wɑz əz dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ ə fɔls ɪn hɝsɛlf əz ʃi wɑz ə ðoʊz ɪn ʌðɝz.

Into that moment of silence, Chesa came bustling with Egwene's midday meal on a cloth-covered tray. Dark-haired, plump and pretty in her middle years, Chesa managed to convey a proper respect without cringing. Her curtsy was as simple as her dark gray dress, with just a touch of plain lace at the throat. "Forgive me for intruding, Mother, Aes Sedai. I am sorry this is late, Mother, but Meri seems to have wandered off." She clicked her tongue in exasperation as she set the tray in front of Egwene. Wandering seemed very unlike the misnamed Meri. That dour woman was as disapproving of faults in herself as she was of those in others.

ɹoʊmændə fɹaʊnd, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi kəd hɑɹdli ʃoʊ tu mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn wʌn ʌv ɛɡwinz meɪdz. ɪspɛʃli wən ðə wʊmən wɑz əɹ spaɪ. dʒʌst əz sɛləm wɑz ləleɪnz. ɛɡwin əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət θiədʒɹɪn əɹ fɑoʊleɪn, boʊθ stɪl stændɪŋ duɾifəli ɪn ðɛɹ kɔɹnɝz laɪk æksɛptɪd, ɹæðɝ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz.

Romanda frowned, but she said nothing. After all, she could hardly show too much interest in one of Egwene's maids. Especially when the woman was her spy. Just as Selame was Lelaine's. Egwene avoided looking at Theodrin or Faolain, both still standing dutifully in their corners like Accepted, rather than Aes Sedai themselves.

tʃɛsə hæf-oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn, pɝhæps ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə sɪɾɝz. ɛɡwin wɑz ɹɪlivd wən ʃi dɪpt ənʌðɝ kɝtsi ən lɛft wɪð ə mɝmɝd "baɪ jəɹ liv, mʌðɝ." tʃɛsəz ædvaɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪndɝɛkt ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni sɪstɝ wən ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz pɹɛzənt, bʌt ɹaɪt ðɛn, ðə læs θɪŋ ɛɡwin wɑntəd wɑz ivən ə sɝkəmspɛkt ɹimaɪndɝ tə it waɪl əɹ fud wɑz hɑt.

Chesa half-opened her mouth, but closed it again, perhaps intimidated by the Sitters. Egwene was relieved when she dipped another curtsy and left with a murmured "By your leave, Mother." Chesa's advice was always indirect enough for any sister when anyone else was present, but right then, the last thing Egwene wanted was even a circumspect reminder to eat while her food was hot.

ləleɪn tʊk ʌp əz ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ɪntɝʌpʃən. "ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, "ɪz tə lɝn wʌt ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑnt. əɹ wʌt ðə bɔɪ dʌz. meɪbi hi wɑns tə bi ðɛɹ kɪŋ, tu." hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz, ʃi əlaʊd fɑoʊleɪn tə ɹɪstɔɹ əɹ kloʊk, wɪtʃ ðə dɑɹk jʌŋ wʊmən dɪd wɪð kɛɹ. "ju wɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə lemi noʊ ɪf juv ɛni θɔts ɑn ɪt, mʌðɝ?" ðət wɑz dʒʌs bɛɹli ə ɹɪkwɛst.

Lelaine took up as if there had been no interruption. "The important thing," she said firmly, "is to learn what the Atha'an Miere want. Or what the boy does. Maybe he wants to be their king, too." Holding out her arms, she allowed Faolain to restore her cloak, which the dark young woman did with care. "You will remember to let me know if you have any thoughts on it, Mother?" That was just barely a request.

"aɪ wɪl θɪŋk hɑɹd," ɛɡwin toʊl hɝ. wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt tə seɪ ʃi wəd ʃɛɹ əɹ θɔts. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə ði ænsɝ. ðət ði æθɑn maɪɹ bɪlivd ɹænd wɑz ðɛɹ pɹɑfəsaɪd kɔɹəmʊɹ, ʃi nu, ðoʊ ðə hɔl dɪd nɑt, bʌt wʌɾ i wɑntəd fɹəm ðɛm, əɹ əm fɹəm hɪm, ʃi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɪleɪn, ðə si foʊk wɪð əm hæd noʊ klu. əɹ sɛd nɑt. ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt wʌn ə ðə hændfʊl ə sɪstɝz u hæd kʌm fɹəm ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑz ɪn ðə kæmp. ɔlmoʊst. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ðoʊz wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ gɑnə kɑz tʃɹʌbəl.

"I will think hard," Egwene told her. Which was not to say she would share her thoughts. She wished she had a glimmer of the answer. That the Atha'an Miere believed Rand was their prophesied Coramoor, she knew, though the Hall did not, but what he wanted from them, or them from him, she could not begin to imagine. According to Elayne, the Sea Folk with them had no clue. Or said not. Egwene almost wished one of the handful of sisters who had come from the Atha'an Miere was in the camp. Almost. One way or another, those Windfinders were going to cause trouble.

əɾ ə weɪv ə ɹoʊmændəz hænd, θiədʒɹɪn lɛp fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə sɪɾɝz kloʊk əz ðoʊ ɡusd. baɪ ɹoʊmændəz ɪkspɹɛʃən, ləleɪnz ɹəkʌvɝi dɪd nɑt bɛs pliz hɝ. "ju wɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə tɛl mɛɝɪlɪl aɪ wɪʃ tə spik wɪð hɝ, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd, ən ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹɪkwɛst əɾ ɔl.

At a wave of Romanda's hand, Theodrin leaped forward with the Sitter's cloak as though goosed. By Romanda's expression, Lelaine's recovery did not best please her. "You will remember to tell Merilille I wish to speak with her, Mother," she said, and that was not a request at all.

fəɹ ə bɹif moʊmən ðə tu sɪɾɝz stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ɛɡwin fɝɡɑɾən əɡɛn ɪn ðɛɹ mjutʃəwəl ænəmɑsəɾi. ðeɪ dɪpɑɹɾəd wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd tə hɝ, vɛɹi nɪɹli dʒɑsəlɪŋ fəɹ pɹɛsəɾəns bɪfɔɹ ɹoʊmændə slɪpt aʊt fɝst, dʒɹɔɪŋ θiədʒɹɪn ɪn əɹ weɪk. bɛɹɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ləleɪn pɹæktəkli pʊʃt fɑoʊleɪn fɹəm ðə tɛn əhɛɾ ə hɝ.

For a brief moment the two Sitters stood staring at each other, Egwene forgotten again in their mutual animosity. They departed without a word to her, very nearly jostling for precedence before Romanda slipped out first, drawing Theodrin in her wake. Baring her teeth, Lelaine practically pushed Faolain from the tent ahead of her.

sɪuən hivd ə hɑɹɾi saɪ, ən meɪd noʊ ətɛmp tə haɪɾ əɹ ɹɪlif.

Siuan heaved a hearty sigh, and made no attempt to hide her relief.

"baɪ jəɹ liv, mʌðɝ," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd mɑkəŋli. "ɪf jə pliz, mʌðɝ. jə meɪ ɡoʊ, dɔɾɝz." lɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ, ʃi sɛɾəld bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. wɪtʃ pɹɑmpli pɪtʃt əɹ ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts ɪn ə hip. ʃi pɪk hɝsɛlf ʌp sloʊli ən dʒɝkt əɹ skɝts stʃɹeɪt, pʊɾ əɹ stoʊl tə ɹaɪts. ət list ɪt hæd nɑt hæpən ɪn fɹʌn ə ðoʊz tu. "ɡoʊ ɡɛt sʌmθɪŋ tə it, sɪuən. ən bɹɪŋ ɪt bæk. wiv ə lɔŋ deɪ, jɛt."

"By your leave, Mother," Egwene muttered mockingly. "If you please, Mother. You may go, daughters." Letting out a long breath, she settled back in her chair. Which promptly pitched her onto the carpets in a heap. She picked herself up slowly and jerked her skirts straight, put her stole to rights. At least it had not happened in front of those two. "Go get something to eat, Siuan. And bring it back. We've a long day, yet."

"sʌm fɔlz hɝt lɛs ðən ʌðɝz," sɪuən sɛɾ əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf bɪfɔɹ dʌkɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ʃi wɛn soʊ kwɪkli, əɹ ɛɡwin maɪɾ əv ɡɪvən əɹ ən ɪɹfəl.

"Some falls hurt less than others," Siuan said as if to herself before ducking outside. It was a good thing she went so quickly, or Egwene might have given her an earful.

ʃi ɹɪtɝn sun, ðoʊ, ən ðeɪ eɪt hɑɹd ɹoʊlz ən lɛntəl stu leɪst wɪð tʌf kæɹəɾ ən skɹæps ə miɾ ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt lʊk ət kloʊsli. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə fju ɪntɝʌpʃənz, ɪntʃɹuʒənz wɛɹ ðeɪ fɛl saɪlən ən pɹitɛndəd tə stʌɾi ɹɪpɔɹts. tʃɛsə keɪm tə teɪk əweɪ ðə tʃɹeɪ, ən leɪɾɝ tə ɹipleɪs ðə kændəlz, ə tæsk ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld oʊvɝ, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt laɪk hɝ.

She returned soon, though, and they ate hard rolls and lentil stew laced with tough carrot and scraps of meat Egwene did not look at closely. There were only a few interruptions, intrusions where they fell silent and pretended to study reports. Chesa came to take away the tray, and later to replace the candles, a task she grumbled over, which was not like her.

"huɾ ɪkspɛk sɛləm tə ɡoʊ mɪsɪŋ, tu?" ʃi mʌɾɝd, hæf tə hɝsɛlf. "ɔf kənudlɪŋ wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz, aɪ ɪkspɛkt. ðət hɑliməz ə bæɾ ɪnfluəns."

"Who'd expect Selame to go missing, too?" she muttered, half to herself. "Off canoodling with the soldiers, I expect. That Halima's a bad influence."

ə skɪni jʌŋ fɛloʊ wɪð ə dʒɹɪpɪŋ noʊz ɹɪnud ði ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd koʊlz ɪn ðə bɹeɪʒɝz - ði æmɪɝlɪn ɡɑt mɔɹ wɔɹmθ ðən moʊst, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil - ən i stʌmbəld oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn buts ən ɡeɪpt əɾ ɛɡwin ɪn ə mænɝ kwaɪt ɡɹæɾəfaɪɪŋ æftɝ ðə tu sɪɾɝz. ʃɛɹiəm əpɪɹd tə æsk wɛðɝ ɛɡwin hæɾ ɛni fɝðɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ən ðən sim tə wɑnə steɪ. pɝhæps ðə fju sikɹəts ʃi nu meɪɾ əɹ nɝvəs; hɝ aɪz sɝɾənli dɑɹɾɪd ənizəli.

A skinny young fellow with a dripping nose renewed the already dead coals in the braziers - the Amyrlin got more warmth than most, but that was not a great deal - and he stumbled over his own boots and gaped at Egwene in a manner quite gratifying after the two Sitters. Sheriam appeared to ask whether Egwene had any further instructions, of all things, and then seemed to want to stay. Perhaps the few secrets she knew made her nervous; her eyes certainly darted uneasily.

ðət wɑz ðə lɑt, ən ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz kəz noʊ wʌn bɑðɝd ði æmɪɝlɪn wɪθaʊt kɑz, əɹ kəz ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðə ɹil dɪsɪʒənz wɝ meɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl.

That was the lot, and Egwene was not sure whether it was because no one bothered the Amyrlin without cause, or because everyone knew the real decisions were made in the Hall.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs ɹipɔɹɾ ə soʊlʒɝz muvɪŋ saʊθ aʊɾ ə kændɝ," sɪuən sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə tɛntflæp fɛl bɪhaɪnd ʃɛɹiəm. "ðɛɹz dʒʌs ðə wʌn, ən bɔɹɾɝləndɝz sɛldəm ɡoʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə blaɪt, bʌɾ ɛvɹi ful noʊz ðæt, soʊ ɪts hɑɹdli ðə kaɪndə teɪl ɛniwʌn wəd meɪk ʌp." ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹiɾɪŋ fɹəm ə peɪdʒ, naʊ.

"I don't know about this report of soldiers moving south out of Kandor," Siuan said as soon as the tentflap fell behind Sheriam. "There's just the one, and Borderlanders seldom go far from the Blight, but every fool knows that, so it's hardly the kind of tale anyone would make up." She was not reading from a page, now.

sɪuən hæd mænədʒ tə kip vɛɹi tɛnjəwəs kəntʃɹoʊl ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz nɛtwɝk ʌv aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz soʊ fɑɹ, ən ɹɪpɔɹts, ɹumɝz, ən ɡɑsəp floʊd tə hɝ ɪn stɛɾi stʃɹimz, tə bi stʌɾid bɪfɔɹ ʃi ən ɛɡwin dɪsaɪɾɪd wʌt tə pæs ɑn tə ðə hɔl. lin hæɾ əɹ oʊn nɛtwɝk, tə æd tə ðə floʊ. moʊst ʌv ɪt wɑz pæst ɑn - səm θɪŋz ðə hɔl hæd tə noʊ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɛɹənti ðət ði ədʒəz wəd pæs ɑn wʌt ðɛɹ oʊn eɪdʒəns lɝnd - bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔl hæd tə bi siv fəɹ wʌt maɪt bi deɪnʒɝəs, əɹ sɝv tə daɪvɝɾ ətɛnʃən fɹəm ðə ɹil ɡoʊl.

Siuan had managed to keep very tenuous control of the Amyrlin's network of eyes-and-ears so far, and reports, rumors, and gossip flowed to her in steady streams, to be studied before she and Egwene decided what to pass on to the Hall. Leane had her own network, to add to the flow. Most of it was passed on - some things the Hall had to know, and there was no guarantee that the Ajahs would pass on what their own agents learned - but it all had to be sieved for what might be dangerous, or serve to divert attention from the real goal.

fju ʌv ðoʊz stʃɹimz kæɹiɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɡʊd, ʌv leɪt. kɛɹhin hæd pɹədust ɛni nʌmbɝ ə ɹumɝz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ əlaɪd wɪð ɹænd, ɔɹ, wɝs, sɝvɪŋ hɪm, jɛɾ ət lis ðoʊz kəd bi dɪsmɪst aʊɾ ə hænd. ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd nɑt seɪ mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl əbaʊt ɹænd əɹ ɛniwʌn kənɛktəd tə hɪm, bʌɾ əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðɛm, mɛɹænə wɑz əweɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɹɪtɝn, ən sɝɾənli sɪstɝz ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs, wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kɛpt ɪz fɝs θɹoʊn, wɝ mɔɹ ðən siɾ ɪnʌf tə ɡɹoʊ ðoʊz teɪlz. ʌðɝz wɝ nɑɾ izəli ɪɡnɔɹd, ivən wən ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə noʊ wʌt tə meɪk ə ðɛm. ə pɹɪntɝ ɪn ɪljən əsɝɾəd ðəɾ i hæd pɹuf ɹænd hæd kɪl mæɾɪn stɛpeɪnəoʊz wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz ən dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə bɑɾi wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, waɪl ə leɪbɝɝ ɑn ðə dɑks ðəɹ kleɪmd ʃi hæd sin ðə fɔɹmɝ kɪŋ kæɹid, baʊn ən ɡæɡd ən ɹoʊld ɪn ə ɹʌɡ, əbɔɹɾ ə ʃɪp ðət hæd seɪld ɪn ðə naɪt wɪð ðə blɛsɪŋz ə ðə kæptən ə ðə pɔɹt wɑtʃ. ðə fɝst wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ laɪkli, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hoʊp nʌn ə ði ədʒəz' eɪdʒəns hæd pɪkt ʌp ðə seɪm teɪl. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi tu mɛni blæk mɑɹks əɡɛnst ɹændz neɪm ɪn ðə sɪstɝz' bʊks.

Few of those streams carried anything good, of late. Cairhien had produced any number of rumors of Aes Sedai allied with Rand, or, worse, serving him, yet at least those could be dismissed out of hand. The Wise Ones would not say much at all about Rand or anyone connected to him, but according to them, Merana was awaiting his return, and certainly sisters in the Sun Palace, where the Dragon Reborn kept his first throne, were more than seed enough to grow those tales. Others were not easily ignored, even when it was hard to know what to make of them. A printer in Illian asserted that he had proof Rand had killed Mattin Stepaneos with his own hands and destroyed the body with the One Power, while a laborer on the docks there claimed she had seen the former King carried, bound and gagged and rolled in a rug, aboard a ship that had sailed in the night with the blessings of the captain of the Port Watch. The first was far more likely, but Egwene hoped none of the Ajahs' agents had picked up the same tale. There were already too many black marks against Rand's name in the sisters' books.

ɪt wɛn ɑn laɪk ðæt. ðə sintʃæn sim tə bi teɪkɪŋ ə fɝm hoʊld ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, əɡɛns vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɹɪzɪstəns. ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn ə lænd wɛɹ ðə kwinz tʃɹu ɹul ɛndəɾ ə fju deɪz' ɹaɪd fɹəm əɹ kæpəɾəl, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli hɑɹɾənɪŋ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sim tə bi ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ðoʊ wɝɾ ə ðɛm ɔlweɪz keɪm fɹəm sʌmwʌn u hæd hɝd fɹəm sʌmwʌn u hæd hɝd. moʊst sɪstɝz sim tə bɪliv ðə skæɾɝd ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ɹændz wɝk dɪspaɪt ðə waɪz wʌnz' dɪnaɪəlz, kæɹid baɪ ʃɛɹiəm. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə pɹoʊb ðə waɪz wʌnz' səpoʊz laɪz tu kloʊsli, ʌv kɔɹs. ðəɹ wɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɪkskjusɪz, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə miɾ əm ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ ɪksɛp ðə sɪstɝz swɔɹn tə ɛɡwin, ən ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɔɹɾɝd. æneɪjə dʒɹaɪli kɔl ði ɪnkaʊntɝz "kwaɪt kɑmpæk lɛsənz ɪn hjumɪlɪɾi," ən ʃi dɪd nɑt sim əɾ ɔl əmjuzd.

It went on like that. The Seanchan seemed to be taking a firm hold in Ebou Dar, against very little resistance. That might have been expected in a land where the Queen's true rule ended a few days' ride from her capital, yet it was hardly heartening. The Shaido seemed to be everywhere, though word of them always came from someone who had heard from someone who had heard. Most sisters seemed to believe the scattered Shaido were Rand's work despite the Wise Ones' denials, carried by Sheriam. No one wanted to probe the Wise Ones' supposed lies too closely, of course. There were a hundred excuses, but no one was willing to meet them in Tel'aran'rhiod except the sisters sworn to Egwene, and they had to be ordered. Anaiya dryly called the encounters "quite compact lessons in humility," and she did not seem at all amused.

"ðɛɹ kæn bi ðət mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd. noʊ ɝbz hæd bɪn æɾəd tə ðə sɛkən bætʃ ə tʃɑɹkoʊl, wɪtʃ wɑz daɪɪŋ daʊn ɪn feɪn ɛmbɝz, ən əɹ aɪz ætʃt fɹəm ðə smoʊk ðət hʌŋ θɪn ɪn ði ɛɹ. tʃænəlɪŋ tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt wəd dɪspɝs ðə læst wɔɹmθ, tu. "sʌm ə ðɪs mʌs bi bændəts' wɝk." æftɝ ɔl, hu kəd tɛl ə vɪlədʒ ɛmptid baɪ pipəl fliɪŋ bɹɪɡænz fɹəm wʌn ɛmptid baɪ ʃeɪɾoʊ? ɪspɛʃli ət θɝd hænd, əɹ fɪfθ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ sɝɾənli ɪnʌf bændəts ɝaʊn tə əkaʊn fəɹ səm ʌv ɪt." moʊs kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, wɪtʃ wɑz noʊ hɛlp əɾ ɔl. ʃi wɝkt əɹ ʃoʊldɝz tə lusən ə fju ʌv ðə nɑts ɪn əɹ mʌsəlz.

"There can't be that many Shaido," Egwene muttered. No herbs had been added to the second batch of charcoal, which was dying down in faint embers, and her eyes ached from the smoke that hung thin in the air. Channeling to get rid of it would disperse the last warmth, too. "Some of this must be bandits' work." After all, who could tell a village emptied by people fleeing brigands from one emptied by Shaido? Especially at third hand, or fifth. "There are certainly enough bandits around to account for some of it." Most calling themselves Dragonsworn, which was no help at all. She worked her shoulders to loosen a few of the knots in her muscles.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət sɪuən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ soʊ ɪntɛnli ðət ʃi əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə slɪp ɔf ə hɝ stul. "sɪuən, ɑɹ jə fɔlɪŋ əslip? wi meɪ hæv wɝk moʊst ə ðə deɪ, bʌɾ ɪts stɪl laɪɾ aʊt." ðəɹ wɑz laɪɾ ət ðə smoʊk hoʊl, ðoʊ ɪt dɪɾ əpɪɹ tə bi feɪɾɪŋ.

Abruptly she realized that Siuan was staring at nothing so intently that she appeared ready to slip off of her stool. "Siuan, are you falling asleep? We may have worked most of the day, but it's still light out." There was light at the smoke hole, though it did appear to be fading.

sɪuən blɪŋkt. "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ leɪtli, ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə ʃɛɹ ɪt wɪð ju. əbaʊt ðə hɔl."

Siuan blinked. "I'm sorry. I've been thinking about something lately, and trying to decide whether to share it with you. About the Hall."

"ðə hɔl! sɪuən, ɪf jə noʊ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə hɔl - !"

"The Hall! Siuan, if you know something about the Hall - !"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ," sɪuən kʌɾ ɪn. "ɪts wʌɾ aɪ səspɛkt." ʃi klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ənɔɪəns. "nɑɾ ivən səspɛkt, ɹɪli. ət list, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt tə səspɛkt. bʌɾ aɪ si ə pæɾɝn."

"I don't know anything," Siuan cut in. "It's what I suspect." She clicked her tongue in annoyance. "Not even suspect, really. At least, I don't know what to suspect. But I see a pattern."

"ðɛn jə hæd bɛs tɛl mi əbaʊɾ ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd. sɪuən hæd ʃoʊn hɝsɛlf vɛɹi skɪld ət dɪtɛktɪŋ pæɾɝnz wɛɹ ʌðɝz sɔ oʊnli ə dʒʌmbəl.

"Then you had best tell me about it," Egwene said. Siuan had shown herself very skilled at detecting patterns where others saw only a jumble.

ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn əɹ stul, sɪuən lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli. "ɪts ðɪs. əsaɪd fɹəm ɹoʊmændə ən mɔɹiə, ðə sɪɾɝz tʃoʊzən ɪn sɑlədɑɹ ɑɹ . . . ðəɹ tu jʌŋ." mʌtʃ hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn sɪuən, bʌt spikɪŋ ʌv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz' eɪdʒəz klɪɹli meɪɾ əɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. "ɛskɹɑldi ɪz ði oʊldəst, ən aɪm ʃʊɹ ʃi ɪzən mʌtʃ pæst sɛvənti. aɪ kæn bi sɝɾən wɪθaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə nɑvəs bʊk ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, əɹ əɹ tɛlɪŋ ʌs, bʌɾ aɪm əz ʃʊɹ əz aɪ kən bi. ɪɾ ɪzən ɔfən ðə hɔl əz hɛl mɔɹ ðən wʌn sɪɾɝ ʌndɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd, ən hɪɹ wɪv eɪt!"

Shifting on her stool, Siuan leaned forward intently. "It's this. Aside from Romanda and Moria, the Sitters chosen in Salidar are . . . they're too young." Much had changed in Siuan, but speaking of other sisters' ages clearly made her uncomfortable. "Escaralde is the oldest, and I'm sure she isn't much past seventy. I can't be certain without going into the novice book in Tar Valon, or her telling us, but I'm as sure as I can be. It isn't often the Hall has held more than one Sitter under a hundred, and here we have eight!"

"bʌt ɹoʊmændə ən mɔɹiə ɑɹ nu," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɛnli, ɹɛstɪŋ əɹ ɛlboʊz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ deɪ. "ænd niðɝ ɪz jʌŋ. meɪbi wi ʃəd bi ɡɹeɪtfəl ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ, əɹ ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə ɹeɪz mi." ʃi cʊɾə pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət sɪuən hɝsɛlf hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən æmɪɝlɪn ət lɛs ðən hæf ɛskɹɑldiz eɪdʒ, bʌt ðə ɹimaɪndɝ wʊɾə bɪn kɹuəl.

"But Romanda and Moria are new," Egwene said gently, resting her elbows on the table. It had been a long day. "And neither is young. Maybe we should be grateful the others are, or they might not have been willing to raise me." She could have pointed out that Siuan herself had been chosen Amyrlin at less than half Escaralde's age, but the reminder would have been cruel.

"meɪbi," sɪuən sɛd stʌbɝnli. "ɹoʊmændə wɑz sɝɾən fəɹ ðə hɔl əz sun əz ʃi ʃoʊɾ ʌp. aɪ daʊt ðɛɹz ə jɛloʊ wəd dɛɹ spik əɡɛnst əɹ fəɹ ə tʃɛɹ. ən mɔɹiə. . . . ʃi dʌzn klɪŋ tə ləleɪn, bʌt ləleɪn ən laɪɹɛl pɹɑbli θɔt ʃi wʊd. aɪ doʊnt noʊ. mɑɹk mi, ðoʊ. wən ə wʊmən ɪz ɹeɪz tu jʌŋ, ðɛɹz ə ɹizən." ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪnkluɾɪŋ wən aɪ wɑz." ðə peɪn ə lɔs flæʃt əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs, ðə lɔs ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit sɝɾənli, meɪbi ʌv ɔl ðə lɔsəz ʃi hæd sʌfɝd. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz ɪt keɪm. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn ə wʊmən əz stʃɹɔŋ əz sɪuən sɑntʃ. "ðɪs taɪm, ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf sɪstɝz ə pɹɑpɝ eɪdʒ tə tʃuz fɹʌm, ən aɪ kæn si faɪv ədʒəz dɛdlɑkɪŋ ɑn ɔl ə ðɛm. ðəɹ ɪz ə pæɾɝn, ən aɪ min tə pɪk ɪɾ aʊt."

"Maybe," Siuan said stubbornly. "Romanda was certain for the Hall as soon as she showed up. I doubt there's a Yellow would dare speak against her for a chair. And Moria. . . . She doesn't cling to Lelaine, but Lelaine and Lyrelle probably thought she would. I don't know. Mark me, though. When a woman is raised too young, there's a reason." She took a deep breath. "Including when I was." The pain of loss flashed across her face, the loss of the Amyrlin Seat certainly, maybe of all the losses she had suffered. It was gone almost as soon as it came. Egwene did not think she had ever known a woman as strong as Siuan Sanche. "This time, there were more than enough sisters of proper age to choose from, and I can't see five Ajahs deadlocking on all of them. There is a pattern, and I mean to pick it out."

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑɾ əɡɹi. tʃeɪnʒ hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ wɛðɝ sɪuən wɑntəd tə si ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. ɪleɪɾə hæd bɹoʊkən kʌstəm, kʌm vɛɹi kloʊs tə bɹeɪkɪŋ lɔ, ɪn jusɝpɪŋ sɪuənz pleɪs. sɪstɝz hæd flɛd ðə taʊɝ ən lɛt ðə wɝl noʊ ʌv ɪt, ən ðət læst sɝɾənli hæd nɛvɝ hæpən bɪfɔɹ. tʃeɪnʒ. oʊldɝ sɪstɝz wɝ mɔɹ laɪkli tə bi taɪd tə ði oʊld weɪz, bʌɾ ivən səm ə ðɛm hæd tə si ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ʃɪftɪŋ. ʃʊɹli ðət wɑz waɪ jʌŋɡɝ wɪmən, mɔɹ oʊpən tə ðə nu, hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən. ʃəd ʃi ɔɹɾɝ sɪuən tə stɑp weɪstɪŋ əɹ taɪm wɪð ðɪs? sɪuən hæɾ ɪnʌf ɛls tə du. əɹ wəɾ ɪt bi ə kaɪndnəs tə lɛɾ əɹ kəntɪnju? ʃi wɑntəd soʊ dipli tə pɹuv ðət ðə tʃeɪnʒ ʃi sɔ wɑz nɑt ɹɪli əkɝɪŋ əɾ ɔl.

Egwene did not agree. Change hung in the air whether Siuan wanted to see it or not. Elaida had broken custom, come very close to breaking law, in usurping Siuan's place. Sisters had fled the Tower and let the world know of it, and that last certainly had never happened before. Change. Older sisters were more likely to be tied to the old ways, but even some of them had to see that everything was shifting. Surely that was why younger women, more open to the new, had been chosen. Should she order Siuan to stop wasting her time with this? Siuan had enough else to do. Or would it be a kindness to let her continue? She wanted so deeply to prove that the change she saw was not really occurring at all.

bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin kəd meɪk ə dɪsɪʒən, ɹoʊmændə dʌkt ɪndə ðə tɛn ən stʊd hoʊldɪŋ ðə tɛntflæp oʊpən. lɔŋ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ aʊtsaɪd. ivnɪŋ wɑz kʌmɪŋ fæst. ɹoʊmændəz feɪs wɑz əz dɑɹk əz ðoʊz ʃædoʊz. ʃi fɪkst sɪuən wɪð ə stɝn ɡeɪz ən snæpt wʌn wɝd. "aʊt!"

Before Egwene could make a decision, Romanda ducked into the tent and stood holding the tentflap open. Long shadows stretched across the snow outside. Evening was coming fast. Romanda's face was as dark as those shadows. She fixed Siuan with a stern gaze and snapped one word. "Out!"

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ən ɪnfɪnɪtɛsɪməl nɑd, bʌt sɪuən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn əɹ fit. ʃi mɪst ə stɛp, ðən ɔl bʌt ɹæn fɹəm ðə tɛnt. ə sɪstɝ u stʊd wɛɹ sɪuən dɪd wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə oʊbeɪ ɛni sɪstɝ ə ɹoʊmændəz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, nɑt dʒʌst ə sɪɾɝ.

Egwene gave an infinitesimal nod, but Siuan was already on her feet. She missed a step, then all but ran from the tent. A sister who stood where Siuan did was expected to obey any sister of Romanda's strength in the Power, not just a Sitter.

θɹoʊɪŋ daʊn ðə tɛntflæp, ɹoʊmændə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd hɝ, ən ʃi woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɝaʊn ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə pɹitɛns ʌv æskɪŋ ɛɡwinz pɝmɪʃən. "ju ɑɹ ə ful!" ʃi ɡɹeɪɾɪd. "haʊ lɔŋ dɪd jə θɪŋk jə kəd kip ðɪs ə sikɹət? soʊlʒɝz tɔk, tʃaɪld. mɛn ɔlweɪz tɔk! bɹaɪn wɪl bi lʌki ɪf ðə hɔl dʌzn pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ə paɪk."

Throwing down the tentflap, Romanda embraced the Source. The glow of saidar surrounded her, and she wove a ward against eavesdropping around the inside of the tent without so much as a pretense of asking Egwene's permission. "You are a fool!" she grated. "How long did you think you could keep this a secret? Soldiers talk, child. Men always talk! Bryne will be lucky if the Hall doesn't put his head on a pike."

ɛɡwin stʊd sloʊli, smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝt. ʃi hæd bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɪs, bʌt ʃi stɪl niɾəd tə bi kɛɹfəl. ðə ɡeɪm wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm pleɪɾ aʊt, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd stɪl tɝn əɡɛnst əɹ ɪn ə flæʃ. ʃi hæd tə pɹitɛn ɪnəsəns, əntɪl ʃi kəɾ əfɔɹd tə stɑp pɹitɛndɪŋ. "mʌst aɪ ɹimaɪn jə ðət ɹudnəs tə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪz ə kɹaɪm, dɔɾɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. ʃi hæd bɪn pɹitɛndɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ, ən ʃi wɑz soʊ kloʊz.

Egwene stood slowly, smoothing her skirt. She had been waiting for this, but she still needed to be careful. The game was far from played out, and everything could still turn against her in a flash. She had to pretend innocence, until she could afford to stop pretending. "Must I remind you that rudeness to the Amyrlin Seat is a crime, daughter," she said instead. She had been pretending so long, and she was so close.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit." ɹoʊmændə stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts tə wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ ʌv ɛɡwin, ən baɪ hɝ ɡlɛɹ, ðə θɔɾ ə ɹitʃɪŋ mɔɹ kɹɔst əɹ maɪnd. "jɔɹ ən ɪnfənt! jəɹ bɑɾəm stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðə læst swɪtʃɪŋ ɪt hæɾ əz ə nɑvəs! æftɝ ðɪs, jəl bi lʌki ɪf ðə hɔl dʌzn pʊt jə ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ wɪð ə fju pleɪ pɹɪɾiz. ɪf jə wɑnə əvɔɪd ðæt, jəl lɪsən tə mi, ən də əz aɪ tɛl ju. naʊ, sɪt daʊn!"

"The Amyrlin Seat." Romanda strode across the carpets to within arm's reach of Egwene, and by her glare, the thought of reaching more crossed her mind. "You're an infant! Your bottom still remembers the last switching it had as a novice! After this, you'll be lucky if the Hall doesn't put you in a corner with a few play pretties. If you want to avoid that, you will listen to me, and do as I tell you. Now, sit down!"

ɛɡwin siðd ɪnsaɪd, bʌt ʃi sæt. ɪt wɑz tu sun.

Egwene seethed inside, but she sat. It was too soon.

wɪð ə ʃɑɹp, sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd, ɹoʊmændə plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. ʃi stɛɹd daʊn əɾ ɛɡwin laɪk ə stɝn æn lɛktʃɝɪŋ ə mɪsbəheɪvɪŋ nis. ə vɛɹi stɝn ænt. əɹ ə hɛdzmən wɪð ə tuθæk. "ðɪs miɾɪŋ wɪð pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɑɝəθɛl əz tə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd, naʊ ɪts bɪn ɝeɪnʒd. ðeɪ ɪkspɛk ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ðəl si hɝ. jəl ətɛnd wɪð ɔl ðə pɑmp ən dɪɡnəɾi jəɹ taɪɾəl dɪzɝvz. ən jəl tɛl əm aɪm tə spik fəɹ ju, æftɝ wɪtʃ, jəl hoʊl jəɹ tʌŋ! ɡɛɾɪŋ əm aʊɾ ʌv əɹ weɪ wɪl ɹikwaɪɝ ə fɝm hænd, ən sʌmwʌn u noʊz wʌt ʃiz əbaʊt. noʊ daʊt ləleɪn wɪl bi hɪɹ ɛni mɪnət, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt hɝsɛlf fɔɹwɝd, bʌt jə dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə tʃɹʌbəl ʃiz ɪn. aɪv spɛn ðə deɪ spikɪŋ wɪð ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz, ən ɪɾ əpɪɹz vɛɹi laɪkli ðət mɛɝɪlɪl ən mɛɹænəz feɪljɝz wɪl bi kwaɪt fɝmli ətætʃt tə ləleɪn wən ðə hɔl sɪts nɛkst. soʊ, ɪf juv ɛni hoʊp ʌv ɡeɪnɪŋ ði ɪkspɪɹiəns jəl nid tə ɡɹoʊ ɪndə ðət stoʊl, ɪt laɪz wɪð mi! dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?"

With a sharp, satisfied nod, Romanda planted her fists on her hips. She stared down at Egwene like a stern aunt lecturing a misbehaving niece. A very stern aunt. Or a headsman with a toothache. "This meeting with Pelivar and Arathelle has to go forward, now it's been arranged. They expect the Amyrlin Seat, and they will see her. You will attend with all the pomp and dignity your title deserves. And you will tell them I am to speak for you, after which, you will hold your tongue! Getting them out of our way will require a firm hand, and someone who knows what she's about. No doubt Lelaine will be here any minute, trying to put herself forward, but you just remember the trouble she's in. I've spent the day speaking with other Sitters, and it appears very likely that Merilille and Merana's failures will be quite firmly attached to Lelaine when the Hall sits next. So, if you have any hope of gaining the experience you'll need to grow into that stole, it lies with me! Do you understand me?"

"aɪ ʌndɝstæn pɝfəkli," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɪn wʌt ʃi hoʊpt wɑz ə mik vɔɪs. ɪf ʃi lɛt ɹoʊmændə spik ɪn əɹ pleɪs, ðəɹ wəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi ɛni daʊts. ðə hɔl ən ðə hoʊl wɝld wəd noʊ hu hɛld ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə hɝ nɛk.

"I understand perfectly," Egwene said, in what she hoped was a meek voice. If she let Romanda speak in her place, there would no longer be any doubts. The Hall and the whole world would know who held Egwene al'Vere by the scruff of her neck.

ɹoʊmændəz aɪz sim tə bɔɹ ɪndə hɝ hɛd bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən ɡeɪv ə kɝt nɑd. "aɪ hoʊp ðət jə du. aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɹimuv ɪleɪɾə fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən aɪ woʊn si ðət ɹuən kəz ə tʃaɪl θɪŋks ʃi noʊz ɪnʌf tə faɪn əɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit wɪθaʊɾ əɹ hæn hɛld." wɪð ə snɔɹt, ʃi flʌŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ən flʌŋ hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. ðə wɔɹd vænɪʃt əz ʃi dɪd.

Romanda's eyes seemed to bore into her head before the woman gave a curt nod. "I hope that you do. I intend to remove Elaida from the Amyrlin Seat, and I won't see that ruined because a child thinks she knows enough to find her way across the street without her hand held." With a snort, she flung her cloak around her and flung herself out of the tent. The ward vanished as she did.

ɛɡwin sæɾ ən fɹaʊn ət ðə tɛns ɛntʃɹɑns. ə tʃaɪld? bɝn ðə wʊmən, ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! wɛðɝ ðeɪ laɪkt ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ hæd ɹeɪz hɝ, ən ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə hæv tə lɪv wɪð ɪt! ɪvɛntʃəwəli. snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə stoʊn ɪŋkwɛl, ʃi hɝld ɪɾ ət ðə tɛntflæp.

Egwene sat and frowned at the tent's entrance. A child? Burn the woman, she was the Amyrlin Seat! Whether they liked it or not, they had raised her, and they were going to have to live with it! Eventually. Snatching up the stone inkwell, she hurled it at the tentflap.

ləleɪn dɑdʒ bæk, bɛɹli əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə splæʃ. "tɛmpɝ, tɛmpɝ," ʃi tʃaɪɾɪd, kʌmɪŋ ɑn ɪn.

Lelaine dodged back, barely avoiding the splash. "Temper, temper," she chided, coming on in.

noʊ mɔɹ æskɪŋ pɝmɪʃən ðən ɹoʊmændə hæd, ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən woʊv ə wɔɹd tə stɑp ɛniwʌn oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd tə seɪ. wɛɹ ɹoʊmændə hæd bɪn ɪn ə fjʊɹi, ləleɪn əpɪɹd plizd wɪð hɝsɛlf, ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌv hænz ən smaɪlɪŋ.

No more asking permission than Romanda had, she embraced the Source and wove a ward to stop anyone overhearing what she had to say. Where Romanda had been in a fury, Lelaine appeared pleased with herself, rubbing her gloved hands and smiling.

"aɪ doʊn səpoʊz aɪ nid tɛl jə jəɹ lɪɾəl sikɹəɾ ɪz aʊt. vɛɹi bæɾ ə lɔɹd bɹaɪn, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk hiz tu væljəbəl tə kɪl. ə ɡʊd θɪŋ fəɹ ɪm aɪ du. lemi si. aɪ səpoʊz ɹoʊmændə toʊl jə ðət ðəɹ wɪl bi ə miɾɪŋ wɪð pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɑɝəθɛl, bʌt jə ɑɹ tə lɛɾ əɹ də ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ. æm aɪ ɹaɪt?" ɛɡwin stɝd, bʌt ləleɪn weɪvd ə hæn ət hɝ. "noʊ nid tə ænsɝ. aɪ noʊ ɹoʊmændə. ənfɔɹtʃənətli fəɹ hɝ, aɪ lɝn əbaʊt ðɪs bɪfɔɹ ʃi dɪd, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ tə jə stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ, aɪv bɪn poʊlɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz. dʒju wɑnə noʊ wʌt ðeɪ θɪŋk?"

"I don't suppose I need tell you your little secret is out. Very bad of Lord Bryne, but I think he's too valuable to kill. A good thing for him I do. Let me see. I suppose Romanda told you that there will be a meeting with Pelivar and Arathelle, but you are to let her do all the talking. Am I right?" Egwene stirred, but Lelaine waved a hand at her. "No need to answer. I know Romanda. Unfortunately for her, I learned about this before she did, and instead of running to you straightaway, I've been polling the other Sitters. Do you want to know what they think?"

ɛɡwin bɔld əɹ fɪsts ɪn əɹ læp, wɛɹ ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi noʊɾəst. "aɪ ɪkspɛk jəɹ gɑnə tɛl mi."

Egwene balled her fists in her lap, where she hoped they would not be noticed. "I expect you're going to tell me."

"ju ɑɹ ɪn noʊ pəzɪʃən tə teɪk ðət toʊn wɪð mi," ləleɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli, bʌt ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, hɝ smaɪl ɹɪtɝnd. "ðə hɔl ɪz dɪsplizd wɪð ju. vɛɹi dɪsplizd. wʌtɛvɝ ɹoʊmændə hæz θɹɛɾənd jə wɪð - ən ɪts izi ɪnʌf tə ɪmædʒən - aɪ kən dɪlɪvɝ. ɹoʊmændə, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hæz əpsɛɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə sɪɾɝz wɪð əɹ bʊliɪŋ. soʊ, ənlɛs jə wɑnə faɪn jɝsɛlf wɪð lɛs əθɔɹəɾi ðən ðə lɪɾəl juv naʊ, ɹoʊmændə ɪz gɑnə bi sɝpɹaɪz təmɑɹoʊ wən jə neɪm mi tə spik fəɹ ju. ɪts hɑɹd tə bɪliv ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ wɝ fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə pʊɾ ə θɪŋ laɪk ðɪs ɪn moʊʃən, bʌt ðəl slɪŋk əweɪ wɪð ðɛɹ teɪlz bɪtwin ðɛɹ lɛɡz wʌns aɪm dʌn wɪð ðɛm."

"You are in no position to take that tone with me," Lelaine said sharply, but the next instant, her smile returned. "The Hall is displeased with you. Very displeased. Whatever Romanda has threatened you with - and it's easy enough to imagine - I can deliver. Romanda, on the other hand, has upset a number of Sitters with her bullying. So, unless you want to find yourself with less authority than the little you have now, Romanda is going to be surprised tomorrow when you name me to speak for you. It's hard to believe Arathelle and Pelivar were foolish enough to put a thing like this in motion, but they'll slink away with their tails between their legs once I'm done with them."

"haʊ də aɪ noʊ jə woʊn kæɹi aʊt ðoʊz θɹɛts ɛniweɪ?" ɛɡwin hoʊpt əɹ æŋɡɹi mʌɾɝ saʊndəd laɪk sʌlənnəs. laɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz taɪɝɾ ə ðɪs!

"How do I know you won't carry out those threats anyway?" Egwene hoped her angry mutter sounded like sullenness. Light, but she was tired of this!

"bɪkɔz aɪ seɪ aɪ woʊnt," ləleɪn snæpt. "doʊn jə noʊ baɪ naʊ ðət jə ɑɹən ɹɪli ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ? ðə hɔl ɪz, ən ðəɾ ɪz bɪtwin ɹoʊmændə ən mi. ɪn ənʌðɝ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, jə meɪ ɡɹoʊ ɪndə ðə stoʊl, bʌt fəɹ naʊ, sɪt kwaɪətli, foʊl jəɹ hænz, ən lɛt sʌmwʌn u noʊz wʌt ʃiz əbaʊt si tə pʊlɪŋ ɪleɪɾə daʊn."

"Because I say I won't," Lelaine snapped. "Don't you know by now that you aren't really in charge of anything? The Hall is, and that is between Romanda and me. In another hundred years, you may grow into the stole, but for now, sit quietly, fold your hands, and let someone who knows what she is about see to pulling Elaida down."

æftɝ ləleɪn lɛft, ɛɡwin wʌns mɔɹ sæt stɛɹɪŋ. ðɪs taɪm, ʃi wɑz nɑt lɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɝ bɔɪl. jə meɪ ɡɹoʊ ɪndə ðə stoʊl. ɔlmoʊs ðə seɪm θɪŋ ɹoʊmændə hæd sɛd. sʌmwʌn u noʊz wʌt ʃiz əbaʊt. wɑz ʃi dɪsivɪŋ hɝsɛlf? ə tʃaɪld, ɹuɪnɪŋ wʌɾ ə wʊmən wɪð ɪkspɪɹiəns kəd hændəl izəli?

After Lelaine left, Egwene once more sat staring. This time, she was not letting anger boil. You may grow into the stole. Almost the same thing Romanda had said. Someone who knows what she is about. Was she deceiving herself? A child, ruining what a woman with experience could handle easily?

sɪuən slɪpt ɪndə ðə tɛn ən stʊd lʊkɪŋ wɝid. "ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn dʒʌs keɪm tə tɛl mi ðə hɔl noʊz," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ʌv æskɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz ʃɝts. hɪm ən ɪz blʌɾi ʃɝts! ðə miɾɪŋ ɪz sɛt fəɹ təmɑɹoʊ, əɾ ə leɪk əbaʊt faɪv aʊɝz tə ðə nɔɹθ. pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɑɝəθɛl ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə weɪ. æɛmlɪn, tu. ðæts ə θɝd stʃɹɔŋ haʊs."

Siuan slipped into the tent and stood looking worried. "Gareth Bryne just came to tell me the Hall knows," she said dryly. "Under cover of asking about his shirts. Him and his bloody shirts! The meeting is set for tomorrow, at a lake about five hours to the north. Pelivar and Arathelle are already on the way. Aemlyn, too. That's a third strong House."

"ðæts mɔɹ ðən ləleɪn əɹ ɹoʊmændə sɔ fɪt tə tɛl mi," ɛɡwin sɛd, dʒʌst əz dʒɹaɪli. noʊ. ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ə biɪŋ lɛd baɪ ðə hænd, pʊʃt baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə hɝ nɛk, əɹ fɪfti jɪɹz, əɹ faɪv, ən ʃi wəd bi fɪt fəɹ nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. ɪf ʃi hæd tə ɡɹoʊ, ʃi hæd tə ɡɹoʊ naʊ.

"That's more than Lelaine or Romanda saw fit to tell me," Egwene said, just as dryly. No. A hundred years of being led by the hand, pushed by the scruff of her neck, or fifty years, or five, and she would be fit for nothing more. If she had to grow, she had to grow now.

"oʊ, blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," sɪuən ɡɹoʊnd. "aɪ kæn stæn ɪt! wʌd ðeɪ seɪ? haʊ dɪɾ ɪt ɡoʊ?"

"Oh, blood and bloody ashes," Siuan groaned. "I can't stand it! What did they say? How did it go?"

"əbaʊɾ əz wi ɪkspɛktəd." ɛɡwin smaɪld wɪð ə wʌndɝ ðət tʌtʃt əɹ vɔɪs, tu. "sɪuən, ðeɪ kʊdn əv hændəd mi ðə hɔl bɛɾɝ ɪf aɪ hæd toʊld əm wʌt tə du."

"About as we expected." Egwene smiled with a wonder that touched her voice, too. "Siuan, they couldn't have handed me the Hall better if I had told them what to do."
