ðə læs laɪt wɑz feɪlɪŋ əz ʃɛɹiəm əpɹoʊtʃt əɹ taɪni tɛnt, smɔlɝ ivən ðən ɛɡwinz. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn kipɝ, ʃi wʊɾə hæd tə ʃɛɹ. dʌkɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, ʃi hæɾ oʊnli taɪm tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn wən ʃi wɑz ʃildɪɾ ən flʌŋ feɪsdaʊn ɑn əɹ kɑt. stʌnd, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɹaɪ aʊt, bʌɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ʌv wʌn ə hɝ blæŋkəts wɑɾəd ɪtsɛlf ɪndə hɝ maʊθ. dʒɹɛs ən ʃɪf bɝst əweɪ fɹəm əɹ bɑɾi laɪk ə pɹɪk bʌbəl.

The last light was failing as Sheriam approached her tiny tent, smaller even than Egwene's. If she had not been Keeper, she would have had to share. Ducking inside, she had only time to realize she was not alone when she was shielded and flung facedown on her cot. Stunned, she tried to cry out, but a corner of one of her blankets wadded itself into her mouth. Dress and shift burst away from her body like a pricked bubble.

ə hæn stʃɹoʊkt əɹ hɛd. "ju wɝ səpoʊz tə kip mi ɪnfɔɹmd, ʃɛɹiəm. ðət ɡɝl ɪz ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ, ən aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌt."

A hand stroked her head. "You were supposed to keep me informed, Sheriam. That girl is up to something, and I want to know what."

ɪt tʊk ə lɔŋ taɪm tə kənvɪns əɹ kwɛstʃənɝ ðət ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊld ɔl ʃi nu, ðət ʃi wəd nɛvɝ hoʊl bæk ə wɝd, nɑɾ ə wɪspɝ. wən ʃi wɑz lɛft əloʊn ət læst, ɪt wɑz tə laɪ kɝld ʌp ən wɪmpɝɪŋ fɹəm əɹ wɛls, bɪɾɝli wɪʃɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɪn əɹ laɪf spoʊkən tə ə sɪŋɡəl sɪstɝ ɪn ðə hɔl.

It took a long time to convince her questioner that she had already told all she knew, that she would never hold back a word, not a whisper. When she was left alone at last, it was to lie curled up and whimpering from her welts, bitterly wishing that she had never in her life spoken to a single sister in the Hall.


tʃæptɝ sɛvəntin


CHAPTER 17

aʊɾ ɑn ði aɪs


Out on the Ice

ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, ə kɑləm ɹoʊd nɔɹθ fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp wɛl bɪfɔɹ dɔn, nɪɹ saɪlən ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə kɹik ə sæɾəlz ən ðə kɹʌntʃ ə hʊvz bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊz kɹɪsp kɹʌst. əkeɪʒənəli ə hɔɹs snɔɹɾɪd, əɹ mɛɾəl dʒɪŋɡəld ən wɑz kwɪkli mʌfəld. ðə mun wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi daʊn, ðə skaɪ ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɪð stɑɹz, bʌt ðə peɪl blæŋkət laɪɪŋ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪloʊ laɪɾənd ðə dɑɹknəs. wən ðə fɝst ɡlɪmɝz ə deɪ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ist, ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə ɡʊɾ aʊɝ əɹ mɔɹ. wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt tə seɪ ðeɪ hæd tʃɹævəl fɑɹ. oʊvɝ səm oʊpən stʃɹɛtʃəz, ɛɡwin kəd lɛt deɪʃɝ ɡoʊ əɾ ə sloʊ kæntɝ ðət spɹeɪd waɪt laɪk splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ðə hɔɹsəz wɔkt, ən nɑt kwɪkli, θɹu spɑɹs fɔɹəst wɛɹ ðə snoʊ meɪd dip dʒɹɪfs bɪloʊ ən klʌŋ tə bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd. oʊk ən paɪn, saʊɝɡəm ən lɛðɝlif ən tʃɹiz ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɔl lʊkt ivən mɔɹ bi dʒɹæɡəl ðən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ðə hiɾ ən dʒɹaʊt. tədeɪ wɑz ðə fist ʌv əbɹæm, bʌt ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ pɹaɪzəz beɪkt ɪn hʌnikeɪks. ðə laɪt sɛn səm pipəl faʊn sɝpɹaɪzəz ɪn ðə deɪ, ðoʊ.

The next morning, a column rode north from the Aes Sedai camp well before dawn, near silent except for the creak of saddles and the crunch of hooves breaking through the snow's crisp crust. Occasionally a horse snorted, or metal jingled and was quickly muffled. The moon was already down, the sky glistening with stars, but the pale blanket lying over everything below lightened the darkness. When the first glimmers of day appeared in the east, they had been riding a good hour or more. Which was not to say they had traveled far. Over some open stretches, Egwene could let Daishar go at a slow canter that sprayed white like splashing water, but for the most part, the horses walked, and not quickly, through sparse forest where the snow made deep drifts below and clung to branches overhead. Oak and pine, sourgum and leatherleaf and trees she did not recognize all looked even more be draggled than they had in the heat and drought. Today was the Feast of Abram, but there would be no prizes baked in honeycakes. The Light send some people found surprises in the day, though.

ðə sʌn ɹoʊz ən klaɪmd, ə peɪl ɡoʊldən bɔl ðət ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ. ɛvɹi bɹɛθ stɪl bɪt ðə θɹoʊɾ ən pɹədust ə pʌf ə mɪst. ə ʃɑɹp wɪn blu, nɑt hɑɹd, bʌt kʌɾɪŋ, ən tə ðə wɛs dɑɹk klaʊdz ɹoʊl nɔɹθ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ændɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə tʌtʃ ə pɪɾi fəɹ huɛvɝ wəd noʊ ðə bɝɾən ə ðoʊz klaʊdz. ən ɹɪlif ðət ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ əweɪ. weɪɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ deɪ wʊɾə bɪn mæɾənɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn əneɪbəl tə slip əɾ ɔl, fəɹ fɪdʒəti ɹɛsləsnəs, nɑt hɛdeɪks. ɹɛsləsnəs, ən tɛnʒɹəlz ə fɪɹ ðət hæd kɹɛpt ɪn laɪk koʊld ɛɹ ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə tɛnt. ʃi wɑz nɑt taɪɝd, ðoʊ. ʃi fɛlt laɪk ə kəmpɹɛst spɹɪŋ, ə taɪt-waʊn klɑk, fʊl ʌv ɛnɝdʒi ðət wɑntəd dɛspɝətli tə faɪn ɹilis. laɪt, ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd stɪl ɡoʊ hɔɹəbli ɹɔŋ.

The sun rose and climbed, a pale golden ball that gave no warmth. Every breath still bit the throat and produced a puff of mist. A sharp wind blew, not hard, but cutting, and to the west dark clouds rolled north on their way to Andor. She felt a touch of pity for whoever would know the burden of those clouds. And relief that they were heading away. Waiting another day would have been maddening. She had been unable to sleep at all, for fidgety restlessness, not headaches. Restlessness, and tendrils of fear that had crept in like cold air under the edges of the tent. She was not tired, though. She felt like a compressed spring, a tight-wound clock, full of energy that wanted desperately to find release. Light, everything could still go horribly wrong.

ɪt wɑz ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv kɑləm, bɪhaɪn ðə stændɝɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ðə waɪt fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn sɛntɝɾ ɑn ə spaɪɹəl ə sɛvən kʌlɝz, wʌn fəɹ itʃ ədʒɑ. soʊn sikɹɪtli ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, ɪt hæd leɪn ɪn ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə tʃɛst ɛvɝ sɪns, wɪð ðə kiz ɪn ðə kipɪŋ ə ðə hɔl. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wʊɾə pɹədust ɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋz nid fəɹ pɑmp. ə θaʊzən hɛvi kævəlɹi ɪn pleɪt-ænd-meɪl pɹəvaɪɾəd ə kloʊs ɛskɔɹt, ə pænɑpli ʌv lænsɪz, sɔɹdz, meɪsəz ən æksiz sɛldəm sin saʊθ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðɛɹ kəmændɝ wɑz ə wʌn-aɪd ʃaɪnɝən wɪð ə vɪvədli peɪntəɾ aɪpætʃ, ə mæn ʃi hæd mɛt wʌns, wʌt simd ən eɪdʒ əɡoʊ. ənoʊ noʊmstə ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə tʃɹiz θɹu ðə stil bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlməts feɪsɡɑɹɾ əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛvɹi læst wʌn tə haɪɾ ən æmbʊʃ, ən ɪz mɛn sim nɪɹli əz wɑtʃfəl, ɪɹɛkt ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz.

It was an impressive column, behind the standard of the White Tower, the white Flame of Tar Valon centered on a spiral of seven colors, one for each Ajah. Sewn secretly in Salidar, it had lain in the bottom of a chest ever since, with the keys in the keeping of the Hall. She did not think they would have produced it except for this morning's need for pomp. A thousand heavy cavalry in plate-and-mail provided a close escort, a panoply of lances, swords, maces and axes seldom seen south of the Borderlands. Their commander was a one-eyed Shienaran with a vividly painted eyepatch, a man she had met once, what seemed an Age ago. Uno Nomesta glared at the trees through the steel bars of his helmet's faceguard as if he expected every last one to hide an ambush, and his men seemed nearly as watchful, erect in their saddles.

ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə saɪɾ əhɛd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ɹoʊɾ ə nɑɾ ə mɛn u wɔɹ hɛlməts, bɹɛst- ən bækpleɪts, bʌt noʊ ʌðɝ ɑɹmɝ. ðɛɹ kloʊks wɪpt əbaʊt fɹili; ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn fəɹ ðə ɹeɪnz ən ə hæn fəɹ ðə ʃɔɹt baʊ ðeɪ itʃ kæɹid lɛf nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɹæsp ət wɔɹmθ. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ fɑɹðɝ ɑn, ən bɪɑn saɪt tə lɛft ən ɹaɪɾ ən bɪhaɪnd, ənʌðɝ θaʊzən ɔltəɡɛðɝ, tə skaʊɾ ən skɹin. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tʃɹɪkɝi fɹəm ði ændɔɹənz, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ bɪfɔɹ, soʊ hi sɛd, ən ðə mʊɹændiənz wɝ ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv əsæsənz ɪn ɪleɪɾəz peɪ, əɹ ivən dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wən ə dɑɹkfɹɛn maɪt dɪsaɪd tə kɪl, əɹ waɪ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðoʊ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ səpoʊzədli fɑɹ əweɪ, noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ sim tə noʊ ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ əntɪl ðə kɪlɪŋ bɪɡæn. ivən bændəts maɪɾ əv tʃɹaɪd ðɛɹ hænd wɪð tu smɔl ə pɑɹɾi. lɔɹd bɹaɪn wɑz nɑɾ ə mæn tə teɪk tʃænsəz ənnɛsəsɛɹəli, ən ɛɡwin wɑz vɛɹi ɡlæd. tədeɪ, ʃi wɑntəɾ əz mɛni wɪtnəsəz əz pɑsəbəl.

Almost out of sight ahead through the trees rode a knot of men who wore helmets, breast- and backplates, but no other armor. Their cloaks whipped about freely; a gauntleted hand for the reins and a hand for the short bow they each carried left nothing to grasp at warmth. There were more farther on, and beyond sight to left and right and behind, another thousand altogether, to scout and screen. Gareth Bryne did not expect trickery from the Andorans, but he had been wrong before, so he said, and the Murandians were another matter. And then there was the possibility of assassins in Elaida's pay, or even Darkfriends. The Light alone knew when a Darkfriend might decide to kill, or why. For that matter, though the Shaido were supposedly far away, no one ever seemed to know they were there until the killing began. Even bandits might have tried their hand with too small a party. Lord Bryne was not a man to take chances unnecessarily, and Egwene was very glad. Today, she wanted as many witnesses as possible.

ʃi hɝsɛlf ɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə ðə bænɝ, wɪð ʃɛɹiəm ən sɪuən ən bɹaɪn. ði ʌðɝz əpɪɹd kɑɾ ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn θɔts. lɔɹd bɹaɪn sæɾ ɪz sæɾəl izəli, ðə mɪst ə hɪz ivən bɹɛθ fɔɹmɪŋ ə laɪt fɹɔst ɑn ɪz feɪsɡɑɹd, jɛɾ ɛɡwin kəd si hɪm kɑmli mɑɹkɪŋ tɝeɪn ɪn ɪz maɪnd. ɪn keɪs i hæd tə faɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪt. sɪuən ɹoʊd soʊ stɪfli ðət ʃi wəd bi sɔɹ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ ðɛɹ dɛstəneɪʃən, bʌt ʃi stɛɹd nɔɹθ əz ðoʊ ʃi kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi si ðə leɪk, ən səmtaɪmz ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf, əɹ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv dʌn ðəɾ ənlɛs ʃi wɑz ənizi. ʃɛɹiəm nu noʊ mɔɹ ʌv wʌt wɑz tə kʌm ðən ðə sɪɾɝz dɪd, jɛt ʃi əpɪɹɾ ivən mɔɹ nɝvəs ðən sɪuən, ʃɪftɪŋ kɑnstənli ɪn əɹ sæɾəl ən ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. æŋɡɝ ʃoʊn ɪn əɹ ɡɹin aɪz, tu, fəɹ səm ɹizən.

She herself rode ahead of the banner, with Sheriam and Siuan and Bryne. The others appeared caught in their own thoughts. Lord Bryne sat his saddle easily, the mist of his even breath forming a light frost on his faceguard, yet Egwene could see him calmly marking terrain in his mind. In case he had to fight over it. Siuan rode so stiffly that she would be sore long before reaching their destination, but she stared north as though she could already see the lake, and sometimes she nodded to herself, or shook her head. She would not have done that unless she was uneasy. Sheriam knew no more of what was to come than the Sitters did, yet she appeared even more nervous than Siuan, shifting constantly in her saddle and grimacing. Anger shone in her green eyes, too, for some reason.

kloʊs bɪhaɪn ðə bænɝ keɪm ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪn dʌbəl kɑləm, wɛɹɪŋ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlks ən ɹɪtʃ vɛlvəts ən fɝz ən kloʊks wɪð ðə fleɪm lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə bæk. wɪmən u sɛldəm wɔɹ mɔɹ ɔɹnəməns ðən ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɝ dɛk tədeɪ ɪn ðə faɪnəs dʒɛmz ðə kæmps dʒuəlɹi kæskəts kəd səplaɪ. ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz meɪɾ ə mɔɹ splɛndəd dɪspleɪ sɪmpli baɪ wɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks; pɑɹts ə ðə mɛn sim tə vænɪʃ əz ðə dɪskwaɪəɾɪŋ kloʊks swɝld ɪn ðə stɪf bɹiz. sɝvəns fɑloʊd, tu əɹ θɹi fəɹ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ, ɑn ðə bɛs hɔɹsəz ðət kəd bi faʊn fəɹ ðɛm. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv pæs fəɹ lɛsɝ noʊbɪləɾi ðɛmsɛlvz ɪf ə nʌmbɝ hæd nɑt bɪn liɾɪŋ pæk ænəməlz; ɛvɹi tʃɛst ɪn ðə kæmp hæd bɪn ɹænsæk tə aʊtfɪɾ əm ɪn bɹaɪt kʌlɝz.

Close behind the banner came the entire Hall of the Tower in double column, wearing embroidered silks and rich velvets and furs and cloaks with the Flame large on the back. Women who seldom wore more ornaments than the Great Serpent ring were decked today in the finest gems the camp's jewelry caskets could supply. Their Warders made a more splendid display simply by wearing their color-shifting cloaks; parts of the men seemed to vanish as the disquieting cloaks swirled in the stiff breeze. Servants followed, two or three for every sister, on the best horses that could be found for them. They might have passed for lesser nobility themselves if a number had not been leading pack animals; every chest in the camp had been ransacked to outfit them in bright colors.

pɝhæps kəz ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz wɪθaʊɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ, dɛlænə hæd bɹɔt hɑlimə əlɔŋ, ɑn ə spɪɹəɾəd waɪt mɛɹ. ðə tu ɹoʊɾ ɔlmoʊs ni-tə-ni. səmtaɪmz dɛlænə wəd lin təwɔɹd hɑlimə tə spik pɹaɪvətli, ðoʊ hɑlimə əpɪɹd tu ɪksaɪɾəd tə lɪsən. səpoʊzədli, hɑlimə wɑz dɛlænəz sɛkɹətɛɹi, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn bɪlivd ɪɾ ə keɪs ə tʃɛɹɪɾi, əɹ pɑsəbli fɹɛndʃɪp, haʊɛvɝ ənlaɪkli, bɪtwin ðə dɪɡnəfaɪd, peɪl-hɛɹd sɪstɝ ən ðə hɑt-neɪtʃɝd, ɹeɪvən-hɛɹd kʌntʃɹi wʊmən. ɛɡwin hæd sin hɑliməz hænd, ən ɪt hæd ði ənfɔɹm lʊk ʌv ə tʃaɪlz dʒʌs lɝnɪŋ əɹ lɛɾɝz. tədeɪ, ʃi wɑz ɪn ɡɑɹməns əz faɪn əz ɛni sɪstɝz, wɪð dʒɛmz ðəɾ izəli ikwəl dɛlænəz, hu mʌst əv bɪn ðɛɹ sɔɹs. wɛnɛvɝ ə ɡʌst oʊpən əɹ vɛlvət kloʊk, ʃi dɪspleɪɾ ə ʃɑkɪŋ əmaʊn ə bʊzəm, ən ʃi ɔlweɪz læft ən tʊk əɹ taɪm əbaʊt ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ əɡɛn, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðət ʃi fɛl ðə koʊld ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə sɪstɝz dɪd.

Perhaps because she was one of the Sitters without a Warder, Delana had brought Halima along, on a spirited white mare. The two rode almost knee-to-knee. Sometimes Delana would lean toward Halima to speak privately, though Halima appeared too excited to listen. Supposedly, Halima was Delana's secretary, but everyone believed it a case of charity, or possibly friendship, however unlikely, between the dignified, pale-haired sister and the hot-natured, raven-haired country woman. Egwene had seen Halima's hand, and it had the unformed look of a child's just learning her letters. Today, she was in garments as fine as any sister's, with gems that easily equaled Delana's, who must have been their source. Whenever a gust opened her velvet cloak, she displayed a shocking amount of bosom, and she always laughed and took her time about gathering it around her again, refusing to admit that she felt the cold any more than the sisters did.

fəɹ wʌns, ɛɡwin wɑz ɡlæɾ ʌv ɔl ðə ɡɪfs ə kloʊðɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɪvən, əlaʊɪŋ əɹ tə sɝpæs ðə sɪɾɝz. hɝ ɡɹin-ænd-blu sɪlk wɑz slæʃt wɪð waɪɾ ən wɝkt wɪð sid pɝlz. pɝlz ivən dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə bæks ə hɝ ɡlʌvz. ət ðə læs mɪnuɾ ə kloʊk laɪnd wɪð ɝmən hæd bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd baɪ ɹoʊmændə, ən ə nɛkləs ən ɪɹɪŋz ʌv ɛmɹəlz ən waɪɾ oʊpəlz baɪ ləleɪn. ðə munstoʊnz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ keɪm fɹəm dʒɑnjə. ði æmɪɝlɪn hæd tə bi ɹisplɛndən tədeɪ. ivən sɪuən əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə bɔl, ɪn blu vɛlvəts ən kɹim leɪs, wɪð ə waɪd bæn ə pɝlz əɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən mɔɹ leɪs θɹu hɝ hɛɹ.

For once, Egwene was glad of all the gifts of clothing she had been given, allowing her to surpass the Sitters. Her green-and-blue silk was slashed with white and worked with seed pearls. Pearls even decorated the backs of her gloves. At the last minute a cloak lined with ermine had been provided by Romanda, and a necklace and earrings of emeralds and white opals by Lelaine. The moonstones in her hair came from Janya. The Amyrlin had to be resplendent today. Even Siuan appeared ready for a ball, in blue velvets and cream lace, with a wide band of pearls at her throat and more laced through her hair.

ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn lɛd ðə sɪɾɝz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ soʊ kloʊsli bɪhaɪn ðə soʊlʒɝ bɛɹɪŋ ðə bænɝ ðəɾ i ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ nɝvəsli ən səmtaɪmz ɛdʒd ɪz hɔɹs nɪɹɝ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz əhɛɾ ə hɪm. ɛɡwin mænədʒ nɑt tə lʊk bæk mɔɹ ðən wʌns əɹ twaɪs, jɛt ʃi kəd fil ðɛɹ aɪz pɹɛsɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. itʃ θɔɾ əɹ taɪɾ ɪn ə nit bʌndəl, bʌɾ itʃ hæd tə bi wʌndɝɪŋ huz kɔɹdz hæd dʌn ðə baɪndɪŋ. oʊ, laɪt, ðɪs kəd nɑt ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ. nɑt naʊ.

Romanda and Lelaine led the Sitters, riding so closely behind the soldier bearing the banner that he glanced over his shoulder nervously and sometimes edged his horse nearer the riders ahead of him. Egwene managed not to look back more than once or twice, yet she could feel their eyes pressing between her shoulder blades. Each thought her tied in a neat bundle, but each had to be wondering whose cords had done the binding. Oh, Light, this could not go wrong. Not now.

ʌðɝ ðən ðə kɑləm, lɪɾəl muvd ɪn ɔl ðət snoʊ-kʌvɝd lændskeɪp. ə bɹɔd-wɪŋ hɔk wild oʊvɝhɛɾ əɡɛns ðə koʊl blu skaɪ fəɹ ə taɪm bɪfɔɹ wɪŋɪŋ istwɝd. twaɪs ɛɡwin sɔ blæk-teɪl fɑksəz tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, stɪl ɪn ðɛɹ sʌmɝ fɝ, ən wʌns, ə lɑɹdʒ dɪɹ wɪð tɔl fɔɹkt ænlɝz ɡɑstɪɾ əweɪ ən vænɪʃt əmɪd ðə tʃɹiz. ə hɛɹ, stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ bɛləz hʊvz ən baʊndɪŋ ɔf, meɪd ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ tɔs əɹ hɛd, ən sɪuən jɛlpt ən ɡɹæbd ət ðə ɹeɪnz əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəd bɛlə tə boʊlt. ʌv kɔɹs, bɛlə oʊnli ɡeɪv ə ɹipɹoʊtʃfəl snɔɹɾ ən plɑɾəd ɔnwɝd. ɛɡwinz tɔl ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ ʃaɪd mɔɹ, ən ðə hɛɹ hæd nɑt ɡɔn nɪɹ hɪm.

Other than the column, little moved in all that snow-covered landscape. A broad-winged hawk wheeled overhead against the cold blue sky for a time before winging eastward. Twice Egwene saw black-tailed foxes trotting in the distance, still in their summer fur, and once, a large deer with tall forked antlers ghosted away and vanished amid the trees. A hare, starting up right under Bela's hooves and bounding off, made the shaggy mare toss her head, and Siuan yelped and grabbed at the reins as if she expected Bela to bolt. Of course, Bela only gave a reproachful snort and plodded onward. Egwene's tall roan gelding shied more, and the hare had not gone near him.

sɪuən bɪɡæn ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ æftɝ ðə hɛɹ skæmpɝɾ əweɪ, ən ɪt tʊk kwaɪt səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃi iz bɛləz ɹeɪnz. biɪŋ ɑn ə hɔɹs ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ ɡɹʌmpi - ʃi tʃɹævəld ɪn wʌn ə ðə wæɡənz wɛnɛvɝ pɑsəbəl - bʌt ʃi wɑz sɛldəm ðɪs bæd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə lʊk fɝðɝ ðən lɔɹd bɹaɪn, əɹ əɹ fɪɹs ɡlænsɪz ət hɪm, tə noʊ waɪ.

Siuan began grumbling under her breath after the hare scampered away, and it took quite some time before she eased Bela's reins. Being on a horse always made her grumpy - she traveled in one of the wagons whenever possible - but she was seldom this bad. There was no need to look further than Lord Bryne, or her fierce glances at him, to know why.

ɪf i noʊɾəst sɪuənz lʊks, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn. ði oʊnli wʌn nɑɾ ɪn faɪn ɝeɪ, hi lʊkt əz i ɔlweɪz dɪd, pleɪn ən slaɪtli bæɾɝd. ə ɹɑk ðət hæd wɛðɝd stɔɹmz ən wəɾ aʊtlæs mɔɹ tə kʌm. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ɛɡwin wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd ɹɪzɪstɪd ðɛɹ ɛfɝts tə dʒɹɛs ɪm ɪn faɪnɝ ɡɑɹb. ðeɪ tʃɹuli dɪd nid tə meɪk ən ɪmpɹɛʃən, jɛt ʃi θɔɾ i meɪɾ ən ɛksələnt wʌn əz i wɑz.

If he noticed Siuan's looks, he gave no sign. The only one not in fine array, he looked as he always did, plain and slightly battered. A rock that had weathered storms and would outlast more to come. For some reason, Egwene was glad he had resisted their efforts to dress him in finer garb. They truly did need to make an impression, yet she thought he made an excellent one as he was.

"ɪts ə faɪn mɔɹnɪŋ tə bi ɪn ðə sæɾəl," ʃɛɹiəm sɛɾ æftɝ ə taɪm. "nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə ɡʊd ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ tə klɪɹ ðə hɛd." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz nɑt loʊ, ən ʃi kʌɾ əɹ aɪz ət ðə stɪl-mʌɾɝɪŋ sɪuən wɪð ə taɪni smaɪl.

"It's a fine morning to be in the saddle," Sheriam said after a time. "Nothing like a good ride in the snow to clear the head." Her voice was not low, and she cut her eyes at the still-muttering Siuan with a tiny smile.

sɪuən dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ - ʃi hɑɹdli kəd də ðəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə soʊ mɛni aɪz - bʌt ʃi dɪd ɡɪv ʃɛɹiəm ə hɑɹd lʊk ðət pɹɑməst ʃɑɹp wɝdz fəɹ leɪɾɝ. ðə faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən twɪstəɾ əweɪ əbɹʌpli wɪð vɛɹi kloʊs tə ə wɪns. wɪŋ, hɝ dæpəld ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ, pɹænst ə fju stɛps, ən ʃɛɹiəm sɛɾəld əɹ daʊn wɪð ɔlmoʊs tu fɝm ə hænd. ʃi hæd ʃoʊn lɪɾəl ɡɹæɾətud tə ðə wʊmən u hæd neɪmd əɹ mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, ən laɪk moʊst ɪn ðət pəzɪʃən, ʃi faʊn ɹizənz tə bleɪm sɪuən. ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli flɔ ɛɡwin hæd faʊn ɪn əɹ sɪns ðə swɛɹɪŋ. wɛl, ʃi hæd pɹətɛstəd ðæt, əz kipɝ, ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv tə teɪk ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm sɪuən ðə weɪ ði ʌðɝz u hæd swɔɹn dɪd, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd sin ɹaɪɾ əweɪ wɛɹ ðət wəd lɛd. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ʃɛɹiəm hæd tʃɹaɪd tə plæn ə bɑɹb. sɪuən ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn hænlɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm hɝsɛlf, ən əɹ pɹaɪd wɑz tu fɹædʒəl fəɹ ɛɡwin tə dɪnaɪ ðə ɹɪkwɛst ənlɛs mæɾɝz ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə hænd.

Siuan did not say anything - she hardly could do that in front of so many eyes - but she did give Sheriam a hard look that promised sharp words for later. The fire-haired woman twisted away abruptly with very close to a wince. Wing, her dappled gray mare, pranced a few steps, and Sheriam settled her down with almost too firm a hand. She had shown little gratitude to the woman who had named her Mistress of Novices, and like most in that position, she found reasons to blame Siuan. It was the only flaw Egwene had found in her since the swearing. Well, she had protested that, as Keeper, she should not have to take orders from Siuan the way the others who had sworn did, but Egwene had seen right away where that would lead. This was not the first time Sheriam had tried to plant a barb. Siuan insisted on handling Sheriam herself, and her pride was too fragile for Egwene to deny the request unless matters got out of hand.

ɛɡwin wɪʃt ðəɹ wɝ səm weɪ tə meɪk mɔɹ spid. sɪuən wɛn bæk tə hɝ ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ, ən ʃɛɹiəm wɑz ɑbviəsli θɪŋkɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ ɛls tə seɪ ðət wəd nɑt kwaɪt bɹɪŋ ə ɹibjuk. ɔl ðət mʌɾɝɪŋ ən kʌɾɪŋ ʌv aɪz bɪɡæn tə faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ ʌndɝ ɛɡwinz skɪn. æftɝ ə waɪl, ivən bɹaɪnz lɛvlhɛɾɪd pɔɪz bɪɡæn tə wɛɹ. ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ ə θɪŋz ʃi maɪt seɪ ðət wəd ʃeɪk ɪz əplɑm. ənfɔɹtʃənətli - əɹ pɝhæps fɔɹtʃənətli - ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ kʊd. bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd tə weɪt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ʃi θɔt ʃi maɪt bɝs fɹəm ʃɪɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns.

Egwene wished there were some way to make more speed. Siuan went back to her grumbling, and Sheriam was obviously thinking of something else to say that would not quite bring a rebuke. All that muttering and cutting of eyes began to find their way under Egwene's skin. After a while, even Bryne's levelheaded poise began to wear. She found herself thinking of things she might say that would shake his aplomb. Unfortunately - or perhaps fortunately - she did not believe anything could. But if she had to wait much longer, she thought she might burst from sheer impatience.

ðə sʌn klaɪm təwɔɹd mɪddeɪ, ðə peɪnfəli sloʊ maɪlz pæs bɪhaɪnd, ən ət læst wʌn ə ðə ɹaɪɾɝz əhɛd tɝn ən ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd. wɪð ə heɪsti əpɑlədʒi tə ɛɡwin, bɹaɪn ɡæləp fɔɹwɝd. ɪt wɑz ɹɪli mɔɹ ʌv ə lʌmbɝ θɹu ðə snoʊ fəɹ ɪz stɝɾi beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ, tʃɹævəlɝ, bʌɾ i kɑɾ ʌp tə ði aʊtʃɹaɪɾɝz, ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə fju wɝdz, ðən sɛn əm ɑn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz tə ɹitʃ hɪm.

The sun climbed toward midday, the painfully slow miles passed behind, and at last one of the riders ahead turned and raised his hand. With a hasty apology to Egwene, Bryne galloped forward. It was really more of a lumber through the snow for his sturdy bay gelding, Traveler, but he caught up to the outriders, exchanged a few words, then sent them on through the trees and waited for Egwene and the others to reach him.

əz i fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ wʌns mɔɹ, ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn dʒɔɪn ðɛm. ðə tu sɪɾɝz bɛɹli æknɑlɪdʒd ɛɡwinz pɹɛzəns, fɪksɪŋ bɹaɪn wɪð ðə kul sɝɛnəɾi ðət hæd ʃeɪkən soʊ mɛni mɛn feɪsɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪksɛp ðət naʊ ən ðɛn, itʃ ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət ði ʌðɝ ɪn ə kənsɪɾɝɪŋ weɪ. ðeɪ hɑɹdli sim tə ɹilaɪz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. ɛɡwin hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ hæf əz nɝvəs əz ʃi; ʃi wəd bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðæt.

As he fell in beside her once more, Romanda and Lelaine joined them. The two Sitters barely acknowledged Egwene's presence, fixing Bryne with the cool serenity that had shaken so many men facing Aes Sedai. Except that now and then, each glanced sideways at the other in a considering way. They hardly seemed to realize what they were doing. Egwene hoped they were half as nervous as she; she would be satisfied with that.

kuli sɝin stɛɹz wɑʃt oʊvɝ bɹaɪn laɪk ɹeɪn oʊvɝ ðət ɹɑk. hi meɪd slaɪt baʊz tə ðə sɪɾɝz, bʌɾ i spoʊk tə ɛɡwin. "ðeɪv ɔlɹɛɾi ɝaɪvd, mʌðɝ." ðət hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktəd. "ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni mɛn əz wi dɪd, bʌt ðəɹ ɔl ɑn ðə nɔɹθ saɪɾ ə ðə leɪk. aɪv pʊt skaʊts aʊt tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊbɑdi tʃɹaɪz sɝkəlɪŋ ɝaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛkt ɪt."

Coolly serene stares washed over Bryne like rain over that rock. He made slight bows to the Sitters, but he spoke to Egwene. "They've already arrived, Mother." That had been expected. "They brought almost as many men as we did, but they're all on the north side of the lake. I've put scouts out to make sure nobody tries circling around, but in truth, I don't expect it."

"lɛɾ əs hoʊp jəɹ ɹaɪt," ɹoʊmændə toʊld ɪm ʃɑɹpli, ən ləleɪn æɾəd ɪn ə mʌtʃ koʊldɝ toʊn, "jɔɹ dʒʌdʒmən əz nɑt bɪn ɔl ɪt ʃəd bi, ʌv leɪt, lɔɹd bɹaɪn." ə fɹɪdʒəd, kʌɾɪŋ toʊn.

"Let us hope you're right," Romanda told him sharply, and Lelaine added in a much colder tone, "Your judgment has not been all it should be, of late, Lord Bryne." A frigid, cutting tone.

"æz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ." hi meɪɾ ənʌðɝ slaɪt baʊ wɪθaʊt ɹɪli tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ɛɡwin. laɪk sɪuən, hi wɑz taɪd tə hɝ oʊpənli naʊ, ət list soʊ fɑɹ əz ðə hɔl wɑz kənsɝnd. ɪf oʊnli ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ taɪtli. ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd bi ʃʊɹ haʊ taɪtli. "wʌn θɪŋ mɔɹ, mʌðɝ," hi wɛn ɑn. "tælmɑnz ɪz ðəɹ ət ðə leɪk, tu. ðəɹ ɑɹ əbaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə bæn ɑn ði ist saɪd. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kɑz tʃɹʌbəl ivən ɪf i wɑntəd tə, ən smɔl tʃæns i wʊd, aɪ θɪŋk."

"As you say, Aes Sedai." He made another slight bow without really turning from Egwene. Like Siuan, he was tied to her openly now, at least so far as the Hall was concerned. If only they did not know how tightly. If only she could be sure how tightly. "One thing more, Mother," he went on. "Talmanes is there at the lake, too. There are about a hundred of the Band on the east side. Not enough to cause trouble even if he wanted to, and small chance he would, I think."

ɛɡwin mɪɹli nɑɾəd. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kɑz tʃɹʌbəl? tælmɑnz əloʊn maɪt bi ɪnʌf! ʃi teɪstəd baɪl. ɪt - kəd - nɑt - ɡoʊ - ɹɔŋ - naʊ!

Egwene merely nodded. Not enough to cause trouble? Talmanes alone might be enough! She tasted bile. It - could - not - go - wrong - now!

"tælmɑnz!" ləleɪn ɪkskleɪmd, sɝɛnəɾi ʃæɾɝɪŋ. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn əz mʌtʃ ɑn ɛdʒ əz ɛɡwin. "haʊ dɪɾ i faɪn aʊt? ɪf juv ɪnkluɾəd dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ɪn jəɹ skimɪŋ, lɔɹd bɹaɪn, jə tʃɹuli wɪl lɝn wʌt ɡoʊɪŋ tu fɑɹ minz!"

"Talmanes!" Lelaine exclaimed, serenity shattering. She must have been as much on edge as Egwene. "How did he find out? If you've included Dragonsworn in your scheming, Lord Bryne, you truly will learn what going too far means!"

ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə hɝ, ɹoʊmændə ɡɹaʊld, "ðɪs ɪz dɪsɡɹeɪsfəl! jə seɪ juv oʊnli lɝn ə hɪz pɹɛzəns naʊ? ɪf ðæts soʊ, jəɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən ɪz pʌft ʌp laɪk ə bɔɪl!" ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm wɑz ə θɪn leɪɝ fəɹ səm tədeɪ, ɪt simd.

Right on top of her, Romanda growled, "This is disgraceful! You say you've only learned of his presence now? If that's so, your reputation is puffed up like a boil!" Aes Sedai calm was a thin layer for some today, it seemed.

ðeɪ kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ðət veɪn, bʌt bɹaɪn ɹoʊɾ ɑn, oʊnli mɝmɝɪŋ ði əkeɪʒənəl "æz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," wən i hæd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ. hi hæd ɹəsivd wɝs ɪn ɛɡwinz hɪɹɪŋ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ɹiæktəd noʊ mɔɹ. ɪt wɑz sɪuən u faɪnəli snɔɹɾɪd, ən ðən blʌʃt kɹɪmzən wən ðə sɪɾɝz lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. sɪuən wɑz vɛɹi dɛfənətli ɪn lʌv. ən ʃi vɛɹi dɛfənətli niɾəd tɔkɪŋ tə! fəɹ səm ɹizən, bɹaɪn smaɪld, bʌt ðət maɪt dʒʌst əv bɪn kəz i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ði əbdʒɛkt ə ðə sɪɾɝz' ətɛnʃən.

They continued in that vein, but Bryne rode on, only murmuring the occasional "As you say, Aes Sedai," when he had to say something. He had received worse in Egwene's hearing this morning, and reacted no more. It was Siuan who finally snorted, and then blushed crimson when the Sitters looked at her in surprise. Egwene almost shook her head. Siuan was very definitely in love. And she very definitely needed talking to! For some reason, Bryne smiled, but that might just have been because he was no longer the object of the Sitters' attention.

tʃɹiz ɡeɪv weɪ tə ənʌðɝ oʊpən speɪs, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən moʊst, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ taɪm fəɹ fɹɪvələs θɔts.

Trees gave way to another open space, larger than most, and there was no more time for frivolous thoughts.

əsaɪd fɹəm ə waɪd ɹɪm ə tɔl bɹaʊn ɹidz ən kæteɪlz poʊkɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊ, nʌθɪŋ neɪm ðɪs ə leɪk. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ə bɪɡ mɛdoʊ, flæɾ ən vɛɹi ɹʌfli oʊvəl ɪn ʃeɪp. səm dɪstəns fɹəm ðə tʃɹilaɪn, ɑn ðə fɹoʊzən leɪk, stʊɾ ə lɑɹdʒ blu kænəpi ɑn tɔl poʊlz, wɪð ə smɔl kɹaʊɾ ə pipəl mɪlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ən dʌzənz ə hɔɹsəz hɛl baɪ sɝvəns bɪhaɪnd. ðə bɹiz ɹʌfəld ə bɹaɪt θɪkɪɾ ə pɛnəns ən bænɝz, ən kæɹid mʌfəld ʃaʊts ðət kəɾ oʊnli hæv bɪn ɔɹɾɝz. mɔɹ sɝvəns dɑɹɾɪd əbaʊt heɪstəli. əpɛɹənli, ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ðəɹ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə fɪnɪʃ ðɛɹ pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz.

Aside from a wide rim of tall brown reeds and cattails poking through the snow, nothing named this a lake. It could have been a big meadow, flat and very roughly oval in shape. Some distance from the treeline, on the frozen lake, stood a large blue canopy on tall poles, with a small crowd of people milling about it and dozens of horses held by servants behind. The breeze ruffled a bright thicket of pennants and banners, and carried muffled shouts that could only have been orders. More servants darted about hastily. Apparently, they had not been there long enough to finish their preparations.

pɝhæps ə maɪl əweɪ ðə tʃɹiz bɪɡæn əɡɛn, ən ðə fibəl sʌnlaɪt ɡlɪntɪɾ ɔf mɛɾəl ðɛɹ. kwaɪɾ ə lɑɾ ə mɛɾəl, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə fɑɹ ʃɔɹ. tə ði ist, ɔlmoʊst əz kloʊs əz ðə pəvɪljən, ðə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ə ðə bæn meɪd noʊ ɛfɝɾ ət kənsilmənt, stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ maʊns dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wɛɹ ðə kæteɪlz bɪɡæn. ə fju ʌv əm pɔɪntəd wən ðə flæɡ ʌv tɑɹ vəlɑn əpɪɹd. ðə pipəl ət ðə pəvɪljən stɑp tə lʊk.

Perhaps a mile away the trees began again, and the feeble sunlight glinted off metal there. Quite a lot of metal, stretching the length of the far shore. To the east, almost as close as the pavilion, the hundred men of the Band made no effort at concealment, standing beside their mounts just short of where the cattails began. A few of them pointed when the flag of Tar Valon appeared. The people at the pavilion stopped to look.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt pɔz bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə snoʊ-kʌvɝɾ aɪs. ʃi dɪɾ ɪmædʒən hɝsɛlf ə ɹoʊzbʌɾ oʊpənɪŋ tə ðə sʌn, ðoʊ, ðəɾ oʊl nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪz. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æktʃəli  ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt ðə kɑm ðət keɪm wɑz vɛɹi wɛlkəm.

Egwene did not pause before riding out onto the snow-covered ice. She did imagine herself a rosebud opening to the sun, though, that old novice exercise. She did not actually embrace saidar, but the calm that came was very welcome.

sɪuən ən ʃɛɹiəm fɑloʊd, ən ðə sɪɾɝz wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz, ən ðə sɝvəns. lɔɹd bɹaɪn ən ðə bænɝ-mæn wɝ ði oʊnli tu soʊlʒɝz u wɛnt. ʃaʊts ɹaɪzɪŋ bɪhaɪn əɹ toʊld ʌv ənoʊ pʊɾɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmɝd hɔɹsmən ɪndə pəzɪʃən əlɔŋ ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn. ðə mɔɹ laɪtli ɑɹmɝd mɛn wɝ ɝeɪd tə iðɝ saɪd, ðoʊz nɑɾ ɔf ɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɡɛns tʃɹɛtʃɝi. wʌn ɹizən ðə leɪk hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən wɑz ðət ði aɪs wɑz θɪk ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə hɔɹsəz, bʌt nɑt hʌnʒɹədz, mʌtʃ lɛs θaʊzənz. ðət kʌt daʊn ɑn ðə tʃæns ə ʃɪkeɪnɝi. ʌv kɔɹs, ə pəvɪljən bɪɑn baʊʃɑt wɑz nɑt bɪɑn ðə ɹeɪnʒ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, nɑɾ ɪf ɪt kəd bi sin. ɪksɛp ðət ðə wɝs mæn ɪn ðə wɝl nu hɪmsɛlf seɪf fɹəm ðəɾ ənlɛs i θɹɛɾənd ə sɪstɝ. ɛɡwin ɛksheɪld ʃɑɹpli, ən bɪɡæn əkwaɪɹɪŋ kɑm ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn.

Siuan and Sheriam followed, and the Sitters with their Warders, and the servants. Lord Bryne and the banner-man were the only two soldiers who went. Shouts rising behind her told of Uno putting his armored horsemen into position along the shoreline. The more lightly armored men were arrayed to either side, those not off guarding against treachery. One reason the lake had been chosen was that the ice was thick enough to hold a fair number of horses, but not hundreds, much less thousands. That cut down on the chance of chicanery. Of course, a pavilion beyond bowshot was not beyond the range of the One Power, not if it could be seen. Except that the worst man in the world knew himself safe from that unless he threatened a sister. Egwene exhaled sharply, and began acquiring calm all over again.

ə pɹɑpɝ ɡɹiɾɪŋ fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ʃʊɾə hæd sɝvəns ɹʌʃɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð wɔɹm dʒɹɪŋks ən klɔθs ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɑt bɹɪks, ən ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ðɛmsɛlvz tə teɪk ɹeɪnz ən ɔfɝ ə kɪs ɪn toʊkən ʌv əbɹæm. ɛni vɪzəɾɝ ə ɹæŋk əɾ ɔl wʊɾə hæd ðə sɝvəns, bʌt noʊ wʌn stɝd fɹəm ðə pəvɪljən. bɹaɪn hɪmsɛlf dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən keɪm tə hoʊl deɪʃɝz bɹaɪɾəl, ən ðə seɪm læŋki jʌŋ mæn u hæd kʌm wɪð fɹɛʃ tʃɑɹkoʊl ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ ɹæn tə hoʊld ɛɡwinz stɝəp. hɪz noʊz stɪl dʒɹɪpt, bʌɾ ɪn ə ɹɛd vɛlvət koʊɾ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl tu lɑɹdʒ fəɹ ɪm ən ə bɹaɪt blu kloʊk, hi aʊtʃoʊn ɛni ʌv ðə noʊbəlz u stʊd stɛɹɪŋ fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə kænəpi. ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə bi ɪn staʊt wʊlənz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, wɪð nɑt mʌtʃ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən vɛɹi lɪɾəl sɪlk əɹ leɪs. laɪkli ðeɪ hæd hæd tə skɹæmbəl tə faɪn suɾəbəl kloʊðz wʌns ðə snoʊz bɪɡæn, ən əm ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ. ðoʊ ðə sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ wɑz ðət ðə jʌŋ mæn maɪɾ əv aʊtʃoʊn ə tɪŋkɝ.

A proper greeting for the Amyrlin Seat should have had servants rushing forward with warm drinks and cloths wrapped around hot bricks, and the lords and ladies themselves to take reins and offer a kiss in token of Abram. Any visitor of rank at all would have had the servants, but no one stirred from the pavilion. Bryne himself dismounted and came to hold Daishar's bridle, and the same lanky young man who had come with fresh charcoal the day before ran to hold Egwene's stirrup. His nose still dripped, but in a red velvet coat only a little too large for him and a bright blue cloak, he outshone any of the nobles who stood staring from under the canopy. They appeared to be in stout woolens for the most part, with not much embroidery and very little silk or lace. Likely they had had to scramble to find suitable clothes once the snows began, and them already on the march. Though the simple truth was that the young man might have outshone a Tinker.

kɑɹpəts hæd bɪn leɪd tə flɔɹ ðə pəvɪljən, ən bɹeɪʒɝz lɪt, ðoʊ ðə bɹiz kæɹiɾ əweɪ hiɾ ən smoʊk əlaɪk. tʃɛɹz stʊɾ ɪn tu feɪsɪŋ laɪnz fəɹ ðə dɛləɡeɪʃənz, eɪɾ ɪn itʃ. ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd soʊ mɛni sɪstɝz. səm ə ðə weɪɾɪŋ noʊbəlz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks ə kɑnstɝneɪʃən, ən ə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛɹ sɝvəns æktʃəli  ɹʌŋ ðɛɹ hænz, wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt tə du. ðeɪ nid nɑt hæv.

Carpets had been laid to floor the pavilion, and braziers lit, though the breeze carried away heat and smoke alike. Chairs stood in two facing lines for the delegations, eight in each. They had not expected so many sisters. Some of the waiting nobles exchanged looks of consternation, and a number of their servants actually wrung their hands, wondering what to do. They need not have.

ðə tʃɛɹz wɝ ə mɪsmætʃt mɪsəleɪni, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl əlaɪk ɪn saɪz, ən nʌn wɑz noʊɾɪsəbli mɔɹ wɔɹn əɹ bæɾɝd ðən ənʌðɝ. nʌn hæd noʊɾɪsəbli mɔɹ əɹ lɛs ɡɪldɪd kɑɹvɪŋ. ðə læŋki jʌŋ mæn ən ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝz tʃɹɑɾəd ɪn ən ʌndɝ ðə fɹaʊnz ə ðə noʊbəlz, wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə baɪ-jɔɹ-liv, kæɹid ðoʊz mɛn fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə snoʊ, ðən ɹʌʃt tə hɛlp wɪð ənloʊɾɪŋ ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. stɪl, noʊ wʌn spoʊk ə wɝd.

The chairs were a mismatched miscellany, but they were all alike in size, and none was noticeably more worn or battered than another. None had noticeably more or less gilded carving. The lanky young man and a number of others trotted in and under the frowns of the nobles, without so much as a by-your-leave, carried those meant for Aes Sedai out into the snow, then rushed to help with unloading the packhorses. Still, no one spoke a word.

kwɪkli, sits wɝ sɛɾ ʌp səfɪʃən fəɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl, ən ɛɡwin. oʊnli sɪmpəl bɛntʃɪz, ðoʊ pɑlɪʃt tɪl ðeɪ ɡlimd, bʌɾ itʃ stʊɾ ɑn ə waɪd bɑks kʌvɝd wɪð klɔθ ɪn ðə kʌlɝ ə ðə sɪɾɝz ədʒɑ, ɪn ə lɔŋ ɹoʊ əz waɪɾ əz ðə kænəpi. ðə bɑks pleɪst ɪn fɹʌnt, fəɹ ɛɡwinz bɛntʃ, wɑz stʃɹaɪp laɪk əɹ stoʊl. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə ɡɹeɪt flɝi ʌv æktɪvəɾi ɪn ðə naɪt, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð faɪndɪŋ biswæks fəɹ pɑlɪʃ ən ɡʊd klɔθ ə ðə ɹaɪt kʌlɝz.

Quickly, seats were set up sufficient for the entire Hall, and Egwene. Only simple benches, though polished till they gleamed, but each stood on a wide box covered with cloth in the color of the Sitter's Ajah, in a long row as wide as the canopy. The box placed in front, for Egwene's bench, was striped like her stole. There had been a great flurry of activity in the night, beginning with finding beeswax for polish and good cloth of the right colors.

wən ɛɡwin ən ðə sɪɾɝz tʊk ðɛɹ pleɪsəz, ðeɪ sæɾ ə fʊt haɪɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls. ʃi hæd hæɾ əɹ daʊts əbaʊt ðæt, bʌt ðə læk ʌv ɛni wɝɾ ʌv wɛlkəm hæd sɛɾəld ðoʊz. ðə minəs fɑɹmɝ wʊɾə ɔfɝɾ ə kʌp ən ə kɪs tə ə væɡəbɑn ɑn ðə fist ʌv əbɹæm. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt sʌpləkəns, ən ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ikwəlz. ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

When Egwene and the Sitters took their places, they sat a foot higher than anyone else. She had had her doubts about that, but the lack of any word of welcome had settled those. The meanest farmer would have offered a cup and a kiss to a vagabond on the Feast of Abram. They were not supplicants, and they were not equals. They were Aes Sedai.

wɔɹɾɝz stʊd bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən sɪuən ən ʃɛɹiəm flæŋkt ɛɡwin. ðə sɪstɝz ɑstənteɪʃəsli flʌŋ bæk kloʊks ən tʌkt ɡlʌvz əweɪ tə ɛmfəsaɪz ðət ðə koʊl dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ ðɛm, ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə noʊbəlz klʌtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn kloʊks kloʊs. aʊtsaɪd, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn lɪftəɾ ɪn ðə stɪfənɪŋ bɹiz. oʊnli hɑlimə, laʊnʒɪŋ bɪsaɪd dɛlænəz tʃɛɹ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹeɪ-kʌvɝd bɑks, əɾ ɔl spɔɪl ðə ɡɹæn ɪmədʒ, ən əɹ bɪɡ ɡɹin aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ði ændɔɹənz ən mʊɹændiənz soʊ tʃælənʒɪŋli ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt spɔɪl ɪt mʌtʃ.

Warders stood behind their Aes Sedai, and Siuan and Sheriam flanked Egwene. The sisters ostentatiously flung back cloaks and tucked gloves away to emphasize that the cold did not touch them, a sharp contrast to the nobles clutching their own cloaks close. Outside, the Flame of Tar Valon lifted in the stiffening breeze. Only Halima, lounging beside Delana's chair on the edge of the gray-covered box, at all spoiled the grand image, and her big green eyes stared at the Andorans and Murandians so challengingly that she did not spoil it much.

ðəɹ wɝ ə fju stɛɹz wən ɛɡwin tʊk ðə siɾ ɪn fɹʌnt, bʌɾ oʊnli ə fju. noʊ wʌn ɹɪli lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd. aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪv hɝɾ ɔl əbaʊt ðə ɡɝl æmɪɝlɪn, ʃi θɔt dʒɹaɪli. wɛl, ðəɹ hæd bɪn kwinz jʌŋɡɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ kwinz ʌv ændɝ ən mʊɹændi. kɑmli, ʃi nɑɾəd, ən ʃɛɹiəm dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə laɪn ə tʃɛɹz. noʊ mæɾɝ u hæɾ ɝaɪv fɝst əɹ pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə pəvɪljən, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ u hæd kɔl ðɪs miɾɪŋ. hu wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ.

There were a few stares when Egwene took the seat in front, but only a few. No one really looked surprised. I suppose they've heard all about the girl Amyrlin, she thought dryly. Well, there had been queens younger, including queens of Andor and Murandy. Calmly, she nodded, and Sheriam gestured to the line of chairs. No matter who had arrived first or provided the pavilion, there was no doubt who had called this meeting. Who was in charge.

hɝ ækʃən wɑz nɑt wɛl ɹəsivd, ʌv kɔɹs. ðəɹ wɑz ə moʊmən ə saɪlən hɛzəteɪʃən waɪl ðə noʊbəlz kæs ðɛɹ maɪnz əbaʊt fəɹ səm weɪ tə ɹɪɡeɪn ən ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ, ən noʊ fju ɡɹɪməsɪz əz ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd ɪt kəd nɑt bi dʌn. ɡɹɪm-feɪst, eɪɾ ə ðɛm sæt daʊn, fɔɹ mɛn ən fɔɹ wɪmən, wɪð mʌtʃ æŋɡɹi ɡæðɝɪŋ ə kloʊks ən ədʒʌstɪŋ ə skɝts. ðoʊz ə lɛsɝ ɹæŋk stʊd bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɛɹz, ən klɪɹli ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl lʌv lɔs bɪtwin ændɔɝən ən mʊɹændiən. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðə mʊɹændiənz, mɛn ən wɪmən əlaɪk, mʌɾɝd ən dʒɑsəld wʌn ənʌðɝ fəɹ pɹɛsəɾəns əz fɪɹsli əz ðeɪ dɪd ðɛɹ "ælaɪz" fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹəsivd ə ɡʊd mɛni dɑɹk lʊks əz wɛl, ən ə fju foʊk spɛɹd skaʊlz fəɹ bɹaɪn, hu stʊɾ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd wɪð ɪz hɛlməɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. hi wɑz wɛl noʊn ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə bɔɹɾɝ, ən ɹɪspɛktɪɾ ivən baɪ moʊst ə ðoʊz u wʊɾə laɪk tə si hɪm dɛd. ət list, ðət hæd bɪn ðə keɪs bɪfɔɹ i tɝn ʌp liɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɑɹmi. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛɹ æsəd ɡlɛɹz əz i hæd ðə sɪɾɝz' æsəd tʌŋz.

Her action was not well received, of course. There was a moment of silent hesitation while the nobles cast their minds about for some way to regain an equal footing, and no few grimaces as they realized it could not be done. Grim-faced, eight of them sat down, four men and four women, with much angry gathering of cloaks and adjusting of skirts. Those of lesser rank stood behind the chairs, and clearly there was little love lost between Andoran and Murandian. For that matter, the Murandians, men and women alike, muttered and jostled one another for precedence as fiercely as they did their "allies" from the north. The Aes Sedai received a good many dark looks as well, and a few folk spared scowls for Bryne, who stood off to one side with his helmet under his arm. He was well known on both sides of the border, and respected even by most of those who would have liked to see him dead. At least, that had been the case before he turned up leading the Aes Sedai's army. He ignored their acid glares as he had the Sitters' acid tongues.

ənʌðɝ mæn dɪd nɑt dʒɔɪn wɪð iðɝ pɑɹɾi. ə peɪl mæn, lɛs ðən ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən ɛɡwin, ɪn ə dɑɹk koʊɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪt, hi wɔɹ ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ ɹɛd skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz lɛft ɑɹm. hɪz dip ɡɹeɪ kloʊk hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd hænd wɝkt ɑn ðə bɹɛst. tælmɑnz stʊɾ ɑpəzət bɹaɪn, linɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə pəvɪljənz poʊlz wɪð ən ɛɹəɡən kæʒəɑlnəs, ən wɑtʃt wɪθaʊt ɹɪvilɪŋ ə hɪn ə hɪz θɔts. ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi nu wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ ðɛɹ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi nu wʌɾ i hæd sɛd bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɝaɪvd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi hæd tə spik wɪð hɪm. ɪf ɪt kəd bi mænədʒd wɪθaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɪɹz lɪsnɪŋ.

Another man did not join with either party. A pale man, less than a hand taller than Egwene, in a dark coat and breastplate, he wore the front of his head shaved, and there was a long red scarf tied around his left arm. His deep gray cloak had a large red hand worked on the breast. Talmanes stood opposite Bryne, leaning against one of the pavilion's poles with an arrogant casualness, and watched without revealing a hint of his thoughts. Egwene wished she knew what he was doing there. She wished she knew what he had said before she arrived. In any case, she had to speak with him. If it could be managed without a hundred ears listening.

ə lin, wɛðɝd mæn ɪn ə ɹɛd kloʊk, sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹoʊ ʌv tʃɛɹz, lin fɔɹwɝɾ ən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt ʃɛɹiəm fɔɹstɑld ɪm ɪn ə klɪɹ, kæɹiɪŋ vɔɪs.

A lean, weathered man in a red cloak, sitting in the middle of the row of chairs, leaned forward and opened his mouth, but Sheriam forestalled him in a clear, carrying voice.

"mʌðɝ, meɪ aɪ pɹɛzən tə ju, ʌv ændɝ, ɑɝəθɛl ɹɛnʃɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ɹɛnʃɝ. pɛlɪvɑɹ koʊələn, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs koʊələn. æɛmlɪn kɑɝənd, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs kɑɝənd, ən əɹ hʌzbənd, kʌlhən kɑɝənd." ðeɪ æknɑlɪdʒ ðɛɹ neɪmz saʊɝli, wɪð bɛɹ nɑdz ən noʊ mɔɹ. pɛlɪvɑɹ wɑz ðə lin mæn; hi wɑz luzɪŋ ɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ fɹəm ðə fɹʌnt. ʃɛɹiəm wɛn ɑn wɪθaʊt pɔz; ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ bɹaɪn hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə səplaɪ ðə neɪmz ə ðoʊz u hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən tə spik. "meɪ aɪ pɹɛzənt, ʌv mʊɹændi, dɑnəl də mɔɝni əlɔɹdaɪn. ʃin də mɛhɑn æmækənsə. peɪtʃɹ də fɝnə ækən. sɛɡən də əvhɑɝɪn ɹuz." ðə mʊɹændiənz sim tə fil ðə læk ə taɪɾəlz ivən mɔɹ ðən ði ændɔɹənz. dɑnəl, wɛɹɪŋ mɔɹ leɪs ðən moʊst ə ðə wɪmən, twɪstəɾ ɪz kɝl mʌstæʃɪz fɪɹsli, ən peɪtʃɹ əpɪɹd tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə jæŋk ɪz lus. sɛɡən pɝs fʊl lɪps ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz kɑt faɪɝ, waɪl ʃin, ə stɑki, ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən, snɔɹɾɪd kwaɪt laʊdli. ʃɛɹiəm tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs. "ju ɑɹ bɪniθ ði aɪz ə ðə wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz. jə ɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. jə meɪ pɹizɛn jəɹ sʌpləkeɪʃənz tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit."

"Mother, may I present to you, of Andor, Arathelle Renshar, High Seat of House Renshar. Pelivar Coelan, High Seat of House Coelan. Aemlyn Carand, High Seat of House Carand, and her husband, Culhan Carand." They acknowledged their names sourly, with bare nods and no more. Pelivar was the lean man; he was losing his dark hair from the front. Sheriam went on without pause; it was a good thing Bryne had been able to supply the names of those who had been chosen to speak. "May I present, of Murandy, Donel do Morny a'Lordeine. Cian do Mehon a'Macansa. Paitr do Fearna a'Conn. Segan do Avharin a'Roos." The Murandians seemed to feel the lack of titles even more than the Andorans. Donel, wearing more lace than most of the women, twisted his curled mustaches fiercely, and Paitr appeared to be trying to yank his loose. Segan pursed full lips and her dark eyes caught fire, while Cian, a stocky, graying woman, snorted quite loudly. Sheriam took no notice. "You are beneath the eyes of the Watcher of the Seals. You are before the Flame of Tar Valon. You may present your supplications to the Amyrlin Seat."

wɛl. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk ðæt, nɑɾ ɪn ðə list. ɛɡwin hæd θɔɾ əm saʊɝ bɪfɔɹ, bʌt naʊ ðeɪ lʊk stʌft fʊl ʌv ɡɹin pɝsimənz. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd bɪliv ðeɪ kəd pɹitɛnd ʃi wɑz nɑt ði æmɪɝlɪn əɾ ɔl. ðeɪ wəd lɝn. ʌv kɔɹs, fɝst ʃi hæd tə titʃ ðə hɔl.

Well. They did not like that, not in the least. Egwene had thought them sour before, but now they looked stuffed full of green persimmons. Perhaps they had believed they could pretend she was not the Amyrlin at all. They would learn. Of course, first she had to teach the Hall.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ eɪntʃən taɪz bɪtwin ændɝ ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ," ʃi sɛd, laʊdli ən fɝmli. "sɪstɝz əv ɔlweɪz ɪkspɛktəd wɛlkəm ɪn ændɝ əɹ mʊɹændi. waɪ ðən dʒju bɹɪŋ ən ɑɹmi əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ? jə mɛɾəl wɛɹ θɹoʊnz ən neɪʃənz fɪɹ tə stɛp. θɹoʊnz əv fɔlən, mɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn ði əfɛɹz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"There are ancient ties between Andor and the White Tower," she said, loudly and firmly. "Sisters have always expected welcome in Andor or Murandy. Why then do you bring an army against Aes Sedai? You meddle where thrones and nations fear to step. Thrones have fallen, meddling in the affairs of Aes Sedai."

ðət saʊndəd suɾəbli θɹɛɾənɪŋ, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt maɪɹɛl ən ði ʌðɝz hæd mænədʒ tə pɹipɛɹ əɹ weɪ. wɪð lʌk, ðeɪ wɝ wɛl ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ bæk tə ðə kæmp, wɪð noʊ wʌn ðə waɪzɝ. ənlɛs wʌn ə ðiz noʊbəlz spoʊk ðə ɹɔŋ neɪm. ðət wəd luz əɹ ən ædvæntɪdʒ əɡɛns ðə hɔl, bʌɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹɔ bɪsaɪɾ ə heɪlɔft.

That sounded suitably threatening, whether or not Myrelle and the others had managed to prepare her way. With luck, they were well on their way back to the camp, with no one the wiser. Unless one of these nobles spoke the wrong name. That would lose her an advantage against the Hall, but alongside everything else, it was a straw beside a hayloft.

pɛlɪvɑɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð ðə wʊmən siɾəd bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən ʃi stʊd. kɹisɪz ɪn əɹ feɪs kəd nɑt dɪsɡaɪz ðə fæk ðəɾ ɑɝəθɛl hæd bɪn ə bjuɾəfəl, faɪn-boʊnd wʊmən wən jʌŋ; naʊ, ɡɹeɪ θɹɛɾəd θɪkli θɹu hɝ hɛɹ, ən əɹ ɡeɪz stʃɹʌk əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛni wɔɹɾɝz. hɝ ɹɛd-ɡlʌv hænz ɡɹɪp ði ɛdʒəz ə hɝ kloʊk əɾ əɹ saɪdz, bʌt pleɪnli nɑɾ ɪn wɝi. maʊθ kəmpɹɛs tə ə θɪn laɪn, ʃi skæn ðə laɪn ə sɪɾɝz, ən oʊnli ðən spoʊk. pæst ɛɡwin, tə ðə sɪstɝz bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ɛɡwin pʊɾ ɑn ən ətɛntɪv ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Pelivar exchanged looks with the woman seated beside him, and she stood. Creases in her face could not disguise the fact that Arathelle had been a beautiful, fine-boned woman when young; now, gray threaded thickly through her hair, and her gaze struck as hard as any Warder's. Her red-gloved hands gripped the edges of her cloak at her sides, but plainly not in worry. Mouth compressed to a thin line, she scanned the line of Sitters, and only then spoke. Past Egwene, to the sisters behind her. Gritting her teeth, Egwene put on an attentive expression.

"wi ɑɹ hɪɹ pɹɪsaɪsli kəz wi də nɑt wɑnə bɪkʌm ɛntæŋɡəld ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝz əfɛɹz." ɑɝəθɛlz vɔɪs hɛl toʊnz ʌv əθɔɹəɾi, ənsɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə haɪ siɾ ʌv ə paʊɝfəl haʊs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɪn ə ðə dɪfəɾəns ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəd, ivən fɹəm ə paʊɝfəl haɪ sit, feɪsɪŋ soʊ mɛni sɪstɝz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. "ɪf ɔl wiv hɝɾ ɪz tʃɹu, ðən ət bɛst, əlaʊɪŋ jə tə pæs θɹu ændɝ ənhɪndɝd meɪ sim laɪk ɡɪvɪŋ eɪd, əɹ ivən əlaɪəns, ɪn ði aɪz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. feɪljɝ tə əpoʊz jə maɪt min lɝnɪŋ wʌt ðə ɡɹeɪp lɝnz ɪn ðə waɪnpɹɛs." sɛvɹəl ə ðə mʊɹændiənz tɝn ðɛɹ skaʊlz ɑn hɝ. noʊ wʌn ɪn mʊɹændi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə hɪndɝ ðə sɪstɝz' pæsədʒ. vɛɹi laɪkli, noʊ wʌn hæd kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾiz bɪɑn ðə deɪ ðeɪ pæst ɑntu ənʌðɝz lænz.

"We are here precisely because we do not want to become entangled in the White Tower's affairs." Arathelle's voice held tones of authority, unsurprising in the High Seat of a powerful House. There was no hint of the diffidence that might have been expected, even from a powerful High Seat, facing so many sisters, not to mention the Amyrlin Seat. "If all we've heard is true, then at best, allowing you to pass through Andor unhindered may seem like giving aid, or even alliance, in the eyes of the White Tower. Failure to oppose you might mean learning what the grape learns in the winepress." Several of the Murandians turned their scowls on her. No one in Murandy had tried to hinder the sisters' passage. Very likely, no one had considered the possibilities beyond the day they passed onto another's lands.

ɑɝəθɛl kəntɪnjuɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊɾəst, bʌɾ ɛɡwin daʊɾɪd ðæt. "æt wɝst. . . . wɪv hɝd . . . ɹɪpɔɹts . . . ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə ændɝ ɪn sikɹət, ən taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz. ɹumɝz maɪt bi ə bɛɾɝ wɝd, bʌt ðeɪ kʌm fɹəm mɛni pleɪsəz. nʌn ʌv əs wəd laɪk tə si ə bæɾəl bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ændɝ."

Arathelle continued as if she had not noticed, but Egwene doubted that. "At worst. . . . We have heard . . . reports . . . of Aes Sedai making their way into Andor in secret, and Tower Guards. Rumors might be a better word, but they come from many places. None of us would like to see a battle between Aes Sedai in Andor."

"ðə laɪt pɹəzɝv ən pɹətɛkt ʌs!" dɑnəl bɝst aʊt, ɹɛd-feɪst. peɪtʃɹ nɑɾəd ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, slaɪɾɪŋ tə ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz sit, ən ʃin lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə dʒʌmp ɪn hɝsɛlf. "noʊ wʌn wɑns tə si ɪt hɪɹ, iðɝ!" dɑnəl spæt. "nɑt bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ! fəɹ ʃʊɹ, wiv hɝd wʌt hæpən aʊɾ ist! ən ðoʊz sɪstɝz - !"

"The Light preserve and protect us!" Donel burst out, red-faced. Paitr nodded encouragement, sliding to the edge of his seat, and Cian looked ready to jump in herself. "No one wants to see it here, either!" Donel spat. "Not between Aes Sedai! For sure, we've heard what happened out east! And those sisters - !"

ɛɡwin bɹiðd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ izəli wən ɑɝəθɛl stɛpt ɑn ɪm fɝmli. "ɪf jə pliz, lɔɹd dɑnəl. jəl əv jəɹ tɝn tə spik." ʃi tɝn bæk tə ɛɡwin - tə ðə sɪɾɝz wʌns mɔɹ, ɹɪli - wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɹɪplaɪ, livɪŋ ɪm spləɾɝɪŋ ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi mʊɹændiənz ɡlaʊɝɪŋ. ʃi hɝsɛlf lʊkt kwaɪɾ ʌndɪstɝbd, sɪmpli ə wʊmən leɪɪŋ aʊt ðə fæks. leɪɪŋ əm aʊt, ən minɪŋ ðət ðeɪ ʃəd bi sin əz ʃi sɔ ðɛm.

Egwene breathed a little more easily when Arathelle stepped on him firmly. "If you please, Lord Donel. You will have your turn to speak." She turned back to Egwene - to the Sitters once more, really - without waiting on his reply, leaving him spluttering and the other three Murandians glowering. She herself looked quite undisturbed, simply a woman laying out the facts. Laying them out, and meaning that they should be seen as she saw them.

"æz aɪ wɑz seɪɪŋ. ðəɾ ɪz ðə wɝst wi fɪɹ, ɪf ðə teɪlz ɑɹ tʃɹu. ən ɔlsoʊ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt. ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bi ɡæðɝɪŋ sikɹɪtli ɪn ændɝ, wɪð taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ən ɑɹmi ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə ɛntɝ ændɝ. ɔfən ɪnʌf ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz sim tə eɪm ət wʌn tɑɹɡət, oʊnli fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs tə lɝn leɪɾɝ ɪt wɑz eɪmɪŋ əɾ ənʌðɝ ɔl əlɔŋ. aɪ kən hɑɹdli ɪmædʒən ivən ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ðɪs fɑɹ, bʌɾ ɪf ɛvɝ ðəɹ wɑz ə tɑɹɡət jə maɪt twɪs jʊɹsɛlvz ɪndə ə nɑt fɔɹ, ɪts ðə blæk taʊɝ." ɑɝəθɛl ʃɪvɝd slaɪtli, ən ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ðə koʊld. "ə bæɾəl bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt ɹuən ðə læn fəɹ maɪlz ɝaʊnd. ðət bæɾəl maɪt ɹuən hæf ʌv ændɝ."

"As I was saying. That is the worst we fear, if the tales are true. And also if they are not. Aes Sedai may be gathering secretly in Andor, with Tower Guards. Aes Sedai with an army are ready to enter Andor. Often enough the White Tower has seemed to aim at one target, only for the rest of us to learn later it was aiming at another all along. I can hardly imagine even the White Tower going this far, but if ever there was a target you might twist yourselves into a knot for, it's the Black Tower." Arathelle shivered slightly, and Egwene did not think it was the cold. "A battle between Aes Sedai might ruin the land for miles around. That battle might ruin half of Andor."

pɛlɪvɑɹ spɹæŋ tə hɪz fit. "ðə pleɪn ʌv ɪɾ ɪz, jə mʌst ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli haɪ, bʌt noʊ lɛs fɝm ðən ɑɝəθɛlz. "ɪf aɪ mʌs daɪ tə dɪfɛn maɪ lænz ən maɪ pipəl, ðən bɛɾɝ hɪɹ ðən wɛɹ maɪ lænz ən pipəl daɪ, tu."

Pelivar sprang to his feet. "The plain of it is, you must go another way." His voice was surprisingly high, but no less firm than Arathelle's. "If I must die to defend my lands and my people, then better here than where my lands and people die, too."

hi səbsaɪɾɪd əɾ ɑɝəθɛlz suðɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ, sɪŋkɪŋ bæk ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ. hɑɹd-aɪd, hi dɪd nɑt lʊk mɑləfaɪd. æɛmlɪn, ə plʌmp wʊmən ɹæpt ɪn dɑɹk wʊl, nɑɾəd əɡɹimənt wɪð hɪm, əz dɪɾ əɹ skwɛɹ-feɪs hʌzbənd.

He subsided at Arathelle's soothing gesture, sinking back into his chair. Hard-eyed, he did not look mollified. Aemlyn, a plump woman wrapped in dark wool, nodded agreement with him, as did her square-faced husband.

dɑnəl stɛɹɾ ət pɛlɪvɑɹ əz ðoʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ hæd ðɪs θɔɾ iðɝ, ən i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. səm ə ðə stændɪŋ mʊɹændiənz bɪɡæn tə ɑɹɡju aʊt laʊɾ əntɪl ʌðɝz kwaɪəɾəd ðɛm. səmtaɪmz wɪð ə ʃeɪkən fɪst. wʌtɛvɝ hæd pəzɛs ðiz pipəl tə dʒɔɪn fɔɹsɪz wɪð ði ændɔɹənz?

Donel stared at Pelivar as though he had never had this thought either, and he was not the only one. Some of the standing Murandians began to argue out loud until others quieted them. Sometimes with a shaken fist. Whatever had possessed these people to join forces with the Andorans?

ɛɡwin dʒɹu bɹɛθ. ə ɹoʊzbʌd, oʊpənɪŋ tə ðə sʌn. ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ æknɑlɪdʒd əɹ əz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit - ɑɝəθɛl hæd kʌm əz kloʊs tə ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ əz wɑz pɑsəbəl wɪθaʊt pʊʃɪŋ əɹ əsaɪd! - jɛt ðeɪ hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ʃi cʊɾə wɪʃt fɔɹ. kɑm. naʊ wɑz wən ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə wəd bi ɪkspɛktɪŋ əɹ tə neɪm wʌn ə ðɛm tə hændəl ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ʃi hoʊp ðɛɹ stʌməks wɝ taɪɾ ɪn nɑts wɪð wʌndɝɪŋ wɪtʃ ə ðɛm ɪt wəd bi. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ðəɹ kəd bi nʌn.

Egwene drew breath. A rosebud, opening to the sun. They had not acknowledged her as the Amyrlin Seat - Arathelle had come as close to ignoring her as was possible without pushing her aside! - yet they had given her everything else she could have wished for. Calm. Now was when Lelaine and Romanda would be expecting her to name one of them to handle the negotiations. She hoped their stomachs were tied in knots with wondering which of them it would be. There would be no negotiations. There could be none.

"ɪleɪɾə," ʃi sɛd lɛvəli, aɪɪŋ ɑɝəθɛl ən ðə siɾəd noʊbəlz ɪn tɝn, "ɪz ə jusɝpɝ u hæz vaɪəleɪɾɪd wʌt laɪz ət ðə vɛɹi hɑɹɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. aɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit." ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ steɪtli ʃi mænədʒ tə saʊnd, haʊ kul. bʌt nɑɾ əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz ʃi wʌns wəɾ əv bɪn. ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. "wi ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə ɹimuv ɪleɪɾə ən tʃɹaɪ hɝ, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ðə waɪt taʊɝz bɪznəs, ən nʌn ə jʊɹz ɪksɛp tə noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ. ðɪs soʊ-kɔl blæk taʊɝ ɔlsoʊ ɪz əɹ bɪznəs; mɛn u kən tʃænəl əv ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝz əfɛɹ. wɪl dil wɪð əm əz wi tʃuz, wən ðə taɪm ɪz ɹaɪp, bʌɾ aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, ðət taɪm ɪz nɑt naʊ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz mʌs teɪk pɹɛsəɾəns."

"Elaida," she said levelly, eyeing Arathelle and the seated nobles in turn, "is a usurper who has violated what lies at the very heart of the White Tower. I am the Amyrlin Seat." She was surprised at how stately she managed to sound, how cool. But not as surprised as she once would have been. The Light help her, she was the Amyrlin Seat. "We go to Tar Valon to remove Elaida and try her, but that is the White Tower's business, and none of yours except to know the truth. This so-called Black Tower also is our business; men who can channel have always been the White Tower's affair. We will deal with them as we choose, when the time is ripe, but I assure you, that time is not now. More important matters must take precedence."

ʃi hɝd muvmən əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz bɪhaɪn hɝ. ən æktʃəwəl ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn bɛntʃɪz ən ðə kɹɪsp swɪʃɪŋ ə dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts biɪŋ ədʒʌstəd. ət list səm mʌs bi səvɪɹli ædʒəteɪɾəd. wɛl, sɛvɹəl hæd sədʒɛstəd ðət ðə blæk taʊɝ maɪt bi dɛlt wɪð ɪn pæsɪŋ. nɑt wʌn bɪliv ðəɹ kəd bi mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ mɛn ðəɹ ət moʊst, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðeɪ hɝd; æftɝ ɔl, ɪt sɪmpli wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl ðət hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn wəd wɑnə tʃænəl. ðən əɡɛn, ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə ɹiləzeɪʃən ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt gɑnə neɪm iðɝ ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn.

She heard movement among the Sitters behind her. An actual shifting on benches and the crisp swishing of divided skirts being adjusted. At least some must be severely agitated. Well, several had suggested that the Black Tower might be dealt with in passing. Not one believed there could be more than a dozen or so men there at most, no matter what they heard; after all, it simply was not possible that hundreds of men would want to channel. Then again, it might have been the realization that Egwene was not going to name either Romanda or Lelaine.

ɑɝəθɛl fɹaʊnd, pɝhæps kætʃɪŋ ə hɪn ə sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. pɛlɪvɑɹ muvd, ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə ɹaɪzɪŋ əɡɛn, ən dɑnəl dʒɹu hɪmsɛlf ʌp kwɛɹələsli. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə pɹɛs ɑn. ðəɹ nɛvɝ hæd bɪn.

Arathelle frowned, perhaps catching a hint of something in the air. Pelivar moved, on the point of rising again, and Donel drew himself up querulously. There was nothing for it but to press on. There never had been.

"aɪ ʌndɝstæn jəɹ kənsɝnz," ʃi kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ðə seɪm fɔɹməl toʊn, "æn əl ædʒɹɛs ðɛm." wʌt wɑz ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ kɔl tə ɑɹmz ðə bæn juzd? jɛs. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə tɔs ðə daɪs. "aɪ ɡɪv jə ðɪs əʃʊɹəns əz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. fəɹ wʌn mʌnθ wɪl steɪ hɪɹ, ɹɛstɪŋ, ən ðən wɪl liv mʊɹændi, bʌt wɪl nɑt kɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ændɝ. mʊɹændi wɪl bi tʃɹʌbəl baɪ əs noʊ mɔɹ æftɝ ðæt, ən ændɝ wɪl nɑt bi tʃɹʌbəld əɾ ɔl. aɪm sɝɾən," ʃi æɾəd, "ðə mʊɹændiən lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz hɪɹ wɪl bi hæpi tə səplaɪ əɹ wɑns ɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ ɡʊd sɪlvɝ. wɪl peɪ fɛɹ pɹaɪsəz." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn mɑləfaɪɪŋ ði ændɔɹənz ɪf ɪt mɛn mʊɹændiənz ɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz ən səplaɪ tʃɹeɪnz.

"I understand your concerns," she continued in the same formal tone, "and I will address them." What was that strange call to arms the Band used? Yes. It was time to toss the dice. "I give you this assurance as the Amyrlin Seat. For one month we will stay here, resting, and then we will leave Murandy, but we will not cross the border into Andor. Murandy will be troubled by us no more after that, and Andor will not be troubled at all. I'm certain," she added, "the Murandian lords and ladies here will be happy to supply our wants in exchange for good silver. We will pay fair prices." There was no point mollifying the Andorans if it meant Murandians raiding the horses and supply trains.

ðə mʊɹændiənz, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ənizəli, əpɪɹd dɪsaɪɾədli tɔɹn ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðəɹ wɑz kɔɪn tə bi meɪd, ən ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪt səplaɪɪŋ ən ɑɹmi soʊ lɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hu kəd hæɡəl səksɛsfəli wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ən ɑɹmi soʊ lɑɹdʒ ɔfɝd? dɑnəl æktʃəli  simd ɹɛɾi tə sɪk ʌp, waɪl ʃin sim tə bi duɪŋ sʌmz ɪn əɹ hɛd. mʌɾɝz ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ði ɔnlʊkɝz. mɔɹ ðən mʌɾɝz; nɪɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛɡwin.

The Murandians, looking around uneasily, appeared decidedly torn in any case. There was coin to be made, and a great deal of it supplying an army so large, but on the other hand, who could haggle successfully with whatever an army so large offered? Donel actually seemed ready to sick up, while Cian seemed to be doing sums in her head. Mutters rose among the onlookers. More than mutters; nearly loud enough for Egwene.

ʃi wɑntəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ðə saɪləns fɹəm ðə sɪɾɝz wɑz dɛfənɪŋ. sɪuən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ən ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ skɝts əz ɪf tə kip hɝsɛlf lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd baɪ meɪn fɔɹs. ət list ʃi hæd noʊn wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ. ʃɛɹiəm, hu hæd nɑt, aɪd ði ændɔɹənz ən mʊɹændiənz ɹiɡəli, kɑmli, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛvɹi wɝd.

She wanted to look over her shoulder. The silence from the Sitters was deafening. Siuan was staring straight ahead and gripping her skirts as if to keep herself looking forward by main force. At least she had known what was coming. Sheriam, who had not, eyed the Andorans and Murandians regally, calmly, as though she had expected every word.

ɛɡwin niɾəd tə meɪk əm fɝɡɛt ðə ɡɝl ðeɪ sɔ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ən hɪɹ ə wʊmən wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz ə paʊɝ fɝmli ɪn hænd. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪn əɹ hænz naʊ, ðeɪ wəd bi! ʃi fɝmd əɹ vɔɪs. "mɑɹk mi wɛl. aɪ hæv meɪd maɪ dɪsɪʒən; ɪts fəɹ jə tə æksɛpt ɪt. əɹ feɪs wʌt ʃʊɹli wɪl kʌm fɹəm jəɹ feɪljɝ." əz ʃi fɛl saɪlənt, ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd tə ə bɹif haʊl, ɹætlɪŋ ðə kænəpi, tʌɡɪŋ ət ɡɑɹməns. ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ hɛɹ kɑmli. səm ə ðə wɑtʃɪŋ noʊbəlz ʃɪvɝɾ ən twɪtʃt ðɛɹ kloʊks ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ʃi hoʊp ðɛɹ ʃɪvɝz keɪm fɹəm mɔɹ ðən ðə wɛðɝ.

Egwene needed to make them forget the girl they saw before them, and hear a woman with the reins of power firmly in hand. If they were not in her hands now, they would be! She firmed her voice. "Mark me well. I have made my decision; it is for you to accept it. Or face what surely will come from your failure." As she fell silent, the wind gusted to a brief howl, rattling the canopy, tugging at garments. Egwene straightened her hair calmly. Some of the watching nobles shivered and twitched their cloaks around them, and she hoped their shivers came from more than the weather.

ɑɝəθɛl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð pɛlɪvɑɹ ən æɛmlɪn, ən ɔl θɹi stʌɾid ðə sɪɾɝz bɪfɔɹ sloʊli nɑɾɪŋ. ðeɪ bɪlivd ʃi wɑz mɪɹli maʊðɪŋ wɝdz ðə sɪɾɝz hæd pʊɾ ɑn əɹ tʌŋ! ivən soʊ, ɛɡwin vɛɹi nɪɹli saɪd wɪð ɹɪlif.

Arathelle exchanged looks with Pelivar and Aemlyn, and all three studied the Sitters before slowly nodding. They believed she was merely mouthing words the Sitters had put on her tongue! Even so, Egwene very nearly sighed with relief.

"ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ," ðə hɑɹd-aɪd noʊbəlwʊmən sɛd. əɡɛn, tə ðə sɪɾɝz. "wi də nɑt daʊt ðə wɝɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt jəl ʌndɝstæn ɪf wi ɔlsoʊ ɹɪmeɪn. səmtaɪmz, wʌt jə hɪɹ ɪzənt wʌt jə θɪŋk jə hɝd. nɑt ðət ðæts ðə keɪs hɪɹ, aɪm ʃʊɹ. bʌt wɪl steɪ waɪl jə du." dɑnəl tʃɹuli lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə ɛmpti hɪmsɛlf. vɛɹi laɪkli hɪz lænz leɪ nɪɹbaɪ. ændɔɝən ɑɹmiz ɪn mʊɹændi hæd sɛldəm bɪn noʊn tə peɪ fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ.

"It will be as you say," the hard-eyed noblewoman said. Again, to the Sitters. "We do not doubt the word of Aes Sedai, of course, but you will understand if we also remain. Sometimes, what you hear isn't what you think you heard. Not that that's the case here, I'm sure. But we will stay while you do." Donel truly looked ready to empty himself. Very likely his lands lay nearby. Andoran armies in Murandy had seldom been known to pay for anything.

ɛɡwin stʊd, ən ʃi kəd hɪɹ ðə ɹʌsəl ə ðə sɪɾɝz ɹaɪzɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid, ðɛn. wi mʌst ɔl dɪpɑɹt sun, ɪf wəɹ tə ɹɪtɝn tə əɹ oʊn bɛdz bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk, bʌt wi ʃəd spɛɹ ə fju moʊməns. ɡɛɾɪŋ tə noʊ wʌn ənʌðɝ ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ naʊ maɪɾ əvɔɪd mɪsʌndɝstændɪŋz leɪɾɝ." ən tɔk maɪt ɡɪv əɹ ə tʃæns tə ɹitʃ tælmɑnz. "oʊ. wʌn ʌðɝ θɪŋ jə ʃəɾ ɔl bi əwɛɹ ʌv. ðə nɑvəs bʊk ɪz naʊ oʊpən tə ɛni wʊmən, wʌtɛvɝ əɹ eɪdʒ, ɪf ʃi tɛsts tʃɹu." ɑɝəθɛl blɪŋkt. sɪuən dɪd nɑt, jɛɾ ɛɡwin θɔt ʃi hɝɾ ə feɪnt ɡɹʌnt. ðɪs wɑz nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæd dɪskʌst, bʌt ðəɹ wəd nɛvɝ bi ə bɛɾɝ taɪm. "kʌm. aɪm ʃʊɹ jə wəɾ ɔl laɪk tə spik wɪð ðə sɪɾɝz. lɛt fɔɹmæləɾi ɡoʊ."

Egwene stood, and she could hear the rustle of the Sitters rising behind her. "It is agreed, then. We must all depart soon, if we are to return to our own beds before dark, but we should spare a few moments. Getting to know one another a little better now might avoid misunderstandings later." And talk might give her a chance to reach Talmanes. "Oh. One other thing you should all be aware of. The novice book is now open to any woman, whatever her age, if she tests true." Arathelle blinked. Siuan did not, yet Egwene thought she heard a faint grunt. This was not part of what they had discussed, but there would never be a better time. "Come. I'm sure you would all like to speak with the Sitters. Let formality go."

wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ʃɛɹiəm tə ɔfɝ ə hænd, ʃi stɛp daʊn. ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛlt laɪk læfɪŋ. læs naɪt ʃi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd ʃi maɪt nɛvɝ ɹitʃ əɹ ɡoʊl, bʌt ʃi wɑz hæfweɪ ðɛɹ, ɔlmoʊs hæfweɪ, ən ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn nɪɹli əz dɪfəkəlt əz ʃi hæd fɪɹd. ʌv kɔɹs, ði ʌðɝ hæf ɹɪmeɪnd.

Without waiting for Sheriam to offer a hand, she stepped down. She almost felt like laughing. Last night she had been afraid she might never reach her goal, but she was halfway there, almost halfway, and it had not been nearly as difficult as she had feared. Of course, the other half remained.


tʃæptɝ eɪtin


CHAPTER 18

eɪ pəkjuljɝ kɔlɪŋ


A Peculiar Calling

fəɹ ə moʊmən æftɝ ɛɡwin dɪsɛndəd, noʊ wʌn ɛls muvd. ən ðən ði ændɔɹənz ən mʊɹændiənz hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə sɪɾɝz, ɔlmoʊst əz wʌn. əpɛɹənli, ə ɡɝl æmɪɝlɪn - ə ɡɝl pʌpəɾ ən fɪɡjɝhɛd! - hɛl noʊ ɪntʃɹəst, nɑt wɪð eɪdʒləs feɪsəz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ðəɾ ət list sɛd ðeɪ æktʃəli  wɝ spikɪŋ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. tu əɹ θɹi lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn itʃ sɪɾɝ, səm θɹʌstɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɪnz dɪmændɪŋli, ʌðɝz dɪfəɾəntli bɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ nɛks, jɛɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ɪnsɪstən ɑn biɪŋ hɝd. ðə ʃɑɹp bɹiz wɪskt əweɪ ðə mɪst ə ðɛɹ bɹɛθ ən flʌɾɝd kloʊks fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ði ɪmpɔɹɾəns ʌv æskɪŋ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz. ʃɛɹiəm wɑz bʌɾənhoʊld tu, baɪ ɹɛd-feɪs lɔɹd dɑnəl, hu blʌstɝɾ ən dʒɝk baʊz baɪ tɝnz.

For a moment after Egwene descended, no one else moved. And then the Andorans and Murandians headed for the Sitters, almost as one. Apparently, a girl Amyrlin - a girl puppet and figurehead! - held no interest, not with ageless faces in front of them that at least said they actually were speaking to Aes Sedai. Two or three lords and ladies clustered around each Sitter, some thrusting their chins demandingly, others diffidently bending their necks, yet every one insistent on being heard. The sharp breeze whisked away the mist of their breath and fluttered cloaks forgotten in the importance of asking their questions. Sheriam was buttonholed too, by red-faced Lord Donel, who blustered and jerked bows by turns.

ɛɡwin pʊld ʃɛɹiəm əweɪ fɹəm ðə nɛɹoʊ-aɪd mæn. "faɪn aʊt dɪskɹitli ɔl jə kən əbaʊt ðiz sɪstɝz ən taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz ɪn ændɝ," ʃi wɪspɝd heɪstəli. əz sun əz ʃi ɹilis ðə wʊmən, dɑnəl ɹikleɪm hɝ. ʃɛɹiəm æktʃəli  lʊk pʊt-əpɑn, bʌɾ əɹ fɹaʊn dɪsəpɪɹd kwɪkli. dɑnəl blɪŋkt ənizəli əz ʃi bɪɡæn kwɛstʃənɪŋ hɪm.

Egwene pulled Sheriam away from the narrow-eyed man. "Find out discreetly all you can about these sisters and Tower Guards in Andor," she whispered hastily. As soon as she released the woman, Donel reclaimed her. Sheriam actually looked put-upon, but her frown disappeared quickly. Donel blinked uneasily as she began questioning him.

ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn ɡeɪzd əɾ ɛɡwin θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɪð feɪsəz kɑɹv fɹəm aɪs, bʌɾ itʃ hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə pɛɹ ə noʊbəlz u wɑntəd. . . . sʌmθɪŋ. ɹiəʃʊɹəns ðət ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɪɾən tʃɹɪk ɪn ɛɡwinz wɝdz, pɝhæps. haʊ ðeɪ wəd heɪt duɪŋ ðæt, bʌt dɑdʒ ən dʌk əz ðeɪ wəd - ən ðeɪ wʊd! - ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɹɪli əvɔɪd ðət ɹiəʃʊɹəns wɪθaʊt ɹipjuɾieɪtɪŋ əɹ ɑn ðə spɑt. ivən ðoʊz tu wəd nɑt ɡoʊ ðət fɑɹ. nɑt hɪɹ, nɑt pʌblɪkli.

Romanda and Lelaine gazed at Egwene through the crowd with faces carved from ice, but each had acquired a pair of nobles who wanted. . . . Something. Reassurance that there was no hidden trick in Egwene's words, perhaps. How they would hate doing that, but dodge and duck as they would - and they would! - there was no way to really avoid that reassurance without repudiating her on the spot. Even those two would not go that far. Not here, not publicly.

sɪuən slɪp kloʊs tə ɛɡwin, fitʃɝz sɛɾ ɪn miknəs. ɪksɛp ðəɾ əɹ aɪz dɑɹɾɪd, meɪbi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn kʌmɪŋ tə siz əm wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd, ən fɝɡɛt lɔ, kʌstəm, pɹəpɹaɪəɾi ən u wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ. "ʃaɪn tʃʌnlə," ʃi ɔl bʌt hɪst ɪn ə wɪspɝ.

Siuan slipped close to Egwene, features set in meekness. Except that her eyes darted, maybe looking for Romanda or Lelaine coming to seize them where they stood, and forget law, custom, propriety and who was watching. "Shein Chunla," she all but hissed in a whisper.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz sɝtʃt fəɹ tælmɑnz. moʊst ə ðə mɛn ən səm ə ðə wɪmən wɝ tɔl ɪnʌf tə haɪd hɪm. wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ʃɪftɪŋ əbaʊt. . . . ʃi wɛn ʌp ɑn əɹ toʊz. wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɔn tə?

Egwene nodded, but her eyes searched for Talmanes. Most of the men and some of the women were tall enough to hide him. With everyone shifting about. . . . She went up on her toes. Where had he gone to?

sɛɡən plæntəd hɝsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, aɪɪŋ sɪuən daʊtfəli. ɛɡwin lɛɾ əɹ hilz daʊn hɝidli. ði æmɪɝlɪn kəd nɑt bɑb əbaʊt laɪk ə ɡɝl əɾ ə dæns lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə bɔɪ. ə ɹoʊzbʌɾ ənfoʊldɪŋ. kɑm. sɝɛnəɾi. dʒɹæɾ ɔl mɛn!

Segan planted herself in front of her, fists on her hips, eyeing Siuan doubtfully. Egwene let her heels down hurriedly. The Amyrlin could not bob about like a girl at a dance looking for a boy. A rosebud unfolding. Calm. Serenity. Drat all men!

ə slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ, sɛɡən sim tə hæv bɪn bɔɹn pɛtʃələnt, hɝ fʊl maʊθ fɪkst ɪn ə paʊt. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɡʊd blu wʊl ən meɪd fəɹ wɔɹmθ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ vɪvəd ɡɹin ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əkɹɔs əɹ bʊzəm, ən əɹ ɡlʌvz wɝ bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə tɪŋkɝ. ʃi lʊkt ɛɡwin ʌp ən daʊn, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps, wɪð əz mʌtʃ ɪnkɹədulɪɾi ɑn əɹ feɪs əz ʃi hæd ɡɪvən sɪuən. "wʌt jə sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə nɑvəs bʊk," ʃi sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. "wɝ jə minɪŋ ɛni wʊmən ʌv ɛni eɪdʒ əɾ ɔl? ɛni kən bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðɛn?"

A slender woman with long dark hair, Segan seemed to have been born petulant, her full mouth fixed in a pout. Her dress was good blue wool and made for warmth, but it had far too much vivid green embroidery across her bosom, and her gloves were bright enough for a Tinker. She looked Egwene up and down, pursing her lips, with as much incredulity on her face as she had given Siuan. "What you said about the novice book," she said abruptly. "Were you meaning any woman of any age at all? Any can become Aes Sedai, then?"

ə kwɛstʃən kloʊs tə ɛɡwinz hɑɹt, ən ən ænsɝ ʃi dɪɹli wɑntəd tə ɡɪv - əlɔŋ wɪð ə bɑks ɑn ði ɪɹ fəɹ ðə daʊt - bʌt dʒʌs ðən ə smɔl ɡæp ɪn ðə floʊ ʌv pipəl ʃoʊɾ əɹ tælmɑnz nɪɹ ðə bæk ə ðə pəvɪljən. tɔkɪŋ wɪð pɛlɪvɑɹ! ðeɪ stʊd stɪfli, mæstəfs nɑt kwaɪt ɹɛɾi tə ʃoʊ tiθ, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ kipɪŋ ə wɑtʃ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn keɪm kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə seɪ. "ɛni wʊmən ʌv ɛni eɪdʒ əɾ ɔl, dɔɾɝ," ʃi əɡɹiɾ æbsənli. pɛlɪvɑɹ?

A question close to Egwene's heart, and an answer she dearly wanted to give - along with a box on the ear for the doubt - but just then a small gap in the flow of people showed her Talmanes near the back of the pavilion. Talking with Pelivar! They stood stiffly, mastiffs not quite ready to show teeth, yet they were keeping a watch to make sure no one came close enough to overhear what they had to say. "Any woman of any age at all, daughter," she agreed absently. Pelivar?

"θæŋk ju," sɛɡən sɛd, ən hɔltɪŋli æɾəd, "mʌðɝ." ʃi skɛtʃt ə kɝtsi, ðə bɛɹəs hɪn ʌv wʌn, bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɔf. ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ æftɝ hɝ. wɛl, ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

"Thank you," Segan said, and haltingly added, "Mother." She sketched a curtsy, the barest hint of one, before hurrying off. Egwene stared after her. Well, it was a beginning.

sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ doʊn maɪn seɪlɪŋ ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɪf aɪ mʌst," ʃi mʌɾɝd hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "wi dɪskʌs ðæt; wi weɪd ðə deɪnʒɝz, ən ɛniweɪ, ðəɹ dʌzn sim tə bi ə ɡʌlz læs dɪnɝ fəɹ tʃɔɪs. bʌt juv tə sɛɾ ə faɪɝ ɑn dɛk dʒʌs tə meɪk θɪŋz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. nɛɾɪŋ laɪən-fɪʃ ɪzən ɪnʌf fəɹ ju. juv tə stʌf ə pɹɪkəlbæk daʊn jəɹ dʒɹɛs, tu. jə ɑɹən kɑntɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə weɪɾ ə skul ə sɪlvɝpaɪk - "

Siuan snorted. "I don't mind sailing the Fingers of the Dragon in the dark if I must," she muttered half under her breath. "We discussed that; we weighed the dangers, and anyway, there doesn't seem to be a gull's last dinner for choice. But you have to set a fire on deck just to make things interesting. Netting lion-fish isn't enough for you. You have to stuff a prickleback down your dress, too. You aren't content trying to wade a school of silverpike - "

ɛɡwin bɹoʊk ɪn. "sɪuən, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd tɛl lɔɹd bɹaɪn jəɹ hɛɾ oʊvɝ hilz ɪn lʌv wɪð hɪm. ɪts oʊnli fɛɹ ðəɾ i noʊ, doʊn jə əɡɹi?" sɪuənz blu aɪz bʌlʒd, ən əɹ maʊθ wɝkt, bʌɾ ɔl ðət keɪm aʊt wɑz ə sɔɹɾ ʌv ɡɑbəlɪŋ. ɛɡwin pæɾəd əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. "jɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɪuən. tʃɹaɪ tə meɪnteɪn ət list ə lɪɾəl dɪɡnəɾi. ən tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn aʊɾ əbaʊt ðoʊz sɪstɝz ɪn ændɝ." ðə kɹaʊd pɑɹɾəd əɡɛn. ʃi sɔ tælmɑnz ɪn ə dɪfɹən pleɪs, bʌt stɪl ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə pəvɪljən. ən əloʊn, naʊ.

Egwene broke in. "Siuan, I think I should tell Lord Bryne you're head over heels in love with him. It's only fair that he know, don't you agree?" Siuan's blue eyes bulged, and her mouth worked, but all that came out was a sort of gobbling. Egwene patted her shoulder. "You're Aes Sedai, Siuan. Try to maintain at least a little dignity. And try to find out about those sisters in Andor." The crowd parted again. She saw Talmanes in a different place, but still on the edge of the pavilion. And alone, now.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə hɝi, ʃi wɔkt ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, livɪŋ sɪuən stɪl ɡɑbəlɪŋ. ə pɹɪɾi, blæk-hɛɹd sɝvɪŋ mæn, huz bʌlki wʊlən bɹitʃɪz kəd nɑt kwaɪt haɪd nitli tɝn kævz, ɔfɝd sɪuən ə stimɪŋ sɪlvɝ kʌp fɹəm ə tʃɹeɪ. ʌðɝ sɝvəns wɝ muvɪŋ əbaʊt wɪð ʌðɝ sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪz. ɹəfɹɛʃmənt wɑz biɪŋ ɔfɝd, ɪf ə bɪt leɪt. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tu leɪt fəɹ ðə kɪs ə pis. ʃi dɪd nɑt hɪɹ wʌt sɪuən sɛɾ əz ʃi snætʃt ə kʌp, bʌt fɹəm ðə weɪ ðə fɛloʊ dʒɝkt ən stɑɹɾəd bɑbɪŋ baʊz, hi hæd ɹəsivd ʃɑɹp ʃɑɹdz ə hɝ tɛmpɝ ət ðə list. ɛɡwin saɪd.

Trying not to hurry, she walked in his direction, leaving Siuan still gobbling. A pretty, black-haired serving man, whose bulky woolen breeches could not quite hide neatly turned calves, offered Siuan a steaming silver cup from a tray. Other servants were moving about with other silver trays. Refreshment was being offered, if a bit late. It was much too late for the kiss of peace. She did not hear what Siuan said as she snatched a cup, but from the way the fellow jerked and started bobbing bows, he had received sharp shards of her temper at the least. Egwene sighed.

tælmɑnz stʊd wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd, əbzɝvɪŋ ðə ɡoʊɪŋz-ɑn wɪð ən əmjuz smaɪl ðət dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ ɪz aɪz. hi sim pɔɪz tə ɪksploʊɾ ɪndə moʊʃən, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ taɪɝd. əɾ əɹ əpɹoʊtʃ, hi meɪɾ ə ɹɪspɛkfəl lɛɡ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹaɪ tʌtʃ tə hɪz vɔɪs wən i sɛd, "ju tʃeɪnʒd ə bɔɹɾɝ tədeɪ." hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz kloʊk əɡɛns ði aɪsi bɹiz. "ɪɾ əz ɔlweɪz bɪn . . . fluəd . . . bɪtwin ændɝ ən mʊɹændi, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt mæps seɪ, bʌɾ ændɝ əz nɛvɝ kʌm saʊθ ɪn sətʃ nʌmbɝz bɪfɔɹ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ði il wɔɹ, ən ðə waɪtkloʊk wɔɹ, ɛniweɪ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli pæsɪŋ θɹu, ðɛn. wʌns ðeɪv bɪn hɪɹ ə mʌnθ, nu mæps wɪl ʃoʊ ə nu laɪn. lʊk ət ðə mʊɹændiənz skɹæmbəl, fɔnɪŋ oʊvɝ pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɪz kəmpænjənz əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ də ðə sɪstɝz. ðeɪ ɑɹ hoʊpɪŋ tə meɪk nu fɹɛnz fəɹ ðə nu deɪ."

Talmanes stood with arms folded, observing the goings-on with an amused smile that did not reach his eyes. He seemed poised to explode into motion, but his eyes were tired. At her approach, he made a respectful leg, but there was a wry touch to his voice when he said, "You changed a border today." He gathered his cloak against the icy breeze. "It has always been . . . fluid . . . between Andor and Murandy, no matter what maps say, but Andor has never come south in such numbers before. Except for the Aiel War, and the Whitecloak War, anyway, but they were only passing through, then. Once they have been here a month, new maps will show a new line. Look at the Murandians scramble, fawning over Pelivar and his companions as much as they do the sisters. They are hoping to make new friends for the new day."

tə ɛɡwin, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənsil əɹ kɛɹfəl wɑtʃ ɑn ðoʊz u maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, ɪt sim ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə noʊbəlz, mʊɹændiən ən ændɔɝən, wɝ ɪntɛn ɑn ðə sɪɾɝz, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi hæd slaɪtli mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz ɪn maɪn ðən bɔɹɾɝz. tə hɝ, ɪf nɑt tə ðə noʊbəlz. ɪksɛp fəɹ bɹif moʊməns, nʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ vɪzəbəl bɪɑn ðə tɑps ə ðɛɹ hɛdz. oʊnli hɑlimə ən sɪuən sim tə noʊɾəs hɝ, ən ə bæbəl laɪk ðəɾ ʌv ə flɑk ʌv ɪksaɪɾəd ɡis fɪl ði ɛɹ. ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs, ən tʃoʊz əɹ wɝdz kɛɹfəli.

To Egwene, trying to conceal her careful watch on those who might be watching her, it seemed that all of the nobles, Murandian and Andoran, were intent on the Sitters, crowding around them. In any case, she had slightly more important matters in mind than borders. To her, if not to the nobles. Except for brief moments, none of the Sitters were visible beyond the tops of their heads. Only Halima and Siuan seemed to notice her, and a babble like that of a flock of excited geese filled the air. She lowered her voice, and chose her words carefully.

"fɹɛnz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, tælmɑnz. juv bɪn ə ɡʊd fɹɛn tə mæt, ən aɪ θɪŋk tə mi. aɪ hoʊp ðət hæzən tʃeɪnʒd. aɪ hoʊp juv nɑt toʊld ɛniwʌn wʌt jə ʃʊdnt." laɪt, ʃi wɑz æŋkʃəs, əɹ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn soʊ dɝɛkt. nɛkst, ʃi wəd kʌm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən æsk wʌɾ i ən pɛlɪvɑɹ hæd bɪn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt!

"Friends are always important, Talmanes. You've been a good friend to Mat, and I think to me. I hope that hasn't changed. I hope you've not told anyone what you shouldn't." Light, she was anxious, or she would not have been so direct. Next, she would come right out and ask what he and Pelivar had been talking about!

lʌkəli, hi dɪd nɑt læf əɾ əɹ fəɹ ə blʌnt-tʌŋ vɪlədʒ wʊmən. ðoʊ hi maɪɾ əv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ɪt. hi stʌɾid əɹ sɪɹiəsli bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs. hi ɔlsoʊ nu kɑʃən. "nɑɾ ɔl mɛn ɡɑsəp. tɛl mi, wən jə sɛn mæt saʊθ, dɪd jə noʊ wʌt jə wəd də hɪɹ tədeɪ?"

Luckily, he did not laugh at her for a blunt-tongued village woman. Though he might have been thinking it. He studied her seriously before speaking. In a soft voice. He also knew caution. "Not all men gossip. Tell me, when you sent Mat south, did you know what you would do here today?"

"haʊ kəɾ aɪ noʊ ðət tu mʌnθs əɡoʊ? noʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹən ɑmnɪʃənt, tælmɑnz." ʃi hæd hoʊp fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd pʊɾ əɹ ɪn ðə pleɪs ʃi wɑz, hæd plæn fəɹ ɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn, nɑt bæk ðɛn. ʃi ɔlsoʊ hoʊpt i dɪd nɑt ɡɑsəp. səm mɛn dɪd nɑt.

"How could I know that two months ago? No, Aes Sedai aren't omniscient, Talmanes." She had hoped for something that would put her in the place she was, had planned for it, but she had not known, not back then. She also hoped he did not gossip. Some men did not.

ɹoʊmændə stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹɾ əɹ wɪð ə fɝm stʃɹaɪɾ ən ə fɹoʊzən feɪs, bʌɾ ɑɝəθɛl ɪntɝsɛptəd hɝ, kætʃɪŋ ðə jɛloʊ sɪɾɝz ɑɹm ən ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bi pʊɾ ɔf dɪspaɪt ɹoʊmændəz əstɑnɪʃmənt.

Romanda started toward her with a firm stride and a frozen face, but Arathelle intercepted her, catching the Yellow Sitter's arm and refusing to be put off despite Romanda's astonishment.

"wɪl jə ət lis tɛl mi wɛɹ mæt ɪz?" tælmɑnz æskt. "ɑn ɪz weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ? waɪ ɑɹ jə sɝpɹaɪzd? ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən wɪl spik tə ə soʊlʒɝ wən fɛtʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə seɪm stʃɹim. ivən wən hiz ə hɔɹəbəl dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn," hi æɾəd dʒɹaɪli.

"Will you at least tell me where Mat is?" Talmanes asked. "On his way to Caemlyn with the Daughter-Heir? Why are you surprised? A serving woman will speak to a soldier when fetching water from the same stream. Even when he is a horrible Dragonsworn," he added dryly.

laɪt! mɛn ɹɪli wɝ . . . ɪnkənvinjənt . . . ət taɪmz. ðə bɛst ə ðɛm faʊnd weɪz tə seɪ ɪɡzækli ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ ət ðə ɹɔŋ moʊmənt, tə æsk ðə ɹɔŋ kwɛstʃən. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ɪnveɪiɡəlɪŋ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ɪndə pɹæɾəl. soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ ɪf ʃi kəd dʒʌs laɪ, bʌɾ i hæd ɡɪvən əɹ plɛnti ʌv ɹum wɪðɪn ði oʊðz. hæf ðə tʃɹuθ wəd səfaɪs, ən kip ɪm fɹəm hɛɹɪŋ ɔf tə ɛbu dɑɹ. meɪbi lɛs ðən hæf.

Light! Men really were . . . inconvenient . . . at times. The best of them found ways to say exactly the wrong thing at the wrong moment, to ask the wrong question. Not to mention inveigling serving women into prattle. So much easier if she could just lie, but he had given her plenty of room within the Oaths. Half the truth would suffice, and keep him from haring off to Ebou Dar. Maybe less than half.

oʊvɝ ɪn ðə fɑɹ kɔɹnɝ ə ðə pəvɪljən, sɪuən stʊd kənvɝsɪŋ wɪð ə tɔl jʌŋ ɹɛdhɛd wɪð kɝl mʌstæʃɪz u wɑz aɪɪŋ əɹ əz dubiəsli əz sɛɡən hæd. noʊbəlz juʒəwəli nu ðə lʊk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌɾ i hɛld oʊnli ə pɑɹɾ ə sɪuənz ətɛnʃən. hɝ ɡeɪz kɑnstənli flɪkɝd təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin. ɪt sim tə ʃaʊt, laʊɾ əz kɑnʃəns. iziɝ. ɪkspiɾiənt. wʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn əbaʊt tədeɪ, oʊnli hoʊpt! ɛɡwin ɪkspɛld ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd bɹɛθ. bɝn ðə wʊmən!

Over in the far corner of the pavilion, Siuan stood conversing with a tall young redhead with curled mustaches who was eyeing her as dubiously as Segan had. Nobles usually knew the look of Aes Sedai. But he held only a part of Siuan's attention. Her gaze constantly flickered toward Egwene. It seemed to shout, loud as conscience. Easier. Expedient. What it was to be Aes Sedai. She had not known about today, only hoped! Egwene expelled an irritated breath. Burn the woman!

"hi wɑz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðə læst aɪ hɝd," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "bʌɾ i mʌs bi hɝiɪŋ nɔɹθ əz fæst əz i kən baɪ naʊ. hi stɪl θɪŋks hiz tə seɪv mi, tælmɑnz, ən meɪtʃɹim kɔθən wʊdn mɪs ðə tʃæns tə bi ɑn ðə spɑt soʊ hi kən seɪ aɪ toʊl jə soʊ."

"He was in Ebou Dar, the last I heard," she muttered. "But he must be hurrying north as fast as he can by now. He still thinks he has to save me, Talmanes, and Matrim Cauthon wouldn't miss the chance to be on the spot so he can say I told you so."

tælmɑnz dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɔl sɝpɹaɪzd. "aɪ θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi soʊ," hi saɪd. "aɪ hæv . . . fɛlt . . . sʌmθɪŋ, fəɹ wiks naʊ. ʌðɝz ɪn ðə bæn hæv, tu. nɑɾ ɝdʒənt, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ. əz ɪf i niɾəd mi. əz ɪf aɪ ʃəd lʊk saʊθ, ɛniweɪ. ɪt kən bi pəkjuljɝ, fɑloʊɪŋ ə tɑvɝən."
