Talmanes did not look at all surprised. "I thought it might be so," he sighed. "I have . . . felt . . . something, for weeks now. Others in the Band have, too. Not urgent, but always there. As if he needed me. As if I should look south, anyway. It can be peculiar, following a ta'veren."

"aɪ səpoʊz ɪt kæn," ʃi əɡɹid, hoʊpɪŋ nʌn ə hɝ ɪnkɹədulɪɾi ʃoʊd. ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪnʌf tə θɪŋk ə mæt ðə weɪstʃɹəl əz liɾɝ ə ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, mʌtʃ lɛs əz tɑvɝən, bʌt ʃʊɹli ə tɑvɝən hæd tə bi pɹɛzənt, nɪɹbaɪ ət list, tə hæv ɛni ɪfɛkt.

"I suppose it can," she agreed, hoping none of her incredulity showed. It was strange enough to think of Mat the wastrel as leader of the Band of the Red Hand, much less as ta'veren, but surely a ta'veren had to be present, nearby at least, to have any effect.

"mæt wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt jə niɾɪŋ ɹɛskju. jə nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ə kʌmɪŋ tə mi fəɹ hɛlp, dɪd ju?"

"Mat was wrong about you needing rescue. You never had any intention of coming to me for help, did you?"

hi stɪl spoʊk sɔfli, bʌt ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn hɝidli ɛniweɪ. sɪuən wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm. ən soʊ wɑz hɑlimə. peɪtʃɹ stʊd mʌtʃ tu kloʊs tə hɝ, pʌfɪŋ ən pɹinɪŋ ən stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz - fɹəm ðə weɪ hi stɛɹd daʊn əɹ dʒɹɛs, hi hæd nɑt mɪsteɪkən əɹ fəɹ ə sɪstɝ, ðət wɑz sɝɾən! - bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm oʊnli hæf əɹ maɪnd, dɑɹɾɪŋ saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz ɪn ɛɡwinz dɝɛkʃən waɪl ʃi smaɪld ʌp əɾ ɪm wɔɹmli. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls əpɪɹɾ ɑkjəpaɪd, ən noʊ wʌn stʊd kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ.

He still spoke softly, but she looked around hurriedly anyway. Siuan was still watching them. And so was Halima. Paitr stood much too close to her, puffing and preening and stroking his mustaches - from the way he stared down her dress, he had not mistaken her for a sister, that was certain! - but she was giving him only half her mind, darting sidelong glances in Egwene's direction while she smiled up at him warmly. Everyone else appeared occupied, and no one stood close enough to hear.

"ði æmɪɝlɪn sit kəd hɑɹdli ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ sæŋktʃuɛɹi, naʊ kəd ʃi? bʌt ðəɹ əv bɪn taɪmz ɪts bɪn ə kʌmfɝt noʊɪŋ jə wɝ ðɛɹ," ʃi ədmɪɾəd. ɹɪlʌktənli. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz hɑɹdli səpoʊz tə niɾ ə boʊlt-hoʊl, bʌɾ ɪt kəd də noʊ hɑɹm soʊ lɔŋ əz nʌn ə ðə sɪɾɝz nu. "ju hæv bɪn ə fɹɛnd, tælmɑnz. aɪ hoʊp ðət kəntɪnjuz. aɪ tʃɹuli du."

"The Amyrlin Seat could hardly go running for sanctuary, now could she? But there have been times it's been a comfort knowing you were there," she admitted. Reluctantly. The Amyrlin Seat was hardly supposed to need a bolt-hole, but it could do no harm so long as none of the Sitters knew. "You have been a friend, Talmanes. I hope that continues. I truly do."

"ju hæv bɪn mɔɹ . . . oʊpən . . . wɪð mi ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd," hi sɛd sloʊli, "soʊ əl tɛl jə sʌmθɪŋ." hɪz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ - tə ɛni wɑtʃɝ, hi mʌst əv simd əz kæʒəwəl əz bɪfɔɹ - bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs dʒɹɑp tə ə wɪspɝ. "aɪ hæv hæɾ əpɹoʊtʃɪz fɹəm kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən əbaʊt ðə bænd. ɪt simz hiz hoʊps ə biɪŋ mʊɹændiz fɝst ɹil kɪŋ. hi wɑns tə haɪɝ ʌs. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv kənsɪɾɝd ɪt, nɔɹməli, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nɛvɝ ɪnʌf kɔɪn, ən wɪð ðɪs . . . ðɪs fil ə mæt niɾɪŋ ʌs. . . . ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ ɪf wi ɹɪmeɪn ɪn mʊɹændi. klɪɹ əz ɡʊd ɡlæs, jə ɑɹ wɛɹ jə wɑnə bi ən əv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn hænd."

"You have been more . . . open . . . with me than I expected," he said slowly, "so I will tell you something." His face did not change - to any watcher, he must have seemed as casual as before - but his voice dropped to a whisper. "I have had approaches from King Roedran about the Band. It seems he has hopes of being Murandy's first real king. He wants to hire us. I would not have considered it, normally, but there is never enough coin, and with this . . . this feel of Mat needing us. . . . It might be better if we remain in Murandy. Clear as good glass, you are where you want to be and have everything in hand."

hi fɛl saɪlən əz ə jʌŋ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kɝtsid tə ɔfɝ mʌld waɪn. ʃi wɔɹ faɪnli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin wʊl ən ə kloʊk plʌʃ wɪð spɑɾəd ɹæbət. ʌðɝ sɝvəns fɹəm ðə kæmp wɝ hɛlpɪŋ aʊt naʊ, əz wɛl, noʊ daʊt fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə də bɪsaɪdz stæn ən ʃɪvɝ. ðə jʌŋ wʊmənz ɹaʊn feɪs wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli pɪntʃt fɹəm ðə koʊld.

He fell silent as a young serving woman curtsied to offer mulled wine. She wore finely embroidered green wool and a cloak plush with spotted rabbit. Other servants from the camp were helping out now, as well, no doubt for something to do besides stand and shiver. The young woman's round face was decidedly pinched from the cold.

tælmɑnz weɪvd əɹ ɔf ən pʊld ɪz kloʊk bæk ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌɾ ɛɡwin tʊk ə sɪlvɝ kʌp tə ɡeɪn ə moʊmən fəɹ θɔt. tʃɹuli ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl nid fəɹ ðə bæn ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ðə mʌɾɝɪŋ, ðə sɪstɝz tʊk ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns əz ə mæɾɝ ə kɔɹs naʊ, dʒɹæɡən-swɔɹn əɹ nɑt; ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɪɹɾ ən ətæk, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ɹil nid tə juz ðə bænz pɹɛzəns tə pɹɑɾ əm ɪndə muvɪŋ sɪns livɪŋ sɑlədɑɹ. ði oʊnli tʃɹu pɝpəs ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ sɝv naʊ wɑz tə dʒɹɔ ɹəkɹuts ɪndə bɹaɪnz ɑɹmi, mɛn u θɔt tu ɑɹmiz mɛn ə bæɾəl ən wɑntəd tə bi ɑn ðə saɪd wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst nʌmbɝz. ʃi hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðɛm, bʌt tælmɑnz hæɾ æktəɾ əz ə fɹɛnd. ən ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. səmtaɪmz fɹɛndʃɪp ən ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi pʊʃt ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən.

Talmanes waved her off and pulled his cloak back around him, but Egwene took a silver cup to gain a moment for thought. Truly there was little need for the Band any longer. Despite all the muttering, the sisters took their presence as a matter of course now, Dragon-sworn or not; they no longer feared an attack, and there had been no real need to use the Band's presence to prod them into moving since leaving Salidar. The only true purpose Shen an Calhar served now was to draw recruits into Bryne's army, men who thought two armies meant a battle and wanted to be on the side with the greatest numbers. She had no need of them, but Talmanes had acted as a friend. And she was Amyrlin. Sometimes friendship and responsibility pushed in the same direction.

əz ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən muvd ɔf, ɛɡwin leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn tælmɑnz' ɑɹm. "ju mʌs nɑt də ðæt. ivən ðə bæn kæn kɑŋkɝ ɔl ə mʊɹændi baɪ ɪtsɛlf, ən ɛvɹi hænd wɪl bi əɡɛns ju. jə noʊ vɛɹi wɛl ðə wʌn θɪŋ ðət meɪks mʊɹændiənz stæn təɡɛðɝ ɪz fɔɹənɝz ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɪl. fɑloʊ əs tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, tælmɑnz. mæt wɪl kʌm ðɛɹ; aɪ hæv noʊ daʊɾ ə ðæt." mæt wəd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn əntɪl i sɔ hɝ wɛɹɪŋ ðə stoʊl ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

As the serving woman moved off, Egwene laid a hand on Talmanes' arm. "You must not do that. Even the Band can't conquer all of Murandy by itself, and every hand will be against you. You know very well the one thing that makes Murandians stand together is foreigners on their soil. Follow us to Tar Valon, Talmanes. Mat will come there; I have no doubt of that." Mat would not really believe she was the Amyrlin until he saw her wearing the stole in the White Tower.

"ɹɔdʒɹən ɪz noʊ ful," hi sɛd plɑtʃədli. "ɔl i wɑns əs tə də ɪz sɪɾ ən weɪt, ə fɔɹən ɑɹmi - wɪθaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ - ən noʊbɑdi noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɪts ʌp tə. hi ʃəd nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl junaɪɾɪŋ ðə noʊbəlz əɡɛnst ʌs. ðɛn, soʊ hi sɛz, wi kwaɪətli slɪp əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ. hi θɪŋks i kən hoʊld ɑn tə ðɛm æftɝwɝd."

"Roedran is no fool," he said placidly. "All he wants us to do is sit and wait, a foreign army - without Aes Sedai - and nobody knowing what it is up to. He should not have much trouble uniting the nobles against us. Then, so he says, we quietly slip across the border. He thinks he can hold on to them afterward."

ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ə tʌtʃ ə hiɾ ɛntɝɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. "ænd wʌɾ ɪz tə stɑp ɪm bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ ju? ɪf ðə θɹɛt ɡoʊz əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪt, hɪz dʒɹim ʌv ə junaɪɾəd mʊɹændi maɪt, tu." ðə ful mæn simd əmjuzd!

She could not stop a touch of heat entering her voice. "And what is to stop him betraying you? If the threat goes away without a fight, his dream of a united Murandy might, too." The fool man seemed amused!

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə ful iðɝ. ɹɔdʒɹən kænɑt bi ɹɛɾi bɪfɔɹ spɹɪŋ. ðɪs lɑt wəd nɛvɝ əv stɝd fɹəm ðɛɹ mænɝz ɪf ði ændɔɹənz hæd nɑt kʌm saʊθ, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ bɪfɔɹ ðə snoʊz bɪɡæn. bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, mæt wɪl faɪn ʌs. ɪf hiz kʌmɪŋ nɔɹθ, hi mʌs hɪɹ ʌv ʌs. ɹɔdʒɹən wɪl əv tə bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð wʌtɛvɝ hiz mænədʒ baɪ ðɛn. soʊ ɪf mæt dʌz ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, aɪ meɪ si jə ðəɹ jɛt."

"I am not a fool either. Roedran cannot be ready before spring. This lot would never have stirred from their manors if the Andorans had not come south, and they were on the march before the snows began. Before then, Mat will find us. If he is coming north, he must hear of us. Roedran will have to be satisfied with whatever he has managed by then. So if Mat does intend to go to Tar Valon, I may see you there yet."

ɛɡwin meɪɾ ə vɛkst saʊnd. ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl plæn, ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ sɪuən maɪt dɪvaɪz, ən hɑɹdli ə skim ʃi θɔt ɹɔdʒɹən ælmɹɪk də ɹəloʊə ænælɔɪ kəd kæɹi ɔf. ðə fɛloʊ wɑz sɛd tə bi soʊ dɪsəluɾ i meɪd mæt lʊk hoʊlsəm. bʌt ðɛn, ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ə skim ʃi wʊɾə bɪlivd ɹɔdʒɹən kəd θɪŋk ʌp. ði oʊnli sɝɾənti wɑz ðət tælmɑnz hæd meɪɾ ʌp ɪz maɪnd.

Egwene made a vexed sound. It was a remarkable plan, the sort of thing Siuan might devise, and hardly a scheme she thought Roedran Almaric do Arreloa a'Naloy could carry off. The fellow was said to be so dissolute he made Mat look wholesome. But then, it was hardly a scheme she would have believed Roedran could think up. The only certainty was that Talmanes had made up his mind.

"aɪ wɑn jəɹ wɝd, tælmɑnz, ðət jə woʊn lɛt ɹɔdʒɹən pʊl jə ɪndə ə wɔɹ." ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ðə nɛɹoʊ stoʊl ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk sim tə weɪ tɛn taɪmz mɔɹ ðən əɹ kloʊk. "ɪf i muvz sunɝ ðən jə θɪŋk, jəl liv wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt mæt əz dʒɔɪn ju."

"I want your word, Talmanes, that you won't let Roedran pull you into a war." Responsibility. The narrow stole around her neck seemed to weigh ten times more than her cloak. "If he moves sooner than you think, you will leave whether or not Mat has joined you."

"aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd pɹɑməs, bʌɾ ɪts nɑt pɑsəbəl," hi pɹətɛstəd. "aɪ ɪkspɛk ðə fɝst ɹeɪɾ əɡɛns maɪ fɔɹədʒɝz θɹi deɪz ət moʊst æftɝ aɪ stɑɹt muvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm lɔɹd bɹaɪnz ɑɹmi. ɛvɹi lɔɹɾəlɪŋ ən fɑɹmɝ wɪl θɪŋk i kən pɪk ʌp ə fju hɔɹsəz ɪn ðə naɪt, ɡɪmi ə pɪnpɹɪk, ən ɹʌn ɔf tə haɪd."

"I wish I could promise, but it is not possible," he protested. "I expect the first raid against my foragers three days at most after I start moving away from Lord Bryne's army. Every lordling and farmer will think he can pick up a few horses in the night, give me a pinprick, and run off to hide."

"aɪm nɑt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt dɪfɛndɪŋ jɝsɛlf, ən jə noʊ ɪt," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "jɔɹ wɝd, tælmɑnz. əɹ əl nɑɾ əlaʊ jəɹ əɡɹimənt wɪð ɹɔdʒɹən." ði oʊnli weɪ tə stɑp ɪt wɑz tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ɪt, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt liv ə wɔɹ ɪn əɹ weɪk, ə wɔɹ ʃi hæd stɑɹɾəd baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ tælmɑnz hɪɹ.

"I'm not talking about defending yourself, and you know it," she said firmly. "Your word, Talmanes. Or I will not allow your agreement with Roedran." The only way to stop it was to betray it, but she would not leave a war in her wake, a war she had started by bringing Talmanes here.

stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ əz ɪf fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi faɪnəli bɛn ɪz hɛd. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðət simd mɔɹ fɔɹməl ðən ɪz baʊ hæd. "ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ, mʌðɝ. tɛl mi, ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ nɑt tɑvɝən, tu?"

Staring at her as if for the first time, he finally bent his head. Strangely, that seemed more formal than his bow had. "It will be as you say, Mother. Tell me, are you sure you are not ta'veren, too?"

"aɪ æm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "ðæɾ ɪz kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn." ʃi tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm əɡɛn. "ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju, tælmɑnz." hɪz smaɪl nɪɹli tʌtʃt ɪz aɪz ðɪs taɪm.

"I am the Amyrlin Seat," she replied. "That is quite enough for anyone." She touched his arm again. "The Light shine on you, Talmanes." His smile nearly touched his eyes this time.

ɪnɛvəɾəbli, dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ wɪspɝz, ðɛɹ tɔk hæd bɪn noʊɾəst. meɪbi kəz ə ðɛɹ wɪspɝz. ðə ɡɝl u kleɪm tə bi æmɪɝlɪn, ə ɹɛbəl əɡɛns ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ðə liɾɝ ə tɛn θaʊzən dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn. hæd ʃi meɪd tælmɑnz' skim wɪð ɹɔdʒɹən hɑɹɾɝ, əɹ iziɝ? wɑz wɔɹ ɪn mʊɹændi lɛs laɪkli, əɹ mɔɹ? sɪuən ən əɹ blʌɾi lɔ ʌv ʌnɪntɛndɪd kɑnsəkwɛnsəz! fɪfti ɡeɪzəz fɑloʊd hɝ, ðən dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ, əz ʃi muv θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn əɹ kʌp. wɛl, moʊs dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ. ðə sɪɾɝz' feɪsəz wɝ ɔl eɪdʒləs ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi, bʌt ləleɪn maɪɾ əv bɪn ə bɹaʊn-aɪd kɹoʊ wɑtʃɪŋ ə fɪʃ stʃɹʌɡəl ɪn ðə ʃæloʊz, waɪl ɹoʊmændəz slaɪtli dɑɹkɝ aɪz cʊɾə dʒɹɪl hoʊlz θɹu aɪɝn.

Inevitably, despite their whispers, their talk had been noticed. Maybe because of their whispers. The girl who claimed to be Amyrlin, a rebel against the White Tower, in conversation with the leader of ten thousand Dragonsworn. Had she made Talmanes' scheme with Roedran harder, or easier? Was war in Murandy less likely, or more? Siuan and her bloody Law of Unintended Consequences! Fifty gazes followed her, then darted away, as she moved through the crowd warming her fingers on her cup. Well, most darted away. The Sitters' faces were all ageless Aes Sedai serenity, but Lelaine might have been a brown-eyed crow watching a fish struggle in the shallows, while Romanda's slightly darker eyes could have drilled holes through iron.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ə wɑtʃ ɑn ðə sʌn aʊtsaɪd, ʃi meɪɾ ə sloʊ sɝkət θɹu ðə pəvɪljən. ðə noʊbəlz wɝ stɪl ɪmpɹtunɪŋ sɪɾɝz, bʌt ðeɪ muv fɹəm wʌn tə ənʌðɝ əz ɪf sikɪŋ bɛɾɝ ænsɝz, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə noʊɾəs smɔl θɪŋz. dɑnəl pɔzd ɑn ɪz weɪ fɹəm dʒɑnjə tə mɔɹiə, boʊɪŋ loʊ tə æɛmlɪn, hu æknɑlɪdʒd ɪm wɪð ə ɡɹeɪʃəs nɑd. ʃin, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm tɑkimə, kɝtsid dipli tə pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɹəsivd ə slaɪt baʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz, ɔlweɪz ə mʊɹændiən dɪfɝɪŋ tə ən ændɔɝən u ɹɪspɑndɪd dʒʌst əz fɔɹməli. ði ændɔɹənz tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ bɹaɪn ɪksɛp fəɹ ði ɑd skaʊl, bʌɾ ɛni nʌmbɝ ə mʊɹændiənz sɔɾ ɪm aʊt, wʌn baɪ wʌn ən wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ən fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃənz ðɛɹ aɪz wɛnt, ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌsɪŋ pɛlɪvɑɹ, əɹ ɑɝəθɛl, əɹ æɛmlɪn. pɝhæps tælmɑnz hæd bɪn ɹaɪt.

Trying to keep a watch on the sun outside, she made a slow circuit through the pavilion. The nobles were still importuning Sitters, but they moved from one to another as if seeking better answers, and she began to notice small things. Donel paused on his way from Janya to Moria, bowing low to Aemlyn, who acknowledged him with a gracious nod. Cian, turning away from Takima, curtsied deeply to Pelivar and received a slight bow in return. There were others, always a Murandian deferring to an Andoran who responded just as formally. The Andorans tried to ignore Bryne except for the odd scowl, but any number of Murandians sought him out, one by one and well away from everyone else, and from the directions their eyes went, it was plain they were discussing Pelivar, or Arathelle, or Aemlyn. Perhaps Talmanes had been right.

ʃi ɹəsiv baʊz ən kɝtsiz, tu, ðoʊ nʌn soʊ dip əz ðoʊz ɡɪvən ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ ən æɛmlɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə sɪɾɝz. hæf ə dʌzən wɪmən toʊld əɹ haʊ θæŋkfəl ðeɪ wɝ ðət mæɾɝz hæd bɪn ɹizɑlv pisfəli, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni meɪd nɑnkəmɪɾəl nɔɪzɪz əɹ ʃɹʌɡd ənizəli wən ʃi ɪkspɹɛs ðə seɪm sɛntəmənt, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ ənsɝɾən ɪɾ ɔl wəɾ ɛn pisfəli. hɝ əʃʊɹənsɪz ðəɾ ɪt wəd wɝ mɛt wɪð ə fɝvənt "ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt soʊ!" əɹ ə ɹɪzaɪnd "ɪf ðə laɪt wɪlz." fɔɹ kɔld əɹ mʌðɝ, wʌn wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ fɝst. θɹi ʌðɝz sɛd ðət ʃi wɑz kwaɪt lʌvli, ðət ʃi hæd bjuɾəfəl aɪz, ən ðət ʃi hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪsfəl kæɹɪdʒ, ɪn ðəɾ ɔɹɾɝ; suɾəbəl kɑmpləməns pɝhæps fəɹ ɛɡwinz eɪdʒ bʌt nɑɾ əɹ steɪʃən.

She received bows and curtsies, too, though none so deep as those given Arathelle and Pelivar and Aemlyn, much less the Sitters. Half a dozen women told her how thankful they were that matters had been resolved peacefully, though in truth, almost as many made noncommittal noises or shrugged uneasily when she expressed the same sentiment, as though they were uncertain it all would end peacefully. Her assurances that it would were met with a fervent "The Light send it so!" or a resigned "If the Light wills." Four called her Mother, one without hesitating first. Three others said that she was quite lovely, that she had beautiful eyes, and that she had a graceful carriage, in that order; suitable compliments perhaps for Egwene's age but not her station.

ət list ʃi faʊnd wʌn ənælɔɪd plɛʒɝ. sɛɡən wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn ɪn biɪŋ ɪntʃɹiɡd baɪ hɝ ənaʊnsmən kənsɝnɪŋ ðə nɑvəs bʊk. pleɪnli ðət wɑz waɪ moʊst ə ðə wɪmən spoʊk tə hɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. æftɝ ɔl, ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz maɪt bi ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə taʊɝ, bʌt ʃi kleɪm tə bi ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðɛɹ ɪntʃɹəs hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ tə oʊvɝkʌm ðæt, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə lɛɾ ɪt ʃoʊ. ɑɝəθɛl meɪd ði ɪnkwaɪɹi wɪð ə fɹaʊn ðət pʊt mɔɹ kɹisɪz ɪn əɹ tʃiks. æɛmlɪn ʃʊk əɹ ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɾ ət ði ænsɝ. blɑki ʃin æskt, fɑloʊd baɪ ə ʃɑɹp-feɪst ændɔɝən leɪɾi neɪm nɛɡɑɹə, ðən ə pɹɪɾi, bɪɡ-aɪd mʊɹændiən kɔl dʒɛnət, ən ʌðɝz. nʌn wɑntəd tə noʊ fəɹ hɝsɛlf - sɛvɹəl meɪd ðət klɪɹ kwɪkli, ɪspɛʃli ðə jʌŋɡɝ wɪmən - bʌt bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl noʊbəlwʊmən ðəɹ hæɾ æskt, ən sɛvɹəl sɝvəns əz wɛl, ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ʌv ɔfɝɪŋ mɔɹ spaɪst waɪn. wʌn, ə wɪɹi wʊmən neɪm nɪlʒɹə, hæd kʌm fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp.

At least she found one unalloyed pleasure. Segan was not alone in being intrigued by her announcement concerning the novice book. Plainly that was why most of the women spoke to her in the first place. After all, the other sisters might be in rebellion against the Tower, but she claimed to be the Amyrlin Seat. Their interest had to be strong to overcome that, though no one wanted to let it show. Arathelle made the inquiry with a frown that put more creases in her cheeks. Aemlyn shook her graying head at the answer. Blocky Cian asked, followed by a sharp-faced Andoran lady named Negara, then a pretty, big-eyed Murandian called Jennet, and others. None wanted to know for herself - several made that clear quickly, especially the younger women - but before long, every single noblewoman there had asked, and several servants as well, under cover of offering more spiced wine. One, a wiry woman named Nildra, had come from the Aes Sedai camp.

ɛɡwin fɛl kwaɪt plizd wɪð ðə sid ʃi hæd plæntəd ðɛɹ. ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ plizd wɪð ðə mɛn. ə fju spoʊk tə hɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli wən ðeɪ keɪm feɪs-tə-feɪs ən sim tə hæv noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. ə mɝmɝd wɝɾ əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ, iðɝ pɹeɪzɪŋ ði ɛn ə ðə dʒɹaʊɾ əɹ dɪplɔɹɪŋ ðə sʌɾən snoʊz, ə mʌɾɝd hoʊp ðət ðə bændət pɹɑbləm wəɾ ɛn sun, pɝhæps wɪð ə səɡnɪfɪkən lʊk təwɔɹd tælmɑnz, ən ðeɪ slɪpt əweɪ laɪk ɡɹis pɪɡz. ə bɛɹ ʌv ən ændɔɝən baɪ ðə neɪm ə mækɝən tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn buts tə əvɔɪd hɝ. ɪn ə weɪ, ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ. ðə wɪmən hæd ðə dʒʌstəfəkeɪʃən, ɪf oʊnli tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ʌv ðə nɑvəs bʊk, bʌt ðə mɛn hæɾ oʊnli ðə θɔt ðət biɪŋ sin kənvɝsɪŋ wɪð əɹ maɪt tɑɹ əm wɪð ðə seɪm bɹʌʃ.

Egwene felt quite pleased with the seed she had planted there. She was not so pleased with the men. A few spoke to her, but only when they came face-to-face and seemed to have no other choice. A murmured word about the weather, either praising the end of the drought or deploring the sudden snows, a muttered hope that the bandit problem would end soon, perhaps with a significant look toward Talmanes, and they slipped away like greased pigs. A bear of an Andoran by the name of Macharan tripped over his own boots to avoid her. In a way, it was hardly surprising. The women had the justification, if only to themselves, of the novice book, but the men had only the thought that being seen conversing with her might tar them with the same brush.

ɪt wɑz ɹɪli kwaɪt dɪskɝədʒɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌt ðə mɛn θɔɾ əbaʊt nɑvəsɪz, bʌt ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑntəd tə noʊ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əz fɪɹfəl əz ðə wɪmən ðət ðɪs wəd kʌm tə bloʊz ɪn ði ɛnd. fɪɹz laɪk ðət kəd fʊlfɪl ðɛmsɛlvz vɛɹi izəli. ət læst, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə faɪn aʊt.

It was really quite discouraging. She did not care what the men thought about novices, but she very much wanted to know if they were as fearful as the women that this would come to blows in the end. Fears like that could fulfill themselves very easily. At last, she decided there was only one way to find out.

pɛlɪvɑɹ tɝn fɹəm teɪkɪŋ ə fɹɛʃ kʌp ʌv waɪn fɹəm ə tʃɹeɪ ən stɑɹɾəd bæk, wɪð ə mʌfəld oʊθ, tə kip fɹəm bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə hɝ; hæd ʃi stʊɾ ɛni kloʊsɝ, ʃi wʊɾə hæd tə stæn ɑn ɪz buts. hɑt waɪn splæʃt oʊvɝ ɪz ɡlʌv hæn ən ɹæn daʊn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊtsliv, pɹədusɪŋ ə kɝs nɑt soʊ mjuɾɪd. tɔl ɪnʌf tə lum oʊvɝ hɝ, hi meɪɾ ə ɡʊd dʒɑb ʌv ɪt. hɪz skaʊl bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə mæn wɑntɪŋ tə sɛn ən ənɔɪɪŋ jʌŋ wʊmən bɹɪskli aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ. əɹ ɑn ə mæn u hæd nɪɹli stɛpt ɑn ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ. ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf ɪɹɛkt ən foʊkəst ɑn ən ɪmədʒ ə hɪm əz ə smɔl bɔɪ ʌp tə noʊ ɡʊd; ðəɾ ɔlweɪz hɛlpt; moʊs mɛn sim tə fil ɪt. hi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ - ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə pəlaɪt ɡɹiɾɪŋ, əɹ ənʌðɝ oʊθ - ən dɪpt ɪz hɛd slaɪtli, ðən tʃɹaɪd tə stɛp ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi saɪd-stɛp tə steɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. hi muv bæk, ən ʃi fɑloʊd. hi bɪɡæn tə lʊk hʌntəd. ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ pʊɾɪŋ ɪm əɾ iz bɪfɔɹ pɹɛsɪŋ ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt kwɛstʃən. ʃi wɑntəɾ ænsɝz, nɑt mɔɹ mʌmbəlɪŋ.

Pelivar turned from taking a fresh cup of wine from a tray and started back, with a muffled oath, to keep from bumping into her; had she stood any closer, she would have had to stand on his boots. Hot wine splashed over his gloved hand and ran down under his coatsleeve, producing a curse not so muted. Tall enough to loom over her, he made a good job of it. His scowl belonged on a man wanting to send an annoying young woman briskly out of his way. Or on a man who had nearly stepped on a red adder. She held herself erect and focused on an image of him as a small boy up to no good; that always helped; most men seemed to feel it. He muttered something - it might have been a polite greeting, or another oath - and dipped his head slightly, then tried to step around her. She side-stepped to stay in front of him. He moved back, and she followed. He began to look hunted. She decided to try putting him at ease before pressing the important question. She wanted answers, not more mumbling.

"ju mʌs bi pliz tə hɪɹ ðət ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɪz ɑn əɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn, lɔɹd pɛlɪvɑɹ." ʃi hæd hɝd sɛvɹəl ə ðə sɪɾɝz mɛnʃən ðæt.

"You must be pleased to hear that the Daughter-Heir is on her way to Caemlyn, Lord Pelivar." She had heard several of the Sitters mention that.

hɪz feɪs wɛn blæŋk. "ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən əz ə ɹaɪt tə pʊɾ ɪn əɹ kleɪm tə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn," hi ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs.

His face went blank. "Elayne Trakand has a right to put in her claim to the Lion Throne," he replied in a flat voice.

ɛɡwinz aɪz waɪɾənd, ən i stɛp bæk əɡɛn, ənsɝteɪnli. pɝhæps i θɔɾ əɹ æŋɡɹi oʊvɝ ði æbsəns ə hɝ taɪɾəl, bʌt ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðæt. pɛlɪvɑɹ hæd səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ ɪn əɹ kleɪm fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn, ən ɪleɪn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i wəd səpɔɹt hɝ, tu. ʃi spoʊk ə pɛlɪvɑɹ fɑnli, laɪk ə feɪvɹɪɾ ʌŋkəl.

Egwene's eyes widened, and he stepped back again, uncertainly. Perhaps he thought her angry over the absence of her title, but she barely noticed that. Pelivar had supported Elayne's mother in her claim for the throne, and Elayne had been sure he would support her, too. She spoke of Pelivar fondly, like a favorite uncle.

"mʌðɝ," sɪuən mɝmɝɾ əɾ əɹ ɛlboʊ, "wi mʌs liv ɪf jə wɑnə bi ʃʊɹ ə ɹitʃɪŋ ðə kæmp bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt." ʃi mænədʒ tə pʊt kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɝdʒənsi ɪndə ðoʊz kwaɪət wɝdz. ðə sʌn hæd pæst ɪts pik.

"Mother," Siuan murmured at her elbow, "we must leave if you want to be sure of reaching the camp before sunset." She managed to put considerable urgency into those quiet words. The sun had passed its peak.

"ðɪs ɪz noʊ wɛðɝ tə bi ɪn ði oʊpən ət naɪtfɔl," pɛlɪvɑɹ sɛd hɝidli. "ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, aɪ mʌs meɪk ɹɛɾi tə liv." ʃʌvɪŋ ɪz kʌp ɑntu ðə tʃɹeɪ ʌv ə pæsɪŋ sɝvənt, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ hæfweɪ meɪkɪŋ ə lɛɡ, ən stɔkt ɔf wɪð ði ɛɹ ʌv ə mæn u hæd ɹɪəl fɹi ʌv ə tʃɹæp.

"This is no weather to be in the open at nightfall," Pelivar said hurriedly. "If you will excuse me, I must make ready to leave." Shoving his cup onto the tray of a passing servant, he hesitated before halfway making a leg, and stalked off with the air of a man who had wriggled free of a trap.

ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ wɪð fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. wʌd ðə mɛn θɪŋk ə ðɛɹ əɡɹimənt? ɪf ɪt kəd bi kɔl ðæt, ðə weɪ ʃi hæd fɔɹst ɪɾ ɑn ðɛm. ɑɝəθɛl ən æɛmlɪn hæd mɔɹ paʊɝ ən ɪnfluəns ðən moʊst ə ðə mɛn, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz pɛlɪvɑɹ ən kʌlhən ən ðə laɪk u ɹoʊd wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz; ðeɪ kəd stɪl meɪk ðɪs flɛɹ ʌp ɪn əɹ feɪs laɪk ə bæɹəl ə læmp ɔɪl.

Egwene wanted to grind her teeth with frustration. What did the men think of their agreement? If it could be called that, the way she had forced it on them. Arathelle and Aemlyn had more power and influence than most of the men, yet it was Pelivar and Culhan and the like who rode with the soldiers; they could still make this flare up in her face like a barrel of lamp oil.

"faɪnd ʃɛɹiəm," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, "æn tɛl əɹ tə ɡɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn maʊntəd naʊ, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪt teɪks!" ʃi kəd nɑt ɡɪv ðə sɪɾɝz ə naɪt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt hæd hæpən tədeɪ, tə plæn ən plɑt. ðeɪ hæd tə bi bæk ɪn kæmp bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌn wɛn daʊn.

"Find Sheriam," she growled, "and tell her to get everyone mounted now, no matter what it takes!" She could not give the Sitters a night to think about what had happened today, to plan and plot. They had to be back in camp before the sun went down.


tʃæptɝ naɪntin


CHAPTER 19

ðə lɔ


The Law

ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz tə ðɛɹ maʊns pɹuv noʊ bɑðɝ; ðeɪ wɝ əz iɡɝ tə bi əweɪ əz ɛɡwin, ɪspɛʃli ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn, boʊθ koʊld əz ðə wɪn ən wɪð aɪz laɪk θʌndɝklaʊdz. ðə ɹɛst wɝ ðə vɛɹi ɪmədʒ ə kul-aɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi, ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf kəmpoʊʒɝ laɪk ə hɛvi sɛnt, jɛt ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd tə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz soʊ kwɪkli ðət ðə noʊbəlz wɝ lɛft ɡeɪpɪŋ ən ðə bɹaɪtli klæd sɝvəns skɹæmbəld ɪn loʊɾɪŋ ðə pækhɔɹsɪz tə kætʃ ʌp əz bɛs ðeɪ kʊd.

Getting the Sitters to their mounts proved no bother; they were as eager to be away as Egwene, especially Romanda and Lelaine, both cold as the wind and with eyes like thunderclouds. The rest were the very image of cool-eyed Aes Sedai serenity, giving off composure like a heavy scent, yet they glided to their horses so quickly that the nobles were left gaping and the brightly clad servants scrambled in loading the packhorses to catch up as best they could.

ɛɡwin hæd deɪʃɝ sɛɾ ə hɑɹd peɪs ɪn ðə snoʊ, ən wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə lʊk ən ə nɑd fɹəm əɹ lɔɹd bɹaɪn meɪd ʃʊɹ ði ɑɹmɝɾ ɛskɔɹts muvd əz fæst. sɪuən ɑn bɛlə ən ʃɛɹiəm ɑn wɪŋ ɹʌʃt tə dʒɔɪn hɝ. fəɹ lɔŋ stʃɹɛtʃəz ðeɪ tʃɝn θɹu fɛtlɑk-dip kʌvɝ, ðə hɔɹsəz stɛpɪŋ haɪ ət nɪɹ tə ə tʃɹɑt, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ði aɪsi bɹiz, ən ivən wən ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə sloʊ, wən ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ sɪŋkɪŋ ni-dip θɹu ðə snoʊ kɹʌst, ðeɪ kɛp tə ə fæst wɔk.

Egwene had Daishar set a hard pace in the snow, and with no more than a look and a nod from her Lord Bryne made sure the armored escorts moved as fast. Siuan on Bela and Sheriam on Wing rushed to join her. For long stretches they churned through fetlock-deep cover, the horses stepping high at near to a trot, the Flame of Tar Valon rippling in the icy breeze, and even when it was necessary to slow, when the horses were sinking knee-deep through the snow crust, they kept to a fast walk.

ðə sɪɾɝz hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs ɪksɛp tə kip ʌp, ən ðɛɹ spid kʌt daʊn ðɛɹ ɑpɝtunəɾi tə tɔk ɑn ðə weɪ. ət ðət taɪɹɪŋ peɪs, ə læk ʌv ətɛnʃən tə jəɹ hɔɹs kəd bɹɪŋ ə bɹoʊkən lɛɡ fəɹ ði ænəməl ən ə bɹoʊkən nɛk fəɹ ju. ivən soʊ, ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn itʃ mænədʒ tə ɡæðɝ əɹ koʊɾɝi ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ðoʊz tu nɑts flaʊndɝd θɹu ðə snoʊ sɝaʊndəd baɪ wɔɹdz əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. ðə pɛɹ sim tə bi dɪlɪvɝɪŋ taɪɹeɪdz. ɛɡwin kəɾ ɪmædʒən ðə tɑpɪk. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz mænədʒ tə ɹaɪd təɡɛðɝ fəɹ ə taɪm, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ə fju wɝdz kwaɪətli ən kæstɪŋ kul ɡlænsɪz səmtaɪmz əɾ əɹ ən səmtaɪmz ət ðə sɪstɝz ɹæpt ɝaʊn baɪ seɪaɪdɑɹ. oʊnli dɛlænə nɛvɝ dʒɔɪnd wʌn ə ðoʊz bɹif kɑnvɝseɪʃənz. ʃi steɪd kloʊs bɪsaɪd hɑlimə, hu ət læst ədmɪɾəd ðət ʃi wɑz koʊld. feɪs taɪt, ðə kʌntʃɹi wʊmən hɛld əɹ kloʊk kloʊs ɝaʊn hɝ, bʌt ʃi stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə kʌmfɝt dɛlænə, wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɝ ɔlmoʊs kɑnstənli. dɛlænə sim tə nid kʌmfɝɾɪŋ; hɝ bɹaʊz wɝ dʒɹɔn daʊn, pʊɾɪŋ ə kɹis ɪn əɹ fɔɹhɛd ðəɾ æktʃəli  meɪɾ əɹ sim eɪdʒɪd.

The Sitters had no choice except to keep up, and their speed cut down their opportunity to talk on the way. At that tiring pace, a lack of attention to your horse could bring a broken leg for the animal and a broken neck for you. Even so, Romanda and Lelaine each managed to gather her coterie around her, and those two knots floundered through the snow surrounded by wards against eavesdropping. The pair seemed to be delivering tirades. Egwene could imagine the topic. For that matter, other Sitters managed to ride together for a time, exchanging a few words quietly and casting cool glances sometimes at her and sometimes at the sisters wrapped around by saidar. Only Delana never joined one of those brief conversations. She stayed close beside Halima, who at last admitted that she was cold. Face tight, the country woman held her cloak close around her, but she still tried to comfort Delana, whispering to her almost constantly. Delana seemed to need comforting; her brows were drawn down, putting a crease in her forehead that actually made her seem aged.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn wɝid. ði ʌðɝz mæsk ðə filɪŋ ɹɪdʒɪdli, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ æbsəlut pɔɪz, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹoʊd laɪk mɛn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðə wɝs tə lip aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ ət ðə nɛkst stɛp, aɪz ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn ən ənsisɪŋ wɑtʃ, dɪskwaɪəɾɪŋ kloʊks stʃɹimɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn tə liv hænz fɹi. wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝid, hɝ wɔɹɾɝ wɝid, ən ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ tu əbzɔɹb tə θɪŋk ə kɑmɪŋ ðə mɛn. ɛɡwin wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæd tə si ɪt. ɪf ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ tʃɹʌbəld, ðeɪ hæd nɑt jɛt meɪɾ ʌp ðɛɹ maɪnz.

She was not the only one worried. The others masked the feeling rigidly, radiating absolute poise, but the Warders rode like men expecting the worst to leap out of the snow at the next step, eyes shifting in an unceasing watch, disquieting cloaks streaming in the wind to leave hands free. When an Aes Sedai worried, her Warder worried, and the Sitters were too absorbed to think of calming the men. Egwene was just as glad to see it. If the Sitters were troubled, they had not yet made up their minds.

wən bɹaɪn ɹoʊɾ aʊt tə kənfɝ wɪð ənoʊ, ʃi tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə æsk wʌt ðə tu wɪmən hæd lɝn əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz ɪn ændɝ.

When Bryne rode out to confer with Uno, she took the opportunity to ask what the two women had learned about Aes Sedai and Tower Guards in Andor.

"nɑt mʌtʃ," sɪuən ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. ʃæɡi bɛlə dɪd nɑt sim tə bi hævɪŋ ɛni dɪfəkəlti wɪð ðə peɪs, bʌt sɪuən dɪd, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz taɪtli ɪn wʌn hæn ən ðə pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl wɪð ði ʌðɝ. "æz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən meɪk aʊt, ðəɹ ɑɹ fɪfti ɹumɝz ən noʊ fæks. ɪts ə laɪkli sɔɹɾ ə teɪl tə spɹɪŋ ʌp, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt stɪl bi tʃɹu." bɛlə lɝtʃt, hɝ fɹʌn hʊvz sɪŋkɪŋ dip, ən sɪuən ɡæspt. "ðə laɪt bɝn ɔl hɔɹsəz!"

"Not much," Siuan replied in a tight voice. Shaggy Bela did not seem to be having any difficulty with the pace, but Siuan did, gripping her reins tightly in one hand and the pommel of her saddle with the other. "As near as I can make out, there are fifty rumors and no facts. It's a likely sort of tale to spring up, but it might still be true." Bela lurched, her front hooves sinking deep, and Siuan gasped. "The Light burn all horses!"

ʃɛɹiəm hæd lɝnd noʊ mɔɹ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən saɪɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "ɪt saʊnz ɔl fɛðɝz ən nɑnsɛns tə mi, mʌðɝ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ɹumɝz ə sɪstɝz snikɪŋ əbaʊt. dɪdn jə ɛvɝ lɝn tə ɹaɪd, sɪuən?" ʃi æɾəd, hɝ vɔɪs sʌɾənli dʒɹɪpɪŋ dɝɪʒən. "baɪ tənaɪt, jəl bi tu sɔɹ tə wɔk!" ʃɛɹiəmz nɝvz mʌst əv bɪn ɹæɡəd fəɹ əɹ tə bɝst aʊt soʊ oʊpənli. fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi kɛpt ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ətʃivd əɹ pɹidɪkʃən fəɹ sɪuən.

Sheriam had learned no more. She shook her head, and sighed irritably. "It sounds all feathers and nonsense to me, Mother. There are always rumors of sisters sneaking about. Didn't you ever learn to ride, Siuan?" she added, her voice suddenly dripping derision. "By tonight, you'll be too sore to walk!" Sheriam's nerves must have been ragged for her to burst out so openly. From the way she kept shifting in her saddle, she had already achieved her prediction for Siuan.

sɪuənz aɪz hɑɹɾənd, ən ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ɔlɹɛɾi hæf snɑɹlɪŋ, nɛvɝ maɪn u wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə bænɝ.

Siuan's eyes hardened, and she opened her mouth already half snarling, never mind who was watching from behind the banner.

"bi stɪl, boʊθ ə ju!" ɛɡwin snæpt. ʃi tʊk ə dip, kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ. ʃi wɑz ə bɪt ɹæɡəd hɝsɛlf. wʌtɛvɝ ɑɝəθɛl bɪlivd, ɛni fɔɹs ɪleɪɾə sɛn tə ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð əm wəd bi tu lɑɹdʒ fəɹ snikɪŋ. ðət lɛf ðə blæk taʊɝ, ə dɪzæstɝ ɪn ðə meɪkɪŋ. jə ɡɑt fɝðɝ plʌkɪŋ ðə tʃɪkən ɪn fɹʌn ə jə ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑɹɾ ɑn wʌn ʌp ə tʃɹi. ɪspɛʃli wən ðə tʃɹi wɑz ɪn ənʌðɝ kʌntʃɹi ən ðəɹ maɪt nɑɾ ivən bi ənʌðɝ tʃɪkən.

"Be still, both of you!" Egwene snapped. She took a deep, calming breath. She was a bit ragged herself. Whatever Arathelle believed, any force Elaida sent to interfere with them would be too large for sneaking. That left the Black Tower, a disaster in the making. You got further plucking the chicken in front of you than trying to start on one up a tree. Especially when the tree was in another country and there might not even be another chicken.

stɪl, ʃi bɪɾ ɔf əɹ wɝdz ɪn ɡɪvɪŋ ʃɛɹiəm ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə kæmp. ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ðət mɛn ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ əɹ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, ivən ðoʊz fɑloʊɪŋ ɪleɪɾə. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ɹɑk stɛɾi, ðoʊ. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə bi fɹaɪɾənd wʌns jə ɡɹæb ðə wʊlf baɪ ði ɪɹz.

Still, she bit off her words in giving Sheriam instructions for once they reached the camp. She was the Amyrlin Seat, and that meant all Aes Sedai were her responsibility, even those following Elaida. Her voice was rock steady, though. It was too late to be frightened once you grabbed the wolf by the ears.

ʃɛɹiəmz tɪltəɾ aɪz wɛnt waɪɾ ət ði ɔɹɾɝz. "mʌðɝ, ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk, waɪ . . . ?" ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf ʌndɝ ɛɡwinz lɛvəl ɡeɪz, ən swɑloʊd. "ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "stʃɹeɪnʒ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə deɪ jə ən nɪneɪiv keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ, tu ɡɝlz u kʊdn dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə bi ɪksaɪɾəd əɹ fɹaɪɾənd. soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʃeɪnʒd sɪns ðɛn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Sheriam's tilted eyes went wide at the orders. "Mother, if I may ask, why . . . ?" She trailed off under Egwene's level gaze, and swallowed. "It will be as you say, Mother," she said slowly. "Strange. I remember the day you and Nynaeve came to the Tower, two girls who couldn't decide whether to be excited or frightened. So much has changed since then. Everything."

"nʌθɪŋ steɪz ðə seɪm fɝɛvɝ," ɛɡwin toʊl hɝ. ʃi ɡeɪv sɪuən ə səɡnɪfɪkən lʊk, bʌt sɪuən ɹəfjuz tə si. ʃi əpɪɹd tə bi sʌlkɪŋ. ʃɛɹiəm lʊk sɪk.

"Nothing stays the same forever," Egwene told her. She gave Siuan a significant look, but Siuan refused to see. She appeared to be sulking. Sheriam looked sick.

lɔɹd bɹaɪn ɹɪtɝn ðɛn, ən i mʌst əv sɛns ðə muɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm. əsaɪd fɹəm seɪɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ meɪkɪŋ ɡʊd taɪm, hi kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt. ə waɪz mæn.

Lord Bryne returned then, and he must have sensed the mood among them. Aside from saying that they were making good time, he kept his mouth shut. A wise man.

meɪkɪŋ ɡʊd taɪm əɹ nɑt, ðə sʌn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ɑn ðə tʃɹitɑps wən ðeɪ faɪnəli ɹoʊd θɹu ði ɑɹmiz spɹɔlɪŋ kæmp. wæɡənz ən tɛns kæs lɔŋ ʃædoʊz əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ, ən ə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn wɝ hɑɹɾ ət wɝk bɪldɪŋ jɛt mɔɹ loʊ ʃɛltɝz aʊɾ ə bɹʌʃ. ðəɹ wɝ nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf tɛns, ivən fəɹ ɔl ðə soʊlʒɝz, ən ðə kæmp hɛld ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni hɑɹnəsmeɪkɝz ən lɔnʒɹəsəz ən flɛtʃɝz ən ðə laɪk, ɔl ðoʊz u ɪnɛvəɾəbli fɑloʊɾ ɛni ɑɹmi. ðə ɹɪŋɪŋ ʌv ænvəlz spoʊk ə fɛɹiɝz ən ɑɹmɔɹɝz ən blæksmɪθs stɪl ət ðɛɹ leɪbɝz. kʊk faɪɝz wɝ bɝnɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ðə kævəlɹi pild əweɪ, iɡɝ fəɹ wɔɹmθ ən hɑt fuɾ əz sun əz ðɛɹ wɛɹəli plɑɾɪŋ ænəməlz wɝ kɛɹd fɔɹ. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, bɹaɪn ɹoʊɾ ɑn əɾ ɛɡwinz saɪɾ æftɝ ʃi dɪsmɪs hɪm.

Making good time or not, the sun was sitting almost on the treetops when they finally rode through the army's sprawling camp. Wagons and tents cast long shadows across the snow, and a number of men were hard at work building yet more low shelters out of brush. There were not nearly enough tents, even for all the soldiers, and the camp held almost as many harnessmakers and laundresses and fletchers and the like, all those who inevitably followed any army. The ringing of anvils spoke of farriers and armorers and blacksmiths still at their labors. Cook fires were burning everywhere, and the cavalry peeled away, eager for warmth and hot food as soon as their wearily plodding animals were cared for. Surprisingly, Bryne rode on at Egwene's side after she dismissed him.

"ɪf jəl əlaʊ, mʌðɝ," hi sɛd, "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪɾ əkʌmpəni jə ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ." ʃɛɹiəm æktʃəli  twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə stɛɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. sɪuən stɛɹd, tu, stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, əz ɪf nɑt dɛɹɪŋ tə tɝn əɹ sʌɾənli waɪɾ aɪz təwɔɹd hɪm.

"If you will allow, Mother," he said, "I thought I might accompany you a while longer." Sheriam actually twisted in her saddle to stare in astonishment. Siuan stared, too, straight ahead, as if not daring to turn her suddenly wide eyes toward him.

wʌɾ i θɪŋk i kəd du? ækt əz əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd? əɡɛnst sɪstɝz? ðət fɛloʊ wɪð ðə dʒɹɪpi noʊz wəd də əz wɛl. ɹɪvil dʒʌs haʊ kəmplitli hi wɑz ɑn əɹ saɪd? təmɑɹoʊ wɑz taɪm ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt, ɪf ɔl wɛnt wɛl tənaɪt; ðət ɹɛvəleɪʃən naʊ maɪɾ izəli stæmpid ðə hɔl ɪn dɝɛkʃənz ʃi hɑɹdli dɛɹd kɑntəmpleɪt.

What did he think he could do? Act as her bodyguard? Against sisters? That fellow with the drippy nose would do as well. Reveal just how completely he was on her side? Tomorrow was time enough for that, if all went well tonight; that revelation now might easily stampede the Hall in directions she hardly dared contemplate.

"tənaɪɾ ɪz fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪznəs," ʃi toʊld ɪm fɝmli. bʌt, sɪli əz ðə sədʒɛstʃən wɑz, hi hæɾ ɔfɝd tə pʊt hɪmsɛlf ət ɹɪsk fəɹ hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ ɪz ɹizənz - hu nu waɪ ə mæn dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ? - jɛt ʃi oʊɾ ɪm fəɹ ðæt. əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. "ənlɛs aɪ sɛn sɪuən tə jə tənaɪt, lɔɹd bɹaɪn, jə ʃəd liv bɪfɔɹ mɔɹnɪŋ. ɪf bleɪm fəɹ tədeɪ ətætʃɪz ɪtsɛlf tə mi, ɪt maɪt ɹəflɛkt ɑn ju, tu. steɪɪŋ kəd pɹuv deɪnʒɝəs. ivən feɪɾəl. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd nid mʌtʃ ɪkskjuz." noʊ nid tə neɪm u "ðeɪ" wɝ.

"Tonight is for Aes Sedai business," she told him firmly. But, silly as the suggestion was, he had offered to put himself at risk for her. There was no telling his reasons - who knew why a man did anything? - yet she owed him for that. Among other things. "Unless I send Siuan to you tonight, Lord Bryne, you should leave before morning. If blame for today attaches itself to me, it might reflect on you, too. Staying could prove dangerous. Even fatal. I don't think they would need much excuse." No need to name who "they" were.

"aɪ ɡeɪv maɪ wɝd," hi ɹɪplaɪd kwaɪətli, pæɾɪŋ tʃɹævəlɝz nɛk. "tə tɑɹ vəlɑn." pɔzɪŋ, hi ɡlæns təwɔɹd sɪuən. ɪt wɑz lɛs ə hɛzəteɪʃən ðən ə kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən. "wʌtɛvɝ tənaɪts bɪznəs ɪz," hi sɛd faɪnəli, "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət juv θɝɾi θaʊzən mɛn ən ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn bɪhaɪn ju. ðət ʃəd kaʊn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, ivən əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ, mʌðɝ." ɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz bɪɡ-noʊz beɪ ɝaʊnd, hi kɔld oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "aɪ ɪkspɛk tə si jə təmɑɹoʊ, tu, sɪuən. nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒəz ðæt." sɪuən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz bæk əz i ɹoʊɾ əweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz æŋɡwɪʃ ɪn əɹ aɪz.

"I gave my word," he replied quietly, patting Traveler's neck. "To Tar Valon." Pausing, he glanced toward Siuan. It was less a hesitation than a consideration. "Whatever tonight's business is," he said finally, "remember that you have thirty thousand men and Gareth Bryne behind you. That should count for something, even among Aes Sedai. Until tomorrow, Mother." Reining his big-nosed bay around, he called over his shoulder, "I expect to see you tomorrow, too, Siuan. Nothing changes that." Siuan stared at his back as he rode away. There was anguish in her eyes.

ɛɡwin kəd nɑt hɛlp stɛɹɪŋ, tu. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ oʊpən bɪfɔɹ, nɑt nɪɹli. waɪ naʊ, ʌv ɔl taɪmz?

Egwene could not help staring, too. He had never been so open before, not nearly. Why now, of all times?

kɹɔsɪŋ ðə fɔɹɾi əɹ fɪfti peɪsɪz ðət sɛpɝeɪɾəd ði ɑɹmiz kæmp fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪz, ʃi nɑɾəd tə ʃɛɹiəm, hu dʒɹu ɹeɪn ət ðə fɝs tɛns. ʃi ən sɪuən ɹoʊɾ ɑn. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ʃɛɹiəmz vɔɪs ɹoʊz, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli klɪɹ ən stɛɾi. "ði æmɪɝlɪn sit kɔlz ðə hɔl tə sɪt ðɪs deɪ ɪn fɔɹməl sɛʃən. lɛt pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz bi meɪd wɪð ɔl spid." ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk.

Crossing the forty or fifty paces that separated the army's camp from the Aes Sedai's, she nodded to Sheriam, who drew rein at the first tents. She and Siuan rode on. Behind them, Sheriam's voice rose, surprisingly clear and steady. "The Amyrlin Seat calls the Hall to sit this day in formal session. Let preparations be made with all speed." Egwene did not look back.

əɾ əɹ tɛnt, ə boʊni ɡɹum kɪkɪŋ əɹ leɪɝd wʊlən skɝts keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə teɪk deɪʃɝ ən bɛlə. hɝ feɪs wɑz pɪntʃt, ən ʃi bɛɹli dʌkt əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz əz kwɪkli əz ʃi hæd kʌm. ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə ɡloʊɪŋ bɹeɪʒɝz ɪnsaɪd wɑz laɪk ə fɪs kloʊzɪŋ daʊn. ɛɡwin hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz haʊ koʊld ɪt wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ əntɪl ðɛn. əɹ haʊ koʊld ʃi wɑz.

At her tent, a bony groom kicking her layered woolen skirts came running to take Daishar and Bela. Her face was pinched, and she barely ducked her head before hurrying away with the horses as quickly as she had come. The warmth of the glowing braziers inside was like a fist closing down. Egwene had not realized how cold it was outside until then. Or how cold she was.

tʃɛsə tʊk əɹ kloʊk, ən ɪkskleɪmd wən ʃi fɛlt əɹ hænz. "waɪ, jəɹ aɪs tə ðə boʊn, mʌðɝ." tʃæɾɝɪŋ əweɪ, ʃi bʌsəld ɝaʊn foʊldɪŋ ɛɡwinz kloʊk ən sɪuənz, smuðɪŋ ðə nitli tɝnd-daʊn blæŋkəts ɑn ɛɡwinz kɑt, tʌtʃɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ sɛɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə tʃɛsts ðət hæd bɪn pʊl daʊn fɹəm ðə stæk. "aɪd dʒʌmp ɹaɪɾ ɪndə bɛd, wɪð hɑt bɹɪks ɔl ɝaʊnd, ɪf aɪ wɑz ðət tʃɪld. əz sun əz aɪɾ iɾən, ɛniweɪ. wɔɹm aʊtsaɪd dʌz oʊnli soʊ mʌtʃ ɡʊd wɪθaʊt wɔɹm ɪnsaɪd. əl fɛtʃ ə fju ɛkstʃɹə bɹɪks tə tʌk ʌndɝ jəɹ fit waɪl jə sʌp. ən fəɹ sɪuən sədaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. oʊ, ɪf aɪ wɑz əz hʌŋɡɹi əz jə mʌs bi, aɪ noʊ aɪd bi tɛmptəd tə ɡʌlp maɪ fud, bʌt ðəɾ ɔlweɪz ɡɪvz mi peɪnz ɪn ðə stʌmək." pɔzɪŋ baɪ ðə tʃɹeɪ, ʃi aɪɾ ɛɡwin, ən nɑɾəd wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən wən ʃi sɛd ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ it tu fæst.

Chesa took her cloak, and exclaimed when she felt her hands. "Why, you're ice to the bone, Mother." Chattering away, she bustled around folding Egwene's cloak and Siuan's, smoothing the neatly turned-down blankets on Egwene's cot, touching a tray set on one of the chests that had been pulled down from the stack. "I'd jump right into bed, with hot bricks all around, if I was that chilled. As soon as I'd eaten, anyway. Warm outside does only so much good without warm inside. I'll fetch a few extra bricks to tuck under your feet while you sup. And for Siuan Sedai, of course. Oh, if I was as hungry as you must be, I know I'd be tempted to gulp my food, but that always gives me pains in the stomach." Pausing by the tray, she eyed Egwene, and nodded with satisfaction when she said that she would not eat too fast.

meɪkɪŋ ə soʊbɝ ænsɝ wɑz nɑɾ izi. tʃɛsə wɑz ɔlweɪz ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ, bʌɾ æftɝ tədeɪ, ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊs læft wɪð plɛʒɝ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ kɑmpləkeɪʃənz tə tʃɛsə. tu waɪt boʊlz ə lɛntəl stu stʊɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, əlɔŋ wɪð ə tɔl pɪtʃɝ ə spaɪst waɪn, tu sɪlvɝ kʌps, ən tu lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊlz. sʌmhaʊ, ðə wʊmən hæd noʊn sɪuən wəd bi iɾɪŋ wɪð hɝ. stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə boʊlz ən pɪtʃɝ. haʊ ɔfən hæd tʃɛsə hæd tə tʃeɪnʒ ðət tʃɹeɪ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ wɔɹm fud ɡɹiɾəd ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ? sɪmpəl ən ənkɑmpləkeɪɾɪd. ən əz kɛɹɪŋ əz ə mʌðɝ. əɹ ə fɹɛnd.

Making a sober answer was not easy. Chesa was always refreshing, but after today, Egwene almost laughed with pleasure. There were no complications to Chesa. Two white bowls of lentil stew stood on the tray, along with a tall pitcher of spiced wine, two silver cups, and two large rolls. Somehow, the woman had known Siuan would be eating with her. Steam rose from the bowls and pitcher. How often had Chesa had to change that tray to make sure warm food greeted Egwene straightaway? Simple and uncomplicated. And as caring as a mother. Or a friend.

"aɪ mʌs fɔɹɡoʊ bɛd fəɹ naʊ, tʃɛsə. aɪv wɝk jɛt tənaɪt. wəd jə liv ʌs?"

"I must forgo bed for now, Chesa. I've work yet tonight. Would you leave us?"

sɪuən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ðə tɛntflæp fɛl bɪhaɪn ðə plʌmp wʊmən. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ʃi hæzən bɪn ɪn jəɹ sɝvəs sɪns jə wɝ ə beɪb?" ʃi mʌɾɝd.

Siuan shook her head as the tentflap fell behind the plump woman. "Are you sure she hasn't been in your service since you were a babe?" she muttered.

teɪkɪŋ wʌn ə ðə boʊlz, ə ɹoʊl, ən ə spun, ɛɡwin sɛɾəld ɪndə hɝ tʃɛɹ wɪð ə saɪ. ʃi ɔlsoʊ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən wɔɹɾɪd ðə tɛn əɡɛns lɪsənɝz. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, seɪaɪdɑɹ meɪɾ əɹ ɔl ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ əwɛɹ ə hæf-fɹoʊzən hænz ən fit. ðə bɪts ɪn bɪtwin wɝ nɑt mʌtʃ wɔɹmɝ. ðə boʊl simd ɔlmoʊs tu wɔɹm tə hændəl, ən ðə ɹoʊl, əz wɛl. oʊ, haʊ ʃi wʊɾə lʌv tə hæv ðoʊz hɑt bɹɪks.

Taking one of the bowls, a roll, and a spoon, Egwene settled into her chair with a sigh. She also embraced the Source and warded the tent against listeners. Unfortunately, saidar made her all that much more aware of half-frozen hands and feet. The bits in between were not much warmer. The bowl seemed almost too warm to handle, and the roll, as well. Oh, how she would have loved to have those hot bricks.

"ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ wi kən du?" ʃi æskt, ən pɹɑmpli ɡʌlp daʊn ə spunfʊl ə stu. ʃi wɑz ɹævənəs, ən noʊ wʌndɝ, wɪð nʌθɪŋ sɪns bɹɛkfəst ən ðəɾ ɝli. lɛntəlz ən wʊɾi kæɹəts teɪstəd laɪk əɹ mʌðɝz faɪnəs kʊkɪŋ. "aɪ kæn θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt kən ju?"

"Is there anything more we can do?" she asked, and promptly gulped down a spoonful of stew. She was ravenous, and no wonder, with nothing since breakfast and that early. Lentils and woody carrots tasted like her mother's finest cooking. "I can't think of anything, but can you?"

"wʌt kən bi dʌn, hæz bɪn. ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn ɪn." sɪuən tʊk ði ʌðɝ boʊl ən dʒɹɑpt ɑntu ðə loʊ stul, bʌt ðən ʃi sæt stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ stu ən stɝɪŋ ɪt wɪð əɹ spun. "ju wʊdn ɹɪli tɛl hɪm, wəd ju?" ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "aɪ kʊdn bɛɹ ɪf i nu."

"What can be done, has been. There isn't anything else, short of the Creator putting a hand in." Siuan took the other bowl and dropped onto the low stool, but then she sat staring into her stew and stirring it with her spoon. "You wouldn't really tell him, would you?" she said finally. "I couldn't bear if he knew."

"waɪ ɑn ɝθ nɑt?"

"Why on earth not?"

"hid teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ," sɪuən sɛd dɑɹkli. "oʊ, nɑt ðæt. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðæt." ʃi wɑz kwaɪt pɹuɾɪʃ ɪn səm ɛɹiəz. "bʌt ðə mæn wəd meɪk maɪ laɪf ðə pɪɾ ə dum!" ən wɑʃɪŋ ɪz smɔlkloʊðz ən pɑlɪʃɪŋ ɪz buts ən ɪz sæɾəl ɛvɹi deɪ wɑz nɑt?

"He'd take advantage," Siuan said darkly. "Oh, not that. I don't think that." She was quite prudish in some areas. "But the man would make my life the Pit of Doom!" And washing his smallclothes and polishing his boots and his saddle every day was not?

ɛɡwin saɪd. haʊ kəd sətʃ ə sɛnsəbəl, ɪntɛlədʒənt, keɪpəbəl wʊmən tɝn ɪndə ə skæɾɝbɹeɪn oʊvɝ ðɪs wʌn sʌbʒɪkt? laɪk ə hɪsɪŋ vaɪpɝ, ən ɪmədʒ ɹoʊz ɪn əɹ hɛd. hɝsɛlf, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɡɔɪnz ni pleɪɪŋ kɪsɪŋ ɡeɪmz. ɪn ə tævɝn! ʃi ʃʌvd ɪɾ əweɪ, hɑɹd. "sɪuən, aɪ nid jəɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns. aɪ nid jəɹ bɹeɪn. aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə hæv jə hæf-wɪɾɪd kəz ə lɔɹd bɹaɪn. ɪf jə kæn pʊl jɝsɛlf təɡɛðɝ, əl peɪ hɪm wʌt jə oʊ, ən fɝbɪd jə tə si hɪm. aɪ wɪl."

Egwene sighed. How could such a sensible, intelligent, capable woman turn into a scatterbrain over this one subject? Like a hissing viper, an image rose in her head. Herself, sitting on Gawyn's knee playing kissing games. In a tavern! She shoved it away, hard. "Siuan, I need your experience. I need your brain. I can't afford to have you half-witted because of Lord Bryne. If you can't pull yourself together, I'll pay him what you owe, and forbid you to see him. I will."

"aɪ sɛɾ aɪd wɝk ɔf ðə dɛt," sɪuən sɛd stʌbɝnli. "aɪ hæv əz mʌtʃ ɑnɝ əz lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ blʌɾi bɹaɪn! əz mʌtʃ ən mɔɹ! hi kips ɪz wɝd, ən aɪ kip maɪn! bɪsaɪdz, mɪn toʊl mi aɪ hæv tə steɪ kloʊs tə hɪm əɹ wɪl boʊθ daɪ. əɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt." ə pɪŋknəs ɪn əɹ tʃiks ɡeɪv əɹ əweɪ, ðoʊ. hɝ ɑnɝ ən mɪnz vjuɪŋ nɑtwɪθstændɪŋ, ʃi wɑz sɪmpli wɪlɪŋ tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛniθɪŋ tə bi nɪɹ ðə mæn!

"I said I'd work off the debt," Siuan said stubbornly. "I have as much honor as Lord Gareth bloody Bryne! As much and more! He keeps his word, and I keep mine! Besides, Min told me I have to stay close to him or we'll both die. Or something like that." A pinkness in her cheeks gave her away, though. Her honor and Min's viewing notwithstanding, she was simply willing to put up with anything to be near the man!

"vɛɹi wɛl. jəɹ bɛsɑɾɪd, ən ɪf aɪ tɛl jə tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, jəl iðɝ dɪsəbeɪ əɹ moʊp ən ɹæp ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ bɹeɪnz ɪn ə klaʊd. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə gɑnə də əbaʊt hɪm?"

"Very well. You're besotted, and if I tell you to stay away from him, you'll either disobey or mope and wrap the rest of your brains in a cloud. What are you going to do about him?"

skaʊlɪŋ ɪndɪɡnənli, sɪuən wɛn ɑn fəɹ səm lɪɾəl taɪm, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ wʌt ʃi wəd laɪk tə də əbaʊt ɡɛɹɪθ blʌɾi bɹaɪn. hi wʊɾə ɛndʒɔɪd nʌn ʌv ɪt. sʌm, hi maɪt nɑɾ əv sɝvaɪvd.

Scowling indignantly, Siuan went on for some little time, growling what she would like to do about Gareth bloody Bryne. He would have enjoyed none of it. Some, he might not have survived.

"sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli. "ju dɪnaɪ wʌn mɔɹ taɪm wʌts pleɪn əz jəɹ noʊz, ən əl tɛl ɪm ən ɡɪv ɪm ðə mʌni."

"Siuan," Egwene said warningly. "You deny one more time what's plain as your nose, and I'll tell him and give him the money."

sɪuən paʊɾɪd sʌlənli. ʃi paʊɾɪd! sʌlənli! sɪuən! "aɪ doʊn əv taɪm tə bi ɪn lʌv. aɪ bɛɹli hæv taɪm tə θɪŋk, bɪtwin wɝkɪŋ fəɹ jə ən hɪm. ən ivən ɪf ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡoʊz ɹaɪt tənaɪt, əl əv twaɪs əz mʌtʃ tə du. bɪsaɪdz. . . ." hɝ feɪs fɛl, ən ʃi ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə stul. "wʌɾ ɪf i dʌznt . . . ɹɪtɝn maɪ filɪŋz?" ʃi mʌɾɝd. "hiz nɛvɝ ivən tʃɹaɪd tə kɪs mi. ɔl i kɛɹz əbaʊɾ ɪz wɛðɝ ɪz ʃɝts ɑɹ klin."

Siuan pouted sullenly. She pouted! Sullenly! Siuan! "I don't have time to be in love. I barely have time to think, between working for you and him. And even if everything goes right tonight, I'll have twice as much to do. Besides. . . ." Her face fell, and she shifted on the stool. "What if he doesn't . . . return my feelings?" she muttered. "He's never even tried to kiss me. All he cares about is whether his shirts are clean."

ɛɡwin skɹeɪpt əɹ spun θɹu hɝ boʊl, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən ɪt keɪm ʌp ɛmpti. nʌθɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə ɹoʊl bʌɾ ə fju kɹʌmz ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs. laɪt, hɝ mɪɾəl stɪl fɛl hɑloʊ. ʃi aɪd sɪuənz boʊl hoʊpfəli; ðə wʊmən sim tə hæv lɪɾəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌt dʒɹɔɪŋ sɝkəlz ɪn ðə lɛntəlz.

Egwene scraped her spoon through her bowl, and was surprised when it came up empty. Nothing remained of the roll but a few crumbs on her dress. Light, her middle still felt hollow. She eyed Siuan's bowl hopefully; the woman seemed to have little interest in anything but drawing circles in the lentils.

ə sʌɾən θɔɾ əkɝd tə hɝ. waɪ hæd lɔɹd bɹaɪn ɪnsɪstəd ðət sɪuən wɝk ɔf əɹ dɛɾ ivən æftɝ lɝnɪŋ u ʃi wɑz? dʒʌs kəz ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi wʊd? ɪt wɑz ə pɹɪpɑstɝəs ɝeɪnʒmənt. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt dɪd kip əɹ kloʊs tə hɪm wən nʌθɪŋ ɛls wəd hæv. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi hɝsɛlf hæɾ ɔfən wʌndɝd waɪ bɹaɪn hæɾ əɡɹid tə bɪl ði ɑɹmi. hi hæd tə hæv noʊn ðəɹ wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd tʃæns i wɑz leɪɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ðə tʃɑpɪŋ blɑk. ən waɪ hi hæɾ ɔfɝd ðəɾ ɑɹmi tə hɝ, ə ɡɝl æmɪɝlɪn wɪð noʊ ɹil əθɔɹəɾi ən nɑɾ ə fɹɛn əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz ɪksɛp sɪuən, əz fɑɹ əz i nu? kəd ði ænsɝ tə ɔl ə ðoʊz kwɛstʃənz bi əz sɪmpəl əz . . . hi lʌv sɪuən? noʊ; moʊs mɛn wɝ fɹɪvələs ən flaɪɾi, bʌt ðət wɑz tʃɹuli pɹɪpɑstɝəs! stɪl, ʃi ɔfɝd ðə sədʒɛstʃən, ɪf oʊnli tə əmjuz sɪuən. ɪt maɪt tʃɪɹ əɹ ə lɪɾəl.

A sudden thought occurred to her. Why had Lord Bryne insisted that Siuan work off her debt even after learning who she was? Just because she had said she would? It was a preposterous arrangement. Except that it did keep her close to him when nothing else would have. For that matter, she herself had often wondered why Bryne had agreed to build the army. He had to have known there was a very good chance he was laying his head on the chopping block. And why he had offered that army to her, a girl Amyrlin with no real authority and not a friend among the sisters except Siuan, as far as he knew? Could the answer to all of those questions be as simple as . . . he loved Siuan? No; most men were frivolous and flighty, but that was truly preposterous! Still, she offered the suggestion, if only to amuse Siuan. It might cheer her a little.

sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd ɪn dɪsbɪlif. ɪt saʊndəɾ ɑd, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət pɹɪɾi feɪs, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəd pʊt kwaɪt soʊ mʌtʃ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɪndə ə snɔɹɾ əz ʃi dɪd. "hiz nɑɾ ə toʊɾəl ɪɾiət," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ɪn fækt, hiz ə ɡʊd hɛɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. hi θɪŋks laɪk ə wʊmən, moʊst ə ðə taɪm."

Siuan snorted in disbelief. It sounded odd, coming from that pretty face, but no one could put quite so much expression into a snort as she did. "He's not a total idiot," she said dryly. "In fact, he has a good head on his shoulders. He thinks like a woman, most of the time."

"aɪ stɪl hævən hɝd jə seɪ jəl stʃɹeɪɾən ʌp, sɪuən," ɛɡwin pɝsɪstəd. "ju hæv tə, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ."

"I still haven't heard you say you'll straighten up, Siuan," Egwene persisted. "You have to, one way or another."

"wɛl, ʌv kɔɹs aɪ wɪl. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌts bɪn ðə mæɾɝ wɪð mi. ɪɾ ɪzən əz ɪf aɪ nɛvɝ kɪst ə mæn bɪfɔɹ." hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊd sʌɾənli, əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛɡwin tə tʃælənʒ əɹ ɑn ðæt. "aɪ hævən spɛn maɪ hoʊl laɪf ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðɪs ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs! tʃæɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt mɛn, tənaɪɾ ʌv ɔl naɪts!" piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ boʊl, ʃi sim tə ɹilaɪz fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðəɾ ɪt hɛl fud. ʃi fɪld əɹ spun, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ɪɾ əɾ ɛɡwin. "ju hæv tə bi kɛɹfəl ə jəɹ taɪmɪŋ, mɔɹ naʊ ðən ɛvɝ. ɪf ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn ɡɹæbz ðə tɪlɝ, jəl nɛvɝ ɡɛt jəɹ hænz ɑn ɪt."

"Well, of course I will. I don't know what's been the matter with me. It isn't as if I never kissed a man before." Her eyes narrowed suddenly, as if she expected Egwene to challenge her on that. "I haven't spent my whole life in the Tower. This is ridiculous! Chattering about men, tonight of all nights!" Peering into her bowl, she seemed to realize for the first time that it held food. She filled her spoon, gesturing with it at Egwene. "You have to be careful of your timing, more now than ever. If Romanda or Lelaine grabs the tiller, you'll never get your hands on it."

ɹɪdɪkjələs əɹ nɑt, sʌmθɪŋ sɝɾənli hæd ɹɪstɔɹd sɪuənz æpətaɪt. ʃi wɛn θɹu hɝ stu fæstɝ ðən ɛɡwin hæd hɝz, ən nɑɾ ə kɹʌm ə ðə ɹoʊl ɪskeɪp hɝ. ɛɡwin faʊn ðət ʃi hæd dʒɹɔn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɝ oʊn ɛmpti boʊl. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt ðən bʌt tə lɪk ɔf ðə læs fju lɛntəlz, ʌv kɔɹs.

Ridiculous or not, something certainly had restored Siuan's appetite. She went through her stew faster than Egwene had hers, and not a crumb of the roll escaped her. Egwene found that she had drawn her fingers through her own empty bowl. There was nothing for it then but to lick off the last few lentils, of course.

dɪskʌsɪŋ wʌt wɑz tə hæpən tənaɪt sɝv noʊ ɹil pɔɪnt. ðeɪ hæd hoʊn ən ɹəfaɪnd wʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz tə seɪ, ən wɛn, soʊ mɛni taɪmz ðət ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ʃi hæd nɑt dʒɹimd ʌv ɪt. ʃi sɝɾənli cʊɾə dʌn əɹ pɑɹɾ ɪn əɹ slip. sɪuən ɪnsɪstəɾ ɛniweɪ, skɝɾɪŋ vɛɹi nɪɹ ðə pɔɪnt wɛɹ ɛɡwin wəɾ əv tə kɔl əɹ daʊn, ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp pɑsəbɪləɾiz ðeɪ hæd dɪskʌs bɪfɔɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz. stʃɹeɪnʒli, sɪuən hæd faʊn hɝsɛlf ə vɛɹi ɡʊd mud. ʃi ivən ɛseɪɾ ə lɪɾəl hjumɝ, ənjuʒəwəl fəɹ əɹ ə leɪt, ðoʊ səm wɑz ɑn ðə ɡæloʊz saɪd.

Discussing what was to happen tonight served no real point. They had honed and refined what Egwene was to say, and when, so many times that she was surprised she had not dreamed of it. She certainly could have done her part in her sleep. Siuan insisted anyway, skirting very near the point where Egwene would have to call her down, going over it again and again, bringing up possibilities they had discussed before a hundred times. Strangely, Siuan had found herself a very good mood. She even essayed a little humor, unusual for her of late, though some was on the gallows side.

"ju noʊ ɹoʊmændə wɑntəd tə bi æmɪɝlɪn hɝsɛlf wʌns," ʃi sɛɾ ət wʌn pɔɪnt. "aɪv hɝɾ ɪt wɑz tæmɹə ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə stoʊl ən stæf ðət meɪɾ əɹ stɔk ɔf ɪndə ɹitaɪɝmən laɪk ə ɡʌl wɪð əɹ teɪl fɛðɝz klɪpt. əl leɪ ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk aɪ doʊn əv tə ə fɪʃ skeɪl ðəɾ əɹ aɪz bʌlʒ twaɪs əz mʌtʃ əz ləleɪnz."

"You know Romanda wanted to be Amyrlin herself once," she said at one point. "I've heard it was Tamra getting the stole and staff that made her stalk off into retirement like a gull with her tail feathers clipped. I'll lay a silver mark I don't have to a fish scale that her eyes bulge twice as much as Lelaine's."

ən leɪɾɝ. "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd bi ðəɹ tə hɪɹ əm haʊl. sʌmbɑɾiz gɑnə bɪfɔɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ən aɪd ɹæðɝ ɪt wɑz əm ðən ʌs. aɪ nɛvɝ hæd ðə vɔɪs fəɹ sɪŋɪŋ." ʃi æktʃəli  sæŋ ə lɪɾəl snætʃ əbaʊt stɛɹɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ əɾ ə bɔɪ ən hævɪŋ noʊ boʊt. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt; hɝ vɔɪs wɑz plɛzən ɪn ɪts fæʃən, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt kæɹi ə tun ɪn ə bʌkət.

And later. "I wish I could be there to hear them howl. Somebody's going to before much longer, and I'd rather it was them than us. I never had the voice for singing." She actually sang a little snatch about staring across the river at a boy and having no boat. She was right; her voice was pleasant in its fashion, but she could not carry a tune in a bucket.

ən leɪɾɝ stɪl. "ə ɡʊd θɪŋ aɪ hæv sətʃ ə swit feɪs naʊ. ɪf ðɪs ɡoʊz bædli, ðəl dʒɹɛs ðə pɛɹ ʌv əs fəɹ dɑlz ən sɪɾ əs ɑn ə ʃɛlf tə ædmaɪɹ. ʌv kɔɹs, wi maɪɾ əv 'æksəɾənts' ɪnstɛd. dɑlz də ɡɛt bɹoʊkən. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn wɪl əv tə faɪn sʌmwʌn ɛls tə bʊli." ʃi ɹɪli læft ət ðæt.

And later still. "A good thing I have such a sweet face now. If this goes badly, they'll dress the pair of us for dolls and sit us on a shelf to admire. Of course, we might have 'accidents' instead. Dolls do get broken. Gareth Bryne will have to find someone else to bully." She really laughed at that.

ɛɡwin fɛl kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɹɪlif wən ðə tɛntflæp bʌlʒd ɪnwɝd bɹifli, ənaʊnsɪŋ sʌmwʌn u nu ɪnʌf nɑt tə ɛntɝ wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz ə wɔɹd. ʃi ɹɪli dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ wɛɹ sɪuənz hjumɝ wɛn fɹəm ðɛɹ!

Egwene felt considerable relief when the tentflap bulged inward briefly, announcing someone who knew enough not to enter where there was a ward. She really did not want to hear where Siuan's humor went from there!

əz sun əz ʃi ɹilis ðə wɔɹd, ʃɛɹiəm stɛpt ɪnsaɪd, əkʌmpənid baɪ ə ɹʌʃ ʌv ɛɹ ðət sim tɛn taɪmz əz koʊld əz ɝliɝ. "ɪts taɪm, mʌðɝ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz ɹɛɾi." hɝ tɪltəɾ aɪz wɝ waɪd, ən ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps wɪð ðə tɪp ə hɝ tʌŋ.

As soon as she released the ward, Sheriam stepped inside, accompanied by a rush of air that seemed ten times as cold as earlier. "It's time, Mother. Everything is ready." Her tilted eyes were wide, and she licked her lips with the tip of her tongue.

sɪuən baʊndəd tə hɝ fiɾ ən sizd əɹ kloʊk fɹəm ɛɡwinz kɑt, bʌt ʃi pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "aɪ hæv seɪl ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪn ðə dɑɹk, jə noʊ," ʃi sɛd sɪɹiəsli. "ænd nɛɾɪd ə laɪənfɪʃ wʌns, wɪð maɪ fɑðɝ. ɪt kən bi dʌn."

Siuan bounded to her feet and seized her cloak from Egwene's cot, but she paused in the act of draping it on her shoulders. "I have sailed the Fingers of the Dragon in the dark, you know," she said seriously. "And netted a lionfish once, with my father. It can be done."

ʃɛɹiəm fɹaʊn əz sɪuən dɑɹɾɪd aʊt, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn mɔɹ koʊld. "səmtaɪmz, aɪ θɪŋk," ʃi bɪɡæn, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ʃi səmtaɪmz θɔt, ʃi dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ. "waɪ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ ðɪs, mʌðɝ?" ʃi æskt ɪnstɛd. "ɔl ʌv ɪt, tədeɪ ət ðə leɪk, kɔlɪŋ ðə hɔl tənaɪt. waɪ dɪd juv əs spɛn ɔl deɪ jɛstɝdeɪ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt lɑɡən tə ɛvɹibɑɾi wi mɛt? aɪd θɪŋk jə maɪt ʃɛɹ ɪt wɪð mi. aɪm jəɹ kipɝ. aɪ dɪd swɛɹ fiəlti."

Sheriam frowned as Siuan darted out, letting in more cold. "Sometimes, I think," she began, but whatever she sometimes thought, she did not share. "Why are you doing this, Mother?" she asked instead. "All of it, today at the lake, calling the Hall tonight. Why did you have us spend all day yesterday talking about Logain to everybody we met? I'd think you might share it with me. I am your Keeper. I did swear fealty."

"aɪ tɛl jə wʌt jə nid tə noʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ ðət ʃi tʃɹʌstɪɾ ə fɔɹst oʊθ oʊnli soʊ fɑɹ, ivən ə sɪstɝz. ən ʃɛɹiəm maɪt faɪn ə ɹizən tə lɛɾ ə wɝd slɪp ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ ɪɹ dɪspaɪt ðəɾ oʊθ. æftɝ ɔl, ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ noʊɾəd fəɹ faɪndɪŋ luphoʊlz ɪn wʌt ðeɪ hæd sɛd. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ðət wəd hæpən, bʌt dʒʌst əz wɪð lɔɹd bɹaɪn, ʃi kəd nɑt teɪk ivən smɔl tʃænsəz ənlɛs ʃi hæd tə.

"I tell you what you need to know," Egwene said, swinging her cloak around her shoulders. There was no need to say that she trusted a forced oath only so far, even a sister's. And Sheriam might find a reason to let a word slip into the wrong ear despite that oath. After all, Aes Sedai were noted for finding loopholes in what they had said. She did not really believe that would happen, but just as with Lord Bryne, she could not take even small chances unless she had to.

"aɪ hæv tə tɛl ju," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd bɪɾɝli, "aɪ θɪŋk təmɑɹoʊ ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn wɪl bi jəɹ kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz, ən əl bi sɝvɪŋ ə pɛnəns fəɹ nɑt wɔɹnɪŋ ðə hɔl. ən aɪ θɪŋk jə maɪɾ ɛnvi mi."

"I have to tell you," Sheriam said bitterly, "I think tomorrow Romanda or Lelaine will be your Keeper of the Chronicles, and I'll be serving a penance for not warning the Hall. And I think you might envy me."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. ɔl tu pɑsəbəl. "ʃæl wi ɡoʊ?"

Egwene nodded. All too possible. "Shall we go?"

ðə sʌn meɪɾ ə ɹɛd doʊm ɑn ðə tʃɹitɑps tə ðə wɛst, ən ə lʊɹəd laɪt ʃoʊn ɔf ðə snoʊ. sɝvəns mɑɹkt ɛɡwinz pæsədʒ əlɔŋ ðə dip pæðz wɪð saɪlən baʊz ən kɝtsiz. ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ tʃɹʌbəld əɹ ɛls blæŋk; sɝvəns kəd pɪk ʌp ðə mudz ə ðoʊz ðeɪ sɝvd ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz wɔɹɾɝz.

The sun made a red dome on the treetops to the west, and a lurid light shone off the snow. Servants marked Egwene's passage along the deep paths with silent bows and curtsies. Their faces were troubled or else blank; servants could pick up the moods of those they served almost as quickly as Warders.

nɑɾ ə sɪstɝ wɑz tə bi sin, ət fɝst, ən ðən ðeɪ ɔl wɝ, ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt ɡæðɝɪŋ θɹi dip ɝaʊn ə pəvɪljən sɛɾ ʌp ɪn ði oʊnli oʊpən speɪs ɪn ðə kæmp lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf, ði ɛɹiə juz baɪ sɪstɝz skɪmɪŋ tə ðə dʌvəkoʊts ɪn sɑlədɑɹ ən tʃɹævlɪŋ bæk wɪð ɹɪpɔɹts fɹəm ði aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz. ə lɑɹdʒ mʌtʃ-mɛndɪd pis ə hɛvi kænvəs, nɑɾ ə pætʃ ɑn ðə splɛndɝ ə ðə kænəpi ət ðə leɪk, ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɛfɝt tə sɛɾ ʌp. moʊst ɔfən ɪn ðə pæs tu mʌnθs, ðə hɔl hæd kənvin mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ hæd jɛstɝdeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ, əɹ pɝhæps skwizd ɪndə wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ tɛns. ðə pəvɪljən hæd bɪn ɪɹɛktəɾ oʊnli twaɪs sɪns livɪŋ sɑlədɑɹ. boʊθ taɪmz fəɹ ə tʃɹaɪəl.

Not a sister was to be seen, at first, and then they all were, in a great gathering three deep around a pavilion set up in the only open space in the camp large enough, the area used by sisters Skimming to the dovecotes in Salidar and Traveling back with reports from the eyes-and-ears. A large much-mended piece of heavy canvas, not a patch on the splendor of the canopy at the lake, it had been a great deal of effort to set up. Most often in the past two months, the Hall had convened much as they had yesterday morning, or perhaps squeezed into one of the larger tents. The pavilion had been erected only twice since leaving Salidar. Both times for a trial.

noʊɾɪsɪŋ ɛɡwin ən ʃɛɹiəmz əpɹoʊtʃ, sɪstɝz ɪn ðə bæk mɝmɝd tə ðoʊz əhɛd, ən ə ɡæp oʊpən tə lɛɾ əm θɹu. ɪkspɹɛʃənləs aɪz wɑtʃt ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm, ɡɪvɪŋ nɑɾ ə klu tə wɛðɝ ðə wɑtʃɪŋ sɪstɝz nu əɹ ivən səspɛktəd wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. nɑɾ ə klu tə wʌt ðeɪ θɔt. bʌɾɝflaɪz stɝɾ ɪn ɛɡwinz stʌmək. ə ɹoʊzbʌd. kɑm.

Noticing Egwene and Sheriam's approach, sisters in the back murmured to those ahead, and a gap opened to let them through. Expressionless eyes watched the pair of them, giving not a clue to whether the watching sisters knew or even suspected what was happening. Not a clue to what they thought. Butterflies stirred in Egwene's stomach. A rosebud. Calm.

ʃi stɛpt ɑntu ðə leɪɝd kɑɹpəts, woʊvən ɪn bɹaɪt flaʊɝz ən ə dʌzən dɪfɹən pæɾɝnz, ən muv θɹu ðə ɹɪŋ ə bɹeɪʒɝz sɛɾ ʌp ɝaʊn ðə kænəpiz ɹɪm, ən ʃɛɹiəm bɪɡæn. "ʃi kʌmz; ʃi kʌmz. . . ." ɪf ʃi saʊndəɾ ə lɪɾəl lɛs ɡɹæn ðən juʒəwəl, ə tʌtʃ nɝvəs, ɪt wɑz smɔl wʌndɝ.

She stepped onto the layered carpets, woven in bright flowers and a dozen different patterns, and moved through the ring of braziers set up around the canopy's rim, and Sheriam began. "She comes; she comes. . . ." If she sounded a little less grand than usual, a touch nervous, it was small wonder.

ðə pɑlɪʃt bɛntʃɪz ən klɔθ-kʌvɝd bɑksəz fɹəm ðə leɪk wɝ ɪn jus əɡɛn. ðeɪ meɪɾ ə mʌtʃ mɔɹ fɔɹməl saɪt ðən ðə mɪsmætʃt ɡæɡəl ə tʃɛɹz ðət hæd bɪn juz pɹiviəsli, tu slæntɪŋ laɪnz ə naɪn, ɡɹup baɪ θɹiz; ɡɹin, ɡɹeɪ ən jɛloʊ tə wʌn saɪd, waɪt, bɹaʊn ən blu tə ði ʌðɝ. ət ðə waɪɾ ɛnd, fɑɹðəs fɹəm ɛɡwin, stʊd ðə stʃɹaɪp bɑks ən bɛntʃ fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ, ʃi wəd bi ðə foʊkəs ʌv ɛvɹi aɪ, vɛɹi mʌtʃ əwɛɹ ðət ʃi wɑz wʌn feɪsɪŋ eɪtin. əz wɛl ʃi hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd əɹ kloʊðz; ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ stɪl wɔɹ əɹ faɪnɝi fɹəm ðə leɪk, oʊnli æɾɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. ə ɹoʊzbʌd. kɑm.

The polished benches and cloth-covered boxes from the lake were in use again. They made a much more formal sight than the mismatched gaggle of chairs that had been used previously, two slanting lines of nine, grouped by threes; Green, Gray and Yellow to one side, White, Brown and Blue to the other. At the wide end, farthest from Egwene, stood the striped box and bench for the Amyrlin Seat. Sitting there, she would be the focus of every eye, very much aware that she was one facing eighteen. As well she had not changed her clothes; every Sitter still wore her finery from the lake, only adding her shawl. A rosebud. Calm.

wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃɪz wɑz ɛmpti, ðoʊ oʊnli fəɹ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ. dɛlænə keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn dʒʌst əz ʃɛɹiəm fɪnɪʃt əɹ lɪɾəni. lʊkɪŋ bɹɛθləs ən flʌstɝd, ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪɾɝ skɹæmbəld ʌp tə hɝ sit, bɪtwin vɛɹɪlɪn ən kweɪmɛsə, wɪð lɪɾəl ə hɝ juʒəwəl ɡɹeɪs. ʃi wɔɹ ə sɪkli ɡɹɪn, ən tɔɪd nɝvəsli wɪð ðə faɪɝdʒɹɑps ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ɛniwʌn maɪɾ əv θɔt ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn ɑn tʃɹaɪəl. kɑm. noʊ wʌn wɑz ɑn tʃɹaɪəl. jɛt.

One of the benches was empty, though only for a moment longer. Delana came running in just as Sheriam finished her litany. Looking breathless and flustered, the Gray Sitter scrambled up to her seat, between Varilin and Kwamesa, with little of her usual grace. She wore a sickly grin, and toyed nervously with the firedrops around her neck. Anyone might have thought she was the one on trial. Calm. No one was on trial. Yet.

ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd sloʊli əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts, bɪtwin ðə tu ɹoʊz, wɪð ʃɛɹiəm kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, ən kweɪmɛsə stʊd. ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn ɝaʊn ðə dɑɹk slɛndɝ wʊmən, jʌŋɡəst ə ðə sɪɾɝz. tənaɪt ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ skɪmpɪŋ ə ðə fɔɹmæləɾiz. "wʌɾ ɪz bɹɔt bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪz fəɹ ðə hɔl əloʊn tə kənsɪɾɝ," kweɪmɛsə ənaʊnst. "husoʊɛvɝ ɪntʃɹudz ənbɪddən, wʊmən əɹ mæn, ɪnɪʃiəɾ əɹ aʊtsaɪɾɝ, wɛðɝ ðeɪ kʌm ɪn pis əɹ ɪn æŋɡɝ, əl baɪn əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə lɔ, tə feɪs ðə lɔ. noʊ ðət wʌɾ aɪ spik ɪz tʃɹu; ɪɾəl ən ʃæl bi dʌn."

Egwene started slowly across the carpets, between the two rows, with Sheriam close behind, and Kwamesa stood. The light of saidar suddenly shone around the dark slender woman, youngest of the Sitters. Tonight there would be no skimping of the formalities. "What is brought before the Hall of the Tower is for the Hall alone to consider," Kwamesa announced. "Whosoever intrudes unbidden, woman or man, initiate or outsider, whether they come in peace or in anger, I will bind according to the law, to face the law. Know that what I speak is true; it will and shall be done."

ðət fɔɹmjələ wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ði oʊθ əɡɛnst spikɪŋ əntʃɹuθ, fɹəm ə taɪm wən ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni æmɪɝlənz daɪd baɪ əsæsəneɪʃən əz baɪ ɔl ʌðɝ kɑzəz pʊt təɡɛðɝ. ɛɡwin kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ mɛʒɝd tʃɹɛd. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə tʌtʃ əɹ stoʊl, fəɹ ə ɹimaɪndɝ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ əhɛd.

That formula was older than the oath against speaking untruth, from a time when almost as many Amyrlins died by assassination as by all other causes put together. Egwene continued her measured tread. It was an effort not to touch her stole, for a reminder. She tried to concentrate on the bench ahead.

kweɪmɛsə ɹɪzumd əɹ sit, stɪl ʃaɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ən əmʌŋ ðə waɪts, ələdʒɹɪn ɹoʊz, ðə ɡloʊ sɝaʊndɪŋ əɹ əz wɛl. wɪð əɹ dɑɹk ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ən bɪɡ peɪl bɹaʊn aɪz, ʃi wɑz kwaɪt lʌvli wən ʃi smaɪld, bʌt tənaɪɾ ə stoʊn hæd mɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən ʃi. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz wɪðɪn ɪɹʃɑɾ u ɑɹ nɑɾ ə ðə hɔl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kul vɔɪs stʃɹɔŋ wɪð ði æksɛns ə tæɹɑbən. "wʌɾ ɪz spoʊkən ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ ɪz fəɹ ðə hɔl əloʊn tə hɪɹ, əntɪl ən ənlɛs ðə hɔl dɪsaɪdz ʌðɝwaɪz. əl meɪk əs pɹaɪvət. əl sil əɹ wɝdz tə əɹ ɪɹz oʊnli." wivɪŋ ə wɔɹd ðət wɔl ði ɪntaɪɝ pəvɪljən, ʃi sæt. ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz aʊtsaɪd, hu naʊ mʌst wɑtʃ ðə hɔl muv ɪn ʌɾɝ saɪləns.

Kwamesa resumed her seat, still shining with the Power, and among the Whites, Aledrin rose, the glow surrounding her as well. With her dark golden hair and big pale brown eyes, she was quite lovely when she smiled, but tonight a stone had more expression than she. "There are those within earshot who are not of the Hall," she said in a cool voice strong with the accents of Tarabon. "What is spoken in the Hall of the Tower is for the Hall alone to hear, until and unless the Hall decides otherwise. I will make us private. I will seal our words to our ears only." Weaving a ward that walled the entire pavilion, she sat. There was a stir among the sisters outside, who now must watch the Hall move in utter silence.

stʃɹeɪnʒ, ðət soʊ mʌtʃ əmʌŋ sɪɾɝz dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn eɪdʒ, wən dɪstɪŋkʃən baɪ eɪdʒ wɑz nɛks tə ənæθəmə əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. kəd sɪuən əv sin ə pæɾɝn ɪn ðə sɪɾɝz' eɪdʒəz? noʊ. foʊkəs. kɑm, ən foʊkəs.

Strange, that so much among Sitters depended on age, when distinction by age was next to anathema among the rest of Aes Sedai. Could Siuan have seen a pattern in the Sitters' ages? No. Focus. Calm, and focus.

ɡɹɪpɪŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə hɝ kloʊk, ɛɡwin stɛpt ʌp ɑntu ðə bɹaɪtli stʃɹaɪp bɑks ən tɝnd. ləleɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn əɹ fit, blu-fɹɪnd ʃɔl lupt əkɹɔs əɹ ɑɹmz, ən ɹoʊmændə wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ, wɪθaʊɾ ivən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛɡwin tə sɪt. ʃi dɛɹd nɑt lɛɾ iðɝ siz ðə tɪlɝ. "aɪ kɔl ə kwɛstʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə laʊd, fɝm vɔɪs. "hu wɪl stæn tə dɪklɛɹ wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə jusɝpɝ ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən?"

Gripping the edges of her cloak, Egwene stepped up onto the brightly striped box and turned. Lelaine was already on her feet, blue-fringed shawl looped across her arms, and Romanda was rising, without even waiting for Egwene to sit. She dared not let either seize the tiller. "I call a question before the Hall," she said in a loud, firm voice. "Who will stand to declare war against the usurper Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan?"

ən ðən ʃi sæt, θɹoʊɪŋ ɔf əɹ kloʊk ən lɛɾɪŋ ɪt fɔl əkɹɔs ðə bɛntʃ. stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə kɑɹpəts, ʃɛɹiəm əpɪɹd kwaɪt kul ən kəlɛktəd, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ ə smɔl saʊnd, ɔlmoʊst ə wɪmpɝ. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛniwʌn ɛls hæd hɝd. ʃi hoʊp nɑt.

And then she sat, throwing off her cloak and letting it fall across the bench. Standing beside her on the carpets, Sheriam appeared quite cool and collected, but she made a small sound, almost a whimper. Egwene did not think anyone else had heard. She hoped not.

ðəɹ wɑz ə bɹif moʊmən ə ʃɑk, wɪmən fɹoʊzən ɑn ðɛɹ sits, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɪn əmeɪzmənt. pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ kəz ʃi hæɾ æskt əɾ ɔl əz wʌt ʃi hæɾ æskt. noʊ wʌn pʊɾ ə kwɛstʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ saʊndɪŋ aʊt ðə sɪɾɝz; ɪt dʒʌst wɑz nɑt dʌn, fəɹ pɹæktəkəl ɹizənz əz mʌtʃ əz tʃɹədɪʃən.

There was a brief moment of shock, women frozen on their seats, staring at her in amazement. Perhaps as much because she had asked at all as what she had asked. No one put a question before the Hall before sounding out the Sitters; it just was not done, for practical reasons as much as tradition.

ət læs ləleɪn spoʊk. "wi də nɑt dɪklɛɹ wɔɹ ɑn ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs. "nɑɾ ivən ɑn tʃɹeɪɾɝz laɪk ɪleɪɾə. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ kɔl tə ʃɛlv jəɹ kwɛstʃən waɪl wi dil wɪð mɔɹ ɪmiɾiət mæɾɝz." ʃi hæd hæd taɪm tə ɡæðɝ hɝsɛlf sɪns ðə ɹaɪd bæk; hɝ feɪs wɑz mɪɹli hɑɹd naʊ, nɑt θʌndɝəs. bɹʌʃɪŋ blu-slæʃt skɝts əz ɪf bɹʌʃɪŋ əweɪ ɪleɪɾə - əɹ pɝhæps ɛɡwin - ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz. "wʌt bɹɪŋz əs tə sɪt tənaɪɾ ɪz. . . . aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə seɪ sɪmpəl, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzənt. oʊpən ðə nɑvəs bʊk? wi wəɾ əv ɡɹændmʌðɝz klæmɝɪŋ tə bi tɛstəd. ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ ə mʌnθ? aɪ hɑɹdli nid lɪs ðə dɪfəkəltiz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð spɛndɪŋ hæf əɹ ɡoʊld wɪθaʊt kʌmɪŋ ə fʊt nɪɹɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ən əz fəɹ nɑt kɹɔsɪŋ ɪndə ændɝ - "

At last Lelaine spoke. "We do not declare war on individuals," she said in a dry voice. "Not even on traitors like Elaida. In any case, I call to shelve your question while we deal with more immediate matters." She had had time to gather herself since the ride back; her face was merely hard now, not thunderous. Brushing blue-slashed skirts as if brushing away Elaida - or perhaps Egwene - she turned her attention to the other Sitters. "What brings us to sit tonight is. . . . I was about to say simple, but it isn't. Open the novice book? We would have grandmothers clamoring to be tested. Remain here a month? I hardly need list the difficulties, beginning with spending half our gold without coming a foot nearer Tar Valon. And as for not crossing into Andor - "

"maɪ sɪstɝ ləleɪn, ɪn əɹ æŋzaɪəɾi, hæz fɝɡɑɾən u hæz ðə ɹaɪt tə spik fɝst," ɹoʊmændə kʌɾ ɪn smuðli. hɝ smaɪl mænədʒ tə meɪk ləleɪn əpɪɹ mɛɹi. stɪl, ʃi tʊk əɹ taɪm ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl dʒʌst əz ʃi wɑntəd, ə wʊmən wɪð ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə wɝld. "aɪ hæv tu kwɛstʃənz tə kɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl, ən ɪn ðə sɛkən əl ædʒɹɛs ləleɪnz kənsɝnz. ənfɔɹtʃənətli fəɹ hɝ, maɪ fɝs kwɛstʃən kənsɝnz ləleɪnz oʊn fɪtnəs tə kəntɪnju ɪn ðə hɔl." hɝ smaɪl waɪɾənd wɪθaʊt ɡɹoʊɪŋ ðə slaɪɾəst bɪt wɔɹmɝ. ləleɪn sæt sloʊli, hɝ skaʊl kwaɪɾ oʊpən.

"My sister Lelaine, in her anxiety, has forgotten who has the right to speak first," Romanda cut in smoothly. Her smile managed to make Lelaine appear merry. Still, she took her time adjusting her shawl just as she wanted, a woman with all the time in the world. "I have two questions to call before the Hall, and in the second I will address Lelaine's concerns. Unfortunately for her, my first question concerns Lelaine's own fitness to continue in the Hall." Her smile widened without growing the slightest bit warmer. Lelaine sat slowly, her scowl quite open.

ə kwɛstʃən ʌv wɔɹ kænɑt bi ʃɛlvd," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪn ə kæɹiɪŋ toʊn. "ɪt mʌs bi ænsɝd bɪfɔɹ ɛni kwɛstʃən kɔld æftɝ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ðə lɔ."

A question of war cannot be shelved," Egwene said in a carrying tone. "It must be answered before any question called after it. That is the law."

kwɪk, kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɡlænsɪz pæs bɪtwin sɪɾɝz.

Quick, questioning glances passed between Sitters.

"ɪz ðət soʊ?" dʒɑnjə sɛd faɪnəli. skwɪntɪŋ θɔtfəli, ʃi twɪstəɾ ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ tə ædʒɹɛs ðə wʊmən nɛks tə hɝ. "tɑkimə, jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə ɹɛd, ən aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ jə seɪɪŋ jə hæd ɹɛd ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ. ɪz ðət wʌɾ ɪt sɛz?"

"Is that so?" Janya said finally. Squinting thoughtfully, she twisted on her bench to address the woman next to her. "Takima, you remember everything you read, and I'm sure I remember you saying you had read the Law of War. Is that what it says?"

ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ. ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd sɛn soʊlʒɝz tə ɛni nʌmbɝ ʌv wɔɹz oʊvɝ ðə læs θaʊzən jɪɹz, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ɪn ɹɪspɑns tə ə pli fəɹ hɛlp fɹəm ət lis tu θɹoʊnz, ən ɪɾ ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn ðɛɹ wɔɹ, nɑt ðə taʊɝz. ðə læs taɪm ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf æktʃəli  dɪklɛɹd wɔɹ hæd bɪn əɡɛnst ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. sɪuən sɛd ðət naʊ oʊnli ə fju laɪbɹɛɹiənz nu mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ.

Egwene held her breath. The White Tower had sent soldiers to any number of wars over the last thousand years, but always in response to a plea for help from at least two thrones, and it always had been their war, not the Tower's. The last time the Tower itself actually declared war had been against Artur Hawkwing. Siuan said that now only a few librarians knew much more than that there was a Law of War.

ʃɔɹt, wɪð lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ tə hɝ weɪst ən skɪn ðə kʌlɝ ʌv eɪdʒd aɪvɝi, tɑkimə ɔfən ɹimaɪndəd pipəl ʌv ə bɝd, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn θɔt. naʊ ʃi lʊk laɪk ə bɝd ðət wɑntəd tə teɪk flaɪt, ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn əɹ sit, ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl, ənnɛsəsɛɹəli stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ kæp ə pɝlz ən sæfaɪɝz. "ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, ən klæmpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt.

Short, with long dark hair to her waist and skin the color of aged ivory, Takima often reminded people of a bird, tilting her head in thought. Now she looked like a bird that wanted to take flight, shifting on her seat, adjusting her shawl, unnecessarily straightening her cap of pearls and sapphires. "It is," she said finally, and clamped her mouth shut.

ɛɡwin kwaɪətli stɑɹɾəd bɹiðɪŋ əɡɛn.

Egwene quietly started breathing again.

"ɪt simz," ɹoʊmændə sɛɾ ɪn ə klɪp toʊn, "ðæt sɪuən sɑntʃ əz bɪn titʃɪŋ jə wɛl. mʌðɝ. haʊ spik jə ɪn səpɔɹɾ ə dɪklɛɹɪŋ wɔɹ? ɑn ə wʊmən." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊʃ sʌmθɪŋ dɪsəɡɹiəbəl aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ, ən ʃi dʒɹɑpt ɑntu hɝ sit weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪt tə dɪpɑɹt.

"It seems," Romanda said in a clipped tone, "that Siuan Sanche has been teaching you well. Mother. How speak you in support of declaring war? On a woman." She sounded as if she were trying to push something disagreeable out of her way, and she dropped onto her seat waiting for it to depart.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪʃəsli ɛniweɪ, ən ɹoʊz. ʃi mɛt ðə sɪɾɝz' ɡeɪzəz wʌn baɪ wʌn, lɛvəli, fɝmli. tɑkimə əvɔɪɾəd əɹ aɪz. laɪt, ðə wʊmən nu! bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. wəd ʃi hoʊl saɪlən lɔŋ ɪnʌf? ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ plænz.

Egwene nodded graciously anyway, and rose. She met the Sitters' gazes one by one, levelly, firmly. Takima avoided her eyes. Light, the woman knew! But she had not said anything. Would she hold silent long enough? It was too late to change plans.

"tədeɪ wi faɪn aʊɝsɛlvz kənfɹʌntəd baɪ ən ɑɹmi, lɛd baɪ pipəl u daʊɾ ʌs. ðəɾ ɑɹmi wəd nɑt bi ðəɹ ʌðɝwaɪz." ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə pʊt pæʃən ɪndə hɝ vɔɪs, tə lɛɾ ɪt bɝst aʊt, bʌt sɪuən hæɾ ædvaɪzd ʌɾɝ kulnəs, ən faɪnəli ʃi hæɾ əɡɹid. ðeɪ niɾəd tə si ə wʊmən ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝsɛlf, nɑɾ ə ɡɝl biɪŋ ɹɪɾən baɪ hɝ hɑɹt. ðə wɝdz keɪm fɹəm əɹ hɑɹt, ðoʊ. "ju hɝɾ ɑɝəθɛl seɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bɪkʌm ɛntæŋɡəld ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ əfɛɹz. jɛt ðeɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ ən ɑɹmi ɪndə mʊɹændi ən stæn ɪn əɹ weɪ. kəz ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt sɝɾən u wi ɑɹ, əɹ wʌt wəɹ əbaʊt. dɪɾ ɛni ʌv jə fil ðət ðeɪ tʃɹuli bɪliv jə ɑɹ sɪɾɝz?" mɑlɪnd, ɹaʊnd-feɪst ən fɪɹs-aɪd, ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹinz, ən soʊ dɪd sæliɾə, twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, ðoʊ hɝ dɑɹk feɪs mænədʒ tə haɪɾ ɛni ɪkspɹɛʃən. bɛɹænə, ənʌðɝ sɪɾɝ tʃoʊzən ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, fɹaʊn θɔtfəli. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðə ɹiækʃən tə hɝ əz æmɪɝlɪn; ɪf ðət θɔt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə plæn ɪt.

"Today we find ourselves confronted by an army, led by people who doubt us. That army would not be there otherwise." Egwene wanted to put passion into her voice, to let it burst out, but Siuan had advised utter coolness, and finally she had agreed. They needed to see a woman in control of herself, not a girl being ridden by her heart. The words came from her heart, though. "You heard Arathelle say she did not want to become entangled in Aes Sedai affairs. Yet they were willing to bring an army into Murandy and stand in our way. Because they are not certain who we are, or what we are about. Did any of you feel that they truly believe you are Sitters?" Malind, round-faced and fierce-eyed, shifted on her bench among the Greens, and so did Salita, twitching her yellow-fringed shawl, though her dark face managed to hide any expression. Berana, another Sitter chosen in Salidar, frowned thoughtfully. Egwene did not mention the reaction to her as Amyrlin; if that thought was not already in their heads, she did not want to plant it.

"wiv lɪstəɾ ɪleɪɾəz kɹaɪmz tə kaʊnləs noʊbəlz," ʃi wɛn ɑn. "wiv toʊld əm wi ɪntɛn tə ɹimuv hɝ. bʌt ðeɪ daʊt. ðeɪ θɪŋk ðət meɪbi - meɪbi - wəɹ wʌt wi seɪ. ən meɪbi ðɛɹz ə tʃɹɪk ɪn əɹ wɝdz. pɝhæps wəɹ oʊnli ɪleɪɾəz hænd, wivɪŋ səm ɪlæbɹət skim. daʊt livz pipəl flaʊndɝɪŋ. daʊt ɡeɪv pɛlɪvɑɹ ən ɑɝəθɛl ðə nɝv tə stæn bɪfɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən seɪ, 'ju kænɑt ɡoʊ fɝðɝ.' hu ɛls wɪl stæn ɪn əɹ weɪ, əɹ ɪntɝfɪɹ, kəz ðeɪ ɑɹən sɝɾən, ən ənsɝɾənti lidz əm tə ækt ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə kənfjuʒən? ðɛɹz oʊnli wʌn weɪ fəɹ əs tə dɪspɛl ðɛɹ kənfjuʒən. wɪv ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. wʌns wi dɪklɛɹ aʊɝsɛlvz ət wɔɹ wɪð ɪleɪɾə, ðəɹ kən bi noʊ daʊts. aɪ doʊn seɪ ðəɾ ɑɝəθɛl ən pɛlɪvɑɹ ən æɛmlɪn wɪl mɑɹtʃ əweɪ əz sun əz wi də soʊ, bʌt ðeɪ ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɪl noʊ hu wi ɑɹ. noʊ wʌn wɪl dɛɹ əɡɛn tə ʃoʊ daʊt soʊ oʊpənli wən jə seɪ jə ɑɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. noʊ wʌn wɪl dɛɹ stæn ɪn əɹ weɪ, mɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə ðə taʊɝ θɹu ənsɝɾənti ən ɪɡnɝəns. wɪv wɔk tə ðə dɔɹ ən pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðə lætʃ. ɪf jə ɑɹ əfɹeɪd tə wɔk θɹu, ðən jə ɔl bʌɾ æsk ðə wɝl tə bɪliv ðət jə ɑɹ nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪleɪɾəz pʌpəts."

"We've listed Elaida's crimes to countless nobles," she went on. "We've told them we intend to remove her. But they doubt. They think that maybe - maybe - we are what we say. And maybe there's a trick in our words. Perhaps we are only Elaida's hand, weaving some elaborate scheme. Doubt leaves people floundering.
