Doubt gave Pelivar and Arathelle the nerve to stand before Aes Sedai and say, 'You cannot go further.' Who else will stand in our way, or interfere, because they aren't certain, and uncertainty leads them to act in a cloud of confusion? There's only one way for us to dispel their confusion. We have already done everything else. Once we declare ourselves at war with Elaida, there can be no doubts. I don't say that Arathelle and Pelivar and Aemlyn will march away as soon as we do so, but they and everyone else will know who we are. No one will dare again to show doubt so openly when you say you are the Hall of the Tower. No one will dare stand in our way, meddling in the affairs of the Tower through uncertainty and ignorance. We have walked to the door and put our hands on the latch. If you are afraid to walk through, then you all but ask the world to believe that you are nothing but Elaida's puppets."

ʃi sæt, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kɑm ʃi fɛlt. bɪɑn ðə tu ɹoʊz ə sɪɾɝz, sɪstɝz aʊtsaɪd stɝd, pʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ. ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən ði ɪksaɪɾəd mɝmɝz ðəɾ ələdʒɹɪnz wɔɹd blɑkt ɔf. naʊ ɪf oʊnli tɑkimə kɛpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt lɔŋ ɪnʌf.

She sat, surprised at how calm she felt. Beyond the two rows of Sitters, sisters outside stirred, putting their heads together. She could imagine the excited murmurs that Aledrin's ward blocked off. Now if only Takima kept her mouth shut long enough.

ɹoʊmændə ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli, ən stʊɾ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə seɪ, "hu stænz fəɹ dɪklɛɹɪŋ wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə?" hɝ ɡeɪz ɹɪtɝn tə ləleɪn, ən əɹ koʊld, smʌɡ smaɪl ɹɪtɝnd. ɪt wɑz klɪɹ wʌt ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ɪmpɔɹɾənt, wʌns ðɪs nɑnsɛns wɑz dʌn wɪð.

Romanda grunted impatiently, and stood only long enough to say, "Who stands for declaring war against Elaida?" Her gaze returned to Lelaine, and her cold, smug smile returned. It was clear what she considered important, once this nonsense was done with.

dʒɑnjə ɹoʊz ɪmiɾiətli, ðə lɔŋ bɹaʊn fɹɪnʒ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl sweɪɪŋ. "wi maɪɾ əz wɛl," ʃi sɛd. ʃi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə spik, bʌɾ əɹ sɛt dʒɔ ən ʃɑɹp ɡeɪz dɛɹɾ ɛniwʌn tə kɔl əɹ daʊn. ʃi wɑz nɑt nɔɹməli soʊ fɔɹsfəl, bʌɾ əz juʒəwəl, hɝ wɝdz nɪɹli tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ. "mɛndɪŋ wʌt ðə wɝl noʊz woʊn bi ɛni hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɪts fəɹ ðɪs. wɛl? wɛl? aɪ doʊn si ðə pɔɪn ʌv weɪɾɪŋ." ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə tɑkimə, ɛskɹɑldi nɑɾəd ən stʊd.

Janya rose immediately, the long brown fringe on her shawl swaying. "We might as well," she said. She was not supposed to speak, but her set jaw and sharp gaze dared anyone to call her down. She was not normally so forceful, but as usual, her words nearly tripped over one another. "Mending what the world knows won't be any harder than it is for this. Well? Well? I don't see the point of waiting." On the other side of Takima, Escaralde nodded and stood.

mɔɹiə ɔl bʌt baʊndəd tə hɝ fit, fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət laɪɹɛl, hu ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts əz ɪf tə ɹaɪz, ðən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ən lʊkt ət ləleɪn kwɛstʃənɪŋli. ləleɪn wɑz tu bɪzi fɹaʊnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts ət ɹoʊmændə tə noʊɾəs.

Moria all but bounded to her feet, frowning down at Lyrelle, who gathered her skirts as if to rise, then hesitated and looked at Lelaine questioningly. Lelaine was too busy frowning across the carpets at Romanda to notice.

əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹinz, səmeɪlɪn ən mɑlɪn stʊd təɡɛðɝ, ən feɪsɛl lʊkt ʌp wɪð ə dʒɝk. ə stɑki, kɑpɝ-skɪn dəmɑni, feɪsɛl wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən stɑɹɾəld baɪ mʌtʃ, bʌt ʃi lʊk stɑɹɾəld naʊ, hɝ skwɛɹ feɪs swɪŋɪŋ waɪd-aɪd fɹəm səmeɪlɪn tə mɑlɪn ən bæk.

Among the Greens, Samalin and Malind stood together, and Faiselle looked up with a jerk. A stocky, copper-skinned Domani, Faiselle was not a woman startled by much, but she looked startled now, her square face swinging wide-eyed from Samalin to Malind and back.

sæliɾə ɹoʊz, kɛɹfəli ədʒʌstɪŋ ðə jɛloʊ fɹɪnʒ ə hɝ ʃɔl ən dʒʌst əz kɛɹfəli əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɹoʊmændəz sʌɾən fɹaʊn. kweɪmɛsə stʊd, ən ðən ələdʒɹɪn, dʒɹɔɪŋ bɛɹænə ʌp baɪ hɝ sliv. dɛlænə twɪstəd kəmplitli ɝaʊn ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ, piɹɪŋ ət ðə sɪstɝz aʊtsaɪd. ivən ɪn saɪləns ðə spɛkteɪɾɝz' ɪksaɪtmən kəmjunəkeɪɾɪd ɪtsɛlf ɪn kɑnstənt ʃɪftɪŋ, hɛdz ɡoʊɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾɝz. dɛlænə ɹoʊz sloʊli, boʊθ hænz pɹɛs tə hɝ mɪɾəl, lʊkɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə sɪk ʌp ɑn ðə spɑt. tɑkimə ɡɹɪməst ən stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz. sɛɝɔɪjə stʌɾid ði ʌðɝ tu waɪt sɪɾɝz, tʌɡɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɪɹ ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd wən dip ɪn θɔt. bʌt noʊ wʌn ɛls muv tə stænd.

Salita rose, carefully adjusting the yellow fringe of her shawl and just as carefully avoiding Romanda's sudden frown. Kwamesa stood, and then Aledrin, drawing Berana up by her sleeve. Delana twisted completely around on her bench, peering at the sisters outside. Even in silence the spectators' excitement communicated itself in constant shifting, heads going together, eyes darting toward the Sitters. Delana rose slowly, both hands pressed to her middle, looking ready to sick up on the spot. Takima grimaced and stared at her hands on her knees. Saroiya studied the other two White Sitters, tugging at her ear the way she did when deep in thought. But no one else moved to stand.

ɛɡwin fɛl baɪl ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn əɹ oʊn θɹoʊt. tɛn. dʒʌs tɛn. ʃi hæd bɪn soʊ ʃʊɹ. sɪuən hæd bɪn soʊ ʃʊɹ. lɑɡən əloʊn ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf, ɡɪvən ðɛɹ ɪɡnɝəns ə ðə lɔ ɪnvɑlvd. pɛlɪvɑɹz ɑɹmi ən ɑɝəθɛl ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðət ðeɪ wɝ sɪɾɝz ʃʊɾə pɹaɪmd əm laɪk ə pʌmp.

Egwene felt bile rising in her own throat. Ten. Just ten. She had been so sure. Siuan had been so sure. Logain alone should have been enough, given their ignorance of the law involved. Pelivar's army and Arathelle refusing to admit that they were Sitters should have primed them like a pump.

"fɔɹ ðə lʌv ə ðə laɪt!" mɔɹiə bɝst aʊt. ɹaʊndɪŋ ɑn laɪɹɛl ən ləleɪn, ʃi plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. ɪf dʒɑnjəz spikɪŋ hæd ɡɔn əɡɛns kʌstəm, ðɪs taɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn ə nɑt. dɪspleɪz ʌv æŋɡɝ wɝ stʃɹɪkli fɔɹbɪɾən ɪn ðə hɔl, bʌt mɔɹiəz aɪz bleɪzd, ən əɹ ɪliɑnɝ æksɛnt wɑz θɪk wɪð ɪt. "waɪ dʒju weɪt? ɪleɪɾə dɪd stil ðə stoʊl ən ðə stæf! ɪleɪɾəz ədʒɑ dɪd meɪk lɑɡən ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, ən oʊnli ðə laɪt noʊz haʊ mɛni ʌðɝ mɛn! noʊ wʊmən ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə taʊɝ dɪɾ ɛvɝ dɪzɝv ðɪs dɛklɝeɪʃən mɔɹ! stænd, əɹ hoʊl saɪlən fɹəm naʊ əbaʊt jəɹ ɹizɑlv tə ɹimuv hɝ!"

"For the love of the Light!" Moria burst out. Rounding on Lyrelle and Lelaine, she planted her fists on her hips. If Janya's speaking had gone against custom, this tied it in a knot. Displays of anger were strictly forbidden in the Hall, but Moria's eyes blazed, and her Illianer accent was thick with it. "Why do you wait? Elaida did steal the stole and the staff! Elaida's Ajah did make Logain a false Dragon, and only the Light knows how many other men! No woman in the history of the Tower did ever deserve this declaration more! Stand, or hold silent from now about your resolve to remove her!"

ləleɪn dɪd nɑt kwaɪt stɛɹ, bʌt baɪ hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ʃi hæd faʊn hɝsɛlf ətæk baɪ ə spɛɹoʊ. "ðɪs ɪz hɑɹdli wɝθ ə voʊt, mɔɹiə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "wi wɪl spik leɪɾɝ əbaʊt dɪkɔɹəm, jə ən aɪ. stɪl, ɪf jə niɾ ə dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃən ə ɹizɑlv. . . ." wɪð ə ʃɑɹp snɪf, ʃi ɹoʊz, ən ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk ə hɝ hɛd ðət pʊld laɪɹɛl tə hɝ fit laɪk stʃɹɪŋz. ləleɪn sim sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt pʊl ʌp feɪsɛl ən tɑkimə, tu.

Lelaine did not quite stare, but by her expression you might have thought she had found herself attacked by a sparrow. "This is hardly worth a vote, Moria," she said in a tight voice. "We will speak later about decorum, you and I. Still, if you need a demonstration of resolve. . . ." With a sharp sniff, she rose, and gave a jerk of her head that pulled Lyrelle to her feet like strings. Lelaine seemed surprised that it did not pull up Faiselle and Takima, too.

fɑɹ fɹəm stændɪŋ, tɑkimə ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz ɪf stʃɹʌk. dɪsbɪlif bɹaɪɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs, ʃi ɹæn əɹ aɪz əlɔŋ ðə wɪmən ɑn ðɛɹ fit, ɑbviəsli kaʊntɪŋ. ən ðən dɪɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn. tɑkimə, hu ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə fɝs taɪm.

Far from standing, Takima grunted as if struck. Disbelief bright on her face, she ran her eyes along the women on their feet, obviously counting. And then did it again. Takima, who remembered everything the first time.

ɛɡwin bɹið dip ɪn ɹɪlif. ɪt wɑz dʌn. ʃi kəd hɑɹdli bɪliv. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt, ən ʃɛɹiəm æktʃəli  dʒʌmpt.

Egwene breathed deep in relief. It was done. She could hardly believe. After a moment, she cleared her throat, and Sheriam actually jumped.

ɡɹin aɪz əz bɪɡ əz tikəps, ðə kipɝ klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt, tu. "ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs stændɪŋ, wɔɹ ɪz dɪklɛɹɾ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz nʌn tu stɛɾi, bʌɾ ɪt səfaɪst. "ɪn ði ɪntʃɹəst ə junəɾi, aɪ æsk fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs tə stænd."

Green eyes as big as teacups, the Keeper cleared her throat, too. "The lesser consensus standing, war is declared against Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan." Her voice was none too steady, but it sufficed. "In the interest of unity, I ask for the greater consensus to stand."

feɪsɛl hæf-muvd, ðən klɛntʃt əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp. sɛɝɔɪjə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪt wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, hɝ feɪs tʃɹʌbəld. noʊ wʌn ɛls stɝd.

Faiselle half-moved, then clenched her hands in her lap. Saroiya opened her mouth, then closed it without speaking, her face troubled. No one else stirred.

"ju woʊnt ɡɛɾ ɪt," ɹoʊmændə sɛd flætli. ðə snɪɹ ʃi dɝɛktəɾ əkɹɔs ðə pəvɪljən ət ləleɪn wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz ə steɪtmən ʌv waɪ ʃi, ət list, wəd nɑt stænd. "naʊ ðət lɪɾəl bɪznəs ɪz fɪnɪʃt, wi kən ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð - "

"You won't get it," Romanda said flatly. The sneer she directed across the pavilion at Lelaine was as good as a statement of why she, at least, would not stand. "Now that little business is finished, we can go on with - "

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi kæn," ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪn. "tɑkimə, wʌt dʌz ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ seɪ əbaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit?" ɹoʊmændə wɑz lɛft wɪð əɹ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən.

"I don't think we can," Egwene cut in. "Takima, what does the Law of War say about the Amyrlin Seat?" Romanda was left with her mouth hanging open.

tɑkiməz lɪps ɹɪθd. ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv bɹaʊn lʊk mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ ə bɝd wɪʃɪŋ tə teɪk flaɪt. "ðə lɔ . . . ." ʃi bɪɡæn, ðən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. "ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ steɪts, 'æz wʌn sɛɾ ə hænz mʌst ɡaɪɾ ə sɔɹd, soʊ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ʃæl dɝɛkt ən pɹɑsəkjut ðə wɔɹ baɪ dɪkɹi. ʃi ʃæl sik ði ædvaɪs ə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, bʌt ðə hɔl ʃæl kæɹi aʊɾ əɹ dɪkɹiz wɪð ɔl pɑsəbəl spid, ən fəɹ ðə seɪk ə junəɾi, ðeɪ ʃæl. . . ." ʃi fɔltɝd, ən hæd tə vɪzəbli fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɡoʊ ɑn. ". . . ðeɪ ʃæl ən mʌst əpɹuv ɛni dɪkɹi ʌv ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ pɹɑsəkjuʃən ə ðə wɔɹ wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs."

Takima's lips writhed. The diminutive Brown looked more than ever a bird wishing to take flight. "The Law . . . ." she began, then took a deep breath and sat up straight. "The Law of War states, 'As one set of hands must guide a sword, so the Amyrlin Seat shall direct and prosecute the war by decree. She shall seek the advice of the Hall of the Tower, but the Hall shall carry out her decrees with all possible speed, and for the sake of unity, they shall. . . ." She faltered, and had to visibly force herself to go on. ". . . they shall and must approve any decree of the Amyrlin Seat regarding prosecution of the war with the greater consensus."

ə lɔŋ saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt. ɛvɹi aɪ sim tə bi ɡɑəlɪŋ. tɝnɪŋ əbɹʌpli, dɛlænə vɑməɾəd ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛntʃ. kweɪmɛsə ən sæliɾə boʊθ klaɪm daʊn ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd hɝ, bʌt ʃi weɪvd əm ɔf, plʌkɪŋ ə skɑɹf fɹəm əɹ sliv tə waɪp əɹ maʊθ. mæɡlə ən sɛɝɔɪjə ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz stɪl siɾəd lʊkt əz ðoʊ ðeɪ maɪt fɑloʊ hɝ ɪɡzæmpəl. noʊ ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, ðoʊ. ɹoʊmændə əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə baɪt θɹu ə neɪl.

A long silence stretched. Every eye seemed to be goggling. Turning abruptly, Delana vomited onto the carpets behind her bench. Kwamesa and Salita both climbed down and started toward her, but she waved them off, plucking a scarf from her sleeve to wipe her mouth. Magla and Saroiya and several others still seated looked as though they might follow her example. No others who had been chosen in Salidar, though. Romanda appeared ready to bite through a nail.

"vɛɹi klɛvɝ," ləleɪn sɛɾ ət læst ɪn klɪp toʊnz, ən æftɝ ə dɪlɪbɝɪt pɔz, æɾəd, "mʌðɝ. wɪl jə tɛl əs wʌt ðə ɡɹeɪt wɪzdəm ə jəɹ væst ɪkspɪɹiəns tɛlz jə tə du? əbaʊt ðə wɔɹ, aɪ min. aɪ wɑnə meɪk maɪsɛlf klɪɹ."

"Very clever," Lelaine said at last in clipped tones, and after a deliberate pause, added, "Mother. Will you tell us what the great wisdom of your vast experience tells you to do? About the war, I mean. I want to make myself clear."

"lɛt mi meɪk maɪsɛlf klɪɹ, tu," ɛɡwin sɛd koʊldli. linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ʃi fɪks ðə blu sɪɾɝ stɝnli. "ə sɝɾən dɪɡɹi ʌv ɹɪspɛkt ɪz ɹikwaɪɝd təwɔɹd ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən fɹəm naʊ ɑn, əl əv ɪt, dɔɾɝ. ðɪs ɪz noʊ taɪm fəɹ mi tə hæv tə əntʃɛɹ jə ən neɪm ə pɛnəns." ləleɪnz aɪz kɹɛpt waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ wɪð ʃɑk. hæd ðə wʊmən ɹɪli bɪlivd ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd kəntɪnju əz bɪfɔɹ? əɹ æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ nɑt dɛɹɪŋ tə ʃoʊ mɔɹ ðən ðə taɪniəs bækboʊn, hæd ləleɪn sɪmpli bɪlivd ʃi hæd nʌn? ɛɡwin ɹɪli dɪd nɑt wɑnə əntʃɛɹ hɝ; ðə bluz wəɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli ɹɪtɝn ðə wʊmən, ən ʃi stɪl hæd tə dil wɪð ðə hɔl ɑn mæɾɝz ðət kəd nɑt bi kənvɪnsɪŋli dɪsɡaɪzd əz pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə.

"Let me make myself clear, too," Egwene said coldly. Leaning forward, she fixed the Blue Sitter sternly. "A certain degree of respect is required toward the Amyrlin Seat, and from now on, I will have it, daughter. This is no time for me to have to unchair you and name a penance." Lelaine's eyes crept wider and wider with shock. Had the woman really believed everything would continue as before? Or after so long not daring to show more than the tiniest backbone, had Lelaine simply believed she had none? Egwene really did not want to unchair her; the Blues would almost certainly return the woman, and she still had to deal with the Hall on matters that could not be convincingly disguised as part of the war against Elaida.

fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, ʃi sɔ ə smaɪl pæs əkɹɔs ɹoʊmændəz lɪps ət siɪŋ ləleɪn sɛt daʊn. smɔl pɹɑfəɾ ɪf ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz ɹeɪz ɹoʊmændəz stɑk wɪð ði ʌðɝz. "ðæt hoʊlz fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn, ɹoʊmændə," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf nid bi, tiɑnə kən faɪn tu bɝtʃɪz əz izəli əz wʌn." ɹoʊmændəz smaɪl vænɪʃt əbɹʌpli.

From the corner of her eye, she saw a smile pass across Romanda's lips at seeing Lelaine set down. Small profit if all she did was raise Romanda's stock with the others. "That holds for everyone, Romanda," she said. "If need be, Tiana can find two birches as easily as one." Romanda's smile vanished abruptly.

"ɪf aɪ meɪ spik, mʌðɝ," tɑkimə sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ sloʊli. ʃi ətɛmptəɾ ə smaɪl, bʌt ʃi stɪl lʊk dɪsaɪɾədli ɪl. "aɪ maɪsɛlf θɪŋk juv bɪɡʌn wɛl. ðəɹ meɪ bi bɛnəfɪts tə stɑpɪŋ hɪɹ ə mʌnθ. əɹ lɔŋɡɝ." ɹoʊmændəz hɛd dʒɝkt ɝaʊn tə stɛɹ ət hɝ, bʌt fəɹ wʌns, tɑkimə dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə noʊɾəs. "wɪntɝɪŋ hɪɹ, wi kən əvɔɪd wɝs wɛðɝ fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ, ən ɔlsoʊ plæn kɛɹfəli - "

"If I may speak, Mother," Takima said, rising slowly. She attempted a smile, but she still looked decidedly ill. "I myself think you have begun well. There may be benefits to stopping here a month. Or longer." Romanda's head jerked around to stare at her, but for once, Takima did not appear to notice. "Wintering here, we can avoid worse weather farther north, and also plan carefully - "

"ðɛɹz ən ɛn tə dɪleɪz, dɔɾɝ," ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪn. "noʊ mɔɹ dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ fit." wəd ʃi bi ənʌðɝ dʒɛɹə, əɹ ənʌðɝ ʃaɪn? iðɝ wɑz stɪl pɑsəbəl. "ɪn wʌn mʌnθ, wɪl tʃɹævəl fɹəm hɪɹ." noʊ; ʃi wɑz ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ən wʌtɛvɝ ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz wəd seɪ ʌv əɹ fɔls ən vɝtʃuz, ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu, bʌt ðeɪ wəd bi hɝz, nɑt kɑpiz ə səm ʌðɝ wʊmənz. "ɪn wʌn mʌnθ, wɪl bɪɡɪn ðə sidʒ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"There's an end to delays, daughter," Egwene cut in. "No more dragging our feet." Would she be another Gerra, or another Shein? Either was still possible. "In one month, we will Travel from here." No; she was Egwene al'Vere, and whatever the secret histories would say of her faults and virtues, the Light only knew, but they would be hers, not copies of some other woman's. "In one month, we will begin the siege of Tar Valon."

ðɪs taɪm, ðə saɪləns wɑz bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ðə saʊn ə tɑkimə wipɪŋ.

This time, the silence was broken only by the sound of Takima weeping.


tʃæptɝ twɛnti

ɪndə ændɝ


Into Andor

ɪleɪn hoʊp ðət ðə dʒɝni tə keɪɛmlɪn wəd ɡoʊ smuðli, ən ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ɪt sim tə də soʊ. ʃi θɔt ðəɾ ivən əz ʃi ən eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt sæt boʊn-wɪɹi ən hʌɾəld ɪn ðə ɹæɡz ðət ɹɪmeɪn ə ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ, fɪlθi wɪð dɝɾ ən dʌst ən ðə blʌɾ ə ði ɪnʒɝiz ðeɪ hæd ɹəsivd wən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪksploʊɾəd. ɪn tu wiks ət moʊst, ʃi wəd bi ɹɛɾi tə pɹizɛn əɹ kleɪmz tə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. ðəɹ ɑn ðə hɪltɑp, nɪneɪiv hil ðɛɹ numɝəs hɝts ən spoʊk bɛɹli ə wɝd, sɝɾənli nɑt bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ ðɛm. ʃʊɹli ðət wɑz ə plɛzən saɪn, ɪf ənjuʒəwəl. ɹɪlif ət faɪndɪŋ əm əlaɪv bæɾəld wɝi ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Elayne hoped that the journey to Caemlyn would go smoothly, and in the beginning, it seemed to do so. She thought that even as she and Aviendha and Birgitte sat bone-weary and huddled in the rags that remained of their clothing, filthy with dirt and dust and the blood of the injuries they had received when the gateway exploded. In two weeks at most, she would be ready to present her claims to the Lion Throne. There on the hilltop, Nynaeve Healed their numerous hurts and spoke barely a word, certainly not berating them. Surely that was a pleasant sign, if unusual. Relief at finding them alive battled worry on her face.

lænz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə ɹimuv ðə sintʃæn kɹɔsboʊ boʊl fɹəm bɝdʒɪts θaɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bi hild ə ðət waʊnd, bʌɾ ɔlðoʊ hɝ feɪs dʒɹeɪn ə blʌɾ ən ɪleɪn fɛlt ə stæb ʌv æɡəni θɹu ðə bɑnd, æɡəni ðət meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə kɹaɪ aʊt, hɝ wɔɹɾɝ bɛɹli ɡɹoʊn θɹu hɝ ɡɹɪɾɪd tiθ.

Lan's strength was necessary to remove the Seanchan crossbow bolt from Birgitte's thigh before she could be Healed of that wound, but although her face drained of blood and Elayne felt a stab of agony through the bond, agony that made her want to cry out, her Warder barely groaned through her gritted teeth.

"teɪʃɝ kændɝ," læn mɝmɝd, tɔsɪŋ ðə paɪl-hɛd kwɔɹəl, meɪd tə pʌntʃ θɹu ɑɹmɝ, əsaɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tʃɹu blʌɾ ə kændɝ. bɝdʒɪt blɪŋkt, ən i pɔzd. "fɝɡɪv mi, ɪf aɪ ɛɹd. aɪ əsum fɹəm jəɹ kloʊðz jə wɝ kændɔɹi."

"Tai'shar Kandor," Lan murmured, tossing the pile-head quarrel, made to punch through armor, aside on the ground. True blood of Kandor. Birgitte blinked, and he paused. "Forgive me, if I erred. I assumed from your clothes you were Kandori."

"oʊ, jɛs," bɝdʒɪt bɹiðd. "kændɔɹi." hɝ sɪkli ɡɹɪn maɪɾ əv bɪn fɹəm əɹ ɪnʒɝiz; nɪneɪiv wɑz ɪmpeɪʃənli ʃuɪŋ læn aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ soʊ ʃi kəd leɪ hænz ɑn hɝ. ɪleɪn hoʊp ðə wʊmən nu mɔɹ ə kændɝ ðən ðə neɪm; wən bɝdʒɪt hæd læs bɪn bɔɹn, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ kændɝ. ʃi ʃʊɾə teɪkən ɪɾ əz ən oʊmən.

"Oh, yes," Birgitte breathed. "Kandori." Her sickly grin might have been from her injuries; Nynaeve was impatiently shooing Lan out of the way so she could lay hands on her. Elayne hoped the woman knew more of Kandor than the name; when Birgitte had last been born, there had been no Kandor. She should have taken it as an omen.

fəɹ ðə faɪv maɪlz tə ðə smɔl sleɪt-ɹuf mænɝ haʊs, bɝdʒɪt ɹoʊd bɪhaɪnd nɪneɪiv ɑn ðə læɾɝz staʊt bɹaʊn mɛɹ - neɪm lʌvɝsknət, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz - ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə ɹoʊd lænz tɔl blæk stæljən. ət list, ɪleɪn sæt mændɑɹbz sæɾəl wɪð eɪvinhəz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst waɪl læn lɛd ðə faɪɝi-aɪɾ ænəməl. tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹhɔɹsɪz wɝ əz mʌtʃ wɛpənz əz ə sɔɹd, ən deɪnʒɝəs maʊns fəɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹaɪɾɝz. bi ʃʊɹ ə jɝsɛlf, ɡɝl, lini hæɾ ɔlweɪz toʊl hɝ, bʌt nɑt tu ʃʊɹ, ən ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ. ʃi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪzd ɪvɛns wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ɪn əɹ kəntʃɹoʊl ðən mændɑɹbz ɹeɪnz.

For the five miles to the small slate-roofed manor house, Birgitte rode behind Nynaeve on the latter's stout brown mare - named Loversknot, of all things - and Elayne and Aviendha rode Lan's tall black stallion. At least, Elayne sat Mandarb's saddle with Aviendha's arms around her waist while Lan led the fiery-eyed animal. Trained warhorses were as much weapons as a sword, and dangerous mounts for strange riders. Be sure of yourself, girl, Lini had always told her, but not too sure, and she did try. She should have realized events were no more in her control than Mandarb's reins.

ət ðə θɹi-stɔɹi stoʊn haʊs, mæstɝ hɔɹnwɛl, staʊɾ ən ɡɹeɪhɛɹd, ən mɪstʃɹəs hɔɹnwɛl, slaɪtli lɛs ɹaʊn ən slaɪtli lɛs ɡɹeɪ bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz ɹɪzɛmbəlɪŋ əɹ hʌzbən ɹɪmɑɹkəbli, hæɾ ɛvɹi læs pɝsən u wɝk ði ɪsteɪts, ən mɛɝɪlɪlz meɪd, pɔl, ən ðə ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt lɪvɹid sɝvəns u hæd kʌm fɹəm ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs əz wɛl, ɔl bʌsəlɪŋ tə faɪn slipɪŋ əkɑmədeɪʃənz fəɹ oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd pipəl, moʊst wɪmən, hu hæɾ əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ wɪð dɑɹk nɪɹ tə fɔlɪŋ. ðə wɝk wɛnt wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ swɪfnəs, ɪn spaɪɾ ə ði ɪsteɪts' pipəl stɑpɪŋ tə ɡɔk əɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz eɪdʒləs feɪs, əɹ ə wɔɹɾɝz ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk meɪkɪŋ pɑɹts ə hɪm vænɪʃ, əɹ wʌn ə ðə si foʊk wɪð ɔl ə hɝ bɹaɪt sɪlks, hɝ ɪɹɪŋz ən noʊsɝɪŋ ən mɛdæljən tʃeɪn. kɪnswɪmən wɝ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðət naʊ ɪt wɑz seɪf tə bi fɹaɪɾənd ən kɹaɪ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ɹin ən ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl sɛd tə ðɛm; wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ snɑɹlɪŋ oʊvɝ haʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sɔl ðeɪ hæd kʌm, əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪl əz ɹɪneɪl dɪn kəlɑn laʊdli kleɪmd; ən noʊbəlz ən kɹæftswɪmən u hæd bɪn ɔl tu wɪlɪŋ tə fli wʌtɛvɝ leɪ bæk ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wɪlɪŋ tə kæɹi ðɛɹ bʌndəl pəzɛʃənz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, wɝ naʊ bɔkɪŋ ət biɪŋ ʃoʊn ə heɪlɔft fəɹ ə bɛd.

At the three-story stone house, Master Hornwell, stout and grayhaired, and Mistress Hornwell, slightly less round and slightly less gray but otherwise resembling her husband remarkably, had every last person who worked the estates, and Merilille's maid, Pol, and the green-and-white liveried servants who had come from the Tarasin Palace as well, all bustling to find sleeping accommodations for over two hundred people, most women, who had appeared out of nowhere with dark near to falling. The work went with surprising swiftness, in spite of the estates' people stopping to gawk at an Aes Sedai's ageless face, or a Warder's shifting cloak making parts of him vanish, or one of the Sea Folk with all of her bright silks, her earrings and nosering and medallioned chain. Kinswomen were deciding that now it was safe to be frightened and cry no matter what Reanne and the Knitting Circle said to them; Windfinders were snarling over how far from the salt they had come, against their will as Renaile din Calon loudly claimed; and nobles and craftswomen who had been all too willing to flee whatever lay back in Ebou Dar, willing to carry their bundled possessions on their backs, were now balking at being shown a hayloft for a bed.

ɔl ðət wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wən ɪleɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɝaɪvd wɪð ðə sʌn ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə wɛstɝn hɝaɪzən, ə ɡɹeɪɾ əphivəl ən mɪlɪŋ ɔl əbaʊt ðə haʊs ən θætʃ-ɹuft aʊtbɪldɪŋz, bʌɾ æləz tɛndʒaɪl, smaɪlɪŋ plɛzənli ən ɪmplækəbəl əz ən ævəlæntʃ, sim tə hæv ɛvɹiθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪn hæn ðən ivən ðə keɪpəbəl hɔɹnwɛlz. kɪnswɪmən u wɛp hɑɹɾɝ fəɹ ɔl ə ɹinz ətɛmps ət kʌmfɝt dʒɹaɪd ðɛɹ tɪɹz əɾ ə mɝmɝ fɹəm æləz ən bɪɡæn muvɪŋ wɪð ðə pɝpəsfəl ɛɹ ʌv wɪmən u hæd bɪn kɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ə hɑstəl wɝl fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz. hɔɾi noʊbəlz wɪð mɛɹɪdʒ naɪvz dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪndə ði oʊvəl kʌtaʊts ɪn ðɛɹ leɪs-tʃɹɪm bɑɾɪsɪz ən kɹæftswɪmən u dɪspleɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ ɛɹəɡəns ən nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ bʊzəm, ɪf nɑɾ ɪn sɪlk, flɪntʃt ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv æləz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, ən wɛn skɝiɪŋ fəɹ ðə tɔl bɑɹnz hʌɡɪŋ ðɛɹ bʌndəlz ən ənaʊnsɪŋ laʊdli ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi əmjuzɪŋ tə slip ɑn stʃɹɔ. ivən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, mɛni ʌv əm ɪmpɔɹɾənt ən paʊɝfəl wɪmən əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ, mʌfəl ðɛɹ kəmpleɪns wən æləz keɪm nɪɹ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, sɝaɪðə, stɪl lækɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪɡləsnəs, aɪɾ æləz əskæns ən tʌtʃt əɹ bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl əz ɪf tə ɹimaɪn hɝsɛlf ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. mɛɝɪlɪl - ənflæpəbəl mɛɝɪlɪl - wɑtʃt ðə wʊmən ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɝk wɪð ə blɛn ʌv əpɹuvəl ən oʊpən əmeɪzmənt.

All that was going on when Elayne and the others arrived with the sun red on the western horizon, a great upheaval and milling all about the house and thatch-roofed outbuildings, but Alise Tenjile, smiling pleasantly and implacable as an avalanche, seemed to have everything more in hand than even the capable Hornwells. Kinswomen who wept harder for all of Reanne's attempts at comfort dried their tears at a murmur from Alise and began moving with the purposeful air of women who had been caring for themselves in a hostile world for many years. Haughty nobles with marriage knives dangling into the oval cutouts in their lace-trimmed bodices and craftswomen who displayed almost as much arrogance and nearly as much bosom, if not in silk, flinched at the sight of Alise approaching, and went scurrying for the tall barns hugging their bundles and announcing loudly that they had always thought it might be amusing to sleep on straw. Even the Windfinders, many of them important and powerful women among the Atha'an Miere, muffled their complaints when Alise came near. For that matter, Sareitha, still lacking the Aes Sedai agelessness, eyed Alise askance and touched her brown-fringed shawl as if to remind herself it was there. Merilille - unflappable Merilille - watched the woman go about her work with a blend of approval and open amazement.

klæmbɝɪŋ daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ət ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ ə ðə haʊs, nɪneɪiv ɡlɛɹd təwɔɹɾ æləz, ɡeɪv əɹ dɑɹk bɹeɪd wʌn dɪlɪbɝɪt, mɛʒɝd tʌɡ ðət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz fɑɹ tu bɪzi tə noʊɾəs, ən stɔkt ɪnsaɪd, stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɔf əɹ blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz ən mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊ, læn tʃʌkəl sɔfli, ðən staɪfəld ɪz læftɝ ɪmiɾiətli wən ɪleɪn dɪsmaʊntɪd. laɪt, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ koʊld! fəɹ nɪneɪivz seɪk, ʃi hoʊp ðə mæn kəd bi seɪv fɹəm ɪz feɪt, jɛt lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðoʊz aɪz, ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt.

Clambering down from her saddle at the front door of the house, Nynaeve glared toward Alise, gave her dark braid one deliberate, measured tug that the other woman was far too busy to notice, and stalked inside, stripping off her blue riding gloves and muttering to herself. Watching her go, Lan chuckled softly, then stifled his laughter immediately when Elayne dismounted. Light, but his eyes were cold! For Nynaeve's sake, she hoped the man could be saved from his fate, yet looking into those eyes, she did not believe it.

"wɛɹ ɪz ɪspæn?" ʃi mɝmɝd, hɛlpɪŋ eɪvinhə skɹæmbəl daʊn. soʊ mɛni ʌv ðə wɪmən nu ən ɛɛs sədaɪ - ə blæk sɪstɝ - wɑz biɪŋ hɛl pɹɪznɝ ðət ðə nuz wɑz baʊn tə spɹɛd θɹu ði ɪsteɪts laɪk faɪɝ ɪn dʒɹaɪ ɡɹæs, bʌt bɛɾɝ ɪf ðə mænɝz foʊk hæɾ ə lɪɾəl pɹɛpɝeɪʃən.

"Where is Ispan?" she murmured, helping Aviendha scramble down. So many of the women knew an Aes Sedai - a Black sister - was being held prisoner that the news was bound to spread through the estates like fire in dry grass, but better if the manor's folk had a little preparation.

"æɾɪliz ən vændin tʊk əɹ tə ə smɔl wʊdkəɾɝz hʌɾ əbaʊt hæf ə maɪl əweɪ," hi ɹɪplaɪd dʒʌst əz kwaɪətli. "ɪn ɔl ðɪs, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɛniwʌn noʊɾəst ə wʊmən wɪð ə sæk oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. ðə sɪstɝz sɛd ðeɪ wəd steɪ ðəɹ wɪð əɹ tənaɪt."

"Adeleas and Vandene took her to a small woodcutter's hut about half a mile away," he replied just as quietly. "In all this, I don't think anyone noticed a woman with a sack over her head. The sisters said they would stay there with her tonight."

ɪleɪn ʃɪvɝd. ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɑz tə bi kwɛstʃən əɡɛn wʌns ðə sʌn wɛn daʊn, ɪt simd. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ændɝ, naʊ, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ fil mɔɹ dipli əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ði ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ɪt.

Elayne shivered. The Darkfriend was to be questioned again once the sun went down, it seemed. They were in Andor, now, and that made her feel more deeply as if she had given the order for it.

sun ʃi wɑz ɪn ə kɑpɝ bæθtəb, lʌɡʒʊɹieɪɾɪŋ ɪn pɝfjum soʊp ən klin skɪn əɡɛn, læfɪŋ ən splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ ət bɝdʒɪt, hu lɑld ɪn ənʌðɝ tʌb ɪksɛpt wən ʃi wɑz splæʃɪŋ bæk, boʊθ ə ðɛm ɡɪɡəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɪnsɪŋ hɔɹɝ eɪvinhə kəd nɑt kwaɪt kənsil ət sɪɾɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ bɹɛsts ɪn wɔɾɝ. ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd dʒoʊk ɑn hɝsɛlf, ðoʊ, ən toʊld ə moʊst ɪmpɹɑpɝ stɔɹi əbaʊɾ ə mæn ɡɛɾɪŋ sɛɡeɪd spaɪnz ɪn ɪz bɑɾəm. bɝdʒɪt toʊld wʌn stɪl mɔɹ ɪmpɹɑpɝ, əbaʊɾ ə wʊmən ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ hɛd kɑt bɪtwin ðə slæts ʌv ə fɛns, ðət meɪɾ ivən eɪvinhə blʌʃ. ðeɪ wɝ fʌni, ðoʊ. ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi nu wʌn tə tɛl.

Soon she was in a copper bathtub, luxuriating in perfumed soap and clean skin again, laughing and splashing water at Birgitte, who lolled in another tub except when she was splashing back, both of them giggling over the wincing horror Aviendha could not quite conceal at sitting up to her breasts in water. She thought it was a very good joke on herself, though, and told a most improper story about a man getting segade spines in his bottom. Birgitte told one still more improper, about a woman getting her head caught between the slats of a fence, that made even Aviendha blush. They were funny, though. Elayne wished she knew one to tell.

ʃi ən eɪvinhə koʊmd ən bɹʌʃt itʃ ʌðɝz hɛɹ - ə naɪtli ɹɪtʃuəl fəɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝz - ən ðən ðeɪ snʌɡəl taɪɹədli ɪndə ðə kænəpid bɛɾ ɪn ə smɔl ɹum. ʃi ən eɪvinhə, bɝdʒɪɾ ən nɪneɪiv, ən lʌki ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ. lɑɹdʒɝ ɹumz hæd kɑts ən pæləts kʌvɝɪŋ ðə flɔɹz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹumz, ðə kɪtʃənz, ən moʊst ə ðə hɔlz. nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd hæf ðə naɪɾ əbaʊt ði ɪndisənsi ʌv meɪkɪŋ ə wʊmən slip əpɑɹt fɹəm əɹ hʌzbənd, ən fəɹ ði ʌðɝ hæf, hɝ ɛlboʊz sim tə weɪk ɪleɪn ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi dʒɹɑpt ɔf. bɝdʒɪt flætli ɹəfjuz tə tʃeɪnʒ pleɪsəz, ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ æsk eɪvinhə tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ðə wʊmənz ʃɑɹp pɹɑɾɪŋ, soʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə slip.

She and Aviendha combed and brushed each other's hair - a nightly ritual for near-sisters - and then they snuggled tiredly into the canopied bed in a small room. She and Aviendha, Birgitte and Nynaeve, and lucky there were no more. Larger rooms had cots and pallets covering the floors, including the sitting rooms, the kitchens, and most of the halls. Nynaeve muttered half the night about the indecency of making a woman sleep apart from her husband, and for the other half, her elbows seemed to wake Elayne every time she dropped off. Birgitte flatly refused to change places, and she could not ask Aviendha to endure the woman's sharp prodding, so she did not get a great deal of sleep.

ɪleɪn wɑz stɪl ɡɹɑɡi wən ðeɪ pɹipɛɹd tə dɪpɑɹt ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, wɪð ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ə moʊltən bɔl ʌv ɡoʊld. ðə mænɝ hæd fju ænəməlz tə spɛɹ ənlɛs ʃi stʃɹɪp ði ɪsteɪts bɛɹ, soʊ waɪl ʃi ɹoʊɾ ə blæk ɡɛldɪŋ neɪm faɪɹhɑɹt, ən eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt hæd nu maʊns, ðoʊz u hæd bɪn əfʊt wən ðeɪ flɛd ðə kɪnz fɑɹm ɹɪmeɪn əfʊt. ðəɾ ɪnkluɾəd moʊst ə ðə kɪnswɪmən ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə sɝvəns liɾɪŋ ðə pæk ænəməlz, ən ðə twɛnti-ɑd wɪmən u pleɪnli wɝ bɪɑn ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ vɪzət tə ðə kɪnz fɑɹm ɪn hoʊps ə pis ən kɑntəmpleɪʃən. ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹoʊɾ əhɛd tə skaʊt ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz kʌvɝɾ ɪn dʒɹaʊt-stɑɹv fɔɹəst, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪn ə moʊs pəkjuljɝ sneɪk, wɪð nɪneɪiv ən hɝsɛlf ən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ət ðə hɛd. ən eɪvinhə, ʌv kɔɹs.

Elayne was still groggy when they prepared to depart the next morning, with the rising sun a molten ball of gold. The manor had few animals to spare unless she stripped the estates bare, so while she rode a black gelding named Fireheart, and Aviendha and Birgitte had new mounts, those who had been afoot when they fled the Kin's farm remained afoot. That included most of the Kinswomen themselves, the servants leading the pack animals, and the twenty-odd women who plainly were beyond regretting their visit to the Kin's farm in hopes of peace and contemplation. The Warders rode ahead to scout the way across rolling hills covered in drought-starved forest, and the rest of them stretched out in a most peculiar snake, with Nynaeve and herself and the other sisters at the head. And Aviendha, of course.

ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ə ɡɹup ðət kəɾ ɪskeɪp noʊɾəs, soʊ mɛni wɪmən tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð soʊ fju mɛn fəɹ ɡɑɹdz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən twɛnti dɑɹk wɪndfɪndɝz, ɑkwɝɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən əz bɹaɪɾ əz ɛɡzɑɾɪkli pluməɡd bɝdz, ən eɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, faɪv ə ðɛm ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbli soʊ tə ɛniwʌn u nu wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ. ðoʊ wʌn dɪd ɹaɪd wɪð ə lɛðɝ sæk oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd, ʌv kɔɹs. əz ɪf ðət wəd nɑɾ ətʃɹækt aɪz baɪ ɪtsɛlf. ɪleɪn hæd hoʊp tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ənnoʊɾɪst, bʌt ðət noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim pɑsəbəl. stɪl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəd səspɛk ðət ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən hɝsɛlf, wɑz wʌn ə ðɪs ɡɹup. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ʃi θɔt ðət ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst dɪfəkəlti ðeɪ maɪt feɪs wəd bi sʌmwʌn u əpoʊzd əɹ kleɪmz lɝnɪŋ ə hɝ pɹɛzəns, sɛndɪŋ ɑɹmd mɛn tə tʃɹaɪ teɪkɪŋ əɹ ɪndə kʌstəɾi əntɪl ðə səksɛʃən wɑz sɛɾəld.

It was hardly a group that could escape notice, so many women traveling with so few men for guards, not to mention twenty dark Windfinders, awkward on their horses and as bright as exotically plumaged birds, and eight Aes Sedai, five of them recognizably so to anyone who knew what to look for. Though one did ride with a leather sack over her head, of course. As if that would not attract eyes by itself. Elayne had hoped to reach Caemlyn unnoticed, but that no longer seemed possible. Still, there was no reason that anyone would suspect that the Daughter-Heir, Elayne Trakand herself, was one of this group. In the beginning, she thought that the greatest difficulty they might face would be someone who opposed her claims learning of her presence, sending armed men to try taking her into custody until the succession was settled.

ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi ɪkspɛktəd ðə fɝs tʃɹʌbəl tə kʌm fɹəm ðə fʊtsɔɹ kɹæftswɪmən ən noʊbəlz, pɹaʊd wɪmən ɔl, ən nʌn juz tə tʃɹæmpɪŋ dʌsti hɪlz. ɪspɛʃli sɪns mɛɝɪlɪlz meɪd hæɾ əɹ oʊn plʌmp mɛɹ tə ɹaɪd. ðə fju fɑɹmwaɪvz əmʌŋ əm dɪd nɑt sim tə maɪn tu mʌtʃ, bʌt nɪɹli hæf ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ wɝ wɪmən u pəzɛs lænz ən mænɝz ən pæləsəz, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst cʊɾə əfɔɹɾəd tə baɪ ən ɪsteɪɾ ɪf nɑt tu əɹ θɹi. ðeɪ ɪnkluɾəd tu ɡoʊlsmɪθs, θɹi wivɝz u oʊn oʊvɝ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd lumz bɪtwin ðɛm, ə wʊmən huz mænjəfæktɝiz pɹədust ə tɛnθ ʌv ɔl ðə lækɹwɛɹ ɛbu dɑɹ pɹədust, ən ə bæŋkɝ. ðeɪ wɔkt, ðɛɹ pəzɛʃənz stʃɹæp tə ðɛɹ bæks, waɪl ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɔɹ pæksæɾəlz leɪɾən wɪð fud. ðəɹ wɑz ɹil nid. ɛvɹi læs kɔɪn ɪn ɛvɹiwʌnz pɝs hæd bɪn pul təɡɛðɝ ən ɡɪvən ɪndə nɪneɪivz taɪtfɪstɪd kipɪŋ, bʌɾ ɔl maɪt nɑt bi səfɪʃən tə baɪ fud, fɑɾɝ ən lɑdʒɪŋz fəɹ soʊ lɑɹdʒ ə pɑɹɾi ɔl ðə weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə ʌndɝstænd. ðeɪ kəmpleɪn laʊdli ən ɪnsɛsənli θɹu ðə fɝs deɪz mɑɹtʃ. laʊɾəst ʌv ɔl wɑz ə slɪm leɪɾi wɪð ə θɪn skɑɹ ɑn wʌn tʃik, ə stɝn-feɪst wʊmən neɪmd mɑliən, hu wɑz nɪɹli bɛn dʌbəl ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ʌv ə hjudʒ bʌndəl kənteɪnɪŋ ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ dʒɹɛsəz ən ɔl ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ðət wɛnt wɪð ðɛm.

In truth, she expected the first trouble to come from the footsore craftswomen and nobles, proud women all, and none used to tramping dusty hills. Especially since Merilille's maid had her own plump mare to ride. The few farmwives among them did not seem to mind too much, but nearly half their number were women who possessed lands and manors and palaces, and most of the rest could have afforded to buy an estate if not two or three. They included two goldsmiths, three weavers who owned over four hundred looms between them, a woman whose manufactories produced a tenth of all the lacquerware Ebou Dar produced, and a banker. They walked, their possessions strapped to their backs, while their horses bore packsaddles laden with food. There was real need. Every last coin in everyone's purse had been pooled together and given into Nynaeve's tightfisted keeping, but all might not be sufficient to buy food, fodder and lodgings for so large a party all the way to Caemlyn. They did not seem to understand. They complained loudly and incessantly through the first day's march. Loudest of all was a slim lady with a thin scar on one cheek, a stern-faced woman named Malien, who was nearly bent double under the weight of a huge bundle containing a dozen or more dresses and all the changes that went with them.

wən ðeɪ meɪd kæmp ðət fɝs naɪt, wɪð ðɛɹ kʊk faɪɝz ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪɾ ən ɛvɹiwʌn fʊl ə binz ən bɹɛɾ ɪf nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðɛm, mɑliən ɡæðɝd ðə noʊbəlwɪmən ɝaʊn hɝ, ðɛɹ sɪlks mɔɹ ðən tʃɹævəl-steɪnd. ðə kɹæftswɪmən dʒɔɪn ɪn, tu, ən ðə bæŋkɝ, ən ðə fɑɹmɝz stʊd kloʊs. bɪfɔɹ mɑliən kəd seɪ ə wɝd, ɹin stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɡɹup. hɝ feɪs fʊl ə smaɪl laɪnz, ɪn pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊlənz wɪð əɹ skɝts soʊn ʌp ɑn ðə lɛf tə ɪkspoʊz bɹaɪt leɪɝd pɛɾikoʊts, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɑɹm wɪmən.

When they made camp that first night, with their cook fires glowing in the twilight and everyone full of beans and bread if not entirely satisfied with them, Malien gathered the noblewomen around her, their silks more than travel-stained. The craftswomen joined in, too, and the banker, and the farmers stood close. Before Malien could say a word, Reanne strode into the group. Her face full of smile lines, in plain brown woolens with her skirts sewn up on the left to expose bright layered petticoats, she might have been one of the farm women.

"ɪf jə wɪʃ tə ɡoʊ hoʊm," ʃi ənaʊnst ɪn ðət sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli haɪ vɔɪs, "ju meɪ də soʊ əɾ ɛni taɪm. aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðət wi mʌs kip jəɹ hɔɹsəz, ðoʊ. jəl bi peɪd fəɹ əm əz sun əz kən bi ɝeɪnʒd. ɪf jə tʃuz tə ɹɪmeɪn, pliz ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ðə ɹulz ə ðə fɑɹm stɪl əplaɪ." ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə wɪmən ɝaʊn əɹ ɡeɪpt. mɑliən wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn ɪn oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli.

"If you wish to go home," she announced in that surprisingly high voice, "you may do so at any time. I regret that we must keep your horses, though. You will be paid for them as soon as can be arranged. If you choose to remain, please remember that the rules of the farm still apply." A number of the women around her gaped. Malien was not alone in opening her mouth angrily.

æləz dʒʌst sim tə əpɪɹ ət ɹinz saɪd, fɪsts plæntəɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps. ʃi wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ naʊ. "aɪ sɛd ðə læs tɛn tə bi ɹɛɾi wəd də ðə wɑʃɪŋ ʌp," ʃi toʊld əm fɝmli. ən ʃi neɪmd əm ɔf; dʒɪliən, ə plʌmp ɡoʊldsmɪθ; neɪsɛl, ðə kul-aɪd bæŋkɝ; ən ɔl eɪɾ ə ðə noʊbəlz. ðeɪ stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ əntɪl ʃi klæpt əɹ hænz ən sɛd, "doʊn meɪk mi ɪnvoʊk ðə ɹul ɑn feɪljɝ tə də jəɹ ʃɛɹ ə ðə tʃɔɹz."

Alise just seemed to appear at Reanne's side, fists planted on her hips. She was not smiling now. "I said the last ten to be ready would do the washing up," she told them firmly. And she named them off; Jillien, a plump goldsmith; Naiselle, the cool-eyed banker; and all eight of the nobles. They stood staring at her until she clapped her hands and said, "Don't make me invoke the rule on failure to do your share of the chores."

mɑliən, waɪd-aɪɾ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn dɪsbɪlif, wɑz ðə læs tə dɑɹɾ ɔf ən bɪɡɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ dɝɾi boʊlz, bʌt ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ ʃi pɛɹɾ əɹ bʌndəl daʊn, livɪŋ leɪs-tʃɹɪm sɪlk dʒɹɛsəz ən ʃɪfs tə bi tʃɹæmpəld ɑn ðə hɪlsaɪɾ əz ðeɪ dɪpɑɹɾəd. ɪleɪn kəntɪnjud tə ɪkspɛkt ən ɪksploʊʒən, bʌt ɹin kɛpt ə fɝm hæn ɑn ðɛm, æləz kɛpt ə fɝmɝ, ən ɪf mɑliən ən ði ʌðɝz ɡlɛɹɾ ən mʌɾɝd oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹis steɪnz ðət ɡɹu ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊðz deɪ baɪ deɪ, ɹin hæɾ oʊnli tə spik ə fju wɝdz tə sɛn əm tə ðɛɹ wɝk. æləz oʊnli hæd tə klæp əɹ hænz.

Malien, wide-eyed and muttering in disbelief, was the last to dart off and begin gathering dirty bowls, but the next morning she pared her bundle down, leaving lace-trimmed silk dresses and shifts to be trampled on the hillside as they departed. Elayne continued to expect an explosion, but Reanne kept a firm hand on them, Alise kept a firmer, and if Malien and the others glared and muttered over the grease stains that grew on their clothes day by day, Reanne had only to speak a few words to send them to their work. Alise only had to clap her hands.

ɪf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dʒɝni cʊɾə ɡɔn əz smuðli, ɪleɪn wʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðoʊz wɪmən ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹisi leɪbɝz. lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn, ʃi nu ðət fəɹ ə fækt.

If the rest of the journey could have gone as smoothly, Elayne would have been willing to join those women in their greasy labors. Long before reaching Caemlyn, she knew that for a fact.

wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɝs nɛɹoʊ dʌsti ɹoʊd, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən kɑɹt tʃɹæk, fɑɹmz bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ, θætʃt stoʊn haʊsəz ən bɑɹnz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə hɪlsaɪdz əɹ nɛsəld ɪn hɑloʊz. fɹəm ðən ɑn, wɛðɝ ðə lænd wɑz hɪli əɹ flæt, fɔɹəstəɾ əɹ klɪɹd, ðeɪ ɹɛɹli spɛn mɛni aʊɝz bɪɑn saɪɾ ʌv ə fɑɹm əɹ ə vɪlədʒ. əɾ itʃ ə ðoʊz, waɪl ðə loʊkəl foʊk ɡɑɡəld ət ðə vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd tə lɝn haʊ mʌtʃ səpɔɹt haʊs tʃɹəkən hæd, ən wʌt kənsɝn ðə pipəl moʊst. ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ðoʊz kənsɝnz wəd bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn meɪkɪŋ əɹ kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stænd, əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz ðə bækɪŋ ʌv ʌðɝ haʊsəz. ʃi hɝɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil, ɪf nɑɾ ɔlweɪz wʌt ʃi wɪʃt tə hɪɹ. ændɔɹənz kleɪm ðə ɹaɪt tə spik ðɛɹ maɪnz tə ðə kwin hɝsɛlf; ðeɪ wɝ hɑɹdli ʃaɪ wɪð ə jʌŋ noʊbəlwʊmən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ pəkjuljɝ əɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz.

Once they reached the first narrow dusty road, little more than cart track, farms began to appear, thatched stone houses and barns clinging to the hillsides or nestled in hollows. From then on, whether the land was hilly or flat, forested or cleared, they rarely spent many hours beyond sight of a farm or a village. At each of those, while the local folk goggled at the very strange strangers, Elayne tried to learn how much support House Trakand had, and what concerned the people most. Addressing those concerns would be important in making her claim to the throne strong enough to stand, as important as the backing of other Houses. She heard a great deal, if not always what she wished to hear. Andorans claimed the right to speak their minds to the Queen herself; they were hardly shy with a young noblewoman, no matter how peculiar her traveling companions.

ɪn ə vɪlədʒ kɔl deɪməliən, wɛɹ θɹi mɪlz sæt bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl ɹɪvɝ ʃɹʌŋkən tə liv ðɛɹ tɔl wɔɾɝ-wilz dʒɹaɪ, ðə skwɛɹ-dʒɔɾ ɪnkipɝ ət ðə ɡoʊldən ʃivz əlaʊɾ əz haʊ hi θɔt mɔɹɡeɪs hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd kwin, ðə bɛs ðət kəd bi, ðə bɛs ðəɾ ɛvɝ wɑz. "hɝ dɔɾɝ maɪɾəv bɪn ə ɡʊd ɹulɝ, tu, aɪ səpoʊz," hi mʌɾɝd, θʌmɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn. "pɪɾi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kɪl ðɛm. aɪ səpoʊz i hæd tə - ðə pɹɑfəsiz əɹ səm sətʃ - bʌɾ i hæd noʊ kɔl tə dʒɹaɪ ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝz, naʊ dɪd hi? haʊ mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪn dɪd jə seɪ jəɹ hɔɹsəz nid, maɪ leɪɾi? ɪts dʒɹɛdfəl dɪɹ, maɪnd."

In a village called Damelien, where three mills sat beside a small river shrunken to leave their tall water-wheels dry, the square-jawed innkeeper at The Golden Sheaves allowed as how he thought Morgase had been a good queen, the best that could be, the best that ever was. "Her daughter might've been a good ruler, too, I suppose," he muttered, thumbing his chin. "Pity the Dragon Reborn killed them. I suppose he had to - the Prophecies or some such - but he had no call to dry up the rivers, now did he? How much grain did you say your horses need, my lady? It's dreadful dear, mind."

ə hɑɹd-feɪst wʊmən, ɪn ə wɔɹn bɹaʊn dʒɹɛs ðət hʌŋ ɑn əɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæd lɔst weɪt, sɝveɪɾ ə fil sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə loʊ stoʊn wɔl, wɛɹ ðə hɑt wɪn sɛnt ʃits ə dʌs mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə wʊdz. ði ʌðɝ fɑɹmz ɝaʊn bɛɹihɪl lʊkt əz bæɾ əɹ wɝs. "ðæt dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz ɡɑt noʊ ɹaɪt tə də ðɪs tə ʌs, naʊ hæz hi? aɪ æsk ju!" ʃi spæɾ ən fɹaʊn ʌp əɾ ɪleɪn ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. "ðə θɹoʊn? oʊ, daɪɛlɪnz əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛni, naʊ mɔɹɡeɪs ən əɹ ɡɝl ɑɹ dɛd. səm ɝaʊn hɪɹ stɪl spik ʌp fəɹ nɑiən əɹ ɛləniə, bʌɾ aɪm fəɹ daɪɛlɪn. ɛni lʊkaʊt, keɪɛmlɪnz ə lɔŋ weɪ ɔf. aɪv ɡɑt kɹɑps tə wɝi əbaʊt. ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ meɪk ənʌðɝ kɹɑp."

A hard-faced woman, in a worn brown dress that hung on her as if she had lost weight, surveyed a field surrounded by a low stone wall, where the hot wind sent sheets of dust marching into the woods. The other farms around Buryhill looked as bad or worse. "That Dragon Reborn's got no right to do this to us, now has he? I ask you!" She spat and frowned up at Elayne in her saddle. "The throne? Oh, Dyelin's as good as any, now Morgase and her girl are dead. Some around here still speak up for Naean or Elenia, but I'm for Dyelin. Any lookout, Caemlyn's a long way off. I've got crops to worry about. If I ever make another crop."

"oʊ, ɪts tʃɹu, maɪ leɪɾi, soʊ ɪɾ ɪz; ɪleɪnz əlaɪv," ə nɑɹld oʊl kɑɹpəntɝ toʊld əɹ ɪn fɔɹəl mɑɹkət. hi wɑz bɔld əz ə lɛðɝ ɛɡ, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz twɪstəd wɪð eɪdʒ, bʌt ðə wɝk stændɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪvɪŋz ən sɔdʌs ðət lɪɾɝd ɪz ʃɑp lʊkt əz faɪn əz ɛni ɪleɪn hæd sin. ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli pɝsən ɪn ðə ʃɑp bɪsaɪdz hɪm. fɹəm ðə lʊk ə ðə vɪlədʒ, hæf ðə ɹɛzəɾənts hæd lɛft. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz hævɪŋ əɹ bɹɔt tə keɪɛmlɪn soʊ hi kən pʊt ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ɑn əɹ hɛd hɪmsɛlf," hi əlaʊd. "ðə nuz ɪz ɔl oʊvɝ. 'tɪsn ɹaɪt, ɪf jə æsk mi. hiz wʌn ə ðɛm blæk-aɪɾ ilmɛn, aɪ hɪɹ. wi ɔt tə mɑɹtʃ ɑn keɪɛmlɪn ən dʒɹaɪv ɪm ən ɔl əm il bæk wɛɹ ðeɪ kʌm fɹʌm. ðən ɪleɪn kən kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn əɹ oʊn sɛlf. ɪf daɪɛlɪn lɛts əɹ kip ɪt, ɛniweɪ."

"Oh, it's true, my lady, so it is; Elayne's alive," a gnarled old carpenter told her in Forel Market. He was bald as a leather egg, his fingers twisted with age, but the work standing among the shavings and sawdust that littered his shop looked as fine as any Elayne had seen. She was the only person in the shop besides him. From the look of the village, half the residents had left. "The Dragon Reborn is having her brought to Caemlyn so he can put the Rose Crown on her head himself," he allowed. "The news is all over. 'Tisn't right, if you ask me. He's one of them black-eyed Aielmen, I hear. We ought to march on Caemlyn and drive him and all them Aiel back where they come from. Then Elayne can claim the throne her own self. If Dyelin lets her keep it, anyway."

ɪleɪn hɝɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil əbaʊt ɹænd, ɹumɝz ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm ɪm swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti tə ɪleɪɾə tə hɪm biɪŋ ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. ɪn ændɝ, hi wɑz bleɪm fəɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bæd ðət hæpən fəɹ ðə læs tu əɹ θɹi jɪɹz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ stɪlbɝθs ən bɹoʊkən lɛɡz, ɪnfɛsteɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹæshɑpɝz, tu-hɛɾəd kævz, ən θɹi-lɛɡəd tʃɪkənz. ən ivən pipəl u θɔɾ əɹ mʌðɝ hæd ɹuən ðə kʌntʃɹi ən ən ɛn tə ðə ɹeɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd wɑz ɡʊd ɹɪɾəns stɪl bɪlivd ɹænd ælθɹ ən ɪnveɪɾɝ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz səpoʊz tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, ən i ʃəd bi dʒɹɪvən aʊɾ ʌv ændɝ. nɑt wʌt ʃi hæd hoʊp tə hɪɹ, nɑɾ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪt. bʌt ʃi hɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzən dʒɝni əɾ ɔl. ɪt wɑz wʌn lɔŋ lɛsən ɪn wʌn ə liniz feɪvɹɪt seɪɪŋz. ɪɾ ɪzən ðə stoʊn jə si ðət tʃɹɪps jə ɑn jəɹ noʊz.

Elayne heard a great deal about Rand, rumors ranging from him swearing fealty to Elaida to him being the King of Illian, of all things. In Andor, he was blamed for everything bad that happened for the last two or three years, including stillbirths and broken legs, infestations of grasshoppers, two-headed calves, and three-legged chickens. And even people who thought her mother had ruined the country and an end to the reign of House Trakand was good riddance still believed Rand al'Thor an invader. The Dragon Reborn was supposed to fight the Dark One at Shayol Ghul, and he should be driven out of Andor. Not what she had hoped to hear, not a bit of it. But she heard it all again and again. It was not a pleasant journey at all. It was one long lesson in one of Lini's favorite sayings. It isn't the stone you see that trips you on your nose.

ʃi θɔɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə θɪŋz bɪsaɪd ðə noʊbəlz maɪt kɑz tʃɹʌbəl, səm ʃʊɹ tə bi ɪksploʊʒənz əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, smʌɡ ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən meɪd wɪð nɪneɪiv ən hɝsɛlf, bɪheɪvd ɪn ən ɪɹɪteɪɾɪŋli supɪɹiɝ mænɝ təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪspɛʃli æftɝ ɪt keɪm aʊt ðət mɛɝɪlɪl hæd lɛt hɝsɛlf əɡɹi tə bi wʌn ə ðə fɝst sɪstɝz tə ɡoʊ ɑn ðə ʃɪps. jɛɾ ɪf ðə sɪzəlɪŋ ðəɹ kəntɪnjud laɪk ðə bɝnɪŋ ʌv ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz fjuz-kɔɹd, ði ɪksploʊʒən nɛvɝ kwaɪt keɪm. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ən ðə kɪnswɪmən, ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, simd əz sɝɾən tə bloʊ ʌp. ðeɪ kʌt wʌn ənʌðɝ dɛd wən nɑt snɪɹɪŋ oʊpənli, ðə kɪn ət "si foʊk waɪldɝz ɡɛɾɪŋ əbʌv ðɛmsɛlvz," ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ət "kɹɪŋɪŋ sændlæpɝz kɪsɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ fit." bʌɾ ɪt nɛvɝ wɛn bɪɑn lɪps kɝld əɹ dæɡɝz kɝɛst.

She thought a number of things beside the nobles might cause trouble, some sure to be explosions as great as the gateway. The Windfinders, smug in the bargain made with Nynaeve and herself, behaved in an irritatingly superior manner toward the Aes Sedai, especially after it came out that Merilille had let herself agree to be one of the first sisters to go on the ships. Yet if the sizzling there continued like the burning of an Illuminator's fuse-cord, the explosion never quite came. The Windfinders and the Kinswomen, in particular the Knitting Circle, seemed as certain to blow up. They cut one another dead when not sneering openly, the Kin at "Sea Folk wilders getting above themselves," the Windfinders at "cringing sandlappers kissing Aes Sedai feet." But it never went beyond lips curled or daggers caressed.

ɪspæn sɝɾənli pɹizɛntəd pɹɑbləmz ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ wəd ɡɹoʊ, jɛɾ æftɝ ə fju deɪz, vændin ən æɾɪliz lɛɾ əɹ ɹaɪɾ ənhʊɾɪd ɪf nɑɾ ənʃildɪd, ə saɪlən fɪɡjɝ wɪð kʌlɝd bidz ɪn əɹ θɪn bɹeɪdz, eɪdʒləs feɪs tɝn daʊn ən hænz stɪl ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz. ɹɪneɪl toʊld ɛvɹiwʌn u wəd lɪsən ðəɾ əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɑz stʃɹɪpt ə hɪz əɹ əɹ neɪmz əz sun əz pɹuvən ɡɪlti, ðən θɹoʊn oʊvɝ ðə saɪd taɪd tə bæləst stoʊnz. əmʌŋ ðə kɪnswɪmən, ivən ɹin ən æləz peɪld ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ sɔ ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən. bʌɾ ɪspæn ɡɹu mikɝ ən mikɝ, iɡɝ tə pliz ən fʊl ʌv ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪlz fəɹ ðə tu waɪt-hɛɹd sɪstɝz noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðeɪ dɪd tə hɝ wən ðeɪ kæɹiɾ əɹ əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ət naɪt. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, æɾɪliz ən vændin ɡɹu mɔɹ ən mɔɹ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd. æɾɪliz toʊl nɪneɪiv ɪn ɪleɪnz hɪɹɪŋ ðət ðə wʊmən spɪld aʊt vɑljumz əbaʊɾ oʊl plɑts ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ðoʊz ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɪnvɑlvd ɪn mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪnθuziæstɪkli ðən ðoʊz ʃi wɑz, jɛɾ ivən wən ðeɪ pɹɛst əɹ hɑɹd - ɪleɪn kəd nɑt kwaɪt meɪk hɝsɛlf æsk haʊ ðeɪ pɹɛst - ən ʃi lɛt slɪp ðə neɪmz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, moʊst wɝ sɝɾənli dɛɾ ən nʌn wɑz ə sɪstɝ. vændin sɛd ðeɪ wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɪɹ ʃi hæd teɪkən ən oʊθ - ðə kæpəɾəl wɑz ɑɾəbəl - əɡɛns bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ əɹ koʊhɔɹts. ðeɪ kəntɪnjud tə aɪsəleɪɾ ɪspæn əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl ən kəntɪnjud wɪð ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðeɪ wɝ filɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ blaɪnli, naʊ, ən kɛɹfəli.

Ispan certainly presented problems that Elayne was sure would grow, yet after a few days, Vandene and Adeleas let her ride unhooded if not unshielded, a silent figure with colored beads in her thin braids, ageless face turned down and hands still on her reins. Renaile told everyone who would listen that among the Atha'an Miere, a Darkfriend was stripped of his or her names as soon as proven guilty, then thrown over the side tied to ballast stones. Among the Kinswomen, even Reanne and Alise paled every time they saw the Taraboner woman. But Ispan grew meeker and meeker, eager to please and full of ingratiating smiles for the two white-haired sisters no matter what it was they did to her when they carried her away from the others at night. On the other hand, Adeleas and Vandene grew more and more frustrated. Adeleas told Nynaeve in Elayne's hearing that the woman spilled out volumes about old plots of the Black Ajah, those she had not been involved in much more enthusiastically than those she was, yet even when they pressed her hard - Elayne could not quite make herself ask how they pressed - and she let slip the names of Darkfriends, most were certainly dead and none was a sister. Vandene said they were beginning to fear she had taken an Oath - the capital was audible - against betraying her cohorts. They continued to isolate Ispan as much as possible and continued with their questions, but it was plain they were feeling their way blindly, now, and carefully.

ən ðəɹ wɑz nɪneɪiv, ən læn. moʊs dɛfənətli nɪneɪiv ən læn, wɪð əɹ nɪɹ tə bɝstɪŋ ət ði ɛfɝɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ əɹ tɛmpɝ ɝaʊn hɪm, munɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪm wən ðeɪ hæd tə slip əpɑɹt - wɪtʃ wɑz nɪɹli ɔlweɪz, ðə weɪ əkɑmədeɪʃənz dɪvaɪɾəd ʌp - ən tɔɹn bɪtwin iɡɝ ən əfɹeɪd wən ʃi kəd snik ɪm ɔf tə ə heɪlɔft. ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊn fɔl fəɹ tʃuzɪŋ ə si foʊk wɛɾɪŋ, ɪn ɪleɪnz ɛstəmeɪʃən. ðə si foʊk bɪlivd ɪn haɪɝɑɹki əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪn ðə si, ən ðeɪ nu ə wʊmən ən əɹ hʌzbən maɪt bi pɹəmoʊɾəd wʌn pæs ði ʌðɝ mɛni taɪmz ɪn ðɛɹ lɪvz. ðɛɹ mɛɹɪdʒ ɹaɪts tʊk ðəɾ ɪndə əkaʊnt. huɛvɝ hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə kəmæn ɪn pʌblɪk, mʌst oʊbeɪ ɪn pɹaɪvət. læn nɛvɝ tʊk ædvæntɪdʒ, soʊ nɪneɪiv sɛd - "nɑt ɹɪli," wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min! ʃi ɔlweɪz blʌʃt wən ʃi sɛɾ ɪt - bʌt ʃi kɛpt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə də soʊ, ən i dʒʌst sim tə ɡɹoʊ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ əmjuzd. ðɪs əmjuzmənt, ʌv kɔɹs, skɹud nɪneɪivz tɛmpɝ tə ə fivɝ pɪtʃ. nɪneɪiv dɪɾ ɪɹʌpt, aʊɾ ʌv ɔl ði ɪksploʊʒənz ɪleɪn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. ʃi snæpt əɾ ɛniwʌn ən ɛvɹiwʌn u ɡɑɾ ɪn əɹ weɪ. ɪksɛpt ət læn; wɪð hɪm, ʃi wɑz ɔl hʌni ən kɹim. ən nɑɾ əɾ æləz. ʃi keɪm kloʊs wʌns əɹ twaɪs, bʌɾ ivən nɪneɪiv kəd nɑt sim tə meɪk hɝsɛlf snæp əɾ æləz.

And there was Nynaeve, and Lan. Most definitely Nynaeve and Lan, with her near to bursting at the effort of holding her temper around him, mooning over him when they had to sleep apart - which was nearly always, the way accommodations divided up - and torn between eager and afraid when she could sneak him off to a hayloft. It was her own fault for choosing a Sea Folk wedding, in Elayne's estimation. The Sea Folk believed in hierarchy as they did in the sea, and they knew a woman and her husband might be promoted one past the other many times in their lives. Their marriage rites took that into account. Whoever had the right to command in public, must obey in private. Lan never took advantage, so Nynaeve said - "not really," whatever that was supposed to mean! She always blushed when she said it - but she kept waiting for him to do so, and he just seemed to grow more and more amused. This amusement, of course, screwed Nynaeve's temper to a fever pitch. Nynaeve did erupt, out of all the explosions Elayne had expected. She snapped at anyone and everyone who got in her way. Except at Lan; with him, she was all honey and cream. And not at Alise. She came close once or twice, but even Nynaeve could not seem to make herself snap at Alise.

ɪleɪn hæd hoʊps, nɑt wɝiz, əbaʊt ðə θɪŋz bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹæhəɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz. eɪvinhə hɛlpt əɹ sɝtʃ, ən soʊ dɪd nɪneɪiv wʌns əɹ twaɪs, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɪntaɪɝli tu sloʊ ən dʒɪnʒɝ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ən ʃoʊd lɪɾəl skɪl ət faɪndɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ. ðeɪ faʊnd noʊ mɔɹ æŋɡɹil, jɛt ðə kəlɛkʃən ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɡɹu; wʌns ɔl ðə ɹʌbɪʃ hæd bɪn θɹoʊn əweɪ, ɑbʒɛkts ðət juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɪl faɪv ɪntaɪɝ pænɪɝz ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz.

Elayne had hopes, not worries, about the things brought out of the Rahad along with the Bowl of the Winds. Aviendha helped her search, and so did Nynaeve once or twice, but she was entirely too slow and ginger about it and showed little skill at finding what they were searching for. They found no more angreal, yet the collection of ter'angreal grew; once all the rubbish had been thrown away, objects that used the One Power filled five entire panniers on the packhorses.

kɛɹfəl əz ɪleɪn wɑz, ðoʊ, hɝ ətɛmps tə stʌɾi ðɛm dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ soʊ wɛl. spɪɹət wɑz ðə seɪfəst ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz tə juz ɪn ðɪs - ənlɛs, ʌv kɔɹs, spɪɹət hæpən tə bi wʌt tʃɹɪɡɝd ðə θɪŋ! - jɛɾ ət taɪmz ʃi hæd tə juz ʌðɝ floʊz, əz faɪn əz ʃi kəd wiv. səmtaɪmz əɹ dɛləkət pɹoʊbɪŋ dɪd nʌθɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ fɝs tʌtʃ ət ðə θɪŋ ðət lʊk laɪk ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl meɪɾ ʌv ɡlæs lɛft əɹ dɪzi ən əneɪbəl tə slip fəɹ hæf ðə naɪt, ən ə θɹɛɾ ə faɪɝ tʌtʃɪŋ wʌt lʊk laɪk ə hɛlmət meɪɾ ə flʌfi mɛɾəl fɛðɝz ɡeɪv ɛvɹiwʌn wɪðɪn twɛnti peɪsɪz ə blaɪndɪŋ hɛdeɪk. ɪksɛp fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ən ðən ðəɹ wɑz ðə kɹɪmzən ɹɑd ðət fɛl hɑt; hɑt, ɪn ə weɪ.

Careful as Elayne was, though, her attempts to study them did not go so well. Spirit was the safest of the Five Powers to use in this - unless, of course, Spirit happened to be what triggered the thing! - yet at times she had to use other flows, as fine as she could weave. Sometimes her delicate probing did nothing, but her first touch at the thing that looked like a blacksmith's puzzle made of glass left her dizzy and unable to sleep for half the night, and a thread of Fire touching what looked like a helmet made of fluffy metal feathers gave everyone within twenty paces a blinding headache. Except for herself. And then there was the crimson rod that felt hot; hot, in a way.

sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ bɛɾ əɾ ən ɪn kɔl ðə waɪl bɔɹ, ʃi ɪɡzæmən ðə smuð ɹɑd baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə tu pɑlɪʃt bɹæs læmps. ɹɪst-θɪk ən ə fʊt lɔŋ, ɪt lʊk laɪk stoʊn, bʌt fɛl fɝm ɹæðɝ ðən hɑɹd. ʃi wɑz əloʊn; sɪns ðə hɛlmət, ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə də hɝ stʌɾiɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz. ðə hiɾ ə ðə ɹɑd meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə faɪɝ. . . .

Sitting on the edge of her bed at an inn called The Wild Boar, she examined the smooth rod by the light of two polished brass lamps. Wrist-thick and a foot long, it looked like stone, but felt firm rather than hard. She was alone; since the helmet, she had tried to do her studying away from the others. The heat of the rod made her think of Fire. . . .

blɪŋkɪŋ, ʃi oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən sæɾ ʌp ɪn ðə bɛd. sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimd ɪn ət ðə wɪndoʊ. ʃi wɑz ɪn əɹ ʃɪft, ən nɪneɪiv, fʊli dʒɹɛst, stʊd fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ. eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ.

Blinking, she opened her eyes and sat up in the bed. Sunlight streamed in at the window. She was in her shift, and Nynaeve, fully dressed, stood frowning down at her. Aviendha and Birgitte were watching from beside the door.

"wʌt hæpənd?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəd, ən nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɡɹɪmli.

"What happened?" Elayne demanded, and Nynaeve shook her head grimly.

"ju doʊnt wɑnə noʊ." hɝ lɪps twɪtʃt.

"You don't want to know." Her lips twitched.

eɪvinhəz feɪs ɡeɪv əweɪ nʌθɪŋ. bɝdʒɪts maʊθ maɪɾ əv bɪn ə lɪɾəl taɪt, bʌt ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪmoʊʃən ɪleɪn fɛl fɹəm əɹ wɑz ə kɑmbəneɪʃən ə ɹɪlif ən - hɪlɛɹəɾi! ðə wʊmən wɑz duɪŋ əɹ ʌtmoʊs nɑt tə ɹoʊl ɑn ðə flɔɹ læfɪŋ!

Aviendha's face gave away nothing. Birgitte's mouth might have been a little tight, but the strongest emotion Elayne felt from her was a combination of relief and - hilarity! The woman was doing her utmost not to roll on the floor laughing!

ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt wɑz, noʊ wʌn wəd tɛl wʌt hæd hæpənd. wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd, əɹ dʌn; ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ðæt, baɪ ðə kwɪkli hɪɾən ɡɹɪnz ʃi sɔ, fɹəm kɪnswɪmən ən wɪndfɪndɝz əz wɛl əz sɪstɝz. bʌt noʊ wʌn wəd tɛl hɝ! æftɝ ðæt, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv stʌɾiɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil tə sʌmwɛɹ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ðən ə ɪn. sʌmwɛɹ dɛfənətli mɔɹ pɹaɪvət!

The worst of it was, no one would tell what had happened. What she had said, or done; she was sure it was that, by the quickly hidden grins she saw, from Kinswomen and Windfinders as well as sisters. But no one would tell her! After that, she decided to leave studying the ter'angreal to somewhere more comfortable than a inn. Somewhere definitely more private!

naɪn deɪz æftɝ ðɛɹ flaɪt fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, skæɾɝd klaʊdz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ ən ə spɹɪŋklɪŋ ə fæt ɹeɪndʒɹɑps splæʃt dʌst ɪn ðə ɹoʊd. ən ɪntɝmɪɾənt dʒɹɪzəl fɛl ðə nɛks deɪ, ən ðə deɪ æftɝ, ə dɛljudʒ kɛpt əm hʌɾəld ɪn ðə haʊsəz ən steɪbəlz ə fɔɹəl mɑɹkət. ðət naɪt, ðə ɹeɪn tɝn tə slit, ən baɪ mɔɹnɪŋ, θɪk flɝiz ə snoʊ dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ə klaʊd-dɑɹk skaɪ. mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ kəd meɪk ɪɾ ɪn tu wiks fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd.

Nine days after their flight from Ebou Dar, scattered clouds appeared in the sky and a sprinkling of fat raindrops splashed dust in the road. An intermittent drizzle fell the next day, and the day after, a deluge kept them huddled in the houses and stables of Forel Market. That night, the rain turned to sleet, and by morning, thick flurries of snow drifted from a cloud-dark sky. More than halfway to Caemlyn, Elayne began to wonder whether they could make it in two weeks from where they stood.

wɪð ðə snoʊ, kloʊðz bɪkeɪm ə wɝi. ɪleɪn bleɪm hɝsɛlf fəɹ nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə fæk ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn maɪt nid wɔɹm kloʊðz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðɛɹ dɛstəneɪʃən. nɪneɪiv bleɪm hɝsɛlf fəɹ nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt. mɛɝɪlɪl θɔt ʃi wɑz ət fɔlt, ən ɹin θɔt ʃi wɑz. ðeɪ æktʃəli  stʊɾ ɪn ðə meɪn stʃɹiɾ ə fɔɹəl mɑɹkət ðət mɔɹnɪŋ wɪð snoʊ-fleɪks dʒɹɪftɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz, ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ u kəd kleɪm ðə bleɪm. ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ ə ðɛm sɔ ði əbsɝɾəti fɝst, hu wɑz ðə fɝs tə læf, bʌɾ ɔl wɝ læfɪŋ əz ðeɪ sɛɾəld ɝaʊn ə teɪbəl ɪn ðə waɪt swɑn tə dɪsaɪd wʌt tə du. ə səluʃən tɝn aʊt tə bi noʊ læfɪŋ mæɾɝ. pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ wʌn wɔɹm koʊɾ əɹ kloʊk fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn wəd teɪk ə lɑɹdʒ baɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kɔɪn, ɪf soʊ mɛni kəd bi faʊnd. dʒuəlɹi kəd bi soʊld əɹ tʃɹeɪɾɪd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt noʊ wʌn ɪn fɔɹəl mɑɹkət sim tə bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn nɛkləsɪz əɹ bɹeɪslɪts, haʊɛvɝ faɪn.

With the snow, clothes became a worry. Elayne blamed herself for not thinking of the fact that everyone might need warm clothes before they reached their destination. Nynaeve blamed herself for not thinking of it. Merilille thought she was at fault, and Reanne thought she was. They actually stood in the main street of Forel Market that morning with snow-flakes drifting down on their heads, arguing over who could claim the blame. Elayne was not sure which of them saw the absurdity first, who was the first to laugh, but all were laughing as they settled around a table in The White Swan to decide what to do. A solution turned out to be no laughing matter. Providing one warm coat or cloak for everyone would take a large bite out of their coin, if so many could be found. Jewelry could be sold or traded, of course, but no one in Forel Market seemed to be interested in necklaces or bracelets, however fine.

eɪvinhə sɑlv ðət dɪfəkəlti baɪ pɹədusɪŋ ə smɔl sæk ðət bʌlʒd wɪð klɪɹ, pɝfək dʒɛmstoʊnz, səm kwaɪt lɑɹdʒ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə seɪm foʊk u hæd sɛd wɪð bɛɹ pəlaɪtnəs ðət ðeɪ hæd noʊ jus fəɹ bi-ɡɛm nɛkləsɪz wɛn ɹaʊnd-aɪɾ ət ði ənsɛt stoʊnz ɹoʊlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn eɪvinhəz pɑm. ɹin sɛd ðeɪ sɔ wʌn əz fɹɪpɝi, ði ʌðɝ əz wɛlθ, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ ɹizənz, ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ tu ɹubiz ə mɑɾɝət saɪz, wʌn lɑɹdʒ munstoʊn, ən ə smɔl faɪɝdʒɹɑp, ðə pipəl ə fɔɹəl mɑɹkət wɝ mɔɹ ðən wɪlɪŋ tə pɹəvaɪɾ əz mɛni θɪk wʊlənz əz ðɛɹ vɪzəɾɝz dɪzaɪɝd, səm ə ðɛm hɑɹdli wɔɹn.

Aviendha solved that difficulty by producing a small sack that bulged with clear, perfect gemstones, some quite large. Strangely, the same folk who had said with bare politeness that they had no use for be-gemmed necklaces went round-eyed at the unset stones rolling about in Aviendha's palm. Reanne said they saw one as frippery, the other as wealth, but whatever their reasons, in return for two rubies of moderate size, one large moonstone, and a small firedrop, the people of Forel Market were more than willing to provide as many thick woolens as their visitors desired, some of them hardly worn.

"vɛɹi dʒɛnɝəs ə ðɛm," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd saʊɝli əz pipəl bɪɡæn ɹuɾɪŋ kloʊðz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ tʃɛsts ən æɾɪks. ə stɛɾi stʃɹim mɑɹtʃt ɪndə ði ɪn wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmz fʊl. "ðoʊz stoʊnz kəd baɪ ðə hoʊl vɪlədʒ!" eɪvinhə ʃɹʌɡd slaɪtli; ʃi wʊɾə sɝɛndɝɾ ə hændfʊl ə ðə dʒɛmz ɪf ɹin hæd nɑɾ ɪntɝvind.

"Very generous of them," Nynaeve muttered sourly as people began rooting clothes out of their chests and attics. A steady stream marched into the inn with their arms full. "Those stones could buy the whole village!" Aviendha shrugged slightly; she would have surrendered a handful of the gems if Reanne had not intervened.

mɛɝɪlɪl ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "wi hæv wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt, bʌt ðeɪv wʌt wi nid. aɪm əfɹeɪd ðət minz ðeɪ sɛt ðə pɹaɪs." wɪtʃ wɑz ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ laɪk ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɪð ðə si foʊk. nɪneɪiv lʊk pɑzəɾɪvli ɪl.

Merilille shook her head. "We have what they want, but they have what we need. I'm afraid that means they set the price." Which was entirely too much like the situation with the Sea Folk. Nynaeve looked positively ill.

wən ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, ɪn ə hɔlweɪ ʌv ði ɪn, ɪleɪn æskt eɪvinhə wɛɹ ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən sətʃ ə fɔɹtʃən ɪn dʒuəlz, ən wʌn ʃi simd iɡɝ tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv. ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ tə seɪ ðeɪ wɝ əɹ teɪkɪŋz fɹəm ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, əɹ pɝhæps kɛɹhin.

When they were alone, in a hallway of the inn, Elayne asked Aviendha where she had gotten such a fortune in jewels, and one she seemed eager to be rid of. She expected her near-sister to say they were her takings from the Stone of Tear, or perhaps Cairhien.

"ɹæn ælθɹ tʃɹɪk mi," eɪvinhə mʌɾɝd sʌlənli. "aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə baɪ maɪ toʊ fɹəm hɪm. aɪ noʊ ðəɾ ɪz ðə list ɑnɝəbəl weɪ," ʃi pɹətɛstəd, "bʌɾ aɪ kəd si noʊ ʌðɝ. ən i stʊd mi ɑn maɪ hɛd! waɪ ɪz ɪt, wən jə ɹizən θɪŋz aʊt lɑdʒɪkli, ə mæn ɔlweɪz dʌz sʌmθɪŋ kəmplitli ɪlɑdʒɪkəl ən ɡeɪnz ði ʌpɝ hænd?"

"Rand al'Thor tricked me," Aviendha muttered sullenly. "I tried to buy my toh from him. I know that is the least honorable way," she protested, "but I could see no other. And he stood me on my head! Why is it, when you reason things out logically, a man always does something completely illogical and gains the upper hand?"

"ðɛɹ pɹɪɾi hɛdz ɑɹ soʊ fʌzi, ə wʊmən kæn ɪkspɛk tə fɑloʊ haʊ ðeɪ skɪɾɝ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪnkwaɪɹ wʌt toʊ eɪvinhə hæd tʃɹaɪd tə baɪ, əɹ haʊ ði ətɛmp hæɾ ɛndəd wɪð əɹ nɪɹ-sɪstɝ pəzɛsɪŋ ə sæk fʊl ə ɹɪtʃ dʒɛmz. tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd wɑz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt wɛɹ ðət maɪt lɛd.

"Their pretty heads are so fuzzy, a woman can't expect to follow how they skitter," Elayne told her. She did not inquire what toh Aviendha had tried to buy, or how the attempt had ended with her near-sister possessing a sack full of rich gems. Talking about Rand was hard enough without where that might lead.

snoʊ bɹɔt mɔɹ ðən ə nid fəɹ wɔɹm kloʊðɪŋ. ət mɪddeɪ, wɪð ðə snoʊ flɝiz fɔlɪŋ θɪkɝ baɪ ðə mɪnət, ɹɪneɪl stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə stɛɹz ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum, pɹoʊkleɪm ðəɾ əɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən hæd bɪn mɛt, ən dɪmændəd nɑɾ oʊnli ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, bʌt mɛɝɪlɪl. ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ stɛɹɾ ɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən, ən soʊ dɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ʌðɝz. ðə bɛntʃɪz wɝ fɪld wɪð kɪnswɪmən teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn ət ðə mɪddeɪ mil, ən sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən ɹæn tə sɝv ðɪs θɝd lɑɾ ə milz. ɹɪneɪl dɪd nɑt kip əɹ vɔɪs daʊn, ən ɛvɹi hɛɾ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum swɪvəl təwɔɹd hɝ.

Snow brought more than a need for warm clothing. At midday, with the snow flurries falling thicker by the minute, Renaile strode down the stairs into the common room, proclaimed that her part of the bargain had been met, and demanded not only the Bowl of the Winds, but Merilille. The Gray sister stared in consternation, and so did a great many others. The benches were filled with Kinswomen taking their turn at the midday meal, and serving men and women ran to serve this third lot of meals. Renaile did not keep her voice down, and every head in the common room swiveled toward her.

"ju kən bɪɡɪn jəɹ titʃɪŋ, naʊ," ɹɪneɪl toʊl ðə waɪd-aɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ʌp ðə læɾɝ wɪð jə tə maɪ kɔɹɾɝz." mɛɝɪlɪl stɑɹɾəd tə pɹoʊtɛst, bʌt feɪs sʌɾənli koʊld, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps plæntəd fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. "wɛn aɪ ɡɪv ə kəmænd, mɛɝɪlɪl ʃiændɪvɪn," ʃi sɛɾ aɪsɪli, "aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɛvɹi hæn ɑn dɛk tə dʒʌmp. naʊ dʒʌmp!"

"You can begin your teaching, now," Renaile told the wide-eyed Aes Sedai. "Up the ladder with you to my quarters." Merilille started to protest, but face suddenly cold, the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships planted fists on her hips. "When I give a command, Merilille Ceandevin," she said icily, "I expect every hand on deck to jump. Now jump!"

mɛɝɪlɪl dɪd nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli dʒʌmp, bʌt ʃi dɪd ɡæðɝ hɝsɛlf ən ɡoʊ, wɪð ɹɪneɪl pɹæktəkli tʃɪviɪŋ əɹ ʌp ðə stɛɹz fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. ɡɪvən əɹ pɹɑməs, ʃi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. ɹinz feɪs wɑz əɡæst. æləz ən staʊt sumeɪkoʊ, stɪl wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɹɛd bɛlt, wɑtʃt θɔtfəli.

Merilille did not precisely jump, but she did gather herself and go, with Renaile practically chivvying her up the stairs from behind. Given her promise, she had no other choice. Reanne's face was aghast. Alise and stout Sumeko, still wearing her red belt, watched thoughtfully.

ɪn ðə deɪz ðət fɑloʊd, wɛðɝ leɪbɝɪŋ əlɔŋ ə snoʊ-kʌvɝd ɹoʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, wɔkɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ʌv ə vɪlədʒ, əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɹum fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn əɾ ə fɑɹm, ɹɪneɪl kɛp mɛɝɪlɪl əɾ əɹ hilz ɪksɛpt wən ʃi toʊld əɹ ɔf tə fɑloʊ ənʌðɝ wɪndfɪndɝ. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ ən əɹ ɛskɔɹɾ ɔlmoʊs kɑnstənli, ən mɛɝɪlɪl dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd wivz ənsizɪŋli. ðə peɪl kɛɹhinɪn wɑz mɑɹkədli ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ðə dɑɹk si foʊk wɪmən, bʌɾ ət fɝs mɛɝɪlɪl mænədʒ tə stæn tɔlɝ baɪ ðə ʃɪɹ fɔɹs ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪɡnəɾi. sun, ðoʊ, ʃi bɪɡæn tə wɛɹ ə pɝmənənli stɑɹɾəld ɪkspɹɛʃən. ɪleɪn lɝn ðət wən ðeɪ ɔl hæd bɛdz tə slip ɪn, wɪtʃ ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz, mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz ʃɛɹɪŋ wɪð pɔl, hɝ meɪd, ən ðə tu əpɹɛntəs wɪndfɪndɝz, tɑlɑn ən mɛtʃɹə. wʌt ðət sɛɾ ə mɛɝɪlɪlz stæɾəs, ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. klɪɹli, ðə wɪndfɪndɝz dɪd nɑt pʊɾ əɹ ɑn ə lɛvəl wɪð ði əpɹɛntəsɪz. ðeɪ dʒʌst ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə də əz ʃi wɑz toʊld, wən ʃi wɑz toʊld, wɪð noʊ dɪleɪz əɹ ɛkwɪvəkeɪʃənz.

In the days that followed, whether laboring along a snow-covered road on their horses, walking the streets of a village, or trying to find room for everyone at a farm, Renaile kept Merilille at her heels except when she told her off to follow another Windfinder. The glow of saidar surrounded the Gray sister and her escort almost constantly, and Merilille demonstrated weaves unceasingly. The pale Cairhienin was markedly shorter than any of the dark Sea Folk women, but at first Merilille managed to stand taller by the sheer force of Aes Sedai dignity. Soon, though, she began to wear a permanently startled expression. Elayne learned that when they all had beds to sleep in, which they did not always, Merilille was sharing with Pol, her maid, and the two apprentice Windfinders, Talaan and Metarra. What that said of Merilille's status, Elayne was not sure. Clearly, the Windfinders did not put her on a level with the apprentices. They just expected her to do as she was told, when she was told, with no delays or equivocations.

ɹin ɹɪmeɪn əpɔld ət ðə tɝn ʌv ɪvɛns, bʌɾ æləz ən sumeɪkoʊ wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz əmʌŋ ðə kɪn tə wɑtʃ kloʊsli, nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz tə nɑd θɔtfəli. ən sʌɾənli, ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm keɪm tə ɪleɪnz noʊɾəs. ðə kɪnswɪmən sɔ ɪspæn meɪd mɔɹ ən mɔɹ mæliəbəl ɪn əɹ kæptɪvəɾi, bʌt ʃi wɑz ðə pɹɪznɝ ʌv ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə si foʊk wɝ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən mɛɝɪlɪl nɑɾ ə pɹɪznɝ, jɛt ʃi wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə dʒʌmp wən ɹɪneɪl ɪʃuɾ ə kəmænd, ɔɹ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, wən dɔɹəl, əɹ kɛɹ, əɹ kɛɹz blʌd-sɪstɝ tɛbɹl dɪd. itʃ ə ðoʊz wɑz wɪndfɪndɝ tə ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs, ən nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz meɪɾ əɹ hɑp wɪð sətʃ əlækɹəɾi, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪnʌf. mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðə kɪn slɪd fɹəm hɔɹəfaɪd ɡeɪpɪŋ tə θɔtfəl ɑbzɝveɪʃən. pɝhæps ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ nɑɾ ə dɪfɹən flɛʃ æftɝ ɔl. ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ dʒʌst wɪmən laɪk ðɛmsɛlvz, waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ sʌbʒɪkt ðɛmsɛlvz wʌns mɔɹ tə ðə ɹɪɡɝz ə ðə taʊɝ, tə ɛɛs sədaɪ əθɔɹəɾi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪsəplən? hæd ðeɪ nɑt sɝvaɪvd vɛɹi wɛl ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn, səm fəɹ mɔɹ jɪɹz ðən ɛni ʌv ði oʊldɝ sɪstɝz wɝ kwaɪt ɹɛɾi tə bɪliv? ɪleɪn kəd pɹæktəkli si ði aɪdiə fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz.

Reanne remained appalled at the turn of events, but Alise and Sumeko were not the only ones among the Kin to watch closely, not the only ones to nod thoughtfully. And suddenly, another problem came to Elayne's notice. The Kinswomen saw Ispan made more and more malleable in her captivity, but she was the prisoner of other Aes Sedai. The Sea Folk were not Aes Sedai, and Merilille not a prisoner, yet she was starting to jump when Renaile issued a command, or, for that matter, when Dorile, or Caire, or Caire's blood-sister Tebreille did. Each of those was Windfinder to a clan Wavemistress, and none of the others made her hop with such alacrity, but that was enough. More and more of the Kin slid from horrified gaping to thoughtful observation. Perhaps Aes Sedai were not a different flesh after all. If Aes Sedai were just women like themselves, why should they subject themselves once more to the rigors of the Tower, to Aes Sedai authority and Aes Sedai discipline? Had they not survived very well on their own, some for more years than any of the older sisters were quite ready to believe? Elayne could practically see the idea forming in their heads.

wən ʃi mɛnʃən ɪt tə nɪneɪiv, ðoʊ, nɪneɪiv dʒʌs mʌɾɝd, "əbaʊt taɪm səm ə ðə sɪstɝz lɝnd wʌɾ ɪts laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə titʃ ə wʊmən u θɪŋks ʃi noʊz mɔɹ ðən əɹ titʃɝ. ðoʊz u hæv ə tʃæns əɾ ə ʃɔl wɪl stɪl wɑn ɪt, ən fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, aɪ doʊn si waɪ ðeɪ ʃʊdnt ɡɹoʊ səm bækboʊn." ɪleɪn ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm mɛnʃənɪŋ nɪneɪivz kəmpleɪns əbaʊt sumeɪkoʊ, hu hæd sɝɾənli ɡɹoʊn bækboʊn; sumeɪkoʊ hæd kɹɪɾəsaɪzd sɛvɹəl ə nɪneɪivz hilɪŋ wivz əz "klʌmzi," ən ɪleɪn hæd θɔt nɪneɪiv wɑz gɑnə hæv æpəplɛksi ɑn ðə spɑt. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə tɛl ɛɡwin əbaʊt ðɪs. ɪf ʃiz ðɛɹ. ɛni ʌv ɪt. ʃiz ɪnʌf ɑn əɹ pleɪt." wɪθaʊt daʊt, "ɛni ʌv ɪt" ɹəfɝd tə mɛɝɪlɪl ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz.

When she mentioned it to Nynaeve, though, Nynaeve just muttered, "About time some of the sisters learned what it's like trying to teach a woman who thinks she knows more than her teacher. Those who have a chance at a shawl will still want it, and for the rest, I don't see why they shouldn't grow some backbone." Elayne refrained from mentioning Nynaeve's complaints about Sumeko, who had certainly grown backbone; Sumeko had criticized several of Nynaeve's Healing weaves as "clumsy," and Elayne had thought Nynaeve was going to have apoplexy on the spot. "In any case, there's no need to tell Egwene about this. If she's there. Any of it. She has enough on her plate." Without doubt, "any of it" referred to Merilille and the Windfinders.

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɪfs, siɾəd ɑn ðɛɹ bɛɾ ɑn ðə sɛkən flɔɹ ə ðə nu plaʊ, wɪð ðə twɪstəd-ɹɪŋ dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil hæŋɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ nɛks, ɪleɪnz ɑn ə sɪmpəl lɛðɝ kɔɹd, nɪneɪivz əlɔŋsaɪd lænz hɛvi sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn ə nɛɹoʊ ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn. eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt, stɪl fʊli dʒɹɛst, sæɾ ɑn tu ʌv ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ tʃɛsts. stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd, ðeɪ kɔld ɪt, əntɪl ʃi ən nɪneɪiv ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz. boʊθ wɔɹ ðɛɹ kloʊks əntɪl ðeɪ kəd klaɪm ʌndɝ ðə blæŋkəts. ðə nu plaʊ wɑz dɛfənətli nɑt nu; kɹæks spaɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə plæstɝd wɔlz, ən ənfɔɹtʃənət dʒɹæfs kɹɛpt ɪn ɛvɹiwɛɹ.

They were in their shifts, seated on their bed on the second floor of The New Plow, with the twisted-ring dream ter'angreal hanging about their necks, Elayne's on a simple leather cord, Nynaeve's alongside Lan's heavy signet ring on a narrow golden chain. Aviendha and Birgitte, still fully dressed, sat on two of their clothing chests. Standing guard, they called it, until she and Nynaeve returned from the World of Dreams. Both wore their cloaks until they could climb under the blankets. The New Plow was definitely not new; cracks spidered across the plastered walls, and unfortunate drafts crept in everywhere.

ðə ɹum ɪtsɛlf wɑz smɔl, ən ðə tʃɛsts ən stæk bʌndəlz lɛft ɹum fəɹ lɪɾəl bɪɑn ðə bɛɾ ən wɑʃstænd. ɪleɪn nu ʃi hæd tə pɹizɛn hɝsɛlf pɹɑpɝli ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt səmtaɪmz ʃi fɛlt ɡɪlti, wɪð əɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɑn pæk ænəməlz wən moʊst ʌðɝz hæd tə meɪk də wɪð wʌt ðeɪ kəd kæɹi ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. nɪneɪiv sɝɾənli nɛvɝ ʃoʊɾ ɛni ɹɪɡɹɛts oʊvɝ əɹ tʃɛsts. ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɪkstin deɪz ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, ðə fʊl mun aʊtsaɪd ðə nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊ ʃoʊn ɑn ə waɪt blæŋkəɾ ə snoʊ ðət wəd meɪk tʃɹævlɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ sloʊ ivən ɪf ðə skaɪ ɹɪmeɪn klɪɹ, ən ɪleɪn θɔɾ ənʌðɝ wik tə keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ən ɑptəmɪstɪk ɛstəmət.

The room itself was small, and the chests and stacked bundles left room for little beyond the bed and washstand. Elayne knew she had to present herself properly in Caemlyn, but sometimes she felt guilty, with her belongings on pack animals when most others had to make do with what they could carry on their backs. Nynaeve certainly never showed any regrets over her chests. They had been sixteen days on the road, the full moon outside the narrow window shone on a white blanket of snow that would make traveling tomorrow slow even if the sky remained clear, and Elayne thought another week to Caemlyn was an optimistic estimate.

"aɪ hæv ɪnʌf sɛns nɑt tə ɹimaɪn hɝ," ʃi toʊl nɪneɪiv. "aɪ doʊnt wɑn maɪ noʊz snæpt ɔf əɡɛn."

"I have enough sense not to remind her," she told Nynaeve. "I don't want my nose snapped off again."

ðət wɑz ə maɪld weɪ ʌv pʊɾɪŋ ɪt. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd sɪns ɪnfɔɹmɪŋ ɛɡwin, ðə naɪɾ æftɝ livɪŋ ði ɪsteɪt, ðət ðə boʊl hæd bɪn juzd. ɹɪlʌktənli, ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ hæd toʊld əɹ ə ðə bɑɹɡən ðeɪ hæd bɪn fɔɹst ɪndə wɪð ðə si foʊk, ən faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz feɪsɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɪð ðə stʃɹaɪp stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ɪleɪn nu ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi ən ɹaɪt - ə kwinz kloʊsəs fɹɛn əmʌŋ əɹ sʌbʒɪkts nu ʃi wɑz ðə kwin əz wɛl əz ə fɹɛnd, hæd tə noʊ - bʌt ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɛndʒɔɪɾ əɹ fɹɛn tɛlɪŋ əm ɪn ə hiɾəd vɔɪs ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪheɪv laɪk wɪtləs lubiz u maɪɾ əv bɹɔt ɹuən daʊn ɑn ɔl ðɛɹ hɛdz. ɪspɛʃli wən ʃi hɝsɛlf əɡɹid. ʃi hæd nɑt laɪk hɪɹɪŋ ðət ði oʊnli ɹizən ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt sɛɾ əm boʊθ ə pɛnəns ðət wəd kɝl ðɛɹ hɛɹ wɑz ðət ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə hæv əm weɪs ðə taɪm. nɛsəsɛɹi ən ɹaɪt, ðoʊ; wən ʃi sæɾ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, ʃi wəd stɪl bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən sʌbʒɪkt tə ðə lɔz ən ɹulz ən kʌstəmz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑt fəɹ ændɝ - ʃi wəd nɑt ɡɪv əɹ læn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ - bʌt fəɹ hɝsɛlf. soʊ, ənplɛzən əz ɪt hæd bɪn, ʃi æksɛptɪɾ əɹ kæstəɡeɪʃən kɑmli. nɪneɪiv hæd ɹɪθd ən stæmɝd wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, pɹətɛstəɾ ən ɔl bʌt paʊɾɪd, ðən əpɑlədʒaɪz soʊ pɹəfjusli ðəɾ ɪleɪn hɑɹdli bɪlivd ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm wʊmən ʃi nu. kwaɪt ɹaɪtli, ɛɡwin hæd ɹɪmeɪn ði æmɪɝlɪn, kul ɪn əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ ivən waɪl ɡɪvɪŋ pɑɹɾən fəɹ ðɛɹ mɪsteɪks. ət bɛst, tənaɪt kəd nɑt bi plɛzən əɹ kʌmftəɹbəl ɪf ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ.

That was a mild way of putting it. They had not been in Tel'aran'rhiod since informing Egwene, the night after leaving the estate, that the Bowl had been used. Reluctantly, they also had told her of the bargain they had been forced into with the Sea Folk, and found themselves facing the Amyrlin Seat with the striped stole on her shoulders. Elayne knew it was necessary and right - a Queen's closest friend among her subjects knew she was the Queen as well as a friend, had to know - but she had not enjoyed her friend telling them in a heated voice that they had behaved like witless loobies who might have brought ruin down on all their heads. Especially when she herself agreed. She had not liked hearing that the only reason Egwene did not set them both a penance that would curl their hair was that she could not afford to have them waste the time. Necessary and right, though; when she sat on the Lion Throne, she would still be Aes Sedai, and subject to the laws and rules and customs of Aes Sedai. Not for Andor - she would not give her land to the White Tower - but for herself. So, unpleasant as it had been, she accepted her castigation calmly. Nynaeve had writhed and stammered with embarrassment, protested and all but pouted, then apologized so profusely that Elayne hardly believed it was the same woman she knew. Quite rightly, Egwene had remained the Amyrlin, cool in her displeasure even while giving pardon for their mistakes. At best, tonight could not be pleasant or comfortable if she was there.

bʌt wən ðeɪ dʒɹim ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə ðə sɑlədɑɹ ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ɪndə ðə ɹum ɪn ðə lɪɾəl taʊɝ ðət hæd bɪn kɔl ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, ʃi wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, ən ði oʊnli saɪn ʃi hæd vɪzəɾəd sɪns ðɛɹ miɾɪŋ wɑz səm bɛɹli vɪzəbəl wɝdz ɹʌfli skɹætʃt ɑn ə biɾəl-ɹɪdəld wɔl pænəl, əz ɪf baɪ ən aɪɾəl hæn ðət dɪd nɑt wɑnə spɛn ði ɛfɝt tə kɑɹv dipli.

But when they dreamed themselves into the Salidar of Tel'aran'rhiod, into the room in the Little Tower that had been called the Amyrlin's Study, she was not there, and the only sign she had visited since their meeting was some barely visible words roughly scratched on a beetle-riddled wall panel, as if by an idle hand that did not want to spend the effort to carve deeply.

steɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ən ə fju fiɾ əweɪ:

STAY IN CAEMLYN And a few feet away:

kip saɪlən ən bi kɛɹfəl ðoʊz hæd bɪn ɛɡwinz faɪnəl ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz tə ðɛm. ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən steɪ ðəɹ əntɪl ʃi kəd pʌzəl aʊt haʊ tə kip ðə hɔl fɹəm sɔltɪŋ ɔl ə ðɛm daʊn ən neɪlɪŋ əm ɪndə ə bæɹəl. ə ɹimaɪndɝ ðeɪ hæd noʊ weɪ tə ɪɹeɪs.

KEEP SILENT AND BE CAREFUL Those had been Egwene's final instructions to them. Go to Caemlyn, and stay there until she could puzzle out how to keep the Hall from salting all of them down and nailing them into a barrel. A reminder they had no way to erase.

ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɪleɪn tʃænəl tə liv əɹ oʊn mɛsədʒ, ðə nʌmbɝ fɪftin simɪŋli skɹætʃt ɑn ðə hɛvi teɪbəl ðət hæd bɪn ɛɡwinz ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk. ɪnvɝɾɪŋ ðə wiv ən taɪɪŋ ɪɾ ɔf mɛn ðəɾ oʊnli sʌmwʌn u ɹæn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əkɹɔs ðə numɝəlz wəd ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɹɪli ðɛɹ. pɝhæps ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk fɪftin deɪz tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ə wik, ʃi wɑz sɝɾən.

Embracing saidar, Elayne channeled to leave her own message, the number fifteen seemingly scratched on the heavy table that had been Egwene's writing desk. Inverting the weave and tying it off meant that only someone who ran her fingers across the numerals would realize they were not really there. Perhaps it would not take fifteen days to reach Caemlyn, but more than a week, she was certain.

nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊd tə ðə wɪndoʊ ən pɪɹɾ aʊt boʊθ weɪz, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ aʊt θɹu ði oʊpən keɪsmənt. ɪt wɑz naɪɾ aʊt ðəɹ əz ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld, ə fʊl mun ɡlimɪŋ ɑn bɹaɪt snoʊ, ðoʊ ði ɛɹ dɪd nɑt fil koʊld. noʊ wʌn ɛls ʃəd bi ðəɹ ɪksɛp ðɛm, ən ɪf ɛniwʌn wɑz, ɪt wɑz sʌmwʌn tə əvɔɪd. "aɪ hoʊp ʃi ɪzən hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð əɹ plænz," ʃi mʌɾɝd.

Nynaeve strode to the window and peered out both ways, careful not to put her head out through the open casement. It was night out there as in the waking world, a full moon gleaming on bright snow, though the air did not feel cold. No one else should be there except them, and if anyone was, it was someone to avoid. "I hope she isn't having trouble with her plans," she muttered.

"ʃi toʊld əs nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðoʊz ivən tə itʃ ʌðɝ, nɪneɪiv. 'ə sikɹət spoʊkən faɪnz wɪŋz.' " ðət hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ ə liniz mɛni feɪvɹɪts.

"She told us not to mention those even to each other, Nynaeve. 'A secret spoken finds wings.' " That had been another of Lini's many favorites.
