nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪməst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə piɹɪŋ daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ æli. "ɪts dɪfɹən fəɹ ju. aɪ tɛndəɾ əɹ əz ə tʃaɪld, tʃeɪnʒd əɹ swɑɾəlɪŋ, smækt əɹ bɑɾəm ə taɪm əɹ tu. ən naʊ aɪ hæv tə lip wən ʃi snæps əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ɪts hɑɹd."

Nynaeve grimaced over her shoulder, then returned to peering down the narrow alley. "It's different for you. I tended her as a child, changed her swaddling, smacked her bottom a time or two. And now I have to leap when she snaps her fingers. It's hard."

ɪleɪn kəd nɑt hɛlp hɝsɛlf. ʃi snæpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

Elayne could not help herself. She snapped her fingers.

nɪneɪiv spʌn soʊ fæs ðət ʃi blɝd, hɝ feɪs pɑpeɪd wɪð hɔɹɝ. hɝ dʒɹɛs blɝd, tu, fɹəm blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ sɪlks tə ən æksɛptɪdz bændɪd waɪt tə wʌt ʃi ɹəfɝd tə əz ɡʊd, staʊt tu ɹɪvɝz wʊl, dɑɹk ən θɪk. wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, hæd nɑt bɪn lɪsnɪŋ, ʃi ɔlmoʊs feɪntɪd wɪð ɹɪlif.

Nynaeve spun so fast that she blurred, her face popeyed with horror. Her dress blurred, too, from blue riding silks to an Accepted's banded white to what she referred to as good, stout Two Rivers wool, dark and thick. When she realized Egwene was not there, had not been listening, she almost fainted with relief.

wən ðeɪ stɛp bæk tə ðɛɹ bɑɾiz ən woʊk lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tɛl ði ʌðɝz ðeɪ kəd kʌm tə bɛd, eɪvinhə sɝɾənli θɔɾ ɪɾ ə ɡʊd dʒoʊk, ən bɝdʒɪt læft əz wɛl. nɪneɪiv hæɾ əɹ ɹivɛnʒ, ðoʊ. ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, ʃi woʊk ɪleɪn wɪð ən aɪsɪkəl. ɪleɪnz ʃɹiks woʊk ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls ɪn ðə hoʊl vɪlədʒ.

When they stepped back to their bodies and woke long enough to tell the others they could come to bed, Aviendha certainly thought it a good joke, and Birgitte laughed as well. Nynaeve had her revenge, though. The next morning, she woke Elayne with an icicle. Elayne's shrieks woke everybody else in the whole village.

θɹi deɪz leɪɾɝ, ðə fɝst ɪksploʊʒən keɪm.

Three days later, the first explosion came.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn


CHAPTER 21

ænsɝɪŋ ðə sʌmənz


Answering the Summons

ðə ɡɹeɪt wɪntɝ tɛmpɛsts kɔl ðə sɛmɑɹoʊz kəntɪnjud tə ɹoʊl ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, hɑɹʃɝ ðən ɛni ɪn mɛmɹi. səm sɛd ðɪs jɪɹ ðə sɛmɑɹoʊz wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ðə mʌnθs ə dɪleɪ. laɪtnɪŋ kɹækəld əkɹɔs ðə skaɪz, ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə dɑɹknəs pætʃi ət naɪt. wɪn læʃt ðə læn ən ɹeɪn fleɪld ɪt, tɝnɪŋ ɔl bʌt ðə hɑɹɾəst ɹoʊdz tə ɹɪvɝz ə mʌd. səmtaɪmz ðə mʌd fɹoʊz æftɝ naɪtfɔl, bʌt sʌnɹaɪz ɔlweɪz bɹɔɾ ə θɔ, ivən ʌndɝ ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪkeɪm bɑɡz wʌns mɔɹ. ɹænd wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ mʌtʃ ɔl ðət hæmpɝɾ ɪz plænz.

The great winter tempests called the cemaros continued to roll up out of the Sea of Storms, harsher than any in memory. Some said this year the cemaros was trying to make up for the months of delay. Lightning crackled across the skies, enough to make the darkness patchy at night. Wind lashed the land and rain flailed it, turning all but the hardest roads to rivers of mud. Sometimes the mud froze after nightfall, but sunrise always brought a thaw, even under a gray sky, and the ground became bogs once more. Rand was surprised at how much all that hampered his plans.

ði æʃəmən i hæd sɛn fəɹ keɪm kwɪkli, ət mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ ðə nɛks deɪ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə ə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ daʊnpɔɹ ðəɾ əbskjʊɹd ðə sʌn soʊ, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn twaɪlaɪt. θɹu ðə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, snoʊ fɛl bæk ɪn ændɝ, fæt waɪt fleɪks swɝlɪŋ əbaʊt θɪkli ən haɪɾɪŋ wʌt leɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. moʊst ə ðə mɛn ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt kɑləm wɝ bʌndəld ɪn hɛvi blæk kloʊks, bʌt ðə ɹeɪn sim tə slɪp ɝaʊn əm ən ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɑbviəs, jɛɾ ɛniwʌn u noʊɾəst wəd lʊk twaɪs, ɪf nɑt θɹi taɪmz. kipɪŋ dʒɹaɪ ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ə sɪmpəl wiv, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə dɪd nɑt maɪn flɔntɪŋ wʌt jə wɝ. bʌt ðɛn, ðə blæk-ænd-waɪt dɪsk wɝkt ɑn ə kɹɪmzən sɝkəl ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə ðɛɹ kloʊks dɪd ðæt. ivən hæf-hɪɾən baɪ ðə ɹeɪn, ðəɹ wɑz ə pɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðɛm, ən ɛɹəɡəns ɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. ə dɪfaɪəns. ðeɪ ɡlɔɹaɪɾ ɪn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ.

The Asha'man he had sent for came quickly, at midmorning the next day, riding out of a gateway into a driving downpour that obscured the sun so, it might as well have been twilight. Through the hole in the air, snow fell back in Andor, fat white flakes swirling about thickly and hiding what lay behind them. Most of the men in the short column were bundled in heavy black cloaks, but the rain seemed to slip around them and their horses. It was not obvious, yet anyone who noticed would look twice, if not three times. Keeping dry required only a simple weave, so long as you did not mind flaunting what you were. But then, the black-and-white disc worked on a crimson circle on the breast of their cloaks did that. Even half-hidden by the rain, there was a pride about them, an arrogance in the way they sat their saddles. A defiance. They gloried in what they were.

ðɛɹ kəmændɝ, tʃɑɹl dʒɛdwɪn, wɑz ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd, ʌv mɪɾəlɪŋ haɪɾ ən wɛɹɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən, laɪk tɔɹvəl, ɑn ə vɛɹi wɛl kʌt, haɪ-kɑlɝd koʊɾ ə ðə bɛs blæk sɪlk. hɪz sɔɹd wɑz maʊntəd lʌʃli wɪð sɪlvɝ, hɪz sɪlvɝ-wɝk sɔɹd bɛl fæsənd wɪð ə sɪlvɝ bʌkəl ʃeɪpt ɪn ə klɛntʃt fɪst. dʒɛdwɪn tɝm hɪmsɛlf tsɹoʊvænmhl; ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, stɔɹm liɾɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min. ɪt simd əpɹoʊpɹiət tə ðə wɛðɝ, ət list.

Their commander, Charl Gedwyn, was a few years older than Rand, of middling height and wearing the Sword and Dragon, like Torval, on a very well cut, high-collared coat of the best black silk. His sword was mounted lushly with silver, his silver-worked sword belt fastened with a silver buckle shaped in a clenched fist. Gedwyn termed himself Tsorovan'm'hael; in the Old Tongue, Storm Leader, whatever that was supposed to mean. It seemed appropriate to the weather, at least.

ivən soʊ, hi stʊd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ɹændz ɔɹneɪt ɡɹin tɛn ən skaʊld aʊɾ ət ðə kæskeɪɾɪŋ ɹeɪn. ə ɡɑɹɾ ə maʊntəd kəmpænjənz ɪnsɝkəl ðə tɛnt, noʊ mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi peɪsɪz əweɪ, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ bɛɹli vɪzəbəl. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn stætʃuz, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə tɔɹənt.

Even so, he stood just inside the entrance to Rand's ornate green tent and scowled out at the cascading rain. A guard of mounted Companions encircled the tent, no more than thirty paces away, yet they were barely visible. They might have been statues, ignoring the torrent.

"haʊ dʒju ɪkspɛk mi tə faɪn ɛniwʌn ɪn ðɪs?" dʒɛdwɪn mʌɾɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ɹænd. ə tɪk leɪt, hi æɾəd, "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." hɪz aɪz wɝ hɑɹɾ ən tʃælənʒɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlweɪz wɝ, wɛðɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə mæn əɹ ə fɛnspoʊst. "ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən aɪ bɹɔɾ eɪt dɛɾəkeɪtəd ən fɔɹɾi soʊlʒɝz, ɪnʌf tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ən ɑɹmi əɹ kaʊ tɛn kɪŋz. wi maɪɾ ivən meɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ blɪŋk," hi sɛd ɹaɪli. "bɝn mi, ðə pɛɹ ʌv əs kəd də ə fɛɹ dʒɑb əloʊn. əɹ jə kʊd. waɪ dʒju niɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls?"

"How do you expect me to find anyone in this?" Gedwyn muttered, glancing back over his shoulder at Rand. A tick late, he added, "My Lord Dragon." His eyes were hard and challenging, but they always were, whether looking at a man or a fencepost. "Rochaid and I brought eight Dedicated and forty Soldiers, enough to destroy an army or cow ten kings. We might even make an Aes Sedai blink," he said wryly. "Burn me, the pair of us could do a fair job alone. Or you could. Why do you need anyone else?"

"aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə oʊbeɪ, dʒɛdwɪn," ɹænd sɛd koʊldli. stɔɹm liɾɝ? ən mənəl ɹɑtʃeɪd, dʒɛdwɪnz sɛkənd, kɔl hɪmsɛlf beɪaɪjænmhl, ətæk liɾɝ. wʌt wɑz teɪm ʌp tə, kɹieɪɾɪŋ nu ɹæŋks? ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ wɑz ðət ðə mæn meɪd wɛpənz. ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ wɑz ðət ðə wɛpənz steɪd seɪn lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bi juzd. "æn aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛk jə tə weɪs taɪm kwɛstʃənɪŋ maɪ ɔɹɾɝz."

"I expect you to obey, Gedwyn," Rand said coldly. Storm Leader? And Manel Rochaid, Gedwyn's second, called himself Baijan'm'hael, Attack Leader. What was Taim up to, creating new ranks? The important thing was that the man made weapons. The important thing was that the weapons stayed sane long enough to be used. "And I don't expect you to waste time questioning my orders."

"æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," dʒɛdwɪn mʌɾɝd. "aɪl sɛn mɛn aʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli." wɪð ə kɝt səlut, fɪs tə tʃɛst, hi stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stɔɹm. ðə dɛljudʒ bɛn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ʃiɾɪŋ daʊn ðə smɔl ʃild i woʊv ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf. ɹænd wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðə mæn səspɛktəd haʊ kloʊs i hæd kʌm tə daɪɪŋ wən i siz seɪɾɪn wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ.

"As you command, my Lord Dragon," Gedwyn muttered. "I'll send men out immediately." With a curt salute, fist to chest, he strode out into the storm. The deluge bent away from him, sheeting down the small shield he wove around himself. Rand wondered whether the man suspected how close he had come to dying when he seized saidin without warning.

jə mʌs kɪl ɪm bɪfɔɹ i kɪlz ju, luz θɝɪn ɡɪɡəld. ðeɪ wɪl, jə noʊ. dɛd mɛn kæn bɪtʃɹeɪ ɛniwʌn. ðə vɔɪs ɪn ɹændz hɛd tɝnd wʌndɝɪŋ. bʌt səmtaɪmz ðeɪ doʊn daɪ. æm aɪ dɛd? ɑɹ ju?

You must kill him before he kills you, Lews Therin giggled. They will, you know. Dead men can't betray anyone. The voice in Rand's head turned wondering. But sometimes they don't die. Am I dead? Are you?

ɹænd pʊʃt ðə wɝdz daʊn tə ə flaɪz bʌzɪŋ, dʒʌst ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə noʊɾəs. sɪns ɪz ɹiəpɪɹəns ɪnsaɪd ɹændz hɛd, luz θɝɪn sɛldəm wɛn saɪlən ənlɛs fɔɹst. ðə mæn simd mæɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ moʊst ə ðə taɪm, ən juʒəwəli æŋɡɹiɝ əz wɛl. stʃɹɔŋɝ səmtaɪmz, tu. ðət vɔɪs ɪnveɪɾəd ɹændz dʒɹimz, ən wən i sɔ hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə dʒɹim, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz hɪmsɛlf əɾ ɔl ðəɾ i sɔ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz luz θɝɪn, iðɝ, ðə feɪs i hæd kʌm tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əz luz θɝɪnz. səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz blɝd, jɛt veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ, ən luz θɝɪn sim stɑɹɾəld baɪ ɪt, tu. ðət wɑz ən ɪndəkeɪʃən haʊ fɑɹ ðə mænz mædnəs wɛnt. əɹ meɪbi hɪz oʊn.

Rand pushed the words down to a fly's buzzing, just on the edge of notice. Since his reappearance inside Rand's head, Lews Therin seldom went silent unless forced. The man seemed madder than ever most of the time, and usually angrier as well. Stronger sometimes, too. That voice invaded Rand's dreams, and when he saw himself in a dream, it was not always himself at all that he saw. It was not always Lews Therin, either, the face he had come to recognize as Lews Therin's. Sometimes it was blurred, yet vaguely familiar, and Lews Therin seemed startled by it, too. That was an indication how far the man's madness went. Or maybe his own.

nɑt jɛt, ɹænd θɔt. aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə ɡoʊ mæd jɛt.

Not yet, Rand thought. I can't afford to go mad yet.

wɛn, ðɛn? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd mjuɾ ɪm əɡɛn.

When, then? Lews Therin whispered before Rand could mute him again.

wɪð ði ɝaɪvəl ə dʒɛdwɪn ən ði æʃəmən, hɪz plæn tə swip ðə sintʃæn wɛstwɝd ɡɑɾ ʌndɝ weɪ. ɡɑɾ ʌndɝ weɪ, ən kɹɛp fɔɹwɝɾ əz sloʊli əz ə mæn leɪbɝɪŋ əlɔŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz maɪɹd ɹoʊdz. hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz oʊn kæmp ət wʌns, meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt tə haɪɾ ɪz muvməns. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl pɔɪn tə stʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ sikɹəsi. wɝd tʃɹævəl sloʊli baɪ pɪdʒən, ən fɑɹ sloʊɝ baɪ kɝiɝ, wʌns ðə sɛmɑɹoʊz keɪm, jɛɾ i hæd noʊ daʊts i wɑz wɑtʃt, baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, baɪ ðə fɔɹseɪkən, baɪ ɛniwʌn u sɔ ɡeɪn əɹ lɔs ɪn wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɛn ən kəɾ əfɔɹd tə slɪp kɔɪn tə ə soʊlʒɝ. meɪbi ivən baɪ ðə sintʃæn. ɪf i kəd skaʊt ðɛm, waɪ nɑt ðeɪ hɪm? bʌt nɑɾ ivən ði æʃəmən nu waɪ hi wɑz muvɪŋ.

With the arrival of Gedwyn and the Asha'man, his plan to sweep the Seanchan westward got under way. Got under way, and crept forward as slowly as a man laboring along one of those mired roads. He shifted his own camp at once, making no effort to hide his movements. There was little point to straining for secrecy. Word traveled slowly by pigeon, and far slower by courier, once the cemaros came, yet he had no doubts he was watched, by the White Tower, by the Forsaken, by anyone who saw gain or loss in where the Dragon Reborn went and could afford to slip coin to a soldier. Maybe even by the Seanchan. If he could scout them, why not they him? But not even the Asha'man knew why he was moving.

waɪl ɹænd wɑz aɪdli wɑtʃɪŋ mɛn foʊld ɪz tɛn ɑntu ə haɪ-wil kɑɹt, wɪɹɑmɑn əpɪɹɾ ɑn wʌn ə hɪz mɛni hɔɹsəz, ə pɹænsɪŋ waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ ə ðə faɪnəs tɛɹən blʌdstɑk. ðə ɹeɪn hæd klɪɹd, ðoʊ ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz stɪl veɪl ðə nundeɪ sʌn ən ði ɛɹ fɛlt əz ɪf jə kəd skwiz wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt wɪð jəɹ hænz. ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ ən ðə bænɝ ə laɪt hʌŋ lɪmp ən sɑɾən ɑn ðɛɹ tɔl stæfs.

While Rand was idly watching men fold his tent onto a high-wheeled cart, Weiramon appeared on one of his many horses, a prancing white gelding of the finest Tairen bloodstock. The rain had cleared, though gray clouds still veiled the noonday sun and the air felt as if you could squeeze water out of it with your hands. The Dragon Banner and the Banner of Light hung limp and sodden on their tall staffs.

tɛɹən dɪfɛndɝz hæd ɹipleɪs ðə kəmpænjənz, ən əz wɪɹɑmɑn ɹoʊd θɹu ðɛɹ maʊntəd ɹɪŋ, hi fɹaʊn ət ɹɑdʒɹəvɑɹ taɪhɛɹə, ə lin fɛloʊ, dɑɹk ivən fəɹ ə tɛɹən, wɪð ə ʃɔɹt bɪɹd tʃɹɪm tə ə vɛɹi ʃɑɹp pɔɪnt. ə vɛɹi maɪnɝ noʊbəl u hæd hæd tə ɹaɪz θɹu hɪz əbɪləɾiz, taɪhɛɹə wɑz pəŋktɪliəs ɪn ði ɪkstʃɹim. ðə fæt waɪt plumz bɑbɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɹɪm hɛlməɾ æɾəd ɛmbɛlɪʃmən tə ði ɪlæbɹət baʊ hi ɡeɪv wɪɹɑmɑn. ðə haɪ lɔɹdz fɹaʊn dipənd.

Tairen Defenders had replaced the Companions, and as Weiramon rode through their mounted ring, he frowned at Rodrivar Tihera, a lean fellow, dark even for a Tairen, with a short beard trimmed to a very sharp point. A very minor noble who had had to rise through his abilities, Tihera was punctilious in the extreme. The fat white plumes bobbing on his rimmed helmet added embellishment to the elaborate bow he gave Weiramon. The High Lord's frown deepened.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ ðə kæptən ə ðə stoʊn tə bi pɝsənəli ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ɹændz bɑɾiɡɑɹd, bʌɾ i fɹikwənli wɑz, dʒʌst əz mɑɹkəlɪn ɔfən kəmændəd ðə kəmpænjənz hɪmsɛlf. ən ɔfən bɪɾɝ ɹaɪvəlɹi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp bɪtwin dɪfɛndɝz ən kəmpænjənz, sɛntɝɪŋ ɑn u ʃəd ɡɑɹd ɹænd. ðə tɛɹənz kleɪm ðə ɹaɪt kəz i hæd ɹuld lɔŋɡɝ ɪn tɛɹ, ði ɪliɑnɝz kəz i wɑz, æftɝ ɔl, kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən. pɝhæps wɪɹɑmɑn hæd hɝd səm ə ðə mʌɾɝz əmʌŋ ðə dɪfɛndɝz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm tiɹ hæɾ ə kɪŋ ʌv ɪts oʊn, ən u bɛɾɝ ðən ðə mæn u hæd teɪkən ðə stoʊn? wɪɹɑmɑn mɔɹ ðən əɡɹid wɪð ðə nid, bʌt nɑt wɪð ðə tʃɔɪs ə hu ʃəd wɛɹ ðə kɹaʊn. hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn.

There was no need for the Captain of the Stone to be personally in charge of Rand's bodyguard, but he frequently was, just as Marcolin often commanded the Companions himself. An often bitter rivalry had grown up between Defenders and Companions, centering on who should guard Rand. The Tairens claimed the right because he had ruled longer in Tear, the Illianers because he was, after all, King of Illian. Perhaps Weiramon had heard some of the mutters among the Defenders that it was time Tear had a king of its own, and who better than the man who had taken the Stone? Weiramon more than agreed with the need, but not with the choice of who should wear the crown. He was not the only one.

ðə mæn smuðd ɪz fitʃɝz əz sun əz i sɔ ɹænd lʊkɪŋ, ən swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz ɡoʊld-tul sæɾəl tə ɔfɝ ə baʊ ðət meɪd taɪhɛɹəz sim sɪmpəl. aɪɝn-spaɪn əz i wɑz, hi kəd pʌf ʌp ən stʃɹʌɾ ɪn ɪz slip. ðoʊ hi dɪd ɡɹɪmɑs slaɪtli ət pʊɾɪŋ ɪz pɑlɪʃt buɾ ɪndə ðə mʌd. hi wɔɹ ə ɹeɪn keɪp, tə kip ðə mɪst ɔf ɪz faɪn kloʊðz, bʌɾ ivən ðət wɑz ɛnkɹʌstɪd wɪð ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən hæɾ ə kɑlɝ ə sæfaɪɝz. fəɹ ɔl ə ɹændz koʊɾ ə dip ɡɹin sɪlk, wɪð ɡoʊldən biz klaɪmɪŋ ðə slivz ən ləpɛlz, ɛniwʌn maɪɾ əv bɪn fɝɡɪvən fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz bɪlɔŋd ɑn ði ʌðɝz hɛd, nɑt hɪz.

The man smoothed his features as soon as he saw Rand looking, and swung down from his gold-tooled saddle to offer a bow that made Tihera's seem simple. Iron-spined as he was, he could puff up and strut in his sleep. Though he did grimace slightly at putting his polished boot into the mud. He wore a rain cape, to keep the mist off his fine clothes, but even that was encrusted with gold embroidery and had a collar of sapphires. For all of Rand's coat of deep green silk, with golden bees climbing the sleeves and lapels, anyone might have been forgiven for thinking the Crown of Swords belonged on the other's head, not his.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," wɪɹɑmɑn ɪntoʊnd. "aɪ kænɑɾ ɪkspɹɛs haʊ hæpi aɪm tə si jə ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ tɛɹənz, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ʃʊɹli ðə wɝld wəd wip ɪf ɛniθɪŋ əntuɔɹd hæpənd." hi wɑz tu ɪntɛlədʒən tə kʌm aʊɾ ən kɔl ðə kəmpænjənz əntʃɹʌstwɝði. baɪ ə hɛɹ, hi wɑz.

"My Lord Dragon," Weiramon intoned. "I cannot express how happy I am to see you guarded by Tairens, my Lord Dragon. Surely the world would weep if anything untoward happened." He was too intelligent to come out and call the Companions untrustworthy. By a hair, he was.

"sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ɪt wʊd," ɹænd sɛd dʒɹaɪli. æftɝ ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt fɪnɪʃt sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ. "aɪ noʊ haʊ hɑɹd jud kɹaɪ, wɪɹɑmɑn."

"Sooner or later it would," Rand said dryly. After a good part of it finished celebrating. "I know how hard you'd cry, Weiramon."

ðə fɛloʊ æktʃəli  pɹind, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik bɪɹd. hi hɝd wʌɾ i wɑntəd tə hɪɹ. "jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, jə kən bi əʃʊɹɾ ə maɪ kɑnstənsi. wɪtʃ ɪz waɪ aɪm kənsɝn baɪ ði ɔɹɾɝz jəɹ mæn bɹɔt mi ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ." ðət wɑz ædli; mɛni ʌv ðə noʊbəlz θɔt pɹitɛndɪŋ ði æʃəmən wɝ mɪɹli ɹændz sɝvəns wəd sʌmhaʊ meɪk əm lɛs deɪnʒɝəs. "waɪz ə jə tə sɛn əweɪ moʊst ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn. ən ði ɪliɑnɝz, ʌv kɔɹs; ðət ɡoʊz wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ. aɪ kən ivən ʌndɝstænd waɪ jə lɪmət ɡəm ən ði ʌðɝz." wɪɹɑmɑnz buts skwɛltʃt ɪn ðə mʌɾ əz i stɛp nɪɹɝ, ən ɪz vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ə kənfaɪɾɪŋ toʊn. "aɪ də bɪliv səm ə ðɛm - aɪ wʊdn seɪ plɑɾəd əɡɛns ju, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk pɝhæps ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti hæz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn wɪθaʊt kwɛstʃən. əz maɪn ɪz. wɪθaʊt kwɛstʃən." hɪz vɔɪs ʃɪftəɾ əɡɛn, tə stʃɹɔŋ ən kɑnfəɾənt, ə mæn kənsɝn oʊnli wɪð ðə nidz ə ðə wʌn i sɝvd. ðə wʌn u ʃʊɹli wəd meɪk ɪm ðə fɝs kɪŋ ə tɛɹ. "əlaʊ mi tə bɹɪŋ ɔl ə maɪ ɑɹmmɪn, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. wɪð ðɛm, ən ðə dɪfɛndɝz, aɪ kən əʃʊɹ ði ɑnɝ ə ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ɪz seɪfti."

The fellow actually preened, stroking the point of his gray-streaked beard. He heard what he wanted to hear. "Yes, my Lord Dragon, you can be assured of my constancy. Which is why I'm concerned by the orders your man brought me this morning." That was Adley; many of the nobles thought pretending the Asha'man were merely Rand's servants would somehow make them less dangerous. "Wise of you to send away most of the Cairhienin. And the Illianers, of course; that goes without saying. I can even understand why you limit Gueyam and the others." Weiramon's boots squelched in the mud as he stepped nearer, and his voice took on a confiding tone. "I do believe some of them - I wouldn't say plotted against you, but I think perhaps their loyalty has not always been without question. As mine is. Without question." His voice shifted again, to strong and confident, a man concerned only with the needs of the one he served. The one who surely would make him the first King of Tear. "Allow me to bring all of my armsmen, my Lord Dragon. With them, and the Defenders, I can assure the honor of the Lord of the Morning, and his safety."

ɪn ɔl ə ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl kæmps əkɹɔs ðə hiθ, wæɡənz ən kɑɹts wɝ biɪŋ loʊɾəd, hɔɹsəz sæɾəld. moʊs tɛns wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi daʊn. ðə haɪ leɪɾi ɹoʊzænə wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɔɹθ, hɝ bænɝ hɛɾɪŋ ə kɑləm lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə ɹeɪz hævək əmʌŋ ðə bændəts ən ət list ɡɪv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ pɔz. bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə plænt noʊʃənz ɪn əɹ hɛd, ɪspɛʃli nɑt wən hæf wɝ ɡəmz ən mɑɹəkənz ɹɪteɪnɝz mɪkst wɪð dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn. mʌtʃ ðə seɪm əplaɪd tə spɪɝən nɛɹɛɾɪn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ istwɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə tɔl ɹɪdʒ wɪð əz mɛni kəmpænjənz ən mɛn swɔɹn tə ʌðɝz ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn əz ɪz oʊn lidʒmən, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ teɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɑn fʊt, səm ə ðə fɛloʊz u hæd sɝɛndɝɾ ɪn ðə wʊdz bɪɑn ðət ɹɪdʒ ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ. ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ nʌmbɝ hæd tʃoʊzən tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌst əm ɪnʌf tə liv əm təɡɛðɝ. toʊlmɝæn wɑz dʒʌst stɑɹɾɪŋ saʊθ wɪð ðə seɪm kaɪndə blɛnd, ən ʌðɝz wəd bi mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɔf əz sun əz ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ kɑɹts ən wæɡənz loʊɾəd. itʃ ɪn ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən, ən nʌn eɪbəl tə tʃɹʌs ðə mɛn ət ðɛɹ bæks fɑɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə də mɔɹ ðən fɑloʊ ði ɔɹɾɝz ɹænd hæd ɡɪvən. bɹɪŋɪŋ pis tə ɪljən wɑz ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk, jɛɾ ɛvɹi læs lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd biɪŋ sɛn əweɪ fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, pleɪnli wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ɪt mɛn ðeɪ hæd slɪpt ɪn ɪz tʃɹʌst. ðoʊ ə fju maɪɾ əv kənsɪɾɝd waɪ hi tʃoʊz tə kip ðoʊz i dɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz aɪ. ɹoʊzænə hæd sɝɾənli lʊk θɔtfəl.

In all of the individual camps across the heath, wagons and carts were being loaded, horses saddled. Most tents were already down. The High Lady Rosana was riding north, her banner heading a column large enough to raise havoc among the bandits and at least give the Shaido pause. But not enough to plant notions in her head, especially not when half were Gueyam's and Maraconn's retainers mixed with Defenders of the Stone. Much the same applied to Spiron Narettin, riding eastward over the tall ridge with as many Companions and men sworn to others of the Council of Nine as his own liegemen, not to mention a hundred more tailing behind on foot, some of the fellows who had surrendered in the woods beyond that ridge the day before. A surprising number had chosen to follow the Dragon Reborn, but Rand did not trust them enough to leave them together. Tolmeran was just starting south with the same kind of blend, and others would be marching off as soon as they had their carts and wagons loaded. Each in a different direction, and none able to trust the men at their backs far enough for them to do more than follow the orders Rand had given. Bringing peace to Illian was an important task, yet every last lord and lady regretted being sent away from the Dragon Reborn, plainly wondering whether it meant they had slipped in his trust. Though a few might have considered why he chose to keep those he did under his eye. Rosana had certainly looked thoughtful.

"jɔɹ kənsɝn tʌtʃəz mi," ɹænd toʊld wɪɹɑmɑn, "bʌt haʊ mɛni bɑɾiɡɑɹdz dʌz wʌn mæn nid? aɪm nɑɾ ɔf tə stɑɹɾ ə wɔɹ." ə faɪn pɔɪnt, pɝhæps, jɛt ðɪs wɔɹ wɑz wɛl ʌndɝ weɪ. ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn ət fɑlm, ɪf nɑt bɪfɔɹ. "ɡɛt jəɹ pipəl ɹɛɾi."

"Your concern touches me," Rand told Weiramon, "but how many bodyguards does one man need? I'm not off to start a war." A fine point, perhaps, yet this war was well under way. It had begun at Falme, if not before. "Get your people ready."

haʊ mɛni hæv daɪd fəɹ maɪ pɹaɪd? luz θɝɪn moʊnd. haʊ mɛni hæv daɪd fəɹ maɪ mɪsteɪks?

How many have died for my pride? Lews Therin moaned. How many have died for my mistakes?

"meɪ aɪ ət list æsk wɛɹ wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ?" wɪɹɑmɑnz kwɛstʃən, nɑt kwaɪɾ ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd, keɪm ɹaɪɾ ətɑp ðə vɔɪs ɪn ɹændz hɛd.

"May I at least ask where we are going?" Weiramon's question, not quite exasperated, came right atop the voice in Rand's head.

"ðə sɪɾi," ɹænd snæpt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni hæd daɪd fəɹ ɪz mɪsteɪks, bʌt nʌn fəɹ ɪz pɹaɪd. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðæt.

"The City," Rand snapped. He did not know how many had died for his mistakes, but none for his pride. He was sure of that.

wɪɹɑmɑn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, pleɪnli kənfjuzd əz tə wɛðɝ i mɛn tiɹ əɹ ɪljən, əɹ meɪbi ivən kɛɹhin, bʌt ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪm əweɪ wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ, ə ʃɑɹp stæbɪŋ moʊʃən ðət meɪd ðə ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt tæsəl swɪŋ. hi hæf wɪʃt i kəd stæb luz θɝɪn wɪð ɪt. "aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə sɪt hɪɹ ɔl deɪ, wɪɹɑmɑn! ɡoʊ tə jəɹ mɛn!"

Weiramon opened his mouth, plainly confused as to whether he meant Tear or Illian, or maybe even Cairhien, but Rand gestured him away with the Dragon Scepter, a sharp stabbing motion that made the green-and-white tassel swing. He half wished he could stab Lews Therin with it. "I don't intend to sit here all day, Weiramon! Go to your men!"

lɛs ðən ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ i tʊk hoʊld ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən pɹipɛɹd tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ. hi hæd tə faɪt ðə dɪzinəs ðət ɡɹɪpt ɪm leɪtli wɛnɛvɝ i sizd əɹ lus ðə paʊɝ; hi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt sweɪ ɪn teɪdeɪʃɝz sæɾəl. wʌt wɪð ðə moʊltən fɪlθ floʊɾɪŋ ɑn seɪɾɪn, ðə fɹoʊzən slaɪm, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹs keɪm kloʊs tə ɛmptiɪŋ ɪz stʌmək. siɪŋ dʌbəl, ivən fəɹ oʊnli ə fju moʊməns, meɪd wivɪŋ floʊz dɪfəkəlt ɪf nɑɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl, ən i cʊɾə toʊl dæʃivə əɹ flɪn əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz tə də ɪt, bʌt dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɝ hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' ɹeɪnz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ blæk-koʊɾəd soʊlʒɝz, ɔl u hæd nɑt bɪn aʊt tə sɝtʃ. dʒʌst stændɪŋ ðəɹ peɪʃənli. ən wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd. ɹɑtʃeɪd, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd ən meɪbi tu jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ, wɑz ɔlsoʊ fʊl æʃəmən, ən ɪz koʊt, tu, wɑz sɪlk. ə smɔl smaɪl pleɪɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, əz ɪf i nu θɪŋz ʌðɝz dɪd nɑɾ ən wɑz əmjuzd. wʌɾ i noʊ? əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn, ʃʊɹli, ɪf nɑt ɹændz plænz fəɹ ðɛm. wʌɾ ɛls? meɪbi nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ɹænd wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ʃoʊ ɛni wiknəs ɪn fɹʌn ə ðət pɛɹ. ðə dɪzinəs feɪɾəd kwɪkli, ðə twɪn saɪɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ sloʊli, əz ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd, ðiz læs fju wiks, ən i kəmpliɾəd ðə wiv, ðɛn, wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ, dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz ən ɹoʊd θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ ðəɾ ənfoʊldəd bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

Less than an hour later he took hold of the True Source and prepared to make a gateway for Traveling. He had to fight the dizziness that gripped him lately whenever he seized or loosed the Power; he did not quite sway in Tai'daishar's saddle. What with the molten filth floating on saidin, the frozen slime, touching the Source came close to emptying his stomach. Seeing double, even for only a few moments, made weaving flows difficult if not impossible, and he could have told Dashiva or Flinn or one of the others to do it, but Gedwyn and Rochaid were holding their horses' reins in front of a dozen or so black-coated Soldiers, all who had not been out to search. Just standing there patiently. And watching Rand. Rochaid, no more than a hand shorter than Rand and maybe two years younger, was also full Asha'man, and his coat, too, was silk. A small smile played on his face, as if he knew things others did not and was amused. What did he know? About the Seanchan, surely, if not Rand's plans for them. What else? Maybe nothing, but Rand was not about to show any weakness in front of that pair. The dizziness faded quickly, the twinned sight a little more slowly, as it always did, these last few weeks, and he completed the weave, then, without waiting, dug in his heels and rode through the opening that unfolded before him.

ðə sɪɾi hi hæd mɛnt wɑz ɪljən, ðoʊ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən tə ðə nɔɹθ ə ðət sɪɾi. dɪspaɪt wɪɹɑmɑnz səpoʊz kənsɝnz, hi hɑɹdli wɛn ʌnpɹətɛktɪɾ ən əloʊn. nɪɹli θɹi θaʊzən mɛn ɹoʊd θɹu ðət tɔl skwɛɹ hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɪndə ɹoʊlɪŋ mɛɾoʊlənd nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə bɹɔd mʌɾi ɹoʊd ðət lɛd daʊn tə ðə kɑzweɪ ʌv ðə nɔɹðɝn stɑɹ. ivən wən ɛvɹi lɔɹd hæɾ oʊnli bɪn əlaʊɾ ə hændfʊl ʌv ɑɹmmɪn - tə mɛn əkʌstəm tə liɾɪŋ ə θaʊzən ɪf nɑt θaʊzənz, ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ wɝ ə hændfʊl - ðeɪ æɾəd ʌp. tɛɹənz ən kɛɹhinɪn ən ɪliɑnɝz, dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ taɪhɛɹə ən kəmpænjənz ʌndɝ mɑɹkəlɪn, æʃəmən hilɪŋ dʒɛdwɪn. ði æʃəmən u hæd kʌm wɪð hɪm, ɛniweɪ. dæʃivə ən flɪn ən ðə ɹɛs kɛp ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɹænd. ɔl bʌt nɛɹɪʃmə. nɛɹɪʃmə hæd nɑt kʌm bæk jɛt. ðə mæn nu wɛɹ tə faɪn hɪm, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt.

The City he had meant was Illian, though the gateway opened to the north of that city. Despite Weiramon's supposed concerns, he hardly went unprotected and alone. Nearly three thousand men rode through that tall square hole in the air, into rolling meadowland not far from the broad muddy road that led down to the Causeway of the Northern Star. Even when every lord had only been allowed a handful of armsmen - to men accustomed to leading a thousand if not thousands, a hundred or so were a handful - they added up. Tairens and Cairhienin and Illianers, Defenders of the Stone under Tihera and Companions under Marcolin, Asha'man heeling Gedwyn. The Asha'man who had come with him, anyway. Dashiva and Flinn and the rest kept their horses close behind Rand. All but Narishma. Narishma had not come back yet. The man knew where to find him, but Rand did not like it.

itʃ kaɪn kɛp tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl. ɡəm ən mɑɹəkən ən ɑɹəkʌm ɹoʊd wɪð wɪɹɑmɑn, ɔl aɪɪŋ ɹænd mɔɹ ðən wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn pɑnɝ wɪð θɹi ʌðɝz ə ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn, linɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz tə spik sɔfli ən ənizəli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. səmɝædʒɹɪd, wɪð ə nɑɾ ə taɪt-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹdz bɪhaɪn hɪm, wɑtʃt ɹænd ɔlmoʊst əz kloʊsli əz ðə tɛɹənz dɪd. ɹænd hæd tʃoʊzən ðoʊz u keɪm wɪð ɪm əz kɛɹfəli əz ðoʊz i sɛn əweɪ, nɑɾ ɔlweɪz fəɹ ðə ɹizənz ʌðɝz maɪɾ əv juzd.

Each kind kept to themselves as much as possible. Gueyam and Maraconn and Aracome rode with Weiramon, all eyeing Rand more than where they were going, and Gregorin Panar with three others of the Council of Nine, leaning in their saddles to speak softly and uneasily among themselves. Semaradrid, with a knot of tight-faced Cairhienin lords behind him, watched Rand almost as closely as the Tairens did. Rand had chosen those who came with him as carefully as those he sent away, not always for the reasons others might have used.

hæd ðəɹ bɪn ɛni ɔnlʊkɝz, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə bɹeɪv dɪspleɪ, wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ bɹaɪt bænɝz ən pɛnəns, ən smɔl kɑn ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm səm ə ðə kɛɹhinɪnz bæks. bɹaɪɾ ən bɹeɪv ən vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs. səm hæd plɑɾəd əɡɛns hɪm, ən i hæd lɝn ðət səmɝædʒɹɪdz haʊs mɛɹɑvɪn hæɾ oʊld əlaɪənsəz wɪð haʊs ɹieɪɾən, wɪtʃ stʊɾ ɪn oʊpən ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ɪm ɪn kɛɹhin. səmɝædʒɹɪd dɪd nɑt dɪnaɪ ðə kənɛkʃən, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt mɛnʃən ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɹænd hɝd, iðɝ. ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn wɝ dʒʌs tu nu tə hɪm tə ɹɪsk livɪŋ əm ɔl bɪhaɪnd. ən wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz ə ful. lɛf tə hɪz oʊn dɪvaɪsəz, hi maɪt wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡeɪn ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz feɪvɝ baɪ mɑɹtʃɪŋ ən ɑɹmi əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn, əɹ mʊɹændi, əɹ ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu hu əɹ wɛɹ. tu stupəd tə liv bɪhaɪnd, tu paʊɝfəl tə ʃʌv əsaɪd, soʊ hi ɹoʊd wɪð ɹænd ən θɔt hɪmsɛlf ɑnɝd. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ə pɪɾi hi wɑz nɑt stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə də sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd ɡɛɾ ɪm ɛksəkjuɾəd.

Had there been any onlookers, it would have been a brave display, with all their bright banners and pennants, and small con rising from some of the Cairhienin's backs. Bright and brave and very dangerous. Some had plotted against him, and he had learned that Semaradrid's House Maravin had old alliances with House Riatin, which stood in open rebellion against him in Cairhien. Semaradrid did not deny the connection, but he had not mentioned it before Rand heard, either. The Council of Nine were just too new to him to risk leaving them all behind. And Weiramon was a fool. Left to his own devices, he might well try to gain the Lord Dragon's favor by marching an army against the Seanchan, or Murandy, or the Light alone knew who or where. Too stupid to leave behind, too powerful to shove aside, so he rode with Rand and thought himself honored. It was almost a pity he was not stupid enough to do something that would get him executed.

bɪhaɪn keɪm ðə sɝvəns ən kɑɹts - noʊ wʌn ʌndɝstʊd waɪ ɹænd hæd sɛn ɔl ə ðə wæɡənz wɪð ði ʌðɝz, ən i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɪkspleɪn; hu oʊn ðə nɛks pɛɹ ʌv ɪɹz ðət wəd hɪɹ? - ən ðən ðə lɔŋ stʃɹɪŋz ə spɛɹ maʊns lɛd baɪ hɔɹs hænlɝz, ən stʃɹæɡəlɪŋ faɪlz ə mɛn ɪn bæɾɝd bɹɛstpleɪts ðət dɪd nɑt kwaɪt fɪɾ əɹ lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪnz soʊn wɪð ɹʌsti stil dɪsks, kæɹiɪŋ baʊz əɹ kɹɔsboʊz əɹ spɪɹz, ən ivən ə fju paɪks; mɔɹ ə ðə fɛloʊz u hæɾ oʊbeɪd "lɔɹd bɹɛnz" sʌmənz ən dɪsaɪɾɪd əɡɛnst ɡoʊɪŋ hoʊm ənɑɹmd. ðɛɹ liɾɝ wɑz ðə ɹʌni-noʊz mæn ɹænd hæd spoʊkən tə ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wʊdz, iɡən pædʒɹoʊs baɪ neɪm ən mʌtʃ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən i lʊkt. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl fəɹ ə kɑmənɝ tə ɹaɪz vɛɹi fɑɹ, moʊs pleɪsəz, bʌt ɹænd hæd mɑɹk pædʒɹoʊs aʊt. ðə fɛloʊ ɡæðɝɾ ɪz mɛn ɔf tə wʌn saɪd, bʌt ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm mɪld əbaʊt, ɛlboʊɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ əsaɪd fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ vju saʊθwɝd.

Behind came the servants and carts - no one understood why Rand had sent all of the wagons with the others, and he was not about to explain; who owned the next pair of ears that would hear? - and then the long strings of spare mounts led by horse handlers, and straggling files of men in battered breastplates that did not quite fit or leather jerkins sewn with rusty steel discs, carrying bows or crossbows or spears, and even a few pikes; more of the fellows who had obeyed "Lord Brend's" summons and decided against going home unarmed. Their leader was the runny-nosed man Rand had spoken to on the edge of the woods, Eagan Padros by name and much brighter than he looked. It was difficult for a commoner to rise very far, most places, but Rand had marked Padros out. The fellow gathered his men off to one side, but the whole lot of them milled about, elbowing one another aside for a better view southward.

ðə kɑzweɪ ʌv ðə nɔɹðɝn stɑɹ stʃɹɛtʃt æɹoʊ-stʃɹeɪt θɹu ðə maɪlz ə bɹaʊn mɑɹʃ ðət sɝaʊndəɾ ɪljən, ə waɪd ɹoʊɾ ə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt bɹoʊkən baɪ flæt stoʊn bɹɪdʒəz. ə wɪn fɹəm ðə saʊθ kæɹid si sɔlt ən ə hɪn ə tænɝiz. ɪljən wɑz ə spɹɔlɪŋ sɪɾi, izəli əz lɑɹdʒ əz keɪɛmlɪn əɹ kɛɹhin. bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd ɹuf taɪlz ən hʌnʒɹədz ə θɹʌstɪŋ taʊɝz, ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, wɝ dʒʌs vɪzəbəl əkɹɔs ðət si ʌv ɡɹæs wɛɹ lɔŋ-lɛɡəd kɹeɪnz weɪɾɪd ən flɑks ʌv waɪt bɝdz flu loʊ ʌɾɝɪŋ ʃɹɪl kɹaɪz. ɪljən hæd nɛvɝ niɾəd wɔlz. nɑt ðət wɔlz wʊɾə dʌn ðə sɪɾi ɛni ɡʊɾ əɡɛns hɪm.

The Causeway of the Northern Star stretched arrow-straight through the miles of brown marsh that surrounded Illian, a wide road of hard-packed dirt broken by flat stone bridges. A wind from the south carried sea salt and a hint of tanneries. Illian was a sprawling city, easily as large as Caemlyn or Cairhien. Brightly colored roof tiles and hundreds of thrusting towers, gleaming in the sun, were just visible across that sea of grass where long-legged cranes waded and flocks of white birds flew low uttering shrill cries. Illian had never needed walls. Not that walls would have done the City any good against him.

ðəɹ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbəl dɪsəpɔɪnmənt ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt min tə ɛntɝ ɪljən, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn spoʊk ə kəmpleɪnt, ət lis nɑt wɛɹ i kəd hɪɹ. stɪl, ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ɡlʌm feɪsəz ən saʊɝ mʌɾɝz əz heɪsti kæmps bɪɡæn ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp. laɪk moʊst ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, ɪljən hæɾ ə neɪm fəɹ ɪɡzɑɾɪk mɪstɝi, fɹi-hændəd tæpstɝz, ən wɪlɪŋ wɪmən. ət list əmʌŋ mɛn u hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðɛɹ, ivən wən ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ oʊn kæpəɾəl. ɪɡnɝəns ɔlweɪz ɪnfleɪɾəd ə sɪɾiz ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ sətʃ θɪŋz. əz ɪt wɑz, oʊnli mɔɹ ɡæləpt ɔf əkɹɔs ðə kɑzweɪ. mɛn stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm hæmɝɪŋ tɛn pɛɡz əɹ sɛɾɪŋ pɪkət laɪnz fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz, ən fɑloʊɾ ɪm wɪð dʒɛləs aɪz. noʊbəlz wɑtʃt kjʊɹiəsli, waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn ðeɪ wɝ nɑt.

There was considerable disappointment that he did not mean to enter Illian, though no one spoke a complaint, at least not where he could hear. Still, there were plenty of glum faces and sour mutters as hasty camps began going up. Like most of the great cities, Illian had a name for exotic mystery, free-handed tapsters, and willing women. At least among men who had never been there, even when it was their own capital. Ignorance always inflated a city's reputation for such things. As it was, only Morr galloped off across the causeway. Men straightened from hammering tent pegs or setting picket lines for the horses, and followed him with jealous eyes. Nobles watched curiously, while trying to pretend they were not.

ði æʃəmən wɪð dʒɛdwɪn peɪd mɔɹ noʊ maɪn əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ oʊn kæmp, wɪtʃ kənsɪstəɾ ʌv ə pɪtʃ-blæk tɛn fəɹ dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən ə speɪs wɛɹ dæmp bɹaʊn ɡɹæs ən mʌd wɝ skwiz flæɾ ən dʒɹaɪ, fəɹ ðə ɹɛs tə slip ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks. ðət wɑz dʌn wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs; ðeɪ dɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝɪŋ tə bɪl kʊk faɪɝz. ə fju ɪn ði ʌðɝ kæmps stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm, waɪd-aɪd, əz ðə tɛn sim tə spɹɪŋ ʌp ʌv ɪts oʊn əkɔɹɾ ən hæmpɝz floʊɾəd əweɪ fɹəm pæksæɾəlz, bʌt moʊs lʊkt ɛniwɛɹ ɛls əɾ ɔl wʌns ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ðə blæk-koʊɾəd soʊlʒɝz əpɪɹd tə bi tɔkɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz.

The Asha'man with Gedwyn paid Morr no mind as they made their own camp, which consisted of a pitch-black tent for Gedwyn and Rochaid and a space where damp brown grass and mud were squeezed flat and dry, for the rest to sleep wrapped in their cloaks. That was done with the Power, of course; they did everything with the Power, not even bothering to build cook fires. A few in the other camps stared at them, wide-eyed, as the tent seemed to spring up of its own accord and hampers floated away from packsaddles, but most looked anywhere else at all once they realized what was going on. Two or three of the black-coated Soldiers appeared to be talking to themselves.

flɪn ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd nɑt dʒɔɪn dʒɛdwɪnz lɑt - ðeɪ hæɾ ə pɛɹ ə tɛns ðət wɛn ʌp nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɹændz - bʌt dæʃivə wɑndɝɾ oʊvɝ tə wɛɹ ðə "stɔɹm liɾɝ" ən ði "ətæk liɾɝ" wɝ stændɪŋ ət ðɛɹ iz, ən əkeɪʒənəli ɪʃuɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp ɔɹɾɝ. ə fju wɝdz, ən i wɑndɝd bæk ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɝ nɑɾ ə fɹɛnli pɛɹ. əz wɛl ðeɪ wɝ nɑt.

Flinn and the others did not join Gedwyn's lot - they had a pair of tents that went up not far from Rand's - but Dashiva wandered over to where the "Storm Leader" and the "Attack Leader" were standing at their ease, and occasionally issuing a sharp order. A few words, and he wandered back shaking his head and muttering angrily under his breath. Gedwyn and Rochaid were not a friendly pair. As well they were not.

ɹænd tʊk tə hɪz tɛn əz sun əz ɪt wɑz pɪtʃt, ən spɹɔl fʊli kloʊðd ɑn ɪz kɑt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə sləp silɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ biz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ði ɪnsaɪɾ əz wɛl, ɑn ə fɔls ɹuf meɪɾ ə sɪlk. hɑpwəl bɹɔɾ ə stimɪŋ pjuɾɝ mʌɡ ʌv mʌld waɪn - ɹænd hæd lɛft ɪz sɝvəns bɪhaɪnd - bʌt ðə waɪn ɡɹu koʊld ɑn ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. hɪz maɪnd wɝk fɛvɝɪʃli. tu əɹ θɹi mɔɹ deɪz, ən ðə sintʃæn wʊɾə bɪn dɛlt ə bloʊ ðət nɑkt əm ɑn ðɛɹ hilz. ðən ɪt wɑz bæk tə kɛɹhin tə si haʊ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪð ðə si foʊk hæd ɡɔn, tə lɝn wʌt kædzueɪn wɑz æftɝ - hi oʊɾ əɹ ə dɛt, bʌt ʃi wɑz æftɝ sʌmθɪŋ! - meɪbi tə pʊɾ ə faɪnəl ɛn tə wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə ɹɪbɛljən ðɛɹ. hæd kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹɾ ən dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə slɪpt əweɪ ɪn ðə kənfjuʒən? ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɪn ɪz hænz maɪt fɪnɪʃ ðə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn tiɹ, əz wɛl. ændɝ. ɪf mæt ən ɪleɪn wɝ ɪn mʊɹændi, ðə weɪ ɪɾ əpɪɹd, ɪt wəd bi wiks mɔɹ ət bɛs bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn kəd kleɪm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. wʌns ðət hæpənd, hi wəɾ əv tə steɪ klɪɹ ə keɪɛmlɪn. bʌɾ i hæd tə tɔk tə nɪneɪiv. kəɾ i klɛnz seɪɾɪn? ɪt maɪt wɝk. ɪt maɪt dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə wɝld, tu. luz θɝɪn ɡɪbɝɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn stɑɹk tɛɹɝ. laɪt, wɛɹ wɑz nɛɹɪʃmə?

Rand took to his tent as soon as it was pitched, and sprawled fully clothed on his cot, staring at the sloped ceiling. There were bees embroidered on the inside as well, on a false roof made of silk. Hopwil brought a steaming pewter mug of mulled wine - Rand had left his servants behind - but the wine grew cold on his writing table. His mind worked feverishly. Two or three more days, and the Seanchan would have been dealt a blow that knocked them on their heels. Then it was back to Cairhien to see how negotiations with the Sea Folk had gone, to learn what Cadsuane was after - he owed her a debt, but she was after something! - maybe to put a final end to what remained of the rebellion there. Had Caraline Damodred and Darlin Sisnera slipped away in the confusion? The High Lord Darlin in his hands might finish the rebellion in Tear, as well. Andor. If Mat and Elayne were in Murandy, the way it appeared, it would be weeks more at best before Elayne could claim the Lion Throne. Once that happened, he would have to stay clear of Caemlyn. But he had to talk to Nynaeve. Could he cleanse saidin? It might work. It might destroy the world, too. Lews Therin gibbered at him in stark terror. Light, where was Narishma?

ə sɛmɑɹoʊz stɔɹm swɛpt ɪn, ɔl ðə fɪɹsɝ ðɪs nɪɹ ðə si. ɹeɪn biɾ ɪz tɛn laɪk ə dʒɹʌm. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃɪz fɪl ði ɛntʃɹəns wɪð blu-waɪt laɪt, ən θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld, ðə saʊn laɪk maʊntənz tʌmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə lænd.

A cemaros storm swept in, all the fiercer this near the sea. Rain beat his tent like a drum. Lightning flashes filled the entrance with blue-white light, and thunder rumbled, the sound like mountains tumbling across the land.

aʊɾ ə ðæt, nɛɹɪʃmə stɛpt ɪndə ðə tɛnt, dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɛt, dɑɹk hɛɹ plæstɝd tə hɪz hɛd. hɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs əɾ ɔl kɑst. noʊ flɔntɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. hɪz sɑɾən koʊt wɑz pleɪn bɹaʊn, ən ɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ wɑz taɪd bæk, nɑt bɹeɪɾɪd. ivən wɪθaʊt bɛlz, nɪɹ weɪst-lɛŋθ hɛɹ ɑn ə mæn ətʃɹæktəɾ aɪz. hi wɔɹ ə skaʊl, tu, ən ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm i kæɹiɾ ə səlɪnʒɹɪkəl bʌndəl taɪd wɪð kɔɹd, fæɾɝ ðən ə mænz lɛɡ, laɪk ə smɔl kɑɹpət.

Out of that, Narishma stepped into the tent, dripping wet, dark hair plastered to his head. His orders had been to avoid notice at all cost. No flaunting for him. His sodden coat was plain brown, and his dark hair was tied back, not braided. Even without bells, near waist-length hair on a man attracted eyes. He wore a scowl, too, and under his arm he carried a cylindrical bundle tied with cord, fatter than a man's leg, like a small carpet.

spɹɪŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɑt, ɹænd snætʃt ðə bʌndəl bɪfɔɹ nɛɹɪʃmə kəd pɹɑfɝ ɪt. "dɪɾ ɛniwʌn si ju?" hi dɪmændəd. "wʌt tʊk jə soʊ lɔŋ? aɪ ɪkspɛktəd jə læs naɪt!"

Springing from the cot, Rand snatched the bundle before Narishma could proffer it. "Did anyone see you?" he demanded. "What took you so long? I expected you last night!"

"ɪt tʊk ə waɪl tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə du," nɛɹɪʃmə ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "ju dɪdn tɛl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ. jə nɪɹli kɪl mi."

"It took a while to figure out what I had to do," Narishma replied in a flat voice. "You didn't tell me everything. You nearly killed me."

ðət wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs. ɹænd hæd toʊld ɪm ɛvɹiθɪŋ i niɾəd tə noʊ. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn tə tʃɹʌstɪŋ ðə mæn əz fɑɹ əz i hæd, oʊnli tə hæv ɪm daɪ ən ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. kɛɹfəli hi tʌk ðə bʌndəl bɪniθ ɪz kɑt. hɪz hænz tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð ði ɝdʒ tə stʃɹɪp ðə ɹæpɪŋz əweɪ, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hɛld wʌt nɛɹɪʃmə hæd bɪn sɛn fɔɹ. ðə mæn wəd nɑɾ əv dɛɹd ɹɪtɝn ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt. "ɡɛt jɝsɛlf ɪndə ə pɹɑpɝ koʊt bɪfɔɹ jə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz," hi sɛd. "ænd nɛɹɪʃmə. . . . ɹænd stʃɹeɪɾənd, fɪksɪŋ ði ʌðɝ mæn wɪð ə stɛɾi ɡeɪz. "ju tɛl ɛniwʌn əbaʊt ðɪs, ən əl kɪl ju."

That was ridiculous. Rand had told him everything he needed to know. He was sure of it. There was no point to trusting the man as far as he had, only to have him die and ruin everything. Carefully he tucked the bundle beneath his cot. His hands trembled with the urge to strip the wrappings away, to make sure they held what Narishma had been sent for. The man would not have dared return if they did not. "Get yourself into a proper coat before you join the others," he said. "And Narishma. . . . Rand straightened, fixing the other man with a steady gaze. "You tell anyone about this, and I will kill you."

kɪl ðə hoʊl wɝld, luz θɝɪn læft, ə moʊn ə dɝɪʒən. ʌv dɪspɛɹ. aɪ kɪl ðə wɝld, ən jə kæn, tu, ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ hɑɹd.

Kill the whole world, Lews Therin laughed, a moan of derision. Of despair. I killed the world, and you can, too, if you try hard.

nɛɹɪʃmə stʃɹʌk hɪmsɛlf hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə tʃɛst wɪð ɪz fɪst. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛd saʊɝli.

Narishma struck himself hard on the chest with his fist. "As you command, my Lord Dragon," he said sourly.

bɹaɪɾ ən ɝli ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, ə θaʊzən mɛn ə ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən mɑɹtʃt aʊɾ ʌv ɪljən, əkɹɔs ðə kɑzweɪ ʌv ðə nɔɹðɝn stɑɹ, stɛpɪŋ tə ðə stɛɾi biɾ ə dʒɹʌmz. wɛl, ɪt wɑz ɝli, ɛniweɪ. θɪk ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz ɹɔɪld əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, ən ə stɪf si bɹiz ʃɑɹp wɪð sɔlt wɪp kloʊks ən bænɝz, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌv ənʌðɝ stɔɹm ɑn ðə weɪ. ðə lidʒən ətʃɹæktəɾ ə ɡʊd bɪɾ ʌv ətɛnʃən fɹəm ði ɑɹmmɪn ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə kæmp, wɪð ðɛɹ blu-peɪntəɾ ændɔɝən hɛlməts ən ðɛɹ lɔŋ blu koʊts wɝkt ɑn ðə tʃɛst wɪð ə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən. ə blu pɛnən bɛɹɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ən ə nʌmbɝ mɑɹkt itʃ ə ðə faɪv kʌmpəniz. ðə lidʒənmɛn wɝ dɪfɹən ɪn mɛni weɪz. fəɹ ɪnstəns, ðeɪ wɔɹ bɹɛstpleɪts, bʌt bɪniθ ðɛɹ koʊts, soʊ əz nɑt tə haɪd ðə dʒɹæɡənz - ðə seɪm ɹizən ðə koʊts bʌɾənd ʌp wʌn saɪd - ən ɛvɹi mæn kæɹiɾ ə ʃɔɹt-sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp ən ə stil-ɑɹm kɹɔsboʊ, ɛvɹi wʌn ʃoʊldɝɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm əz ɛvɹi ʌðɝ. ði ɔfəsɝz wɔkt, itʃ wɪð ə tɔl ɹɛd plum ɑn ɪz hɛlmət, dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə dʒɹʌm ən pɛnənt. ði oʊnli hɔɹsəz wɝ mɔɹz maʊs-kʌlɝd ɡɛldɪŋ, ət ðɛɹ hɛd, ən pæk ænəməlz ət ðə ɹɪɹ.

Bright and early the next morning, a thousand men of the Legion of the Dragon marched out of Illian, across the Causeway of the Northern Star, stepping to the steady beat of drums. Well, it was early, anyway. Thick gray clouds roiled across the sky, and a stiff sea breeze sharp with salt whipped cloaks and banners, muttering of another storm on the way. The Legion attracted a good bit of attention from the armsmen already in the camp, with their blue-painted Andoran helmets and their long blue coats worked on the chest with a red-and-gold Dragon. A blue pennant bearing the Dragon and a number marked each of the five companies. The Legionmen were different in many ways. For instance, they wore breastplates, but beneath their coats, so as not to hide the Dragons - the same reason the coats buttoned up one side - and every man carried a short-sword at his hip and a steel-armed crossbow, every one shouldered exactly the same as every other. The officers walked, each with a tall red plume on his helmet, just ahead of drum and pennant. The only horses were Morr's mouse-colored gelding, at their head, and pack animals at the rear.

"fʊt," wɪɹɑmɑn mʌɾɝd, slæpɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz ɑn ə ɡɔntələɾəd hænd. "bɝn maɪ soʊl, ðəɹ noʊ ɡʊd, fʊt. ðəl skæɾɝ ət ðə fɝs tʃɑɹdʒ. bɪfɔɹ." ðə fɝst ə ðə kɑləm stʃɹoʊɾ ɔf ðə kɑzweɪ. ðeɪ hæd hɛlp teɪk ɪljən, ən ðeɪ hæd nɑt skæɾɝd.

"Foot," Weiramon muttered, slapping his reins on a gauntleted hand. "Burn my soul, they're no good, foot. They'll scatter at the first charge. Before." The first of the column strode off the causeway. They had helped take Illian, and they had not scattered.

səmɝædʒɹɪd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ paɪks," hi mʌɾɝd. "aɪ hæv sin wɛl-lɛd fʊt hoʊld, wɪð paɪks, bʌt wɪθaʊt. . . ." hi meɪɾ ə saʊn ə dɪsɡʌst ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

Semaradrid shook his head. "No pikes," he muttered. "I have seen well-led foot hold, with pikes, but without. . . ." He made a sound of disgust in his throat.

ɡɹɛɡɹɪn pɑnɝ, ðə θɝd mæn sɪɾɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl nɪɹ ɹænd tə wɑtʃ ðə nu ɝaɪvəlz, sɛd nʌθɪŋ. pɝhæps i hæd noʊ pɹɛdʒəɾɪs əɡɛnst ɪnfəntʃɹi - ðoʊ ɪf i dɪd nɑt, hi wəd bi wʌn ʌv oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə noʊbəlmən ɹænd hæd mɛt wɪθaʊɾ ɪt - bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd hɑɹd nɑt tə fɹaʊn ən ɔlmoʊst səksiɾəd. ɛvɹiwʌn nu baɪ naʊ ðət ðə mɛn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts bɔɹ ɑɹmz kəz ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən tə fɑloʊ ɹænd, tʃoʊzən tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, fəɹ noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən ðən ðət ðeɪ wɑntəd tə. ði ɪliɑnɝ hæd tə bi wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ðət ɹænd wɑntəd ðə lidʒən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə naɪn wɑz nɑt tʃɹʌstɪd tə noʊ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, səmɝædʒɹɪɾ aɪd ɹænd saɪdweɪz. oʊnli wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz tu stupəd tə θɪŋk.

Gregorin Panar, the third man sitting his saddle near Rand to watch the new arrivals, said nothing. Perhaps he had no prejudice against infantry - though if he did not, he would be one of only a handful of noblemen Rand had met without it - but he tried hard not to frown and almost succeeded. Everyone knew by now that the men with the Dragon on their chests bore arms because they had chosen to follow Rand, chosen to follow the Dragon Reborn, for no other reason than that they wanted to. The Illianer had to be wondering where they were going that Rand wanted the Legion and the Council of Nine was not trusted to know. For that matter, Semaradrid eyed Rand sideways. Only Weiramon was too stupid to think.

ɹænd tɝn teɪdeɪʃɝ əweɪ. nɛɹɪʃməz pækədʒ hæd bɪn ɹiɹæpt, ɪndə ə θɪnɝ bʌndəl, ən taɪd bɪniθ ɪz lɛf stɝəp lɛðɝ. "stʃɹaɪk ðə kæmp; wɝ muvɪŋ," hi toʊl ðə θɹi noʊbəlz.

Rand turned Tai'daishar away. Narishma's package had been rewrapped, into a thinner bundle, and tied beneath his left stirrup leather. "Strike the camp; we're moving," he told the three nobles.

ðɪs taɪm, hi lɛt dæʃivə wiv ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tə teɪk əm ɔl əweɪ. ðə pleɪn-feɪs fɛloʊ fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm ən mʌmbəl tə hɪmsɛlf - dæʃivə æktʃəli  simd əfɹʌntɪd, fəɹ səm ɹizən! - ən dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ʃoʊldɝ-baɪ-ʃoʊldɝ, wɑtʃt wɪð sɑɹdɑnɪk smaɪlz əz ðə sɪlvɝi slæʃ ə laɪt ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ɪndə ə hoʊl ɪn nʌθɪŋ. wɑtʃt ɹænd mɔɹ ðən dæʃivə. wɛl, lɛɾ əm wɑtʃ. haʊ ɔfən kəɾ i siz seɪɾɪn ən ɹɪsk fɔlɪŋ dɪtsəli ɑn ɪz feɪs bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪli dɪd fɔl? ɪt kəd nɑt bi wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd si.

This time, he let Dashiva weave the gateway to take them all away. The plain-faced fellow frowned at him and mumbled to himself - Dashiva actually seemed affronted, for some reason! - and Gedwyn and Rochaid, their horses shoulder-by-shoulder, watched with sardonic smiles as the silvery slash of light rotated into a hole in nothing. Watched Rand more than Dashiva. Well, let them watch. How often could he seize saidin and risk falling dizzily on his face before he really did fall? It could not be where they could see.

ðɪs taɪm, ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tʊk əm tə ə waɪd ɹoʊd kɑɹv θɹu ðə loʊ, bɹʌʃi fʊthɪlz ə maʊntənz tə ðə wɛst. ðə nəmɑɝɛlɪn maʊntənz. nɑt ði ikwəlz ə ðə maʊntən ə mɪst, ən nɑɾ ə pætʃ ɑn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, bʌt ðeɪ ɹoʊz dɑɹk ən səvɪɹ əɡɛns ðə skaɪ, ʃɑɹp piks ðət wɔl ðə wɛs koʊst ʌv ɪljən. bɪɑn əm leɪ kɑbəl dip, ən bɪɑn ðæt. . . .

This time, the gateway took them to a wide road carved through the low, brushy foothills of mountains to the west. The Nemarellin Mountains. Not the equals of the Mountain of Mist, and not a patch on the Spine of the World, but they rose dark and severe against the sky, sharp peaks that walled the west coast of Illian. Beyond them lay Kabal Deep, and beyond that. . . .

mɛn bɪɡæn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə piks sun ɪnʌf. ɡɹɛɡɹɪn pɑnɝ tʊk wʌn lʊk ɝaʊn ən nɑɾəd ɪn sʌɾən sæɾəsfækʃən. ði ʌðɝ θɹi kaʊnsəlɝz ən mɑɹkəlɪn ɹeɪn kloʊs tə hɪm tə tɔk waɪl hɔɹsmən wɝ stɪl pɔɹɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. səmɝædʒɹɪd ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli ə bɪt lɔŋɡɝ tə pʌzəl ɪɾ aʊt, ən taɪhɛɹə, ən ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd naʊ.

Men began to recognize the peaks soon enough. Gregorin Panar took one look around and nodded in sudden satisfaction. The other three Councilors and Marcolin reined close to him to talk while horsemen were still pouring through the gateway. Semaradrid required only a bit longer to puzzle it out, and Tihera, and they also looked as if they understood now.

ðə sɪlvɝ ɹoʊd ɹæn fɹəm ðə sɪɾi tə luɡɹd, ən kæɹiɾ ɔl ə ði ɪnlæn tʃɹeɪd fəɹ ðə wɛst. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡoʊld ɹoʊd, tu, ðət lɛd tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ɹoʊdz ən neɪmz əlaɪk deɪɾɪd fɹəm bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən ɪljən. sɛntʃɝiz ʌv wæɡən wilz, hʊvz ən buts hæd biɾən əm hɑɹd, ən ðə sɛmɑɹoʊz kəɾ oʊnli skɪm əm wɪð mʌd. ðeɪ wɝ əmʌŋ ðə fju ɹɪlaɪəbəl haɪweɪz ɪn ɪljən fəɹ muvɪŋ lɑɹdʒ ɡɹups ə mɛn ɪn wɪntɝ. ɛvɹiwʌn nu əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ baɪ ðɪs taɪm, ðoʊ ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðə teɪlz ɹænd hæd hɝɾ əmʌŋ ði ɑɹmmɪn meɪd ði ɪnveɪɾɝz sim tʃɹɑləks' minɝ kʌzənz. ɪf ðə sintʃæn ɪntɛndəd tə stʃɹaɪk ɪndə ɪljən, ðə sɪlvɝ ɹoʊd wɑz ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə ɡæðɝ fəɹ dɪfɛns.

The Silver Road ran from the City to Lugard, and carried all of the inland trade for the west. There was a Gold Road, too, that led to Far Madding. Roads and names alike dated from before there had been an Illian. Centuries of wagon wheels, hooves and boots had beaten them hard, and the cemaros could only skim them with mud. They were among the few reliable highways in Illian for moving large groups of men in winter. Everyone knew about the Seanchan in Ebou Dar by this time, though a good many of the tales Rand had heard among the armsmen made the invaders seem Trollocs' meaner cousins. If the Seanchan intended to strike into Illian, the Silver Road was a good place to gather for defense.

səmɝædʒɹɪɾ ən ði ʌðɝz θɔt ðeɪ nu wʌɾ i plænd: hi mʌst əv lɝn ðət ðə sintʃæn wɝ kʌmɪŋ, ən ði æʃəmən wɝ ðəɹ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm wən ðeɪ dɪd. ɡɪvən ðə stɔɹiz əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn, noʊ wʌn sim tu əpsɛt ðət ðət lɛf lɪɾəl fəɹ əm tə du. ʌv kɔɹs, wɪɹɑmɑn hæd tə hæv ɪɾ ɪkspleɪn tə hɪm faɪnəli, baɪ taɪhɛɹə, ən i wɑz ʌpsɛt, ðoʊ hi tʃɹaɪd tə mæsk ɪt bɪhaɪn ə ɡɹæn spitʃ əbaʊt ðə wɪzdəm ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ən ðə mɪlətɛɹi dʒinjəs ə ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əlɔŋ wɪð haʊ hi, pɝsənəli, wəd lɛd ðə fɝs tʃɑɹdʒ əɡɛns ðiz sintʃæn. ə pjʊɹ bʊl-ɡus ful. wɪð lʌk, ɛniwʌn ɛls u lɝn ʌv ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑn ðə sɪlvɝ ɹoʊd wəɾ ət lis nɑt bi tu mʌtʃ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən səmɝædʒɹɪɾ əɹ ɡɹɛɡɹɪn. wɪð lʌk, noʊ wʌn u mæɾɝd wəd lɝn bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

Semaradrid and the others thought they knew what he planned: he must have learned that the Seanchan were coming, and the Asha'man were there to destroy them when they did. Given the stories about the Seanchan, no one seemed too upset that that left little for them to do. Of course, Weiramon had to have it explained to him finally, by Tihera, and he was upset, though he tried to mask it behind a grand speech about the wisdom of the Lord Dragon and the military genius of the Lord of the Morning, along with how he, personally, would lead the first charge against these Seanchan. A pure bull-goose fool. With luck, anyone else who learned of a gathering on the Silver Road would at least not be too much brighter than Semaradrid or Gregorin. With luck, no one who mattered would learn before it was too late.

sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn tə weɪt, ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt wəɾ oʊnli bi ənʌðɝ deɪ əɹ soʊ, bʌɾ əz ðə deɪz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt, hi bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ wɛðɝ i maɪt bi nɪɹli əz bɪɡ ə ful əz wɪɹɑmɑn.

Settling in to wait, Rand thought it would only be another day or so, but as the days stretched out, he began to wonder whether he might be nearly as big a fool as Weiramon.

moʊst ə ði æʃəmən wɝ aʊt sɝtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪljən ən tiɹ ən ðə pleɪnz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðoʊz ɹænd wɑntəd. sɝtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə sɛmɑɹoʊz. ɡeɪtweɪz ən tʃɹævlɪŋ wɝ ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌɾ ivən æʃəmən tʊk taɪm tə faɪn u ðeɪ sɔt wən daʊnpɔɹz hɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ fɪfti peɪsɪz əweɪ ən kwæɡmaɪɹz dʒɹæɡd ɹumɝ tə ə nɪɹ hɔlt. sɝtʃɪŋ æʃəmən pæst wɪðɪn ə maɪl ə ðɛɹ kwɔɹi ɪn ɪɡnɝəns, ən tɝn oʊnli tə lɝn ðə mɛn hæd muvd ɑn əɡɛn. səm hæd fɑɹðɝ tə ɡoʊ, sikɪŋ pipəl nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli iɡɝ tə bi faʊnd. deɪz pæs bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝs bɹɔt nuz.

Most of the Asha'man were out searching across Illian and Tear and the Plains of Maredo for the rest of those Rand wanted. Searching through the cemaros. Gateways and Traveling were all very well, but even Asha'man took time to find who they sought when downpours hid anything fifty paces away and quagmires dragged rumor to a near halt. Searching Asha'man passed within a mile of their quarry in ignorance, and turned only to learn the men had moved on again. Some had farther to go, seeking people not necessarily eager to be found. Days passed before the first brought news.

ðə haɪ lɔɹd sunəmən dʒɔɪnd wɪɹɑmɑn, ə fæt mæn wɪð ən ʌŋtʃwəs mænɝ - təwɔɹd ɹænd, ət list. smuð ɪn ɪz faɪn sɪlk koʊt, ɔlweɪz smaɪlɪŋ, hi wɑz vɑljəbəl ɪn ɪz dɛklɝeɪʃənz ə lɔɪəlti, bʌɾ i hæd plɑɾəd əɡɛnst ɹænd soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ i pɹɑbli dɪd soʊ ɪn ɪz slip. ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹiən keɪm, wɪð ɪz lʌmpi fɑɹmɝz feɪs ən ɪz væst wɛlθ, stæmɝɪŋ əbaʊt ði ɑnɝ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ ət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz saɪd. ɡoʊl kənsɝn tʃɹiən mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ɪksɛpt pɑsəbli ðə pɹɪvlədʒəz ɹænd hæd teɪkən əweɪ fɹəm ðə noʊbəlz ɪn tɛɹ. hi sim pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dɪsmeɪd tə lɝn ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz ɪn ðə kæmp, ən nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə vɪlədʒ nɪɹbaɪ wɛɹ kəmplaɪən fɑɹmɡɝlz maɪt bi faʊnd. tʃɹiən hæd skimd əɡɛnst ɹænd ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ɔfən əz sunəmən. meɪbi ivən mɔɹ ðən ɡəm, əɹ mɑɹəkən, əɹ ɑɹəkʌm.

The High Lord Sunamon joined Weiramon, a fat man with an unctuous manner - toward Rand, at least. Smooth in his fine silk coat, always smiling, he was voluble in his declarations of loyalty, but he had plotted against Rand so long that he probably did so in his sleep. The High Lord Torean came, with his lumpy farmer's face and his vast wealth, stammering about the honor of riding once more at the Lord Dragon's side. Gold concerned Torean more than anything else, except possibly the privileges Rand had taken away from the nobles in Tear. He seemed particularly dismayed to learn there were no serving girls in the camp, and not so much as a village nearby where compliant farmgirls might be found. Torean had schemed against Rand every bit as often as Sunamon. Maybe even more than Gueyam, or Maraconn, or Aracome.

ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz. ðəɹ wɑz bɝtoʊm seɪɡən, ə ʃɔɹt, ɹʌɡədli hænsəm mæn wɪð ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd. hi səpoʊzədli dɪd nɑt mɔɹn ðə dɛθ ə hɪz kʌzən koʊləveɪɪɹ tu ɡɹeɪtli, boʊθ kəz ðət meɪɾ ɪm ðə nu haɪ siɾ ə haʊs seɪɡən ən kəz ɹumɝ sɛd ɹænd hæɾ ɛksəkjuɾəd hɝ. əɹ mɝɾɝd hɝ. bɝtoʊm baʊɾ ən smaɪld, ən ɪz smaɪl nɛvɝ ɹitʃt ɪz dɑɹk aɪz. səm sɛɾ i hæd bɪn vɛɹi fɑn ə hɪz kʌzən. eɪlɪl ɹieɪɾən keɪm, ə slɪm dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən wɪð bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz, nɑt jʌŋ bʌt kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, pɹətɛstɪŋ ðət ʃi hæɾ ə læns-kæptən tə liɾ əɹ ɑɹmmɪn ən noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə teɪk ðə fild ɪn pɝsən. pɹətɛstɪŋ əɹ lɔɪəlti fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, tu. bʌɾ əɹ bɹʌðɝ tɔɹæm kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn ɹænd mɛn fəɹ ɪleɪn, ən ɪt wɑz wɪspɝd ðət ʃi wəd də ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ tɔɹæm, ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ivən dʒɔɪn wɪð ɪz ɛnəmiz; tə hæmpɝ əɹ tə spaɪ əɹ boʊθ, ʌv kɔɹs. dælθeɪnz ænælɪn keɪm, ən əmənʒɹɪd əsiɛlɪn, ən dɔɹɛsɪn tʃuliəndɝd, lɔɹdz u hæd səpɔɹɾəd koʊləveɪɪɹz siʒɝ ə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn wən ðeɪ θɔt ɹænd wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹhin.

There were others. There was Bertome Saighan, a short, ruggedly handsome man with the front of his head shaved. He supposedly did not mourn the death of his cousin Colavaere too greatly, both because that made him the new High Seat of House Saighan and because rumor said Rand had executed her. Or murdered her. Bertome bowed and smiled, and his smile never reached his dark eyes. Some said he had been very fond of his cousin. Ailil Riatin came, a slim dignified woman with big dark eyes, not young but quite pretty, protesting that she had a Lance-captain to lead her armsmen and no desire to take the field in person. Protesting her loyalty for the Lord Dragon, too. But her brother Toram claimed the throne Rand meant for Elayne, and it was whispered that she would do anything for Toram, anything at all. Even join with his enemies; to hamper or to spy or both, of course. Dalthanes Annallin came, and Amondrid Osiellin, and Doressin Chuliandred, lords who had supported Colavaere's seizure of the Sun Throne when they thought Rand would never return to Cairhien.

kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹən, ðeɪ wɝ bɹɔɾ ɪn wʌn baɪ wʌn, wɪð fɪfti ɹɪteɪnɝz, əɹ ət moʊst ə hʌnʒɹəd. mɛn ən wɪmən i tʃɹʌstɪɾ ivən lɛs ðən i dɪd ɡɹɛɡɹɪn əɹ səmɝædʒɹɪd. moʊst wɝ mɛn, nɑt kəz i θɔt ðə wɪmən ɛni lɛs deɪnʒɝəs - hi wɑz nɑt ðət bɪɡ ə ful; ə wʊmən wəd kɪl jə twaɪs əz fæst əz ə mæn, ən juʒəwəli fəɹ hæf ðə ɹizən! - bʌt kəz i kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə teɪk ɛni wʊmən ɪksɛp ðə moʊs deɪnʒɝəs, wɛɹ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ. eɪlɪl kəd smaɪl wɔɹmli waɪl ʃi kælkjəleɪɾəd wɛɹ tə plæn ðə naɪf ɪn jəɹ ɹɪbz. ænɑiɛlə, ə wɪləwi sɪmpɝɪŋ haɪ leɪɾi hu ɡeɪv ə fɛɹ ɪməteɪʃən ʌv ə bjuɾəfəl ɡusbɹeɪn, hæd ɹɪtɝn tə tɛɹ fɹəm kɛɹhin ən oʊpənli bɪɡʌn tɔkɪŋ ə hɝsɛlf fəɹ ði æz-jɛt-nɑnəɡzɪstən θɹoʊn ə tɛɹ. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz ə ful, bʌt ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə ɡeɪn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə səpɔɹt, boʊθ əmʌŋ noʊbəlz ən ɪn ðə stʃɹits.

Cairhienin and Tairen, they were brought in one by one, with fifty retainers, or at most a hundred. Men and women he trusted even less than he did Gregorin or Semaradrid. Most were men, not because he thought the women any less dangerous - he was not that big a fool; a woman would kill you twice as fast as a man, and usually for half the reason! - but because he could not bring himself to take any woman except the most dangerous, where he was going. Ailil could smile warmly while she calculated where to plant the knife in your ribs. Anaiyella, a willowy simpering High Lady who gave a fair imitation of a beautiful goosebrain, had returned to Tear from Cairhien and openly begun talking of herself for the as-yet-nonexistent throne of Tear. Perhaps she was a fool, but she had managed to gain a great deal of support, both among nobles and in the streets.

soʊ hi ɡæðɝɾ əm ɪn, ɔl ðə foʊk u hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz aɪ. hi kəd nɑt wɑtʃ ɔl ə ðɛm ɔl ðə taɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə lɛɾ əm fɝɡɛt ðəɾ i dɪd wɑtʃ səmtaɪmz. hi ɡæðɝd ðɛm, ən i weɪɾəd. fəɹ tu deɪz. næʃɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hi weɪɾəd. faɪv deɪz. eɪt.

So he gathered them in, all the folk who had been too long out from under his eye. He could not watch all of them all the time, but he could not afford to let them forget that he did watch sometimes. He gathered them, and he waited. For two days. Gnashing his teeth, he waited. Five days. Eight.

ɹeɪn wɑz biɾɪŋ ə dɪmɪnɪʃɪŋ dʒɹʌm ɑn ɪz tɛnt wən ðə læs mæn i wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ faɪnəli ɝaɪvd.

Rain was beating a diminishing drum on his tent when the last man he was waiting for finally arrived.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ə smɔl tɔɹən fɹəm ɪz ɔɪld-klɔθ keɪp, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ blu aʊɾ ɪz θɪk, ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik mʌstæʃɪz ɪn dɪsɡʌst ən tɔs ðə keɪp oʊvɝ ə bæɹəl tʃɛɹ. ə ʃɔɹt mæn wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt hʊk bik ʌv ə noʊz, hi sim lɑɹdʒɝ ðən i wɑz. nɑt kəz i stʃɹʌɾɪd, bʌt kəz i əsum ðəɾ i wɑz əz tɔl əz ɛni mæn pɹɛzənt, ən ʌðɝ mɛn tʊk ɪm soʊ. waɪz mɛn dɪd. ðə wʊlf-hɛɾəd aɪvɝi bətɑn ə ðə mɑɹʃəl-dʒɛnɝəl ə sɑldɑiə, tʌkt kɛɹləsli bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt, hæd bɪn ɝn ɑn skɔɹz ə bæɾəlfildz ən əɾ əz mɛni kaʊnsəl teɪbəlz. hi wɑz wʌn ə ðə vɛɹi fju mɛn ɹænd wəd tʃɹʌst wɪð ɪz laɪf.

Shaking a small torrent from his oiled-cloth cape, Davram Bashere blew out his thick, gray-streaked mustaches in disgust and tossed the cape over a barrel chair. A short man with a great hooked beak of a nose, he seemed larger than he was. Not because he strutted, but because he assumed that he was as tall as any man present, and other men took him so. Wise men did. The wolf-headed ivory baton of the Marshal-General of Saldaea, tucked carelessly behind his sword belt, had been earned on scores of battlefields and at as many council tables. He was one of the very few men Rand would trust with his life.

"aɪ noʊ jə doʊn laɪk ɪkspleɪnɪŋ," bæʃɪɹ mʌɾɝd, "bʌɾ aɪ kəd juz ə lɪɾəl ɪluməneɪʃən." ədʒʌstɪŋ ɪz sɝpəntaɪn sɔɹd, hi spɹɔld ɪn ənʌðɝ tʃɛɹ ən flʌŋ ə lɛɡ oʊvɝ ði ɑɹm ʌv ɪt. hi ɔlweɪz simd əɾ ɪz iz, bʌɾ i kəɾ ʌnkɔɪl fæstɝ ðən ə wɪp. "ðæɾ æʃəmən fɛloʊ wʊdn seɪ mɔɹ ðən jə niɾəd mi jɛstɝdeɪ, jɛɾ i sɛd nɑt tə bɹɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə θaʊzən mɛn. aɪ oʊnli hæd hæf ðət wɪð mi, bʌɾ aɪ bɹɔt ðɛm. ɪt kæn bi ə bæɾəl. hæf ðə sɪɡəlz aɪ sɔ aʊt ðəɹ bɪlɔŋ tə mɛn hud baɪt ðɛɹ tʌŋz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ ə fɛloʊ bɪhaɪn jə wɪð ə naɪf, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛs tə mɛn hud tʃɹaɪ tə hoʊl jəɹ ətɛnʃən. ɪf ðeɪ hædn peɪd ðə naɪf mæn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"I know you don't like explaining," Bashere muttered, "but I could use a little illumination." Adjusting his serpentine sword, he sprawled in another chair and flung a leg over the arm of it. He always seemed at his ease, but he could uncoil faster than a whip. "That Asha'man fellow wouldn't say more than you needed me yesterday, yet he said not to bring more than a thousand men. I only had half that with me, but I brought them. It can't be a battle. Half the sigils I saw out there belong to men who'd bite their tongues if they saw a fellow behind you with a knife, and most of the rest to men who'd try to hold your attention. If they hadn't paid the knife man in the first place."

siɾəd bɪhaɪn ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ɹænd wɛɹəli pɹɛs ðə hilz ə hɪz pɑmz əɡɛnst ɪz aɪz. wɪð bɔɹiən kɛɹɪvɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ðə læmp wɪks niɾəd pɹɑpɝ tʃɹɪmɪŋ, ən ə feɪn heɪz ə smoʊk hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. bɪsaɪdz, hi hæd bɪn əweɪk moʊst ə ðə naɪt pɔɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə mæps skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl. mæps ə sʌðɝn ɔltɑɹə. noʊ tu əɡɹiɾ ɑn vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

Seated behind his writing table in his shirtsleeves, Rand wearily pressed the heels of his palms against his eyes. With Boreane Carivin left behind, the lamp wicks needed proper trimming, and a faint haze of smoke hung in the air. Besides, he had been awake most of the night poring over the maps scattered across the table. Maps of southern Altara. No two agreed on very much.

"ɪf jəɹ gɑnə faɪɾ ə bæɾəl," hi toʊl bæʃɪɹ, "hu bɛɾɝ tə peɪ ðə bʊtʃɝz bɪl ðən mɛn u wɑn jə dɛd? ɛniweɪ, ɪɾ ɪzən soʊlʒɝz hul wɪn ðɪs bæɾəl. ɔl ðeɪv tə də ɪz kip ɛnibəɾi fɹəm snikɪŋ ʌp ɑn ði æʃəmən. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðæt?"

"If you're going to fight a battle," he told Bashere, "who better to pay the butcher's bill than men who want you dead? Anyway, it isn't soldiers who'll win this battle. All they have to do is keep anybody from sneaking up on the Asha'man. What do you think of that?"

bæʃɪɹ snɔɹɾɪd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz hɛvi mʌstæʃɪz stɝd. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ə dɛdli stu, ɪz wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk. sʌmbɑɾiz gɑnə tʃoʊk tə dɛθ ɑn ɪt. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪɾ ɪzən ʌs." ən ðən i læft əz ɪf ðət wɝ ə faɪn dʒoʊk.

Bashere snorted so hard that his heavy mustaches stirred. "I think it's a deadly stew, is what I think. Somebody's going to choke to death on it. The Light send it isn't us." And then he laughed as if that were a fine joke.

luz θɝɪn læft, tu.

Lews Therin laughed, too.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu


CHAPTER 22

ɡæðɝɪŋ klaʊdz


Gathering Clouds

ʌndɝ ə stɛɾi dʒɹɪzəl ɹændz smɔl ɑɹmi fɔɹm kɑləmz əkɹɔs ðə loʊ foʊldəd hɪlz feɪsɪŋ ðə nəmɑɝɛlɪn piks, dɑɹk ən ʃɑɹp əɡɛns ðə wɛstɝn skaɪ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil nid tə feɪs ðə dɝɛkʃən jə ɪntɛndəd tə tʃɹævəl, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz fɛlt əskju tə ɹænd ʌðɝwaɪz. dɪspaɪt ðə ɹeɪn, ɹæpədli θɪnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz lɛt θɹu stɑɹtlɪŋli bɹaɪt sʌnʃaɪn. əɹ meɪbi ðə deɪ oʊnli sim bɹaɪt, æftɝ ɔl ðə ɹisənt ɡlum.

Under a steady drizzle Rand's small army formed columns across the low folded hills facing the Nemarellin peaks, dark and sharp against the western sky. There was no real need to face the direction you intended to Travel, but it always felt askew to Rand otherwise. Despite the rain, rapidly thinning gray clouds let through startlingly bright sunshine. Or maybe the day only seemed bright, after all the recent gloom.

fɔɹ ə ðə kɑləmz wɝ hɛɾəd baɪ bæʃɪɹz sɑldəiənz, bændi-lɛɡəɾ ənɑɹmɝd mɛn ɪn ʃɔɹt koʊts stændɪŋ peɪʃənli bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ maʊns bɪniθ ə smɔl fɔɹəst ə ʃaɪnɪŋ læns hɛdz, ði ʌðɝ faɪv baɪ blu-koʊɾəd mɛn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, kəmændəd baɪ ə ʃɔɹt stɑki fɛloʊ neɪm dʒæk meɪsɑnd. wən meɪsɑn muvd, ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ kwɪknəs, bʌɾ i wɑz ʌɾɝli stɪl naʊ, fit plæntəɾ əstʃɹaɪɾ ən hænz foʊldəd bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hɪz mɛn wɝ ɪn pleɪs, ən soʊ wɝ ðə dɪfɛndɝz ən kəmpænjənz, ɡɹʌmpi əbaʊt biɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪnfəntʃɹi. ɪt wɑz ðə noʊbəlz ən ðɛɹ foʊk, meɪnli, hu mɪld əbaʊɾ əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ. θɪk mʌd sʌkt ət hʊvz ən buts, ən maɪɹd kɑɹt wilz; ʃaʊɾəd kɝsɪz ɹoʊz. ɪt tʊk taɪm tə laɪn ʌp nɪɹli sɪks θaʊzən soʊk mɛn, ɡɛɾɪŋ wɛɾɝ baɪ ðə mɪnət. ən ðət wɑz nɑt kaʊntɪŋ ðə səplaɪ kɑɹts, ən ðə ɹimaʊns.

Four of the columns were headed by Bashere's Saldaeans, bandy-legged unarmored men in short coats standing patiently beside their mounts beneath a small forest of shining lance heads, the other five by blue-coated men with the Dragon on their chests, commanded by a short stocky fellow named Jak Masond. When Masond moved, it was always with surprising quickness, but he was utterly still now, feet planted astride and hands folded behind his back. His men were in place, and so were the Defenders and Companions, grumpy about being behind infantry. It was the nobles and their folk, mainly, who milled about as if unsure where to go. Thick mud sucked at hooves and boots, and mired cart wheels; shouted curses rose. It took time to line up nearly six thousand soaked men, getting wetter by the minute. And that was not counting the supply carts, and the remounts.

ɹænd hæd dɑn ɪz faɪnəst, soʊ hi wəd stæn aʊɾ əɾ ə ɡlæns. ə lɪk wɪð ðə paʊɝ hæd pɑlɪʃt ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝz spɪɹhɛd tə mɪɹɝ bɹaɪtnəs, ən ənʌðɝ hæd bɝnɪʃt ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz soʊ ðə ɡoʊld ɡlimd. ðə ɡɪldɪd dʒɹæɡən bʌkəl ə hɪz sɔɹd bɛl kɑt ðə laɪt, ən soʊ dɪd ðə θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ðət kʌvɝɾ ɪz blu sɪlk koʊt. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ɡɪvɪŋ əweɪ ðə dʒɛmz ðət wʌns hæd dɛkt ɪz sɔɹdz hɪlt ən skæbɝd. ðə dɑɹk bɔɹhaɪd wɑz sɝvəsəbəl, bʌɾ ɛni ɑɹmsmən cʊɾə wɔɹn ðæt. lɛt mɛn noʊ hu hi wɑz. lɛt ðə sintʃæn noʊ hu hæd kʌm tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm.

Rand had donned his finest, so he would stand out at a glance. A lick with the Power had polished the Dragon Scepter's spearhead to mirror brightness, and another had burnished the Crown of Swords so the gold gleamed. The gilded Dragon buckle of his sword belt caught the light, and so did the thread-of-gold embroidery that covered his blue silk coat. For a moment, he regretted giving away the gems that once had decked his sword's hilt and scabbard. The dark boarhide was serviceable, but any armsman could have worn that. Let men know who he was. Let the Seanchan know who had come to destroy them.

sɪɾɪŋ teɪdeɪʃɝ ɑn ə bɹɔd flæt, hi ɪmpeɪʃənli wɑtʃt ðə noʊbəlz ɹɔɪl əbaʊɾ ɑn ðə hɪlz. ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf ɑn ðə flæt, dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ mɛn, ɔl fɔɹmd ɪndə ə pɹɪsaɪs bɑks, dɛɾəkeɪtəd ɪn ðə fɹʌn ɹæŋk, soʊlʒɝz laɪn ʌp bɪhaɪnd. ðeɪ lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə pɝeɪd. əz mɛni hæd ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ əɹ nɪɹli nʌn əz wɝ jʌŋ - sɛvɹəl wɝ əz jʌŋ əz hɑpwəl əɹ mɔɹ - bʌɾ ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðət hæd bɪn ə ɹɪkwaɪɹmənt. flɪn ən dæʃivə weɪɾəd bɪhaɪn ɹænd ɪn ə kæʒəwəl klʌstɝ wɪð ædli ən mɔɹ, hɑpwəl ən nɛɹɪʃmə. ən ə ɹɪdʒəd pɛɹ ə maʊntəd bænɝmɪn, wʌn tɛɹən ən wʌn kɛɹhinɪn, ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts ən ivən ðɛɹ stil-bækt ɡɔnləts bʌft ən pɑlɪʃt tɪl ðeɪ ʃoʊn. ðə kɹɪmzən bænɝ ə laɪɾ ən ðə lɔŋ waɪt dʒɹæɡən bænɝ hʌŋ lɪmp ən dʒɹɪpɪŋ. ɹænd hæɾ əsum ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪz tɛnt, wɛɹ ɪz moʊməntɛɹi stæɡɝ wəd nɑt bi sin, ən ðə spɑɹs ɹeɪn feɪl baɪ ən ɪntʃ tə tʌtʃ ɪm əɹ ɪz hɔɹs.

Sitting Tai'daishar on a broad flat, he impatiently watched the nobles roil about on the hills. A little way off on the flat, Gedwyn and Rochaid sat their saddles in front of their men, all formed into a precise box, Dedicated in the front rank, Soldiers lined up behind. They looked ready to parade. As many had gray hair or nearly none as were young - several were as young as Hopwil or Morr - but every one was strong enough to make a gateway. That had been a requirement. Flinn and Dashiva waited behind Rand in a casual cluster with Adley and Morr, Hopwil and Narishma. And a rigid pair of mounted bannermen, one Tairen and one Cairhienin, their breastplates and helmets and even their steel-backed gauntlets buffed and polished till they shone. The crimson Banner of Light and the long white Dragon Banner hung limp and dripping. Rand had assumed the Power in his tent, where his momentary stagger would not be seen, and the sparse rain failed by an inch to touch him or his horse.

ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn fɛlt ɪspɛʃli hɛvi tədeɪ, ə θɪk faʊl ɔɪl ðəɾ uzd ɪndə hɪz pɔɹz ən steɪn ɪz boʊnz dip. steɪn ɪz soʊl. hi hæd θɔt hɪmsɛlf əkʌstəm tə ðə vɪlnəs, æftɝ ə fæʃən, jɛt tədeɪ ɪt wɑz nɔʒieɪɾɪŋ, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə fɹoʊzən faɪɝ ən moʊltən koʊld ə seɪɾɪn ɪtsɛlf. hi hɛld ɑn tə ðə sɔɹs əz ɔfən əz pɑsəbəl naʊ, æksɛptɪŋ ðə vɪlnəs tə əvɔɪd ðə nu sɪknəs ə sizɪŋ ɪt. ɪt kəd bi dɛdli, ɪf i lɛt sɪknəs dɪstʃɹækt ɪm fɹəm ðət stʃɹʌɡəl. meɪbi ɪt wɑz kənɛktəd tə ðə dɪzi spɛlz, sʌmhaʊ. laɪt, hi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ mæd jɛt, ən i kəd nɑt daɪ. nɑt jɛt. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ stɪl tə bi dʌn.

The taint on saidin felt especially heavy today, a thick foul oil that oozed into his pores and stained his bones deep. Stained his soul. He had thought himself accustomed to the vileness, after a fashion, yet today it was nauseating, stronger than the frozen fire and molten cold of saidin itself. He held on to the Source as often as possible now, accepting the vileness to avoid the new sickness of seizing it. It could be deadly, if he let sickness distract him from that struggle. Maybe it was connected to the dizzy spells, somehow. Light, he could not go mad yet, and he could not die. Not yet. There was too much still to be done.

hi pɹɛst ɪz lɛf lɛɡ əɡɛns teɪdeɪʃɝz flæŋk dʒʌs tə fil ðə lɔŋ bʌndəl stʃɹæp bɪtwin stɝəp lɛðɝ ən skɑɹlət sæɾəl klɔθ. ɛvɹi taɪm i dɪd ðæt, sʌmθɪŋ ɹɪəld əkɹɔs ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə vɔɪd. æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ən meɪbi ə tʌtʃ ə fɪɹ. wɛl tʃɹeɪnd, ðə ɡɛldɪŋ stɑɹɾəd tə tɝn lɛft, ən ɹænd hæd tə ɹeɪn ɪm bæk. wən wəd ðə noʊbəlz sɔɹt ðɛmsɛlvz aʊt? hi ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ ɪn ɪmpeɪʃəns.

He pressed his left leg against Tai'daishar's flank just to feel the long bundle strapped between stirrup leather and scarlet saddle cloth. Every time he did that, something wriggled across the outside of the Void. Anticipation, and maybe a touch of fear. Well trained, the gelding started to turn left, and Rand had to rein him back. When would the nobles sort themselves out? He ground his teeth in impatience.

hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ əz ə bɔɪ hɪɹɪŋ mɛn læf ðət wən ɹeɪn fɛl ɪn sʌnʃaɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz biɾɪŋ sɛmɝhɪdʒ. səm ə ðət læftɝ hæd bɪn ənizi, ðoʊ, ən skɹɔni oʊl sɛn bui wəɾ ɔlweɪz snɑɹl ðət sɛmɝhɪdʒ wəd bi smɑɹɾɪŋ ən æŋɡɹi æftɝ ðæt, ən kʌm fəɹ smɔl bɔɪz u dɪd nɑt kip aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ ɛldɝz' weɪ. ðət hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə sɛn ɹænd ɹʌnɪŋ, wən i wɑz lɪɾəl. hi wɪʃt sɛmɝhɪdʒ wəd kʌm fəɹ ɪm naʊ, ɹaɪt ðəɾ ɪnstənt. hi wəd meɪk əɹ wip.

He could remember as a boy hearing men laugh that when rain fell in sunshine the Dark One was beating Semirhage. Some of that laughter had been uneasy, though, and scrawny old Cenn Buie would always snarl that Semirhage would be smarting and angry after that, and come for small boys who did not keep out of their elders' way. That had been enough to send Rand running, when he was little. He wished Semirhage would come for him now, right that instant. He would make her weep.

nʌθɪŋ meɪks sɛmɝhɪdʒ wip, luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝd. ʃi ɡɪvz tɪɹz tə ʌðɝz, bʌt ʃiz nʌn hɝsɛlf.

Nothing makes Semirhage weep, Lews Therin muttered. She gives tears to others, but she has none herself.

ɹænd læf sɔfli. ɪf ʃi keɪm tədeɪ, hi wəd meɪk əɹ wip. hɝ ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən təɡɛðɝ, ɪf ðeɪ keɪm tədeɪ. moʊst əʃʊɹədli hi wəd meɪk ðə sintʃæn wip.

Rand laughed softly. If she came today, he would make her weep. Her and the rest of the Forsaken together, if they came today. Most assuredly he would make the Seanchan weep.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz plizd wɪð ði ɔɹɾɝz i hæd ɡɪvən. sunəmənz ɔɪli smaɪl vænɪʃt wən i θɔt ɹænd dɪd nɑt si. tʃɹiən hæɾ ə flæsk ɪn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, noʊ daʊt bɹændi, əɹ meɪbi sɛvɹəl flæsks, kəz i dʒɹæŋk stɛɾəli ən nɛvɝ əpɪɹd tə ɹʌn dʒɹaɪ. səmɝædʒɹɪɾ ən mɑɹkəlɪn ən taɪhɛɹə itʃ əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd tə pɹoʊtɛs ðə nʌmbɝz wɪð sɑmbɝ feɪsəz. ə fju jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ, kloʊs ɑn sɪks θaʊzən mɛn wʊɾə bɪn ɑɹmi ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni wɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ hæd sin ɑɹmiz ɪn ðə tɛnz ə θaʊzənz, naʊ, hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz, əz ɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz deɪ, ən tə ɡoʊ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn, ðeɪ wɑntəd fɑɹ mɔɹ. hi sɛn əm əweɪ dɪsɡɹʌntəld. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðət fɪfti-ɑɾ æʃəmən wɝ əz bɪɡ ə hæmɝ əz ɛniwʌn kəd wɪʃ fɔɹ. ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt ðeɪ wʊɾə sɛd hæɾ i toʊld əm i wɑz hæmɝ ɪnʌf baɪ hɪmsɛlf. hi hæd kənsɪɾɝd duɪŋ ðɪs baɪ hɪmsɛlf. ɪt maɪt kʌm tə ðət jɛt.

Not everyone was pleased with the orders he had given. Sunamon's oily smile vanished when he thought Rand did not see. Torean had a flask in his saddlebags, no doubt brandy, or maybe several flasks, because he drank steadily and never appeared to run dry. Semaradrid and Marcolin and Tihera each appeared in front of Rand to protest the numbers with somber faces. A few years before, close on six thousand men would have been army enough for any war, but they had seen armies in the tens of thousands, now, hundreds of thousands, as in Artur Hawkwing's day, and to go against the Seanchan, they wanted far more. He sent them away disgruntled. They did not understand that fifty-odd Asha'man were as big a hammer as anyone could wish for. Rand wondered what they would have said had he told them he was hammer enough by himself. He had considered doing this by himself. It might come to that yet.

wɪɹɑmɑn keɪm; hi dɪd nɑt laɪk hævɪŋ tə teɪk ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm bæʃɪɹ, əɹ ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə maʊntənz - vɛɹi hɑɹd tə maʊn ə disən tʃɑɹdʒ ɪn maʊntənz - əɹ sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ θɪŋz - ɹænd wɑz sɝɾən ðəɹ wɝ ət list sɛvɹəl mɔɹ - ðət ɹænd dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm ʌɾɝ.

Weiramon came; he did not like having to take orders from Bashere, or the fact that they were going into mountains - very hard to mount a decent charge in mountains - or several other things - Rand was certain there were at least several more - that Rand did not let him utter.

"ðə sɑldəiən simz tə bɪliv aɪ ʃəd ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə ɹaɪt flæŋk," wɪɹɑmɑn mʌɾɝd dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli. hi twɪstəɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əz ðoʊ ðə ɹaɪt flæŋk wɝ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnsəlt, fəɹ səm ɹizən. "æn ðə fʊt, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ɹɪli, aɪ θɪŋk - "

"The Saldaean seems to believe I should ride on the right flank," Weiramon muttered disparagingly. He twisted his shoulders as though the right flank were a great insult, for some reason. "And the foot, my Lord Dragon. Really, I think - "

"aɪ θɪŋk jə ʃəd ɡɛt jəɹ mɛn ɹɛɾi," ɹænd sɛd koʊldli. pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɪl wɑz ði ɪfɛkt ə floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ɪmoʊʃənləs ɛmptinəs. "ɔɹ jə woʊn bi ɑn ɛni flæŋk." hi mɛn ðəɾ i wəd liv ðə mæn bɪhaɪn ɪf i wɑz nɑt ɹɛɾi ɪn taɪm. ʃʊɹli sətʃ ə ful kəd nɑt meɪk mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl lɛft ɪn ðɪs ɹɪmoʊt spɑt wɪð oʊnli ə fju ɑɹmmɪn. ɹænd wəd bi bæk bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹaɪd tə ɛniθɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə vɪlədʒ.

"I think you should get your men ready," Rand said coldly. Part of the chill was the effect of floating in emotionless emptiness. "Or you won't be on any flank." He meant that he would leave the man behind if he was not ready in time. Surely such a fool could not make much trouble left in this remote spot with only a few armsmen. Rand would be back before he could ride to anything larger than a village.

blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm wɪɹɑmɑnz feɪs, ðoʊ. "æz maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən kəmænz," hi sɛd, bɹɪskli fəɹ hɪm, ən wɑz wɝlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝdz wɝ wɛl aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊð. hɪz maʊnt wɑz ə tɔl dip-tʃɛstəd beɪ, tədeɪ.

Blood drained from Weiramon's face, though. "As my Lord Dragon commands," he said, briskly for him, and was whirling his horse away before the words were well out of his mouth. His mount was a tall deep-chested bay, today.

ðə peɪl leɪɾi eɪlɪl ɹeɪn tə ə stɑp ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, əkʌmpənid baɪ ðə haɪ leɪɾi ænɑiɛlə, ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɛɹ tə bi ɪn kʌmpəni, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ðɛɹ neɪʃənz heɪɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ. eɪlɪl wɑz tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɑz dɪɡnəɾi ən pɹisɪʒən, fɹəm ði ɑɹtʃ ə hɝ aɪbɹaʊ tə ðə tɝn ə hɝ ɹɛd-ɡlʌvd ɹɪs tə ðə weɪ hɝ pɝl-kɑlɝd ɹeɪn keɪp leɪ spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹʌmp ə hɝ smoʊk-ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ. ənlaɪk səmɝædʒɹɪɾ əɹ mɑɹkəlɪn, wɪɹɑmɑn əɹ taɪhɛɹə, ʃi dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz blɪŋk ət ðə saɪɾ ə ɹeɪndʒɹɑps slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn nʌθɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ænɑiɛlə dɪd blɪŋk. ən ɡæsp. ən tɪɾɝ bɪhaɪn əɹ hænd. ænɑiɛlə wɑz wɪləwi ən dɑɹkli bjuɾəfəl, hɝ ɹeɪn keɪp kɑlɝd wɪð ɹubiz ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊl bɪsaɪdz, bʌt ðəɹ ɛni ɹɪzɛmbləns tə eɪlɪl ɛndəd. ænɑiɛlə wɑz ɔl mɪnsɪŋ ɛləɡəns ən sɪmpɝz. wən ʃi baʊd, hɝ waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ dɪd, tu, bɛndɪŋ ɪts fɔɹɛlɛɡz. ðə pɹænsɪŋ ænəməl wɑz ʃoʊi, bʌt ɹænd səspɛktəɾ ɪt hæd noʊ bɑɾəm. laɪk ɪts mɪstʃɹəs.

The pale Lady Ailil reined to a stop in front of Rand, accompanied by the High Lady Anaiyella, a strange pair to be in company, and not just because their nations hated one another. Ailil was tall for a Cairhienin woman, if only for a Cairhienin, and everything about her was dignity and precision, from the arch of her eyebrow to the turn of her red-gloved wrist to the way her pearl-collared rain cape lay spread across the rump of her smoke-gray mare. Unlike Semaradrid or Marcolin, Weiramon or Tihera, she did not so much as blink at the sight of raindrops sliding down nothing around him. Anaiyella did blink. And gasp. And titter behind her hand. Anaiyella was willowy and darkly beautiful, her rain cape collared with rubies and embroidered with gold besides, but there any resemblance to Ailil ended. Anaiyella was all mincing elegance and simpers. When she bowed, her white gelding did, too, bending its forelegs. The prancing animal was showy, but Rand suspected it had no bottom. Like its mistress.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," eɪlɪl sɛd, "aɪ mʌs meɪk wʌn mɔɹ pɹoʊɾɛst əɡɛns maɪ ɪnkluʒən ɪn ðɪs . . . ɛkspədɪʃən." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kuli nutʃɹəl, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ənfɹɛnli. "aɪ wɪl sɛn maɪ ɹɪteɪnɝz wɛɹ jə kəmæn ən wɛn, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ əɾ ɔl tə bi ɪn ðə θɪk ʌv ə bæɾəl."

"My Lord Dragon," Ailil said, "I must make one more protest against my inclusion in this . . . expedition." Her voice was coolly neutral, if not exactly unfriendly. "I will send my retainers where you command and when, but I have no desire at all to be in the thick of a battle."

"oʊ, noʊ," ænɑiɛlə æɾəd, wɪð ə dɛləkət ʃʌɾɝ. ivən əɹ toʊn sɪmpɝd! "næsti θɪŋz, bæɾəlz. soʊ maɪ mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs sɛz. ʃʊɹli jə woʊn ɹɪli meɪk əs ɡoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən? wiv hɝd juv ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ kɛɹ fəɹ wɪmən. hævənt wi, eɪlɪl?"

"Oh, no," Anaiyella added, with a delicate shudder. Even her tone simpered! "Nasty things, battles. So my Master of the Horse says. Surely you won't really make us go, my Lord Dragon? We've heard you have a particular care for women. Haven't we, Ailil?"

ɹænd wɑz soʊ əstɑnɪʃt ðət ðə vɔɪd kəlæpst, ən seɪɾɪn vænɪʃt. ɹeɪndʒɹɑps bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɪkəl θɹu hɪz hɛɹ ən sip θɹu hɪz koʊt, bʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz sæɾəlz haɪ pɑməl tə hoʊl hɪmsɛlf əpɹaɪt, siɪŋ fɔɹ wɪmən ɪnstɛɾ ə tu, hi wɑz tu stʌn tə noʊɾəs. haʊ mʌtʃ dɪd ðeɪ noʊ? ðeɪ hæd hɝd? haʊ mɛni pipəl nu? haʊ dɪɾ ɛniwʌn noʊ? laɪt, ɹumɝ hæɾ ɪm kɪlɪŋ mɔɹɡeɪs, ɪleɪn, koʊləveɪɪɹ, ə hʌnʒɹəd wɪmən pɹɑbli, ən itʃ ɪn ə wɝs weɪ ðən ðə læst! hi swɑloʊɾ əɡɛns ði ɝdʒ tə sɪk ʌp. ðət wɑz oʊnli pɑɹtli seɪɾɪnz fɔlt. bɝn mi, haʊ mɛni spaɪz ɑɹ ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ mi? ðə θɔt wɑz ə ɡɹaʊl.

Rand was so astonished that the Void collapsed, and saidin vanished. Raindrops began to trickle through his hair and seep through his coat, but for a moment, clutching his saddle's high pommel to hold himself upright, seeing four women instead of two, he was too stunned to notice. How much did they know? They had heard? How many people knew? How did anyone know? Light, rumor had him killing Morgase, Elayne, Colavaere, a hundred women probably, and each in a worse way than the last! He swallowed against the urge to sick up.
