That was only partly saidin's fault. Burn me, how many spies are there watching me? The thought was a growl.

ðə dɛd wɑtʃ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. ðə dɛd nɛvɝ kloʊs ðɛɹ aɪz. ɹænd ʃɪvɝd.

The dead watch, Lews Therin whispered. The dead never close their eyes. Rand shivered.

"aɪ də tʃɹaɪ tə bi kɛɹfəl ʌv wɪmən," hi toʊld əm wən i kəd spik. fæstɝ ðən ə mæn, ən fəɹ hæf ðə ɹizən. "ðæts waɪ aɪ wɑnə kip jə kloʊz ðə nɛks fju deɪz. bʌɾ ɪf jə ɹɪli dɪslaɪk ði aɪdiə soʊ mʌtʃ, aɪ kəd tɛl ɔf wʌn ə ði æʃəmən. jud bi seɪf ət ðə blæk taʊɝ." ænɑiɛlə skwik pɹɪɾəli, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɛnt ɡɹeɪ.

"I do try to be careful of women," he told them when he could speak. Faster than a man, and for half the reason. "That's why I want to keep you close the next few days. But if you really dislike the idea so much, I could tell off one of the Asha'man. You'd be safe at the Black Tower." Anaiyella squeaked prettily, but her face went gray.

"θæŋk ju, noʊ," eɪlɪl sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, æbsəlutli kɑm. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ hæd bɛs kənfɝ wɪð maɪ læns-kæptən əbaʊt wʌt tə ɪkspɛkt." bʌt ʃi pɔzd ɪn tɝnɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ əweɪ, ən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɹænd wɪð ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "maɪ bɹʌðɝ tɔɹæm ɪz . . . ɪmpɛtʃwəs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ivən ɹæʃ. aɪm nɑt."

"Thank you, no," Ailil said after a moment, absolutely calm. "I suppose I had best confer with my lance-captain about what to expect." But she paused in turning her mare away, and regarded Rand with a sidelong look. "My brother Toram is . . . impetuous, my Lord Dragon. Even rash. I am not."

ænɑiɛlə smaɪl mʌtʃ tu switli ət ɹænd, ən æktʃəli  ɹɪəl slaɪtli bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ, bʌt wʌns ʃi feɪst əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ʃi dʌɡ ɪn əɹ hilz ən wɝkt əɹ dʒuəl-hændəl kwɝt, kwɪkli pæsɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ðət waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ ʃoʊɾ ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ tɝn ə spid.

Anaiyella smiled much too sweetly at Rand, and actually wriggled slightly before following, but once she faced away from him, she dug in her heels and worked her jewel-handled quirt, quickly passing the other woman. That white gelding showed a surprising turn of speed.

ət læst ɔl wɑz ɹɛɾi, ðə kɑləmz fɔɹmd, sneɪkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ðə loʊ hɪlz.

At last all was ready, the columns formed, snaking back over the low hills.

"bɪɡɪn," ɹænd toʊl dʒɛdwɪn, hu wild ɪz hɔɹs ən bɪɡæn bɑɹkɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz tə hɪz mɛn. ði eɪt dɛɾəkeɪtəd ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝɾ ən dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ðeɪ hæd mɛmɝaɪzd, feɪsɪŋ ðə maʊntənz. wʌn ə ðɛm lʊk fəmɪljɝ, ə ɡɹɪzəl fɛloʊ huz pɔɪntəd tɛɹən bɪɹɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑɾ ɑn ɪz ɹɪŋkəl kʌntʃɹimənz feɪs. eɪt vɝɾɪkəl laɪnz ə ʃɑɹp blu laɪt tɝn ən bɪkeɪm oʊpənɪŋz ðət ʃoʊd slaɪtli dɪfɹən vjuz ʌv ə lɔŋ, spɑɹsli wʊɾɪd maʊntən væli ɹaɪzɪŋ tə ə stip pæs. ɪn ɔltɑɹə. ɪn ðə vɛnɪɹ maʊntənz.

"Begin," Rand told Gedwyn, who wheeled his horse and began barking orders to his men. The eight Dedicated rode forward and dismounted on the ground they had memorized, facing the mountains. One of them looked familiar, a grizzled fellow whose pointed Tairen beard appeared odd on his wrinkled countryman's face. Eight vertical lines of sharp blue light turned and became openings that showed slightly different views of a long, sparsely wooded mountain valley rising to a steep pass. In Altara. In the Venir Mountains.

kɪl ðɛm, luz θɝɪn wɛpt pliɾɪŋli. ðəɹ tu deɪnʒɝəs tə lɪv! wɪθaʊt θɔt, ɹænd səpɹɛs ðə vɔɪs. ənʌðɝ mæn tʃænəlɪŋ ɔfən bɹɔt ðət ɹiækʃən fɹəm luz θɝɪn, əɹ ivən ə mæn u kʊd. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wʌndɝd waɪ.

Kill them, Lews Therin wept pleadingly. They're too dangerous to live! Without thought, Rand suppressed the voice. Another man channeling often brought that reaction from Lews Therin, or even a man who could. He no longer wondered why.

ɹænd mʌɾɝd ə kəmænd, ən flɪn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðə laɪn ən wiv ə naɪnθ ɡeɪtweɪ. nʌn wɑz əz lɑɹdʒ əz ɹænd kəd meɪk, bʌɾ ɛni wəd pæs ə kɑɹt, ɪf kloʊsli. hi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə də ðət hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə tʃæns sizɪŋ seɪɾɪn əɡɛn ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn. hi noʊɾəst dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, wɛɹɪŋ aɪdɛntɪkəl noʊɪŋ smaɪlz. ən dæʃivə əz wɛl, fɹaʊnɪŋ, lɪps muvɪŋ əz i tɔk tə hɪmsɛlf. wɑz ɪɾ ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, əɹ wɑz nɛɹɪʃmə aɪɪŋ ɪm əskæns tu? ən ædli? mɔɹ?

Rand muttered a command, and Flinn blinked in surprise before hurrying to join the line and weave a ninth gateway. None was as large as Rand could make, but any would pass a cart, if closely. He had intended to do that himself, but he did not want to chance seizing saidin again in front of everyone. He noticed Gedwyn and Rochaid watching him, wearing identical knowing smiles. And Dashiva as well, frowning, lips moving as he talked to himself. Was it his imagination, or was Narishma eyeing him askance too? And Adley? Morr?

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp hɪmsɛlf. mɪstʃɹʌst ə dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑz sɪmpəl sɛns, bʌt wɑz i kʌmɪŋ daʊn wɪð wʌt nɪneɪiv hæd kɔl ðə dʒɹɛdz? ə kaɪndə mædnəs, ə kɹɪpəlɪŋ dɑɹk səspɪʃən ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ? ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə kɑplɪn, bɛnli, hu θɔɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz skimɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. hi hæd stɑɹv tə dɛθ wən ɹænd wɑz ə bɔɪ, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə it fəɹ fɪɹ ə pɔɪzən.

Rand shivered before he could stop himself. Mistrust of Gedwyn and Rochaid was simple sense, but was he coming down with what Nynaeve had called the dreads? A kind of madness, a crippling dark suspicion of everyone and everything? There had been a Coplin, Benly, who thought everybody was scheming against him. He had starved to death when Rand was a boy, refusing to eat for fear of poison.

dʌkɪŋ loʊ ɑn teɪdeɪʃɝz nɛk, ɹænd hil ðə ɡɛldɪŋ θɹu ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɡeɪtweɪ. flɪnz, əz ɪt hæpənd, bʌɾ i wʊɾə ɹɪɾən θɹu wʌn meɪd baɪ dʒɛdwɪn ɹaɪt ðɛn. hi wɑz ðə fɝst ɑntu ɔltɑɹən sɔɪl.

Ducking low on Tai'daishar's neck, Rand heeled the gelding through the largest gateway. Flinn's, as it happened, but he would have ridden through one made by Gedwyn right then. He was the first onto Altaran soil.

ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊd kwɪkli, ði æʃəmən fɝst ʌv ɔl. dæʃivə stɛɹɾ ɪn ɹændz dɝɛkʃən, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən nɛɹɪʃmə, tu, bʌt dʒɛdwɪn ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn dɝɛktɪŋ ɪz soʊlʒɝz. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðeɪ ɹʌʃt fɔɹwɝd, oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ ən dɑɹɾɪd θɹu, dʒɹæɡɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊns bɪhaɪn ðɛm. əhɛɾ ʌp ðə væli, bɹaɪt flæʃɪz ə laɪt toʊld ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ. ði æʃəmən kəd tʃɹævəl ʃɔɹt dɪstənsəz wɪθaʊt fɝs mɛmɝaɪzɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ðeɪ lɛft fɹʌm, ən kʌvɝ ɡɹaʊn fɑɹ fæstɝ ðən ɹaɪɾɪŋ. ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ, oʊnli dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd ɹɪmeɪnd, əsaɪd fɹəm ðə dɛɾəkeɪtəd hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪz. ði ʌðɝz wəd bi fænɪŋ aʊt wɛstwɝd, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ sintʃæn. ðə sɑldəiənz wɝ θɹu fɹəm ɪljən, ən maʊntɪŋ. lidʒənmɛn spɹɛɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz əɾ ə tʃɹɑt, kɹɔsboʊz hɛld ɹɛɾi. ɪn ðɪs kʌntʃɹi, ðeɪ kəd muv əz fæst əfʊɾ əz mɛn ɑn hɔɹsbæk.

The others followed quickly, the Asha'man first of all. Dashiva stared in Rand's direction, frowning, and Narishma, too, but Gedwyn immediately began directing his Soldiers. One by one, they rushed forward, opened a gateway and darted through, dragging their mounts behind them. Ahead up the valley, bright flashes of light told of gateways opening and closing. The Asha'man could Travel short distances without first memorizing the ground they left from, and cover ground far faster than riding. In short order, only Gedwyn and Rochaid remained, aside from the Dedicated holding the gateways. The others would be fanning out westward, searching for Seanchan. The Saldaeans were through from Illian, and mounting. Legionmen spread into the trees at a trot, crossbows held ready. In this country, they could move as fast afoot as men on horseback.

əz ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɑɹmi bɪɡæn ɪmɝdʒɪŋ, ɹænd ɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə væli ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ði æʃəmən hæd ɡɔn. maʊntənz ɹoʊz haɪ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ə wɔl fɹʌntɪŋ ðə dip, bʌt wɛs ðə piks ɹæn ɔlmoʊs tə ɛbu dɑɹ. hi kwɪkən ðə ɡɛldɪŋz peɪs tə ə kæntɝ.

As the rest of the army began emerging, Rand rode up the valley in the direction the Asha'man had gone. Mountains rose high behind him, a wall fronting the Deep, but west the peaks ran almost to Ebou Dar. He quickened the gelding's pace to a canter.

bæʃɪɹ kɑɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə pæs. ðə mænz beɪ wɑz smɔl - moʊst ə ðə sɑldəiənz ɹoʊd smɔl hɔɹsəz - bʌt kwɪk. "noʊ sintʃæn hɪɹ, ɪt simz," hi sɛɾ ɔlmoʊst aɪdli, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə nʌkəl. "bʌt ðəɹ kəɾ əv bɪn. tɛnoʊbiəz laɪkli tə hæv maɪ hɛɾ ɑn ə paɪk sun ɪnʌf fəɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ə laɪv dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə dɛd wʌn."

Bashere caught him before he reached the pass. The man's bay was small - most of the Saldaeans rode small horses - but quick. "No Seanchan here, it seems," he said almost idly, stroking his mustaches with a knuckle. "But there could have been. Tenobia's likely to have my head on a pike soon enough for following a live Dragon Reborn, much more a dead one."

ɹænd skaʊld. meɪbi hi kəd teɪk flɪn, tə wɑtʃ ɪz bæk, ən nɛɹɪʃmə, ænd. . . . flɪn hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf; ðə mæn hæd tə bi tʃɹu. mɛn kəd tʃeɪnʒ, ðoʊ. ən nɛɹɪʃmə? ivən æftɝ . . . ? hi fɛl koʊld ət ðə ɹɪsk i hæd teɪkən. nɑt ðə dʒɹɛdz. nɛɹɪʃmə hæd pɹuv tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl hæd bɪn ə mæd ɹɪsk. əz mæɾ əz ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm stɛɹz i wɑz nɑɾ ivən ʃʊɹ wɝ ɹil, ɹʌnɪŋ tə wɛɹ i hæd noʊ noʊʃən wʌt wɑz weɪɾɪŋ. bæʃɪɹ wɑz ɹaɪt, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt fɝðɝ.

Rand scowled. Maybe he could take Flinn, to watch his back, and Narishma, and. . . . Flinn had saved his life; the man had to be true. Men could change, though. And Narishma? Even after . . . ? He felt cold at the risk he had taken. Not the dreads. Narishma had proved true, but it still had been a mad risk. As mad as running from stares he was not even sure were real, running to where he had no notion what was waiting. Bashere was right, but Rand did not want to talk about it further.

ðə sloʊps liɾɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ðə pæs wɝ bɛɹ stoʊn ən boʊldɝz ʌv ɔl saɪzəz, bʌɾ əmʌŋ ðə nætʃɹəl stoʊn leɪ wɛðɝd pisəz ʌv wʌt mʌst əv wʌns bɪn ə hjudʒ stætʃu. səm wɝ dʒʌst ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl əz wɝk stoʊn, ʌðɝz mɔɹ soʊ. ə bɛɹɪn hænd nɪɹli bɪɡ əz ɪz tʃɛst, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə sɔɹd hɪlt wɪð ə bɹoʊkən stʌb ə bleɪd waɪɾɝ ðən ɪz hænd. ə ɡɹeɪt hɛd, ə wʊmən wɪð kɹæks əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs ən ə kɹaʊn ðət sim tə bi meɪɾ ʌv ʌp-θɹʌstɪŋ dæɡɝz, səm stɪl hoʊl.

The slopes leading up into the pass were bare stone and boulders of all sizes, but among the natural stone lay weathered pieces of what must have once been a huge statue. Some were just recognizable as worked stone, others more so. A beringed hand nearly big as his chest, gripping a sword hilt with a broken stub of blade wider than his hand. A great head, a woman with cracks across her face and a crown that seemed to be made of up-thrusting daggers, some still whole.

"hu dʒju θɪŋk ʃi wɑz?" hi æskt. ə kwin, ʌv kɔɹs. ivən ɪf mɝtʃəns əɹ skɑlɝz hæd wɔɹn kɹaʊnz ɪn səm dɪstən taɪm, oʊnli ɹulɝz ən dʒɛnɝəlz ɝn stætʃuz.

"Who do you think she was?" he asked. A queen, of course. Even if merchants or scholars had worn crowns in some distant time, only rulers and generals earned statues.

bæʃɪɹ twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə stʌɾi ðə hɛd bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "eɪ kwin ə ʃioʊɾə, əl weɪdʒɝ," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "nɑɾ oʊldɝ. aɪ sɔ ə stætʃu meɪɾ ɪn ɛɹən wʌns, ən ɪt wɑz soʊ wɔɹn jə kʊdn seɪ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz mæn əɹ wʊmən. ə kɑŋkɝɝ, əɹ ðeɪ wʊdn əv ʃoʊn əɹ wɪð ə sɔɹd. ən aɪ sim tə ɹikɔl ʃioʊɾə ɡeɪv ə kɹaʊn laɪk ðət tə ɹulɝz u ɪkspændəd ðə bɔɹɾɝz. meɪbi ðeɪ kɔld ɪt ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz, ɛ? eɪ bɹaʊn sɪstɝ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə tɛl jə mɔɹ."

Bashere twisted in his saddle to study the head before speaking. "A Queen of Shiota, I'll wager," he said finally. "Not older. I saw a statue made in Eharon once, and it was so worn you couldn't say whether it was man or woman. A conqueror, or they wouldn't have shown her with a sword. And I seem to recall Shiota gave a crown like that to rulers who expanded the borders. Maybe they called it the Crown of Swords, eh? A Brown sister might be able to tell you more."

"ɪɾ ɪzən ɪmpɔɹɾənt," ɹænd toʊld ɪm ɪɹɪɾəbli. ðeɪ dɪd lʊk laɪk sɔɹdz.

"It isn't important," Rand told him irritably. They did look like swords.

bæʃɪɹ wɛn ɑn ɛniweɪ, ɡɹeɪɪŋ aɪbɹaʊz loʊɝd, ɡɹeɪvli sɪɹiəs. "aɪ ɪkspɛk θaʊzənz tʃɪɹd hɝ, kɔld əɹ ðə hoʊp ə ʃioʊɾə, meɪbi ivən bɪlivd ʃi wɑz. ɪn əɹ taɪm, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn əz fɪɹɾ ən ɹɪspɛktɪɾ əz ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz leɪɾɝ, bʌt naʊ ivən ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz meɪ nɑt noʊ hɝ neɪm. wən jə daɪ, pipəl bɪɡɪn tə fɝɡɛt, hu jə wɝ ən wʌt jə dɪd, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə du. ɛvɹibɑɾi daɪz ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪz fɝɡɑɾən, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, bʌt ðɛɹz noʊ blʌɾi pɔɪn daɪɪŋ bɪfɔɹ jəɹ taɪm kʌmz."

Bashere went on anyway, graying eyebrows lowered, gravely serious. "I expect thousands cheered her, called her the hope of Shiota, maybe even believed she was. In her time, she might have been as feared and respected as Artur Hawkwing was later, but now even the Brown sisters may not know her name. When you die, people begin to forget, who you were and what you did, or tried to do. Everybody dies eventually, and everybody is forgotten, eventually, but there's no bloody point dying before your time comes."

"aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə," ɹænd sɛd ʃɑɹpli. hi nu wɛɹ i wɑz mɛn tə daɪ, ɪf nɑt wɛn. hi θɔɾ i dɪd.

"I don't intend to," Rand said sharply. He knew where he was meant to die, if not when. He thought he did.

ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ kɑt moʊʃən, bæk daʊn wɛɹ bɛɹ stoʊn ɡeɪv weɪ tə bɹʌʃ ən ə fju smɔl tʃɹiz. fɪfti peɪsɪz əweɪ, ə mæn stɛpt ɪndə ði oʊpən ən ɹeɪzd ə baʊ, smuðli dʒɹɔɪŋ flɛtʃɪŋz tə tʃik. ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə hæpən ət wʌns.

The corner of his eye caught motion, back down where bare stone gave way to brush and a few small trees. Fifty paces away, a man stepped into the open and raised a bow, smoothly drawing fletchings to cheek. Everything seemed to happen at once.

snɑɹlɪŋ, ɹænd hɔl teɪdeɪʃɝ ɝaʊnd, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɑɹtʃɝ ədʒʌs tə fɑloʊ. hi siz seɪɾɪn ən swit laɪf ən fɪlθ pɔɹɾ ɪndə hɪm təɡɛðɝ. hɪz hɛd spʌn. ðəɹ wɝ tu ɑɹtʃɝz. baɪl ɹoʊz ɪn ɪz θɹoʊɾ əz i fɔt waɪld, ʌnkəntʃɹoʊl sɝdʒəz ə ðə paʊɝ ðət tʃɹaɪd tə sɪɹ ɪm tə ðə boʊn ən fɹiz ɪz flɛʃ sɑləd. hi kəd nɑt kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛm; ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə steɪ əlaɪv. dɛspɝətli, hi fɔt tə klɪɹ ɪz saɪt, tə bi eɪbəl tə si wɛl ɪnʌf tə wiv ðə floʊz i kəd bɛɹli fɔɹm, wɪð nɔziə flʌɾɪŋ ɪm əz stʃɹɔŋli əz ðə paʊɝ. hi θɔɾ i hɝd bæʃɪɹ ʃaʊt. tu ɑɹtʃɝz lust.

Snarling, Rand hauled Tai'daishar around, watching the archer adjust to follow. He seized saidin and sweet life and filth poured into him together. His head spun. There were two archers. Bile rose in his throat as he fought wild, uncontrolled surges of the Power that tried to sear him to the bone and freeze his flesh solid. He could not control them; it was all he could do to stay alive. Desperately, he fought to clear his sight, to be able to see well enough to weave the flows he could barely form, with nausea flooding him as strongly as the Power. He thought he heard Bashere shout. Two archers loosed.

ɹænd ʃəɾ əv daɪd. ət ðət ɹeɪnʒ, ə bɔɪ cʊɾə hɪɾ ɪz tɑɹɡət. meɪbi biɪŋ tɑvɝən seɪv hɪm. əz ði ɑɹtʃɝ lɛt flaɪ, ə kʌvi ʌv ɡɹeɪ-wɪŋ kweɪl bɝst ʌp ɔlmoʊst əɾ ɪz fiɾ ʌɾɝɪŋ pɪɹsɪŋ wɪsəlz. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə θɹoʊ ɔf ən ɪkspɪɹiəns mæn, ən ɪndid, ðə fɛloʊ oʊnli flɪntʃt ə hɛɹ. ɹænd fɛl ðə wɪn ə ði æɹoʊz pæsədʒ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃik.

Rand should have died. At that range, a boy could have hit his target. Maybe being ta'veren saved him. As the archer let fly, a covey of gray-winged quail burst up almost at his feet uttering piercing whistles. Not enough to throw off an experienced man, and indeed, the fellow only flinched a hair. Rand felt the wind of the arrow's passage against his cheek.

faɪɝbɔlz ðə saɪz ə fɪsts sʌɾənli stʃɹʌk ði ɑɹtʃɝ. hi skɹimd əz ɪz ɑɹm spʌn əweɪ, hæn stɪl ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə baʊ. ənʌðɝ tʊk ɪz lɛf lɛɡ ət ðə ni, ən i fɛl ʃɹikɪŋ.

Fireballs the size of fists suddenly struck the archer. He screamed as his arm spun away, hand still gripping the bow. Another took his left leg at the knee, and he fell shrieking.

linɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl, ɹænd vɑməɾəd ɑntu ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz stʌmək tʃɹaɪd tə hiv ʌp ɛvɹi mil i hæɾ ɛvɝ iɾən. ðə vɔɪɾ ən seɪɾɪn lɛft wɪð ə sɪkənɪŋ ɹɛntʃ. ɪt wɑz nɪɹli mɔɹ ðən i kəd mænədʒ nɑt tə fɔl.

Leaning out of his saddle, Rand vomited onto the ground. His stomach tried to heave up every meal he had ever eaten. The Void and saidin left with a sickening wrench. It was nearly more than he could manage not to fall.

wən i kəd sɪɾ əpɹaɪɾ əɡɛn, hi tʊk ðə waɪt lɪnən hæŋkɝtʃɪf bæʃɪɹ saɪlənli ɔfɝd, ən waɪpt ɪz maʊð. ðə sɑldəiən fɹaʊnd wɪð kənsɝn, əz wɛl i maɪt. ɹændz stʌmək wɑntəd tə faɪn mɔɹ tə spju aʊt. hi θɔɾ ɪz feɪs mʌs bi peɪl. hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. luzɪŋ seɪɾɪn ðət weɪ kəd kɪl ju. bʌɾ i kəd stɪl sɛns ðə sɔɹs; ət list seɪɾɪn hæd nɑt bɝn ɪm aʊt. ət list i kəd si pɹɑpɝli; ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ. bʌt ði ɪlnəs simd ə lɪɾəl wɝs itʃ taɪm i siz seɪɾɪn.

When he could sit upright again, he took the white linen handkerchief Bashere silently offered, and wiped his mouth. The Saldaean frowned with concern, as well he might. Rand's stomach wanted to find more to spew out. He thought his face must be pale. He drew a deep breath. Losing saidin that way could kill you. But he could still sense the Source; at least saidin had not burned him out. At least he could see properly; there was only one Davram Bashere. But the illness seemed a little worse each time he seized saidin.

"lɛts si ɪf ðɛɹz ɪnʌf lɛft ə ðɪs fɛloʊ tə tɔk," hi toʊl bæʃɪɹ. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt.

"Let's see if there's enough left of this fellow to talk," he told Bashere. There was not.

ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑz ɑn ɪz niz, kɑmli sɝtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə kɔɹpsəz tɔɹn, blʌdsteɪn koʊt. bɪsaɪdz ɪz mɪsɪŋ ɑɹm ən lɛɡ, ðə dɛd mæn hæɾ ə blækən hoʊl əz bɪɡ əz ɪz hɛɾ ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu hɪz tʃɛst. ɪt wɑz iɡən pædʒɹoʊs; hɪz saɪtləs aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. dʒɛdwɪn ɪɡnɔɹd ðə bɑɾi əɾ ɪz fit, stʌɾiɪŋ ɹænd ɪnstɛd, əz koʊld əz ɹɑtʃeɪd. boʊθ mɛn hɛl seɪɾɪn. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, luz θɝɪn oʊnli moʊnd.

Rochaid was on his knees, calmly searching through the corpse's torn, bloodstained coat. Besides his missing arm and leg, the dead man had a blackened hole as big as his head all the way through his chest. It was Eagan Padros; his sightless eyes stared at the sky in surprise. Gedwyn ignored the body at his feet, studying Rand instead, as cold as Rochaid. Both men held saidin. Surprisingly, Lews Therin only moaned.

ɪn ə klæɾɝ ə hʊvz ɑn stoʊn, flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹaɪz, fɑloʊd baɪ nɪɹli ə hʌnʒɹəd sɑldəiənz. əz ðeɪ keɪm kloʊs, ɹænd kəd fil ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðə ɡɹɪzəld oʊl mæn ən ðə jʌŋɡɝ, meɪbi əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ kəd hoʊld. ðeɪ hæd boʊθ lɛpt ʌp ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ sɪns dəməaɪz wɛlz. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt wɪð mɛn; wɪmən sim tə ɡeɪn smuðli, bʌt mɛn sʌɾənli dʒʌmpt. flɪn wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən dʒɛdwɪn əɹ ɹɑtʃeɪɾ iðɝ wʌn, ən nɛɹɪʃmə nɑt fɑɹ bɪhaɪnd. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə noʊ haʊ ɪt wəɾ ɛnd. nʌn keɪm kloʊs tə mætʃɪŋ ɹænd, ðoʊ. nɑt jɛt, ɛniweɪ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wʌt taɪm wəd bɹɪŋ. nɑt ðə dʒɹɛdz.

In a clatter of hooves on stone, Flinn and Narishma came galloping up the rise, followed by nearly a hundred Saldaeans. As they came close, Rand could feel the Power in the grizzled old man and the younger, maybe as much as they could hold. They had both leaped up in strength since Dumai's Wells. That was the way of it with men; women seemed to gain smoothly, but men suddenly jumped. Flinn was stronger than Gedwyn or Rochaid either one, and Narishma not far behind. For the time being; there was no way to know how it would end. None came close to matching Rand, though. Not yet, anyway. There was no way to tell what time would bring. Not the dreads.

"ɪt simz ɪts wɛl wi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɑloʊ ju, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." dʒɛdwɪnz vɔɪs əsum kənsɝn, dʒʌst ʃaɪ ʌv mɑkɪŋ. "ɑɹ jə sʌfɝɪŋ fɹəm ə tɛndɝ stʌmək ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ?"

"It seems it's well we decided to follow you, my Lord Dragon." Gedwyn's voice assumed concern, just shy of mocking. "Are you suffering from a tender stomach this morning?"

ɹænd dʒʌst ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi kəd nɑt teɪk ɪz aɪz fɹəm pædʒɹoʊs' feɪs. waɪ? kəz i hæd kɑŋkɝɾ ɪljən? kəz ðə mæn hæd bɪn lɔɪəl tə "lɔɹd bɹɛnd"?

Rand just shook his head. He could not take his eyes from Padros' face. Why? Because he had conquered Illian? Because the man had been loyal to "Lord Brend"?

wɪð ə laʊɾ ɛkskləmeɪʃən, ɹɑtʃeɪd ɹɪpt ə wɑʃ-lɛðɝ paʊtʃ fɹəm pædʒɹoʊs' koʊt pɑkəɾ ən ʌpɛndəɾ ɪt. bɹaɪt ɡoʊldən kɔɪnz spɪld ɑntu ðə stoʊni ɡɹaʊnd, baʊnsɪŋ ən klɪŋkɪŋ. "θɝɾi kɹaʊnz," hi ɡɹaʊld. "tɑɹ vəlɑn kɹaʊnz. noʊ daʊɾ u peɪd hɪm." hi snætʃt ə kɔɪn ən tɔst ɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɹænd, bʌt ɹænd meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə kætʃ ɪt, ən ɪt ɡlænst ɔf ɪz ɑɹm.

With a loud exclamation, Rochaid ripped a wash-leather pouch from Padros' coat pocket and upended it. Bright golden coins spilled onto the stony ground, bouncing and clinking. "Thirty crowns," he growled. "Tar Valon crowns. No doubt who paid him." He snatched a coin and tossed it up for Rand, but Rand made no effort to catch it, and it glanced off his arm.

"ðɛɹz plɛnti ʌv tɑɹ vəlɑn kɔɪn tə bi faʊnd," bæʃɪɹ sɛd kɑmli. "hæf ðə mɛn ɪn ðɪs væli hæv ə fju ɪn ðɛɹ pɑkəts. aɪ du, maɪsɛlf" dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd swɪvəl tə lʊk ət hɪm. bæʃɪɹ smaɪl bɪhaɪn ɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz, əɹ ət list ʃoʊd tiθ, bʌt səm ə ðə sɑldəiənz ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən fɪŋɡɝd bɛl paʊtʃəz.

"There's plenty of Tar Valon coin to be found," Bashere said calmly. "Half the men in this valley have a few in their pockets. I do, myself" Gedwyn and Rochaid swiveled to look at him. Bashere smiled behind his thick mustaches, or at least showed teeth, but some of the Saldaeans shifted uneasily in their saddles and fingered belt pouches.

ʌp wɛɹ ðə pæs lɛvəld ɔf fəɹ ə bɪt bɪtwin stip maʊntən sloʊps, ə slæʃ ə laɪt ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ɪndə ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ə tɑp-nɑɾɪd ʃaɪnɝən ɪn ə pleɪn blæk koʊt tʃɹɑɾəd θɹu, pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs bɪhaɪn hɪm. ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðə fɝst sintʃæn hæd bɪn faʊnd, ən nɑt tu fɑɹ əweɪ ɪf ðə mæn wɑz bæk soʊ kwɪkli.

Up where the pass leveled off for a bit between steep mountain slopes, a slash of light rotated into a gateway, and a top-knotted Shienaran in a plain black coat trotted through, pulling his horse behind him. It appeared the first Seanchan had been found, and not too far away if the man was back so quickly.

"taɪm tə muv," ɹænd toʊl bæʃɪɹ. ðə mæn nɑɾəd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt stɝ. ɪnstɛd, hi stʌɾid ðə tu æʃəmən stændɪŋ nɪɹ pædʒɹoʊs. ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm.

"Time to move," Rand told Bashere. The man nodded, but he did not stir. Instead, he studied the two Asha'man standing near Padros. They ignored him.

"wʌt də wi də wɪð hɪm?" dʒɛdwɪn dɪmændəd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ðə kɔɹps. "wi ɔt tə sɛn ɪm bæk tə ðə wɪtʃəz, ət list."

"What do we do with him?" Gedwyn demanded, gesturing to the corpse. "We ought to send him back to the witches, at least."

"liv hɪm," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd.

"Leave him," Rand replied.

ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi tə kɪl naʊ? luz θɝɪn æskt. hi dɪd nɑt saʊn ɪnseɪn əɾ ɔl.

Are you ready to kill now? Lews Therin asked. He did not sound insane at all.

nɑt jɛt, ɹænd θɔt. sun.

Not yet, Rand thought. Soon.

dɪɡɪŋ ɪz hilz ɪndə teɪdeɪʃɝz flæŋks, hi ɡæləp bæk daʊn təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɑɹmi. dæʃivə ən flɪn fɑloʊd kloʊsli, ən bæʃɪɹ ən ðə hʌnʒɹəd sɑldəiənz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ənʌðɝ ətɛmpt ɑn ɪz laɪf. tə ði ist, blæk klaʊdz wɝ bɪldɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə piks, ənʌðɝ sɛmɑɹoʊz stɔɹm. sun.

Digging his heels into Tai'daishar's flanks, he galloped back down toward his army. Dashiva and Flinn followed closely, and Bashere and the hundred Saldaeans. They were all looking around as if they expected another attempt on his life. To the east, black clouds were building among the peaks, another cemaros storm. Soon.

ðə hɪltɑp kæmp wɑz wɛl leɪɾ aʊt, wɪð ə miændɝɪŋ stʃɹim kloʊs baɪ fəɹ wɔɾɝ ən ɡʊd laɪnz ə saɪt tə ðə laɪkliəst weɪz ɪndə ðə lɔŋ maʊntən mɛdoʊ. əsɪd bɑkən dɪd nɑt fil pɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə kæmp. dʊɹɪŋ θɝɾi jɪɹz ɪn ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi, hi hæd meɪd hʌnʒɹədz ə kæmps; hi wəɾ əz sun əv fɛl pɹaɪɾ ɪn wɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ə ɹum wɪθaʊt fɔlɪŋ daʊn. nɔɹ dɪɾ i fil pɹaɪɾ ɪn wɛɹ i wɑz. θɝɾi jɪɹz sɝvɪŋ ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ən waɪl ðəɹ hæd bɪn ði əkeɪʒənəl ɹɪbɛljən baɪ səm mæɾ ʌpstɑɹt wɪð aɪz ɑn ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ðə bʌlk ə ðoʊz jɪɹz hæd bɪn spɛn pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðɪs. fəɹ tu dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz, waɪl ðə ɡɹeɪt ʃɪps wɝ bɪl tə kæɹi ðə ɹɪtɝn, ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi hæd tʃɹeɪn ən pɹipɛɹd. bɑkən sɝɾənli hæd bɪn pɹaʊd wən i lɝn i wɑz tə bi wʌn ə ðə fɔɹʌnɝz. ʃʊɹli hi kəd bi fɝɡɪvən dʒɹimz ə ɹəteɪkɪŋ ðə lænz stoʊlən fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɹaɪtfəl ɛɹz, ivən waɪl dʒɹimz tə kəmpliɾɪŋ ðɪs nu kənsɑlədeɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ðə kɔɝɪn keɪm. nɑt sətʃ ə waɪl dʒɹim æftɝ ɔl, əz ɪt tɝn aʊt, bʌt nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə weɪ hi hæɾ ɪmædʒənd.

The hilltop camp was well laid out, with a meandering stream close by for water and good lines of sight to the likeliest ways into the long mountain meadow. Assid Bakuun did not feel pride in the camp. During thirty years in the Ever Victorious Army, he had made hundreds of camps; he would as soon have felt pride in walking across a room without falling down. Nor did he feel pride in where he was. Thirty years serving the Empress, might she live forever, and while there had been the occasional rebellion by some mad upstart with eyes on the Crystal Throne, the bulk of those years had been spent preparing for this. For two generations, while the great ships were built to carry the Return, the Ever Victorious Army had trained and prepared. Bakuun certainly had been proud when he learned he was to be one of the Forerunners. Surely he could be forgiven dreams of retaking the lands stolen from Artur Hawkwing's rightful heirs, even wild dreams to completing this new Consolidation before the Corenne came. Not such a wild dream after all, as it turned out, but not at all the way he had imagined.

ə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ pətʃɹoʊl ə fɪfti tæɹɑbənɝ lænsɝz ɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə hɪlsaɪd, ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin stʃɹaɪps peɪntəɾ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ sɑləd bɹɛstpleɪts, veɪlz ə meɪl haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ θɪk mʌstæʃɪz. ðeɪ ɹoʊd wɛl, ən ivən fɔt wɛl, wən ðeɪ hæd disən liɾɝz. mɔɹ ðən tɛn taɪmz əz mɛni wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi əmʌŋ ðə kʊk faɪɝz, əɹ daʊn ət ðə pɪkət laɪnz tɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊns, ən θɹi pətʃɹoʊlz wɝ stɪl aʊt. bɑkən hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf wɪð wɛl oʊvɝ hæf ɪz kəmæn dɪsɛndəns ə θivz. ən ʌnəʃeɪmd ʌv ɪt; ðeɪ wəd lʊk jə stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪz. ðə pətʃɹoʊlz kəmændɝ baʊd loʊ tə hɪm əz ðɛɹ mʌɾi-lɛɡəd hɔɹsəz pæst, bʌt mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz wɛn ɑn tɔkɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ pəkjuljɝ æksɛns, spikɪŋ tu fæs fəɹ bɑkən tə ʌndɝstænd wɪθaʊt lɪsnɪŋ hɑɹd. ðeɪ hæd pəkjuljɝ noʊʃənz ə dɪsəplən, tu.

A returning patrol of fifty Taraboner lancers rode up the hillside, red and green stripes painted across their solid breastplates, veils of mail hiding their thick mustaches. They rode well, and even fought well, when they had decent leaders. More than ten times as many were already among the cook fires, or down at the picket lines tending their mounts, and three patrols were still out. Bakuun had never expected to find himself with well over half his command descendants of thieves. And unashamed of it; they would look you straight in the eyes. The patrol's commander bowed low to him as their muddy-legged horses passed, but many of the others went on talking in their peculiar accents, speaking too fast for Bakuun to understand without listening hard. They had peculiar notions of discipline, too.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, bɑkən stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs tə ðə sʌldəmz lɑɹdʒ tɛnt. lɑɹdʒɝ ðən hɪz, ʌv nəsɛsəɾi. fɔɹ ə ðɛm wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn stulz aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛsəz wɪð ðə fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ ɑn ðə skɝts, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə sʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðɪs bɹeɪk ɪn ðə stɔɹmz. ðoʊz wɝ ɹɛɹ ɪnʌf, naʊ. ðə ɡɹeɪ-klæd deɪmeɪn sæɾ ət ðɛɹ fit, wɪð nɛɹɪθ bɹeɪɾɪŋ əɹ peɪl hɛɹ. tɔkɪŋ tə hɝ, əz wɛl, ɔl ə ðɛm dʒɔɪnɪŋ ɪn ən læfɪŋ sɔfli. ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn ði ɛn ə ðə sɪlvɝi æɾəmz liʃ leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bɑkən ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. hi hæɾ ə feɪvɹɪt wʊlfhnd, bæk hoʊm, ən ivən tɔk tə hɪm səmtaɪmz, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd nɪp tə kæɹi ɑn ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən!

Shaking his head, Bakuun strode across to the sul'dam's large tent. Larger than his, of necessity. Four of them were sitting on stools outside in their dark blue dresses with the forked lightning on the skirts, enjoying the sun during this break in the storms. Those were rare enough, now. The gray-clad damane sat at their feet, with Nerith braiding her pale hair. Talking to her, as well, all of them joining in and laughing softly. The bracelet on the end of the silvery a'dam's leash lay on the ground. Bakuun grunted sourly. He had a favorite wolfhound, back home, and even talked to him sometimes, but he never expected Nip to carry on a conversation!

"ɪz ʃi wɛl?" hi æsk nɛɹɪθ, nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. əɹ ðə tɛnθ. "ɪz ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛl wɪð hɝ?" ðə deɪmeɪn dʒɹɑpt əɹ aɪz ən wɛn saɪlənt.

"Is she well?" he asked Nerith, not for the first time. Or the tenth. "Is everything well with her?" The damane dropped her eyes and went silent.

"ʃi ɪz kwaɪt wɛl, kæptən bɑkən." ə skwɛɹ-feɪst wʊmən, nɛɹɪθ pʊt ðə pɹɑpɝ dɪɡɹi ʌv ɹɪspɛkt ɪndə hɝ vɔɪs ən nɑɾ ə wɪskɝ bɪɑnd. bʌt ʃi stʃɹoʊk ðə deɪmeɪnz hɛd suðɪŋli waɪl ʃi tɔkt. "wʌtɛvɝ ði ɪndɪspəzɪʃən, ɪts ɡɔn, naʊ. ə smɔl θɪŋ, ɪn ɛni keɪs. nʌθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt." ðə deɪmeɪn wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ.

"She is quite well, Captain Bakuun." A square-faced woman, Nerith put the proper degree of respect into her voice and not a whisker beyond. But she stroked the damane's head soothingly while she talked. "Whatever the indisposition, it is gone, now. A small thing, in any case. Nothing to worry about." The damane was trembling.

bɑkən ɡɹʌntɪɾ əɡɛn. nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ði ænsɝ i hæd ɹəsiv bɪfɔɹ. sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ, ðoʊ, bæk ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən nɑt dʒʌst wɪð ðɪs deɪmeɪn. ðə sʌldəm hæɾ ɔl bɪn əz taɪt-lɪpt əz klæmz - ən ðə blʌd wəd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑt tə ðə laɪks ə hɪm! - bʌɾ i hæd hɝd tu mɛni wɪspɝz. ðeɪ sɛd ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ ɔl sɪk, əɹ ɪnseɪn. laɪt, hi hæd nɑt sin ə sɪŋɡəl wʌn juzd ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ wʌns ðə sɪɾi wɑz sɪkjʊɹd, nɑɾ ivən fəɹ ə vɪktɝi dɪspleɪ ʌv skaɪ laɪts, ən u hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd ðə laɪk ə ðæt!

Bakuun grunted again. Not far from the answer he had received before. Something had been wrong, though, back in Ebou Dar, and not just with this damane. The sul'dam had all been as tight-lipped as clams - and the Blood would not say anything, of course, not to the likes of him! - but he had heard too many whispers. They said the damane were all sick, or insane. Light, he had not seen a single one used around Ebou Dar once the city was secured, not even for a victory display of Sky Lights, and who had ever heard the like of that!

"wɛl, aɪ hoʊp ʃi . . . " hi bɪɡæn, ən kʌɾ ɔf əz ə ɹeɪkən əpɪɹd, swipɪŋ θɹu ði istɝn pæs. ɪts ɡɹeɪt lɛðɝi wɪŋz bit paʊɝfli fəɹ haɪt, ən ɹaɪɾ əbʌv ðə hɪl ɪt sʌɾənli tɪltəɾ ən kʌɾ ə taɪt sɝkəl, wʌn wɪŋtɪp pɔɪntəɾ ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪt daʊn. ə θɪn ɹɛd stʃɹimɝ fɛl əweɪ ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ʌv ə lɛd bɔl.

"Well, I hope she . . . " he began, and cut off as a raken appeared, sweeping through the eastern pass. Its great leathery wings beat powerfully for height, and right above the hill it suddenly tilted and cut a tight circle, one wingtip pointed almost straight down. A thin red streamer fell away under the weight of a lead ball.

bɑkən swɑloʊɾ ə kɝs. flaɪɝz wɝ ɔlweɪz ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf, bʌɾ ɪf ðɪs pɛɹ ɪnʒɝd wʌn ə hɪz mɛn dɪlɪvɝɪŋ ðɛɹ skaʊɾɪŋ ɹipɔɹt, hi wəɾ əv ðɛɹ haɪdz noʊ mæɾɝ u hi hæd tə feɪs tə ɡɛt ðɛm. hi wəd nɑɾ əv wɑntəd tə faɪt wɪθaʊt flaɪɝz tə skaʊt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kɑɾəld laɪk səm blʌdz feɪvɹɪt pɛt.

Bakuun swallowed a curse. Fliers were always showing off, but if this pair injured one of his men delivering their scouting report, he would have their hides no matter who he had to face to get them. He would not have wanted to fight without fliers to scout, but they were coddled like some Blood's favorite pet.

æɹoʊ-stʃɹeɪt ðə stʃɹimɝ plʌməɾɪd. ðə lɛd weɪt stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊn ən baʊnst ɑn ðə kɹɛst, ɔlmoʊs bɪsaɪd ðə tɔl θɪn mɛsədʒ poʊl, wɪtʃ wɑz tu lɔŋ tə loʊɝ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz ə mɛsədʒ tə sɛnd. bɪsaɪdz, wən ɪt wɑz lɛf daʊn sʌmbɑɾi wɑz ɔlweɪz stɛpɪŋ ə hɔɹs ɑn ðə θɪŋ ən bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə dʒɔɪnz.

Arrow-straight the streamer plummeted. The lead weight struck the ground and bounced on the crest, almost beside the tall thin message pole, which was too long to lower unless there was a message to send. Besides, when it was left down somebody was always stepping a horse on the thing and breaking the joins.

bɑkən stʃɹoʊd stʃɹeɪt tə hɪz tɛnt, bʌɾ ɪz fɝs lutɛnənt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə mʌd-steɪn stʃɹimɝ ən ðə mɛsədʒ tub. tʃɹəs wɑz ə boʊni mæn ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən hɪm, wɪð ən ənfɔɹtʃənət skɹæp ə bɪɹd klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə pɔɪn ə hɪz tʃɪn.

Bakuun strode straight to his tent, but his First Lieutenant was already waiting with the mud-stained streamer and the message tube. Tiras was a bony man a head taller than him, with an unfortunate scrap of beard clinging to the point of his chin.

ðə ɹipɔɹt ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn ðə θɪn mɛɾəl tub, ɑn ə slɪp ə peɪpɝ bɑkən kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si θɹu, wɑz ɹɪɾən sɪmpli. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn fɔɹs tə ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɹeɪkən əɹ tɔɹeɪkən - ðə laɪt bi θæŋkt, ən ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, bi pɹeɪzd! - bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ɪt wɑz izi tə hændəl ə pɛn ɪn ə sæɾəl stʃɹæp tə ðə bæk ʌv ə flaɪɪŋ lɪzɝd. wʌɾ ɪt sɛd meɪɾ ɪm flɪp oʊpən ðə lɪɾ ə hɪz smɔl kæmp dɛsk ən ɹaɪt hɝidli.

The report rolled up in the thin metal tube, on a slip of paper Bakuun could almost see through, was written simply. He had never been forced to ride on raken or to'raken - the Light be thanked, and the Empress, might she live forever, be praised! - but he doubted it was easy to handle a pen in a saddle strapped to the back of a flying lizard. What it said made him flip open the lid of his small camp desk and write hurriedly.

"ðɛɹz ə fɔɹs nɑt tɛn maɪlz ist ə hɪɹ," hi toʊl tʃɹəs. "faɪv əɹ sɪks taɪmz əɹ nʌmbɝ." flaɪɝz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd səmtaɪmz, bʌt nɑɾ ɔfən baɪ mʌtʃ. haʊ hæd ðət mɛni pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd ðiz maʊntənz soʊ fɑɹ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ spɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ? hi hæd sin ðə koʊs tə ði ist, ən i wɑntəɾ ɪz bɛɹiəl pɹɛɹz peɪd fəɹ bɪfɔɹ i tʃɹaɪɾ ə lændɪŋ ðɛɹ. bɝn ɪz aɪz, ðə flaɪɝz boʊstəd ðeɪ wəd si ə fli muv ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹeɪnʒ. "noʊ ɹizən tə θɪŋk ðeɪ noʊ wɝ hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪd nɑt maɪn ə fju ɹiɪnfɔɹsməns."

"There's a force not ten miles east of here," he told Tiras. "Five or six times our number." Fliers exaggerated sometimes, but not often by much. How had that many penetrated these mountains so far without being spotted before? He had seen the coast to the east, and he wanted his burial prayers paid for before he tried a landing there. Burn his eyes, the fliers boasted they would see a flea move anywhere in the range. "No reason to think they know we're here, but I'd not mind a few reinforcements."

tʃɹəs læft. "wil ɡɪv əm ə bɹʌʃ ə ðə deɪmeɪn, ən ðət wɪl bi ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ aʊtnʌmbɝ əs baɪ twɛnti taɪmz." hɪz oʊnli ɹil fɔlt wɑz ə tʌtʃ ʌv oʊvɝkɑnfɪɾəns. ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ, ðoʊ.

Tiras laughed. "We'll give them a brush of the damane, and that will be that if they outnumber us by twenty times." His only real fault was a touch of overconfidence. A good soldier, though.

"æn ɪf ðeɪv ə fju . . . ɛɛs sədaɪ?" bɑkən sɛd kwaɪətli, hɑɹdli stʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə neɪm, əz i stʌf ðə flaɪɝz ɹipɔɹt bæk ɪndə ðə tub wɪð ɪz oʊn bɹif mɛsədʒ. hi hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪlivd ɛniwʌn kəd lɛt ðoʊz . . . wɪmən ɹʌn fɹi.

"And if they have a few . . . Aes Sedai?" Bakuun said quietly, hardly stumbling over the name, as he stuffed the flier's report back into the tube with his own brief message. He had not really believed anyone could let those . . . women run free.

tʃɹəs' feɪs ʃoʊd ðəɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə teɪlz əbaʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛpən. ðə ɹɛd stʃɹimɝ floʊɾəd bɪhaɪn ɪm əz i ɹæn wɪð ðə mɛsədʒ tub.

Tiras' face showed that he remembered the tales about an Aes Sedai weapon. The red streamer floated behind him as he ran with the message tube.

sun ɪnʌf tub ən stʃɹimɝ wɝ ətætʃt tə ðə tɪp ə ðə mɛsədʒ poʊl, ə taɪni bɹiz stɝɪŋ ðə lɔŋ ɹɛd stʃɹɪp fɪftin peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə hɪl kɹɛst. ðə ɹeɪkən sɔɹd təwɔɹɾ ɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə væli, aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt wɪŋz stɪl əz dɛθ. əbɹʌpli wʌn ə ðə flaɪɝz swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə sæɾəl ən hʌŋ - ʌpsaɪd daʊn! - bɪloʊ ðə ɹeɪkənz tʃɹeɪlɪŋ klɔz. ɪt meɪd bɑkənz stʌmək hɝt tə wɑtʃ. bʌɾ əɹ hæn kloʊzd ɑn ðə stʃɹimɝ, ðə poʊl flɛkst, ðən vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd bæk əpɹaɪɾ əz ðə mɛsədʒ tub pʊl fɹi ʌv ðə klɪp, ən ʃi skɹæmbəl bæk ʌp əz ðə kɹitʃɝ klaɪmd ɪn sloʊ sɝkəlz.

Soon enough tube and streamer were attached to the tip of the message pole, a tiny breeze stirring the long red strip fifteen paces above the hill crest. The raken soared toward it along the valley, outstretched wings still as death. Abruptly one of the fliers swung down from the saddle and hung - upside down! - below the raken's trailing claws. It made Bakuun's stomach hurt to watch. But her hand closed on the streamer, the pole flexed, then vibrated back upright as the message tube pulled free of the clip, and she scrambled back up as the creature climbed in slow circles.

bɑkən θæŋkfəli pʊt ɹeɪkən ən flaɪɝz aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪn əz i sɝveɪd ðə væli. bɹɔɾ ən lɔŋ, nɪɹli flæɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɪs hɪl, ən sɝaʊndəd baɪ stip wʊɾɪd sloʊps; oʊnli ə ɡoʊt kəɾ ɛntɝ, ɪksɛp baɪ ðə pæsəz ɪn ɪz saɪt. wɪð ðə deɪmeɪn, hi kəd kʌɾ ɛnibəɾi tə pisəz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ mænədʒ tə tʃɹaɪ ətækɪŋ əkɹɔs ðət mʌɾi mɛdoʊ. hi hæd pæst wɝɾ əlɔŋ, ðoʊ; ɪf ði ɛnəmi keɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn, ðeɪ wəɾ ɝaɪv bɪfɔɹ ɛni pɑsəbəl ɹiɪnfɔɹsməns baɪ θɹi deɪz ət bɛst. haʊ hæd ðeɪ kʌm ðɪs fɑɹ ənsin?

Bakuun thankfully put raken and fliers out of his mind as he surveyed the valley. Broad and long, nearly flat except for this hill, and surrounded by steep wooded slopes; only a goat could enter, except by the passes in his sight. With the damane, he could cut anybody to pieces before they managed to try attacking across that muddy meadow. He had passed word along, though; if the enemy came straight on, they would arrive before any possible reinforcements by three days at best. How had they come this far unseen?

hi hæd mɪs ðə læs bæɾəlz ə ðə kənsɑlədeɪʃən baɪ tu hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, bʌt səm ə ðoʊz ɹɪbɛljənz hæd nɑt bɪn smɔl. tu jɪɹz faɪɾɪŋ ɑn mɑɹɛndəlɝ, θɝɾi θaʊzən dɛd, ən fɪfti taɪmz ðət ʃɪp bæk tə ðə meɪnlæn əz pɹɑpɝɾi. teɪkɪŋ noʊɾəs ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɛpt ə soʊlʒɝ əlaɪv. ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə kæmp stʃɹʌk ən ɔl saɪnz ʌv ɪt klɪɹd, hi bɪɡæn muvɪŋ ɪz kəmæn tə ðə fɔɹəstəd sloʊps. dɑɹk klaʊdz wɝ mæsɪŋ ɪn ði ist, ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz kɝst stɔɹmz kʌmɪŋ.

He had missed the last battles of the Consolidation by two hundred years, but some of those rebellions had not been small. Two years fighting on Marendalar, thirty thousand dead, and fifty times that shipped back to the mainland as property. Taking notice of the strange kept a soldier alive. Ordering the camp struck and all signs of it cleared, he began moving his command to the forested slopes. Dark clouds were massing in the east, another of those cursed storms coming.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi


CHAPTER 23

fɑɡ ʌv wɔɹ, stɔɹm ə bæɾəl


Fog of War, Storm of Battle

noʊ ɹeɪn fɛl, fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ɹænd ɡaɪɾəd teɪdeɪʃɝ ɝaʊn ən əpɹuɾɪd tʃɹi laɪɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə sloʊp ən fɹaʊn daʊn əɾ ə dɛd mæn spɹɔld ɑn ɪz bæk bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk. ðə fɛloʊ wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən blɑki, hɪz feɪs kɹist, ən ɪz ɑɹmɝ ɔl oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts lækɝd blu ən ɡɹin, bʌt stɛɹɪŋ saɪtləsli ət ðə blæk klaʊdz oʊvɝhɛd, hi lʊkt ə dil laɪk iɡən pædʒɹoʊs, ivən tə ðə mɪsɪŋ lɛɡ. ən ɔfəsɝ, pleɪnli; ðə sɔɹd bɪsaɪɾ ɪz aʊtfləŋ hæn hæɾ ən aɪvɝi hɪl kɑɹvd ɪn ðə laɪknəs ʌv ə wʊmən, ən ɪz lækɝd hɛlmət, ʃeɪp laɪk səm hjudʒ ɪnsɛks hɛd, bɔɹ tu lɔŋ θɪn blu plumz.

No rain fell, for the moment. Rand guided Tai'daishar around an uprooted tree lying across the slope and frowned down at a dead man sprawled on his back behind the tree trunk. The fellow was short and blocky, his face creased, and his armor all overlapping plates lacquered blue and green, but staring sightlessly at the black clouds overhead, he looked a deal like Eagan Padros, even to the missing leg. An officer, plainly; the sword beside his outflung hand had an ivory hilt carved in the likeness of a woman, and his lacquered helmet, shaped like some huge insect's head, bore two long thin blue plumes.

əpɹuɾɪd tʃɹiz ən ʃæɾɝd wʌnz, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ bɝnɪŋ fɹəm ɛn tə ɛnd, lɪɾɝd ðə sloʊp ə ðə maʊntən fəɹ ə ɡʊd faɪv hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz. bɑɾiz, tu, mɛn bɹoʊkən əɹ ɹɪpt əpɑɹt wən seɪɾɪn hɛɹɹoʊd ðə maʊntənsaɪd. moʊst wɔɹ stil veɪlz əkɹɔs ðɛɹ feɪsəz, ən bɹɛstpleɪts peɪntəɾ ɪn hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps. noʊ wɪmən, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ði ɪnʒɝd hɔɹsəz hæd bɪn pʊt daʊn, ənʌðɝ θɪŋ tə bi θæŋkfəl fɔɹ. ɪt wɑz ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl haʊ laʊdli ə hɔɹs kəd skɹim.

Uprooted trees and shattered ones, a fair number burning from end to end, littered the slope of the mountain for a good five hundred paces. Bodies, too, men broken or ripped apart when saidin harrowed the mountainside. Most wore steel veils across their faces, and breastplates painted in horizontal stripes. No women, thank the Light. The injured horses had been put down, another thing to be thankful for. It was incredible how loudly a horse could scream.

dʒju θɪŋk ðə dɛɾ ɑɹ saɪlənt? luz θɝɪnz læf wɑz ɹæspɪŋ. də ju? hɪz vɔɪs tɝn tə peɪn ɹeɪdʒ. ðə dɛd haʊl ət mi!

Do you think the dead are silent? Lews Therin's laugh was rasping. Do you? His voice turned to pained rage. The dead howl at me!

ət mi, tu, ɹænd θɔt sædli. aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə lɪsən, bʌt haʊ dʒju ʃʌɾ əm ʌp? luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn wipɪŋ fəɹ ɪz lɔst aɪlaɪɛnə.

At me, too, Rand thought sadly. I can't afford to listen, but how do you shut them up? Lews Therin began weeping for his lost Ilyena.

"ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi," wɪɹɑmɑn ɪntoʊn bɪhaɪn ɹænd, ðən mʌɾɝd, "bʌt smɔl ɑnɝ ɪn ɪt. ði oʊld weɪz ɑɹ bɛst." mʌd lɪbɝəli dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɹændz koʊt, jɛt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, wɪɹɑmɑn əpɪɹɾ əz pɹɪstin əz i hæd bæk ɑn ðə sɪlvɝ ɹoʊd. hɪz hɛlməɾ ən ɑɹmɝ ʃoʊn. haʊ hæɾ i mænədʒd? ðə tæɹɑbənɝz tʃɑɹdʒd, ət ði ɛnd, lænsɪz ən kɝədʒ əɡɛns ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən wɪɹɑmɑn hæd lɛɾ ɪz oʊn tʃɑɹdʒ tə bɹeɪk ðɛm. wɪθaʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz, ən fɑloʊd baɪ ɛvɹi tɛɹən seɪv ðə dɪfɛndɝz, ivən ə hæf-dʒɹʌŋk tʃɹiən, sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli. baɪ səmɝædʒɹɪɾ ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn pɑnɝ, tu, wɪð moʊst ə ðə kɛɹhinɪn ən ɪliɑnɝz. stændɪŋ stɪl hæd bɪn hɑɹd baɪ ðət taɪm, ən ɛvɹi mæn wɑntəd tə kʌm tə ɡɹɪps wɪð sʌmθɪŋ i æktʃəli  kəd kʌm tə ɡɹɪps wɪð. ði cʊɾə əv dʌn ɪt fæstɝ. ɪf sʌmwʌt mɔɹ mɛsəli.

"A great victory," Weiramon intoned behind Rand, then muttered, "But small honor in it. The old ways are best." Mud liberally decorated Rand's coat, yet surprisingly, Weiramon appeared as pristine as he had back on the Silver Road. His helmet and armor shone. How had he managed? The Taraboners charged, at the end, lances and courage against the One Power, and Weiramon had led his own charge to break them. Without orders, and followed by every Tairen save the Defenders, even a half-drunk Torean, surprisingly. By Semaradrid and Gregorin Panar, too, with most of the Cairhienin and Illianers. Standing still had been hard by that time, and every man wanted to come to grips with something he actually could come to grips with. The Asha'man could have done it faster. If somewhat more messily.

ɹænd hæd teɪkən noʊ pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ, ɪksɛp tə sɪɾ ɪz sæɾəl wɛɹ mɛn kəd si hɪm. hi hæd bɪn əfɹeɪd tə siz ðə paʊɝ. hi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ dɪspleɪ wiknəs fəɹ əm tə kætʃ. nɑɾ ə skɹæp. luz θɝɪn ɡɪbɝd wɪð hɔɹɝ ət ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə.

Rand had taken no part in the fighting, except to sit his saddle where men could see him. He had been afraid to seize the Power. He did not dare display weakness for them to catch. Not a scrap. Lews Therin gibbered with horror at the very idea.

ikwəli sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ əz wɪɹɑmɑnz ənsʌlid koʊt, ænɑiɛlə ɹoʊd wɪð hɪm, ən fəɹ wʌns nɑt sɪmpɝɪŋ. hɝ feɪs wɑz pɪntʃt ən dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɪt dɪd nɑt spɔɪl əɹ lʊks nɪɹli soʊ mʌtʃ əz əɹ ʌŋtʃwəs smaɪlz dɪd. ʃi hæd nɑt dʒɔɪn ðə tʃɑɹdʒ hɝsɛlf, ʌv kɔɹs, ɛni mɔɹ ðən eɪlɪl, bʌɾ ænɑiɛləz mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs hæd, ən ðə mæn wɑz moʊs dɛfənətli dɛd, wɪð ə tæɹɑbənɝ læns θɹu hɪz tʃɛst. ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ðət wʌn bɪt. bʌt waɪ dɪd ʃi əkʌmpəni wɪɹɑmɑn? dʒʌs tɛɹənz flɑkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ? meɪbi. ʃi hæd bɪn wɪð sunəmən, ðə læst ɹænd hæd sin.

Equally surprising as Weiramon's unsullied coat, Anaiyella rode with him, and for once not simpering. Her face was pinched and disapproving. Strangely, it did not spoil her looks nearly so much as her unctuous smiles did. She had not joined the charge herself, of course, any more than Ailil, but Anaiyella's Master of the Horse had, and the man was most definitely dead, with a Taraboner lance through his chest. She did not like that one bit. But why did she accompany Weiramon? Just Tairens flocking together? Maybe. She had been with Sunamon, the last Rand had seen.

bæʃɪɹ wɔkt ɪz beɪ ʌp ðə sloʊp, pɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ ɝaʊn ðə dɛd waɪl simɪŋ tə peɪ ðɛm noʊ mɔɹ maɪn ðən i dɪɾ ə splɪntɝd tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk əɹ ə bɝnɪŋ stʌmp. hɪz hɛlmət hʌŋ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, ən ɪz ɡɔnləts wɝ stʌf bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. hi wɑz mʌɾ ɔl daʊn ɪz ɹaɪt saɪd, ən ɪz hɔɹs əz wɛl.

Bashere walked his bay up the slope, picking his way around the dead while seeming to pay them no more mind than he did a splintered tree trunk or a burning stump. His helmet hung from his saddle, and his gauntlets were stuffed behind his sword belt. He was mud all down his right side, and his horse as well.

"ɑɹəkʌmz ɡɔn," hi sɛd. "flɪn tʃɹaɪd hilɪŋ hɪm, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɑɹəkʌm wɑntəd tə lɪv laɪk ðæt. ðɛɹz nɪɹ fɪfti dɛd soʊ fɑɹ, ən səm ə ðə ɹɛs maɪt nɑt sɝvaɪv." ænɑiɛlə peɪld. ɹænd hæd sin əɹ nɪɹ ɑɹəkʌm, ɛmptiɪŋ hɝsɛlf. dɛd kɑmənɝz dɪd nɑɾ əfɛkt əɹ soʊ mʌtʃ.

"Aracome's gone," he said. "Flinn tried Healing him, but I don't think Aracome wanted to live like that. There's near fifty dead so far, and some of the rest might not survive." Anaiyella paled. Rand had seen her near Aracome, emptying herself. Dead commoners did not affect her so much.

ɹænd fɛlt ə moʊmən ə pɪɾi. nɑt fəɹ hɝ, ən nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ fəɹ ɑɹəkʌm. fəɹ mɪn, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz seɪfli bæk ɪn kɛɹhin. mɪn hæd fɔɹtoʊld ɑɹəkʌmz dɛθ fɹəm wʌn ə hɝ vjuɪŋz, ən ɡəm ən mɑɹəkənz, tu. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi hæd sin, ɹænd hoʊpt ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ðə ɹiæləɾi.

Rand felt a moment of pity. Not for her, and not very much for Aracome. For Min, though she was safely back in Cairhien. Min had foretold Aracome's death from one of her viewings, and Gueyam and Maraconn's, too. Whatever she had seen, Rand hoped it had not been anywhere near the reality.

moʊst ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɔf skaʊɾɪŋ əɡɛn, bʌt daʊn ɪn ðə bɹɔd mɛdoʊ, ɡeɪtweɪz woʊvən baɪ dʒɛdwɪnz dɛɾəkeɪtəd wɝ spɪlɪŋ aʊt ðə səplaɪ kɑɹts ən ðə ɹimaʊns. ðə mɛn kʌmɪŋ wɪð əm ɡeɪpt əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ klɪɹ ɪnʌf tə si. ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊnd wɑz nɑt soʊ wɛl plaʊɾ əz ðə maʊntənsaɪd, jɛt blækən fɝoʊz, tu peɪsɪz waɪɾ ən fɪfti lɔŋ, kɑɹv θɹu ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæs, ən ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊlz ə hɔɹs maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə lip. ðeɪ hæd nɑt faʊn ðə deɪmeɪn soʊ fɑɹ. ɹænd θɔt ðəɹ hæd tə bi oʊnli wʌn; mɔɹ wʊɾə dʌn kənsɪɾɝəbli ɡɹeɪɾɝ dæmədʒ ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz.

Most of the Soldiers were off scouting again, but down in the broad meadow, gateways woven by Gedwyn's Dedicated were spilling out the supply carts and the remounts. The men coming with them gaped as soon as they were clear enough to see. The muddy ground was not so well plowed as the mountainside, yet blackened furrows, two paces wide and fifty long, carved through the brown grass, and gaping holes a horse might not be able to leap. They had not found the damane so far. Rand thought there had to be only one; more would have done considerably greater damage under the circumstances.

mɛn muvd ɝaʊn ə nʌmbɝ ə smɔl faɪɝz wɛɹ wɔɾɝ bɔɪl fəɹ ti, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. fəɹ wʌns, tɛɹənz, kɛɹhinɪn ən ɪliɑnɝz mɪŋɡəld. nɑt dʒʌs ðə kɑmənɝz. səmɝædʒɹɪd wɑz ʃɛɹɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl-flæsk wɪð ɡəm, hu wɛɹəli ɹʌbd ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz bɔl hɛd. mɑɹəkən ən kɹəl dʒɹeɪpeɪnəoʊz, ə stɔɹk ʌv ə mæn huz skwɛɹ-kʌt bɪɹd lʊkt ɑɾ ɑn ɪz nɛɹoʊ feɪs, wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz nɪɹ wʌn ə ðə faɪɝz. pleɪɪŋ kɑɹdz, baɪ ðə lʊk ʌv ɪt! tʃɹiən hæɾ ə hoʊl sɝkəl ə læfɪŋ kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹɾəlɪŋz ɝaʊn hɪm, ðoʊ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn lɛs əmjuz baɪ hɪz dʒoʊks ðən baɪ ðə weɪ hi sweɪɾ ən ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz pəteɪtoʊ noʊz. ðə lidʒənmɛn kɛpt əpɑɹt, bʌt ðeɪ hæd teɪkən ɪn ðə "vɑləntɪɹz" hu hæd fɑloʊd pædʒɹoʊs tə ðə bænɝ ə laɪt. ðət lɑt simd mɔɹ iɡɝ ðən ɛniwʌn sɪns lɝnɪŋ haʊ pædʒɹoʊs daɪd. blu-koʊɾəd lidʒənmɛn wɝ ʃoʊɪŋ əm haʊ tə tʃeɪnʒ dɝɛkʃən wɪθaʊt fɔlɪŋ əpɑɹt laɪk ə ɡæɡəl ʌv ɡis.

Men moved around a number of small fires where water boiled for tea, among other things. For once, Tairens, Cairhienin and Illianers mingled. Not just the commoners. Semaradrid was sharing his saddle-flask with Gueyam, who wearily rubbed a hand over his bald head. Maraconn and Kiril Drapaneos, a stork of a man whose square-cut beard looked odd on his narrow face, were squatting on their heels near one of the fires. Playing cards, by the look of it! Torean had a whole circle of laughing Cairhienin lordlings around him, though they might have been less amused by his jokes than by the way he swayed and rubbed at his potato nose. The Legionmen kept apart, but they had taken in the "volunteers" who had followed Padros to the Banner of Light. That lot seemed more eager than anyone since learning how Padros died. Blue-coated Legionmen were showing them how to change direction without falling apart like a gaggle of geese.

flɪn wɑz əmʌŋ ðə wundəd wɪð ædli ən mɔɹ ən hɑpwəl. nɛɹɪʃmə kəd hil lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən maɪnɝ kʌts, noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɹænd, ən dæʃivə nɑɾ ivən ðæt. dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd stʊd tɔkɪŋ wɛl əpɑɹt fɹəm ɛniwʌn ɛls, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz ətɑp ðə hɪl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə væli. ðə hɪl wɛɹ ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə kætʃ ðə sintʃæn baɪ sɝpɹaɪz wən ðeɪ ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪt. nɪɹ fɪfti dɛd, ən mɔɹ tə kʌm, bʌɾ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn əbʌv tu hʌnʒɹəd wɪθaʊt flɪn ən ðə ɹɛst u kəd mænədʒ hilɪŋ tə wʌn dɪɡɹi əɹ ənʌðɝ. dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə dɝɾi ðɛɹ hænz ən ɡɹɪməst wən ɹænd dʒɹoʊv əm tə ɪt. wʌn ə ðə dɛd wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ, ən ənʌðɝ soʊlʒɝ, ə ɹaʊnd-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn, sæt slʌmp bɪsaɪɾ ə faɪɝ wɪð ə deɪz lʊk ðət ɹænd hoʊp keɪm fɹəm biɪŋ tɔs θɹu ði ɛɹ baɪ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪɹʌptɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ ɪz fit.

Flinn was among the wounded with Adley and Morr and Hopwil. Narishma could Heal little more than minor cuts, no better than Rand, and Dashiva not even that. Gedwyn and Rochaid stood talking well apart from anyone else, holding their horses by the reins atop the hill in the middle of the valley. The hill where they had expected to catch the Seanchan by surprise when they rushed out of gateways surrounding it. Near fifty dead, and more to come, but it would have been above two hundred without Flinn and the rest who could manage Healing to one degree or another. Gedwyn and Rochaid had not wanted to dirty their hands and grimaced when Rand drove them to it. One of the dead was a Soldier, and another Soldier, a round-faced Cairhienin, sat slumped beside a fire with a dazed look that Rand hoped came from being tossed through the air by the ground erupting almost under his feet.

daʊn ðəɹ ɑn ðə fɝoʊd flæts, eɪlɪl wɑz kənfɝɪŋ wɪð əɹ læns-kæptən, ə peɪl lɪɾəl mæn kɔl dɛnhɝəd. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz stʊd nɪɹli tʌtʃɪŋ, ən əkeɪʒənəli ðeɪ lʊkt ʌp ðə maʊntən təwɔɹd ɹænd. wʌt wɝ ðeɪ skimɪŋ?

Down there on the furrowed flats, Ailil was conferring with her Lance-captain, a pale little man called Denharad. Their horses stood nearly touching, and occasionally they looked up the mountain toward Rand. What were they scheming?

"wil də bɛɾɝ nɛks taɪm," bæʃɪɹ mɝmɝd. hi ɹæn ɪz ɡeɪz ɝaʊn ðə væli, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðə wɝs mɪsteɪk ɪz tə meɪk ðə seɪm wʌn twaɪs, ən wi woʊnt."

"We'll do better next time," Bashere murmured. He ran his gaze around the valley, then shook his head. "The worst mistake is to make the same one twice, and we won't."

wɪɹɑmɑn hɝɾ ɪm ən ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə seɪm θɪŋ, bʌt juzɪŋ twɛnti taɪmz ðə wɝdz, ən flaʊɝi ɪnʌf fəɹ ə ɡɑɹɾən ɪn spɹɪŋ. wɪθaʊɾ ædmɪɾɪŋ ðət ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛni mɪsteɪks, sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɑn ɪz pɑɹt. hi əvɔɪɾəd ɹændz mɪsteɪks wɪð ikwəl ædʒɹɔɪɑtnəs.

Weiramon heard him and repeated the same thing, but using twenty times the words, and flowery enough for a garden in spring. Without admitting that there had been any mistakes, certainly not on his part. He avoided Rand's mistakes with equal adroitness.

ɹænd nɑɾəd, hɪz maʊθ taɪt. nɛks taɪm ðeɪ wəd də bɛɾɝ. ðeɪ hæd tə, ənlɛs i wɑntəd tə liv hæf ɪz mɛn bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðiz maʊntənz. ɹaɪt ðɛn, hi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt tə də wɪð ðə pɹɪznɝz.

Rand nodded, his mouth tight. Next time they would do better. They had to, unless he wanted to leave half his men buried in these mountains. Right then, he was wondering what to do with the prisoners.

moʊst ə ðoʊz u ɪskeɪp dɛθ ɑn ðə maʊntənsaɪd hæd mænədʒ tə wɪðdʒɹɔ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ðət ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ. wɪð əmeɪzɪŋli ɡʊɾ ɔɹɾɝ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ, bæʃɪɹ kleɪmd, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ ənlaɪkli tə bi mʌtʃ θɹɛt naʊ. nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ hæd ðə deɪmeɪn wɪð ðɛm. bʌɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ mɛn sæt hʌɾəld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, stʃɹɪpt ʌv wɛpənz ən ɑɹmɝ, ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ə tu dʌzən maʊntəd kəmpænjənz ən dɪfɛndɝz. tæɹɑbənɝz, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ðeɪ hæd nɑt fɔt laɪk mɛn dʒɹɪvən tə ɪt baɪ kɑŋkɝɝz. ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ hɛl ðɛɹ hɛdz ʌp, ən dʒɪɹɾ ət ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz. dʒɛdwɪn hæd wɑntəd tə kɪl ðɛm, æftɝ pʊɾɪŋ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən. wɪɹɑmɑn dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ θɹoʊts slɪt, bʌɾ i kənsɪɾɝd tɔɹtʃɝ ə weɪst ə taɪm. nʌn wəd noʊ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl, hi meɪnteɪnd; ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʌn nɑbli bɔɹn.

Most of those who escaped death on the mountainside had managed to withdraw through the trees that remained standing. With amazingly good order considering, Bashere claimed, yet they were unlikely to be much threat now. Not unless they had the damane with them. But a hundred or so men sat huddled on the ground, stripped of weapons and armor, under the watchful eyes of two dozen mounted Companions and Defenders. Taraboners, for the most part, they had not fought like men driven to it by conquerors. A fair number held their heads up, and jeered at their guards. Gedwyn had wanted to kill them, after putting them to the question. Weiramon did not care whether they had their throats slit, but he considered torture a waste of time. None would know anything useful, he maintained; there was not a one nobly born.

ɹænd ɡlænst ət bæʃɪɹ. wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz stɪl ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn sənɝəsli. ". . . swip ðiz maʊntənz klin fəɹ ju, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. wɪl tʃɹæmpəl əm bɪniθ əɹ hʊvz, ænd. . . ." ænɑiɛlə wɑz nɑɾɪŋ ɡɹɪm əpɹuvəl.

Rand glanced at Bashere. Weiramon was still going on sonorously. ". . . sweep these mountains clean for you, my Lord Dragon. We'll trample them beneath our hooves, and. . . ." Anaiyella was nodding grim approval.

"sɪks ʌp, ən hæf ə dʌzən daʊn," bæʃɪɹ sɛd sɔfli. hi skɹeɪp mʌd fɹəm wʌn ə hɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl. "ɔɹ əz səm ə maɪ tɛnəns seɪ, wʌt jə ɡeɪn ɑn ðə swɪŋz, jə luz ɑn ðə ɹaʊndəbaʊts." wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz ə ɹaʊndəbaʊt? ə ɡɹeɪt hɛlp ðət wɑz!

"Six up, and half a dozen down," Bashere said softly. He scraped mud from one of his thick mustaches with a fingernail. "Or as some of my tenants say, what you gain on the swings, you lose on the roundabouts." What in the Light was a roundabout? A great help that was!

ən ðən wʌn ə bæʃɪɹz pətʃɹoʊlz meɪd mæɾɝz wɝs.

And then one of Bashere's patrols made matters worse.

ðə sɪks mɛn keɪm pɹɑɾɪŋ ə pɹɪznɝ əlɔŋ ðə sloʊp əhɛɾ ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɪð ðə bʌts ə ðɛɹ lænsɪz. ʃi wɑz ə blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ə tɔɹn ən dɝɾi dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs, wɪð ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn ðə bɹɛst ən skɝts bɛɹɪŋ fɔɹk laɪtnɪŋ. hɝ feɪs wɑz dɝɾi, tu, ən tɛɹ-stʃɹikt. ʃi stʌmbəld ən hæf-fɛl, bʌt ðə pɹɑɾɪŋ wɑz mɔɹ dʒɛstʃɝ ðən æktʃəwəl tʌtʃɪŋ. ʃi ɡlɛɹd skɔɹnfəli əɾ əɹ kæptɝz, ivən spɪɾɪŋ wʌns. ʃi snɪɹɾ ət ɹænd, tu.

The six men came prodding a prisoner along the slope ahead of their horses with the butts of their lances. She was a black-haired woman in a torn and dirty dark blue dress, with red panels on the breast and skirts bearing forked lightning. Her face was dirty, too, and tear-streaked. She stumbled and half-fell, but the prodding was more gesture than actual touching. She glared scornfully at her captors, even spitting once. She sneered at Rand, too.

"dɪd jə hɝt hɝ?" hi dɪmændəd. ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kwɛstʃən, pɝhæps, əbaʊɾ ən ɛnəmi æftɝ wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðɪs væli. əbaʊɾ ə sʌldəm. bʌɾ ɪt pɑpt aʊt.

"Did you hurt her?" he demanded. A strange question, perhaps, about an enemy after what had happened in this valley. About a sul'dam. But it popped out.

"nɑɾ ʌs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ðə ɡɹʌf-feɪs pətʃɹoʊl liɾɝ sɛd. "wi faʊn əɹ laɪk ðɪs." skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz tʃɪn θɹu ə blæk floʊɪŋ bɪɹd, hi aɪd bæʃɪɹ əz ɪf fəɹ səpɔɹt. "ʃi kleɪmz wi kɪld əɹ ɡaɪl. ə pɛt dɔɡ, əɹ kæt, əɹ səm sʌtʃ, ðə weɪ ʃi kæɹiz ɑn. hɝ neɪmz nɛɹɪθ. wi ɡɑt ðət mʌtʃ aʊɾ ə hɝ." ðə wʊmən tɝn ən snɑɹəld əɾ ɪm əɡɛn.

"Not us, my Lord Dragon," the gruff-faced patrol leader said. "We found her like this." Scratching his chin through a black flowing beard, he eyed Bashere as if for support. "She claims we killed her Gille. A pet dog, or cat, or some such, the way she carries on. Her name's Nerith. We got that much out of her." The woman turned and snarled at him again.

ɹænd saɪd. nɑɾ ə pɛt dɔɡ. noʊ! ðət neɪm dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ ɑn ðə lɪst! bʌɾ i kəd hɪɹ ðə lɪɾəni ʌv neɪmz ɹisaɪɾɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən "ɡaɪl ðə deɪmeɪn" wɑz ðɛɹ. luz θɝɪn moʊn fəɹ ɪz aɪlaɪɛnə. hɝ neɪm ɔlsoʊ wɑz ɑn ðə lɪst. ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt hæɾ ə ɹaɪt.

Rand sighed. Not a pet dog. No! That name did not belong on the list! But he could hear the litany of names reciting itself in his head, and "Gille the damane" was there. Lews Therin moaned for his Ilyena. Her name also was on the list. Rand thought it had a right.

"ðɪs ɪz ə sintʃæn ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ænɑiɛlə æsk sʌɾənli, linɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl tə pɪɹ hɑɹɾ ət nɛɹɪθ. nɛɹɪθ spæɾ ət hɝ, əz wɛl, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ ɪn aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ɹænd ɪkspleɪn ðə lɪɾəl i nu ʌv sʌldəm, ðət ðeɪ kəntʃɹoʊld wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl wɪð ði eɪɾ ʌv ə liʃ-ænd-kɑlɝ tɛɹæŋɡɹil bʌt kəd nɑt ðɛmsɛlvz tʃænəl, ən tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ðə deɪnti sɪmpɝɪŋ haɪ leɪɾi sɛd koʊldli, "ɪf maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən filz kənstʃɹeɪnd, əl hæŋ əɹ fəɹ hɪm." nɛɹɪθ spæɾ əɾ əɹ əɡɛn! kəntɛmptʃwəsli, ðɪs taɪm. noʊ ʃɔɹtfɔl ə kɝədʒ ðɛɹ.

"This is a Seanchan Aes Sedai?" Anaiyella asked suddenly, leaning over the pommel of her saddle to peer hard at Nerith. Nerith spat at her, as well, eyes widening in outrage. Rand explained the little he knew of sul'dam, that they controlled women who could channel with the aide of a leash-and-collar ter'angreal but could not themselves channel, and to his surprise, the dainty simpering High Lady said coldly, "If my Lord Dragon feels constrained, I'll hang her for him." Nerith spat at her again! Contemptuously, this time. No shortfall of courage there.

"noʊ!" ɹænd ɡɹaʊld. laɪt, ðə θɪŋz pipəl wəd də tə ɡɛɾ ɑn ɪz ɡʊd saɪd! əɹ meɪbi ænɑiɛlə hæd bɪn kloʊsɝ tə hɝ mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs ðən wɑz kənsɪɾɝd pɹɑpɝ. ðə mæn hæd bɪn staʊɾ ən bɔldɪŋ - ən ə kɑmənɝ; ðət kaʊntəd hɛvəli wɪð tɛɹənz - bʌt wɪmən dɪɾ əv stʃɹeɪnʒ teɪsts ɪn mɛn. hi nu ðət fəɹ ə pjʊɹ fækt.

"No!" Rand growled. Light, the things people would do to get on his good side! Or maybe Anaiyella had been closer to her Master of the Horse than was considered proper. The man had been stout and balding - and a commoner; that counted heavily with Tairens - but women did have strange tastes in men. He knew that for a pure fact.

"æz sun əz wɝ ɹɛɾi tə muv əɡɛn," hi toʊl bæʃɪɹ, "tɝn ðə mɛn daʊn ðəɹ lus." teɪkɪŋ pɹɪznɝz əlɔŋ wən i lɔntʃt ɪz nɛkst ətæk wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən, ən livɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn - ə hʌnʒɹəd naʊ; mɔɹ leɪɾɝ, fəɹ ʃʊɹ - livɪŋ əm tə fɑloʊ wɪð ðə səplaɪ kɑɹts ɹɪsk fɪfti kaɪnz ə mɪstʃəf. ðeɪ kəd kɑz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ivən ðə fɛloʊz u hæd ɡɑɾən əweɪ ɑn hɔɹsbæk kəd nɑt kæɹi ə wɔɹnɪŋ fæstɝ ðən i kəd tʃɹævəl.

"As soon as we're ready to move again," he told Bashere, "turn the men down there loose." Taking prisoners along when he launched his next attack was out of the question, and leaving a hundred men - a hundred now; more later, for sure - leaving them to follow with the supply carts risked fifty kinds of mischief. They could cause no trouble left behind. Even the fellows who had gotten away on horseback could not carry a warning faster than he could Travel.

bæʃɪɹ ʃɹʌɡd feɪnli; hi θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi soʊ, bʌt ðən əɡɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ði ɑd tʃæns. stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz hæpən ivən wɪθaʊɾ ə tɑvɝən ɝaʊnd.

Bashere shrugged faintly; he thought it might be so, but then again there was always the odd chance. Strange things happened even without a ta'veren around.

wɪɹɑmɑn ən ænɑiɛlə oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz ɔlmoʊs təɡɛðɝ, feɪsəz sɛɾ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst, bʌt ɹænd pɹɛst ɑn. "aɪv spoʊkən, ən ɪts dʌn! wɪl kip ðə wʊmən, ðoʊ. ən ɛni mɔɹ wɪmən wi kæptʃɝ."

Weiramon and Anaiyella opened their mouths almost together, faces set in protest, but Rand pressed on. "I've spoken, and it's done! We'll keep the woman, though. And any more women we capture."

"bɝn maɪ soʊl," wɪɹɑmɑn ɪkskleɪmd. "waɪ?" ðə mæn əpɪɹd dʌmfaʊndɪd, ən fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, bæʃɪɹ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾəld dʒɝk ə hɪz hɛd. ænɑiɛləz maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn kəntɛmp bɪfɔɹ ʃi mænədʒ tə tɝn ɪt tə ə sɪmpɝɪŋ smaɪl fəɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. pleɪnli, ʃi θɔɾ ɪm tu sɑf tə sɛn ə wʊmən ɔf wɪð ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ wəɾ əv hɑɹd wɔkɪŋ ɪn ðɪs tɝeɪn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ʃɔɹt ɹæʃənz. ən ðə wɛðɝ wɑz nɑt wɛðɝ tə tɝn ə wʊmən aʊɾ ɪn.

"Burn my soul," Weiramon exclaimed. "Why?" The man appeared dumbfounded, and for that matter, Bashere gave a startled jerk of his head. Anaiyella's mouth twisted in contempt before she managed to turn it to a simpering smile for the Lord Dragon. Plainly, she thought him too soft to send a woman off with the others. They would have hard walking in this terrain, not to mention short rations. And the weather was not weather to turn a woman out in.

"aɪ hæv ɪnʌf ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɛns mi wɪθaʊt sɛndɪŋ sʌldəm bæk tə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪd," hi toʊl ðɛm. ðə laɪt nu ðət wɑz tʃɹu! ðeɪ nɑɾəd, ɪf wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz sloʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt; bæʃɪɹ lʊkt ɹɪlivd, ænɑiɛlə dɪsəpɔɪntɪd. bʌt wʌt tə də wɪð ðə wʊmən, ən ɛni mɔɹ i kæptʃɝd? hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə tɝn ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪndə ə pɹɪzən. ði il kəd hoʊl ðɛm. ɪksɛp ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz maɪt slɪt ðɛɹ θɹoʊts ðə moʊmən ɪz bæk wɑz tɝnd. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə sɪstɝz ðət mæt wɑz teɪkɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ɪleɪn, ðoʊ? "wɛn ðɪs ɪz dʌn, əl hæn əɹ oʊvɝ tə səm ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪ tʃuz." ðeɪ maɪt si ɪɾ əz ə dʒɛstʃɝ ʌv ɡʊdwɪl, ə lɪɾəl hʌni tə swiɾən ðɛɹ hævɪŋ tə æksɛpt ɪz pɹətɛkʃən.

"I have enough Aes Sedai against me without sending sul'dam back to their trade," he told them. The Light knew that was true! They nodded, if Weiramon was slow about it; Bashere looked relieved, Anaiyella disappointed. But what to do with the woman, and any more he captured? He did not intend to turn the Black Tower into a prison. The Aiel could hold them. Except that the Wise Ones might slit their throats the moment his back was turned. What about the sisters that Mat was taking to Caemlyn with Elayne, though? "When this is done, I'll hand her over to some Aes Sedai I choose." They might see it as a gesture of goodwill, a little honey to sweeten their having to accept his protection.

noʊ sunɝ wɝ ðə wɝdz aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ ðən nɛɹɪθs feɪs wɛn dɛd waɪɾ ən ʃi skɹimd ət ðə tɑp ə hɝ lʌŋz. haʊlɪŋ wɪθaʊt sis, ʃi flʌŋ hɝsɛlf daʊn ðə sloʊp, skɹæbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ daʊn tʃɹiz, fɔlɪŋ ən skɹæmbəlɪŋ bæk ʌp.

No sooner were the words out of his mouth than Nerith's face went dead white and she screamed at the top of her lungs. Howling without cease, she flung herself down the slope, scrabbling over downed trees, falling and scrambling back up.

"blʌɾi - ! kætʃ hɝ!" ɹænd snæpt, ən ðə sɑldəiən pətʃɹoʊl lɛpt æftɝ ðə wʊmən, dʒʌmpɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊns əkɹɔs ðə tʃɹi-lɪɾɝd sloʊp kɛɹləs ə bɹoʊkən lɛɡz ən nɛks. stɪl weɪlɪŋ, ʃi dɑdʒd ən dɑɹɾɪd əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz wɪð ivən lɛs kɛɹ.

"Bloody - ! Catch her!" Rand snapped, and the Saldaean patrol leaped after the woman, jumping their mounts across the tree-littered slope careless of broken legs and necks. Still wailing, she dodged and darted among the horses with even less care.

ɪn ðə maʊθ ə ði istɝnmoʊs pæs, ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ɪn ə flæʃ ə sɪlvɝ laɪt. ə blæk-koʊɾəd soʊlʒɝ pʊld ɪz hɔɹs θɹu, dʒʌmp tə ðə sæɾəl əz ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋkt aʊɾ ən pʊɾ ɪz maʊn tə ə ɡæləp, təwɔɹd ðə hɪltɑp wɛɹ dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd weɪɾəd. ɹænd wɑtʃt ɪmpæsɪvli. ɪn ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn snɑɹəld ə kɪlɪŋ, kɪlɪŋ ɔl ði æʃəmən bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

In the mouth of the easternmost pass, a gateway opened in a flash of silver light. A black-coated Soldier pulled his horse through, jumped to the saddle as the gateway winked out and put his mount to a gallop, toward the hilltop where Gedwyn and Rochaid waited. Rand watched impassively. In his head, Lews Therin snarled of killing, killing all the Asha'man before it was too late.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðə θɹi ʌv əm stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə sloʊp təwɔɹd ɹænd, fɔɹ ə ðə sɑldəiənz hæd nɛɹɪθ daʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, baɪndɪŋ əɹ hæn ən fʊt. ɪt tʊk fɔɹ, ðə weɪ ʃi θɹæʃt ən bɪɾ ət ðɛm, ən ən əmjuz bæʃɪɹ wɑz ɔfɝɪŋ ɑdz ɑn wɛðɝ ʃi maɪt nɑɾ oʊvɝkʌm əm ɪnstɛd. ænɑiɛlə mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt kɹækɪŋ ðə wʊmənz hɛd. dɪd ʃi min kɹækɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən? ɹænd fɹaʊn ət hɝ.

By the time the three of them started up the slope toward Rand, four of the Saldaeans had Nerith down on the ground, binding her hand and foot. It took four, the way she thrashed and bit at them, and an amused Bashere was offering odds on whether she might not overcome them instead. Anaiyella muttered something about cracking the woman's head. Did she mean cracking it open? Rand frowned at her.

ðə soʊlʒɝ bɪtwin dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd ɡlænst ət nɛɹɪθ ənizəli əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd pæst. ɹænd veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝd siɪŋ ɪm ət ðə blæk taʊɝ, ðə deɪ hi fɝs hændəɾ aʊt ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹdz, ən ɡeɪv teɪm ðə vɛɹi fɝs dʒɹæɡən pɪn. hi wɑz ə jʌŋ mæn, vɛɹəl nɛnsən baɪ neɪm, stɪl wɛɹɪŋ ə tʃɹænspɛɹən veɪl tə kʌvɝ ɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz. hi hæd nɑt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wən i faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ɪz kʌntʃɹimɪn, ðoʊ. əlidʒəns wɑz tə ðə blæk taʊɝ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, naʊ, soʊ teɪm ɔlweɪz sɛd. ðə sɛkən pɑɹɾ ə ðəɾ ɔlweɪz saʊndəɾ ən æftɝθɑt.

The Soldier between Gedwyn and Rochaid glanced at Nerith uneasily as they rode past. Rand vaguely remembered seeing him at the Black Tower, the day he first handed out the silver Swords, and gave Taim the very first Dragon pin. He was a young man, Varil Nensen by name, still wearing a transparent veil to cover his thick mustaches. He had not hesitated when he found himself facing his countrymen, though. Allegiance was to the Black Tower and the Dragon Reborn, now, so Taim always said. The second part of that always sounded an afterthought.

"ju meɪ hæv ði ɑnɝ ə meɪkɪŋ jəɹ ɹipɔɹt tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, soʊlʒɝ nɛnsən," dʒɛdwɪn sɛd. ɹaɪli.

"You may have the honor of making your report to the Dragon Reborn, Soldier Nensen," Gedwyn said. Wryly.

nɛnsən sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!" hi bɑɹkt, slæpɪŋ fɪs tə tʃɛst. "ðɛɹz mɔɹ ə ðɛm əbaʊt θɝɾi maɪlz wɛst, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." θɝɾi maɪlz wɑz əz fɑɹ əz ɹænd hæd toʊl ðə skaʊts tə ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪf wʌn soʊlʒɝ faʊn sintʃæn waɪl ðə ɹɛs kɛp muvɪŋ ɛvɝ fɑɹðɝ wɛst? "meɪbi hæf wʌt wɝ hɪɹ," nɛnsən wɛn ɑn. ænd. . . ." hɪz dɑɹk aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd nɛɹɪθ əɡɛn. ʃi wɑz taɪd, naʊ, ðə sɑldəiənz stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ oʊvɝ ə hɔɹs. "æn aɪ sɔ noʊ saɪn ʌv wɪmən, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."

Nensen sat up straight in his saddle. "My Lord Dragon!" he barked, slapping fist to chest. "There's more of them about thirty miles west, my Lord Dragon." Thirty miles was as far as Rand had told the scouts to go before returning. What good if one Soldier found Seanchan while the rest kept moving ever farther west? "Maybe half what were here," Nensen went on. And. . . ." His dark eyes flickered toward Nerith again. She was tied, now, the Saldaeans struggling to get her over a horse. "And I saw no sign of women, my Lord Dragon."

bæʃɪɹ skwɪntɪɾ ət ðə skaɪ. dɑɹk klaʊdz leɪ ɪn ə blæŋkət fɹəm maʊntən pik tə maʊntən pik, bʌt ðə sʌn ʃəd stɪl bi haɪ. "taɪm tə fid ðə mɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛst ɹɪtɝn," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən. nɛɹɪθ hæd mænədʒ tə sɪŋk əɹ tiθ ɪndə ə sɑldəiənz ɹɪst ən wɑz hæŋɪŋ ɑn laɪk ə bædʒɝ.

Bashere squinted at the sky. Dark clouds lay in a blanket from mountain peak to mountain peak, but the sun should still be high. "Time to feed the men before the rest return," he said, nodding in satisfaction. Nerith had managed to sink her teeth into a Saldaean's wrist and was hanging on like a badger.

"fiɾ əm kwɪk," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. wəɾ ɛvɹi sʌldəm i kæptʃɝd bi əz dɪfəkəlt? vɛɹi laɪkli. laɪt, wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ tʊk ə deɪmeɪn? "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə spɛn ɔl wɪntɝ ɪn ðiz maʊntənz." ɡaɪl ðə deɪmeɪn. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪɹeɪs ə neɪm wʌns ɪt wɛn ɑntu ðət lɪst.

"Feed them quick," Rand said irritably. Would every sul'dam he captured be as difficult? Very likely. Light, what if they took a damane? "I don't want to spend all winter in these mountains." Gille the damane. He could not erase a name once it went onto that list.

ðə dɛɾ ɑɹ nɛvɝ saɪlənt, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. ðə dɛd nɛvɝ slip.

The dead are never silent, Lews Therin whispered. The dead never sleep.

ɹænd ɹoʊd daʊn təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝz. hi dɪd nɑt fil laɪk iɾɪŋ.

Rand rode down toward the fires. He did not feel like eating.

fɹəm ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə θɹʌstɪŋ ʃoʊldɝ ə stoʊn, fɹɪk kɛɹid kɛɹfəli stʌɾid ðə fɔɹəstəd maʊntənz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm, ʃɑɹp piks laɪk dɑɹk fæŋz. hɪz hɔɹs, ə tɔl dæpəld ɡɛldɪŋ, stɪfən ɪz ɪɹz əz ðoʊ kætʃɪŋ ə saʊn i hæd mɪst, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz ði ænəməl wɑz stɪl. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən, kɛɹid hæd tə stɑp ən waɪp ðə lɛnz ə hɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ə laɪt ɹeɪn fɛl fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ. hɪz hɛlməts tu blæk plumz wɝ bɛn oʊvɝ ɪnstɛɾ ə stændɪŋ stʃɹeɪt, ən wɔɾɝ ɹæn daʊn ɪz bæk. ə laɪt ɹeɪn kəmpɛɹd tə jɛstɝdeɪ, ɛniweɪ, ən pɹɑbli kəmpɛɹd tə təmɑɹoʊ. əɹ ðɪs æftɝnun, pɝhæps. θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld ɑmənəsli ɪn ðə saʊθ. kɛɹidz kənsɝn hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð wɛðɝ, ðoʊ.

From the point of a thrusting shoulder of stone, Furyk Karede carefully studied the forested mountains rising all around him, sharp peaks like dark fangs. His horse, a tall dappled gelding, stiffened his ears as though catching a sound he had missed, but otherwise the animal was still. Every so often, Karede had to stop and wipe the lens of his looking glass. A light rain fell from a gray morning sky. His helmet's two black plumes were bent over instead of standing straight, and water ran down his back. A light rain compared to yesterday, anyway, and probably compared to tomorrow. Or this afternoon, perhaps. Thunder rumbled ominously in the south. Karede's concern had nothing to do with weather, though.

bɪloʊ hɪm, ðə læst ə twɛnti-θɹi hʌnʒɹəd mɛn sneɪk θɹu ðə waɪndɪŋ pæsəz, mɛn ɡæðɝd fɹəm fɔɹ aʊtpoʊsts. wɛl-maʊntəd, ɹizənəbli wɛl-lɛd, jɛɾ ə bɛɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd wɝ sintʃæn, ən dʒʌs tu bɪsaɪdz hɪmsɛlf wɔɹ ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin ə ðə ɡɑɹd. moʊst ə ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ wɝ tæɹɑbənɝz - hi nu ðɛɹ mɛɾəl - bʌɾ ə ɡʊd θɝd wɝ ɑmɑdɪʃənz ən ɔltɑɹənz, tu nu tə ðɛɹ oʊðz fəɹ ɛni tə bi ʃʊɹ haʊ ðeɪ wəd stæn ʌp. səm ɔltɑɹənz ən ɑmɑdɪʃənz hæd swɪtʃt əlidʒəns tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz ɔlɹɛɾi. tʃɹaɪd tə, ɛniweɪ. pipəl ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən hæd noʊ ʃeɪm. ə dʌzən sʌldəm ɹoʊd nɪɹ ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɑləm, ən i wɪʃt ɔl twɛlv hæd liʃt deɪmənz wɔkɪŋ baɪ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊnli tu.

Below him, the last of twenty-three hundred men snaked through the winding passes, men gathered from four outposts. Well-mounted, reasonably well-led, yet a bare two hundred were Seanchan, and just two besides himself wore the red-and-green of the Guard. Most of the remainder were Taraboners - he knew their mettle - but a good third were Amadicians and Altarans, too new to their oaths for any to be sure how they would stand up. Some Altarans and Amadicians had switched allegiance two or three times already. Tried to, anyway. People this side of the Aryth Ocean had no shame. A dozen sul'dam rode near the front of the column, and he wished all twelve had leashed damanes walking by their horses instead of only two.

fɪfti peɪsɪz fɑɹðɝ ɑn, ðə tɛn mɛn ə ðə spɪɹhɛd wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sloʊps əbʌv ðɛm, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz kɛɹfəli əz ðeɪ ʃəd hæv. tu mɛni mɛn u ɹoʊd spɪɹhɛd ɹɪlaɪɾ ɑn ðə fɔɹwɝd skaʊts tə faɪn ɛni deɪnʒɝz. kɛɹid meɪɾ ə noʊt tə spik tə ðɛm pɝsənəli. ðeɪ wəd də ðɛɹ duɾiz pɹɑpɝli æftɝ ðæt, əɹ i wəd sɛn əm tə ðə leɪbɝ lɛviz.

Fifty paces farther on, the ten men of the spearhead were watching the slopes above them, though not as carefully as they should have. Too many men who rode spearhead relied on the forward scouts to find any dangers. Karede made a note to speak to them personally. They would do their duties properly after that, or he would send them to the labor levies.

ə ɹeɪkən əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ist əhɛd, skɪmɪŋ loʊ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹitɑps, twɪstɪŋ ən tɝnɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə kɝvz ə ðə læn laɪk ə mæn ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz hæn daʊn ə wʊmənz bæk. pəkjuljɝ. mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən, flaɪɝz, ɔlweɪz laɪk tə sɔɹ haɪ ənlɛs ðə skaɪ wɑz æktʃəli  fʊl ə laɪtnɪŋ. kɛɹid loʊɝd ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə wɑtʃ.

A raken appeared in the east ahead, skimming low over the treetops, twisting and turning to follow the curves of the land like a man running his hand down a woman's back. Peculiar. Morat'raken, fliers, always liked to soar high unless the sky was actually full of lightning. Karede lowered the looking glass to watch.

"meɪbi wɪl faɪnəli ɡɛɾ ənʌðɝ skaʊɾɪŋ ɹipɔɹt," dʒædʒɹæŋkə sɛd. tə ði ʌðɝ ɔfəsɝz weɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn kɛɹid, nɑt tə hɪm. θɹi ʌv ðə tɛn mætʃt kɛɹidz ɹæŋk, jɛt fju ɪksɛp ðə blʌd dɪstɝbd ə mæn ɪn ðə blʌd-ɹɛɾ ən nɪɹli blæk ɡɹin ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd. nɑt ðət mɛni əmʌŋ ðə blʌd dɪd.

"Maybe we'll finally get another scouting report," Jadranka said. To the other officers waiting behind Karede, not to him. Three of the ten matched Karede's rank, yet few except the Blood disturbed a man in the blood-red and nearly black green of the Deathwatch Guard. Not that many among the Blood did.

əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə teɪlz i hæd hɝɾ əz ə tʃaɪld, wʌn ə hɪz ænsɛstɝz, ə noʊbəl, hæd fɑloʊd luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ tə sintʃæn əɾ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz kəmænd, bʌt tu hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz leɪɾɝ, wɪð oʊnli ðə nɔɹθ sɪkjʊɹ, ənʌðɝ ænsɛstɝ tʃɹaɪd tə kɑɹv aʊɾ ə kɪŋdəm ə hɪz oʊn ən ɛndəd soʊl fɹəm ðə blɑk ɪnstɛd. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz soʊ; mɛni dækoʊvæl kleɪm noʊbəl ænsɛstɝz. əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ət list; fju ʌv ðə blʌd faʊn sətʃ tʃæɾɝ əmjuzɪŋ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, kɛɹid hæd fɛlt lʌki wən ðə tʃuzɝz pɪkt ɪm aʊt, ə stɝɾi bɔɪ nɑt jɛɾ oʊld ɪnʌf tə bi əsaɪn duɾiz, ən i stɪl fɛl pɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪvənz tætuɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. mɛni dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz wɛnt wɪθaʊt koʊɾ əɹ ʃɝt wɛnɛvɝ pɑsəbəl, tə dɪspleɪ ðoʊz. ðə hjumənz, ɛniweɪ. oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz wɝ nɑt mɑɹkt əɹ oʊnd, bʌt ðət wɑz bɪtwin əm ən ði ɛmpɹɛs.

According to the tales he had heard as a child, one of his ancestors, a noble, had followed Luthair Paendrag to Seanchan at Artur Hawkwing's command, but two hundred years later, with only the north secure, another ancestor tried to carve out a kingdom of his own and ended sold from the block instead. Perhaps it was so; many da'covale claimed noble ancestors. Among themselves, at least; few of the Blood found such chatter amusing. In any case, Karede had felt lucky when the Choosers picked him out, a sturdy boy not yet old enough to be assigned duties, and he still felt pride in the ravens tattooed on his shoulders. Many Deathwatch Guards went without coat or shirt whenever possible, to display those. The humans, anyway. Ogier Gardeners were not marked or owned, but that was between them and the Empress.

kɛɹid wɑz dækoʊvæl ən pɹaʊɾ ʌv ɪt, laɪk ɛvɹi mæn ə ðə ɡɑɹd, ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, bɑɾi ən soʊl. hi fɔt wɛɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs pɔɪntəd, ən wəd daɪ ðə deɪ ʃi sɛd daɪ. tə ði ɛmpɹɛs əloʊn dɪd ðə ɡɑɹɾ ænsɝ, ən wɛɹ ðeɪ əpɪɹd, ðeɪ əpɪɹɾ əz əɹ hænd, ə vɪzəbəl ɹimaɪndɝ ə hɝ. noʊ wʌndɝ ðət səm əmʌŋ ðə blʌd kəd bɪkʌm ənizi wɑtʃɪŋ ə dɪtætʃmən ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn pæs. ə fɑɹ bɛɾɝ laɪf ðən mʌkɪŋ aʊɾ ə lɔɹdz steɪbəlz əɹ sɝvɪŋ kæf tə ə leɪɾi. bʌɾ i kɝs ðə lʌk ðət hæd sɛn ɪm ɪndə ðiz maʊntənz tə ɪnspɛk ði aʊtpoʊsts.

Karede was da'covale and proud of it, like every man of the Guard, the property of the Crystal Throne, body and soul. He fought where the Empress pointed, and would die the day she said die. To the Empress alone did the Guard answer, and where they appeared, they appeared as her hand, a visible reminder of her. No wonder that some among the Blood could become uneasy watching a detachment of Guardsmen pass. A far better life than mucking out a Lord's stables or serving kaf to a Lady. But he cursed the luck that had sent him into these mountains to inspect the outposts.

ðə ɹeɪkən dɑɹɾɪd ɑn wɛstwɝd, ðə tu flaɪɝz kɹaʊtʃt loʊ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ skaʊɾɪŋ ɹipɔɹt, noʊ mɛsədʒ fəɹ hɪm. fɹɪk nu ɪt wɑz ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, bʌt ðə kɹitʃɝz lɔŋ, aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt nɛk sʌmhaʊ lʊkt . . . æŋkʃəs. hæɾ i bɪn ɛniwʌn ɛls, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn æŋkʃəs, tu. ðəɹ hæd bɪn fju mɛsədʒəz fəɹ ɪm sɪns ɪz ɔɹɾɝz θɹi deɪz əɡoʊ tə əsum kəmæn ən muv ist. itʃ mɛsədʒ hæd θɪkən ðə fɑɡ mɔɹ ðən klɪɹɾ ɪt.

The raken darted on westward, the two fliers crouched low in their saddle. There was no scouting report, no message for him. Furyk knew it was his imagination, but the creature's long, outstretched neck somehow looked . . . anxious. Had he been anyone else, he might have been anxious, too. There had been few messages for him since his orders three days ago to assume command and move east. Each message had thickened the fog more than cleared it.

ðə loʊkəlz, ðiz ɔltɑɹənz, hæd muvd ɪndə ðə maʊntənz ɪn fɔɹs, ɪt simd, bʌt haʊ? ðə ɹoʊdz əlɔŋ ðə nɔɹðɝn bɔɹɾɝ ə ðɪs ɹeɪnʒ wɝ pətʃɹoʊld ən wɑtʃt nɪɹli tə ðə bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɪljən, baɪ flaɪɝz ən mɔɹɑtʃɹm əz wɛl əz hɔɹs-maʊntəd pɑɹɾiz. wʌt cʊɾə meɪd ði ɔltɑɹənz dɪsaɪd tə ʃoʊ soʊ mɛni tiθ? tə stæn təɡɛðɝ? ə mæn maɪt faɪn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə duəl fəɹ ə lʊk - ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn tə lɝn tʃælənʒɪŋ ə ɡɑɹdzmæn wɑz dʒʌst ə sloʊɝ weɪ ʌv kʌɾɪŋ jəɹ oʊn θɹoʊt - bʌɾ i hæd sin noʊbəlz ə ðɪs soʊ-kɔl neɪʃən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɛl itʃ ʌðɝ ən ðɛɹ kwin fəɹ ðə mɪɹ sədʒɛstʃən ðət ðɛɹ oʊn lænz maɪt bi pɹətɛktəɾ ən pɝhæps ðoʊz ə ðɛɹ neɪbɝ æɾəd tə ðɛm.

The locals, these Altarans, had moved into the mountains in force, it seemed, but how? The roads along the northern border of this range were patrolled and watched nearly to the border of Illian, by fliers and morat'torm as well as horse-mounted parties. What could have made the Altarans decide to show so many teeth? To stand together? A man might find himself in a duel for a look - though they had begun to learn challenging a Guardsman was just a slower way of cutting your own throat - but he had seen nobles of this so-called nation trying to sell each other and their Queen for the mere suggestion that their own lands might be protected and perhaps those of their neighbor added to them.

nəɾək, ə bɪɡ mæn wɪð ə dɪsɛptɪvli maɪl feɪs, twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə wɑtʃ ðə ɹeɪkən. "aɪ doʊn laɪk mɑɹtʃɪŋ blaɪnd," hi mʌɾɝd. "nɑt wən ði ɔltɑɹənz əv mænədʒ tə pʊt fɔɹɾi θaʊzən mɛn ʌp hɪɹ. fɔɹɾi, ət list."

Nadoc, a big man with a deceptively mild face, twisted in his saddle to watch the raken. "I don't like marching blind," he muttered. "Not when the Altarans have managed to put forty thousand men up here. Forty, at least."

dʒædʒɹæŋkə snɔɹɾɪd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz tɔl waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ ʃɪftəd. dʒædʒɹæŋkə wɑz ðə sinjɝ ə ðə θɹi kæptənz bɪhaɪn kɛɹid, hævɪŋ sɝvd əz lɔŋ əz kɛɹid hɪmsɛlf. ə ʃɔɹt θɪn mæn wɪð ə pɹɑmənənt noʊz ən sətʃ ɛɹz jə maɪɾ əv θɔɾ ɪm ə ðə blʌd. ðət hɔɹs wəd stæn aʊɾ əɾ ə maɪl. "fɔɹɾi θaʊzən əɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd, nəɾək, ðəɹ skæɾɝd fɹəm hɪɹ tə ði ɛn ə ðə ɹeɪnʒ, tu fɑɹ əpɑɹt tə səpɔɹt wʌn ənʌðɝ. stæb maɪ aɪz, laɪkli hæf ɑɹ dɛɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðeɪ mʌs bi tæŋəlɪŋ wɪð aʊtpoʊsts ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ðæts waɪ wi ɑɹənt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts. wɝ dʒʌst ɪkspɛktəd tə swip ʌp ðə ɹɛmnəns."

Jadranka snorted so hard that his tall white gelding shifted. Jadranka was the senior of the three captains behind Karede, having served as long as Karede himself. A short thin man with a prominent nose and such airs you might have thought him of the Blood. That horse would stand out at a mile. "Forty thousand or a hundred, Nadoc, they're scattered from here to the end of the range, too far apart to support one another. Stab my eyes, likely half are dead already. They must be tangling with outposts everywhere. That's why we aren't getting reports. We're just expected to sweep up the remnants."

kɛɹid swɑloʊɾ ə saɪ. hi hæd hoʊp dʒædʒɹæŋkə wɑz nɑɾ ə ful ətɑp ɪz ɛɹz. pɹeɪz ə vɪktɝz spɹɛd kwɪkli, wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ ən ɑɹmi əɹ hæf ə bænɝ. ɪt wɑz ðə ɹɛɹ dɪfits ðət wɝ swɑloʊɾ ɪn saɪləns ən fɝɡɑɾən. soʊ mʌtʃ saɪləns wɑz . . . ɑmənəs.

Karede swallowed a sigh. He had hoped Jadranka was not a fool atop his airs. Praise of victors spread quickly, whether they were an army or half a Banner. It was the rare defeats that were swallowed in silence and forgotten. So much silence was . . . ominous.

"ðæt læst ɹipɔɹt dɪdn saʊn laɪk ɹɛmnəns tə mi," nəɾək pɝsɪstəd. hi wɑz noʊ ful. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ faɪv θaʊzən mɛn nɑt fɪfti maɪlz əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs, ən aɪ daʊt wɪl teɪk əm wɪð bɹumz."

"That last report didn't sound like remnants to me," Nadoc persisted. He was no fool. "There are five thousand men not fifty miles ahead of us, and I doubt we'll take them with brooms."

dʒædʒɹæŋkə snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn. "wil kɹʌʃ ðɛm, wɪð sɔɹdz əɹ bɹumz. ðə laɪt bɝn maɪ aɪz, aɪ kən hɑɹdli weɪt fəɹ ə disən ɛnɡeɪdʒmənt. aɪ toʊl ðə skaʊts tə pɹɛs ɑn əntɪl ðeɪ faʊn ðɛm. aɪ woʊn əv əm slɪpɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ʌs."

Jadranka snorted again. "We'll crush them, with swords or brooms. The Light burn my eyes, I can hardly wait for a decent engagement. I told the scouts to press on until they found them. I won't have them slipping away from us."

"ju dɪd wʌt?" kɛɹid sɛd sɔfli.

"You did what?" Karede said softly.

sɑft əɹ nɑt, hɪz wɝdz dʒɝkt ɛvɹi aɪ təwɔɹd hɪm. ðoʊ nəɾək ən ə fju ʌv ði ʌðɝz hæd tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə stɑp ɡeɪpɪŋ ət dʒædʒɹæŋkə. skaʊts toʊl tə pɹɛs əhɛd, skaʊts toʊld wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ. wʌt hæd ɡɔn ənsin fəɹ ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz?

Soft or not, his words jerked every eye toward him. Though Nadoc and a few of the others had to struggle to stop gaping at Jadranka. Scouts told to press ahead, scouts told what to look for. What had gone unseen for those orders?
