bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ ʃaʊts ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə mɛn ɪn ðə pæs, skɹimz ən ðə ʃɹiks ə hɔɹsəz.

Before anyone could open his mouth shouts rose from the men in the pass, screams and the shrieks of horses.

kɛɹid pɹɛs ðə lɛðɝ tub ə ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɪz aɪ. əlɔŋ ðə pæs əhɛɾ ə hɪm, mɛn ən hɔɹsəz wɝ daɪɪŋ ʌndɝ ə heɪl ʌv wʌɾ i θɔt mʌs bi kɹɔsboʊ boʊls, ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæmɝd θɹu stil bɹɛstpleɪts, ɪksploʊɾəd θɹu tʃɛsts pɹətɛktəd baɪ meɪl. hʌnʒɹədz wɝ daʊn ɔlɹɛɾi, hʌnʒɹədz mɔɹ sæɡɪŋ wundəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz əɹ əfʊɾ ən ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm hɔɹsəz θɹæʃɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. tu mɛni wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ. ivən əz i lʊkt, mɛn stɪl maʊntəd wɝl ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz tə tʃɹaɪ fliɪŋ bæk ʌp ðə pæs. wɛɹ ɪn ðə laɪt wɝ ðə sʌldəm? hi kəd nɑt faɪn ðɛm. hi hæd feɪst ɹɛbəlz u hæd sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz hæd tə bi kɪld əz fæst əz pɑsəbəl. meɪbi ðə loʊkəlz hæd lɝn ðæt.

Karede pressed the leather tube of the looking glass to his eye. Along the pass ahead of him, men and horses were dying under a hail of what he thought must be crossbow bolts, the way they hammered through steel breastplates, exploded through chests protected by mail. Hundreds were down already, hundreds more sagging wounded in their saddles or afoot and running from horses thrashing on the ground. Too many were running. Even as he looked, men still mounted whirled their horses to try fleeing back up the pass. Where in the Light were the sul'dam? He could not find them. He had faced rebels who had sul'dam and damane, and they always had to be killed as fast as possible. Maybe the locals had learned that.

sʌɾənli, ʃɑkɪŋli, ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪɡæn tə ɪɹʌpt ɪn ɹɔɹɪŋ faʊntənz ɔl əlɔŋ ðə ɹaɪðɪŋ sneɪk ə hɪz kəmænd, faʊntənz ðət flʌŋ mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz izəli əz dɝɾ ən stoʊnz. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ, blu-waɪt boʊls ʃæɾɝɪŋ ɝθ ən mɛn əlaɪk. ʌðɝ mɛn sɪmpli ɪksploʊɾəd, ɹɪp tə ʃɹɛdz baɪ nʌθɪŋ i kəd si. dɪd ðə loʊkəlz əv deɪmeɪn ə ðɛɹ oʊn? noʊ, ɪt wəd bi ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Suddenly, shockingly, the ground began to erupt in roaring fountains all along the writhing snake of his command, fountains that flung men and horses into the air as easily as dirt and stones. Lightning flashed out of the sky, blue-white bolts shattering earth and men alike. Other men simply exploded, ripped to shreds by nothing he could see. Did the locals have damane of their own? No, it would be those Aes Sedai.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" nəɾək sɛd. hi saʊndəd ʃeɪkən. əz wɛl i maɪt.

"What are we going to do?" Nadoc said. He sounded shaken. As well he might.

"du jə θɪŋk tə əbændən jəɹ mɛn?" dʒædʒɹæŋkə snɑɹəld. "wi ɹæli ðɛm ən ətæk, jə - !" hi kʌɾ ɔf, ɡɝɡəlɪŋ, əz kɛɹidz sɔɹdpɔɪnt wɛnt nitli ɪndə hɪz θɹoʊt. ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz fulz kəd bi tɑlɝeɪɾəd, ən taɪmz nɑt. əz ðə mæn tɑpəl fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, kɛɹid dɛfli waɪpt ɪz bleɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɛldɪŋz waɪt meɪn bɪfɔɹ ði ænəməl boʊltəd. ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz fəɹ ə lɪɾəl ʃoʊ, tu.

"Do you think to abandon your men?" Jadranka snarled. "We rally them and attack, you - !" He cut off, gurgling, as Karede's swordpoint went neatly into his throat. There were times fools could be tolerated, and times not. As the man toppled from his saddle, Karede deftly wiped his blade on the gelding's white mane before the animal bolted. There were times for a little show, too.

"wi ɹæli wʌt kən bi ɹælid, nəɾək," hi sɛɾ əz ɪf dʒædʒɹæŋkə hæd nɛvɝ spoʊkən. əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn. "wi seɪv wʌt kən bi seɪvd, ən fɔl bæk."

"We rally what can be rallied, Nadoc," he said as if Jadranka had never spoken. As if he had never been. "We save what can be saved, and fall back."

tɝnɪŋ tə ɹaɪd daʊn ɪndə ðə pæs wɛɹ laɪtnɪŋz flæʃt ən θʌndɝz ɹɔɹd, hi ɔɹɾɝd æŋhɑɹ, ə stɛɾi-aɪd jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə fæs hɔɹs, tə ɹaɪɾ ist ən ɹipɔɹt wʌt hæd tʃɹænspaɪɝd hɪɹ. pɝhæps ə flaɪɝ wəd si ən pɝhæps nɑt, ðoʊ kɛɹid səspɛktəɾ i nu waɪ ðeɪ flu loʊ, naʊ. hi səspɛktəd ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ ən ðə dʒɛnɝəlz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌt wɑz əkɝɪŋ ʌp hɪɹ, tu. wɑz tədeɪ ðə deɪ hi daɪd fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs? hi dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə hɪz hɔɹsəz flæŋks.

Turning to ride down into the pass where lightnings flashed and thunders roared, he ordered Anghar, a steady-eyed young man with a fast horse, to ride east and report what had transpired here. Perhaps a flier would see and perhaps not, though Karede suspected he knew why they flew low, now. He suspected the High Lady Suroth and the generals in Ebou Dar already knew what was occurring up here, too. Was today the day he died for the Empress? He dug his heels into his horse's flanks.

fɹəm ðə flæt, θɪnli tʃɹid ɹɪdʒ, ɹænd pɪɹd wɛstwɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə fɔɹəs bɪfɔɹ hɪm. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪm - laɪf, soʊ swit; vɪlnəs, oʊ, soʊ vaɪl - hi kəd si ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl livz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. teɪdeɪʃɝ stæmpt ə huf. ðə dʒæɡd piks bɪhaɪnd, tə iðɝ saɪd, ən ɔl ɝaʊn oʊvɝtɑp ðə ɹɪdʒ baɪ ə maɪl əɹ mɔɹ, bʌt ðə ɹɪdʒ stʊd wɛl əbʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps bɪloʊ, ə ɹoʊlɪŋ wʊɾɪd væli oʊvɝ ə liɡ ɪn lɛŋθ ən nɪɹli əz waɪd. ɔl wɑz stɪl daʊn ðɛɹ. əz kwaɪəɾ əz ðə vɔɪɾ i floʊɾəd ɪn. kwaɪət fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɛniweɪ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ plumz ə smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm wɛɹ tu əɹ θɹi tʃɹiz ɪn ə klʌmp bɝn laɪk tɔɹtʃɪz. oʊnli ðə dʒɛnɝəl wɛt stɑpt əm tɝnɪŋ ðə væli ɪndə ə kɑnfləɡɹeɪʃən.

From the flat, thinly treed ridge, Rand peered westward over the forest before him. With the Power in him - life, so sweet; vileness, oh, so vile - he could see individual leaves, but it was not enough. Tai'daishar stamped a hoof. The jagged peaks behind, to either side, and all around overtopped the ridge by a mile or more, but the ridge stood well above the treetops below, a rolling wooded valley over a league in length and nearly as wide. All was still down there. As quiet as the Void he floated in. Quiet for the moment, anyway. Here and there plumes of smoke rose from where two or three trees in a clump burned like torches. Only the general wet stopped them turning the valley into a conflagration.

flɪn ən dæʃivə wɝ ði oʊnli æʃəmən stɪl wɪð hɪm. ɔl ðə ɹɛst wɝ daʊn ɪn ðə væli. ðə pɛɹ stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl weɪ fɹəm ɪm ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz ən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə fɔɹəs bɪloʊ. wɛl, flɪn stɛɹd, əz ɪntɛnli əz ɹænd hɪmsɛlf. dæʃivə ɡlænst əkeɪʒənəli, twɪstɪŋ ɪz maʊθ, səmtaɪmz mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə weɪ ðət meɪd flɪn ʃɪft ɪz fiɾ ən aɪ hɪm saɪdweɪz. ðə paʊɝ fɪl boʊθ mɛn, nɪɹli tə oʊvɝfloʊɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, luz θɝɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ðə mæn simd ɪnkɹisɪŋli tə hæv ɡɔn bæk ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə læs fju deɪz.

Flinn and Dashiva were the only Asha'man still with him. All the rest were down in the valley. The pair stood a little way from him at the edge of the trees, holding their horses by the reins and staring at the forest below. Well, Flinn stared, as intently as Rand himself. Dashiva glanced occasionally, twisting his mouth, sometimes muttering to himself in a way that made Flinn shift his feet and eye him sideways. The Power filled both men, nearly to overflowing, but for a change, Lews Therin said nothing. The man seemed increasingly to have gone back into hiding over the last few days.

ɪn ðə skaɪ ðəɹ wɑz æktʃəli  sʌnlaɪt, ən ðə skæɾɝd klaʊdz wɝ ɡɹeɪ. ɪt wɑz faɪv deɪz sɪns ɹænd hæd bɹɔɾ ɪz smɔl ɑɹmi tə ɔltɑɹə, faɪv deɪz sɪns i hæd sin ɪz fɝst sintʃæn dɛd. hi hæd sin kwaɪɾ ə fju sɪns. θɔt slɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə sɝfəs ə ðə vɔɪd. hi kəd fil ðə hɛɹən bɹændɪɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑm pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ θɹu hɪz ɡlʌv. saɪlənt. ðəɹ wɝ nʌn ə ðə flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝz tə bi sin. θɹi ʌv ðoʊz hæd daɪd, slæʃt fɹəm ðə skaɪ baɪ laɪtnɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz lɝn tə steɪ klɪɹ. bæʃɪɹ wɑz fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ ðə kɹitʃɝz. kwaɪət.

In the sky there was actually sunlight, and the scattered clouds were gray. It was five days since Rand had brought his small army to Altara, five days since he had seen his first Seanchan dead. He had seen quite a few since. Thought slid across the surface of the Void. He could feel the heron branded into his palm pressing against the Dragon Scepter through his glove. Silent. There were none of the flying creatures to be seen. Three of those had died, slashed from the sky by lightning, before their riders learned to stay clear. Bashere was fascinated by the creatures. Quiet.

"pɝhæps ɪts fɪnɪʃt, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." eɪlɪlz vɔɪs wɑz kɑm ən kul, bʌt ʃi pæɾəd əɹ mɛɹz nɛk, ðoʊ ði ænəməl dɪd nɑt nid suðɪŋ. ʃi aɪd flɪn ən dæʃivə saɪdweɪz ən stʃɹeɪɾənd, ənwɪlɪŋ tə ɹɪvil ə ʃɹɛɾ ʌv əniz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm.

"Perhaps it is finished, my Lord Dragon." Ailil's voice was calm and cool, but she patted her mare's neck, though the animal did not need soothing. She eyed Flinn and Dashiva sideways and straightened, unwilling to reveal a shred of unease in front of them.

ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf hʌmɪŋ ən stɑpt əbɹʌpli. ðət wɑz luz θɝɪnz hæbət, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən, nɑt hɪz. nɑt hɪz! laɪt, ɪf i stɑɹɾəd teɪkɪŋ ɑn ðə fɛloʊz mænɝɪzəmz, ən wən i wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, ət ðət . . . !

Rand found himself humming and stopped abruptly. That was Lews Therin's habit, looking at a pretty woman, not his. Not his! Light, if he started taking on the fellow's mannerisms, and when he was not there, at that . . . !

əbɹʌpli, hɑloʊ θʌndɝ bumd ʌp ðə væli. faɪɝ faʊnteɪn aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ə ɡʊd tu maɪlz əweɪ əɹ mɔɹ, ðən əɡɛn, ən əɡɛn, əɡɛn. laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹik daʊn ɪndə ðə fɔɹəs nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ ðə tɔl fleɪmz hæd blumd, sɪŋɡəl slæʃɪz laɪk dʒæɡd blu-waɪt lænsɪz. ə flɝi ʌv laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ən faɪɝ, ən ɔl wɑz stɪl əɡɛn. noʊ tʃɹiz hæd kɑt faɪɝ, ðɪs taɪm.

Abruptly, hollow thunder boomed up the valley. Fire fountained out of the trees a good two miles away or more, then again, and again, again. Lightning streaked down into the forest not far from where the tall flames had bloomed, single slashes like jagged blue-white lances. A flurry of lightning bolts and fire, and all was still again. No trees had caught fire, this time.

səm ə ðət hæd bɪn seɪɾɪn. səm ʌv ɪt.

Some of that had been saidin. Some of it.

ʃaʊts ɹoʊz, dɪm ən dɪstənt, fɹəm ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə væli, hi θɔt. tu fɑɹ fəɹ ivən ɪz seɪɾɪn-ɛnhænst ɪɹz tə hɪɹ ðə kɹæʃ ə stil. dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɑz biɪŋ dʌn baɪ æʃəmən ən dɛɾəkeɪtəd ən soʊlʒɝz.

Shouts rose, dim and distant, from another part of the valley, he thought. Too far for even his saidin-enhanced ears to hear the crash of steel. Despite everything, not all of the fighting was being done by Asha'man and Dedicated and Soldiers.

ænɑiɛlə lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ ʃi mʌst əv bɪn hoʊldɪŋ sɪns ði ɪkstʃeɪnʒ wɪð ðə paʊɝ bɪɡæn. mɛn faɪɾɪŋ wɪð stil dɪd nɑt dɪstɝb hɝ. ðən ʃi pæɾəd əɹ maʊns nɛk. ðə ɡɛldɪŋ hæɾ oʊnli flɪkɝɾ ən ɪɹ. ɹænd hæd noʊɾəst ðəɾ əbaʊt wɪmən. kwaɪɾ ɔfən, wən ə wʊmən wɑz ædʒəteɪɾəd, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə suð ʌðɝz wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɹikwaɪɝd suðɪŋ əɹ nɑt. ə hɔɹs wəd du. wɛɹ wɑz luz θɝɪn?

Anaiyella let out a long breath she must have been holding since the exchange with the Power began. Men fighting with steel did not disturb her. Then she patted her mount's neck. The gelding had only flickered an ear. Rand had noticed that about women. Quite often, when a woman was agitated, she tried to soothe others whether they required soothing or not. A horse would do. Where was Lews Therin?

ɪɹɪɾəbli hi lin fɔɹwɝd tə stʌɾi ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi əɡɛn. ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðoʊz tʃɹiz wɝ ɛvɝɡɹinz - oʊk ən paɪn ən lɛðɝlif - ən dɪspaɪt ðə leɪt dʒɹaʊt, ðeɪ meɪɾ ən ɪfɛktɪv skɹin, ivən tə hɪz ɪntɛnsəfaɪd vɪʒən. əz ɪf aɪdli, hi tʌtʃt ðə nɛɹoʊ bʌndəl ʌndɝ ɪz stɝəp lɛðɝ. hi kəd teɪk ə hænd. ən stʃɹaɪk blaɪnli. hi kəd ɹaɪd daʊn ɪndə ðə wʊdz. ən bi eɪbəl tə si tɛn peɪsɪz ət moʊst. daʊn ðɛɹ, hi wəd bi lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv ðən wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz.

Irritably he leaned forward to study the forest canopy again. A good many of those trees were evergreens - oak and pine and leatherleaf - and despite the late drought, they made an effective screen, even to his intensified vision. As if idly, he touched the narrow bundle under his stirrup leather. He could take a hand. And strike blindly. He could ride down into the woods. And be able to see ten paces at most. Down there, he would be little more effective than one of the Soldiers.

ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz ə lɪɾəl weɪ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪdʒ, sɪlvɝi slæʃ waɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə ə hoʊl ðət ʃoʊd dɪfɹən tʃɹiz ən θɪk wɪntɝ bɹaʊn ʌndɝbɹʌʃ. ə kɑpɝ-skɪn soʊlʒɝ wɪð ə θɪn mʌstæʃ ɑn ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp ən ə smɔl pɝl ɪn ɪz ɪɹ ɛɡzəɾɪd əfʊɾ ən lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃ. hi wɑz ʃʌvɪŋ ə sʌldəm əhɛɾ ə hɪm wɪð əɹ ɹɪsts taɪd bɪhaɪn hɝ, ə hænsəm wʊmən ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə pɝpəl nɑɾ ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ðət sim tə ɡoʊ əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ skaʊl, ðoʊ, əz wɛl əz ɪt dɪd wɪð əɹ ɹʌmpəld, lif-steɪn dʒɹɛs. ʃi snɪɹɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə soʊlʒɝ waɪl i pʊʃt əɹ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪdʒtɑp tə ɹænd, ən ðən ʃi snɪɹɾ ʌp ət ɹænd.

A gateway opened among the trees a little way along the ridge, silvery slash widening into a hole that showed different trees and thick winter brown underbrush. A copper-skinned Soldier with a thin mustache on his upper lip and a small pearl in his ear exited afoot and let the gateway vanish. He was shoving a sul'dam ahead of him with her wrists tied behind her, a handsome woman except for the purple knot on the side of her head. That seemed to go along with her scowl, though, as well as it did with her rumpled, leaf-stained dress. She sneered over her shoulder at the Soldier while he pushed her along the ridgetop to Rand, and then she sneered up at Rand.

ðə soʊlʒɝ stɪfənd, səluɾɪŋ smɑɹtli. "soʊlʒɝ ɑɹlən næləm, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi bɑɹkt, stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹændz sæɾəl. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz ɔɹɾɝz wɝ tə bɹɪŋ ɛni wɪmən kæptʃɝd tə hɪm."

The Soldier stiffened, saluting smartly. "Soldier Arlen Nalaam, my Lord Dragon," he barked, staring straight at Rand's saddle. "My Lord Dragon's orders were to bring any women captured to him."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. ɪt wɑz oʊnli tə ɡɪv ɪm ði əpɪɹəns ə duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ɪnspɛktɪŋ pɹɪznɝz tə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ wʌɾ ɛni ɪɾiət kəd si ðeɪ wɝ. "teɪk əɹ bæk tə ðə kɑɹts, soʊlʒɝ næləm, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə faɪɾɪŋ." hi ɔlmoʊst ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ seɪɪŋ ðæt. ɹɪtɝn tə ðə faɪɾɪŋ. waɪl ɹænd ælθɹ, dʒɹæɡən. ɹibɔɹn ən kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, sæɾ ɪz hɔɹs ən wɑtʃt tʃɹitɑps!

Rand nodded. It was only to give him the appearance of doing something, inspecting prisoners to be sure they were what any idiot could see they were. "Take her back to the carts, Soldier Nalaam, then return to the fighting." He almost ground his teeth saying that. Return to the fighting. While Rand al'Thor, Dragon. Reborn and King of Illian, sat his horse and watched treetops!

næləm səluɾəd əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ pʊʃɪŋ əweɪ ðə wʊmən əhɛɾ ə hɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt sloʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ʃi kɛpt piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn, jɛt nɑɾ ət ðə soʊlʒɝ ðɪs taɪm. ət ɹænd. wɪð waɪd-aɪd, oʊpənməðd əstɑnɪʃmənt. fəɹ səm ɹizən, næləm dɪd nɑt pʊl əɹ tə ə hɔlt əntɪl i ɹitʃt ðə spɑt wɛɹ i hæd kʌm aʊt. ɔl ðət wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi wɑz tə ɡoʊ fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə əvɔɪɾ ɪnʒɝɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz.

Nalaam saluted again before pushing away the woman ahead of him, but he was not slow about it. She kept peering over her shoulder again, yet not at the Soldier this time. At Rand. With wide-eyed, openmouthed astonishment. For some reason, Nalaam did not pull her to a halt until he reached the spot where he had come out. All that was necessary was to go far enough to avoid injuring the horses.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ?" ɹænd dɪmændəɾ əz seɪɾɪn fɪl ðə mæn.

"What are you doing?" Rand demanded as saidin filled the man.

næləm hæf tɝn bæk tə hɪm, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ bɹifli. "ɪt simz iziɝ, hɪɹ, ɪf aɪ juz ə pleɪs aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi meɪɾ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. seɪɾɪn . . . seɪɾɪn filz . . . stʃɹeɪnʒ . . . tə mi hɪɹ." hɪz pɹɪznɝ tɝn tə fɹaʊn ət hɪm.

Nalaam half turned back to him, hesitating briefly. "It seems easier, here, if I use a place I've already made a gateway, my Lord Dragon. Saidin . . . Saidin feels . . . strange . . . to me here." His prisoner turned to frown at him.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪm tə ɡoʊ əhɛd. flɪn pɹitɛndəd tə bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɪz hɔɹsəz sæɾəl ɡɝθ, bʌt ðə bɔldɪŋ oʊl mæn smaɪl feɪnli. smʌɡli. dæʃivə . . . ɡɪɡəld. flɪn hæd bɪn ðə fɝs tə mɛnʃən ən ɑd fil tə seɪɾɪn ɪn ðɪs væli. ʌv kɔɹs, nɛɹɪʃmə ən hɑpwəl hæd hɝd hɪm, ən mɔɹ æɾəd ɪz teɪlz ə ðə "stʃɹeɪnʒnəs" ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ. smɔl wʌndɝ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz kleɪmɪŋ tə fil sʌmθɪŋ naʊ, ðoʊ nɑɾ ə wʌn kəd seɪ wʌt. seɪɾɪn dʒʌs fɛlt . . . pəkjuljɝ. laɪt, wɪð ðə teɪn θɪk ɑn ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs, wʌɾ ɛls wəɾ ɪt fil? ɹænd hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɔl kʌmɪŋ daʊn wɪð ɪz nu sɪknəs.

After a moment, Rand gestured him to go ahead. Flinn pretended to be interested in his horse's saddle girth, but the balding old man smiled faintly. Smugly. Dashiva . . . giggled. Flinn had been the first to mention an odd feel to saidin in this valley. Of course, Narishma and Hopwil had heard him, and Morr added his tales of the "strangeness" around Ebou Dar. Small wonder everyone was claiming to feel something now, though not a one could say what. Saidin just felt . . . peculiar. Light, with the taint thick on the male half of the Source, what else would it feel? Rand hoped they were not all coming down with his new sickness.

næləmz ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənd, ən vænɪʃt bɪhaɪn ɪm ən ɪz pɹɪznɝ. ɹænd lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɹɪli fil seɪɾɪn. laɪf ən kɝʌpʃən kɑmɪŋɡəld; aɪs tə meɪk wɪntɝz hɑɹt sim wɔɹm, ən faɪɝ tə meɪk ə fɔɹdʒəz fleɪmz koʊld; dɛθ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə slɪp. wɑntɪŋ ɪm tə slɪp. ɪt dɪd nɑt fil ɛni dɪfɹənt. dɪɾ ɪt? hi skaʊld ət wɛɹ næləm hæd dɪsəpɪɹd. næləm ən ðə wʊmən.

Nalaam's gateway opened, and vanished behind him and his prisoner. Rand let himself really feel saidin. Life and corruption commingled; ice to make winter's heart seem warm, and fire to make a forge's flames cold; death, waiting for him to slip. Wanting him to slip. It did not feel any different. Did it? He scowled at where Nalaam had disappeared. Nalaam and the woman.

ʃi wɑz ðə fɔɹθ sʌldəm teɪkən ðɪs æftɝnun. ðət meɪd twɛnti-θɹi sʌldəm pɹɪznɝz wɪð ðə kɑɹts. ən tu deɪmeɪn, itʃ stɪl ɪn əɹ sɪlvɝi liʃ ən kɑlɝ, kæɹiɾ ɑn sɛpɹət kɑɹts; ɪn ðoʊz kɑlɝz, ðeɪ kəd nɑt wɔk θɹi stɛps bɪfɔɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ vaɪələnli sɪk ðən ɹænd dɪd sizɪŋ ðə sɔɹs. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðə sɪstɝz wɪð mæt wəd bi pliz tə ɹəsiv əm æftɝ ɔl. ðə fɝs deɪmeɪn, θɹi deɪz bɪfɔɹ, hi hæd nɑt θɔɾ ʌv əz ə pɹɪznɝ. ə slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð peɪl jɛloʊ hɛɹ ən bɪɡ blu aɪz, ʃi wɑz ə sintʃæn kæptɪv tə bi fɹid. hi θɔt. bʌt wən i fɔɹst ə sʌldəm tə ɹimuv ðə wʊmənz kɑlɝ, hɝ æɾəm, ʃi skɹim fəɹ ðə sʌldəm tə hɛlp əɹ ən ɪmiɾiətli bɪɡæn læʃɪŋ aʊt wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ʃi hæɾ ivən ɔfɝɾ əɹ nɛk fəɹ ðə sʌldəm tə ɹipleɪs ðə θɪŋ! naɪn dɪfɛndɝz ən ə soʊlʒɝ daɪd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bi ʃildɪd. dʒɛdwɪn wʊɾə kɪld əɹ ɑn ðə spɑt hæd ɹænd nɑt stɑpt ɪt. ðə dɪfɛndɝz, nɪɹli əz ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɝaʊnd wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl əz ʌðɝz wɝ ɝaʊn mɛn u kəd - ðə dɪfɛndɝz stɪl wɑntəɾ əɹ dɛd. ðeɪ hæd teɪkən kæʒəwəltiz ɪn ðə faɪɾɪŋ ðiz pæs deɪz, bʌt hævɪŋ mɛn kɪl baɪ ə pɹɪznɝ sim tə əfɛn ðɛm.

She was the fourth sul'dam taken this afternoon. That made twenty-three sul'dam prisoners with the carts. And two damane, each still in her silvery leash and collar, carried on separate carts; in those collars, they could not walk three steps before becoming more violently sick than Rand did seizing the Source. He was not sure the sisters with Mat would be pleased to receive them after all. The first damane, three days before, he had not thought of as a prisoner. A slender woman with pale yellow hair and big blue eyes, she was a Seanchan captive to be freed. He thought. But when he forced a sul'dam to remove the woman's collar, her a'dam, she screamed for the sul'dam to help her and immediately began lashing out with the Power. She had even offered her neck for the sul'dam to replace the thing! Nine Defenders and a Soldier died before she could be shielded. Gedwyn would have killed her on the spot had Rand not stopped it. The Defenders, nearly as uncomfortable around women who could channel as others were around men who could - the Defenders still wanted her dead. They had taken casualties in the fighting these past days, but having men killed by a prisoner seemed to offend them.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ kæʒəwəltiz ðən ɹænd hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. θɝɾi-wʌn dɪfɛndɝz dɛd, ən fɔɹɾi-sɪks kəmpænjənz. mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd əmʌŋ ðə lidʒənmɛn ən ðə noʊbəlz ɑɹmmɪn. sɛvən soʊlʒɝz ən ə dɛɾəkeɪtəd, mɛn ɹænd hæd nɛvɝ mɛt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ænsɝɾ ɪz sʌmənz tə ɪljən. tu mɛni, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ ɔl ɪksɛp ðə ɡɹævəst ɪnʒɝi kəd bi hild, ɪf ə mæn kəɾ oʊnli hæŋ ɑn əntɪl ðəɹ wɑz taɪm. bʌɾ i wɑz dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə sintʃæn wɛst. dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əm hɑɹd.

There had been more casualties than Rand had expected. Thirty-one Defenders dead, and forty-six Companions. More than two hundred among the Legionmen and the noble's armsmen. Seven Soldiers and a Dedicated, men Rand had never met before they answered his summons to Illian. Too many, considering that all except the gravest injury could be Healed, if a man could only hang on until there was time. But he was driving the Seanchan west. Driving them hard.

mɔɹ ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɹoʊz sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ ɔf daʊn ɪn ðə væli. faɪɝ blɑsəmd ə ɡʊd θɹi maɪlz tə ðə wɛst, ən laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹʌk, tɑpəlɪŋ tʃɹiz. tʃɹiz ən stoʊn ɪɹʌptəd fɹəm ə maʊntənsaɪd fɑɹðɝ ɑn, stʃɹeɪnʒ faʊntənz mɑɹtʃɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə sloʊp. ðə ɹɔɹɪŋ bumz swɑloʊd ʃaʊts. ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ.

More shouting rose somewhere far off down in the valley. Fire blossomed a good three miles to the west, and lightning struck, toppling trees. Trees and stone erupted from a mountainside farther on, strange fountains marching along the slope. The roaring booms swallowed shouts. The Seanchan were retreating.

"ɡɛt daʊn ðɛɹ," ɹænd toʊl flɪn ən dæʃivə. "boʊθ ə ju. faɪn dʒɛdwɪn ən tɛl ɪm aɪ sɛd pʊʃ! pʊʃ!"

"Get down there," Rand told Flinn and Dashiva. "Both of you. Find Gedwyn and tell him I said push! Push!"

dæʃivə ɡɹɪməst ət ðə fɔɹəs bɪloʊ, ðən bɪɡæn ɔkwɝdli tʌɡɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪdʒ. ðə mæn wɑz ənɡeɪnli wɪð hɔɹsəz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əɹ liɾɪŋ. hi nɪɹli tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ ɪz sɔɹd!

Dashiva grimaced at the forest below, then began awkwardly tugging his horse along the ridge. The man was ungainly with horses, riding or leading. He nearly tripped over his sword!

flɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ɹænd wɝidli. "ju min tə steɪ hɪɹ əloʊn, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?"

Flinn looked up at Rand worriedly. "You mean to stay here alone, my Lord Dragon?"

"aɪm hɑɹdli əloʊn," ɹænd sɛd dʒɹaɪli, ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə. ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən bæk tə ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn, ɔlmoʊs tu hʌnʒɹəd lænsɝz weɪɾɪŋ dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wɛɹ ðə ɹɪdʒ bɪɡæn tə sloʊp daʊn tə ði ist. ət ðɛɹ hɛd, dɛnhɝəd fɹaʊn θɹu ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət. hi hæd kəmæn ə boʊθ lɑts, naʊ, ən ɪf ɪz kənsɝn wɑz fəɹ eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə, hɪz fɛloʊz stɪl meɪɾ ə ʃoʊ fɪt tə kip əweɪ moʊst ətækɝz. bɪsaɪdz, wɪɹɑmɑn hæd ðə nɔɹðɝn ɛn ə ðɪs ɹɪdʒ sɪkjʊɹd soʊ ə flaɪ kəd nɑt pæs, hi kleɪmd, ən bæʃɪɹ hɛl ðə saʊθ. wɪθaʊt boʊstɪŋ; bæʃɪɹ dʒʌst ɪɹɛktəɾ ə wɔl ə lænsɪz wɪθaʊt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ən ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ. "æn aɪm hɑɹdli hɛlpləs, ɛniweɪ, flɪn."

"I'm hardly alone," Rand said dryly, glancing at Ailil and Anaiyella. They had ridden back to their armsmen, almost two hundred lancers waiting just short of where the ridge began to slope down to the east. At their head, Denharad frowned through the face-bars of his helmet. He had command of both lots, now, and if his concern was for Ailil and Anaiyella, his fellows still made a show fit to keep away most attackers. Besides, Weiramon had the northern end of this ridge secured so a fly could not pass, he claimed, and Bashere held the south. Without boasting; Bashere just erected a wall of lances without talking about it. And the Seanchan were retreating. "And I'm hardly helpless, anyway, Flinn."

flɪn æktʃəli  lʊk daʊtfəl ən skɹætʃt ɪz fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪt hɛɹ bɪfɔɹ səluɾɪŋ ən liɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs təwɔɹd wɛɹ dæʃivəz ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wɪŋkɪŋ aʊt. lɪmpɪŋ əlɔŋ, flɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf fɪt fəɹ dæʃivə. ɹænd wɑntəd tə snɑɹl. hi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ mæd, ən niðɝ kəd ðeɪ.

Flinn actually looked doubtful and scratched his fringe of white hair before saluting and leading his horse toward where Dashiva's gateway was already winking out. Limping along, Flinn shook his head, muttering to himself fit for Dashiva. Rand wanted to snarl. He could not go mad, and neither could they.

flɪnz ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃt, ən ɹænd ɹɪtɝn tə hɪz stʌɾi ʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps. ɪt wɑz kwaɪəɾ əɡɛn. taɪm stʃɹɛtʃt ɪn stɪlnəs. ðɪs noʊʃən ə teɪkɪŋ ði aʊtpoʊsts ɪn ðə maʊntənz hæd bɪn ə bæd wʌn; hi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðæt, naʊ. ɪn ðɪs tɝeɪn, jə kəd bi hæf ə maɪl fɹəm ən ɑɹmi wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ. ɪn ðoʊz tæŋɡəld wʊdz daʊn ðɛɹ, jə kəd bi tɛn fit fɹəm əm wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ! hi niɾəd tə feɪs ðə sintʃæn ɑn bɛɾɝ ɡɹaʊnd. hi niɾəd. . . .

Flinn's gateway vanished, and Rand returned to his study of the treetops. It was quiet again. Time stretched in stillness. This notion of taking the outposts in the mountains had been a bad one; he was willing to admit that, now. In this terrain, you could be half a mile from an army without knowing. In those tangled woods down there, you could be ten feet from them without knowing! He needed to face the Seanchan on better ground. He needed. . . .

əbɹʌpli hi wɑz faɪɾɪŋ seɪɾɪn, faɪɾɪŋ waɪl sɝdʒəz ðət tʃɹaɪd tə ɹim aʊɾ ɪz skʌl. ðə vɔɪd wɑz vænɪʃɪŋ, mɛltɪŋ bɪniθ ði ɔnslɔt. fɹæntɪk, deɪzd, hi ɹilis ðə sɔɹs bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd kɪl hɪm. nɔziə twɪstəɾ ɪz mɪɾəl. dʌbəl vɪʒən ʃoʊɾ ɪm tu kɹaʊnz ə sɔɹdz. laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə θɪk mʌltʃ ə dɛd livz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs! hi wɑz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd! hi kəd nɑt sim tə bɹið pɹɑpɝli, ən stʃɹʌɡəl tə sʌk ɪn ɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɪp bɹoʊkən ɔf wʌn ə ðə kɹaʊnz ɡoʊldən lɔɹəl livz, ən blʌd steɪn sɛvɹəl ə ðə taɪni ɡoʊldən sɔɹdpɔɪns. ə nɑɾ ə hɑt peɪn ɪn ɪz saɪd toʊld ɪm ðoʊz nɛvɝ-hilɪŋ wunz hæd bɹoʊkən oʊpən. hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ hɪmsɛlf ʌp, ən kɹaɪɾ aʊt. ɪn stʌn əmeɪzmən i stɛɹɾ ət ðə dɑɹk flɛtʃɪŋz ʌv ən æɹoʊ stʌk θɹu hɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm. wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn i kəlæpst. sʌmθɪŋ ɹæn daʊn ɪz feɪs. sʌmθɪŋ dʒɹɪpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪ. blʌd.

Abruptly he was fighting saidin, fighting wild surges that tried to ream out his skull. The Void was vanishing, melting beneath the onslaught. Frantic, dazed, he released the Source before it could kill him. Nausea twisted his middle. Double vision showed him two Crowns of Swords. Lying on the thick mulch of dead leaves in front of his face! He was on the ground! He could not seem to breathe properly, and struggled to suck in air. There was a chip broken off one of the crown's golden laurel leaves, and blood stained several of the tiny golden swordpoints. A knot of hot pain in his side told him those never-healing wounds had broken open. He tried to push himself up, and cried out. In stunned amazement he stared at the dark fletchings of an arrow stuck through his right arm. With a groan he collapsed. Something ran down his face. Something dripped in front of his eye. Blood.

veɪɡli hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə juləleɪɾɪŋ kɹaɪz. hɔɹsmən əpɪɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz tə ðə nɔɹθ, ɡæləpɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪdʒ, səm wɪð loʊɝd lænsɪz, səm wɝkɪŋ ʃɔɹt baʊz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd nɑk ən dʒɹɔ. hɔɹsmən ɪn blu-ænd-jɛloʊ ɑɹmɝ ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts, ən hɛlməts laɪk hjudʒ ɪnsɛks' hɛdz. sintʃæn, sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm ɪt simd. fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ wɪɹɑmɑnz flaɪ.

Vaguely he became aware of ululating cries. Horsemen appeared among the trees to the north, galloping along the ridge, some with lowered lances, some working short bows as fast as they could nock and draw. Horsemen in blue-and-yellow armor of overlapping plates, and helmets like huge insects' heads. Seanchan, several hundred of them it seemed. From the north. So much for Weiramon's fly.

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəl tə ɹitʃ ðə sɔɹs. tu leɪt tə wɝi əbaʊt sɪkɪŋ ʌp, əɹ fɔlɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs. ənʌðɝ taɪm, hi maɪɾ əv læft ət ðæt. hi stʃɹʌɡəld. . . . ɪt wɑz laɪk fʌmbəlɪŋ fəɹ ə pɪn ɪn ðə dɑɹk wɪð nʌm fɪŋɡɝz.

Rand struggled to reach the Source. Too late to worry about sicking up, or falling on his face. Another time, he might have laughed at that. He struggled. . . . It was like fumbling for a pin in the dark with numbed fingers.

taɪm tə daɪ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. ɹænd hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn luz θɝɪn wəd bi ðəɹ ət ði ɛnd.

Time to die, Lews Therin whispered. Rand had always known Lews Therin would be there at the end.

nɑt fɪfti peɪsɪz fɹəm ɹænd, skɹimɪŋ tɛɹənz ən kɛɹhin plaʊɾ ɪndə ðə sintʃæn.

Not fifty paces from Rand, screaming Tairens and Cairhien plowed into the Seanchan.

"faɪt, jə dɑɡz!" ænɑiɛlə ʃɹikt, swɪŋɪŋ daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl bɪsaɪd hɪm. "faɪt!" ðə wɪloʊ leɪɾi ɪn əɹ sɪlks ən leɪsəz hɝld ə stʃɹɪŋ ə kɝsɪz ðət wʊɾə meɪɾ ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz tʌŋ ɡoʊ dʒɹaɪ.

"Fight, you dogs!" Anaiyella shrieked, swinging down from her saddle beside him. "Fight!" The willow lady in her silks and laces hurled a string of curses that would have made a wagon driver's tongue go dry.

ænɑiɛlə stʊd hoʊldɪŋ əɹ maʊns ɹeɪnz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə mɪl ə mɛn ən stil tə ɹænd. ɪt wɑz eɪlɪl u tɝn ɪm ɑntu hɪz bæk. nilɪŋ ðɛɹ, ʃi lʊk daʊn əɾ ɪm wɪð ən ənɹiɾəbəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ɪn əɹ bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz. hi kəd nɑt sim tə muv. hi fɛl dʒɹeɪnd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd blɪŋk. skɹimz ən ðə klæʃ ə stil ɹæŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz.

Anaiyella stood holding her mount's reins, glaring from the mill of men and steel to Rand. It was Ailil who turned him onto his back. Kneeling there, she looked down at him with an unreadable expression in her big dark eyes. He could not seem to move. He felt drained. He was not sure he could blink. Screams and the clash of steel rang in his ears.

"ɪf i daɪz ɑn əɹ hænz, bæʃɪɹ wɪl hæŋ boʊθ ʌv ʌs!" ænɑiɛlə sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt sɪmpɝɪŋ naʊ. "ɪf ðoʊz blæk-koʊɾəd mɑnstɝz ɡɛt hoʊld ʌv əs . . . !" ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd, ən bɛn kloʊsɝ tə eɪlɪl, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ə bɛl naɪf i hæd nɑt noʊɾəst ɪn əɹ hæn bɪfɔɹ. ə ɹubi spɑɹkəl blʌd-ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə hɪlt. "jɔɹ læns-kæptən kəd bɹeɪk ɔf ɪnʌf mɛn tə ɡɛɾ əs əweɪ. wi kəd bi maɪlz əweɪ bɪfɔɹ hiz faʊnd, ən bæk tə əɹ ɪsteɪts baɪ ðə taɪm - "

"If he dies on our hands, Bashere will hang both of us!" Anaiyella certainly was not simpering now. "If those black-coated monsters get hold of us . . . !" She shuddered, and bent closer to Ailil, gesturing with a belt knife he had not noticed in her hand before. A ruby sparkled blood-red on the hilt. "Your Lance-captain could break off enough men to get us away. We could be miles away before he's found, and back to our estates by the time - "

"aɪ θɪŋk i kən hɪɹ ʌs," eɪlɪl bɹoʊk ɪn kɑmli. hɝ ɹɛd-ɡlʌv hænz muvd əɾ əɹ weɪst. ʃiðɪŋ ə bɛl naɪf? əɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ wʌn? "ɪf i daɪz hɪɹ - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz ʃɑɹpli əz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd, ən əɹ hɛd dʒɝkt ɝaʊnd.

"I think he can hear us," Ailil broke in calmly. Her red-gloved hands moved at her waist. Sheathing a belt knife? Or drawing one? "If he dies here - " She cut off as sharply as the other woman had, and her head jerked around.

hʊvz θʌndɝd pæst ɹænd ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ɪn θɪk stʃɹimz. ɡæləpɪŋ nɔɹθ, təwɔɹd ðə sintʃæn. sɔɹɾ ɪn hænd, bæʃɪɹ bɛɹli ɹeɪn ɪn bɪfɔɹ lipɪŋ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl. ɡɹɛɡɹɪn pɑnɝ dɪsmaʊntɪd mɔɹ sloʊli, bʌɾ i weɪvd ɪz sɔɹɾ ət ðə mɛn flʌɾɪŋ baɪ. "stʃɹaɪk hoʊm fəɹ kɪŋ ən ɪljən!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "stʃɹaɪk hoʊm! ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ! ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ!" ðə kɹæʃ ə stil ɹoʊz haɪɝ. ən ðə skɹimɪŋ.

Hooves thundered past Rand on either side in thick streams. Galloping north, toward the Seanchan. Sword in hand, Bashere barely reined in before leaping from his saddle. Gregorin Panar dismounted more slowly, but he waved his sword at the men flooding by. "Strike home for King and Illian!" he shouted. "Strike home! The Lord of the Morning! The Lord of the Morning!" The crash of steel rose higher. And the screaming.

"ɪt wəd bi laɪk ðɪs ət ðə læst ʌv ɪt," bæʃɪɹ ɡɹaʊld, feɪvɝɪŋ ðə tu wɪmən wɪð səspɪʃəs ɡlɛɹz. hi weɪstəɾ oʊnli ən ɪnstənt, ðoʊ, bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əbʌv ðə dɪn ə bæɾəl. "mɔɹ! bɝn jəɹ æʃəmən haɪd! hɪɹ, naʊ!" hi dɪd nɑt ʃaʊt ðət ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɑz daʊn, θæŋk ðə laɪt.

"It would be like this at the last of it," Bashere growled, favoring the two women with suspicious glares. He wasted only an instant, though, before raising his voice above the din of battle. "Morr! Burn your Asha'man hide! Here, now!" He did not shout that the Lord Dragon was down, thank the Light.

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɛd pɝhæps ə hænd. ɪnʌf tə si ɪliɑnɝz ən sɑldəiənz dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɑn nɔɹθ. ðə sintʃæn mʌst əv ɡɪvən weɪ.

With an effort, Rand turned his head perhaps a hand. Enough to see Illianers and Saldaeans driving on north. The Seanchan must have given way.

"mɔɹ!" ðə neɪm ɹɔɹd θɹu bæʃɪɹz mʌstæʃɪz, ən mɔɹ hɪmsɛlf dʒɹɑp fɹəm ə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹs nɪɹli ɑn tɑp ʌv ænɑiɛlə. ʃi lʊk dɪsɡɹʌntəld ət ðə læk ʌv ən əpɑlədʒi əz ðə mæn nɛl bɪsaɪd ɹænd, skɹʌbɪŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs. ʃi muv bæk kwɪkli ɪnʌf wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd i ɪntɛndəd tə tʃænəl, ðoʊ, pɹæktəkli baʊndɪŋ əweɪ. eɪlɪl wɑz mʌtʃ smuðɝ əbaʊt ɹaɪzɪŋ, bʌt nɑt noʊɾɪsəbli sloʊɝ ɪn stɛpɪŋ klɪɹ. ən ʃi slɪpt ə sɪlvɝ-hændəl bɛl naɪf bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ əɾ əɹ weɪst.

"Morr!" The name roared through Bashere's mustaches, and Morr himself dropped from a galloping horse nearly on top of Anaiyella. She looked disgruntled at the lack of an apology as the man knelt beside Rand, scrubbing dark hair out of his face. She moved back quickly enough when she realized he intended to channel, though, practically bounding away. Ailil was much smoother about rising, but not noticeably slower in stepping clear. And she slipped a silver-handled belt knife back into its sheath at her waist.

hilɪŋ wɑz ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli kʌmftəɹbəl. ðə flɛtʃɪŋz wɝ bɹoʊkən ɔf ən ði æɹoʊ dʒɹɔn ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ θɹu wɪð ə ʃɑɹp dʒɝk ðət bɹɔɾ ə ɡæsp tə ɹændz lɪps, bʌt ðət wɑz dʒʌs tə klɪɹ ðə weɪ. dɝɾ ən laɪtli ɛmbɛɾɪd fɹæɡməns wəd fɔl əweɪ əz flɛʃ nɪɾ ɪtsɛlf ʌp, bʌɾ oʊnli flɪn ən ə fju ʌðɝz kəd juz ðə paʊɝ tə ɹimuv wʌt wɑz dʒɹɪvən dip. ɹɛstɪŋ tu fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɹændz tʃɛst, mɔɹ kɑɾ ɪz tʌŋ bɪtwin ɪz tiθ wɪð ə fɪkst ɪkspɹɛʃən ən woʊv hilɪŋ. ðət wɑz haʊ hi ɔlweɪz dɪɾ ɪt; ɪt dɪd nɑt wɝk fəɹ hɪm, ʌðɝwaɪz. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə kɑmplɛks wivz ðət flɪn juzd. fju kəd mænədʒ ðæt, ən nʌn əz wɛl əz flɪn, soʊ fɑɹ. ðɪs wɑz sɪmpəlɝ. ɹʌfɝ. weɪvz ə hit ɹʌʃt θɹu ɹænd, stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm ɡɹʌn ən sɛn swɛt ɡʌʃɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi pɔɹ. hi kwɪvɝd vaɪələnli fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt. ə ɹoʊst ɪn ði ʌvən mʌst əv fɛl ðət weɪ.

Healing was a simple matter, if not exactly comfortable. The fletchings were broken off and the arrow drawn the rest of the way through with a sharp jerk that brought a gasp to Rand's lips, but that was just to clear the way. Dirt and lightly embedded fragments would fall away as flesh knit itself up, but only Flinn and a few others could use the Power to remove what was driven deep. Resting two fingers on Rand's chest, Morr caught his tongue between his teeth with a fixed expression and wove Healing. That was how he always did it; it did not work for him, otherwise. It was not the complex weaves that Flinn used. Few could manage that, and none as well as Flinn, so far. This was simpler. Rougher. Waves of heat rushed through Rand, strong enough to make him grunt and send sweat gushing from every pore. He quivered violently from head to foot. A roast in the oven must have felt that way.

ðə sʌɾən flʌɾ ə hiɾ ɛb sloʊli, ən ɹænd leɪ pæntɪŋ. ɪn ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd, tu. kɪl hɪm! kɪl hɪm! oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ.

The sudden flood of heat ebbed slowly, and Rand lay panting. In his head, Lews Therin panted, too. Kill him! Kill him! Over and over.

mjuɾɪŋ ðə vɔɪs tə ə feɪn bʌz, ɹænd θæŋk mɔɹ - ðə jʌŋ mæn blɪŋkt əz ɪf sɝpɹaɪzd! - ðən ɡɹæb ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn ən fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz fit. ɪɹɛkt, hi sweɪd slaɪtli. bæʃɪɹ stɑɹɾəd tə ɔfɝ ən ɑɹm, ðən bækt əweɪ əɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ. ɹænd kəd stæn əneɪɾɪd. bɛɹli. hi kəɾ əz sun əv floʊn baɪ weɪvɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz əz tʃænəld, ðoʊ. wən i tʌtʃt ɪz saɪd, hɪz ʃɝt slɪpt ɑn blʌd, jɛt ði oʊld ɹaʊn skɑɹ ən ðə nuɝ slæʃ əkɹɔs ɪt mɪɹli fɛl tɛndɝ. hæf-hild oʊnli, bʌt ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn bɛɾɝ ðən ðət sɪns i ɡɑt ðɛm.

Muting the voice to a faint buzz, Rand thanked Morr - the young man blinked as if surprised! - then grabbed the Dragon Scepter from the ground and forced himself to his feet. Erect, he swayed slightly. Bashere started to offer an arm, then backed away at a gesture. Rand could stand unaided. Barely. He could as soon have flown by waving his arms as channeled, though. When he touched his side, his shirt slipped on blood, yet the old round scar and the newer slash across it merely felt tender. Half-healed only, but they had never been better than that since he got them.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi stʌɾid ðə tu wɪmən. ænɑiɛlə mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ veɪɡli kənɡɹætʃələtɔɹi ən ɔfɝɾ ɪm ə smaɪl ðət meɪɾ ɪm wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə lɪk ɪz ɹɪst. eɪlɪl stʊd vɛɹi stʃɹeɪt, vɛɹi kul, əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæd hæpənd. hæd ðeɪ mɛn tə liv ɪm tə daɪ? əɹ tə kɪl hɪm? bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, waɪ sɛn ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ɪn ən ɹʌʃ tə tʃɛk ɑn hɪm? ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, eɪlɪl hæd dʒɹɔn əɹ naɪf wʌns ðə tɔk ə hɪm daɪɪŋ bɪɡæn.

For a moment, he studied the two women. Anaiyella murmured something vaguely congratulatory and offered him a smile that made him wonder whether she intended to lick his wrist. Ailil stood very straight, very cool, as if nothing had happened. Had they meant to leave him to die? Or to kill him? But if so, why send their armsmen charging in and rush to check on him? On the other hand, Ailil had drawn her knife once the talk of him dying began.

moʊst ə ðə sɑldəiənz ən ɪliɑnɝz wɝ ɡæləpɪŋ nɔɹθ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, pɝsuɪŋ ðə læst ə ðə sintʃæn. ən ðən wɪɹɑmɑn əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə tɔl, ɡlɔsi blæk əɾ ə sloʊ kæntɝ ðət pɪkt ʌp wən i sɔ ɹænd. hɪz ɑɹmmɪn ɹoʊɾ ɪn dʌbəl faɪl əɾ ɪz bæk.

Most of the Saldaeans and Illianers were galloping north or riding down the slope of the ridge, pursuing the last of the Seanchan. And then Weiramon appeared from the north, riding a tall, glossy black at a slow canter that picked up when he saw Rand. His armsmen rode in double file at his back.

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ðə haɪ lɔɹɾ ɪntoʊn əz i dɪsmaʊntɪd. hi stɪl simd əz klin əz i hæɾ ɪn ɪljən. bæʃɪɹ sɪmpli lʊkt ɹʌmpəld ən ə bɪt ɡɹaɪmi hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, bʌt ɡɹɛɡɹɪnz faɪnɝi wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli dɝt-steɪnd, ən slæʃt daʊn wʌn sliv bɪsaɪdz. wɪɹɑmɑn flɝɪʃt ə baʊ tə ʃeɪm ə kɪŋz kɔɹt. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ sɔ sintʃæn ədvænsɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹɪdʒ ən wɛn tə mit ðɛm. aɪ nɛvɝ səspɛktəd ðɪs ʌðɝ kʌmpəni. jə kænt noʊ haʊ ɪt wəd peɪn mi ɪf jə wɝ ɪnʒɝd."

"My Lord Dragon," the High Lord intoned as he dismounted. He still seemed as clean as he had in Illian. Bashere simply looked rumpled and a bit grimy here and there, but Gregorin's finery was decidedly dirt-stained, and slashed down one sleeve besides. Weiramon flourished a bow to shame a king's court. "Forgive me, my Lord Dragon. I thought I saw Seanchan advancing in front of the ridge and went to meet them. I never suspected this other company. You can't know how it would pain me if you were injured."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd dʒɹaɪli, ən wɪɹɑmɑn blɪŋkt. sintʃæn ədvænsɪŋ? pɝhæps. wɪɹɑmɑn wəɾ ɔlweɪz snætʃ əɾ ə tʃæns fəɹ ɡlɔɹi ɪn ðə tʃɑɹdʒ. "wʌt dɪd jə min, 'æt ðə læst,' bæʃɪɹ?"

"I think I know," Rand said dryly, and Weiramon blinked. Seanchan advancing? Perhaps. Weiramon would always snatch at a chance for glory in the charge. "What did you mean, 'at the last,' Bashere?"

"ðeɪɹ pʊlɪŋ bæk," bæʃɪɹ ɹɪplaɪd. ɪn ðə væli, faɪɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ ɪɹʌptəd fəɹ ə moʊmən əz ɪf tə ɡɪv ɪm ðə laɪ, bʌt nɪɹli tə ðə fɑɹ ɛnd.

"They're pulling back," Bashere replied. In the valley, fire and lightning erupted for a moment as if to give him the lie, but nearly to the far end.

"jɔɹ . . . skaʊts də seɪ ðeɪ ɔl də bi ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn sɛd, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz bɪɹd, ən ɡeɪv mɔɹ ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ, ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɡlæns. mɔɹ ɡɹɪn əɾ ɪm tuthəli. ɹænd hæd sin ði ɪliɑnɝ ɪn ðə θɪk ə faɪɾɪŋ hɛɾɪŋ ɪz mɛn, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmən ən leɪɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ əbaʊt wɪð waɪld əbændən, bʌɾ i flɪntʃt ət mɔɹz ɡɹɪn.

"Your . . . scouts do say they all do be retreating," Gregorin said, rubbing his beard, and gave Morr a sidelong, uncomfortable glance. Morr grinned at him toothily. Rand had seen the Illianer in the thick of fighting heading his men, shouting encouragement and laying his sword about with wild abandon, but he flinched at Morr's grin.

dʒɛdwɪn stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp ðɛn, liɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs kɛɹləsli, ɪnsələnli. hi ɔlmoʊst snɪɹɾ ət bæʃɪɹ ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, fɹaʊn ət wɪɹɑmɑn əz ɪf ɔlɹɛɾi noʊɪŋ ðə mænz blʌndɝ, ən aɪɾ eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə əz ðoʊ hi maɪt pɪntʃ ðɛm. ðə tu wɪmən dʒɹu bæk fɹəm ɪm heɪstəli, bʌt ðɛn, soʊ dɪd ðə mɛn ɪksɛp fəɹ bæʃɪɹ. ivən mɔɹ. dʒɛdwɪnz səlut tə ɹænd wɑz ə kæʒəwəl tæp ə fɪs tə tʃɛst. "aɪ sɛn skaʊts aʊɾ əz sun əz aɪ sɔ ðɪs lɑt wɑz dʌn. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɹi mɔɹ kɑləmz ɪnsaɪd tɛn maɪlz."

Gedwyn strode up then, leading his horse carelessly, insolently. He almost sneered at Bashere and Gregorin, frowned at Weiramon as if already knowing the man's blunder, and eyed Ailil and Anaiyella as though he might pinch them. The two women drew back from him hastily, but then, so did the men except for Bashere. Even Morr. Gedwyn's salute to Rand was a casual tap of fist to chest. "I sent scouts out as soon as I saw this lot was done. There are three more columns inside ten miles."

"ɔl hɛɾəd wɛst," bæʃɪɹ pʊɾ ɪn kwaɪətli, bʌɾ i lʊkt ət dʒɛdwɪn ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə slaɪs stoʊn. "juv dʌn ɪt," hi toʊld ɹænd. "ðeɪɹ ɔl fɔlɪŋ bæk. aɪ daʊt ðəl stɑp ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. kæmpeɪnz doʊn ɔlweɪz ɛnd wɪð ə ɡɹæn mɑɹtʃ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ən ðɪs wʌn ɪz fɪnɪʃt."

"All headed west," Bashere put in quietly, but he looked at Gedwyn sharp enough to slice stone. "You've done it," he told Rand. "They're all falling back. I doubt they'll stop short of Ebou Dar. Campaigns don't always end with a grand march into the city, and this one is finished."

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli - əɹ pɝhæps nɑt - wɪɹɑmɑn bɪɡæn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ fəɹ ən ədvæns, tə "teɪk ɛbu dɑɹ fəɹ ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ," əz i pʊɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sɝɾənli ə ʃɑk tə hɪɹ dʒɛdwɪn seɪ hi wəd nɑt maɪn teɪkɪŋ ə fju mɔɹ swaɪps ət ðiz sintʃæn ən i sɝɾənli wəd nɑt maɪn siɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ. ivən eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə æɾəd ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv "pʊɾɪŋ ən ɛn tə ðə sintʃæn wʌns ən fəɹ ɔl," ðoʊ eɪlɪl dɪɾ æd ðət ʃi wəɾ əz sun laɪk tə əvɔɪd hævɪŋ tə ɹɪtɝn tə fɪnɪʃ. ʃi wɑz kwaɪt ʃʊɹ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wəɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn əɹ kʌmpəni fəɹ ɪt. ðəɾ ɪn ə toʊn əz kul ən dʒɹaɪ əz naɪɾ ɪn ði il weɪst.

Surprisingly - or perhaps not - Weiramon began arguing for an advance, to "take Ebou Dar for the glory of the Lord of the Morning," as he put it, but it was certainly a shock to hear Gedwyn say he would not mind taking a few more swipes at these Seanchan and he certainly would not mind seeing Ebou Dar. Even Ailil and Anaiyella added their voices in favor of "putting an end to the Seanchan once and for all," though Ailil did add that she would as soon like to avoid having to return to finish. She was quite sure the Lord Dragon would insist on her company for it. That in a tone as cool and dry as night in the Aiel Waste.

oʊnli bæʃɪɹ ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn spoʊk fəɹ tɝnɪŋ bæk, ən ɹeɪz ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪnkɹisɪŋli əz ɹænd stʊd saɪlənt. saɪlən ən stɛɹɪŋ wɛst. təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ.

Only Bashere and Gregorin spoke for turning back, and raise their voices they did increasingly as Rand stood silent. Silent and staring west. Toward Ebou Dar.

"wi dɪd də wʌt wi keɪm fɔɹ," ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ɪnsɪstəd. "laɪts mɝsi, dʒju θɪŋk tə teɪk ɛbu dɑɹ ɪtsɛlf?"

"We did do what we came for," Gregorin insisted. "Light's mercy, do you think to take Ebou Dar itself?"

teɪk ɛbu dɑɹ, ɹænd θɔt. waɪ nɑt? noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɪkspɛk ðæt. ə toʊɾəl sɝpɹaɪz, fəɹ ðə sintʃæn ən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls.

Take Ebou Dar, Rand thought. Why not? No one would expect that. A total surprise, for the Seanchan and everybody else.

"taɪmz ɑɹ, jə siz ði ædvæntɪdʒ ən ɹaɪɾ ɑn," bæʃɪɹ ɡɹaʊld. "ʌðɝ taɪmz, jə teɪk jəɹ wɪnɪŋz ən ɡoʊ hoʊm. aɪ seɪ ɪts taɪm tə ɡoʊ hoʊm."

"Times are, you seize the advantage and ride on," Bashere growled. "Other times, you take your winnings and go home. I say it's time to go home."

aɪ wəd nɑt maɪn jə ɪn maɪ hɛd, luz θɝɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɔlmoʊst seɪn, ɪf jə wɝ nɑt soʊ klɪɹli mæd.

I would not mind you in my head, Lews Therin said, sounding almost sane, if you were not so clearly mad.

ɛbu dɑɹ. ɹænd taɪɾənd ɪz hæn ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ, ən luz θɝɪn kækəld.

Ebou Dar. Rand tightened his hand on the Dragon Scepter, and Lews Therin cackled.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ


CHAPTER 24

eɪ taɪm fəɹ aɪɝn


A Time for Iron

əɾəzən liɡz ist ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, ɹeɪkən ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə klaʊd-stʃɹik sʌnɹaɪz tə læn ɪn ə lɔŋ pæstʃɝ mɑɹkt əz ðə flaɪɝz' fil baɪ kʌlɝd stʃɹimɝz ɑn tɔl poʊlz. ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæsəz hæd bɪn tʃɹæmpəld ən skɔɹd deɪz sɪns. ɔl ə ðə kɹitʃɝz' ɡɹeɪs ɪn ði ɛɹ wɑz lɔst əz sun əz ðɛɹ klɔz tʌtʃt ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ə lʌmbɝɪŋ ɹʌn, lɛðɝi pɪnjənz θɝɾi peɪsɪz əɹ mɔɹ waɪd hɛl haɪ əz ɪf ði ænəməl wɑntəd tə swip ɪtsɛlf bæk ʌpwɝd. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl bjuɾi, iðɝ, ɪn ðə ɹeɪkən ðət ɹæn ɔkwɝdli daʊn ðə fil biɾɪŋ ɹɪbd wɪŋz, flaɪɝz kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ðə sæɾəl əz ɪf tə pʊl ðə bist ʌp baɪ meɪn fɔɹs, ɹæn ɑn əntɪl ət læs ðeɪ stʌmbəld ɪndə ði ɛɹ, wɪŋtəps bɛɹli klɪɹɪŋ ðə tɑps ə ði ɑləv tʃɹiz ət ði ɛn ə ðə fild. oʊnli əz ðeɪ ɡeɪn haɪɾ ən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə sʌn, sɔɹd təwɔɹd ðə klaʊdz, dɪd ðə ɹeɪkən ɹɪɡeɪn dɪɡnəfaɪd ɡɹænduɹ. flaɪɝz u lændəd dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə dɪsmaʊnt. waɪl ə ɡɹaʊnlɪŋ hɛld ə bæskəɾ ʌp fəɹ ðə ɹeɪkən tə ɡʌlp hoʊl ʃɹɪvəl fɹuts baɪ ðə dʌbəl-hændfʊl əɾ ə taɪm, wʌn ə ðə flaɪɝz wəd hæn daʊn ðɛɹ skaʊɾɪŋ ɹipɔɹt tə ə stɪl mɔɹ sinjɝ ɡɹaʊnlɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝ bɛn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd tə ɹəsiv nu ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm ə flaɪɝ tu sinjɝ tə hændəl ɹeɪnz pɝsənəli vɛɹi ɔfən. ɔlmoʊs ðət kwɪkli æftɝ kʌmɪŋ tə ə hɔlt, ðə kɹitʃɝ wɑz ɹeɪn ɝaʊn tə wɑɾəl oʊvɝ tə wɛɹ fɔɹ əɹ faɪv ʌðɝz weɪɾəd ðɛɹ tɝn tə meɪk ðət lɔŋ, ənɡeɪnli ɹʌn tə ðə skaɪ.

Adozen leagues east of Ebou Dar, raken glided in out of the cloud-streaked sunrise to land in a long pasture marked as the fliers' field by colored streamers on tall poles. The brown grasses had been trampled and scored days since. All of the creatures' grace in the air was lost as soon as their claws touched the ground in a lumbering run, leathery pinions thirty paces or more wide held high as if the animal wanted to sweep itself back upward. There was little beauty, either, in the raken that ran awkwardly down the field beating ribbed wings, fliers crouching in the saddle as if to pull the beast up by main force, ran on until at last they stumbled into the air, wingtips barely clearing the tops of the olive trees at the end of the field. Only as they gained height and turned toward the sun, soared toward the clouds, did the raken regain dignified grandeur. Fliers who landed did not bother to dismount. While a groundling held a basket up for the raken to gulp whole shriveled fruits by the double-handful at a time, one of the fliers would hand down their scouting report to a still more senior groundling, and the other bent on the other side to receive new orders from a flier too senior to handle reins personally very often. Almost that quickly after coming to a halt, the creature was reined around to waddle over to where four or five others waited their turn to make that long, ungainly run to the sky.

əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn, dɑdʒɪŋ bɪtwin muvɪŋ fɔɹmeɪʃənz ə kævəlɹi ən ɪnfəntʃɹi, mɛsənʒɝz kæɹid ðə skaʊɾɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts tə ðə hjudʒ ɹɛd-bænɝd kəmæn tɛnt. ðəɹ wɝ hɔɾi tæɹɑbənɝ lænsɝz ən stɑləɾ ɑmɑdɪʃən pɪkmɛn ɪn wɛl-ɔɹɾɝd skwɛɹz, bɹɛstpleɪts stʃɹaɪp hɔɹɪzɑntəli ɪn ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə ɹɛdʒəməns ðeɪ wɝ ətætʃt tə. ɔltɑɹən laɪt hɔɹs ɪn dɪsɔɹɾɝd bʌntʃəz meɪd ðɛɹ maʊns pɹæns, veɪn ə ðə ɹɛd slæʃɪz kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə mɑɹkɪŋz ɛniwʌn ɛls wɔɹ. ði ɔltɑɹənz dɪd nɑt noʊ ðoʊz ɪndəkeɪɾəd ɪɹɛɡjəlɝz ə daʊtfəl ɹilaɪəbɪləɾi. əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz, neɪmd ɹɛdʒəməns wɪð pɹaʊɾ ɑnɝz wɝ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd, fɹəm ɛvɹi kɔɹnɝ ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ, peɪl-aɪd mɛn fɹəm ælkəm, hʌni-bɹaʊn mɛn fɹəm ɑn, mɛn blæk əz koʊl fɹəm kaʊil ən dælənʃɝ. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹɑtʃɹm ɑn ðɛɹ sɪnwəs bɹɑnz-skeɪl maʊns ðət meɪd hɔɹsəz wɪkɝ ən dæns ɪn fɹaɪt, ən ivən ə fju mɔɹɑtɡɹoʊm wɪð ðɛɹ skwɑt, bik-maʊð tʃɑɹdʒəz, bʌt wʌn θɪŋ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz əkʌmpəniɾ ə sintʃæn ɑɹmi wɑz kənspɪkjuəs baɪ ɪɾ æbsəns. ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn wɝ stɪl ɪn ðɛɹ tɛns. kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl kɛnɝ mɪɹaɪ θɔɾ ə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn ə ɡɹeɪt dil.

At a dead run, dodging between moving formations of cavalry and infantry, messengers carried the scouting reports to the huge red-bannered command tent. There were haughty Taraboner lancers and stolid Amadician pikemen in well-ordered squares, breastplates striped horizontally in the colors of the regiments they were attached to. Altaran light horse in disordered bunches made their mounts prance, vain of the red slashes crisscrossing their chests, so different from the markings anyone else wore. The Altarans did not know those indicated irregulars of doubtful reliability. Among the Seanchan soldiers, named regiments with proud honors were represented, from every corner of the Empire, pale-eyed men from Alqam, honey-brown men from N'Kon, men black as coal from Khoweal and Dalenshar. There were morat'torm on their sinuous bronze-scaled mounts that made horses whicker and dance in fright, and even a few morat'grolm with their squat, beak-mouthed charges, but one thing that always accompanied a Seanchan army was conspicuous by it absence. The sul'dam and damane were still in their tents. Captain-General Kennar Miraj thought of sul'dam and damane a great deal.

fɹəm ɪz siɾ ɑn ðə deɪz i kəd si ðə mæp teɪbəl klɪɹli, wɛɹ hɛlmɔɪtləs ʌndɝ-lutɛnəns tʃɛk ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ən pleɪs mɑɹkɝz tə ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə fɔɹsɪz ɪn ðə fild. ə smɔl peɪpɝ bænɝ stʊɾ əbʌv itʃ mɑɹkɝ, ɪŋk sɪmbəlz ɡɪvɪŋ ðə saɪz ən kɑmpəzɪʃən ə ðə fɔɹs. faɪndɪŋ disən mæps ɪn ðiz lænz wɑz nɛks tə ɪmpɑsəbəl, bʌt ðə mæp kɑpiɾ ətɑp ðə lɑɹdʒ teɪbəl wɑz səfɪʃənt. ən wɝiɪŋ, ɪn wʌɾ ɪt toʊl hɪm. blæk dɪsks fəɹ aʊtpoʊsts oʊvɝɹʌn əɹ dɪspɝst. fɑɹ tu mɛni ʌv ðoʊz, dɑɾɪŋ ðə hoʊl istɝn hæf ə ðə vɛnɪɹ ɹeɪnʒ. ɹɛd wɛdʒəz, fəɹ kəmænz ɑn ðə muv, mɑɹk ðə wɛstɝn ɛn əz θɪkli, ɔl pɔɪntəd bæk təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. ən skæɾɝd əmʌŋ ðə blæk dɪsks, sɛvəntin stɑɹk waɪt. əz i wɑtʃt, ə jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ ɪn ðə bɹaʊn-ænd-blæk ʌv ə mɔɹɑtʃɹm kɛɹfəli pleɪst ən eɪtinθ. ɛnəmi fɔɹsɪz. ə fju maɪt bi ðə seɪm ɡɹup sin twaɪs, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ðeɪ wɝ mʌtʃ tu fɑɹ əpɑɹt, ðə taɪmɪŋ ə ðə saɪɾɪŋz ɹɔŋ.

From his seat on the dais he could see the map table clearly, where helmetless under-lieutenants checked the reports and placed markers to represent the forces in the field. A small paper banner stood above each marker, inked symbols giving the size and composition of the force. Finding decent maps in these lands was next to impossible, but the map copied atop the large table was sufficient. And worrying, in what it told him. Black discs for outposts overrun or dispersed. Far too many of those, dotting the whole eastern half of the Venir range. Red wedges, for commands on the move, marked the western end as thickly, all pointed back toward Ebou Dar. And scattered among the black discs, seventeen stark white. As he watched, a young officer in the brown-and-black of a morat'torm carefully placed an eighteenth. Enemy forces. A few might be the same group seen twice, but for the most part they were much too far apart, the timing of the sightings wrong.

əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz ə ðə tɛnt, klɝks ɪn pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊts, mɑɹkt oʊnli wɪð ɪnsɪɡniə ʌv ɹæŋk əmʌŋ klɝks ɑn ðə waɪd kɑlɝz, weɪɾəd ət ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəlz, pɛnz ɪn hænd, fəɹ mɪɹaɪ tə ɪʃu ɔɹɾɝz ðət ðeɪ wəd kɑpi aʊt fəɹ dɪstʃɹəbjuʃən. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən wʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz i kʊd. ðəɹ wɝ əz mɛni əz naɪnti θaʊzən ɛnəmi soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðə maʊntənz, nɪɹli twaɪs wʌɾ i kəd mʌstɝ hɪɹ ivən wɪð ðə neɪɾɪv lɛviz. tu mɛni fəɹ bɪlif, ɪksɛp ðət skaʊts dɪd nɑt laɪ; laɪɝz hæd ðɛɹ θɹoʊts slɪt baɪ ðɛɹ fɛloʊz. tu mɛni, spɹɪŋɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊn laɪk tʃɹæp-wɝmz ɪn ðə sɛn tʃjɔɹ. ət lis ðeɪ hæɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ə maʊntən jɛt tə kʌvɝ ɪf ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə θɹɛɾən ɛbu dɑɹ. ɔlmoʊs tu hʌnʒɹəd, fəɹ ðə waɪt dɪsks fɑɹðəst ist. ən hɪl kʌntʃɹi æftɝ ðət fəɹ ənʌðɝ hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz. ʃʊɹli ði ɛnəmi dʒɛnɝəl kəd nɑt min tə lɛɾ ɪz dɪspɝs fɔɹsɪz bi kənfɹʌntəd wʌn baɪ wʌn. ɡæðɝɪŋ əm təɡɛðɝ wəd teɪk mɔɹ taɪm. taɪm əloʊn wɑz ɑn ɪz saɪd, ɹaɪt ðɛn.

Along the walls of the tent, clerks in plain brown coats, marked only with insignia of rank among clerks on the wide collars, waited at their writing tables, pens in hand, for Miraj to issue orders that they would copy out for distribution. He had already given what orders he could. There were as many as ninety thousand enemy soldiers in the mountains, nearly twice what he could muster here even with the native levies. Too many for belief, except that scouts did not lie; liars had their throats slit by their fellows. Too many, springing out of the ground like trap-worms in the Sen T'jore. At least they had a hundred miles of mountain yet to cover if they intended to threaten Ebou Dar. Almost two hundred, for the white discs farthest east. And hill country after that for another hundred miles. Surely the enemy general could not mean to let his dispersed forces be confronted one by one. Gathering them together would take more time. Time alone was on his side, right then.

ði ɛntʃɹi flæps ə ðə tɛn swɛpt oʊpən, ən ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪn, blæk hɛɹ ə pɹaʊd kɹɛst spɪlɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk, pliɾɪd snoʊ-waɪt ɡaʊn ən ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd oʊvɝ-ɹoʊb sʌmhaʊ əntʌtʃt baɪ ðə mʌɾ aʊtsaɪd. hi hæd θɔɾ əɹ stɪl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ; ʃi mʌst əv floʊn aʊt baɪ tɔɹeɪkən. ʃi wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ ə smɔl ɑntʊɹɑʒ, fəɹ hɝ. ə pɛɹ ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz wɪð blæk tæsəlz ɑn ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls hɛl ðə tɛntflæps, ən mɔɹ wɝ vɪzəbəl aʊtsaɪd, stoʊn-feɪs mɛn ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin. ði ɛmbɑɾimənt ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. ivən ðə blʌd tʊk noʊɾ ə ðɛm. sjuɹɔθ seɪl pæst əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əz mʌtʃ sɝvəns əz ðə lʌʃli bɑɾid dækoʊvæl ɪn slɪpɝz ən ə nɪɹli tʃɹænspɛɹənt waɪt ɹoʊb, hɝ hʌni-jɛloʊ hɛɹ ɪn ə mʌltətuɾ ə θɪn bɹeɪdz, hu kæɹid ðə haɪ leɪɾiz ɡɪldɪd ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk ə mik tu peɪsɪz bɪhaɪnd. sjuɹɔθs vɔɪs ə ðə blʌd, ælwɪn, ə ɡlaʊɝɪŋ wʊmən ɪn ɡɹin ɹoʊbz wɪð ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd ʃeɪvd ən ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ə hɝ peɪl bɹaʊn hɛɹ ɪn ə səvɪɹ bɹeɪd, fɑloʊd kloʊs ɑn əɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz hilz. əz mɪɹaɪ stɛp daʊn fɹəm ðə deɪz, hi ɹilaɪzd wɪð ʃɑk ðət ðə sɛkən dækoʊvæl bɪhaɪn sjuɹɔθ, ʃɔɹɾ ən dɑɹk-hɛɹɾ ən slɪm ɪn əɹ daɪəfənəs ɹoʊb, wɑz deɪmeɪn! ə deɪmeɪn ɡɑɹbd əz pɹɑpɝɾi wɑz ənhɝɾ ʌv, bʌɾ ɑɾɝ stɪl, ɪt wɑz ælwɪn u lɛɾ əɹ baɪ ði æɾəm!

The entry flaps of the tent swept open, and the High Lady Suroth glided in, black hair a proud crest spilling down her back, pleated snow-white gown and richly embroidered over-robe somehow untouched by the mud outside. He had thought her still in Ebou Dar; she must have flown out by to'raken. She was accompanied by a small entourage, for her. A pair of Deathwatch Guards with black tassels on their sword hilts held the tentflaps, and more were visible outside, stone-faced men in red-and-green. The embodiment of the Empress, might she live forever. Even the Blood took note of them. Suroth sailed past as if they were as much servants as the lushly bodied da'covale in slippers and a nearly transparent white robe, her honey-yellow hair in a multitude of thin braids, who carried the High Lady's gilded writing desk a meek two paces behind. Suroth's Voice of the Blood, Alwhin, a glowering woman in green robes with the left side of her head shaved and the remainder of her pale brown hair in a severe braid, followed close on her mistress's heels. As Miraj stepped down from the dais, he realized with shock that the second da'covale behind Suroth, short and dark-haired and slim in her diaphanous robe, was damane! A damane garbed as property was unheard of, but odder still, it was Alwhin who led her by the a'dam!

hi lɛt nʌn ə hɪz əmeɪzmənt ʃoʊ əz i wɛn tə wʌn ni, mɝmɝɪŋ, "ðə laɪt bi əpɑn ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ. ɔl ɑnɝ tə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ." ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn ðə kænvəs ɡɹaʊndklɔθ, aɪz daʊn. mɪɹaɪ wɑz ə ðə blʌd, ɪf tu loʊ tə ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ə hɪz skælp laɪk sjuɹɔθ. oʊnli ðə neɪlz ə hɪz lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz wɝ lækɝd. mʌtʃ tu loʊ tə ɹɛdʒɪstɝ sɝpɹaɪz ɪf ə haɪ leɪɾi əlaʊɾ əɹ vɔɪs tə kəntɪnju æktɪŋ əz sʌldəm æftɝ biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə ðə sɔɪhɪn. stʃɹeɪnʒ taɪmz ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ lænd, wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɔkt ən mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɹæn waɪl tə kɪl ən ɛnslɑv wɛɹ ðeɪ wʊd.

He let none of his amazement show as he went to one knee, murmuring, "The Light be upon the High Lady Suroth. All honor to the High Lady Suroth." Everyone else prostrated themselves on the canvas groundcloth, eyes down. Miraj was of the Blood, if too low to shave the sides of his scalp like Suroth. Only the nails of his little fingers were lacquered. Much too low to register surprise if a High Lady allowed her Voice to continue acting as sul'dam after being raised to the so'jhin. Strange times in a strange land, where the Dragon Reborn walked and marath'damane ran wild to kill and enslave where they would.

sjuɹɔθ bɛɹli ɡlænst əɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə stʌɾi ðə mæp teɪbəl, ən ɪf əɹ blæk aɪz taɪɾənd ət wʌt ʃi sɔ, ʃi hæd kɑz. ʌndɝ hɝ, ðə heɪlin hæd dʌn fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən hæd bɪn dʒɹimd, ɹikleɪmɪŋ ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛtʃəz ə ðə stoʊlən lænz. ɔl ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛn fəɹ wɑz tə skaʊt ðə weɪ, ən æftɝ fɑlm, səm hæd θɔɾ ivən ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl. ʃi dʒɹʌm fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪɹɪɾəbli, ðə lɔŋ blu-lækɝd fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɑn ðə fɝs tu klɪkɪŋ. kəntɪnjud səksɛs, ən ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ʃeɪv əɹ hɛɾ ɪntaɪɝli ən peɪn ə θɝd neɪl ɑn itʃ hænd. ədɑpʃən ɪndə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli wɑz nɑɾ ənhɝɾ ə fəɹ ətʃivməns soʊ ɡɹeɪt. ən ɪf ʃi stɛp tu fɑɹ, oʊvɝstɛpt, ʃi maɪt faɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz klɪpt ən hɝsɛlf stʌft ɪndə ə fɪlmi ɹoʊb tə sɝv wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ɪf nɑt soʊl tə ə fɑɹmɝ tə hɛlp tɪl ɪz filz, əɹ swɛɾ ɪn ə wɛɹhaʊs. ət wɝst, mɪɹaɪ wəɾ oʊnli hæv tə oʊpən ɪz oʊn veɪnz.

Suroth barely glanced at him before turning to study the map table, and if her black eyes tightened at what she saw, she had cause. Under her, the Hailene had done far more than had been dreamed, reclaiming great stretches of the stolen lands. All they had been sent for was to scout the way, and after Falme, some had thought even that impossible. She drummed fingers on the table irritably, the long blue-lacquered fingernails on the first two clicking. Continued success, and she might be able to shave her head entirely and paint a third nail on each hand. Adoption into the Imperial family was not unheard of for achievements so great. And if she stepped too far, overstepped, she might find her fingernails clipped and herself stuffed into a filmy robe to serve one of the Blood, if not sold to a farmer to help till his fields, or sweat in a warehouse. At worst, Miraj would only have to open his own veins.

hi kəntɪnjud tə wɑtʃ sjuɹɔθ ɪn peɪʃən saɪləns, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ə skaʊt lutɛnənt, mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən, bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌd, ən i kəd nɑt hɛlp biɪŋ əwɛɹ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ə skaʊt lɪvd əɹ daɪd baɪ wʌɾ i sɔ əɹ dɪd nɑt, ən soʊ dɪɾ ʌðɝz. ðə mɛn laɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɝaʊn ðə tɛnt; səm hɑɹdli sim tə bɹið. sjuɹɔθ ʃʊɾə teɪkən ɪm əsaɪɾ ən lɛɾ əm kəntɪnju wɪð ðɛɹ wɝk. ə mɛsənʒɝ wɑz biɪŋ tɝn bæk baɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz ət ði ɛntʃɹəns. haʊ daɪɹ wɑz ðə mɛsədʒ ðət ðə wʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ pæs dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz?

He continued to watch Suroth in patient silence, but he had been a scout lieutenant, morat'raken, before being raised to the Blood, and he could not help being aware of everything around him. A scout lived or died by what he saw or did not, and so did others. The men lying on their faces around the tent; some hardly seemed to breathe. Suroth should have taken him aside and let them continue with their work. A messenger was being turned back by the soldiers at the entrance. How dire was the message that the woman tried to push past Deathwatch Guards?

ðə dækoʊvæl wɪð ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz kɑɾ ɪz aɪ. skaʊlz flæʃt əkɹɔs əɹ pɹɪɾi dɑlz feɪs, nɛvɝ pʊʃt daʊn fəɹ mɔɹ ðən moʊməns. pɹɑpɝɾi ʃoʊɪŋ æŋɡɝ? ən ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. hɪz ɡeɪz flɪkɝd tə ðə deɪmeɪn, hu stʊd wɪð əɹ hɛd daʊn bʌt stɪl lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɪð kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. bɹaʊn-aɪd dækoʊvæl ən peɪl-aɪd deɪmeɪn lʊkt əbaʊɾ əz dɪfɹən əz tu wɪmən kʊd, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm. sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. stʃɹeɪnʒ. hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd haʊ oʊld iðɝ wɑz.

The da'covale with the writing desk in her arms caught his eye. Scowls flashed across her pretty doll's face, never pushed down for more than moments. Property showing anger? And there was something else. His gaze flickered to the damane, who stood with her head down but still looked around with curiosity. Brown-eyed da'covale and pale-eyed damane looked about as different as two women could, yet there was something about them. Something in their faces. Strange. He could not have said how old either was.

kwɪk əz ɪz ɡlæns wɑz, ælwɪn noʊɾəst. wɪð ə twɪtʃ ə ði æɾəmz sɪlvɝi liʃ ʃi pʊt ðə deɪmeɪn feɪsdaʊn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊndklɔθ. snæpɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə kænvəs wɪð ðə hænd nɑɾ ɛnkʌmbɝd baɪ ði æɾəmz bɹeɪslət, ðən ɡɹɪməst wən ðə hʌni-hɛɹd dækoʊvæl dɪd nɑt muv. "daʊn, liɑnʒɹɪn!" ʃi hɪst ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. wɪð ə ɡlɛɹ fəɹ ælwɪn - ə ɡlɛɹ! - ðə dækoʊvæl sæŋk tə hɝ niz, fitʃɝz peɪntəd wɪð sʌlkənəs.

Quick as his glance was, Alwhin noticed. With a twitch of the a'dam's silvery leash she put the damane facedown on the groundcloth. Snapping her fingers, she pointed to the canvas with the hand not encumbered by the a'dam's bracelet, then grimaced when the honey-haired da'covale did not move. "Down, Liandrin!" she hissed almost under her breath. With a glare for Alwhin - a glare! - the da'covale sank to her knees, features painted with sulkiness.

moʊst stʃɹeɪnʒ. bʌt hɑɹdli ɪmpɔɹɾənt. feɪs ɪmpæsɪv, ən ʌðɝwaɪz bɝstɪŋ wɪð ɪmpeɪʃəns, hi weɪɾəd. ɪmpeɪʃəns ən noʊ lɪɾəl dɪskʌmfɝt. hi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌɾ æftɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ fɪfti maɪlz ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl naɪt wɪð θɹi æɹoʊz ɪn ɪm tə bɹɪŋ wɝɾ ʌv ə ɹɛbəl ɑɹmi mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn sindɑɹ ɪtsɛlf, ən ɪz bæk stɪl peɪn hɪm.

Most strange. But hardly important. Face impassive, and otherwise bursting with impatience, he waited. Impatience and no little discomfort. He had been raised to the Blood after riding fifty miles in a single night with three arrows in him to bring word of a rebel army marching on Seandar itself, and his back still pained him.

faɪnəli, sjuɹɔθ tɝn fɹəm ðə mæp teɪbəl. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ɪm liv tə ɹaɪz, mʌtʃ lɛs ɛmbɹeɪs ɪm əz wʌn ə ðə blʌd. nɑt ðəɾ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðæt. hi wɑz fɑɹ bɪniθ hɝ. "ju ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə mɑɹtʃ?" ʃi dɪmændəd kɝtli. ət list ʃi dɪd nɑt spik tə hɪm θɹu hɝ vɔɪs. bɪfɔɹ soʊ mɛni ʌv ɪz ɔfəsɝz, ðə ʃeɪm wʊɾə pʊɾ ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn fəɹ mʌnθs ɪf nɑt jɪɹz.

Finally, Suroth turned from the map table. She did not give him leave to rise, much less embrace him as one of the Blood. Not that he had expected that. He was far beneath her. "You are ready to march?" she demanded curtly. At least she did not speak to him through her Voice. Before so many of his officers, the shame would have put his eyes on the ground for months if not years.

"aɪ wɪl bi, sjuɹɔθ," hi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, miɾɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪz. hi wɑz ə ðə blʌd, haʊɛvɝ loʊ. "ðeɪ kænɑt kɑmbaɪn ɪn fjuɝ ðən tɛn deɪz, wɪð ət list ənʌðɝ tɛn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən ɛɡzɪt ðə maʊntənz. wɛl bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, aɪ - "

"I will be, Suroth," he replied calmly, meeting her gaze. He was of the Blood, however low. "They cannot combine in fewer than ten days, with at least another ten before they can exit the mountains. Well before then, I - "

"ðeɪ kəd bi hɪɹ təmɑɹoʊ," ʃi snæpt. "tədeɪ! ɪf ðeɪ kʌm, mɪɹaɪ, ðəl kʌm baɪ ði eɪntʃən ɑɹɾ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ, ən ɪt simz vɛɹi pɑsəbəl ðət ðəl kʌm."

"They could be here tomorrow," she snapped. "Today! If they come, Miraj, they will come by the ancient art of Traveling, and it seems very possible that they will come."

hi hɝd mɛn ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɹistʃɹeɪn ðɛmsɛlvz. sjuɹɔθ lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝ ɪmoʊʃənz ən bæbəld ə lɛdʒənz? "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" ðə wɝdz pɑpt aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp ðɛm.

He heard men shifting on their bellies before they could restrain themselves. Suroth lost control of her emotions and babbled of legends? "Are you certain?" The words popped out of his mouth before he could stop them.

hi hæɾ oʊnli θɔt ʃi hæd lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl bɪfɔɹ. hɝ aɪz bleɪzd. ʃi ɡɹɪp ði ɛdʒəz ə hɝ flaʊɝ-wɝkt ɹoʊb, waɪt-nʌkəld, ən əɹ hænz ʃʊk. "du jə kwɛstʃən mi?" ʃi snɑɹəld ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "səfaɪs ɪt ðəɾ aɪ hæv maɪ sɔɹsəz ʌv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən." ən wɑz fjʊɹiəs wɪð əm əz mʌtʃ əz wɪð hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd. "ɪf ðeɪ kʌm, ðəɹ wɪl bi pɝhæps əz mɛni əz fɪfti ʌv ðiz ɡɹænli neɪmd æʃəmən, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən faɪv əɹ sɪks θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz. ɪt simz ðəɹ əv bɪn noʊ mɔɹ sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, wʌtɛvɝ ðə flaɪɝz seɪ."

He had only thought she had lost control before. Her eyes blazed. She gripped the edges of her flower-worked robe, white-knuckled, and her hands shook. "Do you question me?" she snarled incredulously. "Suffice it that I have my sources of information." And was furious with them as much as with him, he realized. "If they come, there will be perhaps as many as fifty of these grandly named Asha'man, but no more than five or six thousand soldiers. It seems there have been no more since the beginning, whatever the fliers say."

mɪɹaɪ nɑɾəd sloʊli. faɪv θaʊzən mɛn, muvd əbaʊɾ ɪn səm weɪ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, wəɾ ɪkspleɪn ə ɡɹeɪt dil. wʌt wɝ əɹ sɔɹsəz, ðət ʃi nu nʌmbɝz soʊ pɹɪsaɪsli? hi wɑz nɑt ful ɪnʌf tə æsk. ʃi sɝɾənli hæd lɪsənɝz ən sikɝz ɪn əɹ sɝvəs. wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, tu. fɪfti æʃəmən. ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə ʌv ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə spɪɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst. ɹumɝ kleɪm ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ ɡæðɝd fɹəm ɛvɹi neɪʃən baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðɪs ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd ðəɹ kəd bi soʊ mɛni. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kəd tʃænəl, ɪt wɑz sɛd. ðət maɪt bi tʃɹu, bʌɾ i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Miraj nodded slowly. Five thousand men, moved about in some way with the One Power, would explain a great deal. What were her sources, that she knew numbers so precisely? He was not fool enough to ask. She certainly had Listeners and Seekers in her service. Watching her, too. Fifty Asha'man. The very idea of a man channeling made him want to spit in disgust. Rumor claimed they were being gathered from every nation by the Dragon Reborn, this Rand al'Thor, but he had never expected there could be so many. The Dragon Reborn could channel, it was said. That might be true, but he was the Dragon Reborn.

ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən hæd bɪn noʊn ɪn sintʃæn ivən bɪfɔɹ luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ bɪɡæn ðə kənsɑlədeɪʃən. ɪn kɝʌptɪd fɔɹm, ɪt wɑz sɛd, mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə pjʊɹ vɝʒən luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ bɹɔt. mɪɹaɪ hæd sin sɛvɹəl vɑljumz ə ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl pɹɪntəɾ ɪn ðiz lænz, ən ðeɪ wɝ kɝʌptɪd tu - nɑt wʌn mɛnʃən ɪm sɝvɪŋ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn! - bʌt ðə pɹɑfəsiz hɛl mɛnz maɪnz ən hɑɹts stɪl. mɔɹ ðən ə fju hoʊp ðə ɹɪtɝn keɪm sun, ðət ðiz lænz kəd bi ɹikleɪm bɪfɔɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən soʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kəd wɪn ðə læs bæɾəl fəɹ ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. ði ɛmpɹɛs ʃʊɹli wəd wɑn ælθɹ sɛn tə hɝ, soʊ ʃi kəd si wʌt sɔɹɾ ə mæn sɝv hɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ dɪfəkəlti wɪð ælθɹ wʌns i hæd nɛl tə hɝ. fju izəli ʃʊk ɔf ði ɑ ðeɪ fɛlt, nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, wɪð ðə θɝs tə oʊbeɪ dʒɹaɪɪŋ ðɛɹ tʌŋz. bʌɾ ɪt simd ɑbviəs ðət bʌndəlɪŋ ðə fɛloʊ ɑntu ə ʃɪp wəd bi iziɝ ɪf dɪspoʊzɪŋ ə ði æʃəmən - ðeɪ hæd tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv, sɝɾənli - weɪɾəd əntɪl ælθɹ wɑz wɛl ɑn ɪz weɪ əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə sindɑɹ.

The Prophecies of the Dragon had been known in Seanchan even before Luthair Paendrag began the Consolidation. In corrupted form, it was said, much different from the pure version Luthair Paendrag brought. Miraj had seen several volumes of The Karaethon Cycle printed in these lands, and they were corrupted too - not one mentioned him serving the Crystal Throne! - but the Prophecies held men's minds and hearts still. More than a few hoped the Return came soon, that these lands could be reclaimed before Tarmon Gai'don so the Dragon Reborn could win the Last Battle for the glory of the Empress, might she live forever. The Empress surely would want al'Thor sent to her, so she could see what sort of man served her. There would be no difficulty with al'Thor once he had knelt to her. Few easily shook off the awe they felt, kneeling before the Crystal Throne, with the thirst to obey drying their tongues. But it seemed obvious that bundling the fellow onto a ship would be easier if disposing of the Asha'man - they had to be disposed of, certainly - waited until al'Thor was well on his way across the Aryth Ocean to Seandar.

wɪtʃ bɹɔɾ ɪm bæk tə ðə pɹɑbləm i hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd, hi ɹilaɪzd wɪð ən ɪnwɝd stɑɹt. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə mæn tə ʃaɪ fɹəm dɪfəkəltiz, mʌtʃ lɛs ɪɡnɔɹ əm blaɪnli, bʌt ðɪs wɑz dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni hi hæd feɪs bɪfɔɹ. hi hæd fɔɾ ɪn tu dʌzən bæɾəlz wɪð deɪmeɪn juzd ɑn boʊθ saɪdz; hi nu ðə weɪ ʌv ðɛm. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli ə mæɾɝ ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊt wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ɪkspɪɹiənst sʌldəm kəd sʌmhaʊ si wʌt deɪmeɪn əɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn dɪɾ ən deɪmeɪn wəd tɛl ði ʌðɝz, soʊ ðeɪ kəd dɪfɛn əz wɛl. kəd sʌldəm si wʌɾ ə mæn dɪd, tu? wɝs. . . .

Which brought him back to the problem he had been trying to avoid, he realized with an inward start. He was not a man to shy from difficulties, much less ignore them blindly, but this was different from any he had faced before. He had fought in two dozen battles with damane used on both sides; he knew the way of them. It was not only a matter of striking out with the Power. Experienced sul'dam could somehow see what damane or marath'damane did and damane would tell the others, so they could defend as well. Could sul'dam see what a man did, too? Worse. . . .

"ju wɪl ɹilis ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn tə mi?" hi sɛd. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, hi æɾəd, "ɪf ðəɹ stɪl sɪk, ɪɾəl bi ə ʃɔɹt faɪɾ ən blʌɾi. ɑn əɹ saɪd."

"You will release the sul'dam and damane to me?" he said. Taking a deep breath in spite of himself, he added, "If they're still sick, it will be a short fight and bloody. On our side."

wɪtʃ pɹədust ənʌðɝ stɝ əmʌŋ ðə mɛn weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ɛvɹi sɛkən ɹumɝ ɪn ðə kæmp wɑz əbaʊt wʌɾ ɪlnəs hæd kənfaɪn ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn tə ðɛɹ tɛns. ælwɪn ɹiæktəd kwaɪɾ oʊpənli, moʊst ɪmpɹɑpɝ ɪn ə sɔɪhɪn, wɪð ə fjʊɹiəs ɡlɛɹ. ðə deɪmeɪn flɪntʃt əɡɛn, ən bɪɡæn tə ʃɪvɝ wɛɹ ʃi leɪ. ɑdli, ðə hʌni-hɛɹd dækoʊvæl flɪntʃt, əz wɛl.

Which produced another stir among the men waiting on their faces. Every second rumor in the camp was about what illness had confined the sul'dam and damane to their tents. Alwhin reacted quite openly, most improper in a so'jhin, with a furious glare. The damane flinched again, and began to shiver where she lay. Oddly, the honey-haired da'covale flinched, as well.

smaɪlɪŋ, sjuɹɔθ ɡlaɪɾɪd tə wɛɹ ðə dækoʊvæl nɛlt. waɪ wəd ʃi smaɪl əɾ ə pʊɹli tʃɹeɪn sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl? ʃi bɪɡæn stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə nilɪŋ wʊmənz θɪn bɹeɪdz, ən ə sʌlən paʊɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðət ɹoʊzbʌd maʊð. ə fɔɹmɝ noʊbəlwʊmən ə ðiz lænz? sjuɹɔθs fɝst wɝdz səpɔɹɾəd ðæt, ðoʊ ɑbviəsli mɛn fəɹ hɪm. "smɔl feɪljɝz bɹɪŋ smɔl kɑsts; ɡɹeɪt feɪljɝz bɹɪŋ peɪnfəli ɡɹeɪt kɑsts. jəl əv ðə deɪmeɪn jə ɹikwaɪɝ, mɪɹaɪ. ən jəl titʃ ðiz æʃəmən ðeɪ ʃʊɾə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə nɔɹθ. jəl waɪp əm fɹəm ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ, ði æʃəmən, ðə soʊlʒɝz, ɔl ə ðɛm. tə ðə mæn. mɪɹaɪ. aɪ hæv spoʊkən."

Smiling, Suroth glided to where the da'covale knelt. Why would she smile at a poorly trained serving girl? She began stroking the kneeling woman's thin braids, and a sullen pout appeared on that rosebud mouth. A former noblewoman of these lands? Suroth's first words supported that, though obviously meant for him. "Small failures bring small costs; great failures bring painfully great costs. You will have the damane you require, Miraj. And you will teach these Asha'man they should have remained in the north. You will wipe them from the face of the earth, the Asha'man, the soldiers, all of them. To the man. Miraj. I have spoken."

"ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ, sjuɹɔθ," hi ɹɪplaɪd. "ðeɪ wɪl bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd. tə ðə mæn." ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls i kəd seɪ, naʊ. hi wɪʃt, ðoʊ, ðət ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ən ænsɝ əbaʊt wɛðɝ ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn wɝ stɪl sɪk.

"It will be as you say, Suroth," he replied. "They will be destroyed. To the man." There was nothing else he could say, now. He wished, though, that she had given him an answer about whether the sul'dam and damane were still sick.

ɹænd ɹeɪn teɪdeɪʃɝ ɝaʊnd nɪɹ ðə kɹɛst ə ðə bɛɹ, stoʊni hɪl tə wɑtʃ moʊst ə hɪz smɔl ɑɹmi spɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ʌðɝ hoʊlz ɪn ði ɛɹ. hi hɛl hɑɹd tə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪt sim tə tʃɹɛmbəl ɪn ɪz ɡɹæsp. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm, ðə ʃɑɹp pɔɪns ə ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz pɹɪkɪŋ ɪz tɛmpəlz fɛlt ət wʌns kinɝ ðən ɛvɝ ən ʌɾɝli ɹimuvd, ðə mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ tʃɪl boʊθ koʊldɝ ən bɪniθ noʊɾəs. ðə nɛvɝ-hilɪŋ wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd wɝ ə dʌl ən dɪstən eɪk. luz θɝɪn sim tə bi pæntɪŋ ɪn ənsɝɾənti. əɹ pɝhæps fɪɹ. meɪbi æftɝ kʌmɪŋ soʊ kloʊs tə dɛθ ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, hi dɪd nɑt wɑn soʊ mʌtʃ tə daɪ ɛnimɔɹ. bʌt ðɛn, hi dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz wɑnə daɪ. ði oʊnli kɑnstən ɪn ðə mæn wɑz ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə kɪl. wɪtʃ dʒʌs hæpən tə ɪnklud kɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ɔfən ɪnʌf.

Rand reined Tai'daishar around near the crest of the bare, stony hill to watch most of his small army spilling out of other holes in the air. He held hard to the True Source, so hard it seemed to tremble in his grasp. With the Power in him, the sharp points of the Crown of Swords pricking his temples felt at once keener than ever and utterly removed, the midmorning chill both colder and beneath notice. The never-healing wounds in his side were a dull and distant ache. Lews Therin seemed to be panting in uncertainty. Or perhaps fear. Maybe after coming so close to death the day before, he did not want so much to die anymore. But then, he did not always want to die. The only constant in the man was the desire to kill. Which just happened to include killing himself, often enough.

ðɛɹəl bi kɪlɪŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛnibəɾi, sun, ɹænd θɔt. laɪt, ðə læst sɪks deɪz wɝ ɪnʌf tə sɪkən ə vʌltʃɝ. hæɾ ɪɾ oʊnli bɪn sɪks deɪz? ðə dɪsɡʌs dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ hɪm, ðoʊ. hi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪt. luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ. jɛs. ɪt wɑz ə taɪm fəɹ aɪɝn hɑɹts. ən aɪɝn stʌməks, tu. hi bɛn ə moʊmən tə tʌtʃ ðə lɔŋ klɔθ-ɹæpt pækədʒ ʌndɝ ɪz stɝəp lɛðɝ. noʊ. nɑt taɪm, jɛt. meɪbi nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. ənsɝɾənti ʃɪmɝɾ əkɹɔs ðə vɔɪd, ən meɪbi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl, hi hoʊpt. ənsɝɾənti, jɛs, bʌt ði ʌðɝ hæd nɑt bɪn fɪɹ. ɪt hæd nɑt!

There'll be killing enough for anybody, soon, Rand thought. Light, the last six days were enough to sicken a vulture. Had it only been six days? The disgust did not touch him, though. He would not let it. Lews Therin did not answer. Yes. It was a time for iron hearts. And iron stomachs, too. He bent a moment to touch the long cloth-wrapped package under his stirrup leather. No. Not time, yet. Maybe not at all. Uncertainty shimmered across the Void, and maybe something else. Not at all, he hoped. Uncertainty, yes, but the other had not been fear. It had not!

hæf ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ loʊ hɪlz wɝ kʌvɝd wɪð skwɑt, nɑɹld ɑləv tʃɹiz, dæpəl baɪ ðə sʌnlaɪt, wɛɹ lænsɝz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ klɪɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ʌv wɝkɝz ɪn ðoʊz ɔɹtʃɝdz, noʊ fɑɹmhaʊs, noʊ stʃɹʌktʃɝ ʌv ɛni kaɪn ɪn saɪt. ə fju maɪlz tə ðə wɛst, ðə hɪlz wɝ dɑɹkɝ, fɔɹəstəd. lidʒənmɛn, ɪmɝdʒɪŋ ɪn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ faɪlz bɪloʊ ɹænd, fɔɹmd ʌp, tʃɹeɪl baɪ ə ɹæɡəd skwɛɹ ʌv ɪliɑnɝ vɑləntɪɹz, naʊ ɛnlɪstɪɾ ɪndə ðə lidʒən. əz sun əz ðɛɹ ɹæŋks wɝ əlaɪnd, ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ dɪfɛndɝz ən kəmpænjənz. ðə ɡɹaʊn simd moʊsli kleɪ, ən buts ən hʊvz əlaɪk skɪɾəd ɪn ðə θɪn skɪm ə mʌd. fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ðoʊ, oʊnli ə fju klaʊdz hʌŋ ɪn ðə skaɪ, waɪɾ ən klin. ðə sʌn wɑz ə peɪl jɛloʊ bɔl. ən nʌθɪŋ flu ʌp ðəɹ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə spɛɹoʊ.

Half the surrounding low hills were covered with squat, gnarled olive trees, dappled by the sunlight, where lancers already rode along the rows to make sure they were clear. There was no sign of workers in those orchards, no farmhouse, no structure of any kind in sight. A few miles to the west, the hills were darker, forested. Legionmen, emerging in trotting files below Rand, formed up, trailed by a ragged square of Illianer volunteers, now enlisted into the Legion. As soon as their ranks were aligned, they marched out of the way to make room for Defenders and Companions. The ground seemed mostly clay, and boots and hooves alike skidded in the thin skim of mud. For a wonder, though, only a few clouds hung in the sky, white and clean. The sun was a pale yellow ball. And nothing flew up there larger than a sparrow.

dæʃivə ən flɪn wɝ əmʌŋ ðə mɛn hoʊldɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz, əz wɝ ædli ən hɑpwəl, mɔɹ ən nɛɹɪʃmə. səm ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪz leɪ aʊɾ ə ɹændz saɪt bɪhaɪn ðə foʊldəd hɪlz. hi wɑntəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn θɹu əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl, ən ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju soʊlʒɝz skænɪŋ ðə skaɪ, ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊɾ u wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi aʊt skaʊɾɪŋ hɛld ə wiv. ivən dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd, ðoʊ boʊθ ɡɹɪməst oʊvɝ ɪt, əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ən ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. ɹænd θɔɾ əm noʊ lɔŋɡɝ juz tə duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ soʊ kɑmən əz hoʊldɪŋ ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ ʌðɝz tə juz.

Dashiva and Flinn were among the men holding gateways, as were Adley and Hopwil, Morr and Narishma. Some of the gateways lay out of Rand's sight behind the folded hills. He wanted everyone through as quickly as possible, and except for a few Soldiers scanning the sky, every man in a black coat who was not already out scouting held a weave. Even Gedwyn and Rochaid, though both grimaced over it, at each other and in his direction. Rand thought them no longer used to doing anything so common as holding a gateway for others to use.

bæʃɪɹ kæntɝɾ ʌp ðə sloʊp, vɛɹi mʌtʃ əɾ iz wɪð hɪmsɛlf, ən wɪð ɪz ʃɔɹt beɪ. hɪz kloʊk wɑz flʌŋ bæk dɪspaɪt ðə mɔɹnɪŋz kulnəs, nɑt soʊ koʊld əz ðə maʊntənz, bʌt stɪl wɪntɝi. hi nɑɾəd kæʒəwəli tə ænɑiɛlə ən eɪlɪl, hu ɡeɪv blik stɛɹz ɪn ɹɪtɝn. bæʃɪɹ smaɪl θɹu ðoʊz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz, laɪk daʊn-kɝvɪŋ hɔɹnz, ə nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli plɛzən smaɪl. hi hæɾ əz mɛni daʊts ə ðə wɪmən əz ɹænd dɪd. ðə wɪmən nu, əbaʊt bæʃɪɹz ɹɛzɝveɪʃənz ət list. tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɛd kwɪkli fɹəm ðə sɑldəiən, ænɑiɛlə ɹɪtɝn tə stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋz meɪn; eɪlɪl hɛld əɹ ɹeɪnz tu ɹɪdʒɪdli.

Bashere cantered up the slope, very much at ease with himself, and with his short bay. His cloak was flung back despite the morning's coolness, not so cold as the mountains, but still wintery. He nodded casually to Anaiyella and Ailil, who gave bleak stares in return. Bashere smiled through those thick mustaches, like down-curving horns, a not entirely pleasant smile. He had as many doubts of the women as Rand did. The women knew, about Bashere's reservations at least. Turning her head quickly from the Saldaean, Anaiyella returned to stroking her gelding's mane; Ailil held her reins too rigidly.

ðət pɛɹ hæd nɑt stʃɹeɪd fɑɹ fɹəm ɹænd sɪns ði ɪnsəɾənt ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ, ivən hævɪŋ ðɛɹ tɛns pɪtʃt ɪn ɪɹʃɑɾ ə hɪz ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. ɑn ə bɹaʊn-ɡɹæs hɪlsaɪɾ ɑpəzət, dɛnhɝəd ʃɪftəd tə stʌɾi ðə tu noʊbəlwɪmənz ɹɪteɪnɝz, ɝeɪd təɡɛðɝ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðən kwɪkli ɹɪtɝn tə wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd. vɛɹi laɪkli hi wɑtʃt eɪlɪl, ən meɪbi ænɑiɛlə əz wɛl, bʌɾ i wɑtʃt ɹænd wɪθaʊt daʊt. ɹænd wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ stɪl fɪɹd tə teɪk ðə bleɪm ɪf i wɑz kɪld əɹ sɪmpli wɑntəd tə si ɪt hæpən. ðə wʌn θɪŋ i wɑz sɝɾən ʌv wɑz ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd wɑn ɪm dɛd, hi wəd ɡɪv əm noʊ ɑpɝtunəɾi.

That pair had not strayed far from Rand since the incident on the ridge, even having their tents pitched in earshot of his the night before. On a brown-grass hillside opposite, Denharad shifted to study the two noblewomen's retainers, arrayed together behind him, then quickly returned to watching Rand. Very likely he watched Ailil, and maybe Anaiyella as well, but he watched Rand without doubt. Rand was unsure whether they still feared to take the blame if he was killed or simply wanted to see it happen. The one thing he was certain of was that if they did want him dead, he would give them no opportunity.

hu noʊz ə wʊmənz hɑɹt? luz θɝɪn tʃʌkəld ɹaɪli. hi saʊndəɾ ɪn wʌn ə hɪz seɪnɝ mudz. moʊst wɪmən wɪl ʃɹʌɡ ɔf wʌɾ ə mæn wəd kɪl jə fɔɹ, ən kɪl jə fəɹ wʌɾ ə mæn wəd ʃɹʌɡ ɔf.

Who knows a woman's heart? Lews Therin chuckled wryly. He sounded in one of his saner moods. Most women will shrug off what a man would kill you for, and kill you for what a man would shrug off.

ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm. ðə læst ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ɹændz saɪt wɪŋkt aʊt. ði æʃəmən maʊntɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ tu fɑɹ fəɹ ɪm tə seɪ fəɹ ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ɛni stɪl hɛld ɑn tə seɪɾɪn, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd. klʌmzi dæʃivə tʃɹaɪd tə maʊn kwɪkli ən nɪɹli fɛl ɔf twaɪs bɪfɔɹ səksɛsfəli ɹitʃɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl. moʊst ə ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn ɪn vju bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɔɹθ əɹ saʊθ.

Rand ignored him. The last gateway in Rand's sight winked out. The Asha'man mounting their horses were too far for him to say for sure whether any still held on to saidin, but it did not matter so long as he did. Clumsy Dashiva tried to mount quickly and nearly fell off twice before successfully reaching his saddle. Most of the black-coated men in view began riding north or south.
