ðə ɹɛst ə ðə noʊbəlz ɡæðɝd kwɪkli wɪð bæʃɪɹ ɑn ðə sloʊp dʒʌs bɪloʊ ɹænd, ðə haɪəst ɹæŋkɪŋ ən ðoʊz wɪð ðə moʊs paʊɝ ɪn fɹʌn æftɝ ə lɪɾəl dʒɑsəlɪŋ hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, wɛɹ pɹɛsəɾəns ɹɪmeɪn ənsɝɾən. taɪhɛɹə ən mɑɹkəlɪn kɛp ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɑn ðə fɹɪnʒɪz, ɑn ɑpəzət saɪdz ə ðə mæs ə noʊbəlz, feɪsəz kɛɹfəli blæŋk; ðeɪ maɪt bi æsk fəɹ ædvaɪs, bʌt boʊθ nu ðə faɪnəl dɪsɪʒənz ɹɛstəd wɪð ʌðɝz. wɪɹɑmɑn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ wɪð ə ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝ, daʊtləs tə bɪɡɪn ənʌðɝ splɛndəd pɝɝeɪʃən ɑn ðə ɡlɔɹiz ə fɑloʊɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. sunəmən ən tʃɹiən, əkʌstəm tə hɪz spitʃəz ən paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf tə teɪk noʊ kɛɹ ɝaʊn hɪm, ɹeɪn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz təɡɛðɝ ən bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli. sunəmənz feɪs wɔɹ ən ʌnəkʌstəm hɑɹdnəs, ən tʃɹiən simd ɹɛɾi tə skwɑbəl oʊvɝ ə baʊndɝi laɪn dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɛd sæɾən stʃɹaɪps ɑn ɪz koʊtslivz. skwɛɹ-dʒɔd bɝtoʊm ən səm ə ði ʌðɝ kɛɹhinɪn wɝ nɑt kwaɪəɾ əɾ ɔl, læfɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝz dʒoʊks. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd hæɾ ə bɛlɪfəl ʌv wɪɹɑmɑnz ɡɹæn dɪkləmeɪʃənz. ðoʊ səmɝædʒɹɪdz skaʊl dipən ɛvɹi taɪm i lʊkt əɾ eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə - hi dɪd nɑt laɪk əm ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ kloʊs tə ɹænd, ɪspɛʃli hɪz kaʊʌntʃɹiwʊmən - soʊ pɝhæps ɪz saʊɝnəs hæd mɔɹ ɹut ðən wɪɹɑmɑnz wɪndinəs.

The rest of the nobles gathered quickly with Bashere on the slope just below Rand, the highest ranking and those with the most power in front after a little jostling here and there, where precedence remained uncertain. Tihera and Marcolin kept their horses on the fringes, on opposite sides of the mass of nobles, faces carefully blank; they might be asked for advice, but both knew the final decisions rested with others. Weiramon opened his mouth with a grand gesture, doubtless to begin another splendid peroration on the glories of following the Dragon Reborn. Sunamon and Torean, accustomed to his speeches and powerful enough to take no care around him, reined their horses together and began talking quietly. Sunamon's face wore an unaccustomed hardness, and Torean seemed ready to squabble over a boundary line despite the red satin stripes on his coatsleeves. Square-jawed Bertome and some of the other Cairhienin were not quiet at all, laughing at each other's jokes. Everyone had had a bellyful of Weiramon's grand declamations. Though Semaradrid's scowl deepened every time he looked at Ailil and Anaiyella - he did not like them remaining close to Rand, especially his countrywoman - so perhaps his sourness had more root than Weiramon's windiness.

"əbaʊt tɛn maɪlz fɹəm ʌs," ɹænd sɛd laʊdli, "ə ɡʊd fɪfti θaʊzən mɛn ɑɹ pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə mɑɹtʃ." ðeɪ wɝ əwɛɹ ə ðæt, bʌɾ ɪt pʊld ɛvɹi aɪ tə hɪm ən saɪlənst ɛvɹi tʌŋ. wɪɹɑmɑnz maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt saʊɝli; ðə fɛloʊ dɪd lʌv tə hɪɹ hɪmsɛlf tɔk. ɡəm ən mɑɹəkən, tʌɡɪŋ ət ʃɑɹp ɔɪl bɪɹdz, smaɪld ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən, ðə fulz. səmɝædʒɹɪd lʊk laɪk ə mæn u hæɾ iɾən ən ɪntaɪɝ boʊl ə bæd plʌmz; ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən ðə θɹi lɔɹdz ə ðə naɪn wɪð ɪm mɪɹli wɔɹ ɡɹɪm dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. nɑt fulz. "ðə skaʊts sɔ noʊ saɪnz ə sʌldəm əɹ deɪmeɪn," ɹænd wɛn ɑn, "bʌɾ ivən wɪθaʊt ðɛm, ivən wɪð æʃəmən, ðæts ɪnʌf tə kɪl ə lɑɾ ʌv əs ɪf ɛnibəɾi fɝɡɛts ðə plæn. noʊ wʌn wɪl fɝɡɛt, ðoʊ, aɪm ʃʊɹ." noʊ tʃɑɹdʒəz wɪθaʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz, ðɪs taɪm. hi hæd meɪd ðət klɪɹ əz ɡlæs, ən hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn. noʊ hɛɹɪŋ ɔf kəz jə θɔt meɪbi jə dʒʌs maɪɾ əv sin sʌmθɪŋ, iðɝ.

"About ten miles from us," Rand said loudly, "a good fifty thousand men are preparing to march." They were aware of that, but it pulled every eye to him and silenced every tongue. Weiramon's mouth snapped shut sourly; the fellow did love to hear himself talk. Gueyam and Maraconn, tugging at sharp oiled beards, smiled in anticipation, the fools. Semaradrid looked like a man who had eaten an entire bowl of bad plums; Gregorin and the three lords of the Nine with him merely wore grim determination on their faces. Not fools. "The scouts saw no signs of sul'dam or damane," Rand went on, "but even without them, even with Asha'man, that's enough to kill a lot of us if anybody forgets the plan. No one will forget, though, I'm sure." No charges without orders, this time. He had made that clear as glass, and hard as stone. No haring off because you thought maybe you just might have seen something, either.

wɪɹɑmɑn smaɪld, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə pʊɾ əz mʌtʃ ɔɪl ɪndə ɪɾ əz sunəmən ɛvɝ kʊd.

Weiramon smiled, managing to put as much oil into it as Sunamon ever could.

ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl plæn, ɪn ɪts weɪ. ðeɪ wəɾ ədvæns wɛst ɪn faɪv kɑləmz, itʃ wɪð æʃəmən, ən ətɛmp tə fɔl ɑn ðə sintʃæn fɹəm ɛvɹi saɪɾ ət wʌns. əɹ əz kloʊs tə ɔl saɪdz əz kəd bi mænədʒd. sɪmpəl plænz wɝ bɛst, bæʃɪɹ ɪnsɪstəd. ɪf jə woʊn bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ə hoʊl lɪɾɝ ə fæt paɪɡələts, hi hæd mʌɾɝd, ɪf juv tə ɹʌʃ ɪndə ðə wʊdz tə faɪn ði oʊl saʊ, ðən doʊnt ɡɛt tu fænsi, əɹ ʃɪl ɡʌt ju.

It was a simple plan, in its way. They would advance west in five columns, each with Asha'man, and attempt to fall on the Seanchan from every side at once. Or as close to all sides as could be managed. Simple plans were best, Bashere insisted. If you won't be satisfied with a whole litter of fat piglets, he had muttered, if you have to rush into the woods to find the old sow, then don't get too fancy, or she'll gut you.

noʊ plæn ə bæɾəl sɝvaɪvz fɝs kɑntækt, luz θɝɪn sɛɾ ɪn ɹændz hɛd. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi stɪl sim lusəd. fəɹ ə moʊmənt. sʌmθɪŋ ɪz ɹɔŋ, hi ɡɹaʊl sʌɾənli. hɪz vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə ɡeɪn ɪntɛnsəɾi, ən dʒɹɪft ɪndə waɪl dɪsbɪlivɪŋ læftɝ. ɪt kæn bi ɹɔŋ, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ, sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ, skɪɾɝɪŋ, dʒʌmpɪŋ, twɪtʃɪŋ. hɪz kækəlz tɝn tə wipɪŋ. ɪt kæn bi! aɪ mʌs bi mæd! ən i vænɪʃt bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd mjut hɪm. bɝn hɪm, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ðə plæn, əɹ bæʃɪɹ wʊɾə bɪn ɑn ɪt laɪk ə dʌk ɑn ə biɾəl.

No plan of battle survives first contact, Lews Therin said in Rand's head. For a moment, he still seemed lucid. For a moment. Something is wrong, he growled suddenly. His voice began to gain intensity, and drift into wild disbelieving laughter. It can't be wrong, but it is. Something strange, something wrong, skittering, jumping, twitching. His cackles turned to weeping. It can't be! I must be mad! And he vanished before Rand could mute him. Burn him, there was nothing wrong with the plan, or Bashere would have been on it like a duck on a beetle.

luz θɝɪn wɑz mæd, noʊ daʊɾ ʌv ɪt. bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ɹænd ælθɹ ɹɪmeɪn seɪn. . . . ə bɪɾɝ dʒoʊk ɑn ðə wɝld, ɪf ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɛn mæd bɪfɔɹ ðə læs bæɾəl ivən bɪɡæn. "teɪk jəɹ pleɪsəz," hi kəmændəd wɪð ə weɪv ə ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. hi hæd tə faɪt daʊn ði ɝdʒ tə læf ət ðət dʒoʊk.

Lews Therin was mad, no doubt of it. But so long as Rand al'Thor remained sane. . . . A bitter joke on the world, if the Dragon Reborn went mad before the Last Battle even began. "Take your places," he commanded with a wave of the Dragon Scepter. He had to fight down the urge to laugh at that joke.

ðə lɑɹdʒ klʌmp ə noʊbəlz bɹoʊk əpɑɹɾ əɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ, mɪlɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ əz ðeɪ sɔɹɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz aʊt. fju laɪk ðə weɪ ɹænd hæd dɪvaɪɾəd əm ʌp. wʌtɛvɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn ə bæɹiɝz hæɾ əkɝɾ ɪn ðə ʃɑk ə ðə fɝs faɪɾ ɪn ðə maʊntənz, ðeɪ hæd spɹʌŋ ʌp əɡɛn ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli.

The large clump of nobles broke apart at his order, milling and muttering as they sorted themselves out. Few liked the way Rand had divided them up. Whatever breaking down of barriers had occurred in the shock of the first fight in the mountains, they had sprung up again almost immediately.

wɪɹɑmɑn fɹaʊn oʊvɝ ɪz ʌndɪlɪvɝd spitʃ, bʌɾ æftɝ ən ɪlæbɹət baʊ ðət θɹʌst ɪz bɪɹɾ ət ɹænd laɪk ə spɪɹ i ɹoʊd nɔɹθ oʊvɝ ðə hɪlz fɑloʊd baɪ kɹəl dʒɹeɪpeɪnəoʊz, bɝtoʊm, dɔɹɛsɪn, ən sɛvɹəl maɪnɝ kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹdz, ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðɛm stoʊni-feɪst əɾ ə tɛɹən biɪŋ pleɪst oʊvɝ ðɛm. dʒɛdwɪn ɹoʊd baɪ wɪɹɑmɑnz saɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i wɝ ðə wʌn liɾɪŋ, ən ɡɑt dɑɹk skaʊlz fəɹ ɪt ðəɾ i əfɛktəd nɑt tə noʊɾəs. ði ʌðɝ ɡɹupɪŋz wɝ əz mɪkst. ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ɔlsoʊ hɛɾəd nɔɹθ, wɪð ə sʌlən sunəmən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛn i wɑz hɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən baɪ hæpənstæns, ən dælθeɪnz liɾɪŋ lɛsɝ kɛɹhinɪn bɪhaɪnd. dʒɛɹdwɪn səmɛɝɪs, ənʌðɝ ə ðə naɪn, fɑloʊd bæʃɪɹ saʊθ wɪð əmənʒɹɪd ən ɡəm. ðoʊz θɹi hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðə sɑldəiən ɔlmoʊst iɡɝli fəɹ ðə sɪmpəl ɹizən ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt tɛɹən, əɹ kɛɹhinɪn, əɹ ɪliɑnɝ, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə mæn. ɹɑtʃeɪd sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðə seɪm wɪð bæʃɪɹ ðət dʒɛdwɪn wɑz wɪð wɪɹɑmɑn, bʌt bæʃɪɹ əpɪɹd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt. ə lɪɾəl weɪ fɹəm bæʃɪɹz pɑɹɾi, tʃɹiən ən mɑɹəkən ɹoʊd wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, laɪkli vɛntɪŋ splin ət hævɪŋ səmɝædʒɹɪd pleɪst oʊvɝ ðɛm. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɝʃɪn nɛtɑɹi kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd dʒɛɹdwɪn, ən stændɪŋ ɪn ɪz stɝəps tə lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən kɹəl, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ɪmpɹɑbəbəl i kəd si ðɛm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ pæs ðə hɪlz. səmɝædʒɹɪd, hɪz bæk aɪɝn-ɹɑd stʃɹeɪt, lʊkt əz ənflæpəbəl əz bæʃɪɹ.

Weiramon frowned over his undelivered speech, but after an elaborate bow that thrust his beard at Rand like a spear he rode north over the hills followed by Kiril Drapaneos, Bertome, Doressin, and several minor Cairhienin lords, every last one of them stony-faced at a Tairen being placed over them. Gedwyn rode by Weiramon's side almost as if he were the one leading, and got dark scowls for it that he affected not to notice. The other groupings were as mixed. Gregorin also headed north, with a sullen Sunamon trying to pretend he was heading in the same direction by happenstance, and Dalthanes leading lesser Cairhienin behind. Jeordwyn Semaris, another of the Nine, followed Bashere south with Amondrid and Gueyam. Those three had accepted the Saldaean almost eagerly for the simple reason that he was not Tairen, or Cairhienin, or Illianer, depending on the man. Rochaid seemed to be trying the same with Bashere that Gedwyn was with Weiramon, but Bashere appeared to ignore it. A little way from Bashere's party, Torean and Maraconn rode with their heads together, likely venting spleen at having Semaradrid placed over them. For that matter, Ershin Netari kept glancing toward Jeordwyn, and standing in his stirrups to look back toward Gregorin and Kiril, though it was improbable he could see them any longer past the hills. Semaradrid, his back iron-rod straight, looked as unflappable as Bashere.

ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm pɹɪnsəpəl ɹænd hæd juzd ɔl əlɔŋ. hi tʃɹʌstɪd bæʃɪɹ, ən i θɔɾ i maɪt bi eɪbəl tə tʃɹʌst ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, ən nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz kəd dɛɹ θɪŋk ə tɝnɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪm wɪð soʊ mɛni aʊtləndɝz ɝaʊn hɪm, soʊ mɛni oʊld ɛnəmiz ən soʊ fju fɹɛnz. ɹænd læf sɔfli, wɑtʃɪŋ əm ɔl ɹaɪɾ ɔf fɹəm ɪz hɪlsaɪd. ðeɪ wəd faɪt fəɹ hɪm, ən faɪt wɛl, kəz ðeɪ hæd noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. ɛni mɔɹ ðən i hæd.

It was the same principle Rand had used all along. He trusted Bashere, and he thought he might be able to trust Gregorin, and none of the others could dare think of turning against him with so many outlanders around him, so many old enemies and so few friends. Rand laughed softly, watching them all ride off from his hillside. They would fight for him, and fight well, because they had no other choice. Any more than he had.

mædnəs, luz θɝɪn hɪst. ɹænd ʃʌv ðə vɔɪs əweɪ æŋɡɹəli.

Madness, Lews Therin hissed. Rand shoved the voice away angrily.

hi wɑz hɑɹdli əloʊn, ʌv kɔɹs. taɪhɛɹə ən mɑɹkəlɪn hæd moʊst ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz ən kəmpænjənz maʊntəɾ ɪn ɹæŋks əmʌŋ ði ɑləv tʃɹiz ɑn hɪlz flæŋkɪŋ ðə wʌn wɛɹ i sæɾ ɪz hɔɹs. ðə ɹɛst wɝ aʊɾ əz ə skɹin əɡɛnst sɝpɹaɪz. ə kʌmpəni ʌv blu-koʊɾəd lidʒənmɛn weɪɾəd peɪʃənli ɪn ðə hɑloʊ bɪloʊ ʌndɝ meɪsɑnz aɪ, ən ət ðɛɹ ɹɪɹ, əz mɛni mɛn ɪn wʌt ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn sɝɛndɝɪŋ ɑn ðə hiθ bæk ɪn ɪljən. ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛmjəleɪt ðə lidʒənmɛnz kɑm - ði ʌðɝ lidʒənmɛn, naʊ - tʃɹaɪɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə səksɛs.

He was hardly alone, of course. Tihera and Marcolin had most of the Defenders and Companions mounted in ranks among the olive trees on hills flanking the one where he sat his horse. The rest were out as a screen against surprise. A company of blue-coated Legionmen waited patiently in the hollow below under Masond's eye, and at their rear, as many men in what they had worn surrendering on the heath back in Illian. They were trying to emulate the Legionmen's calm - the other Legionmen, now - trying without a great deal of success.

ɹænd ɡlænst əɾ eɪlɪl ən ænɑiɛlə. ðə tɛɹən wʊmən ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɪmpɝɪŋ smaɪl, bʌɾ ɪt fɔltɝd wikli. ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmənz feɪs wɑz fɹɔst. hi kəd nɑt fɝɡɛt ðɛm, əɹ dɛnhɝəɾ ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn. hɪz kɑləm, ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, wəd bi ðə lɑɹdʒəst, ən ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs baɪ ə fɛɹ mɑɹdʒən. ə vɛɹi fɛɹ mɑɹdʒən.

Rand glanced at Ailil and Anaiyella. The Tairen woman gave him a simpering smile, but it faltered weakly. The Cairhienin woman's face was frost. He could not forget them, or Denharad and their armsmen. His column, in the center, would be the largest, and the strongest by a fair margin. A very fair margin.

flɪn ən ðə mɛn ɹænd hæd tʃoʊzən aʊɾ æftɝ dəməaɪz wɛlz ɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə hɪl təwɔɹd hɪm. ðə bɔldɪŋ oʊl mæn ɔlweɪz lɛd, ðoʊ ɔl seɪv ædli ən nɛɹɪʃmə naʊ wɔɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən əz wɛl əz ðə sɔɹd, ən dæʃivə hæd wɔɹn ɪt fɝst. ɪn pɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz kəz ðə jʌŋɡɝ mɛn dɪfɝd tə flɪn, wɪð ɪz lɔŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns əz ə bænɝ-mæn ɪn ði ændɔɝən kwinz ɡɑɹdz. ɪn pɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz kəz dæʃivə dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ. hi oʊnli əpɪɹɾ əmjuz baɪ ði ʌðɝz. wən i kəd spɛɹ taɪm fɹəm tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, ðət wɑz. moʊst ɔfən, hi hɑɹdli simd əwɛɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ pæst ɪz oʊn noʊz.

Flinn and the men Rand had chosen out after Dumai's Wells rode up the hill toward him. The balding old man always led, though all save Adley and Narishma now wore the Dragon as well as the Sword, and Dashiva had worn it first. In part it was because the younger men deferred to Flinn, with his long experience as a banner-man in the Andoran Queen's Guards. In part it was because Dashiva did not seem to care. He only appeared amused by the others. When he could spare time from talking to himself, that was. Most often, he hardly seemed aware of anything past his own nose.

fəɹ ðət ɹizən, ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə ʃɑk wən dæʃivə ɔkwɝdli buɾɪd ɪz slæb-saɪɾəd maʊn əhɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛst. ðət pleɪn feɪs, soʊ ɔfən veɪɡ əɹ bɪmjuzd wɪð ðə fɛloʊz oʊn θɔts, wɑz fɪkst ɪn ə wɝid fɹaʊn. ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə ʃɑk wən i siz seɪɾɪn əz sun əz i ɹitʃt ɹænd ən woʊv ə bæɹiɝ ɝaʊn əm əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑt weɪs bɹɛθ - ɪf ə dɪsɪbɑɾid vɔɪs hæd bɹɛθ - ɑn mʌɾɝz əbaʊt kɪlɪŋ; hi lɝtʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs snɑɹlɪŋ wɝdləsli, tʃɹaɪd tə klɔ ðə paʊɝ əweɪ fɹəm ɹænd. ən dʒʌst əz əbɹʌpli fɛl saɪlən ən vænɪʃt.

For that reason, it was something of a shock when Dashiva awkwardly booted his slab-sided mount ahead of the rest. That plain face, so often vague or bemused with the fellow's own thoughts, was fixed in a worried frown. It was more than something of a shock when he seized saidin as soon as he reached Rand and wove a barrier around them against eavesdropping. Lews Therin did not waste breath - if a disembodied voice had breath - on mutters about killing; he lurched for the Source snarling wordlessly, tried to claw the Power away from Rand. And just as abruptly fell silent and vanished.

"ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ əskju wɪð seɪɾɪn hɪɹ, sʌmθɪŋ əmɪs," dæʃivə sɛd, saʊndɪŋ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl veɪɡ. ɪn fækt, hi saʊndəd . . . pɹɪsaɪs. ən tɛsti. ə titʃɝ lɛktʃɝɪŋ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli dɛns pjupəl. hi ivən stæbd ə fɪŋɡɝ ət ɹænd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. nʌθɪŋ kən twɪst seɪɾɪn, ən ɪf ɪt kəd bi twɪstəd, wiɾ əv fɛlt ɪt bæk ɪn ðə maʊntənz. wɛl, ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðɛɹ, jɛstɝdeɪ, bʌt soʊ smɔl. . . . aɪ fil ɪt klɪɹli hɪɹ, ðoʊ. seɪɾɪn ɪz . . . iɡɝ. aɪ noʊ; aɪ noʊ. seɪɾɪn ɪz nɑɾ əlaɪv. bʌɾ ɪt . . . pʌlsɪz, hɪɹ. ɪts dɪfəkəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl."

"There's something askew with saidin here, something amiss," Dashiva said, sounding not at all vague. In fact, he sounded . . . precise. And testy. A teacher lecturing a particularly dense pupil. He even stabbed a finger at Rand. "I don't know what it is. Nothing can twist saidin, and if it could be twisted, we'd have felt it back in the mountains. Well, there was something there, yesterday, but so small. . . . I feel it clearly here, though. Saidin is . . . eager. I know; I know. Saidin is not alive. But it . . . pulses, here. It is difficult to control."

ɹænd fɔɹst ɪz hæn tə lusən ɪts ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ʃʊɹ dæʃivə wɑz nɪɹli əz mæɾ əz luz θɝɪn hɪmsɛlf. juʒəwəli ðə mæn meɪnteɪn ə bɛɾɝ hoʊld ɑn hɪmsɛlf, ðoʊ, haʊɛvɝ pɹɪkɛɹiəsli. "aɪv bɪn tʃænəlɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ju, dæʃivə. jəɹ dʒʌs filɪŋ ðə teɪn mɔɹ." hi kəd nɑt sɑfən ɪz toʊn. laɪt, hi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ mæd jɛt, ən niðɝ kəd ðeɪ! "ɡɛt tə jəɹ pleɪs. wɪl bi muvɪŋ sun." ðə skaʊts hæd tə ɹɪtɝn sun. ivən ɪn ðɪs flæɾɝ kʌntʃɹi, ivən lɪməɾəd tə noʊ fɑɹðɝ ðən ðeɪ kəd si, tɛn maɪlz wəd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ tə kʌvɝ, tʃɹævlɪŋ.

Rand forced his hand to loosen its grip on the Dragon Scepter. He had always been sure Dashiva was nearly as mad as Lews Therin himself. Usually the man maintained a better hold on himself, though, however precariously. "I've been channeling longer than you, Dashiva. You're just feeling the taint more." He could not soften his tone. Light, he could not go mad yet, and neither could they! "Get to your place. We'll be moving soon." The scouts had to return soon. Even in this flatter country, even limited to no farther than they could see, ten miles would not take long to cover, Traveling.

dæʃivə meɪd noʊ muv tə oʊbeɪ. ɪnstɛd, hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, ðən snæpt ɪt ʃʌt. ʃeɪkɪŋ vɪzəbli, hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ æm wɛl əwɛɹ haʊ lɔŋ juv tʃænəld," hi sɛɾ ɪn ən aɪsi, ɔlmoʊs kəntɛmptʃuəs vɔɪs, "bʌt ʃʊɹli ivən jə kən fil ɪt. fil, mæn! aɪ doʊn laɪk 'stʃɹeɪnʒ' əplaɪd tə seɪɾɪn, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə daɪ əɹ . . . əɹ bi bɝn aʊt kəz jəɹ blaɪnd! lʊk ət maɪ wɔɹd! lʊk əɾ ɪt!"

Dashiva made no move to obey. Instead, he opened his mouth angrily, then snapped it shut. Shaking visibly, he drew a deep breath. "I am well aware how long you have channeled," he said in an icy, almost contemptuous voice, "but surely even you can feel it. Feel, man! I don't like 'strange' applied to saidin, and I don't want to die or . . . or be burned out because you're blind! Look at my ward! Look at it!"

ɹænd stɛɹd. dæʃivə pʊʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɔɹwɝd wɑz pəkjuljɝ ɪnʌf, bʌt dæʃivə ɪn ə tɛmpɝ? ən ðən i dɪd lʊk ət ðə wɔɹd. ɹɪli lʊk. ðə floʊz ʃʊɾə bɪn əz stɛɾi əz ðə θɹɛdz ɪn taɪt-woʊvən kænvəs. ðeɪ vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd. ðə wɔɹd stʊd sɑləɾ əz ɪt ʃəd bi, bʌt ði ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl θɹɛdz ə ðə paʊɝ ʃɪmɝd wɪð feɪn muvmənt. mɔɹ hæd sɛd seɪɾɪn wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ nɪɹ ɛbu dɑɹ, ən fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɝaʊnd. ðeɪ wɝ kloʊsɝ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz, naʊ.

Rand stared. Dashiva pushing himself forward was peculiar enough, but Dashiva in a temper? And then he did look at the ward. Really look. The flows should have been as steady as the threads in tight-woven canvas. They vibrated. The ward stood solid as it should be, but the individual threads of the Power shimmered with faint movement. Morr had said saidin was strange near Ebou Dar, and for a hundred miles around. They were closer than a hundred miles, now.

ɹænd meɪd hɪmsɛlf fil seɪɾɪn. hi wɑz ɔlweɪz əwɛɹ ə ðə paʊɝ - ɛniθɪŋ ɛls mɛn dɛθ əɹ wɝs - jɛɾ i hæd bɪkʌm juz tə ðə stʃɹʌɡəl. hi fɔt fəɹ laɪf, bʌt ðə faɪt hæd bɪkʌm əz nætʃɹəl əz laɪf. ðə stʃɹʌɡəl wɑz laɪf. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf fil ðət bæɾəl, hɪz laɪf. koʊl tə meɪk stoʊn ʃæɾɝ ɪndə dʌst. faɪɝ tə meɪk stoʊn flæʃ tə veɪpɝ. fɪlθ tə meɪk ə ɹɑɾən sɛspɪt smɛl ə ɡɑɹɾən ɪn fʊl flaʊɝ. ən . . . ə pʌlsɪŋ, laɪk sʌmθɪŋ kwɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ɪz fɪst. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɹɑbɪŋ i hæd fɛlt ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, wən ðə teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn hæd ɹɛzəneɪɾɪd wɪð ði ivəl ə ðət pleɪs, ən seɪɾɪn hæd pʌlsd wɪð ɪt. ðə vɪlnəs wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt stɛɾi hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz seɪɾɪn ɪtsɛlf ðət sim fʊl ə kɝəns ən sɝdʒəz. iɡɝ, dæʃivə kɔld ɪt, ən ɹænd kəd si waɪ.

Rand made himself feel saidin. He was always aware of the Power - anything else meant death or worse - yet he had become used to the struggle. He fought for life, but the fight had become as natural as life. The struggle was life. He made himself feel that battle, his life. Cold to make stone shatter into dust. Fire to make stone flash to vapor. Filth to make a rotten cesspit smell a garden in full flower. And . . . a pulsing, like something quivering in his fist. This was not the sort of throbbing he had felt in Shadar Logoth, when the taint on saidin had resonated with the evil of that place, and saidin had pulsed with it. The vileness was strong, but steady here. It was saidin itself that seemed full of currents and surges. Eager, Dashiva called it, and Rand could see why.

daʊn ðə sloʊp, bɪhaɪn flɪn, mɔɹ skɹʌbd ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ ən lʊkt ɝaʊn ənizəli. flɪn ɔltɝneɪɾəd ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl ən izɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. nɛɹɪʃmə, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪ fəɹ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝz, blɪŋk tu ɔfən. ə mʌsəl twɪtʃt ɪn ædliz tʃik. ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm dɪspleɪd səm saɪn ə nɝvəsnəs, ən lɪɾəl wʌndɝ. ɹɪlif wɛld ʌp ɪn ɹænd. nɑt mædnəs æftɝ ɔl.

Down the slope, behind Flinn, Morr scrubbed a hand through his hair and looked around uneasily. Flinn alternated shifting on his saddle and easing his sword in its scabbard. Narishma, watching the sky for flying creatures, blinked too often. A muscle twitched in Adley's cheek. Every one of them displayed some sign of nervousness, and little wonder. Relief welled up in Rand. Not madness after all.

dæʃivə smaɪld, ə twɪstəd sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl. "aɪ kænɑt bɪliv jə dɪdnt noʊɾəs bɪfɔɹ." ðəɹ wɑz vɛɹi kloʊz tə ə snɪɹ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "juv bɪn hoʊldɪŋ seɪɾɪn pɹæktəkli deɪ ən naɪt sɪns wi bɪɡæn ðɪs mæɾ ɛkspədɪʃən. ðɪs ɪz ə sɪmpəl wɔɹd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt wɑnə fɔɹm, ðən ɪt snæp təɡɛðɝ laɪk pʊlɪŋ aʊɾ ə maɪ hænz."

Dashiva smiled, a twisted self-satisfied smile. "I cannot believe you didn't notice before." There was very close to a sneer in his voice. "You've been holding saidin practically day and night since we began this mad expedition. This is a simple ward, but it did not want to form, then it snapped together like pulling out of my hands."

ðə sɪlvɝ-blu slæʃ ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɹoʊteɪɾɪd oʊpən ətɑp wʌn ə ðə bɛɹ hɪlz, hæf ə maɪl tə ðə wɛst, ən ə soʊlʒɝ pʊld ɪz hɔɹs θɹu ən maʊntəd hɝidli, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə skaʊt. ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns, ɹænd kəd meɪk aʊt ðə feɪnt ʃɪmɝ ə ðə wivz sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ vænɪʃt. ðə ɹaɪɾɝ hæd nɑt ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɪl bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən ɑn ðə kɹɛst, ən ðən ə θɝd, ə fɔɹθ, mɔɹ, wʌn æftɝ ənʌðɝ, ɔlmoʊst əz fæst əz ðə pɹisiɾɪŋ mæn kəd ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ.

The silver-blue slash of a gateway rotated open atop one of the bare hills, half a mile to the west, and a Soldier pulled his horse through and mounted hurriedly, returning from the scout. Even at a distance, Rand could make out the faint shimmer of the weaves surrounding the gateway before they vanished. The rider had not reached the bottom of the hill before another gateway opened on the crest, and then a third, a fourth, more, one after another, almost as fast as the preceding man could get out of the way.

"bʌɾ ɪt dɪd fɔɹm," ɹænd sɛd. soʊ hæd ðə skaʊts' ɡeɪtweɪz. "ɪf seɪɾɪn ɪz hɑɹd tə kəntʃɹoʊl, ɪts ɔlweɪz hɑɹd, ən ɪt stɪl dʌz wʌt jə wɑnt." bʌt waɪ mɔɹ dɪfəkəl hɪɹ? ə kwɛstʃən fəɹ ənʌðɝ taɪm. laɪt, hi wɪʃt hɹɪd fɛl wɝ stɪl əlaɪv; ði oʊl fəlɑsəfɝ maɪɾ əv hæɾ ən ænsɝ. "ɡɛt bæk wɪð ði ʌðɝz, dæʃivə," hi ɔɹɾɝd, bʌt ðə mæn stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt, ən i hæd tə ɹɪpit hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ðə fɛloʊ lɛt ðə wɔɹd vænɪʃ, dʒɝkt ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊnd wɪθaʊɾ ə səluɾ ən θʌmp ði ænəməl bæk daʊn ðə sloʊp wɪð ɪz hilz.

"But it did form," Rand said. So had the scouts' gateways. "If saidin is hard to control, it's always hard, and it still does what you want." But why more difficult here? A question for another time. Light, he wished Herid Fel were still alive; the old philosopher might have had an answer. "Get back with the others, Dashiva," he ordered, but the man stared at him in astonishment, and he had to repeat himself before the fellow let the ward vanish, jerked his horse around without a salute and thumped the animal back down the slope with his heels.

"sʌm tʃɹʌbəl, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?" ænɑiɛlə sɪmpɝd. eɪlɪl mɪɹli lʊkt ət ɹænd wɪð flæɾ aɪz.

"Some trouble, my Lord Dragon?" Anaiyella simpered. Ailil merely looked at Rand with flat eyes.

siɪŋ ðə fɝst skaʊɾ ɑn ðə weɪ təwɔɹd ɹænd, ði ʌðɝz fæn ɔf tə nɔɹθ ən saʊθ, wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd dʒɔɪn wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ kɑləmz. faɪndɪŋ əm ði oʊld-fæʃənd weɪ wəd bi fæstɝ ðən kæstɪŋ əbaʊt wɪð ɡeɪtweɪz. dʒɹɔɪŋ ɹeɪn ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, næləm slæp fɪs tə tʃɛst - dɪɾ i lʊk ə bɪt waɪld-aɪd? noʊ mæɾɝ. seɪɾɪn stɪl dɪd wʌt ðə mæn wildɪŋ ɪt meɪɾ ɪt du. næləm səluɾəd ən ɡeɪv ɪz ɹipɔɹt. ðə sintʃæn wɝ nɑɾ ɪnkæmp tɛn maɪlz əweɪ, ðeɪ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ðən faɪv əɹ sɪks dɪstənt, mɑɹtʃɪŋ ist. ən ðeɪ hæd sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn baɪ ðə skɔɹ.

Seeing the first scout on the way toward Rand, the others fanned off to north and south, where they would join one of the other columns. Finding them the old-fashioned way would be faster than casting about with gateways. Drawing rein in front of Rand, Nalaam slapped fist to chest - did he look a bit wild-eyed? No matter. Saidin still did what the man wielding it made it do. Nalaam saluted and gave his report. The Seanchan were not encamped ten miles away, they were no more than five or six distant, marching east. And they had sul'dam and damane by the score.

ɹænd ɪʃuɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz əz næləm ɡæləpt əweɪ, ən ɪz kɑləm bɪɡæn muvɪŋ wɛst. ðə dɪfɛndɝz ən ðə kəmpænjənz ɹoʊɾ ɑn iðɝ flæŋk. ðə lidʒənmɛn mɑɹtʃt ət ðə ɹɪɹ, dʒʌs bɪhaɪn dɛnhɝəd. ə ɹimaɪndɝ tə ðə noʊbəlwɪmən, ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn, ɪf ðeɪ niɾəd wʌn. ænɑiɛlə sɝɾənli lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ɔfən ɪnʌf, ən eɪlɪlz ɹəfjuzəl tə wɑz pɔɪntəd. ɹænd fɔɹm ðə meɪn θɹʌst ə ðə kɑləm, ɹænd ən flɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, dʒʌst əz ɪt wəd bi wɪð ði ʌðɝ kɑləmz. æʃəmən tə stʃɹaɪk, ən mɛn wɪð stil tə ɡɑɹd ðɛɹ bæks waɪl ðeɪ kɪld. ðə sʌn stɪl hæɾ ə lɔŋ weɪ tə klaɪm bɪfɔɹ mɪddeɪ. nʌθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd tə ɔltɝ ðə plæn.

Rand issued his orders as Nalaam galloped away, and his column began moving west. The Defenders and the Companions rode on either flank. The Legionmen marched at the rear, just behind Denharad. A reminder to the noblewomen, and their armsmen, if they needed one. Anaiyella certainly looked over her shoulder often enough, and Ailil's refusal to was pointed. Rand formed the main thrust of the column, Rand and Flinn and the others, just as it would be with the other columns. Asha'man to strike, and men with steel to guard their backs while they killed. The sun still had a long way to climb before midday. Nothing had changed to alter the plan.

mædnəs weɪts fəɹ sʌm, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. ɪt kɹips ʌp ɑn ʌðɝz.

Madness waits for some, Lews Therin whispered. It creeps up on others.

mɪɹaɪ ɹoʊd nɪɹ ðə hɛɾ ə hɪz ɑɹmi mɑɹtʃɪŋ ist əlɔŋ ə mʌɾi ɹoʊd ðət waʊn θɹu hɪli ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz ən pætʃi fɔɹəst. nɑɾ ət ðə hɛd. ə fʊl ɹɛdʒəmənt, moʊst sintʃæn, ɹoʊd bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə fɔɹwɝd skaʊts. hi hæd noʊn dʒɛnɝəlz u wɑntəd tə bi ət ðə vɛɹi fɹʌnt. moʊst wɝ dɛd. moʊs hæd lɔs ðə bæɾəlz ðeɪ daɪɾ ɪn. mʌd kɛp daʊn dʌst, jɛt wɝɾ ʌv ən ɑɹmi ɑn ðə muv ɹæn laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ ɑn ðə sɑlɑz pleɪnz, wʌtɛvɝ ðə lænd. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ əmʌŋ ði ɑləv tʃɹiz i spɑɾəd ən oʊvɝtɝnd wilbɛɹoʊ əɹ ən əbændən pɹunɪŋ hʊk, bʌt ðə wɝkɝz hæd vænɪʃt lɔŋ sɪns. lʌkəli, ðeɪ wəɾ əvɔɪɾ ɪz əpoʊnəns əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ dɪd hɪm. wɪð lʌk, lækɪŋ ɹeɪkən, hɪz əpoʊnəns wəd nɑt noʊ hi wɑz ɑn əm əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. kɛnɝ mɪɹaɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk tʃɹʌstɪŋ tə lʌk.

Miraj rode near the head of his army marching east along a muddy road that wound through hilly olive groves and patchy forest. Not at the head. A full regiment, most Seanchan, rode between him and the forward scouts. He had known generals who wanted to be at the very front. Most were dead. Most had lost the battles they died in. Mud kept down dust, yet word of an army on the move ran like wildfire on the Sa'las Plains, whatever the land. Here and there among the olive trees he spotted an overturned wheelbarrow or an abandoned pruning hook, but the workers had vanished long since. Luckily, they would avoid his opponents as much as they did him. With luck, lacking raken, his opponents would not know he was on them until it was too late. Kennar Miraj did not like trusting to luck.

əsaɪd fɹəm ʌndɝ-ɔfəsɝz ɹɛɾi tə pɹədus mæps əɹ kɑpi ɔɹɾɝz ən mɛsənʒɝz ɹɛɾi tə kæɹi ðɛm, hi ɹoʊɾ əkʌmpəniɾ oʊnli baɪ ɑbɑldɑɹ julən, smɔl ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪz kwaɪɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ sim ɪmɛns, ə faɪɝi mæn wɪð ðə neɪlz ə hɪz lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz peɪntəd ɡɹin u wɔɹ ə blæk wɪɡ tə kənsil ɪz bɔlnəs, ən lɪseɪn dʒɑɹəθ, ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən fɹəm sindɑɹ ɪtsɛlf, huz peɪl plʌmp feɪs ən blu aɪz wɝ ə stʌɾi ɪn sɝɛnəɾi. julən wɑz nɑt kɑm; mɪɹaɪz koʊl-dɑɹk kæptən ə ði ɛɹ ɔfən wɔɹ ə skaʊl fəɹ ðə ɹulz ðət sɛldəm lɛɾ ɪm tʌtʃ ðə ɹeɪnz ʌv ə ɹeɪkən ɛnimɔɹ, bʌt tədeɪ hɪz fɹaʊn wɛn boʊn dip. ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ, pɝfəkt wɛðɝ fəɹ ɹeɪkən, bʌt baɪ sjuɹɔθs kəmænd, nʌn ə hɪz flaɪɝz wəd bi ɪn ðə sæɾəl tədeɪ, nɑt hɪɹ. ðəɹ wɝ tu fju ɹeɪkən wɪð ðə heɪlin tə ɹɪsk əm ənnɛsəsɛɹəli. lɪseɪnz kɑm tʃɹʌbəl mɪɹaɪ mɔɹ. mɔɹ ðən ðə sinjɝ dɝsʌldəm ʌndɝ ɪz kəmænd, ʃi wɑz ə fɹɛnd wɪð hum i hæd ʃɛɹd mɛni ə kʌp ə kæf ən mɛni ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz. ən ænəmeɪɾəd wʊmən, ɔlweɪz bʌbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ wɪð ɪnθuziæzəmz ən əmjuzmənt. ən ʃi wɑz aɪsi kɑm, əz saɪlən əz ɛni sʌldəm i hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kwɛstʃən.

Aside from under-officers ready to produce maps or copy orders and messengers ready to carry them, he rode accompanied only by Abaldar Yulan, small enough to make his quite ordinary brown gelding seem immense, a fiery man with the nails of his little fingers painted green who wore a black wig to conceal his baldness, and Lisaine Jarath, a gray-haired woman from Seandar itself, whose pale plump face and blue eyes were a study in serenity. Yulan was not calm; Miraj's coal-dark Captain of the Air often wore a scowl for the rules that seldom let him touch the reins of a raken anymore, but today his frown went bone deep. The sky was clear, perfect weather for raken, but by Suroth's command, none of his fliers would be in the saddle today, not here. There were too few raken with the Hailene to risk them unnecessarily. Lisaine's calm troubled Miraj more. More than the senior der'sul'dam under his command, she was a friend with whom he had shared many a cup of kaf and many a game of stones. An animated woman, always bubbling over with enthusiasms and amusement. And she was icy calm, as silent as any sul'dam he had tried to question.

wɪðɪn ɪz saɪt wɝ twɛnti deɪmeɪn flæŋkɪŋ ðə hɔɹsmən, itʃ wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ sʌldəmz maʊnt. ðə sʌldəm bɑbd ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, bɛndɪŋ tə pæɾ ə deɪmeɪnz hɛd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ oʊnli tə bɛn əɡɛn tə stʃɹoʊk əɹ hɛɹ. ðə deɪmeɪn lʊk stɛɾi ɪnʌf tə hɪz aɪ, bʌt pleɪnli ðə sʌldəm wɝ ɑn ɹeɪzɝz ɛdʒ. ən ɪbʌljən lɪseɪn ɹoʊd saɪlən əz ə stoʊn.

Within his sight were twenty damane flanking the horsemen, each walking beside her sul'dam's mount. The sul'dam bobbed in their saddles, bending to pat a damane's head, straightening only to bend again to stroke her hair. The damane looked steady enough to his eye, but plainly the sul'dam were on razor's edge. And ebullient Lisaine rode silent as a stone.

ə tɔɹm əpɪɹɾ əhɛd, ɹeɪsɪŋ daʊn ðə kɑləm. wɛl ɔf tə ðə saɪd, ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹoʊvz, jɛt hɔɹsəz wɪkɝɾ ən ʃaɪɾ əz ðə bɹɑnz-skeɪl kɹitʃɝ floʊd pæst. ə tʃɹeɪn tɔɹm wəd nɑɾ ətæk hɔɹsəz - ət lis nɑɾ ənlɛs ðə kɪlɪŋ fɹɛnzi oʊvɝtʊk ɪt, ðə ɹizən tɔɹm wɝ noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪn bæɾəl - bʌt hɔɹsəz tʃɹeɪn tə bi kɑm ɝaʊn tɔɹm wɝ ɪn əz ʃɔɹt səplaɪ əz tɔɹm ðɛmsɛlvz.

A torm appeared ahead, racing down the column. Well off to the side, on the edge of the groves, yet horses whickered and shied as the bronze-scaled creature flowed past. A trained torm would not attack horses - at least not unless the killing frenzy overtook it, the reason torm were no good in battle - but horses trained to be calm around torm were in as short supply as torm themselves.

mɪɹaɪ sɛn ə skɪni ʌndɝ-lutɛnənt neɪm vɑɹɛk tə fɛtʃ ðə mɔɹɑtʃɹmz skaʊɾɪŋ ɹipɔɹt. əfʊt, ən ðə laɪt kənsum wɛðɝ vɑɹɛk lɔst seɪaɪtɑɹ. hi wəd nɑt weɪs taɪm ɑn vɑɹɛk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ə maʊn əkwaɪɝd loʊkəli. ðə mæn ɹɪtɝn fæstɝ ðən i wɛn ən meɪɾ ə kɹɪsp baʊ, bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪz ɹipɔɹt bɪfɔɹ ɪz bæk wɑz stʃɹeɪɾ əɡɛn.

Miraj sent a skinny under-lieutenant named Varek to fetch the morat'torm's scouting report. Afoot, and the Light consume whether Varek lost sei'taer. He would not waste time on Varek trying to control a mount acquired locally. The man returned faster than he went and made a crisp bow, beginning his report before his back was straight again.

"ði ɛnəmi ɪz lɛs ðən faɪv maɪlz du ist, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪplɔɪɾ ɪn faɪv kɑləmz speɪst əpɹɑksəmətli wʌn maɪl əpɑɹt."

"The enemy is less than five miles due east, my Lord Captain-General, marching in our direction. They are deployed in five columns spaced approximately one mile apart."

soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ lʌk. bʌt mɪɹaɪ hæd kənsɪɾɝd haʊ hi wəɾ ətæk fɔɹɾi θaʊzənd wɪð oʊnli faɪv hɪmsɛlf, ən fɪfti deɪmeɪn. kwɪkli mɛn wɝ ɡæləpɪŋ wɪð ɔɹɾɝz tə dɪplɔɪ tə miɾ ən ətɛmptəɾ ɛnvɛləpmənt, ən ðə ɹɛdʒəməns bɪhaɪn ɪm bɪɡæn tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹoʊvz, sʌldəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ əm wɪð ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn.

So much for luck. But Miraj had considered how he would attack forty thousand with only five himself, and fifty damane. Quickly men were galloping with orders to deploy to meet an attempted envelopment, and the regiments behind him began turning into the groves, sul'dam riding among them with their damane.

ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz kloʊk əɡɛnst ə sʌɾən koʊld wɪnd, mɪɹaɪ noʊɾəst sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm fil koʊldɝ stɪl. lɪseɪn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sʌldəm vænɪʃ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, tu. ən ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə swɛt.

Gathering his cloak against a sudden cold wind, Miraj noticed something that made him feel colder still. Lisaine was watching the sul'dam vanish into the trees, too. And she had begun to sweat.

bɝtoʊm ɹoʊɾ izəli, lɛɾɪŋ ðə wɪn stʃɹim ɪz kloʊk tə wʌn saɪd, bʌɾ i stʌɾid ðə fɔɹəstəd kʌntʃɹi əhɛd wɪð ə wɛɹinɪs i bɛɹli ətɛmptəd tə kənsil. ʌv ɪz fɔɹ kʌntʃɹimɪn əɾ ɪz bæk, oʊnli dɔɹɛsɪn wɑz tʃɹuli skɪld ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. ðət ful tɛɹən dɔɡ wɪɹɑmɑn wɑz blaɪnd, ʌv kɔɹs. bɝtoʊm ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə pʌft-ʌp bəfunz bæk. wɪɹɑmɑn ɹoʊd wɛl əhɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛst ɪn dip kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð dʒɛdwɪn, ən ɪf bɝtoʊm niɾəd ɛni fɝðɝ pɹuf ðət ðə tɛɹən wəd smaɪl ət wʌt ɡæɡd ə ɡoʊt, ɪt wɑz haʊ hi tɑlɝeɪɾəd ðət hɑt-aɪd jʌŋ mɑnstɝ. hi noʊɾəst kɹəl ɡlænsɪŋ saɪdweɪz ət hɪm, ən ɹeɪn ɪz ɡɹeɪ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə taʊɝɪŋ mæn. hi hæd noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɛnməɾi təwɔɹd ði ɪliɑnɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd heɪt pipəl lumɪŋ oʊvɝ hɪm. hi kəd nɑt weɪt tə ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹhin, wɛɹ i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi sɝaʊndəd baɪ ənɡeɪnli dʒaɪəns. kɹəl dʒɹeɪpnəoʊz wɑz nɑt blaɪnd, ðoʊ, haʊɛvɝ oʊvɝ-tɔl. hi hæd sɛn ə dʌzən skaʊts fɔɹwɝd, tu. wɪɹɑmɑn hæd sɛnt wʌn.

Bertome rode easily, letting the wind stream his cloak to one side, but he studied the forested country ahead with a wariness he barely attempted to conceal. Of his four countrymen at his back, only Doressin was truly skilled in the Game of Houses. That fool Tairen dog Weiramon was blind, of course. Bertome glared at the puffed-up buffoon's back. Weiramon rode well ahead of the rest in deep conversation with Gedwyn, and if Bertome needed any further proof that the Tairen would smile at what gagged a goat, it was how he tolerated that hot-eyed young monster. He noticed Kiril glancing sideways at him, and reined his gray farther from the towering man. He had no particular enmity toward the Illianer, but he did hate people looming over him. He could not wait to return to Cairhien, where he did not have to be surrounded by ungainly giants. Kiril Drapeneos was not blind, though, however over-tall. He had sent a dozen scouts forward, too. Weiramon had sent one.

"dɔɹɛsɪn," bɝtoʊm sɛd sɔfli, ðɛn, ə lɪɾəl laʊɾɝ, "dɔɹɛsɪn, jə lʌmp!"

"Doressin," Bertome said softly, then, a little louder, "Doressin, you lump!"

ðə boʊni mæn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. laɪk bɝtoʊm, laɪk ði ʌðɝ θɹi, hi hæd ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd; ðə staɪl ə mɑɹkɪŋ jɝsɛlf laɪk ə soʊlʒɝ hæd bɪkʌm kwaɪt fæʃənəbəl. dɔɹɛsɪn ʃʊɾə kɔld ɪm ə toʊɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn, ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd sɪns bɔɪhʊd, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i hild ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd bɝtoʊmz ən lin kloʊs. hi wɑz wɝid, ən lɛɾɪŋ ɪt ʃoʊ, hɪz fɔɹhɛd fɝoʊd dipli. "ju ɹilaɪz ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən minz əs tə daɪ?" hi wɪspɝd, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə kɑləm tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "blʌɾ ən faɪɝ, aɪ oʊnli lɪsən tə koʊləveɪɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊn aɪ wɑz ə dɛd mæn sɪns i kɪl hɝ."

The bony man gave a start in his saddle. Like Bertome, like the other three, he had shaved and powdered the front of his head; the style of marking yourself like a soldier had become quite fashionable. Doressin should have called him a toad in return, the way they had since boyhood, but instead he heeled his gelding up beside Bertome's and leaned close. He was worried, and letting it show, his forehead furrowed deeply. "You realize the Lord Dragon means us to die?" he whispered, glancing at the column trailing behind them. "Blood and fire, I only listened to Colavaere, but I have known I was a dead man since he killed her."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bɝtoʊm aɪd ðə kɑləm ʌv ɑɹmmɪn, sneɪkɪŋ bæk θɹu ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz. ðə tʃɹiz wɝ mɔɹ skæɾɝd hɪɹ ðən əhɛd, bʌt stɪl ɪnʌf tə ʃild ən ətæk əntɪl ɪt wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ju. ðə læst ɑləv ɡɹoʊv leɪ nɪɹli ə maɪl bɪhaɪnd. wɪɹɑmɑnz mɛn ɹoʊɾ ət ðə fɔɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪn ðoʊz ɹɪdɪkjələs koʊts wɪð ðɛɹ fæt waɪt-stʃɹaɪp slivz, ən ðən kɹəlz ɪliɑnɝz ɪn ɪnʌf ɡɹin ən ɹɛd tə ʃeɪm tɪŋkɝz. hɪz oʊn pipəl, disənli klæɾ ɪn dɑɹk blu bɪniθ ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts, wɝ stɪl bɪɑn ɪz saɪt wɪð dɔɹɛsɪnz ən ði ʌðɝz', əhɛɾ oʊnli ʌv ðə kʌmpəni ʌv lidʒənmɛn. wɪɹɑmɑn hæd sim sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðə fʊt kɛpt ʌp, ðoʊ hi hæd hɑɹdli sɛɾ ə dɪfəkəl peɪs.

For a moment, Bertome eyed the column of armsmen, snaking back through the rolling hills. The trees were more scattered here than ahead, but still enough to shield an attack until it was right on top of you. The last olive grove lay nearly a mile behind. Weiramon's men rode at the fore, of course, in those ridiculous coats with their fat white-striped sleeves, and then Kiril's Illianers in enough green and red to shame Tinkers. His own people, decently clad in dark blue beneath their breastplates, were still beyond his sight with Doressin's and the others', ahead only of the company of Legionmen. Weiramon had seemed surprised that the foot kept up, though he had hardly set a difficult pace.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ði ɑɹmmɪn bɝtoʊm ɡlænst æt, ðoʊ. sɛvən mɛn ɹoʊd bɪfɔɹ ivən wɪɹɑmɑnz, sɛvən mɛn wɪð hɑɹd feɪsəz ən dɛθ-koʊld aɪz, ɪn blæk koʊts. wʌn wɔɹ ə pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz tɔl kɑlɝ.

It was not really the armsmen Bertome glanced at, though. Seven men rode before even Weiramon's, seven men with hard faces and death-cold eyes, in black coats. One wore a pin in the shape of a silver sword on his tall collar.

"æn ɪlæbɹət weɪ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt," hi toʊl dɔɹɛsɪn dʒɹaɪli. "æn aɪ daʊɾ ælθɹ wʊɾə sɛn ðoʊz fɛloʊz wɪð ʌs, ɪf wi wɝ dʒʌs biɪŋ fɛɾ ɪndə ə sɔsədʒ ɡɹaɪndɝ." fɔɹhɛd stɪl kɹist, dɔɹɛsɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əɡɛn, bʌt bɝtoʊm sɛd, "aɪ nid tə tɔk tə ðə tɛɹən." hi dɪslaɪk siɪŋ ɪz tʃaɪldhʊd fɹɛn ðɪs weɪ. ælθɹ hæɾ ənhɪnʒd hɪm.

"An elaborate way to go about it," he told Doressin dryly. "And I doubt al'Thor would have sent those fellows with us, if we were just being fed into a sausage grinder." Forehead still creased, Doressin opened his mouth again, but Bertome said, "I need to talk to the Tairen." He disliked seeing his childhood friend this way. Al'Thor had unhinged him.

əbzɔɹbd ɪn wʌn ənʌðɝ, wɪɹɑmɑn ən dʒɛdwɪn dɪd nɑt hɪɹ ɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ɑn ðɛm. dʒɛdwɪn wɑz aɪdli pleɪɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɹeɪnz, hɪz fitʃɝz koʊld wɪð kəntɛmpt. ðə tɛɹən wɑz ɹɛd-feɪst. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ u jə ɑɹ," hi wɑz seɪɪŋ tə ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mæn ɪn ə loʊ, hɑɹd vɔɪs, spɪɾəl flaɪɪŋ, "aɪ woʊn teɪk mɔɹ ɹɪsk wɪθaʊɾ ə kəmæn dɝɛk fɹəm ðə lɪps ʌv - "

Absorbed in one another, Weiramon and Gedwyn did not hear him riding up on them. Gedwyn was idly playing with his reins, his features cold with contempt. The Tairen was red-faced. "I don't care who you are," he was saying to the black-coated man in a low, hard voice, spittle flying, "I won't take more risk without a command direct from the lips of - "

əbɹʌpli ðə pɛɹ bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə bɝtoʊm, ən wɪɹɑmɑnz maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt. hi ɡlɛɹɾ əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə kɪl bɝtoʊm. ði æʃəmənz ɛvɝ-pɹɛzən smaɪl mɛltəɾ əweɪ. ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd, koʊld ən ʃɑɹp əz klaʊdz dʒɹɪftəɾ əkɹɔs ðə sʌn, bʌt noʊ koʊldɝ ðən dʒɛdwɪnz sʌɾən stɛɹ. wɪð ə smɔl ʃɑk bɝtoʊm ɹilaɪz ðə mæn ɔlsoʊ wɑntəd tə stʃɹaɪk ɪm dɛɾ ɑn ðə spɑt.

Abruptly the pair became aware of Bertome, and Weiramon's mouth snapped shut. He glared as if he wanted to kill Bertome. The Asha'man's ever-present smile melted away. The wind gusted, cold and sharp as clouds drifted across the sun, but no colder than Gedwyn's sudden stare. With a small shock Bertome realized the man also wanted to strike him dead on the spot.

dʒɛdwɪnz aɪsɪli mɝɾɝəs ɡeɪz dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt wɪɹɑmɑnz feɪs ʌndɝwɛn ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl tʃɹænsfɝmeɪʃən. ðə ɹɛd feɪɾəd sloʊli əz i pɹədust ə smaɪl ɪn ən ɪnstənt, ən ɔɪli smaɪl wɪð oʊnli ə tʃɹeɪs ə mɑkɪŋ kɑndəsɛnʃən. "aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ju, bɝtoʊm," hi sɛd hɑɹɾəli. "ə pɪɾi ælθɹ stʃɹæŋɡəl jəɹ kʌzən. wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz, aɪ hɪɹ. fɹæŋkli, aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz jə keɪm wən i kɔld. aɪv sin ɪm wɑtʃɪŋ ju. aɪ fɪɹ i plænz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ . . . ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ . . . fəɹ jə ðən θɹæʃɪŋ jəɹ hilz ɑn ðə flɔɹ waɪl ɪz fɪŋɡɝz taɪɾən ɑn jəɹ θɹoʊt."

Gedwyn's icily murderous gaze did not change, but Weiramon's face underwent a remarkable transformation. The red faded slowly as he produced a smile in an instant, an oily smile with only a trace of mocking condescension. "I've been thinking about you, Bertome," he said heartily. "A pity al'Thor strangled your cousin. With his own hands, I hear. Frankly, I was surprised you came when he called. I've seen him watching you. I fear he plans something more . . . interesting . . . for you than thrashing your heels on the floor while his fingers tighten on your throat."

bɝtoʊm səpɹɛst ə saɪ, ən nɑɾ oʊnli ət ðə fulz klʌmzinəs. ə ɡʊd mɛni θɔt tə mənɪpjəleɪɾ ɪm wɪð koʊləveɪɪɹz dɛθ. ʃi hæd bɪn ɪz feɪvɹɪt kʌzən, bʌɾ æmbɪʃəs bɪɑn ɹizən. seɪɡən hæd ɡʊd kleɪmz tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv hɛld ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ɹieɪɾən əɹ dəmədʒɹɾ iðɝ wʌn, lɛɾ əloʊn boʊθ təɡɛðɝ, nɑt wɪθaʊt ði oʊpən blɛsɪŋz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ əɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. stɪl, ʃi hæd bɪn ɪz feɪvɹɪt. wʌd wɪɹɑmɑn wɑnt? sɝɾənli nɑt wʌɾ ɪt simd ɑn ðə sɝfəs. ivən ðɪs tɛɹən ɑf wɑz nɑt ðət sɪmpəl.

Bertome suppressed a sigh, and not only at the fool's clumsiness. A good many thought to manipulate him with Colavaere's death. She had been his favorite cousin, but ambitious beyond reason. Saighan had good claims to the Sun Throne, yet she could not have held it against the strength of Riatin or Damodred either one, let alone both together, not without the open blessings of the White Tower or the Dragon Reborn. Still, she had been his favorite. What did Weiramon want? Certainly not what it seemed on the surface. Even this Tairen oaf was not that simple.

bɪfɔɹ i kəd fɹeɪm ɛni ɹɪspɑns, ə hɔɹsmən keɪm ɡæləpɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm θɹu ðə tʃɹiz əhɛd. eɪ kɛɹhinɪn, ən əz i ɹeɪn tə ə sʌɾən hɔlt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, ðət meɪɾ ɪz hɔɹs sɪt bæk ɑn ɪts hɔntʃɪz, bɝtoʊm ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌn ə hɪz oʊn ɑɹmmɪn, ə ɡæp-tuθ fɛloʊ wɪð sim skɑɹz ɑn boʊθ tʃiks. dɔɪl, hi θɔt. fɹəm ðə koʊltʃeɪn ɪsteɪts.

Before he could frame any response, a horseman came galloping toward them through the trees ahead. A Cairhienin, and as he reined to a sudden halt in front of them, that made his horse sit back on its haunches, Bertome recognized one of his own armsmen, a gap-toothed fellow with seamed scars on both cheeks. Doile, he thought. From the Colchaine estates.

"maɪ lɔɹd bɝtoʊm," ðə fɛloʊ pæntɪd, boʊɪŋ heɪstəli. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tu θaʊzən tæɹɑbənɝz hɑɹɾ ɑn maɪ hilz. ən wɪmən wɪð ðɛm! wɪð laɪtnɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz!"

"My Lord Bertome," the fellow panted, bowing hastily. "There are two thousand Taraboners hard on my heels. And women with them! With lightning on their dresses!"

"hɑɹɾ ɑn ɪz hilz," wɪɹɑmɑn mɝmɝd dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli. "wil si wʌt maɪ mæn əz tə seɪ wən i ɡɛts bæk. aɪ sɝɾənli doʊn si ɛni - !"

"Hard on his heels," Weiramon murmured disparagingly. "We'll see what my man has to say when he gets back. I certainly don't see any - !"

sʌɾən wups ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns əhɛd kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, ən ðə θʌndɝ ə hʊvz, ən ðən kwɪkli ɡæləpɪŋ lænsɝz əpɪɹd, ə floʊɪŋ taɪd spɹɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹd bɝtoʊm ən ði ʌðɝz.

Sudden whoops in the near distance ahead cut him off, and the thunder of hooves, and then quickly galloping lancers appeared, a flowing tide spreading through the trees. Straight toward Bertome and the others.

wɪɹɑmɑn læft. "kɪl huɛvɝ jə wɪʃ, wɛɹɛvɝ jə wɪʃ, dʒɛdwɪn," hi sɛd, dʒɹɔɪŋ sɔɹd wɪð ə flɝɪʃ. "aɪ juz ðə mɛθədz aɪ jus, ən ðæts ðæt!" ɹeɪsɪŋ bæk təwɔɹɾ ɪz ɑɹmmɪn, hi weɪv ðə bleɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "sɑniəɡoʊ! sɑniəɡoʊ ən ɡlɔɹi!" ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz i dɪd nɑɾ æɾ ə ʃaʊt fəɹ ɪz kʌntʃɹi tə ðoʊz fəɹ ɪz haʊs ən ɪz ɡɹeɪɾəst lʌv.

Weiramon laughed. "Kill whoever you wish, wherever you wish, Gedwyn," he said, drawing sword with a flourish. "I use the methods I use, and that's that!" Racing back toward his armsmen, he waved the blade over his head shouting, "Saniago! Saniago and glory!" It was no surprise he did not add a shout for his country to those for his House and his greatest love.

spɝɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən, bɝtoʊm ɹeɪzd ɪz oʊn vɔɪs. "seɪɡən ən kɛɹhin!" noʊ nid fəɹ sɔɹd weɪvɪŋ jɛt. "seɪɡən ən kɛɹhin!" wʌt hæd ðə mæn bɪn æftɝ?

Spurring in the same direction, Bertome raised his own voice. "Saighan and Cairhien!" No need for sword waving yet. "Saighan and Cairhien!" What had the man been after?

θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld, ən bɝtoʊm lʊk tə ðə skaɪ, pɝplɛkst. ðəɹ wɝ fju mɔɹ klaʊdz ðən ɝliɝ. noʊ; dɔɪl - dælɪn? - hæd mɛnʃən ðoʊz wɪmən. ən ðən i fɝɡɑɾ ɔl əbaʊt wʌtɛvɝ ðə ful tɛɹən wɑntəɾ əz stil-veɪl tæɹɑbənɝz pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə wʊɾɪd hɪlz təwɔɹd hɪm, ði ɝθ blumɪŋ faɪɝ ən ðə skaɪ ɹeɪnɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm.

Thunder rumbled, and Bertome looked to the sky, perplexed. There were few more clouds than earlier. No; Doile - Dalyn? - had mentioned those women. And then he forgot all about whatever the fool Tairen wanted as steel-veiled Taraboners poured over the wooded hills toward him, the earth blooming fire and the sky raining lightning ahead of them.

"seɪɡən ən kɛɹhin!" hi ʃaʊɾəd.

"Saighan and Cairhien!" he shouted.

ðə wɪn ɹoʊz.

The wind rose.

hɔɹsmən klæʃt əmɪd θɪk tʃɹiz ən hɛvi ʌndɝbɹʌʃ, wɛɹ ʃædoʊz hʌŋ hɛvəli. ðə laɪt sim tə bi feɪlɪŋ, ðə klaʊdz θɪkənɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə seɪ wɪð ðə dɛns fɔɹəs kænəpi fəɹ ə ɹuf. bumɪŋ ɹɔɹz hæf-dʒɹaʊn ðə ɹɪŋ ə stil ɑn stil, ðə ʃaʊts ə mɛn, ðə skɹimz ə hɔɹsəz. səmtaɪmz ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃʊk. səmtaɪmz ði ɛnəmi ɹeɪzd ʃaʊts.

Horsemen clashed amid thick trees and heavy underbrush, where shadows hung heavily. The light seemed to be failing, the clouds thickening overhead, but it was hard to say with the dense forest canopy for a roof. Booming roars half-drowned the ring of steel on steel, the shouts of men, the screams of horses. Sometimes the ground shook. Sometimes the enemy raised shouts.

"dɛn lʌʃɪnoʊz! dɛn lʌʃɪnoʊz ən ðə biz!"

"Den Lushenos! Den Lushenos and the Bees!"

ænælɪn! ɹæli tə ænælɪn!"

Annallin! Rally to Annallin!"

"hɛlɪn! hɛlɪn! fəɹ ðə haɪ lɔɹd sunəmən!"

"Haellin! Haellin! For the High Lord Sunamon!"

ðə læst wɑz ði oʊnli kɹaɪ vɑɹɛk ʌndɝstʊɾ ɪn ðə list, ðoʊ hi səspɛktəɾ ɛni ʌv ðə loʊkəlz u neɪm ðɛmsɛlvz haɪ lɔɹdz əɹ leɪɾiz maɪt nɑt bi ɔfɝd ðə tʃæns tə swɛɹ ði oʊθ.

The last was the only cry Varek understood in the least, though he suspected any of the locals who named themselves High Lords or Ladies might not be offered the chance to swear the Oath.

hi dʒɝkt ɪz sɔɹd fɹi fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd dʒæmd ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz əpoʊnəns ɑɹmpɪt, dʒʌst əbʌv ðə bɹɛstpleɪt, ən lɛt ðə peɪl lɪɾəl mæn tɑpəl. ə deɪnʒɝəs faɪɾɝ, əntɪl i meɪd ðə mɪsteɪk ə ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz bleɪd tu haɪ. ðə mænz beɪ kɹæʃt ɔf θɹu ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ, ən vɑɹɛk spɛɹɾ ə moʊmən fəɹ ɹəɡɹɛt. ði ænəməl lʊk bɛɾɝ ðən ðə waɪt-fʊɾɪd dʌn i wɑz fɔɹs tə ɹaɪd. ə moʊmən oʊnli, ən ðən i wɑz piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊs-sɛt tʃɹiz, wɛɹ ɪt sim vaɪnz dæŋɡəl fɹəm hæf ðə bɹæntʃəz ən bʌntʃəz ə səm ɡɹeɪ, fɛðɝi plæn fɹəm nɪɹli ɔl.

He jerked his sword free from where he had jammed it into his opponent's armpit, just above the breastplate, and let the pale little man topple. A dangerous fighter, until he made the mistake of raising his blade too high. The man's bay crashed off through the undergrowth, and Varek spared a moment for regret. The animal looked better than the white-footed dun he was forced to ride. A moment only, and then he was peering through the close-set trees, where it seemed vines dangled from half the branches and bunches of some gray, feathery plant from nearly all.

saʊnz ə bæɾəl ɹoʊz fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, bʌɾ ət fɝst i kəd si nʌθɪŋ ðət muvd. ðən ə dʌzən ɔltɑɹən lænsɝz əpɪɹɾ ət fɪfti peɪsɪz, wɔkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən piɹɪŋ əbaʊt kɛɹfəli, ðoʊ ðə weɪ ðeɪ tɔk laʊdli əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz mɔɹ ðən dʒʌstəfaɪd ðə ɹɛd slæʃɪz kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts. vɑɹɛk ɡæðɝɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz, minɪŋ tə teɪk əm ɪn. ən ɛskɔɹt, ivən ðɪs əndɪsɪplɪn ɹæbəl, maɪt bi ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ði ɝdʒən mɛsədʒ i kæɹid ɹitʃɪŋ bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kiænməaɪ ən nɑt.

Sounds of battle rose from every direction, but at first he could see nothing that moved. Then a dozen Altaran lancers appeared at fifty paces, walking their horses and peering about carefully, though the way they talked loudly among themselves more than justified the red slashes crisscrossing their breastplates. Varek gathered his reins, meaning to take them in. An escort, even this undisciplined rabble, might be the difference between the urgent message he carried reaching Banner-General Chianmai and not.

blæk stʃɹiks flæʃt fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ɛmptiɪŋ ɔltɑɹən sæɾəlz. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz dæʃt ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən əz ðə ɹaɪɾɝz fɛl, ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə dʌzən kɔɹpsəz spɹɔld ɑn ðə dæmp kɑɹpəɾ ə dɛd livz, ət list wʌn kɹɔsboʊ boʊl dʒʌɾɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi mæn. nʌθɪŋ muvd. vɑɹɛk ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. ðoʊz fʊɾ ɪn blu koʊts hæd simd izi ət fɝst, wɪð noʊ paɪks tə stæn bɪhaɪnd, bʌt ðeɪ nɛvɝ keɪm ɪndə ði oʊpən, haɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn tʃɹiz, ɪn dɪps ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ðə wɝst. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ æftɝ ðə fɹæntɪk ɹitʃɹit tə ðə ʃɪps ət fɑlm ðəɾ i hæd sin ðə wɝs i ɛvɝ kəd si, ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi ɪn ə ɹaʊt. nɑt hæf ən aʊɝ ɡɔn, ðoʊ, hi hæd sin ə hʌnʒɹəd tæɹɑbənɝz feɪs wʌn loʊn mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt. ə hʌnʒɹəd lænsɝz əɡɛnst wʌn, ən ðə tæɹɑbənɝz hæd bɪn ɹɪp tə ʃɹɛdz. lɪɾɝəli ɹɪp tə ʃɹɛdz, mɛn ən hɔɹsəz sɪmpli ɪksploʊɾɪŋ əz fæst i kəd kaʊnt; ðə slɔɾɝ hæd kəntɪnjuɾ æftɝ ðə tæɹɑbənɝz tɝn tə fli, wɛn ɑn soʊ lɔŋ əz wʌn ə ðɛm ɹɪmeɪn ɪn saɪt. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ɹɪli noʊ wɝs ðən hævɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪɹʌp bɪniθ jəɹ fit, bʌɾ ət lis deɪmeɪn juʒəwəli lɛft ɪnʌf ə jə tə bi bɛɹid.

Black streaks flashed from among the trees, emptying Altaran saddles. Their horses dashed in every direction as the riders fell, and then there were only a dozen corpses sprawled on the damp carpet of dead leaves, at least one crossbow bolt jutting from every man. Nothing moved. Varek shivered in spite of himself. Those foot in blue coats had seemed easy at first, with no pikes to stand behind, but they never came into the open, hiding behind trees, in dips in the ground. They were not the worst. He had been sure after the frantic retreat to the ships at Falme that he had seen the worse he ever could see, the Ever Victorious Army in a rout. Not half an hour gone, though, he had seen a hundred Taraboners face one lone man in a black coat. A hundred lancers against one, and the Taraboners had been ripped to shreds. Literally ripped to shreds, men and horses simply exploding as fast he could count; the slaughter had continued after the Taraboners turned to flee, went on so long as one of them remained in sight. Perhaps it was really no worse than having the ground erupt beneath your feet, but at least damane usually left enough of you to be buried.

hi hæd bɪn toʊl baɪ ðə læs mæn i mænədʒ tə spik tə ɪn ðiz wʊdz, ə ɡɹɪzəl vɛɾɝən fɹəm hoʊm liɾɪŋ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɑmɑdɪʃən paɪks, ðət kiænməaɪ wɑz ɪn ðɪs dɝɛkʃən. əhɛd, hi spɑɾəd ɹaɪɾɝləs hɔɹsəz taɪd tə tʃɹiz, ən mɛn əfʊt. meɪbi ðeɪ kəd ɡɪv ɪm fɝðɝ dɝɛkʃən. ən i wəd ɡɪv əm ðə læʃ ə hɪz tʌŋ fəɹ stændɪŋ əbaʊt waɪl ə bæɾəl ɹeɪdʒd.

He had been told by the last man he managed to speak to in these woods, a grizzled veteran from home leading a hundred Amadician pikes, that Chianmai was in this direction. Ahead, he spotted riderless horses tied to trees, and men afoot. Maybe they could give him further direction. And he would give them the lash of his tongue for standing about while a battle raged.

wən i ɹoʊɾ ɪn əmʌŋ ðɛm, hi fɝɡɑt tʌŋ-læʃɪŋz. hi hæd faʊnd wʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ, bʌt nɑɾ əɾ ɔl wʌɾ i wɑntəd tə faɪnd. ə dʌzən bædli bɝn kɔɹpsəz leɪ ɪn ə ɹoʊ. wʌn, hɪz hʌni-bɹaʊn feɪs əntʌtʃt, wɑz ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbli kiænməaɪ. ðə mɛn ɑn ðɛɹ fit wɝ ɔl tæɹɑbənɝz, ɑmɑdɪʃənz, ɔltɑɹənz. səm ə ðɛm wɝ ɪnʒɝd, tu. ði oʊnli sintʃæn wɑz ə taɪt-feɪst sʌldəm suðɪŋ ə wipɪŋ deɪmeɪn.

When he rode in among them, he forgot tongue-lashings. He had found what he was looking for, but not at all what he wanted to find. A dozen badly burned corpses lay in a row. One, his honey-brown face untouched, was recognizably Chianmai. The men on their feet were all Taraboners, Amadicians, Altarans. Some of them were injured, too. The only Seanchan was a tight-faced sul'dam soothing a weeping damane.

"wʌt hæpən hɪɹ?" vɑɹɛk dɪmændəd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz laɪk ðiz æʃəmən tə liv sɝvaɪvɝz. meɪbi ðə sʌldəm hæd fɔɾ ɪm ɔf.

"What happened here?" Varek demanded. He did not think it was like these Asha'man to leave survivors. Maybe the sul'dam had fought him off.

"mædnəs, maɪ lɔɹd." ə hʌlkɪŋ tæɹɑbənɝ ʃɹʌɡd əweɪ ðə mæn u wɑz spɹɛɾɪŋ ɔɪnmənt daʊn ɪz sɪɹd lɛft ɑɹm. ðə sliv əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn bɝn əweɪ klɪɹ tə ðə fɛloʊz bɹɛstpleɪt, jɛt dɪspaɪɾ ɪz bɝnz, hi dɪd nɑt ɡɹɪmɑs. hɪz veɪl ə stil meɪl hʌŋ baɪ ə kɔɹnɝ fɹəm ɪz ɹɛd-plum kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət, bɛɹɪŋ ə hɑɹd feɪs wɪð θɪk ɡɹeɪ mʌstæʃɪz ðət nɪɹli hɪɾ ɪz maʊθ, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ ɪnsʌltɪŋli dɝɛkt. "ə ɡɹup ʌv ɪliɑnɝz, ðeɪ fɛl ɑn əs wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ. ət fɝst, ɔl wɛnt wɛl. ðeɪ hæd nʌn ə ðə blækoʊts wɪð ðɛm. lɔɹd kiænməaɪ, hi lɛɾ əs bɹeɪvli, ən ðə . . . ðə wʊmən . . . tʃænəld laɪtnɪŋz. ðɛn, dʒʌst əz ði ɪliɑnɝz bɹoʊk, ðə laɪtnɪŋz, ðeɪ fɛl əmʌŋ ʌs, tu." hi kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə səɡnɪfɪkən lʊk ət ðə sʌldəm.

"Madness, my lord." A hulking Taraboner shrugged away the man who was spreading ointment down his seared left arm. The sleeve appeared to have been burned away clear to the fellow's breastplate, yet despite his burns, he did not grimace. His veil of steel mail hung by a corner from his red-plumed conical helmet, baring a hard face with thick gray mustaches that nearly hid his mouth, and his eyes were insultingly direct. "A group of Illianers, they fell on us without warning. At first, all went well. They had none of the blackcoats with them. Lord Chianmai, he led us bravely, and the . . . the woman . . . channeled lightnings. Then, just as the Illianers broke, the lightnings, they fell among us, too." He cut off with a significant look at the sul'dam.

ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ fiɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ fɹi fɪst ən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əz fɑɹ təwɔɹd ðə tæɹɑbənɝ əz ðə liʃ ətætʃt tə hɝ ʌðɝ ɹɪst wəɾ əlaʊ. hɝ deɪmeɪn leɪ ɪn ə wipɪŋ hip. "aɪ wɪl nɑt hɪɹ ðɪs dɔɡz wɝdz əɡɛns maɪ zækɑi! ʃiz ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn! ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn!"

She was on her feet in an instant, shaking her free fist and striding as far toward the Taraboner as the leash attached to her other wrist would allow. Her damane lay in a weeping heap. "I will not hear this dog's words against my Zakai! She is a good damane! A good damane!"

vɑɹɛk meɪd suðɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝz tə ðə wʊmən. hi hæd sin sʌldəm meɪk ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz haʊl fəɹ mɪsdidz, ən ə fju hu kɹɪpəl ðə ɹɪkælsɪtʃɹənt, bʌt moʊst wəd bɹɪsəl ivən ət wʌn ə ðə blʌɾ u kæst əspɝʒənz ɑn ə feɪvɹɪt. ðɪs tæɹɑbənɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə blʌd, ən baɪ ðə lʊk ə ðə kwɪvɝɪŋ sʌldəm, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə də mɝɾɝ. hæd ðə mæn vɔɪst ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs, ənspoʊkən tʃɑɹdʒ, vɑɹɛk θɔt ʃi maɪɾ əv kɪld ɪm ɑn ðə spɑt.

Varek made soothing gestures to the woman. He had seen sul'dam make their charges howl for misdeeds, and a few who crippled the recalcitrant, but most would bristle even at one of the Blood who cast aspersions on a favorite. This Taraboner was not of the Blood, and by the look of the quivering sul'dam, she was ready to do murder. Had the man voiced his ridiculous, unspoken charge, Varek thought she might have killed him on the spot.

"pɹɛɹz fəɹ ðə dɛd mʌst weɪt," vɑɹɛk sɛd blʌnli. wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt tə də wəɾ ɛnd wɪð ɪm ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə sikɝz, ɪf i feɪld, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə sintʃæn lɛf stændɪŋ hɪɹ ɪksɛp ðə sʌldəm. "aɪ æm əsumɪŋ kəmænd. wɪl dɪsɪnɡeɪdʒ ən tɝn saʊθ."

"Prayers for the dead must wait," Varek said bluntly. What he was about to do would end with him in the hands of the Seekers, if he failed, but there was not a Seanchan left standing here except the sul'dam. "I am assuming command. We will disengage and turn south."

"dɪsɪnɡeɪdʒ!" ðə hɛvi-ʃoʊldɝd tæɹɑbənɝ bɑɹkt. "ɪt wɪl teɪk əs deɪz tə dɪsɪnɡeɪdʒ! ði ɪliɑnɝz, ðeɪ faɪt laɪk bædʒɝz bækt ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ, ðə kɛɹhinɪn laɪk fɛɹəts ɪn ə bɑks. ðə tɛɹənz, ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt soʊ hɑɹɾ əz aɪ hæv hɝd, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ meɪbi ə dʌzən ə ðiz æʃəmən, jɛs? aɪ də nɑɾ ivən noʊ wɛɹ θɹi-kɔɹɾɝz ə maɪ mɛn ɑɹ, ɪn ðɪs dʒɑli-bæɡ!" ɛmboʊldən baɪ hɪz ɪɡzæmpəl, ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn ɡɪvɪŋ pɹoʊɾɛst, tu.

"Disengage!" the heavy-shouldered Taraboner barked. "It will take us days to disengage! The Illianers, they fight like badgers backed into a corner, the Cairhienin like ferrets in a box. The Tairens, they are not so hard as I have heard, but there are maybe a dozen of these Asha'man, yes? I do not even know where three-quarters of my men are, in this jolly-bag!" Emboldened by his example, the others began giving protest, too.

vɑɹɛk ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. ən fɔɹbɹ æskɪŋ wʌɾ ə "dʒɑli-bæɡ" wɑz; lʊkɪŋ ət ðə tæŋɡəl fɔɹəst ɔl ɝaʊnd, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə klæʃ ə bæɾəl, ðə bumz ʌv ɪksploʊʒənz ən laɪtnɪŋz, hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən. "ju wɪl ɡæðɝ jəɹ mɛn ən bɪɡɪn pʊlɪŋ bæk," hi sɛd laʊdli, kʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðɛɹ tʃæɾɝ. "nɑt tu fæst; jəl ækt ɪn junəsən." mɪɹaɪz ɔɹɾɝz tə kiænməaɪ sɛd "wɪð ɔl pɑsəbəl spid" - hi hæd mɛmɝaɪz ðɛm, ɪn keɪs sʌmθɪŋ hæpən tə ðə kɑpi ɪn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz - "ɔl pɑsəbəl spid," bʌt tu mʌtʃ spiɾ ɪn ðɪs, ən hæf ðə mɛn wəd bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd, tʃɑp tə flɪndɝz ət ði ɛnəmiz lɛʒɝ. "naʊ, muv! jə faɪt fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ!"

Varek ignored them. And forbore asking what a "jolly-bag" was; looking at the tangled forest all around, listening to the clash of battle, the booms of explosions and lightnings, he could imagine. "You will gather your men and begin pulling back," he said loudly, cutting through their chatter. "Not too fast; you will act in unison." Miraj's orders to Chianmai said "with all possible speed" - he had memorized them, in case something happened to the copy in his saddlebags - "all possible speed," but too much speed in this, and half the men would be left behind, chopped to flinders at the enemy's leisure. "Now, move! You fight for the Empress, may she live forever!"

ðət læst wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ jə toʊl fɹɛʃ ɹəkɹuts, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə lɪsnɪŋ mɛn dʒɝkt əz ɪf i hæd stʃɹʌk əm ɔl wɪð ɪz kwɝt. boʊɪŋ kwɪkli ən dipli, hænz ɑn niz, ðeɪ ɔl bʌt flu tə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. stʃɹeɪnʒ. naʊ ɪt wɑz ʌp tə hɪm tə faɪn ðə sintʃæn junəts. wʌn ə ðoʊz wəd bi kəmændəd baɪ sʌmwʌn əbʌv hɪm, ən i kəd pæs ɪz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi.

That last was the sort of thing you told fresh recruits, but for some reason, the listening men jerked as if he had struck them all with his quirt. Bowing quickly and deeply, hands on knees, they all but flew to their horses. Strange. Now it was up to him to find the Seanchan units. One of those would be commanded by someone above him, and he could pass his responsibility.

ðə sʌldəm wɑz ɑn əɹ niz, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ stɪl wipɪŋ deɪmeɪnz hɛɹ ən kɹunɪŋ sɔfli. "ɡɛɾ əɹ suð daʊn," hi toʊl hɝ. wɪð ɔl pɑsəbəl spid. ən i θɔɾ i hæd sin ə tʌtʃ ʌv æŋzaɪəɾi ɪn mɪɹaɪz aɪz. wʌt kəd meɪk kɛnɝ mɪɹaɪ æŋkʃəs? "aɪ θɪŋk wɪl bi dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn jə sʌldəm tə ðə saʊθ." naʊ, waɪ wəd ðət meɪk ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ feɪs?

The sul'dam was on her knees, stroking her still weeping damane's hair and crooning softly. "Get her soothed down," he told her. With all possible speed. And he thought he had seen a touch of anxiety in Miraj's eyes. What could make Kennar Miraj anxious? "I think we will be depending on you sul'dam to the south." Now, why would that make the blood drain from her face?

bæʃɪɹ stʊd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz, fɹaʊnɪŋ θɹu hɪz hɛlməts feɪs-bɑɹz ət wʌɾ i sɔ. hɪz beɪ nʌzəld ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi hɛld ɪz kloʊk kloʊs əɡɛns ðə wɪnd. mɔɹ tə əvɔɪɾ ɛni moʊʃən ðət wəd dʒɹɔ aɪz ðən fəɹ ðə koʊld, ðoʊ ðət tʃɪld ɪz flɛʃ. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə spɹɪŋ bɹiz bæk ɪn sɑldɑiə, bʌt mʌnθs ɪn ðə saʊθlənz hæd sɔfən hɪm. ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹaɪt bɪtwin ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz ðət seɪld əlɔŋ kwɪkli, ðə sʌn stɪl leɪ ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə mɪddeɪ. ən əhɛɾ ə hɪm. dʒʌs kəz jə bɪɡæn ə bæɾəl feɪsɪŋ wɛs dɪd nɑt min jə ɛndəɾ ɪt ðət weɪ. bɪfɔɹ ɪm leɪ ə bɹɔd pæstʃɝ wɛɹ flɑks ə blæk-ænd-waɪt ɡoʊts kɹɑpt ət ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæs ɪn dɛsəltɔɹi fæʃən dʒʌst əz ɪf ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæɾəl ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm. nɑt ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɛni saɪn ʌv ɪt hɪɹ. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ə mæn kəd ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf kʌt tə dɑl ɹæɡz kɹɔsɪŋ ðət mɛdoʊ. ən ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, wɛðɝ fɔɹəst əɹ ɑləv ɡɹoʊvz əɹ θɪkəts, jə dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz si ði ɛnəmi bɪfɔɹ jə wɝ ɑn tɑp ə hɪm, skaʊts əɹ noʊ skaʊts.

Bashere stood just inside the edge of the trees, frowning through his helmet's face-bars at what he saw. His bay nuzzled his shoulder. He held his cloak close against the wind. More to avoid any motion that would draw eyes than for the cold, though that chilled his flesh. It would have been a spring breeze back in Saldaea, but months in the southlands had softened him. Shining bright between gray clouds that sailed along quickly, the sun still lay a little short of midday. And ahead of him. Just because you began a battle facing west did not mean you ended it that way. Before him lay a broad pasture where flocks of black-and-white goats cropped at the brown grass in desultory fashion just as if there was no battle raging all around them. Not that there was any sign of it here. For the moment. A man could get himself cut to doll rags crossing that meadow. And in the trees, whether forest or olive groves or thickets, you did not always see the enemy before you were on top of him, scouts or no scouts.

"ɪf wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə kɹɔs," ɡəm mʌɾɝd, ɹʌbɪŋ ə waɪd hæn oʊvɝ ɪz bɔl hɛd, "wi ʃəd kɹɔs. laɪts tʃɹuθ, wɝ weɪstɪŋ taɪm." əmənʒɹɪd snæpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt; laɪkli, ðə mun-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm θɪŋ. hi wəɾ əɡɹi wɪð ə tɛɹən wən hɔɹsəz klaɪm tʃɹiz.

"If we're going to cross," Gueyam muttered, rubbing a wide hand over his bald head, "we should cross. Light's truth, we're wasting time." Amondrid snapped his mouth shut; likely, the moon-faced Cairhienin had been about to say much the same thing. He would agree with a Tairen when horses climbed trees.

dʒɛɹdwɪn səmɛɝɪs snɔɹɾɪd. ðə mæn ʃʊɾə ɡɹoʊn ə bɪɹd tə haɪd ðət nɛɹoʊ dʒɔ. ɪt meɪɾ ɪz hɛd lʊk laɪk ə fɔɹəstɝz splɪɾɪŋ wɛdʒ. "aɪ də seɪ ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd," hi mʌɾɝd. "aɪv lɔst ɪnʌf mɛn tə ðoʊz laɪt-kɝs deɪmeɪn, ən . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf wɪð ən ənizi ɡlæns təwɔɹd ɹɑtʃeɪd.

Jeordwyn Semaris snorted. The man should have grown a beard to hide that narrow jaw. It made his head look like a forester's splitting wedge. "I do say go around," he muttered. "I've lost enough men to those Light-cursed damane, and . . ." He trailed off with an uneasy glance toward Rochaid.

ðə jʌŋ æʃəmən stʊd baɪ hɪmsɛlf, maʊθ taɪt, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðət dʒɹæɡən pɪn ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ. meɪbi wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz wɝθ ɪt, baɪ ðə lʊk ə hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ noʊɪŋ ɛɹ əbaʊt ðə bɔɪ naʊ, oʊnli fɹaʊnɪŋ wɝi.

The young Asha'man stood by himself, mouth tight, fingering that Dragon pin on his collar. Maybe wondering whether it was worth it, by the look of him. There was no knowing air about the boy now, only frowning worry.

liɾɪŋ kwɪk baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz, bæʃɪɹ stʃɹoʊd tə ði æʃəmən ən dʒɹu hɪm fɑɹðɝ əsaɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. pʊʃt ɪm fɑɹðɝ əsaɪd. ɹɑtʃeɪd skaʊld, ɡoʊɪŋ ɹɪlʌktənli. ðə mæn wɑz tɔl ɪnʌf tə lum oʊvɝ bæʃɪɹ, bʌt bæʃɪɹ wɑz hævɪŋ nʌn ʌv ɪt.

Leading Quick by the reins, Bashere strode to the Asha'man and drew him farther aside in the trees. Pushed him farther aside. Rochaid scowled, going reluctantly. The man was tall enough to loom over Bashere, but Bashere was having none of it.

"kæn aɪ kaʊn ɑn jəɹ pipəl nɛks taɪm?" bæʃɪɹ dɪmændəd, dʒɝkɪŋ ə mʌstæʃ ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. "noʊ dɪleɪz?" ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən ɪz fɛloʊz sim tə hæv ɡɹoʊn sloʊɝ ən sloʊɝ ɹɪspɑndɪŋ wən ðeɪ faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz ɑpəzət deɪmeɪn.

"Can I count on your people next time?" Bashere demanded, jerking a mustache in irritation. "No delays?" Rochaid and his fellows seemed to have grown slower and slower responding when they found themselves opposite damane.

"aɪ noʊ wʌɾ aɪm əbaʊt, bæʃɪɹ," ɹɑtʃeɪd snɑɹəld. "ɑɹənt wi kɪlɪŋ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm fəɹ ju? əz fɑɹ əz aɪ kən si, wɝ əbaʊt dʌn!"

"I know what I'm about, Bashere," Rochaid snarled. "Aren't we killing enough of them for you? As far as I can see, we're about done!"

bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd sloʊli. nɑɾ ɪn əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə læst. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ɛnəmi soʊlʒɝz lɛft, ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ jə lʊk hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf. bʌɾ ə ɡʊd mɛni wɝ dɛd. hi hæd pæɾɝnd ɪz muvməns ɑn wʌɾ i hæd stʌɾid ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wən ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə laɪt sɛldəm keɪm ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ðə nʌmbɝz ðeɪ hæd tə feɪs. slæʃ ət ðə flæŋks, ən ɹʌn. slæʃ ət ðə ɹɪɹ, ən ɹʌn. slæʃ, ən ɹʌn, ən wən ði ɛnəmi tʃeɪst æftɝ, tɝn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn jə hæd tʃoʊzən bɪfɔɹhænd, wɛɹ ðə lidʒənmɛn leɪ weɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ kɹɔsboʊz, tɝn ən kʌɾ əɾ ɪm əntɪl ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɹʌn əɡɛn. əɹ əntɪl i bɹoʊk. ɔlɹɛɾi tədeɪ hi hæd bɹoʊkən tæɹɑbənɝz, ɑmɑdɪʃənz, ɔltɑɹənz ən ðiz sintʃæn ɪn ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɑɹmɝ. hi hæd sin mɔɹ ɛnəmi dɛd ðən ɪn ɛni faɪt sɪns ðə blʌd snoʊ. bʌɾ ɪf i hæɾ æʃəmən, ði ʌðɝ saɪd hæd ðoʊz deɪmeɪn. ə ɡʊd θɝɾ ə hɪz sɑldəiənz leɪ dɛɾ əlɔŋ ðə maɪlz bɪhaɪnd. nɪɹli hæf ɪz fɔɹs wɑz dɛd, ɔl toʊld, ən ðəɹ wɝ stɪl mɔɹ sintʃæn aʊt ðəɹ wɪð ðɛɹ kɝst wɪmən, ən tæɹɑbənɝz, ən ɑmɑdɪʃənz ən ɔltɑɹənz. ðeɪ dʒʌs kɛp kʌmɪŋ, mɔɹ əpɪɹɪŋ əz sun əz i fɪnɪʃt ðə læst. ən ði æʃəmən wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ . . . hɛzɪɾənt.

Bashere nodded slowly. Not in agreement with the last. There were plenty of enemy soldiers left, almost anywhere you looked hard enough. But a good many were dead. He had patterned his movements on what he had studied of the Trolloc Wars, when the forces of the Light seldom came anywhere near the numbers they had to face. Slash at the flanks, and run. Slash at the rear, and run. Slash, and run, and when the enemy chased after, turn on the ground you had chosen beforehand, where the legionmen lay waiting with their crossbows, turn and cut at him until it was time to run again. Or until he broke. Already today he had broken Taraboners, Amadicians, Altarans and these Seanchan in their strange armor. He had seen more enemy dead than in any fight since the Blood Snow. But if he had Asha'man, the other side had those damane. A good third of his Saldaeans lay dead along the miles behind. Nearly half his force was dead, all told, and there were still more Seanchan out there with their cursed women, and Taraboners, and Amadicians and Altarans. They just kept coming, more appearing as soon as he finished the last. And the Asha'man were growing . . . hesitant.

swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə kwɪks sæɾəl, hi ɹoʊd bæk tə dʒɛɹdwɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. "wi ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd," hi ɔɹɾɝd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ dʒɛɹdwɪnz nɑdz əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd ɡəm ən əmənʒɹɪdz skaʊlz. "tʃɹɪpəl skaʊts aʊt. aɪ min tə pʊʃ hɑɹd, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ə deɪmeɪn." noʊ wʌn læft.

Swinging into Quick's saddle, he rode back to Jeordwyn and the others. "We go around," he ordered, ignoring Jeordwyn's nods as much as he did Gueyam and Amondrid's scowls. "Triple scouts out. I mean to push hard, but I don't want to trip over a damane." No one laughed.

ɹɑtʃeɪd hæd ɡæðɝd ði ʌðɝ faɪv æʃəmən ɝaʊn hɪm, wʌn wɪð ə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd pɪn tə hɪz kɑlɝ, ði ʌðɝz wɪθaʊt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu mɔɹ wɪð bɛɹ kɑlɝz wən ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd aʊt ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf æʃəmən nu haʊ tə kɪl, soʊ dɪd deɪmeɪn. weɪvɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz æŋɡɹəli, ɹɑtʃeɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɹɛd, ðɛɹz blæŋk ən stʌbɝn. bæʃɪɹ dʒʌs hoʊpt ɹɑtʃeɪd kəd kip ɔl ə ðɛm fɹəm dɛzɝɾɪŋ. tədeɪ hæd bɪn kɑsli ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ ðət sɔɹɾ ə mæn wɑndɝɪŋ əbaʊt lus.

Rochaid had gathered the other five Asha'man around him, one with a silver sword pinned to his collar, the others without. There had been two more with bare collars when they started out that morning, but if Asha'man knew how to kill, so did damane. Waving his arms angrily, Rochaid appeared to be arguing with them. His face was red, theirs blank and stubborn. Bashere just hoped Rochaid could keep all of them from deserting. Today had been costly enough without adding that sort of man wandering about loose.

ə laɪt ɹeɪn fɛl. ɹænd skaʊld ət ðə θɪk blæk klaʊdz ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə skaɪ, ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə əbskjʊɹ ə peɪl sʌn hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə fɑɹ hɝaɪzən. laɪt ɹeɪn naʊ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd θɪkən laɪk ðoʊz klaʊdz! ɪɹɪɾəbli hi ɹɪtɝn tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə læn əhɛɾ ə hɪm. ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz pɹɪkt ɪz tɛmpəlz. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm, ðə lænd wɑz klɪɹ əz ə mæp dɪspaɪt ðə wɛðɝ. klɪɹ ɪnʌf, ɛniweɪ. hɪlz sɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ, səm kʌvɝd wɪð θɪkəts əɹ ɑləv tʃɹiz, ʌðɝz bɛɹ ɡɹæs əɹ dʒʌst stoʊn ən widz. hi θɔɾ i sɔ muvmən ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə kɑps, ðən əɡɛn əmʌŋ ðə ɹoʊz ʌv ən ɑləv ɔɹtʃɝɾ ɑn ənʌðɝ hɪl ə maɪl fɹəm ðə kɑps. θɪŋkɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. dɛd mɛn leɪ əkɹɔs ðə maɪlz bɪhaɪnd, dɛɾ ɛnəmiz. dɛd wɪmən, tu, hi nu, bʌɾ i hæd steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn hæd daɪd, ɹəfjuz tə si ðɛɹ feɪsəz. moʊs θɔɾ ɪt wɑz heɪtʃɹəd fəɹ ðoʊz u kɪl soʊ mɛni ʌv ɪz fɑloʊɝz.

A light rain fell. Rand scowled at the thick black clouds gathering the sky, already beginning to obscure a pale sun halfway down to the far horizon. Light rain now, but it would thicken like those clouds! Irritably he returned to studying the land ahead of him. The Crown of Swords pricked his temples. With the Power in him, the land was clear as a map despite the weather. Clear enough, anyway. Hills sinking away, some covered with thickets or olive trees, others bare grass or just stone and weeds. He thought he saw movement at the edge of a copse, then again among the rows of an olive orchard on another hill a mile from the copse. Thinking was not enough. Dead men lay across the miles behind, dead enemies. Dead women, too, he knew, but he had stayed away from anywhere sul'dam and damane had died, refused to see their faces. Most thought it was hatred for those who killed so many of his followers.

teɪdeɪʃɝ fɹɪskt ə fju stɛps ɑn ðə hɪltɑp bɪfɔɹ ɹænd sɛɾəld ɪm wɪð ə fɝm hæn ən ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz niz. ə faɪn θɪŋ ɪf ə sʌldəm spɑɾəd ɪz muvmənt. ðə fju tʃɹiz ɝaʊn ɪm wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə haɪd mʌtʃ. veɪɡli, hi ɹilaɪzd i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə wʌn ə ðɛm. teɪdeɪʃɝ tɔst ɪz hɛd. ɹænd tʌk ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, dʒʌs ðə kɑɹv bʌɾ ɛn stɪkɪŋ aʊt, tə fɹi boʊθ hænz ɪn keɪs ðə ɡɛldɪŋ wɑz nɑt sæɾəsfaɪd. hi cʊɾə teɪkən wɪɹinəs fɹəm ðə hɔɹs wɪð seɪɾɪn, bʌɾ i nu noʊ weɪ tə meɪk ɪɾ oʊbeɪ wɪð ðə paʊɝ.

Tai'daishar frisked a few steps on the hilltop before Rand settled him with a firm hand and the pressure of his knees. A fine thing if a sul'dam spotted his movement. The few trees around him were not enough to hide much. Vaguely, he realized he did not recognize a one of them. Tai'daishar tossed his head. Rand tucked the Dragon Scepter into his saddlebags, just the carved butt end sticking out, to free both hands in case the gelding was not satisfied. He could have taken weariness from the horse with saidin, but he knew no way to make it obey with the Power.

hi kəd nɑt si haʊ ðə ɡɛldɪŋ ɹɪteɪn ɪnʌf ɛnɝdʒi. seɪɾɪn fɪl hɪm, bʌbəld ɪn hɪm, bʌɾ ɪz dɪstənli fɛl bɑɾi wɑntəd tə sæɡ wɪð wɪɹinəs. pɑɹɾ ə ðət wɑz ðə ʃɪɹ əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ i hæd hændəl tədeɪ. pɑɹt wɑz ðə stʃɹeɪn ə faɪɾɪŋ seɪɾɪn tə meɪk ɪt də wʌɾ i wɑntəd. ɔlweɪz, seɪɾɪn hæd tə bi kɑŋkɝd, fɔɹst, bʌt nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ laɪk tədeɪ. ðə hæf-hild, nɛvɝ-hilɪŋ wunz ɪn ɪz lɛf saɪd wɝ æɡəni, ði oʊldɝ ən ɔɡɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɪl θɹu ðə vɔɪd, ðə nuɝ ə bleɪz ə ɹɔ fleɪm.

He could not see how the gelding retained enough energy. Saidin filled him, bubbled in him, but his distantly felt body wanted to sag with weariness. Part of that was the sheer amount of the Power he had handled today. Part was the strain of fighting saidin to make it do what he wanted. Always, saidin had to be conquered, forced, but never before like today. The half-healed, never-healing wounds in his left side were agony, the older an auger trying to drill through the Void, the newer a blaze of raw flame.

"ɪt wɑz ən æksəɾənt, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ædli sɛd sʌɾənli. "aɪ swɛɹ ɪt wɑz!"

"It was an accident, my Lord Dragon," Adley said suddenly. "I swear it was!"

"ʃʌɾ ʌp ən wɑtʃ!" ɹænd toʊld ɪm hɑɹʃli. ædliz aɪz sæŋk tə hɪz hænz ɑn ɪz oʊn ɹeɪnz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən i ɹeɪk dæmp hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs ən dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ʌp oʊbiɾiəntli.

"Shut up and watch!" Rand told him harshly. Adley's eyes sank to his hands on his own reins for a moment, then he raked damp hair out of his face and jerked his head up obediently.

tədeɪ, hɪɹ, kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ seɪɾɪn wɑz hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, bʌt lɛɾɪŋ ɪt slɪp ɛnitaɪm, ɛniwɛɹ, kəd kɪl ju. ædli hæd lɛɾ ɪt slɪp, ən mɛn hæd daɪɾ ɪn ʌnkəntʃɹoʊl bɝsts ə faɪɝ, nɑt dʒʌs ði ɑmɑdɪʃənz i hæd bɪn eɪmɪŋ æt, bʌt nɪɹ θɝɾi ʌv eɪlɪlz ɑɹmmɪn ən ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni ʌv ænɑiɛləz.

Today, here, controlling saidin was harder than ever, but letting it slip anytime, anywhere, could kill you. Adley had let it slip, and men had died in uncontrolled bursts of fire, not just the Amadicians he had been aiming at, but near thirty of Ailil's armsmen and almost as many of Anaiyella's.

ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz slɪp, ædli wʊɾə bɪn wɪð mɔɹ, wɪð ðə kəmpænjənz ɪn ðə wʊdz hæf ə maɪl tə ðə saʊθ. nɛɹɪʃmə ən hɑpwəl wɝ wɪð ðə dɪfɛndɝz, tə ðə nɔɹθ. ɹænd wɑntəɾ ædli ʌndɝ ɪz aɪ. hæɾ ɛni ʌðɝ "æksəɾənts" hæpənd, aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt? hi kəd nɑt wɑtʃ ɛvɹiwʌn, ɔl ðə taɪm. flɪnz feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪm əz deɪ-oʊl dɛθ, ən dæʃivə, fɑɹ fɹəm lʊkɪŋ veɪɡ, simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə swɛɾɪŋ wɪð kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. hi stɪl mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, soʊ loʊ ɹænd kəd nɑt hɪɹ ivən wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm, bʌt ðə mæn mɑpt ɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz feɪs kəntɪnjuəli wɪð ə sɑɾən leɪs-ɛdʒ lɪnən hæŋkɝtʃɪf ðət hæd ɡɹoʊn mɔɹ ðən ɡɹaɪmi əz ðə deɪ wɔɹ ɑn. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd slɪpt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, niðɝ ðeɪ nɔɹ ædli hɛl ðə paʊɝ naʊ. nɔɹ wəɾ əntɪl i ɪnstʃɹʌktəɾ əm tə siz ɪt.

Except for his slip, Adley would have been with Morr, with the Companions in the woods half a mile to the south. Narishma and Hopwil were with the Defenders, to the north. Rand wanted Adley under his eye. Had any other "accidents" happened, out of his sight? He could not watch everyone, all the time. Flinn's face was grim as day-old death, and Dashiva, far from looking vague, seemed on the point of sweating with concentration. He still muttered to himself under his breath, so low Rand could not hear even with the Power in him, but the man mopped rain from his face continually with a sodden lace-edged linen handkerchief that had grown more than grimy as the day wore on. Rand did not think they had slipped. In any case, neither they nor Adley held the Power now. Nor would until he instructed them to seize it.

"ɪz ɪt dʌn?" ænɑiɛlə æsk bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"Is it done?" Anaiyella asked behind him.

hidləs ə hu maɪt bi wɑtʃɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ, ɹænd wil teɪdeɪʃɝ ɝaʊn tə feɪs hɝ. ðə tɛɹən wʊmən stɑɹɾəd bæk ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ ɹɪtʃli ɪlæbɹət ɹeɪn keɪp fɔlɪŋ tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. hɝ tʃik ɡeɪv ə twɪtʃ. hɝ aɪz maɪɾ əv bɪn fʊl ə fɪɹ, əɹ heɪt. əɾ əɹ saɪd, eɪlɪl fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz kɑmli wɪð ɹɛd-ɡlʌv hænz.

Heedless of who might be watching out there, Rand wheeled Tai'daishar around to face her. The Tairen woman started back in her saddle, the hood of her richly elaborate rain cape falling to her shoulders. Her cheek gave a twitch. Her eyes might have been full of fear, or hate. At her side, Ailil fingered her reins calmly with red-gloved hands.

"wʌt mɔɹ kən jə wɑnt?" ðə smɔlɝ wʊmən æskt ɪn ə kul vɔɪs. ə leɪɾi biɪŋ pəlaɪt tə ə miniəl. bɛɹli. "ɪf ðə saɪz ʌv ə vɪktɝi ɪz əkaʊntəd baɪ dɛɾ ɛnəmiz, aɪ θɪŋk tədeɪ əloʊn wɪl pʊt jəɹ neɪm ɪn ðə hɪstɝiz."

"What more can you want?" the smaller woman asked in a cool voice. A lady being polite to a menial. Barely. "If the size of a victory is accounted by dead enemies, I think today alone will put your name in the histories."

"aɪ min tə dʒɹaɪv ðə sintʃæn ɪndə ðə si!" ɹænd snæpt. laɪt, hi hæd tə fɪnɪʃ əm naʊ, wən i hæd ðə tʃæns! hi kəd nɑt faɪt ðə sintʃæn ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu hu əɹ wʌɾ ɛls, ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm! "aɪ dɪɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ, ən əl əɡɛn!"

"I mean to drive the Seanchan into the sea!" Rand snapped. Light, he had to finish them now, when he had the chance! He could not fight the Seanchan and the Forsaken and the Light alone knew who or what else, all at the same time! "I did it before, and I will again!"

juv ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ hɪɾən ɪn jəɹ pɑkət ðɪs taɪm? luz θɝɪn æsk slaɪli. ɹænd snɑɹəld əɾ ɪm saɪlənli.

Do you have the Horn of Valere hidden in your pocket this time? Lews Therin asked slyly. Rand snarled at him silently.

"ðɛɹz sʌmwʌn bɪloʊ," flɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. "ɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðɪs weɪ. fɹəm ðə wɛst."

"There's someone below," Flinn said suddenly. "Riding up this way. From the west."

ɹænd pʊld ɪz maʊn bæk ɝaʊnd. lidʒənmɛn ɹɪŋ ðə sloʊps ə ðə hɪl, ðoʊ ðeɪ hɪd wɛl ɪnʌf ðəɾ i sɛldəm kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ə blu koʊt. nʌn ə ðɛm hæɾ ə hɔɹs. hu wəd bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ . . .

Rand pulled his mount back around. Legionmen ringed the slopes of the hill, though they hid well enough that he seldom caught sight of a blue coat. None of them had a horse. Who would be riding . . .

bæʃɪɹz beɪ tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp ðə sloʊp ɔlmoʊst əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ lɛvəl ɡɹaʊnd. bæʃɪɹz hɛlmət hʌŋ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, ən ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf lʊk taɪɝd. wɪθaʊt pɹiæmbəl, hi spoʊk ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "wɝ fɪnɪʃt, hɪɹ. pɑɹɾ ə faɪɾɪŋ ɪz noʊɪŋ wən tə ɡoʊ, ən ɪts taɪm. aɪv lɛft faɪv hʌnʒɹəd dɛd bɪhaɪnd, nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ən tu ʌv jəɹ soʊlʒɝz fəɹ sɔlt. aɪ sɛn θɹi mɔɹ tə faɪn səmɝædʒɹɪd, ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən wɪɹɑmɑn ən tɛl əm tə ɹæli ɑn ju. aɪ daʊt ðəɹ ɪn ɛni bɛɾɝ kəndɪʃən ðən aɪ æm. haʊ dʌz jəɹ bʊtʃɝz bɪl ɹʌn?"

Bashere's bay trotted up the slope almost as though it were level ground. Bashere's helmet hung from his saddle, and the man himself looked tired. Without preamble, he spoke in a flat voice. "We're finished, here. Part of fighting is knowing when to go, and it's time. I've left five hundred dead behind, near enough, and two of your Soldiers for salt. I sent three more to find Semaradrid, Gregorin and Weiramon and tell them to rally on you. I doubt they're in any better condition than I am. How does your butcher's bill run?"

ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kwɛstʃən. hɪz oʊn dɛd tɑp bæʃɪɹz baɪ kloʊs tə tu hʌnʒɹəd. "ju hæd noʊ ɹaɪt sɛndɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz tə ði ʌðɝz. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðəɹ ɑɹ hæf ə dʌzən æʃəmən lɛft - soʊ lɔŋ əz ðɛɹz mi! - aɪ hæv ɪnʌf! aɪ min tə faɪn ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sintʃæn ɑɹmi ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt, bæʃɪɹ. aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm æɾ ɔltɑɹə tə tæɹɑbən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə."

Rand ignored the question. His own dead topped Bashere's by close to two hundred. "You had no right sending orders to the others. So long as there are half a dozen Asha'man left - so long as there's me! - I have enough! I mean to find the rest of the Seanchan army and destroy it, Bashere. I won't let them add Altara to Tarabon and Amadicia."

bæʃɪɹ nʌkəld ɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə ɹaɪ læf. "ju wɑnə faɪn ðɛm. lʊk aʊt ðɛɹ." hi swɛpt ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn əkɹɔs ðə hɪlz tə ðə wɛst. "aɪ kæn pɔɪn tə ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ spɑt, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ tɛn, meɪbi fɪftin θaʊzən kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si fɹəm hɪɹ, ɪf ðoʊz tʃɹiz wɝn ɪn ðə weɪ. aɪ dænst wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɡɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðɛm ənsin tə ɹitʃ ju. meɪbi ə hʌnʒɹəd deɪmeɪn daʊn ðɛɹ. meɪbi mɔɹ. mɔɹ kʌmɪŋ, fəɹ ʃʊɹ, ən mɔɹ mɛn. simz ðɛɹ dʒɛnɝəl əz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ju. aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪzən ɔlweɪz tʃiz ən eɪl biɪŋ tɑvɝən."

Bashere knuckled his thick mustaches with a wry laugh. "You want to find them. Look out there." He swept a gauntleted hand across the hills to the west. "I can't point to a particular spot, but there are ten, maybe fifteen thousand close enough to see from here, if those trees weren't in the way. I danced with the Dark One getting through them unseen to reach you. Maybe a hundred damane down there. Maybe more. More coming, for sure, and more men. Seems their general has decided to concentrate on you. I suppose it isn't always cheese and ale being ta'veren."

"ɪf ðəɹ aʊt ðəɹ . . ." ɹænd skæn ðə hɪlz. ðə ɹeɪn fɛl mɔɹ hɛvəli. wɛɹ hæɾ i sin muvmənt? laɪt, hi wɑz taɪɝd. seɪɾɪn hæmɝɾ ət hɪm. ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi tʌtʃt ðə ɹæp bʌndəl bɪniθ ɪz stɝəp lɛðɝ. hɪz hæn dʒɝkt əweɪ ʌv ɪts oʊn əkɔɹd. tɛn θaʊzənd, ivən fɪftin . . . wʌns səmɝædʒɹɪd ɹitʃt hɪm, ən ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, ən wɪɹɑmɑn . . . mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, wʌns ðə ɹɛst ə ði æʃəmən dɪd . . . "ɪf ðəɹ aʊt ðɛɹ, ðæts wɛɹ əl dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðɛm, bæʃɪɹ. əl hɪɾ əm fɹəm ɔl saɪdz, ðə weɪ wi ɪntɛndəɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs."

"If they're out there . . ." Rand scanned the hills. The rain fell more heavily. Where had he seen movement? Light, he was tired. Saidin hammered at him. Unconsciously he touched the wrapped bundled beneath his stirrup leather. His hand jerked away of its own accord. Ten thousand, even fifteen . . . Once Semaradrid reached him, and Gregorin, and Weiramon . . . More important, once the rest of the Asha'man did . . . "If they're out there, that's where I'll destroy them, Bashere. I'll hit them from all sides, the way we intended in the first place."
