fɹaʊnɪŋ, bæʃɪɹ ɹeɪn ɪz hɔɹs kloʊsɝ, əntɪl ɪz ni ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃt ɹænz. flɪn muvd ɪz maʊn əweɪ, bʌɾ ædli wɑz tu foʊkəst ɑn stɛɹɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹeɪn tə noʊɾəs ɛniθɪŋ soʊ nɪɹ, ən dæʃivə, stɪl waɪpɪŋ ɪz feɪs ɪnsɛsənli, stɛɹd wɪð oʊpən ɪntʃɹəst. bæʃɪɹ loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs tə ə mɝmɝ. "ju ɑɹən θɪŋkɪŋ stʃɹeɪt. ðət wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn, ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, bʌt ðɛɹ dʒɛnɝəl θɪŋks fæst. hi spɹɛɾ aʊt tə blʌn əɹ ətæks bɪfɔɹ wi kəd fɔl ɑn ɪm spɹɛɾ aʊt mɑɹtʃɪŋ. wiv kɑst ɪm ivən soʊ, ɪt simz, ən i naʊ hiz pʊlɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. jə woʊn kætʃ ɪm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. hi wɑns əs tə kʌm ət hɪm. hiz aʊt ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪt. æʃəmən əɹ noʊ æʃəmən, ɪf wi stænd noʊz-tə-noʊz wɪð ðɪs fɛloʊ, aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi ðə vʌltʃɝz ɡɹoʊ fæɾ ən noʊbɑdi ɹaɪdz əweɪ."

Frowning, Bashere reined his horse closer, until his knee almost touched Rand's. Flinn moved his mount away, but Adley was too focused on staring through the rain to notice anything so near, and Dashiva, still wiping his face incessantly, stared with open interest. Bashere lowered his voice to a murmur. "You aren't thinking straight. That was a good plan, in the beginning, but their general thinks fast. He spread out to blunt our attacks before we could fall on him spread out marching. We've cost him even so, it seems, and he now he's pulling everything together. You won't catch him by surprise. He wants us to come at him. He's out there waiting for it. Asha'man or no Asha'man, if we stand nose-to-nose with this fellow, I think maybe the vultures grow fat and nobody rides away."

"noʊbɑdi stænz noʊz-tə-noʊz wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ɹænd ɡɹaʊld. "ðə fɔɹseɪkən kəd tɛl ɪm ðæt, huɛvɝ i ɪz. ɹaɪt, flɪn? dæʃivə?" flɪn nɑɾəd ənsɝteɪnli. dæʃivə flɪntʃt. "ju θɪŋk aɪ kæn sɝpɹaɪz hɪm, bæʃɪɹ? wɑtʃ!" pʊlɪŋ ðə lɔŋ bʌndəl lus, hi stʃɹɪpt əweɪ ðə klɔθ kʌvɝɪŋ, ən ɹænd hɝd ɡæsps əz ɹeɪndʒɹɑps ɡlɪsən ɑn ə sɔɹd simɪŋli meɪɾ ə kɹɪstəl. ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd. "lɛts si ɪf hiz sɝpɹaɪz baɪ kælændɝ ɪn ðə hænz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bæʃɪɹ."

"Nobody stands nose-to-nose with the Dragon Reborn," Rand growled. "The Forsaken could tell him that, whoever he is. Right, Flinn? Dashiva?" Flinn nodded uncertainly. Dashiva flinched. "You think I can't surprise him, Bashere? Watch!" Pulling the long bundle loose, he stripped away the cloth covering, and Rand heard gasps as raindrops glistened on a sword seemingly made of crystal. The Sword That Is Not a Sword. "Let's see if he's surprised by Callandor in the hands of the Dragon Reborn, Bashere."

kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ðə tʃɹænslusən bleɪɾ ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɛlboʊ, ɹænd ɹoʊd teɪdeɪʃɝ fɔɹwɝɾ ə fju stɛps. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə. hi hæd noʊ klɪɹɝ vju fɹəm ðɛɹ. ɪksɛpt . . . sʌmθɪŋ spaɪɾɝd əkɹɔs ði aʊɾɝ sɝfəs ə ðə vɔɪd, ə ɹɪəlɪŋ blæk wɛb. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd. ðə læs taɪm i hæd juz kælændɝ, ɹɪli juzd ɪt, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ ðə dɛd bæk tə laɪf. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i kəd də ɛniθɪŋ, ðɛn, ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. laɪk ə mædmæn θɪŋkɪŋ i kəd flaɪ. bʌɾ i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ. hæɾ i nɑt pɹuvd ɪt taɪm ən əɡɛn? hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs θɹu ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd.

Cradling the translucent blade in the crook of his elbow, Rand rode Tai'daishar forward a few steps. There was no reason to. He had no clearer view from there. Except . . . Something spidered across the outer surface of the Void, a wriggling black web. He was afraid. The last time he had used Callandor, really used it, he had tried to bring the dead back to life. He had been sure he could do anything, then, anything at all. Like a madman thinking he could fly. But he was the Dragon Reborn. He could do anything. Had he not proved it time and again? He reached for the Source through the Sword That Is Not a Sword.

seɪɾɪn sim tə lip ɪndə kælændɝ bɪfɔɹ i tʌtʃt ðə sɔɹs θɹu ɪt. fɹəm pɑməl tə pɔɪnt, ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd ʃoʊn wɪð ə waɪt laɪt. hi hæɾ oʊnli θɔt ðə paʊɝ fɪld ɪm bɪfɔɹ. naʊ hi hɛl mɔɹ ðən tɛn mɛn kəɾ əv əneɪɾɪd, ə hʌnʒɹəd, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ mɛni. ðə faɪɝz ə ðə sʌn, sɪɹɪŋ θɹu hɪz hɛd. ðə koʊld ʌv ɔl ə ðə wɪntɝz ʌv ɔl ði eɪdʒəz, iɾɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hɑɹt. ɪn ðət tɔɹənt, ðə teɪnt wɑz ɔl ðə mɪɾən hips ɪn ðə wɝld ɛmptiɪŋ ɪndə hɪz soʊl. seɪɾɪn stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm, tʃɹaɪd tə skaʊɝ əweɪ, bɝn əweɪ, fɹiz əweɪ, ɛvɹi skɹæp ə hɪm, bʌɾ i fɔt, ən i lɪv fəɹ ə moʊmən mɔɹ, ən ənʌðɝ moʊmənt, ənʌðɝ. hi wɑntəd tə læf. hi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ!

Saidin seemed to leap into Callandor before he touched the Source through it. From pommel to point, the crystal sword shone with a white light. He had only thought the Power filled him before. Now he held more than ten men could have unaided, a hundred, he did not know how many. The fires of the sun, searing through his head. The cold of all of the winters of all the Ages, eating into his heart. In that torrent, the taint was all the midden heaps in the world emptying into his soul. Saidin still tried to kill him, tried to scour away, burn away, freeze away, every scrap of him, but he fought, and he lived for a moment more, and another moment, another. He wanted to laugh. He could do anything!

wʌns, hoʊldɪŋ kælændɝ, hi hæd meɪɾ ə wɛpən ðət sɝtʃt aʊt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn θɹu ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ, stʃɹʌk əm dɛd wɪð hʌntɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ stʊɾ əɹ ɹæn əɹ hɪd. ʃʊɹli ðəɹ mʌs bi sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt, tə juz əɡɛnst ɪz ɛnəmiz hɪɹ. bʌt wən i kɔl tə luz θɝɪn, oʊnli æŋɡwɪʃt wɪmpɝz ænsɝd, əz ɪf ðət dɪsɪbɑɾid vɔɪs fɪɹd ðə peɪn ə seɪɾɪn.

Once, holding Callandor, he had made a weapon that searched out Shadowspawn through the Stone of Tear, struck them dead with hunting lightning wherever they stood or ran or hid. Surely there must be something like that, to use against his enemies here. But when he called to Lews Therin, only anguished whimpers answered, as if that disembodied voice feared the pain of saidin.

wɪð kælændɝ bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd - hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə bleɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd - hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə hɪlz wɛɹ ɪz ɛnəmiz hɪd. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɹeɪ naʊ, wɪð θɪkənɪŋ ɹeɪn, ən dɛns blæk klaʊdz blɑkɪŋ ðə sʌn. wʌt wɑz ɪɾ i hæd toʊld iɡən pædʒɹoʊs?

With Callandor blazing in his hand - he did not remember raising the blade overhead - he stared at the hills where his enemies hid. They were gray now, with thickening rain, and dense black clouds blocking the sun. What was it he had told Eagan Padros?

"aɪ æm ðə stɔɹm," hi wɪspɝd - ə ʃaʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, ə ɹɔɹ - ən i tʃænəld.

"I am the storm," he whispered - a shout in his ears, a roar - and he channeled.

oʊvɝhɛd, ðə klaʊdz bɔɪld. wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðə blæk ə sʊt, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm mɪdnaɪt, ðə hɑɹɾ ə mɪdnaɪt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ. soʊ ɔfən, hi dɪd nɑt, ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv æzmɑɾiənz titʃɪŋ. meɪbi luz θɝɪn wɑz ɡaɪɾɪŋ hɪm, ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə mænz wipɪŋ. floʊz ə seɪɾɪn spʌn əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, wɪn ən wɔɾɝ ən faɪɝ. faɪɝ. ðə skaɪ tʃɹuli dɪd ɹeɪn laɪtnɪŋ. ə hʌnʒɹəd boʊls ət wʌns, hʌnʒɹədz, fɔɹk blu-waɪt ʃæfs stæbɪŋ daʊn əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si. ðə hɪlz bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɪɹʌptəd. səm flu əpɑɹɾ ʌndɝ ðə tɔɹən ə laɪtnɪŋ laɪk kɪkt ænthɪlz. fleɪmz spɹæŋ ʌp ɪn θɪkəts, tʃɹiz tɝnɪŋ tə tɔɹtʃɪz ɪn ðə ɹeɪn, fleɪmz ɹeɪsɪŋ θɹu ɑləv ɔɹtʃɝdz.

Overhead, the clouds boiled. Where they had been the black of soot, they became midnight, the heart of midnight. He did not know what he was channeling. So often, he did not, in spite of Asmodean's teaching. Maybe Lews Therin was guiding him, in spite of the man's weeping. Flows of saidin spun across the sky, Wind and Water and Fire. Fire. The sky truly did rain lightning. A hundred bolts at once, hundreds, forked blue-white shafts stabbing down as far as he could see. The hills before him erupted. Some flew apart under the torrent of lightning like kicked anthills. Flames sprang up in thickets, trees turning to torches in the rain, flames racing through olive orchards.

sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk ɪm hɑɹd, ən i ɹilaɪzd i wɑz pɪkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə kɹaʊn hæd fɔlən fɹəm ɪz hɛd. kælændɝ stɪl bleɪzd ɪn ɪz hænd, ðoʊ. veɪɡli, hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə teɪdeɪʃɝ skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə hɪz fit, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. soʊ ðeɪ θɔt tə stʃɹaɪk bæk ət hɪm, dɪd ðeɪ.

Something struck him hard, and he realized he was picking himself up from the ground. The crown had fallen from his head. Callandor still blazed in his hand, though. Vaguely, he was aware of Tai'daishar scrambling to his feet, trembling. So they thought to strike back at him, did they.

ʃʌvɪŋ kælændɝ haɪ, hi skɹimd ət ðɛm. "kʌm əɡɛns mi, ɪf jə dɛɹ! aɪm ðə stɔɹm! kʌm ɪf jə dɛɹ, ʃeɪtɑn! aɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!" ə θaʊzən sɪzəlɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls heɪl daʊn fɹəm ðə klaʊdz.

Shoving Callandor high, he screamed at them. "Come against me, if you dare! I am the storm! Come if you dare, Shai'tan! I am the Dragon Reborn!" A thousand sizzling lightning bolts hailed down from the clouds.

əɡɛn sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk ɪm daʊn. hi tʃɹaɪd tə faɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn. kælændɝ, stɪl ʃaɪnɪŋ, leɪ ə peɪs fɹəm ɪz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd. ðə skaɪ ʃæɾɝd wɪð laɪtnɪŋz. sʌɾənli, hi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə weɪɾ ətɑp ɪm wɑz bæʃɪɹ, ðət ðə mæn wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ hɪm. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn bæʃɪɹ u hæd flʌŋ ɪm daʊn!

Again something struck him down. He tried to fight up again. Callandor, still shining, lay a pace from his outstretched hand. The sky shattered with lightnings. Suddenly, he realized that the weight atop him was Bashere, that the man was shaking him. It must have been Bashere who had flung him down!

"stɑp ɪt!" ðə sɑldəiən ʃaʊɾəd. blʌd fæn daʊn ɪz feɪs fɹəm ə splɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz skælp. "jɔɹ kɪlɪŋ ʌs, mæn! stɑp!"

"Stop it!" the Saldaean shouted. Blood fanned down his face from a split across his scalp. "You're killing us, man! Stop!"

ɹænd tɝn ɪz hɛd, ən wʌn stʌn lʊk wɑz ɪnʌf. laɪtnɪŋz flæʃt ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm, ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ə boʊl stæb daʊn ɑntu ðə ɹɪvɝs sloʊp, wɛɹ dɛnhɝəɾ ən ði ɑɹmmɪn wɝ; ðə skɹimz ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz ɹoʊz. ænɑiɛlə ən eɪlɪl wɝ boʊθ əfʊt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ veɪnli tə kwaɪət maʊns ðət ɹɪɹd, aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪp ɹeɪnz fɹi. flɪn wɑz bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ sʌmwʌn, nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ə dɛd hɔɹs wɪð lɛɡz ɔlɹɛɾi stɪf.

Rand turned his head, and one stunned look was enough. Lightnings flashed all around him, in every direction. A bolt stabbed down onto the reverse slope, where Denharad and the armsmen were; the screams of men and horses rose. Anaiyella and Ailil were both afoot, trying vainly to quiet mounts that reared, eyes rolling, trying to rip reins free. Flinn was bending over someone, not far from a dead horse with legs already stiff.

ɹænd lɛt seɪɾɪn ɡoʊ. hi lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ, bʌt fəɹ moʊməns ɪt stɪl floʊɾ ɪndə hɪm, ən laɪtnɪŋ ɹeɪdʒd. ðə floʊ ɪndə hɪm dwɪndəld, teɪld ɔf ən vænɪʃt. dɪzinəs swɛp θɹu hɪm ɪn ɪts pleɪs. fəɹ θɹi mɔɹ hɑɹtbits, tu ʌv kælændɝ ʃoʊn wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən laɪtnɪŋ fɛl. ðɛn, saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ dʒɹʌm ə ðə ɹeɪn. ən ðə skɹimz fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə hɪl.

Rand let saidin go. He let it go, but for moments it still flowed into him, and lightning raged. The flow into him dwindled, tailed off and vanished. Dizziness swept through him in its place. For three more heartbeats, two of Callandor shone where they lay on the ground, and lightning fell. Then, silence except for the rising drum of the rain. And the screams from behind the hill.

sloʊli bæʃɪɹ klaɪmd ɔf ə hɪm, ən ɹænd ɹoʊz əneɪɾɪd ɑn tɑɾɝɪŋ lɛɡz, blɪŋkɪŋ əz ɪz saɪt ɹɪtɝn tə nɔɹməl. ðə sɑldəiən wɑtʃt ɪm əz i maɪɾ əv ə ɹæbɪd laɪən, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ænɑiɛlə tʊk wʌn lʊk ət ɹænd ɑn ɪz fiɾ ən kəlæpst ɪn ə feɪnt; hɝ hɔɹs dæʃt əweɪ, ɹeɪnz dæŋɡəlɪŋ. eɪlɪl, stɪl faɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɹɪɹɪŋ ænəməl, spɛɹd fju ɡlænsɪz fəɹ ɹænd. ɹænd lɛt kælændɝ laɪ wɛɹ ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i dɛɹd pɪk ɪɾ ʌp. nɑt jɛt.

Slowly Bashere climbed off of him, and Rand rose unaided on tottering legs, blinking as his sight returned to normal. The Saldaean watched him as he might have a rabid lion, fingering his sword hilt. Anaiyella took one look at Rand on his feet and collapsed in a faint; her horse dashed away, reins dangling. Ailil, still fighting her rearing animal, spared few glances for Rand. Rand let Callandor lie where it was for the moment. He was not sure he dared pick it up. Not yet.

flɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ðən stʊd saɪlənli əz ɹænd wɛn ənstɛɾəli tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə ɹeɪn fɛl ɑn dʒoʊnən ædliz saɪtləs aɪz, bʌlʒɪŋ əz ɪf ɪn hɔɹɝ. dʒoʊnən hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɝst. ðoʊz skɹimz fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə hɪl sim tə slaɪs θɹu ðə ɹeɪn. haʊ mɛni mɔɹ, ɹænd wʌndɝd. əmʌŋ ðə dɪfɛndɝz? ðə kəmpænjənz? əmʌŋ . . . ?

Flinn straightened, shaking his head, then stood silently as Rand went unsteadily to stand beside him. The rain fell on Jonan Adley's sightless eyes, bulging as if in horror. Jonan had been one of the first. Those screams from behind the hill seemed to slice through the rain. How many more, Rand wondered. Among the Defenders? The Companions? Among . . . ?

ɹeɪn θɪk əz ə blæŋkət hɪd ðə hɪlz wɛɹ ðə sintʃæn ɑɹmi leɪ. hæɾ i hɝɾ əm əɾ ɔl, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊt blaɪnli? əɹ wɝ ðeɪ stɪl weɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðəɹ wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn? weɪɾɪŋ tə si haʊ mɛni mɔɹ ə hɪz oʊn i kəd kɪl fəɹ ðɛm.

Rain thick as a blanket hid the hills where the Seanchan army lay. Had he hurt them at all, striking out blindly? Or were they still waiting out there with all their damane? Waiting to see how many more of his own he could kill for them.

"sɛt wʌtɛvɝ ɡɑɹd jə θɪŋk wi nid," ɹænd toʊl bæʃɪɹ. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz aɪɝn. wʌn ə ðə fɝst. hɪz hɑɹt wɑz aɪɝn. "wɛn ɡɹɛɡɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɹitʃ ʌs, wɪl tʃɹævəl tə wɛɹ ðə kɑɹts ɑɹ weɪɾɪŋ əz fæst əz wi kæn." bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, ən tɝn əweɪ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn.

"Set whatever guard you think we need," Rand told Bashere. His voice was iron. One of the first. His heart was iron. "When Gregorin and the others reach us, we'll Travel to where the carts are waiting as fast as we can." Bashere nodded without speaking, and turned away in the rain.

aɪv lɔst, ɹænd θɔt dʌli. ɪm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, aɪv lɔst.

I've lost, Rand thought dully. I'm the Dragon Reborn, but for the first time, I've lost.

sʌɾənli, luz θɝɪn ɹeɪdʒd ʌp ɪnsaɪd hɪm, slaɪ dɪɡz fɝɡɑɾən. aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn dɪfiɾəd, hi snɑɹəld. aɪm ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ! noʊ wʌn kən dɪfit mi!

Suddenly, Lews Therin raged up inside him, sly digs forgotten. I've never been defeated, he snarled. I am the Lord of the Morning! No one can defeat me!

ɹænd sæɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn, tɝnɪŋ ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz ɪn ɪz hænz, lʊkɪŋ ət kælændɝ laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌd. hi lɛt luz θɝɪn ɹeɪdʒ.

Rand sat in the rain, turning the Crown of Swords in his hands, looking at Callandor lying in the mud. He let Lews Therin rage.

ɑbɑldɑɹ julən wɛpt, ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə daʊnpɔɹ ðət hɪd ðə tɪɹz ɑn ɪz tʃiks. sʌmwʌn wəɾ əv tə ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ. ɪvɛntʃəwəli sʌmwʌn wəɾ əv tə əpɑlədʒaɪz tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ən meɪbi tə sjuɹɔθ sunɝ. ðoʊz wɝ nɑt waɪ hi wɛpt, ðoʊ, nɔɹ ivən fəɹ ə dɛd kɑmɹæd. ɹʌfli ɹɪpɪŋ ə sliv fɹəm ɪz koʊt, hi leɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs mɪɹaɪz stɛɹɪŋ aɪz soʊ ðə ɹeɪn wəd nɑt fɔl ɪn ðɛm.

Abaldar Yulan wept, grateful for the downpour that hid the tears on his cheeks. Someone would have to give the order. Eventually someone would have to apologize to the Empress, might she live forever, and maybe to Suroth sooner. Those were not why he wept, though, nor even for a dead comrade. Roughly ripping a sleeve from his coat, he laid it across Miraj's staring eyes so the rain would not fall in them.

"sɛn aʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz fəɹ ɹitʃɹit," julən ɔɹɾɝd, ən sɔ ðə mɛn stændɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm dʒɝk. fəɹ ðə sɛkən taɪm ɑn ðiz ʃɔɹz, ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi hæd sʌfɝɾ ə dɛvəsteɪɾɪŋ dɪfit, ən julən dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u wɛpt.

"Send out orders for retreat," Yulan ordered, and saw the men standing around him jerk. For the second time on these shores, the Ever Victorious Army had suffered a devastating defeat, and Yulan did not think he was the only one who wept.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

ən ənwɛlkəm ɹɪtɝn


An Unwelcome Return

siɾəd bɪhaɪn əɹ ɡɪldɪd ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ɪleɪɾə fɪŋɡɝɾ ən eɪdʒ-dɑɹk aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ bɝd wɪð ə bik əz lɔŋ əz ɪts bɑɾi ən lɪsənd wɪð səm əmjuzmən tə ðə sɪks wɪmən stændɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. itʃ ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ əɹ ədʒɑ, ðeɪ fɹaʊn saɪdweɪz ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ʃɪftəd vɛlvət slɪpɝz ɑn ðə bɹaɪtli pæɾɝnd kɑɹpət ðət kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə ɹʌsət flɔɹ taɪlz, twɪtʃt ət vaɪn-wɝkt ʃɔlz soʊ ðə kʌlɝd fɹɪnʒɪz dænst, ən dʒɛnɝəli lʊkt ən saʊndəd laɪk ə ɡæɡəl ə pivɪʃ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz wɪʃɪŋ ðeɪ hæd ðə nɝv tə ɡoʊ fəɹ itʃ ʌðɝz' θɹoʊts ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəs. fɹɔs koʊɾəd ðə ɡlæs keɪsməns fɪɾəd ɪndə ðə wɪndoʊz soʊ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli pɑsəbəl tə si ðə snoʊ swɝlɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ðə wɪnz haʊld wɪð ən aɪsi ɹeɪdʒ. ɪleɪɾə fɛl kwaɪt wɔɹm, ən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ ðə θɪk lɔɡz bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs. wɛðɝ ðiz wɪmən nu ɪɾ əɹ nɑt - wɛl, dʌɑɹə nu, sɝɾənli, ən pɝhæps ði ʌðɝz dɪd - ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəs. ði ɪlæbɹət ɡoʊld-kʌvɝd keɪs klɑk ðət səmeɪl hæd kəmɪʃən tɪkt əweɪ. səmeɪlz vænɪʃt dʒɹim wəd kʌm tʃɹu; ðə taʊɝ ɹɪtɝn tə ɪts ɡlɔɹi. ən fɝmli ɪn ðə keɪpəbəl hænz ʌv ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən.

Seated behind her gilded writing table, Elaida fingered an age-dark ivory carving of a strange bird with a beak as long as its body and listened with some amusement to the six women standing on the other side on the table. Each a Sitter for her Ajah, they frowned sideways at one another, shifted velvet slippers on the brightly patterned carpet that covered most of the russet floor tiles, twitched at vine-worked shawls so the colored fringes danced, and generally looked and sounded like a gaggle of peevish serving girls wishing they had the nerve to go for each others' throats in front of their mistress. Frost coated the glassed casements fitted into the windows so that it was hardly possible to see the snow swirling outside, though sometimes the winds howled with an icy rage. Elaida felt quite warm, and not just for the thick logs blazing in the white marble fireplace. Whether these women knew it or not - well, Duhara knew, certainly, and perhaps the others did - she was their mistress. The elaborate gold-covered case clock that Cemaile had commissioned ticked away. Cemaile's vanished dream would come true; The Tower returned to its glory. And firmly in the capable hands of Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan.

"noʊ tɛɹæŋɡɹil əz ɛvɝ bɪn faʊn ðət kən 'kəntʃɹoʊl' ə wʊmənz tʃænəlɪŋ," vɛlinə wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪn ə vɔɪs kul ən pɹɪsaɪs bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst ɡɝlɪʃli haɪ-pɪtʃt, ə vɔɪs ət stʃɹɔŋ ɑdz wɪð əɹ iɡəlz bik ʌv ə noʊz ən əɹ ʃɑɹp, tɪltəɾ aɪz. ʃi sæt fəɹ ðə waɪt, ən wɑz ðə vɛɹi mɑɾəl ʌv ə waɪt sɪstɝ, ɪn ɔl bʌɾ əɹ fɪɹs əpɪɹəns. hɝ pleɪn, snoʊi dʒɹɛs sim stɑɹk ən koʊld. "vɛɹi fju hæv ɛvɝ bɪn faʊn ðət pɝfɔɹm ðə seɪm fʌŋkʃən. ðɛɹfɔɹ, lɑdʒɪkli, ɪf sətʃ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil wɝ faʊnd, əɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn, ɪmpɹɑbəbəl əz ðət mʌs bi, ðəɹ kəd nɑt bi səfɪʃən ə ðɛm tə kəntʃɹoʊl mɔɹ ðən tu əɹ θɹi wɪmən ət moʊst. ɪt fɑloʊz ðət ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ə ðiz soʊ-kɔl sintʃæn ɑɹ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd waɪldli. ɪf wɪmən ɑn 'liʃɪz' ɪɡzɪst, ðeɪ kænɑt tʃænəl. pleɪnli nɑt. aɪ də nɑt dɪnaɪ ðiz pipəl hoʊld ɛbu dɑɹ, ən æmədɔɹ, ən pɝhæps mɔɹ, bʌt klɪɹli ðeɪ ɑɹ bʌɾ ə kɹieɪʃən ə ɹænd ælθɹ, pɝhæps tə fɹaɪɾən pipəl ɪndə flɑkɪŋ tə hɪm. laɪk ðɪs pɹɑfəɾ ə hɪz. ɪts sɪmpəl lɑdʒɪk."

"No ter'angreal has ever been found that can 'control' a woman's channeling," Velina was saying in a voice cool and precise but almost girlishly high-pitched, a voice at strong odds with her eagle's beak of a nose and her sharp, tilted eyes. She sat for the White, and was the very model of a White sister, in all but her fierce appearance. Her plain, snowy dress seemed stark and cold. "Very few have ever been found that perform the same function. Therefore, logically, if such a ter'angreal were found, or more than one, improbable as that must be, there could not be sufficient of them to control more than two or three women at most. It follows that the reports of these so-called Seanchan are exaggerated wildly. If women on 'leashes' exist, they cannot channel. Plainly not. I do not deny these people hold Ebou Dar, and Amador, and perhaps more, but clearly they are but a creation of Rand al'Thor, perhaps to frighten people into flocking to him. Like this Prophet of his. It is simple logic."

"aɪ æm vɛɹi ɡlæd jə doʊn dɪnaɪ æmədɔɹ ən ɛbu dɑɹ ət list, vɛlinə," ʃɛvən sɛd dʒɹɪli. ən ʃi kəd bi vɛɹi dʒɹaɪ ɪndid. əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn, ən boʊnəli θɪn wɪð ɪt, ðə bɹaʊn sɪɾɝ hæɾ ən æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs ən ə lɔŋ tʃɪn, nɑɾ ɪmpɹuv baɪ ə kæp ə kɝlz. wɪð spaɪɾɝi fɪŋɡɝz ʃi ɹiɝeɪnʒd əɹ ʃɔl ən smuð skɝts ə dɑɹk ɡoʊldən sɪlk, ən əɹ vɔɪs tʊk ɑn pɔɪntəɾ əmjuzmənt. "aɪm ənkʌmftəɹbəl seɪɪŋ wʌt kən ən kæn bi. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, nɑt lɔŋ ɡɔn, ɛvɹiwʌn 'nu' oʊnli ə ʃild woʊvən baɪ ə sɪstɝ kəd stɑp ə wʊmən tʃænəlɪŋ. ðən kʌmz ə sɪmpəl ɝb, fɔkɹut, ən ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl kən fid jə ə ti ðət livz jə əneɪbəl əz ə stoʊn tə tʃænəl fəɹ aʊɝz. jusfəl wɪð ənɹuli waɪldɝz əɹ ðə laɪk, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌɾ ə næsti lɪɾəl sɝpɹaɪz fəɹ ðoʊz u θɪŋk ðeɪ nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɛ? meɪbi nɛkst, sʌmwʌn wɪl lɝn tə meɪk tɛɹæŋɡɹil əɡɛn."

"I am very glad you don't deny Amador and Ebou Dar at least, Velina," Shevan said drily. And she could be very dry indeed. As tall as most men, and bonily thin with it, the Brown Sitter had an angular face and a long chin, not improved by a cap of curls. With spidery fingers she rearranged her shawl and smoothed skirts of dark golden silk, and her voice took on pointed amusement. "I'm uncomfortable saying what can and can't be. For example, not long gone, everyone 'knew' only a shield woven by a sister could stop a woman channeling. Then comes a simple herb, forkroot, and anyone at all can feed you a tea that leaves you unable as a stone to channel for hours. Useful with unruly wilders or the like, I suppose, but a nasty little surprise for those who think they knew everything, eh? Maybe next, someone will learn to make ter'angreal again."

ɪleɪɾəz maʊθ taɪɾənd. ʃi dɪd nɑt kənsɝn hɝsɛlf wɪð ɪmpɑsəbɪləɾiz, ən ɪf noʊ sɪstɝ hæd mænədʒ tə ɹiɾɪskʌvɝ ðə meɪkɪŋ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, wʌn nɛvɝ wəɾ ən ðət wɑz ðæt. ɪt wɑz nɑlədʒ slɪpɪŋ θɹu hɝ fɪŋɡɝz wən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪt hɛl kloʊs ðət kɝld ɪleɪɾəz tʌŋ. ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɔl əɹ ɛfɝts, ɛvɹi læst ɪnɪʃiəɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ hæd lɝn ə fɔkɹut, naʊ. noʊ wʌn laɪk noʊɪŋ ɪn ðə list. noʊ wʌn laɪk sʌɾənli biɪŋ vʌlnɝəbəl tə ɛniwʌn wɪð ə nɑlədʒ ə ɝbz ən ə lɪɾəl hɑt wɔɾɝ. ðət nɑlədʒ wɑz wɝs ðən pɔɪzən, əz ðə sɪɾɝz hɪɹ meɪd klɪɹ.

Elaida's mouth tightened. She did not concern herself with impossibilities, and if no sister had managed to rediscover the making of ter'angreal in three thousand years, one never would and that was that. It was knowledge slipping through her fingers when she wanted it held close that curled Elaida's tongue. In spite of all her efforts, every last initiate in the Tower had learned of forkroot, now. No one liked knowing in the least. No one liked suddenly being vulnerable to anyone with a knowledge of herbs and a little hot water. That knowledge was worse than poison, as the Sitters here made clear.

ət mɛnʃən ə ði ɝb, dʌɑɹəz bɪɡ, dɑɹk aɪz ɡɹu ənizi ɪn əɹ kɑpɝi feɪs, ən ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf mɔɹ stɪfli ðən juʒəwəl, hænz klʌtʃɪŋ skɝts soʊ ɹɛd ðeɪ sim nɪɹli blæk. sɛdɔɹi æktʃəli  swɑloʊd, ən əɹ fɪŋɡɝz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə wɝk lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd hændəd hɝ, ðoʊ ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪs jɛloʊ juʒəwəli kæɹid hɝsɛlf wɪð ə fɹɔsti ɛləɡəns. ændaɪə ʃɪvɝd! ʃi æktʃəli  ɹæpt əɹ ɡɹeɪ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɝaʊn əɹ kənvʌlsɪvli.

At mention of the herb, Duhara's big, dark eyes grew uneasy in her coppery face, and she held herself more stiffly than usual, hands clutching skirts so red they seemed nearly black. Sedore actually swallowed, and her fingers tightened on the worked leather folder Elaida had handed her, though the round-faced Yellow usually carried herself with a frosty elegance. Andaya shivered! She actually wrapped her gray-fringed shawl around her convulsively.

ɪleɪɾə wʌndɝd wʌt ðeɪ wəd də ɪf ðeɪ lɝn ði æʃəmən hæd ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd tʃɹævlɪŋ. əz ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ wɝ bɛɹli eɪbəl tə meɪk ðɛmsɛlvz spik ə ðɛm. ət list ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə hoʊl ðət nɑlədʒ tə ə hændfʊl.

Elaida wondered what they would do if they learned the Asha'man had rediscovered Traveling. As it was, they were barely able to make themselves speak of them. At least she had managed to hold that knowledge to a handful.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi maɪt bɛɾɝ kənsɝn aʊɝsɛlvz wɪð wʌt wi noʊ tə bi tʃɹu, jɛs?" ændaɪə sɛd fɝmli, bæk ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝsɛlf. hɝ laɪt bɹaʊn hɛɹ, bɹʌʃt tɪl ɪt ɡlimd, hʌŋ floʊɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk, ən əɹ sɪlvɝ-slæʃt blu dʒɹɛs wɑz kʌɾ ɪn ðə staɪl ʌv ændɝ, bʌt tæɹɑbən stɪl ɹɛstəd stʃɹɔŋli ɑn əɹ tʌŋ. ðoʊ niðɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli smɔl nɔɹ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli slɪm, ʃi sʌmhaʊ ɔlweɪz ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪleɪɾə ʌv ə spɛɹoʊ əbaʊt tə hɑp ɑn ə bɹæntʃ. ə moʊst ənlaɪkli-əpɪɹɪŋ nəɡoʊʃieɪɾɝ, ðoʊ hɝ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən hæd bɪn ɝnd. ʃi smaɪld ət ði ʌðɝz, nɑt vɛɹi plɛzənli, ən ðət sim spɛɹoʊlaɪk, tu. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz haʊ ʃi hɛld əɹ hɛd. "aɪɾəl spɛkjəleɪʃən, ɪt weɪsts pɹɛʃəs taɪm. ðə wɝl hæŋz baɪ ə θɹɛd, ən maɪsɛlf, aɪ də nɑt wɪʃ tə fɹɪɾɝ əweɪ væljəbəl aʊɝz pɹæɾəlɪŋ əbaʊt səpoʊz lɑdʒɪk əɹ tʃæɾɝɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌɾ ɛvɹi ful ən nɑvəs noʊz. dʌz ɛniwʌn əv ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl tə seɪ?" fəɹ ə spɛɹoʊ, ʃi kəd pʊɾ æsəɾ ɑn əɹ wɝdz. vɛlinəz feɪs wɛn ɹɛd, ən ʃɛvənz dɑɹkənd.

"I think we might better concern ourselves with what we know to be true, yes?" Andaya said firmly, back in control of herself. Her light brown hair, brushed till it gleamed, hung flowing down her back, and her silver-slashed blue dress was cut in the style of Andor, but Tarabon still rested strongly on her tongue. Though neither particularly small nor particularly slim, she somehow always reminded Elaida of a sparrow about to hop on a branch. A most unlikely-appearing negotiator, though her reputation had been earned. She smiled at the others, not very pleasantly, and that seemed sparrowlike, too. Perhaps it was how she held her head. "Idle speculation, it wastes precious time. The world hangs by a thread, and myself, I do not wish to fritter away valuable hours prattling about supposed logic or chattering over what every fool and novice knows. Does anyone have anything useful to say?" For a sparrow, she could put acid on her words. Velina's face went red, and Shevan's darkened.

ɹubɪn twɪstəɾ əɹ lɪps ət ðə ɡɹeɪ. pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ mɛn tə meɪk ə smaɪl, bʌt ðeɪ mɪɹli sim tə ɹɪð. wɪð ɹeɪvən-blæk hɛɹ ən aɪz laɪk sæfaɪɝz, ðə minɝ juʒəwəli lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə wɔk θɹu ə stoʊn wɔl, ən plæntɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps naʊ, ʃi simd ɹɛɾi tə wɔk θɹu tu. "wiv dɛlt wɪð wʌt wi kən fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, ændaɪə. moʊst ʌv ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ðə ɹɛbəlz ɑɹ kɑt baɪ ðə snoʊz ɪn mʊɹændi, ən wɪl meɪk wɪntɝ hɑɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm ðəɾ ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ ðəl kʌm kɹɔlɪŋ bæk tə əpɑlədʒaɪz ən bɛɡ pɛnəns. tiɹ wɪl bi teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv əz sun əz wi faɪnd wɛɹ ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn əz vænɪʃt tə, ən kɛɹhin wʌns wi ɹut kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹɾ ən tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ haɪɾɪŋ pleɪsəz. ælθɹ əz ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, bʌt ðæts ɪn wɝk. soʊ, ənlɛs juv ə skim fəɹ snæfəlɪŋ ðə mæn ɪndə ðə taʊɝ əɹ meɪkɪŋ ðiz soʊ-kɔld æʃəmən' vænɪʃ, aɪ hæv ðə bɪznəs ə maɪ ədʒɑ tə bi əbaʊt."

Rubinde twisted her lips at the Gray. Perhaps they were meant to make a smile, but they merely seemed to writhe. With raven-black hair and eyes like sapphires, the Mayener usually looked as if she intended to walk through a stone wall, and planting her fists on her hips now, she seemed ready to walk through two. "We've dealt with what we can for the time being, Andaya. Most of it, anyway. The rebels are caught by the snows in Murandy, and we'll make winter hot enough for them that in the spring they'll come crawling back to apologize and beg penance. Tear will be taken care of as soon as we find where the High Lord Darlin has vanished to, and Cairhien once we root Caraline Damodred and Toram Riatin out of their hiding places. Al'Thor has the crown of Illian for the moment, but that's in work. So, unless you have a scheme for snaffling the man into the Tower or making these so-called Asha'man' vanish, I have the business of my Ajah to be about."

ændaɪə dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, hɝ fɛðɝz wɛl ən tʃɹuli ɹʌfəld. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, dʌɑɹəz aɪz nɛɹoʊd; mɛnʃən ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ɔlweɪz lɪt faɪɝz ɪn əɹ hɛd. ʃɛvən klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ əz ɪf ət tʃɪlʒɹən skwɑbəlɪŋ - ðoʊ ʃi lʊk pliz tə si ɪt - ən vɛlinə fɹaʊnd, fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃʊɹ ʃɛvən hæɾ eɪmd ət hɝ. ðɪs wɑz əmjuzɪŋ, bʌt ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hænd.

Andaya drew herself up, her feathers well and truly ruffled. For that matter, Duhara's eyes narrowed; mention of men who could channel always lit fires in her head. Shevan clicked her tongue as if at children squabbling - though she looked pleased to see it - and Velina frowned, for some reason sure Shevan had aimed at her. This was amusing, but getting out of hand.

"ðə bɪznəs ə ði ədʒəz ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, dɔɾɝz." ɪleɪɾə dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɛvɹi hɛd swɪvəl təwɔɹd hɝ. ʃi ɹipleɪs ði aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ kəlɛkʃən ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ bɑks kʌvɝd wɪð ɹoʊzɪz ən ɡoʊldən skɹoʊlz, kɛɹfəli ədʒʌstəd ðə pəzɪʃənz ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ keɪs ən kɔɹəspɑndəns bɑks soʊ ðə θɹi lækɝd bɑksəz laɪn ʌp dʒʌst soʊ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ən wʌns ðɛɹ saɪləns wɑz pɝfəkt ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ðə bɪznəs ə ðə taʊɝ ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðoʊ. aɪ tʃɹʌs jəl ɪfɛk maɪ dɪkɹiz pɹɑmpli. aɪ si tu mʌtʃ sloʊθ ɪn ðə taʊɝ. aɪ fɪɹ sɪlviænə meɪ faɪn hɝsɛlf vɛɹi bɪzi ɪf mæɾɝz də nɑt kʌm ɹaɪt sun." ʃi dɪd nɑt vɔɪs ɛni fɝðɝ θɹɛt. ʃi mɪɹli smaɪld.

"The business of the Ajahs is important, daughters." Elaida did not raise her voice, but every head swiveled toward her. She replaced the ivory carving with the rest of her collection in the large box covered with roses and golden scrolls, carefully adjusted the positions of her writing case and correspondence box so the three lacquered boxes lined up just so on the table, and once their silence was perfect she went on. "The business of the Tower is more important, though. I trust you will effect my decrees promptly. I see too much sloth in the Tower. I fear Silviana may find herself very busy if matters do not come right soon." She did not voice any further threat. She merely smiled.

"æz jə kəmænd, mʌðɝ," mɝmɝd sɪks vɔɪsəz nɑt soʊ stɛɾi əz ðɛɹ oʊnɝz maɪɾ əv wɪʃt. ivən dʌɑɹəz feɪs wɑz peɪsti peɪl əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ kɝtsiz. tu sɪɾɝz hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt ə ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz, ən hæf ə dʌzən hæd sɝv deɪz ə leɪbɝ fəɹ pɛnəns - wɪtʃ wɑz hjumɪlieɪɾɪŋ ɪnʌf ɪn ðɛɹ pəzɪʃən tə bi mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ə ðə spɪɹət bɪsaɪdz; ʃɛvən ən sɛdɔɹi sɝɾənli wɔɹ taɪt maʊðz əz ðeɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɔl tu wɛl skɹʌbɪŋ flɔɹz ən wɝkɪŋ ɪn ðə lɔnʒɹiz - bʌt nʌn hæd bɪn sɛn tə sɪlviænə fəɹ mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ə ðə flɛʃ. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə bi. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz hæd tu əɹ θɹi vɪzəts itʃ wik fɹəm sɪstɝz u bɪn ɡɪvən pɛnəns baɪ ðɛɹ ədʒəz əɹ sɛt wʌn fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz - ə doʊs ə ðə stʃɹæp, haʊɛvɝ peɪnfəl, wɑz dʌn wɪð mʌtʃ mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ɹeɪkɪŋ ɡɑɹɾən pæðz fəɹ ə mʌnθ - bʌt sɪlviænə pəzɛs kənsɪɾɝəbli lɛs mɝsi wɪð sɪstɝz ðən wɪð ðə nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɑɹdʒ. mɔɹ ðən wʌn sɪstɝ mʌst əv spɛn ðə nɛks fju deɪz wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ə mʌnθ pʊlɪŋ ə ɹeɪk maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn pɹɛfɝəbəl æftɝ ɔl.

"As you command, Mother," murmured six voices not so steady as their owners might have wished. Even Duhara's face was pasty pale as they made their curtsies. Two Sitters had been stripped of their chairs, and half a dozen had served days of Labor for penance - which was humiliating enough in their position to be Mortification of the Spirit besides; Shevan and Sedore certainly wore tight mouths as they remembered all too well scrubbing floors and working in the laundries - but none had been sent to Silviana for Mortification of the Flesh. No one wanted to be. The Mistress of Novices had two or three visits each week from sisters who been given penance by their Ajahs or set one for themselves - a dose of the strap, however painful, was done with much more quickly than raking garden paths for a month - but Silviana possessed considerably less mercy with sisters than with the novices and Accepted in her charge. More than one sister must have spent the next few days wondering whether a month pulling a rake might not have been preferable after all.

ðeɪ skɝid təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹz, iɡɝ tə bi əweɪ. sɪɾɝz əɹ noʊ, nɑt wʌn wʊɾə sɛt fʊt ðɪs haɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪleɪɾəz dɝɛk sʌmənz. fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ stʃɹaɪp stoʊl, ɪleɪɾə lɛɾ əɹ smaɪl bɪkʌm wʌn ə plɛʒɝ. jɛs, ʃi wɑz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əz wɑz oʊnli pɹɑpɝ fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

They scurried toward the doors, eager to be away. Sitters or no, not one would have set foot this high in the Tower without Elaida's direct summons. Fingering her striped stole, Elaida let her smile become one of pleasure. Yes, she was the mistress in the White Tower. As was only proper for the Amyrlin Seat.

bɪfɔɹ ðət fæst-stɛpɪŋ nɑɾ ə sɪɾɝz ɹitʃ ðə dɔɹweɪ, ðə lɛft-hæn dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən ɑlviɛɝɪn stɛpt ɪn, ðə nɛɹoʊ waɪt stoʊl ə ðə kipɝ ɔlmoʊs vænɪʃɪŋ əɡɛnst ə sɪlk dʒɹɛs ðət meɪd vɛlinəz sim dɪnʒi.

Before that fast-stepping knot of Sitters reach the doorway, the left-hand door opened, and Alviarin stepped in, the narrow white stole of the Keeper almost vanishing against a silk dress that made Velina's seem dingy.

ɪleɪɾə fɛlt əɹ smaɪl ɡoʊ kɹʊkəɾ ən bɪɡɪn slaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm əɹ feɪs. ɑlviɛɝɪn hæɾ ə sɪŋɡəl ʃiɾ ə pɑɹtʃmən ɪn wʌn slɪm hænd. ɑd, wʌt wʌn noʊɾəst əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs. ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn ɡɔn ɔlmoʊs tu wiks, vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə taʊɝ wɪθaʊt wɝɾ əɹ noʊt, wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz siɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊ, ən ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk fɑn θɔts ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪn laɪɪŋ ɪn ə snoʊbæŋk, əɹ swɛpt əweɪ ɪn ə ɹɪvɝ, slaɪɾɪŋ bɪniθ ði aɪs.

Elaida felt her smile go crooked and begin sliding from her face. Alviarin had a single sheet of parchment in one slim hand. Odd, what one noticed at a time like this. The woman had been gone almost two weeks, vanished from the Tower without word or note, without anyone so much as seeing her go, and Elaida had begun to think fond thoughts of Alviarin lying in a snowbank, or swept away in a river, sliding beneath the ice.

ðə sɪks sɪɾɝz skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt ənsɝteɪnli wən ɑlviɛɝɪn dɪd nɑt muv aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ. ivən ə kipɝ wɪð ɑlviɛɝɪnz ɪnfluəns dɪd nɑɾ ɪmpid sɪɾɝz. ðoʊ vɛlinə, nɔɹməli ðə moʊst sɛlf-pəzɛst wʊmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ, flɪntʃt fəɹ səm ɹizən. ɑlviɛɝɪn ɡlænst wʌns əɾ ɪleɪɾə, kuli, stʌɾid ðə sɪɾɝz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən ʌndɝstʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ.

The six Sitters skidded to a halt uncertainly when Alviarin did not move out of their way. Even a Keeper with Alviarin's influence did not impede Sitters. Though Velina, normally the most self-possessed woman in the Tower, flinched for some reason. Alviarin glanced once at Elaida, coolly, studied the Sitters for a moment, and understood everything.

"aɪ θɪŋk jə ʃəd liv ðət wɪð mi," ʃi sɛd tə sɛdɔɹi ɪn toʊnz oʊnli ə fɹækʃən wɔɹmɝ ðən ðə snoʊ aʊtsaɪd. "ðə mʌðɝ laɪks tə kənsɪɾɝ əɹ dɪkɹiz kɛɹfəli, əz jə noʊ. ðɪs wəd nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi tʃeɪnʒd əɹ maɪn æftɝ saɪnɪŋ." ʃi hɛld aʊɾ ə slɪm hænd.

"I think you should leave that with me," she said to Sedore in tones only a fraction warmer than the snow outside. "The Mother likes to consider her decrees carefully, as you know. This would not be the first time she changed her mind after signing." She held out a slim hand.

sɛdɔɹi, huz ɛɹəɡəns wɑz noʊɾəbəl ivən əmʌŋ jɛloʊz, bɛɹli hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ.

Sedore, whose arrogance was notable even among Yellows, barely hesitated before giving her the leather folder.

ɪleɪɾə ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ ɪn fjʊɹi. sɛdɔɹi hæd heɪɾəd əɹ faɪv deɪz ʌp tə hɝ ɛlboʊz ɪn hɑt wɔɾɝ ən skɹʌb bɔɹdz. ɪleɪɾə wəd faɪn sʌmθɪŋ lɛs kʌmftəɹbəl fəɹ əɹ nɛks taɪm. meɪbi sɪlviænə æftɝ ɔl. meɪbi klinɪŋ ðə sɛspɪts!

Elaida ground her teeth in fury. Sedore had hated her five days up to her elbows in hot water and scrub boards. Elaida would find something less comfortable for her next time. Maybe Silviana after all. Maybe cleaning the cesspits!

ɑlviɛɝɪn stɛpt əsaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd, ən ðə sɪɾɝz wɛnt, ədʒʌstɪŋ ʃɔlz, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ɹiəsumɪŋ ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʌv ðə hɔl. bɹɪskli, ɑlviɛɝɪn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn əm ən wɔk təwɔɹɾ ɪleɪɾə θʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə peɪpɝz ɪn ðə foʊldɝ. ðə dɪkɹiz ʃi hæd saɪn hoʊpɪŋ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz dɛd. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɛstəɾ ɑn hoʊp. ʃi hæd nɑt spoʊkən tə sin, ɪn keɪs sʌmwʌn maɪt si ən tɛl ɑlviɛɝɪn wən ʃi ɹɪtɝnd, bʌt sin wɑz sɝɾənli wɝkɪŋ əweɪ əz ɪnstʃɹʌktəd, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə pæθ ə tʃɹizən ðət ʃʊɹli wəd lɛd tə ɑlviɛɝɪn fɹaɪɾən. bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd hoʊpt. oʊ, haʊ ʃi hæd hoʊpt.

Alviarin stepped aside without a word, and the Sitters went, adjusting shawls, muttering to themselves, reassuming the dignity of the Hall. Briskly, Alviarin closed the door behind them and walked toward Elaida thumbing through the papers in the folder. The decrees she had signed hoping Alviarin was dead. Of course, she had not rested on hope. She had not spoken to Seaine, in case someone might see and tell Alviarin when she returned, but Seaine was certainly working away as instructed, following the path of treason that surely would lead to Alviarin Freidhen. But Elaida had hoped. Oh, how she had hoped.

ɑlviɛɝɪn mɝmɝd tə hɝsɛlf əz ʃi ɹaɪfəl ðə foʊldɝ. "ðɪs kən ɡoʊ θɹu, aɪ səpoʊz. bʌt nɑt ðɪs. əɹ ðɪs. ən sɝɾənli nɑt ðɪs!" ʃi kɹʌmpəld ə dɪkɹi, saɪn ən sil baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən tɔst ɪt tə ðə flɔɹ kəntɛmptʃwəsli. stɑpɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪɾəz ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹ, wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪn munstoʊnz ətɑp ɪts haɪ bæk, ʃi slæp ðə foʊldɝ ən əɹ oʊn pɑɹtʃmən daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ən ðən slæpt ɪleɪɾəz feɪs soʊ hɑɹd ʃi sɔ blæk flɛks.

Alviarin murmured to herself as she rifled the folder. "This can go through, I suppose. But not this. Or this. And certainly not this!" She crumpled a decree, signed and sealed by the Amyrlin Seat, and tossed it to the floor contemptuously. Stopping beside Elaida's gilded chair, with the Flame of Tar Valon in moonstones atop its high back, she slapped the folder and her own parchment down on the table. And then slapped Elaida's face so hard she saw black flecks.

"aɪ θɔt wi hæd sɛɾəld ðɪs, ɪleɪɾə." ðə mɑnstʃɹəs wʊmənz vɔɪs meɪd ðə snoʊstɔɹm aʊtsaɪd sim wɔɹm. "aɪ noʊ haʊ tə seɪv ðə taʊɝ fɹəm jəɹ blʌndɝz, ən aɪ woʊn əv jə meɪkɪŋ nu wʌnz bɪhaɪn maɪ bæk. ɪf jə pɝsɪst, bi əʃʊɹd ðəɾ əl si jə dɪpoʊzd, stɪld, ən haʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə bɝtʃ bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹi ɪnɪʃiəɾ ən ivən ðə sɝvəns!"

"I thought we had settled this, Elaida." The monstrous woman's voice made the snowstorm outside seem warm. "I know how to save the Tower from your blunders, and I won't have you making new ones behind my back. If you persist, be assured that I will see you deposed, stilled, and howling under the birch before every initiate and even the servants!"

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ɪleɪɾə kɛpt əɹ hæn əweɪ fɹəm əɹ tʃik. ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ə mɪɹɝ tə tɛl əɹ ɪt wɑz ɹɛd. ʃi hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl. sin hæd faʊnd nʌθɪŋ jɛt, əɹ ʃi wəɾ əv kʌm. ɑlviɛɝɪn kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ən ɹɪvil ðə hoʊl dɪzæstʃɹəs kɪdnæpɪŋ ə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ. ʃi maɪt si hɝ dɪpoʊzd, ən stɪld ən bɝtʃt wɪð ðəɾ əloʊn, bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn hæɾ ənʌðɝ stʃɹɪŋ tə hɝ baʊ. tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl wɑz liɾɪŋ fɪfti sɪstɝz ən tu hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ə blæk taʊɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ, wən ʃi ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝz, hɛl pɝhæps tu əɹ θɹi mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. jɛɾ ivən wɪð ðə hʌnʒɹədz - hʌnʒɹədz! wɪð ɑlviɛɝɪn stɛɹɪŋ koʊldli daʊn ət hɝ, ðət θɔt stɪl kɝɾəld ɪleɪɾəz stʌmək! - ivən wɪð hʌnʒɹədz ə ðiz æʃəmən, ʃi hæd hoʊp fəɹ tʌvaɪn. ðə blæk taʊɝ wəd bi ɹɛn ɪn faɪɝ ən blʌd, ʃi hæd fɔɹtoʊld, ən sɪstɝz wəd wɔk ɪts ɡɹaʊnz. ʃʊɹli ðət mɛn ðət sʌmhaʊ, tʌvaɪn wəd tʃɹaɪəmf. mɔɹ, ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ hæd toʊld əɹ ðət ðə taʊɝ wəd ɹɪɡeɪn ɔl ɪts oʊld ɡlɔɹiz ʌndɝ hɝ, ðəɾ ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf wəd kweɪl əɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ. ɑlviɛɝɪn hæd hɝd ðə wɝdz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪleɪɾəz maʊθ wən ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ tʊk hɝ. ən ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝd leɪɾɝ, wən ʃi bɪɡæn əɹ blækmeɪl, hæd nɑɾ ʌndɝstʊɾ əɹ oʊn dum. ɪleɪɾə weɪɾəd ɪn peɪʃəns. ʃi wəd ɹipeɪ ðə wʊmən θɹi-foʊld! bʌt ʃi kəd bi peɪʃənt. fəɹ naʊ.

With an effort, Elaida kept her hand away from her cheek. She did not need a mirror to tell her it was red. She had to be careful. Seaine had found nothing yet, or she would have come. Alviarin could open her mouth before the Hall and reveal the whole disastrous kidnapping of the al'Thor boy. She might see her deposed, and stilled and birched with that alone, but Alviarin had another string to her bow. Toveine Gazal was leading fifty sisters and two hundred of the Tower Guard against a Black Tower Elaida had been sure, when she gave the orders, held perhaps two or three men who could channel. Yet even with the hundreds - hundreds! with Alviarin staring coldly down at her, that thought still curdled Elaida's stomach! - even with hundreds of these Asha'man, she had hope for Toveine. The Black Tower would be rent in fire and blood, she had Foretold, and sisters would walk its grounds. Surely that meant that somehow, Toveine would triumph. More, the rest of the Foretelling had told her that the Tower would regain all its old glories under her, that al'Thor himself would quail at her anger. Alviarin had heard the words coming out of Elaida's mouth when the Foretelling took her. And she had not remembered later, when she began her blackmail, had not understood her own doom. Elaida waited in patience. She would repay the woman three-fold! But she could be patient. For now.

meɪkɪŋ noʊ ətɛmp tə haɪɾ əɹ snɪɹ, ɑlviɛɝɪn pʊʃt ðə foʊldɝ əsaɪɾ ən muv ðə sɪŋɡəl pɑɹtʃmən ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪleɪɾə. ʃi flɪpt oʊpən ðə ɡɹin-ænd-ɡoʊld ɹaɪɾɪŋ keɪs, dɪpt ɪleɪɾəz pɛn ɪn ði ɪŋkwɛl ən θɹʌst ɪɾ ət hɝ. "saɪn."

Making no attempt to hide her sneer, Alviarin pushed the folder aside and moved the single parchment in front of Elaida. She flipped open the green-and-gold writing case, dipped Elaida's pen in the inkwell and thrust it at her. "Sign."

ɪleɪɾə tʊk ðə pɛn wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt mædnəs ʃi wəd bi pʊɾɪŋ əɹ neɪm tə ðɪs taɪm. jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɪnkɹis ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd, wən ðə ɹɛbəlz wəd bi dʌn bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni jus fəɹ soʊlʒɝz? ənʌðɝ ətɛmp tə meɪk ði ədʒəz ɹɪvil pʌblɪkli wɪtʃ sɪstɝz hɛɾəd ðɛm? ðət hæd sɝɾənli fɔlən ɑn ɪts noʊz! ɹɛɾɪŋ kwɪkli, ʃi fɛlt ə nɑɾ ʌv aɪs ɡɹoʊ ɪn əɹ bɛli ən kip ɡɹoʊɪŋ. ɡɪvɪŋ itʃ ədʒɑ faɪnəl əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ɛni sɪstɝ ɪn ɪts kɔɹɾɝ noʊ mæɾɝ əɹ oʊn ədʒɑ hæd bɪn ðə wɝst ɪnsænəɾi soʊ fɑɹ - haʊ kəd pɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt ðə vɛɹi fæbɹɪk ə ðə taʊɝ seɪv ɪt? - bʌt ðɪs - !

Elaida took the pen wondering what madness she would be putting her name to this time. Yet another increase in the Tower Guard, when the rebels would be done before there was any use for soldiers? Another attempt to make the Ajahs reveal publicly which sisters headed them? That had certainly fallen on its nose! Reading quickly, she felt a knot of ice grow in her belly and keep growing. Giving each Ajah final authority over any sister in its quarter no matter her own Ajah had been the worst insanity so far - how could picking apart the very fabric of the Tower save it? - but this - !

ðə wɝl naʊ noʊz ðət ɹænd ælθɹ ɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə wɝl noʊz ðət hiz ə mæn u kən tʌtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. sətʃ mɛn əv leɪn wɪðɪn ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɪns taɪm ɪməmɔɹiəl. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz ɡɹæntəd ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðə taʊɝ, bʌt husoʊɛvɝ ətɛmps tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪm seɪv θɹu ðə waɪt taʊɝ laɪz əɾəntɪd ə tʃɹizən əɡɛns ðə laɪt, ən ənæθəmə ɪz pɹənaʊnst əɡɛnst əm naʊ ən fɝɛvɝ. ðə wɝl meɪ ɹɛst izəli noʊɪŋ ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɪl seɪfli ɡaɪd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə ðə læs bæɾəl ən ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl tʃɹaɪəmf.

The world now knows that Rand al'Thor is the Dragon Reborn. The world knows that he is a man who can touch the One Power. Such men have lain within the authority of the White Tower since time immemorial. The Dragon Reborn is granted the protection of the Tower, but whosoever attempts to approach him save through the White Tower lies attainted of treason against the Light, and anathema is pronounced against them now and forever. The world may rest easily knowing that the White Tower will safely guide the Dragon Reborn to the Last Battle and the inevitable triumph.

ɔɾəmætɪkli, nʌmbli, ʃi æɾəd "ʌv ðə laɪt" æftɝ "tʃɹaɪəmf," bʌt ðən əɹ hæn fɹoʊz. pʌblɪkli æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ælθɹ əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kəd bi bɔɹn, sɪns i wɑz, ən ðɪs maɪt lɛd mɛni tə æksɛp ðə ɹumɝz ðəɾ i hæd nɛl tə hɝ ɔlɹɛɾi, wɪtʃ wəd pɹuv jusfəl, bʌt fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv soʊ mʌtʃ dæmədʒ kəd bi kənteɪn ɪn soʊ fju wɝdz.

Automatically, numbly, she added "of the Light" after "triumph," but then her hand froze. Publicly acknowledging al'Thor as the Dragon Reborn could be borne, since he was, and this might lead many to accept the rumors that he had knelt to her already, which would prove useful, but for the rest, she could not believe so much damage could be contained in so few words.

"ðə laɪɾ əv mɝsi," ʃi bɹið fɝvənli. "ɪf ðɪs ɪz pɹoʊkleɪmd, ɪɾəl bi ɪmpɑsəbəl tə kənvɪns ælθɹ ðəɾ ɪz æbdʌkʃən wɑz ənsæŋkʃənd." ɪt wəd bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt, bʌt ʃi hæd sin pipəl kənvɪns bɪfɔɹ ðət wʌt hæd hæpənd, hæd nɑt, ən əm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt hæpənɪŋ. "æn hɪl bi tɛn taɪmz ɑn ɪz ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ ətɛmpt. ɑlviɛɝɪn, ət bɛst, ðɪs wɪl fɹaɪɾən əweɪ ə fju ʌv ɪz fɑloʊɝz. ət bɛst!" mɛni laɪkli hæd weɪɾɪd soʊ dip wɪð ɪm ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dɛɹ tʃɹaɪ tə weɪd bæk. sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪ θɔɾ ənæθəmə ɔlɹɛɾi hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz! "aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl sɛt faɪɝ tə ðə taʊɝ wɪð maɪ oʊn hæn əz saɪn ðɪs!"

"The Light have mercy," she breathed fervently. "If this is proclaimed, it will be impossible to convince al'Thor that his abduction was unsanctioned." It would be hard enough without, but she had seen people convinced before that what had happened, had not, and them in the middle of it happening. "And he will be ten times on his guard against another attempt. Alviarin, at best, this will frighten away a few of his followers. At best!" Many likely had waded so deep with him they did not dare try to wade back. Certainly not if they thought anathema already hung over their heads! "I might as well set fire to the Tower with my own hand as sign this!"

ɑlviɛɝɪn saɪɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "ju hævən fɝɡɑɾən jəɹ kæɾəkɪzəm, hæv ju? seɪ ɪt fəɹ mi, əz aɪ tɔt ju."

Alviarin sighed impatiently. "You haven't forgotten your catechism, have you? Say it for me, as I taught you."

ɪleɪɾəz lɪps kəmpɹɛst ə ðɛɹ oʊn əkɔɹd. wʌn plɛʒɝ ɪn ðə wʊmənz æbsəns - nɑt ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst, bʌɾ ə vɛɹi ɹil plɛʒɝ - hæd bɪn nɑt biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ɹɪpit ðət vaɪl lɪɾəni ɛvɹi deɪ. "aɪ wɪl də əz aɪm toʊld," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit! "aɪ wɪl spik ðə wɝdz jə tɛl mi tə spik, ən noʊ mɔɹ." hɝ fɔɹtɛlɪŋ ɔɹdeɪn əɹ tʃɹaɪəmf, bʌt, oʊ, laɪt, lɛɾ ɪt kʌm sun! "aɪ wɪl saɪn wʌt jə tɛl mi tə saɪn, ən nʌθɪŋ ɛls. aɪm . . ." ʃi tʃoʊkt oʊvɝ ðə læst. "aɪ æm oʊbiɾiənt tə jəɹ wɪl."

Elaida's lips compressed of their own accord. One pleasure in the woman's absence - not the greatest, but a very real pleasure - had been not being forced to repeat that vile litany every day. "I will do as I am told," she said at last, in a flat voice. She was the Amyrlin Seat! "I will speak the words you tell me to speak, and no more." Her Foretelling ordained her triumph, but, oh, Light, let it come soon! "I will sign what you tell me to sign, and nothing else. I am . . ." She choked over the last. "I am obedient to your will."

"ju saʊn əz ɪf jə nid tə bi ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðæt," ɑlviɛɝɪn sɛd wɪð ənʌðɝ saɪ. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪv lɛf jə əloʊn tu lɔŋ." ʃi tæp ðə pɑɹtʃmənt wɪð ə pɝɛmptɝi fɪŋɡɝ. "saɪn."

"You sound as if you need to be reminded of the truth of that," Alviarin said with another sigh. "I suppose I've left you alone too long." She tapped the parchment with a peremptory finger. "Sign."

ɪleɪɾə saɪnd, dʒɹæɡɪŋ ðə pɛn əkɹɔs ðə pɑɹtʃmənt. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls ʃi kəd du.

Elaida signed, dragging the pen across the parchment. There was nothing else she could do.

ɑlviɛɝɪn bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə pɛnz nɪb tə lɪf bɪfɔɹ snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə dɪkɹi. "aɪ wɪl sil ðɪs maɪsɛlf," ʃi sɛd, hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ ʃʊdn əv lɛf ði æmɪɝlɪnz sil wɛɹ jə kəd faɪn ɪt. aɪ wɑnə tɔk tə jə leɪɾɝ. aɪ hæv lɛf jə tə jɝsɛlf tu lɔŋ. bi hɪɹ wən aɪ ɹɪtɝn."

Alviarin barely waited for the pen's nib to lift before snatching up the decree. "I will seal this myself," she said, heading for the door. "I shouldn't have left the Amyrlin's seal where you could find it. I want to talk to you later. I have left you to yourself too long. Be here when I return."

"leɪɾɝ?" ɪleɪɾə sɛd. "wɛn? ɑlviɛɝɪn? ɑlviɛɝɪn?"

"Later?" Elaida said. "When? Alviarin? Alviarin?"

ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə wʊmən, livɪŋ ɪleɪɾə tə fjum. bi ðəɹ wən ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹɪtɝnd! kənfaɪn tə hɝ kɔɹɾɝz laɪk ə nɑvəs ɪn ðə pʌnɪʃmən sɛlz!

The door closed behind the woman, leaving Elaida to fume. Be there when Alviarin returned! Confined to her quarters like a novice in the punishment cells!

fəɹ ə taɪm ʃi fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ kɔɹəspɑndəns bɑks, wɪð ɪts ɡoʊldən hɔks faɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ waɪt klaʊdz ɪn ə blu skaɪ, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑt meɪk hɝsɛlf oʊpən ɪt. wɪð ɑlviɛɝɪn ɡɔn, ðət bɑks hæd bɪɡʌn wʌns mɔɹ tə hoʊld lɛɾɝz ən ɹɪpɔɹts ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns, nɑt dʒʌs ðə teɪbəl skɹæps ɑlviɛɝɪn lɛt fɔl tə hɝ, jɛt wɪð ðə wʊmənz ɹɪtɝn, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ɛmpti. ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi bɪɡæn ɹiɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðə ɹoʊzɪz ɪn ðɛɹ waɪt veɪsəz, itʃ ətɑp ə waɪt mɑɹbəl plɪnθ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum. blu ɹoʊzɪz; ðə moʊst ɹɛɹ.

For a time she fingered her correspondence box, with its golden hawks fighting among white clouds in a blue sky, yet she could not make herself open it. With Alviarin gone, that box had begun once more to hold letters and reports of importance, not just the table scraps Alviarin let fall to her, yet with the woman's return, it might as well have been empty. Rising, she began rearranging the roses in their white vases, each atop a white marble plinth in a corner of the room. Blue roses; the most rare.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə bɹoʊkən ɹoʊz stɛm ɪn əɹ hænz, snæpt ɪn tu. hæf ə dʌzən mɔɹ lɪɾɝd ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ʃi meɪɾ ə vɛkst saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. ʃi hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝ hænz ɝaʊn ɑlviɛɝɪnz θɹoʊt. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi hæd kənsɪɾɝd kɪlɪŋ ðə wʊmən. bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wʊɾə teɪkən pɹikɔʃənz. sil dɑkjəməns, tə bi oʊpənd ʃəɾ ɛniθɪŋ əntuɔɹd hæpən, hæd noʊ daʊt bɪn lɛft wɪð ðə læst sɪstɝz ɪleɪɾə wəd səspɛkt. ðət hæd bɪn əɹ wʌn ɹil wɝi dʊɹɪŋ ɑlviɛɝɪnz æbsəns, ðət sʌmwʌn ɛls maɪt θɪŋk ðə wʊmən dɛd, ən kʌm fɔɹwɝd wɪð ði ɛvəɾəns ðət wəd dʒɹæɡ ðə stoʊl fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz fɪnɪʃt, əz ʃʊɹli əz ðoʊz ɹoʊzɪz wɝ -  "ju dɪdn ænsɝ maɪ nɑk, mʌðɝ, soʊ aɪ keɪm ɑn ɪn," ə wʊmən sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Abruptly she realized that she was staring at a broken rose stem in her hands, snapped in two. Half a dozen more littered the floor tiles. She made a vexed sound in her throat. She had been thinking of her hands around Alviarin's throat. It was not the first time she had considered killing the woman. But Alviarin would have taken precautions. Sealed documents, to be opened should anything untoward happen, had no doubt been left with the last sisters Elaida would suspect. That had been her one real worry during Alviarin's absence, that someone else might think the woman dead, and come forward with the evidence that would drag the stole from her shoulders. Sooner or later, though, one way or another, Alviarin was finished, as surely as those roses were -  "You didn't answer my knock, Mother, so I came on in," a woman said gruffly behind her.

ɪleɪɾə tɝnd, ɹɛɾi tə fleɪ wɪð əɹ tʌŋ, bʌɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stɑki, skwɛɹ-feɪst wʊmən ɪn ə ɹɛd-fɹɪnd ʃɔl stændɪŋ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ oʊn tʃiks.

Elaida turned, ready to flay with her tongue, but at the sight of the stocky, square-faced woman in a red-fringed shawl standing just inside the room, the blood drained from her own cheeks.

"ðə kipɝ sɛd jə wɑntəd tə spik mi," sɪlviænə sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "əbaʊɾ ə pɹaɪvət pɛnəns." ivən tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ʃi meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə haɪɾ əɹ dɪsɡʌst. sɪlviænə bɪliv pɹaɪvət pɛnəns ə ɹɪdɪkjələs æfɛkteɪʃən. pɛnəns wɑz pʌblɪk; oʊnli pʌnɪʃmən tʊk pleɪs ɪn pɹaɪvət. "ʃi ɔlsoʊ æsk mi tə ɹimaɪn jə ʌv sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt ʃi ɹʌʃt ɔf bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ wʌt." ʃi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ə snɔɹt. sɪlviænə sɔ ɛniθɪŋ ðət tʊk taɪm əweɪ fɹəm əɹ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪɾ əz nidləs ɪntɝʌpʃən.

"The Keeper said you wanted to speak me," Silviana said irritably. "About a private penance." Even to the Amyrlin Seat, she made no effort to hide her disgust. Silviana believed private penance a ridiculous affectation. Penance was public; only punishment took place in private. "She also asked me to remind you of something, but she rushed off before saying what." She finished with a snort. Silviana saw anything that took time away from her novices and Accepted as needless interruption.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ," ɪleɪɾə toʊld əɹ dʌli.

"I think I remember," Elaida told her dully.

wən sɪlviænə faɪnəli lɛft - æftɝ oʊnli hæf ən aʊɝ baɪ ðə tʃaɪmz ə səmeɪlz klɑk, jɛɾ ən ɛnləs ɪtɝnəɾi - ɔl ðət kɛpt ɪleɪɾə fɹəm kɔlɪŋ ðə hɔl tə sɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli soʊ ʃi kəd dɪmæn ɑlviɛɝɪn bi stʃɹɪpt ə ðə kipɝz stoʊl wɝ ðə sɝɾənti ʌv əɹ fɔɹtɛlɪŋ ən ðə sɝɾənti ðət sin wəd tʃɹeɪs ðət tʃɹeɪl ə tʃɹizən bæk tə ɑlviɛɝɪn. ðæt, ən ðə ʃʊɹ fæk ðət wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn fɛl ɪn ðə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən, ʃi hɝsɛlf dɛfənətli wʊd. soʊ, ɪleɪɾə də əvɹaɪni ɹɔɪhən, wɑtʃɝ ə ðə silz, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ʃʊɹli ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɹulɝ ɪn ðə wɝld, leɪ feɪsdaʊn ɑn əɹ bɛɾ ən blʌbɝɾ ɪndə hɝ pɪloʊz, tu tɛndɝ tə dɑn ðə ʃɪf ðət leɪ dɪskɑɹɾɪd ɑn ðə flɔɹ, sɝɾən ðət wən ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹɪtɝnd, ðə wʊmən wəɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn əɹ sɪɾɪŋ θɹu ði ɪntaɪɝ ɪntɝvju. ʃi blʌbɝd, ən θɹu hɝ tɪɹz ʃi pɹeɪd fəɹ ɑlviɛɝɪnz daʊnfɔl tə kʌm sun.

When Silviana finally left - after only half an hour by the chimes of Cemaile's clock, yet an endless eternity - all that kept Elaida from calling the Hall to sit immediately so she could demand Alviarin be stripped of the Keeper's stole were the certainty of her Foretelling and the certainty that Seaine would trace that trail of treason back to Alviarin. That, and the sure fact that whether or not Alviarin fell in the confrontation, she herself definitely would. So, Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan, Watcher of the Seals, the Flame of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat, surely the most powerful ruler in the world, lay facedown on her bed and blubbered into her pillows, too tender to don the shift that lay discarded on the floor, certain that when Alviarin returned, the woman would insist on her sitting through the entire interview. She blubbered, and through her tears she prayed for Alviarin's downfall to come soon.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt tɛl jə tə hæv ɪleɪɾə . . . biɾən," ðət vɔɪs ə kɹɪstəl tʃaɪmz sɛd. "du jə ɹaɪz əbʌv jɝsɛlf?"

"I did not tell you to have Elaida . . . beaten," that voice of crystal chimes said. "Do you rise above yourself?"

ɑlviɛɝɪn flʌŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm əɹ niz ɑntu hɝ bɛli bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən u simd meɪɾ ə dɑɹk ʃædoʊz ən sɪlvɝi laɪt. sizɪŋ ðə hɛm ə mɛsænəz dʒɹɛs, ʃi ɹeɪn kɪsəz ɑn ɪt. ðə wiv ʌv ɪluʒən - ɪt mʌs bi ðæt, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑt si ə sɪŋɡəl θɹɛɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi kəd sɛns ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl ɪn ðə wʊmən u stʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ - dɪd nɑt hoʊl kəmplitli, wɪð əɹ fɹæntəkəli ʃɪftɪŋ ðə skɝts ɛdʒ. flɪkɝz ə bɹɑnz sɪlk wɪð ə θɪn bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɪntʃɹəkətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blæk skɹɑlwɝk ʃoʊd θɹu.

Alviarin flung herself from her knees onto her belly before the woman who seemed made of dark shadows and silvery light. Seizing the hem of Mesaana's dress, she rained kisses on it. The weave of Illusion - it must be that, though she could not see a single thread of saidar any more than she could sense the ability to channel in the woman who stood over her - did not hold completely, with her frantically shifting the skirt's edge. Flickers of bronze silk with a thin border of intricately embroidered black scrollwork showed through.

"aɪ lɪv tə sɝv ən oʊbeɪ ju, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ɑlviɛɝɪn pæntɪd bɪtwin kɪsəz. "aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪm əmʌŋ ðə loʊəst ə ðə loʊ, ə wɝm ɪn jəɹ pɹɛzəns, ən aɪ pɹeɪ oʊnli fəɹ jəɹ smaɪl." ʃi hæd bɪn pʌnɪʃt wʌns fəɹ "ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv hɝsɛlf" - nɑt fəɹ dɪsəbiɾiəns, θæŋks bi tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk! - ən ʃi nu ðət wʌtɛvɝ haʊlz ɪleɪɾə maɪt bi ɹeɪzɪŋ ɹaɪt ðɛn, ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi hæf soʊ laʊɾ əz əɹ oʊn hæd bɪn.

"I live to serve and obey you, Great Mistress," Alviarin panted between kisses. "I know that I am among the lowest of the low, a worm in your presence, and I pray only for your smile." She had been punished once for "rising above herself" - not for disobedience, thanks be to the Great Lord of the Dark! - and she knew that whatever howls Elaida might be raising right then, they could not be half so loud as her own had been.

mɛsænə lɛt ðə kɪsɪŋ ɡoʊ ɑn fəɹ səm taɪm, ən faɪnəli sɪɡnəld ən ɛn baɪ tɪpɪŋ ɑlviɛɝɪnz feɪs ʌp wɪð ðə toʊ ʌv ə slɪpɝ bɪniθ ðə tʃɪn. "ðə dɪkɹi hæz ɡɔn aʊt." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn ænsɝd heɪstəli.

Mesaana let the kissing go on for some time, and finally signaled an end by tipping Alviarin's face up with the toe of a slipper beneath the chin. "The decree has gone out." It was not a question, but Alviarin answered hastily.

"jɛs, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs. kɑpiz wɛn tə nɔɹθhɑɹbɝ ən saʊθhɑɹbɝ ivən bɪfɔɹ aɪ hæɾ ɪleɪɾə saɪn. ðə fɝs kɝiɝz əv ɡɔn, ən noʊ mɝtʃənt wɪl liv ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt kɑpiz tə dɪstʃɹɪbjut." mɛsænə nu ɔl ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ə kɹæmp taɪɾənd ðə bæk ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪnz ɔkwɝdli kɹeɪnd nɛk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt muv. mɛsænə wəd tɛl əɹ wən tə muv. "ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs, ɪleɪɾə ɪz ən ɛmpti hʌsk. wɪð ɔl hjumɪlɪɾi, wəɾ ɪt nɑt bi bɛɾɝ wɪθaʊt ðə nid tə juz hɝ?" ʃi hɛld əɹ bɹɛθ. kwɛstʃənz kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən.

"Yes, Great Mistress. Copies went to Northharbor and Southharbor even before I had Elaida sign. The first couriers have gone, and no merchant will leave the city without copies to distribute." Mesaana knew all that, of course. She knew everything. A cramp tightened the back of Alviarin's awkwardly craned neck, but she did not move. Mesaana would tell her when to move. "Great Mistress, Elaida is an empty husk. With all humility, would it not be better without the need to use her?" She held her breath. Questions could be dangerous, with the Chosen.

ə ʃædoʊ-neɪl sɪlvɝi fɪŋɡɝ tæp sɪlvɝ lɪps pɝst ɪn ən əmjuz smaɪl. "bɛɾɝ ɪf jə wɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl, tʃaɪld?" mɛsænə sɛɾ ət læst. "æn æmbɪʃən smɔl ɪnʌf tə fɪt ju, bʌɾ ɔl ɪn ɪts taɪm. fəɹ naʊ, aɪ hæv ə taɪni tæsk fəɹ ju. ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɔl ðə wɔlz ðəɾ əv ɡɔn ʌp bɪtwin ði ədʒəz, ðə hɛdz ə ði ədʒəz sim tə ɪnkaʊntɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ fɹikwənsi. baɪ tʃæns, ðeɪ meɪk ɪt sim. ɔl bʌt ðə ɹɛd, ət list; ə pɪɾi ɡəlinə ɡɑt hɝsɛlf kɪld, əɹ ʃi kəd tɛl jə wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ əbaʊt. vɛɹi pɹɑbli ɪts tʃɹɪviəl, bʌt jəl lɝn waɪ ðeɪ bɛɹ tiθ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn pʌblɪk, ðən wɪspɝ təɡɛðɝ ɪn pɹaɪvət."

A shadow-nailed silvery finger tapped silver lips pursed in an amused smile. "Better if you wore the Amyrlin's stole, child?" Mesaana said at last. "An ambition small enough to fit you, but all in its time. For now, I have a tiny task for you. In spite of all the walls that have gone up between the Ajahs, the heads of the Ajahs seem to encounter one another with surprising frequency. By chance, they make it seem. All but the Red, at least; a pity Galina got herself killed, or she could tell you what they are about. Very probably it is trivial, but you will learn why they bare teeth at one another in public, then whisper together in private."

"aɪ hɪɹ ən oʊbeɪ, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹɪplaɪd pɹɑmpli, ɡɹeɪtfəl ðət mɛsænə kənsɪɾɝd ɪɾ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə ɡɹeɪt "sikɹət" ʌv u hɛɾəd ði ədʒəz wɑz nʌn tə hɝ - ɛvɹi blæk sɪstɝ wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə ɹileɪ tə ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl ɛvɹi wɪspɝ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ səpoʊzd ədʒɑ - bʌɾ oʊnli ɡəlinə əmʌŋ əm hæd bɪn blæk. ðət mɛn kwɛɝaɪɪŋ ðə blæk sɪstɝz əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz, wɪtʃ mɛnt ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ɔl ðə leɪɝz bɪtwin əm ən hɝ. ðət wəd teɪk taɪm, ən wɪθaʊɾ ɛni sɝɾənti ʌv səksɛs. ɪksɛp fəɹ fɛɹən nhɝən ən swænə dʒɹeɪɡənd, hu wɝ ðə hɛdz ə ðə ðɛɹ ədʒəz, sɪɾɝz ɹɛɹli sim tə noʊ wʌt ðɛɹ ədʒɑz hɛd wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ toʊld. "aɪ wɪl tɛl jə əz sun əz aɪ lɝn, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs."

"I hear and obey, Great Mistress," Alviarin replied promptly, grateful that Mesaana considered it unimportant. The great "secret" of who headed the Ajahs was none to her - every Black sister was required to relay to the Supreme Council every whisper inside her supposed Ajah - but only Galina among them had been Black. That meant querying the Black sisters among the Sitters, which meant going through all the layers between them and her. That would take time, and without any certainty of success. Except for Ferane Neheran and Suana Dragand, who were the heads of the their Ajahs, Sitters rarely seemed to know what their Ajah's head was thinking until they were told. "I will tell you as soon as I learn, Great Mistress."

bʌt ʃi dɪd faɪl əweɪ ə tɪdbɪt fəɹ hɝsɛlf. tʃɹɪviəl mæɾɝ əɹ nɑt, mɛsænə dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət hæpən ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ən ɑlviɛɝɪn wəd kip əɹ aɪz oʊpən fəɹ ə sɪstɝ ɪn bɹɑnz skɝts bɔɹɾɝd ɑn ðə hɛm ɪn blæk skɹɑlwɝk. mɛsænə wɑz haɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən nɑlədʒ wɑz paʊɝ.

But she did file away a tidbit for herself. Trivial matter or not, Mesaana did not know everything that happened in the White Tower. And Alviarin would keep her eyes open for a sister in bronze skirts bordered on the hem in black scrollwork. Mesaana was hiding herself in the Tower, and knowledge was power.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks


CHAPTER 26

ði ɛkstʃɹə bɪt


The Extra Bit

sin stʃɹoʊd ðə hɔlweɪz ə ðə taʊɝ wɪð ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ sɛns ə biɪŋ kənfaʊndɪɾ əɾ ɛvɹi tɝn. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz kwaɪt lɑɹdʒ, tʃɹu, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ət ðɪs fəɹ aʊɝz. ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑntəd tə bi snʌɡ ɪn əɹ oʊn ɹumz. dɪspaɪt keɪsməns ɪn pleɪs ɪn ɛvɹi wɪndoʊ, dʒɹæfs dʒɹɪftəɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɹɔd, tæpəstʃɹi-hʌŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz ən meɪd ðə stænd-læmps flɪkɝ. koʊl dʒɹæfs, ən dɪfəkəl tə ɪɡnɔɹ wən ðeɪ slɪpt ʌndɝ əɹ skɝts. hɝ ɹumz wɝ wɔɹm ən kʌmftəɹbəl, ən seɪf.

Seaine strode the hallways of the Tower with a growing sense of being confounded at every turn. The White Tower was quite large, true, but she had been at this for hours. She very much wanted to be snug in her own rooms. Despite casements in place in every window, drafts drifted along the broad, tapestry-hung corridors and made the stand-lamps flicker. Cold drafts, and difficult to ignore when they slipped under her skirts. Her rooms were warm and comfortable, and safe.

meɪdz bɑb kɝtsiz ən mænsɝvəns baʊɾ ɪn əɹ weɪk, hæf-sin ən kəmplitli ɪɡnɔɹd. moʊst sɪstɝz wɝ ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒəz' kɔɹɾɝz, ən ðoʊz fju aʊɾ ən əbaʊt muvd wɪð wɛɹi pɹaɪd, ɔfən ɪn pɛɹz, ɔlweɪz ə ðə seɪm ədʒɑ, ʃɔlz spɹɛɾ əlɔŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən dɪspleɪd laɪk bænɝz. ʃi smaɪld ən nɑɾəd plɛzənli tə tælin, bʌt ðə stætʃuɛsk, ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd sɪɾɝ ɹɪtɝn ə hɑɹd stɛɹ, bjuɾi kɑɹv fɹəm aɪs, ðən stɔkt əweɪ twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl.

Maids bobbed curtsies and manservants bowed in her wake, half-seen and completely ignored. Most sisters were in their own Ajahs' quarters, and those few out and about moved with wary pride, often in pairs, always of the same Ajah, shawls spread along their arms and displayed like banners. She smiled and nodded pleasantly to Talene, but the statuesque, golden-haired Sitter returned a hard stare, beauty carved from ice, then stalked away twitching her green-fringed shawl.

tu leɪt naʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ tælin əbaʊt biɪŋ pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɝtʃ, ivən hæd pɛvɑɹə bɪn əɡɹiəbəl. pɛvɑɹə kaʊnsəl kɑʃən, ðən mɔɹ kɑʃən, ən tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, sin wɑz mɔɹ ðən wɪlɪŋ tə lɪsən ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət tælin wɑz ə fɹɛnd. hæd bɪn ə fɹɛnd.

Too late now to approach Talene about being part of the search, even had Pevara been agreeable. Pevara counseled caution, then more caution, and truth to tell, Seaine was more than willing to listen under the circumstances. It was just that Talene was a friend. Had been a friend.

tælin wɑz nɑt ðə wɝst. sɛvɹəl ɔɹɾənɛɹi sɪstɝz snɪft əɾ əɹ oʊpənli. əɾ ə sɪɾɝ! nʌn waɪt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðət ʃʊɾə meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə taʊɝ, pɹəpɹaɪəɾiz ʃəd bi əbzɝvd. dʒuleɪn mədoʊm, ə tɔl, ətʃɹæktɪv wʊmən wɪð ʃɔɹt-kʌt blæk hɛɹ u hæd hɛld ə tʃɛɹ fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn lɛs ðən ə jɪɹ, bɹʌʃt pæst əɹ wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə mɝmɝ ʌv əpɑlədʒi ən wɛn ɔf wɪð ðoʊz mænɪʃ stʃɹaɪdz ə hɝz. sɹɪn æsnoʊbɑɹ, ənʌðɝ bɹaʊn sɪɾɝ, ɡeɪv sin ə fɪɹs skaʊl ən fɪŋɡɝd ðət kɝv naɪf ʃi ɔlweɪz kæɹid bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛl bɪfɔɹ dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ daʊn ə saɪd kɔɹəɾɝ. sɹɪn wɑz ɔltɑɹən, slaɪt tʌtʃəz ʌv waɪɾ əɾ əɹ dɑɹk tɛmpəlz ɛmfəsaɪzɪŋ ə θɪn eɪdʒ-feɪɾəd waɪt skɑɹ əkɹɔs wʌn ɑləv tʃik, ən oʊnli ə wɔɹɾɝ kəd mætʃ əɹ fəɹ skaʊlɪŋ.

Talene was not the worst. Several ordinary sisters sniffed at her openly. At a Sitter! None White, of course, but that should have made no difference. No matter what was going on in the Tower, proprieties should be observed. Juilaine Madome, a tall, attractive woman with short-cut black hair who had held a chair for the Brown less than a year, brushed past her without so much as a murmur of apology and went off with those mannish strides of hers. Saerin Asnobar, another Brown Sitter, gave Seaine a fierce scowl and fingered that curved knife she always carried behind her belt before disappearing down a side corridor. Saerin was Altaran, slight touches of white at her dark temples emphasizing a thin age-faded white scar across one olive cheek, and only a Warder could match her for scowling.

pɝhæps ðiz θɪŋz wɝ ɔl tə bi ɪkspɛktəd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn sɛvɹəl ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ ɪnsəɾənts ɹisənli, ən noʊ sɪstɝ wəd fɝɡɛt biɪŋ bʌndəld ʌnsɛɹəmoʊniəsli fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪz ɝaʊn ənʌðɝ ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz, mʌtʃ lɛs wʌt hæd səmtaɪmz ɡɔn wɪð ɪt. ɹumɝ sɛɾ ə sɪɾɝ - ə sɪɾɝ! - hæd hæd mɔɹ ðən əɹ dɪɡnəɾi ɹʌfəl baɪ ðə ɹɛdz, ðoʊ nɑt hu. ə ɡɹeɪt pɪɾi ðə hɔl kəd nɑɾ əbstʃɹʌkt ɪleɪɾəz mæd dɪkɹi, bʌt fɝst wʌn ədʒɑ, ðən ənʌðɝ, hæd lɛpt ɑn ðə nu pɹɪɹɑɡəɾɪvz, fju sɪɾɝz wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ əm ʌp naʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɪn pleɪs, ən ðə ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ə taʊɝ dɪvaɪɾəd vɛɹi nɪɹli ɪndə ɑɹm kæmps. wʌns sin hæd θɔt ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ fɛlt laɪk ə kwɪvɝɪŋ hɑt dʒɛli ʌv səspɪʃən ən bækbaɪɾɪŋ; naʊ ɪt wɑz kwɪvɝɪŋ hɑt dʒɛli wɪð ən æsəd baɪt.

Perhaps these things were all to be expected. There had been several unfortunate incidents recently, and no sister would forget being bundled unceremoniously from the hallways around another Ajah's quarters, much less what had sometimes gone with it. Rumor said a Sitter - a Sitter! - had had more than her dignity ruffled by the Reds, though not who. A great pity the Hall could not obstruct Elaida's mad decree, but first one Ajah, then another, had leaped on the new prerogatives, few Sitters were willing to think of giving them up now that they were in place, and the result was a Tower divided very nearly into armed camps. Once Seaine had thought the air in the Tower felt like a quivering hot jelly of suspicion and backbiting; now it was quivering hot jelly with an acid bite.

klɪkɪŋ əɹ tʌŋ ɪn vɛkseɪʃən, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ oʊn waɪt-fɹɪnd ʃɔl əz sɹɪn vænɪʃt. ɪt wɑz ɪlɑdʒɪkəl tə flɪntʃ kəz ən ɔltɑɹən skaʊld - ivən sɹɪn wəd ɡoʊ noʊ fɑɹðɝ; ʃʊɹli nɑt - ən mɔɹ ðən ɪlɑdʒɪkəl tə wɝi oʊvɝ wʌt ʃi kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ wən ʃi hæɾ ə tæsk.

Clicking her tongue in vexation, she adjusted her own white-fringed shawl as Saerin vanished. It was illogical to flinch because an Altaran scowled - even Saerin would go no farther; surely not - and more than illogical to worry over what she could not change when she had a task.

ən ðɛn, æftɝ ɔl ə hɝ sɝtʃ ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, ʃi tʊk ə sɪŋɡəl stɛp ən sɔ hɝ lɔŋ-sɔt kwɔɹi wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ. zɛɹə dɑkən wɑz ə slɪm, blæk-hɛɹd ɡɝl wɪð ə pɹaɪdfəl ɛɹ, pɹɑpɝli sɛlf-pəzɛst, ən baɪ ɔl aʊtwɝɾ ɛvəɾəns əntʌtʃt baɪ ðə hiɾəd kɝəns floʊɪŋ θɹu ðə taʊɝ ðiz deɪz. wɛl, nɑɾ ə ɡɝl pɹɪsaɪsli, bʌt sin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd nɑt wɔɹn ðət waɪt-fɹɪnd ʃɔl fɪfti jɪɹz jɛt. ʃi wɑz ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst. ɹɛləɾɪvli ɪnɪkspɪɹiənst. ðət maɪt hɛlp.

And then, after all of her search that morning, she took a single step and saw her long-sought quarry walking toward her. Zerah Dacan was a slim, black-haired girl with a prideful air, properly self-possessed, and by all outward evidence untouched by the heated currents flowing through the Tower these days. Well, not a girl precisely, but Seaine was sure she had not worn that white-fringed shawl fifty years yet. She was inexperienced. Relatively inexperienced. That might help.

zɛɹə meɪd noʊ muv tə əvɔɪɾ ə sɪɾɝ ə hɝ oʊn ədʒɑ, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn ɹɪspɛkt əz sin fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd hɝ. kwaɪɾ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɪntʃɹəkət ɡoʊldən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi klaɪm ðə slivz ə hɝ snoʊi dʒɹɛs ən meɪɾ ə waɪd bæn ət ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ skɝt. ɪt wɑz ən ənjuʒəwəl dɪɡɹi ʌv ʃoʊ fəɹ ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ. "sɪɾɝ," ʃi mɝmɝd. dɪɾ əɹ blu aɪz hoʊld ə tʌtʃ ʌv wɝi?

Zerah made no move to avoid a Sitter of her own Ajah, bowing her head in respect as Seaine fell in beside her. Quite a lot of intricate golden embroidery climbed the sleeves of her snowy dress and made a wide band at the bottom of her skirt. It was an unusual degree of show for the White Ajah. "Sitter," she murmured. Did her blue eyes hold a touch of worry?

"aɪ nid jə fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ," sin sɛd mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt. vɛɹi laɪkli ʃi wɑz tʃɹænsplæntɪŋ əɹ oʊn filɪŋz ɪndə zɛɹəz bɪɡ aɪz. "kʌm wɪð mi." ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ, nɑɾ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt kipɪŋ əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst, ənklɛntʃt, ɹikwaɪɝd sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɛfɝt.

"I need you for something," Seaine said more calmly than she felt. Very likely she was transplanting her own feelings into Zerah's big eyes. "Come with me." There was nothing to fear, not in the heart of the White Tower, but keeping her hands folded at her waist, unclenched, required surprising effort.

əz ɪkspɛktəd - əz hoʊpt - zɛɹə wɛn əlɔŋ wɪð oʊnli ənʌðɝ mɝmɝ, ðɪs ʌv ækwiɛsəns. ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd ət sinz saɪd kwaɪt ɡɹeɪsfəli əz ðeɪ dɪsɛndəd bɹɔd mɑɹbəl stɛɹkeɪsɪz ən waɪd kɝvɪŋ ɹæmps, ən ɡeɪv oʊnli ðə slaɪɾəst fɹaʊn wən sin oʊpən ə dɔɹ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ, ɑntu nɛɹoʊ stɛɹz ðət spaɪɹəl daʊn ɪndə dɑɹknəs.

As expected - as hoped - Zerah went along with only another murmur, this of acquiescence. She glided at Seaine's side quite gracefully as they descended broad marble staircases and wide curving ramps, and gave only the slightest frown when Seaine opened a door on the ground floor, onto narrow stairs that spiraled down into darkness.

"æftɝ ju, sɪstɝ," sin sɛd, tʃænəlɪŋ ə smɔl bɔl ə laɪt. baɪ pɹoʊɾəkɑl, ʃi ʃʊɾə pɹɪsiɾɪd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə də ðæt.

"After you, sister," Seaine said, channeling a small ball of light. By protocol, she should have preceded the other woman, but she could not bring herself to do that.

zɛɹə dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪɾ ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn. lɑdʒɪkli, ʃi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ fɹəm ə sɪɾɝ, ə waɪt sɪɾɝ. lɑdʒɪkli, sin wəd tɛl əɹ wʌt ʃi wɑntəd wən ðə taɪm wɑz ɹaɪp, ən ɪt wəd bi nʌθɪŋ ʃi kəd nɑt du. ɪlɑdʒɪkli, sinz stʌmək flʌɾɝd laɪk ə hjudʒ mɔθ. laɪt, ʃi hɛl seɪaɪdɑɹ ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən dɪd nɑt. zɛɹə wɑz wikɝ ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ. wɪtʃ dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə kwaɪət ðoʊz flʌɾɝɪŋ wɪŋz ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl.

Zerah did not hesitate in going down. Logically, she had nothing to fear from a Sitter, a White Sitter. Logically, Seaine would tell her what she wanted when the time was ripe, and it would be nothing she could not do. Illogically, Seaine's stomach fluttered like a huge moth. Light, she held saidar and the other woman did not. Zerah was weaker in any case. There was nothing to fear. Which did nothing to quiet those fluttering wings in her middle.

daʊn ðeɪ klaɪmd ən daʊn, pæs dɔɹz lɛɾɪŋ ɑntu beɪsməns ən sʌbəsməns, əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə vɛɹi loʊəs lɛvəl, bɪloʊ ivən wɛɹ ði æksɛptɪd wɝ tɛstəd. ðə dɑɹk hɔlweɪ wɑz lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ sinz smɔl laɪt. ðeɪ hɛl ðɛɹ skɝts haɪ, bʌt ðɛɹ slɪpɝz kɪkt ʌp smɔl klaʊdz ə dʌs haʊɛvɝ kɛɹfəli ðeɪ stɛpt. pleɪn wʊɾən dɔɹz laɪn ðə smuð stoʊn wɔlz, mɛni wɪð ɡɹeɪt lʌmps ə ɹʌs fəɹ hɪnʒɪz ən lɑks.

Down they climbed and down, past doors letting onto basements and subbasements, until they reached the very lowest level, below even where the Accepted were tested. The dark hallway was lit only by Seaine's small light. They held their skirts high, but their slippers kicked up small clouds of dust however carefully they stepped. Plain wooden doors lined the smooth stone walls, many with great lumps of rust for hinges and locks.

"sɪɾɝ," zɛɹə æskt, faɪnəli ʃoʊɪŋ daʊt, "wʌtɛvɝ kən wi bi æftɝ daʊn hɪɹ? aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɛniwʌn əz bɪn ðɪs dip fəɹ jɪɹz."

"Sitter," Zerah asked, finally showing doubt, "whatever can we be after down here? I don't believe anyone has been this deep for years."

sin wɑz ʃʊɹ əɹ oʊn vɪzət, ə fju deɪz ɝliɝ, hæd bɪn ðə fɝs tə ðɪs lɛvəl ɪn ət list ə sɛntʃɝi. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə ɹizənz ʃi ən pɛvɑɹə hæd tʃoʊzən ɪt. "dʒʌst ɪn hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ oʊpən ə dɔɹ ðət muvd wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl skwilɪŋ. noʊ əmaʊn ʌv ɔɪl kəd lusən ɔl ðə ɹʌst, ən ɛfɝts tə juz ðə paʊɝ hæd bɪn jusləs. hɝ əbɪləɾiz wɪð ɝθ wɝ bɛɾɝ ðən pɛvɑɹəz, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt seɪɪŋ vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

Seaine was sure her own visit, a few days earlier, had been the first to this level in at least a century. That was one of the reasons she and Pevara had chosen it. "Just in here," she said, swinging open a door that moved with only a little squealing. No amount of oil could loosen all the rust, and efforts to use the Power had been useless. Her abilities with Earth were better than Pevara's, but that was not saying very much.

zɛɹə stɛpt ɪn, ən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ɪn ən ʌðɝwaɪz ɛmpti ɹum, pɛvɑɹə sæt bɪhaɪn ə stɝɾi ɪf ɹæðɝ wɔɹn teɪbəl wɪð θɹi smɔl bɛntʃɪz ɝaʊn ɪt. ɡɛɾɪŋ ðoʊz fju pisəz daʊn ənsin hæd bɪn dɪfəkəlt - ɪspɛʃli wən sɝvəns kəd nɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪd. klɪɹɪŋ aʊt ðə dʌs hæd bɪn mʌtʃ sɪmpəlɝ ɪf noʊ mɔɹ plɛzənt, ən smuðɪŋ ðə dʌst ɪn ðə hɔl aʊtsaɪd, nɛsəsɛɹi æftɝ ɛvɹi vɪzət, hæd bɪn sɪmpli oʊnɝəs.

Zerah stepped in, and blinked in surprise. In an otherwise empty room, Pevara sat behind a sturdy if rather worn table with three small benches around it. Getting those few pieces down unseen had been difficult - especially when servants could not be trusted. Clearing out the dust had been much simpler if no more pleasant, and smoothing the dust in the hall outside, necessary after every visit, had been simply onerous.

"aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə ɡɪv ʌp sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk," pɛvɑɹə ɡɹaʊld. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəɾ əɹ əz ʃi lɪftəɾ ə læntɝn fɹəm bɪniθ ðə teɪbəl ən tʃænəld ɪɾ əlaɪt, kæstɪŋ əz mʌtʃ ɪluməneɪʃən əz ðə ɹʌf-wɔl fɔɹmɝ stɔɹɹum dɪzɝvd. sʌmwʌt plʌmp ən nɔɹməli pɹɪɾi, ðə ɹɛd sɪɾɝ lʊkt ə bɛɹ wɪð tu sɔɹ tiθ. "wi wɑnə æsk jə ə fju kwɛstʃənz, zɛɹə." ən ʃi ʃildɪd ðə wʊmən əz sin ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ.

"I was about to give up sitting here in the dark," Pevara growled. The glow of saidar surrounded her as she lifted a lantern from beneath the table and channeled it alight, casting as much illumination as the rough-walled former storeroom deserved. Somewhat plump and normally pretty, the Red Sitter looked a bear with two sore teeth. "We want to ask you a few questions, Zerah." And she shielded the woman as Seaine shut the door.

zɛɹəz ʃæɾoʊd feɪs ɹɪmeɪn ʌɾɝli kɑm, bʌt ʃi swɑloʊɾ ɑɾəbli. "əbaʊt wʌt, sɪɾɝz?" ðəɹ wɑz ðə feɪntəs tʃɹɛmɝ ɪn ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmənz vɔɪs, əz wɛl. ɪt kəd bi sɪmpli ðə muɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ðoʊ.

Zerah's shadowed face remained utterly calm, but she swallowed audibly. "About what, Sitters?" There was the faintest tremor in the younger woman's voice, as well. It could be simply the mood of the Tower, though.

"ðə blæk ədʒɑ," pɛvɑɹə ɹɪplaɪd kɝtli. "wi wɑnə noʊ wɛðɝ jəɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

"The Black Ajah," Pevara replied curtly. "We want to know whether you're a Darkfriend."

əmeɪzmən ən aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ʃæɾɝd zɛɹəz kɑm. moʊst wʊɾə teɪkən ðət fəɹ səfɪʃən dɪnaɪəl wɪθaʊɾ əɹ snæpt "aɪ doʊn əv tə teɪk ðət fɹəm ju! jə ɹɛdz əv bɪn sɛɾɪŋ ʌp fɔls dʒɹæɡənz fəɹ jɪɹz! ɪf jə æsk mi, ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə lʊk fɝðɝ ðən ðə ɹɛd kɔɹɾɝz tə faɪn blæk sɪstɝz!"

Amazement and outrage shattered Zerah's calm. Most would have taken that for sufficient denial without her snapped "I don't have to take that from you! You Reds have been setting up false Dragons for years! If you ask me, there's no need to look further than the Red quarters to find Black sisters!"

pɛvɑɹəz feɪs dɑɹkənd wɪð fjʊɹi. hɝ lɔɪəlti tə hɝ ədʒɑ wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, wɪtʃ wɛnt wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ, bʌt wɝs, ʃi hæd lɔst əɹ ɪntaɪɝ fæmli tə dɑɹkfɹɛnz. sin dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stɛp ɪn bɪfɔɹ pɛvɑɹə ɹɪzɔɹɾɪd tə bɹut fɔɹs. ðeɪ hæd noʊ pɹuf. nɑt jɛt.

Pevara's face darkened with fury. Her loyalty to her Ajah was strong, which went without saying, but worse, she had lost her entire family to Darkfriends. Seaine decided to step in before Pevara resorted to brute force. They had no proof. Not yet.

"sɪt, zɛɹə," ʃi sɛd wɪð əz mʌtʃ wɔɹmθ əz ʃi kəd mʌstɝ. "sɪt daʊn, sɪstɝ."

"Sit, Zerah," she said with as much warmth as she could muster. "Sit down, sister."

zɛɹə tɝn təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ əz ðoʊ ʃi maɪt dɪsəbeɪ ən ɔɹɾɝ fɹəm ə sɪɾɝ - ən ə hɝ oʊn ədʒɑ! - bʌɾ ət læst ʃi sɛɾəld ɑntu wʌn ə ðə bɛntʃɪz, stɪfli, sɪɾɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ət ði ɛdʒ.

Zerah turned toward the door as though she might disobey an order from a Sitter - and of her own Ajah! - but at last she settled onto one of the benches, stiffly, sitting right at the edge.

bɪfɔɹ sin hæd fɪnɪʃt teɪkɪŋ ə sit ðət pleɪs zɛɹə bɪtwin ðɛm, pɛvɑɹə leɪd ði aɪvɝi-waɪɾ oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɑn ðə bæɾɝd teɪbəltɑp. sin saɪd. ðeɪ wɝ sɪɾɝz, wɪð ə pɝfəkt ɹaɪt tə juz ɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðeɪ wɪʃt, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ðə wʌn tə fɪltʃ ɪt - ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ əz fɪlkɪŋ wən ʃi hæɾ əbzɝv nʌn ə ðə pɹɑpɝ pɹəsidʒɝz - ən ðə hoʊl taɪm, ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ʃi wəd tɝn tə faɪn lɔŋ-dɛd sɛɝl beɪɡən stændɪŋ hɪɹ, ɹɛɾi tə hɔl əɹ ɔf tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz' stʌɾi baɪ hɝ ɪɹ. ɪɹæʃənəl, bʌt noʊ lɛs ɹil.

Before Seaine had finished taking a seat that placed Zerah between them, Pevara laid the ivory-white Oath Rod on the battered tabletop. Seaine sighed. They were Sitters, with a perfect right to use any ter'angreal they wished, but she had been the one to filch it - she could not help thinking of it as filching when she had observed none of the proper procedures - and the whole time, in the back of her head, she had been sure she would turn to find long-dead Sereille Bagand standing here, ready to haul her off to the Mistress of Novices' study by her ear. Irrational, but no less real.

"wi wɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ jə tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ," pɛvɑɹə sɛd, stɪl saʊndɪŋ laɪk ən æŋɡɹi bɛɹ, "soʊ jəl swɛɹ ən oʊθ ɑn ðɪs, ən ðən əl æsk əɡɛn."

"We want to make sure you tell the truth," Pevara said, still sounding like an angry bear, "so you will swear an oath on this, and then I'll ask again."

"aɪ ʃəd nɑt bi səbdʒɛktɪd tə ðɪs," zɛɹə sɛd wɪð ən əkjuzɪŋ lʊk ət sin, "bʌɾ əl ɹeɪ-swɛɹ ɔl ə ði oʊðz, ɪf ðæts wʌɾ ɪt nidz tə sæɾəsfaɪ ju. ən əl dɪmæn ən əpɑlədʒi fɹəm jə boʊθ, æftɝwɝd." ʃi hɑɹdli saʊndəd laɪk ə wʊmən ʃildɪɾ ən æsk sətʃ ə kwɛstʃən. ɔlmoʊs kəntɛmptʃwəsli, ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə slɪm, fʊt-lɔŋ ɹɑd. ɪt ʃoʊn ɪn ðə dɪm laɪɾ ə ðə læntɝn.

"I should not be subjected to this," Zerah said with an accusing look at Seaine, "but I will re-swear all of the Oaths, if that's what it needs to satisfy you. And I will demand an apology from you both, afterward." She hardly sounded like a woman shielded and asked such a question. Almost contemptuously, she reached for the slim, foot-long rod. It shone in the dim light of the lantern.

"jul swɛɹ tə oʊbeɪ ðə tu ʌv əs æbsəlutli," pɛvɑɹə toʊl hɝ, ən ðət hæn snætʃt bæk əz ɪf fɹəm ə kɔɪl vaɪpɝ. pɛvɑɹə wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn, ivən slaɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹɑd kloʊsɝ tə ðə wʊmən wɪð tu fɪŋɡɝz. "ðæt weɪ, wi kən tɛl jə tə ænsɝ tʃɹuθfəli ən noʊ jə wɪl, ən ɪf jə ɡɪv ðə ɹɔŋ ænsɝ, wi kən noʊ jəl bi oʊbiɾiənt ən hɛlpfəl ɪn hɛlpɪŋ əs hʌn daʊn jəɹ blæk sɪstɝz. ðə ɹɑd kən bi juz tə fɹi jə ʌv ði oʊθ, ɪf jə ɡɪv ðə ɹaɪɾ ænsɝ."

"You'll swear to obey the two of us absolutely," Pevara told her, and that hand snatched back as if from a coiled viper. Pevara went right on, even sliding the Rod closer to the woman with two fingers. "That way, we can tell you to answer truthfully and know you will, and if you give the wrong answer, we can know you'll be obedient and helpful in helping us hunt down your Black sisters. The Rod can be used to free you of the oath, if you give the right answer."

"tə fɹi - ?" zɛɹə ɪkskleɪmd. "aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn biɪŋ lus fɹəm ən oʊθ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd."

"To free - ?" Zerah exclaimed. "I've never heard of anyone being loosed from an oath on the Oath Rod."

"ðæɾ ɪz waɪ wəɹ teɪkɪŋ ɔl ðiz pɹikɔʃənz," sin toʊl hɝ. "lɑdʒɪkli, ə blæk sɪstɝ mʌs bi eɪbəl tə laɪ, wɪtʃ minz ʃi mʌst əv bɪn fɹiɾ ʌv ət lis ðəɾ oʊθ ən laɪkli ɔl θɹi. pɛvɑɹə ən aɪ tɛstəd, ən faʊn ðə pɹəsidʒɝ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm əz teɪkɪŋ ən oʊθ." ʃi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən haʊ peɪnfəl ɪt hæd bɪn, ðoʊ, livɪŋ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm wipɪŋ. ʃi ɔlsoʊ dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðət zɛɹə wəd nɑt bi fɹiɾ ə hɝ oʊθ wʌtɛvɝ əɹ ænsɝ, nɑɾ əntɪl ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ keɪm tə ə kənkluʒən. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ʃi kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɹʌn ɔf ən kəmpleɪn əbaʊt ðɪs kwɛstʃənɪŋ, wɪtʃ ʃi moʊst sɝɾənli wʊd, wɪð ɛvɹi ɹaɪt, ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə blæk. ɪf.

"That is why we are taking all these precautions," Seaine told her. "Logically, a Black sister must be able to lie, which means she must have been freed of at least that Oath and likely all three. Pevara and I tested, and found the procedure much the same as taking an oath." She did not mention how painful it had been, though, leaving the pair of them weeping. She also did not mention that Zerah would not be freed of her oath whatever her answer, not until the search for the Black Ajah came to a conclusion. For one thing, she could not be allowed to run off and complain about this questioning, which she most certainly would, with every right, if she was not of the Black. If.

laɪt, bʌt sin wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd faʊn ə sɪstɝ fɹəm ənʌðɝ ədʒɑ hu fɪt ðə kɹaɪtɪɹiə ðeɪ hæd sɛt. eɪ ɡɹin əɹ ə jɛloʊ wʊɾə dʌn kwaɪt naɪsli. ðət lɑt wɝ oʊvɝwinɪŋ ət ðə bɛst ə taɪmz, ən ə leɪt . . . ! noʊ. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə fɔl pɹeɪ tə ðə sɪknəs spɹɛɾɪŋ θɹu ðə taʊɝ. jɛt ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp ðə neɪmz ðət flæʃt θɹu hɝ hɛd, ə dʌzən ɡɹinz, twaɪs əz mɛni jɛloʊz, ən ɛvɹi wʌn lɔŋ pæs du teɪkɪŋ daʊn ə fju ɹʌŋz. snɪf əɾ ə sɪɾɝ?
