Light, but Seaine wished they had found a sister from another Ajah who fit the criteria they had set. A Green or a Yellow would have done quite nicely. That lot were overweening at the best of times, and of late . . . ! No. She was not going to fall prey to the sickness spreading through the Tower. Yet she could not help the names that flashed through her head, a dozen Greens, twice as many Yellows, and every one long past due taking down a few rungs. Sniff at a Sitter?

"ju fɹid jʊɹsɛlvz fɹəm wʌn ə ði oʊðz?" zɛɹə saʊndəd stɑɹɾəld, dɪsɡʌstəd, ənizi, ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm. pɝfəkli ɹizənəbəl ɹɪspɑnsɪz.

"You freed yourselves from one of the Oaths?" Zerah sounded startled, disgusted, uneasy, all at the same time. Perfectly reasonable responses.

"æn tʊk ɪɾ əɡɛn," pɛvɑɹə mʌɾɝd ɪmpeɪʃənli. snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə slɪm ɹɑd, ʃi tʃænəld ə lɪɾəl spɪɹəɾ ɪndə wʌn ɛnd waɪl meɪnteɪnɪŋ zɛɹəz ʃild. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ vaʊ tə spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ vaʊ tə meɪk noʊ wɛpən fəɹ wʌn mæn tə kɪl ənʌðɝ. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ vaʊ nɑt tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ɪksɛpt əɡɛns dɑɹk-fɹɛnz əɹ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əɹ ɪn ðə læs dɪfɛns ə maɪ laɪf, ðə laɪf ə maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, əɹ ðəɾ ʌv ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɹɪmɑs oʊvɝ ðə pɑɹɾ əbaʊt wɔɹɾɝz; nu sɪstɝz baʊn fəɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ɔfən dɪd. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. aɪ hoʊp ðət sæɾɪsfaɪz ju." ʃi ʃoʊd zɛɹə hɝ tiθ, bʌt wɛðɝ ɪn smaɪl əɹ snɑɹl wɑz hɑɹd tə seɪ.

"And took it again," Pevara muttered impatiently. Snatching up the slim rod, she channeled a little Spirit into one end while maintaining Zerah's shield. "Under the Light, I vow to speak no word that is not true. Under the Light, I vow to make no weapon for one man to kill another. Under the Light, I vow not to use the One Power as a weapon except against Dark-friends or Shadowspawn, or in the last defense of my life, the life of my Warder, or that of another sister." She did not grimace over the part about Warders; new sisters bound for the Red often did. "I am not a Darkfriend. I hope that satisfies you." She showed Zerah her teeth, but whether in smile or snarl was hard to say.

sin ɹitʊk ði oʊðz ɪn tɝn, itʃ pɹədusɪŋ ə slaɪt moʊməntɛɹi pɹɛʃɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ fɹəm əɹ skælp tə ðə soʊlz ə hɝ fit. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðə pɹɛʃɝ wɑz dɪfəkəl tə dɪtɛkt əɾ ɔl, wɪð əɹ skɪn stɪl filɪŋ tu taɪt fɹəm ɹəteɪkɪŋ ði oʊθ əɡɛnst spikɪŋ ə laɪ. kleɪmɪŋ ðət pɛvɑɹə hæɾ ə bɪɹɾ əɹ ðət ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɝ peɪvd wɪð tʃiz hæd bɪn stʃɹeɪnʒli ɪɡzɪlɝeɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə taɪm - ivən pɛvɑɹə hæd ɡɪɡəld - bʌt hɑɹdli wɝθ ðə dɪskʌmfɝt naʊ. tɛstɪŋ hæd nɑt ɹɪli sim nɛsəsɛɹi, tə hɝ. lɑdʒɪkli, ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. seɪɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə blæk twɪstəɾ əɹ tʌŋ - ə vaɪl θɪŋ tə bi fɔɹs tə dɪnaɪ - bʌt ʃi hændəd zɛɹə ði oʊθ ɹɑd wɪð ə dɪsaɪsɪv nɑd.

Seaine retook the Oaths in turn, each producing a slight momentary pressure everywhere from her scalp to the soles of her feet. In truth, the pressure was difficult to detect at all, with her skin still feeling too tight from retaking the Oath against speaking a lie. Claiming that Pevara had a beard or that the streets of Tar Valon were paved with cheese had been strangely exhilarating for a time - even Pevara had giggled - but hardly worth the discomfort now. Testing had not really seemed necessary, to her. Logically, it must be so. Saying that she was not of the Black twisted her tongue - a vile thing to be forced to deny - but she handed Zerah the Oath Rod with a decisive nod.

ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ, ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən tɝn ðə smuð waɪt ɹɑɾ ɪn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, swɑloʊɪŋ kənvʌlsɪvli. ðə peɪl læntɝn laɪt meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ ɪl. ʃi lʊk fɹəm wʌn ə ðɛm tə ði ʌðɝ, waɪd-aɪd, ðən əɹ hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə ɹɑd, ən ʃi nɑɾəd.

Shifting on her bench, the slender woman turned the smooth white rod in her fingers, swallowing convulsively. The pale lantern light made her appear ill. She looked from one of them to the other, wide-eyed, then her hands tightened on the Rod, and she nodded.

"ɪɡzækli əz aɪ sɛd," pɛvɑɹə ɡɹaʊld, tʃænəlɪŋ spɪɹət tə ðə ɹɑɾ əɡɛn, "ɔɹ jəl bi swɛɹɪŋ əntɪl juv ɪt ɹaɪt."

"Exactly as I said," Pevara growled, channeling Spirit to the Rod again, "or you'll be swearing until you have it right."

"aɪ vaʊ tə oʊbeɪ ðə tu ʌv jə æbsəlutli," zɛɹə sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, ðən ʃʌɾɝəd əz ði oʊθ tʊk hoʊld. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz taɪɾɝ ət ðə fɝst. "æsk mi əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ," ʃi dɪmændəd. hɝ hænz ʃʊk hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɑd. "æsk mi əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ!" hɝ ɪntɛnsəɾi toʊl sin ði ænsɝ ivən bɪfɔɹ pɛvɑɹə ɹilis ðə floʊ ʌv spɪɹəɾ ən æsk ðə kwɛstʃən, kəmændɪŋ ʌɾɝ tʃɹuθ. "noʊ!" zɛɹə pɹæktəkli ʃaʊɾəd. "noʊ, aɪm nɑt blæk ədʒɑ! naʊ teɪk ðɪs oʊθ fɹəm mi! fɹi mi!"

"I vow to obey the two of you absolutely," Zerah said in a tight voice, then shuddered as the oath took hold. It was always tighter at the first. "Ask me about the Black Ajah," she demanded. Her hands shook holding the Rod. "Ask me about the Black Ajah!" Her intensity told Seaine the answer even before Pevara released the flow of Spirit and asked the question, commanding utter truth. "No!" Zerah practically shouted. "No, I am not Black Ajah! Now take this oath from me! Free me!"

sin slʌmp dɪdʒɛktɪdli, ɹɛstɪŋ əɹ ɛlboʊz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ʃi sɝɾənli hæd nɑt wɑntəd zɛɹə tə ænsɝ jɛs, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hæd faʊn ði ʌðɝ wʊmən aʊɾ ɪn ə laɪ. wʌn laɪ faʊnd, əɹ soʊ ɪt hæd simd, æftɝ wiks ə sɝtʃɪŋ. haʊ mɛni mɔɹ wiks ə sɝtʃɪŋ leɪ əhɛd? ən ə lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ fɹəm weɪkɪŋ tə slipɪŋ? wən ʃi mænədʒ tə slip.

Seaine slumped dejectedly, resting her elbows on the table. She certainly had not wanted Zerah to answer yes, but she had been sure they had found the other woman out in a lie. One lie found, or so it had seemed, after weeks of searching. How many more weeks of searching lay ahead? And of looking over her shoulder from waking to sleeping? When she managed to sleep.

pɛvɑɹə stæbd ən əkjuzɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ ət ðə wʊmən. "ju toʊl pipəl ðət jə keɪm fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ."

Pevara stabbed an accusing finger at the woman. "You told people that you came from the north."

zɛɹəz aɪz wɛnt waɪɾ əɡɛn. "aɪ dɪd," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ ɹoʊd daʊn ðə bæŋk ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn tə wɑlh. naʊ fɹi mi ʌv ðɪs oʊθ!" ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps.

Zerah's eyes went wide again. "I did," she said slowly. "I rode down the bank of the Erinin to Jualdhe. Now free me of this oath!" She licked her lips.

sin fɹaʊn ət hɝ. "ɡoʊldɪnθɝn sidz ən ə ɹɛd kɑkəlbɝ wɝ faʊn ɑn jəɹ sæɾələklɔθ, zɛɹə. ɡoʊldɪnθɝn ən ɹɛd kɑkəlbɝ kæn bi faʊn fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz saʊθ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

Seaine frowned at her. "Goldenthorn seeds and a red cockleburr were found on your saddlecloth, Zerah. Goldenthorn and red cockleburr can't be found for a hundred miles south of Tar Valon."

zɛɹə lɛp tə hɝ fit, ən pɛvɑɹə snæpt, "sɪt daʊn!"

Zerah leaped to her feet, and Pevara snapped, "Sit down!"

ðə wʊmən dʒɹɑpt ɑntu ðə bɛntʃ wɪð ə laʊd smæk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən wɪns. ʃi wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. noʊ, ʃeɪkɪŋ. hɝ maʊθ wɑz klæmpt ʃʌt, ʌðɝwaɪz sin wɑz ʃʊɹ əɹ tiθ wʊɾə bɪn tʃæɾɝɪŋ. laɪt, ðə kwɛstʃən ə nɔɹθ əɹ saʊθ fɹaɪɾənd əɹ mɔɹ ðən ən ækjəzeɪʃən ə biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd.

The woman dropped onto the bench with a loud smack, but she did not even wince. She was trembling. No, shaking. Her mouth was clamped shut, otherwise Seaine was sure her teeth would have been chattering. Light, the question of north or south frightened her more than an accusation of being a Darkfriend.

"fɹʌm wɛɹ dɪd jə stɑɹɾ aʊt," sin æsk sloʊli, "ænd waɪ - ?" ʃi mɛn tə æsk waɪ ðə wʊmən hæd ɡɔn ɹaʊndəbaʊt - wɪtʃ pleɪnli ʃi hæd - dʒʌs tə haɪd wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən ʃi keɪm fɹʌm, bʌɾ ænsɝz bɝs fɹəm zɛɹəz maʊθ.

"From where did you start out," Seaine asked slowly, "and why - ?" She meant to ask why the woman had gone roundabout - which plainly she had - just to hide which direction she came from, but answers burst from Zerah's mouth.

"fɹʌm sɑlədɑɹ," ʃi skwild. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ wɝd fəɹ ɪt. stɪl klʌtʃɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑd, ʃi ɹɪθd ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ. tɪɹz spɪl fɹəm əɹ aɪz, aɪz əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ən fɪkst ɑn pɛvɑɹə. wɝdz pɔɹɾ aʊt, ðoʊ hɝ tiθ tʃɹuli dɪd tʃæɾɝ naʊ. "aɪ si-keɪm tə ɛm-meɪk ʃʊɹ ɔl ðə sɪstɝz hɪɹ noʊ əbaʊt ði ɑɹ-ɹɛdz ən lɑɡən, soʊ ðəl di-dɪpoʊz ɪleɪɾə ən ðə ti-taʊɝ kən bi hoʊl əɡɛn." wɪð ə weɪl ʃi kəlæpst ɪndə oʊpənməð bɔlɪŋ əz ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɹɛd sɪɾɝ.

"From Salidar," she squealed. There was no other word for it. Still clutching the Oath Rod, she writhed on her bench. Tears spilled from her eyes, eyes as wide as they would go and fixed on Pevara. Words poured out, though her teeth truly did chatter now. "I c-came to m-make sure all the sisters here know about the R-Reds and Logain, so they'll d-depose Elaida and the T-Tower can be whole again." With a wail she collapsed into openmouthed bawling as she stared at the Red Sitter.

"wɛl," pɛvɑɹə sɛd. ðən əɡɛn, mɔɹ ɡɹɪmli, "wɛl!" hɝ feɪs wɑz ɔl kəmpoʊʒɝ, bʌt ðə ɡlɪɾɝ ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə mɪstʃəf sin ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əz nɑvəs ən æksɛptɪd. "soʊ jə ɑɹ ðə sɔɹs ə ðət . . . ɹumɝ. jə ɑɹ gɑnə stæn bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ən ɹɪvil ɪt fəɹ ðə laɪ ɪɾ ɪz! ədmɪt ðə laɪ, ɡɝl!"

"Well," Pevara said. Then again, more grimly, "Well!" Her face was all composure, but the glitter in her dark eyes was far from the mischief Seaine remembered as novice and Accepted. "So you are the source of that . . . rumor. You are going to stand before the Hall and reveal it for the lie it is! Admit the lie, girl!"

ɪf zɛɹəz aɪz hæd bɪn waɪd bɪfɔɹ, ðeɪ bʌlʒd naʊ. ðə ɹɑd dʒɹɑp fɹəm əɹ hænz tə ɹoʊl əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəltɑp, ən ʃi klʌtʃt əɹ θɹoʊt. ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊn keɪm fɹəm əɹ sʌɾənli ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊθ. pɛvɑɹə stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ ɪn ʃɑk, bʌt sʌɾənli sin ʌndɝstʊd.

If Zerah's eyes had been wide before, they bulged now. The Rod dropped from her hands to roll across the tabletop, and she clutched her throat. A choking sound came from her suddenly gaping mouth. Pevara stared at her in shock, but suddenly Seaine understood.

"laɪts mɝsi," ʃi bɹiðd. "ju də nɑɾ əv tə laɪ, zɛɹə." zɛɹəz lɛɡz θɹæʃt bɪniθ ðə teɪbəl əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪz ən kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ əɹ fiɾ ʌndɝ hɝ. "tɛl hɝ, pɛvɑɹə. ʃi bɪlivz ɪts tʃɹu! juv kəmændəɾ əɹ tə spik ðə tʃɹuθ ən tə laɪ. doʊn lʊk ət mi ðət weɪ! ʃi bɪlivz!" ə bluɪʃ tɪnʒ əpɪɹɾ ɑn zɛɹəz lɪps. hɝ aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd. sin ɡæðɝd kɑm wɪð boʊθ hænz. "pɛvɑɹə, jə ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ soʊ əpɛɹənli jə mʌst ɹilis hɝ, əɹ ʃɪl sʌfəkeɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌs."

"Light's mercy," she breathed. "You do not have to lie, Zerah." Zerah's legs thrashed beneath the table as if she were trying to rise and could not get her feet under her. "Tell her, Pevara. She believes it's true! You've commanded her to speak the truth and to lie. Don't look at me that way! She believes!" A bluish tinge appeared on Zerah's lips. Her eyelids fluttered. Seaine gathered calm with both hands. "Pevara, you gave the order so apparently you must release her, or she will suffocate right in front of us."

"ʃiz ə ɹɛbəl." pɛvɑɹəz mʌɾɝ ɪnvɛstəd ðət wɝd wɪð ɔl ðə skɔɹn ɪt kəd hoʊld. bʌt ðən ʃi saɪd. "ʃi hæzən bɪn tʃɹaɪd, jɛt. jə doʊn əv tə . . . laɪ . . . ɡɝl." zɛɹə tɑpəl fɔɹwɝɾ ən leɪ wɪð əɹ tʃik pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə teɪbəltɑp, ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ bɪtwin wɪmpɝz.

"She's a rebel." Pevara's mutter invested that word with all the scorn it could hold. But then she sighed. "She hasn't been tried, yet. You don't have to . . . lie . . . girl." Zerah toppled forward and lay with her cheek pressed against the tabletop, gulping air between whimpers.

sin ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv kənflɪktɪŋ oʊðz. wʌɾ ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ dɪd nɑt mɪɹli ɹimuv ði oʊθ əɡɛns laɪɪŋ, bʌt ɹipleɪst ɪt wɪð wʌn ə ðɛɹ oʊn? wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɹipleɪst ɔl θɹi wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn oʊðz? ʃi ən pɛvɑɹə wəd nid tə ɡoʊ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli ɪf ðeɪ dɪd faɪn ə blæk sɪstɝ, əɹ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv əɹ fɔl dɛd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ nu wʌt ðə kɑnflɪkt wɑz. pɝhæps fɝst ə ɹɪnʌnsieɪʃən ʌv ɔl oʊðz - noʊ weɪ tə ɡoʊ əbaʊɾ ɪt mɔɹ kɛɹfəli wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt blæk sɪstɝz swɔɹ - fɑloʊd baɪ ɹəteɪkɪŋ ðə θɹi? laɪt, ðə peɪn ə biɪŋ lus fɹəm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ət wʌns wəd bi lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə biɪŋ pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən. meɪbi nɑt ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɪɾ əɾ ɔl. bʌt sɝɾənli ə dɑɹkfɹɛn dɪzɝv ðəɾ ən mɔɹ. ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ faʊnd wʌn.

Seaine shook her head in wonder. They had not considered the possibility of conflicting oaths. What if the Black Ajah did not merely remove the Oath against lying, but replaced it with one of their own? What if they replaced all Three with their own oaths? She and Pevara would need to go very carefully if they did find a Black sister, or they might have her fall dead before they knew what the conflict was. Perhaps first a renunciation of all oaths - no way to go about it more carefully without knowing what Black sisters swore - followed by retaking the Three? Light, the pain of being loosed from everything at once would be little short of being put to the question. Maybe not short of it at all. But certainly a Darkfriend deserved that and more. If they ever found one.

pɛvɑɹə ɡlɛɹd daʊn ət ðə ɡæspɪŋ wʊmən wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst tʌtʃ ə pɪɾi ɑn əɹ feɪs. "wɛn ʃi stænz tʃɹaɪəl fəɹ ɹɪbɛljən, aɪ ɪntɛn tə sɪɾ ɑn əɹ kɔɹt."

Pevara glared down at the gasping woman without the slightest touch of pity on her face. "When she stands trial for rebellion, I intend to sit on her court."

"wɛn ʃiz tʃɹaɪd, pɛvɑɹə," sin sɛd θɔtfəli. "ə pɪɾi tə luz ði əsɪstəns ʌv wʌn wi noʊ ɪzən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ən sɪns ʃiz ə ɹɛbəl, wi nid nɑt bi oʊvɝli kənsɝn əbaʊt juzɪŋ hɝ." ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə nʌmbɝ ə dɪskʌʃənz, nʌn tə ə kənkluʒən, əbaʊt ðə sɛkən ɹizən fəɹ livɪŋ ðə nu oʊθ ɪn pleɪs. ə sɪstɝ swɔɹn tə oʊbeɪ kəd bi kəmpɛld - sin ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli; ðət saʊndəɾ ɪntaɪɝli tu kloʊs tə ðə fɔɹbɪɾən vɪlnəs ə kəmpʌlʃən - ʃi kəd bi ɪndus tə hɛlp ɪn ðə hʌnt, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə dɪd nɑt maɪn fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ tə æksɛp ðə deɪnʒɝ, wɛðɝ ʃi wɪʃt tə əɹ nɑt. "aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd sɛn oʊnli wʌn," ʃi wɛn ɑn. "zɛɹə, haʊ mɛni ʌv jə keɪm tə spɹɛd ðɪs teɪl?"

"When she is tried, Pevara," Seaine said thoughtfully. "A pity to lose the assistance of one we know isn't a Darkfriend. And since she is a rebel, we need not be overly concerned about using her." There had been a number of discussions, none to a conclusion, about the second reason for leaving the new oath in place. A sister sworn to obey could be compelled - Seaine shifted uneasily; that sounded entirely too close to the forbidden vileness of Compulsion - she could be induced to help in the hunt, so long as you did not mind forcing her to accept the danger, whether she wished to or not. "I cannot think they would send only one," she went on. "Zerah, how many of you came to spread this tale?"

"tɛn," ðə wʊmən mʌmbəld əɡɛns ðə teɪbəltɑp, ðən dʒɝkt ɪɹɛkt, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɪn dɪfaɪəns. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bɪtʃɹeɪ maɪ sɪstɝz! aɪ woʊnt - !" əbɹʌpli ʃi kʌɾ ɔf, lɪps twɪstɪŋ bɪɾɝli əz ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd dʌn dʒʌs ðæt.

"Ten," the woman mumbled against the tabletop, then jerked erect, glaring in defiance. "I will not betray my sisters! I won't - !" Abruptly she cut off, lips twisting bitterly as she realized she had done just that.

"neɪmz!" pɛvɑɹə bɑɹkt. "ɡɪv mi ðɛɹ neɪmz, əɹ əl əv jəɹ haɪd hɪɹ ən naʊ!"

"Names!" Pevara barked. "Give me their names, or I will have your hide here and now!"

neɪmz spɪl fɹəm zɛɹəz ənwɪlɪŋ lɪps. ət ðə kəmænd, sɝɾənli, mɔɹ ðən ðə θɹɛt. lʊkɪŋ ət pɛvɑɹəz ɡɹɪm feɪs, ðoʊ, sin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi niɾəd lɪɾəl pɹɑvəkeɪʃən tə stʃɹaɪp zɛɹə laɪk ə nɑvəs kɑt stilɪŋ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi hɝsɛlf dɪd nɑt fil ðə seɪm ænəmɑsəɾi. ɹɪvʌlʃən, jɛs, bʌt klɪɹli nɑɾ əz stʃɹɔŋ. ðə wʊmən wɑz ə ɹɛbəl u hæd hɛlp bɹeɪk ðə waɪt taʊɝ wən ə sɪstɝ mʌst æksɛpt ɛniθɪŋ tə kip ðə taʊɝ hoʊl, ən jɛt. . . . vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ.

Names spilled from Zerah's unwilling lips. At the command, certainly, more than the threat. Looking at Pevara's grim face, though, Seaine was sure she needed little provocation to stripe Zerah like a novice caught stealing. Strangely, she herself did not feel the same animosity. Revulsion, yes, but clearly not as strong. The woman was a rebel who had helped break the White Tower when a sister must accept anything to keep the Tower whole, and yet. . . . Very strange.

"ju əɡɹi, pɛvɑɹə?" ʃi sɛd wən ðə lɪs kənkluɾəd. ðə stʌbɝn wʊmən ɡeɪv əɹ oʊnli ə fɪɹs nɑd fəɹ əɡɹimənt. "vɛɹi wɛl. zɛɹə, jəl bɹɪŋ bɝneɪl tə maɪ ɹumz ðɪs æftɝnun." ðəɹ wɝ tu fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ ɛksɛptɪŋ ðə blu ən ðə ɹɛd, ɪt simd, bʌt bɛs tə bɪɡɪn wɪð ði ʌðɝ waɪt. "ju wɪl seɪ oʊnli ðəɾ aɪ wɪʃ tə spik tə hɝ ɑn ə pɹaɪvət mæɾɝ. jəl ɡɪv əɹ noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ baɪ wɝd, did, əɹ oʊmɪʃən. ðən jəl stæn kwaɪətli ən lɛt pɛvɑɹə ən mi də wʌɾ ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi. jə ɑɹ biɪŋ ɹɪkɹuɾɪd ɪndə ə wɝðiɝ kɑz ðən jəɹ mɪsɡaɪɾɪd ɹɪbɛljən, zɛɹə." ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz mɪsɡaɪɾɪd. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mæd wɪð paʊɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd bɪkʌm. "ju ɑɹ gɑnə hɛlp əs hʌn daʊn ðə blæk ədʒɑ."

"You agree, Pevara?" she said when the list concluded. The stubborn woman gave her only a fierce nod for agreement. "Very well. Zerah, you will bring Bernaile to my rooms this afternoon." There were two from each Ajah excepting the Blue and the Red, it seemed, but best to begin with the other White. "You will say only that I wish to speak to her on a private matter. You will give her no warning by word, deed, or omission. Then you will stand quietly and let Pevara and me do what is necessary. You are being recruited into a worthier cause than your misguided rebellion, Zerah." Of course it was misguided. No matter how mad with power Elaida had become. "You are going to help us hunt down the Black Ajah."

zɛɹəz hɛd dʒɝkt ənwɪlɪŋ nɑdz əɾ itʃ ɪndʒʌŋkʃən, hɝ feɪs peɪnd, bʌɾ ət mɛnʃən ʌv ə hʌn fəɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ʃi ɡæspt. laɪt, hɝ wɪts mʌst əv bɪn toʊɾəli ənhɪnʒd baɪ hɝ ɪkspɪɹiənsɪz nɑt tə si ðæt!

Zerah's head jerked unwilling nods at each injunction, her face pained, but at mention of a hunt for the Black Ajah, she gasped. Light, her wits must have been totally unhinged by her experiences not to see that!

"æn jəl stɑp spɹɛɾɪŋ ðiz . . . stɔɹiz," pɛvɑɹə pʊɾ ɪn stɝnli. "fɹʌm ðɪs moʊmənt, jəl nɑt mɛnʃən ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ən fɔls dʒɹæɡənz təɡɛðɝ. æm aɪ ʌndɝstʊd?"

"And you will stop spreading these . . . stories," Pevara put in sternly. "From this moment, you'll not mention the Red Ajah and false Dragons together. Am I understood?"

zɛɹəz feɪs dɑn ə mæsk ə sʌlən stʌbɝnnəs. zɛɹəz maʊθ sɛd, "aɪ ʌndɝstænd, sɪɾɝ." ʃi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə bɪɡɪn wipɪŋ əɡɛn fɹəm ʃɪɹ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən.

Zerah's face donned a mask of sullen stubbornness. Zerah's mouth said, "I understand, Sitter." She looked ready to begin weeping again from sheer frustration.

"ðɛn ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt," pɛvɑɹə toʊl hɝ, ɹilisɪŋ ðə ʃild ən seɪaɪdɑɹ təɡɛðɝ. "æn kəmpoʊz jɝsɛlf! wɑʃ jəɹ feɪs ən stʃɹeɪɾən jəɹ hɛɹ!" ðət læst wɑz dɝɛktəɾ ət ðə bæk ə ðə wʊmən ɔlɹɛɾi dɑɹɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. zɛɹə hæd tə pʊl əɹ hænz əweɪ fɹəm əɹ hɛɹ tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. əz ðə dɔɹ skwikt ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ, pɛvɑɹə snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɪt pæst əɹ tə hæv ɡɔn tə ðɪs bɝneɪl laɪk ə sloʊvən, hoʊpɪŋ tə wɔɹn əɹ ðət weɪ."

"Then get out of my sight," Pevara told her, releasing the shield and saidar together. "And compose yourself! Wash your face and straighten your hair!" That last was directed at the back of the woman already darting from the table. Zerah had to pull her hands away from her hair to open the door. As the door squeaked shut behind her, Pevara snorted. "I wouldn't put it past her to have gone to this Bernaile like a sloven, hoping to warn her that way."

"ə væləd pɔɪnt," sin ədmɪɾəd. "bʌɾ u wɪl wi wɔɹn ɪf wi skaʊl ɹaɪɾ ən lɛft ət ðiz wɪmən? ət ðə vɛɹi list, wɪl ətʃɹæk noʊɾəs."

"A valid point," Seaine admitted. "But who will we warn if we scowl right and left at these women? At the very least, we will attract notice."

"ðə weɪ mæɾɝz ɑɹ, sin, wi wʊdn ətʃɹæk noʊɾəs kɪkɪŋ əm əkɹɔs ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz." pɛvɑɹə saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðət wɝ ən ətʃɹæktɪv noʊʃən. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹəbɛlz, ən aɪ ɪntɛn tə hoʊld əm soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ skwik ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm soʊ mʌtʃ əz əz ə ɹɔŋ θɔt!"

"The way matters are, Seaine, we wouldn't attract notice kicking them across the Tower grounds." Pevara sounded as if that were an attractive notion. "They are rebels, and I intend to hold them so hard they squeak if one of them so much as has a wrong thought!"

ðeɪ wɛn ɹaʊn ən ɹaʊn əbaʊt ðæt. sin ɪnsɪstəd ðət kɛɹ ɪn ði ɔɹɾɝz ðeɪ ɡeɪv, livɪŋ noʊ luphoʊlz, wəd bi səfɪʃənt. pɛvɑɹə pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət ðeɪ wɝ lɛɾɪŋ tɛn ɹɛbəlz - tɛn! - wɔk ðə taʊɝz hɔlz ənpʌnɪʃt. sin sɛd ðeɪ wəd feɪs pʌnɪʃmən ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən pɛvɑɹə ɡɹaʊl ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli wɑz nɑt sun ɪnʌf. sin hæɾ ɔlweɪz ədmaɪɝd ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌv wɪl, bʌt ɹɪli, səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz pjʊɹ stʌbɝnnəs.

They went round and round about that. Seaine insisted that care in the orders they gave, leaving no loopholes, would be sufficient. Pevara pointed out that they were letting ten rebels - ten! - walk the Tower's halls unpunished. Seaine said they would face punishment eventually, and Pevara growled that eventually was not soon enough. Seaine had always admired the other woman's strength of will, but really, sometimes it was pure stubbornness.

ə feɪn kɹik fɹəm ə hɪnʒ wɑz ɔl ðə wɔɹnɪŋ sin hæd tə snætʃ ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɪndə hɝ læp, haɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn foʊlz ə hɝ skɝɾ əz ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd waɪd. ʃi ən pɛvɑɹə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ɔlmoʊst əz wʌn.

A faint creak from a hinge was all the warning Seaine had to snatch the Oath Rod into her lap, hiding it in folds of her skirt as the door opened wide. She and Pevara embraced the Source almost as one.

sɹɪn wɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum kɑmli, hoʊldɪŋ ə læntɝn, ən stʊɾ əsaɪd fəɹ tælin, hu wɑz fɑloʊd baɪ taɪni jukɪɝi, wɪð ə sɛkən laɪt, ən bɔɪɪʃli slɪm dʌsin, tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, hu kloʊz ðə dɔɹ kwaɪt fɝmli ən sɛɾəld əɹ bæk əɡɛnst ɪɾ əz ɪf tə kip ɛniwʌn fɹəm livɪŋ. fɔɹ sɪɾɝz, ɹɛpɹɪzɛntɪŋ ɔl ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ədʒəz ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ðeɪ sim tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə fæk ðət sin ən pɛvɑɹə hɛl seɪaɪdɑɹ. sʌɾənli, tə sin, ðə ɹum fɛlt ɹæðɝ kɹaʊɾəd. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, ən ɪɹæʃənəl, bʌt . . .

Saerin walked into the room calmly, holding a lantern, and stood aside for Talene, who was followed by tiny Yukiri, with a second light, and boyishly slim Doesine, tall for a Cairhienin, who closed the door quite firmly and settled her back against it as if to keep anyone from leaving. Four Sitters, representing all the remaining Ajahs in the Tower. They seemed to ignore the fact that Seaine and Pevara held saidar. Suddenly, to Seaine, the room felt rather crowded. Imagination, and irrational, but . . .

"stʃɹeɪnʒ tə si ðə pɛɹ ə jə təɡɛðɝ," sɹɪn sɛd. hɝ feɪs maɪt bi sɝin, bʌt ʃi slɪd fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ðə hɪlt ə ðət kɝv naɪf bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt. ʃi hæd hɛld əɹ tʃɛɹ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz, lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə hɔl, ən ɛvɹiwʌn hæd lɝn tə bi kɛɹfəl ə hɝ tɛmpɝ.

"Strange to see the pair of you together," Saerin said. Her face might be serene, but she slid fingers along the hilt of that curved knife behind her belt. She had held her chair forty years, longer than anyone else in the Hall, and everyone had learned to be careful of her temper.

"wi maɪt seɪ ðə seɪm ə ju," pɛvɑɹə ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. sɹɪnz tɛmpɝ nɛvɝ əpsɛt hɝ. "ɔɹ dɪd jə kʌm daʊn hɪɹ tə hɛlp dʌsin tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛt səm ə hɝ oʊn bæk?" ə sʌɾən flʌʃ meɪd ðə jɛloʊz feɪs lʊk ivən mɔɹ ðəɾ ʌv ə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɛləɡən bɛɹɪŋ, ən toʊl sin wɪtʃ sɪɾɝ hæd stʃɹeɪd tu nɪɹ ðə ɹɛd kɔɹɾɝz wɪð ənfɔɹtʃənət ɹɪzʌls. "aɪ wʊdn əv θɔt ðət wəd bɹɪŋ jə təɡɛðɝ, ðoʊ. ɡɹinz ət jɛloʊz' θɹoʊts, bɹaʊnz ət ɡɹeɪz'. əɹ dɪd jə dʒʌs bɹɪŋ əm daʊn fəɹ ə kwaɪət duəl, sɹɪn?"

"We might say the same of you," Pevara replied dryly. Saerin's temper never upset her. "Or did you come down here to help Doesine try to get some of her own back?" A sudden flush made the Yellow's face look even more that of a pretty boy despite her elegant bearing, and told Seaine which Sitter had strayed too near the Red quarters with unfortunate results. "I wouldn't have thought that would bring you together, though. Greens at Yellows' throats, Browns at Grays'. Or did you just bring them down for a quiet duel, Saerin?"

fɹæntəkəli, sin kæst ɝaʊn fəɹ wʌt ɹizən wəɾ əv ðiz fɔɹ ðɪs dip ɪndə ðə bɛdʒɹɑk ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wʌt kəd taɪ ðɛm təɡɛðɝ? ðɛɹ ədʒəz - ɔl ə ði ədʒəz - tʃɹuli wɝ ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts. ɔl fɔɹ hæd bɪn hændəd pɛnənsɪz baɪ ɪleɪɾə. noʊ sɪɾɝ kəɾ ɛndʒɔɪ leɪbɝ, ɪspɛʃli wən ɛvɹiwʌn nu ɪɡzækli waɪ ʃi wɑz skɹʌbɪŋ flɔɹz əɹ pɑts, jɛt ðət wɑz hɑɹdli ə bɑnd. wʌɾ ɛls? nʌn wɝ nɑbli bɔɹn. sɹɪn ən jukɪɝi wɝ ðə dɔɾɝz ʌv ɪnkipɝz, tælin ə fɑɹmɝz, waɪl dʌsinz fɑðɝ hæd bɪn ə kʌtlɝ. sɹɪn hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪn fɝs baɪ ðə dɔɾɝz ə saɪləns, ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðət lɑt tə ɹitʃ ðə ʃɔl. æbsəlutli jusləs dʒɹɪvəl. sʌɾənli, sʌmθɪŋ dɪd stʃɹaɪk hɝ, ən dʒɹaɪɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. sɹɪn wɪð əɹ tɛmpɝ ɔfən bɛɹli ɪn ɹeɪn. dʌsin, hu hæɾ æktʃəli  ɹʌn əweɪ θɹi taɪmz əz ə nɑvəs, ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ oʊnli wʌns meɪɾ ɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðə bɹɪdʒəz. tælin, hu maɪɾ əv ɝn mɔɹ pʌnɪʃməns ðən ɛni ʌðɝ nɑvəs ɪn ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə taʊɝ. jukɪɝi, ɔlweɪz ðə læst ɡɹeɪ tə dʒɔɪn əɹ sɪstɝz' kənsɛnsəs wən ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ, ðə læs tə dʒɔɪn ðə hɔlz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɔl fɔɹ wɝ kənsɪɾɝd ɹɛbəlz, ɪn ə weɪ, ən ɪleɪɾə hæd hjumɪlieɪɾɪd ɛvɹi wʌn. kəd ðeɪ bi θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk, stændɪŋ tə dɪpoʊz sɪuən ən ɹeɪz ɪleɪɾə? ðeɪv hæv faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊt zɛɹə ən ði ʌðɝz? ən ɪf wʌd dɪd ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə du?

Frantically, Seaine cast around for what reason would have these four this deep into the bedrock of Tar Valon. What could tie them together? Their Ajahs - all of the Ajahs - truly were at one another's throats. All four had been handed penances by Elaida. No Sitter could enjoy Labor, especially when everyone knew exactly why she was scrubbing floors or pots, yet that was hardly a bond. What else? None were nobly born. Saerin and Yukiri were the daughters of innkeepers, Talene of farmers, while Doesine's father had been a cutler. Saerin had been trained first by the Daughters of Silence, the only one of that lot to reach the shawl. Absolutely useless drivel. Suddenly, something did strike her, and dried her throat. Saerin with her temper often barely in rein. Doesine, who had actually run away three times as a novice, though she had only once made it as far as the bridges. Talene, who might have earned more punishments than any other novice in the history of the Tower. Yukiri, always the last Gray to join her sisters' consensus when she wanted to go another way, the last to join the Hall's, for that matter. All four were considered rebels, in a way, and Elaida had humiliated every one. Could they be thinking they had made a mistake, standing to depose Siuan and raise Elaida? Could they have found out about Zerah and the others? And if so, what did they intend to do?

mɛntəli, sin pɹipɛɹd hɝsɛlf tə wiv seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðoʊ wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ hoʊp ðət ʃi kəɾ ɪskeɪp. pɛvɑɹə mætʃt sɹɪn ən jukɪɝi ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ, bʌt ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz wikɝ ðən ɛni hɪɹ seɪv dʌsin. ʃi pɹipɛɹd hɝsɛlf, ən tælin stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən bɝst ɔl ə hɝ lɑdʒɪkəl dɪdʌkʃənz tə flɪndɝz.

Mentally, Seaine prepared herself to weave saidar, though without much hope that she could escape. Pevara matched Saerin and Yukiri in strength, but she herself was weaker than any here save Doesine. She prepared herself, and Talene stepped forward and burst all of her logical deductions to flinders.

"jukɪɝi noʊɾəst jə tu snikɪŋ əbaʊt təɡɛðɝ, ən wi wɑnə noʊ waɪ." hɝ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dip vɔɪs hɛl hit dɪspaɪt ði aɪs ðət sim tə koʊɾ əɹ feɪs. "dɪd ðə hɛdz ə jəɹ ədʒəz sɛt jə ə sikɹət tæsk? ɪn pʌblɪk, ði ədʒəz' hɛdz snɑɹl ət wʌn ənʌðɝ wɝs ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls, bʌt ðeɪv bɪn snikɪŋ ɔf ɪndə kɔɹnɝz tə tɔk, ɪt simz. wʌtɛvɝ ðəɹ skimɪŋ, ðə hɔl əz ə ɹaɪt tə noʊ."

"Yukiri noticed you two sneaking about together, and we want to know why." Her surprisingly deep voice held heat despite the ice that seemed to coat her face. "Did the heads of your Ajahs set you a secret task? In public, the Ajahs' heads snarl at one another worse than anyone else, but they've been sneaking off into corners to talk, it seems. Whatever they're scheming, the Hall has a right to know."

"oʊ, də ɡɪv oʊvɝ, tælin." jukɪɝiz vɔɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz ən ivən bɪɡɝ sɝpɹaɪz ðən tælinz. ðə wʊmən lʊkt ə mɪniətʃʊɹ kwin, ɪn dɑɹk sɪlvɝ sɪlk wɪð aɪvɝi leɪs, bʌt ʃi saʊndəɾ ə kʌmftəɹbəl kʌntʃɹi wʊmən. ʃi kleɪm ðə kɑntʃɹæs hɛlpt ɪn nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ʃi smaɪld ət sin ən pɛvɑɹə, ə mɑnɑɹk pɝhæps ənʃʊɹ haʊ ɡɹeɪʃəs ʃi ʃəd bi. "aɪ sɔ ðə pɛɹ ə jə snɪfɪŋ əbaʊt laɪk fɛɹəts ət ðə hɛnkup," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ hɛl maɪ tʌŋ - jə maɪt bi pɪloʊ fɹɛnz, fəɹ ɔl aɪ noʊ, ən huz bɪznəs ɪz ðət bʌt jʊɹz? - aɪ hɛl maɪ tʌŋ tɪl tælin hɪɹ stɑɹɾəd jɛlpɪŋ əbaʊt huz bɪn hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn kɔɹnɝz. aɪv sin ə bɪɾ ə hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn kɔɹnɝz maɪsɛlf, ən aɪ səspɛk səm ə ðoʊz wɪmən maɪt hɛd ðɛɹ ədʒəz əz wɛl, soʊ. . . . səmtaɪmz sɪks ən sɪks meɪk ə dʌzən, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪ meɪk ə mɛs. tɛl əs ɪf jə kæn, naʊ. ðə hɔl dʌz əv ə ɹaɪt."

"Oh, do give over, Talene." Yukiri's voice was always an even bigger surprise than Talene's. The woman looked a miniature queen, in dark silver silk with ivory lace, but she sounded a comfortable country woman. She claimed the contrast helped in negotiations. She smiled at Seaine and Pevara, a monarch perhaps unsure how gracious she should be. "I saw the pair of you sniffing about like ferrets at the hencoop," she said, "but I held my tongue - you might be pillow friends, for all I know, and whose business is that but yours? - I held my tongue till Talene here started yelping about who's been huddling in corners. I've seen a bit of huddling in corners myself, and I suspect some of those women might head their Ajahs as well, so. . . . Sometimes six and six make a dozen, and sometimes they make a mess. Tell us if you can, now. The Hall does have a right."

"wi ɑɹ nɑt livɪŋ əntɪl jə də tɛl," tælin pʊɾ ɪn ivən mɔɹ hiɾɪdli ðən bɪfɔɹ.

"We are not leaving until you do tell," Talene put in even more heatedly than before.

pɛvɑɹə snɔɹɾɪd ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz. "ɪf ðə hɛɾ ə maɪ ədʒɑ spoʊk tu wɝdz tə mi, aɪd si noʊ ɹizən tə tɛl jə wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. əz ɪt hæpənz, wʌt sin ən aɪ wɝ dɪskʌsɪŋ əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə ɹɛɾ əɹ ðə waɪt. snup ɛlswɛɹ." bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilis seɪaɪdɑɹ. niðɝ dɪd sin.

Pevara snorted and folded her arms. "If the head of my Ajah spoke two words to me, I'd see no reason to tell you what they were. As it happens, what Seaine and I were discussing has nothing to do with the Red or the White. Snoop elsewhere." But she did not release saidar. Neither did Seaine.

"blʌɾi jusləs ən aɪ blʌɾi nu ɪt," dʌsin mʌɾɝd fɹəm əɹ pleɪs baɪ ðə dɔɹ. "waɪ aɪ ɛvɝ fleɪmɪŋ lɛt jə tɔk mi ɪndə ðɪs. . . . dʒʌst əz blʌɾi wɛl noʊbɑdi ɛls noʊz, əɹ wiɾ əv ʃipswæləp ɔl oʊvɝ feɪsəz fəɹ ðə hoʊl blʌɾi taʊɝ tə si." ət taɪmz ʃi hæɾ ə tʌŋ laɪk ə bɔɪ, tu, ə bɔɪ hu niɾəd ɪz maʊθ wɑʃt aʊt.

"Bloody useless and I bloody knew it," Doesine muttered from her place by the door. "Why I ever flaming let you talk me into this. . . . Just as bloody well nobody else knows, or we'd have sheepswallop all over faces for the whole bloody Tower to see." At times she had a tongue like a boy, too, a boy who needed his mouth washed out.

sin wʊɾə stʊd tə liv ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt fɪɹɾ əɹ niz wəd bɪtʃɹeɪ hɝ. pɛvɑɹə dɪd stænd, ən ɹeɪzd ən ɪmpeɪʃən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə wɪmən bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə dɔɹ.

Seaine would have stood to leave if she had not feared her knees would betray her. Pevara did stand, and raised an impatient eyebrow at the women between her and the door.

sɹɪn fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ naɪf hɪlt ən aɪɾ əm kwɪtsɪkli, nɑt ʃɪftɪŋ ə stɛp. "ə pʌzəl," ʃi mɝmɝd. sʌɾənli ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd fɔɹwɝd, hɝ fɹi hæn dɪpɪŋ ɪndə sinz læp soʊ kwɪkli ðət sin ɡæspt. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kip ði oʊθ ɹɑd hɪɾən, bʌt ði oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ðət ʃi ɛndəd wɪð sɹɪn hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɑd weɪs haɪ wɪð wʌn hænd waɪl ʃi hɛl ði ʌðɝ ɛn ən ə fɪsfəl ə hɝ skɝts. "aɪ ɛndʒɔɪ pʌzəlz," sɹɪn sɛd.

Saerin fingered her knife hilt and eyed them quizzically, not shifting a step. "A puzzle," she murmured. Suddenly she glided forward, her free hand dipping into Seaine's lap so quickly that Seaine gasped. She tried to keep the Oath Rod hidden, but the only result was that she ended with Saerin holding the Rod waist high with one hand while she held the other end and a fistful of her skirts. "I enjoy puzzles," Saerin said.

sin lɛt ɡoʊ ən ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs; ðəɹ sim nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə du.

Seaine let go and adjusted her dress; there seemed nothing else to do.

ði əpɪɹəns ə ðə ɹɑd pɹədust ə moʊməntɛɹi bæbəl əz nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn spoʊk ət wʌns.

The appearance of the Rod produced a momentary babble as nearly everyone spoke at once.

"blʌɾ ən faɪɝ," dʌsin ɡɹaʊld. "ɑɹ jə daʊn hɪɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ nu blʌɾi sɪstɝz?"

"Blood and fire," Doesine growled. "Are you down here raising new bloody sisters?"

"oʊ, liv ɪt wɪð ðɛm, sɹɪn," jukɪɝi læft ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə hɝ. "wʌtɛvɝ ðəɹ ʌp tə, ɪts ðɛɹ oʊn bɪznəs."

"Oh, leave it with them, Saerin," Yukiri laughed right on top of her. "Whatever they're up to, it's their own business."

ətɑp boʊθ, tælin bɑɹkt, "waɪ ɛls ɑɹ ðeɪ snikɪŋ əbaʊt - təɡɛðɝ! - ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən tə də wɪð ði ədʒɑ hɛdz?"

Atop both, Talene barked, "Why else are they sneaking about - together! - if it isn't to do with the Ajah heads?"

sɹɪn weɪvd ə hænd, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt ɡeɪn kwaɪət. ɔl pɹɛzənt wɝ sɪɾɝz, bʌt ʃi hæd ðə ɹaɪt tə spik fɝst ɪn ðə hɔl, ən əɹ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz kaʊntəd fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, tu. "ðɪs ɪz ðə ki tə ðə pʌzəl, aɪ θɪŋk," ʃi sɛd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə ɹɑd wɪð əɹ θʌm. "waɪ ðɪs, æftɝ ɔl?" əbɹʌpli ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd hɝ, tu, ən ʃi tʃænəl spɪɹət tə ðə ɹɑd. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, əl spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. aɪm nɑɾ ə dɑɹk-fɹɛnd."

Saerin waved a hand, and after a moment gained quiet. All present were Sitters, but she had the right to speak first in the Hall, and her forty years counted for something, too. "This is the key to the puzzle, I think," she said, stroking the Rod with her thumb. "Why this, after all?" Abruptly the glow of saidar surrounded her, too, and she channeled Spirit to the Rod. "Under the Light, I will speak no word that is not true. I am not a Dark-friend."

ɪn ðə saɪləns ðət fɑloʊd, ə maʊs snizɪŋ wʊɾə saʊndəd laʊd.

In the silence that followed, a mouse sneezing would have sounded loud.

"æm aɪ ɹaɪt?" sɹɪn sɛd, ɹilisɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ʃi hɛl ðə ɹɑɾ aʊt təwɔɹd sin.

"Am I right?" Saerin said, releasing the Power. She held the Rod out toward Seaine.

fəɹ ðə θɝd taɪm, sin ɹitʊk ði oʊθ əɡɛns laɪɪŋ, ən fəɹ ðə sɛkən taɪm ɹɪpiɾɪd ðət ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə blæk. pɛvɑɹə dɪd ðə seɪm wɪð fɹoʊzən dɪɡnəɾi. ən aɪz ʃɑɹp əz ən iɡəlz.

For the third time, Seaine retook the Oath against lying, and for the second time repeated that she was not of the Black. Pevara did the same with frozen dignity. And eyes sharp as an eagle's.

"ðɪs ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs," tælin sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ blæk ədʒɑ."

"This is ridiculous," Talene said. "There is no Black Ajah."

jukɪɝi tʊk ðə ɹɑd fɹəm pɛvɑɹə ən tʃænəld. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, əl spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu. aɪm nɑt blæk ədʒɑ." ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɝaʊn əɹ wɪŋkt aʊt, ən ʃi hændəd ðə ɹɑd tə dʌsin.

Yukiri took the Rod from Pevara and channeled. "Under the Light, I will speak no word that is not true. I am not Black Ajah." The light of saidar around her winked out, and she handed the Rod to Doesine.

tælin fɹaʊn ɪn dɪsɡʌst. "stæn əsaɪd, dʌsin. aɪ fəɹ wʌn wɪl nɑt pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðɪs fɪlθi sədʒɛstʃən."

Talene frowned in disgust. "Stand aside, Doesine. I for one will not put up with this filthy suggestion."

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, əl spik noʊ wɝd ðəɾ ɪz nɑt tʃɹu," dʌsin sɛɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɛvɝənli, ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn əɹ laɪk ə heɪloʊ. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ." wən mæɾɝz wɝ sɪɹiəs, hɝ tʌŋ wɑz əz klin əz ɛni mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz kəɾ əv wɪʃt. ʃi ɪkstɛndəd ðə ɹɑd tə tælin.

"Under the Light, I will speak no word that is not true," Doesine said almost reverently, the glow around her like a halo. "I am not of the Black Ajah." When matters were serious, her tongue was as clean as any Mistress of Novices could have wished. She extended the Rod to Talene.

ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən stɑɹɾəd bæk əz fɹəm ə pɔɪzənəs sneɪk. "ivən tə æsk ðɪs ɪz ə slændɝ. wɝs ðən slændɝ!" sʌmθɪŋ fɛɹəl muvd ɪn əɹ aɪz. ən ɪɹæʃənəl θɔt, pɝhæps, bʌt ðət wɑz wʌt sin sɔ. "naʊ muv aʊɾ ə maɪ weɪ," tælin dɪmændəd wɪð ɔl ði əθɔɹəɾi ʌv ə sɪɾɝ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ æm livɪŋ!"

The golden-haired woman started back as from a poisonous snake. "Even to ask this is a slander. Worse than slander!" Something feral moved in her eyes. An irrational thought, perhaps, but that was what Seaine saw. "Now move out of my way," Talene demanded with all the authority of a Sitter in her voice. "I am leaving!"

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt," pɛvɑɹə sɛd kwaɪətli, ən jukɪɝi nɑɾəd sloʊli ɪn əɡɹimənt. sɹɪn dɪd nɑt stʃɹoʊk əɹ naɪf hɪlt; ʃi ɡɹɪpt ɪt tɪl əɹ nʌkəlz wɛnt waɪt.

"I think not," Pevara said quietly, and Yukiri nodded slowly in agreement. Saerin did not stroke her knife hilt; she gripped it till her knuckles went white.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə dip snoʊz ʌv ændɝ, flaʊndɝɪŋ θɹu ðɛm, tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl kɝs ðə deɪ ʃi wɑz bɔɹn. ʃɔɹɾ ən slaɪtli plʌmp, wɪð smuð kɑpɝ skɪn ən lɔŋ ɡlɔsi dɑɹk hɛɹ, ʃi hæd sim pɹɪɾi tə mɛni oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, bʌt nʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ kɔld əɹ bjuɾəfəl. sɝɾənli nʌn wəd naʊ. ðə dɑɹk aɪz ðət hæd wʌns bɪn dɝɛk naʊ bɔɹɾ ɪndə wʌtɛvɝ ʃi lʊkt æt. ðət wɑz wən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æŋɡɹi. ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi tədeɪ. wən tʌvaɪn wɑz æŋɡɹi, sɝpəns flɛd.

Riding through the deep snows of Andor, floundering through them, Toveine Gazal cursed the day she was born. Short and slightly plump, with smooth copper skin and long glossy dark hair, she had seemed pretty to many over the years, but none had ever called her beautiful. Certainly none would now. The dark eyes that had once been direct now bored into whatever she looked at. That was when she was not angry. She was angry today. When Toveine was angry, serpents fled.

fɔɹ ʌðɝ ɹɛdz ɹoʊd - flaʊndɝd - əɾ əɹ bæk, ən bɪhaɪn əm twɛnti ʌv ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹɾ ɪn dɑɹk koʊts ən kloʊks. nʌn ə ðə mɛn laɪkt ɪt ðət ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ wɑz stoʊɾ əweɪ ɑn ðə pækhɔɹsɪz, ən ðeɪ wɑtʃt ðə fɔɹəs laɪnɪŋ boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə ɹoʊɾ əz ðoʊ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ətæk ɛni moʊmənt. haʊ ðeɪ θɔt tə kɹɔs θɹi hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ʌv ændɝ ənnoʊɾɪst, wɛɹɪŋ koʊts ən kloʊks wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ʃaɪnɪŋ bɹaɪɾ ɑn ðɛm, tʌvaɪn kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən. ðə dʒɝni wɑz ɔlmoʊs dʌn, ðoʊ. ɪn ənʌðɝ deɪ, pɝhæps tu wɪð ɹoʊdz ni-dip ɪn snoʊ ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz, ʃi wəd dʒɔɪn wɪð naɪn ʌðɝ pɑɹɾiz ɪɡzækli laɪk hɝz. nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn əm wɝ ɹɛd, ənfɔɹtʃənətli, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌbəl əɹ oʊvɝmək. tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl, wʌns ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə ɹɛd, wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə hɪstɝiz əz ðə wʊmən u dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðɪs blæk taʊɝ.

Four other Reds rode - floundered - at her back, and behind them twenty of the Tower Guard in dark coats and cloaks. None of the men liked it that their armor was stowed away on the packhorses, and they watched the forest lining both sides of the road as though expecting attack any moment. How they thought to cross three hundred miles of Andor unnoticed, wearing coats and cloaks with the Flame of Tar Valon shining bright on them, Toveine could not imagine. The journey was almost done, though. In another day, perhaps two with roads knee-deep in snow on the horses, she would join with nine other parties exactly like hers. Not all of the sisters in them were Red, unfortunately, but that did not trouble her overmuch. Toveine Gazal, once a Sitter for the Red, would go into the histories as the woman who destroyed this Black Tower.

ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪleɪɾə θɔɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə tʃæns, kɔl bæk fɹəm ɛɡzaɪl ən dɪsɡɹeɪs, ɡɪvən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ ɹɪdɛmpʃən. ʃi snɪɹd, ən ɪf ə wʊlf hæd bɪn lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðə dip hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk, ɪt maɪɾ əv kweɪld. wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, ən ðə laɪt bɝn ɔl ðoʊz u mʌɾɝd ðət ðə blæk ədʒɑ mʌst əv bɪn ɪnvɑlvd. ɪt hæd bɪn nɛsəsɛɹi ən ɹaɪt, bʌt tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl hæd bɪn dʒɹɪvən fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə hɔl, ən fɔɹs tə haʊl fəɹ mɝsi ʌndɝ ðə bɝtʃ, wɪð ði əsɛmbəl sɪstɝz wɑtʃɪŋ, ən ivən nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd wɪtnəsɪŋ ðət sɪɾɝz, tu, leɪ bɪniθ ðə lɔ, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt toʊld wʌt lɔ. ən ðən ʃi hæd bɪn sɛn tə wɝk ðiz læs twɛnti jɪɹz ɑn ði aɪsəleɪɾəd blæk hɪlz fɑɹm ə mɪstʃɹəs dʒɑɹə daʊil, ə wʊmən u kənsɪɾɝd ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝvɪŋ pɛnəns ɪn ɛɡzaɪl noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ hæn leɪbɝɪŋ ɪn sʌn ən snoʊ. tʌvaɪnz hænz ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz; ʃi kəd fil ðə kælʌsɪz. mɪstʃɹəs daʊil - ivən naʊ, ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ə ðə wʊmən wɪθaʊt ði ɑnɝɪfɪk ʃi hæd dɪmændəd - mɪstʃɹəs daʊil bɪlivd ɪn hɑɹd wɝk. ən dɪsəplən əz taɪɾ əz ɛni nɑvəs feɪst! ʃi hæd noʊ mɝsi ɑn ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə ʃɝk ðə bækbɹeɪkɪŋ leɪbɝ ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf ʃɛɹd, ən lɛs ðən nʌn fəɹ ə wʊmən u snikt əweɪ tə kʌmfɝt hɝsɛlf wɪð ə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ. ðət hæd bɪn tʌvaɪnz laɪf fəɹ fɪftin jɪɹz. ən ɪleɪɾə hæd slɪp θɹu ðə kɹæks ənkɔt, dænst əɹ weɪ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ðət tʌvaɪn hæd wʌns dʒɹimd ə fəɹ hɝsɛlf. noʊ, ʃi wɑz nɑt ɡɹeɪtfəl. bʌt ʃi hæd lɝn tə weɪɾ əɹ tʃæns.

She was sure Elaida thought her grateful for the chance, called back from exile and disgrace, given the opportunity for redemption. She sneered, and if a wolf had been looking into the deep hood of her cloak, it might have quailed. What had been done twenty years ago was necessary, and the Light burn all those who muttered that the Black Ajah must have been involved. It had been necessary and right, but Toveine Gazal had been driven from her chair in the Hall, and forced to howl for mercy under the birch, with the assembled sisters watching, and even novices and Accepted witnessing that Sitters, too, lay beneath the law, though they were not told what law. And then she had been sent to work these last twenty years on the isolated Black Hills farm of Mistress Jara Doweel, a woman who considered an Aes Sedai serving penance in exile no different from any other hand laboring in sun and snow. Toveine's hands shifted on her reins; she could feel the calluses. Mistress Doweel - even now, she could not think of the woman without the honorific she had demanded - Mistress Doweel believed in hard work. And discipline as tight as any novice faced! She had no mercy on anyone who tried to shirk the backbreaking labor that she herself shared, and less than none for a woman who sneaked away to comfort herself with a pretty boy. That had been Toveine's life for fifteen years. And Elaida had slipped through the cracks uncaught, danced her way to the Amyrlin Seat that Toveine had once dreamed of for herself. No, she was not grateful. But she had learned to wait her chance.

əbɹʌpli, ə tɔl mæn ɪn ə blæk koʊt, dɑɹk hɛɹ fɔlɪŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, spɝɾ ɪz hɔɹs aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst ɪndə ðə ɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ, spɹeɪɪŋ snoʊ. "ðɛɹz noʊ pɔɪn stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ," hi ənaʊns fɝmli, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə ɡlʌv hænd. "sɝɛndɝ pisfəli, ən noʊ wʌn wɪl bi hɝt."

Abruptly, a tall man in a black coat, dark hair falling to his shoulders, spurred his horse out of the forest into the road ahead of her, spraying snow. "There's no point struggling," he announced firmly, raising a gloved hand. "Surrender peacefully, and no one will be hurt."

ɪt wɑz niðɝ ɪz əpɪɹəns nɔɹ ɪz wɝdz ðət meɪd tʌvaɪn ɹeɪn ʌp ʃɔɹt, lɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɡæðɝ bɪsaɪd hɝ. "teɪk hɪm," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "ju hæd bɛɾɝ lɪŋk. hiz mi ʃildɪd." ɪt simd wʌn ə ðiz æʃəmən hæd kʌm tə hɝ. haʊ kənvinjən ə hɪm.

It was neither his appearance nor his words that made Toveine rein up short, letting the other sisters gather beside her. "Take him," she said calmly. "You had better link. He has me shielded." It seemed one of these Asha'man had come to her. How convenient of him.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət nʌθɪŋ wɑz hæpənɪŋ ən tʊk əɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə fɛloʊ tə fɹaʊn ət dʒɛnɛɹ. ðə wʊmənz peɪl, skwɛɹ feɪs simd æbsəlutli blʌdləs. "tʌvaɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli, "aɪ ɔlsoʊ æm ʃildɪd."

Abruptly she realized that nothing was happening and took her eyes from the fellow to frown at Jenare. The woman's pale, square face seemed absolutely bloodless. "Toveine," she said unsteadily, "I also am shielded."

"aɪ æm ʃildɪd, tu," ləməaɪ bɹiðd ɪn dɪsbɪlif, ən ði ʌðɝz tʃaɪmd ɪn, ɪnkɹisɪŋli fɹæntɪk. ɔl ʃildɪd.

"I am shielded, too," Lemai breathed in disbelief, and the others chimed in, increasingly frantic. All shielded.

mɔɹ mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts əpɪɹd fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz stɛpɪŋ sloʊli, ɔl ɝaʊnd. tʌvaɪn stɑp kaʊntɪŋ ət fɪftin. ðə ɡɑɹdz mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli, weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə sɪstɝz kəmænd. ðeɪ nu nʌθɪŋ jɛɾ ɪksɛp ðəɾ ə bæn ə ɹoʊɡz hæd weɪleɪd ðɛm. tʌvaɪn klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. ðiz mɛn kəd nɑɾ ɔl tʃænəl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ɛvɹi æʃəmən u kəd də soʊ hæd kʌm əɡɛns hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt pænɪk. ənlaɪk səm ə ðə sɪstɝz wɪð hɝ, ðiz wɝ nɑt ðə fɝs mɛn u tʃænəl ðət ʃi hæd kənfɹʌntəd. ðə tɔl mæn bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ, smaɪlɪŋ, əpɛɹənli θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊbeɪɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs ɔɹɾɝ.

More men in black coats appeared from among the trees, their horses stepping slowly, all around. Toveine stopped counting at fifteen. The Guards muttered angrily, waiting on a sister's command. They knew nothing yet except that a band of rogues had waylaid them. Toveine clicked her tongue in irritation. These men could not all channel, of course, but apparently every Asha'man who could do so had come against her. She did not panic. Unlike some of the sisters with her, these were not the first men who channeled that she had confronted. The tall man began riding toward her, smiling, apparently thinking they had obeyed his ridiculous order.

"æt maɪ kəmænd," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli, "wi wɪl bɹeɪk ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. əz sun əz jə ɑɹ fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ ðət ðə mæn luzəz ðə ʃild," mɛn ɔlweɪz θɔt ðeɪ hæd tə bi eɪbəl tə si tə hoʊl ðɛɹ wivz, wɪtʃ mɛn ðət ðeɪ dɪɾ əv tə, "tɝn bæk ən hɛlp ðə ɡɑɹdz. ɹɛɾi jʊɹsɛlvz." ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs tə ə ʃaʊt. "ɡɑɹdzmɪn, faɪt ðɛm!"

"At my command," she said quietly, "we will break in every direction. As soon as you are far enough away that the man loses the shield," men always thought they had to be able to see to hold their weaves, which meant that they did have to, "turn back and help the Guards. Ready yourselves." She raised her voice to a shout. "Guardsmen, fight them!"

ɹɔɹɪŋ, ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn sɝdʒ fɔɹwɝd, weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən noʊ daʊt θɪŋkɪŋ tə sɝaʊn ən pɹətɛk ðə sɪstɝz. pʊlɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ ɝaʊn tə ðə ɹaɪt, tʌvaɪn dʌɡ ɪn əɹ hilz ən kɹaʊtʃt loʊ oʊvɝ spɛɹoʊz nɛk, dɑdʒɪŋ bɪtwin stɑɹɾəld ɡɑɹdzmɪn, ðən bɪtwin tu vɛɹi jʌŋ mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts u ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ðən ʃi wɑz ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, ɝdʒɪŋ mɔɹ spid, snoʊ spɹeɪɪŋ waɪldli, kɛɹləs ʌv wɛðɝ ðə mɛɹ bɹoʊk ə lɛɡ. ʃi laɪk ði ænəməl, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ə hɔɹs wəd daɪ tədeɪ. bɪhaɪn hɝ, ʃaʊts. ən wʌn vɔɪs, ɹɔɹɪŋ θɹu ɔl ðə kækɑfəni. ðə tɔl mænz vɔɪs.

Roaring, the Guardsmen surged forward, waving their swords and no doubt thinking to surround and protect the sisters. Pulling her mare around to the right, Toveine dug in her heels and crouched low over Sparrow's neck, dodging between startled Guardsmen, then between two very young men in black coats who gaped at her in astonishment. Then she was into the trees, urging more speed, snow spraying wildly, careless of whether the mare broke a leg. She liked the animal, but more than a horse would die today. Behind her, shouts. And one voice, roaring through all the cacophony. The tall man's voice.

"teɪk əm əlaɪv, baɪ ɔɹɾɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! hɑɹm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən jəl ænsɝ tə mi!"

"Take them alive, by order of the Dragon Reborn! Harm an Aes Sedai, and you'll answer to me!"

baɪ ɔɹɾɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, tʌvaɪn fɛl fɪɹ, ən aɪsɪkəl wɝmɪŋ ɪndə hɝ mɪɾəl. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ʃi θɹæʃt spɛɹoʊz nɛk wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz. ðə ʃild wɑz stɪl ɑn hɝ! ʃʊɹli ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf tʃɹiz bɪtwin əm ɔlɹɛɾi tə blɑk ðə kɝs mɛnz saɪɾ ə hɝ! oʊ, laɪt, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn!

By order of the Dragon Reborn. For the first time, Toveine felt fear, an icicle worming into her middle. The Dragon Reborn. She thrashed Sparrow's neck with the reins. The shield was still on her! Surely there were enough trees between them already to block the cursed men's sight of her! Oh, Light, the Dragon Reborn!

ʃi ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk əɹ əkɹɔs ðə mɪɾəl, ə bɹæntʃ wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɹæntʃ, snætʃɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. ʃi hʌŋ ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ spɛɹoʊ plaʊ ɔf əɾ əz mʌtʃ ʌv ə ɡæləp əz ðə snoʊ əlaʊd. ʃi hʌŋ ðɛɹ. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹ, ɑɹmz tʃɹæpt əɾ əɹ saɪdz, fit dæŋɡəlɪŋ ə peɪs əɹ mɔɹ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi swɑloʊd. hɑɹd. ɪt hæd tə bi ðə meɪl pɑɹɾ ə ðə paʊɝ hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ʌp. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tʌtʃt baɪ seɪɾɪn bɪfɔɹ. ʃi kəd fil ðə θɪk bæn ə nʌθɪŋ snʌɡ ɝaʊn əɹ mɪɾəl. ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd fil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪnt. ʃi kwɪvɝd, faɪɾɪŋ daʊn skɹimz.

She grunted as something struck her across the middle, a branch where there was no branch, snatching her out of the saddle. She hung there watching Sparrow plow off at as much of a gallop as the snow allowed. She hung there. In the middle of the air, arms trapped at her sides, feet dangling a pace or more above the ground. She swallowed. Hard. It had to be the male part of the Power holding her up. She had never been touched by saidin before. She could feel the thick band of nothing snug around her middle. She thought she could feel the Dark One's taint. She quivered, fighting down screams.

ðə tɔl mæn ɹeɪn ɪz hɔɹs tə ə hɔlt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən ʃi floʊɾəd daʊn tə sɪt saɪdweɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz sæɾəl. hi dɪd nɑt sim pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hi hæd kæptʃɝd, ðoʊ. "hɑɹdlɪn!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "nɔɹli! kɑdʒimə! wʌn ə jə blʌɾi jʌŋ laʊts kʌm hɪɹ naʊ!"

The tall man reined his horse to a halt in front of her, and she floated down to sit sideways in front of his saddle. He did not seem particularly interested in the Aes Sedai he had captured, though. "Hardlin!" he shouted. "Norley! Kajima! One of you bloody young louts come here now!"

hi wɑz vɛɹi tɔl, wɪð ʃoʊldɝz ən æks-hændəl waɪd. ðət wɑz haʊ mɪstʃɹəs daʊil wʊɾə pʊɾ ɪt. dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, hænsəm ɪn ə bɹuɾɪŋ, ɹʌɡəd fæʃən. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk ðə pɹɪɾi bɔɪz tʌvaɪn laɪkt, iɡɝ ən ɡɹeɪtfəl ən soʊ izəli kəntʃɹoʊld. ə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə tɔl kɑlɝ ə hɪz blæk wʊl koʊɾ ɑn wʌn saɪd, wɪð ə pəkjuljɝ kɹitʃɝ ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl ɑn ði ʌðɝ. hi wɑz ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl. ən i hæɾ əɹ ʃildɪɾ ən ə pɹɪznɝ.

He was very tall, with shoulders an axe-handle wide. That was how Mistress Doweel would have put it. Just short of his middle years, handsome in a brooding, rugged fashion. Not at all like the pretty boys Toveine liked, eager and grateful and so easily controlled. A silver sword decorated the tall collar of his black wool coat on one side, with a peculiar creature in gold and red enamel on the other. He was a man who could channel. And he had her shielded and a prisoner.

ðə ʃɹik ðət bɝs fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt stɑɹɾəld ivən hɝ. ʃi wʊɾə hɛld ɪt bæk ɪf ʃi kʊd, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ lɛpt aʊt bɪhaɪn ɪt, haɪɝ stɪl, ən ənʌðɝ ivən haɪɝ, ənʌðɝ ən ənʌðɝ. kɪkɪŋ waɪldli, ʃi flʌŋ hɝsɛlf fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. jusləs əɡɛns ðə paʊɝ. ʃi nu ðæt, bʌɾ oʊnli ɪn ə taɪni kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maɪnd. ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ haʊld ət ðə tɑp ə hɝ lʌŋz, haʊld wɝdləs pliz fəɹ ɹɛskju fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ. skɹimɪŋ, ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld laɪk ə mæd bist.

The shriek that burst from her throat startled even her. She would have held it back if she could, but another leaped out behind it, higher still, and another even higher, another and another. Kicking wildly, she flung herself from side to side. Useless against the Power. She knew that, but only in a tiny corner of her mind. The rest of her howled at the top of her lungs, howled wordless pleas for rescue from the Shadow. Screaming, she struggled like a mad beast.

dɪmli ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɪz hɔɹs plʌnʒɪŋ ən dænsɪŋ əz əɹ hilz dʒɹʌmd ɪts ʃoʊldɝ. dɪmli ʃi hɝd ðə mæn tɔkɪŋ. "izi, jə lʌmp-ɪɹd sæk ə koʊl! kɑm daʊn, sɪstɝ. aɪm nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə - izi, jə speɪvən mjul! laɪt! maɪ əpɑlədʒiz, sɪstɝ, bʌt ðɪs ɪz haʊ wi lɝn tə də ɪt." ən ðən i kɪs hɝ.

Dimly she was aware of his horse plunging and dancing as her heels drummed its shoulder. Dimly she heard the man talking. "Easy, you lump-eared sack of coal! Calm down, sister. I'm not going to - Easy, you spavined mule! Light! My apologies, sister, but this is how we learn to do it." And then he kissed her.

ʃi hæɾ oʊnli ə hɑɹtbit tə ɹilaɪz ɪz lɪps wɝ tʌtʃɪŋ hɝz, ðən saɪt vænɪʃt, ən wɔɹmθ flʌɾəd θɹu hɝ. mɔɹ ðən wɔɹmθ. ʃi wɑz mɛltəd hʌni ɪnsaɪd, bʌbəlɪŋ hʌni, ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə bɔɪl. ʃi wɑz ə hɑɹpstʃɹɪŋ, vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ fæstɝ ən fæstɝ, vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ tə ɪnvɪzəbɪləɾi ən fæstɝ stɪl. ʃi wɑz ə θɪn kɹɪstəl veɪs, kwɪvɝɪŋ ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə ʃæɾɝɪŋ. ðə hɑɹpstʃɹɪŋ bɹoʊk; ðə veɪs ʃæɾɝd.

She had only a heartbeat to realize his lips were touching hers, then sight vanished, and warmth flooded through her. More than warmth. She was melted honey inside, bubbling honey, rushing toward the boil. She was a harpstring, vibrating faster and faster, vibrating to invisibility and faster still. She was a thin crystal vase, quivering on the brink of shattering. The harpstring broke; the vase shattered.

"ɑəəəəəəəəəəəəə!"

"Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah!"

ət fɝst, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət saʊn hæd kʌm fɹəm əɹ ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊθ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk koʊhiɹənli. pæntɪŋ, ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ðə meɪl feɪs əbʌv hɝ, wʌndɝɪŋ u ɪt bɪlɔŋ tə. jɛs. ðə tɔl mæn. ðə mæn u kəd -  "aɪ cʊɾə dʌn wɪθaʊt ði ɛkstʃɹə bɪt," hi saɪd, pæɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz nɛk; ði ænəməl snɔɹɾɪd, bʌɾ ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɛpt əbaʊt, "jɛɾ aɪ səpoʊz ɪts nɛsəsɛɹi. jəɹ hɑɹdli ə waɪf. bi kɑm. doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp, doʊn ətæk ɛniwʌn ɪn ə blæk koʊt, ən doʊn tʌtʃ ðə sɔɹs ənlɛs aɪ ɡɪv jə pɝmɪʃən. naʊ, wʌts jəɹ neɪm?"

At first, she did not realize that sound had come from her gaping mouth. For a moment, she could not think coherently. Panting, she stared up at the male face above her, wondering who it belonged to. Yes. The tall man. The man who could -  "I could have done without the extra bit," he sighed, patting the horse's neck; the animal snorted, but it no longer leaped about, "yet I suppose it is necessary. You're hardly a wife. Be calm. Don't try to escape, don't attack anyone in a black coat, and don't touch the Source unless I give you permission. Now, what's your name?"

ənlɛs i ɡeɪv pɝmɪʃən? ði ɪfɹʌntɝi ʌv ðə mæn!

Unless he gave permission? The effrontery of the man!

"tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl," ʃi sɛd, ən blɪŋkt. naʊ, waɪ hæd ʃi ænsɝd hɪm?

"Toveine Gazal," she said, and blinked. Now, why had she answered him?

"ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ," ənʌðɝ blæk-koʊɾəd mæn sɛd, splæʃɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs θɹu ðə snoʊ tə ðɛm. ðɪs wʌn wəd bi mʌtʃ mɔɹ tə hɝ laɪkɪŋ - ɪf i kəd nɑɾ æktʃəli  tʃænəl, ət list. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðɪs pɪŋk-tʃik læd ʃeɪv mɔɹ ðən twaɪs ɪn ðə wik. "laɪt, lɑɡən!" ðə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ ɪkskleɪmd. "dɪd jə teɪk ə sɛkənd wʌn? ðə l woʊn laɪk ðæt! aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i laɪks əs teɪkɪŋ ɛni! meɪbi ɪt woʊn mæɾɝ, ðoʊ, jə tu biɪŋ soʊ kloʊs ən ɔl."

"There you are," another black-coated man said, splashing his horse through the snow to them. This one would be much more to her liking - if he could not actually channel, at least. She doubted this pink-cheeked lad shaved more than twice in the week. "Light, Logain!" the pretty boy exclaimed. "Did you take a second one? The M'Hael won't like that! I don't think he likes us taking any! Maybe it won't matter, though, you two being so close and all."

"kloʊs, vɪntʃhoʊvə?" lɑɡən sɛd ɹaɪli. "ɪf ðə l hæɾ ɪz weɪ, aɪd bi hoʊɪŋ tɝnəps wɪð ðə nu bɔɪz. əɹ bɛɹiɾ ʌndɝ ðə fild," hi æɾəd ɪn ə mʌɾɝ ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i mɛn tə bi hɝd.

"Close, Vinchova?" Logain said wryly. "If the M'Hael had his way, I'd be hoeing turnips with the new boys. Or buried under the field," he added in a mutter she did not think he meant to be heard.

haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ i hɝd, ðə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ læft wɪð ɪnkɹɛdʒələs dɪsbɪlif. tʌvaɪn bɛɹli hɝd hɪm. ʃi wɑz ɡeɪzɪŋ ʌp ət ðə mæn lumɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ. lɑɡən. ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. bʌɾ i wɑz dɛd! stɪld ən dɛd! ən hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɪfɔɹ ɪz sæɾəl wɪð ə kæʒəwəl hænd. waɪ wɑz ʃi nɑt skɹimɪŋ, əɹ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət hɪm? ivən əɹ bɛl naɪf wəd du, ðɪs nɪɹ. jɛt ʃi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ əɾ ɔl tə ɹitʃ fəɹ ði aɪvɝi hæft. ʃi kʊd, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. ðət bæn ɝaʊn əɹ mɪɾəl wɑz ɡɔn. ʃi kəɾ ət list slɪp daʊn ɔf ðə hɔɹs ən tʃɹaɪ tə - ʃi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə də ðæt, iðɝ.

However much he heard, the pretty boy laughed with incredulous disbelief. Toveine barely heard him. She was gazing up at the man looming over her. Logain. The false Dragon. But he was dead! Stilled and dead! And holding her before his saddle with a casual hand. Why was she not screaming, or striking at him? Even her belt knife would do, this near. Yet she had no desire at all to reach for the ivory haft. She could, she realized. That band around her middle was gone. She could at least slip down off the horse and try to - She had no desire to do that, either.

"wʌt dɪd jə də tə mi?" ʃi dɪmændəd. kɑmli. ət list ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðæt!

"What did you do to me?" she demanded. Calmly. At least she had managed to hold on to that!

tɝnɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs tə ɹaɪd bæk tə ðə ɹoʊd, lɑɡən toʊld əɹ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn, ən ʃi pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛns ðət waɪd tʃɛst, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɔl haʊ bɪɡ hi wɑz, ən wɛpt. ʃi wɑz gɑnə meɪk ɪleɪɾə peɪ fəɹ ðɪs, ʃi vaʊd. ɪf lɑɡən ɛvɝ lɛt hɝ, ʃi wʊd. ðət læst wɑz ən ɪspɛʃli bɪɾɝ θɔt.

Turning his horse to ride back to the road, Logain told her what he had done, and she put her head against that wide chest, not caring at all how big he was, and wept. She was going to make Elaida pay for this, she vowed. If Logain ever let her, she would. That last was an especially bitter thought.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

ðə bɑɹɡən


The Bargain

siɾəd kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɪn ə hɛvəli ɡɪldɪd, haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹ, mɪn tʃɹaɪd tə luz hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə lɛðɝ-baʊn kɑpi ʌv hɹɪd fɛlz ɹizən ən ənɹisən laɪɪŋ oʊpən ɑn əɹ niz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi. oʊ, ðə bʊk ɪtsɛlf wɑz mɛzmɝaɪzɪŋ; mæstɝ fɛlz ɹaɪɾɪŋz ɔlweɪz swɛpt əɹ ɪndə wɝlz ə θɔt ʃi hæd nɑt dʒɹimd ʌv waɪl wɝkɪŋ ɪn steɪbəlz. ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ðə swiɾ oʊl mænz dɛθ. ʃi hoʊp tə faɪn ə klu ɪn ɪz bʊks tə waɪ hi hæd bɪn kɪld. hɝ dɑɹk ɹɪŋləts swʌŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə əplaɪ hɝsɛlf.

Seated cross-legged in a heavily gilded, high-backed chair, Min tried to lose herself in the leather-bound copy of Herid Fel's Reason and Unreason lying open on her knees. It was not easy. Oh, the book itself was mesmerizing; Master Fel's writings always swept her into worlds of thought she had not dreamed of while working in stables. She very much regretted the sweet old man's death. She hoped to find a clue in his books to why he had been killed. Her dark ringlets swung as she shook her head and tried to apply herself.

ðə bʊk wɑz fæsəneɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðə ɹum wɑz əpɹɛsɪv. ɹændz smɔl θɹoʊn ɹum ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs wɑz θɪk wɪð ɡɪl fɹəm ðə waɪd kɔɹnɪsəz tə ðə tɔl mɪɹɝz ɑn ðə wɔlz ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ðoʊz ɹænd hæd smæʃt, fɹəm ðə tu ɹoʊz ə tʃɛɹz laɪk ðə wʌn ʃi sæɾ ɪn tə ðə deɪz ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɹoʊz ən ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn ətɑp ðə deɪz. ðət wɑz ə mɑnstʃɹɑsəɾi, ɪn ðə staɪl ə tiɹ əz ɪmædʒən baɪ kɛɹhinɪn kɹæfsmən, ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə bæks ʌv ə pɛɹ ə dʒɹæɡənz wɪð tu mɔɹ dʒɹæɡənz fəɹ ði ɑɹmz ən ʌðɝz klaɪmɪŋ ðə bæk, ɔl wɪð lɑɹdʒ sʌnstoʊnz fəɹ aɪz, ðə hoʊl ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ wɪð ɡɪlt ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl. ə hjudʒ ɡoʊldən, weɪvi-ɹeɪd ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn sɛɾ ɪn ðə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn flɔɹ oʊnli æɾəd tə ðə sɛns ə hɛvinəs. ət lis ðə faɪɝz bleɪzɪŋ ɪn tu ɡɹeɪt faɪɝpleɪsəz, tɔl ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə wɔk ɪntu, ɡeɪv ə plizɪŋ wɔɹmθ, ɪspɛʃli wɪð snoʊ spɪlɪŋ daʊn aʊtsaɪd. ən ðiz wɝ ɹændz ɹumz; ðə kʌmfɝɾ ə ðəɾ əloʊn aʊtweɪɾ ɛni əmaʊn ʌv əpɹɛʃən. ən ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ θɔt. ðɪs wɑz ɹændz ɹum ɪf i ɛvɝ dn tə ɹɪtɝn. ə vɛɹi ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ θɔt. biɪŋ ɪn lʌv wɪð ə mæn sim tə kənsɪs lɑɹdʒli ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ ædmɪʃənz tə jɝsɛlf!

The book was fascinating, but the room was oppressive. Rand's small throne room in the Sun Palace was thick with gilt from the wide cornices to the tall mirrors on the walls replacing those Rand had smashed, from the two rows of chairs like the one she sat in to the dais at the head of the rows and the Dragon Throne atop the dais. That was a monstrosity, in the style of Tear as imagined by Cairhienin craftsmen, resting on the backs of a pair of Dragons with two more Dragons for the arms and others climbing the back, all with large sunstones for eyes, the whole glittering with gilt and red enamel. A huge golden, wavy-rayed Rising Sun set in the polished stone floor only added to the sense of heaviness. At least the fires blazing in two great fireplaces, tall enough for her to walk into, gave a pleasing warmth, especially with snow spilling down outside. And these were Rand's rooms; the comfort of that alone outweighed any amount of oppression. An irritating thought. This was Rand's room if he ever deigned to return. A very irritating thought. Being in love with a man seemed to consist largely of a great many irritating admissions to yourself!

ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn ə veɪn ətɛmp tə meɪk ðə hɑɹd tʃɛɹ kʌmftəɹbəl, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹid, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz kɛp swɪŋɪŋ tə ðə tɔl dɔɹz, itʃ klaɪm baɪ ɪts oʊn laɪn ʌv ɡɪldɪd ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌnz. ʃi hoʊp tə si ɹænd wɔk ɪn; ʃi fɪɹd tə si sɔɹɪliə, əɹ kædzueɪn. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ peɪl blu koʊt, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə taɪni snoʊflaʊɝz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə ləpɛlz. mɔɹ twaɪn ɝaʊn ðə slivz, ən ðə lɛɡz ə bɹitʃɪz meɪɾ əz snʌɡ əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ tə ɹɪɡəl hɝsɛlf ɪntu. nɑt ðət ɡɹeɪɾ ə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɔɹn. nɑt ɹɪli. soʊ fɑɹ, ʃi hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd dʒɹɛsəz, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ʃi wɔɹ, bʌt ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ fɪɹd ðət sɔɹɪliə mɛn tə stʌf əɹ ɪndə ə dʒɹɛs ɪf ðə waɪz wʌn hæd tə pil əɹ aʊɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ wɪð əɹ oʊn hænz.

Shifting in a vain attempt to make the hard chair comfortable, she tried to read, but her eyes kept swinging to the tall doors, each climbed by its own line of gilded Rising Suns. She hoped to see Rand walk in; she feared to see Sorilea, or Cadsuane. Unconsciously, she adjusted her pale blue coat, fingering the tiny snowflowers embroidered on the lapels. More twined around the sleeves, and the legs of breeches made as snug as she could manage to wriggle herself into. Not that great a change from what she had always worn. Not really. So far, she had avoided dresses, however much embroidery she wore, but she very much feared that Sorilea meant to stuff her into a dress if the Wise One had to peel her out of what she was wearing with her own hands.

ðə wʊmən nu ɔl əbaʊɾ əɹ ən ɹænd. ɔl əbaʊt. ʃi fɛlt əɹ tʃiks hiɾɪŋ. sɔɹɪliə sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ mɪn fɑɹʃɔ wɑz ə suɾəbəl . . . lʌvɝ . . . fəɹ ɹænd ælθɹ. ðət wɝd meɪɾ əɹ fil fulɪʃli ɡɪɾi; ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə flʌf-bɹeɪnd ɡɝl! ðət wɝd meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ɡɪltəli fəɹ ði æns u hæd ɹeɪz hɝ. noʊ, ʃi θɔt ɹaɪli, jəɹ nɑt flʌf-bɹeɪnd. flʌf əz ɪts wɪts əbaʊɾ ɪt kəmpɛɹd tə ju!

The woman knew all about her and Rand. All about. She felt her cheeks heating. Sorilea seemed to be trying to decide whether Min Farshaw was a suitable . . . lover . . . for Rand al'Thor. That word made her feel foolishly giddy; she was not a fluff-brained girl! That word made her want to look over her shoulder guiltily for the aunts who had raised her. No, she thought wryly, you're not fluff-brained. Fluff has its wits about it compared to you!

əɹ meɪbi sɔɹɪliə wɑntəd tə noʊ wɛðɝ ɹænd wɑz suɾəbəl fəɹ mɪn; ɪt sim ðət weɪ, ət taɪmz. ðə waɪz wʌnz æksɛptɪd mɪn əz wʌn ə ðɛm, əɹ vɛɹi nɪɹli, bʌt ðiz pæst wiks, sɔɹɪliə hæd ɹʌŋ əɹ aʊt laɪk ə lɔnʒɹɪsəz mæŋɡəl. ðə lɛðɝ-feɪst, waɪt-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn wɑntəd tə noʊ ɛvɹi skɹæp əbaʊt mɪn, ən ɛvɹi ʃɹɛɾ əbaʊt ɹænd. ʃi wɑntəd ðə dʌs fɹəm ðə bɑɾəmz ə hɪz pɑkəts! twaɪs mɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd bɔkɪŋ ət ði ɪnsɛsən ɪntɛɹəɡeɪʃən, ən twaɪs sɔɹɪliə hæd pɹədust ə swɪtʃ! ðət tɛɹəbəl oʊld wʊmən sɪmpli bʌndəld əɹ oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə nɪɹəs teɪbəl, ən æftɝwɝd toʊld əɹ ðət meɪbi ðət wəd lusən ənʌðɝ skɹæp ɪn əɹ hɛd. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz ɡeɪv ðə slaɪɾəst kəməzɝeɪʃən, iðɝ! laɪt, ðə θɪŋz jə hæd tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð fəɹ ə mæn! ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv ɪm fəɹ hɝsɛlf əloʊn, ət ðæt!

Or maybe Sorilea wanted to know whether Rand was suitable for Min; it seemed that way, at times. The Wise Ones accepted Min as one of them, or very nearly, but these past weeks, Sorilea had wrung her out like a laundress's mangle. The leather-faced, white-haired Wise One wanted to know every scrap about Min, and every shred about Rand. She wanted the dust from the bottoms of his pockets! Twice Min had tried balking at the incessant interrogation, and twice Sorilea had produced a switch! That terrible old woman simply bundled her over the side of the nearest table, and afterward told her that maybe that would loosen another scrap in her head. None of the other Wise Ones gave the slightest commiseration, either! Light, the things you had to put up with for a man! And she could not have him for herself alone, at that!

kædzueɪn wɑz ə dɪfɹən pɹɑpəzɪʃən ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ði ɪmɛnsli dɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, əz ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹɾ əz sɔɹɪliə wɑz waɪt, dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ tu fɪɡz fəɹ mɪn əɹ ɹænd iðɝ wʌn, bʌt ʃi spɛn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs. əvɔɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɪntaɪɝli wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl; ʃi sim tə wɑndɝ wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi wɑntəd. ən wən kædzueɪn lʊkt ət mɪn, haʊɛvɝ bɹifli, mɪn kəd nɑt hɛlp siɪŋ ə wʊmən u kəd titʃ bʊlz tə dæns ən bɛɹz tə sɪŋ. ʃi kɛpt ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðə wʊmən tə pɔɪn əɾ əɹ ən ənaʊns ðəɾ ɪt wɑz taɪm mɪn fɑɹʃɔ lɝn tə bæləns ə bɔl ɑn əɹ noʊz. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ɹænd hæd tə feɪs kædzueɪn əɡɛn, ən ðə θɔt taɪd mɪnz stʌmək ɪn nɑts.

Cadsuane was a different proposition altogether. The immensely dignified Aes Sedai, as gray-haired as Sorilea was white, did not seem to care two figs for Min or Rand either one, but she spent a great deal of time in the Sun Palace. Avoiding her entirely was impossible; she seemed to wander wherever she wanted. And when Cadsuane looked at Min, however briefly, Min could not help seeing a woman who could teach bulls to dance and bears to sing. She kept expecting the woman to point at her and announce that it was time Min Farshaw learned to balance a ball on her nose. Sooner or later, Rand had to face Cadsuane again, and the thought tied Min's stomach in knots.

ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf bɛn bæk oʊvɝ əɹ bʊk. wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz swʌŋ oʊpən, ən ɹænd stʃɹoʊld ɪn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ nɛsəld ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɑɹm. hi wɔɹ ə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn, ə bɹɔd sɝkləɾ ə lɔɹəl livz - ðət mʌs bi ðɪs kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt - snʌɡ bɹitʃɪz ðət ʃoʊɾ ɪz lɛɡz tə ædvæntɪdʒ, ən ə ɡoʊld-wɝkt ɡɹin sɪlk koʊt ðət fɪɾ ɪm bjuɾəfli. hi wɑz bjuɾəfəl.

She made herself bend back over her book. One of the doors swung open, and Rand strolled in with the Dragon Scepter nestled in the crook of his arm. He wore a golden crown, a broad circlet of laurel leaves - that must be this Crown of Swords everyone was talking about - snug breeches that showed his legs to advantage, and a gold-worked green silk coat that fit him beautifully. He was beautiful.

mɑɹkɪŋ əɹ pleɪs wɪð ðə noʊt mæstɝ fɛl hæd ɹɪɾən seɪɪŋ ʃi wɑz "tu pɹɪɾi," ʃi kɛɹfəli kloʊz ðə bʊk ən kɛɹfəli sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ. ðən ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ən weɪɾəd. hæd ʃi bɪn stændɪŋ, ʃi wʊɾə tæpt əɹ fʊt, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ðə mæn θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi wɑz spɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp dʒʌs kəz i faɪnəli əpɪɹd.

Marking her place with the note Master Fel had written saying she was "too pretty," she carefully closed the book and carefully set it on the floor beside her chair. Then she folded her arms and waited. Had she been standing, she would have tapped her foot, but she would not have the man thinking she was springing up just because he finally appeared.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stʊd smaɪlɪŋ ət hɝ, ən tʌɡɪŋ ɪz ɝloʊb fəɹ səm ɹizən - hi sim tə bi hʌmɪŋ! - ðən əbɹʌpli hi swʌŋ ɹaʊn tə fɹaʊn ət ðə dɔɹz. "ðə meɪɾənz aʊt ðəɹ dɪdn tɛl mi jə wɝ ɪn hɪɹ. ðeɪ hɑɹdli sɛɾ ə wɝɾ əɾ ɔl. laɪt, ðeɪ lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə veɪl ət ðə saɪɾ ə mi."

For a moment he stood smiling at her, and tugging his earlobe for some reason - he seemed to be humming! - then abruptly he swung round to frown at the doors. "The Maidens out there didn't tell me you were in here. They hardly said a word at all. Light, they looked ready to veil at the sight of me."

"meɪbi ðeɪ ɑɹ ʌpsɛt," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "meɪbi ðeɪ wʌndɝd wɛɹ jə wɝ. ðə weɪ aɪ dɪd. meɪbi ðeɪ wʌndɝd wɛðɝ jə wɝ hɝt, əɹ sɪk, əɹ koʊld." ðə weɪ aɪ dɪd, ʃi θɔt bɪɾɝli. ðə mæn lʊkt kənfjuzd!

"Maybe they are upset," she said calmly. "Maybe they wondered where you were. The way I did. Maybe they wondered whether you were hurt, or sick, or cold." The way I did, she thought bitterly. The man looked confused!

"aɪ ɹoʊt tə ju," hi sɛd sloʊli, ən ʃi snɪft.

"I wrote to you," he said slowly, and she sniffed.

"twaɪs! wɪð æʃəmən tə dɪlɪvɝ jəɹ lɛɾɝz, jə ɹoʊt twaɪs, ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪf jə kɔl ɪt ɹaɪɾɪŋ!"

"Twice! With Asha'man to deliver your letters, you wrote twice, Rand al'Thor. If you call it writing!"

hi stæɡɝɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd slæpt ɪm - noʊ; əz ɪf ʃi hæd kɪkt ɪm ɪn ðə bɛli! - ən blɪŋkt. ʃi tʊk ə fɝm hoʊld ɑn hɝsɛlf ən sɛɾəld əɡɛns ðə tʃɛɹbæk. ɡɪv ə mæn sɪmpəθi ət ðə ɹɔŋ moʊmənt, ən jə nɛvɝ ɹiɡeɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn lɔst. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑntəd tə θɹoʊ hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm, kʌmfɝt hɪm, dʒɹɔ aʊɾ ɔl ɪz peɪnz, suð ɔl ɪz hɝts. hi hæd soʊ mɛni, ən ɹəfjuz tə ədmɪɾ ə wʌn. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə spɹɪŋ ʌp ən ɹʌʃ tə hɪm, ɡʌʃɪŋ tə noʊ wʌt wɑz ɹɔŋ əɹ . . . laɪt, hi hæd tə bi ɔl ɹaɪt.

He staggered as if she had slapped him - no; as if she had kicked him in the belly! - and blinked. She took a firm hold on herself and settled against the chairback. Give a man sympathy at the wrong moment, and you never regained the ground lost. A part of her wanted to throw her arms around him, comfort him, draw out all his pains, soothe all his hurts. He had so many, and refused to admit a one. She was not going to spring up and rush to him, gushing to know what was wrong or . . . Light, he had to be all right.

sʌmθɪŋ tʊk əɹ dʒɛnli bɪniθ ði ɛlboʊz ən lɪftəɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ. blu buts dæŋɡəlɪŋ, ʃi floʊɾəd təwɔɹɾ ɪm θɹu ði ɛɹ. ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ floʊɾəd əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. soʊ, hi θɔɾ i kəd smaɪl, dɪd hi? hi θɔɾ ə pɹɪɾi smaɪl kəd tɝn əɹ ɝaʊnd? ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɡɪv ɪm ə pis ə hɝ maɪnd. ə vɛɹi ʃɑɹp pis! foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ, hi kɪs hɝ.

Something took her gently beneath the elbows and lifted her out of the chair. Blue boots dangling, she floated toward him through the air. The Dragon Scepter floated away from him. So, he thought he could smile, did he? He thought a pretty smile could turn her around? She opened her mouth to give him a piece of her mind. A very sharp piece! Folding his arms around her, he kissed her.

wən ʃi kəd bɹið əɡɛn, ʃi pɪɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ læʃɪz. "ðə fɝs taɪm . . ." ʃi swɑloʊd tə klɪɹ əɹ vɔɪs. "fɝst, dʒɑhɹ nɛɹɪʃmə stɔkt ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛɹ ɪnsaɪɾ ɛvɹibɑɾiz skʌl ðə weɪ hi dʌz, ən vænɪʃt æftɝ hændɪŋ mi ə skɹæp ə pɑɹtʃmənt. lemi si. ɪt sɛd, 'aɪ hæv kleɪm ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən. tʃɹʌs noʊ wʌn əntɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn. ɹænd.' ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə pɹɑpɝ lʌv lɛɾɝ, aɪd seɪ."

When she could breathe again, she peered up at him through her lashes. "The first time . . ." She swallowed to clear her voice. "First, Jahar Narishma stalked in trying to stare inside everybody's skull the way he does, and vanished after handing me a scrap of parchment. Let me see. It said, 'I have claimed the crown of Illian. Trust no one until I return. Rand.' A little short of a proper love letter, I'd say."

hi kɪst əɹ əɡɛn.

He kissed her again.

ðɪs taɪm, ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ bæk tʊk lɔŋɡɝ. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ əz ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ əɾ ɔl. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ɪt wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ vɛɹi bædli. "ðə sɛkən taɪm, dʒoʊnən ædli dɪlɪvɝɾ ə bɪɾ ə peɪpɝ ðət sɛd, 'aɪ wɪl ɹɪtɝn wən aɪ fɪnɪʃ hɪɹ. tʃɹʌs noʊ wʌn. ɹænd.' ædli wɔkt ɪn ɑn mi ɪn maɪ bæθ," ʃi æɾəd, "æn i wɑznt ʃaɪ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ən aɪfəl." ɹænd ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn i wɑz nɑt dʒɛləs - əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ə mæn ɪn ðə wɝld u wɑz nɑt - bʌt ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ɪz skaʊlz ət mɛn u lʊkt ət hɝ. ən ɪz vɛɹi kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɑɹɾɝ wɑz mɔɹ hiɾəd æftɝwɝd, tu. ʃi wʌndɝd wʌt ðɪs kɪs wəd bi laɪk. meɪbi ʃi ʃəd sədʒɛst ɹɪtaɪɹɪŋ tə ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ? noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt bi ðət fɔɹwɝd noʊ mæɾɝ -  ɹænd sɛɾ əɹ daʊn, hɪz feɪs sʌɾənli blik. "ædliz dɛd," hi sɛd. sʌɾənli ðə kɹaʊn flu fɹəm ɪz hɛd, spɪnɪŋ ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə ɹum əz ðoʊ hɝld. dʒʌst wən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd kɹæʃ ɪndə ðə bæk ə ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn, pɝhæps smæʃ θɹu ɪt, ðə waɪd ɹɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊl stɑpt ʃɔɹɾ ən sɛɾəld sloʊli ɑntu ðə θɹoʊnz sit.

This time, getting her breath back took longer. This was not going as she had expected at all. On the other hand, it was not going very badly. "The second time, Jonan Adley delivered a bit of paper that said, 'I will return when I finish here. Trust no one. Rand.' Adley walked in on me in my bath," she added, "and he wasn't shy about getting an eyeful." Rand always tried to pretend he was not jealous - as if there were a man in the world who was not - but she had noticed his scowls at men who looked at her. And his very considerable ardor was more heated afterward, too. She wondered what this kiss would be like. Maybe she should suggest retiring to the bedchamber? No, she would not be that forward no matter -  Rand set her down, his face suddenly bleak. "Adley's dead," he said. Suddenly the crown flew from his head, spinning the length of the room as though hurled. Just when she thought it would crash into the back of the Dragon Throne, perhaps smash through it, the wide ring of gold stopped short and settled slowly onto the throne's seat.

mɪnz bɹɛθ kɑɾ əz ʃi lʊkt ʌp ət hɪm. blʌd ɡlɪsən ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɹɛd kɝlz əbʌv ɪz lɛft ɪɹ. pʊlɪŋ ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv, ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz tɛmpəl, bʌɾ i kɑɾ əɹ ɹɪst.

Min's breath caught as she looked up at him. Blood glistened in the dark red curls above his left ear. Pulling a lace-edged handkerchief from her sleeve, she reached for his temple, but he caught her wrist.

"aɪ kɪl hɪm," hi sɛd kwaɪətli.

"I killed him," he said quietly.

ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðə saʊn ə hɪz vɔɪs. kwaɪət, ðə weɪ ðə ɡɹeɪv wɑz kwaɪət. pɝhæps ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊɾ aɪdiə. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪt wɑz. meɪkɪŋ hɝsɛlf smaɪl - ən blʌʃɪŋ wən ʃi ɹilaɪz haʊ izi ɪt wɑz tə smaɪl, θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðət hjudʒ bɛd - ʃi ɡɹɪp ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz ʃɝt, pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɹɪp ʃɝɾ ən koʊt fɹəm ɪz bæk ɹaɪt ðən ən ðɛɹ.

She shivered at the sound of his voice. Quiet, the way the grave was quiet. Perhaps the bedchamber was a very good idea. No matter how forward it was. Making herself smile - and blushing when she realized how easy it was to smile, thinking of that huge bed - she gripped the front of his shirt, preparing to rip shirt and coat from his back right then and there.

sʌmwʌn nɑkt ət ðə dɔɹz.

Someone knocked at the doors.

mɪnz hænz spɹæŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɹændz ʃɝt. ʃi spɹæŋ əweɪ, tu. hu kəɾ ɪt bi, ʃi wʌndɝɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ðə meɪɾənz iðɝ ənaʊns vɪzəɾɝz wən ɹænd wɑz ðɛɹ, əɹ sɪmpli sɛn əm ɪn.

Min's hands sprang away from Rand's shirt. She sprang away, too. Who could it be, she wondered irritably. The Maidens either announced visitors when Rand was there, or simply sent them in.

"kʌm," hi sɛd laʊdli, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə ɹufəl smaɪl. ən ʃi blʌʃt əɡɛn ət ðæt.

"Come," he said loudly, giving her a rueful smile. And she blushed again at that.

dɑbɹeɪn pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ət ðə dɔɹ, ðən ɛntɝɾ ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm wən i sɔ ðɛm stændɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ðə kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd wɑz ə smɔl mæn, lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən ʃi, wɪð ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz moʊsli ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ fɔlɪŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz. stʃɹaɪps ə blu ən waɪt dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz nɪɹli blæk koʊt tə bɪloʊ hɪz weɪst. ivən bɪfɔɹ ɡeɪnɪŋ ɹændz feɪvɝ i hæd bɪn ə paʊɝ ɪn ðə lænd. naʊ, hi ɹul hɪɹ, ət list əntɪl ɪleɪn kəd kleɪm ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi mɝmɝd, boʊɪŋ. "maɪ leɪɾi tɑvɝən."

Dobraine put his head in at the door, then entered and shut the door behind him when he saw them standing together. The Cairhienin lord was a small man, little taller than she, with the front of his head shaved and the rest of his mostly gray hair falling to his shoulders. Stripes of blue and white decorated the front of his nearly black coat to below his waist. Even before gaining Rand's favor he had been a power in the land. Now, he ruled here, at least until Elayne could claim the Sun Throne. "My Lord Dragon," he murmured, bowing. "My Lady Ta'veren."

"ə dʒoʊk," mɪn mʌɾɝd, wən ɹænd kwɝkt ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɝ.

"A joke," Min muttered, when Rand quirked an eyebrow at her.

"pɝhæps," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ slaɪtli, "jɛt hæf ðə noʊbəlwɪmən ɪn ðə sɪɾi naʊ wɛɹ bɹaɪt kʌlɝz ɪn ɪməteɪʃən ə ðə leɪɾi mɪn. bɹitʃɪz ðət dɪspleɪ ðɛɹ lɛɡz, ən mɛni ɪn koʊts ðət də nɑɾ ivən kʌvɝ ðɛɹ . . ." hi kɔf dɪskɹitli, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət mɪnz koʊt dɪd nɑt kʌvɝ əɹ hɪps kəmplitli.

"Perhaps," Dobraine said, shrugging slightly, "yet half the noblewomen in the city now wear bright colors in imitation of the Lady Min. Breeches that display their legs, and many in coats that do not even cover their . . ." He coughed discreetly, realizing that Min's coat did not cover her hips completely.

ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt tɛlɪŋ ɪm i hæd vɛɹi pɹɪɾi lɛɡz, ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ dɪsaɪɾədli nɑbi, ðən kwɪkli θɔt bɛɾɝ. ɹændz dʒɛləsi maɪt bi ə wʌndɝfəl fleɪm ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪm stʃɹaɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ət dɑbɹeɪn. hi wɑz keɪpəbəl ə ðæt, ʃi fɪɹd. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi θɔɾ ɪt ɹɪli wɑz ə slɪp; lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn wɑz nɑt ðə sɔɹt tə meɪk ivən slaɪtli ɹʌf dʒoʊks.

She thought about telling him he had very pretty legs, even if they were decidedly knobby, then quickly thought better. Rand's jealousy might be a wonderful flame if they were alone, but she did not want him striking out at Dobraine. He was capable of that, she feared. Besides, she thought it really was a slip; Lord Dobraine Taborwin was not the sort to make even slightly rough jokes.

"soʊ jəɹ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə wɝld, tu, mɪn." ɡɹɪnɪŋ, ɹænd tæp ðə tɪp ə hɝ noʊz wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. hi tæpt əɹ noʊz! laɪk ə tʃaɪld i wɑz əmjuzd wɪð! wɝs, ʃi fɛl hɝsɛlf ɡɹɪnɪŋ bæk əɾ ɪm laɪk ə ful. "ɪn bɛɾɝ weɪz ðən aɪ æm, ɪɾ əpɪɹz," hi wɛn ɑn, ən ðət moʊməntɛɹi bɔɪɪʃ ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd laɪk mɪst.

"So you're changing the world, too, Min." Grinning, Rand tapped the tip of her nose with a finger. He tapped her nose! Like a child he was amused with! Worse, she felt herself grinning back at him like a fool. "In better ways than I am, it appears," he went on, and that momentary boyish grin faded like mist.

"ɪz ɔl wɛl ɪn tiɹ ən ɪljən, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən?" dɑbɹeɪn ɛnkwaɪɝd.

"Is all well in Tear and Illian, my Lord Dragon?" Dobraine enquired.

"ɪn tiɹ ən ɪljən, ɔl ɪz wɛl," ɹænd ɹɪplaɪd ɡɹɪmli. "wʌt juv fəɹ mi, dɑbɹeɪn? sɪt, mæn. sɪt." hi moʊʃən təwɔɹd ðə ɹoʊz ə tʃɛɹz, ən tʊk wʌn fəɹ hɪmsɛlf.

"In Tear and Illian, all is well," Rand replied grimly. "What do you have for me, Dobraine? Sit, man. Sit." He motioned toward the rows of chairs, and took one for himself.

"aɪ hæv æktəɾ ɑn ɔl ə jəɹ lɛɾɝz," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd, siɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əkɹɔs fɹəm ɹænd, "bʌt ðəɹ ɪz lɪɾəl ɡʊd tə ɹipɔɹt, aɪ fɪɹ."

"I have acted on all of your letters," Dobraine said, seating himself across from Rand, "but there is little good to report, I fear."

"aɪl ɡɛɾ əs sʌmθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk," mɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. lɛɾɝz? ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi tə stɔk ɪn hil buts - ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn əkʌstəm tə ðɛm, bʌt ðə θɪŋz meɪd jə sweɪ wʌtɛvɝ jə dɪd - nɑɾ izi, jɛɾ ɪnʌf æŋɡɝ meɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ pɑsəbəl. ʃi stɔk tə ðə smɔl ɡɪldɪd teɪbəl bɪniθ wʌn ə ðə hjudʒ mɪɹɝz wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ ən ɡoʊbləts sæt. ʃi bɪzid hɝsɛlf wɪð pɔɹɪŋ spaɪst waɪn, splæʃɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt fjʊɹiəsli. ðə sɝvəns ɔlweɪz bɹɔɾ ɛkstʃɹə ɡoʊbləts, ɪn keɪs ʃi hæd vɪzəɾɝz, ðoʊ ʃi sɛldəm dɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ sɔɹɪliə əɹ ə ful lɑɾ ə noʊbəlwɪmən. ðə waɪn wɑz bɛɹli wɔɹm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən hɑɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə laɪks ə ðət pɛɹ. ʃi hæd ɹəsiv tu lɛɾɝz, bʌt ʃi wəd bɛt dɑbɹeɪn hæd hæd tɛn! twɛnti! bæŋɪŋ pɪtʃɝ ən ɡoʊbləts əbaʊt, ʃi lɪsən kɛɹfəli. wʌt hæd ðeɪ bɪn ʌp tə bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk wɪð ðɛɹ dʌzənz ə lɛɾɝz?

"I'll get us something to drink," Min said in a tight voice. Letters? It was not easy to stalk in heeled boots - she had grown accustomed to them, but the things made you sway whatever you did - not easy, yet enough anger made anything possible. She stalked to the small gilded table beneath one of the huge mirrors where a silver pitcher and goblets sat. She busied herself with pouring spiced wine, splashing it out furiously. The servants always brought extra goblets, in case she had visitors, though she seldom did except for Sorilea or a fool lot of noblewomen. The wine was barely warm, but it was more than hot enough for the likes of that pair. She had received two letters, but she would bet Dobraine had had ten! Twenty! Banging pitcher and goblets about, she listened carefully. What had they been up to behind her back with their dozens of letters?

"tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən əpɪɹz tə hæv vænɪʃt," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd, "ðoʊ ɹumɝ, ət list, sɛz i stɪl laɪvz, wɝs lʌk. ɹumɝz ɔlsoʊ seɪ ðət dɑv hænlən ən dʒɛɹɑl mɔɹɾɪθ - pdən feɪn, əz jə kɔl ðə mæn - hæv dɪzɝɾɪd hɪm. baɪ ðə weɪ, aɪ hæv sɛɾəld tɔɹæmz sɪstɝ, ðə leɪɾi eɪlɪl, ɪn dʒɛnɝəs əpɑɹtməns, wɪð sɝvəns u ɑɹ . . . tʃɹʌstwɝði." baɪ hɪz toʊn, hi klɪɹli mɛn tʃɹʌstwɝði təwɔɹd hɪmsɛlf. ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ dʒɹɛs wɪθaʊɾ ɪm noʊɪŋ. "aɪ kən ʌndɝstæn bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hɪɹ, ən lɔɹd bɝtoʊm ən ði ʌðɝz, bʌt waɪ haɪ lɔɹd wɪɹɑmɑn, əɹ haɪ leɪɾi ænɑiɛlə? ɪt ɡoʊz wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðət ðɛɹ sɝvəns ɔlsoʊ ɑɹ tʃɹʌstwɝði."

"Toram Riatin appears to have vanished," Dobraine said, "though rumor, at least, says he still lives, worse luck. Rumors also say that Daved Hanlon and Jeraal Mordeth - Padan Fain, as you call the man - have deserted him. By the way, I have settled Toram's sister, the Lady Ailil, in generous apartments, with servants who are . . . trustworthy." By his tone, he clearly meant trustworthy toward himself. The woman would not be able to change her dress without him knowing. "I can understand bringing her here, and Lord Bertome and the others, but why High Lord Weiramon, or High Lady Anaiyella? It goes without saying, of course, that their servants also are trustworthy."

"haʊ dʒju noʊ wən ə wʊmən wɑns tə kɪl ju?" ɹænd mjuzd.

"How do you know when a woman wants to kill you?" Rand mused.

"wɛn ʃi noʊz jəɹ neɪm?" dɑbɹeɪn dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf i wɝ dʒoʊkɪŋ. ɹænd tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd θɔtfəli, ðən nɑɾəd. nɑɾəd! ʃi hoʊpt i wɑz nɑt stɪl hɪɹɪŋ vɔɪsəz.
