"When she knows your name?" Dobraine did not sound as if he were joking. Rand tilted his head thoughtfully, then nodded. Nodded! She hoped he was not still hearing voices.

ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ɪf bɹʌʃɪŋ əweɪ ðə wɪmən u wɑntəd tə kɪl hɪm. ə deɪnʒɝəs θɪŋ, wɪð əɹ əbaʊt. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə kɪl hɪm, sɝɾənli, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt maɪn siɪŋ sɔɹɪliə ɡoʊ əɾ ɪm wɪð ðət swɪtʃ! bɹitʃɪz dɪd nɑt ɡɪv mʌtʃ pɹətɛkʃən.

Rand gestured as if brushing away the women who wanted to kill him. A dangerous thing, with her about. She did not want to kill him, certainly, but she would not mind seeing Sorilea go at him with that switch! Breeches did not give much protection.

"wɪɹɑmɑn ɪz ə ful u meɪks tu mɛni mɪsteɪks," ɹænd toʊl dɑbɹeɪn, hu nɑɾəd soʊbɝ əɡɹimənt. "maɪ mɪsteɪk fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ aɪ kəd juz hɪm. hi simz hæpi ɪnʌf tə steɪ nɪɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn ɛni keɪs. wʌɾ ɛls?" mɪn hændəɾ ɪm ə ɡɑblət, ən i smaɪld əɾ əɹ dɪspaɪt ðə waɪn ðət slɑpt oʊvɝ ɪz ɹɪst. meɪbi hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ən æksəɾənt.

"Weiramon is a fool who makes too many mistakes," Rand told Dobraine, who nodded sober agreement. "My mistake for thinking I could use him. He seems happy enough to stay near the Dragon Reborn in any case. What else?" Min handed him a goblet, and he smiled at her despite the wine that slopped over his wrist. Maybe he thought it was an accident.

"lɪɾəl ɛls ən tu mʌtʃ," dɑbɹeɪn bɪɡæn, ðən dʒɝk bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ tə əvɔɪd spɪlɪŋ waɪn əz mɪn ʃʌv ðə sɛkən sɪlvɝ ɡɑbləɾ ət hɪm. ʃi hæd nɑt laɪkt əɹ bɹif stɪn əz ə tɑvɝmeɪd. "maɪ θæŋks, maɪ leɪɾi mɪn," hi mɝmɝd ɡɹeɪʃəsli, bʌɾ i aɪɾ əɹ əskæns əz i tʊk ðə ɡɑblət. ʃi wɔkt kɑmli bæk tə fɛtʃ əɹ oʊn waɪn. kɑmli.

"Little else and too much," Dobraine began, then jerked back in his chair to avoid spilling wine as Min shoved the second silver goblet at him. She had not liked her brief stint as a tavernmaid. "My thanks, my Lady Min," he murmured graciously, but he eyed her askance as he took the goblet. She walked calmly back to fetch her own wine. Calmly.

"aɪ fɪɹ ðət leɪɾi kæɹɑlin ən ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɑɹ ɪn leɪɾi ɑɹɪlɪnz pæləs hɪɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi," ðə kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd wɛn ɑn, "ʌndɝ ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə kædzueɪn sədaɪ. pɝhæps pɹətɛkʃən ɪz nɑt ðə kɝɛkt wɝd. aɪ hæv bɪn ɹəfjuzd ɛntʃɹi tə si ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ ðət ðeɪv ətɛmptəd tə liv ðə sɪɾi ən bɪn bɹɔt bæk laɪk sæks. ɪn ə sæk, wʌn stɔɹi kleɪmz. hævɪŋ mɛt kædzueɪn, aɪ kən ɔlmoʊs bɪliv ɪt."

"I fear that Lady Caraline and the High Lord Darlin are in Lady Arilyn's palace here in the City," the Cairhienin lord went on, "under the protection of Cadsuane Sedai. Perhaps protection is not the correct word. I have been refused entry to see them, but I hear that they have attempted to leave the City and been brought back like sacks. In a sack, one story claims. Having met Cadsuane, I can almost believe it."

"kædzueɪn," ɹænd mɝmɝd, ən mɪn fɛlt ə tʃɪl. hi dɪd nɑt saʊn əfɹeɪd, pɹɪsaɪsli, jɛɾ i dɪd saʊn mɔɹ ðən ənizi. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd də əbaʊt kæɹɑlin ən dɑɹlɪn, mɪn?"

"Cadsuane," Rand murmured, and Min felt a chill. He did not sound afraid, precisely, yet he did sound more than uneasy. "What do you think I should do about Caraline and Darlin, Min?"

sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ tu əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, mɪn dʒɝkt ət sʌɾənli biɪŋ ɪnkluɾəd. ɹufəli, ʃi stɛɹd daʊn ət ðə waɪn soʊkɪŋ θɹu hɝ bɛs kɹim sɪlk blaʊs, ən əɹ bɹitʃɪz, tu. "kæɹɑlin wɪl səpɔɹɾ ɪleɪn fəɹ ðə sʌn θɹoʊn," ʃi sɛd ɡlʌmli. fəɹ wɔɹm waɪn, ɪt sim vɛɹi koʊld, ən ʃi daʊɾɪd ðə steɪn wəɾ ɛvɝ kʌm aʊɾ ə ðə blaʊs. "nɑɾ ə vjuɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv hɝ." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡlæns təwɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn, ðoʊ hi nɑɾəd sədʒli. ɛvɹiwʌn nu əbaʊɾ əɹ vjuɪŋz, naʊ. ði oʊnli ɹɪzʌl hæd bɪn ə stʃɹim ə noʊbəlwɪmən u wɑntəd tə noʊ ðɛɹ fjutʃɝz, ən ɹaɪt sʌlki, tu, wən ʃi sɛd ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl ðɛm. moʊst wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn plizd wɪð ðə lɪɾəl ʃi hæd sin; nʌθɪŋ daɪɹ, bʌt nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə bɹaɪt wʌndɝz ðət fɔɹtʃən-tɛlɝz ət ðə fɛɹ fɔɹkæst. "æz fəɹ dɑɹlɪn, əsaɪd fɹəm ðə fæk ðət hɪl mɛɹi kæɹɑlin, æftɝ ʃiz ɹʌŋ ɪm aʊɾ ən hʌŋ ɪm ʌp tə dʒɹaɪ, ɔl aɪ kən seɪ ɪz ðət wʌn deɪ hɪl bi ə kɪŋ. aɪ sɔ ðə kɹaʊn ɑn ɪz hɛd, ə θɪŋ wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ðə fɹʌn ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt kʌntʃɹi ɪt bɪlɔŋz tə. ænd, oʊ, jɛs. hɪl daɪ ɪn bɛd, ən ʃɪl sɝvaɪv hɪm."

Settling into a chair two away from him, Min jerked at suddenly being included. Ruefully, she stared down at the wine soaking through her best cream silk blouse, and her breeches, too. "Caraline will support Elayne for the Sun Throne," she said glumly. For warm wine, it seemed very cold, and she doubted the stain would ever come out of the blouse. "Not a viewing, but I believe her." She did not glance toward Dobraine, though he nodded sagely. Everyone knew about her viewings, now. The only result had been a stream of noblewomen who wanted to know their futures, and right sulky, too, when she said she could not tell them. Most would not have been pleased with the little she had seen; nothing dire, but not at all the bright wonders that fortune-tellers at the fair forecast. "As for Darlin, aside from the fact that he'll marry Caraline, after she's wrung him out and hung him up to dry, all I can say is that one day he'll be a king. I saw the crown on his head, a thing with a sword on the front of it, but I don't know what country it belongs to. And, oh, yes. He'll die in bed, and she will survive him."

dɑbɹeɪn tʃoʊkt ɑn ɪz waɪn, spləɾɝɪŋ ən dæbɪŋ əɾ ɪz lɪps wɪð ə pleɪn lɪnən hæŋkɝtʃɪf. moʊst ə ðoʊz u nu dɪd nɑt bɪliv. kwaɪt sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð hɝsɛlf, mɪn dʒɹæŋk ðə lɪɾəl ðət ɹɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ ɡɑblət. ən ðən ʃi wɑz tʃoʊkɪŋ ən ɡæspɪŋ, dʒɝkɪŋ əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv tə waɪp əɾ əɹ maʊθ. laɪt, ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɡɪv hɝsɛlf ðə dʒɹɛɡz!

Dobraine choked on his wine, spluttering and dabbing at his lips with a plain linen handkerchief. Most of those who knew did not believe. Quite satisfied with herself, Min drank the little that remained in her goblet. And then she was choking and gasping, jerking her handkerchief from her sleeve to wipe at her mouth. Light, she would have to give herself the dregs!

ɹænd sɪmpli nɑɾəd, piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz ɡɑblət. "soʊ ðəl lɪv tə tʃɹʌbəl mi," hi mɝmɝd. ə vɛɹi sɑf saʊnd, fəɹ wɝdz laɪk stoʊn. hi wɑz hɑɹɾ əz ə bleɪd, hɝ ʃifɝɾɝ. "ænd wʌt də aɪ də əbaʊt - "

Rand simply nodded, peering into his goblet. "So they will live to trouble me," he murmured. A very soft sound, for words like stone. He was hard as a blade, her sheepherder. "And what do I do about - "

əbɹʌpli hi twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹz. wʌn wɑz oʊpənɪŋ. hi hæd vɛɹi ʃɑɹp ɪɹz. mɪn hæd hɝd nʌθɪŋ.

Abruptly he twisted in his chair, toward the doors. One was opening. He had very sharp ears. Min had heard nothing.

niðɝ ə ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɛntɝd wɑz kædzueɪn, ən mɪn fɛlt əɹ ʃoʊldɝz lusən əz ʃi tʌkt əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf əweɪ. waɪl ɹæfɛlə ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ, mɛɹænə kɝtsid dipli tə ɹænd, ðoʊ ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝz heɪzəl aɪz tʊk ɪn mɪn ən dɑbɹeɪn ən faɪld əm əweɪ, ən ðən ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪst ɹæfɛlə wɑz spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ dip blu skɝts waɪd, tu. niðɝ ɹoʊz əntɪl ɹænd dʒɛstʃɝd. ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd tə hɪm wɛɹɪŋ kul sɝɛnəɾi əz ðeɪ dɪd ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz. ɪksɛp ðət ðə plʌmp blu sɪstɝ fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ ʃɔl bɹifli əz ðoʊ tə ɹimaɪn hɝsɛlf ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. mɪn hæd sin ðət dʒɛstʃɝ bɪfɔɹ, fɹəm ʌðɝ sɪstɝz u hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ɹænd. ɪt kəd nɑt bi izi fəɹ ðɛm. oʊnli ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəmændəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ɹænd kɹʊkəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ən ðeɪ keɪm, pɔɪntəɾ ən ðeɪ wɛnt. ɛɛs sədaɪ spoʊk wɪð kɪŋz ən kwinz əz ikwəlz, pɝhæps slaɪtli əz ðɛɹ bɛɾɝz, jɛt ðə waɪz wʌnz kɔld əm əpɹɛntəsɪz ən ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə oʊbeɪ twaɪs əz fæst əz ɹænd dɪd.

Neither of the two Aes Sedai who entered was Cadsuane, and Min felt her shoulders loosen as she tucked her handkerchief away. While Rafela shut the door, Merana curtsied deeply to Rand, though the Gray sister's hazel eyes took in Min and Dobraine and filed them away, and then the round-faced Rafela was spreading her deep blue skirts wide, too. Neither rose until Rand gestured. They glided to him wearing cool serenity as they did their dresses. Except that the plump Blue sister fingered her shawl briefly as though to remind herself it was there. Min had seen that gesture before, from other sisters who had sworn fealty to Rand. It could not be easy for them. Only the White Tower commanded Aes Sedai, but Rand crooked a finger and they came, pointed and they went. Aes Sedai spoke with kings and queens as equals, perhaps slightly as their betters, yet the Wise Ones called them apprentices and expected them to obey twice as fast as Rand did.

nʌn ə ðət ʃoʊɾ ɑn mɛɹænəz smuð feɪs. "maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ʃi sɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli. "wi oʊnli dʒʌs lɝn ðət jə hæd ɹɪtɝnd, ən wi θɔt jə maɪt bi iɡɝ tə lɝn haʊ mæɾɝz wɛnt wɪð ði æθɑn maɪɹ." ʃi mɪɹli ɡlænst ət dɑbɹeɪn, bʌɾ i ɹoʊz ɪmiɾiətli. kɛɹhinɪn wɝ juz tə pipəl wɑntɪŋ tə spik ɪn pɹaɪvət.

None of that showed on Merana's smooth face. "My Lord Dragon," she said respectfully. "We only just learned that you had returned, and we thought you might be eager to learn how matters went with the Atha'an Miere." She merely glanced at Dobraine, but he rose immediately. Cairhienin were used to people wanting to speak in private.

"dɑbɹeɪn kən steɪ," ɹænd sɛd kɝtli. hæɾ i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd? hi dɪd nɑt stænd. hɪz aɪz laɪk blu aɪs, hi wɑz biɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ. mɪn hæd toʊld ɪm ðiz wɪmən wɝ ɪz ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðəɾ ɔl faɪv u hæɾ əkʌmpəniɾ ɪm tə ðə si foʊk ʃɪp wɝ hɪz, ʌɾɝli lɔɪəl tə ðɛɹ oʊθ ən ðɛɹfɔɹ oʊbiɾiənt tə hɪz wɪl, jɛɾ i sim tə faɪn tʃɹʌstɪŋ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪfəkəlt. ʃi ʌndɝstʊd, bʌɾ i wɑz gɑnə hæv tə lɝn haʊ.

"Dobraine can stay," Rand said curtly. Had he hesitated? He did not stand. His eyes like blue ice, he was being the Dragon Reborn for all he was worth. Min had told him these women were his in truth, that all five who had accompanied him to the Sea Folk ship were his, utterly loyal to their oath and therefore obedient to his will, yet he seemed to find trusting any Aes Sedai difficult. She understood, but he was going to have to learn how.

"æz jə wɪʃ," mɛɹænə ɹɪplaɪd, ɪnklaɪnɪŋ əɹ hɛd bɹifli. "ɹæfɛlə ən aɪ hæv ɹitʃt ə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðə si foʊk. ðə bɑɹɡən, ðeɪ kɔl ɪt." ðə dɪfɝəns wɑz klɪɹ tə ði ɪɹ. hænz laɪɪŋ stɪl ɑn ɡɹeɪ-slæʃt ɡɹin skɝts, ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi niɾəd ɪt. "hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə tu wɪnz, weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn, spikɪŋ fəɹ nɛstə dɪn ɹiz tu munz, mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ən ðʌs baɪndɪŋ ɔl ði æθɑn maɪɹ, hæz pɹɑməst sətʃ ʃɪps əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn nidz, tə seɪl wən ən wɛɹ i nidz ðɛm, fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ pɝpəsəz i ɹikwaɪɝz." mɛɹænə dɪd sim tə ɡɹoʊ ə tʌtʃ pɑntɪfəkəl wən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ waɪz wʌnz ɝaʊnd; ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪd nɑɾ əlaʊ ɪt. "ɪn ɹɪtɝn, ɹæfɛlə ən aɪ, spikɪŋ fəɹ ju, pɹɑməs ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ɛni lɔz ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, əz hiz dʌn əmʌŋ ðə . . ." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɔltɝd. "fɝɡɪv mi. aɪm juz tə dɪlɪvɝɪŋ əɡɹiməns ɪɡzækli əz meɪd. ðə wɝd ðeɪ juzd wɑz 'ʃɔɹbaʊnd,' bʌt wʌt ðeɪ min ɪz wʌt juv dʌn ɪn tiɹ ən kɛɹhin." ə kwɛstʃən əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz, ən wɑz ɡɔn. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i hæd dʌn ðə seɪm ɪn ɪljən. ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɹɛst ɹɪlif ðəɾ i hæd tʃeɪnʒd nʌθɪŋ ɪn əɹ neɪɾɪv ændɝ.

"As you wish," Merana replied, inclining her head briefly. "Rafela and I have reached a bargain with the Sea Folk. The Bargain, they call it." The difference was clear to the ear. Hands lying still on gray-slashed green skirts, she drew a deep breath. She needed it. "Harine din Togara Two Winds, Wavemistress of Clan Shodein, speaking for Nesta din Reas Two Moons, Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, and thus binding all the Atha'an Miere, has promised such ships as the Dragon Reborn needs, to sail when and where he needs them, for whatever purposes he requires." Merana did seem to grow a touch pontifical when there were no Wise Ones around; the Wise Ones did not allow it. "In return, Rafela and I, speaking for you, promised that the Dragon Reborn will not change any laws of the Atha'an Miere, as he has done among the . . ." For a moment, she faltered. "Forgive me. I am used to delivering agreements exactly as made. The word they used was 'shorebound,' but what they mean is what you have done in Tear and Cairhien." A question appeared in her eyes, and was gone. Perhaps she was wondering whether he had done the same in Illian. She had expressed relief that he had changed nothing in her native Andor.

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kən lɪv wɪð ðæt," hi mʌɾɝd.

"I suppose I can live with that," he muttered.

"sɛkənli," ɹæfɛlə tʊk ʌp, foʊldɪŋ plʌmp hænz əɾ əɹ weɪst, "ju mʌst ɡɪv ði æθɑn maɪɹ lænd, ə skwɛɹ wʌn maɪl ɑn ə saɪd, əɾ ɛvɹi sɪɾi ɑn nævəɡəbəl wɔɾɝ ðət jə kəntʃɹoʊl naʊ əɹ kʌm tə kəntʃɹoʊl." ʃi saʊndəd lɛs pɑmpəs ðən əɹ kəmpænjən, bʌɾ oʊnli dʒʌst. nɔɹ dɪd ʃi saʊn ɪntaɪɝli plizd wɪð wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. ʃi wɑz tɛɹən, æftɝ ɔl, ən fju pɔɹts hɛld ə taɪɾɝ kəntʃɹoʊl ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪd ðən tɛɹ. "wɪðɪn ðəɾ ɛɹiə, ðə lɔz ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɑɹ tə hoʊl sweɪ əbʌv ɛni ʌðɝz. ðɪs əɡɹimən mʌst ɔlsoʊ bi meɪd baɪ ðə ɹulɝz ə ðoʊz pɔɹts soʊ ðət . . ." ɪt wɑz əɹ tɝn tə fɔltɝ, ən əɹ dɑɹk tʃiks tɝn ə tʃɹaɪfəl ɡɹeɪ.

"Secondly," Rafela took up, folding plump hands at her waist, "you must give the Atha'an Miere land, a square one mile on a side, at every city on navigable water that you control now or come to control." She sounded less pompous than her companion, but only just. Nor did she sound entirely pleased with what she was saying. She was Tairen, after all, and few ports held a tighter control on their trade than Tear. "Within that area, the laws of the Atha'an Miere are to hold sway above any others. This agreement must also be made by the rulers of those ports so that . . ." It was her turn to falter, and her dark cheeks turned a trifle gray.

"soʊ ði əɡɹimənt wɪl sɝvaɪv mi?" ɹænd sɛd dʒɹaɪli. hi bɑɹkt ə læf. "aɪ kən lɪv wɪð ðæt, tu."

"So the agreement will survive me?" Rand said dryly. He barked a laugh. "I can live with that, too."

"ɛvɹi sɪɾi ɑn wɔɾɝ?" dɑbɹeɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "du ðeɪ min hɪɹ, tu?" hi lɛp tə hɪz fiɾ ən bɪɡæn peɪsɪŋ, spɪlɪŋ mɔɹ ə hɪz waɪn ðən mɪn hæd. hi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. "ə maɪl skwɛɹ? ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz wʌt pəkjuljɝ lɔz? aɪv tʃɹævəld ɑn ə si foʊk ʃɪp, ən ɪts pəkjuljɝ! bɛɹ lɛɡz ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪn ɪt! ən wʌɾ ə ðə kʌstəmz duɾiz, ən dɑkɪŋ fiz, ən . . ." sʌɾənli hi ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ɹænd. hi skaʊld ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu peɪɾ ɪm noʊ maɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə ɹænd i spoʊk, ɪn ə toʊn bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ɑn ɹʌnəs. "ðeɪ wɪl ɹuən kɛɹhin ɪn ə jɪɹ, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. ðəl ɹuən ɛni pɔɹt wɛɹ jə əlaʊ ðɛm tə də ðɪs."

"Every city on water?" Dobraine exclaimed. "Do they mean here, too?" He leaped to his feet and began pacing, spilling more of his wine than Min had. He did not seem to notice. "A mile square? Under the Light alone knows what peculiar laws? I've traveled on a Sea Folk ship, and it is peculiar! Bare legs are not in it! And what of the customs duties, and docking fees, and . . ." Suddenly he rounded on Rand. He scowled at the Aes Sedai, who paid him no mind, but it was to Rand he spoke, in a tone bordering on roughness. "They will ruin Cairhien in a year, my Lord Dragon. They will ruin any port where you allow them to do this."

mɪn əɡɹid, saɪlənli, bʌt ɹænd mɪɹli weɪvd ə hæn ən læft əɡɛn. "ðeɪ meɪ θɪŋk soʊ, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ə ðɪs, dɑbɹeɪn. ðeɪ dɪdn seɪ hu tʃuzəz ðə lænd, soʊ ɪt dʌzn əv tə bi ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ əɾ ɔl. ðəl əv tə baɪ ðɛɹ fud fɹəm ju, ən lɪv wɪð jəɹ lɔz wən ðeɪ liv, soʊ ðeɪ kæn bi tu ɛɹəɡənt. ət wɝst, jə kən kəlɛk jəɹ kʌstəmz wən ðə ɡʊdz kʌm aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ . . . sæŋktʃuɛɹi. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst . . . ɪf aɪ kən æksɛpt ɪt, jə kæn, tu." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ læftɝ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs naʊ, ən dɑbɹeɪn baʊɾ ɪz hɛd.

Min agreed, silently, but Rand merely waved a hand and laughed again. "They may think so, but I know something of this, Dobraine. They didn't say who chooses the land, so it doesn't have to be on the water at all. They'll have to buy their food from you, and live with your laws when they leave, so they can't be too arrogant. At worst, you can collect your customs when the goods come out of their . . . sanctuary. For the rest . . . If I can accept it, you can, too." There was no laughter in his voice now, and Dobraine bowed his head.

mɪn wʌndɝd wɛɹ i hæd lɝn ɔl ðæt. hi saʊndəɾ ə kɪŋ, ən wʌn u nu wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. meɪbi ɪleɪn hæd tɔt hɪm.

Min wondered where he had learned all that. He sounded a king, and one who knew what he was doing. Maybe Elayne had taught him.

" 'sɛkənli' ɪmplaɪz mɔɹ," ɹænd sɛd tə ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ.

" 'Secondly' implies more," Rand said to the two Aes Sedai.

mɛɹænə ən ɹæfɛlə ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, ʌnkɑnʃəsli tʌtʃt skɝts ən ʃɔlz, ən ðən mɛɹænə spoʊk, hɝ vɔɪs nɑɾ əɾ ɔl pɑmpəs. ɪn fækt, ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tu laɪt. "θɝdli, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɡɹiz tə kip ən æmbæsəɾɝ tʃoʊzən baɪ ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪð ɪm əɾ ɔl taɪmz. hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə hæz neɪm hɝsɛlf. ʃɪl bi əkʌmpənid baɪ hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ, hɝ sɔɹdmæstɝ ən ə ɹɛɾənu."

Merana and Rafela exchanged glances, unconsciously touched skirts and shawls, and then Merana spoke, her voice not at all pompous. In fact, it was much too light. "Thirdly, the Dragon Reborn agrees to keep an ambassador chosen by the Atha'an Miere with him at all times. Harine din Togara has named herself. She will be accompanied by her Windfinder, her Swordmaster and a retinue."

"wʌt?" ɹænd ɹɔɹd, spɹɪŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃɛɹ.

"What?" Rand roared, springing from the chair.

ɹæfɛlə ɹʌʃt ɪn, ɹʌʃt əhɛd, əz ðoʊ əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. "æn fɔɹθli, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɡɹiz tə ɡoʊ pɹɑmpli tə ə sʌmənz fɹəm ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, bʌt nɑt mɔɹ ðən twaɪs ɪn ɛni θɹi kənsɛkjəɾɪv jɪɹz." ʃi fɪnɪʃt pæntɪŋ ə lɪɾəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ðə læst saʊn laɪk ɪkstɛnjueɪʃən.

Rafela rushed in, rushed ahead, as though afraid he might cut her off. "And fourthly, the Dragon Reborn agrees to go promptly to a summons from the Mistress of the Ships, but not more than twice in any three consecutive years." She finished panting a little, trying to make the last sound like extenuation.

ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ flu fɹəm ðə flɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɹænd, ən i snæɡd ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ. hɪz aɪz wɝ nɑɾ aɪs ɛni mɔɹ. ðeɪ wɝ blu faɪɝ. "eɪ si foʊk æmbæsəɾɝ klɪŋɪŋ tə maɪ hilz?" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "oʊbeɪ sʌmənzɪz?" hi ʃʊk ðə kɑɹv spɪɹhɛɾ ət ðɛm, ðə ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt tæsəl fleɪlɪŋ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə pipəl aʊt ðəɹ u wɑnə kɑŋkɝ ɔl ʌv ʌs, ən maɪt bi eɪbəl tə də ɪt! ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ aʊt ðɛɹ! ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz weɪɾɪŋ! waɪ dɪdn jə əɡɹi aɪd kɑk ðɛɹ hʌlz waɪl jə wɝ əbaʊɾ ɪt!"

The Dragon Scepter flew from the floor behind Rand, and he snagged it out of the air without looking. His eyes were not ice any more. They were blue fire. "A Sea Folk ambassador clinging to my heels?" he shouted. "Obey summonses?" He shook the carved spearhead at them, the green-and-white tassel flailing. "There are a people out there who want to conquer all of us, and might be able to do it! The Forsaken are out there! The Dark One is waiting! Why didn't you agree I'd caulk their hulls while you were about it!"

nɔɹməli, mɪn tʃɹaɪd tə suð ɪz tɛmpɝ wən ɪt flɛɹd, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ʃi sæt fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi əɡɹid wɪð ɪm fʊli. ðeɪ hæd ɡɪvən əweɪ ðə bɑɹn tə sɛl ə hɔɹs!

Normally, Min tried to soothe his temper when it flared, but this time she sat forward and glared at the Aes Sedai. She agreed with him fully. They had given away the barn to sell a horse!

ɹæfɛlə æktʃəli  sweɪd bɪfɔɹ ðət blæst, bʌt mɛɹænə dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, hɝ oʊn aɪz mænɪdʒɪŋ ə ɡʊɾ ɪməteɪʃən ə bɹaʊn faɪɝ flɛkt wɪð ɡoʊld. "ju kæstəɡeɪɾ ʌs?" ʃi snæpt ɪn toʊnz əz fɹɔsti əz əɹ aɪz wɝ hɑt. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ðə tʃaɪl mɪn hæd sin ðɛm, ɹiɡəl əbʌv kwinz, paʊɝfəl əbʌv paʊɝz. "ju wɝ pɹɛzən ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, tɑvɝən, ən jə twɪstəɾ əm əz jə wɑntəd ðɛm. cʊɾə əv hæɾ əm ɔl nilɪŋ tə ju! bʌt jə lɛft! ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pliz tə noʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪn dænsɪŋ fəɹ ə tɑvɝən. sʌmwɛɹ, ðeɪ lɝn tə wiv ʃilz, ən bɪfɔɹ jə wɝ wɛl ɔf ðɛɹ ʃɪp, ɹæfɛlə ən aɪ wɝ ʃildɪd. soʊ wi kəd nɑt teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ sɛd. mɔɹ ðən wʌns, hɑɹɪn θɹɛɾənd tə hæŋ əs ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ baɪ əɹ toʊz əntɪl wi keɪm tə əɹ sɛnsɪz, ən aɪ fəɹ wʌn bɪliv ʃi mɛn ɪt! fil lʌki juv hæv ðə ʃɪps jə wɑnt, ɹænd ælθɹ. wʊɾə əv ɡɪvən jə ə hændfʊl! fil lʌki ʃi dɪdnt wɑn jəɹ nu buts ən ðət ɡæsli θɹoʊn ə jʊɹz əz wɛl! oʊ, baɪ ðə baɪ, ʃi fɔɹməli æknɑlɪdʒ jə əz ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, meɪ jə ɡɛɾ ə bɛlieɪk fɹəm ɪt!"

Rafela actually swayed before that blast, but Merana drew herself up, her own eyes managing a good imitation of brown fire flecked with gold. "You castigate us?" she snapped in tones as frosty as her eyes were hot. She was Aes Sedai as the child Min had seen them, regal above queens, powerful above powers. "You were present in the beginning, ta'veren, and you twisted them as you wanted them. You could have had them all kneeling to you! But you left! They were not pleased to know they had been dancing for a ta'veren. Somewhere, they learned to weave shields, and before you were well off their ship, Rafela and I were shielded. So we could not take advantage with the Power, they said. More than once, Harine threatened to hang us in the rigging by our toes until we came to our senses, and I for one believe she meant it! Feel lucky that you have the ships you want, Rand al'Thor. Harine would have given you a handful! Feel lucky she didn't want your new boots and that ghastly throne of yours as well! Oh, by the by, she formally acknowledged you as the Coramoor, may you get a bellyache from it!"

mɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. ɹænd ən dɑbɹeɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ən ðə kɛɹhinɪnz dʒɔ hʌŋ oʊpən. ɹæfɛlə stɛɹd, hɝ maʊθ wɝkɪŋ saʊnləsli. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðə faɪɝ feɪɾəd fɹəm mɛɹænəz aɪz, ən ðeɪ sloʊli ɡɹu waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ dʒʌs hɪɹɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd.

Min stared at her. Rand and Dobraine stared at her, and the Cairhienin's jaw hung open. Rafela stared, her mouth working soundlessly. For that matter, the fire faded from Merana's eyes, and they slowly grew wider and wider as if she were just hearing what she had said.

ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛptɝ tʃɹɛmbəld ɪn ɹændz fɪst. mɪn hæd sin ɪz fjʊɹi swɛl nɪɹ tə bɝstɪŋ fəɹ fɑɹ lɛs. ʃi pɹeɪd fəɹ ə weɪ tə əvɔɪd ði ɪksploʊʒən, ən kəd nɑt si wʌn.

The Dragon Scepter trembled in Rand's fist. Min had seen his fury swell near to bursting for far less. She prayed for a way to avoid the explosion, and could not see one.

"ɪt simz," hi sɛd faɪnəli, "ðæt ðə wɝdz ə tɑvɝən dʒɹæɡz aʊɾ ɑɹən ɔlweɪz ðə wɝdz i wɑns tə hɪɹ." hi saʊndəd . . . kɑm; mɪn wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə θɪŋk, seɪn. "juv dʌn wɛl, mɛɹænə. aɪ hændəd jə ə dɔɡz dɪnɝ, bʌt jə ən ɹæfɛlə hæv dʌn wɛl."

"It seems," he said finally, "that the words a ta'veren drags out aren't always the words he wants to hear." He sounded . . . calm; Min was not about to think, sane. "You've done well, Merana. I handed you a dog's dinner, but you and Rafela have done well."

ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ sweɪd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, mɪn θɔt ðeɪ maɪt kəlæps ɪn pʌɾəlz ɑn ðə flɔɹ fɹəm ʃɪɹ ɹɪlif.

The two Aes Sedai swayed, and for a moment, Min thought they might collapse in puddles on the floor from sheer relief.

"æt list wi mænədʒ tə kip ðə dɪteɪlz fɹəm kædzueɪn," ɹæfɛlə sɛd, smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts ənstɛɾəli. "ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə stɑp ɛvɹiwʌn lɝnɪŋ wi hæd meɪd səm sɔɹɾ ʌv əɡɹimənt, bʌt wi kɛp ðət mʌtʃ fɹəm hɝ."

"At least we managed to keep the details from Cadsuane," Rafela said, smoothing her skirts unsteadily. "There was no way to stop everyone learning we had made some sort of agreement, but we kept that much from her."

"jɛs," mɛɹænə sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "ʃi ivən weɪleɪɾ əs ɑn ðə weɪ hɪɹ. ɪts dɪfəkəl kipɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm hɝ, bʌt wi dɪd. wi dɪdn θɪŋk jud wɑn əɹ tə . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf ət ðə stoʊni lʊk ɑn ɹændz feɪs.

"Yes," Merana said breathlessly. "She even waylaid us on the way here. It's difficult keeping anything from her, but we did. We didn't think you'd want her to . . ." She trailed off at the stony look on Rand's face.

"kædzueɪn əɡɛn," hi sɛd flætli. hi fɹaʊn ət ðə kɑɹv lɛŋθ ə spɪɹhɛɾ ɪn ɪz hænd, ðən tɔst ɪɾ ɑntu ə tʃɛɹ əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪt. "ʃiz ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs, ɪz ʃi? mɪn, tɛl ðə meɪɾənz aʊtsaɪd tə kæɹi ə mɛsədʒ tə kædzueɪn. ʃiz tə ətɛn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn ɔl heɪst."

"Cadsuane again," he said flatly. He frowned at the carved length of spearhead in his hand, then tossed it onto a chair as if he did not trust himself with it. "She's in the Sun Palace, is she? Min, tell the Maidens outside to carry a message to Cadsuane. She is to attend the Dragon Reborn in all haste."

"ɹænd, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk," mɪn bɪɡæn ənizəli, bʌt ɹænd kʌɾ ɪn. nɑt hɑɹʃli, bʌt kwaɪt fɝmli.

"Rand, I don't think," Min began uneasily, but Rand cut in. Not harshly, but quite firmly.

"du ɪt, pliz, mɪn. ðɪs wʊmən ɪz laɪk ə wʊlf aɪɪŋ ðə ʃipfoʊld. aɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪn aʊt wʌt ʃi wɑns."

"Do it, please, Min. This woman is like a wolf eyeing the sheepfold. I intend to find out what she wants."

mɪn tʊk əɹ taɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp, ən dʒɹæɡd əɹ fit tə ðə dɔɹz. ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə θɪŋk ðɪs ə bæɾ aɪdiə. əɹ ət lis tə wɑnə bi ɛlswɛɹ wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn feɪs kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn. dɑbɹeɪn pæst əɹ ɑn ðə weɪ tə ðə dɔɹ, meɪkɪŋ ə heɪsti baʊ wɪð bɛɹli ə pɔz, ən ivən mɛɹænə ən ɹæfɛlə wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪɾ əpɪɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hɝiɪŋ. ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, ðeɪ dɪd, ɛniweɪ. wən mɪn pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ, ðə tu sɪstɝz hæd kɑt dɑbɹeɪn ən wɝ skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ət lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə tʃɹɑt.

Min took her time getting up, and dragged her feet to the doors. She was not the only one to think this a bad idea. Or at least to want to be elsewhere when the Dragon Reborn faced Cadsuane Melaidhrin. Dobraine passed her on the way to the door, making a hasty bow with barely a pause, and even Merana and Rafela were out of the room before her, though they made it appear they were not hurrying. Inside the room, they did, anyway. When Min put her head into the hallway, the two sisters had caught Dobraine and were scurrying along at little short of a trot.

stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə hæf-dʌzən meɪɾənz u hæd bɪn aʊtsaɪd wən mɪn ɛntɝɾ ɝliɝ hæd naʊ ɡɹoʊn ɪn nʌmbɝ əntɪl ðeɪ laɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd si ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz, tɔl hɑɹd-feɪst wɪmən ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪz ən bɹaʊnz ən ɡɹeɪz ə ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ, ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz wɪð ðə lɔŋ blæk veɪl hæŋɪŋ daʊn. ə ɡʊd mɛni kæɹid ðɛɹ spɪɹz ən bʊl-haɪd bʌklɝz əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə bæɾəl. səm wɝ pleɪɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ-ɡeɪm kɔld "naɪf, peɪpɝ, stoʊn," ən ðə ɹɛst wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ɪntɛnli.

Strangely, the half-dozen Maidens who had been outside when Min entered earlier had now grown in number until they lined the corridor as far as she could see in both directions, tall hard-faced women in the grays and browns and grays of the cadin'sor, shoufa wrapped around their heads with the long black veil hanging down. A good many carried their spears and bull-hide bucklers as if they expected a battle. Some were playing a finger-game called "knife, paper, stone," and the rest were watching intently.

nɑt soʊ ɪntɛnli ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si hɝ, ðoʊ. wən ʃi pæst ɹændz mɛsədʒ, hæntɔk flæʃt ʌp ən daʊn ðə ɹoʊz, ðən tu læŋki meɪɾənz wɛn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɔf. ði ʌðɝz pɹɑmpli ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ɡeɪm, pleɪɪŋ əɹ wɑtʃɪŋ.

Not so intently that they did not see her, though. When she passed Rand's message, handtalk flashed up and down the rows, then two lanky Maidens went trotting off. The others promptly returned to the game, playing or watching.

skɹætʃɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn pʌzəlmənt, mɪn wɛn bæk ɪn. ðə meɪɾənz ɔfən meɪɾ əɹ nɝvəs, jɛt ðeɪ ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə wɝd fəɹ hɝ, səmtaɪmz ɹɪspɛkfəl, əz tə ə waɪz wʌn, səmtaɪmz dʒoʊkɪŋ, ðoʊ ðɛɹ hjumɝ wɑz ɑd, tə seɪ ðə list. nɛvɝ hæd ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ laɪk ðɪs.

Scratching her head in puzzlement, Min went back in. The Maidens often made her nervous, yet they always had a word for her, sometimes respectful, as to a Wise One, sometimes joking, though their humor was odd, to say the least. Never had they ignored her like this.

ɹænd wɑz ɪn ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ðət sɪmpəl fæk sɛɾ əɹ hɑɹt ɹeɪsɪŋ. hi hæɾ ɪz koʊɾ ɔf, hɪz snoʊi ʃɝɾ ənleɪst ət nɛk ən kʌfs ən pʊld aʊɾ ə hɪz bɹitʃɪz. sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛd, ʃi lin bæk əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə hɛvi blækwʊd bɪdpoʊsts ən swʌŋ əɹ fiɾ ʌp, kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ æŋkəlz. ʃi hæd nɑt hæɾ ə tʃæns tə wɑtʃ ɹænd əndʒɹɛs hɪmsɛlf, ən ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɛndʒɔɪ ɪt.

Rand was in the bedchamber. That simple fact set her heart racing. He had his coat off, his snowy shirt unlaced at neck and cuffs and pulled out of his breeches. Sitting on the foot of the bed, she leaned back against one of the heavy blackwood bedposts and swung her feet up, crossing her ankles. She had not had a chance to watch Rand undress himself, and she intended to enjoy it.

ɪnstɛɾ ə kəntɪnjuɪŋ, ðoʊ, hi stʊd ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. "wʌt kən kædzueɪn pɑsəbli titʃ mi?" hi æsk sʌɾənli.

Instead of continuing, though, he stood there looking at her. "What can Cadsuane possibly teach me?" he asked suddenly.

"ju, ən ɔl ði æʃəmən," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. ðət hæd bɪn əɹ vjuɪŋ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt, ɹænd. aɪ oʊnli noʊ juv tə lɝn ɪt. ɔl ə jə du." ɪt dɪd nɑt sim i ɪntɛndəd tə pɹəɡɹɛs bɪɑn lɛɾɪŋ ɪz ʃɝt hæŋ daʊn. saɪɪŋ, ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ju nid hɝ, ɹænd. jə kæn əfɔɹd tə meɪk əɹ æŋɡɹi. jə kæn əfɔɹd tə tʃeɪs əɹ əweɪ." æktʃəli , ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk fɪfti mɹdʒɹɑl ən ə θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks kəd tʃeɪs kædzueɪn ɛniwɛɹ, bʌt ðə pɔɪnt wɑz ðə seɪm.

"You, and all the Asha'man," she replied. That had been her viewing. "I don't know what, Rand. I only know you have to learn it. All of you do." It did not seem he intended to progress beyond letting his shirt hang down. Sighing, she went on. "You need her, Rand. You can't afford to make her angry. You can't afford to chase her away." Actually, she did not think fifty Myrddraal and a thousand Trollocs could chase Cadsuane anywhere, but the point was the same.

ə fɑɹ-ɔf lʊk keɪm ɪndə ɹændz aɪz, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ lɪsən tə ə mædmæn?" hi mʌɾɝd ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. laɪt, dɪɾ i ɹɪli bɪliv luz θɝɪn tɛləmən spoʊk ɪn ɪz hɛd? "lɛt sʌmwʌn noʊ jə nid ðɛm, mɪn, ən ðeɪv ə hoʊld ɑn ju. ə liʃ, tə pʊl jə wɛɹ ðeɪ wɑnt. aɪ woʊn pʊɾ ə hɔltɝ ɑn maɪ oʊn nɛk fəɹ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑt fəɹ ɛniwʌn!" sloʊli hɪz fɪsts ənklɛntʃt. "ju, aɪ nid, mɪn," hi sɛd sɪmpli. "nɑt fəɹ jəɹ vjuɪŋz. aɪ dʒʌs nid ju."

A far-off look came into Rand's eyes, and after a moment, he shook his head. "Why should I listen to a madman?" he muttered almost under his breath. Light, did he really believe Lews Therin Telamon spoke in his head? "Let someone know you need them, Min, and they have a hold on you. A leash, to pull you where they want. I won't put a halter on my own neck for any Aes Sedai. Not for anyone!" Slowly his fists unclenched. "You, I need, Min," he said simply. "Not for your viewings. I just need you."

bɝn hɝ, bʌt ðə mæn kəd swip əɹ fiɾ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ wɪð ə fju wɝdz!

Burn her, but the man could sweep her feet out from under her with a few words!

wɪð ə smaɪl əz iɡɝ əz hɝz, hi ɡɹæsp ðə bɑɾəm ə hɪz ʃɝt wɪð boʊθ hænz ən bɛn tə bɪɡɪn hɔlɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. lɑsɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz oʊvɝ əɹ stʌmək, ʃi sɛɾəld bæk tə wɑtʃ.

With a smile as eager as hers, he grasped the bottom of his shirt with both hands and bent to begin hauling it over his head. Lacing her fingers over her stomach, she settled back to watch.

ðə θɹi meɪɾənz u mɑɹtʃt ɪndə ðə ɹum noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ ðə ʃoʊufə ðət hæd kənsil ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt hɛɹ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɛmpti-hændəd, ən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ ðoʊz hɛvi-bleɪd bɛl naɪvz, iðɝ. ðət wɑz ɔl mɪn hæd taɪm tə noʊɾəs.

The three Maidens who marched into the room no longer wore the shoufa that had concealed their short hair in the corridor. They were empty-handed, and no longer wore those heavy-blade belt knives, either. That was all Min had time to notice.

ɹændz hɛɾ ən ɑɹmz wɝ stɪl ɪnsaɪd ðə ʃɝt, ən soʊmɑɹə, fleɪksən-hɛɹɾ ən tɔl ivən fəɹ ən il wʊmən, siz ðə waɪt lɪnən ən tæŋɡəld ɪt, tʃɹæpɪŋ hɪm. ɔlmoʊst ɪn ðə seɪm muvmənt, ʃi kɪkt ɪm bɪtwin ðə lɛɡz. wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ɡɹoʊn, hi bɛn fɑɹðɝ, stæɡɝɪŋ.

Rand's head and arms were still inside the shirt, and Somara, flaxen-haired and tall even for an Aiel woman, seized the white linen and tangled it, trapping him. Almost in the same movement, she kicked him between the legs. With a strangled groan, he bent farther, staggering.

nəsɹ, faɪɝi-hɛɹɾ ən bjuɾəfəl dɪspaɪt waɪt skɑɹz ɑn boʊθ sʌn-dɑɹk tʃiks, plæntəɾ ə fɪst ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt saɪd hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm stʌmbəl saɪdweɪz.

Nesair, fiery-haired and beautiful despite white scars on both sun-dark cheeks, planted a fist in his right side hard enough to make him stumble sideways.

wɪð ə kɹaɪ, mɪn lɔntʃt hɝsɛlf fɹəm ðə bɛd. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt mædnəs wɑz hæpənɪŋ hɪɹ, kəd nɑɾ ivən bɪɡɪn tə ɡɛs. wʌn ə hɝ naɪvz keɪm smuðli fɹəm itʃ sliv, ən ʃi θɹu hɝsɛlf ət ðə meɪɾənz, ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "hɛlp! oʊ, ɹænd! sʌmbɑɾi, hɛlp!" ət list, ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃaʊt.

With a cry, Min launched herself from the bed. She did not know what madness was happening here, could not even begin to guess. One of her knives came smoothly from each sleeve, and she threw herself at the Maidens, shouting, "Help! Oh, Rand! Somebody, help!" At least, that was what she tried to shout.

ðə θɝd meɪɾən, nændɛɹə, tɝn laɪk ə sneɪk, ən mɪn faʊn ə fʊt plæntəɾ ɪn əɹ stʌmək. bɹɛθ ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ə hɝ ɪn ə wiz. hɝ naɪvz flu fɹəm nʌm hænz, ən ʃi tɝn ə sʌmɝsɔl oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ meɪɾənz fʊt, lændɪŋ ɑn əɹ bæk wɪð ə kɹæʃ ðət dʒɹoʊv aʊt wʌt lɪɾəl ɛɹ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn hɝ. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə muv, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹið - tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʌndɝstænd! - ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz laɪ ðəɹ ən wɑtʃ.

The third Maiden, Nandera, turned like a snake, and Min found a foot planted in her stomach. Breath rushed out of her in a wheeze. Her knives flew from numb hands, and she turned a somersault over the graying Maiden's foot, landing on her back with a crash that drove out what little air remained in her. Trying to move, trying to breathe - trying to understand! - all she could do was lie there and watch.

ðə θɹi wɪmən wɝ kwaɪt θɝoʊ. nəsɹ ən nændɛɹə paʊndɪd ɹænd wɪð ðɛɹ fɪsts waɪl soʊmɑɹə hɛld ɪm bɛn oʊvɝ ən kɑɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn ʃɝt. əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ðeɪ dʒɹoʊv stʌɾid bloʊz ɪndə ɹændz hɑɹd bɛli, ɪndə hɪz ɹaɪt saɪd. mɪn wʊɾə læf hɪstɛɹɪkli, hæd ʃi hæɾ ɛni bɹɛθ. ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə biɾ ɪm tə dɛθ, ən ðeɪ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli əvɔɪd hɪɾɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ ðə tɛndɝ ɹaʊn skɑɹ ɪn ɪz lɛf saɪd wɪð ðə hæf-hil slæʃ ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ɪt.

The three women were quite thorough. Nesair and Nandera pounded Rand with their fists while Somara held him bent over and caught in his own shirt. Again and again and again they drove studied blows into Rand's hard belly, into his right side. Min would have laughed hysterically, had she had any breath. They were trying to beat him to death, and they very carefully avoid hitting anywhere near the tender round scar in his left side with the half-healed slash running through it.

ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl haʊ hɑɹd ɹændz bɑɾi wɑz, haʊ stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəd stæn ʌp tə ðæt. sloʊli, hɪz niz foʊldəd, ən wən ðeɪ θʌmp tə ðə flɔɹ taɪlz, nændɛɹə ən nəsɹ stʊd bæk. itʃ nɑɾəd, ən soʊmɑɹə ɹilist əɹ hoʊld ɑn ɹændz ʃɝt. hi fɛl fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. ʃi kəd hɪɹ ɪm ɡæspɪŋ, faɪɾɪŋ ɡɹoʊnz ðət bʌbəld ʌp dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɛfɝts. nilɪŋ, soʊmɑɹə pʊld ɪz ʃɝt daʊn ɔlmoʊs tɛndɝli. hi leɪ ðəɹ wɪð ɪz tʃik ɑn ðə flɔɹ, aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ.

She knew very well how hard Rand's body was, how strong, but no one could stand up to that. Slowly, his knees folded, and when they thumped to the floor tiles, Nandera and Nesair stood back. Each nodded, and Somara released her hold on Rand's shirt. He fell forward on his face. She could hear him gasping, fighting groans that bubbled up despite his efforts. Kneeling, Somara pulled his shirt down almost tenderly. He lay there with his cheek on the floor, eyes bulging, struggling for breath.

nəsɹ bɛn tə kætʃ ə fɪsfəl ə hɪz hɛɹ ən dʒɝk ɪz hɛɾ ʌp. "wi wʌn ðə ɹaɪt fəɹ ðɪs," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, "bʌɾ ɛvɹi meɪɾən wɑntəd tə leɪ hɝ hænz ɑn ju. aɪ lɛf maɪ klæn fəɹ ju, ɹænd ælθɹ. əl nɑɾ əv jə spɪɾ ɑn mi!"

Nesair bent to catch a fistful of his hair and jerk his head up. "We won the right for this," she growled, "but every Maiden wanted to lay her hands on you. I left my clan for you, Rand al'Thor. I will not have you spit on me!"

soʊmɑɹə muvd ə hæn əz ɪf tə smuð hɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs, ðən snætʃt ɪt bæk. "ðɪs ɪz haʊ wi tʃɹiɾ ə fɝst-bɹʌðɝ u dɪsɑnɝz ʌs, ɹænd ælθɹ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "ðə fɝs taɪm. ðə nɛkst, wɪl juz stʃɹæps."

Somara moved a hand as if to smooth hair out of his face, then snatched it back. "This is how we treat a first-brother who dishonors us, Rand al'Thor," she said firmly. "The first time. The next, we will use straps."

nændɛɹə stʊɾ oʊvɝ ɹænd wɪð fɪs plæntəɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps ən ə feɪs ə stoʊn. "ju kæɹi ði ɑnɝ ə fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, sʌn ʌv ə meɪɾən," ʃi sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "ju pɹɑməs tə kɔl əs tə dæns ðə spɪɹz fəɹ ju, ən ðən jə ɹæn tə bæɾəl ən lɛft əs bɪhaɪnd. jəl nɑt də ðɪs əɡɛn."

Nandera stood over Rand with fist planted on her hips and a face of stone. "You carry the honor of Far Dareis Mai, son of a Maiden," she said grimly. "You promised to call us to dance the spears for you, and then you ran to battle and left us behind. You will not do this again."

ʃi stɛpt oʊvɝ ɪm tə stʃɹaɪɾ aʊt, ən ði ʌðɝ tu fɑloʊd. oʊnli soʊmɑɹə ɡlæns bæk, ən ɪf sɪmpəθi tʌtʃt əɹ blu aɪz, ðəɹ wɑz nʌn ɪn əɹ vɔɪs wən ʃi sɛd, "du nɑt meɪk ðɪs nɛsəsɛɹi əɡɛn, sʌn ʌv ə meɪɾən."

She stepped over him to stride out, and the other two followed. Only Somara glanced back, and if sympathy touched her blue eyes, there was none in her voice when she said, "Do not make this necessary again, son of a Maiden."

ɹænd hæd pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ʌp tə hænz ən niz baɪ ðə taɪm mɪn mænədʒ tə kɹɔl tə hɪm. "ðeɪ mʌs bi mæd," ʃi kɹoʊkt. laɪt, bʌɾ əɹ mɪɾəl hɝt! "ɹəɑɹk wɪl - !" ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ɹəɑɹk wəd du. nɑɾ ɪnʌf, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz. "sɔɹɪliə." sɔɹɪliə wəd steɪk əm aʊɾ ɪn ðə sʌn! tə stɑɹt! "wɛn wi tɛl əɹ - "

Rand had pushed himself up to hands and knees by the time Min managed to crawl to him. "They must be mad," she croaked. Light, but her middle hurt! "Rhuarc will - !" She did not know what Rhuarc would do. Not enough, whatever it was. "Sorilea." Sorilea would stake them out in the sun! To start! "When we tell her - "

"wi tɛl noʊ wʌn," hi sɛd. hi ɔlmoʊst saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪz bɹɛθ bæk, ɔlðoʊ hi wɑz stɪl slaɪtli pɑp-aɪd. haʊ kəɾ i də ðæt? "ðeɪ hæv ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪv ɝn ðə ɹaɪt."

"We tell no one," he said. He almost sounded as if he had his breath back, although he was still slightly pop-eyed. How could he do that? "They have the right. They've earned the right."

mɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət toʊn mʌtʃ tə wɛl. wən ə mæn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bi stʌbɝn, hi wəd sɪt bɛɹ ɪn ə nɛɾəl pætʃ ən dɪnaɪ tə jəɹ feɪs ðət ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪz bɑɾəm stɪŋ! ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊs pliz tə hɪɹ ɪm ɡɹoʊn əz ʃi hɛlpt ɪm tə hɪz fit. wɛl, əz ðeɪ hɛlpt itʃ ʌðɝ. ɪf i wɑz gɑnə bi ə pjʊɹ wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət, hi dɪzɝvd ə fju bɹuzəz!

Min recognized that tone much to well. When a man decided to be stubborn, he would sit bare in a nettle patch and deny to your face that they made his bottom sting! She was almost pleased to hear him groan as she helped him to his feet. Well, as they helped each other. If he was going to be a pure wool-headed idiot, he deserved a few bruises!

hi iz hɪmsɛlf ɑntu ðə bɛd, laɪɪŋ bæk ɑn ðə hipt pɪloʊz, ən ʃi snʌɡəld ɪn bɪsaɪd hɪm. nɑt wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊpɪŋ fɔɹ, bʌɾ əz mʌtʃ əz wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ.

He eased himself onto the bed, lying back on the heaped pillows, and she snuggled in beside him. Not what she had been hoping for, but as much as was going to happen, she was sure.

"nɑt wʌɾ aɪ wɑz hoʊpɪŋ tə juz ðɪs bɛd fɔɹ," hi mʌɾɝd. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd bɪn səpoʊz tə hɪɹ.

"Not what I was hoping to use this bed for," he muttered. She was not sure she had been supposed to hear.

ʃi læft. "aɪ ɛndʒɔɪ jə hoʊldɪŋ mi dʒʌst əz mʌtʃ əz . . . əz ði ʌðɝ." stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi smaɪld əɾ əɹ əz ɪf i nu ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ. hɝ æn mɹən kleɪm ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɹi laɪz ɛni mæn wəd bɪliv fɹəm ə wʊmən.

She laughed. "I enjoy you holding me just as much as . . . as the other." Strangely, he smiled at her as if he knew she was lying. Her Aunt Miren claimed that was one of the three lies any man would believe from a woman.

"ɪf aɪm ɪntɝʌptɪŋ," ə wʊmənz kul vɔɪs sɛd fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ, "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kəd ɹɪtɝn wən ɪts mɔɹ kənvinjənt."

"If I am interrupting," a woman's cool voice said from the doorway, "I suppose I could return when it is more convenient."

mɪn dʒɝkt əweɪ fɹəm ɹænd əz ðoʊ bɝnd, bʌt wən i pʊld əɹ bæk, ʃi sɛɾəld əɡɛnst ɪm əɡɛn. ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ə plʌmp lɪɾəl kɛɹhinɪn wɪð fɔɹ θɪn stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs əɹ fʊl bʊzəm ən waɪt slæʃɪz ɪn əɹ dɑɹk skɝts. deɪdʒiən moʊsənilɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz u hæd kʌm wɪð kædzueɪn. ən ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz oʊvɝbɛɹɪŋ əz kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf, ɪn mɪnz əpɪnjən.

Min jerked away from Rand as though burned, but when he pulled her back, she settled against him again. She recognized the Aes Sedai standing in the doorway, a plump little Cairhienin with four thin stripes of color across her full bosom and white slashes in her dark skirts. Daigian Moseneillin was one of the sisters who had come with Cadsuane. And she was almost as overbearing as Cadsuane herself, in Min's opinion.

"hu maɪt jə bi wən jəɹ ət hoʊm?" ɹænd sɛd læzəli. "huɛvɝ jə ɑɹ, dɪdn ɛniwʌn ɛvɝ titʃ jə tə nɑk?" mɪn ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛvɹi mʌsəl ɪn ði ɑɹm hoʊldɪŋ əɹ wɑz hɑɹɾ əz ə ɹɑk, ðoʊ.

"Who might you be when you're at home?" Rand said lazily. "Whoever you are, didn't anyone ever teach you to knock?" Min realized that every muscle in the arm holding her was hard as a rock, though.

ðə munstoʊn dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑntu deɪdʒiənz fɔɹhɛɾ ɑn ə θɪn sɪlvɝ tʃeɪn swʌŋ əz ʃi sloʊli ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. pleɪnli, ʃi wɑz nɑt plizd. "kædzueɪn sədaɪ ɹəsiv jəɹ ɹɪkwɛst," ʃi sɛd, ivən mɔɹ kuli ðən bɪfɔɹ, "æn æsk mi tə kənveɪ hɝ ɹɪɡɹɛts. ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɪʃɪz tə fɪnɪʃ ðə pis ə niɾəlpɔɪnt ʃiz wɝkɪŋ ɑn. pɝhæps ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə si jə ənʌðɝ deɪ. ɪf ʃi kən faɪn taɪm."

The moonstone dangling onto Daigian's forehead on a thin silver chain swung as she slowly shook her head. Plainly, she was not pleased. "Cadsuane Sedai received your request," she said, even more coolly than before, "and asked me to convey her regrets. She very much wishes to finish the piece of needlepoint she is working on. Perhaps she might be able to see you another day. If she can find time."

"ɪz ðət wʌt ʃi sɛd?" ɹænd æsk deɪnʒɝəsli.

"Is that what she said?" Rand asked dangerously.

deɪdʒiən snɪf dɪsdeɪnfəli. "aɪ wɪl liv jə tə ɹɪzum . . . wʌtɛvɝ jə wɝ duɪŋ." mɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð slæpɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. deɪdʒiən aɪɾ əɹ fɹɔstəli, əz ɪf hɪɹɪŋ ðə θɔt, ən tɝn tə ɡlaɪd fɹəm ðə ɹum.

Daigian sniffed disdainfully. "I will leave you to resume . . . whatever you were doing." Min wondered whether she could get away with slapping an Aes Sedai. Daigian eyed her frostily, as if hearing the thought, and turned to glide from the room.

ɹænd sæɾ ʌp wɪð ə mʌfəld oʊθ. "ju tɛl kædzueɪn ʃi kən ɡoʊ tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum!" hi ʃaʊɾəd æftɝ ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ sɪstɝ. "tɛl əɹ ʃi kən ɹɑt!"

Rand sat up with a muffled oath. "You tell Cadsuane she can go to the Pit of Doom!" he shouted after the retreating sister. "Tell her she can rot!"

"ɪt woʊn du, ɹænd," mɪn saɪd. ðɪs wɑz gɑnə bi hɑɹɾɝ ðən ʃi hæd θɔt. "ju nid kædzueɪn. ʃi dʌznt nid ju."

"It won't do, Rand," Min sighed. This was going to be harder than she had thought. "You need Cadsuane. She doesn't need you."

"dʌznt ʃi?" hi sɛd sɔfli, ən ʃi ʃɪvɝd. ʃi hæɾ oʊnli θɔɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz deɪnʒɝəs bɪfɔɹ.

"Doesn't she?" he said softly, and she shivered. She had only thought his voice was dangerous before.

ɹænd pɹipɛɹd kɛɹfəli, dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹin koʊɾ əɡɛn, sɛndɪŋ mɪn wɪð mɛsədʒəz fəɹ ðə meɪɾənz tə kæɹi. ət lis ðeɪ wəd stɪl də ðæt. hɪz ɹɪbz ætʃt ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt saɪɾ əz ðə wunz dɪɾ ɑn ɪz lɛft, ən ɪz bɛli fɛlt əz i hæd bɪn biɾən wɪð ə bɔɹd. hi hæd pɹɑməs ðɛm. hi siz hoʊld ə seɪɾɪn əloʊn ɪn ɪz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ənwɪlɪŋ tə lɛɾ ivən mɪn si hɪm fɔltɝ əɡɛn. hi kəd kip əɹ seɪf, ət list, sʌmhaʊ, bʌt haʊ kəd ʃi fil seɪf ɪf ʃi sɔ hɪm əbaʊt tə fɔl oʊvɝ? hi hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ, fəɹ əɹ seɪk. hi hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ, fəɹ ðə wɝld. ðət bʌndəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd ðət wɑz ɑlɑnə ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə ðə kɑst ə kɛɹləsnəs. ɹaɪt ðɛn, ɑlɑnə wɑz sʌlkɪŋ. ʃi mʌst əv pʊʃt ə waɪz wʌn tu fɑɹ, kəz ɪf ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ, ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ dʒɪnʒɝli.

Rand prepared carefully, dressing in the green coat again, sending Min with messages for the Maidens to carry. At least they would still do that. His ribs ached almost as much on his right side as the wounds did on his left, and his belly felt as he had been beaten with a board. He had promised them. He seized hold of saidin alone in his bedchamber, unwilling to let even Min see him falter again. He could keep her safe, at least, somehow, but how could she feel safe if she saw him about to fall over? He had to be strong, for her sake. He had to be strong, for the world. That bundle of emotions in the back of his head that was Alanna reminded him of the cost of carelessness. Right then, Alanna was sulking. She must have pushed a Wise One too far, because if she was sitting, she was sitting gingerly.

"aɪ stɪl θɪŋk ðɪs ɪz lunəsi, ɹænd ælθɹ," mɪn sɛɾ əz i pleɪs ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz kɛɹfəli ɑn ɪz hɛd. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðoʊz taɪni bleɪdz tə dʒɹɔ blʌɾ əɡɛn naʊ. "ɑɹ jə lɪsnɪŋ tə mi? wɛl, ɪf jə ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ θɹu wɪð ɪt, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju. jə ədmɪɾəd jə nid mi, ən jəl nid mi mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ fəɹ ðɪs!" ʃi wɑz ɪn fʊl fɪɡ, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, fʊt tæpɪŋ, aɪz ɔl bʌt ɡloʊɪŋ.

"I still think this is lunacy, Rand al'Thor," Min said as he placed the Crown of Swords carefully on his head. He did not want those tiny blades to draw blood again now. "Are you listening to me? Well, if you intend to go through with it, I'm going with you. You admitted you need me, and you'll need me more than ever for this!" She was in full fig, fists on her hips, foot tapping, eyes all but glowing.

"jɔɹ steɪɪŋ hɪɹ," hi toʊld əɹ fɝmli. hi wɑz stɪl nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə du, nɑt fʊli, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə si hɪm stʌmbəl. hi wɑz vɛɹi əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt stʌmbəl. hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ɑɹɡjəmənt, ðoʊ.

"You're staying here," he told her firmly. He was still not sure what he intended to do, not fully, and he did not want her to see him stumble. He was very afraid he might stumble. He expected an argument, though.

ʃi fɹaʊn ət hɪm, ən əɹ fʊt stɑp tæpɪŋ. ði æŋɡɹi laɪɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz feɪɾəd ɪndə wɝi ðət vænɪʃt ɪn ə twɪŋkəlɪŋ. "wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ oʊld ɪnʌf tə kɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɪθaʊt jəɹ hæn hɛld, ʃifɝɾɝ. bɪsaɪdz, aɪm fɔlɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪn maɪ ɹɛɾɪŋ."

She frowned at him, and her foot stopped tapping. The angry light in her eyes faded into worry that vanished in a twinkling. "Well, I suppose you're old enough to cross the stableyard without your hand held, sheepherder. Besides, I am falling behind in my reading."

dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə tɔl ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹz, ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ lɛɡz bɪniθ əɹ ən pɪkt ʌp ðə bʊk ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɛɾɪŋ wən i keɪm ɪn. ɪn moʊməns, ʃi sim toʊɾəli ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ðə peɪdʒ bɪfɔɹ hɝ.

Dropping into one of the tall gilded chairs, she folded her legs beneath her and picked up the book she had been reading when he came in. In moments, she seemed totally engrossed in the page before her.

ɹænd nɑɾəd. ðət wɑz wʌɾ i wɑntəd; hɝ hɪɹ, ən seɪf. stɪl, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə fɝɡɛɾ ɪm soʊ kəmplitli.

Rand nodded. That was what he wanted; her here, and safe. Still, she did not have to forget him so completely.

ðəɹ wɝ sɪks meɪɾənz skwɑɾɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz dɔɹ. ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm flæt-aɪd, nɑt spikɪŋ, nændɛɹəz ɡeɪz ðə flæɾəst ʌv ɔl. ðoʊ soʊmɑɹə ən nəsɹ keɪm kloʊs. hi θɔt nəsɹ wɑz ʃeɪɾoʊ; hi wəɾ əv tə kip ə hɑɹɾ aɪ ɑn hɝ.

There were six Maidens squatting in the hallway outside his door. They stared at him flat-eyed, not speaking, Nandera's gaze the flattest of all. Though Somara and Nesair came close. He thought Nesair was Shaido; he would have to keep a hard eye on her.

ði æʃəmən wɝ weɪɾɪŋ, tu - luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝd dɑɹkli ʌv kɪlɪŋ ɪn ɹændz hɛd - ɔl bʌt nɛɹɪʃmə wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɑn ðɛɹ kɑlɝz əz wɛl əz ðə sɔɹd. kɝtli, hi ɔɹɾɝd nɛɹɪʃmə tə stænd ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ɪz əpɑɹtməns, ən ðə mæn səluɾəd ʃɑɹpli, ðoʊz dɑɹk tu-bɪɡ aɪz siɪŋ tu mʌtʃ, feɪnli əkjuzɪŋ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə meɪɾənz wəd teɪk aʊt ðɛɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ ɑn mɪn, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt teɪkɪŋ ɛni tʃænsəz. laɪt, hi hæd toʊl nɛɹɪʃmə ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃɹæps i hæd woʊvən ɪn ðə stoʊn wən i sɛn ðə mæn tə fɛtʃ kælændɝ. ðə mæn wɑz ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz. bɝn hɪm, bʌt ðət hæd bɪn ə mæd ɹɪsk tə teɪk.

The Asha'man were waiting, too - Lews Therin muttered darkly of killing in Rand's head - all but Narishma with the Dragon on their collars as well as the Sword. Curtly, he ordered Narishma to stand guard on his apartments, and the man saluted sharply, those dark too-big eyes seeing too much, faintly accusing. Rand did not think the Maidens would take out their displeasure on Min, but he was not taking any chances. Light, he had told Narishma everything about the traps he had woven in the Stone when he sent the man to fetch Callandor. The man was imagining things. Burn him, but that had been a mad risk to take.

oʊnli mædmən nɛvɝ tʃɹʌst. luz θɝɪn saʊndəɾ əmjuzd. ən kwaɪt mæd. ðə wunz ɪn ɹændz saɪd θɹɑbd; ðeɪ sim tə ɹɛzəneɪt wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ ɪn dɪstən peɪn.

Only madmen never trust. Lews Therin sounded amused. And quite mad. The wounds in Rand's side throbbed; they seemed to resonate with each other in distant pain.

"ʃoʊ mi wɛɹ tə faɪn kædzueɪn," hi kəmændəd. nændɛɹə ɹoʊz smuðli tə hɝ fiɾ ən stɑɹɾəd ɔf wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝd ɡlæns. hi fɑloʊd, ən ði ʌðɝz fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn hɪm, dæʃivə ən flɪn, mɔɹ ən hɑpwəl. hi ɡeɪv əm heɪsti ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz əz ðeɪ wɔkt. flɪn, ʌv ɔl pipəl, tʃɹaɪd tə pɹoʊtɛst, bʌt ɹænd bɔɹ ɪm daʊn; ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ kweɪlɪŋ. ðə ɡɹɪzəld wʌntaɪm ɡɑɹdzmæn wɑz ðə læst ɹænd hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪɾ ʌv. mɔɹ əɹ hɑpwəl, pɝhæps. ɪf noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzækli dui-aɪd, ðeɪ wɝ stɪl jʌŋ ɪnʌf tə liv ðɛɹ ɹeɪzɝz dʒɹaɪ əz mɛni deɪz əz wɛt. bʌt nɑt flɪn. nændɛɹəz sɑf buts meɪd noʊ saʊnd; ðɛɹ fʊtstɛps ɹɪvɝbɝeɪɾɪd fɹəm ðə haɪ skwɛɹ-vɔltəd silɪŋ, tʃeɪsɪŋ əweɪ ɛvɹiwʌn wɪð ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ə ɹizən fəɹ fɪɹ. hɪz wunz pʌlsd.

"Show me where to find Cadsuane," he commanded. Nandera rose smoothly to her feet and started off without a backward glance. He followed, and the others fell in behind him, Dashiva and Flinn, Morr and Hopwil. He gave them hasty instructions as they walked. Flinn, of all people, tried to protest, but Rand bore him down; this was no time for quailing. The grizzled onetime Guardsman was the last Rand had expected it of. Morr or Hopwil, perhaps. If no longer exactly dewy-eyed, they were still young enough to leave their razors dry as many days as wet. But not Flinn. Nandera's soft boots made no sound; their footsteps reverberated from the high square-vaulted ceiling, chasing away everyone with the shadow of a reason for fear. His wounds pulsed.

ɛvɹi læs pɝsən ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs nu ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɑn saɪt baɪ naʊ, ən ðeɪ nu hu ðə blæk-koʊɾəd mɛn wɝ, tu. blæk-lɪvɹid sɝvəns meɪd dip baʊz əɹ kɝtsiz, ən hɝid tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz saɪt. moʊs noʊbəlz wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪk tə pʊt dɪstəns bɪtwin ðɛmsɛlvz ən faɪv mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, ɡoʊɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ wɪð pɝpəs ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. eɪlɪl wɑtʃt əm pæs wɪð ən ənɹiɾəbəl ɪkspɹɛʃən. ænɑiɛlə sɪmpɝd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt wən ɹænd ɡlæns bæk, ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ æftɝ ɪm wɪð ə feɪs tə mætʃ nændɛɹəz. bɝtoʊm smaɪld əz i meɪɾ ɪz lɛɡ, ə dɑɹk smaɪl wɪð niðɝ mɝθ nɔɹ plɛʒɝ ɪn ɪt.

Every last person in the Sun Palace knew the Dragon Reborn on sight by now, and they knew who the black-coated men were, too. Black-liveried servants made deep bows or curtsies, and hurried to get out of his sight. Most nobles were almost as quick to put distance between themselves and five men who could channel, going somewhere with purpose on their faces. Ailil watched them pass with an unreadable expression. Anaiyella simpered, of course, but when Rand glanced back, she was staring after him with a face to match Nandera's. Bertome smiled as he made his leg, a dark smile with neither mirth nor pleasure in it.

nændɛɹə dɪd nɑt spik ivən wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðɛɹ dɛstəneɪʃən, mɪɹli pɔɪntəd tə ə kloʊz dɔɹ wɪð wʌn ə hɝ spɪɹz, tɝn ɑn əɹ hil, ən stʃɹoʊd bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn wɪθaʊɾ ə sɪŋɡəl meɪɾən tə ɡɑɹd hɪm. dɪd ðeɪ θɪŋk fɔɹ æʃəmən ɪnʌf tə kip ɪm seɪf? əɹ wɑz əɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ ənʌðɝ saɪn ə dɪsplɛʒɝ?

Nandera did not speak even when they reached their destination, merely pointed to a closed door with one of her spears, turned on her heel, and strode back the way they had come. The Car'a'carn without a single Maiden to guard him. Did they think four Asha'man enough to keep him safe? Or was her departure another sign of displeasure?

"du wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju," ɹænd sɛd.

"Do what I told you," Rand said.

dæʃivə ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk əz ɪf kʌmɪŋ bæk tə hɪmsɛlf, ðən siz ðə sɔɹs. ðə waɪd dɔɹ, kɑɹvd ɪn vɝɾɪkəl laɪnz, swʌŋ oʊpən wɪð ə bæŋ ɑn ə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ θɹi tʊk hoʊld ə seɪɾɪn ən fɑloʊd dæʃivə ɪn, feɪsəz ɡɹɪm.

Dashiva gave a jerk as if coming back to himself, then seized the Source. The wide door, carved in vertical lines, swung open with a bang on a flow of Air. The other three took hold of saidin and followed Dashiva in, faces grim.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," dæʃivəz vɔɪs saʊndəd laʊd, mæɡnəfaɪd slaɪtli baɪ ðə paʊɝ, "ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, kʌmz tə si ðə wʊmən, kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn."

"The Dragon Reborn," Dashiva's voice sounded loud, magnified slightly by the Power, "the King of Illian, the Lord of the Morning, comes to see the woman, Cadsuane Melaidhrin."

ɹænd stɛpt ɪn, stændɪŋ tɔl. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ði ʌðɝ wiv dæʃivə hæd kɹieɪɾəd, bʌt ði ɛɹ sim tə hʌm wɪð mɛnəs, ə sɛns ə sʌmθɪŋ ɪnɛksɝəbəl əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɛvɝ nɪɹɝ.

Rand stepped in, standing tall. He did not recognize the other weave Dashiva had created, but the air seemed to hum with menace, a sense of something inexorable approaching, drawing ever nearer.

"aɪ sɛn fəɹ ju, kædzueɪn," ɹænd sɛd. hi dɪd nɑt juz wivz. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɑɹɾ ən flæɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊɾ eɪd.

"I sent for you, Cadsuane," Rand said. He did not use weaves. His voice was hard and flat enough without aid.

ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd sæt bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl teɪbəl wɪð ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ɪn əɹ hænz, ən oʊpən bæskəɾ ɑn ðə pɑlɪʃt teɪbəltɑp spɪlɪŋ aʊt sknz ə bɹaɪt θɹɛd fɹəm səm ʌv ɪts mɛni kəmpɑɹtməns. ʃi wɑz ɪɡzækli əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðət stʃɹɔŋ feɪs tɑp baɪ ən aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ bʌn dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð smɔl dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɡoʊldən fɪʃ ən bɝdz, stɑɹz ən munz. ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz, simɪŋ ɔlmoʊs blæk ɪn əɹ fɛɹ feɪs. kul, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ aɪz. luz θɝɪn ɡeɪv ə weɪl ən flɛɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ.

The Green sister he remembered sat beside a small table with an embroidery hoop in her hands, an opened basket on the polished tabletop spilling out skeins of bright thread from some of its many compartments. She was exactly as he remembered. That strong face topped by an iron-gray bun decorated with small dangling golden fish and birds, stars and moons. Those dark eyes, seeming almost black in her fair face. Cool, considering eyes. Lews Therin gave a wail and fled at the sight of her.

"wɛl," ʃi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ɑn ðə teɪbəl, "aɪ mʌst seɪ aɪv sin bɛɾɝ wɪθaʊt peɪɪŋ. wɪð ɔl aɪv bɪn hɪɹɪŋ əbaʊt ju, bɔɪ, ðə list aɪ ɪkspɛktəd wɑz pilz ə θʌndɝ, tʃɹʌmpəts ɪn ðə hɛvənz, flæʃɪŋ laɪts ɪn ðə skaɪ." kɑmli, ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə faɪv stoʊn-feɪs mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, wɪtʃ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ flɪntʃ. kɑmli, ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. "aɪ hoʊp wʌn ə jə ɪz ət list ɡoʊɪŋ tə dʒʌɡəl," ʃi sɛd. "ɔɹ it faɪɝ? aɪv ɔlweɪz ɛndʒɔɪd wɑtʃɪŋ ɡlimən it faɪɝ."

"Well," she said, setting the embroidery hoop on the table, "I must say I've seen better without paying. With all I've been hearing about you, boy, the least I expected was peals of thunder, trumpets in the heavens, flashing lights in the sky." Calmly, she regarded the five stone-faced men who could channel, which should have been enough to make any Aes Sedai flinch. Calmly, she regarded the Dragon Reborn. "I hope one of you is at least going to juggle," she said. "Or eat fire? I've always enjoyed watching gleemen eat fire."

flɪn bɑɹkt ə læf bɪfɔɹ kætʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ən ivən ðən ɹeɪkt ə hæn θɹu hɪz fɹɪnʒ ə hɛɹ ən sim tə bi stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð əmjuzmənt. mɔɹ ən hɑpwəl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks boʊθ pʌzəld ən mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd. dæʃivə smaɪld ənplɛzənli, ən ðə wiv i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ, əntɪl ɹænd fɛlt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə si wʌt wɑz ɹʌʃɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm.

Flinn barked a laugh before catching himself, and even then raked a hand through his fringe of hair and seemed to be struggling with amusement. Morr and Hopwil exchanged looks both puzzled and more than a little outraged. Dashiva smiled unpleasantly, and the weave he was holding grew stronger, until Rand felt as if he wanted to look over his shoulder to see what was rushing toward him.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɪnʌf ðət jə noʊ aɪm u aɪ æm," ɹænd toʊl hɝ. "dæʃivə, ɔl ə ju, weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd."

"It is enough that you know I am who I am," Rand told her. "Dashiva, all of you, wait outside."

dæʃivə oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əz ɪf tə pɹoʊtɛst. ðət hæd nɑt bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ɹændz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə oʊvɝeɪ ðə wʊmən, nɑt ðɪs weɪ. ðə mæn wɛnt, ðoʊ, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. hɑpwəl ən mɔɹ æktʃəli  stɛpt aʊɾ iɡɝli, wɪð saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz ət kædzueɪn. flɪn wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn tə meɪk ə dɪɡnəfaɪd wɪðdʒɹɔəl, ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪz lɪmp. ən i stɪl simd əmjuzd!

Dashiva opened his mouth as if to protest. That had not been part of Rand's instructions, but they were not going to overawe the woman, not this way. The man went, though, muttering to himself. Hopwil and Morr actually stepped out eagerly, with sidelong glances at Cadsuane. Flinn was the only one to make a dignified withdrawal, in spite of his limp. And he still seemed amused!

ɹænd tʃænəld, ən ə hɛvi, lɛpɝd-kɑɹv tʃɛɹ floʊɾəd ɪndə ði ɛɹ fɹəm ɪts pleɪs baɪ ðə wɔl, spɪnɪŋ ɛn oʊvɝ ɛn ɪn sʌmɝsɔls bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ laɪk ə fɛðɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə kædzueɪn. ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ə hɛvi sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ dʒɹɪftəɾ ʌp fɹəm ə lɔŋ, dʒɹeɪp teɪbəl əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, meɪkɪŋ ə laʊd pɪŋ əz ɪt wɑz sʌɾənli hiɾəd; stim ɡʌʃt fɹəm ðə tɑp, ən ɪt tɪpt oʊvɝ, wɝlɪŋ ɹaʊn ən ɹaʊn laɪk ə sloʊ tɑp, əz ə sɪlvɝ kʌp dɑɹɾɪd ʌp tə nitli kætʃ ðə dɑɹk pɔɹɪŋ.

Rand channeled, and a heavy, leopard-carved chair floated into the air from its place by the wall, spinning end over end in somersaults before settling like a feather in front of Cadsuane. At the same time, a heavy silver pitcher drifted up from a long, draped table across the room, making a loud ping as it was suddenly heated; steam gushed from the top, and it tipped over, whirling round and round like a slow top, as a silver cup darted up to neatly catch the dark pouring.

"tu hɑt, aɪ θɪŋk," ɹænd sɛd, ən ðə ɡlæs keɪsməns lɛp fɹəm ðə tɔl, nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊz. snoʊfleɪks bɪloʊɾ ɪn ɑn ən aɪsi blæst, ən ðə kʌp sɔɹɾ aʊt θɹu wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz, sɔɹd bæk əɡɛn, stʃɹeɪt tə hɪz hæn əz i sæt hɪmsɛlf. lɛɾ əɹ si haʊ kɑm ʃi kəd steɪ wɪð ə mædmæn stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ. ðə dɑɹk lɪkwəd wɑz ti, tu stʃɹɔŋ æftɝ ɪz bɔɪlɪŋ, ən bɪɾɝ ɪnʌf tə sɛɾ ɪz tiθ ɑn ɛdʒ. bʌt ðə wɔɹmθ wɑz dʒʌst ɹaɪt. hɪz skɪn pɛbəld ɪn ðə ɡʌsts haʊlɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum ən flæpɪŋ tæpəstʃɹiz əɡɛns ðə wɔlz, bʌɾ ɪn ðə vɔɪd, ðət wɑz fɑɹ əweɪ, sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz skɪn.

"Too hot, I think," Rand said, and the glassed casements leaped from the tall, narrow windows. Snowflakes billowed in on an icy blast, and the cup soared out through one of the windows, soared back again, straight to his hand as he sat himself. Let her see how calm she could stay with a madman staring at her. The dark liquid was tea, too strong after his boiling, and bitter enough to set his teeth on edge. But the warmth was just right. His skin pebbled in the gusts howling into the room and flapping tapestries against the walls, but in the Void, that was far away, someone else's skin.

"ðə lɔɹəl kɹaʊn ɪz pɹɪɾiɝ ðən sʌm," kædzueɪn sɛd wɪð ə feɪn smaɪl. hɝ hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns sweɪd wɛnɛvɝ ðə wɪn ɹoʊz, ən smɔl wɪsps fleɪld əbaʊɾ əɹ bʌn, bʌt ði oʊnli noʊɾəs ʃi tʊk wɑz tə kætʃ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz bloʊn fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. "aɪ pɹəfɝ ðət neɪm. bʌt jə kæn ɪkspɛk mi tə bi ɪmpɹɛs baɪ kɹaʊnz. aɪv pæɾəld ðə bɑɾəmz ə tu ɹeɪnɪŋ kɪŋz ən θɹi kwinz. nɑt sɪɾɪŋ ɹulɝz, jə ʌndɝstænd, wʌns aɪ wɑz dʌn wɪð ðɛm, nɑt fəɹ ə deɪ əɹ soʊ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd ɡɛt ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən. jə kən si waɪ kɹaʊnz doʊn ɪmpɹɛs mi, ðoʊ."

"The Laurel Crown is prettier than some," Cadsuane said with a faint smile. Her hair ornaments swayed whenever the wind rose, and small wisps flailed about her bun, but the only notice she took was to catch her embroidery hoop just before it was blown from the table. "I prefer that name. But you can't expect me to be impressed by crowns. I've paddled the bottoms of two reigning kings and three queens. Not sitting rulers, you understand, once I was done with them, not for a day or so, but it did get their attention. You can see why crowns don't impress me, though."

ɹænd izd ɪz dʒɔ. ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɪz tiθ wəd nɑt hɛlp. hi waɪɾənd ɪz aɪz, hoʊpɪŋ i lʊkt ɪnseɪn ɪnstɛɾ ə sɪmpli fjʊɹiəs. "moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ əvɔɪd ðə sʌn pæləs," hi toʊl hɝ. "ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz u hæv swɔɹn fiəlti tə mi. ən ðoʊz aɪ hoʊl pɹɪznɝ." laɪt, wʌt wɑz i tə də wɪð ðoʊz? əz lɔŋ əz ðə waɪz wʌnz kɛpt əm aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɹ, ɔl wɑz wɛl ɪnʌf.

Rand eased his jaw. Grinding his teeth would not help. He widened his eyes, hoping he looked insane instead of simply furious. "Most Aes Sedai avoid the Sun Palace," he told her. "Except for those who have sworn fealty to me. And those I hold prisoner." Light, what was he to do with those? As long as the Wise Ones kept them out of his hair, all was well enough.

"ði il sim tə θɪŋk aɪ ʃəd kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz aɪ pliz," ʃi sɛɾ æbsənli, aɪɪŋ ðə hup ɪn əɹ hæn əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ə teɪkɪŋ ʌp əɹ niɾəl əɡɛn. "ə mæɾɝ ə səm tʃɹaɪflɪŋ hɛlp aɪ ɡeɪv səm bɔɪ əɹ ʌðɝ. ðoʊ waɪ ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ɪz mʌðɝ ʃəd θɪŋk ɪm wɝθ ɪt, aɪ kən hɑɹdli seɪ."

"The Aiel seem to think I should come and go as I please," she said absently, eyeing the hoop in her hand as if thinking of taking up her needle again. "A matter of some trifling help I gave some boy or other. Though why anyone but his mother should think him worth it, I can hardly say."

ɹænd meɪɾ ənʌðɝ ɛfɝt nɑt tə ɡɹaɪn ɪz tiθ. ðə wʊmən hæd seɪvd ɪz laɪf. hɝ ən dɑɹnɝ flɪn bɪtwin ðɛm, ən plɛnti ʌv ʌðɝz ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən, mɪn əmʌŋ ðɛm. bʌɾ i stɪl oʊd kædzueɪn sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ ðæt. bɝn hɝ. "aɪ wɑn jə tə bi maɪ ædvaɪzɝ. aɪm kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən naʊ, ən kɪŋz əv ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝz."

Rand made another effort not to grind his teeth. The woman had saved his life. Her and Darner Flinn between them, and plenty of others in the bargain, Min among them. But he still owed Cadsuane something for that. Burn her. "I want you to be my advisor. I'm King of Illian now, and kings have Aes Sedai advisors."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪz kɹaʊn ə dɪsmɪsɪv ɡlæns. "sɝɾənli nɑt. ən ædvaɪzɝ əz tə stæn ən wɑtʃ əɹ tʃɑɹdʒ meɪk ə mʌɾəl mʌtʃ tu ɔfən tə sut mi. ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæz tə teɪk ɔɹɾɝz, sʌmθɪŋ aɪm pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli bæɾ æt. woʊn sʌmwʌn ɛls du? ɑlɑnə, pɝhæps?"

She gave his crown a dismissive glance. "Certainly not. An advisor has to stand and watch her charge make a muddle much too often to suit me. She also has to take orders, something I am particularly bad at. Won't someone else do? Alanna, perhaps?"

dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, ɹænd sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. dɪd ʃi noʊ əbaʊt ðə bɑnd? mɛɹænə hæd sɛɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə kip ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm hɝ. noʊ; hi kəd wɝi leɪɾɝ əbaʊt haʊ mʌtʃ ɪz "feɪθfəl" ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ tɛlɪŋ kædzueɪn. laɪt, hi wɪʃt mɪn kəd bi ɹɔŋ fəɹ wʌns. bʌɾ i wəd bɪliv hɪmsɛlf bɹiðɪŋ wɔɾɝ, fɝst. "aɪ . . ." hi kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf tɛl əɹ ðəɾ i niɾəd hɝ. noʊ hɔltɝ! "wʌɾ ɪf jə dɪdn əv tə swɛɹ ɛni oʊðz?"

Despite himself, Rand sat up straight. Did she know about the bond? Merana had said it was hard to keep anything from her. No; he could worry later about how much his "faithful" Aes Sedai were telling Cadsuane. Light, he wished Min could be wrong for once. But he would believe himself breathing water, first. "I . . ." He could not make himself tell her that he needed her. No halter! "What if you didn't have to swear any oaths?"

"aɪ səpoʊz ðət maɪt wɝk," ʃi sɛd daʊtfəli, piɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ kɝst stɪtʃɝi. hɝ aɪz ɹoʊz tə hɪz. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. "ju saʊnd . . . ənizi. aɪ doʊn laɪk tə tɛl ə mæn hiz əfɹeɪɾ ivən wən hiz ɹizən tə bi. ənizi oʊvɝ ə sɪstɝ jə hævən tɝn ɪndə ə teɪm læpdɔɡ snɛɹɪŋ jə ɪn səm fæʃən? lemi si. aɪ kən meɪk jə ə fju pɹɑməsəz; pɝhæps ðəl sɛt jəɹ maɪn ət ɹɛst. aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə lɪsən, ʌv kɔɹs - meɪk mi weɪs maɪ bɹɛθ, ən jəl jɛlp fəɹ ɪt - bʌɾ aɪ woʊn meɪk jə də wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt. aɪ woʊn tɑlɝeɪɾ ɛniwʌn laɪɪŋ tə mi, sɝɾənli - ðæts ənʌðɝ θɪŋ jəl faɪn dɪsaɪɾədli ənkʌmftəɹbəl - bʌɾ aɪ doʊn ɪkspɛk jə tə tɛl mi ðə dipəs jɝnɪŋz ə jəɹ hɑɹt, iðɝ. oʊ, jɛs. wʌtɛvɝ aɪ du, ɪɾəl bi fəɹ jəɹ oʊn ɡʊd; nɑt maɪn, nɑt ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, jʊɹz. naʊ, dʌz ðəɾ iz jəɹ fɪɹz? pɑɹɾən mi. jəɹ əniz."

"I suppose that might work," she said doubtfully, peering at her cursed stitchery. Her eyes rose to his. Considering. "You sound . . . uneasy. I don't like to tell a man he's afraid even when he has reason to be. Uneasy over a sister you haven't turned into a tame lapdog snaring you in some fashion? Let me see. I can make you a few promises; perhaps they will set your mind at rest. I expect you to listen, of course - make me waste my breath, and you'll yelp for it - but I won't make you do what I want. I won't tolerate anyone lying to me, certainly - that's another thing you'll find decidedly uncomfortable - but I don't expect you to tell me the deepest yearnings of your heart, either. Oh, yes. Whatever I do, it will be for your own good; not mine, not the good of the White Tower, yours. Now, does that ease your fears? Pardon me. Your unease."

wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i wɑz səpoʊz tə læf, ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "du ðeɪ titʃ jə haʊ tə də ðæt?" hi dɪmændəd. "meɪk ə pɹɑməs saʊn ə θɹɛt, aɪ min."

Wondering whether he was supposed to laugh, Rand stared at her. "Do they teach you how to do that?" he demanded. "Make a promise sound a threat, I mean."

"oʊ, aɪ si. jə wɑn ɹulz. moʊs bɔɪz du, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ seɪ. vɛɹi wɛl. lemi si. aɪ kænɑɾ əbaɪɾ ɪnsɪvɪləɾi. soʊ jəl bi pɹɑpɝli sɪvəl tə mi, tə maɪ fɹɛnz, ən maɪ ɡɛsts. ðəɾ ɪnkludz nɑt tʃænəlɪŋ ət ðɛm, ɪn keɪs jə hævənt ɡɛst, ən hoʊldɪŋ jəɹ tɛmpɝ, wɪtʃ aɪ ʌndɝstæn ɪz mɛmɝəbəl. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ teɪks ɪn jəɹ . . . kəmpænjənz ɪn ðoʊz blæk koʊts. ə pɪɾi ɪf aɪ hæd tə spæŋk jə fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm dɪd. dʌz ðət səfaɪs? aɪ kən meɪk mɔɹ, ɪf jə nid ðɛm."

"Oh, I see. You want rules. Most boys do, whatever they say. Very well. Let me see. I cannot abide incivility. So you will be properly civil to me, to my friends, and my guests. That includes not channeling at them, in case you haven't guessed, and holding your temper, which I understand is memorable. It also takes in your . . . companions in those black coats. A pity if I had to spank you for something one of them did. Does that suffice? I can make more, if you need them."

ɹænd sɛɾ ɪz kʌp daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɛɹ. ðə ti hæd ɡɔn koʊld əz wɛl əz bɪɾɝ. snoʊ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə paɪl ʌp ɪn dʒɹɪfs bɪniθ ðə wɪndoʊz. "ɪm ðə wʌn huz səpoʊz tə ɡoʊ mæd, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt jə ɔlɹɛɾi ɑɹ." ɹaɪzɪŋ, hi stʃɹoʊd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ.

Rand set his cup down beside the chair. The tea had gone cold as well as bitter. Snow was beginning to pile up in drifts beneath the windows. "I'm the one who's supposed to go mad, Aes Sedai, but you already are." Rising, he strode for the door.

"aɪ də hoʊp jə hævən tʃɹaɪd tə juz kælændɝ," ʃi sɛd kəmpleɪsənli bɪhaɪn hɪm. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɪts vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə stoʊn. jə mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp wʌns, bʌt jə maɪt nɑt twaɪs."

"I do hope you haven't tried to use Callandor," she said complacently behind him. "I have heard it's vanished from the Stone. You managed to escape once, but you might not twice."

hi stɑpt ʃɔɹt, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə wʊmən wɑz pʊʃɪŋ ðət blʌɾi niɾəl θɹu ðə klɔθ stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn əɹ hup! ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd, swɝlɪŋ snoʊ ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən lɪft əɹ hɛd. "wʌt dʒju min, ɪskeɪp?"

He stopped short, looking over his shoulder. The woman was pushing that bloody needle through the cloth stretched on her hoop! The wind gusted, swirling snow around her, and she did not even lift her head. "What do you mean, escape?"

"wʌt?" ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp. "oʊ. vɛɹi fju ivən ɪn ðə taʊɝ nu wʌt kælændɝ ɪz bɪfɔɹ jə dʒɹu ɪt, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ θɪŋz hɪɾən ɪn mʌsti kɔɹnɝz ə ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi. aɪ wɛn ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ səm jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wən aɪ fɝs hæd ðə səspɪʃən jə maɪt bi sʌklɪŋ ət jəɹ mʌðɝz bɹɛst. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡoʊ bæk ɪndə ɹitaɪɝmənt. beɪbz ɑɹ mɛsi θɪŋz, ən aɪ kəd nɑt si haʊ tə faɪn jə bɪfɔɹ jə stɑp dʒɹɪpɪŋ ət wʌn ɛn əɹ ði ʌðɝ."

"What?" She did not look up. "Oh. Very few even in the Tower knew what Callandor is before you drew it, but there are surprising things hidden in musty corners of the Tower Library. I went rummaging some years ago, when I first had the suspicion you might be suckling at your mother's breast. Just before I decided to go back into retirement. Babes are messy things, and I could not see how to find you before you stopped dripping at one end or the other."

"wʌt dʒju min?" hi dɪmændəd ɹʌfli.

"What do you mean?" he demanded roughly.

kædzueɪn lʊkt ʌp ðɛn, ən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ flʌŋ əbaʊɾ ən snoʊ sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs, ʃi lʊkt ə kwin. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪ kænɑɾ əbaɪɾ ɪnsɪvɪləɾi. ɪf jə æsk fəɹ maɪ hɛlp əɡɛn, aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə æsk pəlaɪtli. ən əl ɪkspɛkt ən əpɑlədʒi fəɹ jəɹ bɪheɪvjɝ tədeɪ!"

Cadsuane looked up then, and with her hair flung about and snow settling on her dress, she looked a queen. "I told you I cannot abide incivility. If you ask for my help again, I expect you to ask politely. And I will expect an apology for your behavior today!"

"wʌt dʒju min əbaʊt kælændɝ?"

"What do you mean about Callandor?"

"ɪɾ ɪz flɔd," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd kɝtli, "lækɪŋ ðə bʌfɝ ðət meɪks ʌðɝ sɑŋɡɹil seɪf tə juz. ən ɪɾ əpɛɹənli mæɡnəfaɪz ðə teɪnt, ɪndusɪŋ waɪlnəs ə ðə maɪnd. soʊ lɔŋ əz ə mæn ɪz juzɪŋ ɪt, ɛniweɪ. ði oʊnli seɪf weɪ fəɹ jə tə juz ðə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ə sɔɹd, ði oʊnli weɪ tə juz ɪt wɪθaʊt ðə ɹɪsk ə kɪlɪŋ jɝsɛlf, əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə də ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz wʌɾ ɪnsænəɾi, ɪz lɪŋkt wɪð tu wɪmən, ən wʌn ə ðɛm ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðə floʊz."

"It is flawed," she replied curtly, "lacking the buffer that makes other sa'angreal safe to use. And it apparently magnifies the taint, inducing wildness of the mind. So long as a man is using it, anyway. The only safe way for you to use The Sword That Is Not a Sword, the only way to use it without the risk of killing yourself, or trying to do the Light alone knows what insanity, is linked with two women, and one of them guiding the flows."

tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə hʌntʃ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hi stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. soʊ ɪt hæd bɪn nɑt dʒʌs ðə waɪlnəs ə seɪɾɪn ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ ðət hæd kɪld ædli. hi hæd mɝɾɝd ðə mæn ðə moʊmən i sɛnt nɛɹɪʃmə fəɹ ðə θɪŋ.

Trying not to hunch his shoulders, he strode away from her. So it had been not just the wildness of saidin around Ebou Dar that had killed Adley. He had murdered the man the moment he sent Narishma for the thing.

kædzueɪnz vɔɪs pɝsud hɪm. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bɔɪ. jə mʌst æsk vɛɹi naɪsli, ən əpɑlədʒaɪz. aɪ maɪɾ ivən əɡɹi, ɪf jəɹ əpɑlədʒi saʊnz tʃɹuli sənsɪɹ."

Cadsuane's voice pursued him. "Remember, boy. You must ask very nicely, and apologize. I might even agree, if your apology sounds truly sincere."

ɹænd bɛɹli hɝd hɝ. hi hæd hoʊp tə juz kælændɝ əɡɛn, hoʊpt ɪt wəd bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. naʊ oʊnli wʌn tʃæns ɹɪmeɪnd, ən ɪt tɛɹəfaɪd hɪm. hi sim tə hɪɹ ənʌðɝ wʊmənz vɔɪs, ə dɛd wʊmənz vɔɪs. jə kəd tʃælənʒ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ.

Rand barely heard her. He had hoped to use Callandor again, hoped it would be strong enough. Now only one chance remained, and it terrified him. He seemed to hear another woman's voice, a dead woman's voice. You could challenge the Creator.


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

kɹɪmsɑnθɝn


Crimsonthorn

ɪt hɑɹdli sim ðə sɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ɪksploʊʒən ɪleɪn fɪɹd. hɑɹlən bɹɪdʒ wɑz ə vɪlədʒ ə mɑɾɝət saɪz, wɪð θɹi ɪnz ən ɪnʌf haʊsəz ðət noʊ wʌn hæd tə slip ɪn ə heɪlɔft. wən ɪleɪn ən bɝdʒɪt wɛn daʊnstɛɹz tə ðə kɑmən ɹum ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs dɪl, ðə ɹaʊn ɪnkipɝ, smaɪld wɔɹmli ən ɔfɝɾ əz mʌtʃ ʌv ə kɝtsi əz əɹ saɪz əlaʊd. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɪstʃɹəs dɪl wɑz soʊ pliz ðəɾ əɹ ɪn wɑz fʊl, wʌt wɪð ðə ɹoʊdz snoʊ-pækt, ðət ʃi bɑbd ət nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn. ət ðɛɹ ɛntʃɹəns, eɪvinhə heɪstəli ɡʌlp ðə læst ə hɝ bɹɛkfəs bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz, bɹʌʃt ə fju kɹʌmz fɹəm əɹ ɡɹin dʒɹɛs, ən snætʃt ʌp əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

It hardly seemed the setting for the explosion Elayne feared. Harlon Bridge was a village of moderate size, with three inns and enough houses that no one had to sleep in a hayloft. When Elayne and Birgitte went downstairs to the common room that morning, Mistress Dill, the round innkeeper, smiled warmly and offered as much of a curtsy as her size allowed. It was not just that Elayne was Aes Sedai. Mistress Dill was so pleased that her inn was full, what with the roads snow-packed, that she bobbed at nearly everyone. At their entrance, Aviendha hastily gulped the last of her breakfast bread and cheese, brushed a few crumbs from her green dress, and snatched up her dark cloak to join them.

aʊtsaɪd, ðə sʌn wɑz dʒʌs pikɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɝaɪzən, ə loʊ doʊm ə peɪl jɛloʊ. oʊnli ə fju klaʊdz mɑɹɾ ə bjuɾəfəl blu skaɪ, ən ðeɪ wɝ waɪɾ ən flʌfi, nɑt ðə sɔɹt tə kæɹi snoʊ. ɪt simd ə wʌndɝfəl deɪ fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ.

Outside, the sun was just peeking over the horizon, a low dome of pale yellow. Only a few clouds marred a beautiful blue sky, and they were white and fluffy, not the sort to carry snow. It seemed a wonderful day for traveling.

ɪksɛp ðəɾ æɾɪliz wɑz tʃɹæmplɪŋ ə pæθ ʌp ðə snoʊi stʃɹit, ən ðə waɪt-hɛɹd sɪstɝ wɑz dʒɹæɡɪŋ wʌn ə ðə kɪn, ɡæɹiniə ɹoʊsɔɪnd, baɪ hɝ ɑɹm. ɡæɹiniə wɑz ə slɪm-hɪp sɑldəiən u hæd spɛn ðə læs twɛnti jɪɹz əz ə mɝtʃən ɔlðoʊ ʃi lʊkt oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən nɪneɪiv dɪd. nɔɹməli, hɝ stʃɹɔŋli hʊk noʊz ɡeɪv əɹ ə fɔɹsfəl əpɪɹəns, ə wʊmən u wəd meɪk hɑɹd tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ən nɑt bæk əweɪ. naʊ hɝ dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz wɝ lɑɹdʒ ɪn əɹ feɪs ən əɹ waɪd maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən, ɪmɪɾɪŋ ə wɝdləs weɪl. ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ nɑɾ ə kɪnswɪmən fɑloʊd bɪhaɪnd, skɝts hɛl haɪ aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ, wɪspɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, wɪð mɔɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən tə dʒɔɪn. ɹin ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɝ ɪn ðə fɹʌnt, ɔl ɡɹɪm-feɪst ɪksɛp fəɹ kɝstʃən, hu simd ivən pəlɝ ðən juʒəwəl. æləz wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, wɛɹɪŋ ən ʌɾɝli blæŋk ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Except that Adeleas was trampling a path up the snowy street, and the white-haired sister was dragging one of the Kin, Garenia Rosoinde, by her arm. Garenia was a slim-hipped Saldaean who had spent the last twenty years as a merchant although she looked only a few years older than Nynaeve did. Normally, her strongly hooked nose gave her a forceful appearance, a woman who would make hard trading and not back away. Now her dark tilted eyes were large in her face and her wide mouth hung open, emitting a wordless wail. A growing knot of Kinswomen followed behind, skirts held high out of the snow, whispering among themselves, with more running from every direction to join. Reanne and the rest of the Knitting Circle were in the front, all grim-faced except for Kirstian, who seemed even paler than usual. Alise was there, too, wearing an utterly blank expression.

æɾɪliz stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪleɪn ən ʃʌvd ɡæɹiniə soʊ hɑɹd ðə wʊmən fɛl tə hænz ən niz ɪn ðə snoʊ. wɛɹ ʃi steɪd, stɪl weɪlɪŋ. ðə kɪnswɪmən ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn hɝ, mɔɹ ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ flɑkɪŋ ɪn.

Adeleas stopped in front of Elayne and shoved Garenia so hard the woman fell to hands and knees in the snow. Where she stayed, still wailing. The Kinswomen gathered behind her, more of their number flocking in.

"aɪm bɹɪŋɪŋ ðɪs tə jə kəz nɪneɪiv ɪz bɪzi," ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ toʊld ɪleɪn. ʃi mɛn ðət nɪneɪiv wɑz ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ə lɪɾəl taɪm əloʊn wɪð læn sʌmwɛɹ, bʌt fəɹ wʌns, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl kɹɔst əɹ lɪps. "bi kwaɪət, tʃaɪld!" ʃi snæpt ət ɡæɹiniə. hu pɹɑmpli wɛn saɪlənt. æɾɪliz ɡeɪv ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. "ðɪs ɪz nɑt ɡæɹiniə ɹoʊsɔɪnd," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ faɪnəli ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɝ. zɛɹjə ælkeɪis, ə nɑvəs u ɹæn əweɪ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ vændin ən aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹɪtaɪɹ ən ɹaɪɾ əɹ hɪstɝi ʌv ðə wɝld. ʃi ədmɪɾəd ɪt, wən aɪ kənfɹʌntəd hɝ. aɪm sɝpɹaɪz kɛɝin dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs; ðeɪ wɝ nɑvəsɪz təɡɛðɝ fəɹ tu jɪɹz. ðə lɔ ɪz klɪɹ, ɪleɪn. ə ɹʌnəweɪ mʌs bi pʊt bæk ɪn waɪɾ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl ən kɛpt ʌndɝ stʃɹɪk dɪsəplən əntɪl ʃi kən bi ɹɪtɝn tə ðə taʊɝ fəɹ pɹɑpɝ pʌnɪʃmənt. ʃi woʊn θɪŋk ə ɹʌnɪŋ əɡɛn æftɝ ðæt!"

"I'm bringing this to you because Nynaeve is busy," the Brown sister told Elayne. She meant that Nynaeve was enjoying a little time alone with Lan somewhere, but for once, not so much as a hint of a smile crossed her lips. "Be quiet, child!" she snapped at Garenia. Who promptly went silent. Adeleas gave a satisfied nod. "This is not Garenia Rosoinde," she said. "I finally recognized her. Zarya Alkaese, a novice who ran away just before Vandene and I decided to retire and write our history of the world. She admitted it, when I confronted her. I'm surprised Careane didn't recognize her before this; they were novices together for two years. The law is clear, Elayne. A runaway must be put back in white as soon as possible and kept under strict discipline until she can be returned to the Tower for proper punishment. She won't think of running again after that!"

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt tə seɪ. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ɡæɹiniə - zɛɹjə - θɔɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ əɡɛn, ʃi wəd nɑt bi əlaʊd ði ɑpɝtunəɾi. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ; ðə taʊɝ wəd nɑt lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɪf ɪt tʊk ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ laɪf tə ɝn ðə ʃɔl. bʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ɹɪkɔlɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʃi hæd hɝd ðɪs wʊmən seɪ ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi mɛt hɝ. ðə minɪŋ hæd nɑt ɹɛdʒəstɝd ðɛn, bʌt naʊ ɪt dɪd. haʊ wəd zɛɹjə feɪs nɑvəs waɪɾ əɡɛn æftɝ lɪvɪŋ əz əɹ oʊn wʊmən fəɹ sɛvənti jɪɹz? wɝs, ðoʊz wɪspɝz əmʌŋ ðə kɪnswɪmən hæd bɪɡʌn tə saʊn laɪk ɹʌmbəlz.

Elayne nodded slowly, trying to think of what to say. Whether or not Garenia - Zarya - thought of running again, she would not be allowed the opportunity. She was very strong in the Power; the Tower would not let her go if it took the rest of her life to earn the shawl. But Elayne was recalling something she had heard this woman say the first time she met her. The meaning had not registered then, but now it did. How would Zarya face novice white again after living as her own woman for seventy years? Worse, those whispers among the Kinswomen had begun to sound like rumbles.

ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv lɔŋ tə θɪŋk. sʌɾənli kɝstʃən fɛl tə hɝ niz, klʌtʃɪŋ əɾ æɾɪliz' skɝts wɪð wʌn hænd. "aɪ səbmɪt maɪsɛlf," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, hɝ toʊn ə wʌndɝ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət blʌdləs feɪs. "aɪ wɑz ɛnɹoʊld ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk ɔlmoʊs θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ən ɹæn əweɪ lɛs ðən ə jɪɹ leɪɾɝ. aɪ səbmɪt maɪsɛlf, ən . . . ən bɛɡ mɝsi."

She did not have long to think. Suddenly Kirstian fell to her knees, clutching at Adeleas' skirts with one hand. "I submit myself," she said calmly, her tone a wonder coming from that bloodless face. "I was enrolled in the novice book almost three hundred years ago, and ran away less than a year later. I submit myself, and . . . and beg mercy."

ɪt wɑz waɪt-hɛɹɾ æɾɪliz' tɝn tə ɡoʊ waɪd-aɪd. kɝstʃən wɑz kleɪmɪŋ tə hæv ɹʌn əweɪ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ wən ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ən ɪnfənt, ɪf nɑt bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz bɔɹn! moʊst ə ðə sɪstɝz stɪl dɪd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ði eɪdʒəz kleɪm baɪ ðə kɪn. ɪndid, kɝstʃən əpɪɹd dʒʌst ɪndə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz.

It was white-haired Adeleas' turn to go wide-eyed. Kirstian was claiming to have run away from the White Tower when she herself was an infant, if not before she was born! Most of the sisters still did not really believe the ages claimed by the Kin. Indeed, Kirstian appeared just into her middle years.

ivən soʊ, æɾɪliz ɹəkʌvɝd hɝsɛlf kwɪkli. haʊɛvɝ oʊl ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz, æɾɪliz hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ əbaʊɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɛniwʌn lɪvɪŋ. ʃi kæɹiɾ ən ɔɹə ʌv eɪdʒ, ən əθɔɹəɾi. "ɪf ðəɾ ɪz soʊ, tʃaɪld," hɝ vɔɪs dɪd fɔltɝ dʒʌst ə bɪɾ ət ðæt, "aɪ fɪɹ wi mʌs pʊt jə ɪn waɪt, tu. jəl stɪl bi pʌnɪʃt, bʌt sɝɛndɝɪŋ əz juv wɪl ɡeɪn jə səm mɪɾɪɡeɪʃən."

Even so, Adeleas recovered herself quickly. However old the other woman was, Adeleas had been Aes Sedai about as long as anyone living. She carried an aura of age, and authority. "If that is so, child," her voice did falter just a bit at that, "I fear we must put you in white, too. You will still be punished, but surrendering as you have will gain you some mitigation."

"ðæɾ ɪz waɪ aɪ dɪɾ ɪt." kɝstʃənz stɛɾi toʊn wɑz spɔɪl sʌmwʌt baɪ ə hɑɹd swɑloʊ. ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹɔŋ əz zɛɹjə - nʌn ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɝ wik - ən ʃi wəd bi hɛl vɛɹi kloʊsli. "aɪ nu jə wəd faɪn mi aʊt sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ."

"That is why I did it." Kirstian's steady tone was spoiled somewhat by a hard swallow. She was almost as strong as Zarya - none of the Knitting Circle were weak - and she would be held very closely. "I knew you would find me out sooner or later."

æɾɪliz nɑɾəd əz ðoʊ ðət wɝ klɪɹli ɑbviəs, ðoʊ haʊ ðə wʊmən wʊɾə bɪn faʊn aʊt, ɪleɪn kəd nɑt ɡɛs. ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊɾɪd ðət kɝstʃən tʃælwɪn wɑz ðə neɪm ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn bɔɹn wɪð. moʊst ə ðə kɪn bɪlivd ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑmnɪsəəns, ðoʊ. ðeɪ hæd, ət list.

Adeleas nodded as though that were clearly obvious, though how the woman would have been found out, Elayne could not guess. She very much doubted that Kirstian Chalwin was the name the woman had been born with. Most of the Kin believed in Aes Sedai omniscience, though. They had, at least.

"ɹʌbɪʃ!" sɹeɪnjə vɔstoʊvənz hʌski vɔɪs kʌt θɹu ðə mɝmɝd bæbəl ə ðə kɪn. niðɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ nɔɹ nɪɹli oʊld ɪnʌf tə stæn vɛɹi haɪ əmʌŋ ðə kɪn, ʃi stɪl stɛp fɹəm ðə pæk dɪfaɪənli.
