"waɪ ʃəd wi ɡɪv əm ʌp tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ? wɪv hɛlpt wɪmən ɹʌn əweɪ, ən ɹaɪtli soʊ! ɪts nɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹulz tə ɡɪv əm bæk!"

"Rubbish!" Sarainya Vostovan's husky voice cut through the murmured babble of the Kin. Neither strong enough to become Aes Sedai nor nearly old enough to stand very high among the Kin, she still stepped from the pack defiantly. "Why should we give them up to the White Tower? We have helped women run away, and rightly so! It is not part of the rules to give them back!"

"kəntʃɹoʊl jɝsɛlf!" ɹin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "æləz, teɪk sɹeɪnjə ɪn hænd, pliz. ɪt simz ʃi fɝɡɛts tu mɛni ʌv ðə ɹulz ʃi kleɪmz tə noʊ."

"Control yourself!" Reanne said sharply. "Alise, take Sarainya in hand, please. It seems she forgets too many of the rules she claims to know."

æləz lʊkt ət ɹin, hɝ feɪs stɪl ənɹiɾəbəl. æləz, hu ɛnfɔɹs ðə kɪnz ɹulz wɪð ə fɝm hænd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv əɹ ɹulz tə hæn ɹʌnəweɪz bæk, ɹin," ʃi sɛd.

Alise looked at Reanne, her face still unreadable. Alise, who enforced the Kin's rules with a firm hand. "It is not part of our rules to hand runaways back, Reanne," she said.

ɹin dʒɝkt əz ðoʊ stʃɹʌk. "æn haʊ dʒju sədʒɛs kipɪŋ ðɛm?" ʃi dɪmændəd faɪnəli. "wi hæv ɔlweɪz hɛld ɹʌnəweɪz əpɑɹɾ əntɪl wi wɝ ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hʌntəd, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ faʊn bɪfɔɹ, wi lɛt ðə sɪstɝz teɪk ðɛm. ðəɾ ɪz ðə ɹul, æləz. wʌɾ ʌðɝ ɹul dʒju pɹəpoʊz vaɪəleɪɾɪŋ? dʒju sədʒɛs ðət wi æktʃəli  sɛɾ aʊɝsɛlvz əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɹɪɾəkjul ə sətʃ ə noʊʃən lɑɹɾɪd əɹ vɔɪs, jɛɾ æləz stʊd lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, saɪlənt.

Reanne jerked as though struck. "And how do you suggest keeping them?" she demanded finally. "We have always held runaways apart until we were sure they were no longer hunted, and if they were found before, we let the sisters take them. That is the rule, Alise. What other rule do you propose violating? Do you suggest that we actually set ourselves against Aes Sedai?" Ridicule of such a notion larded her voice, yet Alise stood looking at her, silent.

"jɛs!" ə vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm ðə kɹaʊɾ ə kɪnswɪmən. "wi ɑɹ mɛni, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ fju!" æɾɪliz stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. ɪleɪn ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðoʊ ʃi nu ðə vɔɪs wɑz ɹaɪt - ðə kɪn wɝ tu mɛni. ʃi fɛlt eɪvinhə ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ən bɝdʒɪt sɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf.

"Yes!" a voice shouted from the crowd of Kinswomen. "We are many, and they are few!" Adeleas stared at the crowd in disbelief. Elayne embraced saidar, though she knew the voice was right - the Kin were too many. She felt Aviendha embracing the Power, and Birgitte setting herself.

ɡɪvɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk əz ɪf kʌmɪŋ tə, æləz dɪd sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ mɔɹ pɹæktəkəl, sɝɾənli fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪfɛktɪv. "sɹeɪnjə," ʃi sɛd laʊdli, "ju wɪl ɹipɔɹt tə mi wən wi stɑp tənaɪt, wɪð ə swɪtʃ jə kʌt jɝsɛlf bɪfɔɹ wi liv ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. ju, tu, eɪsɹə; aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz jəɹ vɔɪs!" ən ðɛn, dʒʌst əz laʊdli, ʃi sɛd tə ɹin, "aɪ wɪl ɹipɔɹt maɪsɛlf fəɹ jəɹ dʒʌdʒmənt wən wi stɑp tənaɪt. aɪ doʊn si ɛniwʌn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi!"

Giving herself a shake as if coming to, Alise did something far more practical, certainly far more effective. "Sarainya," she said loudly, "you will report to me when we stop tonight, with a switch you cut yourself before we leave this morning. You, too, Asra; I recognize your voice!" And then, just as loudly, she said to Reanne, "I will report myself for your judgment when we stop tonight. I don't see anyone getting ready!"

ðə kɪnswɪmən bɹoʊk ʌp kwɪkli ðɛn, hɛɾɪŋ ɔf tə ɡæðɝ ðɛɹ θɪŋz, jɛɾ ɪleɪn sɔ səm ə ðɛm tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli əz ðeɪ wɛnt. wən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə bɹɪdʒ əkɹɔs ðə fɹoʊzən stʃɹim ðət waʊn daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə vɪlədʒ, wɪð nɪneɪiv ɪnkɹɛdʒələs oʊvɝ wʌt ʃi hæd mɪst ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə kɔl daʊn, sɹeɪnjə ən eɪsɹə kæɹid swɪtʃəz - əz dɪɾ æləz - ən zɛɹjə ən kɝstʃən wɔɹ heɪstəli faʊnd waɪt dʒɹɛsəz bɪniθ ðɛɹ dɑɹk kloʊks. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz pɔɪntəɾ əɾ əm ən læft əpɹɔɑɹiəsli. bʌt mɛni ʌv ðə kɪnswɪmən stɪl tɔkt ɪn klʌstɝz, fɔlɪŋ saɪlənt wɛnɛvɝ ə sɪstɝ əɹ wʌn ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl lʊkt ət ðɛm. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə dɑɹknəs tə ðɛɹ aɪz wən ðeɪ lʊkt əɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

The Kinswomen broke up quickly then, heading off to gather their things, yet Elayne saw some of them talking quietly as they went. When they rode over the bridge across the frozen stream that wound down beside the village, with Nynaeve incredulous over what she had missed and glaring about for someone to call down, Sarainya and Asra carried switches - as did Alise - and Zarya and Kirstian wore hastily found white dresses beneath their dark cloaks. The Windfinders pointed at them and laughed uproariously. But many of the Kinswomen still talked in clusters, falling silent whenever a sister or one of the Knitting Circle looked at them. And there was a darkness to their eyes when they looked at Aes Sedai.

eɪt mɔɹ deɪz ə flaʊndɝɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊ wən ɪt wɑz nɑt fɔlɪŋ, ən ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɹ tiθ ɪn ən ɪn wən ɪt wɑz. eɪt mɔɹ deɪz ə bɹuɾɪŋ baɪ ðə kɪn, ʌv stɛɹɪŋ blikli ət ðə sɪstɝz, deɪz ə stʃɹʌɾɪŋ baɪ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɝaʊn kɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əlaɪk. ɑn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ə ðə naɪnθ deɪ, ɪleɪn bɪɡæn tə wɪʃ ɛvɹiwʌn hæd sɪmpli ɡɔn fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛlsəz θɹoʊt.

Eight more days of floundering through the snow when it was not falling, and grinding her teeth in an inn when it was. Eight more days of brooding by the Kin, of staring bleakly at the sisters, days of strutting by the Windfinders around Kin and Aes Sedai alike. On the morning of the ninth day, Elayne began to wish everyone had simply gone for everyone else's throat.

ʃi wɑz dʒʌst wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ kəd kʌvɝ ðə læs tɛn maɪlz tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪθaʊɾ ə mɝɾɝ, wən kɝstʃən ɹæpt əɾ əɹ dɔɹ ən dɑɹɾɪd ɪn wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ. ðə wʊmənz pleɪn wʊlən dʒɹɛs wɑz nɑt ðə ʃeɪɾ ʌv waɪt pɹɑpɝ fəɹ ə nɑvəs, ən ʃi hæd ɹiɡeɪn mʌtʃ ə hɝ dɪɡnəɾi sʌmhaʊ, əz ɪf noʊɪŋ əɹ fjutʃɝ hæd smuðd əɹ pɹɛzənt, bʌt naʊ ʃi meɪɾ ə heɪsti kɝtsi, ɔlmoʊs tʃɹɪpɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ kloʊk, ən əɹ nɪɹli blæk aɪz wɝ æŋkʃəs. "nɪneɪiv sədaɪ, ɪleɪn sədaɪ, lɔɹd læn sɛz jə ɑɹ tə kʌm ət wʌns," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "hi toʊl mi tə spik tə noʊ wʌn, ən jə ɑɹən tə, iðɝ."

She was just wondering whether they could cover the last ten miles to Caemlyn without a murder, when Kirstian rapped at her door and darted in without waiting for an answer. The woman's plain woolen dress was not the shade of white proper for a novice, and she had regained much of her dignity somehow, as if knowing her future had smoothed her present, but now she made a hasty curtsy, almost tripping over her cloak, and her nearly black eyes were anxious. "Nynaeve Sedai, Elayne Sedai, Lord Lan says you are to come at once," she said breathlessly. "He told me to speak to no one, and you aren't to, either."

ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt. nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊl sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əbaʊt ðə mæn nɑt noʊɪŋ pɹaɪvət fɹəm pʌblɪk, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi blʌʃt ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ɪleɪn fɛl bɝdʒɪt foʊkəs, ðə dʒɹɔn æɹoʊ hʌntɪŋ ə tɑɹɡət.

Elayne and Nynaeve exchanged looks with Aviendha and Birgitte. Nynaeve growled something under her breath about the man not knowing private from public, but it was clear before she blushed that she did not believe it. Elayne felt Birgitte focus, the drawn arrow hunting a target.

kɝstʃən dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt læn wɑntəd, oʊnli wɛɹ ʃi wɑz tə lid ðɛm. ðə smɔl hʌɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ə kʌlənz kɹɔsɪŋ wɛɹ æɾɪliz hæd teɪkən ɪspæn ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. læn stʊɾ aʊtsaɪd, hɪz aɪz əz koʊld əz ði ɛɹ, ən wəd nɑt lɛt kɝstʃən ɛntɝ. wən ɪleɪn wɛn ɪnsaɪd, ʃi sɔ waɪ.

Kirstian did not know what Lan wanted, only where she was to lead them. The small hut outside of Cullen's Crossing where Adeleas had taken Ispan the night before. Lan stood outside, his eyes as cold as the air, and would not let Kirstian enter. When Elayne went inside, she saw why.

æɾɪliz leɪ ɑn əɹ saɪd bɪsaɪɾ ən oʊvɝtɝn stul, ə kʌp ɑn ðə ɹʌf wʊɾən flɔɹ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wʌn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd. hɝ aɪz stɛɹd, ən ə pul ə kəndʒil blʌd spɹɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə dip slæʃ əkɹɔs əɹ θɹoʊt. ɪspæn leɪ ɑn ə smɔl kɑt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ. lɪps dʒɹɔn bæk ɪn ə ɹɪktəs bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ, ən əɹ bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz sim fʊl ə hɔɹɝ. əz wɛl ðeɪ maɪt hæv, sɪns ə ɹɪst-θɪk wʊɾən steɪk stʊɾ aʊt fɹəm bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts. ðə hæmɝ ðət hæd pleɪnli bɪn juz tə dʒɹaɪv ɪɾ ɪn leɪ bɪsaɪd ðə kɑt, ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə dɑɹk steɪn ðət ɹæn bæk ʌndɝ ðə kɑt.

Adeleas lay on her side beside an overturned stool, a cup on the rough wooden floor not far from one outstretched hand. Her eyes stared, and a pool of congealed blood spread out from the deep slash across her throat. Ispan lay on a small cot, staring at the ceiling. Lips drawn back in a rictus bared her teeth, and her bulging eyes seemed full of horror. As well they might have, since a wrist-thick wooden stake stood out from between her breasts. The hammer that had plainly been used to drive it in lay beside the cot, on the edge of a dark stain that ran back under the cot.

ɪleɪn fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛmptiɪŋ əɹ stʌmək ɑn ðə spɑt. "laɪt," ʃi bɹiðd. "laɪt! hu kəd də ðɪs? haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn də ðɪs?" eɪvinhə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wʌndɝɪŋli, ən læn dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ wɪð ðæt. hi dʒʌst wɑtʃt naɪn dɝɛkʃənz ət wʌns, əz ðoʊ hi ɪkspɛktəd huɛvɝ, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ, hæd kəmɪɾəd ðɪs mɝɾɝ tə kʌm θɹu wʌn ə ðə tu taɪni wɪndoʊz ɪf nɑt θɹu ðə wɔlz. bɝdʒɪt dʒɹu hɝ bɛl naɪf, ən baɪ hɝ feɪs, ʃi dɪɹli wɪʃt ʃi hæɾ əɹ baʊ. ðət dʒɹɔn æɹoʊ wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛvɝ ɪn ɪleɪnz hɛd.

Elayne forced herself to stop thinking about emptying her stomach on the spot. "Light," she breathed. "Light! Who could do this? How could anyone do this?" Aviendha shook her head wonderingly, and Lan did not even bother with that. He just watched nine directions at once, as though he expected whoever, or whatever, had committed this murder to come through one of the two tiny windows if not through the walls. Birgitte drew her belt knife, and by her face, she dearly wished she had her bow. That drawn arrow was stronger than ever in Elayne's head.

ət fɝst, nɪneɪiv sɪmpli stʊɾ ɪn wʌn spɑt, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə hʌts ɪntɪɹiɝ. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl tə si, əsaɪd fɹəm ði ɑbviəs. ə sɛkən θɹi-lɛɡəd stul, ə ɹʌf teɪbəl hoʊldɪŋ ə flɪkɝɪŋ læmp, ə ɡɹin tipɑɾ ən ə sɛkən kʌp, ə ɹud stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs wɪð koʊld æʃ ɑn ðə hɑɹθstoʊn. ðət wɑz ɔl. ðə hʌt wɑz soʊ smɔl ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk nɪneɪiv ə stɛp tə ɹitʃ ðə teɪbəl. dɪpɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ɪndə ðə tipɑt, ʃi tʌtʃt ɪt tə ðə tɪp ə hɝ tʌŋ, ðən spæt vɪɡɝəsli ən ɛmptid ðə hoʊl tipɑɾ ɪndə ðə teɪbəl ɪn ə wɑʃ ə ti ən ti livz. ɪleɪn blɪŋkt wʌndɝɪŋli.

At first, Nynaeve simply stood in one spot, studying the hut's interior. There was little to see, aside from the obvious. A second three-legged stool, a rough table holding a flickering lamp, a green teapot and a second cup, a rude stone fireplace with cold ash on the hearthstone. That was all. The hut was so small it only took Nynaeve a step to reach the table. Dipping her finger into the teapot, she touched it to the tip of her tongue, then spat vigorously and emptied the whole teapot into the table in a wash of tea and tea leaves. Elayne blinked wonderingly.

"wʌt hæpənd?" vændin æskt kuli fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. læn muv tə bɑɹ əɹ weɪ, bʌt ʃi stɑpt ɪm wɪð ə smɔl dʒɛstʃɝ. ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd tə pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ɹəsivd ənʌðɝ ɹeɪz hæn tə kip əɹ bæk. vændinz aɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɑn əɹ sɪstɝ, kɑm ɪn ə feɪs ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. ðə dɛd wʊmən ɑn ðə kɑt maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv ɪɡzɪstəd. "wɛn aɪ sɔ ɔl ə jə hɛɾɪŋ ðɪs weɪ, aɪ θɔt . . . wi nu wi dɪdn əv mɛni jɪɹz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, bʌt . . ." hɝ vɔɪs saʊndəd sɝɛnəɾi ɪtsɛlf, bʌt smɔl wʌndɝ ɪf ðət wɑz ə mæsk. "wʌɾ əv jə faʊnd, nɪneɪiv?"

"What happened?" Vandene asked coolly from the door. Lan moved to bar her way, but she stopped him with a small gesture. Elayne started to put an arm around her, and received another raised hand to keep her back. Vandene's eyes remained on her sister, calm in a face of Aes Sedai serenity. The dead woman on the cot might as well not have existed. "When I saw all of you heading this way, I thought . . . We knew we didn't have many years remaining, but . . ." Her voice sounded serenity itself, but small wonder if that was a mask. "What have you found, Nynaeve?"

sɪmpəθi lʊkt ɑɾ ɑn nɪneɪivz feɪs. klɪɹɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊt, ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə ti livz wɪθaʊt tʌtʃɪŋ ðɛm. tə waɪt ʃeɪvɪŋz əmʌŋ ðə mæɾɪd blæk livz. "ðɪs ɪz kɹɪmsɑnθɝn ɹut," ʃi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt ən feɪlɪŋ. "ɪts swit, soʊ jə maɪt mɪs ɪɾ ɪn ti ənlɛs jə noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz, ɪspɛʃli ɪf jə teɪk ə lɑɾ ə hʌni."

Sympathy looked odd on Nynaeve's face. Clearing her throat, she pointed to the tea leaves without touching them. To white shavings among the matted black leaves. "This is crimsonthorn root," she said, trying to sound matter-of-fact and failing. "It's sweet, so you might miss it in tea unless you know what it is, especially if you take a lot of honey."

vændin nɑɾəd, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm əɹ sɪstɝ. "æɾɪliz dɪvɛləpt ə teɪs fəɹ swit ti ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ."

Vandene nodded, never taking her eyes from her sister. "Adeleas developed a taste for sweet tea in Ebou Dar."

"ə lɪɾəl kɪlz peɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ðɪs mʌtʃ . . . ðɪs mʌtʃ kɪlz, bʌt sloʊli. ivən ə fju sɪps wəd bi ɪnʌf." teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi æɾəd, "ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ɹɪmeɪn kɑnʃəs fəɹ aʊɝz. nɑɾ eɪbəl tə muv, bʌɾ əwɛɹ. iðɝ huɛvɝ dɪd ðɪs dɪdnt wɑnə ɹɪsk sʌmwʌn kʌmɪŋ tu sun wɪð ən æntɪdoʊt - nɑt ðəɾ aɪ noʊ wʌn, fəɹ ə bɹu ðɪs stʃɹɔŋ - əɹ ɛls ðeɪ wɑntəd wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ tə noʊ hu wɑz kɪlɪŋ ðɛm." ɪleɪn ɡæspt ət ðə bɹutæləɾi, bʌt vændin sɪmpli nɑɾəd.

"A little kills pain," Nynaeve said. "This much . . . This much kills, but slowly. Even a few sips would be enough." Taking a deep breath, she added, "They might have remained conscious for hours. Not able to move, but aware. Either whoever did this didn't want to risk someone coming too soon with an antidote - not that I know one, for a brew this strong - or else they wanted one or the other to know who was killing them." Elayne gasped at the brutality, but Vandene simply nodded.

"ɪspæn, aɪ θɪŋk, sɪns ðeɪ əpɪɹ tə hæv teɪkən ðə moʊs taɪm wɪð hɝ." ðə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡɹin ɔlmoʊst sim tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ əlaʊd, wɝkɪŋ aʊɾ ə pʌzəl. kʌɾɪŋ ə θɹoʊt tʊk lɛs taɪm ðən dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ə steɪk θɹu sʌmwʌnz hɑɹt. ðə kɑm ə hɝ meɪɾ ɪleɪnz skɪn kɹɔl. "æɾɪliz wəd nɛvɝ əv æksɛptɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk fɹəm sʌmwʌn ʃi dɪdnt noʊ, nɑɾ aʊt hɪɹ wɪð ɪspæn. ðoʊz tu fæks neɪm əɹ kɪlɝ, ɪn ə weɪ. eɪ dɑɹk-fɹɛnd, ən wʌn ʌv əɹ pɑɹɾi. wʌn ʌv ʌs." ɪleɪn fɛl tu tʃɪlz, hɝ oʊn, ən bɝdʒɪts.

"Ispan, I think, since they appear to have taken the most time with her." The white-haired Green almost seemed to be thinking aloud, working out a puzzle. Cutting a throat took less time than driving a stake through someone's heart. The calm of her made Elayne's skin crawl. "Adeleas would never have accepted anything to drink from someone she didn't know, not out here with Ispan. Those two facts name her killer, in a way. A Dark-friend, and one of our party. One of us." Elayne felt two chills, her own, and Birgitte's.

"wʌn ʌv ʌs," nɪneɪiv əɡɹid sædli. eɪvinhə bɪɡæn tɛstɪŋ ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ bɛl naɪf ɑn əɹ θʌm, ən fəɹ wʌns, ɪleɪn fɛl noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən.

"One of us," Nynaeve agreed sadly. Aviendha began testing the edge of her belt knife on her thumb, and for once, Elayne felt no objection.

vændin æsk tə bi lɛft əloʊn wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ fəɹ ə fju moʊməns, ən sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ tə kɹeɪɾəl æɾɪliz ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹ. jeɪɛm, vændinz nɑɹld oʊld wɔɹɾɝ, wɑz weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd wɪð ə ʃɪvɝɪŋ kɝstʃən.

Vandene asked to be left alone with her sister for a few moments, and sat on the floor to cradle Adeleas in her arms before they were out of the door. Jaem, Vandene's gnarled old Warder, was waiting outside with a shivering Kirstian.

sʌɾənli ə weɪl bɝst aʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə hʌt, ðə fʊl-θɹoʊɾɪd kɹaɪ ʌv ə wʊmən mɔɹnɪŋ ðə lɔs ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ. nɪneɪiv, ʌv ɔl pipəl, tɝn tə ɡoʊ bæk, bʌt læn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm, ən jeɪɛm plæntəd hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ wɪð aɪz nɑt mʌtʃ wɔɹmɝ ðən lænz. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt liv ðɛm, vændin tə ʃɹik əɹ peɪn, ən jeɪɛm tə ɡɑɹɾ əɹ ɪn ɪt. ən ʃɛɹ ɪt, ɪleɪn ɹilaɪzd, filɪŋ ðət nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn əɹ hɛd ðət wɑz bɝdʒɪt. ʃi ʃɪvɝd, ən bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. eɪvinhə dɪd ðə seɪm fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ən moʊʃən fəɹ nɪneɪiv tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, wɪtʃ ʃi dɪd, æftɝ ə moʊmənt. ðə mɝɾɝ ɪleɪn hæd θɔɾ ə soʊ laɪtli hæd kʌm, wʌn ə ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ðə deɪ sʌɾənli fɛl koʊld ɪnʌf tə ʃæɾɝ boʊnz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə wɔɹmθ ɪn ðə kloʊsnɪs ə hɝ fɹɛnz.

Suddenly a wail burst out inside the hut, the full-throated cry of a woman mourning the loss of everything. Nynaeve, of all people, turned to go back, but Lan laid a hand on her arm, and Jaem planted himself before the door with eyes not much warmer than Lan's. There was nothing to do but leave them, Vandene to shriek her pain, and Jaem to guard her in it. And share it, Elayne realized, feeling that knot of emotions in her head that was Birgitte. She shivered, and Birgitte put an arm around her shoulders. Aviendha did the same from the other side, and motioned for Nynaeve to join them, which she did, after a moment. The murder Elayne had thought of so lightly had come, one of their companions was a Darkfriend, and the day suddenly felt cold enough to shatter bones, but there was a warmth in the closeness of her friends.

ðə læs tɛn fjunɝiəl maɪlz tə keɪɛmlɪn tʊk tu deɪz ɪn ðə snoʊ, wɪð ivən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz disənli səbdud. nɑt ðət ðeɪ pʊʃt mɛɝɪlɪl ɛni lɛs hɑɹd. nɑt ðət kɪn stɑp tɔkɪŋ, ən fɔlɪŋ saɪlənt wɛnɛvɝ ə sɪstɝ əɹ wʌn ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl keɪm nɪɹ. vændin, wɪð əɹ sɪstɝz sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd sæɾəl ɑn əɹ hɔɹs, əpɪɹɾ əz sɝin əz ʃi hæɾ əɾ æɾɪliz' ɡɹeɪvsaɪd, bʌt jeɪɛmz aɪz kæɹiɾ ə saɪlən pɹɑməs ə dɛθ ðət ʃʊɹli ɹoʊɾ ɪn vændinz hɑɹt, tu. ɪleɪn kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn hæpiɝ tə si ðə wɔlz ən taʊɝz ə keɪɛmlɪn ɪf ðə vɛɹi saɪt hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ən bɹɔt bæk æɾɪliz.

The last ten funereal miles to Caemlyn took two days in the snow, with even the Windfinders decently subdued. Not that they pushed Merilille any less hard. Not that Kin stopped talking, and falling silent whenever a sister or one of the Knitting Circle came near. Vandene, with her sister's silver-mounted saddle on her horse, appeared as serene as she had at Adeleas' graveside, but Jaem's eyes carried a silent promise of death that surely rode in Vandene's heart, too. Elayne could not have been happier to see the walls and towers of Caemlyn if the very sight had given her the Rose Crown and brought back Adeleas.

ivən keɪɛmlɪn, wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz ə ðə wɝld, hæd nɛvɝ sin ðə laɪks ə ðɛɹ pɑɹɾi bɪfɔɹ, ən wʌns ɪnsaɪd ðə fɪfti-fʊt wɔlz ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ðeɪ ətʃɹæktəd noʊɾəs əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə nu sɪɾi əlɔŋ waɪd, slʌʃ-fɪl stʃɹits bʌsəlɪŋ wɪð pipəl ən kɑɹts ən wæɡənz. ʃɑpkipɝz stʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ dɔɹweɪz ən ɡeɪpt. wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz ɹeɪn ɪn ðɛɹ timz tə stɛɹ. taʊɝɪŋ ilmɛn ən tɔl meɪɾənz aɪɾ əm fɹəm ɛvɹi kɔɹnɝ, ɪt simd. ðə pipəl sim tə teɪk noʊ noʊɾəs ə ði il, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪd. ʃi lʌvd eɪvinhə əz ʃi dɪd hɝsɛlf, mɔɹ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt lʌv ən ɑɹmi ʌv ɑɹmd il wɔkɪŋ keɪɛmlɪnz stʃɹits.

Even Caemlyn, one of the great cities of the world, had never seen the likes of their party before, and once inside the fifty-foot walls of gray stone they attracted notice as they crossed the New City along wide, slush-filled streets bustling with people and carts and wagons. Shopkeepers stood in their doorways and gaped. Wagon drivers reined in their teams to stare. Towering Aielmen and tall Maidens eyed them from every corner, it seemed. The people seemed to take no notice of the Aiel, but Elayne did. She loved Aviendha as she did herself, more, but she could not love an army of armed Aiel walking Caemlyn's streets.

ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, ɹɪŋ baɪ taʊɝd wɔlz ə sɪlvɝ-stʃɹikt waɪt, wɑz ə ɹɪmɛmbɝd dɪlaɪt, ən ɪleɪn faɪnəli bɪɡæn tə fil ðət ʃi wɑz kʌmɪŋ hoʊm. ðə stʃɹits fɑloʊd ðə kɝvz ə ðə hɪlz, ən ɛvɹi ɹaɪz pɹizɛntəɾ ə nu vɪstə ʌv snoʊ-kʌvɝd pɑɹks ən mɑnjəməns leɪɾ aʊt tə bi sin fɹəm əbʌv əz wɛl əz ʌp kloʊs, ʌv bɹaɪtli taɪl taʊɝz ʃaɪnɪŋ wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd kʌlɝz ɪn ði æftɝnun sʌn. ən ðən ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪtsɛlf wɑz bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ə kənfɛkʃən ə peɪl spaɪɹz ən ɡoʊldən doʊmz ən ɪntʃɹəkət stoʊnwɝk tʃɹeɪsɝiz. ðə bænɝ ʌv ændɝ weɪv fɹəm nɪɹli ɛvɹi pɹɑmənəns, ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn ɹɛd. ən fɹəm ði ʌðɝz, ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝ əɹ ðə bænɝ ə laɪt.

The Inner City, ringed by towered walls of silver-streaked white, was a remembered delight, and Elayne finally began to feel that she was coming home. The streets followed the curves of the hills, and every rise presented a new vista of snow-covered parks and monuments laid out to be seen from above as well as up close, of brightly tiled towers shining with a hundred colors in the afternoon sun. And then the Royal Palace itself was before them, a confection of pale spires and golden domes and intricate stonework traceries. The banner of Andor waved from nearly every prominence, the White Lion on red. And from the others, the Dragon Banner or the Banner of Light.

ət ðə tɔl ɡɪldɪd ɡeɪts ə ðə pæləs, ɪleɪn ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝɾ əloʊn ɪn əɹ tʃɹævəl-steɪnd ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs. tʃɹədɪʃən ən lɛdʒən sɛd wɪmən u fɝst əpɹoʊtʃt ðə pæləs ɪn splɛndɝ ɔlweɪz feɪld. ʃi hæd meɪd klɪɹ ðət ʃi hæd tə də ɪɾ əloʊn, jɛt ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt hæd səksiɾəd ɪn oʊvɝɹulɪŋ hɝ. hæf ðə tu dʌzən ɡɑɹdz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡeɪts wɝ il meɪɾənz, ði ʌðɝz mɛn ɪn blu hɛlməts ən blu koʊts wɪð ə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən mɑɹtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst.

At the tall gilded gates of the Palace, Elayne rode forward alone in her travel-stained gray riding dress. Tradition and legend said women who first approached the Palace in splendor always failed. She had made clear that she had to do it alone, yet she almost wished Aviendha and Birgitte had succeeded in overruling her. Half the two dozen guards in front of the gates were Aiel Maidens, the others men in blue helmets and blue coats with a red-and-gold Dragon marching across the chest.

"aɪ æm ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd," ʃi ənaʊns laʊdli, sɝpɹaɪzd ət haʊ kɑm ʃi saʊndəd. hɝ vɔɪs kæɹid, ən əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹeɪt plɑzə pipəl tɝn fɹəm stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ kəmpænjənz tə stɛɹ ət hɝ. ði eɪntʃən fɔɹmjələ ɹoʊl fɹəm əɹ tʌŋ. "ɪn ðə neɪm ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd, baɪ ɹaɪɾ ə dɪsɛn fɹəm ɪʃɑɹə, aɪ hæv kʌm tə kleɪm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ, ɪf ðə laɪt wɪlz ɪt soʊ."

"I am Elayne Trakand," she announced loudly, surprised at how calm she sounded. Her voice carried, and across the great plaza people turned from staring at her companions to stare at her. The ancient formula rolled from her tongue. "In the name of House Trakand, by right of descent from Ishara, I have come to claim the Lion Throne of Andor, if the Light wills it so."

ðə ɡeɪts oʊpənd waɪd.

The gates opened wide.

ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðəɾ izi, ʌv kɔɹs. ivən pəzɛʃən ə ðə pæləs wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə hoʊl ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ baɪ ɪtsɛlf. pæsɪŋ əɹ kəmpænjənz ɪndə ðə kɛɹ ʌv ən əstɑnɪʃt ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ - ən vɛɹi pliz tə si ðət ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ fɝs meɪd, ɹaʊn ən əz ɹiɡəl əz ɛni kwin, stɪl hæd ðə pæləs ɪn əɹ keɪpəbəl hænz - ən ə koʊɾɝi ʌv sɝvəns ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi, ɪleɪn hɝid tə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, ðə θɹoʊn ɹum ʌv ændɝ. əloʊn, əɡɛn. ðɪs wɑz nɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹɪtʃuəl, nɑt jɛt. ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn gɑnə tʃeɪnʒ ɪndə ðə ɹɛd sɪlk wɪð ðə pɝl-wɝk bɑɾəs ən waɪt laɪənz klaɪmɪŋ ðə slivz, bʌt ʃi fɛl kəmpɛld. ðɪs taɪm, nɑɾ ivən nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə əbdʒɛkt.

It would not be that easy, of course. Even possession of the Palace was not enough to hold the throne of Andor by itself. Passing her companions into the care of an astonished Reene Harfor - and very pleased to see that the graying First Maid, round and as regal as any queen, still had the Palace in her capable hands - and a coterie of servants in red-and-white livery, Elayne hurried to the Grand Hall, the throne room of Andor. Alone, again. This was not part of the ritual, not yet. She should have been going to change into the red silk with the pearl-worked bodice and white lions climbing the sleeves, but she felt compelled. This time, not even Nynaeve tried to object.

waɪt kɑləmz twɛnti peɪsɪz haɪ mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl. ðə θɹoʊn ɹum wɑz ɛmpti, stɪl. ðət wəd nɑt læs lɔŋ. klɪɹ æftɝnun laɪt θɹu ðə ɡlæs keɪsməns ɪn tɔl wɪndoʊz əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz mɪŋɡəld wɪð ðə kʌlɝd laɪt θɹu ðə ɡɹeɪt wɪndoʊz sɛɾ ɪn ðə silɪŋ, wɛɹ ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ ɔltɝneɪɾəd wɪð sinz ʌv ændɔɝən vɪktɝiz ən ðə feɪsəz ə ðə lænz ɝliəs kwinz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ɪʃɑɹə hɝsɛlf, əz dɑɹk əz ɛni ʌv ði æθɑn maɪɹ, əz fʊl ʌv əθɔɹəɾi əz ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ ɹulɝ ʌv ændɝ kəd fɝɡɛt hɝsɛlf wɪð ðə pɹɛɾəsɛsɝz u hæd fɔɹdʒ ðɪs neɪʃən stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət hɝ.

White columns twenty paces high marched down the sides of the Grand Hall. The throne room was empty, still. That would not last long. Clear afternoon light through the glassed casements in tall windows along the walls mingled with the colored light through the great windows set in the ceiling, where the White Lion of Andor alternated with scenes of Andoran victories and the faces of the land's earliest queens, beginning with Ishara herself, as dark as any of the Atha'an Miere, as full of authority as any Aes Sedai. No ruler of Andor could forget herself with the predecessors who had forged this nation staring down at her.

wʌn θɪŋ ʃi fɪɹd tə si - ðə hjudʒ mɑnstʃɹɑsəɾi ʌv ə θɹoʊn, ɔl ɡɪldɪd dʒɹæɡənz, ðət ʃi hæd sin stændɪŋ ɑn ðə deɪz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə hɔl ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ðə laɪən θɹoʊn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ə tɔl plɪnθ laɪk səm tʃɹoʊfi, iðɝ, bʌt kɛpt ɪts pɹɑpɝ pleɪs əpɑn ðə deɪz, ə mæsɪv tʃɛɹ, kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd, bʌt saɪz fəɹ ə wʊmən. ðə waɪt laɪən, pɪkt aʊɾ ɪn munstoʊnz ɑn ə fild ə ɹubiz, wəd stæn əbʌv ðə hɛɾ ʌv ɛni wʊmən u sæt ðɛɹ. noʊ mæn kəd fil əɾ ɪz iz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðət θɹoʊn, bɪkɔz, soʊ lɛdʒən sɛd, hi wəd noʊ hi hæd sild ɪz dum. ɪleɪn θɔɾ ɪt mɔɹ laɪkli ðə bɪldɝz hæd sɪmpli meɪd ʃʊɹ ə mæn wəd nɑt fɪɾ ɑn ɪɾ izəli.

One thing she feared to see - the huge monstrosity of a throne, all gilded Dragons, that she had seen standing on the dais at the far end of the Hall in Tel'aran'rhiod. It was not there, thank the Light. The Lion Throne no longer rested on a tall plinth like some trophy, either, but kept its proper place upon the dais, a massive chair, carved and gilded, but sized for a woman. The White Lion, picked out in moonstones on a field of rubies, would stand above the head of any woman who sat there. No man could feel at his ease sitting on that throne, because, so legend said, he would know he had sealed his doom. Elayne thought it more likely the builders had simply made sure a man would not fit on it easily.

klaɪmɪŋ ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl stɛps ə ðə deɪz, ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn wʌn ɑɹm ə ðə θɹoʊn. ʃi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə sɪɾ ɑn ɪt hɝsɛlf, nɑt jɛt. nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi wɑz æknɑlɪdʒ kwin. bʌt teɪkɪŋ oʊðz ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑz ə kʌstəm əz oʊld əz ændɝ. ʃi hæd tə ɹɪzɪs ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə sɪmpli fɔl ɑn əɹ niz ən wip ɪndə ðə θɹoʊnz sit. ɹɛkənsaɪl tə hɝ mʌðɝz dɛθ ʃi maɪt bi, bʌt ðɪs bɹɔt bæk ɔl ðə peɪn. ʃi kəd nɑt bɹeɪk daʊn naʊ.

Climbing the white marble steps of the dais, she laid a hand on one arm of the throne. She had no right to sit on it herself, not yet. Not until she was acknowledged Queen. But taking oaths on the Lion Throne was a custom as old as Andor. She had to resist the desire to simply fall on her knees and weep into the throne's seat. Reconciled to her mother's death she might be, but this brought back all the pain. She could not break down now.

"ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, əl ɑnɝ jəɹ mɛmɹi, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "aɪ wɪl ɑnɝ ðə neɪm ə mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd, ən tʃɹaɪ tə bɹɪŋ oʊnli ɑnɝ tə haʊs tʃɹəkənd."

"Under the Light, I will honor your memory, Mother," she said softly. "I will honor the name of Morgase Trakand, and try to bring only honor to House Trakand."

"aɪ ɔɹɾɝd ðə ɡɑɹdz tə kip ðə kjʊɹiəs ən ðə feɪvɝ-sikɝz əweɪ. aɪ səspɛktəd jə maɪt wɑnə bi əloʊn hɪɹ fəɹ ə taɪm."

"I ordered the guards to keep the curious and the favor-seekers away. I suspected you might want to be alone here for a time."

ɪleɪn tɝn sloʊli tə feɪs daɪɛlɪn tæɹɑvɪn, əz ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən wɔk ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə ɡɹæn hɔl. daɪɛlɪn hæd bɪn wʌn ə hɝ mʌðɝz ɝliəst səpɔɹɾɝz ɪn əɹ oʊn kwɛs fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ ðən ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd, mɔɹ laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz. ʃi wɑz stɪl kwaɪt bjuɾəfəl. ə stʃɹɔŋ wʊmən. ən paʊɝfəl əz fɹɛn əɹ foʊ.

Elayne turned slowly to face Dyelin Taravin, as the golden-haired woman walked the length of the Grand Hall. Dyelin had been one of her mother's earliest supporters in her own quest for the throne. There was more gray in her hair than Elayne remembered, more lines at the corners of her eyes. She was still quite beautiful. A strong woman. And powerful as friend or foe.

ʃi stɑpt ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə deɪz, lʊkɪŋ ʌp. "aɪv bɪn hɪɹɪŋ fəɹ tu deɪz ðət jə wɝ əlaɪv, bʌɾ aɪ dɪdn ɹɪli bɪliv ɪɾ əntɪl naʊ. juv kʌm tə æksɛp ðə θɹoʊn fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðɛn?"

She stopped at the foot of the dais, looking up. "I've been hearing for two days that you were alive, but I didn't really believe it until now. You've come to accept the throne from the Dragon Reborn, then?"

"aɪ kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn baɪ maɪ oʊn ɹaɪt, daɪɛlɪn, wɪð maɪ oʊn hænd. ðə laɪən θɹoʊn ɪz noʊ bɔbəl tə bi æksɛptɪd fɹəm ə mæn." daɪɛlɪn nɑɾəd, əz ət sɛlf-ɛvəɾənt tʃɹuθ. wɪtʃ ɪt wɑz, tə ɛni ændɔɝən. "haʊ dʒju stænd, daɪɛlɪn? wɪð tʃɹəkənd, əɹ əɡɛnst? aɪ hæv hɝd jəɹ neɪm ɔfən ɑn maɪ weɪ hɪɹ."

"I claim the throne by my own right, Dyelin, with my own hand. The Lion Throne is no bauble to be accepted from a man." Dyelin nodded, as at self-evident truth. Which it was, to any Andoran. "How do you stand, Dyelin? With Trakand, or against? I have heard your name often on my way here."

"sɪns jə kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn baɪ jəɹ oʊn ɹaɪt, wɪð." fju pipəl kəd saʊn əz dʒɹaɪ əz ʃi. ɪleɪn sæt daʊn ɑn ðə tɑp stɛp, ən moʊʃən ði oʊldɝ wʊmən tə dʒɔɪn hɝ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə fju ɑbstəkəlz, ʌv kɔɹs," daɪɛlɪn wɛn ɑn əz ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ blu skɝts tə sɪt. "ðɛɹ əv bɪn sɛvɹəl kleɪməns ɔlɹɛɾi, əz jə meɪ noʊ. nɑiən ən ɛləniə, aɪ hæv sɪkjʊɹli lɑkt ʌp. ɑn ə tʃɑɹdʒ ə tʃɹizən ðət moʊs pipəl sim wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛpt. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. ɛləniəz hʌzbən ɪz stɪl æktɪv fəɹ hɝ, ðoʊ kwaɪətli, ən ɛɹəmɪlə hæz ənaʊnst ə kleɪm, ðə sɪli ɡus. ʃiz ɡɛɾɪŋ səpɔɹɾ ʌv ə kaɪnd, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ðət nid wɝi ju. jəɹ ɹil wɝiz - əsaɪd fɹəm il ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tə kʌm bæk - ɑɹ æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl, ən pɛlɪvɑɹ. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, lwɑn ən ɛlɹin wɪl bi bɪhaɪn ju, bʌt ðeɪ maɪt ɡoʊ oʊvɝ tə ðoʊz θɹi."

"Since you claim the throne by your own right, with." Few people could sound as dry as she. Elayne sat down on the top step, and motioned the older woman to join her. "There are a few obstacles, of course," Dyelin went on as she gathered her blue skirts to sit. "There have been several claimants already, as you may know. Naean and Elenia, I have securely locked up. On a charge of treason that most people seem willing to accept. For the time being. Elenia's husband is still active for her, though quietly, and Arymilla has announced a claim, the silly goose. She's getting support of a kind, but nothing that need worry you. Your real worries - aside from Aiel all over the city waiting for the Dragon Reborn to come back - are Aemlyn, Arathelle, and Pelivar. For the moment, Luan and Ellorien will be behind you, but they might go over to those three."

ə vɛɹi səksɪŋk lɪst, dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪn ə toʊn suɾəbəl fəɹ dɪskʌsɪŋ ə pɑsəbəl hɔɹs tʃɹeɪd. nɑiən ən ɛləniə ʃi nu əbaʊt, ɪf nɑt ðət dʒɑɝɪd stɪl θɔɾ ɪz waɪf hæɾ ə tʃæns ət ðə θɹoʊn. ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz ə ɡus tə bɪliv ʃi wəd bi æksɛptɪd, wʌtɛvɝ əɹ səpɔɹt. ðə læs faɪv neɪmz wɝ wɝiɪŋ, ðoʊ. itʃ hæd bɪn əz stʃɹɔŋ ə səpɔɹɾɝ ə hɝ mʌðɝ, əz hæd daɪɛlɪn, ən itʃ lɛɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ haʊs.

A very succinct list, delivered in a tone suitable for discussing a possible horse trade. Naean and Elenia she knew about, if not that Jarid still thought his wife had a chance at the throne. Arymilla was a goose to believe she would be accepted, whatever her support. The last five names were worrying, though. Each had been as strong a supporter of her mother, as had Dyelin, and each led a strong House.

"soʊ ɑɝəθɛl ən æɛmlɪn wɑn ðə θɹoʊn," ɪleɪn mɝmɝd. "aɪ kæn bɪliv ɪɾ ʌv ɛlɹin, nɑt fəɹ hɝsɛlf." pɛlɪvɑɹ maɪt bi æktɪŋ fəɹ wʌn ə hɪz dɔɾɝz, bʌt lwɑn hæɾ oʊnli ɡɹændɔɾɝz, nʌn nɪɹ oʊld ɪnʌf. "ju spoʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt junaɪt, ɔl faɪv haʊsəz. bɪhaɪn hum?" ðət wəd bi ə daɪɹ θɹɛt.

"So Arathelle and Aemlyn want the throne," Elayne murmured. "I can't believe it of Ellorien, not for herself." Pelivar might be acting for one of his daughters, but Luan had only granddaughters, none near old enough. "You spoke as if they might unite, all five Houses. Behind whom?" That would be a dire threat.

smaɪlɪŋ, daɪɛlɪn pɹɑpt əɹ tʃɪn ɪn əɹ hænd. "ðeɪ sim tə θɪŋk aɪ ʃəɾ əv ðə θɹoʊn. naʊ, wʌt dʒju ɪntɛn əbaʊt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn? hi hæzən bɪn bæk hɪɹ ɪn səm taɪm, bʌɾ i kən pɑp aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ, ɪt simz."

Smiling, Dyelin propped her chin in her hand. "They seem to think I should have the throne. Now, what do you intend about the Dragon Reborn? He hasn't been back here in some time, but he can pop out of the air, it seems."

ɪleɪn skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt wən ʃi oʊpən ðɛm, ʃi wɑz stɪl sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə stɛps ə ðə deɪz ɪn ðə ɡɹæn hɔl, ən daɪɛlɪn wɑz stɪl smaɪlɪŋ ət hɝ. hɝ bɹʌðɝ fɔt fəɹ ɪleɪɾə, ən əɹ hæf-bɹʌðɝ wɑz ə waɪtkloʊk. ʃi hæd fɪl ðə pæləs wɪð wɪmən u maɪt tɝn ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ əɾ ɛni moʊmənt, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə fæk ðət wʌn wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, meɪbi ivən blæk ədʒɑ. ən ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs θɹɛt ʃi feɪst ɪn kleɪmɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn, ə vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ wʌn, stʊd bɪhaɪn ə wʊmən u sɛd ʃi səpɔɹɾəd ɪleɪn. ðə wɝld wɑz kwaɪt mæd. ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl æɾ əɹ bɪt.

Elayne squeezed her eyes shut for a moment, but when she opened them, she was still sitting on the steps of the dais in the Grand Hall, and Dyelin was still smiling at her. Her brother fought for Elaida, and her half-brother was a Whitecloak. She had filled the Palace with women who might turn on one another at any moment, not to mention the fact that one was a Darkfriend, maybe even Black Ajah. And the strongest threat she faced in claiming the throne, a very strong one, stood behind a woman who said she supported Elayne. The world was quite mad. She might as well add her bit.

"aɪ min tə bɑn ɪm maɪ wɔɹɾɝ," ʃi sɛd, ən wɛn ɑn bɪfɔɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən kəd mɔɹ ðən blɪŋk ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. "aɪ ɔlsoʊ hoʊp tə mɛɹi hɪm. ðoʊz θɪŋz əv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, haʊɛvɝ. ðə vɛɹi fɝs θɪŋ aɪ ɪntɛnd . . ."

"I mean to bond him my Warder," she said, and went on before the other woman could more than blink in astonishment. "I also hope to marry him. Those things have nothing to do with the Lion Throne, however. The very first thing I intend . . ."

əz ʃi wɛn ɑn, daɪɛlɪn bɪɡæn tə læf. ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi nu wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz fɹəm dɪlaɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ plænz əɹ kəz daɪɛlɪn sɔ hɝ oʊn pæθ tə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn biɪŋ meɪd smuð. ət list ʃi nu wʌt ʃi feɪst, naʊ.

As she went on, Dyelin began to laugh. Elayne wished she knew whether it was from delight over her plans or because Dyelin saw her own path to the Lion Throne being made smooth. At least she knew what she faced, now.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn, dɑv hænlən kəd nɑt hɛlp θɪŋkɪŋ wʌɾ ə sɪɾi fəɹ ðə luɾɪŋ ɪt wɑz. ɪn ɪz jɪɹz soʊlʒɝɪŋ, hi hæd sin mɛni vɪlədʒəz ən taʊnz luɾəd, ən wʌns, twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi, kɛɹhin, æftɝ ði il lɛft. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðəɾ ɔl ðiz il hæd lɛf keɪɛmlɪn soʊ əpɛɹənli əntʌtʃt, bʌt ðɛn, ɪf ðə tɔlɪs taʊɝz ɪn kɛɹhin hæd nɑt bɪn bɝnɪŋ, ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn hɑɹd tə noʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðɛɹ; plɛnti ʌv ɡoʊld, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, laɪɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ ðə pɪkɪŋ ʌp, ən plɛnti ʌv mɛn tə də ðə pɪkɪŋ. hi kəd si ðiz bɹɔd stʃɹits fʊl ə hɔɹsmən ən fliɪŋ pipəl, fæt mɝtʃəns u wəd ɡɪv ʌp ðɛɹ ɡoʊl bɪfɔɹ ðə naɪf tʌtʃt əm ɪn ðə hoʊp ðɛɹ laɪvz wəd bi spɛɹd, slɪm ɡɝlz ən plʌmp wɪmən soʊ tɛɹəfaɪd wən ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹæɡd ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ ðət ðeɪ kəd hɑɹdli mænədʒ tə skwil, mʌtʃ lɛs stʃɹʌɡəl. hi hæd sin ðoʊz θɪŋz ən dʌn ðɛm, ən i hoʊp tə əɡɛn. nɑɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ðoʊ, hi ədmɪɾəd wɪð ə saɪ. ɪf ði ɔɹɾɝz ðət sɛn ɪm hɪɹ hæd bɪn ðə sɔɹɾ i kəd dɪsəbeɪ, hi wʊɾə ɡɔn wɛɹ ðə pɪkɪŋz maɪt nɑt bi soʊ ɹɪtʃ, bʌt dɛfənətli iziɝ tə plʌk.

Riding into Caemlyn, Daved Hanlon could not help thinking what a city for the looting it was. In his years soldiering, he had seen many villages and towns looted, and once, twenty years ago, a great city, Cairhien, after the Aiel left. Strange that all these Aiel had left Caemlyn so apparently untouched, but then, if the tallest towers in Cairhien had not been burning, it might have been hard to know they had been there; plenty of gold, among other things, lying about for the picking up, and plenty of men to do the picking. He could see these broad streets full of horsemen and fleeing people, fat merchants who would give up their gold before the knife touched them in the hope their lives would be spared, slim girls and plump women so terrified when they were dragged into a corner that they could hardly manage to squeal, much less struggle. He had seen those things and done them, and he hoped to again. Not in Caemlyn, though, he admitted with a sigh. If the orders that sent him here had been the sort he could disobey, he would have gone where the pickings might not be so rich, but definitely easier to pluck.

hɪz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz hæd bɪn klɪɹ. stɑbəlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ət ðə ɹɛd bʊl, ɪn ðə nu sɪɾi, hi wɔkt ə maɪl tə ə tɔl stoʊn haʊs ɑn ə saɪd stʃɹit, ðə haʊs ʌv ə wɛlθi mɝtʃən dɪskɹiɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ ɡoʊld, mɑɹkt wɪð ə taɪni peɪntəd sɪdʒəl ɑn ðə dɔɹz, ə ɹɛd hɑɹɾ ɑn ə ɡoʊldən hænd. ðə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ hu lɛɾ ɪm ɪn wɑz noʊ mɝtʃəns sɝvənt, wɪð ɪz sʌŋkən nʌkəlz ən sʌlən aɪz. wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd, ðə hjudʒ mæn lɛɾ ɪm dipɝ ɪndə ðə haʊs, ðən daʊn, təwɔɹd ðə beɪsməns. hænlən izd ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. əmʌŋ ðə θɪŋz i hæd sin wɝ mɛn ən wɪmən, feɪljɝz, lɛd tə ðɛɹ oʊn vɛɹi ɪlæbɹəɾ ɛksəkjuʃənz. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i hæd feɪld, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, hi hæd hɑɹdli səksiɾəd. hi hæd fɑloʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ. wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɪnʌf.

His instructions had been clear. Stabling his horse at The Red Bull, in the New City, he walked a mile to a tall stone house on a side street, the house of a wealthy merchant discreet about her gold, marked with a tiny painted sigil on the doors, a red heart on a golden hand. The hulking fellow who let him in was no merchant's servant, with his sunken knuckles and sullen eyes. Without a word, the huge man led him deeper into the house, then down, toward the basements. Hanlon eased his sword in its scabbard. Among the things he had seen were men and women, failures, led to their own very elaborate executions. He did not think he had failed, but then again, he had hardly succeeded. He had followed orders, though. Which was not always enough.

ɪn ðə ɹʌf stoʊn beɪsmənt, lɪt baɪ ɡɪldɪd læmps sɛɾ ɔl ɝaʊnd, hɪz aɪz wɛn fɝs tə ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən ɪn ə leɪs-tʃɹɪm dʒɹɛs ə skɑɹlət sɪlk, wɪð əɹ hɛɹ kɑɾ ɪn fɹɔθi leɪs nɛt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ hu ðɪs leɪɾi ʃieɪn wɑz, bʌɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn tə oʊbeɪ hɝ. hi meɪɾ ɪz bɛs lɛɡ, smaɪlɪŋ. ʃi sɪmpli lʊkt ət hɪm, əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə noʊɾəs wʌɾ ɛls ðə beɪsmən hɛld.

In the rough stone basement, lit by gilded lamps set all around, his eyes went first to a pretty woman in a lace-trimmed dress of scarlet silk, with her hair caught in frothy lace net. He did not know who this Lady Shiaine was, but his orders had been to obey her. He made his best leg, smiling. She simply looked at him, as if waiting for him to notice what else the basement held.

hi kəd hɑɹdli hæv mɪst ɪt, sɪns ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju kæsks ðə ɹum hɛld oʊnli ə lɑɹdʒ hɛvi teɪbəl, dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɪn ə vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ fæʃən. tu oʊvəlz hæd bɪn kʌɾ ɪn ðə teɪbəltɑp, ən fɹəm wʌn stʌk ðə hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz ʌv ə mæn, hɪz hɛd ɹɛntʃt bæk əɡɛns ðə wʊɾən sɝfəs ən hɛl ðəɹ baɪ minz ə lɛðɝ stʃɹæps neɪl tə ðə teɪbəltɑp ən fæsən tə ə blɑk ʌv wʊd dʒæm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. ə wʊmən, pɹipɛɹd ðə seɪm, pɹəvaɪɾəd ði ʌðɝ dɛkɝeɪʃən. bɪniθ ðə teɪbəl, ðeɪ nɛlt wɪð ɹɪsts taɪd tə æŋkəlz. kwaɪt sɪkjʊɹli hɛl fəɹ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə plɛʒɝ. ðə mæn hæɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz hɛɹ ən ðə feɪs ʌv ə lɔɹd, bʌɾ ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz ɹoʊld waɪldli. ðə wʊmənz hɛɹ, spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, wɑz dɑɹk ən ɡlɔsi, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz ə lɪɾəl lɔŋ fəɹ hænlənz teɪst.

He could hardly have missed it, since except for a few casks the room held only a large heavy table, decorated in a very strange fashion. Two ovals had been cut in the tabletop, and from one stuck the head and shoulders of a man, his head wrenched back against the wooden surface and held there by means of leather straps nailed to the tabletop and fastened to a block of wood jammed between his teeth. A woman, prepared the same, provided the other decoration. Beneath the table, they knelt with wrists tied to ankles. Quite securely held for any sort of pleasure. The man had a touch of gray in his hair and the face of a lord, but unsurprisingly, his deep-set eyes rolled wildly. The woman's hair, spread out on the table, was dark and glossy, but her face was a little long for Hanlon's taste.

sʌɾənli hi ɹɪli sɔ hɝ feɪs, ən ɪz hæn lɛp tə hɪz sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ i kəd stɑp ɪt. ɹilisɪŋ ðə hɪl tʊk səm ɛfɝt, wɪtʃ i meɪd peɪnz tə haɪd. ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs, bʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu lɛt hɝsɛlf bi fæsən laɪk ðət wɑz noʊ θɹɛt.

Suddenly he really saw her face, and his hand leaped to his sword before he could stop it. Releasing the hilt took some effort, which he made pains to hide. An Aes Sedai's face, but an Aes Sedai who let herself be fastened like that was no threat.

"soʊ juv səm bɹeɪnz," ʃieɪn sɛd. baɪ hɝ æksɛns, ʃi wɑz ə noʊbəl, ən ʃi sɝɾənli hæd ðə kəmændɪŋ ɛɹ, swipɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl tə pɪɹ daʊn ɪndə ðə baʊn mænz feɪs. "aɪ æsk ðə ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ mɔɹaɪɾɪn tə sɛn mi ə mæn wɪð bɹeɪnz. pʊɹ dʒeɪitʃɪm hɪɹ əz vɛɹi fju."

"So you have some brains," Shiaine said. By her accents, she was a noble, and she certainly had the commanding air, sweeping around the table to peer down into the bound man's face. "I asked the Great Master Moridin to send me a man with brains. Poor Jaichim here has very few."

hænlən fɹaʊnd, ən smuðd ɪɾ əweɪ ɪmiɾiətli. hɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd kʌm fɹəm mɑɡiɾin hɝsɛlf. hu ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə dum wɑz mɔɹaɪɾɪn? ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hɪz ɔɹɾɝz hæd kʌm fɹəm mɑɡiɾin; ðət wɑz ɪnʌf.

Hanlon frowned, and smoothed it away immediately. His orders had come from Moghedien herself. Who in the Pit of Doom was Moridin? It did not matter. His orders had come from Moghedien; that was enough.

ðə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ hændəd ʃieɪn ə fʌnəl, wɪtʃ ʃi fɪɾəd ɪndə ə hoʊl bɔɹd θɹu ðə blɑk ʌv wʊd bɪtwin ðɪs dʒeɪitʃɪmz tiθ. ðə mænz aɪz simd ɹɛɾi tə lip fɹəm ɪz hɛd. "pʊɹ dʒeɪitʃɪm hɪɹ feɪl vɛɹi bædli," ʃieɪn sɛd, smaɪlɪŋ laɪk ə fɑks lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə tʃɪkən. "mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɪʃɪz ɪm pʌnɪʃt. pʊɹ dʒeɪitʃɪm dʌz laɪk ɪz bɹændi."

The hulking fellow handed Shiaine a funnel, which she fitted into a hole bored through the block of wood between this Jaichim's teeth. The man's eyes seemed ready to leap from his head. "Poor Jaichim here failed very badly," Shiaine said, smiling like a fox looking at a chicken. "Moridin wishes him punished. Poor Jaichim does like his brandy."

ʃi stɛp bæk, nɑt soʊ fɑɹ ðət ʃi kəd nɑt si klɪɹli, ən hænlən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ðə hʌlkɪŋ mæn keɪm tə ðə teɪbəl wɪð wʌn ə ðə kæsks. hænlən dɪd θɪŋk i cʊɾə lɪftəd ðə θɪŋ əneɪɾɪd, bʌt ðə bɪɡ mæn tɪpt ɪɾ izəli. ðə baʊn mæn ʃɹikt wʌns, ən ðən ə stʃɹim ə dɑɹk lɪkwəd wɑz pɔɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə kæsk ɪndə ðə fʌnəl, tɝnɪŋ ɪz kɹaɪ tə ɡɝɡəlɪŋ. ðə ɹʌf smɛl ə kɹud bɹændi fɪl ði ɛɹ. sɪkjʊɹɾ əz i wɑz, ðə mæn fɔt, θɹæʃɪŋ əbaʊt, ivən mænɪdʒɪŋ tə hiv ðə teɪbəl saɪdweɪz, bʌt ðə bɹændi kɛpt pɔɹɪŋ. bʌbəlz ɹoʊz ɪn ðə fʌnəl əz i tʃɹaɪd tə ʃaʊɾ əɹ skɹim, bʌt ðə stɛɾi stʃɹim nɛvɝ fɔltɝd. ən ðən ɪz θɹæʃɪŋ sloʊɾ ən stɑpt. waɪd, ɡleɪzɪŋ aɪz stɛɹɾ ʌp ðə silɪŋ, ən bɹændi tʃɹɪkəl fɹəm ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz. ðə bɪɡ fɛloʊ stɪl dɪd nɑt stɑp əntɪl ðə læs dʒɹɑps fɛl fɹəm ən ɛmpti kæsk.

She stepped back, not so far that she could not see clearly, and Hanlon gave a start as the hulking man came to the table with one of the casks. Hanlon did think he could have lifted the thing unaided, but the big man tipped it easily. The bound man shrieked once, and then a stream of dark liquid was pouring from the cask into the funnel, turning his cry to gurgling. The rough smell of crude brandy filled the air. Secured as he was, the man fought, thrashing about, even managing to heave the table sideways, but the brandy kept pouring. Bubbles rose in the funnel as he tried to shout or scream, but the steady stream never faltered. And then his thrashing slowed and stopped. Wide, glazing eyes stared up the ceiling, and brandy trickled from his nostrils. The big fellow still did not stop until the last drops fell from an empty cask.

"aɪ θɪŋk pʊɹ dʒeɪitʃɪm əz faɪnəli hæɾ ɪnʌf bɹændi," ʃieɪn sɛd, ən læft ɪn dɪlaɪt.

"I think poor Jaichim has finally had enough brandy," Shiaine said, and laughed in delight.

hænlən nɑɾəd. hi səpoʊz ðə mæn hæd, ət ðæt. hi wʌndɝɾ u hi hæd bɪn.

Hanlon nodded. He supposed the man had, at that. He wondered who he had been.

ʃieɪn wɑz nɑt kwaɪt fɪnɪʃt. əɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm hɝ, ðə hʌlkɪŋ mæn ɹɪpt wʌn ə ðə stʃɹæps hoʊldɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡæɡ ɔf ʌv ɪts neɪl. hænlən θɔt ðə wʊɾən blɑk maɪɾ əv lusən ə fju ʌv əɹ tiθ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ maʊθ, bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, ʃi dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm ɑn ðɛm. ʃi bɪɡæn bæbəlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə fɛloʊ lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə stʃɹæp.

Shiaine was not quite finished. At a gesture from her, the hulking man ripped one of the straps holding the Aes Sedai's gag off of its nail. Hanlon thought the wooden block might have loosened a few of her teeth coming out of her mouth, but if so, she did not waste time on them. She began babbling before the fellow let go of the strap.

"aɪ wɪl oʊbeɪ ju!" ʃi haʊld. "aɪ wɪl oʊbeɪ, əz ðə ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ kəmændəd! hi sɛt ðə ʃild ɑn mi tə dɪzɑlv soʊ aɪ kəɾ oʊbeɪ! hi toʊl mi soʊ! lemi pɹuv maɪsɛlf! əl kɹɔl! aɪm ə wɝm, ən jə ɑɹ ðə sʌn! oʊ, pliz! pliz! pliz!"

"I will obey you!" she howled. "I will obey, as the Great Master commanded! He set the shield on me to dissolve so I could obey! He told me so! Let me prove myself! I will crawl! I am a worm, and you are the sun! Oh, please! Please! Please!"

ʃieɪn staɪfəld wɝdz ɪf nɑt wɪmpɝz baɪ pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz maʊθ. "haʊ də aɪ noʊ jə woʊn feɪl əɡɛn, fæljən? juv feɪl bɪfɔɹ, ən mɔɹaɪɾɪn lɛf jəɹ pʌnɪʃmən tə mi. hi ɡeɪv mi ənʌðɝ; də aɪ nid tu ʌv ju? aɪ meɪ ɡɪv jə ə sɛkən tʃæns tə plid jəɹ keɪs, fæljən - pɝhæps - bʌɾ ɪf aɪ du, jəl əv tə kənvɪns mi. əl ɪkspɛk tʃɹu ɪnθuziæzəm."

Shiaine stifled words if not whimpers by putting a hand over the Aes Sedai's mouth. "How do I know you won't fail again, Falion? You have failed before, and Moridin left your punishment to me. He gave me another; do I need two of you? I may give you a second chance to plead your case, Falion - perhaps - but if I do, you will have to convince me. I will expect true enthusiasm."

fæljən bɪɡæn skɹimɪŋ pliz əɡɛn, meɪkɪŋ ɪkstʃɹævəɡən pɹɑməsəz, ðə moʊmənt ʃieɪnz hæn muvd, bʌt sun ɪnʌf ʃi wɑz ɹədus tə wɝdləs ʃɹiks ən tɪɹz əz ðə ɡæɡ wɑz ɹipleɪst, ðə neɪl dʒɹɪvən θɹu ðə stʃɹæp əɡɛn, ən dʒeɪitʃɪmz fʌnəl pleɪst əbʌv əɹ ɡeɪpɪŋ θɹoʊt. ðə hʌlkɪŋ mæn stʊɾ ənʌðɝ kæsk ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim tə ɡoʊ mæd, bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ, flɪŋɪŋ hɝsɛlf əbaʊt bɪloʊ ðə teɪbəl tɪl ɪt tʃɹɛmbəld.

Falion began screaming pleas again, making extravagant promises, the moment Shiaine's hand moved, but soon enough she was reduced to wordless shrieks and tears as the gag was replaced, the nail driven through the strap again, and Jaichim's funnel placed above her gaping throat. The hulking man stood another cask on the table beside her head. The Aes Sedai seemed to go mad, bulging eyes rolling, flinging herself about below the table till it trembled.

hænlən wɑz ɪmpɹɛst. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌs bi hɑɹɾɝ tə bɹeɪk ðən ə plʌmp mɝtʃən əɹ ɪz ɹaʊnd-tʃik dɔɾɝ. stɪl, ʃi hæd hæd ðə hɛlp ʌv wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ɪt simd. ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃieɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, hi stɑp smaɪlɪŋ daʊn ət fæljən. hɪz fɝst ɹul ɪn laɪf wɑz nɛvɝ tə əfɛn ðoʊz ðə tʃoʊzən sɛɾ əbʌv hɪm.

Hanlon was impressed. An Aes Sedai must be harder to break than a plump merchant or his round-cheeked daughter. Still, she had had the help of one of the Chosen, it seemed. Realizing that Shiaine was looking at him, he stopped smiling down at Falion. His first rule in life was never to offend those the Chosen set above him.

"tɛl mi, hænlən," ʃieɪn sɛd, "haʊ wəd jə laɪk tə pʊt jəɹ hænz ɑn ə kwin?"

"Tell me, Hanlon," Shiaine said, "how would you like to put your hands on a queen?"

hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. ə kwin? ðæt, hi hæd nɛvɝ dʌn.

He licked his lips in spite of himself. A queen? That, he had never done.


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

eɪ kʌp ə slip


A Cup of Sleep

"doʊn bi ən ʌɾɝ wʊlhɛd, ɹænd," mɪn sɛd. meɪkɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, ʃi kɹɔst əɹ lɛɡz ən kɪkt əɹ fʊɾ aɪdli, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt kip ɛksæspɝeɪʃən aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. "ɡoʊ tə hɝ! spik tə hɝ!"

"Don't be an utter woolhead, Rand," Min said. Making herself remain seated, she crossed her legs and kicked her foot idly, but she could not keep exasperation out of her voice. "Go to her! Speak to her!"

"waɪ?" hi snæpt. "aɪ noʊ wɪtʃ lɛɾɝ tə bɪliv, naʊ. ɪts bɛɾɝ ðɪs weɪ. ʃiz seɪf, naʊ. fɹəm ɛniwʌn u wɑns tə stʃɹaɪk ət mi. seɪf fɹəm mi! ɪts bɛɾɝ!" bʌɾ i stɔkt ʌp ən daʊn ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz bɪtwin ðə tu ɹoʊz ə tʃɛɹz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn, hɪz fɪsts waɪt-nʌkəl hɑɹd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ tə bit ðə blæk klaʊdz bɪɑn ðə keɪsməns ðət wɝ leɪɪŋ ə nu blæŋkəɾ ə snoʊ ɑn kɛɹhin.

"Why?" he snapped. "I know which letter to believe, now. It's better this way. She's safe, now. From anyone who wants to strike at me. Safe from me! It's better!" But he stalked up and down in his shirtsleeves between the two rows of chairs in front of the Dragon Throne, his fists white-knuckle hard, glaring to beat the black clouds beyond the casements that were laying a new blanket of snow on Cairhien.

mɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð fɛdwɪn mɔɹ, hu stʊd baɪ ðə sʌn-kɑɹv dɔɹz. ðə meɪɾənz naʊ lɛɾ ɛniwʌn u wɑz nɑɾ ən ɑbviəs θɹɛt wɔk ɪn ʌnənaʊnst, bʌt ðoʊz ɹænd dɪd nɑt wɑnə si ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ wəd bi tɝn əweɪ baɪ ðə hʌski bɔɪ. hi wɔɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ən sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz blæk kɑlɝ, ən mɪn nu hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin mɔɹ bæɾəlz - mɔɹ hɔɹɝ - ðən moʊs mɛn θɹi taɪmz ɪz eɪdʒ, jɛɾ i wɑz ə bɔɪ. tədeɪ, kæstɪŋ ənizi ɡlænsɪz ət ɹænd, hi sim jʌŋɡɝ ðən ɛvɝ. ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp stɪl lʊkt aʊɾ ə pleɪs, tə hɝ.

Min exchanged looks with Fedwin Morr, who stood by the sun-carved doors. The Maidens now let anyone who was not an obvious threat walk in unannounced, but those Rand did not want to see this morning would be turned away by the husky boy. He wore the Dragon and Sword on his black collar, and Min knew he had already seen more battles - more horror - than most men three times his age, yet he was a boy. Today, casting uneasy glances at Rand, he seemed younger than ever. The sword on his hip still looked out of place, to her.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz ə mæn, fɛdwɪn," ʃi sɛd. "æn laɪk ɛni mæn, hiz sʌlkɪŋ kəz i θɪŋks ə wʊmən dʌznt wɑnə si hɪm əɡɛn."

"The Dragon Reborn is a man, Fedwin," she said. "And like any man, he's sulking because he thinks a woman doesn't want to see him again."

ɡɑəlɪŋ, ðə bɔɪ dʒɝkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɡus hɪm. ɹænd stɑp tə skaʊl əɾ əɹ sʌlənli. ɔl ðət kɛpt əɹ fɹəm læfɪŋ wɑz noʊɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz haɪɾɪŋ peɪn əz ɹil əz ɛni stæb waʊnd. ðæt, ən ðə ʃʊɹ nɑlədʒ ðəɾ i wəd bi əz hɝɾ ɪf ʃi hæd dʌn wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn. nɑt ðət ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ əv ðə tʃæns tə ɹɪp daʊn ɪz bænɝz, bʌt ðə pɔɪn əplaɪd. ɹænd hæd bɪn stʌn ət fɝs baɪ ðə nuz teɪm bɹɔt fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn ət dɔn, bʌɾ əz sun əz ðə mæn lɛft, hi hæd stɑp lʊkɪŋ laɪk ə pɑliæks bʊl ən stɑɹɾəd . . . ðɪs!

Goggling, the boy jerked as if she had goosed him. Rand stopped to scowl at her sullenly. All that kept her from laughing was knowing that he was hiding pain as real as any stab wound. That, and the sure knowledge that he would be as hurt if she had done what had been done. Not that she would ever have the chance to rip down his banners, but the point applied. Rand had been stunned at first by the news Taim brought from Caemlyn at dawn, but as soon as the man left, he had stopped looking like a poleaxed bull and started . . . This!

stændɪŋ, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ peɪl ɡɹin koʊt, foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən kənfɹʌntəɾ ɪm dɝɛkli. "wʌɾ ɛls kən ɪt bi?" ʃi æskt kɑmli. wɛl, ʃi tʃɹaɪd fəɹ kɑm, ən ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪt. ʃi lʌv ðə mæn, bʌɾ æftɝ ə mɔɹnɪŋ ə ðɪs, ʃi wɑntəd tə bɑks ɪz ɪɹz saʊnli. "ju hævən mɛnʃən mæt twaɪs, ən jə doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ hiz ivən əlaɪv."

Standing, she adjusted her pale green coat, folded her arms beneath her breasts, and confronted him directly. "What else can it be?" she asked calmly. Well, she tried for calm, and almost made it. She loved the man, but after a morning of this, she wanted to box his ears soundly. "You haven't mentioned Mat twice, and you don't know whether he's even alive."

"mæts əlaɪv," ɹænd snɑɹəld. "aɪd noʊ ɪf i wɑz dɛd. wʌt dʒju min ɪm - !" hɪz dʒɔ klɛntʃt əz ɪf i kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf seɪ ðə wɝd.

"Mat's alive," Rand snarled. "I'd know if he was dead. What do you mean I'm - !" His jaw clenched as if he could not make himself say the word.

"sʌlkɪŋ," ʃi pɹəvaɪɾəd. "sun, jəl bi paʊɾɪŋ. səm wɪmən θɪŋk mɛn ɑɹ pɹɪɾiɝ wən ðeɪ paʊt. aɪm nɑt wʌn ə ðɛm." wɛl, ɪnʌf ə ðæt. hɪz feɪs hæd dɑɹkənd, ən i wɑz nɑt blʌʃɪŋ. "hævən jə twɪstəd jɝsɛlf ɪndə nɑts tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi ɡɑt ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ? wɪtʃ ɪz hɝz baɪ ɹaɪt, maɪɾ aɪ æd. dɪdn jə seɪ jə wɑntəɾ əɹ tə hæv ændɝ hoʊl, nɑt ɹɪpt əpɑɹt laɪk kɛɹhin əɹ tiɹ?"

"Sulking," she provided. "Soon, you'll be pouting. Some women think men are prettier when they pout. I'm not one of them." Well, enough of that. His face had darkened, and he was not blushing. "Haven't you twisted yourself into knots to make sure she got the throne of Andor? Which is hers by right, might I add. Didn't you say you wanted her to have Andor whole, not ripped apart like Cairhien or Tear?"

"aɪ dɪd!" hi ɹɔɹd. "ænd naʊ ɪts hɝz, ən ʃi wɑns mi aʊɾ ʌv ɪt! ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf, aɪ seɪ! ən doʊn tɛl mi əɡɛn tə stɑp ʃaʊɾɪŋ! aɪm nɑt - !" hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz, ən klæmpt ɪz tiθ ʃʌt. ə loʊ ɡɹaʊl keɪm fɹəm ɪz θɹoʊt. mɔɹ sɛt tə stʌɾiɪŋ wʌn ə hɪz bʌɾənz, twɪstɪŋ ɪt bæk ən fɔɹθ. hi hæd bɪn duɪŋ ə lɑɾ ə ðət ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ.

"I did!" he roared. "And now it's hers, and she wants me out of it! Good enough, I say! And don't tell me again to stop shouting! I'm not - !" He realized that he was, and clamped his teeth shut. A low growl came from his throat. Morr set to studying one of his buttons, twisting it back and forth. He had been doing a lot of that this morning.

mɪn kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə slæp hɪm, ən i wɑz tu bɪɡ fəɹ əɹ tə spæŋk. "ændɝ ɪz hɝz, dʒʌst əz jə wɑntəd," ʃi sɛd. kɑmli. ɔlmoʊst. "nʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ əɹ naʊ ʃiz tɔɹn jəɹ bænɝz daʊn." ə deɪnʒɝəs laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðoʊz blu-ɡɹeɪ aɪz, bʌt ʃi pɹɛst ɑn. "dʒʌst əz jə wɑntəd. ən jə kæn bɪliv ʃiz saɪɾɪŋ wɪð jəɹ ɛnəmiz. ændɝ wɪl fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən jə noʊ ɪt. soʊ ði oʊnli ɹizən fəɹ jə tə bi ɪn ə snɪɾ ɪz kəz jə θɪŋk ʃi dʌznt wɑnə si ju. ɡoʊ tə hɝ, jə ful!" ðə nɛks pɑɹt wɑz ðə hɑɹɾəst tə seɪ. "bɪfɔɹ jə kən seɪ tu wɝdz, ʃɪl bi kɪsɪŋ ju." laɪt, ʃi lʌvd ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪd ɹænd - meɪbi əz mʌtʃ, ɪn ə vɛɹi dɪfɹənt weɪ - bʌt haʊ wɑz ə wʊmən tə kəmpit wɪð ə bjuɾəfəl ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd kwin u hæɾ ə paʊɝfəl neɪʃən əɾ əɹ bɛk ən kɔl?

Min kept her face smooth. She was not going to slap him, and he was too big for her to spank. "Andor is hers, just as you wanted," she said. Calmly. Almost. "None of the Forsaken are going after her now she's torn your banners down." A dangerous light appeared in those blue-gray eyes, but she pressed on. "Just as you wanted. And you can't believe she's siding with your enemies. Andor will follow the Dragon Reborn, and you know it. So the only reason for you to be in a snit is because you think she doesn't want to see you. Go to her, you fool!" The next part was the hardest to say. "Before you can say two words, she'll be kissing you." Light, she loved Elayne almost as much as she did Rand - maybe as much, in a very different way - but how was a woman to compete with a beautiful golden-haired queen who had a powerful nation at her beck and call?

"aɪ æm nɑt . . . æŋɡɹi," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. ən stɑɹɾəd peɪsɪŋ əɡɛn. mɪn kənsɪɾɝd kɪkɪŋ ɪm skwɛɹ ɪn ðə bɑɾəm. hɑɹd.

"I am not . . . angry," Rand said in a tight voice. And started pacing again. Min considered kicking him square in the bottom. Hard.

wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz oʊpən tə ədmɪt lɛðɝi waɪt-hɛɹd sɔɹɪliə, hu bɹʌʃt mɔɹ əsaɪɾ ivən əz i wɑz lʊkɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ ɹænd wɑntəɾ əɹ əlaʊɾ ɛntʃɹi. ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ - æŋɡɹəli, wʌtɛvɝ i tʃoʊz tə kleɪm - ən faɪv wɪmən ɪn θɪk blæk ɹoʊbz dæmp wɪð mɛltəd snoʊ fɑloʊd ðə waɪz wʌn ɪndə ðə ɹum, hænz foʊldəd, aɪz daʊn, ən dip hʊdz nɑt kwaɪt haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ðɛɹ fit wɝ ɹæpt ɪn ɹæɡz.

One of the doors opened to admit leathery white-haired Sorilea, who brushed Morr aside even as he was looking to see whether Rand wanted her allowed entry. Rand opened his mouth - angrily, whatever he chose to claim - and five women in thick black robes damp with melted snow followed the Wise One into the room, hands folded, eyes down, and deep hoods not quite hiding their faces. Their feet were wrapped in rags.

mɪnz skælp pɹɪkəld. tə hɝ aɪz, ɪmədʒəz ən ɔʊɹəz dænst ən vænɪʃt ən wɝ ɹipleɪst ɝaʊn ɔl sɪks wɪmən, dʒʌst əz ɝaʊn ɹænd. ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊpɪŋ i hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðoʊz faɪv wɝ əlaɪv. wʌɾ ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə laɪt wɑz ðət wɪkəɾ oʊld wʊmən duɪŋ?

Min's scalp prickled. To her eyes, images and auras danced and vanished and were replaced around all six women, just as around Rand. She had been hoping he had forgotten those five were alive. What in the name of the Light was that wicked old woman doing?

sɔɹɪliə dʒɛstʃɝd wʌns ɪn ə klæɾɝ ʌv ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi bɹeɪslɪts, ən ðə faɪv heɪstəli ɝeɪnʒd ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ə laɪn ətɑp ðə ɡoʊldən ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn sɛɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn flɔɹ. ɹænd stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ðət ɹoʊ, stʃɹɪpɪŋ bæk hʊdz, bɛɹɪŋ feɪsəz ðəɾ i stɛɹɾ ɪndə koʊld-aɪd.

Sorilea gestured once in a clatter of gold and ivory bracelets, and the five hastily arranged themselves in a line atop the golden Rising Sun set in the stone floor. Rand strode along that row, stripping back hoods, baring faces that he stared into cold-eyed.

ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə blæk-ɹoʊbd wɪmən wɑz ənwɑʃt, hɝ hɛɹ læŋk ən dɝɾi wɪð swɛt. ɛlzə pɛnfəl, ə ɡɹin sɪstɝ, mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz iɡɝli, ə stʃɹeɪnʒli fɝvən lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs. nɛsun bihɑɹə, ə slɛndɝ bɹaʊn, stʌɾid ɪm əz ɪntɛnli əz i dɪd hɝ. sɝin nɛmdɑl, soʊ bjuɾəfəl ivən ɪn əɹ dɝt ðət jə θɔɾ əɹ eɪɡləsnəs mʌs bi nætʃɹəl, əpɪɹd tə bi hoʊldɪŋ tə hɝ waɪɾ ədʒɑ kulnəs baɪ ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl. bɛldaɪn nɪɹæm, tu nu tə ðə ʃɔl tə hæv ði eɪdʒləs fitʃɝz, ɛseɪɾ ən ənsɝɾən smaɪl ðət mɛltəɾ ʌndɝ ɪz stɛɹ. ɛɹiən bɹoʊlɛoʊz, peɪl ən ɔlmoʊst əz lʌvli əz sɝin, flɪntʃt, ðən vɪzəbli fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə lʊk ɪndə ðət fɹɪdʒəd ɡeɪz. ðoʊz læs tu ɔlsoʊ wɝ ɡɹin, ən ɔl faɪv hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz u kɪdnæpt ɪm ɑn ɪleɪɾəz ɔɹɾɝz. səm hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ðoʊz u tɔɹtʃɝɾ ɪm waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kæɹi hɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. səmtaɪmz ɹænd stɪl woʊk, swɛɾɪŋ ən pæntɪŋ, mʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊt biɪŋ kənfaɪnd, biɪŋ biɾən. mɪn hoʊpt ʃi dɪd nɑt si mɝɾɝ ɪn ɪz stɛɹ.

Every one of the black-robed women was unwashed, her hair lank and dirty with sweat. Elza Penfell, a Green sister, met his gaze eagerly, a strangely fervent look on her face. Nesune Bihara, a slender Brown, studied him as intently as he did her. Sarene Nemdahl, so beautiful even in her dirt that you thought her agelessness must be natural, appeared to be holding to her White Ajah coolness by a fingernail. Beldeine Nyram, too new to the shawl to have the ageless features, essayed an uncertain smile that melted under his stare. Erian Boroleos, pale and almost as lovely as Sarene, flinched, then visibly forced herself to look into that frigid gaze. Those last two also were Green, and all five had been among the sisters who kidnapped him on Elaida's orders. Some had been among those who tortured him while trying to carry him to Tar Valon. Sometimes Rand still woke, sweating and panting, mumbling about being confined, being beaten. Min hoped she did not see murder in his stare.

"ðiz wɝ neɪm dætsæŋ, ɹænd ælθɹ," sɔɹɪliə sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ fil ðɛɹ ʃeɪm ɪn ðə boʊn, naʊ. ɛɹiən bɹoʊlɛoʊz wɑz ðə fɝs tə æsk tə bi biɾən əz jə wɝ, sʌnɹaɪz ən sʌnsɛt, bʌt naʊ itʃ əz dʌn soʊ. ðət pli hæz bɪn ɡɹæntəd. itʃ əz æsk tə sɝv jə haʊɛvɝ ʃi meɪ. ðə toʊ fəɹ ðɛɹ bɪtʃɹeɪəl kænɑt bi mɛt," hɝ vɔɪs dɑɹkən fəɹ ə moʊmənt; tə ði il, ðə bɪtʃɹeɪəl ə ðə kɪdnæpɪŋ wɑz fɑɹ wɝs ðən wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn æftɝ, "jɛt ðeɪ noʊ ðɛɹ ʃeɪm, ən ðeɪ wɪʃ tə tʃɹaɪ. wɪv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv ðə tʃɔɪs tə ju."

"These were named da'tsang, Rand al'Thor," Sorilea said. "I think they feel their shame in the bone, now. Erian Boroleos was the first to ask to be beaten as you were, sunrise and sunset, but now each has done so. That plea has been granted. Each has asked to serve you however she may. The toh for their betrayal cannot be met," her voice darkened for a moment; to the Aiel, the betrayal of the kidnapping was far worse than what they had done after, "yet they know their shame, and they wish to try. We have decided to leave the choice to you."

mɪn fɹaʊnd. liv ðə tʃɔɪs tə hɪm? waɪz wʌnz ɹɛɹli lɛft ɛni tʃɔɪs ðeɪ kəd meɪk tə ɛniwʌn ɛls. sɔɹɪliə nɛvɝ dɪd. ðə sɪnjui waɪz wʌn kæʒəwəli ʃɪftəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən wɑtʃt ɹænd əz ɪf ðɪs wɑz ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹɾəns əɾ ɔl. bʌt ʃi ʃɑt wʌn blu aɪs ɡlæns ət mɪn, ən sʌɾənli mɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪf ʃi sɛd ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ hɪɹ, ðət boʊni oʊld wʊmən wəɾ əv əɹ haɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə vjuɪŋ. ʃi dʒʌs nu sɔɹɪliə bɛɾɝ ðən ʃi wɑntəd tə, baɪ naʊ.

Min frowned. Leave the choice to him? Wise Ones rarely left any choice they could make to anyone else. Sorilea never did. The sinewy Wise One casually shifted her dark shawl on her shoulders and watched Rand as if this was of no importance at all. But she shot one blue ice glance at Min, and suddenly Min was sure that if she said the wrong thing here, that bony old woman would have her hide. It was not a viewing. She just knew Sorilea better than she wanted to, by now.

dətɝmənədli ʃi sɛt tə stʌɾiɪŋ wʌt wɑz əpɪɹɪŋ ən vænɪʃɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə wɪmən. noʊ izi tæsk wən ðeɪ stʊd soʊ kloʊs təɡɛðɝ ʃi kəd nɑt bi sɝɾən wɛðɝ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɪmədʒ bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn wʊmən əɹ ðə wʊmən nɛks tə hɝ. ət lis ði ɔʊɹəz wɝ ɔlweɪz sɝɾən. laɪt, lɛɾ əɹ bi eɪbəl tə ʌndɝstæn ət list səm ʌv wʌt ʃi sɔ!

Determinedly she set to studying what was appearing and vanishing around the women. No easy task when they stood so close together she could not be certain whether a particular image belonged to one woman or the woman next to her. At least the auras were always certain. Light, let her be able to understand at least some of what she saw!

ɹænd tʊk sɔɹɪliəz ənaʊnsmən kuli, ɑn ðə sɝfəs. hi ɹʌbd ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ sloʊli, ðən θɔtfəli ɪɡzæmən ðə hɛɹənz bɹændɪɾ ɑn ɪz pɑmz. hi ɪɡzæmən itʃ ə ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz ɪn tɝn. faɪnəli, hi foʊkəst ɑn ɛɹiən.

Rand took Sorilea's announcement coolly, on the surface. He rubbed his hands together slowly, then thoughtfully examined the herons branded on his palms. He examined each of those Aes Sedai faces in turn. Finally, he focused on Erian.

"waɪ?" hi æskt əɹ ɪn ə maɪl vɔɪs. "aɪ kɪl tu ʌv jəɹ wɔɹɾɝz. waɪ?" mɪn wɪnst. ɹænd wɑz mɛni θɪŋz, bʌt sɛldəm maɪld. ən ɛɹiən wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu hæd biɾən ɪm mɔɹ ðən wʌns.

"Why?" he asked her in a mild voice. "I killed two of your Warders. Why?" Min winced. Rand was many things, but seldom mild. And Erian was one of the few who had beaten him more than once.

ðə peɪl ɪliɑnɝ sɪstɝ stʃɹeɪɾənd. ɪmədʒəz dænst, ən ɔʊɹəz flæʃt ən wɝ ɡɔn. nʌθɪŋ mɪn kəd ɹid. dɝɾi-feɪst ən əɹ lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ mæɾɪd, ɛɹiən ɡæðɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əθɔɹəɾi ɝaʊn əɹ ən mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz lɛvəli. bʌɾ əɹ ænsɝ keɪm sɪmpli ən dɝɛkli. "wi dɪd bi ɹɔŋ ɪn teɪkɪŋ ju. aɪ hæv kənsɪɾɝd lɔŋ ɑn ɪt. jə mʌs faɪt ðə læs bæɾəl, ən wi mʌs hɛlp ju. ɪf jəl noʊ æksɛp mi, aɪ də ʌndɝstænd, bʌɾ əl hɛlp əz jə də ɹikwaɪɝ ɪf jəl əlaʊ."

The pale Illianer sister straightened. Images danced, and auras flashed and were gone. Nothing Min could read. Dirty-faced and her long black hair matted, Erian gathered Aes Sedai authority around her and met his gaze levelly. But her answer came simply and directly. "We did be wrong in taking you. I have considered long on it. You must fight the Last Battle, and we must help you. If you will no accept me, I do understand, but I will help as you do require if you will allow."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Rand stared at her without expression.

hi pʊt ðət seɪm wʌn-wɝd kwɛstʃən tə itʃ, ən ðɛɹ ænsɝz wɝ əz dɪfɹən əz ðə wɪmən.

He put that same one-word question to each, and their answers were as different as the women.

"ðə ɡɹin ɪz ðə bæɾəl ədʒɑ," bɛldaɪn toʊld ɪm pɹaʊdli, ən dɪspaɪt smʌdʒɪz ɑn əɹ tʃiks ən dɑɹk sɝkəlz bɪniθ əɹ aɪz, ʃi dɪd lʊk ə kwin ə bæɾəlz. bʌt ðɛn, sɑldəiən wɪmən sim tə faɪn ðət sɛkənd neɪtʃɝ. "wɛn jə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹmən ɡdən, ðə ɡɹin mʌs bi ðɛɹ. əl fɑloʊ, ɪf jəl æksɛp mi." laɪt, ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə bɑn ən æʃəmən əz ə wɔɹɾɝ! haʊ . . . ? noʊ; ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt naʊ.

"The Green is the Battle Ajah," Beldeine told him proudly, and despite smudges on her cheeks and dark circles beneath her eyes, she did look a Queen of Battles. But then, Saldaean women seemed to find that second nature. "When you go to Tarmon Gai'don, the Green must be there. I will follow, if you will accept me." Light, she was going to bond an Asha'man as a Warder! How . . . ? No; it was not important now.

"wʌt wi dɪd wɑz lɑdʒɪkəl ət ðə taɪm." sɝinz taɪtli hɛl kul sɝɛnəɾi slɪpt ɪndə klɪɹ wɝi, ən ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "aɪ seɪ ðət tə ɪkspleɪn, nɑt tə ɪkskəlpeɪt. sɝkəmstænsəz əv tʃeɪnʒd. fəɹ ju, ðə lɑdʒɪkəl kɔɹs maɪt sim tə . . ." ʃi dʒɹu ə dɪsaɪɾədli ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ. ɪmədʒəz ən ɔʊɹəz; ə tɛmpɛstʃuəs lʌv əfɛɹ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz! ðə wʊmən wɑz aɪs, haʊɛvɝ bjuɾəfəl. ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ jusfəl ɪn noʊɪŋ səm mæn wəd mɛl hɝ! "tə sɛn əs bæk tə kæptɪvəɾi," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "ɔɹ ivən ɛksəkjuɾ ʌs. fəɹ mi, lɑdʒɪk sɛz aɪ mʌst sɝv ju."

"What we did was logical at the time." Sarene's tightly held cool serenity slipped into clear worry, and she shook her head. "I say that to explain, not to exculpate. Circumstances have changed. For you, the logical course might seem to . . ." She drew a decidedly unsteady breath. Images and auras; a tempestuous love affair, of all things! The woman was ice, however beautiful. And there was nothing useful in knowing some man would melt her! "To send us back to captivity," she went on, "or even execute us. For me, logic says I must serve you."

nɛsun tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, ən əɹ nɪɹli blæk aɪz sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɔɹ əweɪ ɛvɹi skɹæp ə hɪm. wʌn ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin ɔɹə spoʊk ʌv ɑnɝz, ən feɪm. ə hjudʒ bɪldɪŋ əpɪɹɾ əbʌv əɹ hɛɾ ən vænɪʃt. ə laɪbɹɛɹi ʃi wəd faʊnd. "aɪ wɑnə stʌɾi ju," ʃi sɛd sɪmpli. "aɪ kən hɑɹdli də ðət kæɹiɪŋ stoʊnz əɹ dɪɡɪŋ hoʊlz. ðeɪ də liv plɛnti ʌv taɪm fəɹ θɔt, bʌt sɝvɪŋ jə simz ə fɛɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ fəɹ wʌɾ aɪ maɪt lɝn." ɹænd blɪŋkt ət ðə dɝɛknəs ə ðæt, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ.

Nesune tilted her head, and her nearly black eyes seemed to be trying to store away every scrap of him. One red-and-green aura spoke of honors, and fame. A huge building appeared above her head and vanished. A library she would found. "I want to study you," she said simply. "I can hardly do that carrying stones or digging holes. They do leave plenty of time for thought, but serving you seems a fair exchange for what I might learn." Rand blinked at the directness of that, but otherwise, his expression did not alter.

ðə moʊst sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ænsɝ keɪm fɹəm ɛlzə, ɪn əɹ mænɝ ə dɪlɪvɝi mɔɹ ðən ðə wɝdz. sɪŋkɪŋ tə hɝ niz, ʃi ɡeɪzd ʌp ət ɹænd wɪð fivɝɪʃ aɪz. hɝ hoʊl feɪs sim tə ʃaɪn wɪð fɝvɝ. ɔʊɹəz flɛɹɾ ən ɪmədʒəz kæskeɪɾɪd ɝaʊn hɝ, tɛlɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. "ju ɑɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "ju mʌs bi ðəɹ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl. aɪ mʌs hɛlp jə bi ðɛɹ! wʌtɛvɝ ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi, əl du!" ən ʃi flʌŋ hɝsɛlf feɪsdaʊn, pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ lɪps tə ðə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn flɔɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz buts. ivən sɔɹɪliə lʊk teɪkən əbæk, ən sɝinz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən. mɔɹ ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ ən heɪstəli ɹɪtɝn tə twɪstɪŋ ɪz bʌɾən. mɪn θɔɾ i ɡɪɡəl nɝvəsli, ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

The most surprising answer came from Elza, in her manner of delivery more than the words. Sinking to her knees, she gazed up at Rand with feverish eyes. Her whole face seemed to shine with fervor. Auras flared and images cascaded around her, telling nothing. "You are the Dragon Reborn," she said breathlessly. "You must be there for the Last Battle. I must help you be there! Whatever is necessary, I will do!" And she flung herself facedown, pressing her lips to the polished stone floor in front of his boots. Even Sorilea looked taken aback, and Sarene's mouth dropped open. Morr gaped at her and hastily returned to twisting his button. Min thought he giggled nervously, almost under his breath.

tɝnɪŋ ɑn ɪz hil, ɹænd stɔk hæfweɪ tə ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn, wɛɹ ɪz sɛptɝ ən ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən ɹɛstəɾ ətɑp ɪz ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹɛd koʊt. hɪz feɪs wɑz soʊ blik ðət mɪn wɑntəd tə ɹʌʃ tə hɪm noʊ mæɾɝ u wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəntɪnjud tə stʌɾi ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən sɔɹɪliə. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛniθɪŋ ɹɪli jusfəl ɝaʊn ðət waɪt-hɛɹd hɛɹɹəɾən.

Turning on his heel, Rand stalked halfway to the Dragon Throne, where his scepter and the crown of Illian rested atop his gold-embroidered red coat. His face was so bleak that Min wanted to rush to him no matter who was watching, but she continued to study the Aes Sedai. And Sorilea. She had never seen anything really useful around that white-haired harridan.

əbɹʌpli, ɹænd tɝn bæk, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə laɪn ʌv wɪmən soʊ kwɪkli ðət bɛldaɪn ən sɝin stɛp bæk. ə ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm sɔɹɪliə dʒɝkt əm ɪndə pleɪs əɡɛn.

Abruptly, Rand turned back, striding toward the line of women so quickly that Beldeine and Sarene stepped back. A sharp gesture from Sorilea jerked them into place again.

"wʊd jə æksɛp biɪŋ kənfaɪn ɪn ə bɑks?" hɪz vɔɪs ɡɹeɪɾɪd, stoʊn ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɑn fɹoʊzən stoʊn. "lɑkt ɪn ə tʃɛst ɔl deɪ, ən biɾən bɪfɔɹ jə ɡoʊ ɪn ən wən jə kʌm aʊt?" ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn tə hɪm.

"Would you accept being confined in a box?" His voice grated, stone grinding on frozen stone. "Locked in a chest all day, and beaten before you go in and when you come out?" That was what they had done to him.

"jɛs!" ɛlzə moʊn əɡɛns ðə flɔɹ. "wʌtɛvɝ aɪ mʌs du, aɪ wɪl!"

"Yes!" Elza moaned against the floor. "Whatever I must do, I will!"

"ɪf jə də ɹikwaɪɝ ɪt," ɛɹiən mænədʒd ʃɑkəli, ænd, feɪsəz əɡæst, ði ʌðɝz nɑɾəd sloʊli.

"If you do require it," Erian managed shakily, and, faces aghast, the others nodded slowly.

mɪn stɛɹɾ ɪn əmeɪzmənt, nɑɾɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɪn əɹ koʊt pɑkəts. ðəɾ i maɪt θɪŋk ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz oʊn bæk ɪn ðə seɪm mænɝ simd ɔlmoʊs nætʃɹəl, bʌt ʃi hæd tə stɑp ɪt, sʌmhaʊ. ʃi nu hɪm bɛɾɝ ðən i dɪd hɪmsɛlf; ʃi nu wɛɹ i wɑz hɑɹɾ əz ə naɪf bleɪd, ən wɛɹ i wɑz vʌlnɝəbəl noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hi dɪnaɪɾ ɪt. hi wəd nɛvɝ fɝɡɪv hɪmsɛlf ðɪs. bʌt haʊ? fjʊɹi kəntɔɹɾəd ɪz feɪs, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz i dɪd wən ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ðət vɔɪs i hɝd. hi mʌɾɝd wʌn wɝɾ əlaʊd ðət ʃi ʌndɝstʊd. tɑvɝən. sɔɹɪliə stʊd ðəɹ kɑmli ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɪm əz kloʊsli əz nɛsun dɪd. nɑɾ ivən ðə θɹɛɾ ə ðə tʃɛst ʃʊk ðə bɹaʊn. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɛlzə, stɪl moʊnɪŋ ən kɪsɪŋ ðə flɔɹ, ði ʌðɝz wɝ hɑloʊ-aɪd, əz ɪf siɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz dʌbəld ʌp ən baʊn əz i hæd bɪn.

Min stared in amazement, knotting her fists in her coat pockets. That he might think of getting his own back in the same manner seemed almost natural, but she had to stop it, somehow. She knew him better than he did himself; she knew where he was hard as a knife blade, and where he was vulnerable no matter how he denied it. He would never forgive himself this. But how? Fury contorted his face, and he shook his head as he did when arguing with that voice he heard. He muttered one word aloud that she understood. Ta'veren. Sorilea stood there calmly examining him as closely as Nesune did. Not even the threat of the chest shook the Brown. Except for Elza, still moaning and kissing the floor, the others were hollow-eyed, as if seeing themselves doubled up and bound as he had been.

əmʌŋ ɔl ə ðoʊz ɪmədʒəz spɪlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɹænd ən ðə wɪmən, sʌɾənli ən ɔɹə flæʃt, blu ən jɛloʊ tɪŋd wɪð ɡɹin, ɛnkʌmpəsɪŋ əm ɔl. ən mɪn nu ɪts minɪŋ. ʃi ɡæspt, hæf ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, hæf ɪn ɹɪlif.

Among all of those images spilling around Rand and the women, suddenly an aura flashed, blue and yellow tinged with green, encompassing them all. And Min knew its meaning. She gasped, half in surprise, half in relief.

"ðeɪ wɪl sɝv ju, itʃ ɪn əɹ fæʃən, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd hɝidli. "aɪ sɔ ɪt." sɔɹɪliə wəd sɝv hɪm? sʌɾənli mɪn wʌndɝɾ ɪɡzækli wʌt "ɪn əɹ fæʃən" mɛnt. ðə wɝdz keɪm wɪð ðə noʊɪŋ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz noʊ wʌt ðə wɝdz ðɛmsɛlvz mɛnt. bʌt ðeɪ wəd sɝv; ðət mʌtʃ wɑz pleɪn.

"They will serve you, each in her fashion, Rand," she said hurriedly. "I saw it." Sorilea would serve him? Suddenly Min wondered exactly what "in her fashion" meant. The words came with the knowing, but she did not always know what the words themselves meant. But they would serve; that much was plain.

ðə fjʊɹi dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɹændz feɪs əz i saɪlənli stʌɾid ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. səm ə ðɛm ɡlænst ət mɪn wɪð ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊz, ɑbviəsli mɑɹvəlɪŋ ðəɾ ə fju wɝdz fɹəm əɹ kæɹid soʊ mʌtʃ weɪt, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɹænd ən hɑɹdli sim tə bɹið. ivən ɛlzə lɪftəɾ əɹ hɛd tə ɡeɪz ʌp ət hɪm. sɔɹɪliə ɡeɪv mɪn wʌn kwɪk lʊk, ən ðə feɪntəs nɑd. əpɹuvɪŋ, mɪn θɔt. soʊ ði oʊld wʊmən pɹitɛndəd nɑt tə kɛɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ði ʌðɝ, dɪd ʃi?

The fury drained from Rand's face as he silently studied the Aes Sedai. Some of them glanced at Min with raised eyebrows, obviously marveling that a few words from her carried so much weight, but for the most part, they watched Rand and hardly seemed to breathe. Even Elza lifted her head to gaze up at him. Sorilea gave Min one quick look, and the faintest nod. Approving, Min thought. So the old woman pretended not to care one way or the other, did she?

ət læst, ɹænd spoʊk. "ju kən swɛɹ tə mi əz kaɪɹunə ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd. ðæt, əɹ ɡoʊ bæk tə wɛɹɛvɝ ðə waɪz wʌnz əv bɪn kipɪŋ ju. əl æksɛp nʌθɪŋ lɛs." dɪspaɪɾ ə hɪn ə dɪmæn ɪn ɪz vɔɪs, hi lʊkt əz ɪf hi, tu, dɪd nɑt kɛɹ, ɑɹmz foʊldəd, aɪz ɪmpeɪʃənt. ði oʊθ i dɪmændəɾ ə ðɛm keɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ.

At last, Rand spoke. "You can swear to me as Kiruna and the others did. That, or go back to wherever the Wise Ones have been keeping you. I'll accept nothing less." Despite a hint of demand in his voice, he looked as if he, too, did not care, arms folded, eyes impatient. The oath he demanded of them came out in a rush.

mɪn dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt kwɪbəlz, nɑɾ æftɝ əɹ vjuɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə sɝpɹaɪz wən ɛlzə skɹæmbəld ʌp tə hɝ niz, ən ði ʌðɝz loʊɝd ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðɛɹz. ɪn ɹæɡəd junəsən, faɪv mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ swɔɹ ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ ðɛɹ hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən tə sɝv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn feɪθfəli əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl hæd kʌm ən ɡɔn. nɛsun dɪlɪvɝd ðə wɝdz əz ðoʊ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ itʃ wʌn, sɝin əz ɪf steɪɾɪŋ ə pɹɪnsəpəl ə lɑdʒɪk, ɛlzə wɛɹɪŋ ə waɪd, vɪktɔɹiəs smaɪl, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl swɔɹ. haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ i ɡæðɝ ɝaʊn hɪm?

Min did not expect quibbles, not after her viewing, yet it was still a surprise when Elza scrambled up to her knees, and the others lowered themselves to theirs. In ragged unison, five more Aes Sedai swore under the Light and by their hope of salvation to serve the Dragon Reborn faithfully until the Last Battle had come and gone. Nesune delivered the words as though examining each one, Sarene as if stating a principle of logic, Elza wearing a wide, victorious smile, but they all swore. How many Aes Sedai would he gather around him?

wɪð ði oʊθ, ɹænd sim tə luz ɪntʃɹəst. "faɪn əm kloʊðz ən pʊɾ əm wɪð jəɹ ʌðɝ 'əpɹɛntəsɪz,' " hi toʊl sɔɹɪliə æbsənli. hi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌt nɑɾ əɾ əɹ əɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "haʊ mɛni dʒju θɪŋk jəl ɛn ʌp wɪð?" mɪn ɔlmoʊs dʒʌmpt ət ði ɛkoʊ ʌv əɹ oʊn θɔt.

With the oath, Rand seemed to lose interest. "Find them clothes and put them with your other 'apprentices,' " he told Sorilea absently. He was frowning, but not at her or the Aes Sedai. "How many do you think you'll end up with?" Min almost jumped at the echo of her own thought.

"haʊɛvɝ mɛni ɑɹ nɛsəsɛɹi," sɔɹɪliə sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "aɪ θɪŋk mɔɹ wɪl kʌm." ʃi klæpt əɹ hænz wʌns ən dʒɛstʃɝd, ən ðə faɪv sɪstɝz spɹæŋ tə ðɛɹ fit. oʊnli nɛsun lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd ət ði əlækɹəɾi wɪð wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊbeɪd. sɔɹɪliə smaɪld, ə vɛɹi sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl fəɹ ən il, ən mɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz kɑz baɪ ði ʌðɝ wɪmənz oʊbiɾiəns.

"However many are necessary," Sorilea said dryly. "I think more will come." She clapped her hands once and gestured, and the five sisters sprang to their feet. Only Nesune looked surprised at the alacrity with which they had obeyed. Sorilea smiled, a very satisfied smile for an Aiel, and Min did not think it was caused by the other women's obedience.

nɑɾɪŋ, ɹænd tɝn əweɪ. hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə peɪs əɡɛn, ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə skaʊl oʊvɝ ɪleɪn. mɪn sɛɾəld ɪndə hɝ tʃɛɹ wʌns mɔɹ, wɪʃɪŋ ʃi hæd wʌn ə mæstɝ fɛlz bʊks tə ɹid. əɹ tə θɹoʊ ət ɹænd. wɛl, wʌn ə mæstɝ fɛlz tə ɹid, ən sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz tə θɹoʊ.

Nodding, Rand turned away. He was already beginning to pace again, already beginning to scowl over Elayne. Min settled into her chair once more, wishing she had one of Master Fel's books to read. Or to throw at Rand. Well, one of Master Fel's to read, and someone else's to throw.

sɔɹɪliə hɝɾɪd ðə blæk-klæd sɪstɝz aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, bʌɾ ət ðə læst, ʃi pɔzd wɪð wʌn hæn hoʊldɪŋ ə dɔɹ ən lʊk bæk ət ɹænd stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ təwɔɹd ðə ɡɪldɪd θɹoʊn. hɝ lɪps pɝs θɔtfəli. "ðæt wʊmən, kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn, ɪz bɪniθ ðɪs ɹuf əɡɛn tədeɪ," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, tə hɪz bæk. "aɪ θɪŋk ʃi bɪlivz jə ɑɹ əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ, ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə weɪ jə əvɔɪɾ əɹ wɛɹəbaʊts." wɪð ðæt, ʃi lɛft.

Sorilea herded the black-clad sisters out of the room, but at the last, she paused with one hand holding a door and looked back at Rand striding away from her toward the gilded throne. Her lips pursed thoughtfully. "That woman, Cadsuane Melaidhrin, is beneath this roof again today," she said at last, to his back. "I think she believes you are afraid of her, Rand al'Thor, the way you avoid her whereabouts." With that, she left.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ɹænd stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə θɹoʊn. əɹ meɪbi ət sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑn ɪt. əbɹʌpli, hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk ən stʃɹoʊd ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ dɪstəns tə pɪk ʌp ðə kɹaʊn ə sɔɹdz. ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə sɛɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd, ðoʊ, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən pʊɾ ɪt bæk. dɑnɪŋ ðə koʊt, hi lɛf kɹaʊn ən sɛptɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ.

For a long moment, Rand stood staring at the throne. Or maybe at something beyond it. Abruptly, he gave himself a shake and strode the remaining distance to pick up the Crown of Swords. On the point of setting it on his head, though, he hesitated, then put it back. Donning the coat, he left crown and scepter where they lay.

"aɪ min tə faɪn aʊt wʌt kædzueɪn wɑns," hi ənaʊnst. "ʃi dʌzn kʌm tə ðə pæləs ɛvɹi deɪ kəz ʃi laɪks ə tʃɹɪp θɹu ðə snoʊ. wɪl jə kʌm wɪð mi, mɪn? meɪbi jəl əv ə vjuɪŋ."

"I mean to find out what Cadsuane wants," he announced. "She doesn't come to the palace every day because she likes a trip through the snow. Will you come with me, Min? Maybe you'll have a viewing."

ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ fit fæstɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə vɪzət wɪð kædzueɪn wəd laɪkli bi əz plɛʒɝəbəl əz ə vɪzət wɪð sɔɹɪliə, jɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ əloʊn. bɪsaɪdz, meɪbi ʃi wəɾ əv ə vjuɪŋ. fɛdwɪn fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn əɹ ən ɹænd wɪð ən əlɝt lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz.

She was on her feet faster than any of those Aes Sedai. A visit with Cadsuane would likely be as pleasurable as a visit with Sorilea, yet anything was better than sitting there alone. Besides, maybe she would have a viewing. Fedwin fell in behind her and Rand with an alert look in his eyes.

ðə sɪks meɪɾənz aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə tɔl vɔltəd hɔlweɪ ɹoʊz, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ. soʊmɑɹə wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn mɪn nu; ʃi ɡeɪv mɪn ə bɹif smaɪl, ən ɹænd ə flæt, dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ stɛɹ. ði ʌðɝz ɡlaʊɝd. ðə meɪɾənz hæɾ æksɛptɪɾ ɪz ɛkspləneɪʃən əbaʊt waɪ hi hæd ɡɔn wɪθaʊɾ əm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, soʊ ɛni wɑtʃɝz wəd bɪliv fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl ðəɾ i wɑz stɪl ɪn kɛɹhin, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl dɪmændəd tə noʊ waɪ hi hæd nɑt sɛn fəɹ əm æftɝwɝd, ən ɹænd hæd hæd noʊ ænsɝz. hi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, ən kwɪkən ɪz peɪs soʊ mɪn hæd tə stʃɹɛtʃ əɹ lɛɡz tə kip ʌp.

The six Maidens outside in the tall vaulted hallway rose, but they did not follow. Somara was the only one Min knew; she gave Min a brief smile, and Rand a flat, disapproving stare. The others glowered. The Maidens had accepted his explanation about why he had gone without them in the first place, so any watchers would believe for as long as possible that he was still in Cairhien, but they still demanded to know why he had not sent for them afterward, and Rand had had no answers. He muttered something under his breath, and quickened his pace so Min had to stretch her legs to keep up.

"wɑtʃ kædzueɪn kɛɹfəli, mɪn," hi sɛd. "æn ju, tu, mɔɹ. ʃiz ʌp tə səm ɛɛs sədaɪ skim, bʌt bɝn mi ɪf aɪ kən si wʌt. aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ðɛɹz - "

"Watch Cadsuane carefully, Min," he said. "And you, too, Morr. She's up to some Aes Sedai scheme, but burn me if I can see what. I don't know. There's - "

ə stoʊn wɔl sim tə stʃɹaɪk mɪn fɹəm bɪhaɪnd; ʃi θɔt ʃi hɝd ɹɔɹɪŋ, kɹæʃɪŋ. ən ðən ɹænd wɑz tɝnɪŋ əɹ oʊvɝ - ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ? - lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ əɹ wɪð ðə fɝs fɪɹ ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd siɪŋ ɪn ðoʊz mɔɹnɪŋ-blu aɪz. ɪɾ oʊnli feɪɾəd wən ʃi sæɾ ʌp, kɑfɪŋ. ði ɛɹ wɑz fʊl ə dʌst! ən ðən ʃi sɔ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ.
