A stone wall seemed to strike Min from behind; she thought she heard roaring, crashing. And then Rand was turning her over - she was lying on the floor? - looking down at her with the first fear she remembered seeing in those morning-blue eyes. It only faded when she sat up, coughing. The air was full of dust! And then she saw the corridor.

ðə meɪɾənz wɝ ɡɔn fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹændz dɔɹz. ðə dɔɹz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ ɡɔn, əlɔŋ wɪð moʊst ə ðə wɔl, ən ə dʒæɡd hoʊl nɪɹli əz bɪɡ ɡeɪpt ɪn ðə wɔl ɑpəzət. ʃi kəd si ɪndə hɪz əpɑɹtməns klɪɹli dɪspaɪt ðə dʌst, ɪndə dɛvəsteɪʃən. mæsɪv paɪlz ə ɹʌbəl leɪ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən əbʌv, ðə silɪŋ jɔn oʊpən tə ðə skaɪ. snoʊ swɝl daʊn ɑntu fleɪmz dænsɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ɹʌbəl. wʌn ə ðə mæsɪv blækwʊd poʊsts ə hɪz bɛd stʌk bɝnɪŋ aʊɾ ə ʃæɾɝd stoʊn, ən ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi kəd si ɔl ðə weɪ aʊtsaɪd tə ðə stɛp taʊɝz veɪl baɪ ðə snoʊfɔl. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ə hjudʒ hæmɝ hæd smæʃt ɪndə ðə sʌn pæləs. ən hæd ðeɪ bɪn ɪn ðɛɹ, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv gɑnə si kædzueɪn . . . mɪn ʃɪvɝd.

The Maidens were gone from in front of Rand's doors. The doors themselves were gone, along with most of the wall, and a jagged hole nearly as big gaped in the wall opposite. She could see into his apartments clearly despite the dust, into devastation. Massive piles of rubble lay everywhere, and above, the ceiling yawned open to the sky. Snow swirled down onto flames dancing among the rubble. One of the massive blackwood posts of his bed stuck burning out of shattered stone, and she realized she could see all the way outside to the stepped towers veiled by the snowfall. It was as if a huge hammer had smashed into the Sun Palace. And had they been in there, instead of going to see Cadsuane . . . Min shivered.

"wʌt . . . ?" ʃi bɪɡæn ənstɛɾəli, ðən əbændən ðə jusləs kwɛstʃən. ɛni ful wəd si wʌt hæd hæpənd. "hu?" ʃi æskt ɪnstɛd.

"What . . . ?" she began unsteadily, then abandoned the useless question. Any fool would see what had happened. "Who?" she asked instead.

kʌvɝɾ ɪn dʌst, hɛɹ ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ, ən wɪð tɪɹz ɪn ðɛɹ koʊts, ðə tu mɛn lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɹoʊld əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ən pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd. ʃi θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ə ɡʊd tɛn peɪsɪz fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə dɔɹz ðən ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. fɹəm wɛɹ ðə dɔɹz hæd bɪn. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, æŋkʃəs ʃaʊts ɹoʊz, ɛkoʊɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə hɔlz. niðɝ mæn ænsɝd hɝ.

Covered in dust, hair every which way, and with tears in their coats, the two men looked as if they had been rolled along the corridor, and perhaps they had. She thought they were all a good ten paces farther from the doors than she remembered. From where the doors had been. In the distance, anxious shouts rose, echoing along the halls. Neither man answered her.

"kæn aɪ tʃɹʌs ju, mɔɹ?" ɹænd æskt.

"Can I trust you, Morr?" Rand asked.

fɛdwɪn mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz oʊpənli. "wɪð jəɹ laɪf, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛd sɪmpli.

Fedwin met his gaze openly. "With your life, my Lord Dragon," he said simply.

"ðæts wʌɾ aɪm tʃɹʌstɪŋ jə wɪð," ɹænd sɛd. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt əɹ tʃik, ən ðən i stʊɾ əbɹʌpli. "ɡɑɹɾ əɹ wɪð jəɹ laɪf, mɔɹ." hɑɹɾ əz stil, hɪz vɔɪs. ɡɹɪm əz dɛθ. "ɪf ðəɹ stɪl ɪn ðə pæləs, ðəl fil jə tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən stʃɹaɪk bɪfɔɹ jə kən fɪnɪʃ. doʊn tʃænəl əɾ ɔl ənlɛs jə mʌst, bʌt bi ɹɛɾi. teɪk əɹ daʊn tə ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz, ən kɪl ɛniwʌn əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət tʃɹaɪz tə ɡɛt tə hɝ. ɛniwʌn!"

"That's what I am trusting you with," Rand said. His fingers brushed her cheek, and then he stood abruptly. "Guard her with your life, Morr." Hard as steel, his voice. Grim as death. "If they're still in the Palace, they'll feel you try to make a gateway, and strike before you can finish. Don't channel at all unless you must, but be ready. Take her down to the servants' quarters, and kill anyone or anything that tries to get to her. Anyone!"

wɪð ə læs lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ - oʊ, laɪt, ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, ʃi wʊɾə θɔt ʃi kəd daɪ hæpəli, siɪŋ ðət lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz! - hi wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ, əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹuəneɪʃən. əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. huɛvɝ hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm wəd bi hʌntɪŋ fəɹ hɪm.

With a last look down at her - oh, Light, any other time, she would have thought she could die happily, seeing that look in his eyes! - he went running, away from the ruination. Away from her. Whoever had tried to kill him would be hunting for him.

mɔɹ pæɾəd əɹ ɑn ði ɑɹm wɪð ə dʌsti hæn ən ɡeɪv əɹ ə bɔɪɪʃ ɡɹɪn. "doʊnt wɝi, mɪn. əl teɪk kɛɹ ə ju."

Morr patted her on the arm with a dusty hand and gave her a boyish grin. "Don't worry, Min. I'll take care of you."

bʌɾ u wɑz gɑnə teɪk kɛɹ ə ɹænd? kən aɪ tʃɹʌs ju, hi hæɾ æsk ðɪs bɔɪ hu hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɝs tə kʌm æskɪŋ tə lɝn. laɪt, hu wəd meɪk ɪm seɪf?

But who was going to take care of Rand? Can I trust you, he had asked this boy who had been one of the first to come asking to learn. Light, who would make him safe?

ɹaʊndɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ, ɹænd stɑpt wɪð ə hæn əɡɛnst wʌn wɔl tə siz ðə sɔɹs. ə ful θɪŋ, nɑt wɑntɪŋ mɪn tə si hɪm stæɡɝ wən sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm, bʌt ðəɹ ɪt wɑz. nɑt dʒʌst ɛni sʌmwʌn. ə mæn, dɪmɑndɝd, əɹ pɝhæps æzmɑɾiən kʌm bæk ət læst. meɪbi boʊθ; ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən ɑɾəti, əz ɪf ðə wivɪŋ keɪm fɹəm dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃənz. hi hæd fɛl ðə tʃænəlɪŋ tu leɪt tə də ɛniθɪŋ. hi wəɾ əv daɪd, ɪn ɪz ɹumz. hi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə daɪ. bʌt nɑt mɪn, noʊ, nɑt mɪn. ɪleɪn wɑz bɛɾɝ ɔf, tɝnɪŋ əɡɛns hɪm. oʊ, laɪt, ʃi wɑz!

Rounding a corner, Rand stopped with a hand against one wall to seize the Source. A fool thing, not wanting Min to see him stagger when someone tried to kill him, but there it was. Not just any someone. A man, Demandred, or perhaps Asmodean come back at last. Maybe both; there had been an oddity, as if the weaving came from different directions. He had felt the channeling too late to do anything. He would have died, in his rooms. He was ready to die. But not Min, no, not Min. Elayne was better off, turning against him. Oh, Light, she was!

hi siz ðə sɔɹs, ən seɪɾɪn flʌɾəd ɪm wɪð moʊltən koʊld ən fɹizɪŋ hit, wɪð laɪf ən switnəs, fɪlθ ən dɛθ. hɪz stʌmək twɪstəd, ən ðə hɔlweɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm dʌbəld ɪtsɛlf. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hi θɔɾ i sɔ ə feɪs. nɑt wɪð ɪz aɪz; ɪn ɪz hɛd. ə mæn, ʃɪmɝɪŋ ən ənɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl, ɡɔn. hi floʊɾəd ɪn ðə vɔɪd, ɛmpti, ən fʊl ə ðə paʊɝ.

He seized the Source, and saidin flooded him with molten cold and freezing heat, with life and sweetness, filth and death. His stomach twisted, and the hallway in front of him doubled itself. For an instant, he thought he saw a face. Not with his eyes; in his head. A man, shimmering and unrecognizable, gone. He floated in the Void, empty, and full of the Power.

jə woʊnt wɪn, hi toʊld luz θɝɪn. ɪf aɪ daɪ, əl daɪ mi!

You won't win, he told Lews Therin. If I die, I'll die me!

aɪ ʃʊɾə sɛn aɪlaɪɛnə əweɪ, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd bæk. ʃi wəɾ əv lɪvd.

I should have sent Ilyena away, Lews Therin whispered back. She would have lived.

pʊʃɪŋ ðə vɔɪs əweɪ əz i pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf fɹəm ðə wɔl, ɹænd slɪpt əlɔŋ ðə pæləs kɔɹɪɾɝz wɪð ɔl ðə stɛlθ i kəd mʌstɝ, stɛpɪŋ laɪtli, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ kloʊs tə tæpəstʃɹi-hʌŋ wɔlz, ɝaʊnd ɡoʊld-wɝk tʃɛsts ən ɡɪldɪd kæbənəts bɛɹɪŋ fɹædʒəl ɡoʊldən pɔɹsələnz ən aɪvɝi stætʃuɛts. hɪz aɪz sɝtʃt fəɹ ɪz ətækɝz. ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi sæɾəsfaɪd ʃɔɹɾ ə faɪndɪŋ ɪz bɑɾi, bʌt ðeɪ wəd bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl ɪn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪz ɹumz ɪn keɪs i hæd sɝvaɪv baɪ səm tɑvɝən swɝl ə feɪt. ðeɪ wəd weɪt, tə si wɛðɝ i stɝd. ɪn ðə vɔɪd, hi wɑz əz nɪɹ wʌn wɪð ðə paʊɝ əz ɛni mæn kəd lɪv θɹu. ɪn ðə vɔɪd, əz wɪð ə sɔɹd, hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz.

Pushing the voice away as he pushed himself from the wall, Rand slipped along the Palace corridors with all the stealth he could muster, stepping lightly, gliding close to tapestry-hung walls, around gold-worked chests and gilded cabinets bearing fragile golden porcelains and ivory statuettes. His eyes searched for his attackers. They would not be satisfied short of finding his body, but they would be very careful in approaching his rooms in case he had survived by some ta'veren swirl of fate. They would wait, to see whether he stirred. In the Void, he was as near one with the Power as any man could live through. In the Void, as with a sword, he was one with his surroundings.

fɹæntɪk ʃaʊts ən klæmɝ ɹoʊz ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, səm skɹimɪŋ tə noʊ wʌt hæd hæpənd, ʌðɝz kɹaɪɪŋ ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd ɡɔn mæd. ðə bʌndəl ə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɪn ɪz hɛd ðət wɑz ɑlɑnə pɹəvaɪɾəd wʌn smɔl kʌmfɝt. ʃi wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs, əz ʃi hæd bɪn ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ, meɪbi ivən aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. hi wɪʃt mɪn wɑz, tu. səmtaɪmz i sɔ mɛn ən wɪmən daʊn wʌn hɔlweɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, blæk-lɪvɹid sɝvəns meɪnli, ɹʌnɪŋ, fɔlɪŋ daʊn ən skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp tə ɹʌn əɡɛn. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si hɪm. wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm, hi kəd hɪɹ ɛvɹi wɪspɝ. ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə wɪspɝ ə sɑf buts ɹʌnɪŋ, laɪt-fʊɾɪd.

Frantic shouts and clamor rose in every direction, some screaming to know what had happened, others crying that the Dragon Reborn had gone mad. The bundle of frustration in his head that was Alanna provided one small comfort. She was out of the Palace, as she had been all morning, maybe even outside the city walls. He wished Min was, too. Sometimes he saw men and women down one hallway or another, black-liveried servants mainly, running, falling down and scrambling up to run again. They did not see him. With the Power in him, he could hear every whisper. Including the whisper of soft boots running, light-footed.

bækɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪsaɪɾ ə lɔŋ teɪbəl tɑpt wɪð pɔɹsələn, hi kwɪkli woʊv faɪɝ ən ɛɹ ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf ən hɛl vɛɹi stɪl ɹæpt ɪn foʊldəd laɪt.

Backing against the wall beside a long table topped with porcelain, he quickly wove Fire and Air around himself and held very still wrapped in Folded Light.

meɪɾənz əpɪɹd, ə stʃɹim ə ðɛm, veɪld, ən ɹæn baɪ wɪθaʊt siɪŋ hɪm. təwɔɹɾ ɪz əpɑɹtməns. hi kəd nɑt lɛɾ əm əkʌmpəni hɪm; hi hæd pɹɑməst, bʌt tə lɛɾ əm faɪt, nɑt tə liɾ əm tə slɔɾɝ. wən i faʊn dɪmɑndɝɾ ən æzmɑɾiən, ɔl ðə meɪɾənz kəd də wɑz daɪ, ən i ɔlɹɛɾi hæd faɪv neɪmz tə lɝn ən æd tə hɪz lɪst. soʊmɑɹə ʌv ðə bɛn pik dɛɹn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. ə pɹɑməs i hæd hæd tə meɪk, ə pɹɑməs i hæd tə kip. fəɹ ðət pɹɑməs əloʊn, hi dɪzɝv tə daɪ!

Maidens appeared, a stream of them, veiled, and ran by without seeing him. Toward his apartments. He could not let them accompany him; he had promised, but to let them fight, not to lead them to slaughter. When he found Demandred and Asmodean, all the Maidens could do was die, and he already had five names to learn and add to his list. Somara of the Bent Peak Daryne was already there. A promise he had had to make, a promise he had to keep. For that promise alone, he deserved to die!

iɡəlz ən wɪmən kən oʊnli bi kɛp seɪf ɪn keɪdʒɪz, luz θɝɪn sɛɾ əz ðoʊ kwoʊɾɪŋ, ðən əbɹʌpli bɪɡæn wipɪŋ əz ðə læst ə ðə meɪɾənz vænɪʃt.

Eagles and women can only be kept safe in cages, Lews Therin said as though quoting, then abruptly began weeping as the last of the Maidens vanished.

ɹænd muvd ɑn, swipɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu ðə pæləs ɪn ɑɹks ðət sloʊli muvd əweɪ fɹəm ɪz əpɑɹtməns. foʊldəd laɪt juz vɛɹi lɪɾəl ə ðə paʊɝ - soʊ lɪɾəl noʊ mæn cʊɾə fɛl ðə jus ə seɪɾɪn ənlɛs ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪt - ən i juzd ɪt wɛnɛvɝ ɛniwʌn simd əbaʊt tə si hɪm. hɪz ətækɝz hæd nɑt stʃɹʌk əɾ ɪz ɹumz ɑn ðə tʃæns i wəd bi ðɛɹ. ðeɪ hæɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn ðə pæləs. meɪbi ɪt hæd bɪn tɑvɝən wɝk ðət pʊld ɪm aʊɾ ə ði əpɑɹtməns, ɪf ə tɑvɝən kəd wɝk ɑn hɪmsɛlf, ən meɪbi dʒʌs hæpənstæns, bʌt pɝhæps ɪz tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə pæɾɝn kəd bɹɪŋ ɪz ətækɝz wɪðɪn ɪz ɡɹæsp waɪl ðeɪ θɔɾ ɪm dɛɾ əɹ ɪnʒɝd. luz θɝɪn tʃʌkəld ət ðə θɔt. ɹænd kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə mæn ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz ɪn æntɪsəpeɪʃən.

Rand moved on, sweeping back and forth through the palace in arcs that slowly moved away from his apartments. Folded Light used very little of the Power - so little no man could have felt the use of saidin unless right on top of it - and he used it whenever anyone seemed about to see him. His attackers had not struck at his rooms on the chance he would be there. They had eyes-and-ears in the Palace. Maybe it had been ta'veren work that pulled him out of the apartments, if a ta'veren could work on himself, and maybe just happenstance, but perhaps his tugging at the Pattern could bring his attackers within his grasp while they thought him dead or injured. Lews Therin chuckled at the thought. Rand could almost feel the man rubbing his hands in anticipation.

θɹi mɔɹ taɪmz i hæd tə haɪd bɪhaɪn ðə paʊɝ əz veɪl meɪɾənz ɹʌʃt baɪ, ən wʌns wən i sɔ kædzueɪn swipɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ əhɛd wɪð noʊ fjuɝ ðən sɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ əɾ əɹ hilz, ən nɑt wʌn ʌðɝ ðəɾ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz bɪsaɪdz hɝ. ðeɪ sim tə bi hʌntɪŋ. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd sɪstɝ, pɹɪsaɪsli. noʊ, ʌv kɔɹs nɑɾ əfɹeɪd! bʌɾ i weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi ən əɹ fɹɛnz wɝ wɛl aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɪz kənsilɪŋ wiv ɡoʊ. luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑt tʃʌkəl oʊvɝ kædzueɪn. hi wɑz dɛθli saɪlən əntɪl ʃi wɑz ɡɔn.

Three more times he had to hide behind the Power as veiled Maidens rushed by, and once when he saw Cadsuane sweeping along the corridor ahead with no fewer than six Aes Sedai at her heels, and not one other that he recognized besides her. They seemed to be hunting. He was not afraid of the gray-haired sister, precisely. No, of course not afraid! But he waited until she and her friends were well out of sight before letting his concealing weave go. Lews Therin did not chuckle over Cadsuane. He was deathly silent until she was gone.

ɹænd stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔl, ə dɔɹ oʊpən ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən eɪlɪl pikt aʊt. hi hæd nɑt noʊn i wɑz nɪɹ əɹ ɹumz. bɪhaɪn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ stʊɾ ə dɑɹk wʊmən wɪð fæt ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋz ɪn əɹ ɪɹz ən ə mədæljən-fɪld ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs əɹ lɛf tʃik tə hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋ. ʃələn, wɪndfɪndɝ tə hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə, ði æθɑn maɪɹ æmbæsəɾɝ u hæd muvd ɪndə ðə pæləs wɪð əɹ ɹɛɾənu ɔlmoʊst əz mɛɹænə ɪnfɔɹmd ɪm ə ði əɡɹimənt. ən miɾɪŋ wɪð ə wʊmən u maɪt wɑn ɪm dɛd. ðɛɹ aɪz pɑpt ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm.

Rand stepped away from the wall, a door opened right beside him, and Ailil peeked out. He had not known he was near her rooms. Behind her shoulder stood a dark woman with fat golden rings in her ears and a medallion-filled golden chain running across her left cheek to her nose ring. Shalon, Windfinder to Harine din Togara, the Atha'an Miere ambassador who had moved into the Palace with her retinue almost as Merana informed him of the agreement. And meeting with a woman who might want him dead. Their eyes popped at the sight of him.

hi wɑz əz dʒɛntəl əz i kəd bi, bʌɾ i hæd tə bi kwɪk. ə fju moʊməns æftɝ ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, hi wɑz tʌkɪŋ ə sʌmwʌt ɹʌmpəld eɪlɪl bɪniθ əɹ bɛɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ʃələn. pɝhæps ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. pɝhæps. seɪf wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən sɑɹi. ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əbʌv maʊðz wɑɾəd fʊl ʌv eɪlɪlz skɑɹvz, ðə tu wɪmən ɹɪθd əɡɛns ðə tɔɹn stʃɹɪps ə bɛdʃiɾ i hæd juz tə baɪn ðɛɹ ɹɪsts ən æŋkəlz. ðə ʃild i hæd taɪɾ ɔf ɑn ʃələn wəd hoʊld əɹ fəɹ ə deɪ əɹ tu bɪfɔɹ ðə nɑɾ ənɹævəld, bʌt sʌmwʌn wəd faɪn əm ən kʌt ðɛɹ ʌðɝ bɑnz bɪfɔɹ tu mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ.

He was as gentle as he could be, but he had to be quick. A few moments after the door opened, he was tucking a somewhat rumpled Ailil beneath her bed alongside Shalon. Perhaps they were not part of what was happening. Perhaps. Safe was better than sorry. Glaring at him above mouths wadded full of Ailil's scarves, the two women writhed against the torn strips of bedsheet he had used to bind their wrists and ankles. The shield he had tied off on Shalon would hold her for a day or two before the knot unraveled, but someone would find them and cut their other bonds before too much longer.

wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðət ʃild, hi oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ɪnʌf tə tʃɛk ðə hɔlweɪ, ən hɝiɾ aʊt, əlɔŋ ði ɛmpti kɔɹəɾɝ. hi kəd nɑɾ əv lɛf ðə wɪndfɪndɝ fɹi tə tʃænəl, bʌt ʃildɪŋ ə wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ ə mæɾɝ ə dʒɹɪbəlz ə ðə paʊɝ. ɪf wʌn ə hɪz ətækɝz hæd bɪn kloʊs ɪnʌf . . . bʌɾ i sɔ noʊ wʌn daʊn ɛni ʌv ðə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹɪɾɝz, iðɝ.

Worrying about that shield, he opened the door enough to check the hallway, and hurried out, along the empty corridor. He could not have left the Windfinder free to channel, but shielding a woman was not a matter of dribbles of the Power. If one of his attackers had been close enough . . . But he saw no one down any of the crossing corridors, either.

fɪfti peɪsɪz bɪɑn eɪlɪlz ɹumz, ðə kɔɹəɾɝ oʊpən ɪndə ə skwɛɹ-ɹeɪl bælkəni ʌv blu mɑɹbəl wɪð bɹɔd stɛɹz əɾ iðɝ ɛnd, fɹʌntɪŋ ə skwɛɹ tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ə haɪ, vɔltəd silɪŋ ən ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ə bælkəni ət ði ʌðɝ saɪd. tæpəstʃɹiz tɛn peɪsɪz lɔŋ hʌŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz, bɝdz sɔɹɪŋ tə ðə skaɪz ɪn ɹɪdʒəd pæɾɝnz. bɪloʊ, dæʃivə stʊd lʊkɪŋ əbaʊt, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps ənsɝteɪnli. dʒɛdwɪn ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɝ wɪð hɪm! luz θɝɪn tʃɪɾɝd ə kɪlɪŋ.

Fifty paces beyond Ailil's rooms, the corridor opened into a square-railed balcony of blue marble with broad stairs at either end, fronting a square chamber with a high, vaulted ceiling and the same sort of balcony at the other side. Tapestries ten paces long hung along the walls, birds soaring to the skies in rigid patterns. Below, Dashiva stood looking about, licking his lips uncertainly. Gedwyn and Rochaid were with him! Lews Therin chittered of killing.

". . . tɛlɪŋ jə aɪ fɛl nʌθɪŋ," dʒɛdwɪn wɑz seɪɪŋ. "hiz dɛd!"

". . . telling you I felt nothing," Gedwyn was saying. "He's dead!"

ən dæʃivə sɔ ɹænd, ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz.

And Dashiva saw Rand, at the head of the stairs.

ði oʊnli wɔɹnɪŋ i hæd wɑz ðə sʌɾən snɑɹl ðət kəntɔɹɾəd dæʃivəz feɪs. dæʃivə tʃænəld, ən wɪð noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk, ɹænd woʊv - əz soʊ ɔfən, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt; sʌmθɪŋ dʒɹɛdʒ fɹəm luz θɝɪnz mɛmɹiz; hi wɑz nɑɾ ivən ʃʊɹ i kɹieɪɾəd ðə wiv ɪntaɪɝli hɪmsɛlf, əɹ wɛðɝ luz θɝɪn snætʃt ət seɪɾɪn - ɛɹ ən faɪɝ ən ɝθ woʊvən ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf dʒʌst soʊ. ðə faɪɝ ðət lɛp fɹəm dæʃivə ɪɹʌptəd, ʃæɾɝɪŋ mɑɹbəl, flɪŋɪŋ ɹænd bæk daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ, baʊndɪŋ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪz kəkun.

The only warning he had was the sudden snarl that contorted Dashiva's face. Dashiva channeled, and with no time to think, Rand wove - as so often, he did not know what; something dredged from Lews Therin's memories; he was not even sure he created the weave entirely himself, or whether Lews Therin snatched at saidin - Air and Fire and Earth woven around himself just so. The fire that leaped from Dashiva erupted, shattering marble, flinging Rand back down the hallway, bounding and rolling in his cocoon.

ðət bæɹiɝ wəd kip aʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə bɑlfaɪɝ. ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɛɹ tə bɹið. ɹænd ɹilist ɪt pæntɪŋ, skɹeɪpɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə flɔɹ, wɪð ðə kɹæʃ ə ði ɪksploʊʒənz stɪl ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, dʌst stɪl hæŋɪŋ ən bɪts ə bɹoʊkən mɑɹbəl tʌmbəlɪŋ. əz mʌtʃ əz fəɹ bɹɛθ, ðoʊ, hi lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ kəz wʌt kəd kip ðə paʊɝ aʊt, kɛpt ɪɾ ɪn. bɪfɔɹ i stɑp slaɪɾɪŋ, hi tʃænəl faɪɝ ən ɛɹ, bʌt woʊvən mʌtʃ dɪfɹənli ðən fəɹ foʊldəd laɪt. θɪn ɹɛd waɪɝz lɛp fɹəm ɪz lɛf hænd, fænɪŋ aʊɾ əz ðeɪ slaɪs θɹu ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ stoʊn təwɔɹd wɛɹ dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn stændɪŋ. fɹəm ɪz lɛf spɛd bɔlz ə fleɪm, faɪɝ woʊvən wɪð ɛɹ, fæstɝ ðən i kəd kaʊnt, ən ðeɪ bɝn θɹu ðə stoʊn bɪfɔɹ ɪksploʊɾɪŋ ɪn ðət tʃeɪmbɝ. wʌn kəntɪnjuəs dɛfənɪŋ ɹɔɹ meɪd ðə pæləs tʃɹɛmbəl. dʌs ðət hæd fɔlən ɹoʊz ʌp əɡɛn, ən pisəz ə stoʊn baʊnst.

That barrier would keep out anything short of balefire. Including air to breathe. Rand released it panting, scraping along the floor, with the crash of the explosions still ringing in the air, dust still hanging and bits of broken marble tumbling. As much as for breath, though, he let it go because what could keep the Power out, kept it in. Before he stopped sliding, he channeled Fire and Air, but woven much differently than for Folded Light. Thin red wires leaped from his left hand, fanning out as they sliced through the intervening stone toward where Dashiva and the others had been standing. From his left sped balls of flame, Fire woven with Air, faster than he could count, and they burned through the stone before exploding in that chamber. One continuous deafening roar made the Palace tremble. Dust that had fallen rose up again, and pieces of stone bounced.

ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, ðoʊ, hi wɑz ʌp ən ɹʌnɪŋ, bæk pæst eɪlɪlz əpɑɹtməns. ðə mæn u stʃɹʌk ən steɪɾ ɪn wʌn spɑt wɑz æskɪŋ tə daɪ. hi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə daɪ, bʌt nɑt jɛt. snɑɹlɪŋ saʊnləsli, hi spɛd daʊn ənʌðɝ hɔl, dɪsɛndəd nɛɹoʊ sɝvəns' stɛɹz, ən keɪm aʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪloʊ.

Almost immediately, though, he was up and running, back past Ailil's apartments. The man who struck and stayed in one spot was asking to die. He was ready to die, but not yet. Snarling soundlessly, he sped down another hall, descended narrow servants' stairs, and came out on the floor below.

hi tʊk kɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ bæk tə wɛɹ i hæd sin dæʃivə, dɛdli wivz ɹɛɾi tə flɪŋ ət soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlɪmps.

He took care making his way back to where he had seen Dashiva, deadly weaves ready to fling at so much as a glimpse.

aɪ ʃʊɾə kɪld əm ɔl ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd. aɪ ʃʊɾə kɪld əm ɔl!

I should have killed them all in the beginning, Lews Therin panted. I should have killed them all!

ɹænd lɛɾ ɪm ɹeɪdʒ.

Rand let him rage.

ðə lɑɹdʒ tʃeɪmbɝ sim tə hæv bɪn wɑʃt ɪn faɪɝ. oʊnli tʃɑɹd fɹæɡməns lɪk baɪ fleɪmz ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə tæpəstʃɹiz, ən ɡɹeɪt ɡaʊudʒɪz ə peɪs əkɹɔs hæd bɪn bɝn ɪndə flɔɹ ən wɔlz. ðə stɛɹz ɹænd hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə dɪsɛn ɛndəɾ ɪn ə tɛn-fʊt ɡæp hæfweɪ daʊn. ʌv ðə θɹi mɛn, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn. ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn kənsum kəmplitli. sʌmθɪŋ wəɾ əv ɹɪmeɪnd.

The large chamber seemed to have been washed in fire. Only charred fragments licked by flames remained of the tapestries, and great gouges a pace across had been burned into floor and walls. The stairs Rand had been about to descend ended in a ten-foot gap halfway down. Of the three men, there was no sign. They would not have been consumed completely. Something would have remained.

ə sɝvən ɪn ə blæk koʊt kɔʃəsli poʊkt ɪz hɛd fɹəm ə taɪni dɔɹ bɪsaɪd ðə stɛɹz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. hɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ɹænd, ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən i fɛl fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə hip. ənʌðɝ sɝvən pipt aʊɾ ʌv ə kɔɹəɾɝ, ðən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts ən ɹeɪs bæk ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm, ʃɹikɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə hɝ lʌŋz ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz kɪlɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs.

A servant in a black coat cautiously poked his head from a tiny door beside the stairs on the other side of the chamber. His eyes fell on Rand, rolled up in his head, and he fell forward in a heap. Another servant peeped out of a corridor, then gathered her skirts and raced back the way she had come, shrieking at the top of her lungs that the Dragon Reborn was killing everyone in the Palace.

ɹænd slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. hi wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət fɹaɪɾənɪŋ pipəl u kəd nɑt hɑɹm hɪm. vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ.

Rand slipped out of the chamber grimacing. He was very good at frightening people who could not harm him. Very good at destroying.

tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ, əɹ bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd, luz θɝɪn læft. wən ðæts jəɹ tʃɔɪs, ɪz ðəɹ ə dɪfɝəns?

To destroy, or be destroyed, Lews Therin laughed. When that's your choice, is there a difference?

sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə pæləs, ə mæn tʃænəld ɪnʌf ə ðə paʊɝ tə meɪk ə ɡeɪtweɪ. dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝz fliɪŋ? əɹ wɑntɪŋ ɪm tə θɪŋk ðæt?

Somewhere in the Palace, a man channeled enough of the Power to make a gateway. Dashiva and the others fleeing? Or wanting him to think that?

hi wɔk ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə pæləs, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɑðɝɪŋ tə haɪd. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls sim tə bi. ðə fju sɝvəns i sɔ, flɛd skɹimɪŋ. kɔɹəɾɝ æftɝ kɔɹəɾɝ, hi hʌntəd, fɪl nɪɹ tə bɝstɪŋ wɪð seɪɾɪn, fʊl ə faɪɝ ən aɪs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ənaɪəleɪɾ ɪm əz ʃʊɹli əz dæʃivə hæd, fʊl ə ðə teɪnt wɝmɪŋ ɪts weɪ ɪndə hɪz soʊl. hi hæd noʊ niɾ ə luz θɝɪnz ɹæɡəd læftɝ ən ɹeɪvəŋz tə bi fɪld wɪð ə dɪzaɪɝ tə kɪl.

He walked the corridors of the Palace, no longer bothering to hide. Everyone else seemed to be. The few servants he saw, fled screaming. Corridor after corridor, he hunted, filled near to bursting with saidin, full of fire and ice trying to annihilate him as surely as Dashiva had, full of the taint worming its way into his soul. He had no need of Lews Therin's ragged laughter and ravings to be filled with a desire to kill.

ə ɡlɪmps ʌv ə blæk koʊɾ əhɛd, ən ɪz hænd ʃɑɾ ʌp, faɪɝ stʃɹikɪŋ, ɪksploʊɾɪŋ, tɛɹɪŋ əweɪ ðə kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ ðə tu hɔlweɪz mɛt. ɹænd lɛt ðə wiv səbsaɪd, bʌt dɪd nɑt lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ. hæɾ i kɪl hɪm?

A glimpse of a black coat ahead, and his hand shot up, fire streaking, exploding, tearing away the corner where the two hallways met. Rand let the weave subside, but did not let it go. Had he killed him?

"maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," ə vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm bɪɑn ðə tɔɹn stoʊnwɝk, "ɪts mi, nɛɹɪʃmə! ən flɪn!"

"My Lord Dragon," a voice shouted from beyond the torn stonework, "it's me, Narishma! And Flinn!"

"aɪ dɪdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ju," ɹænd laɪd. "kʌm hɪɹ."

"I didn't recognize you," Rand lied. "Come here."

"aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi jəɹ blʌdz hɑt," flɪnz vɔɪs kɔld. "aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi wi ʃəd weɪt fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi tə kul daʊn."

"I think maybe your blood's hot," Flinn's voice called. "I think maybe we should wait for everybody to cool down."

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. hæɾ i ɹɪli tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl nɛɹɪʃmə? hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i kəd kleɪm ði ɪkskjus ə luz θɝɪn. "jɛs, ðət maɪt bi bɛst. fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl lɔŋɡɝ." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ænsɝ. dɪɾ i hɪɹ buts ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ? hi fɔɹst ɪz hænz daʊn ən tɝn ənʌðɝ weɪ.

"Yes," Rand said slowly. Had he really tried to kill Narishma? He did not think he could claim the excuse of Lews Therin. "Yes, that might be best. For a little while longer." There was no answer. Did he hear boots retreating? He forced his hands down and turned another way.

hi sɝtʃt θɹu ðə pæləs fəɹ aʊɝz wɪθaʊt faɪndɪŋ ə saɪn ə dæʃivə əɹ ði ʌðɝz. ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ən ɡɹeɪt hɔlz, ivən ðə kɪtʃənz, wɝ ɛmpti ʌv pipəl. hi faʊnd nʌθɪŋ, ən lɝnd nʌθɪŋ. noʊ. hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd lɝnd wʌn θɪŋ. tʃɹʌst wɑz ə naɪf, ən ðə hɪlt wɑz əz ʃɑɹp əz ðə bleɪd.

He searched through the Palace for hours without finding a sign of Dashiva or the others. The corridors and great halls, even the kitchens, were empty of people. He found nothing, and learned nothing. No. He realized that he had learned one thing. Trust was a knife, and the hilt was as sharp as the blade.

ðən i faʊn peɪn.

Then he found pain.

ðə smɔl stoʊn-wɔld ɹum wɑz dip bɪloʊ ðə sʌn pæləs ən wɔɹm dɪspaɪt ðə læk ʌv ə faɪɝpleɪs, bʌt mɪn fɛl koʊld. θɹi ɡɪldɪd læmps ɑn ðə taɪni wʊɾən teɪbəl ɡeɪv mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf laɪt. ɹænd hæd sɛd ðət fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ əweɪ ivən ɪf sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə ɹut ðə pæləs aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi hæd nɑt saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ dʒoʊkɪŋ.

The small stone-walled room was deep below the Sun Palace and warm despite the lack of a fireplace, but Min felt cold. Three gilded lamps on the tiny wooden table gave more than enough light. Rand had said that from there, he could get her away even if someone tried to root the Palace out of the ground. He had not sounded as if he were joking.

hoʊldɪŋ ðə kɹaʊn ʌv ɪljən ɑn əɹ læp, ʃi wɑtʃt ɹænd. wɑtʃt ɹænd wɑtʃɪŋ fɛdwɪn. hɝ hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə kɹaʊn, ən lusən ɪmiɾiətli ət ðə stæbz ə ðoʊz smɔl sɔɹdz hɪɾən əmʌŋ ðə lɔɹəl livz. stʃɹeɪnʒ, ðət ðə kɹaʊn ən sɛptɝ ʃʊɾə sɝvaɪvd wən ðə dʒɹæɡən θɹoʊn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ə paɪl ʌv ɡɪldɪd splɪntɝz bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɹʌbəl. ə lɑɹdʒ lɛðɝ skɹɪp bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ, wɪð ɹændz sɔɹd bɛlt ən skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹd ɹɛstɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪt, hɛld wʌɾ ɛls i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə sælvədʒ. stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɔɪsəz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ɪn əɹ ɛstəmeɪʃən.

Holding the crown of Illian on her lap, she watched Rand. Watched Rand watching Fedwin. Her hands tightened on the crown, and loosened immediately at the stabs of those small swords hidden among the laurel leaves. Strange, that the crown and scepter should have survived when the Dragon Throne itself was a pile of gilded splinters buried in rubble. A large leather scrip beside her chair, with Rand's sword belt and scabbarded sword resting against it, held what else he had been able to salvage. Strange choices for the most part, in her estimation.

jə bɹeɪnləs lubi, ʃi θɔt. nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌts ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə jə woʊn meɪk ɪt ɡoʊ əweɪ.

You brainless loobie, she thought. Not thinking about what's right in front of you won't make it go away.

ɹænd sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɛɹ stoʊn flɔɹ, stɪl kʌvɝɾ ɪn dʌst ən skɹætʃəz, hɪz koʊt tɔɹn. hɪz feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹvd. hi sim tə wɑtʃ fɛdwɪn wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ. ðə bɔɪ wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, tu, hɪz lɛɡz spɹɔld aʊt. tʌŋ kɑt bɪtwin ɪz tiθ, fɛdwɪn wɑz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn meɪkɪŋ ə taʊɝ aʊɾ ə blɑks ʌv wʊd. mɪn swɑloʊd hɑɹd.

Rand sat cross-legged on the bare stone floor, still covered in dust and scratches, his coat torn. His face might have been carved. He seemed to watch Fedwin without blinking. The boy was sitting on the floor, too, his legs sprawled out. Tongue caught between his teeth, Fedwin was concentrating on making a tower out of blocks of wood. Min swallowed hard.

ʃi kəd stɪl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə hɔɹɝ wən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə bɔɪ "ɡɑɹɾɪŋ" hɝ naʊ hæd ðə maɪn ʌv ə smɔl tʃaɪld. ðə sædnəs ɹɪmeɪnd, tu - laɪt, hi wɑz oʊnli ə bɔɪ! ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹaɪt! - bʌt ʃi hoʊpt ɹænd stɪl hæɾ ɪm ʃildɪd. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn izi, tɔkɪŋ fɛdwɪn ɪndə pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz wʊɾən blɑks ɪnstɛɾ ə pʊlɪŋ stoʊnz aʊɾ ə ðə wɔlz wɪð ðə paʊɝ tə meɪk ə "bɪɡ taʊɝ tə kip jə seɪf ɪn." ən ðən ʃi hæd sæt ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪm əntɪl ɹænd keɪm. oʊ, laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ. fəɹ ɹænd ivən mɔɹ ðən fɛdwɪn.

She could still remember the horror when she realized the boy "guarding" her now had the mind of a small child. The sadness remained, too - Light, he was only a boy! it was not right! - but she hoped Rand still had him shielded. It had not been easy, talking Fedwin into playing with those wooden blocks instead of pulling stones out of the walls with the Power to make a "big tower to keep you safe in." And then she had sat guarding him until Rand came. Oh, Light, she wanted to cry. For Rand even more than Fedwin.

"ju haɪd jɝsɛlf ɪn ðə dɛpθs, ɪɾ əpɪɹz."

"You hide yourself in the depths, it appears."

ðə dip vɔɪs wɑz nɑt fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ bɪfɔɹ ɹænd wɑz ɑn ɪz fit, feɪsɪŋ mæzɹim teɪm. əz juʒəwəl, ðə hʊk-noʊz mæn wɔɹ ə blæk koʊt wɪð blu-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡənz spaɪɹəlɪŋ ʌp ði ɑɹmz. ənlaɪk ði ʌðɝ æʃəmən, hi hæd niðɝ sɔɹd nɔɹ dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz haɪ kɑlɝ. hɪz dɑɹk feɪs wɔɹ nɪɹli əz lɪɾəl ɪkspɹɛʃən əz ɹænz. naʊ, stɛɹɪŋ ət teɪm, ɹænd sim tə bi ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ. mɪn sɝəptɪʃəsli izd ə naɪf ɪn əɹ koʊtsliv. əz mɛni ɪmədʒəz ən ɔʊɹəz dænst ɝaʊnd wʌn əz ði ʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə vjuɪŋ ðət meɪɾ əɹ sʌɾənli wɛɹi. ʃi hæd sin ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə kɪl ənʌðɝ bɪfɔɹ, ən ʃi wɑz siɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛn.

The deep voice was not finished speaking from the doorway before Rand was on his feet, facing Mazrim Taim. As usual, the hook-nosed man wore a black coat with blue-and-gold Dragons spiraling up the arms. Unlike the other Asha'man, he had neither Sword nor Dragon on his high collar. His dark face wore nearly as little expression as Rand's. Now, staring at Taim, Rand seemed to be gritting his teeth. Min surreptitiously eased a knife in her coatsleeve. As many images and auras danced around one as the other, but it was not a viewing that made her suddenly wary. She had seen a man trying to decide whether to kill another before, and she was seeing it again.

"ju kʌm hɪɹ hoʊldɪŋ seɪɾɪn, teɪm?" ɹænd sɛd, mʌtʃ tu sɔfli. teɪm spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz, ən ɹænd sɛd, "ðæts bɛɾɝ." bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ɹɪlæks.

"You come here holding saidin, Taim?" Rand said, much too softly. Taim spread his hands, and Rand said, "That's better." But he did not relax.

"ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðəɾ aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪt bi stæbd baɪ æksəɾənt," teɪm sɛd, "meɪkɪŋ maɪ weɪ hɪɹ θɹu kɔɹɪɾɝz pækt wɪð ðoʊz il wɪmən. ðeɪ sim ædʒəteɪɾəd." hɪz aɪz nɛvɝ lɛft ɹænd, bʌt mɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ i hæd noʊɾəst əɹ tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ naɪf. "ʌndɝstændəbli, ʌv kɔɹs," hi wɛn ɑn smuðli. "aɪ kænɑɾ ɪkspɹɛs maɪ dʒɔɪ ət faɪndɪŋ jə əlaɪv æftɝ siɪŋ wʌɾ aɪ dɪɾ əbʌv. aɪ keɪm tə ɹipɔɹt dɛzɝɾɝz. nɔɹməli, aɪ wʊdn əv bɑðɝd, bʌt ðiz ɑɹ dʒɛdwɪn, ɹɑtʃeɪd, tɔɹvəl, ən kɪsmən. ɪt simz ðeɪ wɝ mælkəntɛntɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪvɛns ɪn ɔltɑɹə, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ðɪs fɑɹ. aɪ hævən sin ɛni ʌv ðə mɛn aɪ lɛft wɪð ju." fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hɪz ɡeɪz flɪkɝd tə fɛdwɪn. fəɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ən ɪnstənt. "ðɛɹ wɝ . . . ʌðɝ . . . kæʒəwəltiz? əl teɪk ðɪs wʌn wɪð mi, ɪf jə wɪʃ."

"It was just that I thought I might be stabbed by accident," Taim said, "making my way here through corridors packed with those Aiel women. They seem agitated." His eyes never left Rand, but Min was sure he had noticed her touching her knife. "Understandably, of course," he went on smoothly. "I cannot express my joy at finding you alive after seeing what I did above. I came to report deserters. Normally, I wouldn't have bothered, but these are Gedwyn, Rochaid, Torval, and Kisman. It seems they were malcontented over events in Altara, but I never thought they would go this far. I haven't seen any of the men I left with you." For an instant, his gaze flickered to Fedwin. For no more than an instant. "There were . . . other . . . casualties? I will take this one with me, if you wish."

"aɪ toʊld əm tə steɪ aʊɾ ə saɪt," ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn ə hɑɹʃ vɔɪs. "æn əl teɪk kɛɹ ə fɛdwɪn. fɛdwɪn mɔɹ, teɪm; nɑt 'ðɪs wʌn.' " hi æktʃəli  bæk tə ðə smɔl teɪbəl tə pɪk ʌp ðə sɪlvɝ kʌp sɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə læmps. mɪnz bɹɛθ kɑt.

"I told them to stay out of sight," Rand said in a harsh voice. "And I'll take care of Fedwin. Fedwin Morr, Taim; not 'this one.' " He actually backed to the small table to pick up the silver cup sitting among the lamps. Min's breath caught.

"ðə wɪzdəm ɪn maɪ vɪlədʒ kəd kjʊɹ ɛniθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛɾ əz i nɛl bɪsaɪd fɛdwɪn. sʌmhaʊ, hi mænədʒ tə smaɪl ət ðə bɔɪ wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm teɪm. fɛdwɪn smaɪl bæk hæpəli ən tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ðə kʌp, bʌt ɹænd hɛld ɪt fəɹ ɪm tə dʒɹɪŋk. "ʃi noʊz mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɝbz ðən ɛnibəɾi aɪv ɛvɝ mɛt. aɪ lɝn ə lɪɾəl fɹəm hɝ, wɪtʃ ɑɹ seɪf, wɪtʃ nɑt." fɛdwɪn saɪɾ əz ɹænd tʊk ðə kʌp əweɪ ən hɛl ðə bɔɪ tə hɪz tʃɛst. "slip, fɛdwɪn," ɹænd mɝmɝd.

"The Wisdom in my village could cure anything," Rand said as he knelt beside Fedwin. Somehow, he managed to smile at the boy without taking his eyes from Taim. Fedwin smiled back happily and tried to take the cup, but Rand held it for him to drink. "She knows more about herbs than anybody I've ever met. I learned a little from her, which are safe, which not." Fedwin sighed as Rand took the cup away and held the boy to his chest. "Sleep, Fedwin," Rand murmured.

ɪt dɪd sim ðət ðə bɔɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə slip. hɪz aɪz kloʊzd. hɪz tʃɛst ɹoʊz ən fɛl mɔɹ sloʊli. sloʊɝ. əntɪl ɪt stɑpt. ðə smaɪl nɛvɝ lɛft ɪz lɪps.

It did seem that the boy was going to sleep. His eyes closed. His chest rose and fell more slowly. Slower. Until it stopped. The smile never left his lips.

"ə lɪɾəl sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪn," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli əz i leɪd fɛdwɪn daʊn. mɪnz aɪz bɝnd, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt kɹaɪ. ʃi wəd nɑt!

"A little something in the wine," Rand said softly as he laid Fedwin down. Min's eyes burned, but she would not cry. She would not!

"ju ɑɹ hɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪ θɔt," teɪm mʌɾɝd.

"You are harder than I thought," Taim muttered.

ɹænd smaɪld ət hɪm, ə hɑɹd fɛɹəl smaɪl. "æd kɔɹlən dæʃivə tə jəɹ lɪst ə dɛzɝɾɝz, teɪm. nɛks taɪm aɪ vɪzət ðə blæk taʊɝ, aɪ ɪkspɛk tə si hɪz hɛɾ ɑn jəɹ tʃɹeɪɾɝz tʃɹi."

Rand smiled at him, a hard feral smile. "Add Corlan Dashiva to your list of deserters, Taim. Next time I visit the Black Tower, I expect to see his head on your Traitor's Tree."

"dæʃivə?" teɪm snɑɹəld, hɪz aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ. wən nɛks jə vɪzət ðə blæk taʊɝ." ðət kwɪkli, hi ɹəkʌvɝd hɪmsɛlf, ɔl pɑlɪʃt stoʊn ən pɔɪz wʌns mɔɹ. haʊ ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd ɹiɾ əɹ vjuɪŋz ə hɪm.

"Dashiva?" Taim snarled, his eyes widening in surprise. "It will be as you say. When next you visit the Black Tower." That quickly, he recovered himself, all polished stone and poise once more. How she wished she could read her viewings of him.

"ɹɪtɝn tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, ən doʊn kʌm hɪɹ əɡɛn." stændɪŋ, ɹænd feɪs ði ʌðɝ mæn oʊvɝ fɛdwɪnz bɑɾi. "aɪ meɪ bi muvɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ ə waɪl."

"Return to the Black Tower, and don't come here again." Standing, Rand faced the other man over Fedwin's body. "I may be moving about for a while."

teɪmz baʊ wɑz mɪnəskjul. "æz jə kəmænd."

Taim's bow was minuscule. "As you command."

əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm, mɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ.

As the door closed behind him, Min let out a long breath.

"noʊ pɔɪnt weɪstɪŋ taɪm, ən noʊ taɪm tə weɪst," ɹænd mʌɾɝd. nilɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, hi tʊk ðə kɹaʊn ən slɪpt ɪɾ ɪndə ðə skɹɪp wɪð ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz. "mɪn, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ðə hoʊl pæk ə haʊnz, tʃeɪsɪŋ daʊn wʌn wʊlf æftɝ ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt simz ɪm ðə wʊlf."

"No point wasting time, and no time to waste," Rand muttered. Kneeling in front of her, he took the crown and slipped it into the scrip with the other things. "Min, I thought I was the whole pack of hounds, chasing down one wolf after another, but it seems I'm the wolf."

"bɝn ju," ʃi bɹiðd. tæŋəlɪŋ boʊθ hænz ɪn ɪz hɛɹ, ʃi stɛɹɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. naʊ blu, naʊ ɡɹeɪ, ə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ dʒʌst ət sʌnɹaɪz. ən dʒɹaɪ. "ju kən kɹaɪ, ɹænd ælθɹ. jə woʊn mɛlt ɪf jə kɹaɪ!"

"Burn you," she breathed. Tangling both hands in his hair, she stared in his eyes. Now blue, now gray, a morning sky just at sunrise. And dry. "You can cry, Rand al'Thor. You won't melt if you cry!"

"aɪ doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ tɪɹz, iðɝ, mɪn," hi sɛd dʒɛnli. "səmtaɪmz, ðə haʊnz kætʃ ðə wʊlf ən wɪʃ ðeɪ hædnt. səmtaɪmz, hi tɝnz ɑn ðɛm, əɹ weɪts ɪn æmbʊʃ. bʌt fɝst, ðə wʊlf əz tə ɹʌn."

"I don't have time for tears, either, Min," he said gently. "Sometimes, the hounds catch the wolf and wish they hadn't. Sometimes, he turns on them, or waits in ambush. But first, the wolf has to run."

"wɛn də wi ɡoʊ?" ʃi æskt. ʃi dɪd nɑt lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ɪz hɛɹ. ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ gɑnə lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv hɪm. nɛvɝ.

"When do we go?" she asked. She did not let go of his hair. She was never going to let go of him. Never.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

bɪɡɪnɪŋz


Beginnings

hoʊldɪŋ ɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk kloʊs wɪð wʌn hænd, pɛɹɪn lɛt steɪɝ wɔk ət ðə beɪz oʊn peɪs. ðə mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ sʌn ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ, ən ðə ɹʌɾɪd snoʊ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd liɾɪŋ ɪndə ɑbilə meɪd pʊɹ fʊɾɪŋ. hi ən ɪz dʌzən kəmpænjənz ʃɛɹd ðə weɪ wɪð oʊnli tu lʌmbɝɪŋ ɑks-kɑɹts ən ə hændfʊl ə fɑɹm-foʊk ɪn pleɪn dɑɹk wʊlənz. ðeɪ ɔl tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ wɪð hɛdz daʊn, klʌtʃɪŋ ət hæɾ əɹ kæp wɛnɛvɝ ə ɡʌst ɹoʊz bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪniθ ðɛɹ ʃuz.

Holding his fur-lined cloak close with one hand, Perrin let Stayer walk at the bay's own pace. The midmorning sun gave no warmth, and the rutted snow on the road leading into Abila made poor footing. He and his dozen companions shared the way with only two lumbering ox-carts and a handful of farm-folk in plain dark woolens. They all trudged along with heads down, clutching at hat or cap whenever a gust rose but otherwise concentrating on the ground beneath their shoes.

bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi hɝd nil meɪk ə ɹibɔl dʒoʊk ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs; ɡɹeɪɾi ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn ɹɪplaɪ, ən beɪlwɝ snɪf pɹɪsəli. nʌn ə ðə θɹi simd əɾ ɔl əfɛktəd baɪ wʌt ðeɪ hæd sin ən hɝd ðɪs pæs mʌnθ sɪns kɹɔsɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ɑmɑdɪʃiə, əɹ baɪ wʌt leɪ əhɛd. ɛdʒɹə wɑz ʃɑɹpli bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ mɑsʊɝi fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ əɹ hʊd slɪp. ɛdʒɹə ən kɛɹɛl boʊθ wɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ən ʃoʊldɝz ɪn ədɪʃən tə kloʊks, bʌɾ ivən æftɝ ædmɪɾɪŋ ðə nəsɛsəɾi tə ɹaɪd, ðeɪ hæd ɹəfjuz tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ bʌlki skɝts, soʊ ðɛɹ dɑɹk-stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡz wɝ bɛɹɾ əbʌv ðə ni. ðə koʊl dɪd nɑt sim tə bɑðɝ əm ɪn ðə list; dʒʌs ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə snoʊ. kɛɹɛl bɪɡæn kwaɪətli ædvaɪzɪŋ siɑnɪɾ əz tə wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt kip əɹ feɪs hɪɾən.

Behind him, he heard Neald make a ribald joke in a low voice; Grady grunted in reply, and Balwer sniffed prissily. None of the three seemed at all affected by what they had seen and heard this past month since crossing the border into Amadicia, or by what lay ahead. Edarra was sharply berating Masuri for letting her hood slip. Edarra and Carelle both wore their shawls wrapped around their heads and shoulders in addition to cloaks, but even after admitting the necessity to ride, they had refused to change out of their bulky skirts, so their dark-stockinged legs were bared above the knee. The cold did not seem to bother them in the least; just the strangeness of snow. Carelle began quietly advising Seonid as to what would happen if she did not keep her face hidden.

ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ʃi lɛɾ əɹ feɪs bi sin tu sun, ə doʊs ə ðə stʃɹæp wəd bi ðə list ʃi hæd tə fɪɹ, əz ʃi ən ðə waɪz wʌn nu wɛl. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ əv tə lʊk bæk tə noʊ ðə sɪstɝz' θɹi wɔɹɾɝz, bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ ɪn ɔɹɾənɛɹi kloʊks, wɝ mɛn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðə niɾ əɾ ɛni moʊmən tə aʊt sɔɹɾ ən kɑɹv ə weɪ klɪɹ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðət weɪ sɪns livɪŋ ðə kæmp ət dɔn. hi ɹæn ə ɡlʌv θʌm əlɔŋ ði æks hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ðən ɹiɡɑðɝɾ ɪz oʊn kloʊk dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ə sʌɾən ɡʌs kəd meɪk ɪt bɪloʊ. ɪf ðɪs wɛn bædli, ðə wɔɹɾɝz maɪt bi ɹaɪt.

Of course, if she let her face be seen too soon, a dose of the strap would be the least she had to fear, as she and the Wise One knew well. Perrin did not have to look back to know the sisters' three Warders, bringing up the rear in ordinary cloaks, were men expecting the need at any moment to out sword and carve a way clear. They had been that way since leaving the camp at dawn. He ran a gloved thumb along the axe hanging at his belt, then regathered his own cloak just before a sudden gust could make it billow. If this went badly, the Warders might be right.

ɔf tə ðə lɛft, ʃɔɹɾ ʌv wɛɹ ðə ɹoʊd kɹɔst ə wʊɾən bɹɪdʒ oʊvɝ ə fɹoʊzən stʃɹim ðət twɪstəɾ əlɔŋ ðə taʊnz ɛdʒ, tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz θɹʌst aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ ətɑp ə lɑɹdʒ skwɛɹ stoʊn plætfɔɹm wɪð dʒɹɪfs paɪld ɝaʊn ðə bɑɾəm. sloʊ tə pɹoʊkleɪm əlidʒəns tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðə loʊkəl lɔɹd hæd bɪn lʌki mɪɹli tə bi flɑɡd ən faɪn ɔl ðəɾ i pəzɛst. ə nɑɾ ə mɛn stændɪŋ ət ðə bɹɪdʒ wɑtʃt ðə maʊntəd pɑɹɾi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. pɛɹɪn sɔ noʊ saɪn ə hɛlməts əɹ ɑɹmɝ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn klʌtʃt spɪɹ əɹ kɹɔsboʊ ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹɾ əz i dɪɾ ɪz kloʊk. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tɔk tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ dʒʌst wɑtʃt, ðə mɪst ə ðɛɹ bɹɛθ kɝlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ ɡɑɹdz bʌntʃt ɔl ɝaʊn ðə taʊn, əɾ ɛvɹi ɹoʊd liɾɪŋ aʊt, əɾ ɛvɹi speɪs bɪtwin tu bɪldɪŋz. ðɪs wɑz ðə pɹɑfəts kʌntʃɹi, bʌt ðə waɪtkloʊks ən kɪŋ eɪlɹənz ɑɹmi stɪl hɛld lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ʌv ɪt.

Off to the left, short of where the road crossed a wooden bridge over a frozen stream that twisted along the town's edge, charred timbers thrust out of the snow atop a large square stone platform with drifts piled around the bottom. Slow to proclaim allegiance to the Dragon Reborn, the local lord had been lucky merely to be flogged and fined all that he possessed. A knot of men standing at the bridge watched the mounted party approaching. Perrin saw no sign of helmets or armor, but every man clutched spear or crossbow almost as hard as he did his cloak. They did not talk to one another. They just watched, the mist of their breath curling before their faces. There were other guards bunched all around the town, at every road leading out, at every space between two buildings. This was the Prophet's country, but the Whitecloaks and King Ailron's army still held large parts of it.

"aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt nɑt tə bɹɪŋ hɝ," hi mʌɾɝd, "bʌɾ əl peɪ fəɹ ɪɾ ɛniweɪ."

"I was right not to bring her," he muttered, "but I'll pay for it anyway."

"ʌv kɔɹs jəl peɪ," ɛlaɪəs snɔɹɾɪd. fəɹ ə mæn u hæd spɛn moʊst ə ðə læs fɪftin jɪɹz əfʊt, hi hændəld ɪz maʊs-kʌlɝd ɡɛldɪŋ wɛl. hi hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə kloʊk laɪnd wɪð blæk fɑks, dɪsɪŋ wɪð ɡælɛn. ɛɹæm, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn pɛɹɪnz ʌðɝ saɪd, aɪɾ ɛlaɪəs dɑɹkli, bʌt ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ɑn wɛl. "ə mæn ɔlweɪz peɪz sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, wɪð ɛni wʊmən, wɛðɝ i oʊz əɹ nɑt. bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɹaɪt, wɑzn aɪ?"

"Of course you'll pay," Elyas snorted. For a man who had spent most of the last fifteen years afoot, he handled his mouse-colored gelding well. He had acquired a cloak lined with black fox, dicing with Gallenne. Aram, riding on Perrin's other side, eyed Elyas darkly, but the bearded man ignored him. They did not get on well. "A man always pays sooner or later, with any woman, whether he owes or not. But I was right, wasn't I?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. ɪt stɪl dɪd nɑt sim ɹaɪt teɪkɪŋ ædvaɪs əbaʊɾ ɪz waɪf fɹəm ənʌðɝ mæn, ivən sɝkəmspɛkli, oʊblikli, jɛɾ ɪt dɪd sim tə bi wɝkɪŋ. ʌv kɔɹs, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs tə feɪl wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪt tə bɹəleɪn, bʌɾ i hæd mænədʒ ðə læs kwaɪɾ ɔfən ən ðə fɝst sɛvɹəl taɪmz. hi hæd fɑloʊɾ ɛlaɪəs' ædvaɪs tə ðə lɛɾɝ. wɛl, moʊst ʌv ɪt. əz wɛl əz i kʊd. ðət spaɪki sɛn ə dʒɛləsi stɪl flɛɹɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə bɹəleɪn, jɛɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ðə hɝt smɛl hæd vænɪʃt əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ sloʊ weɪ saʊθ. stɪl, hi wɑz ənizi. wən i fɝmli toʊld əɹ ʃi wɑz nɑt kʌmɪŋ wɪð ɪm ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹeɪzd ə sɪŋɡəl wɝɾ ə pɹoʊɾɛst! ʃi ivən smɛld . . . plizd! əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ stɑɹɾəld. ən haʊ kəd ʃi bi plizd ən æŋɡɹi ət ðə seɪm taɪm? nɑɾ ə skɹæp ʌv ɪt hæd ʃoʊɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ ɪz noʊz nɛvɝ laɪd. sʌmhaʊ, ɪt sim ðət ðə mɔɹ i lɝn əbaʊt wɪmən, ðə lɛs i nu!

Perrin nodded. Grudgingly. It still did not seem right taking advice about his wife from another man, even circumspectly, obliquely, yet it did seem to be working. Of course, raising his voice to Faile was as hard as not raising it to Berelain, but he had managed the last quite often and the first several times. He had followed Elyas' advice to the letter. Well, most of it. As well as he could. That spiky scent of jealousy still flared at the sight of Berelain, yet on the other hand, the hurt smell had vanished as they made their slow way south. Still, he was uneasy. When he firmly told her she was not coming with him this morning, she had not raised a single word of protest! She even smelled . . . pleased! Among other things, including startled. And how could she be pleased and angry at the same time? Not a scrap of it had showed on her face, but his nose never lied. Somehow, it seemed that the more he learned about women, the less he knew!

ðə bɹɪdʒ ɡɑɹdz fɹaʊn ən fɪŋɡɝd ðɛɹ wɛpənz əz steɪɝz hʊvz θʌddɪd hɑloʊli ɑntu ðə wʊɾən plæŋkɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ ðə juʒəwəl ɑd mɪks ðət fɑloʊd ðə pɹɑfət, dɝɾi-feɪst fɛloʊz ɪn sɪlk koʊts tu bɪɡ fəɹ ðɛm, skɑɹ-feɪst stʃɹit tʌfs ən pɪŋk-tʃikt əpɹɛntəsɪz, fɔɹmɝ mɝtʃəns ən kɹæfsmən u lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd slɛpt ɪn ðɛɹ wʌns faɪn wʊlənz fəɹ mʌnθs. ðɛɹ wɛpənz əpɪɹd wɛl kɛɹd fɔɹ, ðoʊ. səm ə ðə mɛn hæɾ ə fivɝ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz; ðə ɹɛst wɔɹ ɡɑɹɾəd, wʊɾən feɪsəz. əlɔŋ wɪð ənwɑʃt, ðeɪ smɛld iɡɝ, æŋkʃəs, fɝvənt, əfɹeɪd, ɔl dʒʌmbəl təɡɛðɝ.

The bridge guards frowned and fingered their weapons as Stayer's hooves thudded hollowly onto the wooden planking. They were the usual odd mix that followed the Prophet, dirty-faced fellows in silk coats too big for them, scar-faced street toughs and pink-cheeked apprentices, former merchants and craftsmen who looked as if they had slept in their once fine woolens for months. Their weapons appeared well cared for, though. Some of the men had a fever in their eyes; the rest wore guarded, wooden faces. Along with unwashed, they smelled eager, anxious, fervent, afraid, all jumbled together.

ðeɪ meɪd noʊ muv tə bɑɹ pæsədʒ, dʒʌst wɑtʃt, hɑɹdli blɪŋkɪŋ. baɪ wʌt pɛɹɪn hæd hɝd, ɔl sɔɹts fɹəm leɪɾiz ɪn sɪlks tə bɛɡɝz ɪn ɹæɡz keɪm tə ðə pɹɑfət hoʊpɪŋ ðət səbmɪɾɪŋ tə hɪm ɪn pɝsən maɪt ɡeɪn æɾəd blɛsɪŋz. əɹ meɪbi æɾəd pɹətɛkʃən. ðət wɑz waɪ hi hæd kʌm ðɪs weɪ, wɪð oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə kəmpænjənz. hi wəd fɹaɪɾən mæsimə ɪf i hæd tə, ɪf mæsimə kəd bi fɹaɪɾənd, bʌɾ ɪt hæd sim bɛɾɝ tə tʃɹaɪ ɹitʃɪŋ ðə mæn wɪθaʊt faɪɾɪŋ ə bæɾəl. hi kəd fil ðə ɡɑɹdz aɪz ɑn ɪz bæk əntɪl i ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɔl əkɹɔs ðə ʃɔɹt bɹɪdʒ ən ɑntu ðə peɪv stʃɹits ʌv ɑbilə. wən ðət pɹɛʃɝ lɛft, ðoʊ, ɪt bɹɔt noʊ sɛns ə ɹɪlif.

They made no move to bar passage, just watched, hardly blinking. By what Perrin had heard, all sorts from ladies in silks to beggars in rags came to the Prophet hoping that submitting to him in person might gain added blessings. Or maybe added protection. That was why he had come this way, with only a handful of companions. He would frighten Masema if he had to, if Masema could be frightened, but it had seemed better to try reaching the man without fighting a battle. He could feel the guard's eyes on his back until he and the others were all across the short bridge and onto the paved streets of Abila. When that pressure left, though, it brought no sense of relief.

ɑbilə wɑz ə ɡʊdli saɪz taʊn, wɪð sɛvɹəl tɔl wɑtʃtaʊɝz ən mɛni bɪldɪŋz ɹaɪzɪŋ fɔɹ stɔɹiz, ɛvɹi læst wʌn ɹuft ɪn sleɪt. hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, maʊndɪd stoʊn ən tɪmbɝz fɪld ə ɡæp bɪtwin tu stʃɹʌktʃɝz wɛɹ ən ɪn əɹ səm mɝtʃəns haʊs hæd bɪn pʊl daʊn. ðə pɹɑfət dɪsəpɹuvd ʌv wɛlθ ɡeɪn baɪ tʃɹeɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd kəɹaʊzəŋ əɹ wʌɾ ɪz fɑloʊɝz kɔld lud bɪheɪvjɝ. hi dɪsəpɹuvd ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz, ən meɪɾ ɪz filɪŋz noʊn wɪð ʃɑɹp ɪɡzæmpəlz.

Abila was a goodly sized town, with several tall watchtowers and many buildings rising four stories, every last one roofed in slate. Here and there, mounded stone and timbers filled a gap between two structures where an inn or some merchant's house had been pulled down. The Prophet disapproved of wealth gained by trade as much as he did carousing or what his followers called lewd behavior. He disapproved of a great many things, and made his feelings known with sharp examples.

ðə stʃɹits wɝ dʒæmd wɪð pipəl, bʌt pɛɹɪn ən ɪz kəmpænjənz wɝ ði oʊnli wʌnz ɑn hɔɹsbæk. ðə snoʊ hæd lɔŋ sɪns bɪn tʃɹæmpəl tə hæf-fɹoʊzən æŋkəl-dip mʌʃ. plɛnti ʌv ɑks-kɑɹts meɪd ðɛɹ sloʊ weɪ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ, bʌt vɛɹi fju wæɡənz, ən nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl kæɹɪdʒ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz wɛɹɪŋ wɔɹn kæstɔfs əɹ pɑsəbli stoʊlən kloʊðz, ɛvɹiwʌn wɔɹ dʒɹæb wʊlənz. moʊs pipəl hɝid, bʌt laɪk ðə foʊk ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, wɪð hɛdz daʊn. ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt hɝi wɝ stʃɹæɡəlɪŋ ɡɹups ə mɛn kæɹiɪŋ wɛpənz. ɪn ðə stʃɹits, ðə smɛl wɑz meɪnli dɝɾ ən fɪɹ. ɪt meɪd pɛɹɪnz hækəlz ɹaɪz. ət list, ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðæt, ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə taʊn wɪð noʊ wɔl wəd nɑt pɹuv hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn.

The streets were jammed with people, but Perrin and his companions were the only ones on horseback. The snow had long since been trampled to half-frozen ankle-deep mush. Plenty of ox-carts made their slow way through the throng, but very few wagons, and not a single carriage. Except for those wearing worn castoffs or possibly stolen clothes, everyone wore drab woolens. Most people hurried, but like the folk on the road, with heads down. Those who did not hurry were straggling groups of men carrying weapons. In the streets, the smell was mainly dirt and fear. It made Perrin's hackles rise. At least, if it came to that, getting out of a town with no wall would not prove harder than getting in.

"maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ mɝmɝɾ əz ðeɪ keɪm əbɹɛst ʌv wʌn ə ðoʊz hips ə ɹʌbəl. hi bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ pɛɹɪnz nɑd bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ ɪz hæmɝ-noʊz maʊn əsaɪɾ ən meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ ɪn ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən, hʌntʃt ɪn ɪz sæɾəl wɪð ɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk hɛl taɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ wɝiz əbaʊt ðə dʒɹaɪd-ʌp lɪɾəl mæn ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf əloʊn, ivən hɪɹ. fəɹ ə sɛkɹətɛɹi, hi mænədʒ tə lɝn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ əmaʊn ɑn ðiz fɔɹeɪz ə hɪz. hi sim tə noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt.

"My Lord," Balwer murmured as they came abreast of one of those heaps of rubble. He barely waited for Perrin's nod before turning his hammer-nosed mount aside and making his way in another direction, hunched in his saddle with his brown cloak held tight around him. Perrin had no worries about the dried-up little man going off alone, even here. For a secretary, he managed to learn a surprising amount on these forays of his. He seemed to know what he was about.

dɪsmɪsɪŋ beɪlwɝ fɹəm ɪz θɔts, pɛɹɪn sɛt tə wʌɾ i wɑz ðəɹ əbaʊt.

Dismissing Balwer from his thoughts, Perrin set to what he was there about.

ɪt tʊk oʊnli wʌn kwɛstʃən, pʊt tə ə læŋki jʌŋ mæn wɪð ən ɛkstæɾɪk laɪɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, tə lɝn wɛɹ ðə pɹɑfət wɑz steɪɪŋ, ən θɹi mɔɹ tə ʌðɝ foʊk ɪn ðə stʃɹits tə faɪn ðə mɝtʃəns haʊs, fɔɹ stɔɹiz ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɪð waɪt mɑɹbəl moʊldɪŋz ən wɪndoʊ fɹeɪmz. mæsimə dɪsəpɹuvd ʌv ɡɹʌbɪŋ fəɹ mʌni, bʌɾ i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛpt əkɑmədeɪʃənz fɹəm ðoʊz u dɪd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, beɪlwɝ sɛɾ i hæd slɛpt ɪn ə liki fɑɹmhaʊs əz ɔfən ən bɪn əz sæɾəsfaɪd. mæsimə dʒɹæŋk oʊnli wɔɾɝ, ən wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt, hi haɪɝɾ ə pʊɹ wɪɾoʊ ən eɪt ðə fud ʃi pɹipɛɹd, fɛɹ əɹ faʊl, wɪθaʊt kəmpleɪnt. ðə mæn hæd meɪd tu mɛni wɪɾoʊz fəɹ ðət tʃɛɹɪɾi tə kaʊn fɑɹ wɪð pɛɹɪn.

It took only one question, put to a lanky young man with an ecstatic light on his face, to learn where the Prophet was staying, and three more to other folk in the streets to find the merchant's house, four stories of gray stone with white marble moldings and window frames. Masema disapproved of grubbing for money, but he was willing to accept accommodations from those who did. On the other hand, Balwer said he had slept in a leaky farmhouse as often and been as satisfied. Masema drank only water, and wherever he went, he hired a poor widow and ate the food she prepared, fair or foul, without complaint. The man had made too many widows for that charity to count far with Perrin.

ðə θɹɔŋ ðət pæk ðə stʃɹits ɛlswɛɹ wɑz əbsɛn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɔl haʊs, jɛt ðə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑɹmd ɡɑɹdz laɪk ðoʊz ət ðə bɹɪdʒ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɪt. ðeɪ stɛɹɾ ət pɛɹɪn sʌlənli, ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt snɪɹ ɪnsələnli. ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ kɛp ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən ɪn ðɛɹ dip hʊdz ən ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn, waɪt bɹɛθ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə kaʊlz laɪk stim. fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, pɛɹɪn sɔ ɛlaɪəs θʌmɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz lɔŋ naɪf. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɑt tə stʃɹoʊk ɪz æks.

The throng that packed the streets elsewhere was absent in front of the tall house, yet the number of armed guards like those at the bridge almost made up for it. They stared at Perrin sullenly, those who did not sneer insolently. The two Aes Sedai kept their faces hidden in their deep hoods and their heads down, white breath rising from the cowls like steam. From the corner of his eye, Perrin saw Elyas thumbing the hilt of his long knife. It was hard not to stroke his axe.

"aɪv kʌm wɪð ə mɛsədʒ fəɹ ðə pɹɑfət fɹəm ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," hi ənaʊnst. wən nʌn ə ðə mɛn muvd, hi æɾəd, "maɪ neɪm ɪz pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ðə pɹɑfət noʊz mi." beɪlwɝ hæd kɑʃən ɪm əbaʊt ðə deɪnʒɝz ə juzɪŋ mæsiməz neɪm, əɹ kɔlɪŋ ɹænd ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. hi wɑz nɑt ðəɹ tə stɑɹɾ ə ɹaɪət.

"I've come with a message for the Prophet from the Dragon Reborn," he announced. When none of the men moved, he added, "My name is Perrin Aybara. The Prophet knows me." Balwer had cautioned him about the dangers of using Masema's name, or calling Rand anything but the Lord Dragon Reborn. He was not there to start a riot.

ðə kleɪm ə noʊɪŋ mæsimə sim tə pʊɾ ə spɑɹk ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹdz. sɛvɹəl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd waɪd-aɪd lʊks, ən wʌn wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ðə ɹɛst stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ ə ɡlimən. ɪn ə fju moʊməns, ə wʊmən keɪm tə ðə dɔɹ. hænsəm, wɪð waɪɾ əɾ əɹ tɛmpəlz, ɪn ə haɪ-nɛk dʒɹɛs ə blu wʊl ðət wɑz faɪn ɪf ʌnədɔɹnd, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə mɝtʃən hɝsɛlf. mæsimə dɪd nɑt θɹoʊ ðoʊz u ɔfɝɾ ɪm hɑspətæləɾi ɪndə ðə stʃɹits, bʌt ðɛɹ sɝvəns əɹ fɑɹmhænz juʒəwəli ɛndəɾ ʌp wɪð wʌn ə ðə bænz "spɹɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡlɔɹiz ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən."

The claim of knowing Masema seemed to put a spark into the guards. Several exchanged wide-eyed looks, and one went running inside. The rest stared at him as if he were a gleeman. In a few moments, a woman came to the door. Handsome, with white at her temples, in a high-necked dress of blue wool that was fine if unadorned, she might have been the merchant herself. Masema did not throw those who offered him hospitality into the streets, but their servants or farmhands usually ended up with one of the bands "spreading the glories of the Lord Dragon."

"ɪf jəl kʌm wɪð mi, mæstɝ eɪbɑɹə," ðə wʊmən sɛd kɑmli, "ju ən jəɹ fɹɛnz, əl teɪk jə tə ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪz neɪm." kɑm ʃi maɪt saʊnd, bʌt tɛɹɝ fɪld əɹ sɛnt.

"If you will come with me, Master Aybara," the woman said calmly, "you and your friends, I will take you to the Prophet of the Lord Dragon, may the Light illumine his name." Calm she might sound, but terror filled her scent.

tɛlɪŋ nild ən ðə wɔɹɾɝz tə wɑtʃ ðə hɔɹsəz əntɪl ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd, pɛɹɪn fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪnsaɪd wɪð ði ʌðɝz. ði ɪntɪɹiɝ wɑz dɑɹk, wɪð fju læmps lɪt, ən nɑt mʌtʃ wɔɹmɝ ðən aʊtsaɪd. ivən ðə waɪz wʌnz sim səbdud. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt smɛl əfɹeɪd, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst əz kloʊs tə ɪɾ əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɡɹeɪɾi ən ɛlaɪəs smɛld ʌv wɛɹinɪs, ʌv ɹeɪz hækəlz ən ɪɹz leɪd bæk. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɛɹæmz sɛnt wɑz iɡɝ. pɛɹɪn hoʊp ðə mæn dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɹɔ ðət sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk.

Telling Neald and the Warders to watch the horses until they returned, Perrin followed her inside with the others. The interior was dark, with few lamps lit, and not much warmer than outside. Even the Wise Ones seemed subdued. They did not smell afraid, but almost as close to it as the Aes Sedai, and Grady and Elyas smelled of wariness, of raised hackles and ears laid back. Strangely, Aram's scent was eager. Perrin hoped the man did not try to draw that sword on his back.

ðə lɑɹdʒ, kɑɹpəɾɪd ɹum ðə wʊmən lɛɾ əm tə, wɪð faɪɝz bleɪzɪŋ ɑn hɑɹθs əɾ iðɝ ɛnd, maɪɾ əv bɪn ə dʒɛnɝəlz stʌɾi, ɛvɹi teɪbəl ən hæf ðə tʃɛɹz kʌvɝd wɪð mæps ən peɪpɝz, ən wɔɹm ɪnʌf ðət pɛɹɪn tɔst ɪz kloʊk bæk ən ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd wɛɹɪŋ tu ʃɝts ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mæsimə stændɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum u dʒɹu hɪz aɪz ɪmiɾiətli, laɪk aɪɝn faɪlɪŋz tə ə loʊdstoʊn, ə dɑɹk, skaʊlɪŋ mæn wɪð ə ʃeɪvən hɛɾ ən ə peɪl tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ skɑɹ ɑn wʌn tʃik, ɪn ə ɹɪŋkəld ɡɹeɪ koʊɾ ən skʌf buts. hɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz bɝnd wɪð ə blæk faɪɝ, ən ɪz sɛnt . . . ði oʊnli neɪm pɛɹɪn kəd ɡɪv ðət smɛl, stil-hɑɹɾ ən bleɪd-ʃɑɹp ən kwɪvɝɪŋ wɪð waɪld ɪntɛnsəɾi, wɑz mædnəs. ən ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd pʊɾ ə liʃ ɑn ðɪs?

The large, carpeted room the woman led them to, with fires blazing on hearths at either end, might have been a general's study, every table and half the chairs covered with maps and papers, and warm enough that Perrin tossed his cloak back and regretted wearing two shirts under his coat. But it was Masema standing in the middle of the room who drew his eyes immediately, like iron filings to a lodestone, a dark, scowling man with a shaven head and a pale triangular scar on one cheek, in a wrinkled gray coat and scuffed boots. His deep-set eyes burned with a black fire, and his scent . . . The only name Perrin could give that smell, steel-hard and blade-sharp and quivering with wild intensity, was madness. And Rand thought he could put a leash on this?

"soʊ, ɪts ju," mæsimə ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk jə wəd dɛɹ ʃoʊ jəɹ feɪs. aɪ noʊ wʌt juv bɪn ʌp tə! hɑɹi toʊl mi mɔɹ ðən ə wik əɡoʊ, ən aɪ hæv kɛp maɪsɛlf ɪnfɔɹmd." ə mæn ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum, ə nɛɹoʊ-aɪd fɛloʊ wɪð ə θɹʌstɪŋ noʊz, ən pɛɹɪn əpbɹeɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf fəɹ nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ɪm bɪfɔɹ. hɑɹiz ɡɹin sɪlk koʊt wɑz mʌtʃ faɪnɝ ðən wʌɾ i hæd wɔɹn wən i dɪnaɪd kəlɛktɪŋ ɪɹz. ðə fɛloʊ ɹʌbd ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ ən ɡɹɪn ət pɛɹɪn vɪʃəsli, bʌɾ i kɛp saɪlən əz mæsimə wɛn ɑn. ðə pɹɑfəts vɔɪs ɡɹu hɑɾɝ baɪ ðə wɝd, nɑt wɪð æŋɡɝ, bʌɾ əz ðoʊ hi mɛn tə bɝn ɛvɹi sɪləbəl dip ɪndə pɛɹɪnz flɛʃ. "aɪ noʊ əbaʊt jə mɝɾɝɪŋ mɛn u hæv kʌm tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. aɪ noʊ əbaʊt jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɑɹv aʊt jəɹ oʊn kɪŋdəm! jɛs, aɪ noʊ əbaʊt meɪnɛðɝən! əbaʊt jəɹ æmbɪʃən! jəɹ ɡɹid fəɹ ɡlɔɹi! juv tɝn jəɹ bæk ɑn - !"

"So, it is you," Masema growled. "I did not think you would dare show your face. I know what you've been up to! Hari told me more than a week ago, and I have kept myself informed." A man shifted in a corner of the room, a narrow-eyed fellow with a thrusting nose, and Perrin upbraided himself for not noticing him before. Hari's green silk coat was much finer than what he had worn when he denied collecting ears. The fellow rubbed his hands together and grinned at Perrin viciously, but he kept silent as Masema went on. The Prophet's voice grew hotter by the word, not with anger, but as though he meant to burn every syllable deep into Perrin's flesh. "I know about you murdering men who have come to the Lord Dragon. I know about you trying to carve out your own kingdom! Yes, I know about Manetheren! About your ambition! Your greed for glory! You have turned your back on - !"

sʌɾənli mæsiməz aɪz bʌlʒd, ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, æŋɡɝ fleɪmd ɪn ɪz sɛnt. hɑɹi meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊn ən tʃɹaɪd tə bæk θɹu ðə wɔl. siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi hæd loʊɝd ðɛɹ hʊdz ən stʊd wɪð bɛɹ feɪsəz, kɑm ən kul, ən pleɪnli ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɛniwʌn u nu ðə lʊk. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ hɛl ðə paʊɝ. hi wʊɾə weɪdʒɝd ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz dɪd. ɛdʒɹə ən kɛɹɛl wɝ kwaɪətli wɑtʃɪŋ ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns, ən smuð feɪsəz əɹ noʊ, ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɛniwʌn ɹɛɾi tə faɪt, ɪt wɑz ðɛm. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɡɹeɪɾi wɔɹ ɹɛɾinəs laɪk ɪz blæk koʊt; meɪbi hi hɛl ðə paʊɝ, tu. ɛlaɪəs wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪsaɪd ði oʊpən dɔɹz, aʊtwɝdli əz kəmpoʊzd əz ðə sɪstɝz, bʌɾ i smɛld ɹɛɾi tə baɪt. ən ɛɹæm stʊd ɡeɪzɪŋ ət mæsimə wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən! laɪt!

Suddenly Masema's eyes bulged, and for the first time, anger flamed in his scent. Hari made a strangled sound and tried to back through the wall. Seonid and Masuri had lowered their hoods and stood with bare faces, calm and cool, and plainly Aes Sedai to anyone who knew the look. Perrin wondered whether they held the Power. He would have wagered that the Wise Ones did. Edarra and Carelle were quietly watching every direction at once, and smooth faces or no, if he had ever seen anyone ready to fight, it was them. For that matter, Grady wore readiness like his black coat; maybe he held the Power, too. Elyas was leaning against the wall beside the open doors, outwardly as composed as the sisters, but he smelled ready to bite. And Aram stood gazing at Masema with his mouth hanging open! Light!

"soʊ ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹu, tu!" mæsimə snæpt, spɪɾəl flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ɪz lɪps. "wɪð fɪlθi ɹumɝz spɹɛɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə hoʊli neɪm ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, jə dɛɹ tə ɹaɪd wɪð ðiz . . . ðiz . . . !"

"So that is true, too!" Masema snapped, spittle flying from his lips. "With filthy rumors spreading against the holy name of the Lord Dragon, you dare to ride with these . . . these . . . !"

"ðeɪv swɔɹn fiəlti tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, mæsimə," pɛɹɪn kʌɾ ɪn. "ðeɪ sɝv hɪm! də ju? hi sɛn mi tə stɑp ðə kɪlɪŋ. ən tə bɹɪŋ jə tə hɪm." noʊ wʌn wɑz ɔfɝɪŋ ɪm ə tʃɛɹ, soʊ hi pʊʃt ə stæk ə peɪpɝz fɹəm wʌn ən sæt. hi wɪʃt ðə ɹɛst wəd sɪt, tu; ʃaʊɾɪŋ sim hɑɹɾɝ wən jə wɝ sɪɾɪŋ daʊn.

"They've sworn fealty to the Lord Dragon, Masema," Perrin cut in. "They serve him! Do you? He sent me to stop the killing. And to bring you to him." No one was offering him a chair, so he pushed a stack of papers from one and sat. He wished the rest would sit, too; shouting seemed harder when you were sitting down.

hɑɹi ɡɑɡəld ət hɪm, ən mæsimə wɑz pɹæktəkli ʃeɪkɪŋ. kəz i hæd teɪkən ə tʃɛɹ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ æskt? oʊ. jɛs.

Hari goggled at him, and Masema was practically shaking. Because he had taken a chair without being asked? Oh. Yes.

"aɪ hæv ɡɪvən ʌp ðə neɪmz ə mɛn," mæsimə sɛd koʊldli. "aɪ æm sɪmpli ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪm ən ðə wɝl kʌm tə nil bɪfɔɹ hɪm." baɪ hɪz toʊn, ðə wɝld ən ðə laɪt wəd ɹəɡɹɛt feɪljɝ ikwəli. "ðɛɹ ɪz mʌtʃ tə də hɪɹ, jɛt ɡɹeɪt wɝks. ɔl mʌst oʊbeɪ wən ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən kɔlz, bʌɾ ɪn wɪntɝ, tʃɹævəl ɪz ɔlweɪz sloʊ. ə dɪleɪ ʌv ə fju wiks wɪl meɪk lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns."

"I have given up the names of men," Masema said coldly. "I am simply the Prophet of the Lord Dragon, may the Light illumine him and the world come to kneel before him." By his tone, the world and the Light would regret failure equally. "There is much to do here, yet Great works. All must obey when the Lord Dragon calls, but in winter, travel is always slow. A delay of a few weeks will make little difference."

"aɪ kən əv jə ɪn kɛɹhin tədeɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wʌns ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əz spoʊkən tə ju, jə kən ɹɪtɝn ðə seɪm weɪ ən bi bæk hɪɹ ɪn ə fju deɪz." ɪf ɹænd lɛɾ ɪm ɹɪtɝn.

"I can have you in Cairhien today," Perrin said. "Once the Lord Dragon has spoken to you, you can return the same way and be back here in a few days." If Rand let him return.

mæsimə æktʃəli  ɹikɔɪld. bɛɹɪŋ ɪz tiθ, hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "sʌm kəntʃɹaɪvəns ə ðə əl wɪl nɑt bi tʌtʃt wɪð ðə ɪts ɪz blæsfəmi fəɹ mɔɹɾəlz tə tʌtʃ ɪt!"

Masema actually recoiled. Baring his teeth, he glared at the Aes Sedai. "Some contrivance of the Power? I will not be touched with the Power! It is blasphemy for mortals to touch it!"

pɛɹɪn keɪm kloʊs tə ɡeɪpɪŋ. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn tʃænəlz, mæn!"

Perrin came close to gaping. "The Dragon Reborn channels, man!"

"ðə blɛsɪd lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪz nɑɾ əz ʌðɝ mɛn, eɪbɑɹə!" mæsimə snɑɹəld. "hi ɪz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ! əl oʊbeɪ hɪz sʌmənz, bʌɾ əl nɑt bi tʌtʃt baɪ ðə fɪlθ ðiz wɪmən du!"

"The blessed Lord Dragon is not as other men, Aybara!" Masema snarled. "He is the Light made flesh! I will obey his summons, but I will not be touched by the filth these women do!"

slʌmpɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, pɛɹɪn saɪd. ɪf ðə mæn wɑz ðɪs bæɾ oʊvɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, haʊ wəɾ i bi wən i lɝn ðət ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil kəd tʃænəl? fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi kənsɪɾɝd sɪmpli nɑkɪŋ mæsimə oʊvɝ ðə hɛd, ən . . . mɛn wɝ pæsɪŋ baɪ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, pɔzɪŋ tə ɡlæns ɪn bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɑn. ɔl ɪt tʊk wɑz wʌn ə ðɛm ɹeɪzɪŋ ə ʃaʊt, ən ɑbilə kəd bɪkʌm ə slɔɾɝhaʊs. "ðɛn wi ɹaɪd, pɹɑfət," hi sɛd saʊɝli. laɪt, ɹænd hæd sɛd tə kip ðɪs sikɹəɾ əntɪl mæsimə stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm! haʊ tə mænədʒ ðət ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ tə kɛɹhin? "bʌt noʊ dɪleɪz. ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɪz vɛɹi æŋkʃəs tə tɔk wɪð ju."

Slumping back in the chair, Perrin sighed. If the man was this bad over Aes Sedai, how would he be when he learned that Grady and Neald could channel? For a moment, he considered simply knocking Masema over the head, and . . . Men were passing by in the corridor, pausing to glance in before hurrying on. All it took was one of them raising a shout, and Abila could become a slaughterhouse. "Then we ride, Prophet," he said sourly. Light, Rand had said to keep this secret until Masema stood in front of him! How to manage that riding all the way to Cairhien? "But no delays. The Lord Dragon is very anxious to talk with you."

"aɪ æm æŋkʃəs tə spik wɪð ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, meɪ hɪz neɪm bi blɛsɪd baɪ ðə laɪt." hɪz aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt, æktʃəli  smaɪlɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn. bʌɾ i smɛld . . . ɡɹɪm. "aɪ æm vɛɹi æŋkʃəs ɪndid."

"I am anxious to speak with the Lord Dragon, may his name be blessed by the Light." His eyes flickered toward the two Aes Sedai. He tried to hide it, actually smiling at Perrin. But he smelled . . . grim. "I am very anxious indeed."

"wʊd maɪ leɪɾi laɪk mi tə æsk wʌn ə ðə hænlɝz tə bɹɪŋ əɹ ə hɔk?" meɪaɪɡdɪn æskt. wʌn ʌv æliændɝz fɔɹ hɔk hænlɝz, ɔl mɛn əz lin əz ðɛɹ bɝdz, ɝdʒd ə slik dʌkhɔk wɛɹɪŋ ə fɛðɝd hʊɾ ɑntu hɪz hɛvi ɡɔnlət fɹəm ðə wʊɾən stæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz sæɾəl ən lɪftəd ðə ɡɹeɪ bɝd təwɔɹd hɝ. ðə fælkən, wɪð ɪts blu-tɪpt wɪŋz, wɑz ɑn æliændɝz ɡɹin-ɡlʌvd ɹɪst. ðət bɝd wɑz ɹɪzɝv tə hɝ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. æliændɝ nu hɝ pleɪs əz ə væsəl, bʌt feɪl ʌndɝstʊd nɑt wɑntɪŋ tə ɹɪlɪŋkwɪʃ ə feɪvɹɪt bɝd.

"Would my Lady like me to ask one of the handlers to bring her a hawk?" Maighdin asked. One of Alliandre's four hawk handlers, all men as lean as their birds, urged a sleek duckhawk wearing a feathered hood onto his heavy gauntlet from the wooden stand in front of his saddle and lifted the gray bird toward her. The falcon, with its blue-tipped wings, was on Alliandre's green-gloved wrist. That bird was reserved to her, unfortunately. Alliandre knew her place as a vassal, but Faile understood not wanting to relinquish a favorite bird.

ʃi mɪɹli ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn baʊɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl ən muvd əɹ ɹoʊn mɛɹ əweɪ fɹəm swɑloʊ, fɑɹ ɪnʌf nɑt tə ɪntʃɹud bʌt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə bi ət hænd wɪθaʊt feɪl ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs. ðə dɪɡnəfaɪd ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən hæd pɹuv tə bi ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ɡʊɾ ə leɪɾiz meɪɾ əz feɪl hæd hoʊpt, nɑlədʒəbəl, keɪpəbəl. ət list, ʃi hæd wʌns ʃi lɝn ðət wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ ɹɛləɾɪv pəzɪʃənz wɪð ðɛɹ fɔɹmɝ mɪstʃɹəs, lini wɑz fɝst əmʌŋ feɪlz sɝvɪŋ wɪmən, ən wɪlɪŋ tə juz əɹ əθɔɹəɾi. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðət hæɾ æktʃəli  teɪkən ən ɛpəsoʊd wɪð ə swɪtʃ, bʌt feɪl pɹitɛndəd nɑt tə noʊ. oʊnli ən ʌɾɝ ful ɪmbɛɹəst əɹ sɝvəns. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ðə mæɾɝ ə meɪaɪɡdɪn ən tɑlænvɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd bɪɡʌn ʃɛɹɪŋ ɪz bɛd, ən ɪf ʃi faʊn pɹuf, ðeɪ wəd mɛɹi ɪf ʃi hæd tə tɝn lini lus ɑn boʊθ ə ðɛm. stɪl, ðət wɑz ə smɔl mæɾɝ, ən kəd nɑt spɔɪl əɹ mɔɹnɪŋ.

She merely shook her head, and Maighdin bowed in her saddle and moved her roan mare away from Swallow, far enough not to intrude but close enough to be at hand without Faile raising her voice. The dignified golden-haired woman had proved to be every bit as good a lady's maid as Faile had hoped, knowledgeable, capable. At least, she had once she learned that whatever their relative positions with their former mistress, Lini was first among Faile's serving women, and willing to use her authority. Surprisingly, that had actually taken an episode with a switch, but Faile pretended not to know. Only an utter fool embarrassed her servants. There was still the matter of Maighdin and Tallanvor, of course. She was certain Maighdin had begun sharing his bed, and if she found proof, they would marry if she had to turn Lini loose on both of them. Still, that was a small matter, and could not spoil her morning.

hɔkɪŋ hæd bɪn æliændɝz aɪdiə, bʌt feɪl hæd nɑɾ əbdʒɛktəd tə ə ɹaɪd θɹu ðɪs spɑɹs fɔɹəst, wɛɹ snoʊ meɪɾ ə ɹoʊlɪŋ blæŋkəɾ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ən leɪ θɪk ən waɪɾ ɑn bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz. ðə ɡɹin ə ðə tʃɹiz ðət stɪl hɛl ðɛɹ livz simd ʃɑɹpɝ. ði ɛɹ wɑz kɹɪsp, ən ɪt smɛl nu ən fɹɛʃ.

Hawking had been Alliandre's idea, but Faile had not objected to a ride through this sparse forest, where snow made a rolling blanket over everything and lay thick and white on bare branches. The green of the trees that still held their leaves seemed sharper. The air was crisp, and it smelled new and fresh.

beɪn ən kiæd hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn əkʌmpəniɪŋ hɝ, bʌt ðeɪ skwɑɾɪd nɪɹbaɪ, ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz, wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ wɪð dɪsɡɹʌntəld ɪkspɹɛʃənz. səlɪn hæd wɑntəd tə kʌm wɪð ɔl ə ðə meɪɾənz, bʌt wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd stɔɹiz ʌv il dɛpɹədeɪʃənz floʊɾɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ðə saɪɾ ʌv ən il wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɛn moʊs pipəl ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə ɹʌnɪŋ əɹ ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ə sɔɹd. ðəɹ mʌs bi səm tʃɹuθ ɪn ðoʊz teɪlz, əɹ soʊ mɛni wəd nɑt noʊ ən il, ðoʊ ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu hu ðeɪ wɝ əɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd kʌm fɹʌm, jɛɾ ivən səlɪn əɡɹid ðət huɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ, ðeɪ hæd muvd ɑn ist, pɝhæps ɪndə ɔltɑɹə.

Bain and Chiad had insisted on accompanying her, but they squatted nearby, shoufa wrapped around their heads, watching her with disgruntled expressions. Sulin had wanted to come with all of the Maidens, but with a hundred stories of Aiel depredations floating everywhere, the sight of an Aiel was enough to send most people in Amadicia running or reaching for a sword. There must be some truth in those tales, or so many would not know an Aiel, though the Light alone knew who they were or where they had come from, yet even Sulin agreed that whoever they were, they had moved on east, perhaps into Altara.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðɪs kloʊs tə ɑbilə, twɛnti ʌv æliændɝz soʊlʒɝz ən əz mɛni minɝ wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz pɹəvaɪɾəd səfɪʃən ɛskɔɹt. ðə stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðɛɹ lænsɪz, ɹɛɾ əɹ ɡɹin, lɪftəd laɪk ɹɪbənz wən ðə bɹiz stɝd. bɹəleɪnz pɹɛzəns wɑz ði oʊnli blaɪt. ðoʊ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊmən ʃɪvɝ ɪn əɹ fɝ-tʃɹɪmd ɹɛd kloʊk, θɪk ɪnʌf fəɹ tu blæŋkəts, wɑz sɝɾənli əmjuzɪŋ. min dɪd nɑɾ əv ə ɹil wɪntɝ. ðɪs wɑz laɪk ðə læs deɪz ʌv ɔɾəm. ɪn sɑldɑiə, ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv wɪntɝ kəd fɹiz ɪkspoʊz flɛʃ hɑɹɾ əz wʊd. feɪl tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi fɛlt laɪk læfɪŋ.

In any case, this close to Abila, twenty of Alliandre's soldiers and as many Mayener Winged Guards provided sufficient escort. The streamers on their lances, red or green, lifted like ribbons when the breeze stirred. Berelain's presence was the only blight. Though watching the woman shiver in her fur-trimmed red cloak, thick enough for two blankets, was certainly amusing. Mayene did not have a real winter. This was like the last days of autumn. In Saldaea, the heart of winter could freeze exposed flesh hard as wood. Faile took a deep breath. She felt like laughing.

baɪ səm mɪɹəkəl, hɝ hʌzbənd, hɝ bɪlʌvd wʊlf, hæd bɪɡʌn bɪheɪvɪŋ əz i ʃʊd. ɪnstɛɾ ə ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət bɹəleɪn əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm hɝ, pɛɹɪn naʊ tɑlɝeɪɾəd ðə dʒeɪdz blændɪʃməns, pleɪnli tɑlɝeɪɾəd əm ðə weɪ hi wəɾ ə tʃaɪl pleɪɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz niz. ən bɛst ʌv ɔl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛni nid tə tæmp daʊn əɹ æŋɡɝ wən ʃi wɑntəd tə lɛɾ ɪt lus. wən ʃi ʃaʊɾəd, hi ʃaʊɾəd bæk. ʃi nu hi wɑz nɑt sɑldəiən, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn soʊ hɑɹd, θɪŋkɪŋ ɪn əɹ hɑɹɾ ə hɑɹts ðəɾ i bɪlivd əɹ tu wik tə stæn ʌp tə hɪm. ə fju naɪts əɡoʊ ət sʌpɝ, ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs pɔɪntəɾ aʊt tə hɪm ðət bɹəleɪn wɑz gɑnə fɔl aʊɾ ə hɝ dʒɹɛs ɪf ʃi lin oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl ɛni fɑɹðɝ. wɛl, ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə ɡoʊ ðət fɑɹ, nɑt wɪð bɹəleɪn; ðə tʃɹʌl stɪl θɔt ʃi kəd wɪn hɪm. ən ðət vɛɹi mɔɹnɪŋ, hi hæd bɪn kəmændɪŋ, kwaɪətli bɹʊkɪŋ noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt, ðə sɔɹɾ ə mæn ə wʊmən nu ʃi hæd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ tə dɪzɝv, tə ikwəl. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi wəɾ əv tə nɪp ɪm oʊvɝ ðæt. ə kəmændɪŋ mæn wɑz wʌndɝfəl, soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt kʌm tə bɪliv i kəɾ ɔlweɪz kəmænd. læf? ʃi kəɾ əv sʌŋ!

By some miracle, her husband, her beloved wolf, had begun behaving as he should. Instead of shouting at Berelain or running from her, Perrin now tolerated the jade's blandishments, plainly tolerated them the way he would a child playing around his knees. And best of all, there was no longer any need to tamp down her anger when she wanted to let it loose. When she shouted, he shouted back. She knew he was not Saldaean, but it had been so hard, thinking in her heart of hearts that he believed her too weak to stand up to him. A few nights ago at supper, she had almost pointed out to him that Berelain was going to fall out of her dress if she leaned over the table any farther. Well, she was not going to go that far, not with Berelain; the trull still thought she could win him. And that very morning, he had been commanding, quietly brooking no argument, the sort of man a woman knew she had to be strong to deserve, to equal. Of course, she would have to nip him over that. A commanding man was wonderful, so long as he did not come to believe he could always command. Laugh? She could have sung!

"meɪaɪɡdɪn, aɪ θɪŋk æftɝ ɔl əl . . ." meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz ðəɹ ɪmiɾiətli wɪð ən ɛnkwaɪɝɪŋ smaɪl, bʌt feɪl tʃɹeɪld ɔf ət ðə saɪɾ ə θɹi ɹaɪɾɝz əhɛɾ ə hɝ, plaʊɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd pʊʃ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz.

"Maighdin, I think after all I will . . ." Maighdin was there immediately with an enquiring smile, but Faile trailed off at the sight of three riders ahead of her, plowing through the snow as fast as they could push their horses.

"æt lis ðəɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv hɛɹz, maɪ leɪɾi," æliændɝ sɛd, wɔkɪŋ əɹ tɔl waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd swɑloʊ, "bʌɾ aɪ hæd hoʊpt . . . hu ɑɹ ðeɪ?" hɝ fælkən ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ θɪk ɡlʌv, ðə bɛlz ɑn ɪts dʒɛsəz dʒɪŋɡəlɪŋ. "waɪ, ɪt lʊks laɪk səm ə jəɹ pipəl, maɪ leɪɾi."

"At least there are plenty of hares, my Lady," Alliandre said, walking her tall white gelding up beside Swallow, "but I had hoped . . . Who are they?" Her falcon shifted on her thick glove, the bells on its jesses jingling. "Why, it looks like some of your people, my Lady."

feɪl nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli. ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɛm, tu. pɛɹɪlin, ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl. bʌt wʌt wɝ ðeɪ duɪŋ hɪɹ?

Faile nodded grimly. She recognized them, too. Parelean, Arrela and Lacile. But what were they doing here?

ðə θɹi dʒɹu ɹeɪn bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz pæntɪŋ stim. pɛɹɪlin lʊkt əz waɪd-aɪɾ əz ɪz dæpəl. lətʃəl, hɝ peɪl feɪs nɪɹli hɪɾən ɪn ðə dip kaʊl ə hɝ kloʊk, wɑz swɑloʊɪŋ æŋkʃəsli, ən ɹɛləz dɑɹk feɪs simd ɡɹeɪ. "maɪ leɪɾi," pɛɹɪlin sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, "daɪɹ nuz! ðə pɹɑfət mæsimə hæz bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə sintʃæn!"

The three drew rein before her, their horses panting steam. Parelean looked as wide-eyed as his dapple. Lacile, her pale face nearly hidden in the deep cowl of her cloak, was swallowing anxiously, and Arrela's dark face seemed gray. "My Lady," Parelean said urgently, "dire news! The Prophet Masema has been meeting with the Seanchan!"

"ðə sintʃæn!" æliændɝ ɪkskleɪmd. "ʃʊɹli hi kænɑt bɪliv ðəl kʌm tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən!"

"The Seanchan!" Alliandre exclaimed. "Surely he cannot believe they will come to the Lord Dragon!"

"ɪt maɪt bi sɪmpəlɝ," bɹəleɪn sɛd, hilɪŋ əɹ tu-ʃoʊi waɪt mɛɹ ʌp ɑn æliændɝz ʌðɝ saɪd. wɪθaʊt pɛɹɪn əbaʊt fəɹ əɹ tə tʃɹaɪ tə ɪmpɹɛs, hɝ dɑɹk blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɑz kʌt kwaɪt mɑɾəstli, wɪð ə nɛk ʌp ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn. ʃi stɪl ʃɪvɝd. "mæsimə dɪslaɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə sintʃæn kip wɪmən u kən tʃænəl əz pɹɪznɝz."

"It might be simpler," Berelain said, heeling her too-showy white mare up on Alliandre's other side. Without Perrin about for her to try to impress, her dark blue riding dress was cut quite modestly, with a neck up under her chin. She still shivered. "Masema dislikes Aes Sedai, and the Seanchan keep women who can channel as prisoners."

feɪl klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn vɛkseɪʃən. daɪɹ nuz ɪndid, ɪf tʃɹu. ən ʃi kəɾ oʊnli hoʊp pɛɹɪlin ən ði ʌðɝz ɹɪteɪn ɪnʌf ə ðɛɹ wɪts tə ət lis pɹitɛn ðeɪ hæd sɪmpli oʊvɝhɝd tɔk baɪ tʃæns. ivən soʊ, ʃi hæd tə bi ʃʊɹ, ən kwɪkli. pɛɹɪn maɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv ɹitʃt mæsimə. "wʌt pɹuf dʒju hæv, pɛɹɪlin?"

Faile clicked her tongue in vexation. Dire news indeed, if true. And she could only hope Parelean and the others retained enough of their wits to at least pretend they had simply overheard talk by chance. Even so, she had to be sure, and quickly. Perrin might already have reached Masema. "What proof do you have, Parelean?"

"wi tɔk tə θɹi fɑɹmɝz u sɔ ə lɑɹdʒ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝ læn fɔɹ naɪts əɡoʊ, maɪ leɪɾi. ɪt bɹɔɾ ə wʊmən u wɑz teɪkən tə mæsimə ən ɹɪmeɪnd wɪð ɪm fəɹ θɹi aʊɝz."

"We talked to three farmers who saw a large flying creature land four nights ago, my Lady. It brought a woman who was taken to Masema and remained with him for three hours."

"wi wɝ eɪbəl tə tʃɹeɪs əɹ ɔl ðə weɪ tə wɛɹ mæsimə steɪz ɪn ɑbilə," lətʃəl æɾəd.

"We were able to trace her all the way to where Masema stays in Abila," Lacile added.

"ðə θɹi mɛn ɔl θɔt ðə kɹitʃɝ wɑz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn," ɹɛlə pʊɾ ɪn, "bʌt ðeɪ sim fɛɹli ɹɪlaɪəbəl." fəɹ əɹ tə seɪ ɛni mæn nɑɾ ə tʃɑ feɪl wɑz fɛɹli ɹɪlaɪəbəl wɑz ðə seɪm əz ɛniwʌn ɛls seɪɪŋ ðeɪ θɔɾ i wɑz ɑnəst əz ə bɛl.

"The three men all thought the creature was Shadowspawn," Arrela put in, "but they seemed fairly reliable." For her to say any man not of Cha Faile was fairly reliable was the same as anyone else saying they thought he was honest as a bell.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ mʌst ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ɑbilə," feɪl sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ swɑloʊz ɹeɪnz. "æliændɝ, teɪk meɪaɪɡdɪn ən bɹəleɪn wɪð ju." ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, ðə taɪɾənɪŋ ə bɹəleɪnz lɪps oʊvɝ ðət wʊɾə bɪn əmjuzɪŋ. "pɛɹɪlin, ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl wɪl əkʌmpəni mi - " ə mæn skɹimd, ən ɛvɹiwʌn dʒɝkt.

"I think I must ride into Abila," Faile said, gathering Swallow's reins. "Alliandre, take Maighdin and Berelain with you." Any other time, the tightening of Berelain's lips over that would have been amusing. "Parelean, Arrela and Lacile will accompany me - " A man screamed, and everyone jerked.

fɪfti peɪsɪz əweɪ, wʌn ʌv æliændɝz ɡɹin-koʊɾəd soʊlʒɝz wɑz tɑpəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ə wɪŋd ɡɑɹd fɛl wɪð ən æɹoʊ stændɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ɪz θɹoʊt. il əpɪɹɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, veɪld ən wildɪŋ baʊz əz ðeɪ ɹæn. mɔɹ soʊlʒɝz fɛl. beɪn ən kiæd wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fit, dɑɹk veɪlz haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ði aɪz; ðɛɹ spɪɹz wɝ θɹʌs θɹu ðə stʃɹæps ə ðə baʊ keɪsəz ɑn ðɛɹ bæk, ən ðeɪ wɝk ðɛɹ baʊz smuðli, bʌt ðeɪ kæst ɡlænsɪz təwɔɹd feɪl, tu. ðəɹ wɝ il ɔl ɝaʊnd, hʌnʒɹədz ɪt simd, ə ɡɹeɪt nus kloʊzɪŋ ɪn. maʊntəd soʊlʒɝz loʊɝd lænsɪz, pʊlɪŋ bæk ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn sɝkəl ɝaʊn feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz, bʌt ɡæps əpɪɹɾ ɪmiɾiətli əz il æɹoʊz stʃɹʌk hoʊm.

Fifty paces away, one of Alliandre's green-coated soldiers was toppling from his saddle, and a moment later, a Winged Guard fell with an arrow standing out from his throat. Aiel appeared among the trees, veiled and wielding bows as they ran. More soldiers fell. Bain and Chiad were on their feet, dark veils hiding their faces to the eyes; their spears were thrust through the straps of the bow cases on their back, and they worked their bows smoothly, but they cast glances toward Faile, too. There were Aiel all around, hundreds it seemed, a great noose closing in. Mounted soldiers lowered lances, pulling back in their own circle around Faile and the others, but gaps appeared immediately as Aiel arrows struck home.

"sʌmwʌn mʌst ɡɛt ðɪs nuz ə mæsimə tə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," feɪl toʊl pɛɹɪlin ən ðə tu wɪmən. "wʌn ə jə mʌst ɹitʃ hɪm! ɹaɪd laɪk faɪɝ!" hɝ swipɪŋ ɡeɪz tʊk ɪn æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn. ən bɹəleɪn, tu. "ɔl ə ju, ɹaɪd laɪk faɪɝ, əɹ daɪ hɪɹ!" bɛɹli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ nɑdz, ʃi suɾəd ækʃənz tə wɝdz, ən dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪndə swɑloʊz flæŋks, bɝstɪŋ θɹu ðə jusləs ɹɪŋ ə soʊlʒɝz. "ɹaɪd!" ʃi ʃaʊɾəd. sʌmwʌn hæd tə ɡɛt ðə nuz tə pɛɹɪn. "ɹaɪd!"

"Someone must get this news of Masema to Lord Perrin," Faile told Parelean and the two women. "One of you must reach him! Ride like fire!" Her sweeping gaze took in Alliandre and Maighdin. And Berelain, too. "All of you, ride like fire, or die here!" Barely waiting for their nods, she suited actions to words, and dug her heels into Swallow's flanks, bursting through the useless ring of soldiers. "Ride!" she shouted. Someone had to get the news to Perrin. "Ride!"

linɪŋ loʊ ɑn swɑloʊz nɛk, ʃi ɝdʒ ðə blæk mɛɹ fəɹ spid. flit hʊvz splæʃt snoʊ əz swɑloʊ ɹæn, laɪɾ əz əɹ neɪmseɪk. fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd stʃɹaɪdz, feɪl θɔt ʃi maɪt bɹeɪk fɹi. ən ðən swɑloʊ skɹimd ən stʌmbəld, pɪtʃɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð ðə ʃɑɹp snæp ʌv ə bɹeɪkɪŋ lɛɡ. feɪl flu θɹu ɛɹ ən stʃɹʌk hɑɹd, moʊst ə ðə bɹɛθ dʒɹɪvən aʊɾ ə hɝ əz ʃi plʌnʒd feɪsdaʊn ɪndə ðə snoʊ. faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛɹ, ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɝ fiɾ ən snætʃt ə naɪf fɹəm əɹ bɛlt. swɑloʊ hæd skɹim bɪfɔɹ ʃi stʌmbəld, bɪfɔɹ ðəɾ ɑfəl kɹæk.
